Maitreya’s Mahāyānasūtrālaṃkāra: Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras
Translated by Dharmachakra Translation Committee
@##/ /rgya gar skad du/ ma hA yA na sU tra a laM ka ra nA ma kA ri kA/ bod skad du/ theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan zhes bya ba'i tshig le'ur byas pa/
In the Indian language: Mahāyānasūtrālaṃkāra-nāma-kārikā In the Tibetan language: The stanzas entitled Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras.[22]
sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
I pay homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas!
1. [le'u dang po]
1. How the Scripture was Composed

don shes don ston rab tu byed pa ngag dang tshig rnams dri med pas/ / sdug bsngal bsgral phyir de yi bdag nyid sdug bsngal 'gro la snying rje las/ / theg mchog bstan pa'i rnam pa chos kyi de yis 'gro ba'i sems can la/ / 'byor pa'i don tshul bla med gyur pa rnam lnga'i bdag nyid ston par byed/ /

The one who knows the meaning reveals the meaning with immaculate speech and immaculate words. To liberate from misery, this arises from the compassion for suffering beings that is present in those who have that as their very nature. Belonging to the Dharma that teaches the Supreme Vehicle and intended for sentient beings who progress by means of this, It explains the five rich subjects of the Unexcelled. [I.1]

gser las brdungs byas 'dra zhing pad+ma rgyas pa bzhin/ / bkres pas nyen pa g.yos legs kha zas za ba 'dra/ / 'phrin yig legs pa thos 'dra rin chen sgrom phye lta'i/ / chos de 'dir bshad pa yang dga' ba'i mchog skyed do/ /

Resembling shaped gold, a lotus in bloom, And an excellent meal enjoyed when stricken with hunger; Like receiving a letter with good news and an open treasure trove— Such is the Dharma, which when here explained engenders perfect joy. [I.2]

gzugs rgyan rang bzhin yon tan ldan pa me long nang song na/ / mthong ba'i dbang gis mi rnams rab tu dga' ba'i mchog skyed pa/ / de bzhin legs gsungs rtag tu rang bzhin yon tan ldan pa yi/ / chos kyang don rnams phye bas mkhas rnams 'di na dga' mchog skyed/ /

When a body, replete with ornaments and naturally endowed with excellent qualities, is reflected in a mirror, Those who see it will experience total and supreme joy. Likewise, while the well-spoken words of the Dharma are always replete with excellent qualities, When their meaning is explained herein, the wise will experience supreme joy. [I.3]
ji ltar mnams na rab dku la/ / myangs na zhim pa'i sman bzhin du/ / chos kyang de bzhin gnyis su gnas/ / don dang yi ger shes par bya/ /
Like a medicine with a foul odor, Yet of exquisite taste, It should be understood that the Dharma is twofold as well, For there is the meaning and the letters. [I.4]
chos dka' rgya chen zab mo 'di/ / rgyal po bzhin du mnyes par dka'/ / mnyes par byas na de bzhin du/ / yon tan mchog gi nor sbyin byed/ /
This Dharma is hard, vast, and profound. It is difficult to please, just like a king. Yet, similarly, if one succeeds in pleasing, The riches of supreme qualities will be granted. [I.5]
rin chen rigs ldan rin thang med/ / lta mi shes pa'i mig mi mgu/ / de bzhin mi mkhas chos 'di la/ / bzlog na de bzhin mgu bar 'gyur/ /
As with a jewel that is genuine and priceless, Yet unacknowledged by those not acquainted, So do the unwise relate to this Dharma. For others it is different; they cherish it. [I.6]
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las le'u dang po'o// //
This was the first chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras.

d.crumb: 2. theg pa chen po sgrub pa'i skabs

f.d: 2. [theg pa chen po sgrub pa'i skabs kyi le'u]

d.crumb: 2. Establishing the Teachings of the Great Vehicle

f.d: 2. Establishing the Teachings of the Great Vehicle
sngar lung ma bstan lhan cig byung / / spyod yul ma yin grub pa dang / / yod dang med na yod med dang / / gnyen po dang ni sgra gzhan phyir/ /

It was not previously prophesied, and they arose together. It is not within the domain yet is established. It exists, and if not, that would not exist. It is the remedy and means something else—these are the reasons. [II.1]
sangs rgyas rnams ni mngon sum spyan/ / bstan pa dag kyang srung bar mdzad/ / dus la'ang ye shes ma bsgribs pas/ / de phyir btang snyoms mi rung ngo / /
The eyes of the buddhas perceive directly, They protect the teachings, Their wakefulness is unimpeded by time. Hence, they could not be indifferent. [II.2]
ma tshang ba dang 'gal ba dang / / thabs min de ltar ma bstan phyir/ / nyan thos kyi ni theg pa 'di/ / theg chen chos shes bya ba min/ /
It is incomplete, in conflict, and not the means. Given that it does not teach in this way The Vehicle of the Listeners Is not what is known as “the Great Vehicle Dharma.” [II.3]
bsam pa dang ni bstan pa dang / / sbyor ba dang ni rton pa dang / / dus 'gal phyir na dman pa gang / / de ni dman pa kho na yin/ /
There is conflict in terms of Intent and the teaching, Practice, support, and time. Hence, the Lesser Vehicle is utterly inferior. [II.4]
rang gi nyid la 'jug pa dang / / rang gi 'dul la'ang snang phyir dang / / zab pa'i phyir dang rgya che'i phyir/ / chos nyid dang ni 'gal ba med/ /
It applies to its own sūtras, And appears in its own Vinaya. As it is profound and vast, It does not conflict with the intrinsic nature. [II.5]
rtog ge rten cing ma nges la/ / ma khyab kun rdzob skyo ba can/ / byis pa la ni rten par 'dod/ / de phyir de ni de yul min/ /
Logic is dependent, uncertain, Incomprehensive, relative, and tiresome. It is held to be reliable by the childish, And this is, therefore, not within the domain. [II.6]
rgya che'i phyir dang zab pa'i phyir/ / yongs su smin dang rnam mi rtog / de phyir 'di las gnyis bstan te/ / de ni bla na med pa'i thabs/ /
Because of its vastness and profundity, Maturation and nonconceptuality, Its teaching is twofold. Therefore, it is the means for the unexcelled. [II.7]

'gro ba de'i gnas min la skrag pa gdung byed 'gyur/ / bsod nams ma yin phung chen bsags byas yun ring du/ / rigs med grogs ngan sngon dge ma bsags blo ma sbyangs/ / chos 'dis skrag 'gyur 'di na don chen 'di las ltung / /

The fear of wandering beings is unjustified and causes agony Because they amass vast heaps of wrongdoing for a long time. Lacking the potential, keeping unwholesome company, not having gathered virtue in the past, and not training the mind, One is frightened by this Dharma, and so falls short of what is immensely meaningful. [II.8]

de las gzhan dang gzhan med shin tu zab cing rjes song phyir/ / sna tshogs ston cing mang po'i sgo nas rtag tu ston dang ldan/ / ji skad bshad bzhin don min bcom ldan dgongs pa shin tu zab/ / mkhas pa rnams kyis tshul bzhin brtags na chos 'dis skrag mi 'gyur/ /

There is no Great Vehicle other than this anywhere; it is extremely profound and in accord. It teaches a diversity, and it teaches consistently using numerous means. Different from the literal meaning taught, the intent of the Blessed One is extremely profound. The wise who examine it properly are not frightened by this Dharma. [II.9]

'di na dang por thos la brtan nas yid la byed pa 'byung / / tshul bzhin yid la byed las yang dag don yul ye shes 'byung / / de las chos thob de yod de las blo gros rab tu skye/ / gang tshe de ni so so rang rig med na ji ltar nges/ /

Here one begins by receiving teaching, and, based on that, one directs the mind. By properly directing the mind, there will be wakefulness and the object, the true nature. With that comes the attainment of the qualities, and thereby wisdom will fully develop. This is one’s own direct awareness. How can one be certain when lacking this? [II.10]
bdag gis mi shes sangs rgyas zab mo mkhyen ma yin/ / zab mo ci yi phyir na rtog ge'i yul ma yin/ / ci phyir zab mo'i don rig pa dag thar 'gyur zhes/ / bya ba de ni skrag pa'i gnas su rigs ma yin/ /

“I do not understand.” “The Buddha does not know the profound.” “Why is the profound not the domain of logic?” “Why should those who know the profound meaning be liberated?” These are not grounds for fear. [II.11]
dman par mos shing khams kyang shin tu dman/ / grogs po dman pa dag gis yongs bskor ba/ / zab cing rgya che legs par bshad pa'i chos/ / 'di la gal te mos med grub pa yin/ /

If those inspired by the inferior, whose constitutions are extremely inferior, And who are surrounded by inferior company, Have no interest in this well-spoken Dharma of the profound and the vast, It will thereby have been established. [II.12]
thos rjes 'brangs te blo ldan thob nas ni/ / gang zhig thos la rab tu gnas byed pa/ / rnam pa sna tshogs dpag tu med lus la/ / rmongs pa gang gi phyir na nges par byed/ /
Those who achieve understanding through receiving teaching, Yet completely disregard reception and Ignore the boundless diversity, will remain ignorant of it. How could they be certain? [II.13]
don sgra ji bzhin yongs rtog na/ / bdag nyid snyems shing blo nyams 'gyur/ / legs par gsungs pa'ang spangs pas na/ / brlag 'gyur chos la khong khro sgrib/ /

Taking the meaning to be exactly what is literally stated, One becomes arrogant and intelligence deteriorates. As even the excellent discourses are rejected, One will come to ruin with obscurations due to harboring anger toward the Dharma. [II.14]
yid kyi nyes pa rang bzhin gdug pa ste/ / mi rigs pa yi gzugs la'ang mi rigs na/ / the tshom za ba'i chos la smos ci dgos/ / de phyir btang snyoms gzhag legs nyes pa med/ /

The flaw of mind is toxic by nature. Inappropriate even when directed at an unfavorable form, It is obviously so when directed at the Dharma one doubts. Therefore, being neutral is preferable, for then there is no fault. [II.15]
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las theg pa chen po sgrub pa'i skabs kyi le'u ste gnyis pa'o// //
This was the second chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras, the chapter on establishing the Great Vehicle.
3. [skyabs su 'gro ba'i le'u]
3. Going for Refuge

kun du 'gro dang khas len rtogs dang zil gnon par/ / dbye ba'i rang bzhin don rnam bzhi yi khyad par gyis/ / theg pa mchog phyir dkon mchog skyabs rab song ba gang / / de ni skyabs su song ba rnams kyi mchog ces bya/ /

Universality, commitment, realization, and outshining— These four elements distinguish the supreme vehicle. The one who thus goes for refuge in the Jewels Is known as supreme among all who take refuge. [III.1]

gang phyir dang por nges par bya ba 'di dka' ste/ / de ni bskal pa stong phrag du mar bsgrub par dka'/ / gang phyir grub na sems can phan byed don che ste/ / de phyir theg chen 'di la skyabs don mchog yin no/ /

First, this determination is difficult, And the practice throughout many thousands of eons is difficult as well. The purpose is great, for once accomplished, there is benefit for beings. Therefore, taking refuge in this Great Vehicle has a supreme objective. [III.2]

gang zhig sems can thams cad bsgral bar zhugs pa dang / / theg pa ye shes kun tu 'gro la mkhas par ldan/ / gang zhig mya ngan 'das la 'khor zhi ro gcig pa/ / de 'dra'i blo ldan de 'dir kun 'gror shes par bya/ /

Those who pursue the liberation of all sentient beings, Have expertise regarding the vehicles and universal wakefulness, And know cyclic existence and peace to be of one taste within the transcendence of suffering Are wise individuals, who should here be known as “universal.” [III.3]

gang zhig dga' ba mang pos byang chub mchog don gnyer/ / gang zhig skyo ba med par dka' ba yang dag spyod/ / gang zhig rnam sangs rgyas nas sangs rgyas kun mnyam 'gyur/ / blo ldan de ni khas len mchog tu shes par bya/ /

In pursuit of supreme enlightenment with manifold joy, Fully undertaking hardship without weariness, They become buddhas, equal to all the buddhas. Know that such wise individuals have a supreme commitment. [III.4]

sangs rgyas sras kyi mchog tu legs par gang skyes pa/ / sems dang shes rab dang ni tshogs ldan snying rje ni/ / sa bon ma dang mngal gnas ma ma mtshungs pa med/ / blo ldan de ni khas len mchog tu shes par bya/ /

For the one of noble birth, the supreme child of the buddhas, Mind, insight, accumulation, and compassion Are like the unequalled seed, mother, abode of the womb, and nursemaid. Know that this wise individual has a supreme commitment. [III.5]
sna tshogs mtshan rnams kun gyis de'i lus brgyan/ / sems can thams cad smin par byed stobs thob/ / sangs rgyas bde chen mtha' yas zhi ba rnyed/ / sems can kun skyabs thabs chen bsham pa shes/ /

With a body adorned by various marks, The bodhisattva has attained the power to mature all beings And discovered the peace of the buddha’s limitless great bliss, Knowing how to exhibit great means for protecting all beings. [III.6]

sangs rgyas kun gyis 'od zer chen pos dbang bskur byin/ / de ni chos la dbang ba kun dang yang dag ldan/ / sangs rgyas 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor ston pa'i rnam pa shes/ / bslab pa bca' bas tshar gcod phan 'dogs byed la brtson/ /

They have the empowerment bestowed by great rays of light from all the buddhas And possess complete and genuine mastery over phenomena. They know how to display the circle of a buddha’s retinue, And strive, having established the training, to subjugate and assist. [III.7]

blon po chen po lta bur pha rol phyin la 'jug pa'i phyir/ / byang chub chen po'i phyogs mthun bdal la rtag tu spyan byed phyir/ / gsang ba'i gnas ni rnam gsum rtag tu yang dag 'dzin pa'i phyir/ / sems can mang don rtag tu rgyun mi 'chad par rab byed phyir/ /

They resemble a great minister because they practice the transcendences, Always oversee the array of factors that accord with great enlightenment, Always sustain the domains of the triple mystery, And always provide for multitudes of beings without interruption. [III.8]

bsod nams phung chen srid gsum bla ma srid pa'i bde ba dang / / sdug bsngal phung po chen po rab zhi blo mchog bde ba dang / / chos mang phung po mchog rab rtag pa'i sku ste dge ba'i tshogs/ / bag chags bzlog cing srid dang zhi las rnam par grol ba 'thob/ /

They have great heaps of merit, are teachers of the three worlds, and enjoy the pleasures of existence. Completely pacifying great masses of suffering, and with the bliss of supreme intelligence, They possess the supreme assembly of numerous qualities, a permanent body, and a host of virtues. Reversing habitual tendencies, they are liberated from existence and peace—this is their attainment. [III.9]

blo ldan nyan thos tshogs bcas dge ba rgya chen don chen dang / / mtha' yas rtag rgyun mi 'chad zad mi shes pas zil gyis gnon/ / dge ba de yang 'jig rten 'jig rten ma yin yongs smin byed/ / dbang 'byor rnyed pa de ni phung po zhi bas zad mi shes/ /

The wise surpass the gatherings that include the listeners By means of virtues that are vast, tremendously beneficial, infinite, always constant, and inexhaustible. These virtues are, moreover, the mundane, the supramundane, the thorough ripening, and the attainment of mastery. They are not exhausted by the pacification of the aggregates. [III.10]

'di ni de dngos 'dod pas khas len de yang snying brtse las rig bya/ / de las rnam pa kun mkhyen phan dang bde byed dka' la skyo ba med/ / nges par 'byung la theg pa kun gyis rton pa'i yon tan rtag tu ldan/ / brda dang chos nyid thob pa blo ldan rnams kyi skyabs 'gro 'di mchog yin/ /

This is a commitment with the wish for the nature of that, and it should be understood to arise from compassion. Omniscient wakefulness ensues from this, as do benefit and happiness, and no aversion when facing hardship. As for definitive emergence, this always has the qualities that are relied on in all the vehicles. Attained through symbols and the intrinsic nature, the way that the wise go for refuge is supreme. [III.11]
skyabs su 'gro ba 'dir song don chen te/ / de ni dpag med yon tan tshogs 'phel 'gyur/ / 'gro ba 'di la snying rje'i bsam pas khyab/ / mtshungs med 'phags chen chos kyang rgyas par byed/ /

Taking refuge in this has a great purpose, For unfathomable qualities will be gathered thereby, These beings will be embraced by a compassionate intent, And the Dharma of the unequaled, great noble ones will flourish. [III.12]
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las skyabs su 'gro ba'i le'u ste gsum pa'o// //
This was the third chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras, the chapter on going for refuge.
4. [rigs kyi le'u]
4. Potential
yod dang mchog dang mtshan nyid dang / / rtags dang rigs rab dbye ba dang / / nyes dmigs dang ni phan yon dang / / dpe rnam gnyis te rnam pa bzhi/ /
Existence, supremacy, characteristics, Signs, classifications of potential, Flaws, benefits, and the two metaphors— Each of these is fourfold. [IV.1]
khams rnams dang ni mos pa dang / / sgrub pa tha dad dbye ba dang / / 'bras bu tha dad dmigs pa'i phyir/ / rigs yod nyid du nges par brjod/ /
We observe a diversity of elements, interests, Forms of practice, and fruitions. It is, therefore, definitively stated That there is such a thing as potential. [IV.2]
de dge khyad par 'phags pa dang / / thams cad dang ni don chen dang / / mi zad pa yi rgyu mtshan phyir/ / rigs mchog nyid ces brjod pa yin/ /
The virtue of that Is superior, total, Greatly beneficial, and not exhausted. Hence, this potential is declared to be supreme. [IV.3]
rang bzhin dang ni rgyas pa dang / / de ni rten dang brten pa dang / / yod med nyid dang yon tan ni/ / sgrol ba'i don du shes par bya/ /
The natural and the developed Are the support and the supported. Present while not present, It should be known to mean “freeing qualities.” [IV.4]
sbyor ba'i sngon du snying rje dang / / mos pa dang ni bzod pa dang / / dge ba yang dag spyod pa ni/ / rigs kyi rtags su nges par bshad/ /
Before the practice, there is Compassion, inspiration, Forbearance, and genuine experience with virtue. These are definitively taught to be the signs of potential. [IV.5]
rigs ni nges dang ma nges dang / / rkyen rnams kyis ni mi 'phrogs dang / / 'phrogs pa nyid de mdor na rigs/ / dbye ba 'di ni rnam pa bzhi/ /
Potential may be either certain or uncertain, Unaffected by conditions, Or affected by them. In short, the classification of potential is fourfold. [IV.6]
nyon mongs goms dang grogs ngan dang / / 'phongs dang gzhan gyi dbang nyid dang / / mdor na rigs kyi nyes dmigs ni/ / rnam pa bzhi ru shes par bya/ /
Habituation to affliction, negative company, Poverty, and being controlled by other— In short, it should be understood That there are four flaws with regard to potential. [IV.7]
ring mo zhig na ngan song du/ / 'gro zhing myur du thar pa dang / / de na'ang sdug bsngal chung ngu myong / / skyo bcas sems can smin par byed/ /
They seldom go to the lower realms And are freed quickly. Experiencing little suffering even there, Saddened, they bring sentient beings to maturation. [IV.8]
gser gyi rigs bzhin shes par bya/ / dge ba dpag tu med pa'i gnas/ / ye shes dang ni dri med ldan/ / mthu rnams kyi yang gnas yin no/ /
It should be known to be like a gold mine For it is the abode of limitless virtues; It is the abode of wakefulness, stainlessness, As well as the powers. [IV.9]
rin chen mchog rigs bzhin shes bya/ / byang chub chen po'i rgyu mtshan phyir/ / ye shes che dang ting 'dzin 'phags/ / sems can mang po'i don gnas phyir/ /

It should be known to be like a mine of precious jewels, For it is the cause of great enlightenment, And the abode of great wakefulness, superior meditative absorption, And benefits for numerous sentient beings. [IV.10]
la la gcig tu nyes par spyod nges yod/ / la la dkar po'i chos rnams kun du bcom/ / la la thar pa'i cha mthun dge ba med/ / dkar po dman pa yod pa rgyu dang bral/ /

Some are exclusively and decisively engaged in error. Some have completely destroyed their positive qualities. Some lack virtue that is conducive to liberation. Some possess insufficient virtue, and some lack the cause. [IV.11]

zab cing rgya che bshad pa gzhan la phan phyir bstan pa'i chos chen la/ / mi shes bzhin du mos pa shin tu rgya chen 'byung zhing sgrub la bzod/ / de dag tha mar rnam pa gnyis mchog phun sum tshogs 'gyur gang yin de/ / byang chub sems dpa' rang bzhin yon tan ldan de rgyas pa'i rigs las shes/ /

The great Dharma that explains the profound and vast is taught for the sake of benefiting others. Even while not understanding it, they develop tremendous inspiration and bear the practice. Their final perfection is supreme, beyond the two. Know that this is due to the natural presence of bodhisattva qualities and the development of that potential. [IV.12]

yon tan shin tu rgya che byang chub shing skyed phyir/ / bde dang sdug bsngal chen po zhi ba thob bya'i phyir/ / bdag dang gzhan la phan bde byed pa 'bras bu'i phyir/ / rigs mchog de ni rtsa ba bzang po lta bu yin/ /
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ rigs kyi le'u ste bzhi pa'o// //
This was the fourth chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras, the chapter on potential.
5. [sems bskyed pa'i le'u]
5. Developing the Enlightened Mind
spro ba che dang rtsom pa che/ / don che ba dang 'byung ba che/ / byang chub sems dpa'i sems dpa' ste/ / don gnyis ldan pa'i sems 'byung ba/ /
Extremely delightful, vigorous, Meaningful, and productive, The bodhisattva’s mind Is a mental state of intention that possesses two objectives. [V.1]
sems bskyed de ni sa rnams la/ / mos dang lhag bsam dag pa dang / / rnam par smin pa gzhan du 'dod/ / de bzhin sgrib pa spangs pa'o/ /
The mind is developed on the grounds Through inspiration, pure superior intent, And maturation. Likewise, there is the elimination of obscurations. [V.2]
de yi rtsa ba snying rjer 'dod/ / rtag tu sems can phan par sems/ / chos la mos dang de bzhin de'i/ / ye shes tshol ba dmigs pa'o/ /
Its root is held to be compassion. The intention is to always benefit sentient beings. Its inspiration is the Dharma, And its objective is to seek out the wakefulness of that. [V.3]
gong du 'dun pa 'gro ba ste/ / sdom pa rgya chen de yi rten/ / lam 'gog pa ni mi mthun phyogs/ / slong zhing dang du len pa'o/ /
Aspiration reaching ever higher, The vast vow serves as its support. What blocks the path is the arising and pursuit Of conflicting factors. [V.4]
bsod nams ye shes rang bzhin gyi/ / dge ba 'phel ba de'i phan yon/ / pha rol phyin la rtag sbyor ba/ / de ni nges par 'byung bar 'dod/ /
The benefits are an increase of virtues That are the nature of merit and wakefulness. Constant engagement in the transcendences Is held to be the definitive emergence. [V.5]
'di yi mthar thug sa yin te/ / so so rang gi der sbyor bas/ / byang chub sems dpa'i sems bskyed pa/ / rnam par nges par shes par bya/ /
Its culmination is the grounds, As these are individually reached. The bodhisattvas’ development of the mind Should be understood decisively in this way. [V.6]
grogs stobs rgyu stobs rtsa ba'i stobs/ / thos stobs dge ba goms pa las/ / mi brtan pa dang brtan 'byung ba/ / gzhan gyis bstan pa'i sems bskyed bshad/ /

Brought about by the power of the teacher, the cause, the fundamental, Hearing, and familiarity with virtue, The arising is unstable and stable. This cultivation of the mind is explained as being taught by others. [V.7]
rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rab bsnyen byas/ / bsod nams ye shes tshogs rab bsags/ / chos la mi rtog ye shes ni/ / skyes phyir de ni dam par 'dod/ /

The perfect buddhas are served, The accumulations of merit and wakefulness thoroughly gathered, And nonconceptual wakefulness with regard to phenomena is born. Therefore, this is held to be ultimate. [V.8]
chos dang sems can rnams dang ni/ / de yi bya ba sangs rgyas nyid/ / mchog la sems mnyam rnyed pa'i phyir/ / de yi rab dga' khyad par 'phags/ /
With regard to phenomena, sentient beings, Their needs, and the highest buddhahood, One discovers a mind of equality. Hence, this sublime joy is exalted. [V.9]
skye ba rgya chen de la spro/ / bsam pa yang ni dag pa dang / / lhag ma dag la mkhas pa dang / / nges par 'byung bar shes par bya/ /
Birth, vastness, delight in this, Pure intent, expertise in what remains, And definitive emergence— Thus it should be understood. [V.10]
chos la mos pa sa bon dang / / pha rol phyin mchog ma las skyes/ / bsam gtan las byung bde ba mngal/ / snying rje skyed pa'i ma ma'o/ /

Inspiration with respect to the Dharma is the seed, And the supreme transcendence is the mother from whom it is born. Emerging from the womb of the bliss of meditative concentration, It is raised by the nursemaid of compassion. [V.11]
smon lam chen po bcu sgrub phyir/ / rgya che bar ni shes par bya/ /
Because of the practice of the ten great aspirations, It should be known to be vast. [V. 12a–b]
dka' ba yun ring mi skyo'i phyir/ / spro bar khong du chud par bya/ /
Since there is no weariness during long periods of hardship, It should be understood to be delightful. [V.12c–d]
byang chub nye bar rtogs pa dang / / de yi thabs shes rnyed pa'i phyir/ / bsam pa dag par shes par bya/ /
Since it is realized that enlightenment is near, And since knowledge of the means for that has been discovered, The intent should be known to be pure. [V.13a–c]
sa gzhan tshul la mkhas pa nyid/ /
There is expertise with regard to the other grounds. [V.13d]
ji ltar rnam gzhag yid byed pas/ / de rtog nyid du shes phyir dang / / de nyid la yang mi rtog phyir/ / nges par 'byung bar shes par bya/ /
The mind is perfectly attentive to the principles. They are precisely known to be thoughts, And there is no thought with regard to that. Thus, this should be known to be definitive emergence. [V.14]
skyed pa sa dang mtshungs pa ste/ / gzhan ni bzang po'i gser dang 'dra/ / zla ba yar gyi tshes pa bzhin/ / gzhan ni me dang 'drar shes bya/ /
The development is like the earth. Another is like exquisite gold. One is like the waxing moon, Another is known to be like fire. [V.15]
gzhan ni gter chen bzhin shes bya/ / gzhan ni rin chen 'byung gnas bzhin/ / rgya mtsho 'dra bar shes bya gzhan/ / rdo rje dang 'dra ri rab 'dra/ /
Another resembles a great treasure, Another is like a jewel mine. Others are known to be like the ocean, Like a diamond, and like a great mountain. [V.16]
sman gyi rgyal po 'dra ba ste/ / gzhan ni mdza' chen 'drar shes bya/ / yid bzhin nor bu 'dra ba dang / / gzhan ni nyi ma 'drar shes bya/ /
One is like the king of medicines, While another is known to be like a great friend. One resembles a wish-fulfilling jewel. Another is like the sun. [V.17]
gzhan ni dri za'i dbyangs snyan bzhin/ / gzhan ni rgyal po 'drar shes bya/ / de bzhin gzhan ni mdzod lta bu/ / lam po che dang 'drar shes bya/ /
Another is like the melody of the gandharvas, While yet another resembles a king. One is like a treasury, Another is like a highway. [V.18]
theg pa 'dra bar shes bya ste/ / sems bskyed bkod ma 'dra ba yin/ / kun dga'i sgra dang 'dra ba ste/ / klung chen rgyun dang 'dra ba'o/ /
It is known as a vehicle. The development of the mind is like a spring, Like a sound that is lovely to everyone, Like the flow of a great river. [V.19]
rgyal sras rnams kyi sems bskyed pa/ / sprin dang 'dra bar bstan pa ste/ / de phyir de ltar yon tan phyug / sems ni dga' bas yang dag bskyed/ /
The development of the mind of the children Of the victorious ones is said to be like a cloud. Therefore, as it possesses a wealth of qualities, That mind is fully developed with joy. [V.20]
cher 'os sems bskyed spangs pa'i skye bo dag / gzhan don sems dang de yi thabs rnyed dang / / dgongs chen don dang de nyid mchog mthong bas/ / bde ba de spangs zhi bar 'gro bar 'gyur/ /

Beings without this development of the mind, which suits the great, Lack the concern to be of benefit to others, the discovery of the means to do so, The meaning of this great intent, and the vision of supreme reality. Deprived of this happiness, they proceed to peace. [V.21]
blo ldan sems mchog skyes ma thag tu yang / / mtha' yas nyes pa byed las sems rab bsdams/ / gnyis 'phel byed pas rtag tu dge ba dang / / brtse ldan bde dang sdug bsngal dag gis dga'/ /

As soon as the wise give rise to the supreme mind, Their minds are perfectly on guard against doing wrong to the infinite, And, as the two are developed, they are forever in possession of virtue and love, Joyful in both happiness and suffering. [V.22]
gang tshe gzhan gyi don phyir lus dang ni/ / srog la mi lta rab dal khas len pa/ / de lta bu de gzhan gyi gnod pa yis/ / ji ltar ngan par byed pa'i las la 'jug /
When they accept extreme hardship for the sake of others, Without concern for body or life, How could the harm that is inflicted by others Cause them to engage in negative acts? [V.23]
de yis chos kun sgyu ma lta bu dang / / skye ba skyed mos tshal 'gro ltar rtogs nas/ / 'byor ba'i dus dang rgud pa'i dus na'ang 'di/ / nyon mongs sdug bsngal dag gis 'jigs pa med/ /

Realizing that all phenomena are like an illusion And that taking birth is like a trip to a pleasure grove, They do not fear the afflictions or suffering, Regardless of whether they are prosperous or poor. [V.24]
rang gi yon tan sems can phan 'dogs dga'/ / bsams bzhin skye ba rdzu 'phrul rnam par 'phrul/ / rgyan dang ston mo sa mchog brtse dga' ba/ / snying rje'i bdag nyid min pa rnams la med/ /

Joyfully benefiting others with their qualities, Willingly taking birth and displaying miracles, Their joys of ornaments, feasts, supreme grounds, and games Do not belong to those whose very being is not compassion. [V.25]
gzhan don brtson ldan snying rje'i bdag nyid 'di/ / gang tshe mnar med pa la'ang dgar 'dzin pa/ / de 'dra ba dag srid na gzhan rten phyir/ / sdug bsngal 'byung ba rnams kyis ga la 'jigs/ /

Diligently benefiting others, the one whose very being is compassion Holds even the hell of incessant pain to be joyful. When even such a thing is possible, how could those who are supported by others Ever fear painful events? [V.26]
slob dpon brtse chen rtag tu brten pa'i bdag / pha rol sdug bsngal dag gis sems gdungs pa/ / gzhan gyi bya ba nye bar gnas pa la/ / gzhan gyis bskul ba shin tu ngo yang tsha/ /

For those whose nature it is always to rely on the teacher of great love, And who are pained by the suffering of others, To be exhorted by another to work for the welfare of others Would be a matter of great shame. [V.27]
mgo la sems can khur chen khyer ba yi/ / sems can mchog ni dal gyis 'gro mi mdzes/ / bdag gzhan sna tshogs 'ching bas rab bcings pas/ / brtson pa brgya 'gyur du ni bya ba'i rigs/ /
For supreme beings who shoulder the burdens of beings, It is not becoming to walk leisurely. Numerous are the ties that bind oneself and others— This calls for a hundredfold diligence. [V.28]
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las sems bskyed pa'i le'u ste lnga pa'o// //
This was the fifth chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras, the chapter on cultivating the enlightened mind.
6. [sgrub pa'i le'u]
6. Practice
gnas rtsom 'bras bu 'byung ba che bdag nyid/ / rgyal sras rnams kyi sgrub pa yin par 'dod/ / rtag tu len pa che dang bzod pa che/ / don chen yang dag sgrub pa'i bya ba byed/ /

That which consists of the great basis, pursuit, and fruition Is held to be the practice of the children of the victorious one. It is the constant, authentic practice of great concern, great forbearance, And accomplishment of great benefit. [VI.1]
gzhan dang bdag tu mnyam pa'i sems nyid dam/ / bdag pas gzhan ches sdug pa rnyed nas ni/ / de ltar bdag pas gzhan don mchog 'du shes/ / rang gi don gang gzhan gyi don gang yin/ /

There is a mind of equality toward self and other, Or, as one cherishes others more than oneself, A perception of the welfare of others as far more important than one’s own. Which objectives are then one’s own, and which are those of others? [VI.2]

ji ltar snying rje'i bdag nyid gzhan gyi don gyi phyir/ / bdag la sdug bsngal mi bzad gdung ba rab byed pa/ / de ltar 'jig rten gdung ba'i las kyis gzhan dgra la'ang / / shin tu brtse ba med par rab tu 'jug ma yin/ /

Those whose nature is compassion Bring endless torments upon themselves for the sake of others. These exceed the torture that even the most ruthless worldly person Would ever use against his enemy. [VI.3]
tha chad 'bring dang mchog chos nyid gnas la/ / legs par ston dang mgu byed 'jug pa dang / / don la rnam nges dge ba yongs smin byed/ / de bzhin gdams ngag gnas dang blo rnam grol/ /

For those of the lowest, mediocre, and supreme nature, They elegantly explain, delight, provide entry, Ascertain the meaning, and thoroughly mature virtues. Likewise they grant practical instructions, rest, and liberation of the mind. [VI.4]
yon tan khyad par can 'grub de bzhin du/ / rigs su skye dang lung bstan dbang bskur dang / / de bzhin gshegs mkhyen bla med go 'phang ste/ / bcu gsum bdag nyid 'di ni gzhan gyi don/ /

They accomplish special qualities, provide birth into the family, As well as prophecy, empowerment, And the stage of the thus-gone ones’ unsurpassable wakefulness. These are the thirteen ways of benefiting others. [VI.5]
skye bo dang mthun phyin ci ma log 'chad/ / mi 'gying ba dang bdag gi med la mkhas/ / bzod dul shin tu ring song mi zad pa/ / rgyal sras rnams kyi sgrub pa mchog yin no/ /

Teaching correctly and in harmony with beings, Absence of conceit and any notion of “mine,” expertise, Patience, discipline, extremely far reach, and inexhaustibility: Such are the supreme practices of the children of the victorious ones. [VI.6]
'dod ldan skye bo 'jigs pa che la 'jug / srid dga' phyin ci log bde g.yo ba la/ / zhi dga' rang gi len pa rab zhi la/ / snying rje'i bdag nyid len kun zhi la rtag /

The desirous pursue the terrifying, Those fond of existence pursue fleeting, perverse enjoyments, And those fond of peace are concerned with pacifying their own appropriations. Those whose very nature is compassion are constant in pacifying the appropriations of all. [vi.7]
skye bo rmongs pa rang gi bde don brtson/ / rtag tu de ma thob par sdug bsngal 'gyur/ / brtan pa rtag tu gzhan don brtson ldan pa/ / gnyi ka'i don byas mya ngan 'da' bar 'gyur/ /

Deluded beings strive for their own happiness And always suffer because of not finding it. The steadfast ones are always diligent for the sake of others. Accomplishing the welfare of both, they leave suffering behind. [vi.8]
rgyal sras spyod tshe ji lta ji lta bur/ / dbang po'i spyod yul sna tshogs 'jug 'gyur ba/ / de lta de ltar rigs shing mthun tshig gis/ / sems can phan phyir de mngon 'du byed do/ /

When the children of the victorious ones are active, All that they experience through the senses Is accompanied by fitting and agreeable verbal expressions That are formed for the sake of others. [VI.9]

rtag tu nyes pas rang dbang med par byas sems kyi/ / skye bo la ni blo ldan nyes par mi 'dzin te/ / mi 'dod bzhin du log par sgrub par 'gyur ro zhes/ / skye bo dag la snying rje rnam par 'phel phyir ro/ /

Knowing that they are always governed by their flaws, The wise find no flaw in beings. “Their inappropriate conduct occurs against their will”— With this thought, their compassion for beings grows. [VI.10]
sgrub pa 'dis ni srid dang 'gro ba kun/ / zil gyis mnan 'gro zhi ba mchog dang ldan/ / yon tan sna tshogs tshogs kyis rnam par 'phel/ / byams pa'i bsam pas rtag tu 'gro ba sdud/ /

Outshining all of existence and wandering beings, This practice is endowed with supreme peace. Enhanced by the accumulation of numerous qualities, It constantly attracts beings with a loving intent. [VI.11]
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las sgrub pa'i le'u ste drug pa'o// //
This was the sixth chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras, the chapter on practice.
7. [de kho na nyid kyi le'u]
7. Reality
yod min med min de bzhin min gzhan min/ / skye dang 'jig med 'bri bar mi 'gyur te/ / 'phel ba med cing rnam par dag pa'ang med/ / rnam par dag 'gyur de ni don dam mtshan/ /

Not existent and not nonexistent, not the same and not different, Without origination and destruction, decrease and increase, Without becoming pure, it still becomes pure— These are the marks of the ultimate. [VII.1]
bdag tu lta ba bdag nyid bdag mtshan min/ / ngan par gnas min mtshan nyid mi 'dra phyir/ / gnyis las gzhan med de ni nor pa skyes/ / de phyir thar pa nor tsam zad pa yin/ /

The nature of the belief in a self does not characterize the self, Neither do the negative bases, for their characteristics differ. Apart from these two there is nothing; this is a mistake that occurred. Liberation is, therefore, the cessation of a mere mistake. [VII.2]
ji ltar 'khrul pa tsam brten skye bo yis/ / sdug bsngal rang bzhin rgyun chags rtogs mi 'gyur/ / rig min rig nyid sdug bsngal sdug bsngal med/ / chos kyi rang bzhin de yi rang bzhin min/ /

Based on a mere mistake, beings do not realize The continuous nature of suffering. While not aware, there is awareness; there is suffering, yet they do not suffer. This is the nature of phenomena, and yet it is not that nature. [VII.3]
brten nas dngos rab skye ba mngon 'jug na/ / skye bo ji ltar gzhan gyis byas la rten/ / gang phyir yod pa mi mthong med mthong ba/ / 'di 'dra'i mun nag rnam pa de gang zhig /

When they clearly experience the dependent arising of things, Why do beings take recourse to creation by something else? How can they fail to see what exists, and instead see what does not? What sort of dense darkness is this? [VII.4]
'di la don dam tshul gyis zhi ba dang / / skye ba de gnyis khyad par ci yang med/ / 'on kyang dge ba'i las rnams byed pa dag / skye ba zad pas zhi ba 'thob par bshad/ /
There is ultimately no difference whatsoever Between peace and birth; Yet it is said that those performing virtuous acts Bring an end to birth and thereby gain peace. [VII.5]
byang chub sems dpas bsod nams ye shes kyi/ / mtha' yas pha rol tshogs rnams legs bsags nas/ / chos la sems pa shin tu rnam nges phyir/ / don gyi rnam pa brjod pa'i rgyu can rtogs/ /

When a bodhisattva has thoroughly gathered the accumulations Of merit and wakefulness beyond measure, The bodhisattva contemplates the Dharma in a most decisive way, And thereby realizes that the forms of objects are the result of expression. [VII.6]
de yis brjod pa tsam du don rig nas/ / der snang sems tsam la ni yang dag gnas/ / de nas chos dbyings gnyis kyi mtshan nyid dang / / bral ba mngon sum nyid du rtogs par 'gyur/ /

Hence, knowing objects to be mere expressions, The bodhisattva recognizes that such appearances are mind only, And then realizes the basic field of phenomena, Free from the characteristics of duality, in direct perception. [VII.7]
sems las gzhan med par ni blos rig nas/ / de nas sems kyang med pa nyid du rtogs/ / blo dang ldan pas gnyis po med rig nas/ / de mi ldan pa'i chos kyi dbyings la gnas/ /

Becoming aware that there is nothing apart from the mind, The bodhisattva also realizes that the mind does not exist at all. Having seen that the two do not exist, the intelligent one abides In the basic field of phenomena, which does not contain them. [VII.8]
blo dang ldan pas mi rtog ye shes stobs/ / rtag tu kun nas mnyam par song ba yis/ / de la rten pa'i nyes tshogs tshang tshing dag / dug sman chen pos dug bzhin sel bar byed/ /
For the wise, the power of nonconceptual wakefulness Always makes everything equal in all regards. This clears the wilderness of supported flaws Just as a powerful antidote dispels a poison. [VII.9]
thub pas gsungs pa'i dam chos legs bzhag pa/ / rtsa ba chos kyi dbyings la blo gros bzhag / dran rgyu rtog pa tsam rig brtan pa dag / myur du yon tan rgya mtsho'i pha rol 'gro/ /

The Dharma taught by the Able One is presented well. Intelligence is directed toward the root, the basic field of phenomena. Those stable in the awareness that what moves in the mind is mere thought Are swift in crossing the ocean of qualities. [VII.10]
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ de kho na nyid kyi le'u ste bdun pa'o// //
This was the seventh chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras, the chapter on reality.
8. [mthu'i le'u]
8. Power
skye dang ngag sems dge dang mi dge bskyed/ / de yi gnas dang 'byung ba mngon sum gang / / shes pa kun 'gro rab tu dbye bcas la/ / thogs med brtan pa thob pa'i mthu yin no/ /

Birth, speech, mind, the creation of virtue and nonvirtue, The realms, and emergence—these are perceived directly. Omnipresent and unimpeded regarding the subdivisions; This is the power of having attained stability. [VIII.1]
bsam gtan bzhi pa shin tu dag thob nas/ / mi rtog ye shes yongs su bzung ba dang / / ji ltar rnam gnas yid la byed pa las/ / mthu grub pa yi dam pa thob par 'gyur/ /

When the utter purity of the fourth concentration has been attained, Complete embrace by means of nonconceptual wakefulness, Along with the mind’s being directed to the methods, Brings the accomplishment of true power. [VIII.2]
gang gis 'phags dang lha dang tshangs pa yi/ / gnas pa dpe med rgya ches rtag tu gnas/ / phyogs su de song sangs rgyas sems can rnams/ / yang dag mchod byed rnam par dag pa skyed/ /

The one who always abides, incomparably and expansively, In the noble, divine, and sublime abodes, Journeys everywhere to worship thoroughly the buddhas, And bring about the purification of sentient beings. [VIII.3]
chags dang 'jig bcas sems can bcas pa yi/ / 'jig rten khams kun sgyu ma lta bur mthong / / dbang ldan ji ltar 'dod bzhin de dag dang / / rnam bcas sna tshogs dag kyang yang dag ston/ /

Bodhisattvas see the entire world as an illusion, Including its formation and disintegration, and its sentient beings. Possessing mastery, they manifest whatever is wished for, And they present various displays in the most perfect way. [VIII.4]
'od zer btang bas shin tu sdug bsngal ba'i/ / ngan song ba dag mtho ris 'gro bar byed/ / 'dud gnas gzhal med khang mtho mdzes pa dag / bdud bcas kun du bskyod cing skrag par byed/ /
Emitting light rays, they make the wretched Inhabitants of the lower realms depart to the higher. Shaking them in their lofty and beautiful mansions, They terrify the demons. [VIII.5]
de ni mchog tshogs nang du ting nge 'dzin/ / dpag med rnam par rol pa kun ston cing / / bzo dang skye dang mchog gi sprul pa yis/ / sems can rnams kyi don du dus kun gnas/ /

In the supreme gathering, the bodhisattvas revel In an infinite display of meditative absorptions. With creative, incarnate, and supreme emanations, They are constantly present for the welfare of others. [VIII.6]
ye shes dag la dbang phyir zhing rnams ni/ / ji ltar 'dod bzhin bstan phyir dag la 'thob/ / sangs rgyas mtshan mi grags par sangs rgyas mtshan/ / yang dag bsgrags pas de dag khams gzhan 'gyed/ /

With mastery regarding wakefulness, Bodhisattvas display whatever fields are wished for, and thereby accomplish purity. For those who have not heard them, They proclaim the buddhas’ names, and so unfold further realms. [VIII.7]
'dab gshog kun du rgyas pa'i bya bzhin du/ / sems can smin par byed par nus pa nyid/ / sangs rgyas las ni shin tu bsngags pa 'thob/ / skye dgu rnams la tshig gzung 'os par 'gyur/ /

Like a bird with its wings fully developed They are indeed capable of maturing sentient beings. They gain tremendous praise from the buddhas, And sentient beings find their words worthy of recollection. [VIII.8]
mngon par shes pa drug dang rig pa gsum/ / rnam thar brgyad dang de bzhin zil gnon brgyad/ / zad par skye mched bcu dang ting nge 'dzin/ / dpag tu med pa brtan pa thob pa'i mthu/ /
Six superknowledges, three types of awareness, Eight freedoms, eight commands, Ten domains of totality, and boundless meditative absorptions Constitute the power of having gained stability. [VIII.9]
de ni dbang mchog thob pa'i blo dang ldan/ / 'gro ba dbang med rang dbang bkod rtag tu/ / gzhan la phan bya gcig tu mngon dga' ste/ / seng ge bzhin du rab brtan srid na spyod/ /
Wise individuals with supreme mastery Empower beings deprived of freedom. With true delight in doing what benefits others, They participate in existence, indomitable like lions. [VIII.10]
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ mthu'i le'u ste brgyad pa'o// //
This was the eighth chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras, the chapter on power.
9. [yongs su smin pa'i le'u]
9. Full Maturation
dga' dang dad dang rab zhi snying brtse dang / / bzod dang yid gzhungs mthu can nyid dang ni/ / mi 'phrogs pa dang yan lag ldan pa rab/ / de ni rgyal sras yongs su smin pa'i mtshan/ /

Joy, faith, serenity, affection, Forbearance, keen intellect, power, Unassailability, and possession of the factors— The superior presence of these characterizes the full maturation of the children of the victorious ones. [IX.1]
grogs mchog la sogs gsum dang brtson rab dang / / mthar phyin dam pa dang ni chos mchog sdud/ / dam chos cher gzung phyir ni snying rje can/ / yang dag yongs su smin pa'i mtshan nyid 'dod/ /

The supreme friend and the rest of the three, as well as foremost diligence, True perfection, and the gathering of the supreme Dharma— These are held to be the characteristics of a compassionate one’s full maturation For the sake of comprehensively upholding the sacred Dharma. [IX.2]
yon tan shes dang sems kyang mi phyed dang / / ting 'dzin myur du thob dang 'bras bu myong / / ston la yid ches bya phyir rgyal sras kyi/ / yang dag yongs su smin pa'i mtshan nyid 'dod/ /

Knowing the qualities, an undivided mind, Swift attainment of meditative absorption, and the experience of its result— These are held to be the characteristics of the children of the victorious ones’ full maturation For the sake of trust in the teacher. [IX.3]
shin tu sdom zhing nyon mongs rtog pa spong / / bar chad med cing dge la mngon par dga'/ / rgyal ba'i sras kyi nyon mongs bsal ba'i phyir/ / yang dag yongs su smin pa'i mtshan nyid 'dod/ /

Complete restraint, elimination of afflictive thoughts, Absence of obstacles, and delight in virtue— These are held to be the characteristics of the children of the victorious ones’ full maturation That dispels the afflictions. [IX.4]

rang bzhin snying brtse gzhan gyi sdug bsngal mthong / / dman pa'i sems kyang yang dag rab tu spong / / khyad par 'gro dang 'gro ba'i mchog gyur lus/ / gzhan la snying brtse yongs su smin pa'i mtshan/ /

Natural affection, seeing the suffering of others, Complete elimination of the mind-set that is inferior, Distinctive progress, and a body that is supreme among beings— These are the characteristics of the full maturation of affection for others. [IX.5]
rang bzhin brtan pa so sor brtags bsgom pa/ / grang sogs shin tu sdug bsngal rtag mi mjed/ / khyad par 'gro dang dge la mngon par dga'/ / bzod pa yongs su smin pa'i mtshan nyid 'dod/ /

Natural steadfastness, analytical meditation, Remaining unmoved by intense suffering due to cold and the like, Distinctive progress and delight in virtue— These are held to be the characteristics of the full maturation of patience. [IX.6]
rnam smin dag cing thos sogs dran mi brjed/ / de bzhin legs bshad nyes par smras pa dag / rab shes blo chen skye bar rung ba nyid/ / shin tu yid gzhungs yongs su smin pa'i mtshan/ /

Pure ripening, the mindfulness of not forgetting what has been received and so forth, Fully recognizing good and bad statements, And the capacity to engender the great mind— These are the characteristics of the full maturation of a perfectly keen intellect. [IX.7]
dge ba gnyis kyis khams gnyis brtas pa dang / / rten ni 'bras bu skye bar rung ba'i mchog / yid la bsam grub 'gro ba'i mchog gyur pa/ / mthu thob yongs su smin pa'i mtshan nyid do/ /

The strengthening of the two elements through the two virtues, The support being perfectly ready to produce the fruition, Accomplishing what is wished for, and superiority in the world— These are the characteristics of the full maturation of the attainment of power. [IX.8]
chos bzang rigs pas rnam dpyad bsam pa can/ / rtag tu bdud kyi bar chad byed pa med/ / khyad par rnyed dang gzhan gyi phyogs sun 'byin/ / mi 'phrogs yongs su smin pa'i mtshan nyid do/ /

A mind that discerns the good Dharma with reason, Continuous absence of obstacles from demons, Discovery of the extraordinary, and disproof of the position of others— These are the characteristics of the full maturation of unassailability. [IX.9]
dge ba bsags dang rten kyang brtson par rung / / dben dang dge ba mchog la mngon par dga'/ / rgyal ba'i sras kyi yan lag ldan pa yi/ / yang dag yongs su smin pa'i mtshan nyid do/ /

Accumulation of virtue, the support being fit for diligence, Delighting in seclusion and supreme virtue— These are the characteristics of the genuine, full maturation Of the children of the victorious ones’ possession of the factors. [IX.10]
de ltar dngos po rnam dgus smin pa'i bdag / pha rol yongs su smin byed rung dang ldan/ / chos kyi rang bzhin rgyun 'phel bdag nyid can/ / rtag tu 'gro ba'i gnyen mchog gyur pa yin/ /

The one who has matured through these nine factors Is equipped to bring about full maturation in others. The one who embodies the ever-increasing stream of the nature of qualities Will always be the supreme friend of beings. [IX.11]
ji ltar rma dang zas la de dag gi / gzag dang spyad du rung ba smin 'dod ltar/ / de bzhin rten 'dir phyogs gnyis zhi ba dang / / de bzhin spyad pa nyid du smin pa bstan/ /

Boils and food are held to be mature When they are ready to be drained or enjoyed. Similarly, it is taught that maturity is present when The two factors are pacified and enjoyed within their support. [IX.12]
lus can bral bar smin byed de bzhin du/ / yongs smin rab smin mthun par smin byed gzhan/ / legs par smin byed rtogs pas smin byed dang / / rtag smin gong du smin byed bshad par 'dod/ /

The maturation of embodied beings is taught in terms Of separating maturation, complete maturation, full maturation, Accordant maturation, excellent maturation, Realized maturation, constant maturation, and progressing maturation. [IX.13]
ji ltar rgyal sras phan pa'i bsam pas 'dir/ / 'gro kun rnam par smin byed gnas pa ltar/ / de bzhin pha dang ma dang gnyen bshes rnams/ / bu dang gnyen pa rnams la legs mi gnas/ /
The children of the victorious ones, due to their benevolent intent, Are present here to mature all beings. No father, mother, or friend is so kind To children, relatives, or friends. [IX.14]
ji ltar brtse bdag bde dang phan phyir sbyor/ / sems can gzhan la byams 'dod de ltar ni/ / skye bo bdag la 'ang byams par mi 'dod na/ / rab sdug skye bo gzhan brten smos ci dgos/ /
Those who embody love pursue benefit and happiness With affectionate care for other beings. People do not even love themselves this much, Let alone those who are dear to them. [IX.15]
byang chub sems dpa'i lus dang longs spyod dag / gzhan la mi sbyin pa ni yod med de/ / phan 'dogs rnam pa gnyis kyis gzhan smin byed/ / mnyam par sbyin pa'i yon tan ngoms mi 'gyur/ /
For a bodhisattva, there is no body or enjoyment That is not given to others. The bodhisattva matures others by helping in two ways; Giving equally, they never know enough of the qualities. [IX.16]
brtan pa rang bzhin lhag par 'tshe ba med/ / bdag dga' bag yod 'di la gzhan 'god cing / / phan rnam gnyis 'dogs rnam par smin pa dang / / rgyu mthun yon tan brgyud pas gzhan smin byed/ /

Steadfast, natural, completely nonviolent, Inherently delightful, and careful—the bodhisattva establishes others in this. Thus benefiting in the two ways, the bodhisattva matures others Through a succession of qualities of maturation and the causally linked. [IX.17]
gzhan gnod byed la phan byed blo ldan pa/ / gnod byed drag po dag kyang rab tu bzod/ / thabs rig gnod byed bzod pa de dag gis/ / gnod byed dge ba yang dag len du 'jug /
Seeing those who harm them as benefactors, They tolerate even the most severe injuries. Knowing the methods, those who tolerate harm Cause those who do them harm to experience virtue. [IX.18]
rgyal sras brtson 'grus mchog la brten pa de/ / sems can tshogs rab smin par byed pa na/ / pha rol sems dge gcig gi phyir yang ni/ / bskal pa bye ba stong du 'ang skyo mi 'gyur/ /

Relying on supreme diligence, The children of the victorious ones fully mature the gathering of beings. For the sake of even a single virtue in the mind of someone else, The bodhisattva knows no weariness throughout ten trillion eons. [IX.19]
yid kyi dbang ni bla na med thob nas/ / gzhan gyi mchod 'dod thams cad nges bcom ste/ / mchog gi bstan la gzhan dag 'dun byed cing / / de dag dge ba yang dag 'phel bar byed/ /

Having attained supreme mastery of the mind, They have thoroughly vanquished the desire for offerings from others. Inspiring interest in the teaching of the supreme, The bodhisattva completely enriches the virtues of others. [IX.20]
de nyid dgongs don tshul la rab nges te/ / sems can the tshom shin tu sel bar byed/ / de phyir rgyal ba'i bstan la de gus pas/ / rang gzhan dge ba'i yon tan rnam 'phel byed/ /

With complete certainty regarding reality and intended meanings, The bodhisattva thoroughly dispels the doubts of sentient beings. Hence, respect for the victorious ones’ teachings Enriches the virtues of the bodhisattva and others. [IX.21]
de ltar byang chub sems dpa' snying rje yis/ / 'gro kun bde 'gro'i 'gro ba'ang dge gsum la/ / rnam pa chung dang mchog dang 'bring dag gis/ / 'jig rten yod dang mnyam par 'jug pas 'dul/ /

In this way, through compassion the bodhisattvas bring all beings Into the higher realms or the three types of virtue, Manifesting the way of the lesser, the supreme, and the middling. Thus, for as long as it exists, they enter the world and cultivate it. [IX.22]
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las yongs su smin pa'i le'u ste dgu pa'o// //
This was the ninth chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras, the chapter on full maturation.
10. [byang chub kyi le'u]
10. Enlightenment
dka' spyod dpag med brgya phrag dang / / dpag med dge ba bsags pa dang / / dpag tu med pa'i dus dang ni/ / dpag med sgrib pa zad pa'i phyir/ /
Hundreds of immeasurable austerities, Accumulations of immeasurable virtue, Immeasurable time, And exhaustion of immeasurable obscurations—[X.1]
sgrib pa kun gyi dri med pa/ / rnam pa thams cad mkhyen nyid 'thob/ / rin chen snod ni phye ba ltar/ / sangs rgyas nyid ni yang dag bstan/ /
Because of this there are no defilements at all, And omniscience is attained. Like opening a trove of treasures, This is shown to be buddhahood itself. [X.2]
ngal brgyas rmad byung dka' spyad dge kun bsags/ / bskal mchog dus ring 'gro ba'i sgrib kun zad/ / sar gtogs sgrib pa phra bcom sangs rgyas te/ / de ni mthu chen rin chen snod phye bzhin/ /

Hundreds of marvelous hardships have been practiced with austerity. Throughout long eons, all virtue has been gathered. All the obscurations of wandering beings are dissolved; even the subtle ones on the grounds are conquered. This buddhahood possesses great power and can be likened to an open treasure trove. [X.3]
chos rnams thams cad sangs rgyas nyid/ / chos ni gang yang yod ma yin/ / de ni chos dkar rang bzhin yang / / de yis de ni brjod ma yin/ /
All phenomena are buddhahood itself; There are no phenomena at all. Although of the nature of virtuous qualities, Those cannot express it. [x.4]
rin chen chos kyi rgyu mtshan phyir/ / de ni rin chen 'byung gnas bzhin/ / dge ba'i lo tog rgyu mtshan phyir/ / de ni sprin dang 'dra bar 'dod/ /
In being the cause of the jewel of the Dharma, It is likened to a mine of precious jewels. In being the cause of the harvest of virtue, It is held to be like a cloud. [X.5]

sangs rgyas nyid ni chos kun ldan pa'am yang na chos kun bral ba ste/ / rin chen chos rab che yangs 'byung phyir rin chen chos kyi 'byung gnas bzhin/ / skye dgu rnams la legs bshad mi zad chos kyi char chen 'bebs pas na/ / 'byung po'i lo tog dkar po shin tu che 'phel rgyu phyir sprin dang 'dra/ /

Buddhahood itself either contains all phenomena or is free from them all. As the vast and expansive Dharma jewels manifest, it is like a mine of precious jewels. As it rains down the inexhaustible Dharma on beings through excellent statements— Causing tremendous growth of the fine harvest in beings—it is like a cloud. [X.6]
rtag tu nyon mongs tshogs kun dang / / nyes par spyod pa thams cad dang / / rga dang 'chi ba dag las kyang / / sangs rgyas nyid ni yongs su skyob/ /
The entire array of afflictions— All misdeeds, as well as old age and death— Against all this, the Buddha is always The perfect protector. [X.7]
'tshe ba dag ni thams cad dang / / ngan song dang ni thabs min dang / / 'jig tshogs theg pa dman dag las/ / de phyir skyabs kyi dam pa'o/ /
All harmful things, the lower realms, Nonmethods, the transitory collection, And the Lesser Vehicles— Since it saves one from these, it is the sublime refuge. [X.8]

sangs rgyas nyid de skyabs ni dpe med mchog tu 'dod/ / sna tshogs 'jigs gyur 'jig tshogs kun dang theg pa dang / / ngan song rnam mang sdug bsngal thabs min song ba rnams/ / skye dang 'chi dang nyon mongs ngan song kun las srung / /

The refuge of buddhahood is held to be incomparably supreme, For it protects against the different fears, all of the transitory collection, the vehicles, The numerous sufferings of the lower realms, the pursuit of nonmethods, Birth, death, afflictions, and the lower realms. [X.9]

sangs rgyas chos kyi shin tu rdzogs pa'i sku gang yin/ / dam pa'i chos la sems can rab 'dul mkhyen pa gang / / 'gro ba kun la thugs brtse'i pha rol phyin pa gang / / sangs rgyas nyid de 'dir ni skyabs kyi mchog tu 'dod/ /

An utterly perfect body of the qualities of buddhahood, Knowing how to train sentient beings in the sacred Dharma, And transcendent love for all wandering beings; Buddhahood is held to be the supreme refuge here. [X.10]
'jig rten ji srid sems can gyi/ / gnod dang phun sum tshogs pa kun/ / bzlog cing 'byor par bya ba'i phyir/ / sangs rgyas skyabs chen nyid du 'dod/ /
For as long as the world exists, This protects sentient beings from harm And provides them with all that is excellent. Therefore, the Buddha is held to be the great protector. [X.11]

gang la nyon mongs shes bya'i sgrib pa'i sa bon dus ring rtag ldan pa/ / spong ba shin tu rgya chen rnam pa kun gyi rab tu bcom gyur cing / / gnas gyur chos dkar yon tan mchog rab ldan pa thob pa sangs rgyas nyid/ / de ni mi rtog rab dag shin tu yul chen ye shes lam gyis 'thob/ /

Buddhahood is the elimination, extremely vast and completely obliterating, Of the seeds of the afflictive and cognitive obscurations that for so long have been constantly present. It is the attainment of the fundamental transformation with its supreme qualities, Accomplished by the path of the utterly pure nonconceptuality and the wakefulness of the extremely vast field. [X.12]
de bzhin gshegs pa de ni der bzhugs nas/ / ri dbang mtho steng bzhugs bzhin 'gro la gzigs/ / zhi bar mngon dga'i 'gro la'ang thugs rje na/ / srid la mngon dga'i skye bo gzhan ci smos/ /

Abiding there, the Thus Gone One sees wandering beings As though he were standing on the lofty king of mountains. Since he has compassion even for those who are fond of peace, Why mention those who are fond of existence? [X.13]
gnas la 'jug dang rab 'jug mi 'jug dang / / ldog dang kun 'jug gnyis dang mi gnyis dang / / mnyam dang khyad 'phags kun 'gro'i bdag nyid ni/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi yongs gyur 'dod/ /

The nature of transformation is accepted in terms of engagement, superior engagement, nonengagement, Reversal, thoroughgoing engagement, duality, nonduality, Comparability, superiority, and omnipresence. This is the thus-gone ones’ complete transformation. [X.14]
ji ltar nam mkha' rtag tu kun song 'dod/ / de bzhin de yang rtag tu kun song 'dod/ / ji ltar nam mkha' gzugs gyur kun du song / / de bzhin de yang sems can tshogs kun song / /
Just as space is held to always reach everywhere, This is also held to be all-pervasive at all times. Just as space pervades all forms, So does this pervade the entire host of sentient beings. [X.15]
ji ltar chu yi snod chag na/ / zla ba'i gzugs brnyan mi snang ba/ / de bzhin sems can ngan pa la/ / sangs rgyas gzugs kyang mi snang ngo / /
Just as the reflection of the moon Does not appear in a broken water vessel, The form of the buddhas Does not appear to inferior sentient beings. [X.16]
ji ltar me ni gzhan du 'bar/ / gzhan du zhi bar 'gyur ba ltar/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas rnams la yang / / snang dang mi snang shes par bya/ /
Just as in some places fire blazes, Whereas in others it dies out, So also should one understand The appearance and disappearance of the buddhas. [X.17]
ji ltar rnga dag ma brdungs par/ / sgra ni kun du 'byung ba ltar/ / de bzhin rgyal ba gzo med par/ / bshad pa dag ni kun du 'byung / /
Just as the drum resounds Without being beaten, So do the victorious ones teach Without constructing. [X.18]
ji ltar nor bu 'bad med par/ / rang gi 'od ni ston pa ltar/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyang gzo med par/ / de bzhin mdzad pa nges pa ston/ /
Just as a jewel effortlessly Reveals its own luster, The buddhas definitively display Their deeds without constructing. [X.19]
ji ltar mkha' la 'jig rten gyi/ / bya ba rgyun mi 'chad par snang / / de bzhin zag med dbyings na yang / / rgyal ba'i mdzad pa rgyun mi 'chad/ /
Just as all the workings of the world Unfold in space without interruption, The activities of the victorious ones Are unceasing within the undefiled field. [X.20]
ji ltar mkha' la rtag tu ni/ / bya ba nyams shing 'byung ba ltar/ / de bzhin zag med dbyings na yang / / sangs rgyas 'phrin las skye zhing 'bri/ /
Just as within space Activities constantly cease and arise, Buddha activities develop and decline Within the undefiled field. [X.21]
snga ma phyi mar khyad med kyang / / sgrib pa kun gyi dri med pa/ / de bzhin nyid ni sangs rgyas 'dod/ / dag pa ma yin ma dag min/ /
There is no difference between earlier and later, Yet buddhahood is held to be Suchness free from all defilements, Neither pure nor impure. [X.22]
stong pa nyid ni rnam dag na/ / bdag med mchog gi bdag thob pas/ / sangs rgyas dag pa'i bdag thob phyir/ / bdag nyid chen po'i bdag tu 'gyur/ /
Within pure emptiness, The buddhas achieve the supreme self of selflessness. Thus they achieve the pure self, And are hence the self of great beings. [X.23]
de phyir sangs rgyas yod min zhing / / med par yang ni mi brjod do/ / de ltar sangs rgyas de skad 'dri/ / lung ma bstan pa'i tshul du 'dod/ /
Therefore, buddhas do not exist Yet neither are they said to be nonexistent. Thus, questions regarding the Buddha Are held to be indeterminate. [X.24]
ji ltar lcags la tsha ba dang / / mig la rab rib zhi ba ltar/ / sangs rgyas sems dang ye shes la/ / yod dang med par mi brjod do/ /
As with the pacification of heat in iron And haze before the eyes, The buddhas’ mind and wakefulness Cannot be said to feature existence or nonexistence. [X.25]
zag med dbyings na sangs rgyas rnams/ / mkha' ltar lus ni med phyir dang / / sngon gyi lus rjes 'brang ba'i phyir/ / gcig min mang po nyid ma yin/ /
Within the undefiled field, Buddhas, like space, have no bodies, Yet they proceed from their previous bodies. Therefore, they are neither one nor many. [X.26]
stobs sogs sangs rgyas chos rnams la/ / byang chub rin chen 'byung gnas 'dra/ /
Considering the powers and the other qualities of buddhahood, Enlightenment is like a jewel mine. [X.27a–b]
'gro ba'i dge ba'i lo tog la/ / sprin chen dang yang 'dra bar 'dod/ /
With regard to the crops of virtue in wandering beings, It is also held to be like a great cloud. [X.27c–d]
bsod nams ye shes rab rdzogs phyir/ / zla ba nya ba lta bur 'dod/ /
Since merit and wakefulness are completely perfected, It is held to be like the full moon. [X.28a–b]
ye shes snang ba byed pa'i phyir/ / nyi ma chen po 'dra bar 'dod/ /
Since it shines with the light of wakefulness, It is held to be like a great sun. [X.28c–d]
ji ltar nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor gyi/ / 'od zer dpag tu med 'dres shing / / rtag tu bya ba gcig la 'jug / 'jig rten la yang snang ba byed/ /
Just as the innumerable light rays Of the sun’s orb mingle together as one, Always performing the same function Of radiating light in the world, [X.29]
de bzhin zag med dbyings na yang / / sangs rgyas dpag tu med 'dres shing / / mdzad pa gcig ni mdzad pa la/ / ye shes snang bar mdzad par 'dod/ /
It is also held that the innumerable buddhas Mingle together within the undefiled field, Carrying out the same activity And radiating the light of wakefulness. [X.30]
dper na nyi ma'i 'od zer gcig / byung na 'od zer kun 'byung ba/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas rnams kyi yang / / ye shes 'byung bar shes par bya/ /
When, for example, a single ray of sunlight shines forth, All the others also emerge as well. Understand that it is the same With the wakefulness of the buddhas. [X.31]
ji ltar nyi ma'i 'od zer dag / 'jug la bdag gir bya ba med/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas ye shes kyang / / 'jug la bdag gir mdzad mi mnga'/ /
When the rays of the sun shine forth, There is no sense of ownership. Likewise, the wakefulness of the buddhas is active Without any sense of ownership. [X.32]
nyi ma'i 'od zer gcig btang bas/ / 'gro ba snang ba byed pa ltar/ / de bzhin shes bya thams cad la/ / sangs rgyas ye shes cig car snang / /
Just as a single ray emitted from the sun Illuminates the world, The wakefulness of the buddhas Reveals all objects of cognition at once. [X.33]
ji ltar nyi ma'i 'od zer rnams/ / sprin la sogs pas bsgribs par 'dod/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas ye shes rnams/ / sems can gyi ni nyes pas bsgribs/ /
It is held that the rays of the sun Are obscured by things such as clouds. In the same way, the wakefulness of the buddhas Is obscured by the flaws of sentient beings. [X.34]
ji ltar mdud pa'i dbang gis na/ / gos la tshon bkra mi bkra ba/ / de bzhin 'phen pa'i dbang gis na/ / grol ba'i ye shes bkra mi bkra/ /
Just as knots are responsible For the presence or absence of vivid patterns in fabric, So does the driving force determine Whether liberated wakefulness is vivid or not. [X.35]
dri med dbyings la sangs rgyas kyi/ / mtshan nyid dang ni gnas pa dang / / 'phrin las zab pa 'di bshad pa/ / mkha' la tshon gyis ri mo 'dri/ /
This explanation of the buddhas’ profound Characteristics, abode, and activity Within the immaculate field Is like a painting on space. [X.36]
de bzhin nyid ni thams cad la/ / khyad par med kyang dag gyur pa/ / de bzhin gshegs nyid de yi phyir/ / 'gro kun de yi snying po can/ /
Suchness is present in all without distinction, Yet when pure It is a thus-gone one. Therefore, all wandering beings possess this essential nature. [X.37]
nyan thos rnams kyi 'byor pas ni/ / 'jig rten pa yi zil gyis gnon/ / rang sangs rgyas kyi sa pa yis/ / nyan thos kyi yang zil gyis gnon/ /
The mastery of the listeners Surpasses that of mundane beings, While that of the stage of self-realized buddhas Surpasses that of the listeners. [X.38]
de yis byang chub sems dpa' yi/ / 'byor pa'i char yang mi phod do/ / de yis de bzhin gshegs pa yi/ / 'byor pa'i char yang mi phod do/ /
Yet that cannot compare to even a fraction Of the mastery of the bodhisattvas, And that cannot compare to even a fraction Of the mastery of the thus-gone ones. [X.39]
sangs rgyas rnams kyi 'byor pa ni/ / gang gi gang du ji ltar dang / / ji tsam dus gang 'jug pa ni/ / bsam yas dpag tu med par 'dod/ /
The mastery of the buddhas is, In terms of its beneficiaries, locations, Manner, extent, and duration, Held to be employed in inconceivable and infinite ways. [X.40]
dbang po lnga rnams gzhan gyur na/ / don kun 'jug dang thams cad kyi/ / yon tan brgya phrag bcu gnyis 'byung / / 'byor pa dam pa 'thob par 'gyur/ /
When the five faculties have transformed, There is engagement with all objects, And each has twelve hundred qualities. Such true mastery is achieved. [X.41]
yid ni gzhan du gyur pa na/ / 'byor dang mthun spyod mi rtog pa'i/ / ye shes shin tu dri med la/ / 'byor pa dam pa 'thob par 'gyur/ /
When the mind has transformed, There is engagement in accordance with that mastery. Within utterly immaculate nonconceptual wakefulness A true mastery is achieved. [X.42]
don bcas 'dzin pa gzhan gyur na/ / ji ltar 'dod bzhin longs spyod dag / bstan phyir zhing ni dag pa la/ / 'byor pa dam pa 'thob par 'gyur/ /

When apprehending, including its objects, has transformed, There is encounter with whatever is wished for and the capacity to reveal to others. Therefore, with respect to the pure fields, A true mastery is achieved. [X.43]
rnam rtog gzhan du gyur na ni/ / dus rnams rtag tu ye shes dang / / las rnams kun la thogs med la/ / 'byor pa dam pa 'thob par 'gyur/ /
When thought has transformed, There is constant wakefulness and All activities are unimpeded. Such true mastery is achieved. [X.44]
rten ni gzhan du gyur pa na/ / sangs rgyas dri med gnas la ni/ / mi gnas mya ngan 'das pa yi/ / 'byor pa dam pa 'thob par 'gyur/ /
When the support has transformed, There is nonabiding transcendence of suffering Within the immaculate abode of the buddhas. Such true mastery is achieved. [X.45]
'khrig pa gzhan du gyur na ni/ / sangs rgyas bde bar gnas pa dang / / mo mthong nyon mongs med pa la/ / 'byor pa dam pa 'thob par 'gyur/ /
When intercourse has transformed, One dwells within the bliss of the buddhas, And the sight of females is not afflictive. Such true mastery is achieved. [X.46]
nam mkha'i 'du shes gzhan gyur na/ / bsam pa'i don ni 'byor pa dang / / 'gro gzugs rnam par 'byed pa la/ / 'byor pa dam pa 'thob par 'gyur/ /
When the identification of space has transformed, Whatever is wished for manifests. There is passage, as well as the discernment of form. Such true mastery is achieved. [X.47]
de ltar sangs rgyas dri med pa'i/ / gnas na gzhan gyur dpag med la/ / bsam yas bya ba sgrub pa yi/ / 'byor pa dpag tu med par 'dod/ /
Thus, within the stainless abode of the buddhas, There is immeasurable transformation. Regarding the inconceivable engagement in activity, It is held that there is immeasurable mastery. [X.48]

'di na 'jig rten phyogs phyogs rgyal ba'i legs bshad pa'i/ / dge ba 'phel ba'i 'jig rten rnam dag mchog tu 'gro/ / dge ba ma bsags dge ba 'phel ba'i mchog tu 'gro/ / de ltar ma smin smin pa rtag 'gro'ang ma lus min/ /

Here and everywhere throughout the world, the victorious ones’ excellent teachings Cause beings rich in virtue to proceed to supreme purity, While those who have not gathered virtue are made to progress toward the supreme enrichment of virtue. Although the immature are thus always matured, everyone is not. [X.49]

de ltar 'jig rten phyogs phyogs brten rnams rtag par dus kun du/ / byang chub chen po 'thob dka' yon tan mchog ldan rmad byung can/ / rtag brtan skyabs med rnams kyi skyabs gang yin pa thob pa de/ / ya mtshan che la tshul bzang spyad phyir ya mtshan che ba'ang med/ /

Thus, everywhere throughout the world, the steadfast ones constantly and always Achieve the great enlightenment that is hard to achieve, yet is marvelously endowed with supreme qualities: The permanent and steadfast refuge for those who have none. This is a great wonder, but also not, for they have practiced the way of goodness. [X.50]

de ni cig car la lar sgo mang brgya nas chos kyi 'khor lo dang / / la lar skye ba mi snang la lar skye ba'i spyod pa sna tshogs dang / / la lar byang chub thams cad la lar de ni mya ngan 'das ston kyang / / de ni gnas de las kyang rnam par g.yo mi mnga' la thams cad mdzad/ /

All at once, a buddha will in some places display the turning of the Dharma wheel through hundreds of means, While elsewhere showing birth and nonmanifestation, the manifold deeds of the lives, Enlightenment, and the transcendence of suffering. Yet all of this a buddha does without wavering from the abode. [X.51]

sangs rgyas rnams ni 'di snyam lus can 'di ni bdag gis smin byas she'am/ / 'di ni rab tu smin bya gzhan yang da ltar smin par byed snyam du/ / 'du mdzad mi mnga' bar yang phyogs phyogs kun du rtag par sgo gsum nas/ / dge ba'i chos rnams kyis ni skye bo rab tu smin par 'gyur ba nyid/ /

The buddhas do not form thoughts, such as “I have ripened this being,” “This one I shall mature,” or “I am ripening this one now.” Yet everywhere and always, they do indeed mature Beings with the qualities of virtue through the three gateways. [X.52]

ji ltar nyi ma 'bad med phyogs phyogs kun du 'od zer dag / rab 'byams gsal ba mang pos lo tog rnam smin byed pa ltar/ / de bzhin chos ldan nyi ma'ang rab zhi byed pa chos kyi 'od/ / rab 'byams dag gis phyogs phyogs kun du sems can rnam smin mdzad/ /

Just as the sun effortlessly ripens crops everywhere With an abundance of infinite, clear rays, So does the sun of the Dharma mature sentient beings everywhere With the infinite rays of the Dharma that brings peace. [X.53]

ji ltar mar me gcig las mar me'i tshogs rab mang / / dpag med grangs med 'byung yang de la zad pa med/ / de bzhin smin pa gcig las smin pa'i tshogs rab mang / / grangs med dpag med 'byung yang de la zad pa med/ /

Without itself being extinguished, one single lamp May cause innumerable other lamps, beyond all measure. Likewise, without itself becoming extinct, one single maturation Brings about innumerable maturations, beyond all measure. [X.54]

ji ltar rgya mtsho chen po 'di ni chu yis ngoms par mi 'gyur zhing / / chu chen mang po rab tu 'bab pas 'phel bar yang ni mi 'gyur ba/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas khams kyang dag pa 'jug pa rtag rgyun mi 'chad pas/ / ngoms pa mi mnga' 'phel bar mi 'gyur de 'dir rmad du byung ba'i mchog /

Just as the great ocean neither fills up nor increases By the inflow of many great rivers, The realm of the buddhas neither fills up nor increases By the uninterrupted entry of the pure—what a supreme wonder this is! [X.55]
chos rnams kun gyi de bzhin nyid/ / sgrib gnyis dag pa'i mtshan nyid de/ / dngos dang nges dmigs shes pa la/ / dbang zad mi shes mtshan nyid do/ /
It is characterized by the suchness of all phenomena, Free from the two obscurations, And by an inexhaustible mastery Regarding that nature and its observation. [X.56]
de bzhin nyid shes thams cad nas/ / bsgoms pa las ni yang dag 'byung / / sems can kun la rnam kun du/ / gnyis skyed mi zad 'bras bu can/ /
It fully emerges through meditating With full knowledge of suchness. For all sentient beings, this results at all times In the inexhaustible twofold production. [X.57]
sku dang gsung dang thugs sprul pa'i/ / sbyor ba'i thabs kyi las can te/ / ting nge 'dzin dang gzungs sgo dang / / dpag tu med pa gnyis dang ldan/ /
It is active through skillful engagement Of the emanations of body, speech, and mind, Endowed with the gateways of meditative absorption and retention, As well as the two beyond measure. [X.58]
rang bzhin chos rdzogs longs spyod dang / / sprul pa dag gis tha dad du/ / 'jug pa 'di ni sangs rgyas kyi/ / chos dbyings rnam par dag par bshad/ /
Its distinct applications are those of nature, The perfect enjoyment of qualities, and emanation. These are taught to be the purity of the buddhas’ Basic field of phenomena. [X.59]
sangs rgyas rnams kyi sku dbye ba/ / rang bzhin longs spyod rdzogs pa dang / / gzhan ni sprul pa'i sku yin te/ / dang po gnyis po'i rten yin no/ /
The bodies of the buddhas can be divided In terms of the nature body, the perfect enjoyment body, And the emanation body. The first is the support of the two. [X.60]
longs spyod rdzogs pa khams kun du/ / 'khor yongs sdud dang zhing dang mtshan/ / sku dang chos rdzogs longs spyod dang / / mdzad pa dag gis tha dad do/ /
In all the realms, the perfect enjoyment differs With respect to the gathering of retinue, field, name, Body, perfect enjoyment of the Dharma, And the various types of activity. [X.61]
rang bzhin sku ni mnyam pa dang / / phra zhing de dang 'brel pa dang / / dgyes dgur longs spyod bstan pa la/ / longs spyod rdzogs 'byor rgyur 'dod do/ /
The nature body is held to be equal, Subtle, and connected to that. With regard to the display of delightful enjoyments, It is held to be the cause of the mastery of perfect enjoyment. [X.62]
sangs rgyas sprul pa dpag med pa/ / sprul pa'i skur ni 'dod pa ste/ / don gnyis phun sum tshogs pa ni/ / rnam pa thams cad gnyis la gnas/ /
The immeasurable emanations of the Buddha Are held to be the emanation body. The perfection of the twofold benefit Always rests on the two. [X.63]
bzo dang skye dang byang chub che/ / mya ngan 'das pa rtag ston pas/ / sangs rgyas sprul pa'i sku 'di ni/ / rnam par grol ba'i thabs chen no/ /
As it always displays creativity, incarnation, Great enlightenment, and transcendence of suffering, This, the emanation body of the buddhas, Is the great means for liberation. [X.64]
sku gsum dag gis sangs rgyas kyi/ / sku bsdus par ni shes bya ste/ / sku gsum dag gis rang bzhin gyi/ / don 'di rten dang bcas par bstan/ /
It should be known that these three bodies Comprise the bodies of buddhahood. The three bodies consist of benefit For self and others, and also of the support. [X.65]
de dag rten dang dgongs pa dang / / 'phrin las kyis ni mnyam pa nyid/ / rang bzhin dang ni rgyun mi 'chad/ / rgyun gyis de dag rtag pa nyid/ /
With respect to support, realization, and activity, They are completely the same. In terms of nature, no interruption, and continuity, They are indeed permanent. [X.66]
me long ye shes mi g.yo ba/ / ye shes gsum ni de la brten/ / mnyam pa nyid dang so sor rtog / bya ba sgrub pa kho na'o/ /
Mirror-like wakefulness is unmoving And the three types of wakefulness are supported by that. These are, precisely, the wakefulness Of equality, discernment, and accomplishment of activity. [X.67]
me long ye shes nga yi med/ / yongs su ma chad rtag tu ldan/ / shes bya kun la ma rmongs la/ / rtag tu de la mngon phyogs min/ /
Mirror-like wakefulness involves no “mine.” It is unconfined, always present, Free from delusion regarding the objects of cognition, And yet it never turns toward them. [X.68]
ye shes kun gyi rgyu mtshan phyir/ / ye shes 'byung gnas chen po 'dra/ / longs spyod rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas nyid/ / ye shes gzugs brnyan 'byung ba'i phyir/ /
Being the cause of all wakefulness, It is the great source of wakefulness. This, precisely, is the buddha of perfect enjoyment, And reflections of wakefulness appear within it. [X.69]
mnyam nyid ye shes sems can la/ / bsgom pa dag pa la 'dod do/ / mi gnas zhi bar zhugs pa ni/ / mnyam nyid ye shes yin par 'dod/ /
The wakefulness of equality is held to be The pure cultivation with respect to sentient beings. Resting in nonabiding peace, It is held to be the wakefulness of equality. [X.70]
dus rnams kun du byams pa dang / / thugs rje chen po dag dang ldan/ / sems can rnams la mos pa bzhin/ / sangs rgyas sku ni nges par ston/ /
At all times it is endowed With great love and compassion. In accordance with the inclinations of sentient beings, It reveals the body of buddhahood. [X.71]
so sor rtog pa'i ye shes ni/ / shes bya kun la rtag mi thogs/ / ting nge 'dzin dang gzungs rnams kyi/ / gter dang 'dra ba kho na yin/ /
Discriminating wakefulness Is always unimpeded regarding all objects of knowledge; Containing the absorptions and retentions, It is like a great treasure. [X.72]
'khor gyi dkyil 'khor rnams su ni/ / 'byor pa thams cad ston mdzad pa/ / the tshom thams cad gcod pa yi/ / chos chen char ni rab tu 'bebs/ /
Within the circle of the retinue, It reveals all the riches And rains down the great Dharma That cuts through all doubts. [X.73]
bya ba sgrub pa'i ye shes ni/ / khams rnams kun du sna tshogs shing / / dpag med bsam yas sprul pa yis/ / sems can kun gyi don sgrub pa'o/ /

The all-accomplishing wakefulness Is at work throughout all realms; By means of diverse emanations that are immeasurable and inconceivable, It accomplishes the objectives of all sentient beings. [X.74]
sangs rgyas sprul pa de rtag tu/ / mdzad pa grub pa'i bye brag dang / / grangs dang zhing gis rnam kun du/ / bsam mi khyab par shes par bya/ /
It should be understood that the emanations of the Buddha Are always inconceivable With respect to the accomplishment of specific deeds, As well as numbers and fields. [X.75]
'dzin pa'i phyir dang sems mnyam phyir/ / yang dag chos rab ston phyir dang / / bya ba sgrub pa nyid kyi phyir/ / ye shes bzhi po yang dag 'byung / /
The four forms of wakefulness are brought forth Due to retention, equality of mind, Genuine teaching of the Dharma, And the practice of activities. [X.76]
rigs tha dad phyir don yod phyir/ / rdzogs phyir thog ma med pa'i phyir/ / sangs rgyas gcig min dri med gnas/ / tha dad med phyir mang po'ang min/ /
