chos rnams kyi ni gtso bo ste/ / de dag la yod de rnam gsum/ / bsam gtan de 'drar yongs shes nas/ / mkhas pa yang dag sgrub par byed/ /
The foremost among all good qualities, It is of three types. Fully comprehending such concentration, The wise practice it authentically. [XVII.26]
shes bya yang dag rab rnam 'byed/ / ting nge 'dzin la rten pa dang / / kun nas nyon mongs shin tu grol/ / shes rab 'tshe ba legs bshad dang / /

The authentic and thorough discernment of the objects of cognition, It is based on meditative absorption And is utterly free from affliction, Providing sustenance through insight and excellent explanation. [XVII.27]
chos rnams kyi ni mchog yin te/ / de dag la yod de rnam gsum/ / shes rab de 'drar yongs shes nas/ / mkhas pa yang dag sgrub par byed/ /
Supreme among all qualities. It is of three types. Fully comprehending such insight, The wise practice it authentically. [XVII.28]
dkar po'i chos kun rnam par g.yengs pa dang / / mnyam par gzhag dang gnyis kar shes par bya/ / pha rol phyin pa gnyis dang ni/ / gnyis dang gnyis kyis yongs su bsdus/ /
All of the positive qualities should be known To be distracted, composed, or both. They are thoroughly contained In three pairs of transcendences. [XVII.29]
byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa ni/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ / chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ /

The generosity of the bodhisattvas Is unattached, free from attachment, knows no attachment. Nor is it in any way attached, For it is unattached, free from attachment, and knows no attachment. [XVII.30]
byang chub sems dpa'i tshul khrims ni/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ / chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ /

The discipline of the bodhisattvas Is unattached, free from attachment, and knows no attachment. Nor is it in any way attached, For it is unattached, free from attachment, knows no attachment. [XVII.31]
byang chub sems dpa'i bzod pa ni/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ / chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ /

The patience of the bodhisattvas Is unattached, free from attachment, and knows no attachment. Nor is it in any way attached, For it is unattached, free from attachment, knows no attachment. [XVII.32]
byang chub sems dpa'i brtson 'grus ni/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ / chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ /

The diligence of the bodhisattvas Is unattached, free from attachment, and knows no attachment. Nor is it in any way attached, For it is unattached, free from attachment, knows no attachment. [XVII.33]
byang chub sems dpa'i bsam gtan ni/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ / chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ /

The concentration of the bodhisattvas Is unattached, free from attachment, and knows no attachment. Nor is it in any way attached For it is unattached, free from attachment, knows no attachment. [XVII.34]
byang chub sems dpa'i shes rab ni/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ / chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ /
The insight of the bodhisattvas Is unattached, free from attachment, and knows no attachment. Nor is it in any way attached, For it is unattached, free from attachment, knows no attachment. [XVII.35]

sangs rgyas sras rnams slong dang phrad na rang gi srog kyang rtag tu gtong / / snying rjes gzhan las lan kyang mi re 'dod pa'i 'bras bu don mi gnyer/ / sbyin pa de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod/ / sbyin pa ye shes kyis yongs zin pas 'jig rten dag na mi zad bzhag /

When meeting someone in need, the children of the buddhas will always give away even their own lives. Out of compassion they do not hope for reward from others, nor do they aim at cherished results. With their generosity they establish all beings in the three kinds of enlightenment, And, as their generosity is embraced by wakefulness, it remains inexhaustibly in the world. [XVII.36]

sangs rgyas sras rnams sdom dang brtson pa'i rang bzhin tshul khrims gsum rtag blangs/ / mtho ris mngon par mi 'dod yang dag thob kyang de la chags mi skyed/ / tshul khrims de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod/ / tshul khrims ye shes kyis yongs zin pas 'jig rten dag na mi zad bzhag /

The children of the buddhas always abide by the triple discipline, the nature of guarding and persevering. They feel no fondness for the higher realms, and when truly attaining them, do not become attached. With their discipline they establish all beings in the three kinds of enlightenment, And, as their discipline is embraced by wakefulness, it remains inexhaustibly in the world. [XVII.37]

sangs rgyas sras rnams shin tu bya dka' de bzhin mi yi gnod kun bzod/ / mtho ris gnyer dang mi nus pas min 'jigs pas ma yin phan ltas min/ / bzod pa bla na med pas skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod/ / bzod pa ye shes kyis yongs zin pas 'jig rten dag na mi zad bzhag /

The children of the buddhas tolerate what is extremely difficult to endure and likewise accept all the injuries of humanity, Not for the sake of the higher realms, not because they are incapable, not out of fear, and not because they perceive a benefit. With unexcelled patience they establish all beings in the three kinds of enlightenment, And, as their patience is embraced by wakefulness, it remains inexhaustibly in the world. [XVII.38]

rgyal ba'i sras rnams go cha sbyor ba'i bdag nyid brtson 'grus dpe med byas/ / rang dang gzhan gyi nyon mongs tshogs gzhom byang chub dam pa 'thob par byed/ / brtson 'grus de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod/ / brtson 'grus ye shes kyis yongs zin pas 'jig rten dag na mi zad bzhag /

The children of the victorious ones display incomparable diligence, the nature of armor and application; Overcoming their own and others’ afflictions and accomplishing true enlightenment. With their diligence they establish all beings in the three kinds of enlightenment, And, as their diligence is embraced by wakefulness, it remains inexhaustibly in the world. [XVII.39]

rgyal ba'i sras rnams ting 'dzin mang ldan bsam gtan rnam pa thams cad bsgrubs/ / bsam gtan bde ba phul gyis gnas shing snying rjes skye ba dman la rten/ / bsam gtan de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod/ / bsam gtan ye shes kyis yongs zin pas 'jig rten dag na mi zad bzhag /

Endowed with numerous meditative absorptions, the children of the victorious ones practice all forms of concentration. Abiding by the highest bliss of meditation, they compassionately rely on inferior births. With their concentration they establish all beings in the three kinds of enlightenment, And, as their concentration is embraced by wakefulness, it remains inexhaustibly in the world. [XVII.40]

rgyal ba'i sras rnams de nyid shes bya gang yin mtha' dag rnam kun shes/ / mya ngan 'das la'ang blo yis chags rab mi skyed 'khor bar smos ci dgos/ / ye shes de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod/ / ye shes sems can yongs su gsung bas 'jig rten dag na mi zad bzhag /

The children of the victorious ones know reality and the entirety of the objects of knowledge. As their minds do not become attached to the transcendence of suffering at all, what need is there to mention cyclic existence? With their wakefulness they establish all beings in the three kinds of enlightenment, And, as their wakefulness embraces sentient beings, it remains inexhaustibly in the world. [XVII.41]
rgya che ba dang zang zing med/ / don che ba dang mi zad pa/ / sbyin la sogs pa thams cad kyi/ / yon tan bzhir ni shes par bya/ /
Vastness, freedom from materialism, Great purpose, and inexhaustibility— These should be known as four qualities Present throughout generosity and so forth. [XVII.42]
slong ba mthong rdzogs dga' ba dang / / mi dga' ba dang smon pa dang / / sbyin pa po ni brtser ldan pas/ / lhag par ldan pas rtag zil gnon/ /
The perfect joy of those in need, upon sight, Their displeasure, and their prayer, Are by the loving benefactors Always surpassed with their special possession. [XVII.43]
brtse bas sems can rnams la ni/ / srog dang longs spyod chung ma dag / rtag gtong shin tu dga' byed pa/ / de spong ji ltar srung mi 'gyur/ /
The loving ones are always more than happy To offer sentient beings Their own lives, possessions, and spouses. What need is there then to speak of their observing restraint? [XVII.44]
'phags pa mi lta sems snyoms shing / / mi 'jigs brtse phyir kun ster ba/ / gzhan la gnod par byed pa yis/ / log pa'i tshig ni ji ltar smra/ /
The noble ones have no concerns and are of balanced mind. Fearless and loving, they give away everything. How could they ever speak to others With hurtful and inappropriate words? [XVII.45]
snyoms par phan par 'dod pas brtse ba can/ / gzhan gyi sdug bsngal skye bas shin tu 'jigs/ / sems can 'dul ba la ni sems brtson pa/ / ngag gi nyes rnam gsum las shin tu ring / /

The loving ones wish to benefit equally. They are horrified by the suffering of others. As they exert their minds so as to influence sentient beings, They are extremely far from the three flaws of speech. [XVII.46]
thams cad gtong ba snying rje can/ / rten 'byung chos la rab mkhas pa/ / de ni yid kyi nyon mongs kun/ / ji lta bur na dang du len/ /
Universally generous, compassionate, And skilled regarding the phenomena of dependent origination, How could they possibly adhere To any of the mind’s afflictions? [XVII.47]
brtser ldan gang tshe gnod pa byed pa dang / / gzhan la phan pa'i sdug bsngal la rtag tu/ / phan pa'i 'du shes dga' ba rnyed gyur pa/ / de yis gang la ci zhig bzod par bya/ /
Whenever the loving ones are hurt Or suffer for the benefit of others, They think of it as helpful and find joy. For them, what is there to be patient about? [XVII.48]
gzhan la gzhan gyi 'du shes bral ba dang / / bdag pas ches lhag gzhan la rtag byams dang / / dka' ba spyod phyir brtse ba dang bcas la/ / brtson 'grus dka' ba min la shin tu dka'/ /
Without regarding others as others, They always love others much more than themselves. Undertaking hardship and abiding by love— Such diligence is not difficult, but extremely difficult. [XVII.49]
gsum gyi bsam gtan bde ba chung / / bdag bde gzhan pa yongs nyams 'gyur/ / zad 'gyur rmongs dang bcas par 'dod/ / byang chub sems dpa'i bzlog pa'o/ /

In three cases concentration is held To yield little happiness and personal happiness, to be attached, To be subject to deterioration and exhaustion, and to involve delusion. For the bodhisattvas, the case is the opposite. [XVII.50]
ji ltar mtshan mo lag nom dang / / khebs sgron de bzhin shes pa gsum/ / snying rje can gyi shes pa ni/ / nyi ma'i zer bzhin mtshungs pa med/ /
Like groping in the night and a lamp under cover, Such are the three cognitions. The compassionate ones’ knowledge is unequalled, Like the rays of the sun. [XVII.51]
sbyin pa rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /
Generosity is held to be supreme In terms of its support, substance, Reason, dedication, cause, Wakefulness, field, and states. [XVII.52]
tshul khrims rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /
Discipline is held to be supreme In terms of its support, substance, Reason, dedication, cause, Wakefulness, field, and states. [XVII.53]
bzod pa rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /
Patience is held to be supreme In terms of its support, substance, Reason, dedication, cause, Wakefulness, field, and states. [XVII.54]
brtson 'grus rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /
Diligence is held to be supreme In terms of its support, substance, Reason, dedication, cause, Wakefulness, field, and states. [XVII.55]
bsam gtan rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /
Concentration is held to be supreme In terms of its support, substance, Reason, dedication, cause, Wakefulness, field, and states. [XVII.56]
shes rab rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /
Insight is held to be supreme In terms of its support, substance, Reason, dedication, cause, Wakefulness, field, and states. [XVII.57]
byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa ni/ / sems can gcig bde bskal mang du/ / gnod pa byed kyang dga' 'gyur na/ / de las bzlog pa smos ci dgos/ /
The bodhisattva’s generosity is such That, for the sake of the happiness of a single being, Even eons of harm will be the cause of joy. It is needless, then, to speak of different cases. [XVII.58]
lus can rnams ni gang phyir nor 'dod pa/ / brtan rnams de nyid lus can rnams la gtong / / skye bo rnams ni lus phyir nor 'dod de/ / de nyid brtan rnams brgya phrag rnams su gtong / /

The reason that embodied beings wish for wealth Is precisely what the steadfast ones grant to beings. People want wealth for the sake of their bodies. This is exactly what the steadfast ones relinquish hundreds of times. [XVII.59]

gang tshe lus nyid gtong yang yid sdug mi bsngal ba/ / de tshe rdzas ngan lta la smos kyang ci zhig dgos/ / de 'di'i 'jig rten 'das pa de des dga' 'gyur ba/ / gang yin de ni de yi yang ni bla ma yin/ /

When even giving away one’s body causes no anguish to the mind, What need is there then to speak about inferior substances? This is the way that they transcend the world, And the joy they experience thereby is the highest. [XVII.60]
ji ltar blo ldan 'di ni kun gtong bas/ / don gnyer skye bo dga' bas dga' ba ltar/ / de ltar slong mo ba dag blang bya ba/ / 'dod dgu thob pa dag gis dgar mi 'gyur/ /
When, to the delight of the needy, the wise give away everything, The joy that they thereby experience Is not felt by those in need, Who receive all that they wish for. [XVII.61]
blo can bdog dgu btang bas nor med pa/ / bdag nyid nor ldan sems pa ji lta bar/ / slong ba longs spyod kun rdzogs bdag nyid ni/ / de ltar nor dang ldan par mi sems so/ /

When the wise have given away all that they own and have no wealth, They consider themselves prosperous. Their sense of being wealthy is not shared By recipients in possession of perfect enjoyments. [XVII.62]

ji ltar blo ldan 'di ni sbyin pa bzang pos tshul bzhin du/ / don gnyer tshim byas de la phan chen 'dogs par sems pa ltar/ / de bzhin slong mo ba dag shin du nor mang thob nas ni/ / sbyin pa po la rnyed pa'i rgyu yis drin du mi brtsi'o/ /

When the wise have fully satisfied the needy with their excellent generosity, They think of them as benefactors in a way That is not matched by the recipients’ acknowledgment Of their benefactors, the causes of their wealth. [XVII.63]

lam ka'i 'bras mchog ldan pa'i shing las longs spyod ji lta bar/ / lus can rnams kyis gang gi nor rdzas rgya cher blangs nas ni/ / bdag nyid dogs dang bral bar rang nyams spyod par byed pa la/ / btang dga' longs spyod can de byang chub sems dpa' las gzhan min/ /

As if partaking of the perfect fruit of a tree along the road, Embodied beings harvest wealth and possessions And enjoy them without a second thought; None other than the bodhisattva experiences the pleasures of relinquishing all to them. [XVII.64]
gtso dang de'i rgyu las kyi dbye ba dang / / rnam pa'i dbye ba rten gyi dbye ba dang / / bar chad rnam bzhi'i gnyen po'i dbye ba yis/ / brtson 'grus yongs shes bya zhes rab tu bstan/ /
dge ba'i tshogs kyi nang na brtson 'grus mchog / 'di ltar de la brten nas de rjes 'thob/ / brtson 'grus kyis ni mod la bde gnas mchog / 'jig rten 'das dang 'jig rten gtogs pa 'grub/ /

Among all virtues diligence is supreme, For their attainment follows from it. With diligence one gains perfect ease at once. It accomplishes all that transcends the world, as well as the world. [XVII.66]
brtson 'grus kyis ni srid spyod 'dod pa 'thob/ / brtson 'grus kyis ni dag pa rab 'gyur ldan/ / brtson 'grus kyis ni 'jig tshogs 'das nas grol/ / brtson 'grus kyis ni byang chub mchog sangs rgyas/ /

Diligence delivers what is wished for within existence. With diligence purification is attained. Through diligence one transcends the transient collection, gains liberation. Diligence brings buddhahood, supreme enlightenment. [XVII.67]

gzhan yang nyams dang 'phel ba'i brtson 'grus dang / / thar pa'i dbang dang mi mthun phyogs spangs gzhan/ / de nyid rab zhugs yongs su sgyur byed dang / / brtson 'grus don chen nges tshig gzhan du 'dod/ /

Moreover, there is diligence in decrease and increase, Control of liberation, elimination of conflicting factors, Entry into reality, total transformation, And what is ascertained as “diligence of the great objective,” which is held to be distinct. [XVII.68]
thog mar dge ba'i brtson 'grus de nas ni/ / tshul bzhin rab zhugs sbyor ba'i brtson 'grus te/ / ma zhum mi 'gong chog mi shes brtson 'grus/ / rnam pa thams cad sangs rgyas rnams rab gsungs/ /

Diligence of the initial goodness, and then, Diligence of correct entry and application; As well as undaunted, unshakable, and insatiable diligence— All these features the buddhas have taught. [XVII.69]
theg pa gsum brtson skye bo la brten nas/ / bsam blo zhan dang rgya rab che ldan phyir/ / brtson 'grus tha ma 'bring dang mchog gzhan te/ / de ni don chung ba dang don chen 'dod/ /

In terms of the individuals who apply themselves to the three vehicles, For some, intent and intelligence are feeble, whereas for others they are extremely vast. Their inferior, mediocre, and supreme diligence Is respectively held to be of small and great purpose. [XVII.70]
brtson 'grus ldan pa longs spyod kyis pham med/ / brtson 'grus ldan pa nyon mongs kyis pham med/ / brtson 'grus ldan pa skyo bas pham pa med/ / brtson 'grus ldan pa thob pas pham pa med/ /
The diligent are not defeated by wealth. The diligent are not defeated by affliction. The diligent are not defeated by weariness. The diligent are not defeated by attainment. [XVII.71]
phan tshun bsdus phyir rab dbye'i phyir/ / chos nyid phyir dang rgyu mtshan phyir/ / pha rol phyin drug rnam kun du/ / rnam par nges par shes par bya/ /
With reference to their mutual inclusion, divisions, The Dharma, and the reasons, The six transcendences can Be seen as ascertained. [XVII.72]
sbyin mtshungs de ston len 'jug dang / / bdag nyid rjes su 'jug rnams kyis/ / snyan par smra dang don spyod dang / / don mthun nyid du 'dod pa yin/ /
As for generosity, the same holds. Teaching, bringing acceptance, and one’s own consistent engagement Are held to be pleasant speech, meaningful action, And consistency with the meaning. [XVII.73]
phan par byed pa'i thabs dang ni/ / 'dzin par byed dang 'jug byed dang / / de bzhin rjes su 'jug byed pas/ / bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhir shes bya/ /
The means for benefiting, Comprehension, engagement And consistent engagement— These are to be known as the four means of attraction. [XVII.74]
dang pos snod 'gyur dngos po ste/ / gnyis pa yis ni mos pa yin/ / gsum pa yis ni sgrub pa ste/ / bzhi pas rnam par sbyong ba'o/ /
The first creates vessels, The second, devotion, With the third, there is practice, And with the fourth, thorough training. [XVII.75]
zang zing dang ni chos kyi ste/ / dmigs pa'i chos la sogs pa yis/ / bsdu ba gnyis kyi sgo nas ni/ / bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhir 'dod do/ /
In terms of material things and the Dharma, Which includes the Dharma as focal point and so forth, The four means of attraction are held To be included in two. [XVII.76]
rnam pa'i dbye ba'i sgo nas ni/ / bsdu ba dman dang 'bring dang mchog / phal cher don med don yod dang / / rnam kun don yod shes par bya/ /
In terms of divisions, it should be understood That there are the inferior, middling, and supreme attractions; The generally unsuccessful, the successful, And the in-all-regards successful. [XVII.77]
'khor sdud pa dang ldan pa rnams/ / tshul 'di la ni yang dag rten/ / kun gyi don kun sgrub byed cing / / thabs bzang yin par rab tu bsngags/ /
Those involved in attracting a retinue Genuinely follow this way. This accomplishes, in all regards, the aims of all And is extolled as the excellent method. [XVII.78]
bsdus dang sdud par 'gyur ba dang / / gang dag da ltar sdud byed pa/ / de kun de 'drar de lta bas/ / 'di ni sems can smin byed lam/ /
All attraction that took place in the past, That comes about in the future, or which occurs right now Is of this kind, and hence, This is the path of ripening sentient beings. [XVII.79]
de ltar rtag tu longs spyod ma chags blo/ / zhi sdom brtson pa'i pha rol phyin gnas bdag / srid yul mtshan ma rnam par mi rtog pa/ / de ni sems can tshogs sdud byed pa yin/ /

Thus, with a mind always unattached to pleasures, They have gone to the other side of peace, restraint, and endeavor. Those who so abide, not conceiving of any existence, objects, or marks, Are the ones who attract the hosts of sentient beings. [XVII.80]
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ pha rol tu phyin pa dang bsdu ba'i le'u ste bcu bdun pa'o// //
This was the seventeenth chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras, the chapter on the transcendences and attractions.

d.crumb: 18. mchod pa dang bsten pa dang tshad med pa

f.d: 18. [mchod pa dang bsten pa dang tshad med pa'i le'u]
18. Worship, Reliance, and the Immeasurables
rab dang sems dang ldan pa yis/ / tshogs gnyis rdzogs par bya ba'i phyir/ / sangs rgyas rnams la gos sogs kyis/ / mngon sum mngon sum min par mchod/ /
With the most buoyant mind, And in order to perfect the two accumulations, Offerings of clothing and so forth Are presented to the buddhas, whether manifest or not. [XVIII.1]
sangs rgyas 'byung ba don yod par/ / smon lam dang ni ldan pa yi/ / gsum po dmigs par mi byed pa/ / sangs rgyas mchod pa rdzogs pa yin/ /
“May the coming of the Buddha be meaningful.” With this prayer, And without any holding of the three as reference points, The worship of the Buddha is perfected. [XVIII.2]
sems can dag ni tshad med pa/ / yongs su smin par byed pa gzhan/ / rdzas dang sems kyi sgo nas gzhan/ / mos pa dang ni smon pa dang / /
There is also the ripening of The infinite number of sentient beings, The means of substance and mind, Inspiration, aspiration, [XVIII.3]
brtse dang bzod pa dag dang ni/ / yang dag spyod pa'i sgo dang ni/ / gzhi la gtod dang rtogs pa dang / / grol dang de bzhin nyid kyis gzhan/ /
Love, patience, Genuine practice, Turning toward the bases, realization, Liberation, and suchness. [XVIII.4]
rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rten dang dngos dang rgyu dang ni/ / ye shes dang ni zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi mchod pa rab bstan pa/ /
Worship is explained By its reason, dedication, Entity, support, cause, Wakefulness, field, and foundation. [XVIII.5]
rgyu dang 'bras bu nyid dang ni/ / bdag nyid dang ni gzhan dag dang / / rnyed dang bkur sti nyid dang ni/ / sgrub pa'i sgo nas de rnam gnyis/ /
Cause and effect, Oneself and others, Material things, veneration, and practice— These are twofold. [XVIII.6]
mchod pa chung dang chen po de/ / nga rgyal bcas dang nga rgyal med/ / sbyor dang 'gro ba nyid dang ni/ / smon pa'i sgo nas der 'dod do/ /
Worship is minor and great, With pride and without pride, And asserted with reference to Application, lives, and aspiration. [XVIII.7]
rang gi sems kyis sangs rgyas rnams mchod pa/ / chos la mos dang bsam dang dbang 'byor dang / / rnam par mi rtog thabs yongs bzung ba dang / / kun dang don gcig nyid la 'jug pas mchog /

Worship of the Buddha through one’s own mind is supreme As there is inspiration regarding the Dharma, aspiration, mastery, Full embrace by the skillful means of nonconceptuality, And engagement with the single objective of all. [XVIII.8]
bsten pa rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas rab tu bstan/ /
Reliance is explained In terms of support, bases, marks, Dedication, cause, wakefulness, The pure field, and abode. [XVIII.9]
bshes gnyen dul ba zhi zhing nyer zhi ba/ / yon tan lhag pa brtson bcas lung gis phyug / de nyid rab tu rtogs pa smra mkhas ldan/ / brtse ba'i bdag nyid skyo ba spangs la sten/ /

One should follow a spiritual teacher who is gentle, at peace, thoroughly at peace, Possesses superior qualities, is diligent, rich in terms of scripture, Realized with respect to reality, skilled in teaching, Loving in nature, and has relinquished weariness. [XVIII.10]
bkur sti rnyed pa dag dang rim gro dang / / sgrub pa'i sgo nas bshes gnyen bsten par bya/ /
Following the teacher with veneration, material things, Reverence, and practice are the bases for following. [XVIII.11a–b]
bsten gzhi de bzhin blo ldan chos la ni/ / shes bsam dus su 'dud pas bshes gnyen bgrod/ /
The wise wish to understand the Dharma And in a timely manner go respectfully before the teacher. [XVIII.11c–d]
de ni bsnyen bkur rnyed la 'dod pa med/ / bsgrub par bya phyir de yongs sngo bar byed/ /
Without any wish for respect and acquisitions, One brings forth a full dedication to practice. [XVIII.12a–b]
brtan pa ji skad bstan pa sgrub pa des/ / de yi sems ni yang dag mgu bar byed/ /
The steadfast one who practices in accordance with the teaching Will be truly delighting the mind. [XVIII.12c–d]
theg pa gsum la mkhas pa blos rtogs nas/ / rang gi theg pa bsgrub par bya phyir 'bad/ /
Becoming learned and realized with respect to the three vehicles, One persists in the practice of one’s own vehicle [XVIII.13a–b]
sems can tshad med yongs smin bya phyir dang / / zhing dag pa yang sbyang bar bya ba'i phyir/ /
For the sake of fully maturing limitless beings And for the sake of bringing forth the pure fields. [XVIII.13c–d]
de chos bgo skal la spyod yon tan ldan/ / bshes gnyen rab tu bsten bya zang zing min/ /
The spiritual friend is to be followed well for the sake of obtaining One’s share of the Dharma and not of material things. [XVIII.14a–b]
blo dang ldan pa rgyu dang 'bras bu dang / / chos sgo rjes 'gro phyi dang thos mnyan dang / /
The wise should follow the spiritual teacher through the cause and effect, Adhering to the gateway of Dharma [XVIII.14c–d]
sems kyi rnal 'byor nga rgyal bcas pa dang / / nga rgyal med yid ldan pas bshes gnyen bsten/ / blo ldan 'gro dang sbyor ba dang / / smon pa'i sgo nas bshes gnyen bsten/ /

In the outer way, by listening, and through the inner spiritual training, With pride and without pride. The way in which the wise follow a spiritual teacher Takes place in terms of lives, application, and aspiration. [XVIII.15]
rang gi sems kyis bshes gnyen mchog bsten pa/ / chos la mos dang bsam dang dbang 'byor dang / / rnam par mi rtog thabs yongs bzung ba dang / / kun dang don gcig nyid la 'jug pas mchog /

Following the spiritual teacher through one’s own mind is supreme As there is inspiration with respect to the Dharma, intent, mastery, Full embrace of the skillful means of nonconceptuality, And engagement with the single objective of all. [XVIII.16]
brtan pa'i tshangs pa mi mthun spangs/ / rnam par mi rtog ye shes ldan/ / dmigs pa rnam pa gsum la 'jug / sems can rnams ni yongs smin byed/ /

The sublime abodes of the steadfast ones have abandoned the conflicting factors, Are in possession of nonconceptual wakefulness, Engage with the three focal points, And thoroughly ripen sentient beings. [XVIII.17]
brtan pa rnams kyi de dag bde 'dod dang / / sdug bsngal gyis nyam thag dang bde ba dang / / nyon mongs can dang de dag bstan bcos dang / / de yi de bzhin nyid la rab tu 'jug /

Thus, for the steadfast ones, these thoroughly engage With those who are wishing for happiness, who are tormented by suffering, Who are happy, and who are afflicted; With treatises; and with the suchness of those. [XVIII.18]
de don de bzhin nyid phyir dang / / zhi ba thob pas dag phyir dang / / las gnyis nyon mongs zad pa'i phyir/ / byams pa dmigs pa med pa yin/ /

Because its object is suchness, Because of purity through the attainment of peace, And because of the two activities and the exhaustion of afflictions— For these reasons love has no focal point. [XVIII.19]
de dag g.yo dang mi g.yo dang / / chags pas ro myang min zhes bya/ / byang chub sems dpa' mi g.yo ba/ / chags dang bral bar rab tu gnas/ /
These are known as mutable and immutable, Relished with attachment and not so relished. The bodhisattvas thoroughly abide in those That are immutable and free from attachment. [XVIII.20]
mnyam gzhag ngo bo nyid min chung / / 'bring dang dman pa'i sa pa dang / / bsam pa dman dang nga rgyal bcas/ / gang yin de dman gzhan nyid lhag /
Not of the nature of equipoise, lesser, Mediocre, belonging to inferior grounds, Of an inferior mind-set, and involved with pride— These are inferior while others are superior. [XVIII.21]
tshangs pa'i gnas pas gnas pa yi/ / blo ldan rtag tu 'dod par skye/ / des ni tshogs rnams rdzogs byed cing / / sems can dag kyang rnam smin byed/ /
The wise who remain in the sublime abodes Will always take birth in the realm of desire. Through this they perfect the accumulations And mature sentient beings. [XVIII.22]
kun du tshangs dang mi 'bral ba/ / de yi mi mthun phyogs dang bral/ / bag med gyur kyang de yi rkyen/ / mi bzad pas kyang mi 'gyur ro/ /
Never parting from the sublime abodes, They are free from conflicting factors. Even if, while negligent, they perceive the intolerable, It will still not make them change. [XVIII.23]
byang chub sems dpa' gnod sems dang / / rnam 'tshe mi dga' gnod sems dang / / 'dod pa'i 'dod chags dang ldan pa/ / nyes dmigs rnam pa mang la reg /
The bodhisattva who wishes to cause harm, Is hostile, feels displeasure, Or wishes to harm and gain pleasures Encounters numerous flaws. [XVIII.24]
nyon mongs kyis ni bdag 'joms sems can 'joms shing tshul khrims 'joms/ / nyams bcas snyed pas dman zhing srung dang de bzhin ston pas smad/ /
Their afflictions destroy themselves, sentient beings, and their discipline; They fall back, become impoverished, and are disparaged by protectors and by the teacher; [XVIII.25]
rtsod bcas mi snyan de ni gzhan du mi khom rnams su skye/ / thob dang ma thob nyams pas yid la sdug bsngal chen po 'thob/ /
They encounter reproach and disgrace, take birth in unfree states, Lose what they have and do not yet have, and incur great suffering of the mind. [XVIII.26]
nyes pa 'di kun byams sogs la/ / legs par gnas la mi 'byung ste/ / nyon mongs can min sems can gyi/ / don du 'khor ba yongs mi gtong / /
All these flaws are not incurred by those Who adhere to love and the others. Without affliction they will, for the benefit of sentient beings, Never relinquish cyclic existence. [XVIII.27]
ji ltar rgyal ba'i sras rnams sems can la/ / byams pa la sogs sems pa 'di 'byung ba/ / sems can thams cad yon tan ldan pa yi/ / bu gcig pa la'ang de lta ma yin no/ /

Toward sentient beings, the intent of love and the others Thus arises in the children of the victorious ones. This is unlike what any sentient being could possibly feel Toward a precious, only child. [XVII.28]
rab 'bar dgra yi dbang du song / / sdug bsngal gyis non mun pas bsgribs/ / bgrod dka'i lam la kun du zhugs/ / 'ching ba che dang yang dag ldan/ /

Those who are ablaze and under the power of enemies, Who are tormented by suffering and enveloped in darkness, Who have embarked on the path hard to travel, Who are thoroughly tied by great chains, [XVIII.29]
zas chen dug dang 'dres la zhen/ / lam ni rab tu stor gyur pa/ / lam gol rab zhugs stobs chung ba'i/ / sems can rnams la snying rje'o/ /

Who are attached to great food mixed with poison, Who are entirely deprived of the path, Who have strayed from the path, and who have little strength— Toward such beings there is compassion. [XVIII.30]
'tshe spangs byang chub mchog gi sa bon dang / / bde ba bskyed dang gdung byed 'dod pa'i rgyu/ / ngo bo nyid sbyin chos la rten pa yi/ / rgyal ba'i sras la byang chub thag mi ring / /

The elimination of hostility, the seeds of supreme enlightenment, The production of happiness and torments, the cause of the desired, And the supply of the very nature—the children of the victorious ones who rely On this Dharma are not far from enlightenment. [XVIII.31]
snying rje blo mchog 'khor bar gtogs pa yi/ / sdug bsngal bdag nyid kun dang bdag med par/ / rnam par shes nas skyo bar mi 'gyur zhing / / nyes pas rab gnod par yang mi 'gyur ro/ /

Compassion and supreme wakefulness Make known all features of suffering within cyclic existence, Including its absence of identity. This brings neither weariness nor any damage through flaws. [XVIII.32]
'jig rten sdug bsngal bdag nyid lta ba yi/ / brtse dang ldan pas sdug bsngal de dang ni/ / de yongs spong ba'i thabs kyang ji bzhin rig / nyam nga bar byed skyo bar yang mi 'gyur/ /
With love that sees the world as the nature of suffering, Both suffering and the means For its complete elimination are understood correctly. This brings pity but not weariness. [XVIII.33]
snying rje'i bdag nyid can gyi brtse ba 'di/ / rang bzhin dang ni so sor brtags pa dang / / de sngon goms par byas dang ldan pa dang / / mi mthun phyogs nyams rnam dag thob pa bzhi/ /

This love of those whose very nature is compassion Is fourfold because it is natural, has investigated, Has achieved familiarity in the past, And is an attainment of purity where the conflicting factors fall away. [XVIII.34]
mnyam dang rtag min lhag pa'i bsam pas min/ / sgrub pa'i sgo dang 'dod chags bral ba dang / / mi dmigs pas min gang de brtse min te/ / de bzhin brtse med gang de byang chub min/ /

If it is not equality, eternity, superior intention, Means for accomplishment, freedom from desire, and absence of focal point, Then it is not love, And where there is no love, there is no enlightenment. [XVIII.35]
snying rje dang ni bzod dang sems pa dang / / smon lam skye ba sems can yongs smin byed/ / dang po rtsa ba tha ma 'bras mchog ldan/ / 'di ni snying rje'i ljon shing chen po yin/ /
Compassion, patience, attention, Aspirations, births, and the maturation of sentient beings— From the initial root to the final, supreme fruition, This is the great tree of compassion. [XVIII.36]
rtsa ba snying rje med gyur na/ / dka' spyod bzod pa nyid mi 'gyur/ / blo ldan sdug bsngal mi bzod na/ / sems can don sems nyid mi 'gyur/ /

If there were no root of compassion, There would not be the patient acceptance of difficult tasks. If the wise were not to accept suffering, They would not be attentive for the benefit of beings. [XVIII.37]
sems pa dang ni bral ba'i blo/ / skye ba dkar po rnam dag tu/ / smon lam 'debs par mi 'gyur ro/ / skye ba bzang po ma thob na/ / sems can yongs smin byed mi 'gyur/ /
A mind that lacks attention Will not make aspirations For virtuous and pure rebirths. Without the attainment of excellent births, There can be no maturation of sentient beings. [XVIII.38]
snying rje'i 'chu ba byams pa ste/ / de sdug bsngal na bde ba yis/ / sangs rgyas tshul bzhin yid byed pas/ / yal ga rgya chen 'phel ba dang / /
smon lam rgyun ni ma bcad pas/ / lo ma 'dor len rkyen rnam gnyis/ / grub pa de phyir me tog dang / / 'bras bu don yod shes par bya/ /
The continuous stream of aspirations Will make the leaves change and renew themselves; And the accomplishment of the two conditions Will bring the flowers and the meaningful fruition. [XVIII.40]
snying rje chen po yon tan 'byung gnas kyi/ / sems can rnams la snying rje su mi byed/ / 'di ltar 'di dag la ni sdug bsngal yang / / brtses bskyed bde ba gzhal du med pa 'byung / /

As great compassion is the source of good qualities, Who would not be compassionate to sentient beings? They may suffer, but since it is due to love, The bliss they experience is immeasurable. [XVIII.41]
snying rjes zin pa'i brtser ldan rnams/ / zhi la'ang yid ni mi gnas na/ / 'jig rten bde dang rang srog la/ / chags par 'gyur ba smos ci dgos/ /

The minds of the loving ones possessed of compassion Are not even attracted to peace; It is needless, then, to mention that they do not Become attached to worldly pleasures or their own lives. [XVIII.42]
byams pa gang de kha na ma tho ba/ / med dang 'jig rten 'das pa yod ma yin/ / blo ldan rnams kyi brtse bas byams pa ni/ / kha na ma tho med cing 'jig rten 'das/ /
There is no love that is free from evil And beyond the world. The affectionate love of the wise is free from evil And beyond the world. [XVIII.43]
sdug bsngal rba rgal che dang mi shes pa'i/ / mun pa che la rten par gyur pa yi/ / 'jig rten 'dren pa'i thabs gang yin pa de/ / ji ltar kha na ma tho med mi 'gyur/ /
The world is based on the turbulent waves of suffering And the great darkness of unknowing. How could that which is the means for guiding the world Possibly not be free from evil? [XVIII.44]
'jig rten byang chub rang sangs rgyas pa yi/ / dgra bcom rnams la byams pa de med na/ / de las gzhan la smos kyang ci dgos pa/ / ji ltar 'jig rten 'das pa ma yin 'gyur/ /

Not even those destroyers of the enemy, who on their own attain enlightenment, Possess this love for the world; It is needless, then, to mention the case of others. How could this not be beyond the world? [XVIII.45]
byang chub sems dpa' sdug bsngal med/ / brtse bas sdug bsngal gyur pa gang / / de la dang por kun tu skrag / reg nas shin tu mngon par dga'/ /
A bodhisattva free from suffering Experiences suffering because of love; First there is fear, but upon contact There follows utterly intense joy. [XVIII.46]
brtse bas bskyed pa'i sdug bsngal 'jig rten gyi/ / bde ba thams cad zil gyis gnon 'gyur zhing / / don byas rnams kyang de dang mi ldan gang / / de las ngo mtshar che ba ci zhig yod/ /
Suffering due to love Outshines all the world’s happiness, And not even those who have accomplished their objective possess it. What could be more wondrous than this? [XVIII.47]
brtan pa'i brtse dang ldan pa'i sbyin pa yis/ / sbyin pa'i bde ba byed pa gang yin pa/ / de la khams gsum nye bar spyad rnams kyi/ / bde ba de yis char yang mi phod do/ /
When the steadfast ones give with love, They experience a joy of giving Of which the happiness of those experiencing the three realms Cannot match even a fraction. [XVIII.48]
sems can don phyir brtse bas sdug bsngal gyi/ / rang bzhin 'khor ba gang yin mi gtong na/ / snying rje can rnams gzhan la phan pa'i phyir/ / sdug bsngal ci ste khas len byed mi 'gyur/ /

For the benefit of sentient beings, they will not give up That cyclic existence, which by nature is suffering. Why then should the compassionate ones not, For the sake of others, accept suffering? [XVIII.49]
brtse dang ldan pa'i snying rje'i sbyin pa gang / / longs spyod dang ni de las byams pa dang / / rjes su gzung bas bskyed dang de yi mthus/ / byas pa'i bde ba rtag tu 'phel bar 'gyur/ /
The loving ones’ compassionate Generosity and resourcefulness Cause the happiness of affection, successful care, And capability to constantly increase. [XVIII.50]
snying rjes rgyas par bya zhing 'phel bar bya/ / sbyin pas yongs smin bya zhing bde bar bya/ / kun du drang bar bya zhing bkri bya zhes/ / zhen pa rnams la rab tu smra dang 'dra/ /
“Expand, increase, Fully ripen with compassion and enjoy; Carry forth and lead!” Thus, as it were, compassion instructs the weak. [XVIII.51]
snying rjes sdug bsngal dag gis sdug bsngal ba/ / bde ma bskyed par gang gis bde bar 'gyur/ / de phyir brtse dang ldan pas gzhan bde ba/ / bskyed nas bdag nyid bde bar byed pa yin/ /

Those who, due to compassion, are brought to suffer because of suffering, How could anything but the arising of happiness make them happy? Thus the loving ones create their own happiness By giving happiness to others. [XVIII.52]
snying rje can ni rtag tu rang sbyin la/ / ston dang 'dra ste rang bde mi 'dod pa/ / longs spyod rnams kyis gzhan dag bde bar gyis/ / yang na tha dad min bde bdag la'ang min/ /

The compassionate always act Like a teacher to their own generosity: “My own happiness is unimportant, let enjoyments be enjoyed by others. Otherwise, since there is no difference, I will not be happy either.” [XVIII.53]
de bdes bde ba bdag gis sbyin pa ni/ / 'bras dang bcas te sems can rnams la byin/ / gal te khyod kyis bdag la bya ba yod/ / de dag nyid la shin tu 'bras bur byos/ /

“Their happiness makes me happy. My gifts, including their effects, are to be given away to sentient beings. If you have something to do for me, then see to it that they Experience the most tremendous effect.” [XVIII.54]
sbyin pa po ni longs spyod mi 'dod kyang / / longs spyod shin tu mang la bzang dang phrad/ / bdag ni bde ba de 'dod ma yin te/ / 'di ltar bdag ni sbyin la brgyud dang ldan/ /
“The giver does not wish for enjoyments And yet encounters plentiful and excellent enjoyments. I do not wish for happiness, But will in this way let my generosity be continuous.” [XVIII.55]
bdag ni rtag tu brtse bas bdog pa kun/ / yongs su gtong ba gang yin de ltos la/ / des na khyod kyis bdag ni de'i 'bras la/ / don gnyer med pa nyid du shes par bya/ /
“See how, because of constant love, I give away Whatever is in my possession. Realize, then, that for me The effects of this are of no concern.”[XVIII.56]
gal te khyod 'bras thob pa mi gtong na/ / sbyin la mngon dga' yin par mi 'gyur te/ / 'di ltar skad cig tsam yang sbyin med na/ / sbyin la mngon par dga' ba nyid ma yin/ /

“If I were not to give away the effect that is attained as your result, I would not be truly delighting in generosity. If generosity is absent for even an instant, There is no true delight in generosity.” [XVIII.57]
ma byas pa la 'bras bu mi 'byin te/ / 'di ltar lan bltas bdag gi cha ma yin/ / khyod kyi lan la lta dang bral bas na/ / 'bras bu shin tu gzhan la gtong ba yin/ /

“You do not give your fruits to those who do nothing, And since therefore you look for reward, you are inappropriate for me. I have no concern for your rewards And completely give away your fruits to others.” [XVIII.58]
rgyal sras rnams kyi brtse bas sbyin pa ni/ / kha na ma tho med cing dag pa'i gzhi/ / bde ba 'dren par byed pa nyid dang ni/ / rjes su srung bcas tshol med gos pa med/ /
Based on love, the generosity of the children of the victorious ones Is free from evil, of pure basis, Ushers in happiness, is protective, Undiscriminating, and unstained. [XVIII.59]
rgyal sras rnams kyi brtse bas sbyin pa ni/ / mtha' dag rgya che gtso dang rtag pa dang / / dga' dang zang zing med dang dag pa dang / / byang chub la gzhol dge la gzhol ba yin/ /

Based on love, the generosity of the children of the victorious ones Is total, vast, of the best quality, constant, Joyful, without concern for material things, pure, And committed to enlightenment and virtue. [XVIII.60]
ji ltar bde ba gsum gyis tshim pa'i yid/ / brtse ldan yongs su gtong bas dga' 'gyur ba/ / longs spyod can dag nye bar spyad pa yis/ / de ltar dga' bar 'gyur ba ma yin no/ /

With a mind satiated by the threefold pleasure, The loving one experiences the joy of complete relinquishment; No one who partakes of enjoyments can experience A delight that is comparable to this. [XVIII.61]
bkren la brtse dang ma rungs pa la brtse/ / kun 'khrugs la brtse bag med rnams la brtse/ / yul gyi gzhan dbang can la snying rje dang / / log par mngon par zhen la snying rje'o/ /

There is love for the stingy, love for those who do wrong, Love for the disturbed, love for the careless, Compassion for those caught by the objects, And compassion for those with misguided ideas. [XVIII.62]
bde dang sdug bsngal bde rgyu las/ / byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje ste/ / rgyu dang bshes gnyen rang bzhin las/ / byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje'o/ /
From pleasure, pain, and their cause Comes the bodhisattva’s compassion. From the cause, spiritual teacher, and nature Comes the bodhisattva’s compassion. [XVIII.63]
byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje ni/ / mnyam par shes bya de bsam phyir/ / sgrub phyir 'dod chags bral phyir dang / / mi dmigs phyir dang dag phyir ro/ /
The compassion of the bodhisattva Should be understood to be equal Because of its orientation, practice, freedom from desire, Absence of focal point, and purity. [XVIII.64]
rang gi sems kyis byams la sogs/ / sgom pa chos la mos pa dang / / bsam dang dbang 'byor nyid dang ni/ / rnam par mi rtog gcig phyir mchog /
Supreme love and so forth are cultivated in one’s own mind And are due to inspiration with respect to the Dharma, Intent, mastery, Nonconceptuality, and oneness. [XVIII.65]

de ltar bcom ldan 'das la dang ba rab skyes shing / / rdzas dang bkur sti chen pos shin tu rgyun mchod ldan/ / yon tan mang ldan phan byed shes la rtag sten pa/ / 'gro la rjes su brtse ba grub pa kun thob 'gyur/ /

Thus, the mind thoroughly brightens toward the blessed ones, While worship is perfectly continuous with substances and great veneration; The spiritual teacher, possessing numerous qualities and effectively helpful, is followed, And with love for wandering beings, there is accomplishment in all regards. [XVIII.66]
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ mchod pa dang bsten pa dang tshad med pa'i le'u ste bco brgyad pa'o// //
This was the eighteenth chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras, the chapter on worship, reliance, and the transcendences.

d.crumb: 19. byang chub kyi phyogs dang mthun pa

f.d: 19. [byang chub kyi phyogs dang mthun pa'i le'u]

d.crumb: 19. The Factors That Accord with Enlightenment

f.d: 19. The Factors That Accord with Enlightenment
ngo tsha mi mthun phyogs spangs dang / / rnam par mi rtog ye shes ldan/ / kha na ma tho med dman yul/ / sems can smin byed brtan pa'i yin/ /

The conscience of the steadfast ones has abandoned the conflicting factor, Is in possession of nonconceptual wakefulness, Focuses on the lesser absence of negativity as its object, And matures sentient beings. [XIX.1]
pha rol phyin pa drug po yi/ / mi mthun phyogs ni 'phel ba dang / / gnyen po 'grib pas byang chub sems/ / mi zad ngo tsha skye bar 'gyur/ /
An increase of the factors That conflict with the six transcendences And a decrease in the remedies Cause the bodhisattvas to feel unbearable shame. [XIX.2]
brtan rnams pha rol phyin pa drug / brtan pa la ni le lo dang / / nyon mongs rjes su mthun chos la/ / sbyor ba las kyang ngo mtshar 'gyur/ /
If the steadfast ones become lazy In terms of relying on the six transcendences And partake of factors that accord with affliction, This also causes them shame. [XIX.3]
mnyam gzhag ngo bo nyid min chung / / 'bring dang dman pa'i sa pa dang / / bsam pa dman dang ngar bcas pa'i/ / ngo tsha dman de las gzhan lhag /

Not of the nature of equipoise, lesser, Mediocre, belonging to inferior grounds, Of an inferior mind-set, and involved with ego— These forms of conscience are inferior, while others are superior. [XIX.4]
blo ldan khrel med tshul min las/ / nyon mongs dang len khro ba dang / / yal bar 'dor dang nga rgyal gyis/ / sems can rnams dang tshul khrims 'joms/ /
The wise who lack embarrassment and are incorrect Will take in afflictions, develop anger, Have no concern, and be proud, Thereby destroying sentient beings as well as discipline. [XIX.5]
'gyod pas nyams dang bcas 'gyur zhing / / bkur sti dman pa thob 'gyur des/ / dad ldan mi min tshogs dang ni/ / ston pas kyang ni btang snyoms mdzad/ /
They will suffer from remorse And receive little respect; Hence, by the hosts of faithful nonhumans as well as the Teacher, Such people will be ignored. [XIX.6]
rgyal sras chos dang mthun rnams kyis/ / rnam par smod cing 'jig rten las/ / mthong ba'i chos la mi snyan 'thob/ / gzhan du phyir zhing mi khom skye/ /
Reviled by the children of the victorious ones In accord with the Dharma, The world will speak poorly of them in this life, While in others, they will be born unfree. [XIX.7]
des na chos dkar thob pa dang / / ma thob pa las rnam nyams 'gyur/ / de phyir sdug bsngal gnas pa dang / / yid kyang rnal du mi gnas 'gyur/ /
Thus, they will lose what they have and what they have not yet Obtained in terms of virtuous qualities. Thus dwelling in misery, Their minds will be deprived of ease. [XIX.8]
rgyal sras ngo tsha ldan rnams la/ / nyes pa 'di dag kun mi 'byung / / mkhas pa rtag tu lha dag dang / / mi rnams su ni yang dag skye/ /
The children of the victorious ones endowed with conscience Will not incur any such flaws. Skillful, they are always born well Among gods and humans. [XIX.9]
blo ldan ngo tshas myur du ni/ / rdzogs pa'i byang chub tshogs rdzogs byed/ / rgyal ba'i sras ni sems can rnams/ / smin byed skyo bar mi 'gyur nyid/ /
With conscience, the wise swiftly Complete the accumulations for perfect enlightenment; The children of the victorious ones will not Tire as they mature sentient beings. [XIX.10]
de rtag mi mthun phyogs dang ni/ / gnyen po bral dang mi 'bral 'gyur/ / de ltar rgyal sras ngo tsha ldan/ / phan yon de dag 'thob par 'gyur/ /
Forever free from discordant factors And in possession of the remedies, The children of the victorious ones endowed with conscience Will thus obtain these qualities. [XIX.11]
byis pa shin tu gos bzang gyon yang ni/ / khrel dang bral phyir nyes pas dri ma can/ / rgyal sras ngo tsha shes pa'i gos can ni/ / dgab pa med kyang nyes pa'i dri ma bral/ /

The childish may wear the finest clothing, Yet without shame they are stained by flaws. Wearing their sense of shame, the children of the victorious ones May go uncovered, but they have no staining flaws. [XIX.12]
rgyal ba'i sras ni khrel dang ldan gyur pa/ / nam mkha' bzhin du chos kyis gos mi 'gyur/ / rgyal sras rnams kyi nang du 'dus gyur pa/ / ngo tsha shes pas brgyan pa mdzes pa yin/ /

Children of the victorious ones, who are in possession of shame, Like the sky, cannot be tarnished by anything. Within the gathering of children of the victorious ones, They are beautifully adorned by their sense of shame. [XIX.13]
byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni ngo tsha bas/ / gdul bya rnams la ma bzhin byams pa nyid/ / ngo tsha ba ni nyes pa thams cad las/ / 'khor ba kun tu srung bar byed pa'ang yin/ /
Conscience makes the bodhisattvas Care like a mother for those to be trained; Conscience is also the capable protector Against all the flaws of cyclic existence. [XIX.14]
kun la dang du len pa dang / / kun la dang du mi len cing / / kun la mi 'jug 'jug pa ni/ / khrel ldan khrel bas byas pa'i rtags/ /
Eager acceptance of all, Complete detachment from all, Disengagement from all, and engagement with all— These are the marks of shame in those who possess it. [XIX.15]
rang gi sems kyis khrel sgom pa/ / chos la mos dang bsam pa dang / / dbang 'byor pa dang mi rtog dang / / gcig pa nyid kyis gtso bo yin/ /
The supreme presence of shame is cultivated in one’s own mind, And is due to inspiration with regard to the Dharma, Aspiration, mastery, Nonconceptuality, and oneness. [XIX.16]
byang chub sems dpa'i brtan pa ni/ / de las gzhan pa thams cad las/ / mtshan nyid dang ni rab dbye dang / / mi 'gyur bas ni khyad par 'phags/ /
The steadfastness of the bodhisattvas Relates to its characteristics, Divisions, and immutability, Which are superior to those of anyone else. [XIX.17]
brtson 'grus ting 'dzin shes rab ni/ / snying stobs sran thub brtan par 'dod/ / gang phyir gsum gyis byang chub sems/ / 'jigs pa med par rab tu 'jug /
Diligence, meditative absorption, and insight Are held to be courage, fortitude, and steadfastness Because, with these three, the bodhisattvas Fearlessly enter into action. [XIX.18]
zhum dang g.yo dang rmongs pa yis/ / bya ba rnams la 'jigs pa skye/ / de phyir gnyug ma gsum la ni/ / brtan pa'i ming du shes par bya/ /
Faintheartedness, restlessness, and bewilderment Cause fear of the activities. Therefore, the threefold naturalness is known By the name of “steadfastness.” [XIX.19]
rang bzhin dang ni smon lam dang / / lta ba med pa nyid dang ni/ / sems can log par sgrub pa dang / / zab cing rgya che thos pa dang / /
Nature, aspiration, No concern, The ingratitude of sentient beings, Learning the profound and the vast, [XIX.20]
gdul bya gdul bar dka' ba dang / / rgyal sku bsam gyis mi khyab dang / / dka' ba dag ni sna tshogs dang / / 'khor ba gtong ba med nyid dang / /
Taming those difficult to tame, The inconceivable body of the victorious ones, Numerous hardships, No relinquishment of cyclic existence, [XIX.21]
de nyid nyon mongs med pa la/ / brtan pa'i brtan pa skye ba ni/ / de las gzhan dang mi mtshungs te/ / brtan ldan rnams kyi mchog tu 'dod/ /
And no affliction there— As steadfastness arises in the steadfast ones, It has no equal anywhere, And so among the steadfast, they are held to be supreme. [XIX.22]
phye ma leb dang 'dab chags dang / / rgya mtsho dag gis ri rab ltar/ / brtan pa grogs ngan sdug bsngal dang / / zab mo thos pas mi g.yos so/ /
Like a butterfly, the feathered one, And the ocean to the king of mountains, So the steadfast remain unshakable in the face Of negative company, suffering, and hearing the profound. [XIX.23]
byang chub mi skyo mnyam med pa/ / gzhi gsum thos pas mi ngoms dang / / brtson 'grus che dang sdug bsngal la'o/ / ngo tsha brtan la brten pa ste/ /

The indefatigability of the bodhisattvas has no equal. It arises in relation to three bases— Insatiable learning, great diligence, and suffering— And is based on conscience and steadfastness. [XIX.24]
byang chub che la 'dun pa dag / blo ldan rnams kyi mi skyo ba/ / sa rnams la ni ma rdzogs dang / / rdzogs dang shin tu rdzogs par 'dod/ /
This strong aspiration toward great enlightenment, This indefatigability of the wise, Relates to the grounds that are held to be Incomplete, complete, and absolutely complete. [XIX.25]
brtan pa'i bstan bcos shes pa nyid/ / gzhi dang ched du bya ba dang / / las dang mtshan nyid dag dang ni/ / mi zad nyid dang 'bras bu ni/ /
The steadfast ones’ knowledge of treatises Is superior in terms Of basis, objective, activity, Characteristics, inexhaustibility, [XIX.26]
yang dag 'grub pas khyad par 'phags/ / ting nge 'dzin dang gzungs sgos bsdus/ / sems can smin par byed pa dang / / dam chos 'dzin par byed pa'ang yin/ /
And the authentic accomplishment of the fruition. Comprising the gates of meditative absorption and retention, It matures sentient beings And upholds the sacred Dharma. [XIX.27]
brtan rnams 'jig rten shes pa nyid/ / lus dang ngag dang yid dag gis/ / bden pa shes pas mnyam pa med/ / de las gzhan pa dag las 'phags/ /
The steadfast ones’ knowledge of the world constitutes, Through body, speech, and mind, The knowledge of the truth, And is hence superior to others. [XIX.28]
brtan rnams rtag tu 'dzum par byed/ / gsong po dag tu smra ba yin/ / sems can snod du bya ba'i phyir/ / dam chos bsgrub par bya ba'i phyir/ /
The steadfast ones always smile, And they speak truthfully So as to turn sentient beings into vessels And enable them to practice the sacred Dharma. [XIX.29]
gang phyir bden pa gnyis kyis ni/ / 'jig rten rnams rtag 'byung bar 'dod/ / gnyis kyis nub 'gyur de yi phyir/ / de shes 'jig rten shes zhes bya/ /
It is held that the worlds Always arise due to two truths And fade away due to two truths. Hence the knower of this is termed “knower of the world.” [XIX.30]
de dag zhi ba thob bya'i phyir/ / blo ldan bden pa rnams la sbyor/ / gang gis blo ldan bden shes phyir/ / 'jig rten shes zhes nges par brjod/ /

For the sake of their pacification and attainment, The wise apply themselves to the truths. Because they possess knowledge of the truths, the wise Are definitively declared to be “knowers of the world.”[XIX.31]
gtsug lag brtan pa'i chos dang ni/ / de don dgongs pa can dang ni/ / nges don tshad mar ldan pa dang / / de yi brjod med thob pa'o/ /
There are the corpus of the Buddha’s teaching, The intended meaning, The definitive meaning endowed with reliability, And its ineffable attainment. [XIX.32]
spong dang ji skad bshad pa dang / / 'gog par yang dag shes pa dang / / brjod dang bcas par 'thob pa dag / 'dir ni dgag par bstan pa yin/ /
Rejection, literalism, Mistaken identification of the real, And an attainment that involves expression— Thus their refutation is shown. [XIX.33]
mos dang rnam par dpyod pa dang / / gzhan las ji bzhin thos pa dang / / rjod pa med pa'i ye shes las/ / brtan rnams nyams par mi 'gyur ro/ /
Inspiration, discernment, Correct reception from others, And ineffable wakefulness— From these the steadfast ones will not fall. [XIX.34]
rnam grangs dang ni mtshan nyid dang / / tshig dang ye shes shes pa'i phyir/ / byang chub sems dpa'i yang dag rig / bzhi po mtshungs pa med par 'dod/ /
In being the knowledge of categories, characteristics, Words, and wakefulness, The fourfold correct awareness Of the bodhisattvas is held to be supreme. [XIX.35]
bstan pa la ni rab brtson pa'i/ / gang zhig gang gis ston pa ni/ / chos dang don ni gnyis po dag / tshig dang shes pa kho nas ston/ /
The teaching and the means of teaching Of those diligently exerting themselves in teaching Consists of the pair of Dharmas and meanings Taught exclusively through words and knowledge. [XIX.36]
chos ni bstan dang bshad phyir dang / / rnam pa kun du gnyis thob phyir/ / rgol ba rnams kyi lan 'debs phyir/ / so so yang dag rig pa bzhi/ /
The Dharma presented and explained, The two thoroughly attained, And opponents responded to—it is for these reasons That correct awareness is fourfold. [XIX.37]
mnyam nyid so so rang rig nas/ / phyis ni rab tu shes pa yin/ / the tshom thams cad gcod byed pa/ / so so yang dag rig par brjod/ /
Having gained individual direct awareness regarding equality, Thorough knowledge follows. As all doubts are cut through, This is known as “correct awareness.” [XIX.38]
byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi tshogs/ / bsod nams ye shes mtshungs pa med/ / gcig gis 'khor bar mngon mtho byed/ / gzhan gyis nyon mongs med par 'khor/ /

The accumulations of the bodhisattvas Are unequaled merit and wakefulness; With one comes elevation within cyclic existence, And with the other one participates in cyclic existence free from affliction. [XIX.39]
sbyin dang tshul khrims bsod nams kyi/ / tshogs yin shes rab ye shes kyi/ / gsum po gzhan ni gnyis ka'i ste/ / lnga car yang ni ye shes tshogs/ /
Generosity and discipline are the accumulation of merit, And insight is wakefulness; The other three belong to both, But all five are also the accumulation of wakefulness. [XIX.40]
rgyun du sgom pa thob nas ni/ / dge la yang dang yang du sgrub/ / brtan pa'i tshogs gang yin pa de/ / don kun sgrub par byed pa yin/ /
With the continuous accomplishment of cultivation, One practices virtue again and again; These accumulations of the steadfast ones Accomplish all objectives. [XIX.41]
'jug dang mtshan ma med pa dang / / lhun gyis grub par bya ba dang / / dbang bskur mthar thug bya ba'i phyir/ / brtan rnams tshogs ni sgrub par byed/ /
For the sake of access, absence of marks, Spontaneous accomplishment, Empowerment, and perfection, The steadfast ones practice the accumulations. [XIX.42]
blo ldan dran pa nyer gzhag pa/ / bsgom pa rnam pa bcu bzhi yis/ / mtshungs pa med pa'i phyir na de/ / de las gzhan las khyad par 'phags/ /
The wise practice the applications of mindfulness By means of fourteen features That render them unequaled And superior to any others. [XIX.43]
rten dang gnyen po dag dang ni/ / de bzhin rjes su 'jug pa dang / / dmigs pa dang ni yid byed dang / / thob pas bsgom pa khyad par 'phags/ /
Support, remedies, Engagement, focal point, Directing the mind, and attainment— Thus their practice is superior. [XIX.44]
mthun dang rjes su 'jug pa dang / / yongs su shes dang skye ba dang / / chen po dang ni mchog nyid dang / / bsgom dang yang dag 'grub pas gzhan/ /
Accordance, harmonious engagement, Thorough knowledge, birth, Magnificence, supremacy, training, And true accomplishment—these are different. [XIX.45]
brtan pa rnams kyi yang dag spong / / lus can rnams dang mtshungs pa med/ / dran pa nye bar gzhag pa yi/ / nyes pa rnams kyi gnyen por bsgom/ /
The steadfast ones’ authentic eliminations Cannot be matched by embodied beings; These are cultivated as the remedy For flaws in the application of mindfulness. [XIX.46]
'khor ba nye bar spyad pa dang / / sgrib pa dag ni dor ba dang / / yid la byed pa dor ba dang / / sa rnams la ni 'jug pa dang / /
Fully partaking of cyclic existence, Discarding the obscurations, Discarding the directing of the mind, Entering the grounds, [XIX.47]
mtshan ma med par gnas pa dang / / lung bstan pa ni thob pa dang / / sems can rnams yongs smin bya dang / / dbang ni bskur bar bya ba dang / /
Abiding without marks, Obtaining prophecy, Thoroughly ripening sentient beings, Becoming empowered, [XIX.48]
zhing rnams dag par bya phyir dang / / mthar thug nyid du bya ba'i phyir/ / byang chub sems dpa' blo ldan rnams/ / mi mthun phyogs kyi gnyen por bsgom/ /
Thoroughly cultivating the fields, And reaching perfection— With these objectives the wise bodhisattvas Cultivate the remedies for the conflicting factors. [XIX.49]
'dun pa la ni brten nas su/ / rnal 'byor rgyu mtshan bcas bsgom pa/ / yang dag spong ba thams cad la/ / gnyen po zhes ni nges par brjod/ /
Based on aspiration, one engages In spiritual practice endowed with its features. All of the authentic eliminations Are definitively referred to as “remedies.” [XIX.50]
brtan pa rnams kyi rdzu 'phrul gyi/ / rkang pa mtshan nyid mchog ldan bzhi/ / bdag nyid dang ni gzhan dag gi/ / don kun 'grub pa'i phyir skye'o/ /
The steadfast ones’ bases of miraculous power Possess supreme characteristics and are four in number. They arise for the sake of the accomplishment Of one’s own and all others’ objectives. [XIX.51]
rten dang rab tu dbye ba dang / / thabs dang mngon par sgrub pa yis/ / blo ldan rdzu 'phrul rkang pa rnams/ / rnam pa kun tu rnam gzhag 'dod/ /
Support, divisions, Means, and full accomplishment— These are held to constitute a thorough classification Of the steadfast ones’ bases of miraculous power. [XIX.52]
bsam gtan pha rol phyin brten nas/ / rab tu dbye ba dag dang thabs/ / rnam bzhi mngon par sgrub pa ni/ / rnam pa drug tu brjod pa yin/ /
Based on transcendent concentration, The types and the means are four; The full accomplishment is explained To involve six features. [XIX.53]
gcig ni 'bad par byed pa ste/ / gnyis pa phan 'dogs bdag nyid yin/ / gsum pa gtod par byed pa ste/ / bzhi pa gnyen po pa yin no/ /
The first engenders effort, The second contributes, The third places, And the fourth is the remedy. [XIX.54]
mthong ba dang ni gdams ngag dang / / gnas pas rnam par rtse ba dang / / smon lam dang ni dbang dag dang / / chos thob pa ni sgrub pa'i phyir/ /
Vision, instruction, Reveling by way of abidance, Aspiration, mastery, and attainment of qualities— Such is the cultivation. [XIX.55]
byang chub spyod dang thos mchog dang / / zhi gnas lhag mthong dad sogs kyi/ / gzhi yin par ni shes bya ste/ / don sgrub byed pa'i skabs kyis so/ /
Enlightenment, conduct, supreme learning, Calm abiding, and special insight— These should be known as the bases for faith and the rest In the context of accomplishing the objectives. [XIX.56]
dad sogs sa la 'jug pa ste/ / kun nas nyon mongs can du 'dod/ / mi mthun phyogs nyam chung bas yang / / de dag nyid la stobs zhes bya/ /

Faith and the rest bring access to the grounds, But are held to be associated with thorough affliction; Because the conflicting factors have weakened, This set is nevertheless known as “powers.” [XIX.57]
sar zhugs rnams la byang chub kyi/ / yan lag rnam par gzhag par 'dod/ /
The classification of the aspects of enlightenment Is held to pertain to those who have entered the ground. [XIX.58a–b]
chos rnams dang ni sems can kun/ / mnyam pa nyid du rtogs phyir ro/ /
Because they have realized That phenomena and all sentient beings are equality. [XIX.58c–d]
shes byas rgyal rgyal bya yi phyir/ / dran pa dag ni kun tu spyod/ / 'di yi rnam 'byed rtog pa yi/ / mtshan ma thams cad 'joms par byed/ /
For the conquest of objects of knowledge not yet conquered, Mindfulness is fully active; With their thorough discernment, they crush All the marks of thought. [XIX.59]
'di yi brtson 'grus ma lus pa/ / myur du rtogs par bya phyir 'jug / chos kyi snang ba rnam 'phel ba'i/ / dga' bas rtag tu rgyas par 'gyur/ /
With diligence they apply themselves So that they may quickly know all without exception. As the light of Dharma spreads, Their joy is always on the increase. [XIX.60]
sgrib pa kun las thar ba'i phyir/ / shin tu sbyangs pas bde ba 'thob/ / ting nge 'dzin las bsams pa'i don/ / 'byor ba nye bar skye bar 'gyur/ /
Escaping all obscurations, They gain the bliss of agility. Through meditative absorption, they experience The fulfillment of all wishes. [XIX.61]
btang snyoms kyis ni thams cad du/ / 'di ni ji ltar 'dod bzhin gnas/ / rjes la thob dang mi rtog pa'i/ / gnas pas mchog ni rtag tu gnas/ /
With equanimity they abide throughout, Just as they please; Abiding in subsequent attainment and nonconceptuality, They abide always supreme. [XIX.62]
yon tan de lta'i sems dpa' ni/ / 'khor los sgyur ba 'dra bar 'jog / rtag tu rin chen bdun lta bu'i/ / byang chub yan lag rnams kyis bskor/ /
Bodhisattvas endowed with such qualities Are likened to universal monarchs; Resembling the seven jewels, The aspects of enlightenment are their constant retinue. [XIX.63]
rang bzhin yan lag gnas yan lag / gsum pa nges 'byung yan lag ste/ / bzhi pa phan yon yan lag yin/ / rnam gsum nyon mongs med yan lag /
de yi 'og tu ji lta ba/ / rtogs pa'i rjes su 'jug pa ste/ / rnam gzhag ji bzhin rtogs pa dang / / rnam par gzhag la 'jug pa dang / /
Beyond that, one applies oneself In harmony with the realization; Thus one correctly realizes the principles And engages with those principles. [XIX.65]
las gsum rnam par dag pa dang / / shes bya dag dang lam dang ni/ / yon tan khyad par can gyi ni/ / sgrib pa'i gnyen por sgom pa'o/ /
The threefold action is purified. That which is to be known, the path, And the special qualities— One cultivates the remedies for that which obscures them. [XIX.66]
yang dag gnas pa la brten nas/ / sems la sems ni 'jog phyir dang / / chos rab rnam par 'byed pa'i phyir/ / zhi gnas dang ni lhag mthong yin/ /
Based on genuine rest, Mind is placed within mind And fully discerns phenomena; Hence, this is calm abiding and special insight. [XIX.67]
de ni kun 'gro cha gcig dang / / cha gcig ma yin rgyur 'dod do/ / rtogs dang nges par 'byung ba dang / / mtshan med 'du mi byed pa dang / /
These are held to be universal, partial, Not partial, and the cause. Realization, definitive emergence, Absence of marks, nonformation, [XIX.68]
yongs dag rnam par dag pa la/ / brten pa'i zhi gnas lhag mthong gi / rnal 'byor de sa kun 'gro ste/ / thams cad sgrub par byed pa yin/ /
Complete purification, and total purity— The steadfast ones’ spiritual practice of calm abiding and special insight Is universally present on these grounds And accomplishes everything. [XIX.69]
sangs rgyas chos rnams rdzogs bya dang / / sems can rnams yongs smin bya dang / / myur thob bya ba 'grub pa dang / / lam rgyun mi gcod la mkhas pa/ /
Perfection of buddha qualities, Thorough maturation of sentient beings, Swift attainment, accomplishment of activities, And skill in not severing the continuum of the path—[XIX.70]
byang chub sems dpa'i sa kun la/ / thabs ni mtshungs pa med pa ste/ / thabs mkhas de la brten nas ni/ / de dag don kun sgrub par byed/ /
Upon all the grounds of the bodhisattvas, The means are incomparable. Thus, based on their skill in means, They accomplish all objectives. [XIX.71]
rnam smin thos la goms pa dang / / ting nge 'dzin gyi gzungs dag ni/ / chung ngu dang ni chen po ste/ / chen po de yang rnam pa gsum/ /
The retentions based on ripening, Familiarity with learning, and meditative absorption Are lesser and greater; The greater are threefold. [XIX.72]
blo ldan ma zhugs zhugs pa yang / / ma dag sa pa rnams kyi ni/ / chung ngu dang ni 'bring po ste/ / dag pa'i sa pa'i gzungs chen yin/ /
Regarding the wise who have not entered, and those who have, The retentions of those abiding on impure grounds Are lesser and middling, While on the pure grounds they are great. [XIX.73]
byang chub sems dpa' yang dang yang / / de la yang dag brten nas ni/ / rtag tu dam pa'i chos dag kyang / / rab tu ston cing 'dzin par byed/ /
As they again and again Fully rely on these, The bodhisattvas constantly Reveal and retain the sacred Dharma. [XIX.74]
brtan pa rnams kyi smon lam ni/ / sems pa 'dun dang bcas pa ste/ / de ni ye shes kyis bskul ba/ / sa rnams kun la mnyam pa med/ /
The steadfast ones’ aspiration Is attention accompanied by intention; Motivated by wakefulness, It is unequaled upon all the grounds. [XIX.75]
de ni rgyu gyur shes bya ste/ / sems tsam las ni 'grub pa'i phyir/ / sems las mod la 'bras bu can/ / de ni ma 'ongs don 'grub byed/ /
It should be known to serve as cause, Because accomplishment follows from mind only. While, due to mind, it does indeed carry fruit, It accomplishes the aims of the future. [XIX.76]
sna tshogs che dang byang chub par/ / sa rnams gong nas gong du ni/ / rnam dag byang chub sems dpa' yi/ / rang bzhin don rab sgrub byed yin/ /
Diverse and magnificent up to enlightenment, From one ground to the next, It becomes increasingly pure, Accomplishing in full the bodhisattva’s aims for self and others. [XIX.77]
ting 'dzin gsum gyi spyod yul ni/ / bdag med rnam pa gnyis po dang / / bdag tu 'dzin pa'i rten dang ni/ / de rtag nyer zhi yin zhes bya/ /

The sphere of activity of the threefold meditative absorption Consists of the twofold absence of self, The support for the grasping of self, And its so-called lasting and thorough pacification. [XIX.78]
de ni gzung 'dzin ngo bo'i phyir/ / rnam pa gsum du shes par bya/ / rnam par mi rtog rgyab kyis phyogs/ / rab tu dga' dang ldan pa'o/ /
Since in essence this is the apprehending of the apprehended, It should be known to be threefold— Nonconceptuality, turning away, And possession of great joy. [XIX.79]
yongs su shes dang spang ba dang / / mngon sum du ni bya ba'i phyir/ / stong nyid la sogs ting 'dzin rnams/ / don rnam gsum du yongs su bsgrags/ /
In terms of thorough knowledge, abandonment, And direct perception, The meditative absorption in emptiness and the rest Are widely known to have three objectives. [XIX.80]
sems can rnams la phan bzhed pas/ / ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyu nyid du/ / chos kyi sdom ni rnam pa bzhi/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams la bshad/ /
With the wish to benefit sentient beings, And as the cause of meditative absorption, A fourfold summary of the Dharma Is taught to the bodhisattvas. [XIX.81]
brtan pa rnams kyi bzhi po de/ / med pa'i don dang rnam rtog don/ / kun du rtog don kho na dang / / rnam rtog nye bar zhi ba'i don/ /
For the steadfast ones, these four Carry the meaning of absence, Thought, nothing but imagination, And the complete pacification of thought. [XIX.82]
mi rung rgyu las skye phyir dang / / 'gal phyir rang nyid mi gnas phyir/ / med phyir mtshan nyid nges phyir dang / / rjes su 'jug phyir 'gag pa'i phyir/ /
The reasons are inappropriateness, causal arising, Conflict, its own lack of remaining, Nonexistence, definitive characteristics, Pursuit, cessation, [XIX.83]
yongs su 'gyur ba dmigs phyir dang / / de rgyu nyid dang 'bras bu'i phyir/ / zin pa'i phyir dang bdag po'i phyir/ / dge dang sems can rjes 'jug phyir/ /
Observation of transformation, Cause and effect, Embrace, master, And concordance in terms of purity and sentient beings. [XIX.84]
dang po je bas je che dang / / rgyas dang rten gyi dngos po dang / / 'gyur dang yongs su smin pa dang / / de bzhin dman dang khyad par 'phags/ /
Initial, growing, Development, supportive entities, Change, thorough maturation, Inferiority and superiority, [XIX.85]
'od gsal ba dang 'od mi gsal/ / yul gzhan 'gro dang sa bon bcas/ / sa bon med pa'i ngo bo dang / / gzugs brnyan du ni skye ba ste/ /
Clear light and unclear light, Movement to another place, With seeds, without seeds, And birth in the form of a reflection—[XIX.86]
skye ba rnam pa bcu bzhi la/ / rgyu dang tshad kyi khyad par dang / / rgyas pa don med mi rung dang / / rten nyid du ni mi srid dang / /
These are fourteen modes of life. When considering them, differences in cause and size, Meaninglessness and impossibility of development, Impossibility of support, [XIX.87]
gnas pa la ni mi srid dang / / dang po mi 'jig mthar mi 'gyur/ / de bzhin dman dang khyad par 'phags/ / 'od gsal ba dang 'od mi gsal/ /
Impossibility in the case of remaining, Lack of initial disintegration implying final changelessness, Impossibility of inferiority and superiority, As well as clear light and unclear light, [XIX.88]
'gro med gnas pa mi rung dang / / tha ma nyid ni mi srid phyir/ / sems kyi rjes su 'jug pa'i phyir/ / 'dus byas thams cad skad cig ma/ /
No moving, impossibility of remaining, Of finality, and concordance with mind— These all go to show That all conditioned things are momentary. [XIX.89]
'byung ba rnams dang don rnam drug / skad cig nyid du brjod pa ni/ / skam dang 'phel dang rang bzhin gyis/ / g.yo dang 'phel dang 'grib pa'i phyir/ /
The elements and the six objects Are declared to be momentary Because of evaporation, increase, Movement by nature, increase and decrease, [XIX.90]
'byung ba de dang 'phel phyir dang / / yongs su 'gyur ba bzhi yi phyir/ / kha dog dri dang ro dang reg / 'dra phyir de ni de dang 'dra/ /
Relation with the former elements, The four types of change, Color, smell, taste, and tactility being similar, Rendering them similar to them, [XIX.91]
bud shing rag las 'jug pa'i phyir/ / je bas je cher dmigs pa'i phyir/ / sems rjes 'jug phyir dri ba'i phyir/ / des na phyi yang skad cig ma/ /
Function in dependence on fuel, Increase observed, Accordance with the mind, and inquiry. Therefore, the external is also momentary. [XIX.92]
gang zag btags par yod nyid du/ / brjod bya rdzas su ma yin no/ / mi dmigs phyin ci log pa dang / / kun nas nyon mongs nyon mongs rgyu/ /
The person should be considered existent nominally And not substantially. It is unobserved, mistaken, Thorough affliction, and the cause of affliction. [XIX.93]
nyes pa gnyis phyir de las 'di/ / gcig dang gzhan du brjod bya min/ / phung po bdag tu thal ba dang / / de rdzas nyid du thal 'gyur phyir/ /
Since two flaws ensue, It cannot be said to be identical or different; The aggregates would be the self, And the self would be substantial. [XIX.94]
gal te rdzas yod brjod min pa'i/ / dgos pa yang ni brjod dgos so/ / gcig dang gzhan du brjod min pa/ / dgos pa med par mi rigs so/ /
If it were substantial, the need for its being inexpressible Would have to be expressed; Inexpressibility in terms of oneness and difference Does not make any sense if not for any need. [XIX.95]
mtshan nyid dang ni 'jig rten na/ / mthong phyir bstan bcos sgo nas kyang / / bud shing me bzhin gnyis su ni/ / brjod min mi rung gnyis phyir ro/ /

When considering the characteristics, the perception of the world, As well as the treatises, It would not be right to say that, like fire and fuel, They cannot be determined to be two, because those are indeed two. [XIX.96]
gnyis yod rnam shes skye ba'i phyir/ / de rkyen ma yin don med phyir/ / de phyir lta ba po nas ni/ / grol bo'i bar du mi 'gyur ro/ /
Consciousness arises with the presence of two; That is no condition since it would serve no purpose. Hence, from the one that sees To the one that is liberated—it is not that. [XIX.97]
bdag po nyid cig yin na ni/ / mi rtag mi 'dod 'byung mi byed/ / de yis mtshan nyid bsgrub dgos te/ / rdzogs pa'i byang chub gsum la gnod/ /
If there were a single master, Impermanence and the undesired would not occur, Its characteristics would have to be established, And this would invalidate the triple complete enlightenment. [XIX.98]
nyes pa gsum phyir lta sogs la/ / de yi byed pa rang 'byung min/ / byed pa de yi rkyen can yang / / lta sogs byed pa med pa yin/ /

Because there are three flaws, The acts in terms of seeing and the rest are not self-arisen, The person is not a condition for those activities, And it is devoid of the activity of seeing and so forth. [XIX.99]
byed pa min phyir mi rtag phyir/ / cig car rtag tu 'jug pa'i phyir/ / lta la sogs pa'i byed pa ni/ / rang byung nyid du mi rung ngo / /

Because of not being an agent, because of impermanence, And because of simultaneous and constant engagement, The functions in terms of seeing and the rest Could not possibly be self-occurring. [XIX.100]
de bzhin gnas dang zhig pa ni/ / snga na med dang mi rtag dang / / phyogs gsum po yang med pa'i phyir/ / rkyen nyid du ni mi rung ngo / /
Accordingly, that which abides and disintegrates could— Because of prior nonexistence, impermanence, And the nonexistence of any third option— Not serve as a condition. [XIX.101]
'di ltar chos rnams thams cad ni/ / bdag med dam pa'i don du na/ / stong nyid bdag tu dmigs pa ni/ / nyes par bshad pa kho na yin/ /
Thus all phenomena are devoid of self And ultimately empty. The observation of a self is, hence, Exclusively taught to be a flaw. [XIX.102]
kun nas nyon mongs rnam byang ba'i/ / gnas skabs gcod pa'i bye brag dang / / 'jug dang rgyun gyi bye brag kyang / / gang zag gis ni nye bar bstan/ /

The particular distinctions between The contexts of thorough affliction and complete purification, The application, and the particularities of the continuity Are shown clearly by means of the person. [XIX.103]
bdag tu lta ba bskyed mi dgos/ / goms pa thog ma med dus can/ / gang zag yod na thams cad ni/ / 'bad med thar pa'am thar pa med/ /

The view of self need not be generated; Familiarity with that runs since time without beginning. If there were a person, everyone would either Be effortlessly liberated or not liberated at all. [XIX.104]
de ltar yon tan de dag dang / / rtag ldan byang chub sems dpa' ni/ / rang gi don yang mi 'dor zhing / / gzhan gyi don yang sgrub par byed/ /
Thus, always in possession of these qualities, The bodhisattvas do not Reject that which benefits themselves Yet accomplish the welfare of others. [XIX.105]
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ byang chub kyi phyogs dang mthun pa'i le'u ste bcu dgu pa'o// //
This was the nineteenth chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras, the chapter on the factors that accord with enlightenment.
20. [yon tan gyi le'u]
20. The Qualities
rang gi lus dang sdom pa'i phyir/ / phun sum tshogs pa yongs gtong dang / / nyam chung rnams la bzod pa dang / / lus dang srog la mi lta bar/ /
Completely relinquishing one’s own body And perfections for the sake of commitments, Tolerating the weak, Arousing diligence [XX.1]
brtson 'grus rtsom dang bsam gtan gyi/ / bde la ro myang med nyid dang / / shes rab la ni mi rtog pa/ / blo ldan rnams kyi ngo mtshar 'dod/ /
Without concern for body and life, Not dwelling in the bliss of concentration, And insight without thought— These are held to be the wonders of the wise. [XX.2]
de bzhin gshegs rigs skye ba dang / / lung bstan pa dang dbang bskur dang / / byang chub rab tu thob pa yang / / ngo mtshar che ba yin par 'dod/ /
Birth into the family of the thus-gone ones, And the thorough attainments of Prophecy, empowerment, and enlightenment Are likewise considered great wonders. [XX.3]
'dod chags bral dang snying brtse dang / / de bzhin bsgom mchog thob pa dang / / sems mnyam phyir na de dag la/ / sbyor ba ngo mtshar che ma yin/ /
Free from attachment and with a loving heart, Having accomplished supreme meditation And with their mind of equality, It is no wonder that they practice like this. [XX.4]
ji ltar blo ldan sems can la/ / rab tu byams par gyur pa ltar/ / sems can bdag dang chung ma dang / / bu bshes gnyen la de lta min/ /
The love of the wise For sentient beings Is unlike that which sentient beings Have for themselves, their spouse, children, or friends. [XX.5]
don gnyer ba la phyogs med dang / / tshul khrims rtag tu ma nyams dang / / kun du bzod cing thams cad phyir/ / brtson 'grus chen po rtsom pa dang / /
No partiality toward those with wants, Discipline that is never damaged, Forbearance in all regards, Great diligence for the sake of all, [XX.6]
rtag tu bsam gtan dge ba dang / / shes rab rnam par mi rtog nyid/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag la/ / de ltar sems mnyam shes par bya/ /
