Constantly virtuous concentration, And nonconceptual insight— Thus, the bodhisattva’s mind of equality Is to be understood in terms of these. [XX.7]
snod nyid du ni byed pa dang / / tshul khrims dag la 'god pa dang / / gnod pa la ni bzod pa dang / / don byed par ni 'gro ba dang / /
Turning them into vessels, Establishing them in discipline, Tolerating harm, Being active for their benefit, [XX.8]
bstan pa 'di la 'dzud pa dang / / the tshom gcod par byed pa 'di/ / blo ldan rnams kyi sems can la/ / phan 'dogs nyid du 'dod pa yin/ /
Leading them into the teachings, And cutting through their doubts— These are held to be the way in which the wise Bring benefit to sentient beings. [XX.9]
gang dag rtag tu sems can rnams/ / bsam pa mnyam pas 'dzin byed cing / / 'phags pa'i sa la skyed pa dang / / dge ba 'phel bar byed pa dang / /
Always do they uphold sentient beings With their mind of equality. They let them take birth on the grounds of the noble ones And enhance their virtue, [XX.10]
nyes byas las ni yongs srung dang / / thos pa byang bar byed pa ni/ / las lnga dag gis rgyal sras rnams/ / sems can ma dang 'dra ba yin/ /
Fully save them from misdeeds, And bring them learning. Thus, by these five activities the children of the victorious ones Are like mothers to sentient beings. [XX.11]
sems can kun la rtag par ni/ / dad pa skyed par byed pa dang / / lhag pa'i khrims sogs slob pa dang / / rnam par grol la sbyor ba'i phyir/ /
In sentient beings They always engender faith. They train them in special discipline and so forth And let them reach liberation, [XX.12]
sangs rgyas la ni gsol ba dang / / de dag sgrib pa spong ba'i phyir/ / las lnga dag gis rgyal sras rnams/ / sems can pha dang 'dra ba yin/ /
They supplicate the buddhas And eliminate their obscurations. Thus, by these five activities the children of the victorious ones Are like fathers to sentient beings. [XX.13]
gang dag bstan par mi 'os pa/ / sems can rnams la gsang byed cing / / bslab las nyams la smod pa dang / / phun sum tshogs pa bsngags pa nyid/ /
That which cannot be taught They keep secret from sentient beings. Criticizing flawed training While praising excellence, [XX.14]
gdams ngag sbyin par byed pa dang / / bdud rnams sbron par byed pa ste/ / las lnga dag gis rgyal sras rnams/ / sems can rtsa lag 'dra ba yin/ /
They grant instructions And drive away the demons. Thus, by these five activities the children of the victorious ones Are like relatives to sentient beings. [XX.15]
kun nas nyon mongs rnam byang la/ / gang dag rang blo ma 'khrul ba/ / 'jig rten 'jig rten min pa yi/ / phun tshogs zad par sbyin par byed/ /
With their own minds free from delusion Regarding thorough affliction and complete purification, They grant all possible excellence, Both in terms of the world and what lies beyond it. [XX.16]
skyo ba med pas mi phyed cing / / rtag tu phan dang bde 'dod pa/ / las lnga dag gis rgyal sras rnams/ / sems can grogs po 'dra ba yin/ /
Tireless and unshakable, They constantly wish for benefit and happiness. Thus, by these five activities the children of the victorious ones Are like friends to sentient beings. [XX.17]
gang dag sems can smin bya la/ / rtag tu brtson pa dang ldan zhing / / yang dag nges par 'byung ba smra/ / log par sgrub pa rnams la bzod/ /
To ripen sentient beings, They always abide by diligence, Express genuine deliverance, Tolerate ingratitude, [XX.18]
phun sum tshogs pa gnyis sbyin byed/ / de yi thabs la mkhas pa ni/ / las lnga dag gis rgyal sras rnams/ / sems can bran dang 'dra ba yin/ /
And provide the two excellences With expertise about the means. Thus, by these five activities the children of the victorious ones Are like servants to sentient beings. [XX.19]
gang dag mi skye'i chos la ni/ / bzod pa thob par 'dod pa dang / / theg pa thams cad ston pa dang / / rnal 'byor grub par sbyor ba dang / /
Wishing for the attainment Of acceptance of nonarising phenomena, They teach all vehicles and apply themselves For the sake of the accomplishment of spiritual practice. [XX.20]
bzhin mdzes lan du phan 'dogs dang / / rnam par smin la mi lta ba/ / las lnga dag gis rgyal sras rnams/ / sems can slob dpon 'dra ba yin/ /

Their countenance is beautiful, and they have no concern For benefit and ripening in return. Thus, by these five activities the children of the victorious ones Are like teachers to sentient beings. [XX.21]
sems can don la shin tu brtson/ / tshogs rnams rdzogs par byed pa dang / / tshogs bsags myur du grol bar byed/ / mi mthun phyogs ni spong byed cing / /

Exerting themselves for the benefit of beings, They bring the accumulations to completion, And those who have gathered the accumulations they quickly release, Letting them eliminate the conflicting factors. [XX.22]
'jig rten 'jig rten ma yin pa'i/ / phun sum tshogs pa la sbyor ba/ / las lnga dag gis rgyal sras rnams/ / sems can mkhan po 'dra ba yin/ /
They provide excellence that is Of the world and beyond it. Thus, by these five activities the children of the victorious ones Are like preceptors to sentient beings. [XX.23]
longs spyod rnams la ma chags dang / / tshul khrims nyams pa med pa dang / / byas pa gzo dang ldan pa dang / / sgrub pa la yang sbyor ba'i phyir/ /
No attachment to possessions, Flawless discipline, Grateful recognition, And application of the practice—[XX.24]
pha rol phyin pa drug po la/ / de ltar 'jug pa'i lus can dag / byang chub sems dpa' rnams la ni/ / de bzhin lan du phan 'dogs yin/ /
These are the ways In which embodied beings Established in the six transcendences Repay the kindness of the bodhisattvas. [XX.25]
rtag tu 'phel dang nyams pa dang / / sems can rab tu smin pa dang / / sa la khyad par 'gro ba dang / / bla na med pa'i byang chub 'dod/ /
They always wish for increase and decrease, Full maturation of sentient beings, Gaining distinction upon the grounds, And unsurpassable enlightenment. [XX.26]
'jigs spang yang dag bskyed pa dang / / the tshom dag ni gcod pa dang / / sgrub pa yi ni gdams ngag la/ / rgyal sras rtag tu chud mi za/ /
By means of abandonment of fear and true generation, Cutting through doubts And instructions for practice, The children of the victorious ones let nothing be wasted. [XX.27]
re ba med pa'i sbyin pa dang / / yang srid mi 'dod tshul khrims dang / / thams cad la ni bzod pa dang / / yon tan kun 'byung brtson 'grus dang / /
Generosity without expectation, Discipline free from wishes for future lives, Patience that tolerates all, Diligence from which good qualities emerge, [XX.28]
de bzhin bsam gtan gzugs med min/ / shes rab thabs dang ldan pa ni/ / pha rol phyin pa drug po la/ / brtan pa rnams kyi yang dag sbyor/ /
Concentration that is not formless, And insight endowed with means— These six transcendences Are the authentic practice of the steadfast ones. [XX.29]
longs spyod chags dang nyams bcas dang / / nga rgyal nyid dang bsod nyams dang / / ro myang ba dang rnam rtog ni/ / brtan pa rnams kyi nyams pa'i rgyu/ /
Attachment to enjoyments, faults, Pride, indulgence, Relishing the taste, and thoughts— These cause the decline of the steadfast. [XX.30]
de dag gnyen po la gnas pa'i/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi ni/ / de las bzlog phyir khyad par gyi/ / skal can chos su shes par bya/ /
The opposite is the case With bodhisattvas abiding by their remedies. Hence, those are to be known As the factors that bring progress. [XX.31]
sprul pa dang ni tshul 'chos dang / / bzhin mdzes pa ni ston pa dang / / de bzhin 'phral la 'jug pa dang / / lus dang ngag ni zhi ba dang / /
Pretense, hypocrisy, Showing a nice face, Sporadic engagement, Subdued body and mind, [XX.32]

de bzhin smra mkhas phun sum tshogs/ / de dag sgrub dang bral ba ni/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams dag gi / yang dag min pa nyid du bshad/ / bzlog par rab tu sbyor rnams kyi/ / de dag yang dag nyid du bshad/ /
And perfect expertise in teaching— Divorced from practice, These are explained to be The bodhisattvas’ falsity. The opposite, thorough engagement, Is taught to be their authenticity. [XX.33]
blo ldan de dag sa kun du/ / sbyin la sogs pa nyer bsgrubs pas/ / sems can rnams kyi mi mthun phyogs/ / rnam pa drug ni 'dul bar byed/ /
On all the grounds, the wise Accomplish the practices of generosity and so forth. Thereby they tame the six Conflicting factors in sentient beings. [XX.34]
gang zag dus kyi bye brag gis/ / blo ldan lung bstan rnam pa gnyis/ / byang chub dang ni lung ston pa/ / gzhan yang chen por brjod pa ni/ /
In terms of the person and time, the prophecies Regarding the wise are twofold. There is prophecy of enlightenment, of prophecy, And another, referred to as “great,” [XX.35]
mi skye bzod pa thob pa yi/ / nga rgyal rtsol ba spangs pa dang / / sangs rgyas sras bcas thams cad dang / / ngo bo gcig tu gyur pa las/ /
Which is due to having gained acceptance of nonarising, Having relinquished pride and efforts, And having become of the same nature As all the buddhas and bodhisattvas. [XX.36]
yang de zhing dang ming dang ni/ / dus dang bskal pa'i ming dang ni/ / 'khor dang dam pa'i chos dag kyang / / gnas pa'i sgo nas der 'dod do/ /
Likewise, it is held to encompass the field, name, Time, and name of the aeon, The retinue, and the remaining Of the sacred Dharma. [XX.37]

blo ldan rnam pa thams cad du/ / phun tshogs skyed dang mi skyo dang / / rtag tu sgom par byed pa dang / / ting 'dzin nyams pa med pa dang / / bya ba 'grub dang lhun grub pa'i/ / bzod pa 'thob la nges par 'gyur/ /
For the wise, Excellence, life, absence of weariness, Constant practice, No decline in meditative absorption, And spontaneously accomplished acceptance Are all definitively attained. [XX.38]

mchod bslab yang dag blang ba dang / / snying rje dge ba bsgom pa dang / / de bzhin dgon par bag yod dang / / thos don ngoms mi shes pa nyid/ / sa rnams kun la brtan pa yi/ / gdon mi za bar bya ba nyid/ /

Offerings, genuinely assuming the training, Compassion, virtuous practice, Heedfully dwelling in solitude, And never having enough of the meaning of what one learns— On all the grounds these are without a doubt To be engaged in by the steadfast ones. [XX.39]
'dod pa'i nyes dmigs shes pa dang / / 'khrul pa dag la rtog pa dang / / sdug bsngal dang du len nyid dang / / dge ba dag ni sgom pa dang / /
Knowing the flaws of attachment, Keeping check on delusions, Joyfully accepting suffering, Practicing virtue, [XX.40]
bde la ro myang med nyid dang / / mtshan ma rnam par mi rtog pa/ / sa rnams kun la brtan pa yi/ / rtag tu bya ba dag yin no/ /
Avoiding the relish of bliss And not conceiving of marks— On all the grounds these are constantly To be engaged in by the steadfast ones. [XX.41]

chos sbyin tshul khrims dag pa dang / / mi skye bzod pa thob nyid dang / / theg chen brtson 'grus rtsom pa dang / / mtha' la snying rje ldan gnas dang / / shes rab blo dang ldan rnams kyi/ / pha rol phyin pa'i gtso bor 'dod/ /

Granting the Dharma, the discipline of purity, Attaining acceptance of nonarising, Arousing diligence in the Great Vehicle, Abiding by compassion in the final one, And insight—these are held to be the wise ones’ Foremost pursuits in terms of the transcendences. [XX.42]
mdo sogs rnam pa'i bye brag gis/ / rig pa'i gnas ni rnam gzhag pa/ / sa rnams kun la brtan pa yi/ / chos rnams gzhag pa yin zhes bya/ /
The fields of knowledge are classified By means of the distinctions in the sūtras and so forth. On all the grounds, these are known As “the steadfast ones’ classification of the Dharma.”[XX.43]
de bzhin nyid ni rnam bdun la/ / brten nas bden pa rnam par gzhag /
The classification of the truths Is based on seven types of suchness. [XX.44a–b]
rigs pa theg pa rnam gzhag pa/ / rnam pa bzhi dang rnam gsum nyid/ /
The classification of reasoning and vehicles Is fourfold and threefold. [XX.44c–d]
tshul bzhin yid la byed pa dang / / yang dag lta ba 'bras ldan dang / / tshad mas rnam 'byed bsam mi khyab/ / rigs pa bzhir ni shes par bya/ /

Correctly directing the mind, The authentic view, possession of the fruition, Discernment by reliable means of knowledge, and the inconceivable— These are known as the four principles of reasoning. [XX.45]
bsam pa dang ni bshad nyid dang / / sbyor ba dang ni tshogs dag dang / / 'grub pa'i rab tu dbye ba yis/ / theg pa rnam pa gsum du 'dod/ /
In terms of the differences In intent, explanation, Engagement, accumulations, and accomplishment, The vehicles are held to be threefold. [XX.46]
ming dang dngos dag phan tshun du/ / glo bur ba ni nyid du btsal/ / 'dogs pa rnam pa gnyis po 'dir/ / de tsam nyid du tshol ba'o/ /
Names and entities are, upon investigation, Seen to be mutually adventitious. The two designations are here Investigated as just that. [XX.47]
thams cad dmigs su med pa'i phyir/ / yang dag ye shes rnam pa bzhi/ / sa rnams kun la brtan pa yi/ / don kun sgrub par byed par 'gyur/ /
All are unobservable, Hence, the fourfold authentic wakefulness Accomplishes on all the grounds The objectives of the steadfast ones. [XX.48]
'ching ba yi ni rten dag dang / / longs spyod sa bon rgyu mtshan 'dir/ / sems dang sems las byung ba rnams/ / rten bcas sa bon bcas te bcings/ /
Support, enjoyments, and seeds Are the causes of bondage; Mind and mental states, Along with their supports and seeds, are bound here. [XX.49]
mdun bzhag mtshan ma gang yin dang / / bdag nyid 'dug pa gang yin pa/ / thams cad rnam 'jig blo ldan gyis/ / byang chub mchog ni thob par 'gyur/ /
The marks that are placed in front And those that are present by themselves Are all destroyed by the wise one Who attains supreme enlightenment. [XX.50]
de bzhin nyid dmigs shes pa dang / / gnyis su 'dzin pa rnam spangs dang / / gnas ngan len lus mngon sum pa/ / blo ldan de zad byed par 'dod/ /
Knowledge that witnesses suchness, Elimination of dualistic grasping, And direct perception of the body of negative tendencies— It is held that the wise one accomplishes exhaustion. [XX.51]
de bzhin nyid dmigs ye shes ni/ / rnam pa tha dad med bsgoms shing / / yod dang med don mngon sum pa/ / rnam rtog dbang 'byor nyid ces bya/ /
The wakefulness witnessing suchness Practices without distinction. The direct perception of the facts of existence and nonexistence Is known as “the mastery of thought.” [XX.52]
byis pa yang dag nyid bsgribs nas/ / yang dag ma yin kun du snang / / byang chub sems dpa' de bsal nas/ / yang dag nyid ni kun du snang / /
For the childish, the genuine is obscured And so falsity appears everywhere; The bodhisattvas dispel that And so reality appears everywhere. [XX.53]
don med pa dang don yod dag / mi snang snang ba yin zhes bya/ / de ni gnas gzhan gyur pa ste/ / 'dod dgur spyod phyir thar pa yin/ /
That which is known as the nonappearance and appearance Of the meaningless and the meaningful Is fundamental transformation. Since one can do as one pleases, this is liberation. [XX.54]
don chen rnam pa thams cad du/ / gzhan dang gzhan rigs mthun snang ba/ / bar chad byed yin de lta bas/ / yongs shes byas nas de spang ngo / /
The vast object is in all contexts The similar appearance of things that are distinct. As it is an obstacle, this is to be given up By means of thorough knowledge. [XX.55]
yongs smin rnam par sbyang bya dang / / thob bya smin par rung bya dang / / yang dag bshad pa'i dngos po ni/ / blo ldan rnams kyi dpag tu med/ /
To be thoroughly matured, completely purified, Attained, suited for maturation, And authentically explained— These are, in the case of the wise, unfathomable. [XX.56]
byang chub sems ni skye ba dang / / mi skye ba yi bzod pa nyid/ / dri med mig ni dman pa dang / / zag pa zad pa nyid dang ni/ /
Birth of the enlightened mind, Acceptance of nonarising, The inferior stainless eye, The exhaustion of defilement, [XX.57]
dam chos yun ring gnas pa dang / / bye brag shes spyod longs spyod nyid/ / de la zhugs pa blo ldan gyi/ / bshad pa'i 'bras bu yin zhes bya/ /

The long-lasting presence of the sacred Dharma, Knowledge of particularities, cutting through, and enjoyment— These are to be known as the fruits Of the teaching of the wise ones who are committed to that. [XX.58]
dmigs pa che ba nyid dang ni/ / de bzhin sgrub pa gnyis dag dang / / ye shes brtson 'grus rtsom pa dang / / thabs la mkhas par gyur pa dang / /
The vast focal point, The twofold practice, Wakefulness, the arousing of diligence, Skill in means, [XX.59]
yang dag 'grub pa chen po dang / / sangs rgyas phrin las chen po ste/ / chen po 'di dang ldan pa'i phyir/ / theg chen zhes ni nges par brjod/ /
Great authentic accomplishment, And the great buddha activity— As it possesses such greatness, It is definitively referred to as the “Great Vehicle.” [XX.60]
rigs dang chos la mos pa dang / / de bzhin sems ni bskyed pa dang / / sbyin la sogs pa sgrub pa dang / / skyon med pa la 'jug nyid dang / /
There is potential, inspiration with respect to the Dharma, Engendering the mind, Practicing generosity and the rest, Entering the flawless, [XX.61]
sems can rnams yongs smin byed dang / / zhing ni rnam par sbyong ba dang / / mi gnas mya ngan 'das pa dang / / byang chub mchog dang ston pa'o/ /
Thoroughly ripening sentient beings, Cultivating the fields, Nonabiding transcendence of suffering, Supreme enlightenment, and the display. [XX.62]

gcig ni mos pa dang ldan pa/ / lhag pa'i bsam pa dag pa gzhan/ / mtshan ma dang ni mtshan med dang / / mngon par 'du byed med spyod pa/ / lnga po 'di dag sa kun la/ / byang chub sems dpa' yin zhes bya/ /

Some possess inspiration, Others superior pure intent. Some engage with marks, some with absence of marks, And some with nonformation. These five are understood to be The bodhisattvas of all the stages. [XX.63]
'dod la ma chags las gsum rnam par dag / khro ba zil gnon yon tan mchog lhur len/ / chos las mi g.yo de nyid zab mo mthong / / byang chub dga' ldan byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /

Free from attachment to pleasures, pure in the three activities, Subduing anger, appropriating supreme qualities, Not moving away from the Dharma, seeing the profound reality, And endowed with the joy of enlightenment—such are bodhisattvas. [XX.64]
phan 'dogs 'dod dang gnod pa med lta dang / / gzhan gyi gnod pa dang du len pa dang / / brtan pa bag yod mang du thos pa dang / / gzhan gyi don brtson byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /
Wishing to benefit, not wanting to harm, Happily accepting harm from others, Steadfast, heedful, possessing vast learning, And pursuing the welfare of others—such are bodhisattvas. [XX.65]
rang gis yongs su gzung ba'i nyes dmigs shes/ / longs spyod ma chags zhe la khon mi 'dzin/ / rnal 'byor rgyu mtshan la mkhas lta ngan med/ / nang du rab gnas byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /

Aware of the flaws of possessions, Not attached to enjoyments, never holding a grudge, Expert about the marks of spiritual practice, free from negative views, And thoroughly abiding within—such are bodhisattvas. [XX.66]
brtse dang ldan pa ngo tsha yon tan gnas/ / sdug bsngal dang len rang gi bde ma chags/ / dran gtso shin tu mnyam par bzhag pa'i bdag / theg pa mi 'khrugs byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /

Loving and conscientious, Accepting suffering, not attached to their own happiness, Relying on mindfulness as the primary, of the nature of utter equipoise, And unshakable regarding the vehicles—such are bodhisattvas. [XX.67]
sdug bsngal sel ba sdug bsngal mi byed nyid/ / sdug bsngal bzod pa sdug bsngal 'jigs pa med/ / sdug bsngal rnam grol sdug bsngal mi rtog pa/ / sdug bsngal khas len byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /

The dispeller of suffering, not the creator of suffering, Tolerating suffering, fearless about suffering, Free from suffering, not conceiving of suffering, And acknowledging suffering—such are bodhisattvas. [XX.68]
chos la mi dga' rang bzhin chos la dga'/ / chos la smod cing chos la mngon par brtson/ / chos la dbang ba chos la mun pa med/ / chos gtsor byed pa byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /

Displeased with phenomena, delighting in natural phenomena, Scorning phenomena, persisting with phenomena, Mastering phenomena, being unobscured about phenomena, And relying on phenomena—such are bodhisattvas. [XX.69]
longs spyod bag yod nges la bag yod dang / / bsrung la bag yod dge la bag yod dang / / bde la bag yod chos la bag yod dang / / theg pa bag yod byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /

Heedful about possessions, heedful about the definitive, Heedful about protecting, heedful about virtue, Heedful about bliss, heedful about the Dharma, And heedful about vehicles—such are bodhisattvas. [XX.70]
ma gus ngo tsha nyes chung ngo tsha dang / / mi bzod ngo tsha yongs nyams ngo tsha dang / / rnam 'phro ngo tsha lta chung ngo tsha dang / / theg gzhan ngo tsha byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /
Shamed by disrespect, shamed by minor faults, Shamed by impatience, shamed by decline, Shamed by diffusing, shamed by a lesser view, And shamed by other vehicles—such are bodhisattvas. [XX.71]
'di dang pha rol dang ni btang snyoms dang / / 'du byed ldan dang dbang 'byor nyid thob dang / / mtshungs par ston dang 'bras bu chen po yis/ / byang chub sems dpa' phan 'dogs byed la 'jug /
Here and beyond, equanimity, Engagement in formation, possession of mastery, Appropriate teaching, and the great fruition— By these means the bodhisattvas serve. [XX.72]
byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' che/ / blo ldan nyid dang gsal ba'i mchog / rgyal sras rgyal ba'i gzhi dang ni/ / rgyal byed rgyal ba'i myu gu dang / /
They are bodhisattvas, great beings, The wise, supremely clear, Children of the victorious ones, ground of the victorious ones, Conquerors, shoots of the victorious ones, [XX.73]
rtsal ldan dang ni 'phags mchog dang / / ded dpon dang ni grags mchog dang / / snying rje can dang bsod nams che/ / dbang phyug de bzhin chos dang ldan/ /
Powerful ones, supremely noble ones, Captains, supremely renowned ones, Compassionate ones, greatly meritorious ones, Masters, and possessors of Dharma. [XX.74]
de nyid bzang rtogs don chen legs rtogs dang / / don kun rtogs dang kun du rtogs pa dang / / thabs rnams rtogs par 'gyur ba'i khyad par rgyu/ / des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ /

Excellent realization of reality, proper realization of the great aim, Universal realization, constant realization, And realization of the means— For these special reasons, they are known as “bodhisattvas.” [XX.75]
bdag rjes rtogs dang lta ba phra rtogs dang / / rnam rig sna tshogs rnam par rtogs dang kun/ / yang dag min rtog yin par rtogs pa'i rgyu/ / des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ /
Realizing the self, realizing the subtle view, Realizing variegated awareness, And realizing that all is the false imagination— Because of such realization, they are known as “bodhisattvas.” [XX.76]
ma rtogs rtogs dang rjes su rtogs pa rtogs/ / dngos med rtogs dang rab tu skye ba rtogs/ / ma rtogs rtogs pa so sor rtogs pa'i rgyu/ / des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ /

Realizing the unrealized, realizing the subsequent realization, Realizing the absence of entities, realizing emergence, And realizing the lack of realization— Because of such discriminating realization, they are known as “bodhisattvas.” [XX.77]
don med rtogs dang don dam rtogs pa dang / / don kun rtogs dang mtha' dag don rtogs dang / / rtogs bya rtogs gzhi rtogs pa rtogs pa'i rgyu/ / des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ /

Realizing the lack of reality, realizing ultimate reality, Realizing all reality, and realizing the entire reality; Realizing the object of realization, the basis of realization, and the realization— Because of such realization, they are known as “bodhisattvas.” [XX.78]
grub par gyur pa rtogs dang gnas rtogs dang / / lhums rjes rtogs dang rim pa rtogs pa dang / / rab tu rtogs dang the tshom bsal rtogs rgyur/ / des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ /

Realizing the accomplishment, realizing the abode, Realizing the womb, realizing the stages, Realizing thorough realization and the dispelling of doubts— Because of such realization, they are known as “bodhisattvas.”[XX.79]
blo dang ldan pa blo thob ma thob dang / / rab gnas rtogs dang rjes su rtogs pa dang / / so sor 'chad blo rjod med nga bcom dang / / nga can blo gros ma smin yang dag smin/ /

The wise possess a mind of the attained, unattained, and thoroughly abiding, Realization and subsequent realization, Discriminating discernment and ineffability, where “I” is destroyed and “I” is involved, Intelligence that is immature and truly mature. [XX.80]
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ yon tan gyi le'u ste nyi shu pa'o// //
This was the twentieth chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras, the chapter on the qualities.

d.crumb: 21. spyod pa dang mthar thug pa

f.d: 21. [spyod pa dang mthar thug pa'i le'u]
21. Activity and Perfection
brtse dang snyan par smra ba dang / / brtan pa nyid dang lag brkyang nyid/ / dgongs pa zab mo nges 'grel pa/ / 'di dag blo ldan rnams kyi rtags/ /
Love, pleasant speech, Steadfastness, openhandedness, And definitive explanation of the profound intent— These are signs of the wise. [XXI.1]
yongs gzung mos pa thob pa dang / / mi skyo gnyis kyis bsdu ba'i phyir/ / bsam pa dang ni sbyor ba las/ / rtags lngar rnam par shes par bya/ /

In terms of embracing, achieving interest, Absence of weariness, and the twofold magnetizing, It should thus be known that, in relation to intent and application, Five signs are differentiated. [XXI.2]
byang chub sems dpa' rtag tu ni/ / khyim pa 'khor los sgyur rnams su/ / gyur nas skye ba thams cad du/ / sems can rnams kyi don byed do/ /
Bodhisattvas will always Become universal monarchs And so as householders Benefit sentient beings. [XXI.3]
sa rnams kun la blo ldan gyi/ / rab byung len pas thob pa dang / / chos nyid kyis ni thob pa gzhan/ / rab tu byung bar ston byed yin/ /
On all the grounds, the wise Obtain ordination by receiving it, Just as they obtain it by the power of the intrinsic nature. Moreover, they also display ordination. [XXI.4]
rab tu byung ba'i phyogs dag ni/ / yon tan tshad med rnams dang ldan/ / de ltas sdom brtson khyim pa yi/ / byang chub sems dpa' las khyad 'phags/ /
Those who are ordained Possess limitless qualities; Those who persevere in the vows are therefore Superior to householder bodhisattvas. [XXI.5]
sa rnams kun la brtan pa yi/ / pha rol sdug pa'i 'bras bu dang / / 'di la dge ba 'jug 'dod dang / / mya ngan 'das par 'dod pa dang / / ma dag rnam dag rab dag pa/ / sems can rnams la bsam par 'dod/ /

On all the grounds, the steadfast ones’ Wishes for beautiful results beyond, Engagement with virtue within this life, And the transcendence of suffering Are impure, pure, and extremely pure. This is the assertion regarding their intent for sentient beings. [XXI.6]
sa rnams kun la blo ldan pa'i/ / smon lam dang ni sems mnyam dang / / bdag por gyur pa dag dang ni/ / 'khor sdud pa yis yongs su 'dzin/ /
On all the grounds, the wise Embrace beings by means of aspiration, The mind of equality, Being the ruler, and magnetizing a retinue. [XXI.7]
blo ldan rnams kyi las dang ni/ / gzhan yang smon lam dag dang ni/ / ting nge 'dzin dang dbang 'byor pa'i/ / dbang gis skye bar 'dod pa yin/ /
It is held that the wise Will be born because of karmic action, Yet also by the power of aspiration, Meditative absorption, or mastery. [XXI.8]
mtshan nyid gang zag bslab pa dang / / phung po grub pa rtags dang ni/ / nges pa'i tshig dang thob pa yis/ / gnas pa dang ni sa nyid do/ /
Characteristics, persons, trainings, Aggregates, accomplishment, signs, Etymology, and attainment— Such is the treatment of the abodes and grounds. [XXI.9]
stong pa nyid ni mchog rtogs nas/ / las rnams chud mi za bar gnas/ / bsam gtan rab bdes gnas nas ni/ / de yi 'og tu 'dod par skye/ /

Having arrived at the supreme realization of emptiness, One dwells upon the nondissipation of karmic actions. Having abided in the thoroughly enjoyable concentrations, One next takes birth into the realm of desire. [XXI.10]
de nas byang chub phyogs mthun rnams/ / 'khor ba dag tu yongs su bsngo/ / sems kun nyon mongs med par ni/ / sems can rnams yongs smin par byed/ /
From there, the factors of enlightenment Are thoroughly dedicated to the realms of cyclic existence. As the mind is free from afflictions, One thoroughly ripens sentient beings. [XXI.11]
ched du bsams te skye bas na/ / kun nas nyon mongs rjes su srung / / bgrod pa gcig pa'i lam dang 'brel/ / mtshan med gcig tu nges pa'i lam/ /
As one purposely takes birth, One is safeguarded against the afflictions. Connected to the single traversed path, The path is universally ascertained to be devoid of marks. [XXI.12]
mtshan ma med par lhun gyis grub/ / zhing yang rnam par sbyong ba ste/ / de yi 'og tu sems can ni/ / smin par byed pa 'grub par 'gyur/ /
Spontaneously established within the absence of marks, One cultivates the fields. Beyond that, the ability to ripen sentient beings Will be accomplished. [XXI.13]
ting nge 'dzin dang gzungs rnams dang / / byang chub rnam par dag pa nyid/ / rnam par bzhag pa 'di dag gis/ / sa yi mtshan nyid shes par bya/ /
There are meditative absorptions and retentions, And enlightenment is perfectly pure. The characteristics of the grounds Are to be understood by these principles. [XXI.14]
byang chub sems dpa' lta ba rnam dag pa/ / tshul khrims shin tu rnam dag mnyam par gzhag / chos la nga spangs rgyud dang kun nyon mongs/ / rnam par bya ba tha dad nga rgyal med/ /

The bodhisattvas possess pure view, Perfectly pure discipline, and equipoise. They have given up pride regarding the Dharma, streams of being, And the distinction between thorough affliction and complete purification. [XXI.15]
skad cig gcig blo thob pa btang snyoms pa/ / zhing rnams sbyong ba sems can smin byed par/ / mkhas pa mthu chen lus yongs rdzogs pa dang / / nges par ston la mkhas pa dbang bskur yin/ /

They attain instantaneous wakefulness, equanimity, Cultivation of fields, skill in ripening sentient beings, Great power, the body that is perfectly complete, Skill in definitive display, and empowerment. [XXI.16]
chos nyid rab tu rtogs nas 'dir/ / lhag pa'i tshul khrims lhag sems dang / / lhag pa'i shes rab la rjes slob/ / shes rab spyod yul gnyis yin te/ /
Having thoroughly realized the intrinsic nature, They here subsequently train In special discipline, attention, and insight. The sphere of engagement through insight is twofold: [XXI.17]
chos kyi de nyid dang de ni/ / mi shes shes sogs 'jug pa nyid/ / shes rab spyod yul de lta bas/ / de sa gnyis la rnam par gnas/ /

The real nature of phenomena and the processes that ensue From the lack of knowledge and knowledge of that. This being the sphere of engagement through insight, It is encountered on two grounds. [XXI.18]
bslab pa rnams dang bsgom pa yis/ / 'bras bu gzhan ni rnam pa bzhi/ / mtshan med 'du byed dang bcas par/ / gnas pa 'bras bu dang po yin/ /
Additionally, there are four results Of the trainings and meditations. Absence of marks and the presence of formation— Abiding in that is the first fruition. [XXI.19]
de nyid mngon 'du byed med dang / / zhing ni rnam par dag pa dag / 'bras bu gnyis par 'dod pa yin/ / sems can smin par 'grub nyid dang / /
The same without formation, Along with the pure fields, Is held to be the second fruition. The accomplishment of the maturation of beings [XXI.20]
ting nge 'dzin dang gzungs rnams ni/ / 'grub pa 'bras bu dam pa yin/ / 'bras bu rnam pa 'di bzhi ni/ / sa bzhi po la yang dag brten/ /
And the accomplishment of the meditative absorptions and retentions Are held to be authentic fruitions. These four fruitions Are supported by four grounds. [XXI.21]
chos nyid rab tu rtogs nas 'dir/ / tshul khrims kyi ni phung po sbyong / / de yi 'og tu ting 'dzin dang / / shes rab phung po rnam par sbyong / /
Having thoroughly realized the intrinsic nature, The aggregate of discipline is here subsequently cultivated. Next the aggregates of meditative absorption And insight are cultivated. [XXI.22]
de las gzhan pa dag la ni/ / sgrib rnam bzhi dang thogs pa yi/ / sgrib pa las kyang rnam grol dang / / grol ba'i ye shes rnam par sbyong / /
The remaining ones consist of the disappearance Of the four obscurations, as well as the obscuration of impediment. They are thus the cultivation Of liberation and liberated wakefulness. [XXI.23]
sa rnams thams cad ma grub dang / / grub pa dag tu shes par bya/ / grub pa dag kyang ma grub dang / / grub pa dag tu yang 'dod do/ /
All the grounds should be known To be unaccomplished and accomplished. Those accomplished are, moreover, also Held to be unaccomplished and accomplished. [XXI.24]
grub pa ji ltar rnam bzhag bzhin/ / yid la byed pas de rtog par/ / shes pa'i phyir dang de nyid la/ / rnam mi rtog phyir rnam shes bya/ /
The accomplishment should be understood to occur By directing the mind in accord with the classifications, Thereby knowing that it is thinking, And not having any thoughts about that. [XXI.25]
so sor rang rig bya phyir dang / / sangs rgyas rnams kyi yul gyi phyir/ / sa rnams kun la bsgom pa dang / / grub pa yang ni bsam mi khyab/ /

Because they are the objects of individual direct awareness, And because they are the objects of the buddhas, Meditation and accomplishment transcend, Upon all the grounds, that which is conceivable. [XXI.26]
snang dang bcas dang mos pa dang / / ma zhum pa dang mi dman nyid/ / gzhan dring mi 'jog bdag nyid dang / / thams cad rab tu rtogs pa dang / /
Appearance, inspiration, No faintheartedness, no deficiency, Independence from others, Clear realization of all, [XXI.27]
kun la sems ni mnyam pa dang / / bkri dang rjes su chags med dang / / thabs shes 'khor du skye ba ni/ / kun la rtags su 'dod pa yin/ /
A mind of equality toward everyone, Not being led, absence of attachment, Knowledge of skillful means, and birth in the retinue— Throughout, these are held to be the signs. [XXI.28]

'dun pa med pa ma yin chags dang 'khu ba'i snying med khro med le lo med/ / byams dang snying rje min pa'i bsam med blo gros ngan rtog rnam rtog 'phrogs pa med/ / blo gros rnam par g.yengs min bde bas mi 'phrogs sdug bsngal dag gis gnod pa med/ / dge ba'i bshes la nye bar brten cing thos pa lhur len ston pa mchod la brtson/ /

They do not lack motivation, are unattached, free from hostility, have no anger, are free from laziness, Have no thoughts other than love and compassion, have intelligence that is free from negative thoughts and thinking, Have intelligence that is free from distractions, are not brought down by pleasures, not hurt by suffering, Follow the spiritual teacher, persist in learning, and diligently worship the teacher. [XXI.29]

thabs mchog shes pa gang zhig bsod nams yang dag bsdus pa shin tu rgya chen kun/ / gzhan dang thun mong byas nas nyin gcig bzhin du rdzogs pa'i byang chub yongs bsngo zhing / / bzang po'i gnas su skyes pas rtag tu dge byed mngon shes yon tan rnams kyis brtsen/ / sangs rgyas sras de kun gyi bla na 'dug pa yon tan gter du shes par bya/ /

Knowing the supreme methods, they fully gather all of the extremely vast virtues And share them with others in dedication to complete enlightenment every single day. Born in excellent places, they always do good, sporting with qualities of superknowledge. Such children of the buddhas are to be known as superior to everyone; they are treasuries of excellent qualities. [XXI.30]
sa rnams kun la rnam kun tu/ / blo ldan rnams kyi phan yon ni/ / zhi gnas lhag mthong gnyis ka la/ / lnga po'i bdag nyid dag tu 'dod/ /
On all the grounds and in all regards, The benefits for the wise Are held to be of a fivefold nature In relation to calm abiding, to special insight, and to both. [XXI.31]
byang chub la ni nye ba dang / / sems can don sgrub mthong ba la/ / rab tu dga' ba skye 'gyur te/ / de phyir rab dga' zhes brjod do/ /
Seeing that enlightenment is near And that the welfare of sentient beings can be accomplished Produces great joy; Hence, this is known as the Joyous. [XXI.32]
'chal tshul rtsol ba'i dri bral phyir/ / dri ma med pa'i sa zhes bya/ / chos kyi snang ba chen po ni/ / byed pa'i phyir na 'od byed pa'o/ /
Since the stains of flawed discipline and effort are relinquished, It is known as the Stainless. As the great light of Dharma unfolds, It is called the Radiant. [XXI.33]
'di ltar byang chub phyogs mthun chos/ / rab tu sreg byed 'od lta bu/ / de dang ldan phyir sa de ni/ / gnyis po sreg pas 'od 'phro can/ /
On this ground, factors that accord with enlightenment Are like a flaming light. Therefore, as the two are burned away, It is known as the Flaming. [XXI.34]
sems can rnams yongs smin byed cing / / rang gi sems kyang bsrung ba'i phyir/ / blo ldan rnams kyis sbyang dka' ba/ / de phyir sbyang dka' zhes bya'o/ /
Sentient beings are thoroughly ripened, And one’s mind remains guarded; As it is hence hard to conquer for the wise It is known as Hard to Conquer. [XXI.35]
shes rab pha rol phyin brten nas/ / 'khor ba dang ni mya ngan 'das/ / gnyis 'dir mngon du gyur pa'i phyir/ / mngon du gyur pa'i sa zhes bshad/ /
Based on transcendent insight, Both cyclic existence and the transcendence of suffering Are here manifest. Hence, it is known as the ground of the Manifest. [XXI.36]
bgrod gcig lam dang 'brel pa'i phyir/ / ring du song ba'i sar 'dod do/ / 'du shes gnyis kyis mi g.yo'i phyir/ / mi g.yo ba zhes nges par brjod/ /
Connected with the single traversed path, It is known as Far Reaching. Unmoved by either identification, It is referred to as the Unshakable. [XXI.37]
so so yang dag rig blo bzang / / sa de legs pa'i blo gros yin/ / sprin bzhin gnyis kyis nam mkha'i chos/ / khyab pa'i phyir na chos kyi sprin/ /
Endowed with the excellent intelligence of correct awareness, This ground is Excellent Intelligence. Like clouds, the two pervade the field of space. Thus it is the Cloud of Dharma. [XXI.38]
dge ba sgrub pa sna tshogs la/ / dga' bas rtag par thams cad du/ / gnas phyir byang chub sems dpa' yi/ / sa rnams gnas pa yin par 'dod/ /
With joy they constantly abide In the practice of all sorts of virtue; Therefore, the grounds of the bodhisattvas Are held to be abodes. [XXI.39]
'byung po dpag med 'jigs med phyir/ / dpag tu med pa de dag la/ / phyi phyir gong du 'gro ldan phyir/ / de dag nyid ni sar 'dod do/ /
To liberate the innumerable sentient beings from fear, These immeasurable ones support A continuously increasing development; Hence, they are held to be grounds. [XXI.40]
sa 'thob pa ni mos pa dang / / spyod pa dag la 'jug pa dang / / rtogs pa'i phyir dang sa rnams ni/ / 'grub pa'i sgo nas rnam pa bzhi/ /
The attainment of the grounds is fourfold In terms of the inspired, Entry into the activities, Realization, and accomplishment. [XXI.41]

lus can theg pa chen po dang / / theg pa dman la mos pa rnams/ / gnyis ka 'dun par bya ba dang / / gdul ba'i phyir ni brtan rnams kyi/ / spyod pa bzhi po mdo bzhin du/ / rjes su 'brangs nas bshad pa yin/ /

In order to inspire and to tame Embodied beings who are motivated By both the Great And the Inferior Vehicle, The four activities of the steadfast ones Have been explained by relying on the sūtras. [XXI.42]
sems can rnams la brtse ba can/ / phrad dang bral ba'i dgongs pa can/ / mi 'bral ba yi dgongs pa can/ / phan bde dgongs khyod la phyag 'tshal/ /
You who have love for sentient beings, Who are intent on their meeting, their separating, Their never separating, and their benefit and happiness— To you, I prostrate. [XXI.43]
thub pa sgrib kun nges par grol/ / 'jig rten thams cad zil gyis gnon/ / khyod kyi mkhyen pas shes bya khyab/ / thugs grol khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Able One, definitively free from all obscurations, You command the entire world, And your wakefulness pervades all objects of knowledge— I prostrate to you, whose heart is free. [XXI.44]
sems can dag ni thams cad kyi/ / nyon mongs ma lus thams cad 'joms/ / nyon mongs 'joms mdzad nyon mongs la/ / brtse bcas khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Conqueror of the afflictions Of all sentient beings, You conquer afflictions and have love for afflictions— To you, I prostrate. [XXI.45]
lhun gyis grub cing chags mi mnga'/ / thogs par mi mnga' rtag par ni/ / mnyam par bzhag cing 'dri kun gyi/ / lan ldon khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Spontaneously present and free from attachment, Unhindered and constantly in equipoise, You answer all questions— Homage to you. [XXI.46]
rten dang brten pa bshad bya dang / / gsung dang mkhyen pa 'chad byed la/ / blo gros rtag thogs mi mnga' ba/ / legs ston khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

Regarding the subject matter to be explained, the support and the supported, And the means for the explanation, the speech and the knowledge, Your intelligence can never be hindered— Homage to you, excellent teacher. [XXI.47]
gshegs nas spyod pa mkhyen mdzad de/ / de dag skad kyis sems can gyi/ / 'ong dang 'gro dang nges 'byung la/ / legs 'doms khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Moving to sentient beings and knowing their conduct, You teach, in their own languages, About coming, going, and deliverance— Homage to you, excellent instructor. [XXI.48]
lus can kun gyis khyod mthong na/ / skyes bu dam pa lags par 'tshal/ / mthong ba tsam gyis rab dang bar/ / mdzad pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
When corporeal beings see you, They recognize you as a holy being; Homage to you, toward whom fervent faith Arises simply upon sight. [XXI.49]
len dang gnas dang gtong ba dang / / sprul dang yongs su sgyur ba dang / / ting nge 'dzin dang ye shes la/ / mnga' brnyes khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Master of assuming, abiding, and relinquishing; Emanation and transformation, Meditative absorption and wakefulness— Homage to you. [XXI.50]
thabs dang skyabs dang dag pa dang / / theg chen nges par 'byung ba la/ / sems can rnams la rab slu ba'i/ / bdud 'joms khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
You conquer the demons who entirely deceive sentient beings With respect to means, protection, Purity, and deliverance through the Great Vehicle— Homage to you. [XXI.51]
rang gzhan don du ye shes dang / / spangs dang nges 'byung bgegs mdzad par/ / ston mdzad mu stegs gzhan dag gis/ / mi brdzi khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
The wakefulness, elimination, deliverance, and hindrances, Which pertain to the welfare of self and others, You declare without being disturbed by extremists or others— Homage to you. [XXI.52]
bsrung med bsnyel ba mi mnga' bar/ / 'khor gyi nang na bag brkyang gsung / / kun nas nyon mongs gnyis spangs pa/ / 'khor sdud khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Without anything to guard yet without forgetfulness, You speak readily within the assembly; Free from the two afflictions, you gather the circle— Homage to you. [XXI.53]
kun mkhyen khyod la rgyu ba dang / / gnas pa kun la rtag par ni/ / kun mkhyen min spyod mi mnga' ste/ / yang dag don ldan khyod phyag 'tshal/ /
All-Knowing One, as you move or remain, You are at all times free From any conduct that is not omniscient— Homage to you, possessor of the ultimate. [XXI.54]
sems can kun gyi bya ba la/ / khyod ni dus las mi 'da' bas/ / mdzad pa rtag tu don mnga' ba/ / mi bsnyel khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Acting for the benefit Of sentient beings without any delay, Your deeds are always beneficial— Homage to you, who do not know bewilderment. [XXI.55]
'jig rten kun la nyin mtshan du/ / lan drug tu ni so sor gzigs/ / thugs rje chen po dang ldan pa/ / phan dgongs khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Throughout the six times of day and night, You regard the entire world with discernment; Possessor of great compassion, Who is intent on benefiting—homage to you. [XXI.56]
spyod pa dang ni rtogs pa dang / / ye shes dang ni phrin las kyis/ / nyan thos rang sangs rgyas kun gyi/ / bla ma khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Due to your conduct, realization, Wakefulness, and activity, you are the master Of all listeners and self-realized buddhas— Homage to you. [XXI.57]
sku gsum dag gis byang chub che/ / rnam pa kun brnyes thams cad du/ / sems can kun gyi the tshom dag / gcod pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
With the three bodies, you have, in all regards, Attained great enlightenment; Dispeller of all the doubts of sentient beings— Homage to you. [XXI.58]
'dzin pa mi mnga' nyes mi mnga'/ / rnyog pa mi mnga' mi gnas pa/ / mi g.yo chos rnams thams cad la/ / spros med khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Free from grasping, free from flaws, Unsullied and beyond abiding, Unwavering and free from constructs regarding any phenomenon— Homage to you. [XXI.59]
dam pa'i don ni grub pa ste/ / sa kun las ni nges par byung / / sems can kun gyi mchog tu gyur/ / sems can thams cad rnam grol mdzad/ /
With ultimate accomplishment, You have emerged definitively beyond the grounds. Supreme among all beings, You are the liberator of all beings. [XXI.60]
yon tan mi zad mnyam med ldan/ / 'jig rten dag dang dkyil 'khor na'ang / / snang la lha dang mi rnams kyis/ / rnam pa kun tu mi mthong ngo / /
Possessing inexhaustible qualities beyond compare, You appear in the worlds and maṇḍalas, And yet to gods and humans, You remain imperceptible. [XXI.61]
de lta na yang de yi mthus/ / gdul bya'i skal ba ji bzhin du/ / srid pa ji ltar gnas kyi bar/ / de yi mdzad pa rgyun mi 'chad/ /
Still, by the power of that, there arises, In accordance with the fortune of those to be trained And for as long as there is existence, The continuous flow of activities. [XXI.62]
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ spyod pa dang mthar thug pa'i le'u ste nyi shu rtsa gcig pa'o// //
This was the twenty-first chapter of the Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras, the chapter on activity and perfection.
[mjug]
Colophons
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan ces bya ba'i tshig le'ur byas pa 'phags pa byams pas mdzad pa rdzogs so// //
This completes noble Maitreya’s composition Ornament of the Great Vehicle Sūtras.

rgya gar gyi mkhan po shAkya siM ha dang / zhu chen gyi lo tsA ba ban+de dpal brtsegs la sogs pas bsgyur cing zhus te gtan la phab pa/ slad kyi paN+Di ta pa ra hi ta dang / bram ze chen po sad dza na dang / lo tsA ba dge slong blo ldan shes rab kyis cung zad bcos legs par bshad nas gtan la phab pa'o// //

The translation was prepared, edited, and finalized by the Indian preceptor Śākyasiṁha and the great editor of lotsawas, the bandhe Paltsek. Later it was slightly modified and again finalized by the paṇḍita Parahita, the great Brahmin Sadjana, and the lotsawa-monk Loden Sherab, based on fine exposition.
mjug gi sh+lo ka gcig po 'di 'gro don 'phel ba dang gzhung gzhan na 'dug pa ltar bris pa'o// //
The final śloka has been entered, in accordance with what can be found in other scriptures, as a circumstance for increasing the benefits for beings.
mang+ga laM// //
Maṅgalam.
ye d+harmA he tu pra b+ha wA he tun+te ShAn+ta thA ga to h+ya wa data/ te ShAny+tsa yo ni ro d+ha e waM bA dI ma hA shra ma NaH// //

BY JAMGÖN MIPHAM
Names: Asaṅga, author. | Maitreyanātha. | Mi-pham-rgya-mtsho, Jam-mgon Ju, 1846–1912, writer of added commentary. | Comité de traduction Padmakara, translator.
@#/ /theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan gyi dgongs don rnam par bshad pa theg mchog bdud rtsi'i dga' ston ces bya ba bzhugs/

Title: A feast of the nectar of the supreme vehicle: an explanation of the Ornament of the Mahāyāna sūtras: Maitreya’s Mahāyānasūtrālaṅkāra / with a commentary by Jamgön Mipham; translated by the Padmakara Translation Group.
ĀRYA ASAṄGA (FOURTH CENTURY CE)
@#/ /na mo many+dzu shrI ku mArA b+hu tA ya/ /
Namo mañjuśrīkumārabhūtaya

mtshungs med ston pa shAkya'i rgyal po dang / / rgyal tshab sa bcu'i dbang phyug mi pham mgon/ / de yis rjes bzung 'phags pa thogs med zhabs/ / gang gi gsung skyes mkhas mchog dbyig gi gnyen/ / de'i slob mchog gyur dpal ldan blo gros brtan/ / de las rim brgyud dam pa'i tshogs rnams dang / / lam 'di'i bka' drin dngos su 'doms pa yi/ / bshes gnyen rnams la gus pas phyag byas nas/ /

To the incomparable Teacher, King of the Śākyas, The Regent, Lord of the Ten Levels, Invincible Protector,[1] His beloved disciple, Ārya Asaṅga, And to him who was inspired by his words, the sublime scholar Vasubandhu, To the glorious Sthiramati, his foremost student, The host of supreme beings in the lineage that came down from them, And to the spiritual masters, gracious explicators of this path, Respectfully I pay homage.
theg mchog chos kyi dga' ston 'gro kun la/ / rab bkye rgyal tshab chen po'i gsung rab 'dir/ / gcig tu gus shing gzhan la phan pa'i blos/ / rnam bshad theg mchog bdud rtsi'i dga' ston spro/ /

With total reverence for these, the Great Regent’s Excellent Words, This feast of the Supreme Vehicle teachings he gave for all beings, I shall explain them with others’ good in mind. Come now and feast upon the nectar of the highest way.

de yang shing rta chen po thogs med kyis chos kyi rgyun gyi ting nge 'dzin brnyes nas/ dga' ldan chos kyi pho brang du rgyal tshab mi pham mgon po'i zhal nas dngos su nod pa'i byams chos sde lnga'i ya gyal theg pa chen po'i mdo sde'i rgyan gyi gzhung khyad 'phags 'di nyid shin tu gsal bar go bde ba'i tshul du rnam par bshad pa la/ mtshan don/ 'gyur phyag / gzhung don/ mjug don bzhi las/

Here is a clear, easy-to-understand explanation of the extraordinary scriptural text entitled Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, one of the Five Treatises of Maitreya that the great charioteer Asaṅga, having attained the concentration of the stream of Dharma,[2] received in person from the regent Maitreya (“Invincible Protector”) in the Dharma palace of Tuṣita. It has four topics: the title, the translator’s homage, the actual text, and the conclusion.
dang po [mtshan don]/
THE TITLE
@##/ /rgya gar skad du/ ma hA yA na sU tra a laM ka ra nA ma kA ri kA/ bod skad du/ theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan zhes bya ba'i tshig le'ur byas pa/
In Sanskrit: Mahāyāna-sūtra-alāṃkāra-nāma-kārikā In Tibetan: Theg pa chen po mdo sde rgyan zhes bya ba’i tshig le’ur byas pa

rgya gar skad du/ ma hA yA na sU tra a laM kA ra nA ma kA ri kA/ bod skad du/ theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan zhes pa'i tshig le'ur byas pa zhes gsungs te/ chen po bdun dang ldan pa la theg pa chen po zhes bya la/ theg chen mdo sde rnams kyi dgongs pa 'byor ba'i don tshul bla med lnga'i tshul gyis gsal bar byed pa'i rgyan du gyur pas na/ bstan bcos 'di'i mtshan du mdo sde'i rgyan zhes bya zhing / de yang tshigs su bcad pa'i dbyangs kyis brjod pas na tshig le'ur byas pa zhes so/ /

The Sanskrit title is Mahāyāna-sūtra-alāṃkāra-nāma-kārikā, which in Tibetan is Theg pa chen po mdo sde rgyan zhes bya ba’i tshig le’ur byas pa (meaning “A composition in verse entitled Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras”). This treatise is an ornament that illuminates, by means of five unexcelled metaphors, the intended meaning of the sūtras of the Great Vehicle (so called because of seven features that make it great).[3] It was therefore given the title: “Ornament of the Sūtras.” And since it was melodiously expressed in verse, it is “a composition in verse.”
gnyis pa ['gyur phyag]
TRANSLATOR’S HOMAGE
sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas.
lo chen ska ba dpal brtsegs kyis gzhung 'di bod skad du bsgyur ba'i thog mar/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la phyag 'tshal lo zhes 'gyur phyag mdzad pa'o/ /
The scriptural source text was translated into Tibetan by the great translator Kawa Peltsek, who began with the translator’s homage: “Homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas.”
gsum pa gzhung don
THE ACTUAL TEXT
['di] la/ ji ltar rtsom pa'i tshul dang / de ltar brtsams pa'i bstan bcos kyi gzhung bshad pa gnyis/
The third topic, the actual text, consists of two parts: (1) an account of how the treatise was composed and (2) an explanation of the main text of the treatise.
[gleng gzhi]
INTRODUCTION
dang po [ji ltar rtsom pa'i tshul]
HOW THE TREATISE WAS COMPOSED

don shes don ston rab tu byed pa ngag dang tshig rnams dri med pas/ / sdug bsngal bsgral phyir de yi bdag nyid sdug bsngal 'gro la snying rje las/ / theg mchog bstan pa'i rnam pa chos kyi de yis 'gro ba'i sems can la/ / 'byor pa'i don tshul bla med gyur pa rnam lnga'i bdag nyid ston par byed/ / gser las brdungs byas 'dra zhing pad+ma rgyas pa bzhin/ / bkres pas nyen pa g.yos legs kha zas za ba 'dra/ / 'phrin yig legs pa thos 'dra rin chen sgrom phye lta'i/ / chos de 'dir bshad pa yang dga' ba'i mchog skyed do/ /

He who knows the meaning created a composition showing that meaning with flawless speech and phrasing Out of natural compassion for suffering beings in order to free them from suffering. For beings who follow the way expounded in the Supreme Vehicle He revealed the nature of five unexcelled metaphors: (I, 1) The crafting of a piece of gold, the blossoming of a lotus flower, Eating well-cooked food when starving, Hearing good news, and opening a chest of jewels— These illustrate the sublime delights the teachings set forth here will bring. (I, 2)
ces tshigs bcad gsum gyis bstan te/

byed pa po theg pa chen po'i mdo sde'i don shes pa dang / don de gzhan la ston par rab tu byed pa ngag dang tshig rnams dri ma med pas/ dgos pa sems can thams cad sdug bsngal las bsgral ba'i phyir/ rgyu snying rje de yi bdag nyid rnams sdug bsngal ba'i 'gro la snying rje chen po las/ thabs gang ston na theg pa mchog gi rnam pa bstan pa'i chos kyi'o/ / gang zag su la na/ theg pa mchog gi rnam pa de yis 'gro ba ste/ theg pa chen po'i lam gyis 'bras bu'i gnas su 'gro ba'i sems can nam gang zag theg chen pa'i tshogs la/ ji ltar na tshig dang don du 'brel zhing legs par 'byor pa'i don tshul gang zhig / theg pa chen po'i don can yin pas bla na med par gyur pa rnam pa lnga yi bdag nyid ston par byed de/

The author of this text was he who knew the meaning of the Mahāyāna sūtras and gave an explanation showing that meaning to others, with flawless speech and phrasing. His purpose was that all sentient beings should be liberated from suffering, and the causal basis was his natural compassion,[1] great compassion for beings who suffer. The method that he taught was the Dharma as expounded in the Supreme Vehicle. The individuals for whom he taught it were those who follow the Supreme Vehicle—namely, beings who are taking the Mahāyāna path to reach their goal, or the host of Mahāyāna practitioners. As to the manner in which he taught, he revealed the nature of five unexcelled metaphors (unexcelled because they contain the meaning of the Great Vehicle), in which the words and their meanings are perfectly connected.

lnga gang zhe na/ mgar ba mkhas pas gser las rna rgyan sogs brdungs pa byas pa dang 'dra zhing / me tog pad+ma kha phyes te rgyas pa bzhin dang / bkres pas nyen pa dag g.yos su legs par byas pa'i kha zas bzang po za ba dang / sems dga' bar byed pa'i 'phrin yig legs pa thos pa 'dra ba dang / rin chen sna tshogs kyi sgrom kha phye ba lta bu'i theg pa chen po'i chos 'di nyid bstan bcos 'dir bshad pa yang de ltar de dag la dga' ba'i mchog skyed par byed do zhes gsungs te/ skabs 'dir 'byor ba'i don tshul lnga'i sgo nas theg pa chen po'i mdo sde'i dgongs don gsal bar byed pa'i phyir mdo sde'i rgyan zhes bya ba yin pas de lnga'i don ji lta bu yin pa legs par ngos zin pa ni bstan bcos 'di'i dbu zhabs kyi don bsdus pa'i gnad yin pas 'og tu 'chad par bya'o/ /

What are these five? A skillful goldsmith’s fashioning of earrings and the like from gold. A lotus flower coming into full bloom. A starving person eating delicious, perfectly prepared food. Hearing good news that makes one happy. And opening a chest of all kinds of jewels. Such are the sublime joys that the explanations in this treatise—this Dharma of the Great Vehicle—produce. It is because the five metaphors are used to clarify the intended meaning of the Mahāyāna sūtras that we speak of them in this context as an “ornament of the sūtras.” It is essential to recognize the significance of these five, for they summarize the whole of this treatise, and they will therefore be explained below.

skabs 'dir bdag nyid chen po blo gros brtan pa'i 'grel par 'di ltar gsungs te/ bstan bcos 'dis byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa zab cing rgya che ba thams cad gsal bar byed pa yin la/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa mdor bsdu na gsum ste/ gang la slob pa/ ji ltar slob pa/ gang dag gis slob pa gsum las/ dang po gnas bdun gyis bsdus te/ rang don dang / gzhan don dang / de kho na nyid dang / mthu dang / bdag gi sangs rgyas kyi chos yongs su smin pa dang / sems can yongs su smin pa dang / bla med rdzogs byang la slob pa ste de ltar bdun no/ / ji ltar bslab par bya ba la/ thog mar theg chen gyi chos la mos pa mang bar bya ba dang / chos tshol ba dang / chos ston pa dang / chos dang mthun pa'i chos bsgrub pa/ yang dag pa'i gdams ngag dang rjes su bstan pa la gnas pa/ lus ngag yid kyi las thabs kyis zin par bya ba ste rnam pa drug gi tshul gyis so/ / gang dag gis slob pa ni byang chub sems dpa' ste/ de'i bye brag bsdu na bcu ste/ rigs la gnas pa dang / zhugs pa dang / bsam pa ma dag pa dang / bsam pa dag pa dang / bsam pa yongs su ma smin pa dang / bsam pa yongs su smin pa dang / nges pa ma yin par rtogs pa dang / nges par rtogs pa dang / skye ba gcig gis thogs pa dang / srid pa tha ma pa'o/ / byang sems de thams cad kyi ming / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' che/ / blo dang ldan pa sogs gzhung ltar ro/ / bstan bcos kyi lus ni 'di yin no zhes gsungs/

In this context, let us look at what the great being Sthiramati says in his commentary. According to him, this treatise explains all the profound and extensive practices of the bodhisattvas, which can be summarized under three headings: what to train in, how to train, and who is training. The first of these, what one trains in, can be condensed into seven objects in which one trains: one’s own welfare, others’ welfare, thatness, powers, bringing one’s own buddha qualities to maturity, bringing others to maturity, and unsurpassable perfect enlightenment. How one trains is in six ways: by first developing a great interest in the teachings of the Great Vehicle, investigating the Dharma, teaching the Dharma, practicing the Dharma in accord with the teachings, persevering in the correct instructions and follow-up teachings, and imbuing one’s physical, verbal, and mental activities with skillful means. Those who train are the bodhisattvas, of whom there are ten categories: those who are of the bodhisattva type, those who have entered the Great Vehicle, those with impure aspirations, those with pure aspirations, those whose aspirations are not matured, those whose aspirations are matured, those with uncertain realization, those with certain realization, those who are delayed by a single birth,[2] and those who are in their last existence. The names of all these bodhisattvas are Heroes of Enlightenment, Great Heroes, The Wise, and so on, as explained in the text.[3] These points, says Sthiramati, constitute the approach taken in this treatise.

de yang don shes don ston sogs kyi tshigs bcad gnyis so/ /brda sprod pa'i sgra'i gtsug lag las rnam dbye bdun bshad pa dang mtshungs par/ byed pa po dang / las dang / byed pa dang / de'i phyir dang / rgyu'i don dang / yan lag gi don dang / ched kyi don te bdun pos rim pa bshad tshul gsungs pa 'dir/ de'i phyir zhes pa de'i ched du zhes pa rnam dbye bzhi pa ched don gyi ming ste/ sgra'i gzhung las sbyin pa zhes kyang bshad de/ gang gi ched du sbyin pa de ched don gyi ming du brjod do/ / rgyu'i don zhes pa 'byung khungs kyi don dang / yan lag gi don zhes pa drug pa 'brel sgra'i ming ste/ sgra'i gzhung kha cig las/ hasti zhes pa lag pa'am yan lag mtshon byed de/ mchod sbyin gyi lag pa lta bu dang / ched kyi don zhes pa skabs 'dir rnam dbye bzhi pa ched don ma yin gyi theg chen gyi gang zag gi ched du yin pas gang zag de la brten pa rten gnas kyi don can yin te/ sgra'i gzhung 'gar rnam dbye bdun pa'i ming du/ mit+ta sap+ta zhes mtshan ma bdun par brjod pa de yin no/ / de la las su bya ba'i don can gtso cher byas nas 'grel chen las 'di ltar bshad de

He goes on to describe how the elements in the first two verses (“He who knows the meaning…”) can be explained respectively in terms of the seven cases taught in the texts on grammar—namely, the nominative, accusative, instrumental, purposive, causative, appendant, and intentional cases.[4] Here, what he calls the purposive denotes the fourth case, the dative, as is also explained in the grammars—using the example of “giving”: “giving for someone’s benefit” denotes the purpose. What he calls the causative case refers to the ablative. His “appendant case” is the sixth case, the genitive: according to some grammars, the Sanskrit word hasti indicates a hand or appendage, as in “the hand of Chöjin.” The intentional case, in this context, is not the fourth grammatical case, the dative, but signifies the locative, in the sense that since this text is intended for individuals in the Mahāyāna, it depends on (or is located in) those individuals. In some grammars, the seventh case is called nimittasaptami, the attributive case. On this basis, putting the emphasis on the accusative, the long commentary explains the first verse as follows.

byed pa po'am chos kyi ngo bo gang zhig rgyan par byed ce na/ don shes zhes pas theg pa chen po'i mdo sde ni brgyan bya'i ngo bo'am gzhi'o/ / ji ltar na bstan bcos 'dis theg chen mdo sde rnams kyi don shes par byed pa'i tshul gyis brgyan to/ / las su bya ba mdo sde gang de la bstan bcos 'dis ji ltar brgyan pa'i bya ba 'jug na/ de'i don 'dis ston par byed pas so/ / byed pa gang gis na/ ngag dang tshig dri med pas so/ / de ltar rgyan par byed pa de ci zhig gi ched du yin na/ sdug bsngal bsgral phyir zhes so/ / de rgyu ci las byung na/ de yi bdag nyid sdug bsngal 'gro la snying rje las zhes so/ / de gang su dang 'brel zhe na/ theg mchog bstan pa'i chos kyi zhes bstan bcos 'di theg pa chen po'i bka' dang yan lag can dang yan lag lta bur 'brel bar ston to/ / de gang zag gang la brten pa yin zhe na/ rnam pa de yis 'gro ba'i sems can la/ / zhes theg pa chen po'i gang zag gi ched don yin pas de yi rgyud la brten pa ste shing la bya bzhin no/ / 'grel chen las gsungs pa go dka' bar snang bas 'dir gnad gsal bar mdor bsdus te brjod pa'o/ /

What is the agent or entity that is doing the ornamenting? It is “He who knows the meaning,” the Mahāyāna sūtras constituting the entity or basis that is ornamented. How are they ornamented? With this treatise, in its enabling us to understand the meaning of the Mahāyāna sūtras. How does he engage in the action of ornamenting those sūtras (the object) with this treatise? By indicating their meaning. With what means? With flawless speech and phrasing. For what purpose does it so ornament them? “To free them from suffering.” What is the causal factor out of which it arises? It arises “out of natural compassion for suffering beings.” What is it connected with? “The way expounded in the Supreme Vehicle,” showing that this treatise is related to the Mahāyāna scriptures in the same way that a branch is connected to a tree. And on what kind of person does it depend? On “beings who follow that way”: since it is intended for Mahāyāna individuals, it depends on their mind streams, like a bird sitting on a tree. The explanation in the long commentary appears to be difficult to understand, so here I have given a summary to clarify the main points.

yang sgra byed pa sgrub pa gtso che ba'i dbang du byas te bshad na/ gang gis bstan bcos 'di rtsom pa'i byed pa po ni/ don shes zhes pas bstan te theg pa chen po'i mdo sde mtha' dag gi dgongs don ji lta ba bzhin du shes shing gzigs pas don so so yang dag pa'i rig pa brnyes pa rgyal tshab sa bcu'i dbang phyug mi pham mgon pos so/ / des las su bya ba ni/ don ston rab tu byed pa zhes pas mdo sde'i don mtha' dag ston par rab tu byed pa spobs pa so so yang dag par rig pa'i stobs kyis brtsam mo zhes dang / byed pa ci lta bus na/ ngag dang tshig rnams dri med pas zhes rjod byed kyi ngag rnam dag chos so so yang dag par rig pa dang / sems can rnams kyi skad nges pa'i tshig so so yang dag rig pa sgrib pa'i dri ma med pas so/ / gang gi ched du yin zhe na/ sems can thams cad sdug bsngal las bsgral ba'i phyir ram ched du'o/ / kun slong ngam rgyu gang gis na/ shes rab dang snying rje de yi bdag nyid rgyal tshab chen po nyid kyis sdug bsngal ba'i 'gro ba kun la snying rje chen po las so/ / de ltar rtsom pa'i rgyu phun sum tshogs pa las byung ba'i bstan bcos 'di theg pa che chung gang gi phyogs su gtogs pa'am gang dang 'brel zhe na/ theg mchog bstan pa'i chos kyi zhes/ theg chen gyi phyogs su gtogs shing de dang 'brel zhes so/ / 'di gang zag su'i ched du yin zhing su'i rgyud la brten par 'gyur ba yin zhe na/ theg pa mchog gi chos kyi rnam pa de yis 'gro ba'i sems can byang chub sems dpa' rnams la'o/ / zhes shes par bya'o/ /

Alternatively, if we explain this verse mainly stressing the instrumental case, it can be understood as follows. The agent who composed this treatise is indicated by “He who knows the meaning,” that is, the regent Ajitanātha, Lord of the Ten Levels,[5] who understood and perceived the intended meaning, just as it is, of all the sūtras of the Great Vehicle and thereby gained perfect knowledge of all the meanings. What did he create? He “created a composition showing that meaning,” that is, he produced a composition indicating the whole meaning of the sūtras, composed by the power of his perfect knowledge through unbounded intelligence and ability. With what sort of instrument? “With flawless speech and phrasing,” uncontaminated by obscurations—that is, with perfectly pure speech to express it, related to the perfect knowledge of each and every aspect of the Dharma, and with the perfect knowledge of the languages, the different languages of beings. For what purpose? In order to free all sentient beings from suffering. Out of what motivation or causal factor? Out of the great compassion that the Great Regent, whose nature is wisdom and compassion, has for all beings who are suffering. Now, is this treatise, whose composition comes from such a perfect cause, related to, or does it belong to, the Great Vehicle or the Lesser Vehicle? It is of “the way expounded in the Supreme Vehicle,” meaning that it belongs to and is related to the Great Vehicle. And for whom is it intended—on whose mind streams will it depend? For bodhisattvas, beings who are following the way of the Supreme Vehicle.

de yang ngag dri ma med pa mdor bsdus na yan lag brgyad dang ldan pa ste/ grong khyer pa zhes pa thar pa'i grong khyer gyi dbang du byas pa'am tshig yongs su grags pa'o/ / snyan cing 'jebs pa gdangs snyan cing yid du 'jebs pa/ rnam par gsal ba tshig dang yi ge bzang ba/ rnam par rig par byed pa/ don shin tu go bar byed pa/ mnyan par 'os pa don chen po dam pa'i chos kyi don dang ldan pa rten pa med pa ni rab tu dang ba lhag par 'phel ba/ mi mthun pa med pa yid la 'bab cing mngon par 'dod pa/ gtugs pa med pa ni shin tu rgya che ba la mkhas pas mtha' gtug tu med pa'o/ / de brgyad kyi dang po dbang du bya ba'i sgo nas so/ /de'i rjes kyi gnyis ngo bo'i sgo nas dang / lhag ma lnga sbyor ba'i sgo nas yin no/ /

Flawless speech, in short, comprises eight branches: (1) It is “civilized”—that is, it concerns the city of liberation, or it comprises well-known phrases; (2) it is sweet sounding, melodious, and pleasing; (3) it is clear, with fine phrases and words; (4) it confers knowledge; (5) its meaning is entirely comprehensible; (6) it is worth listening to, being endowed with great meaning—the meaning of the sacred Dharma—and disinterested,[6] and it makes one’s faith grow more and more; (7) it is not discordant and is pleasant and inspiring; and (8) it is limitless—it is so vast in scope that a learned scholar could never reach the end of it. The first of these eight is flawless in terms of what such speech concerns; the next two in terms of its nature; and the remaining five in terms of its effect.

tshig dri ma med pa yang yan lag brgyad de/ tshig dang yi ge rigs pa ni/ ming tshig yi ge go rim bzhin 'brel ba dang / don rigs pa'i lam dang ldan pa 'brel ba zhes pa don dang 'byor pa'am don sgrub par byed pa/ mthun pa zhes pa don legs par rnam par bshad pa/ rung ba zhes pa tshig dang yi ge gsal ba/ 'byor pa zhes pa snying la babs pa/ 'phrod pa zhes pa 'khor ji lta ba bzhin yid la 'phrod pa/ 'tshams pa zhes pa chos mthun don ldan dus su 'tshams pa/ 'grus skyong gi yan lag gi tshogs zhes pa/ 'grus skyong ni brtson 'grus te mkhas par byed cing rtag tu byed pa dang / yan lag gi tshogs ni yang dag pa'i lta ba sogs dang ldan pa ste/ de lta bu'i don dang ldan pa'i gtam ston pa'o/ /

Flawless phrasing also comprises eight branches: (1) “The words and letters are rational”—the names, phrases, and letters are connected in the right order; (2) they are “connected, having the right meaning”—they match the meaning or accomplish the meaning; (3) they are “accordant”—they present the meaning properly; (4) they are “appropriate”—the phrases and letters are clear; (5) they are “agreeable”—that is, they are to one’s liking; (6) they are “fitting”—they suit the audience’s mentality; (7) they are “apt”—they are to do with the Dharma and are meaningful and timely; and (8) they comprise the “branches for sustained diligence”—“sustained diligence” referring to diligence that brings about learning and does so constantly, and “branches” referring to the possession of the correct view and so on. All these indicate that everything the author says is meaningful.

'byor pa'i don tshul bla med dpe lngas bstan pa'i don gang yin zhe na/ slob dpon chen po dbyig gnyen gyi zhal snga nas/ bsgrub par bya ba dang / bye brag tu shes par bya ba dang / bsam par bya ba dang / bsam gyis mi khyab pa dang / yongs su grub pa rtogs pa'i don so so rang gis rig par bya ba dang / byang chub kyi phyogs dang mthun pa'i ngo bo nyid do zhes gsungs pa/ 'di lnga yin kyang / mdor bsdus tsam gyi tshig de'i dgongs pa gang yin la/ slob dpon rnams kyis bzhed pa 'ga' byung ste/ slob dpon blo gros brtan pas ni tshig de lnga dngos po lnga dang ngo bo nyid gsum dang / gang zag gsum gyi dbang du byas pa'i sbyar tshul gyi rnam bzhag gsum gsungs pa mdor bsdus su brjod na

dngos po lnga po 'dir theg chen gyi brjod bya kun 'dus pas de dang sbyar na/ dngos po lnga ni/ ming dang / rgyu mtshan dang / rnam par rtog pa dang / de bzhin nyid dang / rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes lnga'o/ / de las dang po chos thams cad ming gis brjod pa ltar 'gro ba rnams don du zhen kyang / ming tsam las brjod pa ltar don ma grub par bsgrub par bya ba dang / rgyu mtshan ni ming du gdags pa'i rgyu mtshan gzhan dbang gi gzung char snang ba rnams yin la/ de sems kyi dbang gis snang ba'i rten 'brel du bye brag tu shes par bya ba yin no/ / rnam rtog ni sems sems byung gi rnam pa 'dzin char snang ba ste/ rnam shes tshogs brgyad gzhan dbang dngos so/ / de'i rang bzhin gtan la 'bebs pa'i tshul gyis bsam par bya yin no/ / de gsum dpe snga ma gsum dang rim par sbyar ro/ / de bzhin nyid yongs grub ste de ni so so rang rig med pas bsam gyis mi khyab pa yin la/ sa dang por de bzhin nyid mngon sum du rtogs tshe byang chub thob par nges pa'i 'phrin yig legs pa thos pa ltar dga' ba skyed do/ / rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes gtso bor gyur pa'i byang chub phyogs mthun gyi chos rnams ni dpe lnga pas bstan byar bzhed de/ theg bsdus las/ yongs grub ci lta bu zhe na/ rnam par byang ba'i chos bzhis shes par bya ste/ rang bzhin gyi rnam byang de bzhin nyid/ dri ma bral ba'i rnam byang de bzhin nyid de sgrib pa thams cad dang bral ba/ de 'thob byed lam gyi rnam byang byang chub phyogs mthun gyi chos de skyed byed dmigs pa rnam par byang ba ni theg pa chen po'i chos so zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

The five categories include all the subjects of the Great Vehicle and can therefore be associated with the above terms. These five categories are name, reason, conception, suchness, and nonconceptual gnosis. (1) With regard to the first of these, inasmuch as they express all phenomena by names, beings cling to them as objects; but inasmuch as these expressions are no more than names, the objects have to be established as not existing. (2) The reason for labeling things with names is that there are the appearances—as the apprehended-object aspect—of the dependent reality. These are what have to be specifically known as dependent appearance through the power of the mind. (3) Conception is what appears as the apprehending-subject aspect of the mind and mental factors: it refers to the eight consciousnesses, which are the actual dependent reality. It is what has to be reflected upon by one’s determining its nature. These three are associated with the first three metaphors respectively. (4) Suchness is the fully present reality: unless it is known personally, it is inconceivable. When suchness is directly realized on the first bodhisattva level, it gives rise to joy at the certainty of attaining enlightenment, as if one were hearing good news. (5) The elements that lead to enlightenment, above all the nonconceptual gnosis, are held to be what is indicated by the fifth metaphor. According to the Compendium of the Great Vehicle, if one were to ask what the full accomplishment is like, it is to be recognized by the four qualities of the purity aspect: the natural purity, or suchness; the uncontaminated purity, which is suchness free of all obscurations; the path purity that makes one attain the latter and comprises the elements that lead to enlightenment; and that which gives rise to it, the referential purity, that is, the Mahāyāna teachings.

ngo bo nyid gsum gyi kun brtags med par bsgrub bya/ gzhan dbang la kun byang gi rten 'brel dang / gzhan dbang la ngo bo nyid dang / yongs grub la 'gyur med yongs grub dang / phyin ci ma log pa'i yongs grub bzhi bye brag tu shes par bya ba sogs bzhi dang sbyar bar mdzad do/ /

Of the three realities, the imputed reality is what is to be established (as having no existence). The other four of the above five points—that which is to be specifically known, and so on—are associated with the dependent arising of the defilement and purity aspects, the essential nature (both related to dependent reality), the unchanging fully present reality, and the unmistaken fully present reality.
gang zag gi dbang du byas na/ mi shes pa dang / the tshom can dang / log shes can la ltos te/ dang po theg chen bka' sgrub tshul sogs gsungs kyang 'dir mang dogs nas ma brjod do/ /

With regard to the three kinds of individual, Sthiramati teaches in terms of the uncomprehending, the doubtful, and those with wrong beliefs, for whom the Great Vehicle has first to be established as the Buddha’s word, and so on. But for fear of being too long, I will not write about this here.

slob dpon dz+nyA na shrIs bsgrubs par bya ba sogs kyi don ming rgyu mtshan sogs lnga la sbyar ba mi 'thad par bstan nas/ rang lugs don tshul lnga po gong ma don shes don ston sogs kyi tshig dang sbyar ba dang / 'og ma theg chen bka' sgrub sogs dang sbyar ba gnyis las 'og ma 'di dbyig gnyen gyis bzhed pa yin te/

The master Jñānaśrī taught that associating the five points (what is to be established and so on) with the five categories (name, reason, and so forth) is not acceptable. His tradition has two approaches, one in which the five metaphors are associated with the earlier lines, “He who knows the meaning…,” and the other in which they are associated with the later sections, “Establishing the Great Vehicle as the Buddha’s Word,” and so on. This second approach is that followed by Vasubandhu and is as follows.

bsgrub par bya ba theg chen bkar sgrub pa dang / sems bskyed kyi yul skyabs 'gro mchog tu sgrub pa dang / nyer len gyi rgyu theg chen gyi rigs sgrub pa gsum/ bye brag tu shes bya sems bskyed dang / don gnyis sgrub pa gnyis/ bsam bya zab pa dang rgya che ba'i de kho na nyid gnyis las 'dir zab pa/ bsam gyis mi khyab pa mthu yongs smin gnyis/ yongs su grub pa byang chub bo/ / de ltar yin pa'i shes byed ni sgrub pa'i skabs kyi zhes dang / rin po che snod ni phye ba ltar zhes pa'i gzhung tshig gis so/ / sdom yang de ltar bstan to/ /

What is to be established is threefold: establishing the Great Vehicle as the Buddha’s word, establishing the object of one’s spiritual intent[10] as the supreme refuge, and establishing that the perpetuating cause is the Mahāyāna potential. What is to be specifically known is twofold: the spiritual intent and accomplishing the twofold goal. What is to be reflected upon is, in this case, thatness in its profound aspect (rather than its extensive aspect). The inconceivable is twofold: powers and full maturation. Full accomplishment refers to enlightenment. All this, says Jñānaśrī, can be understood from the words in the root text, “The chapter on establishing,” and “opening a chest of jewels.” It is also indicated in the Recapitulation.[11]

des ji ltar bslab pa/ mos pa nas gdams ngag rjes bstan bar ro/ / snga ma'i 'gros kyi theg chen bka' sgrub pas mos pa nas sgrub pa'i bar dang / bye brag shes bya gdams ngag rjes bstan/ bsam bya rgya che ba'i thabs mkhas ni bsdu dngos/ phar phyin/ tshad med mchod bsten sogs dang lam byang phyogs/ bsam gyis mi khyab yon tan/ yongs su grub pa rtogs pa'i don mthar thug gi skabs so/ /zhes gsungs pa de dag gang yang mkhas mchog rnams kyi legs bshad yin mod/ 'on kyang bstan bcos 'di'i gzhung don yongs rdzogs la sbyar btub cing go bde ba'i dbang du byas na/

How one trains covers the chapters from “Interest” (11) through to “Instructions and Follow-Up Teachings” (15). Using the same scheme as above, Jñānaśrī explains that what is to be established corresponds to the chapters from “Interest” (gained from the Great Vehicle being established as the Buddha’s word) through to “Practicing the Dharma” (11–14). What is to be specifically known is the instructions and follow-up teachings (15). What is to be reflected upon corresponds to the vast skill in means, comprising the ways of attracting disciples, the transcendent perfections (17); boundless attitudes, offering, and reliance (18), and so on; and the elements on the path leading to enlightenment (19). The inconceivable corresponds to qualities (20). Full accomplishment, which is the point of realization, corresponds to the chapter on consummation (21). Excellent though these explanations are, and by the most learned of scholars, a more convenient and easily understood way to associate the five metaphors with the entire body of this treatise is as follows.

bsgrub par bya ba ni theg pa chen po bkar bsgrubs pas gser brdungs su byas te rgyan nyid du bsgrub pa ltar de bka' nyid du ma rtogs log rtog the tshom dang bral te theg chen la longs spyod pa'i dga' ba skyed do/ /

What is to be established. Establishing the Great Vehicle as the Buddha’s word, which is like beating gold to produce an ornament, frees one from ignorance, wrong understanding, and doubts with regard to its being the Buddha’s word, and gives rise to delight at being able to enjoy the Great Vehicle.

bye brag tu shes par bya ba ni theg pa chen po'i khyad chos te/ gang zhe na skyabs 'gro nas sgrub pa'i bar ro/ / de yang nyan thos rnams la'ang / mchog gsum la skyabs su 'gro ba dang / theg dman gyi rigs dang ldan pa dang / rang don zhi bde'i go 'phang du sems bskyed pa/ lam bslab pa gsum sgrub pa tsam yod mod theg dman las theg chen la khyad par 'phags tshul gyi bye brag shes pas theg chen gyi lam la spro ba lhag par rnyed pa'i phyir pad+ma zlum pa kha phye ba ltar blo theg chen la phyogs pa'i dga' ba bskyed do/ /

What is to be specifically known refers to the distinguishing features of the Great Vehicle, namely, its refuge, potential, spiritual intent, and practice. Now, of course, the listeners also take refuge in the Three Jewels; they have a potential—that of the lower vehicle; they develop a spiritual intent, albeit for their own state of peace and happiness; and, as the path, they practice the three trainings. But when one knows the specific differences that make the Great Vehicle superior to those lower vehicles, one acquires a greater enthusiasm for the Mahāyāna path, because of which one feels the same sort of delight at being Mahāyāna-minded as at a lotus bud blossoming.
