de ltar theg pa che chung gi bye brag shes nas/ theg pa chen po la 'jug pa des bsam par bya ba ni/ theg pa chen po nas bstan pa de kho na nyid kyi don dang / theg chen byang chub sems dpa'i rdzu 'phrul gyi mthu dang / dbang po yongs su smin pa'i tshul la bsam pas de kho na nyid kyi don la nges pa rnyed pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i don gnyis sgrub nus pa'i mthu dang / de 'grub byed dbang po yongs su smin pa'i thabs la rang nyid 'jug par 'gyur te zas g.yos legs za ba bzhin du gang zag de yang de kho na nyid shes pa dang / mthu chen po sgrub pa dang rang gi dbang po smin pa'i yon tan ci rigs thob pa nyams su myong ba'i dga' ba ni bskyed pas so/ /

What is to be reflected upon, once one has understood these specific differences between the greater and lesser vehicles and entered the Great Vehicle, is the meaning of thatness taught in the Great Vehicle, the miraculous powers of the Mahāyāna bodhisattvas, and the manner in which their faculties are brought to full maturation. By reflecting on these, one will oneself engage in gaining certainty as to the meaning of thatness, in the powers that enable one to accomplish the two bodhisattva goals, and in the methods for fully maturing one’s faculties to accomplish the latter, for the experience of obtaining any of the qualities of knowing thatness, accomplishing great powers, and maturing one’s own faculties gives rise to the same delight as eating deliciously prepared food.

bsam gyis mi khyab pa ni byang chub yin te/ spyir de kho na nyid kyang so so rang rig pa med pas ji lta ba bzhin du bsam gyis mi khyab pa yin yang / spyir mtshan tsam gyi sgo nas thos bsam gyis bsam par bya ba yin par 'gal ba med la/ de bzhin du bsam gyis mi khyab pa bzhi gsungs pa'i ya gyal sangs rgyas kyi phrin las sogs bsam gyis mi khyab pa ni bsam gyis mi khyab pa rnams kyi nang na'ang de bas ches lhag pa med pa yin yang / 'dir byang chub de'i rang bzhin gtan la phab pas bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i byang chub de lta bu yang da lta de'i yon tan gyi cha shas tsam mngon du ma gyur kyang / theg pa chen po'i lam la zhugs na de nam zhig 'thob rung bar shes pa ni 'phrin yig legs par thos pa'am mthong ba'ang ste/ rgyal po sogs kyi 'phrin yig las khyod la bya dga' sogs 'di dang 'di lta bu byed do zhes pa'i 'phrin thos tshe bya dga' de da lta mngon du ma gyur kyang / slad nas thob nges so snyam du dga' ba skye ba bzhin no/ / de ltar byang chub de ni yongs su grub pa rtogs pa'i don so so rang gis rig par bya ba yin pas bsam gyis mi khyab pa yin la/ de nyid sgrub par byed pa'i rgyu lam gyi chos thams cad la byang chub kyi phyogs dang mthun pa'i chos kyi ngo bo nyid ces bya ba yin pas na/ byang chub kyi le'u'i rjes kyi le'u mtha' dag ni rin po che'i sgrom kha phye ba'i dpe dang sbyar bar bya ba yin no/ /

The inconceivable refers to enlightenment. Generally speaking, thatness too is inconceivable, for unless it is known personally we cannot imagine what it is like; but this does not contradict the fact that we can conceive of it in a general manner by hearing of it and reflecting on it simply in terms of its characteristics. Thus, although there is nothing more inconceivable than the inconceivable activities of a buddha, or than any others of the four things he taught as being inconceivable,[12] in this case we are determining the nature of enlightenment. By doing so, even though we have not at present achieved even a fraction of the good qualities of such inconceivable enlightenment, we know that once we have entered the path of the Great Vehicle, they will one day be attainable. And knowing this is like hearing or reading good news in a letter—a letter from the king, for example, saying, “He has rewarded you with such and such honors.” Even if one does not actually have the reward at the time one hears the news, one feels delighted, in the certainty that one will receive it in due course. Thus, since enlightenment is the full accomplishment, the point of realization which can only be known personally, it is inconceivable. On the other hand, all the elements of the path that are the causal factors for accomplishing that enlightenment constitute what we call the approach to enlightenment, and so all the chapters that come after the Enlightenment chapter are to be associated with the analogy of opening a chest of jewels.

byang chub kyi skabs su rin po che'i sgrom kha phye ba'i dpe dngos su bstan phyir/ dpe 'di byang phyogs kyi chos la sbyar mi rigs snyam na/ shin tu rigs te lam byang chub phyogs mthun gyi chos rnams yongs su rdzogs pa'i 'bras bu byang chub nyid yin pas/ de ni rin po che'i sgrom kha phye ba'i dpes bstan bya mthar thug yin kyang / skabs 'dir bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i byang chub de thos bsam gyis gtan la 'bebs pa'i skabs yin pas/ dper na 'phrin yig tu khyod la rin po che dpag tu med pas yongs su gang ba'i sgrom chen po zhig sbyin par bya'o zhes thos pa dang 'dra ba'i skabs yin te/ mi slob lam na stobs sogs kyi yon tan rin po che ma tshang ba med pas bkang ba'i sgrom kha phye ba ltar sangs rgyas la mngon du gyur pa yin mod kyi/ slob lam pa'i gang zag gis de ltar yin pa shes par bya ba tsam las mngon du ma gyur pas de'i rang bzhin ji lta ba bzhin bsam gyis mi khyab pa yin kyang / de bsam gyis mi khyab par bsam par bya ba yin pa yang 'gal ba med do/ / de ltar bla med byang chub la dmigs nas de 'thob byed thog mar mos pa nas brtsams te zab cing rgya che ba yi lam mtha' dag ma tshang ba med par nyams su blang ba'i skabs na lam dang sa de dang de'i gnas skabs kyi yon tan ci rigs mngon du gyur pa'i tshe na/ rin po che ci rigs lag tu thob pa ltar mngon du gyur pa yin cing de ltar byang sems de'i sa dang lam gyi yon tan rgya je cher 'phel nas sangs rgyas kyi sa la thug pa'i bar gyi yon tan nyams su myong ba ni rin po che'i sgrom kha phye ba mngon sum spyod yul du gyur pa dang 'dra ba yin pas mos pa nas 'bras chos kyi bar du bstan pa yin no/ /

One might think that the analogy of opening a chest of jewels would actually indicate enlightenment, and that it is therefore inappropriate to associate that analogy with the elements leading to enlightenment. But it is wholly appropriate, because the result of perfectly completing the elements leading to enlightenment—that is, of the path—is indeed enlightenment, so even though enlightenment is the ultimate thing to be indicated by the analogy of opening a chest full of jewels, the Enlightenment chapter in this context is about determining that inconceivable enlightenment by study and reflection. This, therefore, corresponds to the stage illustrated by the analogy of hearing the news in a letter, “You are going to be given a huge chest completely full of priceless jewels”; and it is on the path of no more learning that one realizes buddhahood, which is like opening a chest filled to the brim with all the jewel-like buddha qualities—the strengths and so forth. Individuals on the path of learning, however, only know that it is like that: they have not actually realized it, and so for them its exact nature is inconceivable. But the inconceivable is still what has to be reflected upon, so there is no contradiction here. Having considered unsurpassable enlightenment in this way, to attain enlightenment one then practices the profound and extensive path in its entirety, beginning with interest. During this period, as one realizes the temporary qualities of the paths and levels, in due order, one receives the respective jewels in one’s hand, as it were, and in that way the qualities of the paths and levels of that bodhisattva grow more and more vast, and the experience of those qualities right up until one reaches the buddha level is like actually opening the chest of jewels. The analogy, therefore, indicates the whole path from interest up to the result.

gzugs rgyan rang bzhin yon tan ldan pa me long nang song na/ / mthong ba'i dbang gis mi rnams rab tu dga' ba'i mchog skyed pa/ / de bzhin legs gsungs rtag tu rang bzhin yon tan ldan pa yi/ / chos kyang don rnams phye bas mkhas rnams 'di na dga' mchog skyed/ /

When those of natural and ornamented beauty behold themselves Reflected in a glass, it brings them consummate delight. So too, when the meaning of the Dharma, whose excellent words are always naturally full of virtues, Is clarified, it brings the wise the greatest joy. (I, 3)

kha cig 'di snyam du sangs rgyas kyi gsung rnams ni rang bzhin gyi tshig dang don phun sum tshogs pa'i yon tan dang ldan pa yin pas de la bstan bcos kyis gsar du brgyan par byed ci dgos snyam na/ skyes bu rang bzhin gyi gzugs bzang ba zhig rin po che'i rgyan sna tshogs kyis mdzes pa ni de dag ngo bo nyid kyis sam rang bzhin gyis yon tan ldan pa yin mod kyi/ de nyid rang gi lus rgyan dang bcas pa de me long dwangs pa'i nang du son pa ste shar bar gyur pa de mthong na/ rang gi lus dang rgyan mdzes pa'i rnam pa de lta bu mthong ba'i dbang gis mi rnams lhag par rab tu dga' ba'i mchog yid la skyed pa de bzhin du sangs rgyas kyi legs par gsungs pa gang zhig thog mtha' bar gsum du dge zhing tshig don phun sum tshogs pa dang tshangs spyod kyi yon tan bzhi dang ldan pas mchog tu khyad par 'phags pa'i phyir/ rtag tu rang bzhin gyi yon tan tshad med pa dang ldan pa yi chos de dag kyang bstan bcos 'dis sangs rgyas kyi gsung sna tshogs pa rnams kyi don rgya chen po phyogs gcig tu bsdus shing / go rims legs par bsgrigs te zab mo rtogs dka' ba'i cha rnams rab tu rnam par 'byed pa'i sgo nas rgyal ba'i dgongs don so sor ma nor bar rnam par phye bas na blo ldan mkhas pa rnams kyang rgyal ba'i gsung gi don la nges pa bde blag tu rnyed nas bstan bcos 'di thos pa'i gnas skabs 'di na dga' ba mchog tu gyur pa skyed de/ me long nang gi gzugs brnyan gyis gzugs bzang po'i yon tan gsal bar byed pa bzhin no/ / de'i phyir bstan bcos 'di ni mdo sde rnams kyi dgongs pa gsal bar byed pa'i rgyan du gyur pa yin no/ /

Some people might wonder, since the Buddha’s teachings naturally possess all the qualities of perfection, both in their words and in their meanings, why is it necessary to embellish them with a treatise? It is true that an attractive woman who is adorned with different kinds of precious ornaments naturally has all the virtues of beauty. But if that person, with all her jewelry, looks at herself in a clear mirror, when she sees the image of her bejeweled form, she will feel especially great delight. So it is too for the Buddha’s teachings, which are always endowed with boundless natural good qualities—for all his Excellent Words are virtuous in the beginning, middle, and end; they are perfect and complete in their words and meanings; they are endowed with the four qualities of pure conduct; and they are therefore particularly sublime. This treatise brings together in one text the extensive points in all the Buddha’s varied teachings and arranges them in perfect order, setting forth without error each of the intended meanings of the Victorious One by investigating the profound aspects that are difficult to understand. As a result, the wise and learned have no difficulty in gaining certainty in the meaning of the Buddha’s words, and they feel the greatest joy on hearing this treatise, as one would at seeing a reflection in a mirror that highlights beautiful features. It is in this sense that this treatise is an ornament, illuminating the intended meanings of the sūtras.
gnyis pa bstan bcos gzhung gi don
THE MAIN TEXT OF THE TREATISE

[bstan bcos kyi gzhung bshad pa] la bsgrub par bya ba dang / bye brag tu shes par bya ba/ bsam par bya ba dang / bsam gyis mi khyab pa dang / byang chub kyi phyogs dang mthun pa'i chos rnams kyi ngo bo nyid bshad pa dang lnga las/

The explanation of the main text of the treatise that now follows is divided into five parts: (1) what is to be established; (2) what is to be specifically known; (3) what is to be reflected upon; (4) the inconceivable—that which is beyond reflection; and (5) the actual approach to enlightenment.[13]
dang po [bsgrub par bya ba]
PART ONE. WHAT IS TO BE ESTABLISHED
theg pa chen po bkar bsgrub pa la/ spyir bstan pa dang / bye brag tu bshad pa gnyis las
Establishing the Great Vehicle as the Buddha’s Word
dang po/
1. A GENERAL PRESENTATION OF ESTABLISHING THE GREAT VEHICLE AS THE BUDDHA’S WORD
ji ltar mnams na rab dku la/ / myangs na zhim pa'i sman bzhin du/ / chos kyang de bzhin gnyis su gnas/ / don dang yi ger shes par bya/ /
Like medicine that smells foul Yet tastes quite sweet, Know that the Dharma also has two aspects— The meaning and the words. (I, 4)

zhes tshigs bcad gsum ste/ dpe ji ltar na snar mnams na dri rab tu dku ba sna dbang dang 'phrod dka' ba lta bu gyur la/ de lces myangs na shin tu ro zhim zhing nad sogs zhi ba dang lus la cher phan pa'i sman bzang po bzhin du/ theg pa chen po'i chos kyang rnam pa gnyis su gnas te/ gang zhe na don dang yi ge'i rang bzhin tshig gi rnam pa gnyis so/ / de yang tshig tsam gyi dbang du byas na theg chen gyi gzhung du chos thams cad ngo bo nyid med do zhes sogs dang / mgo dang yan lag gtong ba sogs dka' spyad chen po bskal pa chen po grangs med gsum gyi bar du spyad cing 'khor bar gnas pa sogs thos pas/ dri rtsub cing sna la 'khri ba'am dku ba lta bu'i dbang gis sman chen pa zhim zhing bcud dang ldan pa dag 'dor ba ltar byis pa blo chung ba dman pa la mos pa rnams skrag nas 'dor ba de ni gang zag de'i skyon yin gyi/ theg pa chen po'i chos kyi skyon ma yin te/ de'i don rigs pas tshul bzhin nges na chos thams cad rang gi ngo bos stong yang / tha snyad kyi rnam bzhag ches 'thad pa yin gyi tha snyad du med par bstan pa ma yin pa'am/ byis pa so so'i skye bo rnams kyis kun brtags pa ltar med pa'i don yin gyi/ gzhan dbang tha snyad du yod pa dang yongs grub don dam pa yin pas de med par bstan pa ma yin la/ 'khor bar gnas te dka' ba spyad pa yang / thabs shes khyad par can gyi sgo nas dka' ba med par bsgrub nus pa'i phyir/ chos kyi don shes na theg pa chen po la lhag par mos par 'gyur ba'i phyir tshig tsam la 'chel nas gting ma rtogs pa'i sgo nas spang du mi rung bar gdams pa'o/ /

Some medicines smell so horrible that one can hardly put one’s nose to them, and yet they taste delicious and are highly efficacious, healing one’s ailments and doing one’s body much good. There are similarly two sides to the teachings of the Great Vehicle—namely, the meaning and the written words. In considering the words alone, when immature people with small minds and lowly aspirations hear in the Mahāyāna scriptures that everything is devoid of essence and that one must stay in saṃsāra for up to three measureless great kalpas, undertaking great austerities such as giving away one’s head and limbs, they take fright and reject these teachings as they would sweet-tasting, potent medicines on account of their pungent, unpleasant smell. This is the fault of the individual and not of the Mahāyāna teachings. For if we use reasoning to ascertain their meaning properly, we will see that although the teachings say that all phenomena are empty of an essential nature, they fully accord with presentations of conventional truth and are not indicating that things do not exist conventionally. In other words, they mean that things do not exist in the way they are imputed to exist by ordinary, immature beings. But they are not teaching that there is no dependent reality and no fully present reality, for the former exists conventionally and the latter is ultimate truth. As for remaining in saṃsāra and undertaking austerities, on account of their extraordinary skillful means and wisdom, bodhisattvas are able to accomplish these without any difficulty. So because understanding the meaning of the teachings will make us more interested in the Great Vehicle, this verse advises us not to reject it merely on the basis of the words and without realizing their underlying meaning.
chos dka' rgya chen zab mo 'di/ / rgyal po bzhin du mnyes par dka'/ / mnyes par byas na de bzhin du/ / yon tan mchog gi nor sbyin byed/ /
This difficult Dharma, extensive and profound, Is like a monarch—difficult to please; Yet if pleased, it likewise will bestow The riches of sublime qualities. (I, 5)

yang theg pa chen po'i lam ni/ dka' spyad rgya chen po bzod pa dang / tshogs rgya chen po tshad med pa bsags pa dang / dus yun ring pos bsgrub bya yin yang de theg chen gyi yon tan yin gyi skyon ma yin te/ ci'i phyir na/ theg chen gyi chos shin tu rnyed par dka' ba dang / dam pa min pa rnams 'jug dka' ba yang yin te/ sa dang phar phyin sogs kyi rnam pa tshad med pas rgya chen por gyur pa dang / zab mo khong du chud par dka' ba 'di ni/ dper na 'jig rten na rgyal po chen po rnams bzhin du bya ba chung ngus mnyes par dka' ste/ gal te tshul bzhin mnyes pa'i bya ba chen po byas pas/ rgyal po de mnyes par 'gyur na/ nor dang dbang phyug rgya chen po'i bya dga' thob pa de bzhin du/ theg chen 'di dman pa'i gang zag gis 'grub par dka' yang / thabs dang shes rab zung du 'brel bas bsgrub par byas na/ yon tan mchog gi nor stobs bcu mi 'jigs bzhi sogs nam yang mi zad pa sbyin par byed do/ /

Now although the Mahāyāna path requires forbearance in undertaking immense austerities, a boundless accumulation of merit on a vast scale, and practice over long periods of time, these are good qualities in the Great Vehicle and not defects. Why? These teachings of the Great Vehicle, which are difficult (being extremely hard to obtain and, moreover, difficult for lesser beings to apply), extensive (on account of their infinite aspects such as the levels and transcendent perfections), and profound (being difficult to comprehend), are like kings. In ordinary life, it is hard to please great monarchs with small acts. But if one serves them with great deeds that really delight them, one will be rewarded by vast riches and wealth. Similarly, even though the Great Vehicle is difficult to accomplish for individuals of modest capacity, if it is practiced with a combination of skillful means and wisdom, it bestows the inexhaustible riches of sublime qualities such as the ten strengths and the four fearlessnesses.[1]
rin chen rigs ldan rin thang med/ / lta mi shes pa'i mig mi mgu / de bzhin mi mkhas chos 'di la/ / bzlog na de bzhin mgu bar 'gyur/ /

The purest, priceless jewel will not delight The eyes of those who cannot see its worth. This Dharma is the same for those who lack discernment. But for their opposites, each will bring commensurate delight. (I, 6)

yang theg pa chen po'i chos ni yon tan mchog dang ldan na yang / gang zag shes rab dang mos pa dman pas de mi shes pa'i dpe ni/ rin chen mchog gi rigs dang ldan pa rin thang gzhal du med pa yin yang / de'i rgyus mi shes pa'i skye bo ma rabs kyi lag tu son na/ de'i ngang tshul lta mi shes pa'i phyir ba lang rdzi sogs mi dman pa rnams mi mgu ste/ 'dis ci bya snyam du 'dor ro/ / de bzhin mi mkhas pa'i gang zag rnams kyang chos 'di la mgu ba dang ngo mtshar du mi 'dzin la/ de las ldog ste mkhas shing mos pa rgya chen po dang ldan na/ rin po che'i rgyus shes pa rnams rin chen mchog la dga' ba de bzhin du theg pa chen po 'di la yid shin tu mgu zhing don du gnyer bar 'gyur ro/ /

Again, even though the Mahāyāna teachings have sublime qualities, people with meager understanding and interest in them do not know that. This is illustrated by the analogy of a jewel of the finest quality. Priceless though it is, if it were to fall into the hands of uneducated people who know nothing about jewels, they would not be able to see its true worth. A cowherd or other lowly person, instead of being thrilled, would therefore throw it away, thinking, “What good is this to me?” In the same way, undiscerning people do not derive any satisfaction from these teachings or consider them anything to marvel at. On the other hand, their opposites—those who are discerning and have vast aspirations—will, like people who know about jewels and take delight in the finest stones, derive the greatest joy from this Great Vehicle and take a keen interest in pursuing it.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las le'u dang po'o/
This completes the first chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las le'u dang po'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the first chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras.
gnyis pa
2. SPECIFIC EXPLANATIONS OF ESTABLISHING THE GREAT VEHICLE AS THE BUDDHA’S WORD
theg chen bkar bsgrub pa'i rnam grangs bye brag tu bshad pa la/ log par rtog pa zlog byed kyi rigs pa'i rnam grangs bstan pa dang / theg chen la log par 'dzin pa spong bar gdams pa gnyis/
The specific explanations comprise two sections: (1) different arguments to counteract wrong ways of thinking and (2) instructions on getting rid of wrong beliefs with regard to the Great Vehicle.
dang po/
1. DIFFERENT ARGUMENTS TO COUNTERACT WRONG WAYS OF THINKING
sngar lung ma bstan lhan cig byung / / spyod yul ma yin grub pa dang / / yod dang med na yod med dang / / gnyen po dang ni sgra gzhan phyir/ /

The Great Vehicle is shown to be the Buddha’s word. Because nothing adverse was predicted, it appeared at the same time, It is beyond the scope of intellectuals, it can be proven, Its existence or nonexistence depends on there being another vehicle, It is the antidote, and its words mean something different. (II, 1)
zhes tshigs bcad bdun gyis bstan te/

de yang nyan thos pa dag na re/ nyan thos kyi sde snod gsum po 'di sangs rgyas kyi bka' yin gyi/ theg pa chen po sangs rgyas kyi bka' ma yin te/ sangs rgyas mya ngan las 'das pa'i rjes su bdud kyis bstan pa la tho brtsam phyir mu stegs dang rtog ge ba dag gis brtsams pa yin no/ /zhes zer zhing / sangs rgyas rang nyid kyis sangs rgyas kyi bka' yin min nag po bstan pa dang chen po bstan pa'i khyad par 'byed dgos par gsungs shing / gang mdo sde la 'jug 'dul ba la snang / mngon pa'i chos nyid dang mi 'gal ba ni chen po bstan pa ste de lta bu sangs rgyas kyi bka' yin la/

The followers of the Listeners’ Vehicle say that the three scriptural collections of the listeners are the Buddha’s word but that the Great Vehicle is not. They claim that the latter was made up after the Buddha’s parinirvāṇa by tīrthikas and intellectuals under the influence of demons attempting to damage the Buddha’s doctrine. And, they go on to say, the Buddha himself declared that it is necessary to distinguish between what is and what is not the Buddha’s word, between teachings of the unwholesome and teachings of what is great. Any teachings that are introduced in the Sūtra Collection, appear in the Vinaya, or are not in contradiction with the true nature of things according to the Abhidharma are teachings of what is great; such teachings are the Buddha’s word.

de las ldog pa nag po bstan pa ni bdud dang mu stegs pa'i chos yin no zhes gsungs na/ theg chen las ni/ phung khams skye mched kyi chos kyi ngo bo med par bshad pa de nyan thos kyi gzhung gis phung khams yod par bshad pa'i mdo sde dang mi mthun/ nyan thos pa'i 'dul bar sangs rgyas dang chos dge 'dun med par smras na ltung ba 'byung bar gsungs/ theg chen las med par bshad pas 'dul ba la mi snang / nyan thos pa'i gzhung las rten cing 'brel 'byung skye zhing 'gag pa'i chos can lugs 'byung gis 'khor ba dang / lugs las ldog pas myang 'das su bshad cing / theg chen las chos thams cad mi skye mi 'gag ces bshad pa dang / yang nyan thos pa'i gzhung las mthong sgom gyis spang bya dngos por gyur pa spangs nas myang 'das thob par bshad/ theg chen las spang bya spong byed kyi ngo bo nyid med pa dang / chos rnams rang bzhin gyis myang 'das su bshad pa sogs mngon pa'i chos nyid dang 'gal bas bka' ma yin zhes zer/

Their opposite, teachings of the unwholesome, are the way of demons and tīrthikas. That being the case, the explanation in the Mahāyāna texts that the aggregates, sense spheres, and senses-and-fields are devoid of essence conflicts with the sūtras of the listeners’ scriptures that teach the aggregates and sense spheres as existing. In the listeners’ Vinaya, it is taught that to declare that there is no Buddha, Dharma, or Saṅgha constitutes a downfall: the explanations in Mahāyāna texts that they do not exist do not appear in their Vinaya. The listeners’ scriptures teach that dependent arising, which by nature involves birth and cessation, leads in its forward order to saṃsāra and in the reverse order to nirvāṇa, whereas the Mahāyāna texts state that all phenomena are unborn and unceasing. Furthermore, while the listeners’ scriptures state that it is by eliminating real obscurations on the paths of seeing and meditation that one attains nirvāṇa, the Mahāyāna texts teach that the obscurations to be eliminated and the antidotes eliminating them have no essential reality and that phenomena are by nature nirvāṇa. So on these and other points the Mahāyāna texts contradict the true nature of things according to the Abhidharma. On all these grounds, say the listeners, the Great Vehicle is not the Buddha’s word.

yang nyan thos kyi theg pa 'di kho na dbang po dman pas rang don du bsgrubs na nyan thos kyi 'bras bu dang / 'bring gis bskal pa brgyar goms par byas na rang rgyal bse ru lta bu/ gang zag rab 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal bsran nus pa rnams kyis bskal pa grangs med gsum du goms par byas na sangs rgyas 'grub kyi nyan thos kyi theg pa las gzhan pa'i theg chen med ces zer ro/ /

They go on to point out that if people of modest capacity practice just this Listeners’ Vehicle for their own good, they will attain the result of listener; those of middling capacity, by training for one hundred kalpas, will become rhinoceros-like solitary realizers; and if individuals of superior faculties, who are able to endure the sufferings of saṃsāra, train for three measureless kalpas, they will accomplish buddhahood. But apart from the vehicle of the listeners, they say, there is no other Great Vehicle.
de la lan gsungs pa/
There are eight different arguments in reply to the above objections:

gal te theg pa chen po sangs rgyas kyi bka' ma yin par bstan pa la gnod pa zhig yin na sangs rgyas kyi sngar ma 'ongs pa na 'di ltar 'byung zhes lung ston rigs pa la sngar lung ma bstan pa'i phyir dang /

(1) If the Mahāyāna were not the Buddha’s word and were a doctrine that would have an adverse effect on his teachings, surely the Buddha would previously have predicted it, saying, “This is what will happen in the future.” But he did not.
theg pa che chung gnyis ka sangs rgyas bzhugs pa'i dus su lhan cig byung ba yin pa'i phyis su 'byung ngo zhes pa ma nges pa'i phyir dang /
(2) Both the Great and Lesser Vehicles appeared at the same time, when the Buddha was present in this world, and there can be no certainty in the claim that the Great Vehicle appeared later.
sa dang phar phyin dang stong pa nyid sogs kyi chos zab cing rgya che ba 'di lta bu rtog ge dang mu stegs pa'i spyod yul ma yin pas de dag gis rtsom mi nus pa'i phyir dang /

(3) Since profound and extensive teachings like those on the levels, transcendent perfections, and emptiness are beyond the scope of such intellectuals and tīrthikas, the latter would have been incapable of composing them.
gal te sa dang / phar phyin sogs rang nyid kyis ji lta bar rtogs pa'i sangs rgyas gzhan gyis rtsom pa yin na de sangs rgyas kyi gsung du'ang grub pa yin pa'i phyir dang /

(4) If, then, the teachings on the levels, transcendent perfections, and similar topics were composed by some other buddha—someone who had the same realization of the levels and perfections—this proves that such teachings could also be the Buddha’s word.

gzhan yang bcom ldan 'das shAkya'i rgyal po nyid kyis nyan thos rnams la chos bstan pa'i tshe na theg pa gsum zhes yongs su grags pa yin par ni rtsod pa med la/ sangs rgyas de nyid theg pa gsum ston pa po yin te rigs can gsum gyi lam thams cad mkhyen pa'i ston pa por grub bo/ / de'i phyir yod dang med na yod med dang zhes pa/

Besides, it is well known that at the time Lord Buddha, the King of the Śākyas, taught the Dharma to the listeners, he spoke of the three vehicles—this is not disputed. It is the Buddha himself who taught the three vehicles, for it is established that he is the teacher who knew the paths of the three kinds of individual in their entirety. This is why the root verse says, “Its existence or nonexistence depends on there being another vehicle.”

theg pa chen po zhes pa nyan thos kyi theg pa las logs su yod na nyan thos kyi theg pa'ang yod par 'gyur te theg pa chen po sangs rgyas nyid kyi lam mi bstan pa'i rang don zhi ba don gnyer gyi nyan thos kyi theg pa yang yod par grub bo/ /

(5) If there is a so-called Great Vehicle separate from the Listeners’ Vehicle, there must also be a Listeners’ Vehicle. The fact that one can strive for peace for one’s own sake, something that is not taught in the Great Vehicle, the path for achieving buddhahood, is the proof that there is also a Listeners’ Vehicle.

nyan thos kyi theg pa las gzhan du theg chen med na nyan thos kyi theg pa yang med par 'gyur te/ theg pa gcig la che chung gnyis su bzhag pa mi srid pa'i phyir dang / rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa'i sangs rgyas su sgrub pa'i lam logs su med pas sangs rgyas mi srid par 'gyur la des na de sangs rgyas nas nyan thos kyi theg pa yang bstan par mi srid pa'i phyir dang / yang na nyan thos rnams kyang sangs rgyas su 'gyur rigs na de mi srid phyir nyan thos kyi theg pa yang med pa mgo mnyam par 'gyur ro/ /

And if (6) there were no Great Vehicle other than the Listeners’ Vehicle, there could not be a Listeners’ Vehicle either, because it is impossible to have a single vehicle posited as two, a greater and a lesser. Since there would not then be a separate path for accomplishing omniscient buddhahood, buddhahood would be impossible, and without a buddha it is impossible that even the Listeners’ Vehicle would have been taught. Put another way, since it is impossible for listeners to become buddhas, there would not even be a Listeners’ Vehicle, which comes to the same thing.

gal te theg chen zhig yod na ni de sangs rgyas 'jig rten du byung ba'i tshe gdul bya theg chen rigs can rnams la bstan par rigs te/ de thams cad mkhyen pa yin pa dang rigs can gsum rjes su 'dzin pa'i thugs rje mnga' ba'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir bcom ldan 'das nyid kyis theg chen gsung rigs pas theg chen yod dgos la/ yod na sa dang phar phyin stong nyid sogs phyin ci ma log pa bstan pa'i chos 'di las theg chen gzhan du ma dmigs pa'i phyir/ 'di sangs rgyas kyi bka' theg pa chen po yin gyi rtog ge bas brtsams pa ma yin no/ /

If there is a Great Vehicle, then it is reasonable to suppose that when the Buddha appeared in the world, he would have taught it to those disciples who were of the Mahāyāna family,[1] for he is omniscient and compassionate, taking all three kinds of beings as his disciples. It follows, therefore, that Lord Buddha himself taught a Great Vehicle, so a Great Vehicle must exist. And if it exists, because we know of no great vehicle other than the unmistaken teachings on the levels, transcendent perfections, emptiness, and so forth, these teachings must be the Great Vehicle expounded by the Buddha. They cannot have been composed by intellectuals.

gzhan yang theg chen gyi chos ni sgrib gnyis kyi gnyen po yin pa'i phyir/ gal te de med na nyan thos kyi theg pa las bstan pa'i chos gang zag gi bdag med rtogs pa tsam la ji tsam goms kyang shes sgrib mi spong bas thams cad mkhyen pa'i sangs rgyas su 'grub pa'i lam med par 'gyur ro/ /

(7) Another reason is that the teachings of the Great Vehicle constitute the antidote to the two obscurations. If there were no Great Vehicle, then however much one trained in realizing the individual no-self, which is all that is taught in the Listeners’ Vehicle, one would not eliminate the cognitive obscurations, and there would therefore be no way to accomplish omniscient buddhahood.

sangs rgyas med/ lam med/ 'bras bu med/ skye 'gag med sogs gsungs pa ni/ sgra ji bzhin du kun rdzob tu med par dgag pa ma yin te sgra don gzhan nam dgongs pa gzhan gyi phyir yin pas/ de chos nyid dang 'gal ba ma yin no/ / zhes rigs pa'i rnam grangs brgyad gsungs so/ /

(8) The teachings that there is no Buddha, no path, no result, no birth, no cessation, and so on, do not, as the words appear to suggest, negate their existing in relative truth. These teachings were given in order to convey other meanings or express other intentions, and they are not therefore in contradiction with the nature of things.
sangs rgyas rnams ni mngon sum spyan/ / bstan pa dag kyang srung bar mdzad/ / dus la'ang ye shes ma bsgribs pas/ / de phyir btang snyoms mi rung ngo / /

sangs rgyas kyis sngar lung ma bstan pa tsam gyis theg chen chos log min par ma nges snyam na/ sangs rgyas rnams ni shes bya thams cad la chags thogs med pa'i phyir chos kun la mngon sum gzigs pa'i ye shes kyi spyan mnga' bas mi mkhyen pa ni mi srid la/ sems can gyi don du bstan pa srung bar mdzad pa'i thugs rje dus las mi yol ba mnga' bas bstan pa la gnod pa'i chos 'byung bar gzigs kyang lung mi ston par btang snyoms su bzhag par mi mdzad pa dang / dus gsum kun la'ang ye shes kyi gzigs pa ma sgrib pa 'jug pas na/ rgyu mtshan de gsum gyi phyir lung mi ston par btang snyoms mdzad par mi rung ngo / /

One might argue that just because the Buddha did not predict it, one cannot be certain that the Mahāyāna is not a false teaching. (1) The buddhas, being free of all attachment and obstruction with regard to everything there is to be known, have the eye of gnosis that sees all phenomena directly. That there is something they do not know is, therefore, impossible. (2) They possess timely compassion, acting to preserve the doctrine for beings’ benefit, so they would be watching out for any event that could be detrimental to the teachings and would not remain indifferent by failing to predict it. (3) Their unclouded wisdom-vision penetrates even the whole of the past, present, and future. So for these three reasons, one cannot accept the argument that a buddha might act indifferently and fail to make predictions.
ma tshang ba dang 'gal ba dang / / thabs min de ltar ma bstan phyir/ / nyan thos kyi ni theg pa 'di/ / theg chen chos shes bya ba min/ /
Because it is incomplete and in contradiction, And is neither the method nor taught in that way, This vehicle of the listeners Is not what is known as the Great Vehicle. (II, 3)

gzhan yang nyan thos kyi theg pa 'ba' zhig yun ring goms pas sangs rgyas su 'gyur ba mi rigs te/ theg pa chen po'i lam ni rang dang gzhan gyi don gnyis sgrub par byed pa yin na/ nyan thos kyi theg par gzhan don sgrub pa'i bya ba ma tshang ba dang / rang 'khor bas 'jigs nas skyo zhing chags pa bral te zhi bde don du gnyer bas gzhan don bsgrub par 'gal ba dang / bla med byang chub thob pa'i thabs ni bdag med gnyis ka rtogs pa'i shes rab dang / sems can thams cad sdug bsngal las bsgral bar 'dod pa'i snying rje chen po dang de gnyis gtso bo yin na nyan thos kyi theg pa la zhugs pa ni de lta bu'i thabs min zhing thabs de ltar ma bstan pa'i phyir/ nyan thos kyi theg pa 'di ni theg pa chen po zhes bya ba min te theg chen dang 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ /

Moreover, one cannot attain buddhahood by training for a long time in the Listeners’ Vehicle alone. While the path of the Great Vehicle is the one that accomplishes the twofold goal (one’s own and others’), the accomplishment of others’ goals is lacking in the Listeners’ Vehicle, which is thus incomplete. The fact that listeners, out of fear and disenchantment with saṃsāra, strive to attain freedom from attachment and peace for themselves is in contradiction with accomplishing others’ good. And while the method for attaining unsurpassable enlightenment comprises, above all, both wisdom (the realization of the two kinds of no-self) and great compassion (the wish that all sentient beings be freed from suffering), following the Listeners’ Vehicle is not such a method, and the method is not taught in that way.[2] For this reason, this vehicle of the listeners is not what we call the Great Vehicle, for it conflicts with the Great Vehicle.
bsam pa dang ni bstan pa dang / / sbyor ba dang ni rton pa dang / / dus 'gal phyir na dman pa gang / / de ni dman pa kho na yin/ /
Because its attitude, teachings, Application, support, and duration Conflict and are thus inferior, It is just that—a lesser vehicle. (II, 4)

ji ltar 'gal na/ rang don yid byed kyi bsam pa dang ni bsam pa de dang mthun par de'i lam yang rang don zhi ba tsam thob pa'i ched du bstan pa dang / lam de lta bu la brtson pas sbyor ba dang ni/ rtogs pa tshogs gnyis rgya chen po la mi 'jug par dman pa dang / dus yun thung tshe gsum la sogs pas 'bras bu mthar thug pa thob nus pa'i phyir na bsam pa sogs lnga po de theg chen las dman pa gang yin pa de ni rnam pa kun tu lam rang gi ngo bos theg pa chen po las dman pa kho na yin pas theg chen du ga la 'gyur zhes so/ /

In what way does the Listeners’ Vehicle conflict with the Great Vehicle? Its attitude is to keep one’s own goal in mind. It teaches the listeners’ path consistent with that attitude, in order to obtain mere peace for oneself. Its application involves diligently practicing such a path. The support to be relied upon is inferior in that listeners do not undertake the two accumulations on a vast scale. And its time span is short, for one can attain its ultimate fruit in as little as three lifetimes. Hence, these five aspects (attitude, teaching, application, support, and time) being lesser compared to those of the Great Vehicle, the Listeners’ Vehicle is in every respect, by the very nature of its path, just that—a lesser vehicle compared to the Great Vehicle, so how could it be a great vehicle?
rang gi nyid la 'jug pa dang / / rang gi 'dul la'ang snang phyir dang / / zab pa'i phyir dang rgya che'i phyir/ / chos nyid dang ni 'gal ba med/ /
The Great Vehicle is introduced in its own sūtras, And is evident in its own Vinaya; And because it is profound, because it is extensive, It does not contradict the true nature of things. (II, 5)

mdo sde la mi 'jug pa sogs kyi skyon brjod pa don med de/ nyan thos pa'i mdo sde sogs kha cig dang ma mthun pas theg chen bka' min par mi 'grub ste/ nyan thos sde pa rnams kyi mdo sde yang phan tshun mi mthun pa yod pas/ nged kyi 'dod tshod kyi mdo sde sogs dang mi mthun no snyam pa khyed rang gi blo skyon yin gyi/ theg pa chen po'i chos kyi skyon ma yin te/ khyed rang gis mdo sde'i dgongs don zab mo ma rtogs pas 'gal bar bzung gi sangs rgyas kyi gsung snga phyi la ni don gyis 'gal ba med do/ / mchog gsum dang phung khams skye mched kyi chos rnams byis pa'i ngor kun brtags pa tsam du yod pa'am tha snyad du yod par theg chen pas kyang 'dod la/ 'di ni rnam pa kun tu bden par grub cing mi bslu ba'o zhes de dag rang gi ngo bo nyid don dam par med pa ni khyed cag gis rtogs mi nus pas sangs rgyas kyis kyang kun rdzob tha snyad kyi dbang du byas te skye 'gag dang kun byang dang spang bya dang gnyen po la sogs pa gsungs nas/ chos rnams ngo bo nyid med pa ma bstan kyang / ngo bo nyid med pa'i stong pa ma yin par bstan pa ni med de/ gzugs ni dbu ba rdos pa 'dra zhes sogs phung po lnga gsog gsob sgyu ma ltar gsungs pa nyan thos kyi theg par yang bstan to/ /

To find fault with the Mahāyāna teachings in their not being introduced in the sūtras and so on makes no sense. The fact that the Mahāyāna scriptures do not agree with some of the listeners’ sūtras and other texts does not prove that the Great Vehicle is not the Buddha’s word. Even the sūtras of the different listeners’ orders do not agree with one another, so to think, “The Mahāyāna does not agree with the sūtras and other scriptures that we accept” is a shortcoming in the listeners’ own thinking, not in the Mahāyāna teachings. Because they have not realized the profound intended meaning of the sūtras, they believe that there is a contradiction, but in fact there is no contradiction between the Buddha’s earlier and later teachings. Even the Great Vehicle accepts that phenomena like the Three Jewels and the aggregates, sense spheres, and senses-and-fields exist for immature beings—conventionally or as mere imputations. It is because the listeners would be unable to understand that these phenomena (which they say are in every respect truly existing and undelusory) ultimately have no intrinsic nature that in the Listeners’ Vehicle the Buddha spoke of subjects such as birth, cessation, defilement and purity, obscurations to be eliminated, and antidotes from the point of view of relative, conventional truth, and that he did not teach that phenomena have no intrinsic nature. But at no time did he teach that they were not without intrinsic nature and not empty, for in the Listeners’ Vehicle too he spoke of the five aggregates being hollow and insubstantial, like magical illusions (“Form is like a bubble about to burst,” and so on).[3]

de'i phyir nyan thos kyi theg pa las ches zab cing rgya che ba'i theg pa chen po rang gi dbang du byas nas lhag pa'i bslab pa gsum bstan pa'i mdo sde 'dul ba mngon pa'i chos gsum yod pas/ rang gi mdo sde nyid la 'jug pa dang / theg chen rang gi nyon mongs pa'i phyogs 'dul ba la snang ba'i phyir dang / zab pa dang rgya che ba'i don phyin ci ma log par ston pa'i phyir/ theg pa chen po'i mngon pa nas bstan pa'i chos nyid dang 'gal ba med do/ /

There is, therefore, no contradiction. From its own point of view, the Great Vehicle, which is more profound and extensive than the Listeners’ Vehicle, has all three sections that teach the three superior trainings—namely the Sūtra section, Vinaya, and Abhidharma. It is introduced in its own Sūtra section. It is evident in its own Vinaya, which relates to defilements specific to the Great Vehicle. And because it unmistakenly indicates the profound and extensive teachings, it is not in contradiction with the true nature of things as taught in the Mahāyāna Abhidharma.
rtog ge rten cing ma nges la/ / ma khyab kun rdzob skyo ba can/ / byis pa la ni rten par 'dod/ / de phyir de ni de yul min/ /

Intellectuals are held to be reliant, uncertain, Not comprehensive, confined to the relative, and wearied, And they relate to immature beings. That is why the Great Vehicle is not within their scope. (II, 6)

sngar rtog ge'i spyod yul ma yin zhes pa der ma nges te rtog ge ba spyod pa can dag gi ci yang rtsom nus so snyam na ma yin te/ rtog ge zhes pa ni tshu rol mthong spyod yul 'ba' zhig la rtog dpyod byed kyi/ tshur mthong las brgal ba'i don zab mo la 'jug mi nus pas rtog ge ba zhes grags so/ / de 'dra'i rtog ge ba ni gzhan gyis bshad pa'am rang gis mthong ba'i rtags kyi rgyu mtshan sogs la brten cing / dpyod pa tsam byed pa dang / shes bya thams cad yongs su ma nges la rang gis blos ci tsam bzod pa'i don nyi tshe ba la bsam pa tsam yin pas ji snyed pa'i shes bya kun la ma khyab pa dang / ji lta ba zab mo stong pa nyid kyi don mi shes par tshu rol mthong ba'i rgyud kyi dbang po dang yid kyis ci tsam shes nus pa de tsam gyi kun rdzob kyi spyod yul can yin pa dang / don gyi gnas zab cing rgya che ba gzhal ba la spobs pa gtugs shing gzhal mi nus par skyo ba can yin la/ de dag ni byis pa so so'i skye bo la ni rten par 'dod do/ /

Earlier it was said that the Mahāyāna teachings are beyond the scope of intellectuals. You might argue that there is no certainty in this, and that intellectuals can write anything. This is not the case. Those we call intellectuals apply their gross and subtle analyses only to things that come within their own limited sphere of vision. They are incapable of penetrating profound points that conflict with their own ordinary ways of thinking, and this is why they are called intellectuals. Such intellectuals are held to be reliant on evidence based on others’ explanations or what they see for themselves, and they only practice analysis. Instead of ascertaining everything that can be known,[4] they reflect only on the superficial meanings that their own intellects can accept, so they can neither encompass phenomena in all their multiplicity nor understand that the profound nature of things is emptiness. Their scope is that of relative truth, confined to what they are capable of knowing with their own ordinary senses and minds. Incapable of fathoming the ultimate condition of things, the profound and extensive, for they lack the courage, these wearied individuals[5] relate to ordinary, immature beings.

rgyu mtshan de yi phyir na shin tu zab cing rtogs pa dka' ba dang rgya che mu med pa'i don bstan pa'i theg pa chen po de ni rtog ge de yi yul min te/ sangs rgyas kyis bshad pa'i chos ni thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes mnga' bas gzhan la rten pa sogs rtog ge'i mtshan nyid gong bshad kun las 'das te bsam gyis mi khyab pa yin pas/ rtog ge dang mu stegs kyi chos la 'di lta bu'i chos 'byung mi srid pas de dag gi gzhung na sa dang phar phyin stong pa nyid sogs theg chen las bshad pa de lta bu sngar yang ma mthong la phyis kyang mthong mi srid do/ / nyan thos kyi theg par 'tshang rgya ba'i thabs ma bstan na theg pa chen po las ji ltar bstan zhe na/ rgya che'i phyir dang sogs tshigs bcad gcig gsungs te/

That is why the Great Vehicle, which teaches truths that are extremely profound and difficult to understand and infinitely vast, is not the object of intellectuals. The Dharma expounded by the Buddha is imbued with omniscient gnosis, and therefore it transcends all the aforementioned definitions of intellectuals—relying on others’ logical principles and so on. It is inconceivable. Such a Dharma, therefore, could not possibly originate in the teachings of intellectuals and tīrthikas. Subjects like the levels, transcendent perfections, and emptiness that are explained in the Mahāyāna scriptures have never been seen in their texts in the past, and it is impossible that they will ever appear there in the future either. Were you to ask, “If the method for attaining buddhahood is not taught in the Listeners’ Vehicle,[6] how is it that it is taught in the Great Vehicle?” the answer is given in the following verse.
rgya che'i phyir dang zab pa'i phyir/ / yongs su smin dang rnam mi rtog / de phyir 'di las gnyis bstan te/ / de ni bla na med pa'i thabs/ /

Because it is extensive, because it is deep, One is matured and nonconceptuality is realized. For this reason, both aspects are taught in the Great Vehicle, And it is this that is the means to the unsurpassable. (II, 7)

ji snyed pa sa dang phar phyin sogs rgya che ba'i chos bstan pa'i phyir dang / ji lta ba zab mo stong pa nyid bstan pa'i phyir/ rgya che ba bsod nams kyi tshogs la brten nas rang gi rgyud yongs su smin pa dang / zab pa stong nyid rtogs pa'i dbang gis rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes 'byung ba de phyir theg pa chen po 'di las zab rgya che ba de gnyis bstan te/ de ni bla na med pa'i byang chub bsgrub pa'i thabs yin no/ /

Because the Mahāyāna teaches the full extent of things, the extensive subjects of the levels, transcendent perfections, and so forth, and because it teaches the true nature of things, profound emptiness, one’s stream of being is fully matured through the accumulation of merit (the extensive aspect), and nonconceptual gnosis arises through the realization of emptiness (the profound aspect). For this reason, both the profound and extensive aspects are taught in the Great Vehicle, and it is this that is the means for accomplishing unsurpassable enlightenment.

nyan thos rang don du 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal zhi ba don du gnyer ba rnams ni gang zag gi bdag med tsam shes pas ji lta ba rtogs pa'i ye shes kyang theg chen pa la ltos na yungs 'bru srin gyis zos pa'i nang gi nam mkha' ltar rgya chung zhing / ji snyed pa rtogs pa'ang smon nas shes pa'i mthus yul dus rnam pas shin tu bskal bar ma gyur pa'i dngos po tsam brtags na shes pa dang / dam pa'i chos kyang tshad med pa ma rtogs kyang rten 'brel snying po'i tshigs bcad gcig tsam gyi don las bdag med par rtogs nas 'bras bu thob nus so/ / theg pa chen po'i zab mo'i ye shes ni rnam par mi rtog pa shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa shes bya kun gyi rjes su song bas nam mkha' ltar rgya che ba dang / rig pa'i gnas lnga dang / nang don gyi rig pa theg pa gsum gyi chos rgya che zhing grangs tshad med pa'i yul can yin no/ / theg chen pa'i bsod nams kyi tshogs ni rgya mtsho chen po'i chu ltar tshad med la/ nyan thos pa'i bsod nams kyi tshogs ni ba lang gi rmig rjes kyi chu ltar chung ba yin no/ /zhes gsungs so/ /

It is said that the listeners, striving for their own sake to achieve peace from the sufferings of saṃsāra, know only the no-self of the individual, and therefore their gnosis (the realization of the nature of things), compared to that of a Mahāyāna practitioner, is as minute as the space eaten out by a weevil inside a mustard seed. As for their realization of all things in their multiplicity, by the power of their aspiration for knowledge, they can only know, through examination, things that are not too remote in space or time. And although they have not realized the boundless qualities of the sacred Dharma, they are able to realize no-self from the meaning of just a single verse on the essence of dependent arising and achieve their result. In the Great Vehicle, the gnosis of the profound aspect is nonconceptual transcendent wisdom, and since it realizes everything that is to be known, it is as vast as space. It is the subject that knows the countless, extensive topics of the five sciences and of the three vehicles that make up the inner science of the Buddhist teachings. A Mahāyāna practitioner’s accumulation of merit is as boundless as the water in the ocean, compared to which the accumulation of merit of someone practicing the Listeners’ Vehicle is a mere puddle in a cow’s hoofprint.
gnyis pa theg pa chen po la log par 'dzin pa spang bar gdams pa la/
2. INSTRUCTIONS ON GETTING RID OF WRONG BELIEFS REGARDING THE GREAT VEHICLE

'gro ba de'i gnas min la skrag pa gdung byed 'gyur/ / bsod nams ma yin phung chen bsags byas yun ring du/ / rigs med grogs ngan sngon dge ma bsags blo ma sbyangs/ / chos 'dis skrag 'gyur 'di na don chen 'di las ltung / /

Beings’ groundless fear of the Great Vehicle makes them suffer, Accumulating a great mass of negative karma over long periods of time. With no potential, evil companions, no virtue accumulated from the past, and an untrained mind, They are frightened by this Dharma here, and miss the great goal. (II, 8)
ces tshigs bcad brgyad gsungs te/

'gro ba dman pa rnams ni skrag pa de'i gnas min pa theg chen la skrag pa yi rang gi yid gdung bar byed cing chos la sdang bar byed do/ / des ni bsod nams ma yin pa'i phung po chen po bsags par byas nas dus phyi mar dmyal ba'i sdug bsngal gyis yun ring du gdung bar byed do/ / de ltar theg chen la skrag nas 'dor ba de rgyu gang las 'byung na theg chen gyi rigs med pa dang / rkyen theg chen la sdang ba'i grogs ngan pas bzung ba dang / sngon gyi dge ba ma bsags pas mos par mi nus pa dang / tshe 'dir zab don la blo ma sbyangs pa rnams kyis theg pa chen po'i chos 'dis skrag par 'gyur zhing / 'di na theg pa chen po'i chos yod bzhin du de la gus par mi byed par don chen po 'di las ltung bar 'gyur ba yin pas ci nas de ltar shes pas bag yod pa'i sems kyis nyes pa de las rang bsrung bar gyis shig ces gdams pa'o/ /

Beings of modest capacity are afraid of the Great Vehicle, though it is not something to be afraid of. This causes them mental distress and makes them hostile to the Dharma. As a result, they accumulate an enormous amount of negative karma and in the future will be tormented for long periods of time by the sufferings in the hells. The cause underlying this fear and rejection of the Mahāyāna is that they do not have the Mahāyāna potential. There are also the contributory conditions of their being taken on by the wrong sorts of companions (ones who are hostile to the Great Vehicle), of their having failed to accumulate merit in the past and thus being incapable of any interest in the Great Vehicle, and of their not having trained their minds in the profound meaning in the present life. As a result, they become afraid of these Mahāyāna teachings and, failing to respect the Mahāyāna teachings when they are present here, they will miss the great goal. This verse, therefore, is an instruction to guard oneself at all costs against these shortcomings by acquainting oneself with them and maintaining a careful attitude.

de las gzhan dang gzhan med shin tu zab cing rjes song phyir/ / sna tshogs ston cing mang po'i sgo nas rtag tu ston dang ldan/ / ji skad bshad bzhin don min bcom ldan dgongs pa shin tu zab/ / mkhas pa rnams kyis tshul bzhin brtags na chos 'dis skrag mi 'gyur/ /

There is no other vehicle than the Great Vehicle, for it is utterly profound and it is concordant. Teaching a variety of things and continuously indicating them through numerous means, It does not mean exactly what is said, for the Lord’s intention is exceedingly profound. If properly examined by the wise, this Dharma will not give them cause to fear. (II, 9)

theg pa chen po de las mchog tu gyur pa'i theg pa gzhan dang gzhan yul dus gang na yang med la/ de'i dgongs pa shin tu zab cing gdul bya'i bsam pa'am shes bya'i rnam pa thams cad kyi rjes su song ba'i phyir/ rjes song gi don theg pa che chung dus mtshungs su byung ba la 'chad ba'ang yod/ mchan/ sa dang phar phyin byang phyogs phung khams skye mched gnas gnas min sogs rgya che ba'i chos kyi rnam pa sna tshogs ston cing / stong pa nyid sogs chos kyi rnam grangs re re yang tshig dang don gyi rnam pa tha dad pa'i mdo sde mang po'i sgo nas yang yang rtag tu ston pa dang ldan la dgongs pa dang ldem dgongs kyi sgo nas bstan pa phal cher ji skad bshad pa'i tshig de bzhin don du gzung bar bya ba'ang min pa'i phyir sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi dgongs pa ni shin tu zab pa'o/ / de'i phyir mkhas pa rnams kyis tshul bzhin brtags na theg chen gyi chos 'dis skrag par mi 'gyur bar slar ngo mtshar zhing gus pa'i 'du shes skye ba'i phyir brtags par bya yi ma brtags par spang bar mi bya'o/ / zhes gdams pa'o/ /

There is no Supreme Vehicle other than that Great Vehicle, in any realm or age, for its intent is extremely profound and it concurs with all beings’ aspirations or with all aspects of knowledge. (“Concurs” is also explained as meaning that the Great and Lesser Vehicles appeared at the same time.)[7] It teaches the various aspects of the extensive Dharma—the levels, transcendent perfections, elements leading to enlightenment, aggregates, sense spheres, and senses-and-fields, what is correct and what is incorrect, and so forth. And it repeatedly and continuously demonstrates each of the teachings, such as that on emptiness, in numerous sūtras with different words and meanings. Because these were taught using implied teachings and indirect teachings and the words used to explain them are, for the most part, not to be taken literally, Lord Buddha’s intention is extremely profound. For this reason, if the wise examine them properly, the teachings of the Great Vehicle will not make them afraid. Instead, they will feel all the more wonder and respect. This verse, therefore, advises us to examine the Great Vehicle and not to reject it without having done so.

'di na dang por thos la brtan nas yid la byed pa 'byung / / tshul bzhin yid la byed las yang dag don yul ye shes 'byung / / de las chos thob de yod de las blo gros rab tu skye/ / gang tshe de ni so so rang rig med na ji ltar nges/ /

brtags kyang nges pa ma rnyed pa yang srid mod kyi de ni zab mo'i don la so so rang gis rig pa dngos lta ci rjes su mthun pa'i blo gros ma skyes pas yin par bstan pa ni/ chos la 'jug pa'i gnas skabs 'di na dang po thos pa la brten nas de'i don yid la byed pa 'byung ste ma thos par bsam pa'am yid byed de 'byung mi srid do/ / tshul bzhin yid la byed pa las yang dag pa'i don yul du byed pa'i mos spyod pa'i bzod pa'i ye shes 'byung ba/ de las 'phags pa'i chos sa dang po thob pa dang / de las sa bcu'i ye shes sam blo gros rab tu skye ba yin yang / gang gi tshe yang dag pa'i don zab mo de ni rtogs par byed pa dag tshur mthong gi blos nam yang ma yin te so so rang rig pa yin na/ de 'dra'i so so rang rig med na gzhan rtog ge'i blo gros kyis ji ltar nges te gzugs la lta ba'i mig med na rna ba sogs yod kyang mi mthong ba bzhin no/ /

Even if people do examine it, however, they might still not be convinced. This verse shows that this is because they have not developed an approximate understanding, let alone direct self-cognizant wisdom, with regard to the profound meaning. At this stage of the entrance to the Dharma, one begins by listening to the teachings, and on that basis one will keep their meaning in mind—reflecting on the teachings or keeping them in mind is impossible without having heard them. From properly keeping them in mind, there arises the gnosis of acceptance of a bodhisattva on the path of earnest aspiration that takes the true meaning as its object.[8] From that, the first level on the noble path is attained, and thence the gnosis or wisdom of the ten levels is born. At that time, however, what it is that realizes the profound true meaning is never an ordinary person’s mind but self-cognizant wisdom. So unless one has that self-cognizant wisdom, how can one be convinced with any other, intellectual, understanding? Forms cannot be seen without eyes to see them, even if one has ears and other sense organs.
bdag gis mi shes sangs rgyas zab mo mkhyen ma yin/ / zab mo ci yi phyir na rtog ge'i yul ma yin/ / ci phyir zab mo'i don rig pa dag thar 'gyur zhes/ / bya ba de ni skrag pa'i gnas su rigs ma yin/ /

“I do not understand it.” “Such profundities the Buddha cannot know.” “Why should the profound be beyond the scope of intellectuals?” “Why will those who realize the profound meaning be liberated?” Such thoughts don’t hold as reasons for being afraid. (II, 11)

de'i phyir na rang gis theg chen gyi don khong du ma chud kyang spang bar mi rigs te/ bdag gi mi shes pas na 'di chos yang dag min no zhes bsam par mi rung ste/ bdag tshogs ma bsags pas zab mo'i don rtogs pa'i skal pa med pas na/ dmus long gis nyi ma yod kyang mi mthong ba bzhin no/ / sangs rgyas kyis kyang zab mo gang zhig bdag cag gi blo'i yul du ma gyur pa mkhyen pa ma yin zhes bsam par mi rigs te/ bdag cag yang dag pa'i don la sgrib pa dang bcas pa yin la sangs rgyas ni sgrib pa thams cad bral ba'i ye shes mnga' ba'i phyir bdag gis mi shes pa sangs rgyas kyis cis mi mkhyen te/ rab rib can gyis gzugs phra mo ma mthong yang lha'i mig gis mi mthong ba ma yin pa bzhin no/ /

For this reason, even if one does not completely understand the meaning of the Great Vehicle, it is not right to reject it. It is wrong to think, “Because I don’t understand it, it is not the true Dharma.” We do not understand it because we have not accumulated enough merit and we therefore do not have the good fortune to realize the profound meaning—like blind people who cannot see even in broad daylight. Neither is it right to think that things that are too profound for us cannot be understood by the Buddha either. We are obscured as to the true meaning; the Buddha possesses gnosis free from all obscuration. So why would something we do not understand not be understood by the Buddha? People with blurred vision cannot see minute objects, but this is not the case for someone with the divine eye.

zab mo yin yang ci'i phyir na rtog ge'i yul ma yin zhes bsam par mi bya ste/ rtog ge'i shes pa tsam las ma 'phags na sangs rgyas rnams zab mo mngon par byang chub par ga la 'gyur/ ci'i phyir zab mo'i don skye 'gag med par rig pa dag thar bar 'gyur la/ mngon rjes kyi tshad mas dpyod pa'i rtog ge ba dag thar bar mi 'gyur zhes bsam par bya ba de ni theg chen la skrag pa'i gnas su rigs pa ma yin te/ mngon rjes tsam gyis dngos po la yongs su rtog pas grol na sems can thams cad ye nas grol bar rigs na yang / de mi 'thad de dngos po la mngon par zhen pas 'ching zhing dngos po rang bzhin med par shes na grol bar 'thad pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar byas pa rtog ge ba rang gi blo gros tshad mar bzung nas 'phags chen rnams kyis gzigs pa'i chos kyi don zab mo spangs pa ni khron pa'i rus sbal gyi dpe dang / dmus long gis mig ldan la 'gran pa lta bu shin tu blo gros blun pa ste rang blo tshad min la dpang por byas nas tshad ma sun 'byin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Do not think, “Even if it is profound, why should it not be within the scope of intellectuals?” If it were no better than mere intellectual knowledge, then why would the buddhas need to attain profound, manifest enlightenment? “Why will those who realize the profound meaning—that there is no birth and no cessation—be liberated, while intellectuals who analyze things with the valid cognition of direct perception and inference will not?” This sort of reflection is no reason for fearing the Great Vehicle. If one could be liberated merely by investigating things with direct perception and inferential logic, all sentient beings would be liberated from the beginning. This, however, is not the case, for they are bound by attachment to things. If they knew that things have no intrinsic existence, they would be liberated. Intellectuals who think like that believe their own understanding to be valid and have rejected the profound meaning of the Dharma perceived by the great noble beings. Like the frog in the fable of the frog in the well[9] and like a blind person competing against someone who can see, they are extremely foolish, for they swear by their own invalid thinking and repudiate valid cognition.
dman par mos shing khams kyang shin tu dman/ / grogs po dman pa dag gis yongs bskor ba/ / zab cing rgya che legs par bshad pa'i chos/ / 'di la gal te mos med grub pa yin/ /

The fact that those of lowly aspirations, of very base propensity, Who keep base friends for constant company Have no interest in this Dharma that perfectly explains The extensive and profound is proof of its superiority. (II, 12)

'di ltar bsam pa dman par mos shing / rgyu rigs sam khams kyang shin tu dman pa dang / rkyen grogs po dman pa theg chen la sdang ba dag gis yongs su bskor ba de dag zab cing rgya che ba'i don ma nor bar bshad pa'i chos 'di la gal te mos pa med pa de nyid kyis chos 'di mchog tu grub pa yin te/ dman pa'i spyod yul ma yin pa'i phyir thun mong min pa'i chos su mkhas pa rnams kyis shes so/ /

As a result of their very base potential or propensity,[10] reinforced by the fact that they are surrounded by base companions who are averse to the Great Vehicle, people with lowly aspirations have no interest in these teachings that explain in an unmistaken way the profound and extensive meaning. Therein lies the proof of the Great Vehicle’s superiority. Because it is beyond the scope of inferior beings, the wise know that it is a teaching that is out of the ordinary.
thos rjes 'brangs te blo ldan thob nas ni/ / gang zhig thos la rab tu gnas byed pa/ / rnam pa sna tshogs dpag tu med lus la/ / rmongs pa gang gi phyir na nges par byed/
Adhering to what they have heard, they gain some discernment And despise anything else they hear. Ignorant of the rest of these boundless varied subjects, How could they ever be certain? (II, 13)

thos pa'i rjes su 'brangs te rigs mi rigs cung zad cig dpyod pa'i blo dang ldan pa thob nas ni/ da dung rang gis sngar ma shes pa'i don zab mo la mi dpyod par/ gang zhig thos pa gzhan theg chen la ma brtags par rab tu brnyas par byed pa ni mi rigs te/ ci'i phyir na khyod rang gis theg pa chen po'i dgongs don rnam pa sna tshogs dpag tu med pa ma shes par lhag ma lus pa la/ 'di rigs mi rigs chos yin min zhes rmongs pa khyod gang gi phyir na nges par byed de don tshul bzhin ma shes par blang bya dang dor bya'i khyad par nges par mi nus pa'i phyir ro/

Adhering to what they have heard, non-Mahāyānists have acquired a little bit of discernment in analyzing whether something is valid or invalid. And yet, instead of analyzing profound teachings that are unfamiliar to them, they scorn anything else they hear—that is, the Mahāyāna—without having examined it. This is wrong. Why? Because without knowing the infinite variety of subjects in the Great Vehicle, with all their implications, one will be ignorant as to whether the rest of the teachings are valid or invalid, as to whether they are the Dharma or not. How can you be certain?[11] Without properly understanding the meaning, you cannot be sure of the difference between what to accept and what to reject.
don sgra ji bzhin yongs rtog na/ / bdag nyid snyems shing blo nyams 'gyur/ / legs par gsungs pa'ang spangs pas na/ / brlag 'gyur chos la khong khro sgrib/ /
If one understands the words literally, One becomes proud and one’s intellect declines. Rejecting the Excellent Words as a whole, One will be destroyed, obscured by anger toward the Dharma. (II, 14)
yid kyi nyes pa rang bzhin gdug pa ste/ / mi rigs pa yi gzugs la'ang mi rigs na/ / the tshom za ba'i chos la smos ci dgos/ / de phyir btang snyoms gzhag legs nyes pa med/ /

Negative states of mind are by nature harmful— It is wrong to have them even for illogical things, Let alone for teachings that one doubts. It’s best, therefore, to be impartial, and thus free of fault. (II, 15)

mdo las gzugs med sgra med sogs don gang zhig sgra yis bstan tshod ltar de ji bzhin du nges par yongs su rtog pa'am khong du chud do zhes dgongs pa ma shes par phyin ci log tu bzung na/ tshig de'i don bdag gis shes so snyam du snyems pa skye zhing / don yang dag par ma shes pas blo nyams par 'gyur ba dang / de dang de lta bu la brten nas legs par gsungs pa gzhan yang spangs par byed pas na/ rang nyid brlag par 'gyur te ci'i phyir na zab mo'i chos la khong khro bas sgrib pa tshabs po che bsags par 'gyur bas so/ / de'i rgyu mtshan yid kyi nyes pa khro ba ni rang bzhin gyis gdug pa ste/ lus ngag gi bya ba ltar kun slong sogs kyis gzhan du mi 'gyur ba ngo bo nyid kyis kha na ma tho ba yin pa ste / de'i phyir yid du mi 'ong zhing gnod pa'i rkyen du gyur pa'am/ mi rigs pa yi gzugs mgal dum sogs la'ang khro bar mi rigs pa ni/ nyan thos kyi gzhung sog le lta bu'i mdo las/ dge slong dag mes tshig pa'i mgal dum la yang khro ba'i sems kyang skyed par mi rigs na/ sems dang bcas pa'i lus la lta ci smos/ zhes gsungs pa de ltar na/ chos yang dag yin min gtan la ma pheb par the tshom za ba'i chos la khro bar mi rung ba ni smos ci dgos te/ yang dag pa theg pa chen po'i chos spangs na 'jig rten gyi khams du ma chags 'jig gi bskal pa mang por yang nas yang du brgyud de mnar med du shin tu mi bzad pa'i sdug bsngal myong bar bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir na bdag legs su 'dod pa rnams kyis rang gis nyams 'og tu ma chud pa'i chos gang la yang mos pa ma skyes su zin kyang khro ba dang brnyas pa'i sgo nas smod par mi bya bar btang snyoms su bzhag na legs te rang la nyes pa 'byung ba med pas so/ /

If we take those passages in the sūtras that say, “There is no form, there is no sound…,” incorrectly, without knowing their intended meaning, and we think that we have definitely understood or fully comprehended them, as if they meant what the words indicate, we will become conceited, saying to ourselves, “I know what that phrase means,” and because we have not understood the correct meaning, our discernment will deteriorate. This sort of thing will lead to our rejecting other teachings of the Buddha’s Excellent Words as well. It is therefore destructive for us, for by getting angry at the profound teachings we will accumulate serious obscurations. The reason for this is that the mental fault of anger is naturally harmful. Unlike physical and verbal actions, which can be transformed by their motivation, it is by its very nature negative. It is inappropriate to get angry at something unpleasant that might harm one, or even at illogical objects such as bits of charred wood, for in the Mūlasarvāstivādin Sūtra Like a Saw,[12] the Buddha said, “Monks, it is not right to get angry at a piece of charred wood, let alone at a body that possesses consciousness.” So one need hardly mention that it is out of place to get angry at teachings about which one is skeptical and regarding which one is unable to determine whether or not they are the true Dharma. For as Lord Buddha said, if one has rejected the Mahāyāna teachings, one will repeatedly experience truly terrible suffering in the Hell of Torment Unsurpassed for many kalpas, during which time numerous world systems will be formed and destroyed. This is why, even though they may not feel interested in a teaching that they do not really understand, it is better for those who wish the best for themselves to remain impartial, rather than dishonoring it by getting angry or disrespectful, for they will then not be at fault.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las theg pa chen po sgrub pa'i skabs kyi le'u ste gnyis pa'o// //
This completes the second chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on establishing the Great Vehicle.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ theg pa chen po sgrub pa'i skabs kyi le'u ste gnyis pa'i don rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the meaning of the second chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on establishing the Great Vehicle.

! de ltar theg chen bkar bsgrubs nas theg pa che chung gi khyad par bye brag tu shes par bya ba la dbye sgo du ma yod kyang / skyabs 'gro nas sgrub pa'i bar bzhi po'i khyad par bshad pa rgyu rigs dang lam gyi thog ma'i 'jug sgo skyabs 'gro nas brtsams te bsam sbyor thams cad la khyad zhugs pa shes pa'i phyir ro/ /

Having thus established the Great Vehicle as the Buddha’s word, we now come to what is to be specifically known—namely, the differences between the Great and Lesser vehicles. Although there are many ways of classifying these, they are explained here in terms of the particular features of the four topics of refuge, potential, spiritual intent, and practice, beginning with the potential, which is the cause, and the refuge, which is the initial entrance to the path. From this we can understand the differences in the various attitudes and their application.
gnyis pa bye brag tu shes par bya ba
PART TWO. WHAT IS TO BE SPECIFICALLY KNOWN
['di] la/ skyabs 'gro rigs sems bskyed sgrub pa bzhi las/
This part has four sections: (1) refuge, (2) potential, (3) spiritual intent and (4) practice.
dang po
3. REFUGE
['di] la/ khyad par dang / khyad par de ldan gyi skyabs 'gro'i rang bzhin don bsdus te bstan pa gsum/
This chapter has three sections: (1) particular features; (2) the nature of the refuge that has those features; and (3) a concluding summary.
dang po
1. PARTICULAR FEATURES
['di] la khyad par bzhi mdor bstan/ de'i don rgyas par bshad pa gnyis/
The first of these is divided into two: (1) a brief presentation of the four particular features and (2) a detailed explanation of these four points.
dang po/
a. BRIEF PRESENTATION OF THE FOUR PARTICULAR FEATURES

kun tu 'gro dang khas len rtogs dang zil gnon par/ / dbye ba'i rang bzhin don rnam bzhi yi khyad par gyis/ / theg pa mchog phyir dkon mchog skyabs rab song ba gang / / de ni skyabs su song ba rnams kyi mchog ces bya/ / gang phyir dang por nges par bya ba 'di dka' ste/ / de ni bskal pa stong phrag du mar bsgrub par dka'/ / gang phyir grub na sems can phan byed don che ste/ / de phyir theg chen 'di la skyabs don mchog yin no/ /

Because of four particular features by which they are classified— Universality, commitment, realization, and overpowering supremacy— Those who fully take refuge in the Three Jewels with the Supreme Vehicle in mind Are known as the greatest among those who have gone for refuge. (III, 1) Why? At first it is difficult to make such a definite commitment, And practicing over many thousands of kalpas is hard; Because its accomplishment is of great benefit to beings, Taking refuge in this Great Vehicle is of the highest value. (III, 2)
zhes tshigs bcad gnyis kyis bstan te/

theg pa chen po dag gi skyabs 'gro ni khyad par bzhis 'phags te/ sems can thams cad bsgral bar zhugs pa sogs kyis kun tu 'gro ba dang / sangs rgyas nyid 'thob par bya'o zhes khas len pa dang / bdag med gnyis rtogs pa dang / 'jig rten pa dang nyan rang zil gyis gnon par byed pa ste dbye ba'i rang bzhin spyi don rnam pa bzhi yi khyad par gyis/ theg pa mchog gi don nam tshul gyi phyir ram ched du dkon mchog gsum la skyabs su rab tu song ba gang yin pa de ni/ 'jig rten pa tshangs dang dbang phyug sogs la skyabs su song ba dang / nyan rang rnams rang don du mchog gsum la skyabs su song ba rnams kyi mchog ces bya'o/ / gang gi phyir na so so'i skye bo dag gis dang por sems can thams cad 'khor ba las bsgral nas thar pa dang thams cad mkhyen pa'i go 'phang la bzhag pa'i ched du bdag bla na med pa rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sangs rgyas par bya'o zhes khas blangs shing smon lam 'debs pa'i nges par bya ba 'di dka' ste sems can mang po'i nang nas kyang 'di lta bu'i sems bskyed pa'i smon lam bgyid pa shin tu dkon no/ / de ltar sems bskyed nas bla med byang chub 'thob par bya ba dang sems can rnams yongs su bsgral phyir lus dang longs spyod gtong ba sogs kyi sbyor ba de ni bskal pa stong phrag du mar bsgrub par dka'o/ / gang gi phyir bla na med pa'i byang chub sangs rgyas su grub na sems can thams cad phyi ma'i mtha'i bar du phan pa byed pas don che ste/ de phyir theg pa chen po 'di la lam du bzung nas skyabs su brten pa ni don mchog dang ldan pa yin no/ /

The refuge of the followers of the Great Vehicle is superior on account of four particular features: their universality, for they have undertaken to liberate all sentient beings and so on; their commitment (“to attain buddhahood”); their realization of the two kinds of no-self; and the fact that they outshine worldly beings and listeners and solitary realizers. On account of the particularity of these four general points or divisions, anyone who has fully taken refuge in the Three Jewels with the goal or manner of the Supreme Vehicle specifically in mind is to be known as foremost among those who have gone for refuge—superior to those who have taken refuge in mundane beings such as Brahmā and Īśvara and to the listeners and solitary realizers who have taken refuge in the Three Jewels for their own benefit. Why is this? Because it is difficult in the beginning for ordinary beings to be definite in vowing and praying: “In order to free all sentient beings from saṃsāra and set them in liberation and omniscience, I will attain unsurpassable, perfect enlightenment as a buddha.” Of the numerous beings there are, those who make this kind of aspiration related to their spiritual intent are extremely rare. Then, once they have given rise to this spiritual intent, it is difficult to accomplish, for its application involves giving away their bodies, their possessions, and so forth in order to attain unsurpassable enlightenment and completely liberate sentient beings, and it takes many thousands of kalpas. When they accomplish unsurpassable enlightenment as buddhas, they benefit all sentient beings until the end of time, so it is very meaningful. This is why it is of the greatest value to take this Great Vehicle as the path and rely on it as a refuge.
rgyas bshad la gong gi rim pa bzhin bzhi las/
b. DETAILED EXPLANATION OF THESE FOUR POINTS IN ORDER
kun 'gro'i khyad par ni/
i. UNIVERSALITY

gang zhig sems can thams cad bsgral bar zhugs pa dang / / theg pa ye shes kun tu 'gro la mkhas par ldan/ / gang zhig mya ngan 'das la 'khor zhi ro gcig pa/ / de 'dra'i blo ldan de 'dir kun 'gror shes par bya/ /

Those who have set out to liberate all beings, Whose mastery is all-inclusive with regard to the vehicles and gnosis, And for whom nirvāṇa is the one taste of saṃsāra and peace— Such wise persons should be known for their universality. (III, 3)
zhes pas bstan te/

sems can dang theg pa dang ye shes dang myang 'das kun 'gro bzhi rim pa ltar/ gang zhig mtha' yas pa'i sems can thams cad bsgral bar zhugs pa dang / theg pa gsum po kun tu rtogs pa dang / bdag med gnyis rtogs kyi ye shes kun tu 'gro la mkhas par ldan pa dang / gang zhig mya ngan 'das pa'i dbyings 'khor ba dang zhi ba ro gcig tu rtogs shing shes rab dang snying rjes srid zhi'i mtha' la mi gnas pa myang 'das sam shes bya kun 'gro ste/ de 'dra'i blo ldan de skabs 'dir kun tu 'gro la rig par bya ste nyan thos rnams de lta bu dang mi ldan no/ /

The particular feature of universality is fourfold, related to sentient beings, vehicles, gnosis, and nirvāṇa, in that order. Bodhisattvas are engaged in liberating the whole infinity of sentient beings. They have realization of all three vehicles. They have mastered the universal gnosis that is the realization of the two kinds of no-self. And they have realized the expanse of nirvāṇa as the one taste of saṃsāra and peace and embrace the whole of nirvāṇa or knowable phenomena (for through their wisdom and compassion they do not remain in the extremes of existence and peace).[1] These wise beings are to be understood in this context as universal. The listeners do not possess this particular feature.
khas len
ii. COMMITMENT
['di] la dngos dang / dpes bstan pa gnyis/
This section is divided into two: (1) the actual commitment and (2) analogies indicating the virtues of that commitment.
dang po/
(1) THE ACTUAL COMMITMENT

gang zhig dga' ba mang pos byang chub mchog don gnyer/ / gang zhig skyo ba med par dka' ba yang dag spyod/ / gang zhig rnam sangs rgyas nas sangs rgyas kun mnyam 'gyur/ / blo ldan de ni khas len mchog tu shes par bya/ /

They who, with much joy, strive for supreme enlightenment, Who perfectly undergo austerities without getting discouraged, Who will attain buddhahood and be the equal of all the buddhas— Those wise persons should be known for their supreme commitment. (III, 4)
zhes pas bstan te/

gang zhig sangs rgyas kyi chos stobs dang mi 'jigs pa la sogs pa la snying thag pa nas dga' ba mang pos byang chub mchog don du gnyer ba bsam pa smon lam gyi khyad par dang / gang zhig mos spyod nas sa bcu'i bar du lam sgrub pa la skyo ba med par lus sogs gtong ba dang sdug bsngal dang du len pa sogs dka' ba yang dag par spyod pa bsgrub pa'i khyad par dang / gang zhig rnam par sangs rgyas nas sangs rgyas kun dang spangs rtogs la khyad med cing sku gsung thugs mnyam par 'gyur ba 'bras bu'i khyad par ste/ blo ldan de ni khas len nam dam bca' ba mchog tu shes par bya'o/ /

Bodhisattvas rejoice many times from the depth of their hearts in the Buddha’s qualities (his strengths, fearlessnesses, and so forth) and have the intention of striving for supreme enlightenment, so they are distinguished by their aspiration. From the level of earnest aspiration and through the ten levels, they perfectly undergo austerities such as giving away their bodies and so forth and willingly accepting suffering, without ever getting discouraged from accomplishing the path, so they are distinguished by their practice. Having attained perfect buddhahood, they will be indistinguishable in their elimination and realization from all the buddhas and will become their equal in Body, Speech, and Mind, so they are distinguished by their result. In this way, the wise are to be known for their supreme commitment or pledge.
gnyis pa de'i yon tan dpes bstan pa
(2) ANALOGIES INDICATING THE VIRTUES OF THAT COMMITMENT
['di] la/ rgyal po'i sras kyi dpe dang / blon po chen po'i dpe gnyis/
There are two analogies: that of a prince and that of a great minister.
dang po 'khor los bsgyur ba'i sras kyi dpes sangs rgyas kyi rigs mchog tu skyes pa ni/
(a) THE ANALOGY OF A PRINCE FOR ONE WHO IS BORN INTO THE SUPREME BUDDHA FAMILY

sangs rgyas sras kyi mchog tu legs par gang skyes pa/ / sems dang shes rab dang ni tshogs ldan snying rje ni/ / sa bon ma dang mngal gnas ma ma mtshungs pa med/ / blo ldan de ni khas len mchog tu shes par bya/ /

They who are well born as the supreme children of the buddhas Have the intention, wisdom, merit, and compassion— The incomparable seed, mother, womb, and nurse. Those wise persons should be known for their supreme commitment. (III, 5)
zhes pas bstan te/
