It is great in its undertaking—in its diligence in application, practicing as if one has donned armor. It is great in its goal—in perfectly achieving both one’s own and others’ goals. And it is great in the result that emerges—the attainment of unsurpassable enlightenment. These are its four particular qualities. In essence, bodhicitta is the mental factor of intention in a bodhisattva’s mind. What, then, are bodhisattvas thinking of or considering in arousing bodhicitta? They are thinking of attaining great enlightenment themselves and of bringing benefit and happiness to all other sentient beings. Thus, any thought that arises concomitant with the mental factor of intention possessing these two aims—namely, focusing on enlightenment and on the welfare of beings—is what we call bodhicitta. In short, it is a commitment—the thought and aspiration “For the sake of all sentient beings, I shall attain unsurpassable enlightenment.”
gnyis pa
2. CLASSIFICATIONS
sems bskyed kyi dbye ba la/ sa'i gnas skabs kyi dbye ba dang / rtsa ba sogs kyi sgo nas dbye ba dang / brda dang chos nyid kyis thob pa'i sgo nas dbye ba gsum/

There are three ways in which bodhicitta is classified: (1) in terms of the different levels; (2) in terms of eleven elements of these different kinds of bodhicitta; and (3) in terms of bodhicitta acquired formally and that acquired naturally.
dang po/
a. CLASSIFICATION IN TERMS OF THE DIFFERENT LEVELS
sems bskyed de ni sa rnams la/ / mos dang lhag bsam dag pa dang / / rnam par smin pa gzhan du 'dod/ / de bzhin sgrib pa spangs pa'o/ /
That spiritual intent is classified on the different levels In relation to interest, pure superior intention, Distinct full maturation, And likewise freedom from obscurations. (V, 2)
zhes bstan te/

sems bskyed de ni mos spyod sogs kyi sa yi gnas skabs rnams la 'di ltar mos spyod kyis tshogs sbyor gyi lam du sems bskyed pa ni dang ba tsam gyi mos pa'i sgo nas yin pas mos pa las byung ba'i sems bskyed ces bya'o/ / sa dang po bdun gyi gnas skabs su lhag pa'i bsam pa dag pa'i sems bskyed ces bya ste bdag gzhan mnyam nyid kyi sems thob pas bdag dang gzhan gyi don la khyad med par blo 'byongs pas lhag pa'i bsam pa dang / gzung 'dzin gyi dri ma dang bral bas dag pa zhes bya'o/ / sa brgyad pa nas bcu pa'i bar gyi skabs der rnam par smin pa'i sems bskyed ces bya ste sa de dag tu rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes lhun gyis grub pa thob pas phar phyin rnams rtsol med lhun grub tu spyod pa'i phyir ro / / de ni sems bskyed kyi rnam grangs snga ma las gzhan du 'dod do/ / ces so/ / de bzhin du sangs rgyas kyi sa la sgrib pa spangs pa'i sems bskyed ces bya ste/ sgrib gnyis bag chags dang bcas pa spangs pa'i sems bskyed pa 'bras bu mthar thug pa'i phyir ro/ /

Bodhicitta on the different levels (beginning with the level of earnest aspiration) is classified as follows. Bodhicitta on the level of earnest aspiration, that is, on the paths of accumulation and joining, is developed by means of interest, based simply on faith, and it is therefore known as the bodhicitta that arises through interest. On the first to seventh levels, it is known as the bodhicitta with pure superior intention—“superior intention” because bodhisattvas have acquired the state of mind that realizes that they themselves and others are the same, and their minds are therefore trained to the extent that there is no distinction between their own and others’ welfare; and “pure” because it is uncontaminated by subject-object duality. From the eighth level up to the tenth, it is known as the fully matured bodhicitta, because on these levels bodhisattvas have acquired spontaneous nonconceptual gnosis, and the transcendent perfections are therefore practiced effortlessly and spontaneously. It is in this respect that it is held to be distinct from the previous kinds of bodhicitta.[2] Similarly, on the level of buddhahood, it is known as bodhicitta free of all obscurations, because it is the ultimate, resultant bodhicitta: the two kinds of obscuration and the habitual tendencies have all been eliminated.
gnyis pa sems bskyed de dag gi rtsa ba sogs chos bcu gcig gi dbye ba bshad pa ni/
b. CLASSIFICATION IN TERMS OF ELEVEN ELEMENTS OF THESE DIFFERENT KINDS OF BODHICITTA, BEGINNING WITH THE ROOT
de yi rtsa ba snying rjer 'dod/ / rtag tu sems can phan par sems/ / chos la mos dang de bzhin de'i/ / ye shes tshol ba dmigs pa'o/ /
Its root is held to be compassion, Its intention is to constantly bring benefit to beings, Its interest concerns the teachings, And likewise its object is the quest for gnosis. (V, 3)
byang zhes pas bstan te/

byang chub tu sems bskyed pa de yi rtsa ba gang yin zhe na snying rjer 'dod de/ snying rjes sems can gyi sdug bsngal bsal bar 'dod pa las sems can gyi don du byang chub 'dod pa yin gyi sems can la snying rje med na nyan thos bzhin du bdag gi sdug bsngal la nyer zhi'i myang 'das don du gnyer ba'i phyir ro/ / de'i bsam pa gang zhe na/ 'khor ba'i phyi mtha'i bar dus rtag tu sems can thams cad la 'di dang gtan du phan par sems pa'o/ / de bzhin du sems bskyed kyi mos pa ni theg pa chen po'i zab pa dang rgya che ba'i chos la mos pa'o/ / de bzhin du sems bskyed de'i dmigs pa gang zhe na/ bdag med gnyis rdzogs pa rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes de 'thob pa'i don du theg chen gyi chos nyan bsam bsgom pa'i sgo nas yongs su tshol ba ni dmigs pa'o/ /

What is the root of bodhicitta? It is held to be compassion, for it is from the compassionate desire to dispel sentient beings’ suffering that one has the wish to attain enlightenment for the sake of sentient beings. Without compassion for sentient beings, one is like a listener, striving for the nirvāṇa in which one is completely at peace from one’s own suffering. What is its intention? It is to think—constantly, until the end of saṃsāra—of the benefit of all sentient beings in this life and forever. Similarly, the interest associated with bodhicitta is an interest in the profound and extensive teachings of the Great Vehicle. As for the object on which bodhicitta focuses, it is the quest to obtain the nonconceptual gnosis that is the perfection of the two kinds of no-self, by hearing, reflecting, and meditating upon the teachings of the Great Vehicle.
gong du 'dun pa 'gro ba ste/ / sdom pa rgya chen de yi rten/ / lam 'gog pa ni mi mthun phyogs/ / slong zhing dang du len pa'o/ /

sa yi gnas skabs gang la gnas pa de'i gong nas gong du gyur pa'i sa la 'dun pa yi sgo nas 'jug pa ni sems bskyed de'i theg pa'am 'gro ba ste/ 'dun pa de'i sgo nas gong nas gong du 'phar ba'i phyir ro/ / nyes spyod sdom pa dang / dge ba chos sdud dang / sems can don byed kyi tshul khrims rnam pa gsum dang ldan pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i sdom pa ni sems bskyed de yi rten yin no/ / theg chen lam 'gog pa dman pa'i myang 'das su sems bskyed pa ni byang chub mchog gi sems bskyed pa de'i bar chod dam mi mthun pa'i phyogs so/ / mi mthun pa'i phyogs de nyid rang gi sems la slong zhing de'i rgyun dang du len pa na sems bskyed 'gog par byed pa'o/ /

Determined progress from the level one is on to a higher level is the vehicle or means of proceeding for bodhicitta, because it is by means of determination that one rises higher and higher. The bodhisattva’s vow that involves the three kinds of discipline—namely, avoiding negative actions, gathering virtue, and benefiting others—is the support for bodhicitta. Stopping the Mahāyāna path and arousing the spiritual intent for the nirvāṇa of the lesser vehicles interrupts or counteracts bodhicitta, the intent for supreme enlightenment. If that counteragent arises in one’s mind and one voluntarily continues in that vein, it will obstruct the arousing of bodhicitta. (In some versions, this fourth line appears to be absent.)[3]
bsod nams ye shes rang bzhin gyi/ / dge ba 'phel ba de'i phan yon/ / pha rol phyin la rtag sbyor ba/ / de ni nges par 'byung bar 'dod/ /
dpe la lar rkang pa 'di med pa'ang snang / mchan/

sems can thams cad mya ngan las bzla bar 'dod pa'i snying rje chen po ni bsod nams kyi tshogs dang / don dam pa gang yang mya ngan las bzla ba med par shes pa'i stong nyid rtogs pa'i shes rab ni ye shes kyi tshogs te de ltar tshogs gnyis ni sems bskyed kyi rang bzhin no/ / te zhes pa lhag bcas kyi sgra'o/ / nam mkha'i khams dang sems can gyi khams dang / 'jig rten gyi khams ji tsam gyi bsod nams dge ba 'phel ba ni sems bskyed de yi phan yon no/ / sems bskyed des 'khor ba las ji ltar 'byung zhe na/ khams gsum las nges par 'byung zhing bla med byang chub 'thob pa'i phyir/ pha rol tu phyin pa drug la dus rtag tu sbyor ba ni de'i nges par 'byung bar 'dod do/ /

The great compassion that is the wish to take all beings beyond suffering[4] represents the accumulation of merit; the wisdom that realizes emptiness and knows that in ultimate truth there is nothing to be taken beyond suffering represents the accumulation of wisdom. These two accumulations constitute the nature of bodhicitta. (The Tibetan syllable te here is a continuative particle.)[5] The growth of merit and virtue as far as the reaches of space, of beings, and of worlds is the benefit of bodhicitta. How does arousing bodhicitta bring release from saṃsāra? Constant application to the six transcendent perfections in order to be definitively released from the three worlds and attain unsurpassable enlightenment is held to be its certain deliverance.
'di yi mthar thug sa yin te/ / so so rang gi der sbyor bas/ / byang chub sems dpa'i sems bskyed pa/ / rnam par nges par shes par bya/ /
Its ultimate reach is the level, Brought about by application on each one, respectively. Know that with all these a bodhisattva’s spiritual intent Is definitively established. (V, 6)

byang chub sems bskyed de dag gi mthar thug pa gang zhe na sems bskyed 'di yi mthar thug pa ni sa yin te/ ji ltar na sa bcu po dag so so rang gi gnas skabs de dang der sbyor ba sa re re rdzogs par thob pa las de dang de mthar thug pa zhes bya ste/ sa dang po sbyin pa'i phar phyin rdzogs pa nas sa bcu par ye shes kyi pha rol tu phyin pa rdzogs pa'i bar du phar phyin bcu yongs su rdzogs pa na sa bcu mthar phyin pa zhes bya'o/ / de'i phyir sems bskyed 'dis phar phyin yongs su bsgrub pa ni sa dang der mthar thug pa dang / slob lam gyi sems bskyed mthar thug pa ni sa bcu'i rgyun mtha'o/ / 'bras bu mthar thug pa sangs rgyas kyi sa'o/ / de ltar rnam bzhag rnam pa bcu gcig gis byang chub sems dpa'i sems bskyed pa bshad pa rnam par nges pa'am gdon mi za ba'am rnam par gtan la dbab pa yin par shes par bya'o/ /

What is the ultimate reach of those different kinds of bodhicitta?[6] The ultimate reach of bodhicitta is the level. How is that? Application on each of the ten levels completes each one, and from this we speak of the “ultimate reach” of that particular kind of bodhicitta. In other words, when one completes the ten transcendent perfections, beginning with completing transcendent generosity on the first level and ending with completing transcendent gnosis on the tenth level, one is said to “reach the ultimate point” of the ten levels. For this reason, the full accomplishment of a transcendent perfection with the respective kind of bodhicitta is its ultimate reach on that level; and the ultimate reach of bodhicitta on the path of training is the final stage of the tenth level. The ultimate result is the buddha level. This presentation of the bodhisattva’s spiritual intent in terms of these eleven points is to be understood as being the definitive, or unquestioned, or established explanation.
gsum pa brda dang chos nyid kyis thob pa'i sgo nas dbye ba la/
c. CLASSIFICATION IN TERMS OF BODHICITTA ACQUIRED FORMALLY AND THAT ACQUIRED NATURALLY

mos spyod kyi sa 'jig rten chos mchog man chad kyi sems bskyed ni brdas thob pa'i sems bskyed de bdag nyid kyi dge rtsa dang dge ba'i bshes kyi stobs kyis sems bskyed blangs pa'i tshig gi brjod pa bzhin dam bca' ba'o / / sa dang po pa yan chad kyi sems bskyed ni chos nyid kyis thob pa zhes bya'o/ / gzhan yang kun rdzob sems bskyed ni bla med byang chub 'thob par bya bar sems bskyed pa / don dam sems bskyed ni rang sems spros bral gyi don rtogs pa'am/ chos nyid kyi bden pa rtogs pa gang zer kyang de gnyis don 'dra ste rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes so/ / sa thob nas kun rdzob dang don dam pa'i sems bskyed dbyer med zung 'jug gi ngo bor rtogs par 'gyur ro/ /

Bodhicitta aroused from the level of earnest aspiration up to the supreme mundane level is bodhicitta acquired formally. This refers to the commitment expressed in the words of the bodhicitta vow that is taken through the power of one’s own merit and of the spiritual master. Bodhicitta aroused on the first level upward is what is known as bodhicitta acquired naturally.[7] These two categories are otherwise termed relative bodhicitta (which is the spiritual intent to attain unsurpassable enlightenment) and ultimate bodhicitta (which is the realization of one’s own mind being free of conceptual elaboration or the realization of the truth of ultimate reality—whichever term we use, they both refer to the same thing: nonconceptual gnosis). Once one attains the bodhisattva levels, one will realize the inseparable union of relative and ultimate bodhicitta.
dang po brdas thob pa'am gzhan gyis bstan pa'i sems bskyed skye tshul gyi rnam grangs bshad pa/
To begin with we shall describe the different ways in which bodhicitta acquired formally or revealed by another arises.
grogs stobs rgyu stobs rtsa ba'i stobs/ / thos stobs dge ba goms pa las/ / mi brtan pa dang brtan 'byung ba/ / gzhan gyis bstan pa'i sems bskyed bshad/ /

Bodhicitta arises unstably through the power of a friend, Or in a stable manner through the power of a cause, Of sources of good, of listening, and through habituation to virtue. This describes the bodhicitta that is revealed by someone else. (V, 7)
ces pas bstan te/

dge ba'i bshes kyis sems skyed cig ces bskul nas sems bskyed pa grogs kyi stobs kyis sems bskyed pa zhes bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa'i rigs yod pa'i mthus sems bskyed pa ni rgyu yi stobs las so/ / tshe rabs snga mar sems bskyed pa dang theg pa chen po'i chos spyod pa dang / ye shes kyi tshogs bsags pa'i stobs kyis tshe 'dir byang chub tu sems bskyed pa ni dge ba'i rtsa ba'i stobs kyis so/ / sngon bcom ldan 'das kyis theg pa chen po'i chos bstan pa'i tshe na lha dang mi'i skye rgu mang pos bla med byang chub tu sems bskyed pa lta bu dang gzhan yang gang su dag theg pa chen po'i chos thos pa'i dbang gis sems bskyed pa ni thos pa'i stobs kyis so/ / tshe 'dir theg chen gyi chos la mnyan pa dang / sems pa'i dge ba goms pa las sems bskyed pa dang lnga las dang po mi brtan pa ldog srid pa yin pa dang / phyi ma bzhi brtan par 'byung ba yin pa la/ de ltar lnga po de rnams gzhan gyis bstan pa'i sems bskyed du bshad do/ /

Bodhicitta aroused through the prompting of a spiritual friend is what we call “bodhicitta aroused through the power of a friend.” Bodhicitta aroused because of the presence of the bodhisattva potential arises through the power of a cause. Bodhicitta aroused in this life on account of one’s having aroused bodhicitta, practiced the Mahāyāna teachings, and gathered the accumulation of wisdom in previous lives arises through the power of one’s sources of good. Bodhicitta aroused by anyone as a result of listening to the Mahāyāna teachings (as did many gods and humans in the past who aroused the mind intent on unsurpassable enlightenment when Lord Buddha taught the Great Vehicle) arises through the power of listening. And bodhicitta is aroused through habituation to the virtuous act of listening to the Mahāyāna teachings and reflecting on them in this life. Of these five, the first is unstable since it is possible to revert from it;[8] the last four arise in a stable manner. These five describe the bodhicitta revealed by another.
don dam pa'i sems bskyed ni/
Ultimate bodhicitta is explained in the next seven verses.
rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rab bsnyen byas/ / bsod nams ye shes tshogs rab bsags/ / chos la mi rtog ye shes ni/ / skyes phyir de ni dam par 'dod/ /
Born from attending the perfect buddhas And accumulating merit and wisdom, The gnosis without concepts with regard to phenomena Is therefore held to be sublime. (V, 8)
zhes tshigs bcad bdun gyis bstan te/

mos spyod kyi sar bskal chen grangs med gcig gi bar du rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams la mchod cing chos nyan bsam bsgom par byas pa'i sgo nas rab tu bsnyen par byas pa dang / phar phyin drug gis bsdus pa'i bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs gnyis po rab tu bsags pa'i rgyu des/ chos thams cad la gzung 'dzin dang rtag mi rtag sogs gnyis chos su rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes ni skyes pa'i phyir na rtogs pa dam pa de lta bu sems bskyed pa dam pa'am don dam pa'i sems bskyed par 'dod do/ /

On the level of earnest aspiration, for as long as one measureless great kalpa, bodhisattvas make offerings to the perfect buddhas and attend them by listening to their teachings, reflecting, and meditating. And they fully gather the two accumulations of merit and wisdom, embodied in the six transcendent perfections. As a result of this, there arises the gnosis free from dualistic concepts of phenomena—subject and object, permanence and impermanence, and so on. This sublime realization is held to be the sublime bodhicitta or ultimate bodhicitta.
chos dang sems can rnams dang ni/ / de yi bya ba sangs rgyas nyid/ / mchog la sems mnyam rnyed pa'i phyir/ / de yi rab dga' khyad par 'phags/ /

Because bodhisattvas have acquired realization of the sameness Of phenomena, of sentient beings, Of the deeds that benefit them, and above all of the buddha state, Their joy is particularly great. (V, 9)

de ni sa dang po thob pa na skye zhing de'i rgyus rab tu dga' ba skye bas na sa de'i ming rab tu dga' ba zhes bya'o/ / ci'i phyir de'i tshe rab tu dga' ba skye zhe na phung sogs chos thams cad la sems mnyam rnyed pa dang / de bzhin du sems can rnams dang ni/ sems can de yi don bya ba dang / mchog sangs rgyas rnams kyi chos sku la sems mnyam pa rnyed pa ste mnyam pa bzhi rnyed pas byang sems de yi rab dga' khyad par du 'phags pa'o/ / ji ltar chos dang bdag dang gzhan sangs rgyas rnams kyang chos kyi dbyings kyi rang bzhin du tha mi dad par mnyam pa mngon du rtogs pa'i phyir/ chos kyi rang bzhin shes pas 'khor bas 'jigs pa med cing / gzhan gyi don yang bdag gi don las gzhan du mi rtog pa dang / sems can gyi don 'grub par mthong ba dang / bdag sems can thams cad kyi gnas su 'gyur ro zhes dang / sangs rgyas kyi sa dang nye bar gyur to zhes rtogs nas rab tu dga' ba skye'o/ /

This ultimate bodhicitta arises when the first level is attained, and as a result bodhisattvas feel extremely joyful, which is why that level is called Perfect Joy. Why do they feel so joyful at that time? Because they acquire the state of mind that realizes the sameness of the aggregates and all other phenomena. And in the same way, they acquire the state of mind that realizes the sameness of all sentient beings, the state of mind that realizes the sameness of the deeds to be performed for their benefit, and, above all, the state of mind that realizes the sameness of the buddhas’ body of truth (dharmakāya.) It is from acquiring this fourfold realization of sameness that the bodhisattvas’ joy is particularly great.[9] Because they have realized that there is no difference between phenomena, oneself, others, and the buddhas, and that all these are the same in being by nature the expanse of reality, they understand the nature of phenomena and therefore have no fear of saṃsāra. And from not thinking of others’ welfare as any different from their own, from seeing that they will accomplish beings’ welfare, from realizing that they will be of benefit to all beings, and from realizing that they are approaching the buddha level, they feel immensely joyful.
skye ba rgya chen de la spro/ / bsam pa yang ni dag pa dang / / lhag ma dag la mkhas pa dang / / nges par 'byung bar shes par bya/ /
Bodhicitta’s birth, vastness, Associated enthusiasm, pure intention, Mastery of the remainder, And certain deliverance are the points that should be understood. (V, 10)

don dam pa'i byang chub kyi sems de skye ba yi don dang / rgya chen po'i don dang / de la spro ba'i don dang / bsam pa yang ni dag pa'i don dang / lhag ma dag la mkhas pa'i don dang / nges par 'byung bar 'gyur ba'i don dang drug tu shes par bya'o zhes mdor bstan nas/ de'i don so sor bshad pa la

The ultimate bodhicitta is to be known by six topics: its birth, vastness, enthusiasm with regard to the latter, pure intention, mastery of the remainder, and certain deliverance. This brief exposition is now followed by an explanation of each of these points.
chos la mos pa sa bon dang / / pha rol phyin mchog ma las skyes/ / bsam gtan las byung bde ba mngal/ / snying rje skyed pa'i ma ma'o/ /

It is born from the seed of interest in the Dharma And from the mother of the highest transcendent perfection; The bliss that comes from concentration is its womb, And compassion is the nurse that nurtures it. (V, 11)

dang po skye ba'i don ni rnam pa bzhi ste 'jig rten na mngal skyes rnams skye ba dang tshul mthun par theg pa mchog gi chos la mos pa sa bon dang pha rol tu phyin pas mchog ni chos thams cad stong par rtogs pa shes rab kyi phar phyin ma lta bu las skyes pa dang / sems rtse gcig pa'i bsam gtan las byung ba'i shin tu sbyangs pa'i bde ba ni mngal skyon med pa lta bu'o/ / snying rje chen po ni nyan thos kyi myang 'das kyi g.yang sa las bsrung zhing dge chos skyed bsring pa'i ma ma lta bu'o/ / de ltar rgyu bzhi las skyes pa ni byang chub sems kyi skye ba'o/ /

First, its birth has four aspects, indicated by analogy with the way in which womb-born beings take birth in the world. Interest in the teachings of the Supreme Vehicle is the seed. The highest of the transcendent perfections, transcendent wisdom that is the realization that all phenomena are empty, is, as it were, the mother from which it is born. The bliss of the trained flexibility that comes from one-pointed concentration is like a perfectly healthy womb. And the great compassion is like a nurse, holding one back from the precipice of the listeners’ nirvāṇa and nurturing virtuous ways. It is in arising from these four causes that bodhicitta is born.
smon lam chen po bcu sgrub phyir/ / rgya che bar ni shes par bya/ / dka' ba yun ring mi skyo'i phyir/ / spro bar khong du chud par bya/ /

Bodhisattvas accomplish ten great aspirations, And so their bodhicitta should be known as vast. They are not discouraged by hardships over great lengths of time, And so their bodhicitta should be understood as enthusiastic. (V, 12)

gnyis pa/ nyan thos rnams rang don du sems bskyed kyi/ byang chub sems dpas bdag gzhan gnyis ka'i don du sems bskyed de/ smon lam chen po bcu sgrub pa'i phyir rgya che bar ni shes par bya'o/ / smon lam chen po bcu ni sangs rgyas thams cad mchod pa dang / dam pa'i chos mtha' dag kun tu 'dzin pa dang / lus kun tu ston pa dang / zhing kun tu 'jug pa dang / phar phyin mtha' dag rdzogs pa dang*/ sems can thams cad smin par byed pa dang / zhing yongs su sbyong ba dang / byang sems rnams dang spyod yul mthun par gnas pa dang / spyod pa kun tu don yod pa dang*/ byang chub chen po 'thob pa'o/ /

Second, whereas the listeners give rise to their spiritual intent for their own sake, bodhisattvas arouse bodhicitta for the sake of both themselves and others, accomplishing ten great aspirations, and for this reason their bodhicitta is to be known for its vastness. These ten great aspirations are as follows: (1) to make offerings to all the buddhas; (2) to fully hold all the sacred teachings; (3) to manifest in all kinds of physical forms to teach beings; (4) to enter all kinds of buddha fields; (5) to complete all the transcendent perfections; (6) to bring all sentient beings to maturity; (7) to purify realms as buddha fields; (8) to act in harmony with the bodhisattva activities; (9) to be beneficial in all their activities; and (10) to attain great enlightenment.

smon lam de la smon lam gyi 'khor 'bum phrag grangs med pa yod cing / smon lam de dag kyang mtha' thug pa med pa'i gnas bcu'i tshul gyis bsgrubs te/ sems can gyi khams dang / 'jig rten gyi khams dang / nam mkha'i khams dang / dam pa'i chos ji tsam pa dang / de bzhin mya ngan las 'das pa dang / sangs rgyas 'byung ba dang / sangs rgyas kyi ye shes dang / sems can rnams kyi sems kyi dmigs pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi ye shes kyi spyod yul ji tsam yod pa de tsam du sgrub pa dang / de dgu po bsdus te mdor na 'jig rten gyi rgyud dang / chos kyi rgyud dang / ye shes kyi rgyud kyi khams bya ba bcu po de ni phyogs dang dus kyi mu med par khyab pa yin la/ de snyed du byang chub sems dpa' smon lam gyi rnam par 'phrul ba ston pa la 'jug pa rig par bya'o/ /

These aspirations have countless hundreds of thousands of attendant aspirations, and they are all accomplished with ten limitless objects: the realm of sentient beings; the realm of the universe; the realm of space; the totality of the sacred teachings; likewise nirvāṇa; the coming of the buddhas; the gnosis of the buddhas; the thoughts in sentient beings’ minds; the accomplishment of the entire scope of the buddhas’ gnosis; and, summarizing these nine, what is known as the realm of the continuum of the universe, of the continuum of the Dharma, and of the continuum of gnosis. It should be understood that these ten pervade the whole of space and time without limit, and that it is on such a scale that bodhisattvas engage in displaying manifestations according to their aspirations.

gsum pa nyan thos rnams rang don bya bar spro ba tsam du zad la/ byang chub sems dpa' ni rang gzhan gyi don gnyis bya ba'i ched du gzhan gyis bgyid par mi nus pa'i dka' ba spyod pa sna tshogs yun ring bskal pa grangs med gsum gyi bar du spyad pa la mi skyo ba'i phyir na don dam pa'i byang chub kyi sems de spro bar khong du chud par bya'o/ /

Third, whereas the listeners’ enthusiasm goes no further than the achievement of their own goal, bodhisattvas never tire of performing all kinds of difficult activities that others are incapable of doing in order to achieve both their own and others’ goals, and this over immense periods of time—up to three measureless kalpas. For this reason, the ultimate bodhicitta should be understood as incorporating enthusiasm.
byang chub nye bar rtogs pa dang / / de yi thabs shes rnyed pa'i phyir/ / bsam pa dag par shes par bya/ / sa gzhan tshul la mkhas pa nyid/ /

Bodhisattvas realize that they are nearing enlightenment And they have gathered knowledge of its means, So their intention, you should understand, is pure. They master the methods of the other bodhisattva levels. (V, 13)

bzhi pa/ nyan thos rnams nyon sgrib spangs pas rang 'bras thob pa tsam du zad la/ byang chub sems dpa' ni sgrib pa gnyis po dag pa'i bla med byang chub nye bar rtogs pa dang / sangs rgyas thob pa de yi thabs shes pa'ang rnyed pa'i phyir bsam pa dag par shes par bya'o/ /

Fourth, the listeners go no further than eliminating the obscurations of defilements and thereby attaining their respective result. Bodhisattvas, on the other hand, realize that they are approaching unsurpassable enlightenment in which the two obscurations have been purified, and they also gain knowledge of the means for attaining buddhahood. For this reason, you should understand that their intention is pure.

lnga pa nyan thos dag khams gsum gyi nyon mongs kun brtags dang lhan skyes spangs pa'i tshul las/ rgyun zhugs dang / phyir 'ong dang / phyir mi 'ong dang / dgra bcom pa'i sa la mkhas pa tsam du zad la/ byang chub sems dpa' ni sa dang po sogs thob pa na/ de'i lhag ma'i sa gzhan rang bzhin dang yon tan dang gong ma gong ma ji ltar 'thob pa'i tshul la mkhas pa nyid kyi phyir lhag ma mkhas pa zhes bya'o/ /

Fifth, the listeners, in eliminating the imputational and innate defilements related to the three worlds, go no further than mastering the levels of stream enterer, once-returner, nonreturner, and arhat. Bodhisattvas, when they attain the first level and so on, know how to attain the other, higher remaining levels and their respective qualities, which is why we speak of “mastery of the remainder.”
ji ltar rnam gzhag yid byed pas/ / de rtog nyid du shes phyir dang / / de nyid la yang mi rtog phyir/ / nges par 'byung bar shes par bya/ /
Keeping in mind the presentation of those levels, Bodhisattvas know them to be just concepts, And even in that regard, they have no concepts— Know that because of this deliverance is certain. (V, 14)

drug pa ni sa snga ma 'dor zhing phyi mar 'jug pa'i tshul gyis sa nas sar 'phar zhing nges par 'byung ba ni/ 'di ltar sa dang po la sbyin pa'i phar phyin rdzogs pa dang / sangs rgyas brgya'i zhal blta ba sogs yon tan brgya phrag bcu gnyis la sogs pa kun rdzob tha snyad du sa'i mtshan nyid/ ji lta bu rnam par bzhag pa yang yid la byed pas sa'i mtshan nyid de dag kyang gzhan med de rang gi sems kyis rtog pa'i dbang gis bzhag pa tsam nyid du shes pa'i phyir dang / sems tsam dang rtog pa tsam mo zhes pa'i 'dzin pa de nyid la yang mi rtog par/ rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes la gnas nas sa dang po las 'das te gnyis pa la 'jug par 'gyur ba de'i tshul gyis sa gzhan la'ang shes par bya ste/ de ltar sa nas sar nges par 'byung ba shes par bya'o/ /

Sixth, by leaving behind the previous levels and proceeding to the subsequent ones, bodhisattvas rise from one level to the next and are definitively released. While keeping in mind the arrangement, on the relative, conventional level, of the level’s defining characteristics (such as, on the first level, the completion of transcendent generosity, and the twelve sets of a hundred qualities—beholding a hundred buddhas, and so forth), they also know that that level’s characteristics are merely posited by one’s own mind on account of one’s concepts, and nothing else. And, without conceptualizing even that concept that they are “the mind-only” or “mere concepts,” they dwell in nonconceptual gnosis and will proceed beyond the first level to the second. This should similarly be understood for the other levels as well, and it is how we should understand certain deliverance from one level to the next.
gsum pa sems bskyed pa'i dpe bshad pa ni/
3 ANALOGIES FOR AROUSING BODHICITTA

dang por mos spyod kyi sar sems bskyed thog mar bskyed pa nas brtsams te sa bcu pa'i bar gyi sems bskyed pa rnams dpe rnam pa nyi shu rtsa gnyis dang sbyar ba 'dir ni theg pa chen po'i lam gnad yongs su rdzogs pa yin te/ 'dun bsam sogs mi zad pa brgyad cu dang sbyar ba yin la/

The next six verses provide analogies for arousing bodhicitta. Beginning from when one arouses bodhicitta for the first time on the level of earnest aspiration, and up until the tenth level, the different instances of arousing bodhicitta are associated with twenty-two similes, in which the essential aspects of the Mahāyāna path are complete, and which are related to the eighty inexhaustible qualities—determination, intention, and so forth.[10]
skyed pa sa dang mtshungs pa ste/ / gzhan ni bzang po'i gser dang 'dra/ / zla ba yar gyi tshes pa bzhin/ / gzhan ni me dang 'drar shes bya/ /
Bodhicitta should be understood to be like the earth, Or alternatively like fine gold, Or like the waxing moon; Or resembling fire. (V, 15)
ces tshigs bcad drug gis bstan pa'i don ni/

dang po bla med byang chub 'thob par 'dun pa'i 'dun pa dang mtshungs ldan du gyur pa'i sems bskyed pa de ni theg pa chen po'i bsam sbyor lhag bsam phar phyin nas thabs mkhas kyi bar gyi lam gyi chos dang 'bras bu'i chos stobs dang mi 'jigs ma 'dres pa la sogs pa mtha' dag skyed pa'i rten nam gzhi gcig pu pa yin pa'i phyir dper na sa chen po ni rtswa shing sman 'bru ji snyed pa'i gzhi rten du gyur pa dang mtshungs pa ste/

(1) First, the bodhicitta associated with determination—the determination to attain unsurpassable enlightenment—is the sole support or basis for giving rise to all the elements of the Mahāyāna path (from intention, application, superior intention, and the transcendent perfections through to skill in means) and all the qualities of the Mahāyāna result—the ten strengths, four fearlessnesses, eighteen distinctive qualities, and so forth. It is therefore comparable to the great earth, which is the support for all the grass, trees, medicinal fruits, and grain.

de la brten nas snga ma las gzhan sems can rnams la phan bde byed pa'i bsam pa bzang po 'gyur ba med pa'i sems bskyed ni/ bzang po'i gser bsregs gcod brdar bas brtags kyang kha dog dang ngang tshul gzhan du mi 'gyur ba dang 'dra'o/ /

(2) Next, and based on the previous spiritual intent, is the bodhicitta associated with the unchanging good intention to bring benefit and happiness to sentient beings. It is like fine gold, whose color and properties do not alter even when tested by flaming, cutting, and rubbing.
phar phyin la rab tu sbyor bas tshogs gnyis 'phel ba'i sems bskyed ni zla ba yar gyi ngo la tshes pa gong nas gong du 'phel ba bzhin no/ /
(3) The bodhicitta associated with increasing the two accumulations by thorough application to the transcendent perfections is like the waxing moon.

de las gzhan gzhan don khur khyer nus pa'i lhag bsam dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni me dang 'dra bar shes par bya ste/ me ni bud shing ji tsam yod par ngang gis 'bar zhing mched pa bzhin sbyor lam drod la gnas pas rtse mo nas sangs rgyas kyi sa'i bar du 'thob par bya'o snyam du sems pa des yon tan gong ma rnams 'thob par byed do/ /

(4) Next, the bodhicitta associated with the superior intention that can shoulder the responsibility for others’ welfare is to be understood as being like fire. The more firewood there is, the more the fire will naturally burn and spread. In the same way, bodhisattvas’ intention to attain the next stage, whether it is from the stage of warmth to the peak stage on the path of joining, or from the tenth level to buddhahood, enables them to acquire correspondingly greater qualities.
gzhung gzhan du lhag bsam zla ba tshes pa dang / sbyor ba'i dpe me byas pa yang yod/ 'di bzhi po so so'i skye bos dang po sems bskyed pa nas chos mchog man chad do/ /

In other source texts, the waxing moon is given as the simile for superior intention, and fire as the simile for application. These four apply to ordinary beings, from those who first arouse bodhicitta up to those on the supreme mundane level.
gzhan ni gter chen bzhin shes bya/ / gzhan ni rin chen 'byung gnas bzhin/ / rgya mtsho 'dra bar shes bya gzhan/ / rdo rje dang 'dra ri rab 'dra/ /
Another way it should be known is like a great treasure, Or like a mine of precious jewels, Or like the ocean, Or else a diamond or mountain. (V, 16)

gzhan sbyin pa'i phar phyin dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni gter chen po bzhin du shes par bya ste/ gter chen po dung dang pad+mo dang pad+ma chen po la sogs pa rnam pa bzhi dang / dgur yang bshad de/ mdor na rin po che'i gter 'dzad med yod pa'i gnas las yo byad bza' ba dang bgo ba sogs ji snyed byung yang zad pa med pa ltar sbyin pas sems can tshad med pa rnams zang zing dang chos sogs kyis tshim par byed la byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa de phung po lhag ma med pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa'i dbyings su yang rtag par zad pa med pa'i phyir ro/ /

(5) Next, the bodhicitta associated with transcendent generosity is to be understood as being like a great treasure. A great treasure is described as being of four kinds—conch, lotus, great lotus, and so on—and also of nine kinds, but stated simply, it is an inexhaustible treasure of jewels. In a place where there is such a treasure, however much food, clothes, and other necessary things are produced from it, it never runs out. Generosity satisfies the material and spiritual needs of countless sentient beings in the same way, for a bodhisattva’s generosity never ever comes to an end, even in the expanse of nirvāṇa without residual aggregates.

gzhan tshul khrims kyi phar phyin dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni rin chen sna tshogs kyi 'byung gnas sam 'byung khungs bzhin te gnas de las rin chen sna tshogs dpag tu med pa 'byung ba ltar byang chub sems dpa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed las/ sa dang phar phyin dang byang phyogs dang stobs dang mi 'jigs pa sogs theg pa chen po'i lam dang 'bras bu'i yon tan thams cad kyi rin po che dpag med 'byung bas so/ /

(6) Another kind of bodhicitta, that associated with transcendent discipline, is like a source or mine of all sorts of precious stones. In the same way that an infinite variety of precious gems can be extracted from such a place, from the bodhicitta associated with a bodhisattva’s discipline all the infinite gem-like qualities of the path and result of the Great Vehicle emerge—the levels, transcendent perfections, elements leading to enlightenment, strengths, fearlessnesses, and all the rest.

bzod pa'i phar phyin dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni rgya mtsho chen po dang 'dra bar shes par bya ste/ rgya mtsho chen po gru dang nya dang chu srin sogs kyis dkrugs kyang rnyogs pa can du mi 'gyur ba dang / gting mi g.yo ba bzhin du byang chub sems dpa'i bzod pa ldan pa'i sems de yang dka' spyad dang gzhan gyi gnod pa sogs nyes pa gang gis rnyogs par mi nus pa'i phyir ro/ /

(7) The bodhicitta associated with transcendent patience is to be understood as being like the ocean. Even if the ocean is stirred up by boats, fish, large marine creatures, and the like, its waters will never become clouded, and its depths are not moved. In the same way, no unpleasant conditions such as austere practices and being wronged by others are capable of sullying a bodhisattva’s patient mind.

gzhan brtson 'grus kyi phar phyin dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni rdo rje dang 'dra ba ste rdo rje rin po che ni me chu dang bcad brdar sogs ci yis kyang mi tshugs pa ltar/ byang chub sems dpa' sems bskyed de la yang le lo'i mtshon gyis mi tshugs pa'i phyir ro/ /

(8) Further, the bodhicitta associated with transcendent diligence is like a diamond, for just as a diamond is not affected by anything—fire, water, cutting, grinding, and so forth—a bodhisattva’s bodhicitta cannot be damaged by the dart of laziness.

bsam gtan gyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni ri'i rgyal po ri rab phyogs bzhi'i rlung gang gis kyang bskyod mi nus pa dang 'dra ste/ byang sems kyi ting 'dzin de yang g.yeng ba'i rnam rtog gis mi bskyod pas so/ /

(9) The bodhicitta associated with transcendent concentration is like the king of mountains, Mount Meru, which cannot be moved even by any of the winds of the four directions, for a bodhisattva’s concentration is unmoved by distracting thoughts.
sman gyi rgyal po 'dra ba ste/ / gzhan ni mdza' chen 'drar shes bya/ / yid bzhin nor bu 'dra ba dang / / gzhan ni nyi ma 'drar shes bya/ /
It is like a sovereign medicine, Or like a great friend; Or like a wishing jewel, Or like the sun. (V, 17)

shes rab kyi phar phyin dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni/ rtsi'am sman gyi rgyal po dang 'dra ba ste/ sman de mthong ba'am reg pa dang dri bsnams pa dang khar myang ba tsam gyis rlung mkhris bad kan las gyur pa'i nad thams cad zhi bar byed pa bzhin/ shes rab phar phyin mnyan bsam bsgoms pas nyon shes kyi sgrib pa'i nad thams cad zhi bar byed pa'i phyir ro/ /

(10) The bodhicitta associated with transcendent wisdom is like the king of elixirs or medicines. Merely from the sight of that medicine, or the touch, smell, or taste of it, all illnesses caused by wind, bile, and phlegm disorders are cured. Similarly, the transcendent wisdom that comes from listening, reflecting, and meditating cures all the maladies of the defilement-related and cognitive obscurations.

gzhan tshad med pa bzhi dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni/ mdza' bshes chen po 'dra bar shes par bya ste/ mdza' ba chen pos dus gsum du'ang bde'am sdug gam btang snyoms kyi dus na'ang grogs byed cing mi dor ba ltar/ snying rjes sdug bsngal ba'i dus na sdug bsngal las 'don par byed/ byams pas mi bde ba'i dus na bde ba la gnas par byed/ dga' bas bde ba dang mi 'bral bar dga' zhing 'grogs par byed/ btang snyoms kyis bde ba can la ma chags par gyur cig ces dang / sdug bsngal can la sdug bsngal la zhe sdang dang ldan pa ma gyur cig ces sems pas chags sdang med par sems rnal du gnas par byed pa'i phyir ro/ /

(11) Next, the bodhicitta associated with the four boundless attitudes is to be understood as being like a great friend. True friends help one throughout the three times, in moments of pleasure, moments of pain, and in moments of neither; they never abandon one. Similarly, compassion draws beings out of their misery when they are suffering. Love makes them happy when they are unhappy. Joy rejoices at their happiness and helps them to never lose it. And in thinking, “May they not be attached to being happy,” “May those who are suffering not be averse to suffering,” impartiality makes their minds settle without attachment or aversion.

mngon shes lnga dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni yid bzhin gyi nor bu las dgos 'dod 'byung ba dang 'dra ste/ rdzu 'phrul gyi mig gis gzugs thams cad mthong ba dang 'chi 'pho dang skye ba shes pas phyi ma'i dus shes pa dang / rdzu 'phrul gyi rna bas sgra thams cad thos pa dang / gzhan gyi sems shes pas sems can rnams kyi sems kyi rnam grangs sna tshogs shes pa dang / sngon gnas rjes su dran pas rang gzhan gyi tshe rabs snga ma'i gnas skabs rnams shes pa dang / rdzu 'phrul gyi mngon par shes pas lus sna tshogs su sprul pa sogs rdzu 'phrul rnam pa du ma ston pa ste de ltar mngon par shes pa'i mthus rang gzhan gyi 'dod pa thams cad 'dod dgur sgrub nus pa'i phyir ro/ /

(12) The bodhicitta associated with the five kinds of preternatural knowledge is like the wishing gem, which is the source of everything one could need or wish for. With the miraculous eye, bodhisattvas can see all forms and, through their knowledge of deaths and births, they can tell the future. With the miraculous ear, they can hear all sounds. By knowing others’ minds, they are conscious of sentient beings’ different mental states. By remembering past lives, they know what happened in their own and others’ former series of lives. And by means of the preternatural power of miraculous transformation, they display many kinds of miracles, such as manifesting in various forms. In this manner, with their preternatural knowledge and power, they are able to fulfill all their own and others’ wishes.

gzhan bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhi dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni nyi ma dang 'dra bar shes par bya ste/ nyi mas lo tog sna tshogs smin par byed pa bzhin du/ ser sna can rnams sbyin pas bsdus nas dge ba la 'god/ de bzhin zhe sdang can snyan smra/ gti mug can don spyod/ nga rgyal can don mthun pas bsdus nas dge ba la bkod pa'am/ spyir yang sems can thams cad bsdu ba bzhis bsdus nas dge ba la bkod de rgyud smin par byed pas so/ /

(13) Again, the bodhicitta associated with the four ways of attracting disciples is to be known as being like the sun. Just as the sun makes the various crops ripen, bodhisattvas ripen beings’ mind streams by attracting beings and introducing them to virtue. They attract the miserly with their generosity, and similarly the hateful by speaking agreeably, the confused by means of helpful activity, and the proud by means of consistent behavior. More generally, they use the four ways of attracting disciples to attract all sentient beings and then introduce them to virtue.
gzhan ni dri za'i dbyangs snyan bzhin/ / gzhan ni rgyal po 'drar shes bya/ / de bzhin gzhan ni mdzod lta bu/ / lam po che dang 'drar shes bya/ /
Again, it is like the gandharva’s song, Or understood to be like a king; Or also like a treasury, Or known to be like a busy road. (V, 18)

gzhan chos dang don dang nges tshig dang spobs pa so so yang dag par rig pa bzhi dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni dri za'i dbyangs snyan pa ji bzhin du so so yang dag pa'i rig pa bzhi dang ldan pas sems can so so rang rang gis chos dang don gang dang gang las brtsam ste shes par 'dod pa de dang de dris pa la byang chub sems dpa'i spobs pa mthar gtugs pa med pas sems can de dag so so'i skad kyi ci dang ci dris pa'i don yang dag par bshad pas de dag gis sems shin tu tshim par 'gyur bas/ dri za'i dbyangs ni shin tu snyan pas gang gis thos pas de sems dga' ba des tshim par 'gyur ba lta bu'o/ /

(14) Further, the bodhicitta associated with the four kinds of perfect knowledge (knowledge of phenomena, of meanings, of languages, and of brilliant eloquence) is like the sweet song of a gandharva. Because bodhisattvas possess the four kinds of perfect knowledge, they can correctly answer, with endless confidence and eloquence, and in each being’s language, the different questions that different sentient beings wish to understand regarding different phenomena and meanings, thus completely satisfying their minds. This bodhicitta, therefore, is like the song of a gandharva, which is so beautiful that whoever hears it is delighted and contented.

gzhan rton pa bzhi dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni/ rgyal po dang 'dra bar shes par bya ste/ rgyal po ni yul la dbang bsgyur bas de'i bka' 'bangs rnams kyis gzhan du byed mi nus pas chu mi za ba ltar/ byang sems gang zhig rton pa bzhi dang ldan pa des tshig dang don dang / gang zag dang chos dang / drang don dang / nges don dang / rnam shes dang ye shes kyi dbang du byas te de bzhin gshegs pas bstan pa'i dgos pa thams cad ma nor ba shes pa'i sangs rgyas kyi gsung gis dgongs don chud mi za bar rtogs nus pa'i phyir te/ dper na rgyal po ni bsten legs na srid dang longs spyod sogs sbyin pas gang zag chud mi za ba'i rgyu byed la/ bsten nyes na srid dang srog la bab pas chud za bar byed pa'i rgyu byed pa ltar/ gang zag tsam dang / tshig tsam dang / drang don dang / rnam shes la rton na de ltar rton pa'i gang zag de chud za ba'i rgyur 'gyur/ chos dang don dang nges don dang ye shes la rton na de ltar rton pa de dag sangs rgyas kyi bka' yi don las chud mi za bar 'gyur bas so/ /

(15) Another kind of bodhicitta, associated with the four reliances, is to be understood as being like a king. Since the king has dominion over the land, his subjects are unable to do anything other than what he has commanded, and his words do not, therefore, go to waste. Similarly, a bodhisattva who has the four reliances (reliance on the meaning rather than the words, on the teaching rather than the person, on the ultimate meaning rather than the expedient meaning, and on gnosis rather than intellectual knowledge) is able to know all the intended meanings taught by the Tathāgata without mistake and thus to realize the true meaning of the Buddha’s words without their being wasted. To illustrate this with an analogy, someone who serves their king well will be rewarded with dominion and wealth: their service will not have been wasted. Whereas if they serve him badly, their service will go to waste, for they will lose their dominion and life. In the same way, someone who relies only on the person, on the words, on the expedient meaning, and on intellectual knowledge will see their reliance wasted. For those who rely on the teaching, the meaning, the ultimate meaning, and gnosis, the meaning of the Buddha’s words will not be wasted.

de bzhin du gzhan bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs gnyis dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni bang mdzod lta bu ste/ bang mdzod na 'bru dang nor la sogs pa dpag med yod pa bzhin de dang mtshungs ldan gyi sems bskyed la yang bsod nams kyi tshogs dpag tu med pa dang ye shes kyi tshogs dpag tu med pa yod pa'i phyir ro/ /

(16) Similarly, another kind of bodhicitta, associated with the two accumulations of merit and wisdom, is like a treasury. Just as a treasury can contain an inestimable quantity of grains or coins and so forth, the equivalent bodhicitta has an infinite accumulation of merit and an infinite accumulation of wisdom.

byang chub phyogs kyi chos sum cu rtsa bdun dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni/ dper na lam po che la dus gsum gyi sems can mchog dman thams cad 'gro ba ltar/ byang phyogs so bdun po 'di yang 'das dang da lta ma 'ongs pa'i nyan rang byang sems thams cad lam 'di las rang 'bras byang chub tu gshegs pa'i phyir de gnyis 'dra bar shes par bya'o/ /

(17) The bodhicitta associated with the thirty-seven elements that lead to enlightenment is like a highway on which all kinds of beings, the great and the lowly, have traveled in the past, are traveling at present, and will travel in the future. For these thirty-seven elements that lead to enlightenment are the road by which all the listeners, solitary realizers, and bodhisattvas of the past, present, and future arrive at their respective resultant enlightenment. The highway and the road to enlightenment are to be understood, therefore, as equivalent.
theg pa 'dra bar shes bya ste/ / sems bskyed bkod ma 'dra ba yin/ / kun dga'i sgra dang 'dra ba ste/ / klung chen rgyun dang 'dra ba'o/ /
Know that it is like a vehicle; Bodhicitta is like a fount, Like delightful speech, And like the flow of a great river. (V, 19)

zhi gnas dang lhag mthong dag dang mtshungs par ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni/ theg pa ste bzhon pa 'dra bar shes par bya ste/ rta dang glang po shing rta sogs kyi bzhon pas khur rnams khyer nas gang 'dod pa'i gnas su phyin par byed pa bzhin/ sems mi g.yeng bar rtse gcig tu gnas pa'i zhi gnas dang don ma nor bar rtogs pa'i lhag mthong zung du 'brel ba las gang gtan la dbab par byas pa'i ji ltar ji snyed kyi chos rnams kyi don phyin ci ma log par rtogs nas mthar thug gi 'bras bu'i gnas su phyin par byed pa'i phyir ro/ /

(18) The bodhicitta associated with sustained calm and profound insight is like a vehicle or conveyance. In the same way that a conveyance such as a horse, elephant, or carriage takes the loads it is carrying wherever one wishes, the combination of sustained calm (in which the mind remains one-pointedly concentrated without being distracted) and profound insight (in which one unmistakenly realizes the truth) enables one to attain the correct realization of all phenomena, exactly as they have been established and as many as have been established, and to arrive at the ultimate result.

mi brjed pa'i gzungs dang / mi zad pa'i spobs pa gnyis dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni bkod ma yi chu dang 'dra ste/ kun gyi longs spyod bya'am bkod ma'i chu mig ci tsam bcus kyang mi zad par chu'i rgyun 'dzad pa med pa ltar byang chub sems dpa'i gzungs thob pa'i sngon thos pa'i chos rnams nam yang mi brjed pas nyams pa med pa dang / spobs pas gsar du spros te ci tsam bstan kyang mtha' zad par mi 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

(19) The bodhicitta associated with both infallible memory and inexhaustible confidence and eloquence is like a fountain. However much water one draws from it, a public spring or fountain never runs dry, and the water never ceases to flow. Similarly, for bodhisattvas who have gained the power of retention, the teachings they have heard in the past will never be lost through being forgotten; through their eloquent confidence, they can elaborate on the teachings anew, and however much they teach, it will never come to an end.

'dus byas thams cad mi rtag pa dang / zag bcas thams cad sdug bsngal ba dang / chos thams cad la bdag med pa dang / mya ngan las 'das pa zhi ba'o/ /zhes bya ba'i chos kyi sdom mam mdo bzhi dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni/ yid kun tu dga' ba'i sgra dang 'dra ba ste/ dper na sems can la la zhig nye du dang nor rdzas sogs dang bral te mi dga' ba la/ 'ga' zhig gis khyod nye du dang nor rdzas dang 'phrad par 'gyur ro zhes gtam smras pa'am/ srog yal du dogs pa can la/ srog bskyabs pa'i gtam dang / don gang dang gang 'dod pa la don thob pa'i gtam la sogs pa mdor na rgud pa las dbugs 'byin pa dang / bde zhing skyid pa'i don phun sum tshogs pa'i sgra thos pa ni yid kun tu dga' bar byed pa'i sgra yin pa de ltar chos kyi mdo bzhi brjod pa'i sgra thos na zhi ba mya ngan las 'das pa'i lam yang dag pa'i chos kyi bdud rtsi ni 'di yin pas/ 'di thos pas 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal pha mtha' bral ba las dbugs 'byin/ yang dag pa'i chos kyi rang bzhin rtogs pa dang / gtan du bde ba'i gnas thob pas gang zag skal ba dang ldan pa rnams bdud rtsis tshims pa bzhin du yid la dga' ba rmad du byung ba skye ba'i phyir ro/ /

(20) The bodhicitta associated with the four summaries of the Dharma—namely, that all compounded things are impermanent, all tainted phenomena are suffering, all phenomena are devoid of self, and nirvāṇa is peace—is like delightful speech. Take the example of someone who is unhappy at being separated from their relatives and possessions and is told, “You will find your relatives and possessions”; or of someone who is afraid of dying and receives advice on how their life can be saved; or of someone who wants something and hears advice on how to obtain it—these, in short, are words that are right: they are comforting and of happy import. For such people, they are words that bring delight. Similarly, the words one hears that express the four summaries of the Dharma constitute the nectar-like perfect Dharma, the path that leads to peace beyond suffering. By hearing it, one is relieved of the limitless sufferings of saṃsāra, one realizes the nature of the true Dharma, and one attains the state of everlasting happiness. So this bodhicitta makes fortunate individuals replete as if with nectar and gives rise to the most marvelous joy in their minds.

bgrod pa gcig pa'i lam dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed pa ni klung chen po'i rgyun dang 'dra ba ste/ chu klung chen po 'bad rtsol med par 'gro zhing rgya mtshor ngang gis 'jug pa ltar/ sa brgyad pa la mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa chen po thob ste mnyam rjes kun tu rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes 'bad rtsol med par lhun gyis grub pa thob pa'i tshe/ sa der son pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams rgyud dang bya ba tha dad med par mnyam pas thams cad kyang 'dres shing 'dra bas bgrod pa gcig pa'i lam zhes bya ste bdag nyid kyis sangs rgyas kyi chos yongs su rdzogs pa dang / sems can yongs su smin par bya ba la 'bad rtsol med par lhun gyis grub par 'jug pa de yi phyir na'o/ /

(21) The bodhicitta associated with the single path to tread is like the flow of a great river. A great river proceeds effortlessly and flows by itself into the sea. Similarly, when, on the eighth level, bodhisattvas acquire the great acceptance that phenomena are unborn and nonconceptual gnosis is effortlessly and spontaneously achieved all the time, both in formal meditation and in the postmeditation periods, there is no difference in the mind streams and activities of the bodhisattvas who have reached that level; they are all mingled and equivalent in what is referred to as the single path to tread. Their own completion of the path to buddhahood and the bringing of sentient beings to maturity are undertaken effortlessly and spontaneously.
rgyal sras rnams kyi sems bskyed pa/ / sprin dang 'dra bar bstan pa ste/ / de phyir de ltar yon tan phyug / sems ni dga' bas yang dag bskyed/ /
The bodhisattvas’ bodhicitta Is taught as being like a cloud. Arouse, therefore, this spiritual intent, So rich in qualities, correctly and with joy. (V, 20)

rgyal ba'i sras po rnams kyi thabs mkhas dang ldan pa'i sems bskyed ni sprin dang 'dra bar bstan pa ste/ sprin chen po las char babs pas sa gzhi la lo tog sogs 'jig rten gyi 'byor pa sna tshogs 'byung ba bzhin/ thabs shes zung du 'brel ba'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi dga' ldan gyi pho brang nas 'pho ba sogs mya ngan las 'das pa'i bar gyi mdzad pa ston pa dang / mtho ris dang byang grol gyi phan bde'i chos sna tshogs 'byung ba'i phyir ro/ / de ltar dpe nyer gnyis kyi tshul gyis byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi sems bskyed pa de ni yon tan gyis phyug cing 'byor pa yin phyir/ byang chub mchog gi sems de ni rab tu dad cing dga' bas yang dag par bskyed par bya'o/ /

(22) In the children of the victorious ones, the bodhicitta associated with the skill in means is taught as being like a cloud. As with the rain falling onto the earth from a huge cloud and giving rise to the crops and various other kinds of earthly riches, for bodhisattvas in whom skillful means and wisdom are united, this bodhicitta gives rise to the deeds they display (from descending from the Tuṣita heaven through to the parinirvāṇa)[11] and to the various qualities of benefit and happiness of the higher realms and awakening. As these twenty-two similes show, the bodhisattvas’ bodhicitta is rich in excellent qualities, so you should arouse this spiritual intent for supreme enlightenment correctly, with deep faith and joy.
bzhi pa byang chub kyi sems la bsngags pa'i sgo nas de 'jug par gdams pa ni/
4. IN PRAISE OF THE BENEFITS AND ADVANTAGES OF BODHICITTA
dang po/ theg chen sems bskyed dang bral ba rnams bde ba bzhi las nyams pa'i tshul gsungs pa/
The next eight verses are a praise of bodhicitta, used as an instruction for applying it. The first describes how those who do not have the Mahāyāna spiritual intent lack four kinds of happiness.
cher 'os sems bskyed spangs pa'i skye bo dag / gzhan don sems dang de yi thabs rnyed dang / / dgongs chen don dang de nyid mchog mthong bas/ / bde ba de spangs zhi bar 'gro bar 'gyur/ /

Beings who lack a more worthy spiritual intent Are deprived of the happiness derived from having altruistic thoughts, From acquiring the corresponding means, from understanding the import of the great intention, And from seeing thatness; they thus proceed to peace alone. (V, 21)
zhes bstan te/

byang chub mchog gi sems de ni byang chub sems dpa' dang de bzhin gshegs pa la 'os pas chen po rnams la 'os pa'am cher 'os pa'i sems bskyed spangs pa'i skye bo nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas dag bde ba bzhi las nyams te/

Ordinary people, listeners, and solitary realizers, who do not have the attitude that befits the great, or “a more worthy attitude”—that is, the spiritual intent for supreme enlightenment that befits the bodhisattvas and tathāgatas—lack four kinds of happiness.

sems can gzhan sgrib gnyis spangs pa'i spangs pa phun sum tshogs pa dang / bdag med gnyis rtogs pa'i rtogs pa phun sum tshogs pa la bzhag pa'i don la sems pa'i bde ba ni byang chub sems dpa' la yod de sems can gcig la phan pa phra mo tsam bsgrubs kyang byang sems rnams rang gi don de thob pa las lhag par yid bde ba skye na spangs rtogs phun tshogs la bkod pa lta ci smos/ des na sems can tshad med pa'i don phun sum tshogs pa bsgrubs pa las byung ba'i bde ba mchog tu kha na ma tho ba med pa tshad med pa de las nyan rang rnams nyams par gyur te de dag gis de spang ba'i phyir ro/ /

For bodhisattvas there is the happiness of the courageous intention to bring other sentient beings to perfect elimination (the elimination of the two obscurations) and to perfect realization (the realization of the two kinds of no-self). In fact, bodhisattvas derive greater pleasure from managing to help a single sentient being in some small way than from attaining their own goal, so one need hardly mention their joy at establishing beings in perfect elimination and realization. This boundless, unflawed[12] happiness that arises from accomplishing the perfect goal of infinite sentient beings is lost for listeners and solitary realizers because they lack that intention.

de bzhin du sems can rnams la phan bde bsgrub pa'i thabs rnam pa sna tshogs shes shing rnyed pa las byang chub sems dpa' la bde ba mchog skye zhing / nyan rang rnams rang 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal las thar pa'i thabs shes pa tsam las dga' ba nyi tshe ba 'byung gi byang chub sems dpa'i dga' ba ltar rgya mi che ba dang / dgongs pa chen po'i don ni theg chen las gsungs pa chos thams cad mi skye mi 'gag rang bzhin gyis spros pa dang bral ba zab mo'i don gtan la pheb pa dang / tshig la yang dgongs pa dang ldem dgongs kyi sgo nas bstan pa'i dgongs pa zab mo rnams ji bzhin rtogs pa las byang chub sems dpa' rnams la yid bde mchog tu gyur pa yod pa de lta bu nyan rang la med cing de dag gang zag gi bdag med dang lam nyi tshe ba tsam shes pa'i bde ba myong ngo / /

Similarly, from knowing and acquiring all kinds of different means for accomplishing benefit and happiness for sentient beings, bodhisattvas feel sublimely happy. For the listeners and solitary realizers, there occurs some limited happiness from merely knowing the means for their own liberation from the sufferings of saṃsāra, but it is not the vast joy that is the bodhisattva’s. Bodhisattvas derive the most sublime happiness both from establishing the import of the Buddha’s thinking[13] as taught in the Great Vehicle (the profound meaning by nature free from elaboration, the fact that all phenomena are not born and do not cease) and from realizing, as they are, the profound intentions indicated by his words—that is, of the implied teachings and indirect teachings. Listeners and solitary realizers have nothing like that happiness: they experience the happiness of knowing only the no-self of the individual and their limited path.

byang chub sems dpa' rnams chos thams cad kyi de kho na nyid mthar thug pa'am mchog tu gyur pa stong nyid mnyam pa chen po ji lta ba bzhin du mthong ba'i bde ba chen po mi zad pa nam mkha' dang mnyam pa thob pa de lta bu nyan rang la med de/ dngos po thams cad yod bzhin du de la gang zag gi bdag med pa tsam rtogs pas de kho na nyid ji bzhin ma rtogs pa'o/ /

Bodhisattvas obtain the inexhaustible great bliss, as vast as space, of seeing, just as it is, the ultimate or supreme thatness of all phenomena, emptiness, the great evenness. This is something the listeners and solitary realizers do not have. They have realized only the no-self of the individual, and so they have no realization of thatness as it is with regard to outer objects, which, for them, exist.

de ltar nyan rang rnams kyis byang chub mchog tu sems mi bskyed pas bde ba bzhi po de spangs nas nyer len gyi phung po dang bral ba'i 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal nye bar zhi ba tsam gyi mya ngan las 'das par 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ /zhes nyan rang gi 'bras bu la dga' ba spangs te byang chub mchog tu sems bskyed par 'os par bstan pa'o/ /

Thus, deprived of these four kinds of happiness, for they have not aroused the spiritual intent for supreme enlightenment, listeners and solitary realizers will proceed to the nirvāṇa that is merely complete peace from the sufferings of saṃsāra and is the absence of the perpetuating aggregates. This shows that it is better to give up any inclination for the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ result and to arouse the mind intent on supreme enlightenment.
gnyis pa don dam pa'i byang chub kyi sems skye ba na ngan song dang 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal gyis skyo ba'i 'jigs pa med par bstan pa ni/
The second of these verses shows that when the ultimate bodhicitta is born, there is no fear of being discouraged by the lower realms and the sufferings of saṃsāra.
blo ldan sems mchog skyes ma thag tu yang / / mtha' yas nyes pa byed las sems rab bsdams/ / gnyis 'phel byed pas rtag tu dge ba dang / / brtse ldan bde dang sdug bsngal dag gis dga'/ /

As soon as the wise arouse the sublime intent, Their minds are completely restrained from committing infinite evils. Ever virtuous and loving, as they grow in both, They delight in experiencing both happiness and pain. (V, 22)
zhes pas bstan te/

blo ldan zhes bdag med pa rtogs pa'i ye shes yod pa byang chub sems dpa' des bla na med pa'i byang chub kyi sems mchog tu gyur pa don dam pa'i byang chub sems sa dang po'i gnas skabs su skyes ma thag tu yang / mtha' yas pa'i sems can thams cad la gnod pa'i las su gyur pa rnams dang sgo gsum mi dge ba'i phyogs mtha' yas pa'i nyes pa byed pa las sems rab tu bsdams te slan chad mi byed pa'i chos nyid kyi sdom pa thob bo/ / ji ltar sdig pa mi byed pa'i sdom pa thob pas na ngan song gsum du 'gro ba'i 'jigs pa med do/ / byang chub kyi sems bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ni dge ba 'phel ba dang sems can la snying brtse ba gnyis kyi rgyun 'phel bar byed pas dus rtag tu dge ba la gnas pa dang / sems can la brtse ba dang ldan pa'i phyir na bde ba nyams su myong ba'i dus na yang dga' la/ sdug bsngal myong ba dag gis kyang dga' bar 'gyur bas na rtag tu skyo ba'i 'jigs pa med de dge ba'i dbang gis lha dang mi'i bde ba mang po myong ba na yang dga' la/ brtse ba 'phel bas sdug bsngal can gyi sems can gzhan gyi don du ngan song gsum gyi tsha grang sogs kyi sdug bsngal mang po myong yang dga' bzhin dang du len pas nam yang dga' bar 'gyur ba de 'khor bar skyo bar mi 'gyur bas byang chub kyi sems bskyed pa la rgyab kyis phyogs par mi bya bar dang du blang bar bya'o zhes gdams pa'o/ /

The moment that “the wise”—that is, bodhisattvas who have the gnosis that is the realization of no-self—first give rise to the ultimate bodhicitta, the supreme spiritual intent for unsurpassable enlightenment, their minds are completely bound against doing any evil, in the way of actions that harm any of the infinite sentient beings and the infinite nonvirtuous actions of the body, speech, and mind. And they acquire a natural restraint[14] against ever doing them in the future. Since they have obtained the vow[15] to commit no evil action whatsoever, they have no fear of going to the three lower realms. Bodhisattvas who have aroused bodhicitta are continuously increasing both their virtuous activities and their compassion for beings, so they perform positive actions and are loving toward beings all the time. For this reason, they are not only joyful when they are experiencing bliss but also pleased when they experience pain, and so they never fear getting discouraged. They are happy when, on account of their virtue, they experience the many joys of celestial and human existence, and they are happy when, with their burgeoning love, they gladly take upon themselves numerous sufferings in the three lower realms—heat and cold and suchlike—for the sake of other suffering beings. Such bodhisattvas will never become discouraged by saṃsāra. This verse, therefore, counsels willing acceptance without ever turning one’s back on bodhicitta.
gang tshe gzhan gyi don phyir lus dang ni/ / srog la mi lta rab ngal khas len pa/ / de lta bu de gzhan gyi gnod pa yis/ / ji ltar ngan par byed pa'i las la 'jug /
At that time, for others’ sake, They accept hardship with no regard for their bodies or lives. How could such beings do anything bad When others do them wrong? (V, 23)
ces pas bstan te/

gsum pa/ 'khor ba 'dir gnas na sems can gyis log sgrub mang bas de bzod dka' ba'i phyir byang chub sems dpa' yang ji ltar skyo ba mi skye la ji ltar rang gi dge ba las nyams par mi 'gyur snyam na gang gi tshe byang chub sems dpa' sa thob pa snying rje chen pos bdag las gzhan gces par 'dzin pa rnams sems can gzhan gyi don phyir rang gi lus dang ni srog la mi lta bar lus srog btang nas/ sems can gzhan gyi don du bskal pa mang por mgo dang yan lag btang ba sogs rab tu ngal ba'i sdug bsngal drag po dang du len pa'am khas len pa de lta bu yi byang sems de sems can gzhan gyis de'i srog gcod pa sogs kyi gnod pa byas pa yis/ byang sems des de la gnod lan byed pa sogs ji ltar ngan par byed pa'i las la 'jug rigs te nam yang 'jug mi srid do/ / de'i phyir byang chub tu sems bskyed pa la mos par bya'o/ /

Third, one might think that when one remains here in saṃsāra, it must be hard to put up with the manifold ingratitude of sentient beings. Surely, even bodhisattvas would get discouraged and fail in their virtuous activities. But at such times, bodhisattvas who have reached the levels and who with great compassion cherish others more than themselves have no regard for their own bodies or lives but give away these very things to benefit other beings. They willingly assume or accept intense suffering from extreme hardships such as giving away their heads and limbs for other beings’ sake over many kalpas. How could bodhisattvas like that ever begin to do anything bad, such as retaliating when other beings kill them or otherwise harm them? It is quite impossible for them to do so. For this reason, you should take an interest in arousing their spiritual intent.
de yis chos kun sgyu ma lta bu dang / / skye ba skyed mos tshal 'gro ltar rtogs nas/ / 'byor ba'i dus dang rgud pa'i dus na'ang 'di/ / nyon mongs sdug bsngal dag gis 'jigs pa med/ /

Having realized that all things are like illusions And that taking birth is like going to a pleasure grove, In times of prosperity and times of trouble They are not afraid of defilements or of suffering. (V, 24)
ces pas bstan te/

bzhi pa 'khor ba 'dir byang sems rnams 'byor ba dang rgud pa ji ltar gyur kyang byang chub kyi spyod pa las mi ldog pa ni/ /byang chub sems dpa' de yis phyi nang gi chos thams cad sgyu ma dang rmi lam la sogs pa lta bu nyid du rtogs pa ye shes kyi tshogs dang / bsod nams kyi tshogs kyi dbang gis sems can gyi don du lha dang mi'i gnas ji ltar 'dod pa nyid du skye ba 'dzin pas/ lus snga ma dor nas skye ba gzhan 'dzin pa ni skyed mos tshal bzang por 'gro ba ltar rtogs nas/ 'byor ba'i dus lha dang mi'i dbang phyug tu gyur pa na yang 'og nas 'byung ba ltar 'dod chags la sogs pa'i nyon mongs pa'i 'ching ba'i 'jigs pa med do/ / gong du bshad pa ltar chos thams cad sgyu ma ltar mthong ba'i phyir ro/ / de bzhin du lha sogs kyi lus dang longs spyod de 'dor ba 'chi ba la bab pa rgud pa'i dus na'ang byang sems 'di lus dang longs spyod 'dor ba'i sdug bsngal gyi 'jigs pa med de/ de yang sgyu ma ltar shes shing skye ba skyed mos tshal du 'gro ba ltar shes pa'i phyir ro/ / des na byang chub sems dpa' rnams bde sdug ji ltar gyur kyang lam las mi nyams pas byang chub kyi lam la bslab par bya rigs zhes gdams pa'o / /

Fourth, however well or badly things go for them here in saṃsāra, bodhisattvas never turn back from their bodhisattva activities. On account of their accumulation of wisdom—the realization that all outer and inner phenomena are like magical illusions, like dreams, and so on—and of their accumulation of merit, bodhisattvas, for beings’ sake, take birth wherever they wish in the celestial and human realms. In doing so, they realize that abandoning their previous body and taking another rebirth is like going to a beautiful pleasure grove. When things go well, even if they are the sovereigns of gods and humans, they have no fear of the fetters of defilements such as attachment, as we shall see later. This is because, as mentioned above, they perceive all phenomena as magical illusions. Similarly, even when things go badly, when death befalls them and they have to leave behind their celestial or human bodies and possessions, these bodhisattvas have no fear of the pain of leaving them behind. This is because they know that these too are like magical illusions, and that rebirth is like going to a pleasure grove. This, therefore, is an instruction showing that since bodhisattvas never fall back from the path whatever pleasure or pain befalls them, you should certainly train on the path to enlightenment.
rang gi yon tan sems can phan 'dogs dga'/ / bsam bzhin skye ba rdzu 'phrul rnam par 'phrul/ / rgyan dang ston mo sa mchog brtse dga' ba/ / snying rje'i bdag nyid min pa rnams la med/ /

They delight in the ornaments that are their own qualities, In the festive fare of helping sentient beings, In the sublime location of their voluntary birth, And in the entertainment of miraculous displays. Such delights are not for those who do not embody compassion. (V, 25)
ces pas bstan te/

lnga pa bshad ma thag pas skye ba skyed mos tshal du 'gro ba ltar rtogs pa'i don rgyas par bshad pa ni/ dper na lha dang mi rnams yid dga' ba'i skyed mos tshal du 'gro ba rnams don bzhi'i phyir 'gro ste/ lus bkru bar byas nas rgyan gyis mdzes par byed pa dang / ston mo'i zas skom sna tshogs longs spyad pa dang / nyams dga' ba'i gnas der gnas par byed pa dang / rtsed mo sna tshogs nyams su myong ba'i dga' ba bzhi nyams su bstar ba 'dod pas skyed tshal du sems 'jug cing ldog pa med pa de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' rnams skye ba gcig nas gcig du brgyud de 'jug pa yang rang gi yon tan sbyin pa dang tshul khrims gzungs ting 'dzin shes rab kyi rgyan la sogs pas gong nas gong du rang rgyud brgyan pa'i phyir dang / gang du skye ba'i gnas de'i sems can rnams la phan 'dogs par dga' ba ni zas kyi ston mo lta bu'o/ / gnas gang du lus rten ji 'dra bar bsam bzhin skye ba nas mchog nyams dga' bar sdod pa bzhin no/ / der mngon par shes pa lngas rdzu 'phrul sna tshogs rnam par 'phrul par byed pa ni rtse dga' sna tshogs byed pa bzhin no/ /

The fifth of these verses expands on what is meant by realizing that taking birth is like going to a pleasure grove, as was just mentioned. The analogy refers to the fact that gods and humans who go to a delightful pleasure grove do so with four aims in mind: to bathe and beautify themselves with ornaments; to enjoy different kinds of food and drink in a picnic; to pass the time there in agreeable surroundings; and to enjoy a variety of entertainments. In anticipation of these four pleasures, they make the decision to go to the pleasure grove, and there is no changing their minds. In the same way, when bodhisattvas pass from one life to the next, it is in order to embellish their own mind streams more and more with the ornaments of their own excellent qualities—generosity, discipline, powers of retention, concentration, wisdom, and so forth. Their delight, wherever they are reborn, at benefiting the beings there is analogous to the pleasures of a picnic. Their taking birth wherever and in whatever physical form they wish is analogous to staying in a delightful location. And using their five kinds of preternatural knowledge to display all kinds of miraculous feats there is analogous to taking part in various kinds of entertainment.

de ltar srid par yang nas yang du skye ba bzhes pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams 'jig rten pa rnams skyed tshal du 'gro ba'i las bzhi byas pa'i dga' ba nyams su myong ba dang 'dra ba'i yon tan gyi rgyan gyis brgyan pa'i dga' ba dang / gzhan la phan 'dogs pa'i zas kyi ston mo dag gi dga' ba dang / gzhan don byed pa'i rten pa yid du 'ong ba'i mchog skyed tshal la gnas bcas te bsdad pa'i dga' ba dang / rdzu 'phrul gyi brtse ba sna tshogs nyams su myong ba'i dga' ba bzhi po 'di ni/ snying rje'i bdag nyid byang chub sems dpa' min pa gzhan 'jig rten pa lta ci nyan rang 'phags pa rnams la'ang med do/ /

In this way, bodhisattvas who take birth again and again in existence savor four delights analogous to the pleasures that mundane beings experience in the four activities of going to a pleasure grove: the delight of being adorned with the ornaments of excellent qualities; that of feasting on the food of benefiting others; that of lingering in a sublimely pleasant garden where they can benefit others; and that of performing their various miraculous displays. These four delights are absent in others who are not bodhisattvas, the very embodiments of compassion: even the noble listeners and solitary realizers do not have them, let alone mundane beings.
de'i phyir byang chub tu sems bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams yon tan khyad par 'phags pa'i phyir byang chub tu sems bskyed par rigs so/ /
For this reason, you should certainly arouse bodhicitta, because the qualities of bodhisattvas who have aroused bodhicitta are particularly sublime.
gzhan don brtson ldan snying rje'i bdag nyid 'di/ / gang tshe mnar med pa la'ang dgar 'dzin pa/ / de 'dra ba dag srid na gzhan rten phyir/ / sdug bsngal 'byung ba rnams kyis ga la 'jigs/ /

Striving for the sake of others, these lords of compassion, Even when in the Hell of Torment Unsurpassed, consider it to be delightful. How could such beings be afraid of the pains they suffer For the sake of others in existence? (V, 26)
zhes pas bstan te/

drug pa lus gtong ba sogs sdug bsngal gyis ldog pa med cing mi zhum pa'i tshul gsungs pa/ gang gi phyir chos thams cad bdag med par rtogs pas rang don la chags pa yong ye bral te/ de ltar ma rtogs pa'i sems can gzhan tshe 'di dang gtan du phan bde mchog la 'god pa'i don du phar phyin drug la rtag tu brtson pa dang ldan pa/ gzhan sdug bsngal ba'i rgyus bdag kyang sdug bsngal bar 'gyur bas na snying rje'i bdag nyid byang chub sems dpa' 'di ni/ gang gi tshe gzhan gyi don du 'gyur na dmyal ba mnar med par rang nyid gnas par byed pa la'ang bde zhing dga' bar 'dzin pa dang skyo ba cung zad mi skye ba de 'dra ba dag srid pa 'di na sems can gzhan la phan 'dogs pa'i rten nam don gyi phyir lus dang yan lag gtong ba sogs kyi sdug bsngal 'byung ba rnams kyis ga la 'jigs zhes sdug bsngal drag po dang du len nus par bstan pa'o/ / blo brtan 'grel pa'i 'gyur ltar na/ gzhan la brten pa'i sdug bsngal 'gyur ba yis zhes 'dug pa don 'dra'o/ / de ltar byang chub sems dpa' la yon tan rmad du byung ba de lta bu mnga' bas srid pa 'dir sdug bsngal gang gis kyang 'jigs pa med la thams cad du dga' bzhin dang du len pas dga' ba las nam yang mi nyams pas skyo ba med phyir byang chub kyi lam nyams su blang bar rigs so/ /

Sixth, how is it that bodhisattvas do not recoil and lose heart in the face of painful experiences such as giving away their bodies? As a result of realizing that all phenomena are devoid of self, bodhisattvas are completely free of attachment to their own interests. Their aim is to bring benefit in this life and happiness forever to other sentient beings who do not have such realization, and to this end they exert themselves constantly in practicing the six transcendent perfections. These bodhisattvas—“lords of compassion,” for others’ suffering makes them suffer too—will stay in the Hell of Torment Unsurpassed themselves when it will benefit others, and even that they consider to be blissful and pleasant. It does not arouse in them the slightest regret. How could beings like that be afraid of the pain of giving their bodies, limbs, and the like when it is in order to benefit other beings in this world? This verse demonstrates their capacity to willingly accept intense suffering. (In Sthiramati’s commentary, this part of the root verse has been translated as: “the pains that befall them in dependence on others?”[16] The meaning, however, is the same.) Thus, it is because bodhisattvas have such marvelous qualities that they are not afraid of any sufferings whatsoever in this existence. Rather, they wholly rejoice in it and willingly accept it. And since their joy never diminishes, they are never discouraged. For this reason, you should put the path to enlightenment into practice.

bdun pa/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams sems can thams cad kyi ma 'dris pa'i mdza' bshes chen po ste sngon du bkur sti dang zang zing dang rim gro sogs kyis mnyes par byas pa'am tshe 'di'i gnyen dang rtsa lag tu gyur pa lta bu sngon 'dris pa'i rgyus phan 'dogs pa min gyi/ rang bzhin gyis sems can gzhan la snying brtse ba'i ngang tshul yin pas sems can don la rang nyid ngang gis 'jug par mdzad kyi gzhan gyis bskul mi dgos par bstan pa ni/

Seventh, bodhisattvas are the great “unacquainted” friends of all beings. That is to say, they do not help them on account of previous acquaintance—for example, because those beings have pleased them in the past by serving them, making them material offerings, worshipping them, and so on, or because they are related by family or friendship in this life. Rather, it is in their character to naturally feel love and compassion for other beings, and they therefore, as a matter of course, devote themselves to beings’ welfare. They do not need to be prompted by others, as the following verse shows:
slob dpon brtse chen rtag tu brten pa'i bdag / pha rol sdug bsngal dag gis sems gdungs pa/ / gzhan gyi bya ba nye bar gnas pa la/ / gzhan gyis bskul ba shin tu ngo yang tsha/ /

Those who constantly rely on the teacher, great love, Are deeply pained by others’ sufferings. When it is their duty to act for others, To have another prompt them would be utterly disgraceful. (V, 27)
zhes pas bstan te/
