ji skad bshad pa de ltar dga' ba sogs kyi dngos po rnam pa dgus bdag nyid kyi sangs rgyas kyis chos yongs su smin pa'i bdag nyid du gyur pa de ni pha rol sems can rnams yongs su smin par byed rung ba yi yon tan dang ldan te rang smin pas gzhan smin par byed nus pas so/ / phar phyin drug gi chos kun gyi rang bzhin gyi rgyun gong nas gong du 'phel ba'i bdag can de ni/ rtag tu sems can gzhan smin par byed pas 'gro ba'i gnyen mchog tu gyur pa yin no zhes rang smin pa de bzhin smin par byed pa'i rten du gyur cing rang gi chos kyi lus 'phel bar gyur pa'i yon tan gnyis dang ldan par bstan pa'o/ /

Through delight and the other eight elements that have just been explained, bodhisattvas become the fully mature embodiment of the Buddha’s teachings, and they then have the quality of being fit to bring other sentient beings to full maturity. For by maturing themselves, they are able to bring others to maturity. In them the stream of all the qualities of the six transcendent perfections grows greater and greater. Constantly bringing other sentient beings to maturity, they are “the supreme friends of beings.” This verse shows that maturing oneself has two virtues: it is the basis for maturing others, and it enables the body of one’s own qualities to grow.
gnyis pa
ii. AN ANALOGY FOR MATURATION
ji ltar rma dang zas la de dag gi / gzag dang spyad du rung ba smin 'dod ltar/ / de bzhin rten 'dir phyogs gnyis zhi ba dang / / de bzhin spyad pa nyid du smin pa bstan/ /
We say that boils that drip are “ripe,” And food when it is fit to eat. So too, it is taught that maturity in such individuals Refers to removal and employment with regard to two factors. (IX, 12)
ces pas bstan te/

dpe ni smin pa zhes bya ba ji lta bu zhig yin ce na/ dpe ji ltar na rma dang zas la de dag gi rim pa bzhin nag gzag pa dang spyod du rung ba ni smin no zhes 'jig rten na 'dod pa ltar zhes dpe 'god pa ste/ 'bras sogs rnag tu ma smin pa btol na rnag gzag tu med nad la mi phan pa dang / rnag tu smin na rma btod pa las rnag gzag tu rung bas dus la bab pa la rma smin no zhes dang / rgun 'brum sogs kyi 'bras bu ma smin pa'am/ kha zas g.yos su sbyar ba'ang ma tshos pa sogs kyi tshe spyad du mi rung la/ legs par tshad du smin na spyad du rung ba

To make an analogy for what we call maturation, in ordinary life, abscesses and food are said to be ripe when they respectively drip pus and are fit to eat. If one lances an abscess that is not ripe with pus, no pus will drip out and one will not have done the condition any good. If it is ripe with pus, the time is right for lancing the abscess, since it is ready to drip pus, and we therefore say the abscess is ripe. When fruits such as grapes are unripe, or food, even though prepared, is not well cooked, they are inedible, while when they are ripe to perfection, they can be enjoyed.

de bzhin du phung po lnga'i rten 'dir spang bya dang gnyen po'i phyogs gnyis gang gi go rims ltar zhi ba dang longs spyod pa nyid du rung ba ni smin pa yin par yin te/ 'bras kyi nad sogs rnag gis gang ste smin nas rmar gyur pa la rnag zag nas nad zhi ba ltar lus rten 'di la chags sogs nyon mongs pa rnams spong bar nus pas zhi bar byed pa dang / kha zas smin pa longs spyod pa ltar rten de la dge ba'i phyogs rgyun du spyod cing sgom nus par gyur na gang zag de yongs su smin pa zhes bya ste/

Similarly, for a person with the five aggregates, maturity refers to ability with respect to two factors—being able to remove factors that have to be eliminated and being able to employ remedial factors. Just as boils and so on are sore when they are ripe and full of pus, and are healed by the pus being drained, so it is for someone with this bodily support who is able to eliminate defilements such as attachment and is thereby healed. And just as food that is ripe can be enjoyed, so it is when that person is able to live constantly in virtue and practice it. Such a person is what we call “fully matured.”

theg chen gyi chos la yid dga' ba tsam yod kyang de ma smin pa na/ bshes gnyen bsten nas chos mnyan bsam bsgom pa'i sgo nas dang du len mi nus la/ dga' ba yongs su smin pa'i tshe na dam chos 'dzin nus pa yin pa bzhin gzhan ma brgyad la'ang de ltar shes par bya ste/ yongs su smin pa na de dang de'i bya ba dngos su byed nus pa'i phyir byang chub sems dpa' dad pa la sogs pa'i dbang po yongs su smin pa gong nas gong du 'phel bas theg pa chen po'i lam dang 'bras bu'i chos rang rgyud la rdzogs pa dang sems can smin par byed pa'i phyir byang chub sems dpas dus dang dus su dbang po yongs su sbyang bar bya'o zhes gsungs pa bzhin/ dbang po dman pa 'bring dang 'bring chen por 'gyur ba'i phyir dbang po gong nas gong du rnam par sbyang bar zlobya ba gnad che ste/ dbang po sbyangs na sngar ma rtogs pa rtogs pa dang / ma thob pa 'thob par 'gyur te yon tan rgya cher sangs rgyas kyi sa'i bar du 'phel bar 'gyur ro/ /

However much delight one takes in the Mahāyāna teachings, if that delight is not mature, one will not be able to practice them wholeheartedly, following a spiritual master and listening to, reflecting on, and meditating on the teachings. But when delight is fully matured, one is able to hold the sacred teachings. The same is true for the other eight factors, for when they are fully matured, one is able to actually put each one into effect. It has therefore been said that in order for bodhisattvas to complete the qualities of the Mahāyāna path and result in their own mind streams and to bring sentient beings to maturity, which is by increasing faith and the other fully ripened faculties, they have to fully train in these faculties in a timely manner. Accordingly, in order for beings with fewer faculties to become ones with intermediate faculties, and for those with intermediate faculties to become beings with greater faculties, it is very important that they train completely from one faculty to the next. When they develop these faculties, they will realize what they had not previously realized and will obtain what they had not previously obtained. Their excellent qualities will vastly increase all the way up to the level of buddhahood.
gnyis pa sems can gzhan smin par byed tshul
2. BRINGING OTHERS TO MATURITY
['di] la dbye ba dang / bsam pa dang / sbyor ba gsum las/
This section is divided into three parts, which deal with (1) categories; (2) intention; and (3) application.
dang po/
a. CATEGORIES
lus can bral bar smin byed de bzhin du/ / yongs smin rab smin mthun par smin byed gzhan/ / legs par smin byed rtogs pas smin byed dang / / rtag smin gong du smin byed bshad par 'dod/ /

Bodhisattvas’ maturation of living beings is explained as Maturation through riddance, and likewise full maturation, Perfect maturation, congruent maturation, excellent maturation, Maturation through realization, continuous maturation, and progressive maturation. (IX, 13)

ces dbye ba brgyad de lus can sems can rnams chags sogs nyon mongs pa dang bral bar smin par byed pa dang*/ de bzhin du theg pa gsum gyi rigs can kun yongs su smin par byed pa dang / 'jig rten pa'i lam gyi khams gong mar smin par byas pa ni slar ldog pa yin la theg pa gsum gyis smin par byas pa rnams slar ldog pa med pas rab tu smin par byed pa dang / gdul bya'i rgyud dang rjes su mthun par chags can la mi sdug pa sogs 'tshams par chos bstan pas/ rjes su smin pa'am mthun pa'i smin byed ni snga ma las gzhan no/ / phyogs lhung med pa dang gzhan la gus pa dang bcas pas nan tan bsgrims te legs par smin par byed pa dang / bdag gis sa dang po thob nas gzhan de la 'god pa lhag par smin byed dam rtogs pas smin par byed pa dang sangs rgyas kyis bstan pa'i chos rnams sems can rnams la phyin ci ma log par rtag tu bstan pas rtag tu smin par byed pa dang / mos spyod kyi sa nas brtsams te sa bcu pa'i bar gong nas gong du smin par byed par 'dod do/ /

Bodhisattvas are considered to bring beings to maturity in eight different ways: (1) They mature sentient beings in ridding them of defilements such as attachment. Similarly, (2) they bring to full maturity all those who possess the potentials of the three vehicles. (3) They bring them to perfect maturity, for unlike beings who are brought by mundane paths to the maturity of the higher worlds but then fall back again, those who are matured by the three vehicles do not regress. (4) They mature them consistently or fittingly by giving disciples appropriate teachings suited to their mind streams—for example, teaching ugliness to those with attachment. (This maturation is different from the previous ones.)[5] (5) They mature them excellently, that is, carefully and concentratedly, impartially and with respect for others. (6) They mature them through their superiority or through their realization—that is, having attained the first level themselves, they establish others on that level. (7) They mature them continuously, by constantly and unerringly teaching beings the path taught by the buddhas. And (8) they mature them progressively, beginning from the level of earnest aspiration all the way up to the tenth level.
gnyis pa bsam pa'i khyad par ni/
b. THE SPECIAL QUALITIES OF THEIR INTENTION
ji ltar rgyal sras phan pa'i bsam pas 'dir/ / 'gro kun rnam par smin byed gnas pa ltar/ / de bzhin pha dang ma dang gnyen bshes rnams/ / bu dang gnyen pa rnams la legs mi gnas/ /

Unlike the buddhas’ heirs, who, with their wish to help, Devote themselves to bringing all beings here to maturity, Fathers, mothers, friends, and relatives Never treat their children and friends so well. (IX, 14)
zhes pas bstan te/

ji ltar rgyal sras rnams kyis sems can thams cad la gnas skabs dang mthar thug gi bde ba la 'god par 'dod pa'i phan pa'i bsam pas srid pa 'dir 'gro ba kun rnam par smin par byed pa la gnas pa ltar ram ji lta ba de bzhin du 'jig rten na pha dang ma dang gnyen bshes rnams/ rang rang gi bu dang gnyen du gyur pa rnams la bsam pa de lta bu legs par mi nus te ci'i phyir na pha ma sogs rang gi bu sogs la brtse ba yod kyang gnas skabs tshe 'dir phan par cung zad byed nus kyang gtan du bde ba'i rgyu'i dge ba la 'god 'dod kyi bsam pa skyed mi shes pa dang la lar sdig pa la yang sbyor bas so/ /

Bodhisattvas, with their intention to benefit—their wish to set all sentient beings in temporary and ultimate happiness—are engaged in bringing all beings here in saṃsāra to maturity. Unlike them, fathers, mothers, relatives, and friends in ordinary life have no such excellent intentions for their own children and friends. Why is this? Because although parents and so on love their own children and friends, and although they are able to help them a little bit—on a temporary level, in this life—they are incapable of developing the intention or wish to establish them in virtue, the cause of lasting happiness. And in some cases they even introduce them to negative activities.
ji ltar brtse bdag bde dang phan phyir sbyor/ / sems can gzhan la byams 'dod de ltar ni/ / skye bo bdag la'ang byams par mi 'dod na/ / rab sdug skye bo gzhan brten smos ci dgos/ /

Unlike loving bodhisattvas, who act in order to bring happiness and benefit, Caring affectionately for other sentient beings, Ordinary people feel no kindness for themselves, Let alone for others who depend on them. (IX, 15)

ji ltar brtse ba'i bdag nyid kyis sems can gzhan la phan pa'i phyir ram ched du sbyor ba'i tshe na sems can gzhan 'phrul dang gtan du bde bar byed pa'i byams par 'dod pa de ltar ram de lta bu ni 'jig rten pa'i skye bo rnams bdag rang nyid la yang byams par mi 'dod na de dag gis yid la rab tu sdug par gyur pa'i skye bo gzhan la smos ci dgos zhes so so'i skye bo rnams bdag la byams mod kyi rmongs pa'i dbang gis tshe 'di'i bde ba'i ched du srog gcod dang ma byin par len pa sogs mi dge ba'i rgyus tshe 'dir rgyal po'i chad pa sogs dang / phyi mar sdug bsngal du ma thob pa dang / de bzhin rang gsod pa dang khyi dang ba lang gi brtul zhugs sogs dka' thub ngan pas rang 'di phyir sdug bsngal bar byed pa dang / gtan bde'i lam mi shes pas de la 'jug pa spangs pas so/ / byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad la byams pa ni rnam pa kun tu dge zhing gtan bde 'dod pa'i byams pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

When those who are the embodiment of love act in order to benefit other sentient beings, they lovingly desire to make other beings happy, immediately and forever. Unlike them, ordinary people do not even want to be kind to themselves, let alone to other beings who are dearest to them. Of course, ordinary people love themselves, but as a result of the negative actions (killing, stealing, and the like) that they perform out of ignorance in order to be happy in this life, they are punished by the authorities in this life and achieve much suffering in future lives. Similarly, by killing themselves and practicing unwholesome forms of asceticism such as acting like a dog or an ox, they bring suffering upon themselves in this life and the next, and since they do not know the way to lasting happiness, they are unable to undertake it. Bodhisattvas’ love for all sentient beings is a love that wishes them every kind of virtue and everlasting happiness.
gsum pa sbyor ba'i khyad par ni
c. THE SPECIAL QUALITIES OF THEIR APPLICATION
['di la] pha rol phyin pa drug gis smin par byed pa'i tshigs bcad drug dang / mjug tu don bsdu ba'i tshigs bcad bcas bdun las
This part covers the next seven verses, six verses that deal with maturation through the six transcendent perfections and a concluding verse that serves as a summary.
dang po/
i. GENEROSITY
byang chub sems dpa'i lus dang longs spyod dag / gzhan la mi sbyin pa ni yod med de/ / phan 'dogs rnam pa gnyis kyis gzhan smin byed/ / mnyam par sbyin pa'i yon tan ngoms mi 'gyur/ /

There is nothing, including their bodies and possessions, That bodhisattvas will not give to others. They mature others by bringing them a double benefit, And, giving equally, they never tire of the virtues of generosity. (IX, 16)

zhes sbyin pa ci lta bus sems can smin par byed pa ni thams cad sbyin pa dang / mnyam par sbyin pa dang / mi ngoms par sbyin pa rnam pa gsum gyis te/ byang chub sems dpa'i rang gi lus dang longs spyod dag gzhan la don du 'gyur ba mthong na mi sbyin pa ni cung zad tsam gtan nas sam yong ye med de rang la dbang ba'i bdog pa thams cad gtong ngo / / sbyin pa des kyang dngos po de byin pas phan 'dogs pa tsam kho nar ma zad de/ tshe 'dir sbyin pa de nyid kyis pha rol po de'i bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par byas pa tshe 'dir phan btags pa dang / de'i rgyu dge la bkod nas smin par byas pas tshe phyi mar phan 'dogs shing thar pa'i sa bon bskrun pas gtan bde la 'jog pa'i phyir 'phral dang yun du phan 'dogs rnam pa gnyis kyis sems can rnams yongs su smin par byed do/ / sbyin pa de yang bzang ngan mtho dman nye ring sogs kyi phyogs lhung med par thams cad la sems snyoms pas mnyam par sbyin pa'i rang bzhin can yin pa dang / dngos po 'ga' zhig byin pa dang lo dang bskal pa 'ga' zhig tu sbyin pas chog par mi 'dzin par/ 'khor ba'i mtha'i bar du byin yang sbyin pa'i yon tan gyis ngoms par mi 'gyur ba yin no/ /

Bodhisattvas bring sentient beings to maturity with generosity in three ways: giving everything, giving equally, and giving without ever being satisfied. There is absolutely nothing, not the slightest thing, that bodhisattvas will not give if they see that their own bodies and possessions will benefit others. They give away everything that it is in their power to give. And their generosity brings benefit not only by the gift of those things. That same generosity in this life helps the recipients in this life by completely fulfilling their wishes. And by establishing them in virtuous ways and bringing them to maturity, it benefits them in future lives and sets them in lasting happiness by sowing the seed of liberation. Their generosity thus brings sentient beings to full maturity by benefiting them in two ways—in the short term and the long term. In being generous, bodhisattvas give equally, with the same attitude to everyone, and without making any distinctions between good and bad, between high and low status, or between those who are close and those who are distant. And they never consider it sufficient to give a few things, for a few years or kalpas. Even if they give until the very end of saṃsāra, they will never be satisfied with the virtues of generosity.
gnyis pa tshul khrims ni/
ii. DISCIPLINE
brtan pa rang bzhin lhag par 'tshe ba med/ / bdag dga' bag yod 'di la gzhan 'god cing / / phan rnam gnyis 'dogs rnam par smin pa dang / / rgyu mthun yon tan brgyud pas gzhan smin byed/ /

Establishing others in that which is steadfast, natural, Totally nonviolent, delightful, and careful, They benefit in two respects and mature others Through the continuity of the ripened effects and the qualities similar to the cause. (IX, 17)
ces pas bstan te/

brtan pa zhes pa dus res 'ga' ba min par sems can thams cad kyi mtha'i bar du rtag tu tshul khrims bsrung ba la rtag pa'i tshul khrims te blo brtan 'grel pa'i 'gyur na rtag tu zhes 'dug go / sngon goms pa'i stobs kyis rang bzhin gshis kyis mi dge la 'dzems shing dge ba spyod pa rang bzhin gyi tshul khrims dang / sems can rnams la lhag par 'tshe ba med pa ni mi dge bcu rmi lam du yang mi spyod pas tshul khrims yongs su rdzogs pa ni sa gnyis pa na thob bo/ / bdag dga' zhes pa sa dang por bden pa rtogs pa'i dbang gis chos nyid kyis thob pa 'phags pa dgyes pa'i tshul khrims thob pas mi dge ba'i phyogs ngang gis spangs shing dge ba la dga' ba lhag par rtogs pa'i tshul khrims dang / bag yod ces pas spyod lam kun tu ltung ba'i rnyogs pa'am 'khrul pa phra mo yang mi 'byung ba 'khrul pa med pa'i tshul khrims te/ de lta bu'i tshul khrims lnga dang ldan pa mchog la rang gnas nas tshul khrims 'di lta bu la sems can gzhan 'god cing / 'di dang phyi mar ram 'phral dang gtan gyi phan pa rnam pa gnyis 'dogs shing / de ltar tshul khrims la bkod pas lha mir skye ba sogs rnam smin yid 'ong rten brgyud mar thob pa dang / tshul khrims kyi rgyu mthun pa'i yon tan tshe rabs phyi ma rnams su tshul khrims len pa brgyud mar 'byung bas gzhan smin par byed do/ /

“Steadfast” in this verse refers to perpetual discipline—that is, the keeping of one’s vows not for a short time but forever, until there are no sentient beings left. The translation of Sthiramati’s commentary has “perpetual.”[6] Then there is natural discipline, by which bodhisattvas shy away from negative actions and practice positive actions on account of their natural disposition resulting from previous habituation. Total nonviolence toward beings refers to perfect discipline in not committing any of the ten negative actions even in one’s dreams. This is gained on the second level. Natural delight refers to the discipline of superior realization: as a result of realizing the truth on the first level, bodhisattvas automatically acquire the discipline that delights the noble beings, and by doing so they naturally reject everything that is nonvirtuous and they delight in virtue. Carefulness refers to faultless discipline, through which not even sullying downfalls or subtle mistakes occur in any of the bodhisattva’s conduct. Having themselves observed this supreme discipline with its five aspects, bodhisattvas introduce other beings to such discipline and doubly benefit them—for this life and future ones, or in the immediate term and forever. And by thus introducing them to discipline, they bring others to maturity, for the fully ripened effect of discipline is that one obtains a continuous series of rebirths with a pleasing body—for example, as a celestial or human being; and the qualities similar to the cause are the continued taking of vows in all one’s future lives.
gsum pa bzod pa ni/
iii. PATIENCE
gzhan gnod byed la phan byed blo ldan pa/ / gnod byed drag po dag kyang rab tu bzod/ / thabs rig gnod byed bzod pa de dag gis/ / gnod byed dge ba yang dag len du 'jug /

Thinking of others who harm them as benefactors, They are perfectly patient even with those who do them violent harm. With their knowledge of methods and their endurance of harm They lead those who harm them to truly take up virtue. (IX, 18)
ces pas bstan te/

sems can gzhan dag gis byang chub sems dpa' la lus dang srog la gnod pa'i bar gyi gnod pa che chung sna tshogs byed pa la bdag gi bzod pa rdzogs pa'i rgyu ni 'di yin no zhes dge ba'i bshes gnyen dang 'dra bar sems can de bdag la phan byed du 'dzin pa'i blo dang ldan pa des gnod pa byed pa shin tu drag po lus kyi sha dang rus pa dum bu re re nas gcod pa la sogs pa dag kyang bzod na gnod pa chung ngu lta ci smos/ de ltar bzod pa bsgoms pa'i thabs bshad ma thag pa dang so sor brtags pa sogs kyi thabs dang der ma zad pha rol gnod byed de la 'phral dang yun du phan pa'i tshul des de nyid smin par byed pa'i thabs rig cing de'i phyir gnod pa byed pa bzod pa de dag gis gnod pa byed po de dge ba yang dag par len du 'jug pas smin par byed do/ /

When other sentient beings act adversely toward bodhisattvas, in greater or lesser degrees, even up to physical harm and killing them, those bodhisattvas think, “Because of this, I can perfect my patience,” and they consider that those beings are helping them as if they were spiritual teachers. Bodhisattvas with this sort of attitude endure even the most violent injuries, such as their flesh and bones being hacked to pieces, so there is no need to mention their putting up with minor wrongs. Not only do they know these methods for cultivating patience, as just explained, and the methods of detailed analysis and so on,[7] but they also know that affording immediate and long-term benefit to others who harm them is the way to bring them to maturity, and because of this they patiently endure the harm inflicted on them. By these means they induce those who harm them to genuinely take up virtue, and they thereby bring them to maturity.
bzhi pa brtson 'grus ni/
iv. DILIGENCE
rgyal sras brtson 'grus mchog la brten pa de/ / sems can tshogs rab smin par byed pa na/ / pha rol sems dge gcig gi phyir yang ni/ / bskal pa bye ba stong du'ang skyo mi 'gyur/ /

The buddhas’ heirs, relying on the utmost diligence, Perfectly mature hosts of sentient beings. If only for the sake of another’s single virtuous thought, They will not lose heart even after ten billion kalpas. (IX, 19)
zhes pas bstan te/

rgyal ba'i sras po go cha dang sbyor ba'i brtson 'grus gang zhig sems can gyi don byed pa la mi ldog cing chog mi shes pa mchog la brten pa de ni/ brtson 'grus de lta bu'i sgo nas sems can gyi tshogs mtha' yas pa rab tu smin par byed pa na/ pha rol po de nam zhig smin par byed pa'i sems dge ba sbyin pa la sogs pa skad cig gcig skye nus par gzigs na de'i ched dam phyir du yang bskal pa bye ba stong du yang 'bad pa ci tsam rtsom dgos rtsom par mdzad kyi skyo ba cung zad 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ /

Children of the buddhas rely on the utmost diligence, whether armor-like diligence or diligence in application, never stopping or being satisfied in their work for beings’ welfare, and it is by means of such diligence that they bring infinite hosts of sentient beings to perfect maturity. Thus, when they see another being whom they can one day bring to maturity and who has the potential to give rise to a virtuous thought for a single instant—a single generous thought, for example—they will apply their efforts for as long as it takes to achieve that, even if it is for ten billion kalpas, without getting the slightest bit discouraged.
lnga pa bsam gtan ni/
v. CONCENTRATION
yid kyi dbang ni bla na med thob nas/ / gzhan gyi mchod 'dod thams cad nges bcom ste/ / mchog gi bstan la gzhan dag 'dun byed cing / / de dag dge ba yang dag 'phel bar byed/ /

Having attained unsurpassable mastery of the mind, They definitively overcome any desire for veneration from others. Causing others to aspire to the sublime teachings, They make their virtue perfectly increase. (IX, 20)
ces pas bstan te/

byang chub sems dpa' sems sam yid kyi dbang thob pa ni ting nge 'dzin gyis sems rang dbang du 'gyur bar byed pa'o/ / de yang mngon shes kyi rab dbyer sde tshan drug bshad pa ltar dang / de las khyad par du dpa' bar 'gro ba sogs sangs rgyas dang byang sems rnams kyi ting nge 'dzin khyad par can de dag thob pa'i tshe yid kyi dbang du bla na med pa thob pa yin la/ de thob par gyur nas yon tan de dang ldan pa'i sgo nas bdag la gzhan gyis bkur sti dang grags pa sgrogs pa sogs kyis mchod cing rjed par 'dod pa thams cad nges par bcom ste de 'dra'i bsam pa gtan med par mchog sangs rgyas kyi bstan pa la gzhan dag 'dun par byed cing de dag gi rgyud kyi dge ba phar phyin rnams yang dag par 'phel bar byed de mngon par shes pa'i mthus rdzu 'phrul bstan pa dang / sems shes pas gzhan gyi rgyud dang mthun par chos bstan pa sogs kyi sgo nas so/ /

Bodhisattvas who have acquired “mastery of the mind” have mastered their minds through concentration. When they gain the six kinds of preternatural knowledge, as explained earlier, and in particular the extraordinary concentrations of the buddhas and bodhisattvas, the concentration of Brave Progression and others, they attain unsurpassable mastery of mind. Having done so, they definitively overcome any desire to be honored, held in high repute, and similarly venerated by others on account of their having those good qualities. Utterly devoid of any such motivation, they inspire others to take an earnest interest in the sublime Buddha’s teachings and cause the virtue in their mind streams, the transcendent perfections, to grow perfectly—all this by displaying miracles, by teaching the Dharma in accord with others’ mind streams through knowing their thoughts, and by other powers of preternatural knowledge.
drug pa shes rab ni/
vi. WISDOM
de nyid dgongs don tshul la rab nges te/ / sems can the tshom shin tu sel bar byed/ / de phyir rgyal ba'i bstan la de gus pas/ / rang gzhan dge ba'i yon tan rnam 'phel byed/ /

Certain of the intended meaning of thatness, They completely clarify beings’ doubts. Because of that, through their respect for the victors’ teachings, They increase their own and others’ virtuous qualities. (IX, 21)
ces pas bstan te/

de kho na nyid kyi dgongs don zab mo'i tshul la shes rab kyi stobs kyis the tshom med par gtan la phab nas rab tu nges pa ste/ drang don dang nges don dgongs dgongs min thams cad tshul bzhin rtogs nas de kho na nyid la mkhas par gyur pas/ sems can rnams de kho na nyid dang dgongs dgongs min gyi don la the tshom du gyur pa dag gi the tshom yang rtsad nas bcad de shin tu sel bar byed do/ / shes rab de lta bu mnga' ba de phyir rgyal ba'i bstan la byang sems rang nyid gus pa dang / sems can gzhan yang shes rab de lta bu la bkod pas rgyal ba'i bstan la gus pas smin par byed pas/ rang dang gzhan gyi rgyud kyi dge ba'i yon tan rnam par 'phel bar byed do/ /

By the power of their wisdom, bodhisattvas determine the profound intended meaning of thatness, without any doubts, and gain perfect certainty—that is, having properly understood all the ultimate, expedient, explicit, and implied teachings, they become masters at discerning thatness. They can thus also clarify and completely dispel the doubts of those beings who are perplexed as to thatness and the meaning of the explicit and implied teachings. Because of their having that kind of wisdom, bodhisattvas themselves respect the buddhas’ teachings, and, by introducing other sentient beings to that wisdom, they cause them too to respect the buddhas’ teachings and thus bring them to maturity. By doing so, they make the virtuous qualities in their own and others’ mind streams flourish.
bdun pa/
vii. SUMMARY
de ltar byang chub sems dpa' snying rje yis/ / 'gro kun bde 'gro'i 'gro ba'ang dge gsum la/ / rnam pa chung dang mchog dang 'bring dag gis/ / 'jig rten yod dang mnyam par 'jug pas 'dul/ /
Thus bodhisattvas, through compassion, train all beings, Setting them in the higher realms or in the three virtues, In modest, supreme, and middling ways, For as long as the world exists. (IX, 22)
zhes pas bstan te/

de ltar byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi snying rje yis/ 'gro ba kun gyi don byed de/ 'gro ba rnams gnas skabs bde 'gro'i 'gro ba lha dang mi 'thob par byed pas smin par byed de/ gang zag rigs chad pa dag kyang byang chub sems dpa' dang 'phrad na dge bcu la bkod pas gnas skabs su bde 'gror smin par mdzad do/ / 'ang zhes pa tshig 'og ma dang sdud pa'i sgra'o/ / dge gsum la zhes pa gtan bde thar pa byang chub gsum gyi dge ba la 'god pa ste/ rigs can gsum so so rang rang gi lam la 'god pa'o/ / theg pa chen po la 'god tshul bye brag tu bshad pa ni/

Thus it is that bodhisattvas, through their compassion, work for the benefit of all beings. They bring beings to temporary maturity by causing them to obtain happy rebirth as celestial beings and humans. Even individuals without potential, when they encounter a bodhisattva, are introduced to the ten positive actions and thereby temporarily brought to maturity in the higher realms.[8] “In the three virtues” refers to bodhisattvas’ introducing beings to the virtue related to liberation, that is, lasting happiness in the three kinds of enlightenment: in other words, they set the three kinds of beings[9] on their respective paths. As to how they set beings in the Great Vehicle in particular,
zhes pas bstan te/

tshogs gnyis kyi rnam pa chung ngu mos spyod kyi sa la byed pa dang / mchog dag pa sa gsum du smin par byed pa dang / 'bring sa dang po nas bdun pa'i bar du smin par byed pa dag gis so/ / dus ji srid cig tu smin par byed ce na/ 'jig rten gyi mtha' ji tsam du yod pa de dang mnyam par 'jug pas 'dul lo zhes/ nam mkha'i khams ji tsam pa snyed du sems can gyis khyab/ nam mkha' dang sems can gyi khams ni phyi ma'i mtha'i bar du yod pa de srid dang mnyam par byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis sems can smin par byed pas 'dul te mthar thug pa med pa'o/ /

it is by bringing those with a modest accumulation of merit and wisdom to maturity on the path of earnest aspiration, by bringing those with the greatest accumulation to maturity on the three pure levels, and by bringing those with middling accumulation to maturity on the first to seventh levels. For how long do they bring beings to maturity? For as long as the world exists they will engage in doing so, and thereby train beings. All the space there is, is filled with sentient beings, and space and sentient beings exist until the end of time. That is how long bodhisattvas will train beings by bringing them to maturity—in other words, endlessly.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las yongs su smin pa'i le'u ste dgu pa'o// //
This completes the ninth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on full maturation.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ yongs su smin pa'i le'u ste dgu pa rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the ninth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on full maturation.

! smin pa dgu po de dag gtso cher mos spyod kyi sa'i dbang du byas par mngon yang spyir byang chub sems dpa'i sa dang dbang po smin pa mthar thug pa sa bcu'i rgyun mthar byang chub chen po thob pas na yongs smin gyi rjes su 'bras bu byang chub chen po bshad pa

Although the nine factors of maturation are mainly shown in relation to the level of earnest aspiration, in general, for a bodhisattva the ultimate point of the levels and of the maturation of faculties is the attainment of great enlightenment at the end of the tenth level. For this reason, the chapter on full maturation is followed by an explanation of the result, great enlightenment.
[bsam gyis mi khyab pa]
PART FOUR. THE INCONCEIVABLE, THAT WHICH IS BEYOND REFLECTION
[byang chub chen po]
10. ENLIGHTENMENT
['di] la/ 'thob bya mthar thug yin pa'i sgo nas mdor bstan/ de'i rang bzhin rgyas par bshad/ don bsdus te bla na med pa'i byang chub la dmigs nas sems bskyed par gdams pa gsum/

This chapter has three parts: (1) a brief introduction in terms of enlightenment being the ultimate attainment; (2) a detailed explanation of its nature; and (3) in summary, an instruction on arousing bodhicitta with unsurpassable enlightenment in mind.
dang po/
1. BRIEF INTRODUCTION IN TERMS OF ENLIGHTENMENT BEING THE ULTIMATE ATTAINMENT
de dag gi don bshad pa'i tshigs bcad bcas gsum gyis bstan te/
This brief exposition is indicated by two verses, with a third verse explaining their meaning.

dka' spyod dpag med brgya phrag dang / / dpag med dge ba bsags pa dang / / dpag tu med pa'i dus dang ni/ / dpag med sgrib pa zad pa'i phyir/ / sgrib pa kun gyi dri med pa/ / rnam pa thams cad mkhyen nyid 'thob/ / rin chen snod ni phye ba ltar/ / sangs rgyas nyid ni yang dag bstan/ /

Through their undergoing countless hundreds of austerities, Accumulating countless stores of virtue For countless lengths of time, And exhausting countless obscurations, (X, 1) Omniscience is attained, Free of all contaminating obscurations; As when a chest of jewels is opened, Buddhahood is perfectly revealed. (X, 2)
zhes tshigs bcad gnyis dang /

lus dang longs spyod gtong ba sogs phar phyin drug gis lam la 'bad pa'i dka' spyad dpag tu med pa gang zhig brgya phrag ces mang ba'i don can gyi tshig ste de 'dra'i dka' spyad nyan rang la med de/ mdo las sems can gyi don du ngas mig yongs su btang ba bsags na ri rab bas kyang mtho la/ khrag btang ba phyogs bzhi'i rgya mtsho las mang ngo zhes sogs gsungs pa dang / de bzhin du tshul khrims dang bzod pa sogs kyi sgo nas dka' spyad dpag med mdzad pa mdo rnams su 'byung ba bzhin no/ / phar phyin sa dang byang phyogs sogs kyi sgo nas tshod dpag tu med pa'i dge ba bsags pa dang / dpag tu med pa'i dus yun ring por brtson pa dang / dpag tu med pa'i sgrib pa zad pa'i phyir na/ sgrib pa kun gyi dri ma med pa shes bya'i rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes nyid 'thob pa rin chen sna tshogs bkang ba'i snod ni kha phye ba na rin chen sna tshogs dngos su snang ba ltar 'bras bu mthar thug gi sangs rgyas nyid ni yang dag par bstan to/ / de'i don bsdus na

There are countless “hundreds” (meaning a great many) of difficult practices and efforts that bodhisattvas make on the path with the six transcendent perfections—giving away their bodies and possessions and so forth. The listeners and solitary realizers have no such hardships. As we read in the sūtras, “The eyes that I have given away for the sake of sentient beings, all put together, would be higher than Mount Meru; the blood I’ve spilled is more copious than the oceans in the four directions….” And there are similar descriptions in the sūtras of the countless austerities they undertake with discipline, patience, and so on. By means of the transcendent perfections, levels, and elements leading to enlightenment, they accumulate countless positive actions. They exert themselves diligently over incalculable lengths of time. And they bring to exhaustion countless obscurations. Because of this, they attain the state of gnosis that knows all that is to be known, free of all contaminating obscurations. As when a casket full of all kinds of precious things is opened and the various jewels in it become visible, the ultimate fruit, buddhahood, is truly revealed. The meaning of these two verses is summarized as follows.
ngal brgyas rmad byung dka' spyad dge kun bsags/ / bskal mchog dus ring 'gro ba'i sgrib kun zad/ / sar gtogs sgrib pa phra bcom sangs rgyas te/ / de ni mthu chen rin chen snod phye bzhin/ /

With awesome austerities undertaken, many hundred trials endured, and every merit gathered, The longest kalpas traversed, all obscurations of a being brought to an end, And with the subtlest veils on the levels destroyed, buddhahood is gained, As if a chest of jewels with magical powers were opened. (X, 3)

gzhan gyis mi nus pa'i ngal ba brgyas te rnam grangs sna tshogs shin tu mang pos dka' ba spyad pa'i phyir dka' spyad dpag med do/ / sa dang byang phyogs phar phyin rnams nyi tshe ba grangs yod pa ma yin la nyan rang gi dge rtsa las 'das pa'i rmad du byung ba'i dge ba ma tshang ba med pa kun yongs su rdzogs par bsags pa'i phyir dge ba dpag med ces bya'o/ / dus dpag med ji ltar yin na bskal pa chung ngu bar bskal ma yin gyi bskal pa chen po dang de yang bskal chen gcig dang brgya la sogs pa ma yin gyi grangs med gsum gyi bar du bsgrub pas/ dus shin tu yun ring bas phal pa'i blos dpag tu med pa'o/ / sgrib pa dpag med ji ltar yin na 'gro ba kun gyi rgyud la yod pa'i phyir 'gro ba'i sgrib pa tshe rabs thog med nas nyon mongs pa dang shes bya'i sgrib pa dang rnam pa dmigs yul sogs kyi sgo nas phye na mtha' dang grangs dpag tu med pa zad pa'i phyir ro/ / sgrib pa kun gyi dri ma med pa'i tshul ni sa dang sa so so'i ngos skal gyi spang byar gtogs pa'i sgrib pa rnams sa bcu'i ye shes kyis rim par bcom nas shes bya'i sgrib pa phra mo ma rig bag chags kyang rdo rje lta bu'i ting 'dzin gyis bcom nas sangs rgyas pa ste / spang ba yongs su rdzogs pa dang / rtogs pa mthar thug de ni/ dgos 'dod rtsol ba'i mthu chen po ldan pa'i rin chen sna tshogs kyi snod kha phye ba ltar stobs dang mi 'jigs pa dang ma 'dres pa la sogs pa 'bras chos kyi yon tan mthar thug pa mngon du gyur pa'i phyir ro/ /

In that bodhisattvas have gone through hundreds of ordeals that no one else would be able to face, in immense numbers of different kinds, their austerities are countless. There is no putting a number to the levels, elements leading to enlightenment, and transcendent perfections, yet they have fully accumulated the whole entirety of wondrous virtuous practices that completely transcend the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ sources of good, and so their virtue is boundless. As for their having practiced over incalculable periods of time, it is not for a short, intermediate kalpa, nor for one great kalpa or even a hundred or so great kalpas, but for three measureless kalpas—a period of time so long that it cannot be fathomed by ordinary minds. In what way are the obscurations countless? Obscurations are present in the mind streams of all beings, so when the obscurations a being has had in all its lives since time without beginning are classified in terms of defilement-related obscurations, of cognitive obscurations, of the forms they take, and of their objects, the obscurations a bodhisattva has exhausted are limitless and countless. As to the way in which they are free of all contaminating obscurations, with the different kinds of gnosis of the ten levels they have successively destroyed the corresponding obscurations to be eliminated on each level. And having destroyed even the subtle cognitive obscurations (the habitual tendencies to ignorance) with the vajra-like concentration, they have attained buddhahood—the completion of elimination and the ultimate point of realization. As with the opening of a casket containing all kinds of precious things with the power to grant every need and wish, the ultimate qualities of the fruition—the strengths, fearlessnesses, distinctive qualities, and so forth—have become manifest.
gnyis pa byang chub chen po de'i rang bzhin
2. DETAILED EXPLANATION OF THE NATURE OF GREAT ENLIGHTENMENT
rgyas par bshad pa la/ yon tan gyi rnam grangs bcu yi sgo nas spyir bstan/ yon tan de ldan gyi byang chub nyid ngo bo rgyu 'bras sogs rnam bzhag rnam pa drug gis bshad pa gnyis/
The detailed explanation is divided into (1) a general exposition in terms of ten qualities and (2) a presentation of the great enlightenment that possesses those qualities under six headings.
dang po
a. A GENERAL EXPOSITION IN TERMS OF TEN QUALITIES

['di] la bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i yon tan dang / don gnyis phun tshogs kyi yon tan/ skyabs kyi dam par gyur pa'i yon tan/ gnas gyur pa'i yon tan/ kun tu khyab pa'i yon tan/ mdzad pa rtog med lhun gyis grub par 'jug pa'i yon tan/ zab mo dpag par dka' ba'i yon tan/ snying po 'gyur ba med pa'i yon tan/ 'byor pa tshad med pa'i yon tan/ sems can smin par byed pa'i yon tan dang bcu las dang po gnyis so sor bstan pa tshigs bcad re re dang / thun mong du bshad pa tshigs bcad gcig bcas tshigs su bcad pa gsum gyis bstan te/

The ten qualities are those of (1) inconceivability; (2) the fulfillment of the two goals; (3) enlightenment being the supreme refuge; (4) transformation; (5) all-pervasiveness; (6) the performance of deeds spontaneously and nonconceptually; (7) inestimable profundity; (8) its unchanging essence; (9) its boundless attainments; and (10) bringing sentient beings to maturity. The first two of the ten qualities are indicated separately with one verse each and then dealt with together in a third verse comprising a common explanation.
[bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i yon tan]
i. THE QUALITY OF INCONCEIVABILITY
chos rnams thams cad sangs rgyas nyid/ / chos ni gang yang yod ma yin/ / de ni chos dkar rang bzhin yang / / de yis de ni brjod ma yin/ /
All phenomena are the enlightened state; No phenomena whatsoever exist. Although it is the nature of positive qualities, It cannot be expressed in such terms. (X, 4)

zhes sangs rgyas ni gzung 'dzin gnyis med pa'am yod med gnyis su med pas bsam gyis mi khyab ste/ sangs rgyas pa'i tshe gzung 'dzin gnyis spangs pas dang / gzung 'dzin kun brtags kyi mtshan nyid du yod pa ma yin la yongs su grub pa'i mtshan nyid kyis yod pas yod med las 'das pa'o/ / de yang sangs rgyas zhes bya ba bdag gnyis dang bral ba'i de bzhin nyid glo bur gyi dri mas dag pa yin pas/ ye shes snang ba rgyan gyi mdo las/ rtag tu skye med chos ni de bzhin gshegs/ / chos rnams thams cad bde bar gshegs dang 'dra/ / zhes gsungs pa bzhin/ sangs rgyas chos kyi sku skye 'gags dang bral ba nyid do/ /

The enlightened state[1] does not exist dualistically as an apprehending subject or apprehended object, or as existent or nonexistent—it is inconceivable. For at the time of enlightenment, the dualism of an apprehending subject and apprehended object has been eliminated; and since it does not exist as an imputed, subject-object reality, while existing in terms of the fully present reality, it transcends existence and nonexistence. What we call “Buddha” is suchness free of the two kinds of self and unadulterated by adventitious contaminants. Hence we read in the Sūtra of the Ornament of the Light of Gnosis: Phenomena, forever nonarisen, are the Tathāgata; All phenomena are like the Sugata. In other words, the Buddha is the body of truth, the state devoid of arising and cessation.

de'i phyir rdo rje gcod pa las/ gang dag nga la gzugs su mthong / / gang dag nga la sgrar shes pa/ / log pa'i lam du zhugs pa ste/ / skye bo de dag nga mi mthong / / sangs rgyas de bzhin nyid du blta/ / 'dren pa rnams ni chos kyi sku/ / chos nyid shes par bya min pas/ / de dag rnam par rig mi 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs pa ltar/ de bzhin nyid kyi gnas lugs kyi dbang du byas nas gzhal na ji ltar snang ba'i chos thams cad kyang rang bzhin gyis sangs rgyas nyid de/ de bzhin nyid chos kyi dbyings las/ gzhan du gyur pa'i chos ni gang yang yod pa min pa'i phyir te/ gal te yod na chos thams cad rang bzhin med pa dang / skye ba med pa ma yin pa 'gyur bas so/ / yang na chos ni gang yang byis pa so so'i skye bos kun tu brtags pa ltar yod pa ma yin pa'i phyir ro zhes kyang rung ngo / /

And for this reason, the Diamond Cutter Sūtra states: Those who see me as a physical form, Who perceive me as sound, Have entered the wrong path. Such people are not seeing me. View the Buddha as suchness. The guides are the body of truth. The ultimate reality is not something that can be known, So these are not objects of knowledge. If we consider things from the point of view of the actual nature of suchness, all phenomena, however they appear, are also by nature the enlightened state, for there is no phenomenon whatsoever that is anything other than the expanse of reality, suchness. If there were, it would not be the case that all phenomena are devoid of intrinsic nature and are unproduced. Alternatively, we could also say that there are no phenomena whatsoever that exist in the way they are imputed by immature, ordinary beings.

sangs rgyas de ni sa dang phar phyin dang byang phyogs kyi chos kyis bsgrub pa las byung la/ sangs rgyas pa'i dus na'ang sa dang phar phyin byang phyogs kyi chos dang stobs dang mi 'jigs pa la sogs pa'i zag pa med pa'i chos dkar po kun gyi rang bzhin yin yang / phar phyin la sogs pa de dang de'i rnam par gnyis chos gzung 'dzin can kun brtags kyis dmigs pa'i spyod yul can de yis sangs rgyas de ni 'di lta bu yin no zhes brjod nus pa ma yin te/ dper na sbyin pa'i rang bzhin yin yang / gtong ba po sangs rgyas dang len pa po dang / gtong rgyu'i rdzas lta bur rnam pa gsum du dmigs pa lta bu'i gnyis chos kyi mtshan ma med pa'i phyir/ sangs rgyas ni kun brtags gnyis snang gi shes pas bsam pa'i yul ma yin no/ /

The enlightened state occurs through the accomplishment of the levels, transcendent perfections, and elements leading to enlightenment. And when enlightenment has been attained, its nature is that of all the untainted positive qualities—the levels, transcendent perfections, elements leading to enlightenment, strengths, fearlessnesses, and so forth. Nevertheless, it is not possible for a subject conceptualizing such things as the transcendent perfections by imputing them as this or that in dualistic terms of a subject and object to say, “The enlightened state is like this.” Even though the enlightened state is by nature generosity, for example, no dualistic attributes such as the three concepts of a buddha who gives, a recipient, and a gift are present. The enlightened state is not an object that can be conceived by a dualistic imputing consciousness.
[don gnyis phun tshogs kyi yon tan]
ii. THE QUALITY OF FULFILLMENT OF THE TWO GOALS
rin chen chos kyi rgyu mtshan phyir/ / de ni rin chen 'byung gnas bzhin/ / dge ba'i lo tog rgyu mtshan phyir/ / de ni sprin dang 'dra bar 'dod/ /
Because it is the cause of the jewel-like Dharma, It is like a mine of jewels. Because it is the cause of the crop of virtue, It is likened to a cloud. (X, 5)

de ltar sangs rgyas ni gnyis su med pa'i mtshan nyid kyis bsam gyis mi khyab pa yin la/ de'i mthu ni don gnyis phun tshogs lhun gyis grub pa ste/ ji ltar zhe na sangs rgyas de ni lung gi chos bshad pa dang / rtogs pa'i chos stobs bcu mi 'jigs bzhi sogs rin chen dpag tu med pa'i rgyu dang rkyen byed pa'i rgyu mtshan yin pa'i phyir/ sangs rgyas de ni dper na rin chen sna tshogs kyi 'byung gnas sam 'byung khungs bzhin du gyur pa ni bdag gi don phun sum tshogs pa thob pa'o/ / 'gro ba thams cad kyi dge ba'i lo tog smin par byed pa'i rgyu mtshan gyi phyir/ sangs rgyas de ni sprin dang 'dra bar 'dod de gzhan don phun sum tshogs pa'i mthu mnga' ba'o/ / gong gi tshigs bcad gnyis po'i don bshad pa/

As we have seen, the enlightened state, on account of its nondual nature, is inconceivable. And yet its power is the spontaneous fulfillment of the two goals. How is that? The enlightened state is the causal factor that creates the causes and conditions for the boundless jewels of the Dharma of transmission that is expounded and of the Dharma of realization that comprises the ten strengths, the four fearlessnesses, and all the other qualities. Like a source or mine of all kinds of precious substances, the Buddha has attained the fulfillment of his own goal. And because the enlightened state is the causal factor that ripens the crop of virtue in all beings, the Buddha, who is held to be like a cloud, has the power to fulfill others’ goals. There now follows an explanation of the above two verses:

sangs rgyas nyid ni chos kun ldan pa'am yang na chos kun bral ba ste/ / rin chen chos rab che yangs 'byung phyir rin chen chos kyi 'byung gnas bzhin/ / skye dgu rnams la legs bshad mi zad chos kyi char chen 'bebs pas na/ / 'byung po'i lo tog dkar po shin tu che 'phel rgyu phyir sprin dang 'dra/ /

The buddha state possesses all phenomena, or alternatively is devoid of all phenomena: Because it gives rise to the extensive and vast jewel-like Dharma, it is like a mine of precious things; Because it showers on beings the great rain of the well-explained, inexhaustible Dharma, Thus causing living creatures’ crop of virtue to flourish, it is like a cloud. (X, 6)

sangs rgyas nyid ni shes bya'i chos kun dang ldan pa'am yang na chos kun dang bral ba ste/ chos thams cad chos nyid de bzhin nyid las tha dad ma yin pas chos kun dang ldan par 'gyur te ji snyed pa'i ngos nas gzhal ba'o/ / yang ji lta ba'i ngos nas gzhal na chos kun dang bral ba ste/ de bzhin nyid la gzung 'dzin dang gnyis chos kyi mtshan ma gang yang med pas so/ / de ltar gnyis su med pa'i sangs rgyas de ni rin po che lta bu'i theg chen kyi lung gi chos rab tu rgya che zhing / rtogs pa'i chos sa dang phar phyin stobs dang mi 'jigs pa sogs yangs pa tshad med pa 'byung phyir rin po che'i chos kyi 'byung gnas sam 'byung khungs bzhin no/ / skye dgu rnams la thog mtha' bar du dge ba'i legs par bshad pa gang zhig de yi don lan gcig rtogs na 'khor ba'i mtha'i bar du mi zad pa'am yang na chos kyi rnam grangs kyi mtha' mi zad pa'i chos kyi char chen po 'bebs pas na/ skye dgu'am 'byung po'i tshogs kyi lo tog lta bu dkar po zag med phar phyin gyi dge ba'i sa bon rnams shin tu rgya che bar 'phel ba'i rgyu yin pa'i phyir sprin dang 'dra'o/ /

The enlightened state possesses all dharmas that are to be known or, there again, is devoid of all phenomena. Since all phenomena are no different from the ultimate reality, suchness, it is endowed with all phenomena—this being considered from the point of view of the multiplicity of phenomena. Alternatively, from the point of view of the nature of phenomena, it is devoid of all phenomena, for suchness has none of the attributes of dualistic subject-object phenomena. Because this enlightened state beyond duality gives rise to the jewel-like Dharma—the extensive Dharma of transmission of the Great Vehicle and the immeasurably vast Dharma of realization comprising the levels, transcendent perfections, strengths, fearlessnesses, and the rest—it is like a source or mine of precious things. By showering down on all beings the great rain of Dharma (which is well explained in that it is virtuous in the beginning, middle, and end, and inexhaustible in that if its meaning is realized once, it is never exhausted until the end of saṃsāra, or alternatively, in that there is no end to the number of its topics), it causes the seeds of untainted transcendent virtue to grow like a crop, on a vast scale, in hosts of living creatures. For this reason, it is like a cloud.
gsum pa skyabs kyi dam par gyur pa'i yon tan
iii. THE QUALITY OF BEING THE SUPREME REFUGE
['di] la/ bdag gi don grub pa dang / gzhan gyi don sgrub pa dang / de gnyis kyi phyir skyabs dpe med par bsgrub pa gsum/

This section is divided into three parts: (1) the accomplishment of one’s own goal; (2) the accomplishment of others’ goals; and (3) establishing the enlightened state as the incomparable refuge on account of its twofold accomplishment.
dang po/
(1) THE ACCOMPLISHMENT OF ONE’S OWN GOAL
rtag tu nyon mongs tshogs kun dang / / nyes par spyod pa thams cad dang / / rga dang 'chi ba dag las kyang / / sangs rgyas nyid ni yongs su skyob/ /
Constantly, against the whole host of defilements, Against all kinds of negative actions, And even aging and death, The enlightened state gives complete protection. (X, 7)
ces pas bstan te/

sangs rgyas la skyabs su song na dus res 'ga' ba'i skyabs min par rtag tu ma rig pa dang sred pa sogs nyon mongs pa'i tshogs kun dang / mi dge bcu dang mtshams med pa lnga sogs zag bcas kyi las nyes pa spyod pa thams cad dang / rga ba dang 'chi ba dag las kyang sangs rgyas nyid ni yongs su skyob par mdzad de/ sangs rgyas na nyon mongs pa dang las dang tshe'am skye ba'i kun nyon gsum po gtan du mi 'byung bas na de la skyabs su 'gro ba po de nam zhig 'bras bu'i skyabs su gyur pa thob pa na bdag gi don yongs su rdzogs pas bdag gi skyabs su 'gyur ba bstan te/ 'jig rten pa 'jigs pas nyen pa dag ri dang thug pa sogs su bros te skyabs 'tshol ba dang / 'jig rten gyi rgyal po dang / 'jig rten pa'i lha phra mo rnams dang / tshangs pa dang dbang phyug sogs la skyabs su 'gro bas de ltar skyabs mi nus so/ /

When one has gone for refuge in the Buddha, that enlightened state gives one complete protection from all kinds of defilements such as ignorance and craving, from all negative activities, tainted actions such as the ten negative actions and the five crimes with immediate retribution, and even from aging and death. This is not for a short period or from time to time, but all the time. In the enlightened state, the three components of the defilement aspect—defilements, karmic actions, and life or rebirth—never occur, so when beings who take refuge in the Buddha attain the resultant refuge, they fulfill their own goals and thus become their own refuge. Mundane beings who, stricken by fear, flee to the mountains, to caves and similar places and seek refuge there, or turn for protection to worldly monarchs, minor mundane gods, Brahmā, Īśvara, and the like, cannot enjoy the same sort of protection.
gnyis pa/
(2) THE ACCOMPLISHMENT OF OTHERS’ GOALS
'tshe ba dag ni thams cad dang / / ngan song dang ni thabs min dang / / 'jig tshogs theg pa dman dag las/ / de phyir skyabs kyi dam pa'o/ /
Because it protects from every kind of trouble, From the lower realms, from wrong paths, From the view of the transitory composite, and from lesser vehicles, It is the supreme refuge. (X, 8)
zhes pas bstan te/

sangs rgyas na sems can gzhan rnams la yang skyabs rnam lnga byed de/ 'jig rten na 'tshe ba dag ni ci yod pa thams cad las skyob pa dang / zhes pa/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i byin rlabs las long bas mig rnyed pa dang 'on pas sgra thos/ smyon pas dran pa rnyed/ nad sna tshogs lo nyes sogs sangs rgyas grong du gshegs pa tsam gyis zhi ba dang / gang gis gsol ba btab na yang nyes pa thams cad zhi bar byed pa'o/ / yang de bzhin gshegs pas 'od zer btang bas dmyal ba sogs ngan song ba rnams la reg pa'i mod la de dag gi sdug bsngal thams cad zhi bar byas te mtho ris su skye bar byed pa dang / dmyal ba sogs su sangs rgyas dran pa'am mtshan thos pas kyang de las thar ba dang ni/ yang mu stegs can sogs thar pa'i thabs min pa dka' thub dang brtul zhugs ngan pa la zhugs pa rnams lam de las bslang ste/ mtho ris thar lam la 'jog par mdzad pa dang / yang bdag dang bdag gir lta ba'i 'jig tshogs la lta ba can rnams la gang zag gi bdag med pa bstan nas nyan rang gi myang 'das la 'god pa'i sgo nas skyob pa dang / ma nges pa'i rigs can nyan rang gi lam la zhugs pa'am 'jug par 'dod pa rnams theg pa chen po la gzud pas theg pa dman pa dag las skyob pa de phyir sangs rgyas ni gzhan rnams kyi skyabs kyi dam pa'o/ /

In the enlightened state, there are five ways in which other beings too are protected: (1) The Buddha gives protection from every kind of worldly trouble. Through the blessings of the Tathāgata, the blind can see, the deaf can hear, the insane regain their senses, and all kinds of sickness, failed harvests, and other such blights are removed simply by the Buddha visiting a village. And even praying to him removes all kinds of evil. (2) Furthermore, the minute the rays of light emitted by the Tathāgata touch the inhabitants of the hells and other lower realms, all their sufferings are appeased and they are reborn in the higher realms. And even thinking of the Buddha or hearing his name in the hells brings liberation from those realms. (3) With regard to tīrthikas and others who are engaged in improper austerities and disciplines[2] that are not the means for gaining liberation, the Buddha draws them away from those paths and sets them on the path to the higher realms and liberation. (4) Again, he protects those who hold the view of the transitory composite, the view of “I” and “mine,” by teaching them the individual no-self and setting them in the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ nirvāṇa. (5) And by introducing the Great Vehicle to beings of unfixed potential who have begun following the listeners’ or solitary realizers’ paths, or wish to do so, he gives protection from lesser vehicles. For all these reasons, the Buddha is the supreme refuge of other beings.
gsum pa
(3) ESTABLISHING THE ENLIGHTENED STATE AS THE INCOMPARABLE REFUGE, ON ACCOUNT OF ITS TWOFOLD ACCOMPLISHMENT
['di] la dngos dang skyabs mchog yin pa dang / skyabs chen po yin pa gsum tshigs bcad re res bstan te/
The next three verses each address one of the following three topics: the main presentation, the fact that the enlightened state is the supreme refuge, and the fact that it is the great refuge.

sangs rgyas nyid de skyabs ni dpe med mchog tu 'dod/ / sna tshogs 'jigs gyur 'jig tshogs kun dang theg pa dang / / ngan song rnam mang sdug bsngal thabs min song ba rnams/ / skye dang 'chi dang nyon mongs ngan song kun las srung / /

The enlightened state is the supreme, incomparable refuge. For those who are subject to different kinds of danger, to the transitory composite and all other wrong views, to vehicles, To the sufferings of the many forms of lower rebirth, and to ways that are not the proper means, It gives protection from birth and death, and from all defilements and deeds. (X, 9)
zhes pas bstan te/

gong du bshad pa'i don bsdus nas sangs rgyas nyid 'jig rten pa'i skyabs gnas rnams dang / nyan rang rnams zhi ba phyogs gcig pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa la skyabs su 'gro ba 'jig rten 'das pa'i skyabs gnas de bas kyang sangs rgyas nyid de ni de 'dra'i skyabs kyi dpe gzhan med pa skyabs kun gyi mchog tu 'dod de/ rgyu mtshan ci'i phyir na/ sangs rgyas des 'khor ba 'dir sna tshogs pa'i 'jigs par gyur pa nye bar 'tshe ba thams cad dang / 'jig tshogs la lta ba sogs lta ba ngan pa sna tshogs dang / theg pa dman pa dang / ngan song gi 'gro ba rnam pa mang po dag gi sdug bsngal dang / thar pa'i thabs min par zhugs pa'am song ba rnams skye dang 'chi dang de'i rgyu nyon mongs dang las rnams kun las gtan du srung ba'i skyabs su gyur pa'i phyir ro/ / dpe la lar las kyi tshab tu ngan song zhes 'byung ba ltar na ngan song du skye 'gyur mtshams med pa dang mi dge bcu'i las sogs las kyi kun nas nyon mongs par go bar bya dgos so/ /

To summarize the points presented above, the enlightened state cannot be compared to other refuges: it is held to be supreme among all refuges, superior to mundane refuges and superior even to the refuge of supramundane beings who go for refuge in the partial nirvāṇa that is the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ state of peace. What is the reason for this? The enlightened state is a refuge for those who are subject to all the various fearful afflictions here in saṃsāra, to the different wrong views such as the view of the transitory composite, to involvement in the lesser vehicles, to the sufferings of the many forms of rebirth in the lower realms, and to involvement in ways that give no means of liberation. It protects them forever from birth and death and from all the defilements and karmic actions that are their causes. In some editions of the root text, “lower realms” appears instead of “deeds.” This should be understood as referring to the defiling deeds that lead to rebirth in the lower realms—deeds such as the crimes with immediate retribution and the ten negative actions.

sangs rgyas chos kyi shin tu rdzogs pa'i sku gang yin/ / dam pa'i chos la sems can rab 'dul mkhyen pa gang / / 'gro ba kun la thugs brtse'i pha rol phyin pa gang / / sangs rgyas nyid de 'dir ni skyabs kyi mchog tu 'dod/ /

It comprises the buddha bodies in which the enlightened qualities are fully complete, The knowledge for training beings through the sacred Dharma, And transcendent compassion for all beings— That enlightened state is held to be the supreme refuge here. (X, 10)
ces pas bstan te/

skyabs mchog yin pa'i rgyu mtshan ni/ bdag don dang gzhan don mthar thug pa yin pa'i phyir te 'di ltar sangs rgyas pa'i dus na stobs sogs 'bras bu'i chos rnams kyi yon tan shin tu rdzogs pa'i sku gsum po gang yin pa bdag gi don mthar thug pa dang / gzhan don du dam pa'i chos mdo sde sogs yan lag bcu gnyis la sems can rnams 'dzud cing thabs des de dag rab tu 'dul ba ni khams dbang bsam pa dang mthun par bstan pas rgyud grol bar mdzad nus pa'i mkhyen pa thogs pa med pa ni shes rab bo/ / 'gro ba kun nam yang mi gtong ba'i thugs brtse ba'i pha rol tu phyin pa gang yin pa ni snying rje chen po'o/ / de gnyis las gzhan don mthar thug pa mdzad pa yin no/ / don gnyis mthar thug gi yon tan mnga' ba de'i phyir sangs rgyas nyid ni srid pa 'dir skyabs kyi mchog tu 'dod do/ /

The reason it is the supreme refuge is that it is the consummation of one’s own goal and others’ goals. When enlightenment is attained, the three buddha bodies, in which the strengths and all the other qualities of fruition are fully complete, represent the ultimate fulfillment of one’s own goal. As for others’ goals, their ultimate fulfillment is achieved both through wisdom and through great compassion. Wisdom refers to the unobstructed knowledge and ability to introduce beings to the sacred Dharma—the sūtras and the other eleven branches of the teachings—and by that means to thoroughly train them, liberating their mind streams by teaching them in accordance with their dispositions, faculties, and aspirations. Great compassion is transcendent, unremitting love and compassion for all beings. It is because it possesses the qualities of the consummation of the two goals that the enlightened state is held to be the supreme refuge here in existence.
'jig rten ji srid sems can gyi/ / gnod dang phun sum tshogs pa kun/ / bzlog cing 'byor par bya ba'i phyir/ / sangs rgyas skyabs chen nyid du 'dod/ /
Because, to the very end of the universe, It wards off sentient beings’ every difficulty And brings them all that is perfect, The enlightened state is held to be the great refuge. (X, 11)
ces pas bstan te/

skyabs chen po yin pa ni/ phyogs dang dus kyis bsdus pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams ji srid du sems can thams cad kyi gnod pa mtha' dag bzlog cing gtan du zhi ba dang / 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i phun sum tshogs pa kun 'byor bar bya ba'i mthu mnga' ba'i phyir/ sangs rgyas ni skyabs chen po nyid du 'dod do/ /

It is the great refuge because, for as far as the universe extends, for as long as the universe endures, it has the power to drive away and cure forever every one of the problems that afflict all beings and to make them acquire all that is perfect, both mundane and supramundane. This is why the enlightened state is asserted to be the great refuge.
bzhi pa gnas gyur pa'i yon tan
iv. THE QUALITY OF TRANSFORMATION
['di] la/ gnas gyur pa nyid bshad pa dang / de khyad par 'phags tshul bstan pa gnyis/
This section is divided into (1) an explanation of transformation itself and (2) an explanation of its superiority.
dang po/
(1) AN EXPLANATION OF TRANSFORMATION ITSELF

gang la nyon mongs shes bya'i sgrib pa'i sa bon dus ring rtag ldan pa/ / spong ba shin tu rgya chen rnam pa kun gyi rab tu bcom gyur cing / / gnas gyur chos dkar yon tan mchog rab ldan pa thob pa sangs rgyas nyid/ / de ni mi rtog rab dag shin tu yul chen ye shes lam gyis 'thob/ /

The complete destruction of the seeds of defilement-related and cognitive obscurations, constantly present for great lengths of time, Eliminated through all kinds of extensive means, And the attainment of the transformed state possessed of the sublime qualities of virtue Is buddhahood, attained by the path of the gnosis of utterly pure nonconceptuality and immense scope. (X, 12)
ces pas bstan te/

shes pa'i rgyud gang la nyon mongs pa dang shes bya'i sgrib pa'i bag chags sam sa bon gang zhig dus yun ring po 'khor ba'i thog ma med pa nas 'bral ma myong bar rtag tu rgyun chags par ldan pa nyid/ spong ba las sa dang po nas bcu pa la thug gi bar du 'jig rten las 'das pa'i ye shes dam pa tshogs gnyis rlabs che ba'i rgyu las byung zhing rnam par mi rtog pa nam mkha' mnyam pa shin tu rgya chen por gyur pa gang zhig sa re re la yang ye shes chen po'i chen po sogs dgu re yod pas rnam pa kun gyi rang bzhin dang ldan pa'am/ de lta bu'i rnam pa kun gyis rab tu bcom pa'am spangs par gyur cing / yul phung po lnga chos kyi dbyings shin tu rnam dag gi rang bzhin dang yul can shes pa rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyi rang bzhin du gnas gyur pa'am/ yang na chos rnams kyi stong pa de bzhin nyid rnam par dag pa chos kyi dbyings dang / tshogs brgyad ye shes bzhir gnas gyur pa ste lnga po de la gnas gyur pa zhes bya la/

The habitual tendencies or seeds of the defilement-related and cognitive obscurations have been continuously and inseparably present in one’s stream of consciousness for a great length of time—since the beginning of saṃsāra, to which there is no beginning. With regard to eliminating these, from the first level up to the tenth level, they are completely destroyed or eliminated by the supreme supramundane gnosis. This gnosis is the result of an immense accumulation of merit and wisdom and is as utterly vast as space in its absence of concepts. And it is through having all kinds of aspects—or, alternatively, by means of all its different kinds—that it destroys those seeds, for on each level there are nine kinds of gnosis (greater-great, and so forth).[3] The object (namely, the five aggregates) is transformed into the utterly pure expanse of reality and the subject (consciousness) into nonconceptual gnosis. Alternatively, the empty nature of all phenomena is transformed into the utterly pure expanse of reality, suchness; and the eight consciousnesses into the four kinds of gnosis. These five processes constitute what we call “transformation.”

mdor na gnas su snang ba snod dang / don du snang ba rnam shes tshogs brgyad dang lus su snang ba dang bcas pa'i ma dag pa'i snang ba thams cad ye nas rang bzhin gyis de kho na nyid du gnas mod kyi/ sgrib pa gnyis kyis bsgribs nas de'i rang bzhin ji lta ba bzhin ma mthong ba lam gyis spangs te/ rnam par dag pas khyad par du byas pa'i snang ba rab 'byams mu med pa ni gnas gyur pa zhes bya ste/ ji lta ba nyid kyi dbang du byas na gzung 'dzin gnyis chos med par mnyam pa nyid las ma g.yos bzhin du/ ji snyed pa'i dbang du byas nas shes bya thams cad sgyu ma'i snang ba ltar ma 'dres par snang yang ris chad kyi mtshan ma med pa mnyam pa'o/ /

In short, although all impure appearances—the outer world that appears as the place, the eight consciousnesses that appear as the subject, and what appears as the body—naturally exist as thatness from the very beginning, we fail to see their intrinsic nature as it is, for it has been veiled by the two obscurations. This failure is eliminated with the path, the “transformation” of the boundless, infinite appearances, distinguished by their perfect purity. Although, from the point of view of the nature of phenomena, they are free of subject-object duality and have never moved from the state of evenness, while from the point of view of the multiplicity of phenomena, all things that can be known appear distinctly like the appearances in a magical illusion, they are the same, devoid of one-sided attributes.

de ltar gnas gyur pa de ni zag pa med pa'i chos dkar gyi yon tan stobs dang mi 'jigs pa sogs nyan rang la med pas mchog rab tu gyur pa ldan pa thob pa de ni sangs rgyas zhes bya'i ngo bo nyid de ni byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi mnyam bzhag tu rnam par mi rtog pa rab tu dag pa'am shin tu dag pas chos thams cad nam mkha'i ngos ltar dmigs pa med par rtogs pa dang / rjes thob tu shes bya mtha' yas pa snang yang sgyu ma la sogs pa bzhin du mthong ba'i shin tu yul chen po'i ye shes zhes sam dag pa 'jig rten pa'i ye shes de gnyis bsgom pa'i lam gyis thob pa yin no/ / sangs rgyas pa'i dus na mnyam rjes tha dad du med de rang byung ngam bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i ye shes chen pos ji lta ji snyed kyi chos thams cad dus gcig tu gzigs pa yin no/ /

One who has attained this transformation, which is endowed with the sublime, untainted virtuous qualities such as the strengths and fearlessnesses (“sublime” because they are qualities the listeners and solitary realizers do not have), is known as a buddha, whose very nature is attained by the path, training in two kinds of gnosis. These are the realization, by means of the utterly pure[4] nonconceptuality in the bodhisattvas’ meditative equipoise, that all phenomena are devoid of reference, like the “surface” of the sky; and the so-called “gnosis of immense scope”[5] or pure mundane gnosis in the postmeditational phase, which sees that although the infinite knowable phenomena appear, they are like magical illusions and so forth. At the time of enlightenment, there is no difference between meditation and postmeditation, and by means of the great spontaneous or inconceivable gnosis, all phenomena are beheld simultaneously as they are and in their multiplicity.
gnyis pa
(2) AN EXPLANATION OF ITS SUPERIORITY
['di] la sangs rgyas kyi gnas gyur de nyan rang gi gnas gyur las khyad par 'phags tshul dang / de'i rab dbye bcu bshad pa gnyis/

This explanation has two parts: (1) how the Buddha’s transformation is superior to the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ transformation and (2) ten divisions of the qualities of the Buddha’s transformation.
dang po/
(a) HOW THE BUDDHA’S TRANSFORMATION IS SUPERIOR TO THE LISTENERS’ AND SOLITARY REALIZERS’ TRANSFORMATION
de bzhin gshegs pa de ni der bzhugs nas/ / ri dbang mtho steng bzhugs bzhin 'gro la gzigs/ / zhi bar mngon dga'i 'gro la'ang thugs rje na/ / srid la mngon dga'i skye bo gzhan ci smos/ /

Dwelling in that state, the Tathāgata, As if seated on the lofty king of mountains, watches over beings. If he has compassion even for those who delight in peace, Need one mention his compassion for other beings who delight in existence? (X, 13)
zhes pas bstan te/

chos kyi dbyings ji ltar gnas pa de bzhin du thugs su chud pa'am gshegs pas de bzhin gshegs pa sangs rgyas de ni gnas gyur pa zag med kyi dbyings der bzhugs nas/ dper na ri yi dbang po ri'i rgyal po ri rab kun nas mtho ba de'i steng nas phyogs bcur bltas na/ nye ba dang ring ba'i gzugs bzang ngan kun mthong ba ltar/ de bzhin gshegs pa de ni nyan rang gi gnas gyur las 'phags shing mtho ba sangs rgyas kyi gnas yongs su gyur pa ri dbang mtho ba yi steng na bzhugs bzhin du 'gro ba kun la thugs chen pos gzigs par mdzad de/ bdag don myang 'das zhi ba mngon par dga' ba'i 'gro ba nyan rang la'ang thugs rje'am snying rje chen po mdzad de/ nyan rang de dag 'khor ba thog ma med pa nas gnyen du gyur pa'i sems can gyi don ma byas par snying rje chen po spangs pa dang / chos la bdag med rtogs pa'i shes rab chen po bral bas shes bya'i sgrib pa spangs ma nus pas rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes ma thob pa'i phyir de dag la yang thugs snying rje bar mdzad na/ sdug bsngal gyi gnas srid pa la mngon par dga' ba'i skye bo gzhan 'khor ba pa rnams la thugs brtse ba lta ci smos te de dag sdug bsngal gsum las ma thar pa'i phyir ro/ /

Abiding in that untainted expanse that is the state of transformation, the Buddha, the One Who Has Gone to Suchness[6] (for he has arrived at or realized that “such” is the nature of the expanse of reality), is like someone who looks in the ten directions from the top of Mount Meru, the highest of all mountains, and can see all forms, near and far, good and bad. For in the same way, the Tathāgata, seated atop the lofty peak that is the Buddha’s state of complete transformation, far above the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ transformation, watches over all beings with his great compassion. His great compassion extends even to the listeners and solitary realizers, those who delight in the peace of nirvāṇa for their own sake. In not working for the welfare of sentient beings, with whom they have been related since time without beginning in saṃsāra, the listeners and solitary realizers lack great compassion, and since they do not have the great wisdom that has realized the no-self of phenomena, they are unable to get rid of cognitive obscurations and have therefore not acquired omniscient gnosis. This is why the Buddha has compassion even for them. This being so, one need hardly mention his love and compassion for other beings in saṃsāra who delight in existence, the abode of suffering, for they are not free from the three kinds of suffering.
gnyis pa sangs rgyas kyi gnas gyur pa'i yon tan gyi rnam grangs dbye ba ni/
(b) TEN DIVISIONS OF THE QUALITIES OF THE BUDDHA’S TRANSFORMATION
gnas la 'jug dang rab 'jug mi 'jug dang / / ldog dang kun 'jug gnyis dang mi gnyis dang / / mnyam dang khyad 'phags kun 'gro'i bdag nyid ni/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi yongs gyur 'dod/ /

In that state, there is engagement, perfect engagement, nonengagement, Disengagement, perpetual engagement, dual and nondual engagement, Similarity, superiority, and universality. This is held to be the fully transformed state of the tathāgatas. (X, 14)
ces pas bstan te/

gnas la zhes pa sangs rgyas kyi gnas yongs su gyur pa de la khyad par 'phags pa'i yon tan yod de gang zhe na rtag tu sems can gyi don 'ba' zhig mdzad pas gzhan don la 'jug pa dang / gnas gyur de 'jig rten pa dang 'jig rten 'das pa nyan rang gi gnas gyur sogs chos thams cad kyi mchog yin pas rab tu 'jug pa dang / so so'i skye bo rnams la nyon mongs skye ba'i rgyu ni/ yul ni nye bar gnas pa dang / tshul bzhin min pa yid byed dang / nyon mongs pa'i bag nyal ma spangs pa gsum yin la/ sangs rgyas kyi gnas gyur ni nam yang nyon mongs skye ba'i rgyu la mi 'jug pa dang / gnas gyur pa de thob nas nam yang nyon mongs pa rnams dang mi dge ba'i spyod pa rnams la bdag nyid 'jug mi srid pas de las ldog pa dang / gnas gyur pa de dus lan gcig na thob pa de 'khor ba'i mtha'i bar du nyams pa mi srid pa dus kun tu chad pa med par 'jug pas kun 'jug dang / yang na kun nas nyon mongs pa'i gnyen po'i chos kun la 'jug pas kun 'jug zhes kyang ngo / /

“In that state,” meaning in the Buddha’s state of complete transformation, there are the following extraordinary qualities: (1) Engagement in others’ welfare, in always acting exclusively for the benefit of sentient beings. (2) Perfect engagement, in that the Buddha’s transformation is the greatest of all qualities, greater than the transformation of worldly beings and supramundane beings—that is, listeners and solitary realizers. (3) Nonengagement, in that the Buddha’s transformation never engages in the three causal factors that, in ordinary beings, give rise to defilements: the presence of the related object,[7] thinking of it incorrectly, and not having eliminated latent defilements. (4) Disengagement, in that once that transformation is attained, it is impossible to ever engage in defilements and nonvirtuous activities. (5) Perpetual engagement, for that transformation is attained once and for all and is applied all the time, unceasingly, it being impossible for it to diminish until the end of saṃsāra. Alternatively, total engagement, in that all the antidotes to the defilement process are applied.[8]

yang gnyis dang zhes pa thog mar mngon par byang chub pa ston pa dang mthar mya ngan las 'das par ston pa gnyis la 'jug pa ste/ sangs rgyas nas phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten kun tu sangs rgyas kyi mchog gi sprul skus 'dul ba la byang chub chen po'i tshul dus kun tu ston pa'i phyir ro/ /

(6) Dual engagement, in that the Buddha first displays enlightenment and finally displays the parinirvāṇa. Having attained buddhahood, in all the world systems in the ten directions, at all times, by means of supreme nirmāṇakāya manifestations, the Buddha displays great enlightenment in order to train beings.

don dam par de gnyis su 'jug pa med de 'khor ba dang mya ngan las 'das pa gnyis ka mnyam pa nyid du rtogs pas mi gnyis par 'dug pa dang / yang nyon mongs sa bon dang bcas pa spangs pa'i rnam grol tsam gyi cha nas nyan rang dang cha 'dra ba'am mnyam pa dang / bye brag tu sangs rgyas kyi gnas gyur ni shes bya'i sgrib pa spangs pa dang / stobs dang mi 'jigs pa la sogs pa'i yon tan gyis nyan rang las khyad par 'phags pa dang / kun tu 'gro ba ni sems can rnams la rang rang so so'i rigs dang dbang po mos pa dang 'tshams par theg pa gsum gyi chos ston pas theg pa kun 'gro'i bdag nyid de/

(7) Nondual engagement, in that on the ultimate level the Buddha does not engage in the two—that is, since he has realized that saṃsāra and nirvāṇa are the same, he remains in neither. (8) Similarity, in that simply from the point of view of complete liberation, of having eliminated the defilements together with their seeds, the Buddha is like or similar to the listeners and solitary realizers. (9) Superiority, in that specifically the Buddha’s transformation is superior to that of the listeners and solitary realizers on account of the elimination of cognitive obscurations and of his qualities such as the strengths and fearlessnesses. (10) Universality, in that it applies to all vehicles, for the Buddha teaches sentient beings the Dharma of the three vehicles in accordance with their individual potentials, faculties, and aspirations.

de ltar rnam grangs bcu yi tshul bshad pa 'di lta bu ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi gnas yongs su gyur pa yin par 'dod do/ / de'i phyir sangs rgyas kyi gnas gyur de ni yon tan rab dang ldan pa dang / gnyen po'i chos thams cad la 'jug pas rgya cher 'jug par rig par bya'o/ /

That which is described in terms of these ten categories is held to be the tathāgatas’ state of complete transformation. For this reason, it should be understood that the Buddha’s state of transformation is endowed with the highest qualities and is applied on a vast scale, for it acts as every kind of remedy.
lnga pa kun tu khyab pa'i yon tan
v. THE QUALITY OF ALL-PERVASIVENESS
['di] la dngos dang dogs spong gnyis/
This section is divided into (1) the main explanation and (2) clarification of a doubt.
dang po dus dang phyogs kyi dngos po kun la khyab pa'i tshul ni/
(1) THE MAIN EXPLANATION OF HOW THE ENLIGHTENED STATE PERVADES ALL ENTITIES OF TIME AND SPACE
ji ltar nam mkha' rtag tu kun song 'dod/ / de bzhin de yang rtag tu kun song 'dod/ / ji ltar nam mkha' gzugs gyur kun tu song / / de bzhin de yang sems can tshogs kun song / /

Just as space is accepted as being forever omnipresent, So too is enlightenment considered always omnipresent. Just as space is present in every kind of form, So too is enlightenment omnipresent in the host of sentient beings. (X, 15)
zhes pas bstan te/

ji ltar nam mkha' ni dus gsum po rtag tu bum sogs dngos po kun la rjes su song bar 'dod pa de bzhin du/ chos kyi dbyings zag pa med pa sangs rgyas kyi gnas gyur pa de yang 'das ma 'ongs da lta'i dus rtag tu de dang de'i dus kyi dngos po kun la rjes su song bar 'dod de/ dus gsum gyis bsdus pa'i chos thams cad kyang de bzhin nyid las mi 'da' zhing dbyings de rang bzhin rnam dag yin pas sangs rgyas pa'i dus dang sngar gyi gnas skabs la ngo bo'i sgo nas khyad med pas so/ / ji ltar nam mkha' ni gzugs su gyur pa ring thung dkar dmar bzang ngan bar ma thams cad la khyad med par khyab cing kun tu song ba de bzhin sangs rgyas kyi dbyings de yang sems can bzang ngan bar ma'i tshogs kun gyi rgyud la khyab cing de'i chos nyid kyi rang bzhin du rjes su song ba yin te/ sangs rgyas ni chos kyi dbyings glo bur ba'i dri mas shin tu rnam par dag pa'i rang bzhin yin la/ / sa dang po chos dbyings kun tu 'gro ba'i mtshan nyid rtogs pa'i dus na bdag dang sems can thams cad la sems mnyam pa nyid thob ste/ bdag gang yin pa sems can yang de yin la/ sems can gang yin pa bdag kyang de yin pas khyad med par mnyam pa nyid khong du chud pa de sa bcur rim gyis bsgom pa rdzogs pa sangs rgyas kyi sa thob pa'i dus na sems can thams zhi cad bdag nyid du mngon par rdzogs par byang chub pa'i rang bzhin du thugs su chud pa yongs su rdzogs pa yin pas sems can gyi tshogs thams cad du song ba zhes bya'o/ /

Just as space is considered to be omnipresent in all things (vases and the rest), all the time, throughout past, present, and future, in the same way the untainted expanse of reality that is the transformed, enlightened state is also held to be omnipresent all the time in all entities, past, present, and future. Since none of the phenomena included in the three times are outside the scope of suchness, and since that expanse is perfectly pure in nature, there is no difference, in terms of their essential nature, between how they are at the time of buddhahood and how they were before.
