Just as space is omnipresent in and pervades everything that is form without distinction, whether long or short, white or red, good or bad, or in between, in the same way, the expanse of the enlightened state too pervades the mind streams of the whole host of sentient beings, whether good, bad, or neither, and is naturally present as their true nature. The enlightened state is by nature the expanse of reality, totally purified of adventitious contaminants. When, on the first level, one realizes the nature of the omnipresent expanse of reality, one acquires the state of mind that realizes the sameness of oneself and all beings. Whatever one is, beings are too. Whatever beings are, one is oneself as well. When bodhisattvas who have realized that there is no difference between themselves and all beings and that all are equal complete their gradual training on the ten levels and attain the buddha level, they completely realize that all sentient beings are naturally perfectly enlightened. It is in this sense that the transformed state is omnipresent in the host of sentient beings.
gnyis pa dogs pa spangs pa ni/
(2) CLARIFICATION OF A DOUBT

ji ltar chu yi snod chag na/ / zla ba'i gzugs brnyan mi snang ba/ / de bzhin sems can ngan pa la/ / sangs rgyas gzugs kyang mi snang ngo / / ji ltar me ni gzhan du 'bar/ / gzhan du zhi bar 'gyur ba ltar/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas rnams la yang / / snang dang mi snang shes par bya/ /

Just as in a broken pail The moon’s reflection will not appear, To evil beings, likewise, The Buddha’s form will not appear. (X, 16) Just as a fire will either blaze Or else die down, Likewise, know that the buddhas too Appear or disappear. (X, 17)
zhes pas bstan te/

de ltar sangs rgyas kyi rang bzhin sems can thams cad la rjes su song zhing khyad med na sems can thams cad kyis rang gi sems kyi chos nyid sangs rgyas kyi rang bzhin yang rtag tu mthong ba dang / sangs rgyas gzugs kyi sku yang cis mi mthong zhe na/ de ni sems can rnams kyi rgyud sgrib pas bsgribs nas sangs rgyas mthong ba'i snod ma yin par bstan pa ni/ dper na nam mkha' la zla ba'i dkyil 'khor yod du zin kyang / ji ltar chu yi snod chag ste chu med par gyur na/ zla ba'i gzugs brnyan mi snang ba de bzhin du sems can gyi rgyud der bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs ma bsags shing nyon mongs dang mi dge ba'i las byas pa'i sgrib pa dang ldan pa'i ngan pa dag snod chag pa la chu med pa ltar sems dad pa dang ting nge 'dzin gyi chu dwang ba lta bu med pas/ sangs rgyas kyi rang bzhin dang gzugs kyang mi snang ngo/ / rU pa zhes pa rang bzhin dang gzugs gnyis ka la 'jug go / de'i phyir sangs rgyas kyis gzugs sku mthong ba dang mi mthong ba ni / sangs rgyas thams cad du ma khyab pas min gyi/ sangs rgyas mthong ba'i tshogs bsags pa'i gdul bya gang na yod par snang zhing / de med na mi snang ba ni ji ltar me ni gzhan bud shing yod pa de nyid du 'bar zhing / gzhan bud shing med pa de nyid du me zhi bar 'gyur te mi 'bar ba ltar/ dpe de bzhin du sangs rgyas kyi gzugs sku rnams la yang / gdul bya yod pa la lar sangs rgyas pa dang 'tsho gzhes te snang ba dang / gdul bya med pa'i yul dang dus der mya ngan las 'das nas mi snang ba shes par bya'o/ /

If the nature of the enlightened state is thus present in all sentient beings and there is no difference between them, why is it that all beings do not always see the nature of the enlightened state that is the true nature of their own minds, and why do they not see the Buddha’s form body either? The fact that they cannot see it shows that beings’ minds are veiled by obscurations and they are not therefore suitable vessels for perceiving the Buddha. To illustrate this with an analogy, although the orb of the moon is there in the sky, its reflection will not appear in a vessel that is broken and has no water in it. Similarly, evil beings, who have failed to gather the accumulations of merit and wisdom in their mind streams and are obscured by their defilements and the negative deeds they have committed, are like broken vessels containing no water. They lack the clear water of faith and concentration, and therefore they cannot perceive either the nature of the enlightened state or the Buddha’s form. The term “rūpa”[9] in this verse is used to mean both “nature” and “form.” So the fact that the Buddha’s form body is visible to some and invisible to others is not because it does not pervade everything. It appears wherever there are trainable beings who have accumulated sufficient merit and wisdom to see the Buddha, and it does not appear to those who have not. Just as a fire either flares up in the presence of fuel or dies down and stops burning when there is none, you should understand that so it is for the buddhas’ form bodies. At times when there are beings to be trained, they appear—that is, they attain enlightenment and remain alive. And in those places and times in which there are no suitable beings to be trained, they pass into nirvāṇa and are no longer visible.
drug pa sangs rgyas kyi mdzad pa rtog med lhun gyis grub par 'jug tshul ni/
vi. THE QUALITY OF PERFORMING DEEDS SPONTANEOUSLY AND NONCONCEPTUALLY

mdzad pa sna tshogs ston pa/ rgyun mi 'chad pa skye 'brir snang tshul bzhi tshigs bcad bzhis bstan te/ nyan thos rnams bdag don du 'bad rtsol dang bcas nas mya ngan 'das tshe bya ba rgyun 'chad la/ sangs rgyas kyi gzhan don mdzad pa ni 'bad rtsol gyi rtog pa med par lhun gyis grub pa dang rgyun mi 'chad pa yin pas khyad zhugs pa ste/

The way in which the buddhas perform their deeds spontaneously and nonconceptually is shown in the next four verses, indicating the four ways in which they appear: teaching the Dharma, demonstrating a whole variety of deeds, acting unceasingly, and being more or less active. When the listeners, after exerting themselves for their own benefit, attain nirvāṇa, their activities cease. The buddhas’ activities, for others’ benefit, are quite different in that they are accomplished spontaneously, without any notion of effort, and are unceasing.
ji ltar rnga dag ma brdungs par/ / sgra ni kun tu 'byung ba ltar/ / de bzhin rgyal ba bzo med par/ / bshad pa dag ni kun tu 'byung / /
Just as drums may sound Without their being struck, The teachings appear Without the buddhas deliberately teaching. (X, 18)
zhes chos ston pa/

ji ltar lha'i bsod nams las grub pa'i rnga bo che dag ni nam brgya byin 'dod yon lnga la 'jug pa na sus kyang ma brdung bar 'dod pa lnga la dga' bar 'gyur ba dang rjes su mthun pa'i sgra 'byung ngo / / nam 'dod yon las ldog par 'gyur na 'dod yon lnga las phyir ldog pa dang rjes su mthun pa'i sgra 'byung ba dang / lha min las rgyal ba'i tshe lha rnams rgyal ba'i sgra dang / bag med pa la mi rtag pa sogs kyi sgra ni kun tu 'byung ba ltar/ de bzhin rgyal ba rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyang zag pa med pa'i dbyings su bzhugs te rnam rtog mi mnga' ba rnams la/ gang zag 'di dang 'di la chos 'di dang 'di bstan par bya'o snyam pa'i rnam rtog gi bzo ba'am 'bad rtsol med par/ so so'i bsam pa dang mthun pa'i chos sna tshogs bshad pa dag ni kun tu 'byung ngo / /

When Indra is going to enjoy the pleasures of the five senses, without anyone beating it, the great drum created through the gods’ merit makes a sound signaling his delight in the five pleasures. When he is going to stop enjoying them, it signals that he is turning away from the five sense pleasures. When he is victorious over the demigods, the sound of the gods’ victory occurs. And when he is carefree, there emerges the sound of the teachings on impermanence and so forth.[10] So it is with the victorious ones, perfect buddhas, who dwell in the untainted expanse of reality and have no ordinary thoughts: without their making any effort or deliberately thinking, “I will give such and such a person this or that teaching,” there arises a whole variety of teachings in accord with each being’s individual aspirations.
ji ltar nor bu 'bad med par/ / rang gi 'od ni ston pa ltar/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyang bzo med par/ / de bzhin mdzad pa nges pa ston/ /
Just as the Precious Gem effortlessly Shines with its own light, So too, the buddhas, without thinking, Assuredly demonstrate their deeds. (X, 19)

ji ltar nor bu rin po che la 'bad rtsol med par rang gi 'od ni phyogs kun tu ston pa ltar/ sangs rgyas rnams kyang sems can gyi don mdzad pa la 'di dang 'di bya'o zhes kun slong gi bzo ba'am rtog pa med par/ nor bu de bzhin du sku gsung thugs kyi mdzad pa sna tshogs gdul bya'i don du lhun gyis grub pa'i tshul gyis nges par ston te/

Just as the Precious Gem[11] shines effortlessly, emitting its own light in all directions, when the buddhas act for the sake of sentient beings, without intending or thinking, “I will do this or that,” they spontaneously, like that gem, surely display a variety of physical, verbal, and mental activities for the sake of beings to be trained.
ji ltar mkha' la 'jig rten gyi/ / bya ba rgyun mi 'chad par snang / / de bzhin zag med dbyings na yang / / rgyal ba'i mdzad pa rgyun mi 'chad/ /
Just as in space the activities Of the universe appear unceasingly, So too, in the untainted expanse of reality The victors’ deeds continue without end. (X, 20)

ji ltar nam mkha' ni snod kyi 'jig rten chags gnas 'jig pa dang / sems can rnams kyi 'gro 'dug sogs kyi bya ba rgyun mi 'chad par snang ba de bzhin du sangs rgyas rnams zag pa med pa'i chos dbyings rnam par dag pa'i gnas la gnas na yang / de las ma g.yos bzhin du phyogs bcur phyi ma'i mu mthar thug gi bar du rgyal ba'i mdzad pa rgyun mi 'chad do/ /

Just as in space the formation, duration, and destruction of the universe, and the activities of beings (moving around, sitting, and so on) appear in unceasing continuity, similarly, even though the buddhas remain in the perfectly pure abode of the untainted expanse of reality, without their moving from that state, the activities of the victorious ones continue unceasingly in the ten directions and until the end of time.
ji ltar mkha' la rtag tu ni/ / bya ba nyams shing 'byung ba ltar/ / de bzhin zag med dbyings na yang / / sangs rgyas 'phrin las skye zhing 'bri/ /
Just as all the time in space Things perish and things come into being, So too, in the untainted expanse of reality, The buddhas’ activities grow and decrease. (X, 21)

rgyun mi 'chad pa yin yang gdul bya'i dbang gis sangs rgyas kyi mdzad pa 'jug mi 'jug gi skye 'brir snang ba ni/ ji ltar nam mkha' 'di la dus rtag tu ni/ phyi dang nang gi dngos po skye ba dang gnas pa'i bya ba 'ga' zhig nyams te nags dang khang khyim sogs tshig pa dang / sems can 'chi ba lta bu sngar yod nyams shing / yang phyi nang gi dngos po gzhan gsar du 'byung ba ltar de bzhin zag med dbyings na yang / sangs rgyas gzugs sku 'jig rten du sprul pa sogs kyi phrin las kyang gdul bya'i dbang gis gsar du skye zhing sngar yod 'bri bar snang ba yin no/ /

Unceasing though they are, the buddhas’ activities appear to grow and diminish, to be undertaken and not undertaken, depending on the beings to be trained. Here in space, all the time there are some things, external or internal, that have come into being and remain and then decline. Things that were there before are destroyed—forests, houses, and so forth burn down. Beings die. And there are other things, external and internal, that come newly into being. In the same way, in the untainted expanse of reality, depending on the beings to be trained, the buddhas’ activities of manifesting their form bodies in this world and so on appear to be newly produced, and those previously present appear to diminish.
bdun pa sangs rgyas kyi dbyings zab pa'i tshul/
vii. THE QUALITY OF THE INESTIMABLE PROFUNDITY OF THE EXPANSE THAT IS THE ENLIGHTENED STATE
snga ma phyi mar khyad med kyang / zhes sogs tshigs bcad bcu drug gis bstan pa 'di la don gsum ste/ mtshan nyid zab pa/ gnas pa zab pa/ las zab pa gsum las/
The following sixteen verses cover three points: (1) profound characteristics; (2) profound abiding; and (3) profound activities.
dang po
(1) PROFOUND CHARACTERISTICS

['di] la yang bzhi ste/ rnam par dag pa'i mtshan nyid/ bdag mchog tu gyur pa'i mtshan nyid/ lung du bstan bya min pa'i dngos po'i mtshan nyid/ rnam par grol ba'i mtshan nyid bzhi rim bzhin tshigs bcad re res bstan te/

The four characteristics described in this section, those of (1) perfect purity; (2) the enlightened state being the sublime “self”; (3) inexpressibility; and (4) perfect liberation are indicated by one verse each.
dang po/
(a) THE CHARACTERISTIC OF PERFECT PURITY
snga ma phyi mar khyad med kyang / / sgrib pa kun gyi dri med pa/ / de bzhin nyid ni sangs rgyas 'dod/ / dag pa ma yin ma dag min/ /
Though no different before or after, Suchness free of all contaminating obscurations Is held to be the enlightened state. Neither is it pure nor is it impure. (X, 22)

zhes pa rang bzhin rnam par dag pa'i de bzhin nyid ni so so'i skye bo'i gnas skabs nas sangs rgyas kyi bar du/ snga ma dang phyi mar khyad med de/ stong pa nyid rang bzhin gyis 'od gsal ba de ni nam yang rang gi ngo bo la 'gyur ba med kyang / glo bur gyi sgrib pa kun gyi dri ma med pa yi de bzhin nyid ni sangs rgyas zhes 'dod kyi/ glo bur gyi dri ma dang bcas pa'i tshe na sangs rgyas kyi dbyings zhes mi bya bas/ rang bzhin gyis dag pa ni gdod nas dag pa yin gyi gsar du dag pa'ang ma yin la phyis su glo bur gyi dri mas ma dag pa'ang min pa des na rnam par dag pa'i mtshan nyid zab ste/ gdod nas dri ma med de dag na sems can rnams kyang sangs rgyas su cis mi 'gyur snyam pa dang / phyis su dri ma dag pa'i dus kho nar sangs rgyas yin na gdod nas rang bzhin gyis dag pa ma yin snyam du shes rab chung bas khong du chud dka' ba'o/ /

Suchness, the perfectly pure nature, is no different from one moment to the next—from the condition of an ordinary individual up to enlightenment. The essential nature of emptiness, which is naturally clear and radiant, never changes. We nevertheless hold that suchness completely uncontaminated by adventitious obscurations is what we call the enlightened state, while when it is contaminated by adventitious obscurations we do not call it the expanse of the enlightened state. It is naturally pure, pure from the very beginning: it is not that it has become pure, nor that it is impure on account of subsequent adventitious contamination. Such is the profundity of the characteristic of perfect purity. People of meager intelligence find this difficult to understand, for they think that if it is pure and uncontaminated from the very beginning, why are sentient beings not enlightened? And that if beings are only enlightened at a time in the future when the contaminants are purified, then it cannot be naturally pure from the very beginning.
gnyis pa/
(b) THE CHARACTERISTIC OF THE ENLIGHTENED STATE BEING THE SUBLIME “SELF”
stong pa nyid ni rnam dag na/ / bdag med mchog gi bdag thob pas/ / sangs rgyas dag pa'i bdag thob phyir/ / bdag nyid chen po'i bdag tu 'gyur/ /
When emptiness is completely purified, The sublime nature of no-self is attained; Thus the buddhas obtain the pure nature And they will therefore become the self of the Great Being. (X, 23)
zhes pas bstan te/

stong pa nyid rang bzhin gyis 'od gsal ba de ni rang snang glo bur dri mas rnam par dag pa na/ gang zag dang chos kyi bdag gnyis po med pa dngos po'i rang bzhin nam gnas lugs mchog gi bdag nyid dam rang bzhin nam ngo bo nyid thob pas na/ sangs rgyas rnams ni shin tu rnam par dag pa'i bdag nyid 'thob pa'i phyir/ dngos po'i yin lugs ma nor ba de bzhin nyid bdag nyid chen po'i bdag tu 'gyur ro zhes/ bdag gnyis su 'dzin pa'i zhen yul ni bdag ma yin te dngos po la med pa'i phyir ro/ / bdag gnyis med pa'i de bzhin nyid yod med kyi mtha' dang bral ba ni gnas lugs ma nor ba yin pas de mngon du byas pa ni bdag mchog ste bdag nyid chen po'i bdag ces bya'o zhes so/ /

When this naturally radiant state of emptiness is completely purified of the adventitious contaminants that are its own appearances, one attains the sublime nature or intrinsic nature or essence that is the actual condition or nature of things, devoid of both the individual self and the phenomenal self. Thus the buddhas have obtained the utterly pure nature, and for this reason they are said to become the “self” of the Great Being, the suchness that is the unmistaken condition of things. This is not the self that is the conceived object of the belief in the two kinds of self, for there is no such self in reality. Suchness devoid of the two kinds of self, free from the extremes of existence and nonexistence, is the unmistaken actual condition of things, and so when it is actualized, it is the highest self, what we call the “self of the Great Being.”[12]
gsum pa/
(c) THE CHARACTERISTIC OF INEXPRESSIBILITY
de phyir sangs rgyas yod min zhing / / med par yang ni mi brjod do/ / de ltar sangs rgyas de skad 'dri/ / lung ma bstan pa'i tshul du 'dod/ /
It is not that the Buddha, therefore, exists, Nor can it be said that he does not exist. When questioned in such terms, it’s said, The Buddha did not answer. (X, 24)
ces pas bstan te/

de phyir sangs rgyas ni gang zag dang chos kyi rang bzhin gyi rnam pas yod pa min zhing / de bzhin nyid spros pa las 'das pa'i rang bzhin du med par yang ni mi brjod de/ gnyis chos la brten pa'i blos tha snyad du gang zag gi rgyud nyi tshe ba sangs rgyas su bzung nas/ sangs rgyas mya ngan las 'das nas slar 'byung ngam mi 'byung ba gang yin zhes dang sangs rgyas 'das nas de phan chad yod dam med ces de ltar mtha' gnyis su rtog pa'i sgo nas sangs rgyas la de skad zhu zhing 'dri na gang du'ang lung ma bstan pa'i tshul du 'dod de/ sangs rgyas yod med kyi mtha' las 'das pa dang / 'byung mi 'byung gi tha snyad byar med pas so/ / gal te sprul pa'i sku 'jig rten du slar 'byung mi 'byung dri na gdul bya gang na yod pa'i yul dus su yang yang 'byung ba sems can gyi mtha' srid du yod kyang / de ni sems can shi nas 'byung ba dang tshul mi 'dra la/ sems can bkrongs phan chad 'byung mi 'byung 'dri ba rnams kyis sems can phal pa rnams shi nas skye ba len pa lta bu la bsams nas sangs rgyas slar 'byung mi 'byung dri ba yin pas sangs rgyas la skye ba dang 'byung ba rang mtshan pa med de de bzhin nyid kyi bdag nyid yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

It is not that the Buddha therefore exists as an individual or a phenomenon. Nor can one say that he does not exist as suchness beyond conceptual elaboration. People with dualistic minds maintain the conventional idea that the Buddha is a transient human being and wonder whether or not the Buddha will come again once he has passed into nirvāṇa, and whether or not he exists after passing away. It is said that when he was asked such questions, posed in terms of these two conceptual extremes,[13] the Buddha did not answer, for the Buddha is beyond the extremes of existence and nonexistence and we cannot say that he comes or does not come. Were one to ask whether the manifestation body will appear again in the world or not, it will come again and again, wherever and whenever there are beings to be trained, and it exists as long as there are beings—but not in the same way as sentient beings, who die and then reappear. Those who wonder whether or not a sentient being will appear after it dies ask, “Will the Buddha come again or not?” thinking that he is like ordinary beings who die and are reborn. But for the Buddha there is no real birth or coming, for he is the nature of suchness.
bzhi pa/
(d) THE CHARACTERISTIC OF PERFECT LIBERATION
ji ltar lcags la tsha ba dang / / mig la rab rib zhi ba ltar/ / sangs rgyas sems dang ye shes la/ / yod dang med par mi brjod do/ /
Just as it is for the fading of heat in an iron Or the disappearance of floaters in the eye, One cannot talk about existence or nonexistence In relation to the Buddha’s mind and gnosis. (X, 25)
zhes pas bstan te/

de bzhin nyid kyi ngo bos gnas na rnam par grol ba'ang de dang 'dra bar zab ste/ ji ltar lcags mes bsregs pa'i tsha ba zhi ba dang / mig la rab rib zhi ba ltar zhes pa/ lcags bsil ba la tsha ba zhi ba yod ces mi brjod de da lta lcags bsil bzhin pa de'i dus su tsha ba sngar 'gags nas med na de zhi ba'ang ji ltar yod de mo gsham bu shi ba bzhin no/ / tsha ba zhi ba med ces mi brjod de de'i tshe tsha ba ma zhi na tsha ba yod par 'gyur bas so/ / de bzhin mig la rab rib yod med kyang de dang 'dra'o/ /

Perfect liberation, being by nature suchness, is similarly profound, and likened to the cooling of an iron heated in the fire and to the removal of floaters in the eye. One cannot say that reduction of heat exists in a cool iron, because now, when the iron is cool, the heat has already ceased and is no longer present, so how can we say that its reduction exists? It is like the child of a barren woman. Nor can one talk about there being no reduction of heat in the iron, because if at that time the heat were not reduced, the iron would still be hot. The same argument can be applied to the question of whether or not the disappearance of floaters exists in the eye.

de dpe dang 'dra bar sangs rgyas kyi rnam par grol ba'i sems lcags lta bu la/ 'dod chags kyi me tsha ba 'dra ba zhi ba dang / sangs rgyas kyi shes rab rnam par grol ba'i ye shes mig dang 'dra ba la ma rig pa rab rib 'dra ba zhi ba ni yod pa dang med pa gang du'ang mi brjod do/ / nam sems rnam par grol ba dang / shes rab rnam par grol ba'i dus na 'dod chags kyi tsha ba dag ma rig pa'i rab rib sngar 'gags pa da ltar med pa'i phyir de zhi ba yod par mi brjod do/ / med par yang mi brjod de/ sems rnam par grol ba dang shes rab rnam par grol ba snga ma'i rjes su yod pas so/ / 'di ma dag pa dang dag pa'i gnas skabs kyi sems kyi rgyun la bsams nas spangs pa dang rnam par grol ba zhes brjod de/ de bzhin nyid kyi ngo bos gzhal na ye nas grol ba bzhin sangs rgyas kyi sar mngon du byas pa'i tshe gsar du grol ba'ang med do/ /

As in these examples, one cannot say whether the extinction of the fire of desire (analogous to the heat) in the Buddha’s perfectly liberated mind (analogous to the iron) exists or does not exist, nor whether the disappearance of the floaters of ignorance exists or does not exist in the eye of the Buddha’s gnosis, the wisdom of perfect liberation. When the mind is liberated and wisdom is liberated, the heat of attachment and the floaters of ignorance have already ceased to be and do not now exist, so one cannot talk about their extinction or disappearance existing. Nor can one talk about them not existing either, because the liberated mind and the liberated wisdom are present after the former states. When we think of this in terms of the continuity of the mind with its phases of impurity and purity, we speak of elimination and perfect liberation. But considered in terms of the nature of suchness, being free from the very beginning, when it is realized on the level of buddhahood, there is no new liberation.

mthong bsgom gyis spang bya'i nyon mongs rnams dang bral ba sems rnam par grol ba zhes dang / rnam grol ba la rnam par grol ba nyid du yang dag par shes pa shes rab rnam grol lo zhes 'grel par gsungs/ shes sgrib spangs pas shes rab rnam grol zhes byas kyang rung ste/ don la sgrib pa gnyis las rnam par grol ba'i ye shes so/ /

Freedom from the defilements that are eliminated through the paths of seeing and meditation is what we call the perfect liberation of the mind. And the correct recognition of perfect liberation as perfect liberation is what we call the perfect liberation of wisdom. This is explained in the commentary. We can also speak of the perfect liberation of wisdom in terms of the cognitive obscurations having been eliminated. In fact, it is the gnosis that is perfectly freed of the two obscurations.
gnyis pa gnas pa zab pa ni/
(2) PROFOUND ABIDING
zag med dbyings na sangs rgyas rnams/ / mkha' ltar lus ni med phyir dang / / sngon gyi lus rjes 'brang ba'i phyir/ / gcig min mang po nyid ma yin/ /
Because the buddhas in the untainted expanse of reality Are incorporeal, like the sky, And because they follow on from their previous physical forms, They are neither single nor multiple. (X, 26)
zhes pas bstan te/

zag pa med pa'i dbyings na bzhugs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams ni nam mkha' ltar de bzhin nyid chos kyi skur gcig pas na so sor ris su chad pa'i lus ni med cing bdag tu 'dzin pa'ang med pa'i phyir sangs rgyas tha dad pa mang po nyid ma yin la/ sngon gyi dus na mos pas spyod pa'i sa nas sa bcu pa la thug gi bar du byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa spyad pa na so so'i lus tha dad pa du ma yod pa nyid kyi rjes su 'brang ba'i sgo nas de dang de'i thob pa'i 'bras bu'i sangs rgyas zhes tha snyad btags pa'i phyir sangs rgyas gcig kyang min no/ / de'i phyir sangs rgyas gcig dang du mar gyur pa zag med kyi dbyings la gnas pa'i tshul rtogs dka' bas zab pa yin no/ /

Since the buddhas who dwell in the untainted expanse of reality are the same in being the body of truth, suchness, like the sky, and therefore do not have individual, separate bodies, nor do they have a sense of self, there is not a multitude of different buddhas. But neither is there a single Buddha, because in the past, when they were practicing the bodhisattva activities from the level of earnest aspiration up until the tenth level, they had individual bodies, and we conventionally call their resultant attainment “buddhas” by virtue of the fact that they follow on from their having been multiple, distinct bodhisattvas. This manner in which the Buddha—who is single and multiple—abides in the untainted expanse of reality is therefore very profound, for it is difficult to understand.
gsum pa
(3) PROFOUND ACTIVITIES

las zab pa la byang chub kyi phyogs rin po che'i 'byung gnas lta bu las dang / sems can yongs su smin par byed pa'i las dang / mthar thug par 'gro ba'i las dang / chos bstan pa'i las dang / sprul pa sogs kyi las dang / ye shes 'jug pa'i las dang / rnam par mi rtog pa'i las dang / rnam pa sna tshogs cig car mthong ba'i las dang / ye shes mi 'jug pa'i las dang / rnam grol mtshungs kyang ye shes kyi bye brag gi las dang rnam pa bcu bshad nas/ zab pa gsum gyi mjug sdud tshigs bcad gcig bcas so/ /
There are ten categories of profound activities. This section ends with a verse summarizing the three aspects of profundity.
dang po/
(a) ACTIVITIES RELATED TO ENLIGHTENMENT, LIKE A MINE OF GEMS
stobs sogs sangs rgyas chos rnams la/ / byang chub rin chen 'byung gnas 'dra/ /
With regard to the strengths and other buddha qualities, Enlightenment is like a mine of precious gems. (X, 27ab)
zhes pas bstan te/
stobs bcu mi 'jigs bzhi la sogs pa sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams la de yi 'byung gnas kyi las byed pa'i byang chub chen po ni rin chen sna tshogs kyi 'byung gnas bzhin no/ /

In performing the activities that are the source of the Buddha’s qualities—the ten strengths, four fearlessnesses, and so forth—great enlightenment is like a source of all sorts of precious substances.[14]
gnyis pa/
(b) THE ACTIVITY OF BRINGING SENTIENT BEINGS TO FULL MATURITY
'gro ba'i dge ba'i lo tog la/ / sprin chen dang yang 'dra bar 'dod/ /
For the crop of beings’ virtue It is held to be like a great cloud. (X, 27cd)
ces pas bstan te/
'gro ba'i rgyud la phar phyin drug gi dge ba'i lo tog smin par byed pa la/ dper na sprin chen po las char 'bebs pa dang yang 'dra bar bstan to/ /
In making the virtuous crop of the six transcendent perfections ripen in beings’ mind streams, great enlightenment is like a great cloud sending down rain.
gsum pa/
(c) THE ACTIVITY LEADING TO ULTIMATE PERFECTION
bsod nams ye shes rab rdzogs phyir/ / zla ba nya ba lta bur 'dod/ /
Because merit and wisdom are perfectly complete, It is likened to a full moon. (X, 28ab)
ces pas bstan te/

sangs rgyas kyi sa na bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs rab tu rdzogs pa mthar phyin pa'i phyir zla ba nya ba lta bur 'dod de/ zla ba nya ba na cha ma rdzogs pa cung zad med par yongs su rdzogs pa ltar mthar thug par 'gro ba'i las so/ /

On the level of buddhahood, the accumulation of merit and wisdom has been brought to ultimate completion, so it is likened to the full moon. This refers to the activity of leading to ultimate perfection, which is as complete as the fullness of the moon at full moon, without the slightest incompleteness.[15]
bzhi pa chos bstan pa'i las ni/
(d) THE ACTIVITY OF TEACHING THE DHARMA
ye shes snang ba byed pa'i phyir/ / nyi ma chen po 'dra bar 'dod/ /
Because of its illuminating gnosis, It is likened to a great sun. (X, 28cd)
ces pas bstan te/

sangs rgyas kyi shes bya thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes kyis chos bstan pa'i 'od zer gyis phyogs bcu'i sems can rnams kyi sems rgyud la yang dag pa'i don mthong ba'i snang ba byed pa'i phyir/ nyi ma chen po 'dra bar 'dod ces gsungs te gling bzhi pa'i 'jig rten gcig na nyi ma gcig las med pa'i de la che chung med kyang / sangs rgyas kyi nyi mas ni phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams dpag med snang bar byed pas na de 'dra'i nyi ma chen po zhes sngon med kyi dpe lta bur brjod pa'o/ /

Since the rays of light of the Buddha’s omniscient gnosis, teaching the Dharma, illumine the minds of sentient beings in the ten directions and cause them to see the truth, the enlightened state is likened to a “great sun.” There is, of course, only one sun in a world system of four continents, and so it cannot be termed great or small, but because the sun of enlightenment lights up infinite world systems in the ten directions, it is exemplified by the novel idea of a “great sun.”
lnga pa sprul pa sogs kyi las ni/
(e) ACTIVITIES SUCH AS MANIFESTATION

ji ltar nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor gyi/ / 'od zer dpag tu med 'dres shing / / rtag tu bya ba gcig la 'jug / 'jig rten la yang snang ba byed/ / de bzhin zag med dbyings na yang / / sangs rgyas dpag tu med 'dres shing / / mdzad pa gcig ni mdzad pa la/ / ye shes snang bar mdzad par 'dod/ /

Just as the infinite rays of light Issuing from the sun’s orb are intermingled And always perform the same functions, Lighting up the whole world, (X, 29) Likewise, the infinite buddhas In the untainted expanse are considered to merge together, Performing their deeds in unison And making the light of gnosis shine. (X, 30)
ces pas bstan blo te/

ji ltar nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor gyi cha las byung ba'i 'od zer dpag tu med pa tha dad du 'byed pa med par gcig tu 'dres shing / 'od zer de rnams dus rtag tu bya ba tha dad so so ba med par lo tog smin pa dang 'dam sems pa sogs kyi bya ba la don gcig par 'jug pa dang / 'od des 'jig rten la yang snang bar byed pa de bzhin du zag pa med pa'i chos kyi dbyings rnam par dag pa na bzhugs pa'i sngon gyi lus kyi rjes su 'brang ba'i sgo nas brjod pa'i sangs rgyas dpag tu med pa de bzhin nyid chos sku'i ngo bor ro gcig tu tha dad med par 'dres shing / gdul bya 'dul ba'i mdzad pa gcig pa nyid ni mdzad pa la phyogs bcu'i sems can thams cad la ye shes kyi snang bar mdzad par 'dod de/ sangs rgyas gcig gis sprul pa dang sems can smin pa'i phrin las sogs mdzad na/ chos sku la tha dad med pa'i phyir sangs rgyas dpag tu med pa de thams cad kyis phrin las de nyid mdzad pa yin te 'dres pa yin pa dang / byed pa dang bya ba dang ye shes thams cad gcig las tha dad du med pa'i phyir ro/ / 'dis sprul pa dang chos bstan pa dang gdul bya smin par byed pa dang / rdzu 'phrul 'gyed pa la sogs pa sangs rgyas kyi mdzad pa thams cad sangs rgyas kun 'dus pa'i mdzad pa yin par bstan pa'o/ /

The infinite rays issuing from the sun’s orb are not separate and distinct but mingled together, always performing the same functions—causing the crops to ripen, drying up mud, and so on—without each having a different task. Its light illumines the whole world. In the same way, the infinite buddhas (so styled by virtue of their following on from their former bodies) dwelling in the perfectly pure, untainted expanse of reality are considered to be merged indistinguishably into a single taste as the nature of the body of truth, suchness. They act in unison to benefit beings to be trained, making the light of gnosis shine on all sentient beings in the ten directions. When a single buddha performs the activities of manifesting, bringing sentient beings to maturity, and so forth, because there are no distinctions in the body of truth, in fact all the infinite buddhas are performing that very activity, for they are mingled together. The doers, their deeds, and their gnosis are all but one, and indistinguishable. This verse shows that all the Buddha’s deeds—manifesting, teaching the Dharma, bringing beings to maturity, performing miracles, and the rest—are the activity of all the buddhas combined.
drug pa ye shes 'jug pa'i las ni/
(f) ACTIVITIES OF THE MANIFESTATION OF GNOSIS
dper na nyi ma'i 'od zer gcig / byung na 'od zer kun 'byung ba/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas rnams kyi yang / / ye shes 'byung bar shes par bya/ /
When the sun gives forth a single ray of light, All the rays of light come forth. From this analogy, know that, likewise, The gnosis of all the buddhas manifests. (X, 31)
zhes pas bstan te/

dper na nyi ma'i 'od zer gcig byung na phyogs gzhan dang gzhan gyi char snang ba'i 'od zer kun dus snga phyi med par mnyam du 'byung ba de bzhin du sangs rgyas rnams las sangs rgyas gcig gis gdul bya ni don gang dang gang dris pa lta bu lung bstan pa'i ye shes 'byung ba na/ sangs rgyas gzhan dpag tu med pa rnams kyi yang ye shes thams cad ye shes de nyid la don gcig tu snga phyi med par dus mnyam du 'jug cing 'byung bar shes par bya'o/ /

When a single ray of sunlight shines forth, all the light rays shining in other directions shine forth simultaneously. By analogy, when a single one of all the buddhas gives rise to gnosis in, for example, answering beings’ questions, it should be understood that all the different instances of gnosis of infinite other buddhas are applied simultaneously and arise as one with that same gnosis.
bdun pa rnam par mi rtog pa'i las ni/
(g) NONCONCEPTUALITY IN THE BUDDHAS’ ACTIVITIES
ji ltar nyi ma'i 'od zer dag / 'jug la bdag gir bya ba med/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas ye shes kyang / / 'jug la bdag gir mdzad mi mnga'/ /
Just as the sun’s rays Have no sense of “mine” in where they go, The gnosis of the buddhas too Has no sense of “mine” when it is applied. (X, 32)
zhes pas bstan te/

ji ltar nyi ma'i 'od zer dag gang dang gang du 'jug pa la 'dir 'jug go / 'di snang bar bya'o snyam pa'i bdag gir bya ba med pa de bzhin sangs rgyas kyi ye shes kyang gdul bya rnams la phan bde'i phyir 'jug pa la bdag dang bdag gir mdzad pa mi mnga' ste rnam par mi rtog bzhin du lhun gyis grub par 'jug pa'i phyir ro/ /

Wherever they penetrate, the sun’s rays have no sense of “mine”—they do not think, “I will penetrate here” or “I must illumine this.” In the same way, when the buddhas’ gnosis is applied to beings’ benefit and happiness, there is no notion of “I” and “mine.” It is applied spontaneously, without concepts.
brgyad pa rnam pa sna tshogs cig car mkhyen pa'i las ni/
(h) THE ACTIVITY OF INSTANTLY KNOWING MULTIFARIOUS ASPECTS
nyi ma'i 'od zer gcig btang bas/ / 'gro ba snang ba byed pa ltar/ / de bzhin shes bya thams cad la/ / sangs rgyas ye shes cig car snang / /
Like a single ray of sunlight Making everything visible to beings, The buddhas’ gnosis at once throws light On everything that can be known. (X, 33)
zhes pas bstan te/

nyi ma'i 'od zer gcig yul gang du btang bas 'gro ba rnams la yul de na yod pa'i gzugs thams cad cig car snang bar byed pa ltar/ de bzhin dus gsum dang phyogs bcus bsdus pa'i shes bya thams cad la sangs rgyas kyi ye shes cig car snang ste thams cad dus gcig tu mkhyen pa yin gyi 'ga' zhig sngar mkhyen 'ga' zhig phyis mkhyen pa dang 'ga' zhig mkhyen tshe gzhan ma mkhyen pa lta bu'i mkhyen pa nyi tshe med par skad cig gcig la shes bya yin no cog mkhyen pa dper me long dwangs gsal la spyod yul du gnas pa'i gzugs thams cad cig car 'char gyi snga phyi med pa bzhin no/ /

Just as a single ray of sunlight, wherever it falls, makes everything in that place instantly visible to beings, similarly the buddhas’ gnosis instantly illumines everything there is to be known in the three times and the ten directions. It knows everything at the same time. This is not limited knowledge that knows some things earlier and some things later, or when it knows certain things does not know others. It knows everything there is to be known in a single instant, just as in a clear mirror all the forms reflected there appear together and not at different times.
dgu pa ye shes mi 'jug pa'i las ni/
(i) THE ACTIVITY OF GNOSIS BEING INACCESSIBLE
ji ltar nyi ma'i 'od zer rnams/ / sprin la sogs pas bsgribs par 'dod/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas ye shes rnams/ / sems can gyi ni nyes pas bsgribs/ /
Just as the light of the sun’s rays Is considered to be obscured by clouds, The gnosis of the buddhas Is obscured by sentient beings’ faults. (X, 34)
zhes pas bstan te/

ji ltar nyi ma'i 'od zer rnams kun tu bkye yang / sprin dang khang khyim phug pa la sogs pas bsgribs na 'od mi snang bar 'dod/ de bzhin sangs rgyas rnams kyi ye shes kyi 'od zer kun tu btang ba rnams sems can gyi ni nyes pas bsgribs te mi snang ba yin sangs rgyas sprul pa'i sku mthong ba dang chos nyan pa sogs kyi snod du ma gyur pa'i nyes pa de dag gis sangs rgyas kyi ye shes mi 'jug pa yin no/ /

Although the sun’s rays shine everywhere, it is generally accepted that when they are obscured by such things as clouds and the walls of houses and caves, there is no light. In the same manner, the rays of the light of gnosis that the buddhas send everywhere are obscured by beings’ faults and do not illuminate them. Because of these faults, which make them unsuitable vessels for seeing the buddhas’ nirmāṇakāya manifestations, for hearing the teachings, and so on, the buddhas’ gnosis does not penetrate them.
bcu pa/
(j) DIFFERENCES IN THE ACTIVITY OF GNOSIS DESPITE EQUALITY IN TERMS OF PERFECT LIBERATION
ji ltar mdud pa'i dbang gis na/ / gos la tshon bkra mi bkra ba/ / de bzhin 'phen pa'i dbang gis na/ / grol ba'i ye shes bkra mi bkra/ /
Just as knots tied in a piece of cloth Produce a patchwork when it is dyed, On account of the force that propels it, The gnosis of liberation manifests more or less brightly. (X, 35)
zhes pas bstan te/

nyan rang rnams kyang 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal las rnam par grol ba'i zag med kyi dbyings mngon du byas mod kyi/ ji ltar gos dkar po la mdud pa byas pa'i dbang gis/ tshon du btsos pa na/ mdud pa ma bor ba tshon gyis 'gyur la/ mdud pa bor bar dkar po'i ri mo bkra bas/ gos gcig la tshon khra bo bkra mi bkra ba yod pa de bzhin sngon slob lam du smon lam dang tshogs gnyis kyi 'phen pa'i dbang gis rnam par grol ba'i dbyings su ye shes bkra ba dang mi bkra bar gyur pa yin te/ nyan rang rnams 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal gyi rtsa ba nyon mongs zad pas rnam par grol ba yin la sangs rgyas kyis kyang nyon mongs pa'i sgrib pa bag chags dang bcas pa zad pas 'khor ba las rnam par grol ba yin yang / shes sgrib spangs pa dang sngon gyi smon lam dang tshogs gnyis yongs su rdzogs pa'i ye shes chen po thob pas sems can gyi khams smin par byed pa'i ye shes kyi las sprul pa 'gyed pa sogs rgyun mi 'chad par snang la nyan rang la de lta bu med do/ /

Even the listeners and solitary realizers have realized the untainted expanse that is perfect liberation from the suffering of saṃsāra. However, the gnosis within the expanse of perfect liberation may manifest more or less brightly depending on the propelling force of former aspirations and the accumulation of merit and wisdom made on the path of learning, like a knotted white cloth that has been dyed. As long as the cloth remains knotted, it looks as if it has taken the dye, but once the knots are undone they reveal a white design, so that the same cloth is a patchwork of brightly colored and colorless sections. The listeners and solitary realizers are perfectly liberated in having brought to exhaustion the defilements that are the root of suffering in saṃsāra. The buddhas too are perfectly liberated from saṃsāra in having brought to exhaustion the obscurations deriving from the defilements together with their habitual tendencies. But because they have eliminated the cognitive obscurations, made aspirations in the past, and obtained the great gnosis through completing the two accumulations, the activity of their gnosis in ripening beings’ enlightened element[16] manifests unceasingly, in their sending forth emanations and so on. This is something the listeners and solitary realizers do not have.
bcu gcig pa/
(k) CONCLUDING SUMMARY OF THESE THREE ASPECTS OF PROFUNDITY
dri med dbyings la sangs rgyas kyi/ / mtshan nyid dang ni gnas pa dang / / 'phrin las zab pa 'di bshad pa/ / mkha' la tshon gyis ri mo 'bri/ /
To describe these profound points— The characteristics, way of abiding, and activities Of the buddhas in the uncontaminated expanse of reality— Would be to paint a picture in the sky. (X, 36)
zhes pas bstan te/

zab pa'i don bsdu ba dri ma med pa'i dbyings la ro gcig tu gnas pa sangs rgyas rnams kyi mtshan nyid zab pa bzhi dang ni/ gnas pa zab pa dang / phrin las zab pa bcu po 'di lta bu sangs rgyas kyis bshad pa ni nam mkha' la tshon gyis ri mo 'bri bar bya dka' ba lta bu ste spros pa zhi ba'i dbyings nam mkha' lta bu la rtog pas 'di lta bu'o zhes mtshon par byed pa ni tshon gyis ri mo bris kyang nam mkha' la tshon mi chags pa dang 'dra la 'on kyang bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i gnas yid ches pa dag la nam mkha' la tshon gyis ri mo 'bri nus pa ltar shin tu ngo mtshar bar rig par bya'o gsungs/ de dag gis zab pa'i yon tan bshad/

The four profound characteristics of the buddhas who dwell as one taste in the uncontaminated expanse of reality, their profound abiding, and their ten profound activities have been explained thus by the Buddha, but they are as difficult to describe as painting a picture in the sky. Using concepts to illustrate the sky-like expanse of reality free of conceptual elaboration, saying, “It is like this,” is like painting a picture in the sky—the paint will not stick. Nevertheless, those who have confidence in the inconceivable can paint a picture in the sky.[17] This, we should understand, is how utterly extraordinary these three aspects of profundity are. All the above is an explanation of the enlightened state’s quality of profundity.
brgyad pa chos kyi dbyings de bzhin nyid 'pho 'gyur med pa'i yon tan ni/
viii. THE QUALITY OF ITS UNCHANGING ESSENCE—THE CHANGELESS EXPANSE OF REALITY, SUCHNESS
de bzhin nyid ni thams cad la/ / khyad par med kyang dag gyur pa/ / de bzhin gshegs nyid de yi phyir/ / 'gro kun de yi snying po can/ /
Suchness is present in all, and not different, Yet purified it is the Tathāgata. Thus it is that all beings Are imbued with its essence. (X, 37)
zhes pas bstan te/

chos thams cad kyi chos nyid de bzhin nyid chos kyi dbyings 'di ni sems can thams cad kyi sems la khyad par med par gdod nas yod kyang glo bur gyi dri mas dag par gyur pa yi de bzhin nyid de ni de bzhin gshegs pa nyid yin pa de yi phyir na 'gro ba sems can kun kyang de bzhin nyid rang bzhin 'od gsal ba de yi snying po can yin pas bde gshegs snying po zag med kyi dbyings ni dus gsum po kun tu yang 'pho 'gyur bri gang dang bral ba yin pas de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi sku yongs su dag pa mthar thug pa ni rtag brtan zhi ba 'pho 'gyur med pa yang rgyu mtshan 'dis 'grub pa yin no/ /

This expanse of reality, suchness, the true nature of all phenomena, is present in the minds of all sentient beings from the beginning, and no different in any of them. Yet that suchness, purified of adventitious contaminants, is nothing other than the Tathāgata. Thus all sentient beings too are imbued with the essence of that radiant nature, suchness. This essence of the sugatas, the untainted expanse, is free of all change, of increase and decrease, throughout past, present, and future. For these reasons it is also established that the ultimate, perfectly pure body of gnosis of the tathāgatas is permanent, stable, peaceful, and unchanging.
dgu pa 'byor pa tshad med pa'i yon tan
ix. THE QUALITY OF ITS BOUNDLESS ATTAINMENTS
['di] la/ 'byor pa'i khyad par dang / de yi rab tu dbye ba'i rnam grangs bshad pa gnyis/
This section is divided into (1) the superiority of the Buddha’s attainments and (2) an enumeration of different categories of those attainments.
dang po/
(1) THE SUPERIORITY OF THE BUDDHA’S ATTAINMENTS

nyan thos rnams kyi 'byor pas ni/ / 'jig rten pa yi zil gyis gnon/ / rang sangs rgyas kyi sa pa yis/ / nyan thos kyi yang zil gyis gnon/ / de yis byang chub sems dpa' yi/ / 'byor pa'i char yang mi phod do/ / de yis de bzhin gshegs pa yi/ / 'byor pa'i char yang mi phod do/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyi 'byor pa ni/ / gang gi gang du ji ltar dang / / ji tsam dus gang 'jug pa ni/ / bsam yas dpag tu med par 'dod/ /

The attainments of the listeners Outshine those of the worldly. Those on the level of the solitary realizers Outshine those of the listeners. (X, 38) These cannot approach even a fraction Of the attainments of the bodhisattvas. And those do not compare with even a fraction Of the attainments of the tathāgatas. (X, 39) For whom they are applied, and where, And how, to what extent, and for what length of time— On such grounds are the attainments of the buddhas Held to be inconceivable and immeasurable. (X, 40)
ces pas bstan te/

nyan thos rnams kyi bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs dang mngon par shes pa'i 'byor pas ni/ 'jig rten pa yi tshogs gnyis dang drang srong gi mngon shes sogs kyi 'byor pa zil gyis gnon la/ rang sangs rgyas kyi sa pa yi 'byor pa de yis/ nyan thos kyi 'byor pa yang zil gyis gnon te de las 'phags shing rgya che bas so/ / rang sangs rgyas kyi yon tan gyi 'byor pa de yis byang chub sems dpa' yi tshogs gnyis dang mngon shes sogs kyi 'byor pa'i brgya stong sogs kyi char yang mi phod do zhes dpe dang grangs dang rgyur yang mi 'gro'o/ / byang chub sems dpa'i 'byor pa de yis de bzhin gshegs pa yi tshogs gnyis yongs su rdzogs pa dang / mngon shes dang stobs dang mi 'jigs pa sogs yon tan dpag med kyi pha rol phyin pa'i 'byor pa'i char yang mi phod do/ /zhes byang chub sems dpa'i yon tan gyi 'byor pa shin tu tshad med pa yin mod kyi sangs rgyas kyi yon tan gyi 'byor pa dang bskrun na rdul phra mo gcig dang 'jig rten gyi khams mtha' yas pa'i gtos kyi khyad par bzhin du khyad zhugs pa yin te/

The listeners’ attainments of the accumulation of merit and wisdom and preternatural knowledge outshine such attainments as mundane beings’ two accumulations and rishis’ preternatural knowledge. In comparison, the attainments of those on the solitary realizers’ level outshine even the listeners’ attainments, being superior and vaster. The wealth of qualities the solitary realizers have cannot compare with even a fraction, even a hundredth or a thousandth, of the bodhisattvas’ accumulation of merit and wisdom, preternatural knowledge, and other attainments; they do not approach them in terms of analogies, numbers, or cause. The bodhisattvas’ attainments cannot compare with even a fraction of the tathāgatas’ transcendent attainments—their completion of the two accumulations and their infinite qualities such as preternatural knowledge, strength, and fearlessness. While it is true that the bodhisattvas’ qualities are utterly boundless, they are quite different in magnitude compared to the buddhas’ wealth of good qualities, like a single tiny particle of dust compared to infinite world systems.

de ci'i phyir na yang dag rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi 'byor pa ni/ gang zag gang gi don du 'jug pa yang tshad med de/ gang zag gcig dang brgya la sogs grangs yod pa zhig gi don du ma yin sems can tshad med pa thams cad kyi don du zhugs pa'i phyir ro/ / gang du 'jug pa yang tshad med pa 'jig rten gyi khams nam mkhas gar khyab par 'jug pas dpag tu med do/ / ji ltar 'jug pa yang dpag med de/ bzo dang skye ba mchog gi sprul sku dang rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i thabs kyi rol pa gdul bya'i khams bzhin du tshad med pas so/ / ji tsam du 'jug pa yang dpag tu med de sems can thams cad la phan bde byed pas des phan btags pa ci tsam zhig ces bgrang du med pas so/ / dus gang du 'jug pa yang dpag tu med de sems can thams cad kyi mtha' ma zad pa srid du gzhan don la 'jug pas sems can gyi mtha' zad pa mi srid pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar sangs rgyas rnams kyi 'byor pa ni/ gang gi ched du 'jug pa dang / gang du 'jug pa dang / ji ltar 'jug pa dang / ji tsam zhig 'jug pa dang / dus gang du 'jug pa ni nyan rang rnams kyi'ang yul las 'das pa zab pa'i phyir/ bsam yas pa ste bsam yul las 'das pa dang / rgya che bas rab tu dbye ba'i grangs dpag tu med par 'dod do/ /

The reason for this is that the beings for whose welfare the perfect buddhas’ attainments are applied are boundless, for they are not applied to benefiting a certain number of beings—one being, or a hundred—but to benefiting all the boundless beings there are. Where they are applied is boundless, for they are applied in the infinite universes filling space. How they are applied is infinite, on account of the boundless bodies of manifestation (those who manifest in art, those who manifest through birth, and supreme nirmāṇakāya manifestations) and diversified skillful manifestations displayed according to the dispositions of beings to be trained. The extent of their application is infinite, for since the buddhas work for the benefit and happiness of all sentient beings, there is no calculating the extent of the benefit they do. And the duration of their application is infinite, for the buddhas engage in benefiting others for as long as there are still beings—and to beings there is no end. Thus, because the buddhas’ attainments are so profound, being beyond the scope of the listeners and solitary realizers in terms of whom they are applied to, where, how, to what extent, and for how long, they are said to be inconceivable, beyond the imagination. And, on account of their vastness, the numbers of their categories are immeasurable.
gnyis pa ni/
(2) AN ENUMERATION OF DIFFERENT CATEGORIES OF THOSE ATTAINMENTS
gnas gyur pa las byung ba'i 'byor pa'i rnam grangs bdun bstan pas mtshon nas dpag tu med par bstan pa'i tshigs bcad brgyad kyi don ni/
There are eight verses showing seven different kinds of attainment that come through transformation, along with how infinite these attainments are.
dbang po lnga rnams gzhan gyur na/ / don kun 'jug dang thams cad kyi/ / yon tan brgya phrag bcu gnyis 'byung / / 'byor pa dam pa 'thob par 'gyur/ /
When the five sense organs are transformed, They perceive all the sense objects, and there arise Twelve hundred all-perceiving qualities, Which are obtained as the supreme attainment. (X, 41)
ces pas bstan lcate/

mig sogs dbang po rnams gnas gzhan du gyur te rnam par dag pa'i dus na/ dbang po re re'ang dbang po yi don kun la 'jug pa dang / yul thams cad kyi rnam pa mthong ba'i yon tan brgya phrag bcu gnyis 'byung ba'i 'byor pa dam pa 'thob par 'gyur ro zhes/ sngar dbang po gnas ma gyur pa'i dus na mig dbang gis gzugs 'ba' zhig mthong gi sgra sogs dbang po gzhan gyi spyod yul gcod mi nus so/ / gnas gyur pa'i tshe mig dbang gis gzugs sgra dri ro reg bya kun 'dzin nus pas/ dbang yul gyi don kun la 'jug nus pas so/ /

When the sense organs—the eye and the others—are transformed into the pure state, each sense organ interacts with all the objects of the sense organs, and there arise twelve hundred qualities of perceiving all objects, which will be obtained as the supreme attainment. Previously, when the sense organs had not been transformed, the eye only saw forms, but it could not perceive the objects of the other sense organs—sound and the rest. When they have been transformed, the eye is able to apprehend everything—forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and physical sensations—and it is therefore able to interact with all the sense objects.

yon tan brgya dang bcu gnyis ni blo brtan 'grel par dbang po gcig cig kyang yon tan brgya rtsa bcu gnyis dang ldan par 'gyur te/ gzungs dbang gi mdo dang / dam chos pad dkar las 'byung ba bzhin du blta'o zhes gsungs/ kha cig mtshan dpe bsdoms pas brgya bcu gnyis la 'dod pa dang 'ga' zhig sa yi yon tan sogs la 'dod pa dbang po'i yon tan ma yin pas skabs 'di dang mi 'brel zhes snga ma dag gis bshad pa ltar nges/ yang phyogs drug tu phye nas de re re la yang phyogs bcur phye ba'i don lnga las mig la mtshon na mig gis gzugs mthong ba khyad chos min pas mi brtsi bar/ sgra dri ro reg bzhi 'dzin pas mig la yon tan nyis brgya bzhi bcu/ lnga ga bsdoms na stong dang nyis brgya la brgya phrag tshan pa bcu gnyis su gyur pa'i grangs byed pa'ang snang / dam chos pad dkar las chos de bzung ba'i bsod nams las byung ba'i sha'i dbang pos phyogs kun gyi gzugs sogs kun 'dzin par gsungs pa yod 'dug kyang slar zhib tu mdo dang bstun nas dpyad 'os kyi skabs 'dir thun gyis brel bas ma grub bo/ /

Speaking of one hundred and twelve qualities,[18] Sthiramati’s commentary mentions that even a single sense organ will have one hundred and twelve qualities, for which one should refer to the Sūtra of the Questions of Dhāraṇīśvararāja and the White Lotus Sūtra of the Sacred Dharma. Some people say that these refer to the one hundred and twelve qualities obtained by adding together the major and minor marks.[19] Others say that they are the qualities related to the level and so on. But these are not qualities of the sense organs, and therefore they are not relevant in this context. It is then evident that the twelve hundred qualities must be as explained in the above-named sūtras. Moreover, it appears that one can count them as follows. Each of the five sense objects can be split into six directional aspects,[20] and each of these again into ten aspects corresponding to the ten directions, making sixty such aspects in all. Beginning with the eye (and not counting the eye seeing forms, since that is not an extraordinary feature of the eye), its apprehension of the four objects—sounds, smells, tastes and physical sensations—multiplied by sixty makes two hundred and forty qualities for the eye. Adding all five sense organs together, we get 1,200 qualities, making twelve groups of one hundred. Although it is said in the White Lotus Sūtra that the flesh organs, which are produced through the merit of upholding that teaching,[21] apprehend everything—forms and so on—in all directions, it would be worth checking this point again in detail by referring to the sūtra, but in this general context it may not be relevant.[22]

'dir rnam rig smra ba'i lugs la dbang po gzugs can pa dang yul gzugs sogs gnyis ka med na ji ltar dbang po gnas 'gyur zer na/ rang gi sa bon gang dag la/ / rnam rig snang ba gang 'byung ba/ / skye mched rnam pa gnyis po zhes/ / de dang de dag thub pas gsungs/ / zhes pa ltar kun gzhi rnam shes la gzung ba dang 'dzin pa'i bag chags yod pa las phyi dang nang gi skye mched drug tu snang ste/ mig shes skyed pa'i rten du gyur pa'i nang gi sa bon la mig ces su 'dzin cing / mig shes las gzung yul gzugs su snang 'byung ba la gzugs zhes bya ste/ de bzhin dbang po gzhan yang ngo / / de ltar snang ngos nas phyi nang gi skye mched gnyis su dbye ba yod la/ gang tshe phyin ci log med pa'i ye shes kyi nang gi mngon par chags pa phyin ci log spangs pas gnas gyur pa yin no/ /

One might wonder how the sense organ can be transformed if, as here in the Cittamātra tradition, neither a material sense organ nor form as an object exists. This is answered by the following quotation. Whatever seeds one has Are the source of anything that appears to the consciousness, And these are termed the twofold senses-and-fields, As the Capable One has explained. Accordingly, from the consciousness of the ground of all that has the habitual tendencies of an apprehending subject and an apprehended object there appear the six outer and inner senses-and-fields. The inner seed that is the support for the eye consciousness arising is held to be the “eye,” and the apprehended object that arises from the eye consciousness and appears as form is what we call “form.” It is similar for the other senses. Thus, from the point of view of appearance, there is a classification into two, the outer and inner senses-and-fields. At that time,[23] the mistaken inner attachment is eliminated by the unmistaken gnosis, and transformation thereby takes place.
yid ni gzhan du gyur pa na/ / 'byor dang mthun spyod mi rtog pa'i/ / ye shes shin tu dri med la/ / 'byor pa dam pa 'thob par 'gyur/ /
When the mind is transformed, It functions consistently with that attainment, And supreme attainment is obtained With regard to the uncontaminated nonconceptual gnosis. (X, 42)

yid ni zhes pa nyan thos pas rnam shes drug 'das ma thag pa la yid kyi dbang po zer kyang / theg pa chen po'i lugs kyis yid ni de la mi bya ste/ nyon mongs pa'i yid la yid ces bya zhing de yid kyi rnam shes kyi rten yin par 'dod do/ / dper na mig shes kyi rten mig dbang lta bu'o/ / de lta bu'i nyon mongs pa'i yid de ni gnas ma gyur pa'i dus na bdag tu lta ba can yin la/ nam bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin pa dang bral nas gnas gzhan mnyam pa nyid kyi ye shes su gyur pa na/ gnas gyur pa'i dbang po lnga'i 'byor pa dang mthun par rjes su spyod pa yin pa ni/ ji ltar yid ni gnas ma gyur pa'i dus na yang dbang yul kun la thun mong du 'jug pa bzhin no/ / gzung ba 'dzin par rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes nyon mongs shes bya'i sgrib pa'i shin tu dri ma med pa la/ dbang 'byor ba dam pa thob par 'gyur ro/ /

“Mind” here is not what the listeners call “mind,” that is, the mind organ that comes immediately after the six consciousnesses. What the Mahāyāna tradition calls “mind” is the defiled mind consciousness, which we hold to be the support of the mental consciousness, just as the eye organ, for example, is the support of the eye consciousness. As long as this defiled mind consciousness is not transformed, it has the view of an “I,” whereas when it is freed of the concepts of “I” and “mine,” it is transformed into the gnosis of equality, and it then functions in a way consistent with the attainment of the five transformed sense organs, in the same way that the mind interacts with all the sense objects in common even when it is untransformed. Sublime mastery will be obtained in the gnosis free of the concepts of subject and object and completely uncontaminated by defilement-related and cognitive obscurations.
don bcas 'dzin pa gzhan gyur na/ / ji ltar 'dod bzhin longs spyod dag / bstan phyir zhing ni dag pa la/ / 'byor pa dam pa thob par 'gyur/ /

When the apprehending subjects associated with the sense objects are transformed, These are enjoyed in any way one wishes, And to show this, supreme attainment is obtained With regard to the purification of realms. (X, 43)

yul gzugs la sogs pa'i don lnga dang bcas pa'i yul can 'dzin pa'i dbang lnga'i rnam shes gnas gzhan du gyur na/ dbang shes kyi spyod yul ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin du longs spyod pa dag bstan pa'i phyir/ zhing ni yongs su dag pa bde ba can la sogs pa lta bu ji ltar 'dod pa ston pa la dbang 'byor pa dam pa thob par 'gyur ro/ / blo brtan 'grel las don gzugs nas chos kyi bar don drug dang dbang shes lnga gnas gyur na zhes gsungs/ ma dag pa'i dbang shes so sos rang yul las gzhan mi shes la/ gnas gyur tshe re res kyang yul kun shes so/ /

When the consciousnesses of the five senses (the apprehending subjects associated with the five sense objects—form and the rest) are transformed, the objects of the sense consciousnesses are enjoyed in whatever way one wishes. In order to show this, one will obtain supreme mastery in displaying perfectly pure realms like the Blissful Realm[24] just as one wishes. In his commentary, Sthiramati says, “When the six sense objects from form through to phenomena and the five sense consciousnesses are transformed….” The individual impure sense consciousnesses are not conscious of anything other than their respective objects, but when they are transformed, each of them is conscious of all objects.
rnam rtog gzhan du gyur na ni/ / dus rnams rtag tu ye shes dang / / las rnams kun la thogs med la/ / 'byor pa dam pa thob par 'gyur/ /
When conceptual thought is transformed, Supreme attainment is obtained Regarding gnosis and all activities, At all times and without impediment. (X, 44)

rnam par rtog pa ni yid kyi rnam shes gnas gzhan du gyur na ni/ dus rnams rtag tu shes bya thams cad la thogs pa med pa'i ye shes dang / sprul pa ston pa sogs phrin las kun la thogs pa med pa la dbang 'byor pa dam par thob par 'gyur ro/ /

When conceptual thought, that is, the mind consciousness, is transformed, one will obtain supreme mastery at all times in the unobstructed gnosis that knows everything there is to be known and in all activities such as displaying manifestations without impediment.
rten ni gzhan du gyur pa na/ / sangs rgyas dri med gnas la ni/ / mi gnas mya ngan 'das pa yis/ / 'byor pa dam pa thob par 'gyur/ /
When the support is transformed, Supreme attainment is obtained Of the nondwelling nirvāṇa, The uncontaminated state of buddhahood. (X, 45)

rten kun gzhi rnam shes ni gnas gzhan du gyur pa na/ sangs rgyas kyi dri ma med pa'i gnas la gnas nas ni/ 'khor ba dang mya ngan las 'das pa'i mtha' la mi gnas pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa'i 'byor pa dam pa thob par 'gyur ro/ /

When the support, that is, the consciousness of the ground of all, is transformed, one will dwell in the uncontaminated abode of the enlightened state and obtain the supreme attainment of the nirvāṇa that does not dwell in the extremes of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa.
'khrig pa gzhan du gyur na ni/ / sangs rgyas bde bar gnas pa dang / / mo mthong nyon mongs med pa la/ / 'byor pa dam pa thob par 'gyur/ /
When sexual activity is transformed, Supreme attainment is obtained In terms of dwelling in the buddhas’ bliss And being free of the defilements that relate to seeing women. (X, 46)

pho mo'i dbang po gnyis sprod pa'i 'khrig pa gnas gzhan du gyur na ni/ sangs rgyas kyi spros pa bral ba'i ting 'dzin gyi bde bar gnas pa dang / mo rnams mthong na chags pa'i nyon mongs pa med pa la dbang 'byor pa dam pa thob par 'gyur ro/ /

When sexual activity, the joining of the male and female organs, is transformed, one will obtain mastery in remaining in the bliss of concentration free from the conceptual elaboration that obscures enlightenment and in being without the defilement of desire on seeing members of the opposite sex.
nam mkha'i 'du shes gzhan gyur na/ / bsam pa'i don ni 'byor pa dang / / 'gro gzugs rnam par 'byed pa la/ / 'byor pa dam pa thob par 'gyur/ /
When the perception of space is transformed, Supreme attainment is obtained With regard to acquiring all the riches one wishes, To moving unimpededly, and to taking different forms. (X, 47)

nam mkha'i 'du shes gnas gzhan gyur na/ nam mkha' las ci bsam pa'i don thams cad ni 'byor pa nam mkha' mdzod kyi ting 'dzin thob pa dang / nam mkha' dang ri brag sogs la'ang thogs pa med par 'gro ba dang / gzugs rnam par 'byed pa ni snang bar 'dod na nam mkha' las gzugs gang yang snang bar byed pa dang / mi snang bar 'dod na lus rnam par 'jig pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyis thams cad nam mkha' bzhin du gzugs mi snang bar byed pa la/ dbang 'byor pa dam pa thob par 'gyur ro/ /

When the perception of space is transformed, one will obtain supreme mastery in acquiring the concentration of the Sky Treasury, getting everything one thinks of from space; mastery in moving without impediment through the air, and even through mountains, rocks, and so forth; and mastery in taking different physical forms—that is, when one wishes to be visible, making one’s physical form appear from space, and when one wishes to be invisible, using the concentration of dissolving the body to make everything physically disappear like space.
de ltar sangs rgyas dri med pa'i/ / gnas na gzhan gyur dpag med la/ / bsam yas bya ba sgrub pa yi/ / 'byor pa dpag tu med par 'dod/ /
Thus, in the uncontaminated state of buddhahood There are said to be infinite transformations, With infinite attainments Accomplishing inconceivable activities. (X, 48)

de ltar bshad pa des mtshon nas/ gnas su snang ba dang / lus su snang ba dang / rnam par shes pa dang / yul gzugs la sogs pa'i shes bya'i rnam pa mtha' med pa yod pa de snyed kyi/ snang ba yongs su dag par gnas gyur pa'ang de snyed du tshad med pa'i phyir/ sangs rgyas kyi dri ma med pa'i gnas na/ gnas gzhan du gyur pa dpag tu med pa yod la/ gdul bya la phan pa dang bde ba bsam yas pa'i bya ba bsgrub pa yi/ yon tan nam mthu'i 'byor pa dpag tu med par 'dod do/ / de ltar sangs rgyas kyis yon tan gyi 'byor pa tshad dpag tu med pa brnyes nas/

Thus, as indicated by the above explanations, there are as many boundless transformations into perfectly pure appearances as there are infinite aspects that can be known—environmental appearances, physical appearances, consciousnesses, and sensory objects such as forms. For this reason, in the uncontaminated state of enlightenment there are said to be infinite transformations, with infinite qualities or powers that are attained and that accomplish inconceivable benefit and happiness for beings to be trained. It is from having acquired such boundless qualities and attainments that the buddhas bring sentient beings to maturity, as we shall see next.
bcu pa des sems can gzhan smin par byed pa'i yon tan
x. THE QUALITY OF BRINGING SENTIENT BEINGS TO MATURITY[25]

['di] la/ ji ltar smin pa'i bya ba/ des smin par bya ba'i gang zag smin pa'i thabs sna tshogs mdzad pa/ smin par mdzad pa la rnam rtog med pa/ phyogs lhung med par smin par byed pa/ gcig nas gcig tu brgyud de smin pa/ ngoms pa med cing 'phel 'grib med par rgyun mi chad pa bdun las/

This section is divided into seven parts: (1) how beings are brought to maturity; (2) the individuals that are brought to maturity; (3) the various deeds or means by which beings are brought to maturity; (4) nonconceptuality in maturing beings; (5) impartiality in maturing beings; (6) maturing beings in a chain reaction; and (7) how maturation continues unceasingly without ever reaching a sufficiency and without increase or diminution.
dang po/
(1) How BEINGS ARE BROUGHT TO MATURITY

'di na 'jig rten phyogs phyogs rgyal ba'i legs bshad pa'i/ / dge ba 'phel ba'i 'jig rten rnam dag mchog tu 'gro/ / dge ba ma bsags dge ba 'phel ba'i mchog tu 'gro/ / de ltar ma smin smin pa rtag 'gro'ang ma lus min/ /

Here, in all the regions of the universe, by means of the victors’ excellent explanations, Those in the world who are growing in virtue proceed to the highest purity, While those without a store of merit proceed to the sublime state of growth in virtue. Thus the immature proceed ever to maturity, but there is never no one left. (X, 49)
zhes pas bstan te/

sangs rgyas pa de'i tshe sems can gdul bya'i khams 'di na sems can ji ltar smin par mdzad ce na 'jig rten mtha' yas mu med pa'i phyogs 'ga' zhig ma yin par phyogs bcu'i phyogs rab 'byams rnams su'o/ / gang gis smin par mdzad na rgyal bas so/ / thabs ci yis na/ gsung rab dam pa'i chos legs par bshad pas so/ / ji ltar smin na mos spyod nas sa bcu'i bar du phar phyin drug gi dge ba 'phel ba'i 'jig rten rnams ni gong nas gong du rnam par zadag pa'i mchog mya ngan las 'das pa dag tu 'gro bas smin par byed do/ / sems ma bskyed pa dang lam la ma zhugs pa'i sems can rnams ni sngar dge ba ma bsags pa'i 'jig rten pa yin la de rnams sems bskyed nas lam la zhugs pas dge ba gong nas gong du 'phel ba'i mchog tu 'gro ba'i tshul gyis smin par mdzad do/ / de ltar sems can ma smin pa rnams smin par nyid du byed cing de ltar sems can smin par byed pa'i phrin las nam yang rgyun mi 'chad par rtag pa nyid du 'jug pa'am 'gro ba yin yang sems can ma lus pa smin nas zad par 'gyur ba'ang min te sems can gyi mtha' yas pas bri ba med la chos kyi dbyings skye ba med pa'i phyir 'phel ba med de/ chos thams cad rang bzhin med kyang snang ba yod pa tsam yin pas kun nyon dang rnam byang gi snang tshul zad pa mi srid do/ /

When enlightenment is attained, how are sentient beings brought to maturity in this world of beings to be trained? Not in a few parts of the boundless universe, but in the infinite regions of the ten directions. Who brings them to maturity? The victorious ones. By what means? By clearly expounding the sacred Dharma, the Excellent Words. In what manner are they brought to maturity? Those in the world who, from the level of earnest aspiration up to the tenth level, are growing in the virtuous practices of the six transcendent perfections are brought to maturity in progressing higher and higher up to the sublime purity that is nirvāṇa. Beings who have not aroused bodhicitta and have not set out on the path—that is, mundane beings who have not accumulated merit in the past—are brought to maturity in arousing bodhicitta, starting to practice the path, and thereby progressing to the most excellent state of growing in virtue. Thus the buddhas bring to maturity those beings who are not mature, and in this way they eternally and unceasingly engage or proceed in the activities of bringing sentient beings to maturity. That is not to say, however, that there will be an end to sentient beings, with all having been brought to maturity and none left behind. Beings are infinite in number, so they do not decrease, and because the expanse of reality is unborn, it does not grow. Although all phenomena are devoid of intrinsic existence, they do exist as mere appearance, and so it is impossible for the appearance aspect of defilement and purity to come to an end.
gnyis pa smin par byas pa'i gang zag bstan pa ni/
(2) THE INDIVIDUALS THAT ARE BROUGHT TO MATURITY

de ltar 'jig rten phyogs phyogs brten rnams rtag par dus kun tu/ / byang chub chen po 'thob dka' yon tan mchog ldan rmad byung can/ / rtag brtan skyabs med rnams kyi skyabs gang yin pa thob pa de/ / ya mtshan che la tshul bzang spyad phyir ya mtshan che ba'ang med/ /

Thus the steadfast in different worlds are always and forever attaining The great enlightenment, so hard to attain, marvelous, and endowed with sublime qualities, Eternal, stable, and a refuge for the unprotected. How amazing that is, and yet not at all amazing, for they have practiced the excellent way. (X, 50)
ces pas bstan te/

de ltar sems can tshad med pa smin par byas pas 'jig rten mtha' dag gi phyogs dang phyogs rnams su smin par gyur pa'i gang zag brtan pa byang chub sems dpa' rnams nyi ma re re bzhin du de'i dus kyi skad cig la yang rtag par yang rgyun mi 'chad par dus kun tu/ 'bras bu bla na med pa'i byang chub chen po shin tu 'thob par dka' ba thob na stobs sogs kyi yon tan mchog tu gyur pa dang ldan pa/ 'jig rten pa dang nyan rang las rmad du byung ba can thob nas 'khor ba'i mtha'i bar du yod pas rtag pa/ nam yang nyams pa med pas brtan pa/ 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal gyis mnar ba'i skyabs med pa rnams kyi sdug bsngal thams cad zhi ba'i mya ngan las 'das pa 'thob par byed pa'i skyabs su gyur pa gang yin pa de nyid bshad ma thag pa ltar gang zag mang pos rgyun du rim par nyi ma re re'i skad cig gi tshe la thob pa de ni/ shin tu ya mtshan che la gang zag yongs su smin pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de dag gis sems bskyed nas phar phyin drug gis bsdus pa'i tshogs gnyis zab cing rgya che ba'i lam gyi tshul bzang po la spyad nas 'bras bu de lta bu 'thob pa'i phyir ya mtshan che ba'ang med de rgyu mchog las 'bras bu mchog 'byung ba chos nyid yin pas so/ /

Countless sentient beings have been brought to maturity as just described, and thus bodhisattvas, the steadfast individuals who are brought to maturity in the different regions of all the different worlds, are all the time—in each second of each day, forever and unceasingly—attaining the great enlightenment, the unsurpassable result that is extremely difficult to obtain. It is endowed with the strengths and all the other sublime qualities. It is something to be marveled at compared to the attainments of mundane beings, listeners, and solitary realizers. Once attained, it is eternal, for it exists until the end of saṃsāra. It is stable, for it never deteriorates. It is the refuge of those who have no protection from the torments of saṃsāra, helping them attain nirvāṇa, the end of all their sufferings. And, as has just been mentioned, it is constantly being attained by numerous individuals, one after another, in each second of every day. How utterly amazing that is. And yet, there is nothing at all amazing about it, for those bodhisattvas, fully mature individuals, have aroused bodhicitta, practiced the excellent way of the profound and extensive path—the two accumulations embodied in the six transcendent perfections—and obtained the result. That a sublime cause should give rise to a sublime result is perfectly natural.
gsum pa smin pa'i thabs sna tshogs mdzad pa ni/
(3) THE VARIOUS DEEDS OR MEANS BY WHICH BEINGS ARE BROUGHT TO MATURITY

de ni cig car la lar sgo mang brgya nas chos kyi 'khor lo dang / / la lar skye ba mi snang la lar skye ba'i spyod pa sna tshogs dang / / la lar byang chub thams cad la lar de ni mya ngan 'das ston kyang / / de ni gnas de las kyang rnam par g.yo mi mnga' la thams cad mdzad/ /

A buddha simultaneously displays a variety of deeds— In some places turning the Dharma Wheel in many hundreds of ways, in some taking birth, in others not appearing, In some showing different styles of birth, in some every kind of awakening, and in some the parinirvāṇa, And yet all these are demonstrated without moving from that state. (X, 51)
ces pas bstan te/

sangs rgyas de ni dus cig car ste snga phyi med par yul la lar chos kyi rnam grangs mi 'dra ba'i sgo mang po brgya ste phung khams skye mched rten 'brel bden pas dang phar phyin la sogs pa brjod bya don gyi sgo nas rnam pa sna tshogs pa mang po/ rjod byed tshig gi sgo nas le'u dang tshigs bcad sogs rnam grangs brgya phrag mang po yi chos kyi 'khor lo rab tu bskor ba dang / de dang dus mnyam du zhing khams la lar dga' ldan nas 'phos te 'dzam bu'i gling du skye ba ston pa dang / zhing khams la lar mi snang ba zhes pa mdzad pa bcu gnyis mi ston par byang chub sems dpa'i tshul du ston to/ / zhing khams la lar skye ba'i spyod pa sna tshogs ston pa ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i skyes pa'i rabs kyi spyod pa mdzad pa ste/ 'jig rten gyi khams gcig tu sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa'i spyod pa mdzad de lus dang longs spyod sna tshogs btang bas phan par bsgrub pa dang / de bzhin du tshul khrims dang bzod pa brtson 'grus bsam gtan shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin par spyod pa ston pa dang / skye ba'i gnas bzang ngan bar ma sna tshogs su ston pa'o/ / zhing khams la lar bla na med pa'i byang chub chen po mdzad pa ston pa dang / la lar rang rgyal la lar nyan thos kyi byang chub thob pa'i tshul yang ston te gdul bya 'dul ba'i dbang gis byang chub gsum po thams cad kyang ston to/ blo brtan 'grel na byang chub chen po ston pa zhes gsungs/ zhing khams la lar de ni mya ngan las 'das pa'i tshul ston to/ / mdzad pa de thams cad snga phyi med par dus gcig tu ston kyang / sangs rgyas de ni zag med kyi gnas de bzhin nyid chos kyi dbyings rnam par dag pa de las kyang cung zad g.yo ba mi mnga' la mdzad pa de lta bu thams cad 'bad med lhun gyis grub par mdzad pa yin no/ /

Buddhas simultaneously—that is, not sequentially—display a whole variety of deeds. In some places they turn the wheel of the Dharma, which comprises many hundreds of different approaches or teachings—that is, many varied subjects (the aggregates, sense spheres, and senses-and-fields, dependent arising, the truths, levels, transcendent perfections, and so forth) in many hundreds of different formulations (chapters, verses, and the like). At the same time, in some buddha fields, they demonstrate the deed of descending from the Tuṣita heaven and taking birth in Jambudvīpa; in other buddha fields they “do not appear,” meaning that they do not demonstrate the twelve deeds of a buddha but assume the guise of a bodhisattva. In some buddha fields they demonstrate the various deeds of birth, the activities of the bodhisattva’s series of lives. In certain worlds they benefit beings by practicing transcendent generosity, giving away their various bodies and possessions. Similarly, they demonstrate the practices of transcendent discipline, patience, diligence, concentration, and wisdom. And they demonstrate a variety of modes of birth—good, bad, and neither good nor bad. In some buddha fields they display the deed of attaining unsurpassable great enlightenment, in some they demonstrate attaining the solitary realizers’ enlightenment, and in others the listeners’ enlightenment, demonstrating all three forms of enlightenment depending on the different beings to be trained. Sthiramati says in his commentary that they demonstrate great enlightenment. In some buddha fields they demonstrate passing into nirvāṇa. Although they display all these deeds simultaneously, and not sequentially, the buddhas never move even the slightest bit from the perfectly pure expanse of reality, the untainted state, suchness. These deeds are all performed effortlessly and spontaneously.
bzhi pa smin par mdzad pa la rnam rtog med pa ni/
(4) NONCONCEPTUALITY IN MATURING BEINGS

sangs rgyas rnams ni 'di snyam lus can 'di ni bdag gis smin byas she'am/ / 'di ni rab tu smin bya gzhan yang da ltar smin par byed snyam du/ / 'du mdzad mi mnga' bar yang phyogs phyogs kun tu rtag par sgo gsum nas/ / dge ba'i chos rnams kyis ni skye bo rab tu smin par 'gyur ba nyid/ /

The buddhas never purposefully think, “I matured those beings,” Or “I will mature those,” or “Now I’m maturing these.” Yet constantly in all directions through the three approaches, They will bring beings to perfect maturity through virtuous practice. (X, 52)
ces pas bstan te/

sangs rgyas rnams ni 'di snyam du lus can 'di dag ni bdag gis sngar smin par byas so zhes pas/ 'di ni ma 'ongs pa na smin par bya'o zhes dang / gzhan yang 'di ni da ltar smin par byed snyam du/ mngon par 'du mdzad pa'i 'bad rtsol rnam rtog mi mnga' ba yang phyogs nyi tshe ba min par phyogs dang phyogs mu med pa kun tu dus phyi ma'i mtha'i bar du rtag par theg pa'i sgo gsum char nas zag pa med pa'i dge ba'i chos rnams kyis ni skye bo dpag tu med pa smin par 'gyur ba nyid do/ /

The buddhas do not make a deliberate effort and think, “In the past, I brought those beings to maturity”; “These ones I shall bring to maturity in the future”; and “At present, I am maturing these ones.” And yet, boundlessly in all directions without restriction, constantly until the end of time, they will use the different approaches of the three vehicles to bring infinite beings to maturity through the practice of untainted virtue.
lnga pa phyogs lhung med pa ni/
(5) IMPARTIALITY IN MATURING BEINGS

ji ltar nyi ma 'bad med phyogs phyogs kun tu 'od zer dag / rab 'byams gsal ba mang pos lo tog rnam smin byed pa ltar/ / de bzhin chos ldan nyi ma'ang rab zhi byed pa chos kyi 'od/ / rab 'byams dag gis phyogs phyogs kun tu sems can rnam smin mdzad/ /

Just as the sun, with its many rays shining in all directions throughout the universe, Effortlessly ripens all the numerous crops, The sun of the Dharma, with the universal light of the teachings bringing perfect peace, Brings sentient beings everywhere to maturity. (X, 53)
ces pas bstan te/

ji ltar nyi ma 'di yis 'bad pa med bzhin dang phyogs gcig ma yin pa phyogs phyogs kun tu 'od zer dag rab 'byams gsal ba mang pos lo tog mang po rnam par smin par byed pa ltar/ de bzhin gsung rab yan lag bcu gnyis kyi chos tshad med pa dang ldan pa'i sangs rgyas nyi ma'ang sdug bsngal thams cad rab tu zhi ba mya ngan las 'das pa'i lam ston par byed pa yi chos kyi 'od rab 'byams dag gis phyogs dang phyogs tshad med pa kun tu sems can rnams phyogs lhung med par rnam par smin par mdzad pa yin no/ /

The sun, with its many rays of light shining throughout the universe, not just in one direction but everywhere, ripens numerous crops, effortlessly. In the same way, the sun of the enlightened state, endowed with the countless teachings of the Twelve Branches of Excellent Speech, impartially brings beings in all the boundless regions of the universe to maturity with the universal light of the Dharma that shows the way to nirvāṇa, the state in which all suffering has been completely removed.
drug pa gcig nas gcig tu brgyud de smin pa ni/
(6) MATURING BEINGS IN A CHAIN REACTION
