ji ltar mar me gcig las mar me'i tshogs rab mang / / dpag med grangs med 'byung yang de la zad pa med/ / de bzhin smin pa gcig las smin pa'i tshogs rab mang / / grangs med dpag med 'byung yang de la zad pa med/ /
Just as from a single lamp many countless, infinite lamps Are lit and yet it does not go out, From one mature being many countless, infinite maturations Occur, yet that being is never spent. (X, 54)
ces pas bstan te/

ji ltar mar me gcig las spar ba'i mar me'i tshogs rab tu mang po blo dpag tu med pa dag gis grangs bgrang du med pa 'byung yang / mar me snga ma de las mang po 'phel bas zad pa med pa de bzhin mthar thug par smin pa'i sangs rgyas gcig las smin pa'i tshogs byang chub sems dpa' re res kyang mang po smin zhing / des smin par byas pa de dag gis kyang gzhan mang po gcig nas gcig tu brgyud de phyi ma'i mtha'i bar du smin par byed pas smin pa grangs med dpag med 'byung yang sangs rgyas de la smin pa zad pa med de de ltar smin par rgyun nam yang zad pa med do

Although one would lose count of the great many lamps that are to be lit from a single lamp, that first lamp does not go out as more and more are lit. Similarly, from a single buddha who has attained ultimate maturity there arise a host of mature bodhisattvas, each of whom brings many beings to maturity, and those matured beings again bring others to maturity, one after another in succession, until the end of time, so that there occur infinite, countless maturations. And yet the buddha’s maturation is never spent; such a stream of maturation never comes to an end.
bdun pa ngoms pa med cing 'phel 'bri med la rgyun mi 'chad pa'i tshul ni/
(7) HOW MATURATION CONTINUES UNCEASINGLY WITHOUT EVER REACHING A SUFFICIENCY AND WITHOUT INCREASE OR DIMINUTION

ji ltar rgya mtsho chen po 'di ni chu yis ngoms par mi 'gyur zhing / / chu chen mang po rab tu 'bab pas 'phel bar yang ni mi 'gyur ba/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas khams kyang dag pa 'jug pa rtag rgyun mi 'chad pas/ / ngoms pa mi mnga' 'phel bar mi 'gyur de 'dir rmad du byung ba'i mchog /

Just as the great ocean can never have enough water Nor does it grow larger from the many great rivers flowing into it, The realm of enlightenment never has enough of the constant and unceasing Stream of pure beings entering it and grows no bigger—this is the greatest wonder in this world. (X, 55)
ces pas bstan te/

ji ltar phyi yi rgya mtsho chen po 'di ni phyogs so so'i chu klung dang chu phran sna tshogs rtag tu rgyun mi 'chad par babs kyang chu yis chog pa dang ngoms par mi 'gyur zhing rtag tu de rnams 'bab pa la go 'byed pa dang / chu chen mang po rab tu 'babs pas je mang du 'phel bas yang ni mi 'gyur ba de bzhin sangs rgyas kyi khams sam dbyings de bzhin nyid zag pa med pa dag kyang / sgrib pa dag pa nyan rang byang sems dpag tu med pa mya ngan las 'das pa rnams 'jug pa dus rtag tu rgyun mi chad pas ngoms pa mi mnga' la 'phel bar mi 'gyur ba de lta bu ni 'dir ngo mtshar rmad du byung ba'i mchog go / zhes so/ /

Although many kinds of rivers and streams flow from all directions into the great outer ocean,[26] constantly and unceasingly, for the ocean there can never be enough, and there is always room for the rivers to flow in. And however many great rivers flow into it, it will never grow larger. In the same way, for the realm or expanse of the enlightened state, the untainted state, suchness, there will never be enough of the infinite number of listeners, solitary realizers, and bodhisattvas whose obscurations have been purified and who are constantly and unceasingly entering nirvāṇa, and yet it will not grow larger. This is the most amazing and wondrous thing in this world.
[yon tan de ldan gyi byang chub nyid ngo bo rgyu 'bras sogs rnam bzhag rnam pa drug gis bshad pa]
b. A PRESENTATION OF GREAT ENLIGHTENMENT IN TERMS OF SIX ASPECTS

de ltar byang chub chen po yon tan gyi rnam grangs bcu'i sgo nas bstan pa'i rjes su/ yon tan de ldan gyi byang chub chen po nyid ngo bo sogs rnam bzhag drug gi sgo nas bshad pa la/ dngos dang / 'jug pa bye brag tu bshad pa gnyis/

The above description of great enlightenment in terms of its ten different qualities is now followed by a presentation of the great enlightenment that possesses those qualities, explained in terms of six aspects, beginning with its nature.[27] This is divided into (1) the actual presentation and (2) a specific explanation of its manifestations.
dang po/
i. THE ACTUAL PRESENTATION

tshigs bcad bzhi po 'di'i don mdor bsdus na chos kyi dbyings shin tu rnam par dag pa bstan pa yin pas 'di dang po bshad nas/ de nas me long lta bu la sogs pa ye shes bzhi bshad pa des/ 'phags pa sangs rgyas kyi sa las/ sangs rgyas kyi sa ni chos lngas bsdus te/ chos kyi dbyings rnam par dag pa dang / me long lta bu'i ye shes dang / mnyam pa nyid kyi ye shes dang / so sor kun tu rtog pa'i ye shes dang / bya ba grub pa'i ye shes zhes gsungs pa bzhin du bstan bcos 'di las de'i don mdor bsdus nas gtan la 'bebs par mdzad do/ /

Since the next four verses, in summary, describe the utterly pure expanse of reality, it is this that is explained first, followed by an explanation of the four kinds of gnosis, beginning with mirrorlike gnosis. This accords with the order in the Sūtra on Buddhahood, which states, “Buddhahood embodies five elements: the perfectly pure expanse of reality, mirrorlike gnosis, the gnosis of equality, all-discerning gnosis, and all-accomplishing gnosis.” These are thus established in this treatise by the following summary.
chos rnams kun gyi de bzhin nyid/ / sgrib gnyis dag pa'i mtshan nyid de/ / dngos dang nges dmigs shes pa la/ / dbang zad mi shes mtshan nyid do/ /
Its nature is the suchness of all phenomena Purified of the two obscurations. Its nature is inexhaustible power With regard to knowing the object and focusing on that knowledge. (X, 56)
ces

de yang 'di ltar shes bya 'dus byas dang 'dus ma byas dang zag bcas zag med du gtogs pa'i chos rnams kyi rang bzhin stong pa nyid mtha' thams cad bral ba ni de bzhin nyid ces bya ste/ gnas lugs ma nor ba yang dag pa'i mtha' dang don dam pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de bzhin nyid kyi rang bzhin du gyur pa la khyad par gang yang med mod kyi/ chos can sna tshogs pa'i sgo nas chos zhes bya'o/ / sangs rgyas dang sems can gyi de bzhin nyid la khyad par tha dad du gyur pa med kyang / rang snang phyin ci log glo bur ba'i dri am dang bcas pa sems can gyi rgyud kyi de bzhin nyid la dri bcas de bzhin nyid ces bya'o/ / sgrib pa glo bur ba spang rung yin zhing chos nyid nam yang 'pho 'gyur med pa yin pas/ nam zhig sems can so so'i rgyud kyi nyon mongs pa dang / shes bya'i sgrib pa gnyis yongs su dag pa'i dus na chos kyi dbyings shin tu rnam par dag pa'i mtshan nyid de ni sangs rgyas kyi byang chub ces bya'o/ / 'dis de bzhin nyid gnas gyur pa bstan to/ /

The nature of all knowable phenomena—compounded, uncompounded, tainted, and untainted—is emptiness free of all extremes, and this is what we call suchness. It is their unmistaken actual condition, the ultimately authentic, the ultimate truth. Within the nature of suchness, there are no differences whatsoever, but in terms of the various conditioned phenomena that have that nature we nevertheless speak of “phenomena.” And although there is no difference between the suchness of the buddhas and that of sentient beings, we refer to the suchness in the mind streams of beings, with their adventitious contaminants of mistaken perception, as “suchness with contaminants.” Since the adventitious obscurations can be eliminated and the ultimate reality never changes, when the defilement-related and cognitive obscurations in the mind stream of an individual being are completely purified, that nature, the utterly pure expanse of reality, is what we call the Buddha’s enlightenment. These first two lines indicate the transformation of suchness.

byang chub pa de yang mnyam bzhag tu chos kyi dbyings rnam par dag pa de nyid kyi dngos po la dmigs pa rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyi dbang mi zad pa thob pa dang / rjes thob ye shes kyis rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes de la dmigs pa'i dbang zad mi shes pa thob pa'o/ / de yang rjes thob kyis mi rtog ye shes de'i tshul phyin ci ma log par shes par byed do/ / blo brtan 'grel pa'i 'gyur ltar na dngos po shes pa de la dmigs zhes dngos po kun gzhi rnam shes gzhan dbang gi mtshan nyid gnas gyur pa'i mi rtog ye shes de rjes thob ye shes kyis yang dag par shes zhes dang / de la dmigs zhes pa chos kyi dbyings de la rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyis dmigs zhes gsungs pa 'bru 'grel tshul mi 'dra yang don 'dra ste/ dbang mi zad pa gnyis thob pa ni mnyam rjes kyi dbang du byas pa'i ye shes gnyis la 'chad pas so/ / mdor na sangs rgyas kyi sa na mnyam rjes res 'jog tu med pas ye shes gcig gis ji ltar gzigs pa rnam par mi rtog pa dang / ji snyed pa gzigs pa rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa yin pas de gnyis kyi dbang zad mi shes pa thob pa'i mtshan nyid yin no/ / zhes 'dod do/ / de ltar na chos nyid dang chos can tha mi dad pa yin phyir/ gnas 'gyur mthar thug gi skabs na chos nyid ji lta ba bzhin du gzigs pa las ma g.yos bzhin du chos can ji snyed pa'ang 'bad med lhun grub tu mkhyen pa'i mkhyen pa gnyis la dbang 'byor ba'i ngo bo nyid kyi sku'am chos sku ni byang chub chen po'i mtshan nyid yin pas 'di ni byang chub chen po'i ngo bo'o/ /

That enlightened being acquires the inexhaustible power of nonconceptual gnosis which, in meditative equipoise, takes as its object that same perfectly pure expanse of reality; and he or she acquires the inexhaustible power of focusing with the postmeditational gnosis on that nonconceptual gnosis. That postmeditational gnosis knows unmistakenly the mode of the nonconceptual gnosis. The translation of this line in Sthiramati’s commentary is “Knowing the object and focusing on it,” meaning that the object, the nonconceptual gnosis that is the transformed nature of the dependent reality, the consciousness of the ground of all, is correctly known with the postmeditational gnosis; “focusing on it” means focusing on the expanse of reality with nonconceptual gnosis. The way of commenting word-for-word here is different, but the meaning is the same: the attainment of the double inexhaustible power is explained as two kinds of gnosis, referring to meditation and postmeditation. In short, because on the level of buddhahood there is no alternation of meditation and postmeditation, with a single gnosis there is the nonconceptual vision of the nature of phenomena and the omniscient knowledge that sees all phenomena in their multiplicity, and this is held to be its nature, the attainment of inexhaustible power in these two. There is, therefore, no difference between phenomena and their true nature, the ultimate reality. At the stage of ultimate transformation, without moving from the vision of the true nature of phenomena as it is, one also spontaneously and effortlessly knows all phenomena in their multiplicity. This mastery of the two kinds of knowledge, which is the body of the essential nature (svabhāvikakāya) or body of truth, is a characteristic of the great enlightenment. All this is the nature of great enlightenment.
de bzhin nyid shes thams cad nas/ / bsgoms pa las ni yang dag 'byung / / sems can kun la rnam kun tu/ / gnyis skyed mi zad 'bras bu can/ /
Through knowledge of suchness and meditation, Using all kinds of means, enlightenment occurs And bears inexhaustible fruit, Forever giving rise to the two for all that lives. (X, 57)

byang chub chen po de 'thob byed dam mngon du byed pa'i rgyu ni/ theg pa chen po'i mdo las stong nyid bstan pa ltar de bzhin nyid de thos bsam bsgoms pas gtan la phab nas mos spyod kyi sar tshogs gnyis bsags pa'i sgo nas bsgom par byas pas de bzhin nyid mngon sum shes pa 'jig rten 'das pa'i ye shes dang por skyes pa sa dang po thob nas de'i rjes su sa bcu'i rgyun mtha'i bar du thabs sna tshogs kyi sgo thams cad nas bsgom pa las ni yang dag par byung ba'o/ / byang chub kyi 'bras bu ni mtha' yas pa'i sems can kun la dus rnam pa thams cad du 'phral dang yun gyi phan pa dang bde ba gnyis skyed pa yin la de yang 'khor ba'i mtha' ci tsam pa de srid du mi zad pa'i 'bras bu can zhes so/ /

The cause that makes one attain or realize great enlightenment is as follows. By hearing about, reflecting on, and meditating on suchness in accordance with the teachings on emptiness in the Mahāyāna sūtras, one determines it conclusively. Subsequently, by accumulating merit and wisdom on the level of earnest aspiration, and by meditating, one first gives rise to supramundane gnosis, the direct knowledge of suchness, and attains the first bodhisattva level. After that, meditation, using all the different kinds of methods up until the end of the tenth level, leads correctly to enlightenment. The result of enlightenment is the production of both immediate benefit and long-term happiness at all times for the infinity of sentient beings. And it bears inexhaustible fruit for as long as saṃsāra lasts.
sku dang gsung dang thugs sprul pa'i/ / sbyor ba'i thabs kyi las can te/ / ting nge 'dzin dang gzungs sgo dang / / dpag tu med pa gnyis dang ldan/ /
Active in the skillful application Of manifestation through body, speech, and mind, Enlightenment possesses infinite concentrations, Powers of retention, and the two. (X, 58)

de bzhin du las ni kun snang ba dang gsung gis chos ston pa dang thugs kyis byin gyis brlabs pa'i sprul pa'i las sam sbyor ba'i thabs kyi byed las can ni/ sku sprul pa'i sbyor ba'i thabs kyi las ni sangs rgyas kyi 'dul ba sangs rgyas su ston pa nas lha dang klu sogs sna tshogs pa'i lus su sprul pa'o/ / de bzhin gsung gis dngos su'am nam mkha' dang rtsig pa dang shing sogs las chos kyi sgra 'byung ba'am/ thugs kyis byin brlabs pas blun pos kyang chos zab mo'i don rtogs pa dang / shA ri'i bu dang rab 'byor sogs byin gyis brlabs nas shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa 'chad du bcug pa lta bu'o/ / sbyor ba zhes pa las dang thabs zhes pa sprul pa de byed pa'i thabs mkhyen pa'am/ yang na thabs ni sprul pa'i las de sems can 'dul ba'i thabs su gyur pa'o/ / dpa' bar 'gro ba dang / nam mkha' mdzod la sogs pa ting nge 'dzin dpag tu med pa dang mi zad pa'i za ma tog dang sgo mtha' yas pa la sogs pa gsungs kyi sgo dpag tu med pa dang / bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs dpag tu med pa gnyis dang ldan pa ni ldan pa'i don te/ gzungs dang ting 'dzin tshogs gnyis dpag med dang ldan pa'o/ /

Similarly, the activity of great enlightenment lies in its function of skillful methods of activity or application in manifestation—appearing physically, verbally teaching the Dharma, and mentally conferring blessings. The skillfully applied activity of physical manifestation is appearance as a buddha to benefit beings and manifestation in all kinds of bodies such as those of gods and nāgas. Likewise, there is the skillfully applied activity of verbal manifestation, the sound of the Dharma arising directly, or from the sky, walls, trees, and so forth; and the activity of mental manifestation, whereby, through the Buddha’s blessings, even the dull-witted could understand the meaning of the profound teachings, and Śāriputra, Subhūti, and others were inspired to expound the Perfection of Wisdom. “Application” here means activity; “skillful” refers to knowledge of the means for performing such manifestations, or alternatively to the activity of manifestation becoming the means for training beings. Great enlightenment possesses infinite concentrations such as the concentration of Brave Progression and the Sky Treasury concentration; infinite powers of retention,[28] such as Inexhaustible Caskets and Infinite Doors; and both the infinite accumulations—those of merit and wisdom. Its properties, then, are infinite powers of retention, concentrations, and twofold accumulations.
rang bzhin chos rdzogs longs spyod dang / / sprul pa dag gis tha dad du/ / 'jug pa 'di ni sangs rgyas kyi/ / chos dbyings rnam par dag par bshad/ /
It is distinguished as the nature, The perfect enjoyment of the teachings, and the manifestation. All this describes the perfectly pure Expanse of reality of the enlightened state. (X, 59)

dbye ba ni ngo bo'i cha nas rang bzhin nam chos kyi sku dang / snang ba'i cha nas theg chen gyi chos la rdzogs par longs spyod pa'i sku dang / gzhan don gyi bya ba byed pa'i cha nas sprul pa yi sku dag gis tha dad du 'jug pa dang rnam par bzhag pa drug gis bstan pa 'di ni sangs rgyas kyi chos kyi dbyings rnam par dag par bshad de/ chos kyi dbyings rnam par dag pa'i byang chub chen po nyid ngo bo la sogs pa drug gi sgo nas gtan la phab pa'i phyir ro/ /

The categories of great enlightenment are distinguished as the natural body or body of truth, from the point of view of its essential nature; the body of perfect enjoyment of the Mahāyāna teachings, from the point of view of its appearance; and the body of manifestation, from the point of view of its activity for others’ benefit. This presentation in terms of these six aspects describes the perfectly pure expanse of reality of the enlightened state, for it determines great enlightenment, the perfectly pure expanse of reality, in terms of its nature and the other five topics.
gnyis pa 'jug pa'am dbye ba'i don
ii. A SPECIFIC EXPLANATION OF ITS MANIFESTATIONS
bye brag tu bshad pa la/ rten sku gsum bshad pa/ brten pa ye shes bzhi bshad pa gnyis/
The specific explanation is divided into (1) an explanation of the supports, the three buddha bodies, and (2) an explanation of the four kinds of gnosis that are supported.
dang po
(1) AN EXPLANATION OF THE SUPPORTS, THE THREE BUDDHA BODIES
['di] la/ mdor bstan/ rgyas bshad gnyis/
The first of these is further divided into a brief introduction and a detailed explanation.
dang po/
(a) BRIEF INTRODUCTION
sangs rgyas rnams kyi sku dbye ba/ / rang bzhin longs spyod rdzogs pa dang / / gzhan ni sprul pa'i sku yin te/ / dang po gnyis po'i rten yin no/ /
The bodies of the buddhas are classified as The natural body, the body of perfect enjoyment, And another, the body of manifestation. The first is the basis for the other two. (X, 60)
zhes pas bstan te/

sangs rgyas rnams kyi sku yi dbye bar rang bzhin gyi sku ni chos sku ste/ nam kun gzhi rnam shes la yod pa'i gzung 'dzin gyi dri ma spangs nas chos kyi dbyings ji bzhin gzigs pa me long lta bu'i ye shes su gyur pa'o/ / de bzhin nyid kyi cha nas rang bzhin nam ngo bo nyid sku dang ye shes kyi cha nas chos sku zhes gsungs pa de gnyis chos can dang chos nyid dbyer med pa yin phyir gang ltar bshad kyang zung 'jug gi gnas lugs nyid shin tu rnam par dag pa mngon du gyur pa la 'dzin dgos kyi snang cha stong cha ya bral go mi rung ba ni spyir gzhung thams cad kyi dgongs don dam pa yin no/ / longs spyod rdzogs pa'i sku ni nam nyon mongs pa'i yid gnas 'gyur te mnyam nyid ye shes su gyur pa dang / yid shes sor rtog ye shes su gnas gyur pa gang zhig sa la zhugs pa'i byang sems rnams la theg pa chen po'i chos kyi longs spyod rdzogs par mdzad pa dang / sku de las gzhan pa ni sprul pa'i sku yin te/ nam sgo lnga'i rnam shes gnas 'gyur nas dga' ldan nas 'phos pa sogs bstan pa'i sgo nas 'dzam gling gi sems can sogs smin par mdzad pa'o/ / dang po chos sku ni phyi ma gzugs sku gnyis po'i rten nam gzhi yin te shin tu rnam par dag pa'i byang chub chen po de las dag pa dang ma dag pa'i gdul bya la sku gnyis su snang ba'i phyir ro/ /

The buddhas’ bodies (kāyas) are categorized as follows. The “natural body” is the body of truth (dharmakāya). When the contaminants related to subject and object present in the consciousness of the ground of all are eliminated, the latter is transformed into the mirrorlike gnosis that beholds the expanse of reality as it is. From the point of view of suchness, it is spoken of as the natural or essential body, and from the point of view of gnosis it is referred to as the body of truth. These two are the ultimate nature and phenomena inseparable, and therefore, whichever way it is explained, this buddha body should be understood to be the realization of the utterly pure fundamental nature, which is union.[29] We should not understand it as the appearance aspect on its own. This is, in general, the sublime intended meaning of all the scriptures. As for the body of perfect enjoyment (saṃbhogakāya), when the defiled mind consciousness is transformed into the gnosis of equality and the mind consciousness is transformed into all-discerning gnosis, this body enables bodhisattvas who have entered the bodhisattva levels to have full enjoyment of the Mahāyāna teachings. There is another buddha body apart from these—the manifestation body (nirmāṇakāya), which results from the transformation of the five sense consciousnesses and brings to maturity the beings of Jambudvīpa and elsewhere by displaying transmigration from the Tuṣita heaven and other such deeds. The first, the body of truth, is the support or basis of these last two, which comprise the form body. From that utterly pure great enlightenment the two buddha bodies appear to pure and impure beings destined to be trained.
rgyas bshad
(b) DETAILED EXPLANATION
[rgyas bshad] la sku gsum so sor bshad pa dang / bsdu ba dang mnyam pa/ rtag pa gsum bshad pa gnyis las
The detailed explanation has two parts: (1) individual explanations of the three buddha bodies and (2) an explanation of the inclusiveness, equality, and eternity of the buddha bodies.
dang po/
(i) INDIVIDUAL EXPLANATIONS OF THE THREE BUDDHA BODIES
longs spyod rdzogs pa yi sku ni
1. THE BODY OF PERFECT ENJOYMENT
longs spyod rdzogs pa khams kun tu/ / 'khor yongs sdud dang zhing dang mtshan/ / sku dang chos rdzogs longs spyod dang / / mdzad pa dag gis tha dad do/ /
In all worlds the body of perfect enjoyment Varies on account of its retinues, Buddha fields, names, bodies, Enjoyment of the teachings, and activities. (X, 61)
zhes pas bstan te/

yongs su dag pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams kun tu/ 'khor gyi byang sems yongs su sdud pa tha dad de byang chub sems dpa' mtshan tha dad du ma'i 'khor mi 'dra ba dang / zhing khams kyang shel dang gser dang baiDUr+ya la sogs pa'i kha dog dang / rnam pa tha dad mtshan kyang tha dad de/ rnam par snang mdzad dang / snang ba mtha' yas la sogs pa bzhin no/ / sku yang tha dad de kha cig sku mdog dkar po/ la la ser po la sogs par snang bas so/ / chos la rdzogs par longs spyad pa yang kha cig tu shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa/ kha cig gis sa bcu pa sogs theg chen gyi chos rnam grangs sna tshogs 'chad pa'o/ / mdzad pa yang gdul bya'i bsam pa'i dbang gis la las sku che bar mthong la las chung bar mthong / de bzhin kha dog sogs dang chos kyang gdul bya'i bsam pa dang mthun pa'i theg chen ston pa la sogs pa dag gis rnam pa tha dad par snang ba yin gyi gcig tu ma nges so/ /

In all completely pure worlds there are gathered different retinues of bodhisattvas—that is, different retinues of many differently named bodhisattvas. The buddha fields too have different aspects and colors (crystal, gold, beryl, and so on) and different names. Take, for example, the buddha fields of Vairocana, Amitābha, and other buddhas. Their bodies too are different in appearance: some are white in color, others yellow, and so on. As for the full enjoyment of the teachings, they explain a whole variety of different Mahāyāna subjects: some explain transcendent wisdom, others the ten levels, and so forth. And with regard to their activities, some disciples, depending on their attitudes, see them as physically huge, while some see them as quite small. The same is true with regard to their colors and to the teachings they give in accord with their disciples’ aspirations. In all these respects, the body of perfect enjoyment appears variously, never in a single, definite form.
gnyis pa/
2. THE NATURAL BODY OR BODY OF TRUTH
rang bzhin sku ni mnyam pa dang / / phra zhing de dang 'brel ba dang / / dgyes dgur longs spyod bstan pa la/ / longs spyod rdzogs 'byor rgyur 'dod do/ /
The natural body is uniform, Subtle, and related to the latter body; It manifests enjoyments however they may be desired And so is held to be the cause of the wealth of perfect enjoyment. (X, 62)
zhes pas bstan te/

rang bzhin chos kyi sku ni thams cad du tha dad med par gcig tu mnyam pa ste/ dag pa gnyis ldan chos dbyings shin tu rnam dag gi rang bzhin las mi mthun par snang ba med pa'o/ / phra zhing zhes pa nyan rang sogs kyi spyod yul du ma gyur pa'i phyir ro/ / longs spyod rdzogs pa'i sku de dang 'brel ba de chos sku de longs skur snang ba'i rgyu yin pas so/ / ji ltar yin na chos kyi sku'i rgyu mthun pa las longs sku byung nas sa la zhugs pas byang sems rnams theg pa chen po'i chos la dgyes dgur te 'dod dgur longs spyod par bstan pa la longs sku de ni byang sems de dag gis chos la longs spyod rdzogs par 'byor ba'am nus pa'i rgyur 'dod de longs sku'i 'khor du yod pa'i byang sems de rnams kyi yid la theg pa chen po'i chos mtha' dag rdzogs par longs sku des mdzad pa'i phyir ro/ / ji ltar na phyi'i longs spyod zhing yongs su dag pa dang nang gi longs spyod theg pa chen po'i chos de gnyis dgyes dgur longs spyod pa'i don de longs skus mdzad pa'i slad du'o/ /

The natural body of truth is entirely uniform and undifferentiated: there is no appearance that is incompatible with the nature of the utterly pure expanse of reality possessed of the two purities. It is “subtle,” because it is not within the domain of listeners, solitary realizers, and the like. It is related to the body of perfect enjoyment in that the body of truth is the causal factor for appearance as the body of perfect enjoyment. In what way? The body of perfect enjoyment having arisen from the cause, as it were,[30] that is the body of truth, it manifests as enjoyment, in any way that is desired, of the Mahāyāna teachings for bodhisattvas who have entered the levels. So that body of perfect enjoyment is held to be the cause of those bodhisattvas attaining the wealth of perfect enjoyment or being able to perfectly enjoy the teachings, because it is through the body of perfect enjoyment that all the Mahāyāna teachings are complete in the minds of those bodhisattvas present in the retinue of the body of perfect enjoyment. How? The enjoyment in whatever way is desired of both the outer enjoyments (the perfectly pure buddha field) and the inner enjoyments (the teachings of the Great Vehicle) is brought about by the body of perfect enjoyment.
gsum pa sangs rgyas kyi sprul pa yi sku ni/
3. THE BUDDHA’S MANIFESTATION BODY

sangs rgyas sprul pa dpag med pa/ / sprul pa'i skur ni 'dod pa ste/ / don gnyis phun sum tshogs pa ni/ / rnam pa thams cad gnyis la gnas/ / bzo dang skye dang byang chub che/ / mya ngan 'das pa rtag ston pas/ / sangs rgyas sprul pa'i sku 'di ni/ / rnam par grol ba'i thabs chen no/ /

The boundless manifestations of the enlightened state Are held to be the manifestation body. The fulfillment of the twofold goal Rests entirely on the two. (X, 63) By constantly displaying artistic expression, Birth, great enlightenment, and the parinirvāṇa, The Buddha’s manifestation bodies Are the great means for liberating beings. (X, 64)
zhes pas bstan te/

gang la gang 'dul du sprul pa dpag tu med pa de thams cad sprul pa'i skur ni 'dod pa ste mchog gi sprul sku 'ba' zhig tu ma zad lha la sogs pa 'gro ba so so'i gzugs su sprul pa'ang sprul pa'i sku yin zhes bya'o/ / rang gi don phun tshogs dang gzhan don phun tshogs te de ltar don gnyis phun sum tshogs pa ni/ rnam pa thams cad dam rnam pa kun tu longs sku dang sprul sku gnyis la gnas te/ sangs rgyas kyi bdag don mthar phyin nas yongs su dag pa'i zhing du 'khor dag pa rnams la theg pa chen po'i chos kyi dga' ston spel ba'i rnam pa rtag tu bzhugs pa gzugs sku'i mthar thug longs sku yin pa'i phyir dang / sprul pa'i skus gzhan sems can ma dag pa rnams smin par byed pas gzhan don phun tshogs mdzad pa'o/ / 'di gtso che ba'i cha nas brjod pa'o/ / chos kyi sku ni rang don gzhan don tha dad du 'byed pa med de/ don gnyis phun tshogs kyi sku gnyis 'byung ba'i rten yin la/ sprul pa'i skus gzhan don byed tshul gyi dbye ba ni/ bzo ston pa dang / skye ba ston pa dang / mngon par byang chub chen po ston pa dang / mya ngan las 'das par ston pa bzhi phyi ma'i bar du rtag tu ston pas na sangs rgyas sprul pa'i sku 'di nyid sems can rnams mya ngan las 'das pa'i dbyings su rnam par grol ba'i thabs chen por gyur pa yin no/ / bzo ba ston pa shing mkhan rdza mkhan pi waM mkhan sogs bzo ston pa'o/ / skye ba dga' ldan nas 'phos te rgyal rigs dang bram ze'i rigs sogs su skye ba'o/ / byang chub chen po ni sangs rgyas pa dang / mthar mya ngan las 'das pa ston pa'o zhes blo brtan gsungs te gong du'ang bshad zin to/ /

All the infinite manifestations that benefit beings in whatever ways are appropriate are held to be the manifestation body. This does not refer only to the supreme nirmāṇakāya manifestation. Manifestations in the form of different kinds of beings such as gods are also said to be the manifestation body. The fulfillment of the two goals—that is, the fulfillment of one’s own goal and fulfillment of others’ goal—depends entirely and at all times on the two buddha bodies: the body of perfect enjoyment and the manifestation body. Having finally attained one’s own goal, buddhahood, one constantly dwells in perfectly pure buddha fields propagating the feast-like teachings of the Great Vehicle to pure retinues. This, the ultimate reach of the form body, is the body of enjoyment. And in bringing other, impure beings to maturity by means of the manifestation body, one fulfills others’ goals. This is expressed in terms of the principal aspects.[31] In the body of truth there is no distinction between one’s own and others’ good: it is the basis for the arising of the two buddha bodies for the fulfillment of the two goals. The manifestation body, on the other hand, has four categories, based on the ways in which it benefits others: constantly, until the end of time, it displays manifestations of art, birth, great enlightenment, and parinirvāṇa. The manifestation-body buddhas are thus the great means for liberating beings in the expanse of nirvāṇa. They manifest in art by appearing as artisans such as joiners, potters, and musicians. They manifest in birth by descending from the Tuṣita heaven and taking birth in royal or priestly families, and so forth. They manifest great enlightenment by demonstrating the attainment of buddhahood, and the parinirvāṇa by demonstrating the final nirvāṇa, as Sthiramati describes. This has also been explained above.[32]
gnyis pa/
(ii) AN EXPLANATION OF THE INCLUSIVENESS, EQUALITY, AND ETERNITY OF THE BUDDHA BODIES
sku gsum dag gis sangs rgyas kyi/ / sku bsdus par ni shes bya ste/ / sku gsum dag gis rang gzhan gyi/ / don 'di rten dang bcas par bstan/ /
Know that the bodies of the buddhas Are included in the three buddha bodies. The three bodies are taught as being the fulfillments Of one’s own and others’ goals along with their basis. (X, 65)
ces pas bstan te/

sku gsum po dag gis sangs rgyas thams cad kyi sku bsdus par ni shes par bya ste/ sku gsum po de dag gis rang dang gzhan don byed pa longs sku sprul sku gnyis dang / de gnyis kyi gzhi rten chos sku dang bcas pa bstan pa yin pas/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyi chos sku gcig tu bsdu ba dang / longs sku dpag tu med pa rnams longs skur bsdu ba dang / sprul sku dpag tu med pa rnams sprul pa'i skur bsdus pas sku gsum du ma 'dus pa med do/ /

The bodies of all the buddhas are to be understood as being included in the three buddha bodies. These three buddha bodies refer to the body of perfect enjoyment and the manifestation body, which accomplish one’s own and others’ goals, and the body of truth, which is the basis of these two. The truth body of all the buddhas is a single unity; infinite bodies of enjoyment are included in the body of enjoyment; and infinite bodies of manifestation are included in the body of manifestation. There is nothing that is not included in the three buddha bodies.
de dag rten dang dgongs pa dang / / 'phrin las kyis ni mnyam pa nyid/ / rang bzhin dang ni rgyun mi 'chad/ / rgyun gyis de dag rtag pa nyid/ /
In terms of basis, intention, And activities, they are the same. In terms of nature, incessancy, And continuity, they are eternal. (X, 66)

de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad mnyam pa'o zhes gsungs pa'i don ni sangs rgyas de dag mnyam pa gsum gyis te/ rten nam gnas mnyam pa ni chos dbyings shin tu rnam dag chos skur mnyam zhing tha dad med pa dang / dgongs pa mnyam pa ni longs sku thams cad dgongs pa che chung bzang ngan med kyi thams cad kyang sems can la phan bde mdzad par dgongs pa gcig pa'i phyir ro/ / sprul pa'i sku thams cad phrin las kyis ni sems can 'dul bar mdzad pa mnyam pa dang / sangs rgyas thams cad kyi sprul pa gcig tu 'byung ba sngar bshad pa bzhin no/ / de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi sku rtag pa'o zhes gsungs pa'i don no/ / rtag pa gsum ni chos kyi sku ni rang bzhin gyis skye 'gags med pas ngo bo'am rang bzhin gyis rtag pa dang ni/ longs sku rnams nam yang chos ston pa rgyun mi 'chad pas rtag pa dang / sprul pa'i sku rnams rgyun gyis rtag pa dang / la lar mi snang yang de'i tshe la lar snang ba'i tshul gyis sems can gyi mtha'i bar rgyun gyis 'byung bas rtag pa'o/ / de'i phyir sangs rgyas sku gsum po de dag rtag pa nyid do/ /

It has been taught that all the tathāgatas are equal. This means that the buddhas are the same in three respects: Their basis or abode is the same, for in the body of truth, the utterly pure expanse of reality, they are equal and undifferentiated. Their intentions are equal, for there is no difference in the magnitude or excellence of the intentions of any of the enjoyment-body buddhas. They all have a single intention: to bring benefit and happiness to all sentient beings. And their activities are equal, for the activities of all the manifestation bodies are the same in training beings, and the manifestations of all the buddhas occur together, as explained earlier. It has also been taught that the buddha bodies of all the tathāgatas are eternal. They are eternal in three respects: The body of truth is essentially or naturally eternal because it is by nature devoid of birth and cessation. The enjoyment-body buddhas are eternal in that there is never any interruption in their teaching the Dharma. And the manifestation-body buddhas are eternal in their continuity; they are eternal in that even when they are not visible to some beings, they are visible to others, and in this manner they will appear continuously until the end of saṃsāra.[33] It is for these reasons that the buddhas’ three buddha bodies are said to be eternal.
gnyis pa ye shes bshad pa
(2) AN EXPLANATION OF THE FOUR KINDS OF GNOSIS THAT ARE SUPPORTED
['di] la mdor bstan so sor rgyas par bshad/ ye shes de lta bu 'thob byed kyi rgyu bstan/ sangs rgyas kyi ye shes su lam thams cad mthar thug par bstan pa bzhi las/

This section is divided into four parts: (1) a brief introduction; (2) a detailed explanation of each of the four kinds of gnosis; (3) an explanation of the causes for acquiring the four kinds of gnosis; and (4) an explanation showing that the culmination of all paths is the Buddha’s gnosis.
dang po/
(a) BRIEF INTRODUCTION
me long ye shes mi g.yo ba/ / ye shes gsum ni de la brten/ / mnyam pa nyid dang so sor rtog / bya ba sgrub pa kho na'o/ /
There are only the unmoving mirrorlike gnosis And the three kinds of gnosis based on it— Equalizing, all-discerning, And all-accomplishing. (X, 67)
zhes pas bstan te/

kun gzhi'i rnam shes gnas gyur pa me long lta bu'i ye shes ni chos kyi dbyings rnam par dag pa las rtag tu mi g.yo ba 'khor ba'i mtha'i bar du 'byung ba dang 'jug pa med par gnas pa yin la/ ye shes gsum ni me long lta bu'i ye shes de la gnas shing brten pa yin la 'byung 'jug yod pas g.yo ba'o/ / gsum po gang zhe na nyon mongs pa'i yid gnas gyur pa mnyam pa nyid kyi ye shes dang / yid kyi rnam shes gnas gyur pa so sor kun tu rtog pa'i ye shes dang / dbang po sgo lnga'i rnam shes gnas gyur pa bya ba grub pa yi ye shes gsum mo/ / de ltar tshogs brgyad gnas gyur pa'i ye shes ni bzhi kho na'o/ /

Mirrorlike gnosis, the transformation of the consciousness of the ground of all, never moves from the perfectly pure expanse of reality; it endures until the end of saṃsāra without arising and engaging.[34] The three kinds of gnosis abide in and are dependent on that mirrorlike gnosis, and since they do arise and engage, they are moving. What are these three kinds of gnosis? The defiled mind consciousness transformed, which is the gnosis of equality; the mind consciousness transformed, which is all-discerning gnosis; and the five sense consciousnesses transformed, which is all-accomplishing gnosis. Thus, there are just four kinds of gnosis, the transformations of the eight consciousnesses.
so sor rgyas bshad la bzhi las/
(b) DETAILED EXPLANATION OF EACH OF THE FOUR KINDS OF GNOSIS
[me long ye shes]
(i) MIRRORLIKE GNOSIS
me long ye shes nga yi med/ / yongs su ma chad rtag tu ldan/ / shes bya kun la ma rmongs la/ / rtag tu de la mngon phyogs min/ /
Mirrorlike gnosis is devoid of a sense of possession, Utterly impartial, and ever present; It is not ignorant with regard to all things that can be known, But never directed toward them. (X, 68)
zhes pas bstan te/

me long lta bu'i ye shes la shes bya'i rnam pa thams cad snang yang gzung ba dang 'dzin par rtog pa dang / nga dang bdag tu rtog pa dang / mngon par 'du byed pa'i 'bad rtsol med pas nga yi med pa ste/ dper na me long gi nang gzugs brnyan rnam pa mang po snang yang de me long la de dag grub pa med cing de dag la rtog cing 'du byed pa med pa bzhin no/ / de ni yul dang phyogs kha cig la 'jug kha cig la mi 'jug pa lta bu ma yin pa yul thams cad par ris su ma chad par 'jug pas yongs su ma chad pa'o/ / de ni dus gsum thams cad du 'byung bas rtag tu ldan pa dang / nyon shes kyi sgrib pa gnyis dang bral bas dmigs pa shes bya kun la ma rmongs la ji lta ba bzhin rtogs pa'o/ / rnam pa ni dus rtag tu shes bya de dang de la 'di dang 'di zhes rnam par rtog pas mngon zhen gyis mi 'dzin pas dmigs pa de las mngon du phyogs pa med pa ste snang yang ris chad kyi mtshan ma rnam par mi rtog pa'i phyir ro/ /

In mirrorlike gnosis everything that can be known appears, and yet there are no concepts of subject and object, no “I” and concept of self, and no deliberate effort, and therefore no sense of possession. It is comparable to a mirror in which multiple reflections appear, yet the things reflected have no existence in the mirror; there is no concept of those reflections and no deliberate effort to produce them. It is not as if mirrorlike gnosis penetrates some places and directions and not others. It penetrates all places without bias and is therefore completely impartial. Since it arises throughout the three times, it is ever present. Since it is free of both defilement-related and cognitive obscurations, it is not ignorant with regard to any knowable objects but realizes the nature of things as they are. As for its aspect, since it never apprehends knowable phenomena conceptualizing them as this or that and taking them to be real, it is not directed toward its objects, because although things appear, there are no biased concepts of attributes.
ye shes kun gyi rgyu mtshan phyir/ / ye shes 'byung gnas chen po 'dra/ / longs spyod rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas nyid/ / ye shes gzugs brnyan 'byung ba'i phyir/ /
Because it is the cause of all kinds of gnosis, It is like a great mine of gnosis. It is the enjoyment body itself, For the other kinds of gnosis appear as reflections in it. (X, 69)

ye shes gzhan kun gyi rgyu mtshan te rgyu yin pa'i phyir/ ye shes rin po che thams cad kyi 'byung gnas rgya mtsho chen po 'dra'o/ / de ni longs spyod rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas nyid ces bya ste de'i gdags gzhi mthar thug yin pa'i phyir ro/ / ci'i phyir me long ye shes zhes bya na/ me long dwang ba la gzugs brnyan thams cad snang ba bzhin du ye shes 'dir shes bya yod do cog gi rnam par snang nas/ de dag ji lta ba mnyam pa nyid du rtogs pa dang / ji snyed pa ma 'dres par rtogs pa dang / gdul bya'i don lhun gyis grub pa'i ye shes gsum gyi gzugs brnyan nam rnam pa'i mtshan nyid gzhi de la brten nas 'byung ba'i phyir me long lta bu'i ye shes zhes bya'o/ /

Because it is the cause of all the other kinds of gnosis, it is like an oceanic source of all the jewels of gnosis. It is referred to as the enjoyment body itself, because it is the ultimate basis of designation for the buddhas of perfect enjoyment. It is called mirrorlike gnosis because, just as in a clear mirror everything appears reflected, absolutely everything there is to know appears to this gnosis. And the three kinds of gnosis—the realization of sameness with regard to the nature of things, the realization of each and every one of them distinctly, and the spontaneous accomplishment of beings’ welfare—appear as reflections or specific aspects that are based on and depend on it. This is why it is called mirrorlike gnosis.
mnyam pa nyid kyi ye shes ni
(ii) THE GNOSIS OF EQUALITY

mnyam nyid ye shes sems can la/ / bsgom pa dag pa la 'dod do/ / mi gnas zhi bar zhugs pa ni/ / mnyam nyid ye shes yin par 'dod/ / dus rnams kun tu byams pa dang / / thugs rje chen po dag dang ldan/ / sems can rnams la mos pa bzhin/ / sangs rgyas sku ni nges par ston/ /

The gnosis of equality is held to be Pure as a result of its cultivation with respect to sentient beings. To have entered the nondwelling peace Is said to be the gnosis of equality. (X, 70) Constantly possessed of love And great compassion, It visibly reveals to sentient beings The Buddha’s form according to their aspirations. (X, 71)

sa dang pos bdag dang sems can mnyam pa nyid du rtogs pa de sa bcu pa'i bar du bsgoms pas/ nga dang bdag tu rtog pa'i bag chags phra mo yang spangs nas dag pa sangs rgyas kyi sa'i mnyam pa nyid kyi ye shes su gyur pa la 'dod do/ / srid pa dang zhi ba'i phyogs sam mtha' la mi gnas pa'i 'khor 'das dbyer med mnyam pa nyid du gyur te srid zhi gnyis su dmigs pa zhi ba ni mnyam nyid ye shes kyi ngo bo yin par 'dod do/ / dus rnams kun tu byams pa dang / snying rje'am thugs rje chen po dag dang ldan la/ sems can rnams la so sor rang rang gi ji ltar mos pa bzhin du sangs rgyas kyi sku kha dog dang dbyibs la sogs pa sna tshogs su nges par ston pa'i byed las can no/ /

When the realization gained on the first bodhisattva level that oneself and sentient beings are the same is cultivated up the tenth level, thereby eliminating even the most subtle habitual tendencies of the “I” and concept of self, it is said to become the pure gnosis of equality of the buddha level. This refers to the equality and inseparability of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa that does not dwell in the directions or extremes of existence and peace. The stilling of the dualistic concepts of existence and peace is held to be the essence of the gnosis of equality. It is endowed at all times with love and great compassion. And its function lies in the buddhas displaying themselves to sentient beings in all kinds of bodily colors and shapes in accordance with each being’s individual inclinations.
so sor rtog pa'i ye shes ni/
(iii) ALL-DISCERNING GNOSIS

so sor rtog pa'i ye shes ni/ / shes bya kun la rtag mi thogs/ / ting nge 'dzin dang gzungs rnams kyi/ / gter dang 'dra ba kho na yin/ / 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor rnams su ni/ / 'byor pa thams cad ston mdzad pa/ / the tshom thams cad gcod pa yi/ / chos chen char ni rab tu 'bebs/ /

All-discerning gnosis Is never obstructed as to all there is to know; It is like a treasure house Of concentrations and powers of retention. (X, 72) To the disciples in the retinue It displays all kinds of riches And makes the rain of the Great Dharma pour down, Removing all their doubts. (X, 73)

shes bya thams cad kyi rang dang spyi'i mtshan nyid kun la dus rtag tu thogs pa med par mkhyen pa'i ye shes so/ / de ni ting nge 'dzin tshad med pa dang / gzungs kyi sgo tshad med pa rnams kyi gter dang 'dra ba kho na yin no/ / de'i byed las sangs rgyas kyi 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor thams cad du phyi'i 'dod yon gyi 'byor pa zhing dag pa sa gzhi rin po che las grub pa dang / dpag bsam gyi shing dang / bdud rtsi'i chu klung dang / gzhal med khang bkod pas brgyan pa dang / zag pa med pa'i gzugs sgra dri ro reg bya'i tshogs kyi sprin phung 'khrigs pa la sogs pa phun sum tshogs pa'i 'byor pa thams cad ston par mdzad pa dang / nang chos kyi 'byor pa/ zab cing rgya che ba'i chos thams cad kyi rang spyi'i mtshan nyid phyin ci ma log par yang dag par bstan pas 'khor gyi skye bo rnams kyi the tshom thams cad gcod pa yi theg pa chen po yi chos chen po'i char ni rab tu 'bebs par byed pa'o/ /

All-discerning gnosis is the gnosis that, at all times, has unobstructed knowledge of all the specific and general characteristics of all knowable phenomena. It is like a treasure house of infinite concentrations and infinite powers of retention. Its function is to display to the whole circle of disciples in the Buddha’s retinue the outer riches of enjoyable qualities—all the abundant and perfect riches of a pure buddha field with its adornments and layout (the ground made of jewels, the wish-fulfilling trees, the rivers of nectar, the inestimable palace) and massed clouds of offerings of untainted forms, sounds, fragrances, tastes, and physical sensations. And, by authentically displaying the inner riches of the Dharma, the specific and general characteristics of all the profound and extensive teachings, it makes the great rain of the Mahāyāna teachings pour down, removing all the disciples’ doubts.
bya ba grub pa'i ye shes ni/
(iv) ALL-ACCOMPLISHING GNOSIS

bya ba sgrub pa'i ye shes ni/ / khams rnams kun tu sna tshogs shing / / dpag med bsam yas sprul pa yis/ / sems can kun gyi don sgrub pa'o/ / sangs rgyas sprul pa de rtag tu/ / mdzad pa grub pa'i bye brag dang / / grangs dang zhing gis rnam kun tu/ / bsam mi khyab par shes par bya/ /

All-accomplishing gnosis Accomplishes beings’ welfare In all worlds with multifarious manifestations, Infinite and inconceivable. (X, 74) Know that those manifestations of the buddhas, Forever performing their deeds, Are inconceivable in every way— In their diversity, numbers, and realms. (X, 75)

'jig rten gyi khams rnams mtha' yas pa kun tu sku gsung thugs kyi sprul pa mi 'dra ba rnam pa sna tshogs shing / de dag gi grangs dpag tu med pa dang blos bsam yas pa'i sprul pa yis sems can kun gyi don sgrub pa'o/ / bshad ma thag pa'i sangs rgyas kyi sprul pa de sna tshogs yin pa dang / dpag tu med pa dang / bsam yas pa yin pa'i rgyu mtshan ni/ dus rtag tu sems can khams dang dbang po mos pa tha dad pa'i don mdzad pa'am bya ba grub pa'i bye brag gis sna tshogs pa ste sangs rgyas kyi 'dul ba la sangs rgyas kyi gzugs su sprul pa dang / de bzhin nyan rang dang byang sems lha la sogs pa'i 'gro ba thams cad du sprul nas sems can gyi don mdzad pa sogs mdor na sprul pa mi 'dra ba sna tshogs tshad med par ston pa'i phyir sna tshogs pa yin no/ / sprul pa yang brgya dang stong la sogs pa grangs bgrang ba las 'das pas na dpag tu med pa zhes bya'o/ / zhing gis zhes pa gdul bya'i zhing ni zhing gcig dang brgya la sogs pa nyi tshe ba ma yin par/ gang+gA'i rdul gyi grangs las 'das pa'i phyogs bcu'i zhing rab 'byams mtha' yas mu med pa sprul pa'i rnam par rol pa ston pa'i sangs rgyas kyi sprul pa de ni rnam pa kun tu bsam gyis mi khyab par shes par bya'o/ /

All-accomplishing gnosis accomplishes the goals of all sentient beings in all the infinite worlds by means of a whole variety of different manifestations of body, speech, and mind, infinite in number and inconceivable. The reasons the buddhas’ manifestations are multifarious, infinite, and inconceivable, as has just been mentioned, are as follows. They are multifarious on account of the diversity of deeds or activities that they perform all the time for the welfare of beings, who have different natures, faculties, and degrees of interest. In benefiting beings, the buddhas manifest in the form of buddhas, and similarly as listeners, solitary realizers, bodhisattvas, gods, and every other kind of being, and they work in all sorts of ways for beings’ benefit. In short, it is because they display a boundless variety of different manifestations that these are described as multifarious. Furthermore, since these manifestations are beyond counting in hundreds or thousands, they are spoken of as infinite. Their realms, that is to say, the worlds in which they benefit beings, are not limited to one or a hundred, but exceed in number the grains of sand in the Ganges; they display and manifest an immense infinity of boundless realms in the ten directions. The buddhas’ manifestations are therefore to be understood as being in every way inconceivable.
gsum pa ye shes bzhi po sgrub pa'i rgyu
(c) THE CAUSES FOR ACQUIRING THE FOUR KINDS OF GNOSIS
['di] la rnam smin gyi rgyu dang / yongs su dag pa 'thob byed kyi rgyu gnyis kyi
This section has two parts: (1) the ripening causes and (2) the cause for attaining complete purity.
dang po
(i) THE RIPENING CAUSES
['di] la/ dngos dang / 'phros don gnyis/
The first of these is divided into two: the main explanation and additional points.
dang po/
1. MAIN EXPLANATION
'dzin pa'i phyir dang sems mnyam phyir/ / yang dag chos rab ston phyir dang / / bya ba sgrub pa nyid kyi phyir/ / ye shes bzhi po yang dag 'byung / /
Because of holding the teachings, because of an attitude of equanimity, Because of teaching the true Dharma, And because of accomplishing tasks, The four kinds of gnosis will properly arise. (X, 76)
zhes pas bstan te/

so so'i skye bo'i dus su dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsten nas theg pa chen po'i chos mnyan bsam bsgom pa la sogs kyi sgo nas 'dzin pa ni me long lta bu'i ye shes 'thob pa'i rgyu ste/ rgyu de las rim gyis kun gzhi gnas 'gyur pa me long lta bu'i ye shes su 'gyur pa'i phyir na chos 'dzin pa'i phyir me long ye shes 'byung ngo zhes gzhan ma gsum la'ang de'i 'gres su shes par byas la/ so so'i skye bo'i dus su sems can thams cad la bdag dang 'dra bar byams pa'i sems la blo sbyangs te sems mnyam pa goms par byas pa'i phyir mnyam nyid ye shes 'byung ngo / / mos spyod kyi dus su yang dag pa'i chos ji ltar thos pa bzhin phyin ci ma log par sems can gzhan la rab tu ston par byed pa'i phyir so sor rtog pa'i ye shes 'byung ngo*/ / de bzhin du sems can rnams kyi bya ba rang gis sgrub par byas pa nyid kyi phyir bya ba grub pa'i ye shes 'byung ste/ de ltar rgyu bzhi po de las ye shes bzhi po yang dag par 'byung ngo*/ / de'i phyir so so'i skye bo'i dus na bla na med pa'i ye shes bzhi po 'di thob pa'i ched du byang chub mchog tu sems bskyed nas rgyu bzhi po 'di ci nus su bsgrub cing ye shes de dang de dag thob par yongs su bsngos na rgyu 'bras bslu med kyi rten 'brel las nam zhig ye shes de thob pa'i rgyur chud mi za bar 'gyur ro/ /

If, when one is an ordinary being, one follows a spiritual master and holds the Mahāyāna teachings by listening to them, reflecting on them, meditating on them, and so on, this will act as the cause for acquiring mirrorlike gnosis, for as a result of this cause, the ground of all will gradually be transformed and turned into mirrorlike gnosis. So the first phrase in this verse should be understood as meaning “Because of one’s holding the Dharma, mirrorlike gnosis will arise.” The other three phrases are to be understood following the same principle. Because of one’s cultivating an attitude of equanimity when one is an ordinary being, training one’s mind in having as loving an attitude toward all beings as one has toward oneself, the gnosis of equality will arise. On the level of earnest aspiration, if one teaches other sentient beings the true Dharma, without mistake—as one has heard it—all-discerning gnosis will arise as a result. Similarly, because of one’s doing beings’ work for them, the all-accomplishing gnosis will arise. Thus from these four causal factors the four kinds of gnosis will properly arise. To obtain these four unsurpassable kinds of gnosis, therefore, we should, while we are ordinary beings, arouse the mind turned toward supreme enlightenment and practice these four causal factors as much as possible, dedicating our practice to the attainment of each of these kinds of gnosis, as the case may be. The interdependence of cause and effect is such that our efforts will never be wasted but unfailingly result in our acquiring those different kinds of gnosis.
gnyis pa/
2. ADDITIONAL POINTS

'di ltar sems can tha dad pa dag gis bla na med pa'i ye shes de lta bu thob pa'i tshe rgyud tha dad du ma'i rang bzhin can gyi sangs rgyas du mar 'gyur na sangs rgyas kyang gang zag rang mtshan par 'gyur zhing de'i phung khams skye mched kyi chos rang mtshan pa du mar 'gyur bas 'dus byas dang mi rtag pa'i chos su 'gyur ba de lta na 'phags pa'i gang zag rnams 'dus ma byas kyis rab tu phye ba yin gyi 'dus byas kyis phye ba min par gsungs pa ji ltar 'thad/ gal te sangs rgyas tshe tha dad med na sems can so sos lam bsgrub nas 'bras bu thob pa don med par mi 'gyur ram snyam na/ ji srid gang zag dang chos su 'dzin pa'i 'du shes yod pa de srid du rgyud tha dad pa'i gang zag dang de'i phung khams sogs kyi chos tha dad du mar snang gi don dam par chos dang gang zag gi ngo bo nyid med par/ bdag med gnyis kyi rang bzhin stong pa nyid 'od gsal ba yin pas de bzhin mngon du gyur pa'i dus na gang zag dang chos kyi rang bzhin du 'dzin pa dang bral bas sangs rgyas kyi sa na sangs rgyas rnams chos kyi dbyings kyi rang bzhin ye shes kyi sku bsam gyis mi khyab pa rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa yin pas/ gang zag dang chos rang mtshan pa tha mal pa'i blos bzung ba'i rnam pa 'di lta bu'i mtshan ma ci yang mi mnga' bas/ sangs rgyas rnams la don dam pa tha dad med la/ tha snyad du tha dad par btags pa yod par bstan pa/ rigs tha dad phyir sogs tshigs bcad gcig gis bstan te/

One might argue that if, when individual beings obtain these unsurpassable kinds of gnosis in this way and they become as many buddhas, with as many different mind streams, then those buddhas too must be specifically characterized individuals, and their aggregates, sense spheres, and senses-and-fields must be multiple phenomena with specific characteristics and therefore compounded and impermanent. In that case, how can it be valid for the Buddha to say that noble beings are classified as uncompounded and not as compounded? If they are no different when they attain enlightenment, what, one might wonder, would be the point in each being’s practicing the path and attaining the result? As long as there is the belief in individuals and phenomena, there appear individuals with different mind streams and the multiple different phenomena of their aggregates, sense spheres, and so forth. However, in ultimate truth, there are no intrinsically existent phenomena or individuals: there is only radiant emptiness, the nature of the two kinds of no-self. When this is realized as it is, one is free of the belief in intrinsically existent individuals and phenomena, so that on the level of buddhahood, the buddhas are the omniform, inconceivable body of gnosis, the nature of the expanse of reality. They do not have any of the characteristics and aspects that the ordinary mind believes to be inherently existing individuals and phenomena. It is therefore taught that while the buddhas are no different in ultimate truth, on the conventional level they are designated differently. This is the subject of the following verse.
rigs tha dad phyir don yod phyir/ / rdzogs phyir thog ma med pa'i phyir/ / sangs rgyas gcig min dri med gnas/ / tha dad med phyir mang po'ang min/ /

Because there are different potentials, because there is benefit, Because of fulfillment, and because there is no beginning, The Buddha is not single; but, because in the uncontaminated state There are no distinctions, neither is he multiple. (X, 77)
zhes pas bstan te/

de yang kha cig 'jig rten gyi khams gcig tu sangs rgyas gcig mngon par sangs rgyas na/ de'i tshe phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams gzhan dag tu sangs rgyas gzhan mi skye mi 'byung bas 'jig rten khams kun na sangs rgyas gcig las med pas des 'jig rten gzhan dang gzhan du sprul pas don mdzad ces zer/ kha cig la 'khor ba thog ma med pa'i dus nas sangs rgyas gcig kho nar zad de/ gcig po des sangs rgyas kyi zhing thams cad du sems can gyi don du sangs rgyas kyi phrin las sna tshogs mdzad do zhes zer/ kha cig mthar thug gi sa thob pa'i sangs rgyas kyang gcig ma yin te/ nga bdag tu rtog pa spangs shing sgrib gnyis bral ba'i chos sku yang tha dad pa du ma yod ces zer/

Some people say that when a buddha attains enlightenment in one world, at that time no other buddhas will be born or appear in any of the other worlds in the ten directions, so that there is no more than one buddha in the whole universe, and he therefore benefits beings by producing other manifestations in other worlds. Others say that from time without beginning in saṃsāra there has only ever been one Buddha, and that he alone performs the various buddha activities for beings’ benefit in all the buddha fields. Yet others say that there is not just one buddha who has attained the ultimate level but many different truth bodies rid of the “I” and the concept of self and devoid of the two obscurations.

sangs rgyas gcig dang du ma yin par mtha' gcig tu 'dod pa de gnyis ka ltar ma yin te/ rgyu mtshan gang gi phyir na/ 'jig rten gyi khams na sangs rgyas 'grub rung gi rigs yod pa'i sems can mtha' yas pas rgyu rigs tha dad du yod pa'i phyir 'bras bu sangs rgyas gcig kho na yin par mi rigs te/ dper na 'bru'i phung po chen po las/ 'bru gcig kho na myu gu skye rung yin gyi gzhan ma yin zhes smra ba mi rigs pa ltar ro/ /

Neither of these two unequivocal claims—that there is only one Buddha or that there are multiple buddhas—is correct, for the following reasons. There are infinite sentient beings in the universe who possess the potential for accomplishing buddhahood, and there are therefore many different potentials acting as causes. So it would not be logical for the result to be only a single buddha—just as it would be illogical to say that only one grain out of a whole pile of grain has the potential to produce a shoot, while the others do not.

zas legs par g.yos su byas pa ni su la yang 'grangs pa dang phan par byed pa ltar/ tshogs gnyis po gang zag sus bsags kyang sangs rgyas thob pa'i don yod par 'gyur gyi/ gal te sangs rgyas gcig las med na gang zag du mas sangs rgyas thob pa'i phyir tshogs gnyis bsags pa don med pa 'gyur na'ang de mi rigs pas sangs rgyas gcig las med pa ma yin no/ /

Just as anyone can be filled and nourished with well-cooked food, anyone who gathers the two accumulations will have the benefit of attaining buddhahood. But if there were no more than one buddha, there would be no point in many individuals gathering the two accumulations in order to attain buddhahood. That too does not follow, so there cannot be only one buddha.

sangs rgyas rnams kyis dang por bla na med pa'i byang chub tu thugs bskyed pa na bdag byang chub chen po thob par byas nas sems can rnams byang chub de la 'god par bya'o zhes pa'i dam bca' sangs rgyas kyi sar yongs su rdzogs pa yin na/ sangs rgyas de gcig pu de las sems can gzhan 'tshang rgya ba med na sangs rgyas des sems can gcig tsam yang sangs rgyas kyi sa la bzhag pa med pas des dang por dam bcas pa yongs su ma rdzogs par 'gyur na'ang / de mi rigs te sangs rgyas rnams kyi sems can gyi don bya ba'i dam bca' yongs su rdzogs pa'i phyir sangs rgyas gcig kho nar zad pa min no/ /

When the buddhas first arouse the mind turned toward unsurpassable enlightenment, they take the vow to attain the great enlightenment themselves and then to bring sentient beings to enlightenment, and this promise is completely fulfilled on the level of buddhahood. If there were only one buddha and no other sentient beings attaining enlightenment apart from him, that buddha would not bring even a single being to buddhahood, and therefore the initial promise would never be fulfilled. So again, if the buddhas’ pledges to benefit beings are to be completely fulfilled, there cannot be only one buddha.

'di yan chad kyis 'jig rten gyi khams su sangs rgyas gcig yod kyi 'jig rten gzhan na sangs rgyas gzhan med ces zer ba de bkag pa yin no/ / 'jig rten gyi khams gcig tu 'khor los sgyur ba dang sangs rgyas gnyis dus gcig mi 'byung gsungs pa ni/ gling bzhi pa'i 'jig rten gcig tu yin te/ mchog gi sprul sku shAkya'i rgyal po lta bu sangs rgyas gcig po des stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams gcig na gling bzhi pa'i 'jig rten bye ba phrag brgya yod pa de snyed du sprul pa de snyed cig dus mnyam par lhums su zhugs pa sogs kyi sprul pa'i sangs rgyas re re snang ba yin zhes theg bsdus su gsungs/ de ni dus kyi dbang du byas te thog ma med pa'i dus nas sangs rgyas gcig kho na yin zer ba bkag pa gang gi phyir bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs ma bsags par 'tshang rgya ba ni mi srid la/ tshogs de gnyis kyang lung 'bogs pa'i sangs rgyas gzhan med par rang gar mi 'byung bas sangs rgyas snga ma snga ma'i sngon du sangs rgyas gzhan yod pas 'khor ba la thog ma med pa ltar sangs rgyas la yang thog ma med pa'i phyir thog ma med pa nas sangs rgyas gcig las med pa mi 'thad de gcig nas gcig tu brgyud de sangs rgyas du ma byon pa yin par grub bo/ / de ltar bshad ma thag pa'i rgyu mtshan de rnams kyi phyir sangs rgyas ni gcig kho nar zad pa min te sangs rgyas du ma dpag tu med pa yin no/ /

Up to this point this verse refutes those who say that there is only one buddha in the world and there are no other buddhas in other worlds. It has been said that two universal emperors or two buddhas cannot appear in a single world system at the same time, but this refers to a single world system with four continents. In the Compendium of the Great Vehicle it is stated that one buddha like the supreme manifestation body King of the Śākyas manifests in a great cosmos of a billion worlds as many times as those billion four-continent worlds, with a manifestation-body buddha appearing in each one simultaneously, entering his mother’s womb and so on. This would refute those who say, with regard to time, that there is only one Buddha from time without beginning. It is impossible to attain enlightenment without gathering the accumulations of merit and wisdom. And the two accumulations do not just happen by themselves without another buddha transmitting the relevant instructions. So there must have been another buddha before that one, and others before him. And therefore, just as saṃsāra is without beginning, there can be no beginning to buddhas either. For this reason, we cannot accept that there has been no more than one buddha from time without beginning. And it is an established fact that there are many buddhas who have come, one after another in succession. For all the above-mentioned reasons, therefore, there is not only one single buddha but numerous buddhas, infinite in number.

de ltar na yang chos kyi dbyings sgrib gnyis kyi dri ma med pa shin tu rnam par dag pa zag med kyi dbyings dam pa thob pa'i dus na gnas de la tha dad pa cung zad kyang med pa'i phyir sangs rgyas ni de bzhin nyid dag pa gnyis ldan gyi 'dus ma byas kyis rab tu phye ba'am rnam par bzhag pa yin pas de'i dbang du sangs rgyas mang po'ang min te thams cad chos dbyings de bzhin nyid mtshan ma med pa rang bzhin 'od gsal ba tsam du ro mnyam pa'i phyir te sngar yang bstan pa bzhin no/ /

Nevertheless, when one attains the sublime, untainted expanse, the utterly pure expanse of reality uncontaminated by the two obscurations, in that state there are no distinctions at all: the enlightened state is classified or established as uncompounded suchness endowed with the two purities. So in those terms the enlightened state is not multiple either, for everything is the same taste—simply the expanse of reality, suchness, the natural radiant light, devoid of characteristics, as has already been explained.
gnyis pa/
(ii) THE CAUSE FOR ATTAINING COMPLETE PURITY

gnyis su med pa'i mtshan nyid can gyi byang chub chen po rang byung gi ye shes rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa de 'thob par byed pa ni phar phyin lnga dang de las khyad par du gtso bor gyur pa phar phyin gzhan dag par byed pa shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa yin pas mthar thug gi ye shes chen po 'thob byed kyi rgyu shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa bshad pa/

What brings about the attainment of omniscience—self-originated gnosis, great enlightenment, characterized by nonduality—is the five transcendent perfections and especially the most important transcendent perfection, transcendent wisdom, which makes the other transcendent perfections pure. So there now follows an explanation of transcendent wisdom, the cause for obtaining the ultimate great gnosis.
med pa gang yin de nyid ni/ / yod pa yi ni dam par 'dod/ / rnam pa kun tu mi dmigs pa/ / dmigs pa yi ni mchog tu 'dod/ /
That which does not exist Is held to be the sublime existence. Not conceptualizing in any way Is held to be the sublime conceptualization. (X, 78)
ces pas bstan te/

gzung ba dang 'dzin pa sogs kun tu brtags pa gnyis chos kyi mtshan mar dmigs pa med pa gang yin pa de nyid ni/ don dam par yongs su grub pa'am de bzhin nyid gang zhig bden pa dang yang dag pa dang gnas lugs su yod pa yi ni dam par 'dod do/ / 'di ni yul gyi ngos nas bstan pa'o/ / spros pa'i mtshan ma gang du'ang rnam pa kun tu mi dmigs pa rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes ni dmigs pa yi ni mchog tu 'dod de/ yang dag pa'i mthar ji bzhin gtan la pheb pa'i shes rab yin pa'i phyir ro/ / mi dmigs pa'i ye shes dngos sa dang po'i tshe thob bo/ / dmigs pa med pa spros pa'i mtshan ma thams cad bral ba de ni theg pa chen po'i lta ba rnam par dag pa ste/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa las dmigs pa gang du'ang ma mthong ba mthong ba'i dam par gsungs pa'i don to/ /

The imputed reality of subject and object and so forth, being a nonexistent, dualistic concept, is held in ultimate truth to be the fully present reality or suchness—the true, correct, actual condition of things—the highest form of existence. This is indicated from the point of view of the object. The nonconceptual gnosis that does not in any way have as its object elaborated conceptual constructs is held to be the sublime conceptualization, for it is the wisdom that conclusively determines the nature of the ultimately authentic. The actual nonconceptual gnosis is obtained when one attains the first level. That objectless freedom from all elaborated conceptual constructs is the perfectly pure view of the Great Vehicle. It is what is meant by the passage in the Perfection of Wisdom that says that not seeing anything is the highest form of seeing.
bsgom pa rnam par mi lta ba'i/ / bsgom pa dam par 'dod pa ste/ / thob par lta ba med rnams kyi/ / thob pa yang ni dam par 'dod/ /
Meditation that does not look at aspects Is held to be the sublime meditation. The attainment of those who do not look To attain anything is also held to be sublime. (X, 79)

bsgom pa gzung ba dang 'dzin pa'i rnam par mi lta ba'i phyir bsgom pa'i dam par 'dod pa ste/ gnas lugs dang de kho na nyid dang rjes su mthun par bsgom pa'i phyir sgom pa po dang bsgom bya dang sgom pa'i 'khor gsum du mi dmigs pa mtshan nyid pa ni sa gnyis pa nas bcu pa'i bar du 'byung la/ rjes mthun pa mos spyod du yang yod do/ / 'bras bu sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams kyang rang bzhin gyis dmigs pas dben pa'i phyir yang dag par bden grub kyi rnam pas thob par lta ba med pa rnams kyi thob pa yang ni dam par 'dod de/ ji srid 'thob bya'i chos su 'dzin pa'i mngon zhen ma spangs pa de srid du sangs rgyas mi 'thob la/ thob pa med pa'i mtshan nyid khong du chud pa las sangs rgyas thob pa'i phyir/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa las kyang / mi gnas pa gnas pa'i mchog dang / thob med nyid thob pa'i mchog tu bstan to/ / de ltar gzhi lam 'bras bu'i chos rnams spros pa'i mtshan ma kun gyis dben pa'i de bzhin nyid du ro mnyam par shes pas 'bras bu'i sangs rgyas kyi ye shes chen po thob kyi/ mtshan ma'i 'du shes su byas na 'bras bu'i sher phyin las ring bar gyur nas mi thob la mtshan ma med par rtogs na mi ring bar myur du thob pa'i tshul gsungs/

Because the meditation does not look at any subject or object, it is held to be the highest form of meditation, for bodhisattvas meditate in accord with the way things truly are—thatness. Genuine freedom from the three concepts of a meditator, an object of meditation, and an act of meditating occurs on the second to tenth levels, while on the level of earnest aspiration the meditation is emulative.[35] Even with regard to the qualities of the result, buddhahood, there is naturally no conceptualization, and so the attainment of those who, correctly, do not have the view that attainment is something truly existent is also sublime. As long as one has not eliminated the belief that what is to be attained is something real, one will not attain enlightenment. But from the realization of the nature of “nonattainment,” buddhahood will be attained. Again in the Perfection of Wisdom it is taught that nonabiding is the highest form of abiding, and nonattainment is the highest of attainments. Thus it has been taught that by recognizing that all the elements of the ground, path, and result are of the same taste in suchness devoid of all elaborated conceptual constructs, one obtains the great gnosis of enlightenment, the result. But if one has any notion of attributes, one remains far from the resultant transcendent perfection of wisdom and will not attain it. If, on the other hand, one realizes the absence of attributes, one will swiftly attain it.

bla ma ring dang mtshan ma dang / / bdag gi brtson 'grus lhag lta ba'i/ / byang chub sems dpa' nga rgyal can/ / byang chub las ni ring zhes bya/ / ji skad bshad pa de dag kun/ / rtog pa tsam du lta ba yi/ / byang chub sems dpa' rtog med rnams/ / byang chub thob ces nges par brjod/ /

Those who have views concerning height, distance, attributes, And their own superiority in terms of diligence— Of these proud bodhisattvas It is said, “They are far from enlightenment.” (X, 80) Those who regard all the aforementioned views As mere conceptual constructs— Of these bodhisattvas who are free of concepts It is said, “They will attain enlightenment.” (X, 81)
bla ma rigs dang sogs tshigs bcad gnyis te/

bla ma sangs kyi chos la dngos po dang mtshan ma 'dzin pa'am/ yang na gu ru'i sgra lci ba la 'jug pas blo brtan 'grel pa ltar na/ lci ba dang ni ring ba dang / /mtshan ma dag gis brtson 'grus mthong / /zhes 'dug pa ltar/ bla med byang chub stobs sogs rmad du byung ba'i chos dang ldan yang de bsgrub dka' bas lci bar mthong ba dang*/ bskal pa chen po grangs med gsum gyi bar du bsgrub dgos pas yun ring ba dang / bsgom par bya ba'i yul gyi mtshan ma dang / bdag gis bla med byang chub kyi phyir brtson 'grus brtsams pas gzhan las ches lhag go snyam du lta ba'i byang chub sems dpa' dmigs pa la gnas pa'i nga rgyal can rnams ni bla med byang chub las ring ba zhes bya ste/ dmigs pa dang nga rgyal de dang ma bral bar du byang chub thob pa'i lam yang dag ma thob pa'i phyir ro/ / ji skad bshad ma thag pa dmigs pa can gyi lta ba de dag kun brtags pa tsam dang rang gi de dang der rnam par rtog pa tsam las gzhan du don gyi ngo bos ma grub pas chos thams cad rang gi sems tsam du rtogs pa dang / sems de la yang dngos po dang mtshan mar mi rtog par lta ba'am mthong ba yi/ byang chub sems dpa' mtshan ma'i mngon zhen gyi rtog pa med pa rnams/ bla med byang chub thob ces nges par brjod de/ rnam par mi rtog pa des mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa myur du thob par 'gyur bas so/ /

Bodhisattvas who are proud and full of concepts consider the highest qualities (that is, buddha qualities) to be real things and attributes, or they see unsurpassable enlightenment endowed with marvelous qualities such as the ten strengths as weighty, for it is difficult to accomplish. (This alternative explanation follows Sthiramati’s commentary, in which the word guru is translated in the sense of “weighty,” rendering this verse: “Those who see weight, distance, attributes, and their own diligence.”) They regard enlightenment as far away, because it requires that they practice for three measureless great kalpas. They see in it the attributes of an object that has to be meditated on. And they think that because they are making diligent efforts to attain unsurpassable enlightenment, they are much better than others. Such bodhisattvas are referred to as “a long way from unsurpassable enlightenment.” Until they are free of such conceptualization and pride, they will never gain the correct path for attaining enlightenment. Since all the conceptualized views that have just been mentioned are in fact no more than simple imputations and personal concepts, bodhisattvas free of the concepts of real attributes, who have realized that all phenomena are merely one’s own mind, and who regard or see that mind without any concept of it as a thing or attribute, are described as “gaining unsurpassable enlightenment,” because as a result of that absence of concepts they will rapidly acquire the acceptance that phenomena are unborn.
bzhi pa ni/
(d) SHOWING THAT THE CULMINATION OF ALL PATHS IS THE BUDDHA’S GNOSIS

sems can gyi dus na rang rang gi rtog pa'i dbang gis rgyud tha dad pa dang chos sna tshogs tha dad par snang ba ni 'gog tu med kyang / chos thams cad rtog pa'i dbang gis bzhag pa'am/ rtog pas phar btags pa de tsam las don so sor rang gi ngo bo'am rang bzhin du grub pa gang yang med pas/ rtog pa de nyid rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyis rim par sbyangs pas chos dang gang zag sogs rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i spros pa nye bar zhi ba'i de bzhin nyid gzung 'dzin gyi sgrib pas dag pa gong nas gong du khyad par 'phags pa thob pa'i tshe de bzhin nyid chos kyi dbyings su mi 'dra ba med par mnyam nyid thob pa'i tshul ni/ dper na

It cannot be denied that when one is an ordinary being, on account of one’s concepts one perceives different individuals and all sorts of different phenomena. Yet apart from their merely being classified by means of concepts or labeled by concepts, in fact, there are no phenomena that exist intrinsically and individually. So it is by gradually purifying those very concepts with nonconceptual gnosis that suchness (which is the complete stilling of the various conceptual elaborations such as individuals and phenomena) is progressively purified of the concepts of subject and object that obscure it until one attains the state of evenness, the expanse of reality, suchness, in which there are no differences. This is illustrated as follows.

klung dag sa yi 'og tu ma song ba/ / gnas rnams tha dad chu yang tha dad la/ / chu yang chung zhing bya ba tha dad byed/ / chu gnas srog chags phra mo'i nyer spyad 'gyur/ / rgya mtshor song bar gyur na thams cad kyang / / gnas rnams gcig cing chu yang che la gcig / bya ba gcig cing chu la gnas pa yi/ / srog chags mang po'i rtag tu nyer spyad che/ /

The rivers that have not reached the sea[36] Have different locations, different streams, Little water, with different activities, Providing for the needs of tiny creatures living in them. (X, 82) Yet when they reach the ocean, They all have one location, their water a single vast expanse, With the same activity, an immense and constant source For myriad marine creatures, providing all they need. (X, 83)
zhes pas bstan te/

chu klung dag sa yi 'og tu rgya mtsho chen po la ma song ba'am ma zhugs pa de yi tshe na shar la sogs pa'i yul khams so sos dbye bas/ gnas rnams tha dad pa dang / chu de yang gang+ga dang sin+d+hu sogs chen po dang chu phran chung ngu'i rnam pa tha dad pa dang / rgya mtsho chen po la ltos na chu'i rgyun de yi chu yang chung la/ so so'i bya ba yang tha dad byed de la las rlung dang la las mkhris pa la las bad kan sogs skyed pa dang / zhing la blugs pa dang 'khrud pa sogs sems can tha dad sna tshogs kyis spyod pa'i bya ba tha dad pa byed pa dang / chu de la gnas pa'i srog chags phra mo'am bong chung ba sbal lcong rnams kyi nye bar spyod par 'gyur la/ chu yi rgyun de nyid rgya mtshor song bar gyur na de thams cad rgya mtsho chen po gcig pu der 'dres nas gser gyi sa gzhi la brten pas gnas rnams tha dad med par gcig cing / rgya mtsho'i chu yang kha zheng dang gting dpag dka' bas rgya che ba la gcig tu gyur pa dang / rgya mtsho'i chu thams cad lan tshwa'i ror gcig pa dang / chu yi rgyun rnams spro zhing sdud pa'i bya ba gcig cing / rgya mtsho'i chu la gnas pa yi srog chags chu srin dang nya mid la sogs pa bong che ba dang / chung ba sna tshogs pa mang pos rtag tu nye bar spyod pa che ba nyid du gyur pa yi

Before the earth’s rivers reach (or enter) the sea,[37] they are separated by the lands they flow through and so flow through different places—in the east, in the south, and so on. And they take different forms—great rivers like the Ganges and Sindhu, their tributaries, and smaller rivers and streams. Moreover, the water flowing in them is very little compared to that in the ocean. It also has different effects: some water gives rise to wind disorders, some predisposes to bile disorders, and some causes diseases related to phlegm, and so on. Different beings use it for different purposes—for watering the fields, bathing, and the like. And that water fulfills the needs of the tiny creatures like frogs, tadpoles, and larvae that live in it. But when those rivers reach the sea, they all mingle with it and become one great ocean, resting not on different places but on the single golden ground. It is a single, vast mass of water whose breadth and depth are hard to measure. All the water in the ocean has the same salty taste, and in the way it flows it all behaves in the same manner in spreading and collecting.[38] And for the many kinds of large and small animals—crocodiles, whales, and the like—that inhabit the ocean’s waters, it is a perpetual, abundant source of all they need.

sangs rgyas nyid du ma zhugs brtan pa rnams/ / rten kyang tha dad blo gros tha dad cing / / rtogs chung rang gi bya ba tha dad la/ / sems can nyung don rtag tu nyer spyad 'gyur/ / sangs rgyas nyid du zhugs na de dag kun/ / rten kyang gcig cing rtogs pa che la gcig / mdzad pa gcig tu 'dres shing rtag par yang / / sems can tshogs che'i nye bar spyad pa che/ /

The steadfast who have not reached enlightenment Have different supports, different intellects, Little realization, and different activities; They benefit and constantly provide for only a few beings. (X, 84) Once buddhahood is reached, they all Have but one support and a single great realization; Their deeds blend as one, and eternally and abundantly They fulfill the needs of vast hosts of beings. (X, 85)

dpe de bzhin du/ mthar thug pa sangs rgyas pa'i sa nyid du ma zhugs pa'i brtan pa byang chub sems dpa' rnams so so'i phung po lnga'i rten kyang tha dad pa dang / blo gros rno rtul dang bzang ngan che chung tha dad cing / sgrib pa mtha' dag ma spangs pas thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes med pas rtogs pa yang sangs rgyas la ltos na shin tu chung la/ rang rang gi bya ba sbyin sogs skabs su gang bab pa de tsam la 'jug pas bya ba yang tha dad pa dang / de dag gi sa rang rang gis gdul byar gyur pa'i sems can nyung ngu zhig gi don byed pas gdul bya de dag gis nyer spyad du 'gyur gyi sangs rgyas bzhin du phyogs bcu'i sems can tshad med dpag tu med pa'i don byed pa ma yin no/ / byang sems de thams cad mthar thug sangs rgyas kyi chos dbyings rnam par dag pa dang me long lta bu sogs ye shes bzhi yi rang bzhin can de nyid du zhugs na/ rten nam gnas kyang gcig te chos kyi dbyings rnam par dag pa de gcig pu las phung po'i rgyud kyis phye bas rten tha dad med cing / thams cad kyang shes bya'i rnam pa thams cad mngon sum du mkhyen pa'i rtogs pa che la dbang po rno rtul sogs tha dad du phye ba med par rnam mkhyen gyi ye shes nyid du gcig go / de thams cad la mdzad pa tha dad pa med par gcig tu 'dres shing dus nam yang rgyun mi chad pas rtag par yang phyogs bcu'i nam mkha'i mtha' klas pa'i sems can gyi tshogs che'i zhes pa ches chen po tshad dang mu mtha' gzhal du med pa rnams kyi phan pa dang bde don mdzad pa'i nye bar spyod pa che zhing mi zad pa yin no/ /

By analogy with the above, steadfast bodhisattvas who have not entered ultimate enlightenment have different individual bodies composed of the five aggregates.
