They have different mental powers and intellects—sharp and dull, excellent and poor, powerful and weak—and since they have not got rid of all obscurations and therefore lack omniscient gnosis, their realization, compared to the Buddha’s, is very slight. Their activities too are different, for they engage in generosity, for example, only when it is the moment to do so. In working for the good of a few beings destined to be trained by them, they may fulfill the needs of those beings, but they do not benefit countless sentient beings in the ten directions as does the Buddha. When all those bodhisattvas enter the state of ultimate enlightenment, whose nature is the perfectly pure expanse of reality and the four kinds of gnosis (mirrorlike gnosis and the others), the support or abode is the same, the one perfectly pure expanse of reality, and apart from this they do not have different bodies with distinct sets of aggregates. They all have great realization, with direct knowledge of everything there is to be known: there are no distinctions between sharp or dull faculties but only one state of omniscient gnosis. The activities of all of them are no different, but blended into one, eternally and unceasingly fulfilling the needs, abundantly and inexhaustibly, of the boundlessly, immeasurably vast hosts of the infinite sentient beings in the ten directions of space, ensuring their benefit and happiness.
gsum pa byang chub chen po la bsngags pa'i sgo nas sems bskyed par gdams pa'i tshigs bcad kyis le'u'i mjug sdud pa ni/
3. CONCLUDING SUMMARY OF THE CHAPTER WITH A VERSE IN PRAISE OF GREAT ENLIGHTENMENT AS AN INSTRUCTION FOR AROUSING BODHICITTA
de ltar sangs rgyas nyid ni dkar po'i chos/ / dpe med ldan phyir phan bde'i rgyu yi phyir/ / bde dge dam pa mi zad 'byung gnas phyir/ / blo ldan byang chub sems dge blang ba'i rigs/ /

Thus, because the enlightened state has incomparable virtuous qualities, Because it is the cause of benefit and happiness, And because it is the inexhaustible source of the highest bliss and virtue, The wise should adopt the virtuous intention to attain enlightenment. (X, 86)
zhes pas bstan te/

ji skad bshad pa de ltar sangs rgyas nyid ni rang ngos nas zag pa med pa dkar po'i chos phar phyin dang byang phyogs stobs dang mi 'jigs pa sogs dpe med pa dang ldan pa'i phyir dang / sems can gzhan gyi don du phan pa dang bde ba'i rgyu yi phyir te/ 'bras bu sdug bsngal las gtan du grol ba'i bde ba dang / sdug bsngal gyi nyes spyod las gtan du grol ba'i dge ba dam pa nam yang mi zad pa'i 'byung gnas yin pa'i phyir blo ldan rnams kyis bla na med pa'i byang chub mchog tu sems bskyed pa'i dge ba de ni rang gi rgyud la yang dag par blangs par rigs so zhes gdams par mdzad pa'o/ /

As has been explained, the enlightened state, from its own point of view, possesses incomparable untainted positive qualities—the transcendent perfections, the qualities associated with enlightenment, the strengths, the fearlessnesses, and so on. From other beings’ point of view, it is the cause of benefit and happiness. And it is the inexhaustible source of the highest bliss (lasting freedom from suffering) and virtue (lasting freedom from the negative actions that bring suffering) that constitute the result. For all these reasons, advises Maitreya, the wise should properly adopt in their minds the virtuous spiritual intent to gain that supreme, unsurpassable enlightenment.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ byang chub kyi le'u ste bcu pa'o// //
This completes the tenth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on enlightenment.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ byang chub kyi le'u ste bcu pa rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the tenth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on enlightenment.
[sdom]
RECAPITULATION LISTING THE FIRST TEN CHAPTERS
! sdom ni/ dang po sgrub skyabs rigs dang ni/ / de bzhin du ni sems bskyed dang / / rang gzhan don dang de nyid don/ / mthu dang yongs smin byang chub bo/ /

The following is a recapitulation: Introduction, establishing, refuge, potential, Likewise, spiritual intent, One’s own and others’ benefit, thatness, Powers, full maturation, and enlightenment. (XI, 1)[1]

zhes sdom ni gong gi le'u'i grangs bsdu ba ste/ le'u dang po mdo sde'i rgyan du 'gyur tshul gyi le'u la tshigs bcad lnga'o/ / theg chen bka' sgrub pa tshigs bcad bco lngas bstan to/ / de'i rjes su skyabs 'gro la tshigs bcad bcu gnyis kyis so/ / rigs la tshigs bcad bcu gsum dang ni de bzhin du sems bskyed pa tshigs bcad nyi shu rtsa bdun gyis so/ / rang dang gzhan gyi don bsgrub pa sgrub pa'i skabs la tshigs bcad gsum gyis rang don dang / tshigs bcad drug gis gzhan don bstan to/ / de kho na nyid dam yang dag pa'i don tshigs bcad bcus bstan to/ / mthu tshigs bcad bcus bstan to/ / bdag dang sems can yongs su smin pa tshigs bcad nyi shus so/ / byang chub ni tshigs bcad brgyad cu rtsa bdun gyis bstan par grub bo/ /

The first chapter, the chapter on why this work is called “Ornament of the Sūtras” has five verses. Establishing the Great Vehicle as the Buddha’s word is indicated by fifteen verses. This is followed by twelve verses on the refuge. The potential is covered in thirteen verses, and similarly the spiritual intent by twenty-seven verses.[2] In the chapter on the practice for accomplishing one’s own and others’ goals, three verses are devoted to benefiting oneself and six to benefiting others. Thatness or the true meaning is described in ten verses. Powers are described in ten verses. Full maturation of oneself and sentient beings has twenty verses. Enlightenment completes this section with eighty-seven verses.

de ltar le'u bcu'i rjes su de rnams kyi sdom bstan pa ni 'byor pa'i don tshul bla med gyur pa lnga'i nang nas dang po bzhi bstan pa 'di lam theg chen bka' sgrub pa dang gzhi rigs dang / lam gyi rtsa ba skyabs 'gro/ theg chen lam gyi khyad par bsam pa sems bskyed/ sbyor ba sgrub pa/ sgrub byed khyad par can mthu dang yongs smin/ bsgrubs pa'i 'bras bu byang chub rnams kyi spyi rigs nas bstan pas gang la bslab par bya ba theg pa chen po'i lam 'bras bu bcas pa'i khyad par shes nas/ lam gyi gzhi bting ba'i tshul du dang por bshad nas/

This recapitulation of the first ten chapters refers to the first four of the five unexcelled metaphors. These chapters cover establishing the path, the Great Vehicle, as the Buddha’s teaching; the spiritual potential, which is the basis; refuge, the root of the path; bodhicitta, the spiritual intent that is the particular feature of the Mahāyāna path; its application, the practice; the particular factors that enable accomplishment—the powers and maturation; and enlightenment, the result that is accomplished. All these are described in general terms, constituting an introductory explanation of how to gain knowledge of the particular features of the Mahāyāna path in which one is to be trained, along with its result, and thus to lay the foundation of the path.

de nas ji ltar bslab par bya ba 'bras bu bla med byang chub de nyid mngon par thob pa'i thabs byang chub phyogs mthun gyi ngo bo nyid bshad pa 'byor ba'i don tshul bla na med pa lnga pa nyid 'di man chad kyis ston pas dang po sdom gyis bcad pa 'di yan chad 'jug bya theg pa chen po'i tshul spyi rigs nas bstan pas lam gol bar med pas dkyus bstan pa'i rta ltar the tshom med par 'jug pa'i phyir bsgrub par bya ba sogs bzhi bstan te/ byang chub nyid bsam gyis mi khyab pa rin po che'i sgrom kha phye ba lta bu yin yang don tshul lnga'i skabs su 'thob byar bsam par bya ba'ang yin pas phrin yig legs pa lta bu'i tshul du'o/ / rin chen gyi sgrom dngos su kha phye ba lta bu sangs rgyas kyi sa yin na yang / dngos su kha phye ba lta bu mngon du byed pa'i thabs sam rgyu ni byang chub kyi phyogs mthun pa lam yin pas/ byang chub phyogs mthun zhes pa spyi ming bye brag la chags pa'i byang phyogs so bdun tsam 'ba' shig la mi 'dzin par mos pa dang spyod pa'i bar la go dgos pa ston phyir/

Next there comes an explanation of how one is to be trained,[3] that is, of the actual approach to enlightenment, which is the means for realizing the result, unsurpassable enlightenment. This refers to the fifth unexcelled metaphor, which will be explained from this point onward. The whole first section up until the recapitulation, in describing the general features of the Mahāyāna path that is to be followed, explains the four sections (what is to be established, and the others) so that one can follow the path without hesitating and without mistaking the way, like a horse that is shown a straight course. In the context of the five metaphors, enlightenment, the inconceivable, which might otherwise be thought of as like opening a chest of jewels, is also the object of reflection on what is to be attained, and so it is treated as being like hearing good news. Actually opening the chest of jewels, as it were, corresponds to the level of buddhahood, but the means or cause for realizing it, which actually opens the chest, is the path constituting the elements that lead to enlightenment. “Elements that lead to enlightenment” should be understood as a general term covering Interest through to Conduct[4] and not only in the specific sense of the thirty-seven elements leading to enlightenment.

byang chub gang yin la de'i phyogs mthun gang yin shes pa'i slad du byang chub ni yongs su grub pa rtogs pa mthar thug pa'i don so sor rang gi rig bya le'u bcu pas bstan pa de yin la le'u bcu man chad de sgrub par byed pa'i thabs sam lam yin pas byang chub kyi phyogs dang mthun pa'i ngo bo nyid yin no zhes gsungs shing byang phyogs nyams su blangs pas sa bcu bsgrod cing yon tan gyi khyad par rnams thob ste/ yon tan mthar thug pa sangs rgyas pa'i tshad med bzhi dang rnam thar zad par zil gnon dang stobs bcu la sogs pa mngon du gyur pa'i bar ni don tshul lnga pa yin pas shes par bya'o/ /

To help us understand what enlightenment is and what it is that leads to enlightenment, the tenth chapter describes enlightenment (the fully present reality, the ultimate realization that can only be known personally), and the next ten chapters comprise the so-called approach to enlightenment, the means or path for accomplishing enlightenment. By practicing the elements leading to enlightenment, one traverses the ten levels and gains their particular qualities: all these, up to the realization of the ultimate qualities—the four boundless attitudes of the enlightened state, its perfect freedoms, powers of perceptual limitlessness, perceptual domination, ten strengths, and so forth—are what are to be understood by the fifth metaphor.

de ltar byang chub kyi phyogs dang mthun pa'i ngo bo nyid bshad pa'i skabs 'di ni mos pa nas spyod pa'i le'u'i bar le'u lhag ma bcu gcig gis bstan pa yin la/ 'dir mtshon pa rnal 'byor gyi sa lnga dang cha 'dra sbyar na mos pa nas gdams ngag rjes bstan gyi bar le'u lnga ni gzhi dang / thabs ldan nas byang phyogs bar le'u bzhi skyed pa/ yon tan gyi le'u me long lta bu/ spyod pa'i le'u'i sa bcu mjug sdud kyi tshigs bcad bcas snang ba/ mthar thug 'bras chos kyi tshigs bcad rnams rten yin no/ /

Thus, this section describing the approach to enlightenment comprises the eleven remaining chapters, from the chapter on interest up to that on conduct. They are related to the five indicative stages of yoga as follows. The five chapters from “Interest” through to “Instructions and Follow-Up Teachings” correspond to the foundation; the four chapters “Skillful Activity” through to “Elements Leading to Enlightenment” correspond to development; the chapter on qualities corresponds to the mirrorlike stage; the concluding verses on the ten levels in the Conduct chapter correspond to vision; and the verses on the ultimate qualities of the result correspond to the support.
[lnga pa byang chub kyi phyogs dang mthun pa'i chos rnams kyi ngo bo nyid bshad pa]
PART FIVE. THE APPROACH TO ENLIGHTENMENT

de ltar spyir bstan nas rtsa ba'i sa bcad lnga pa byang chub kyi phyogs dang mthun pa'i ngo bo nyid la sngon du 'gro ba mos pa sogs le'u lnga dngos gzhi thabs ldan sogs le'u bzhi/ de'i gnas skabs kyi yon tan yon tan gyi le'u dang / spyod pa'i sa bcu bshad pa'i bar dang / mthar thug gi yon tan 'bras chos bshad pa bzhi po 'di 'byor pa'i don tshul bla med lnga'i nang nas rin po che'i sgrom kha phye ba lta bu yin no/ /

After this general explanation, we come now to the fifth principal section in the structural outline, the approach to enlightenment, which comprises four subsections: (1) the preliminaries, in five chapters beginning with the Interest chapter; (2) the main explanation, in four chapters beginning with “Skillful Activity”; (3) the temporary qualities of the practice in the Qualities chapter and up to the explanation of the ten levels in the Conduct chapter; and (4) an explanation of the ultimate qualities that are the qualities of the result. These four correspond to the fifth of the five unexcelled metaphors, “opening a chest of jewels.”
[sngon du 'gro ba]
PRELIMINARIES
de'i dang po la rgyu mos pa/ nyams len chos tshol chos bshad chos sgrub pa gsum/ de dag khyad par du 'gro ba gdams ngag rjes bstan gyi le'u bcas lnga las/

The first of these subsections contains five chapters: one chapter on interest (the cause); three chapters on the practice (investigating the Dharma, teaching the Dharma, and practicing the Dharma); and one chapter on the instructions and follow-up teachings that enhance the latter.
dang po mos pa bshad pa ni/
11. INTEREST

lam la 'jug pa'i thog mar mos pa bskyed dgos te/ mdo las/ dge ba'i chos rnams thams cad kyi/ / rtsa ba mos par thub pas gsungs/ / zhes pa ltar dge chos kun gyi thog mar mos pa skyes pa la brten nas dge ba 'grub kyi/ mos pa med na dge ba de dang de la / 'jug pa gtan nas mi 'byung bas mos pa skyed dgos te/ dkon mchog sgron me'i mdo las/ dad pa sngon 'dren ma ltar skyed pa ste/ / yon tan thams cad srung zhing 'phel bar byed/ dogs pa sel zhing chu bo rnams las sgrol/ / dad pa bde ba'i grong khyer mtshon pa yin/ / dad pa rnyogs pa med cing sems dwangs byed/ / nga rgyal spong zhing gus pa'i rtsa ba yin/ / dad pa gter dang nor dang rkang pa'i mchog / lag pa bzhin du dge sdud rtsa ba yin/ / zhes sogs dang / dad pas bdud kyi lam las 'da' byed cing / / thar pa'i lam mchog ston par byed pa yin/ / yon tan zhing gi sa bon ma rul ba/ / dad pa byang chub shing ni rnam par bskyed/ / ces sogs gsungs pa bzhin du thog mar mos pa'i le'u bshad pa

In the beginning when we set out on the path, it is necessary to give rise to interest,[1] for as it is said in the sūtras: The root of all that is virtuous Is interest, so the Capable One has declared. It is by relying on the development of interest at the beginning of every positive activity that we will accomplish virtue. But without interest, we will never engage in any kind of virtue. We must therefore cultivate interest, for as we read in the Sūtra of the Precious Lamp: Developing faith, like a mother leading her children, Preserves all good qualities and makes them grow; It dispels our doubts and rescues us from all the rivers. Faith points us to the city of bliss. Faith is unsullied; it brings clarity of mind; Ridding us of pride, it is the root of respect. Faith is a treasure, a jewel, the perfect base; Like a hand, it is the root for gathering good. And, Faith keeps us off demonic paths; It shows us the sublime path to liberation. An unspoiled seed in the field of good qualities, Faith grows into the tree of enlightenment. Accordingly, it is the chapter on interest that is taught first.
1. GENERAL DESCRIPTION OF THE CATEGORIES OF INTEREST

['di] la/ mos pa'i rnam grangs nyer drug bstan pa dang / de yi bar du gcod pa bcu drug mos pa'i phan yon bcu gcig rnams kyis mos pa'i rnam grangs spyir bstan nas/ theg pa chen po la mos pa bye brag tu bshad pa la/ theg chen la mos pa'i khyad par dpes bstan/ de la ma zhum zhing spro bas 'jug par gdams pa gnyis kyi le'u 'di bshad pa yin pas

This comprises (1) a general description of the categories of interest with an exposition of the twenty-six categories of interest, the sixteen obstacles to interest, and the eleven benefits of having interest, followed by (2) a specific explanation of interest in the Great Vehicle, in two sections: showing by similes the superiority of interest in the Great Vehicle, and instructions on following the Great Vehicle enthusiastically without getting discouraged.
dang po mos pa'i rnam grangs nyer drug bstan pa ni/
a. TWENTY-SIX CATEGORIES OF INTEREST

skyes dang ma skyes 'dzin dang gzung gyur dang / / grogs blangs bdag nyid dang ni nor ba dang / / ma nor mngon sum mngon sum ma yin gzhan/ / sgras byung tshol ba dang ni lta ba po/ / 'phrogs dang 'dres dang mi mthun phyogs ma 'dres/ / dman dang rgya che bsgribs dang ma bsgribs dang / / brtson dang mi brtson bsags dang ma bsags dang / / brtan zhugs ring du song ba'i mos pa'o/ /

Interest may be arisen, nonarisen, subjective, and objective, Received from a friend, natural, mistaken, Unmistaken, manifest, or otherwise nonmanifest, Produced from sound, investigative, and viewing, (XI, 2) Expropriable, mixed, unadulterated by counteragents, Inferior, vast, obscured, and unobscured, Diligent, nondiligent, with accumulation, and without, Firmly engaged, and advanced. (XI, 3)
zhes pas bstan te/

spyir las 'bras dang bden bzhi mchog gsum gyi don la 'di ni 'di bzhin du yin no zhes bden pa yid ches pa'i dad pa sems las byung ba'i chos la/ dad pa'am mos pa zhes bya'o/ / de yang ji ltar 'das da lta ma 'ongs pa dag nye ba dang ring ba sogs kyi gzugs rnams la gzugs kyi phung po zhes rnam par bzhag pa bzhin du/ mos pa 'di la yang dmigs pa'i yul dang dus dang rnam pa sogs kyi bye brag 'di ltar yod do zhes bstan pa ni/ dad pa gang zhig sngon dang da ltar byung ba la skyes pa'i mos pa zhes bya ba dang / ma 'ongs pa'i dad pa la ma skyes pa'i mos pa zhes bya'o/ /

In general, the mental factor of confidence that something is true and as it is—for example, the karmic law of cause and effect, the four noble truths, or the Three Jewels—is what we call “faith” or “interest.” And like the aggregate of form—which term is used for forms past, present, future, near, far, and so on—interest too is taught as being of different kinds, corresponding to its object, time, aspect, and so on. Faith that has arisen in the past or is now present is known as arisen interest. Future faith is called nonarisen interest.

'dzin pa'i mos pa ni sems byung mos pa kho rang ste 'di ni nang gi mos pa zhes bya ba dang / gzung bar gyur pa'i mos pa ni sngar byung ba'i mos pa la dmigs nas/ 'di ni legs so zhes ro myang zhing de la dga' ba ni gzung ba'i mos pa zhes bya ste mos pa gzhan yul du byas pa'i phyir phyi rol gyi mos pa zhes tha snyad byas pa dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis bstan pa ltar bslab pa la mos pa ni grogs las blangs pa'i mos pa zhes bya ste/ de ni mos pa rags pa'o/ /

Subjective interest is the mental factor “interest” itself[2] and is known as internal interest. Interest that is apprehended refers to previously arisen interest, which, when it is considered, is savored as being good and makes one feel happy: it is what we call objective interest. Because it is a different interest, which has been made the object, it is designated “external interest.” Interest in the training as taught by a spiritual friend is known as interest received from a friend. This is gross interest.

bdag nyid la dad mos kyi sa bon yod pa dang / rigs kyi stobs las mos pa skyes pa ni/ bdag nyid kyi mos pa zhes bya ba ste 'di la mos pa phra ba zhes su'ang 'dogs pa dang / mu stegs pa'i chos bdag dang sems can yod par bshad pa la yid ches shing mos pa ni nor ba'i mos pa zhes bya ste mos pa ngan pa yin pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi gsung rab las mi rtag dang sdug bsngal dang bdag med pa bshad pa la yid ches shing dad pa ni ma nor ba'i mos pa zhes bya ste de ni mos pa bzang po'o/ /

Interest that arises from one’s having the seed of faith and devotion and from the strength of one’s potential[3] is known as natural interest, also termed “subtle interest.” Confidence and faith in the explanations of the tīrthika doctrines that the self and beings exist is known as mistaken interest. This is the wrong kind of interest. Confidence and faith in the Buddha’s Excellent Words that teach impermanence, suffering, and no-self is known as unmistaken interest. It is the right kind of interest.

mos pa skye ba'i rgyu rkyen kun tshogs nas mos pa mngon du skyes pa ni mngon sum du mos pa zhes bya ste/ 'di ni mos pa dang nye ba zhes gdags so/ / mos pa skye ba'i rgyu rkyen ma tshogs pas da ltar mngon du ma skyes pa ni mngon sum ma yin pa'i mos pa zhes bya ste/ nam rgyu rkyen tshogs na skye rung yin pa tsam gyi cha nas mos pa snga ma las gzhan mos pa ring ba zhes gdags so/ /

Interest that arises manifestly through the gathering of all the causes and conditions that give rise to interest is known as manifest interest. It is termed “proximate interest.” Interest that has not at present manifestly arisen through the gathering of the causes and conditions that give rise to interest is known as nonmanifest interest. It differs from the previous kind of interest simply from the point of view that it should arise when the causes and conditions are gathered. It is termed “distant interest.”

dad pa'i chos nyan pa las skyes pa'i mos pa ni/ sgras byung ngam sgra las byung bar mos pa'o/ / ji ltar thos pa'i don la rigs pas brtags te mos pa skyes pa ni bsam pas tshol ba'i mos pa zhes bya ba dang ni/ bsgom pa'i stobs kyis don rtogs pa las byung ba'i mos pa ni lta ba'i mos pa'am don la lta ba po yi mos pa'o/ /

Interest that comes from listening to teachings that arouse one’s faith is interest produced by or from sound. Interest that arises through using reasoning to examine the meaning of the teachings that one has heard is known as the interest of investigation through reflection. The interest originating from realizing the meaning of the teachings through meditation is the interest of the view or interest that looks at the meaning.

dad pa skyes kyang bdud dang mu stegs sogs kyis lam gzhan du drangs na dad pa 'gyur ba can ni 'phrogs pa'i mos pa zhes bya ste 'di ni mos pa chung ngu yin pa dang / dad pa 'byung yang bar skabs su ma dad pa yang 'byung bas 'dres mar gyur pa ni 'dres pa'i mos pa zhes bya ste mos pa 'bring po zhes gdags pa dang / dad pa 'ba' zhig rgyun du 'byung gi ma dad pa mi 'byung ba ni mi mthun phyogs dang ma 'dres pa'i mos pa zhes bya ste mos pa chen po'o/ /

If, despite having developed faith, one is drawn onto other paths by tīrthikas, negative forces, and the like, such changeable faith is known as expropriable interest. This is a lesser kind of interest. When faith alternates with moments of lack of faith, the resulting mixture is known as mixed interest and is termed “middling.” When one has nothing but faith, continuously, with no unfaithful thoughts, one has interest unadulterated by counteragents; this is a greater kind of interest.

rang don nyer zhi'i ched du nyan rang gi chos la mos pa ni dman pa'am chung ngu'i mos pa zhes bya ba dang / don gnyis lhun grub mi gnas pa'i myang 'das kyi lam theg pa chen po'i chos la mos pa ni rgya che ba'i mos pa'o/ /

Interest in the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ paths for the sake of perfect peace just for oneself is known as inferior or lesser interest. Interest in the teachings of the Great Vehicle, the path to the nondwelling nirvāṇa that spontaneously accomplishes the two goals, is vast interest.

mos spyod drod nas brtsams te lam thams cad kyi skabs su yang gong ma gong ma'i yon tan khyad par can thob pa'i mos pa la chags sogs nyon mongs pas bar du gcod pa yod pa dang bcas pa ni bsgribs pa'i mos pa dang / bar gcod de dag med pa la ma bsgribs pa'i mos pa zhes bya ba dang / gus sbyor dang rtag sbyor gyi brtson pa dang ldan pas rgyun mi 'chad par 'byung ba'i mos pa la brtson pa'i mos pa'am ldan pa'i mos pa zhes bya ba dang / de lta bu dang ldan pa ma yin pa'i mos pa la mi brtson pa'i mos pa'am mi ldan pa'i mos pa zhes bya'o/ /

All along the path, beginning from the stage of warmth on the path of earnest aspiration, one’s interest in obtaining more and more extraordinary qualities may be interrupted by defilements such as attachment. One’s interest is then obscured interest. Interest without such interruptions is known as unobscured interest. Interest that arises uninterruptedly through diligence (both devoted application and constant application) is called diligent interest or endowed interest. Interest not endowed with such diligence is called nondiligent interest or unendowed interest.

sa dang por chos kyi dbyings rtogs pa'i rgyur gyur pa'i mos spyod kyi sar bskal pa grangs med gcig gi tshogs gnyis bsags pa dang ldan pa'i mos pa la/ tshogs bsags pa'i mos pa zhes bya ba dang / de 'dra'i tshogs dang mi ldan pa'i mos pa la tshogs ma bsags pa'i mos pa zhes bya ste/ spyir yang tshogs bsags dang ldan mi ldan gyi dbang gis theg chen la mos pa rgya che chung dang brtan mi brtan du 'gyur ro/ /

Interest accompanied by the accumulations of merit and wisdom over one measureless kalpa on the level of earnest aspiration, which leads to one’s gaining realization of the expanse of reality on the first bodhisattva level, is known as interest with accumulated merit. Interest that is not accompanied by such accumulations is known as interest without accumulated merit. In general, it is because of one’s possessing or not possessing the accumulations of merit and wisdom that one’s interest in the Great Vehicle will be vast and stable or weak and unstable.

sa dang po nas bdun pa'i bar gyi byang chub sems dpa'i mos pa ni brtan par zhugs pa'i mos pa zhes bya ste/ de dag gis mos pa la bri ba dang nyams pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / sa brgyad pa nas bcu pa'i bar gyi byang chub sems dpa' dag pa'i sa la bzhugs pa rnams kyi mos pa ni ring du song ba'i mos pa zhes bya ste/ rnam par mi rtog pa lhun gyis grub pa'i mos pa dang ldan pas mtshan ma'i rnam par rtog pa dang 'bad rtsol gyi sa las ring du song ba'i phyir de ltar brjod pa'o/ /

The interest of bodhisattvas from the first level up to the seventh is called firmly engaged interest. This is because there is no diminution or deterioration in their interest. The interest of bodhisattvas dwelling on the pure levels, from the eighth level to the tenth level, is called advanced interest, because they have spontaneous, nonconceptual interest and have therefore advanced far beyond the level of conceptual thoughts and effort.
de ltar tshigs bcad gnyis kyis mos pa'i rnam grangs bstan nas gnyis pa mos pa'i bar du gcod pa'i chos bcu drug ni/
These two verses describing the different categories of interest are now followed by an explanation of the sixteen obstacles to interest.
[gnyis pa]
b. SIXTEEN OBSTACLES TO INTEREST
yid la mi byed mang ba dang / / le lo rnal 'byor 'khrugs pa dang / / grogs ngan dge ba zhan pa dang / / tshul bzhin ma yin yid la byed/ /
Abundant failure to keep faith in mind, Laziness, disturbed practice, Bad company, feeble merit, And keeping incorrect ideas in mind, (XI, 4)
zhes pas bstan te/

chos la dad pa yid la mi byed pa mang ba ste shas cher gyur na/ des skyes pa'i mos pa la bar du gcod de/ sngon dang da ltar mos pa lan 'gar byung du zin kyang de'i rgyun bskyangs te yid la ma byas na dad pa de yal bar 'gyur bas so/ /

An abundant or predominant failure to keep faith in the Dharma in mind is an obstacle to arisen interest, because even if one has given rise to interest in the past and present a few times, if one does not preserve the flow of that interest by keeping it in mind, one’s faith will evaporate.
le lo ni dad pa ma skyes pa skye ba la bar du gcod de/ dad pa bskyed phyir ma brtson pa'i le lo can la dad pa mi skye ba'i phyir ro/ /
Laziness is an obstacle to nonarisen faith, because faith does not arise in lazy people who make no effort to develop it.

rnal 'byor 'khrugs pa zhes bya ba ni/ 'das pa'i dad pa bskyed pa de la dmigs nas gzung ba'i dngos por chags pa dang / de la 'dzin pa da ltar gyi mos pa la 'dzin pa'i dngos por chags pa byung ba des/ gzung 'dzin gyi dngos por ma zhen pa'i tshul bzhin yid la byed pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rnal 'byor la bar du gcod pa des na gzung ba'i mos pa dang / 'dzin pa'i mos pa gnyis la bar du gcod par bshad pa dang /

“Disturbed practice” is explained as attachment to the object from thinking of faith developed in the past, and attachment to the subject, the present interest that apprehends the latter. These interrupt the practice of concentration, which consists in proper attentiveness without clinging to subject and object. This is an obstacle to both objective and subjective interest.

grogs ngan te sdig pa'i grogs mi dge ba'i bshes gnyen ni/ grogs las blangs pa'i mos pa'i bar gcod yin te/ sngar dge ba'i grogs las blangs pa'i mos pa yod pa'am sdig grogs kyis chos min bstan pas chud za ba dang / sdig grogs kyis zin pa la dge ba'i bshes kyis bslabs pa las 'byung ba'i mos pa mi skye bas so/ /

“Bad company” refers to evil companions—unspiritual friends. It impedes interest received from a friend, because even if one already has the interest received from a virtuous friend, it goes to waste on account of the anti-Buddhist ways taught by evil companions, and because the interest that comes from being instructed by a spiritual friend cannot arise in someone who is guided by evil companions.

dge rtsa bsags pa zhan pa ni bdag nyid kyi mos pa la bar du gcod de/ bdag nyid la rigs dang mos pa'i sa bon yod kyang dge ba cher ma bsags na bdag nyid theg chen gyi chos sogs la mos pa mi 'byung bas so/ / rtag bde gtsang bdag gi rnam pas tshul bzhin ma yin pa'i yid la byed pas ma nor ba'i mos pa la bar du gcod de mi rtag pa sogs tshul bzhin mi rtogs pa'i phyir ro/ /

A feeble accumulation of sources of good is a hindrance to natural interest, because even if one has the potential and the seed of interest, one’s interest in the Mahāyāna teachings and so on will not emerge if one has not accumulated a great deal of merit. Keeping incorrect ideas in mind—that things are permanent, happy, pure, and endowed with a self—hinders unmistaken interest, for one cannot then realize correctly that things are impermanent and so forth.
bag med pa dang thos pa nyung / / thos dang bsam pa nyung ngus chog / zhi ba tsam gyis nga rgyal dang / / de bzhin ma 'dris yin par 'dod/ /
Carelessness, and little learning, Being satisfied with little learning and reflection, Pride in calm alone, and likewise, it is held, Failure to habituate, (XI, 5)

bag med pas ni mngon du ba'am mngon sum pa'i mos pa la bar du gcod de/ mngon sum pa'i mos pa ni chags sdang gti mug med pa dang brtson 'grus kyi rkyen las skye la/ rkyen de bzhi la bag yod ces bya zhing / chags sdang gti mug le lo bzhi ni bag med ces bya ba yin pas des de ltar bar du gcod do/ /

Carelessness obstructs manifest interest. Manifest interest arises through one’s not having attachment, aversion, and bewilderment, and through diligence. These four conditions constitute carefulness, while attachment, aversion, bewilderment, and laziness constitute carelessness and therefore prevent manifest interest from arising.

drang don gyi mdo sde tsam thos kyi nges don stong pa nyid kyi chos sogs ma thos pa lta bu don nyi tshe ba ston pa'i thos pa nyung ba yis sgras byung gi mos pa la bar du gcod de gang ma thos pa de'i don mi shes pas de la mos pa mi 'byung zhing nges don gyi phyogs ma thos pa dag stong pa nyid sogs zab mo'i don la skrag nas mi mos pa'i phyir ro/ /

Receiving only a little teaching on limited topics—for example, hearing only the expedient teachings taught in the sūtras but not the ultimate teachings on emptiness and so on—hinders sound-produced interest. Since one cannot know about a subject that one has not studied, one will not have any faith in it. And people who have not heard the ultimate teachings are afraid of profound subjects like emptiness and do not have faith in them.

bsam pa dang bsgom pa mi dgos par thos pa tsam gyis chog par 'dzin pa dang / thos pa rgya chen po mi dgos par thos pa gang yang rung ba nyung ngus chog par 'dzin pas ni/ tshol ba'i mos pa la bar du gcod de/ des bsam byung gi shes rab kyis drangs pa'i mos pa mi bskyed pa'am cung zad bskyed kyang rgya che ba dang mthar phyin pa rdzogs par skyed mi nus pa'i phyir dang /

Considering that it is sufficient to hear the teachings without needing to reflect and meditate, and being satisfied with hearing only a few teachings on any subject without needing to study extensively both hinder investigative interest. As a result of such complacency, one cannot develop the interest deriving from the wisdom that comes from reflection; even if one develops it a little, one will not be able to develop it completely and on a vast scale.

thos pa'i don la bsam pa'am cung zad bsam na yang rgya cher ma bsam pa nyung ngus chog par 'dzin pas kyang snga ma bzhin du bsam byung gis tshol ba'i mos pa la bar du gcod de/ mdor na thos bsam nyung ngus chog 'dzin ni/ bsam byung gi mos pa mi skye ba'am cung zad skyes kyang legs par rdzogs pa'i gegs yin no/ /

Failure to reflect on the meaning of the teachings one has heard, or even if one does reflect a bit, to be satisfied with reflecting on them only a little and not very extensively is also, as in the previous case, an impediment to the investigative interest that comes from reflection. In short, if one thinks that it is enough to listen to a few teachings and to reflect on them a little bit, the interest that comes from reflection will not arise or, even if it arises a bit, it will be prevented from doing so properly and completely.

zhi ba tsam gyi nga rgyal ni/ zhi gnas tsam gyis chog par bzung nas lhag mthong mi skyed par phyi rol du g.yeng ba'i rnam rtog zhi ba de tsam gyis chog pa'i nga rgyal byed pa ste/ des lta ba'i mos pa'am sgom byung gi mos pa la bar du gcod de/ lhag mthong med par zhi gnas tsam gyis bden par rtogs par mi 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / der ma zad bsam pa tsam gyis chog par bzung nas bsgom pa la mi sbyor ba yang lta ba'i mos pa'i gegs yin no/ / blta ba zhes pa dri sha'i sgra las mthong ba la yang 'jug pas sems mnyam par bzhag pa'i bsgoms pa las yang dag pa'i don mthong ba'i phyir ro/ /

Pride in calm alone refers to being content with sustained calm alone and becoming self-satisfied, considering that it is enough simply to calm distracting thoughts without developing profound insight. This is an impediment to the interest of the view or interest that comes from meditation, because without profound insight, sustained calm on its own will not result in one’s realizing the truth. Moreover, failure to apply oneself to meditation, thinking that reflection alone is sufficient, is also a hindrance to the interest of the view. “View,” from the Sanskrit word dṛśa, also has the meaning of “seeing”: by meditating, settling the mind in evenness, one sees the truth.

de bzhin ma 'dres yin pas 'dod ces pas/ snga ma de bzhin du/ yang nas yang du rang rgyud la mos pa de goms shing 'dris par ma byas pa'am ma 'dris pa ni/ 'phrog pa'i mos pa dang / 'dres pa'i mos pa gnyis la bar du gcod de/ mos pa yang yang rang rgyud la goms 'dris ma byas pa'i dbang gis/ mos pa skyes kyang rkyen gzhan gyis 'phrogs su rung ba dang / dad mi dad 'dres mar 'byung ba yin la/ ma 'dres pa de las bzlog ste shin tu 'dris goms che ba'i mos pa ni rkyen gyis 'phrog dka' ba dang / bar skabs su ma dad pa yang 'byung dka' 'o/ / de'i phyir de gnyis kyis bar gcod ni mos pa rang rgyud la ma 'dris pa yin par 'dod do/ /

“And likewise, failure to habituate” means that, as in the previous case, failure to accustom oneself to interest again and again, or to blend it with one’s mind, is a hindrance to both expropriable interest and mixed interest. As a result of not training one’s mind again and again in interest, any interest one has is liable to be ravished away by other circumstances, and one’s faith will alternate with lack of faith. The opposite of failure to integrate interest is thoroughly familiarized interest, which makes it hard for one’s interest to be expropriated by circumstances, and also hard for occasional lack of faith to occur. For this reason, it is asserted that the obstacle to these two is not habituating one’s mind to interest.
mi skyo ba dang de bzhin skyo/ / bsgribs pa dang ni mi brtson pa/ / tshogs ma bsags pa mos pa yis/ / bar du gcod par shes par bya/ /
Lack of disenchantment, and likewise disenchantment, Being obscured, lack of diligence, And failure to accumulate merit— These are recognized as obstacles to interest. (XI, 6)

'khor ba la mi skyo ba ni theg pa chung ngu'i mos pa la bar du gcod byed de/ 'khor ba la mi skyo bar chags na zhi bde don du mi gnyer ba yin pa'i phyir dang / de bzhin du 'khor ba la mtha' gcig tu skyo ba ni/ theg pa rgya che ba la mos pa'i bar gcod de/ 'khor bar skyo nas de yongs su 'dor 'dod kyis nyan thos bzhin du rang nyid zhi bar gzhol ba'i phyir ro/ /

Lack of disenchantment with saṃsāra hinders interest in the lesser vehicles because if one is attached to saṃsāra and does not weary of it, one will not strive for peace and happiness. Similarly, being solely disenchanted with saṃsāra is an obstacle to interest in the Extensive Vehicle. This is because, in being fed up with saṃsāra and wanting to abandon it completely, one strives for one’s own peace, like the listeners.

bsgribs pa ni gong du bsgribs pa'i mos pa'i skabs su bshad pa'i bsgribs pa de dag ni/ ma bsgribs pa'i mos pa'i bar gcod yin pa dang ni/ mi brtson pa ni brtson pa'i mos pa la bar du gcod do/ / tshogs rnams ma bsags pa ni/ tshogs bsags pa'i mos pa 'byung ba yi bar du gcod par shes par bya'o/ /

Being obscured, which was explained above with obscured interest, is an obstacle to unobscured interest. Lack of diligence hinders diligent interest. Failure to accumulate merit and wisdom is an obstacle to the arising of interest with accumulated merit.

de ltar bar chad bcu drug las ma bshad pa ni/ nor ba dang / mngon sum min pa dang / bsgribs pa dang / mi brtson pa dang / tshogs ma bsags pa lnga ni/ mi mthun phyogs kyis zin pa yin pas de dag gi bar chad gzhan bshad ma dgos la/ ma 'dres brtan zhugs ring song gsum gnyen po bar chad dang bral ba yin pas de'i bar chad med la gzung 'dzin gnyis dang 'phrog 'dres gnyis kyi bar chad gcig yin pas mos pa bcu phri ba'i phyir bar chad bcu drug tu 'dus so/ /

The above explains only sixteen obstacles that need to be recognized. This is because five kinds of interest—namely, mistaken, nonmanifest, obscured, nondiligent, and without accumulated merit—are already permeated by incompatible factors, so there is no need to mention separate obstacles for them. In addition, three kinds of interest—unadulterated, firmly engaged, and advanced—are free from counteragents that hinder them, and so there are no obstacles to them. Subjective interest and objective interest share a single hindrance, as do expropriable interest and mixed interest. This makes ten fewer kinds of interest, bringing the number of factors that impede interest to sixteen.

bsam byung la thos pas chog pa dang / thos pa nyung ngus chog pa gnyis/ bsgom byung mos pa la bsam pa tsam gyis chog pa dang / zhi ba tsam gyi nga rgyal so sor phye na bar chad bco brgyad du bgrang rung yang / bar du gcad bya'i sgo nas bcu drug byas pa legs so/ / de ltar mos pa so so dang ma sbyar bar spyir yang chos bcu drug po 'di dag gis mos pa la ci rigs su sgrib pas spang bar bya ba yin no/ /

It is also possible to count a total of eighteen obstacles by counting two hindrances for the interest that gives rise to reflection (namely, being content with merely hearing the teachings and being content with hearing only a few teachings) and by separating the hindrances to the interest that gives rise to meditation (namely, being content with only reflecting on the teachings and having pride in mere calm). However, in terms of the kinds of interest that are hindered, it is better to count them as sixteen. Thus, although these sixteen factors do not correspond to each of the different kinds of interest, in general they obscure all forms of interest and are therefore to be avoided.
gsum pa mos pa'i phan yon bcu gcig ni/
c. ELEVEN BENEFITS OF HAVING INTEREST
bsod nams che dang 'gyod pa med/ / yid bde ba dang bde ba che/ / chud mi za dang brtan pa dang / / de bzhin khyad par 'gro ba dang / /
Great merit, absence of regret, Mental bliss, and great bliss, No wastage, stability, And similarly enhancement, (XI, 7)
zhes tshigs bcad gnyis kyis bstan te/
da lta'i mos pa ni chos la dad pa'i bsod nams che ba dpag tu med pa 'phel ba dang /
Present interest infinitely increases the great merit of faith in the Dharma.

'das pa'i mos pa ni sngon theg chen gyi chos la mos pa ni dge ba yin pas da ltar yang des 'gyod pa med pas so/ / gzung ba'i dngos po la dngos por ma chags pa'i de kho na nyid kyi phyogs gcig bzung ba rang bzhin med rtogs kyi ting nge 'dzin thob pas yid bde ba dang /

Past interest, that is, past interest in the Mahāyāna teachings, is meritorious, and so in the present too it is not a cause for regret. As a result of obtaining the concentration that realizes the absence of intrinsic existence in the object—that is, partial realization of thatness, where there is no attachment to the external object as substantially existent—one acquires mental bliss.
'dzin pa rang bzhin med rtogs kyi mos pa chos mchog gam de ma thag pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi bde ba che dang ldan pa dang /

With the interest related to realization of the absence of intrinsic existence in the subject, one gains the great bliss of the concentration of the supreme mundane level or “immediately preceding concentration.”[4]
grogs blangs kyi mos par rkyen gyis bar chad ma byas na dge ba chud mi za ba'i yon tan thob pa dang /
With the interest received from a friend, provided it is not interrupted by circumstances, one obtains the benefit of one’s merit not being wasted.
bdag nyid kyi mos par bar chad med na dge rtsa mi nyams par brtan pa dang
Natural interest, if not obstructed, leads to one’s sources of good becoming stable and not diminishing.

snga ma de bzhin du ma nor ba/ mngon sum/ sgras byung / tshol ba/ lta ba/ 'phrog pa/ ma 'dres pa'i mos pa bdun la mi mthun phyogs kyis bar du ma bcad na de rnams so so rang gi mos pa de dag gong nas gong du khyad par du 'gro ba'i yon tan thob ste/ nor ba med pa 'bring las/ nor ba med pa chen po skye ba sogs so/ /

In the same way as the above, unmistaken interest, evident interest, sound-produced interest, investigative interest, the interest of the view, expropriable interest, and unadulterated interest (seven in all), if not hindered by counteragents, each have the benefit of being self-enhancing. Middling unmistaken interest, for example, gives rise to great unmistaken interest, and so on.
chos ni mngon par rtogs pa dang / / bdag dang gzhan don thob pa'i mchog / mngon shes myur ba de dag ni/ / mos pa yi ni phan yon yin/ /
Direct realization of the nature of phenomena, The supreme attainment of one’s own and others’ goals, And quick preternatural knowledge— These are the benefits of interest. (XI, 8)
mi mthun pa'i phyogs dang ma 'dres pa'i mos pa bar chad med na chos rnams ni mngon par rtogs par 'gyur te sa dang po thob par 'gyur ro/ /
Interest unadulterated by counteragents, if not hindered, leads to direct realization of the nature of phenomena and attainment of the first bodhisattva level.
theg dman la mos pas bar du gcod pa gzhan med na bdag gi don zhi ba myang 'das thob pa dang /
Interest in the lesser vehicles, if not interrupted by anything else, leads to the attainment of nirvāṇa, the goal of peace for oneself.
theg chen la mos pa bar chad dang bral na/ bdag dang gzhan gyi don gnyis ka thob pa'i mchog tu 'gyur ro/ /
Interest in the Great Vehicle, if unobstructed, yields the supreme attainment of both one’s own and others’ goals.

bsgribs med/ brtson pa/ tshogs bsags/ brtan zhugs/ ring song gi mos pa lnga po rkyen gyi gegs dang bral na/ mngon shes myur ba yi yon tan thob ste/ snga ma gsum gyis dbang po rno ba'i mchog thob la/ phyi ma gnyis kyis myur du thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes thob bo/ /

Unobscured interest, diligent interest, interest with accumulated merit, firmly engaged interest, and advanced interest (five in all), if free of obstructing conditions, lead to one’s gaining the qualities of quick preternatural knowledge. With the first three, one obtains the sharpest faculties, while with the last two one swiftly acquires omniscient gnosis.
de ltar rnam grangs bcu gcig bshad pa de dag ni/ mos pa yi ni phan yon yin no/ /
These eleven explanations concern the benefits of interest.

nor ba/ mngon sum min/ ma 'ongs pa/ bsgribs pa/ mi brtson/ ma bsags pa'i mos pa drug la phan yon ma bshad de/ de dag la phan yon srid pa rnams ni dad pa'i phan yon ci rigs su 'dus la/ ma 'ongs pa'i mos pa ma skyes pa sogs dang / nor ba sogs bar chad dang bcas pa'i phyir ro/ /

For six kinds of interest—mistaken, nonevident, future, obscured, and nondiligent interest, and interest without accumulated merit—the benefits are not described because any possible benefits they might have are included in the benefits of faith; future interest has not yet arisen; and mistaken interest and others constitute obstacles.
de ltar mos pa'i phan yon 'di dag so sor ma phye bar spyir dad pa'i phan yon du yang shes nas dad pa bskyed par bya'o/ /
Apart from distinguishing each of these benefits individually, you should recognize that in general the benefits of interest are also those of faith, so make an effort to develop faith.
gsum pa theg pa chen po'i mos pa bye brag tu bshad pa la/
2. SPECIFIC EXPLANATION OF INTEREST IN THE GREAT VEHICLE
theg chen la mos pa'i khyad par dpes bstan pa ni/
a. SHOWING BY SIMILES THE SUPERIORITY OF INTEREST IN THE GREAT VEHICLE
'dod pa can gyi de khyi 'dra/ / ting nge 'dzin pa'i rus sbal bzhin/ / rang don byed pa'i de bran 'dra/ / gzhan don byed pa'i rgyal po bzhin/ /

The interest of the desirous is like a dog, That of those with concentration is like a turtle, That of those who achieve their own goal is like a servant, And that of those who achieve others’ goal is like a king. (XI, 9)
zhes pas bstan te/

phyi rol gyi 'dod yon lnga la chags shing de la longs spyod pa'i 'dod khams pa 'dod pa can gyi mos pa de ni dper na khyi dang 'dra'o/ / 'jig rten pa'i bsam gzugs kyi ting nge 'dzin gyis phyi rol gyi g.yeng ba spangs te nang du mnyam par bzhag pa'i sa pa'i mos pa ni rus sbal bzhin no/ / nyan rang gang zhig rang nyid 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal las thar bar byed pa'i mos pa ni bran dang 'dra'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' sems can gzhan thams cad kyi don byed pa'i mos pa ni rgyal po bzhin no/ / de'i don rgyas par bshad pa/

A simile for the interest of beings full of desire—inhabitants of the world of desire who are attached to and enjoy the five external sense pleasures—is that it is like a dog. The interest of mundane beings who have abandoned external distractions by means of the concentrations of the worlds of form and formlessness and dwell in states of inner equipoise is like a turtle. The interest of listeners and solitary realizers, who obtain liberation for themselves from the sufferings of saṃsāra, is like a servant. And the interest of bodhisattvas, who benefit all other sentient beings, is like a king. The meaning of these similes is explained in detail in the next two verses.

ji ltar khyi ni rtag tu ltogs shing sdug bsngal gyis nyen chog mi shes/ / ji ltar rus sbal de ni chu yi nang na kun nas bskums shing 'dug / ji ltar bran ni rtag tu 'jigs shing skrag pa'i lus kyis rnam par rgyu/ / ji ltar rgyal po yang ni bka' yis yul la dbang sgyur gnas pa ltar/ / de bzhin g.yem dang gnas dang rang gzhan phan bya don byed pa'i/ / mos pa sna tshogs dag gi rtag tu khyad par shes par bya/ / theg pa chen po de la de mchog tshul bzhin rig nas ni/ / 'di na brtan pas de la de nyid rtag par rab tu tshol/ /

Just as a dog is constantly tormented by hunger and never satisfied, A turtle in the water remains completely withdrawn, A servant moves around, their body always cowed in fear, And a king governs his dominion by his edicts, (XI, 10) Similarly, you should always distinguish among the various kinds of interest Of those who are distracted, who remain withdrawn, who benefit themselves, and who bring benefit to others. The steadfast who properly understand that interest in the Great Vehicle is best Will, in this context, forever seek that same interest in it. (XI, 11)

ji ltar khyi dang 'dra na/ khyi ni rtag tu ltogs shing / bkres pa'i yid dang zas kyis dbul ba'i sdug bsngal gyis nyen bzhin zas la chog mi shes pa'i yid dang / ji ltar rus sbal de ni chu yi nang na gzhan gyis 'tsher dogs pas rang gi yan lag kun nas nang du bskums shing 'dug go / ji ltar rgyal po sogs kyi bran ni dus rtag tu rje bo'i sems dang tshig las 'gal bar dogs pas 'jigs shing skrag pa'i lus kyi rje bo'i bya ba la rnam par rgyu'o/ / ji ltar rgyal po yang ni rang gi bka' yis chab 'og gi yul 'dod dgur dbang bsgyur te gnas pa ltar ro/ / rim pa de bzhin du khyi ltar 'dod khams pa rnams phyi'i 'dod yon la rtag tu g.yel zhing g.yeng bas rang dbang med par 'dod pa'i dbang du 'phyan pa dang / khams gong ma gnyis kyi ros g.yeng bas 'jigs nas bdag gi sems byung rnams nang du bsdus pa tsam la gnas pa las shes bya'i rang bzhin zab cing rgya che ba'i chos la blo ma phyogs pas rus sbal 'khum pa lta bu'i mos pa can yin pa dang /

In what way is interest like a dog? Dogs are constantly hungry, forever afflicted by their desire for food and by the lack of it; their appetites are insatiable. A turtle, fearful of the other creatures in the water, retreats into its shell and stays there. The servant of a king or other master goes about the tasks their master has set them with their body constantly cowed, out of fear of displeasing or disobeying him. And a king, with the orders he gives, maintains his authority over the lands under his dominion as he pleases. In the same way, taking these similes in order, the inhabitants of the world of desire, like dogs, spend their whole time in carefree distraction, indulging in the pleasures of the senses; dominated by their desires, they wander helplessly. Those in the two higher worlds, afraid of being distracted from the experience of those states, concentrate their mental functions inward and dwell only on that, with no mental affinity for the profound and extensive Dharma that teaches the nature of knowable phenomena. The interest they have is like a turtle drawn into its shell.

nyan thos ni rang don du rang la phan par bya ba'i don 'ba' zhig lhur len rnams 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal gyis shin tu 'jigs shing / 'khor ba de las thar pa'i thabs chos kyi rgyal po de bzhin gshegs pa'i bslab pa bcas pa las cung zad cig 'gal na yang thar lam la sgrib cing rnam smin yid du mi 'ong ba thob par 'gyur ro zhes skrag bzhin 'khor ba las myur du thar pa'i thabs la ches 'bad par byed pa'i de'i mos pa ni bran rnams kyi mos pa dang tshul 'dra'o/ /

The listeners and solitary realizers, who devote themselves only to benefiting themselves, are terrified of the sufferings of saṃsāra. They are afraid that if they slightly transgress the precepts of the Tathāgata, the Sovereign of the Dharma, which constitute the means for attaining liberation from that saṃsāra, the path to liberation will be obscured and they will obtain unpleasant fully ripened effects. So they apply great effort to the means for swiftly liberating themselves from saṃsāra. Their interest is like that of a servant.

byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi mos pa ni/ ji ltar rgyal po sngon gyi tshogs bsags pa dang ldan pas yul khams la rang dbang 'byor ba ltar/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams shes rab snying rje chen po'i stobs kyis 'khor bar gnas kyang 'khor ba'i skyon gyis mi gos pa dang / zhi ba phyogs gcig pa'i mtha' la mi gnas kyang zhi ba'i go 'phang la 'das pas 'khor 'das gnyis kar dbang gyur te bdag gi don dang gzhan don sems can thams cad la 'di dang gtan du phan par bya ba'i don phun sum tshogs par byed pa'i phyir/ de ltar 'dod khams pa dang / khams gong ma gnyis 'jig rten pa dang / nyan rang rnams 'jig rten las 'das pa de dag gi mos pa dag las/ byang chub sems dpa'i mos pa ni ches mchog tu gyur pa'i phyir na/ sems can khams kyi mos pa sna tshogs pa mi 'dra ba dag gi nang rtag tu theg chen la dad pa byang chub sems dpa'i mos pa ni khyad par du 'phags pa kho na yin par shes par bya zhing / de ltar shes pa'i phyir na sangs rgyas kyi gsung theg pa chen po de la de nyid gzhan las mchog tu gyur pa yin par tshul bzhin rig nas ni/ mos pas 'jug pa'i skabs 'di na byang chub sems dpa' brtan pas theg pa chen po'i chos de la mos pa de nyid rtag par rab tu tshol bar byed do/ /

The bodhisattvas’ interest is like a king. Just as a king has dominion over his kingdom on account of his accumulation of merit in the past, bodhisattvas, because of their great wisdom and compassion, are untainted by the defects of saṃsāra even though they dwell in saṃsāra. And while they do not dwell in the one-sided extreme of peace, they have, rather, transcended the state of peace. They thus have dominion over both saṃsāra and nirvāṇa, and they fulfill the perfect goal of benefiting both themselves and all other sentient beings, now and forever. So the bodhisattva’s interest is far superior to the interests of mundane beings in the world of desire and in the two higher worlds and of supramundane beings like listeners and solitary realizers. For this reason, of all the different varieties of interest in beings’ natures, you should always know that bodhisattvas’ interest, their faith in the Great Vehicle, is the most exalted. Because they know that, steadfast bodhisattvas have properly understood that interest in the Great Vehicle taught by the Buddha is superior to others, and, in this context of setting out on the path with interest, they are forever pursuing interest in the teachings of the Great Vehicle.
[ma zhugs par spro bas 'jug par gdams pa]
b. INSTRUCTIONS ON FOLLOWING THE GREAT VEHICLE ENTHUSIASTICALLY WITHOUT GETTING DISCOURAGED

de ltar mos pa'i khyad par dpes bstan nas theg chen de la ma zhugs par spro bas 'jug par gdams pa la ma zhugs par 'jug pa dang*/ bsod nams chen po 'byung phyir spro bas 'jug pa dang / yon tan gsum bstan pa'i sgo nas 'jug par bstan pas mjug sdud pa gsum las/

This explanation illustrating the superiority of such interest is followed by instructions on following the Great Vehicle enthusiastically without getting discouraged, which has three parts: (1) following the Great Vehicle without getting discouraged; (2) following it enthusiastically because it gives rise to immense merit; and (3) a summary on following the Great Vehicle in terms of three virtues.
dang po/
i. FOLLOWING THE GREAT VEHICLE WITHOUT GETTING DISCOURAGED
gang phyir sems can mir gyur pas/ / tshad med skad cig re re la/ / rdzogs pa'i byang chub thob de'i phyir/ / zhum pa dang du blang mi bya/ /
Sentient beings born as humans, In infinite numbers, in every instant, Attain perfect enlightenment, So do not give in to losing heart. (XI, 12)
zhes pas bstan te/

theg pa chen po ni lam gyi dus su mgo yan lag gtong ba sogs dang / 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal gyis mi 'jigs pa'i dka' spyad dang du len dgos pa dang / de ltar byas na 'bras bu yon tan rmad du byung ba'i sangs rgyas 'grub pa yin mod kyi/ de ni gang zag chen po 'ga' zhig gi spyod yul yin gyi bdag lta bu sems can mir gyur pa phal gyis thob pa ga la nus snyam du sems zhum par mi bya ste/ gang gi phyir na sems can rten mir gyur pas/ zhes byang chub 'grub pa'i rten ni lha yi rten las kyang mi mchog yin la/ mis sangs rgyas thob pa de yang mi la res 'ga' tsam dang nyung ngu tsam ma yin te/ tshad med pa mang pos sangs rgyas de thob pa dang / de dag dus res 'ga' na srid pa tsam yang ma yin te da lta'i skad cig re re la yang / phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten mu med pa rnams su byang chub sems dpa' tshad med pas bla med rdzogs pa'i byang chub thob pa yod pa de'i phyir/ bdag gis byang chub thob mi nus snyam pa'i zhums pa dang du blang bar mi bya ste/ bdag kyang mir skyes la gzhan kyang mir skyes pa 'dra la/ de dag gis kyang theg pa chen po'i lam la mos spyod nas rim par bslabs pas shes rab dang snying rje stobs su gyur te 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal la sgyu ma ltar shes shing / sems can yongs su mi gtong ba'i snying rje chen po'i shugs rdzogs pa'i tshe byang chub kyi spyod pa la dga' ba'i 'du shes med par ma zad ches dga' ba rtogs pa med pa 'jig rten gyi bde ba gang gis kyang 'gran mi nus pa la spyad nas don chen po sangs rgyas nyid thob pa de ltar bdag gis kyang cis mi 'thob ste/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag kyang dang por bdag lta bu'i sems can phal pa yin yang theg pa chen po'i chos la zhugs nas de ltar gyur pa'i phyir ro/ /

In the Great Vehicle, when one is on the path, one has to willingly assume the difficult practices of giving away one’s head and limbs and so forth and of having no fear with regard to the sufferings of saṃsāra, and it is by doing so that one accomplishes the result, buddhahood, with all its marvelous qualities. Nevertheless, you should never be discouraged and think, “This is the domain of a few great beings; how can an ordinary human being like me achieve that?” Why? “Sentient beings born as humans” are the best support for accomplishing enlightenment. They are superior in this respect even to those born as celestial beings. Humans do attain buddhahood, and not just some, not just a few. Many infinite human beings have attained buddhahood. Nor is this possible only occasionally. Right now, with every instant that passes, in the boundless universes in the ten directions, there are infinite bodhisattvas attaining unsurpassable perfect enlightenment. So never give in to losing heart and thinking, “I’ll never be able to get enlightened.” Instead, encourage yourself as follows: “In being born human, I am just the same as other human beings. By training gradually on the Mahāyāna path from the stage of earnest aspiration onward, they gain the power of wisdom and compassion: they understand the sufferings of saṃsāra to be like magical illusions, and they perfect the force of great compassion that never, ever abandons sentient beings. At that time, not only do they not think of the bodhisattva’s practice as being difficult, but they experience the greatest, purest joy, with which no mundane bliss can possibly compare, and they attain the great goal, buddhahood. Why should I not do likewise? Those bodhisattvas also started off as ordinary beings like myself, but after following the teachings of the Great Vehicle, that is how they have ended up.”
gnyis pa/
ii. FOLLOWING THE GREAT VEHICLE ENTHUSIASTICALLY BECAUSE IT GIVES RISE TO IMMENSE MERIT

gzhan dag la ni zas sbyin pa'i/ / bsod nams 'phel ba ji lta bar/ / bdag nyid za ba'i ma yin pa/ / de bzhin gzhan don rten gyi chos/ / bstan las mdo las gsungs pa yi/ / bsod nams cher 'byung thob pa ltar/ / rang gi don gyi rten gyi chos/ / bstan las thob pa ma yin no/ /

Just as merit grows From giving food to others But not from eating food oneself, The greater merit of which the sūtras speak (XI, 13) Is acquired from teaching The way of altruistic aims And not from teaching The way that is based on selfish goals. (XI, 14)
zhes pas bstan te/

theg pa chen po'i chos de la thog mar mos pa tsam yang phan yon tshad med pa'i gnas yin na tshul bzhin nyams su len pa lta ci smos so/ / de ci'i phyir na gzhan don byed par ston pa'i chos yin pa'i phyir te/ 'di ltar sems can gzhan dag la kha zas byin pa'i bsod nams 'phel ba ji lta bar/ bdag nyid kyis kha zas za ba'i dbang gis bsod nams thob pa ma yin pa de bzhin du sems can gzhan don du 'gyur ba'i rten can gyi chos theg pa gzhan la bstan cing rang gi mos pa bskyed pa las ni/ mdo las gsungs pa yi bsod nams cher 'byung ba/ dper na zhing mtha' yas pa rin po che sna bdun gyis yongs su bkang ste de bzhin gshegs pa rnams la phul ba las/ theg chen gyi chos tshigs bcad gcig bshad pa phan yon khyad par 'phags pa thob pa de ltar/ rang gi don gyi rten gyi chos theg dman bstan pa las ni phan yon bzang po yod mod kyi theg chen bstan pa'i phan yon ltar thob pa ma yin no/ /

If simply having an initial interest in the Mahāyāna teachings is a source of boundless benefits, one need hardly mention the benefits of practicing them properly. Why should that be so? Because they are the teachings that show how to achieve others’ goals. Just as there is increasing merit in giving food to other beings but none in eating food oneself, teaching others the Great Vehicle, the path that is the basis for helping other sentient beings, and developing interest in the Great Vehicle oneself give rise to the greater merit that has been mentioned in the sūtras. The benefit acquired by expounding a single verse of the Mahāyāna teachings, for example, is far superior to that of offering to the tathāgatas infinite buddha fields filled with the seven precious attributes of royalty. Likewise, although there are certainly excellent benefits to be derived from teaching the lower vehicles that are the basis for one’s own good, they do not procure benefits like those of teaching the Great Vehicle.
gsum pa mjug sdud kyi tshigs bcad ni/
iii. A SUMMARY ON FOLLOWING THE GREAT VEHICLE IN TERMS OF THREE VIRTUES

de ltar 'phags pa chen po'i chos ni yangs gyur pa/ / blo dang ldan pas rtag tu mos pa cher bskyed na/ / bsod nams rgya chen rgyun mi 'chad dang de 'phel dang / / yon tan dpag tu med pas bdag nyid chen por 'gyur/ /

And thus, if the wise constantly increase their interest In the vast doctrine of the great noble ones, They will gain immense and uninterrupted merit, their interest will grow, And they will attain buddhahood with all its boundless qualities. (XI, 15)
zhes pas bstan te/

de ltar 'phags pa chen po'i zhes theg chen 'phags pa'i lam gyi chos ni yangs shing rgya che bar gyur pa la byang chub sems dpa' blo dang ldan pas dus rtag tu mos pa cher bskyed par byas na bsod nams rgya chen po rgyun mi 'chad par 'byung ba dang / mos pa de nyid gong nas gong du sa bcu pa'i bar du 'phel ba dang / mthar thug yon tan dpag tu med pa'i bdag nyid bla med byang chub chen por 'gyur ro/ /

Thus, if wise bodhisattvas constantly develop greater interest in the extensive Dharma, the path of “the great noble beings” (that is, of the noble beings of the Great Vehicle), an unbroken stream of immense merit will be produced. Their interest will grow greater and greater up to the tenth level. And finally, they will attain unsurpassable great enlightenment, with all its boundless good qualities.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ mos pa'i le'u ste bcu gcig pa'o// //
This completes the eleventh chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on the attitude—faith or interest in the Great Vehicle.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ bsam pa theg chen la dad pa'am mos pa'i le'u ste bcu gcig pa rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the eleventh chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on the attitude—faith or interest in the Great Vehicle.
[yongs su tshol ba]
12. THOROUGH INVESTIGATION

! de ltar mos pa'i le'u bshad nas mos pa tsam gyis mi chog par gang la mos pa theg pa chen po'i chos zab cing rgya che ba rnams thos bsam bsgoms pa'i shes rab kyis yongs su tshol ba'i sgo nas thos pa mang du bsags shing de'i don la nges par rnyed par bya dgos pas chos tshol gyi le'u bshad pa 'di la btsal bya'i chos dang / yid la byed pa gang gis tshol ba dang / yongs su tshol ba'i bye brag dang / chos tshol ba'i 'bras bu dang / don bsdu ba'i tshigs bcad dang lnga las/

On its own, interest, as described in the previous chapter, is not sufficient. It is necessary to use the wisdom gained through listening, reflecting, and meditating to investigate what one is interested in—namely, the profound and extensive teachings of the Great Vehicle—so that one acquires a wide knowledge of the teachings and gains certainty as to what they mean. This is why there now follows the chapter on investigating the Dharma, which has five sections: (1) the Dharma that has to be investigated; (2) the different forms of attentiveness used in investigation; (3) specific kinds of thorough investigation; (4) the results of investigating the Dharma; and (5) a concluding summary verse.
dang po
1. THE DHARMA THAT HAS TO BE INVESTIGATED
['di] la/ bshad bya lung gi chos btsal ba dang / rtogs bya don gyi chos btsal ba gnyis/
This section has two parts: (1) investigating the Dharma of transmission that is to be expounded and (2) investigating the Dharma whose meaning is to be realized.
dang po
a. INVESTIGATING THE DHARMA OF TRANSMISSION THAT IS TO BE EXPOUNDED
['di] la/ dmigs pa gsung rab nyid yongs su btsal ba dang / des bstan don dmigs pa rnyed pa yongs su btsal ba dang / tshol byed yid la byed pa yongs su btsal ba gsum las/

The first of these is divided into three: (1) thorough investigation of the subject, the Buddha’s Excellent Words; (2) thorough investigation in discovering the point, the meaning indicated by the three scriptural collections; and (3) thorough investigation of the investigator, attentiveness.
dang po
i. THOROUGH INVESTIGATION OF THE SUBJECT, THE BUDDHA’S EXCELLENT WORDS
sde snod dag ni gsum mam gnyis kyang rung / / bsdus pa'i phyir te rgyu ni dgur 'dod do/ / des ni bag chags rtogs dang zhi ba dang / / rab tu rtogs pas rnam par grol bar byed/ /

The scriptural collections are summarized as two or three, The reasons for which are held to be ninefold. Through habitual inclination, understanding, pacification, And full realization, they bring one to perfect liberation. (XII, 1)
zhes tshigs bcad bzhi gsungs so/ /

shes rab gsum gyis yul gang la dmigs pa bstan pa'i phyir/ de la dmigs pa ni sangs rgyas kyi gsung rab sde snod kyi chos yin la/ de yang pI Taka zhes pa sde snod de/ de'i nang du shes bya'i don mang po 'dus pa'i phyir de skad btags te/ yul dbus kyi bre bo che la'ang ming de 'jug pa ni/ de'i nang du bre chung mang po 'dus shing shong ba bzhin/ 'dir yang sde snod der brjod bya shes bya'i don mang po 'dus pa'i phyir ro/ / sde snod dag gi dbye ba ni mdo sde'i sde snod/ 'dul ba'i sde snod/ mngon pa'i sde snod gsum mam yang na theg pa chen po byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod dang / theg pa chung ngu nyan thos kyi sde snod gnyis su bsdus kyang rung ngo / / sde snod kyi nges tshig ni don mang po de'i nang du bsdus pa'i phyir te/ gong du bstan pa bzhin no/ / gsung rab la rgyas par yan lag bcu gnyis su dbye ste/ mdo sde dbyangs bsnyad lung bstan tshigs su bcad/ / ched brjod gleng gzhi rtogs brjod da ltar byung / / skyes rabs rgyas dang rmad byung gtan la dbab/ / zhes pa bzhin no/ / de dag las shin tu rgyas par chen po dang / skyes rabs ni byang sems kyi sde snod dang / lhag ma rnams las phal cher nyan thos dang theg pa chen po'i thun mong bar gyur pa'ang yod/ phal cher nyan thos kyi sde snod la gtogs pa'ang yod/ bcu gnyis po de dag kyang bsdu na sde snod gsum du 'du'o/ /

The subject that we have to examine with the three kinds of wisdom is the Dharma that comprises the collections of the Buddha’s Excellent Words. The Sanskrit word piṭaka, meaning a basket, is used for these collections because a great many topics are collected within them. In India the term is also used for a large measure, capable of holding many small measures. And in this context too, what we call the scriptural collections include numerous topics. The categories of these collections may be summarized as three—the Sūtra Collection, Vinaya Collection, and Abhidharma Collection—or, alternatively, as two: namely, the bodhisattvas’ collection, or Great Vehicle, and the listeners’ collection, or Lesser Vehicle. The etymological definition of the term “collection”—as something in which numerous points are collected—has just been explained. A detailed classification of the Buddha’s Excellent Words comprises twelve branches, described as condensed, melodious, prophetic, verse, spoken with a purpose, contextual, biographical, historical, concerning his past lives, very detailed, marvelous, and establishing a truth. Of these, the very detailed teachings and those concerning his past lives belong to the bodhisattvas’ collection, and of the rest there are some that are for the most part common to the Listeners’ Vehicle and Great Vehicle and some that belong mainly to the listeners’ collection. These twelve branches are all included in the three collections.
The Reasons for Defining Three Scriptural Collections

sde snod gsum du 'jog pa'i rgyu ni dgur 'dod do/ / zhes pa spang bya la ltos nas gsum dang / bslab bya la ltos nas gsum dang / shes bya la ltos nas gsum du bzhag pa'i dang po nyon mongs gsum sel ba'i sgo nas te/ phung khams skye mched sogs kyi chos rnams la the tshom pa'i nyon mongs pa sel byed kyi gnyen po mdo sde'i sde snod bshad de/ phung khams skye mched rten 'brel bden pa sa dang phar phyin sogs kyi rang dang spyi'i mtshan nyid kyi don la gang dang ci lta bu yin pa ma shes nas the tshom za ba dag la/ de dag 'di dang 'di lta bu yin no zhes bstan pas don de bzhin rnam par gdon mi za bar shes nas the tshom med par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

The reasons for defining three collections are held to be nine: three with regard to elimination, three with regard to the training, and three with regard to knowledge. The first of these concern the dispelling of three defilements. The antidote that dispels the defilement of doubt[1] with regard to phenomena such as the aggregates, sense spheres, and senses-and-fields is the Sūtra Collection. For those who do not understand the general and specific characteristics of the aggregates, the sense spheres, the senses-and-fields, dependent arising, the truths, the levels, the transcendent perfections, and so forth, and who are uncertain about them, the Sūtra Collection defines and describes these topics, so that they definitely understand them and are freed of their doubts.

'dul ba ni 'dod pa bsod snyoms kyi mtha' dang / dka' tshegs ngal dub kyi mtha' gnyis la/ rjes su sbyor ba'i nye ba'i nyon mongs pa sel ba'i gnyen po ste/ 'dod pa la chags pas kha na ma tho ba dang bcas pa yo byad sna tshogs ji bde bar longs spyod pa khyim pa lta bu'i spyod pa 'gog phyir 'jig rten pa'i spyod pa ngan pa gang gis phas pham pa dang lhag ma dang / ltung ba dang / nyes byas la sogs pa 'byung ba'i spyod pa ni bkag ste ma gnang ngo*/ / lhung bzed dang chos gos sogs rang nyid 'tsho ba'i yo byad kha na ma tho ba med pa ni rjes su gnang ste/ mu stegs can ltar dka' thub drag po dang thal ba tsher ma'i khrod du nyal ba dang / gcer bu dang zas gcod pa dang / khyi dang ba lang sogs kyi dka' thub kyis bdag gi lus ngal zhing sdug bsngal bar byed pa'i gnyen por lus 'tsho ba'i rkyen gyi yo byad sdig med rnams rab byung thun mong ba kun la'ang gnang zhing / tshul khrims dang ldan pa dang yon tan ldan pa'i dge slong ni/ kha zas ro brgya dang ldan pa dang / brgya stong ri ba'i gos dang / khang bzang bkod mdzes mig mang dag kyang spyod du gnang ngo zhes gsungs te/ longs spyod bzang po de dag dang ldan yang chags pa dang rgyags pa med nas de nyid kha na ma tho ba med pa spyod pa yod la/ sngo ngad kyi zas dang phyag dar khrod pa'i gos sogs 'chang ba la gnas kyang chags pa dang rgyags pa yod na de nyid kha na ma tho bar spyod pa yin pas/ de ltar kha na ma tho ba'i yo byad spangs nas kha na ma tho ba med pa'i yo byad la spyod pa'i phyir mtha' gnyis sel ba'i gnyen po yin no/ /

The Vinaya is the antidote that dispels the secondary defilements related to the pursuit of two extremes—merit-sapping pleasures[2] and debilitating austerities.[3] In order to prevent his disciples from acting, through attachment to pleasure, like laypeople in the pleasurable use of all kinds of fault-associated articles, the Buddha forbade activities that give rise, through wrong, worldly behavior, to radical defeats, residual faults, downfalls, minor faults, and the like.[4] He did permit the basic necessities for living, such as the alms bowl and the Dharma robes, which are not associated with negative activity. Any harmless articles[5] that contribute to physical well-being, acting as antidotes to ascetic practices that inflict fatigue and pain on one’s body, such as the tīrthikas’ penances, lying on hot ashes or thorns, going naked, fasting, and acting like a dog or a cow, are permitted for all who have taken ordination. Fully ordained monks who keep the vows and possess good qualities are permitted to enjoy delicious food, wear richly designed clothes, and stay in beautifully designed and decorated mansions with many rooms. Even if they enjoy such pleasures, there is no fault in their conduct provided that they are free of attachment and self-importance. On the other hand, if they have any attachment and self-importance, then even the observance of eating stale, unappetizing food and wearing robes made of rags picked off refuse heaps and the like constitutes faulty conduct. Thus, in the avoidance of articles that lead to faults and the use of things in which there is no fault, the Vinaya is the antidote that dispels the two extremes.

mngon pa'i sde snod ni bdag gi lta ba snyems pa'i gnyen po yin te/ cung zad tsam thos pas nga rgyal byed cing tshul khrims 'chal bar chags pas dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi drung du mang du thos pa mi tshol ba ni lta ba snyems pa zhes bya ste/ mngon par chos kyi rang spyi'i mtshan nyid phyin ci ma log par gtan la phab pas de thos na lta ba dang tshul khrims la phyin ci log tu 'dzin pa'i snyems pa sna tshogs dang lta ba sna tshogs spong bar 'gyur ro/ / yang bslab pa'i dbang du byas na/ lhag pa tshul khrims kyi bslab pa ni thun mong du so sor thar pa'i tshul khrims phun sum tshogs pa'am/ theg pa chen po'i nyes spyod sdom pa dge ba chos sdud sems can don byed kyi tshul khrims rnams so/ / lhag ma sems kyi bslab pa ni/ thun mong du bsam gzugs kyi ting nge 'dzin brgyad dang / thun min byang chub sems dpa'i dpa' bar 'gro ba sogs kyi ting nge 'dzin no/ / lhag pa shes rab kyi bslab pa ni/ thun mong du 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi dang / thun min theg chen gyi rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes so/ / de yang mdo sdes bslab pa gsum ka ston to/ / 'dul ba'i tshul khrims dang ting nge 'dzin gyi bslab pa gnyis ston te/ 'dul ba las 'byung ba bzhin du spyod na tshul khrims dang ldan pa ni 'gyod pa med pa la sogs pas rim gyis ting nge 'dzin thob pa'i phyir ro/ / mngon pas ni chos rnams kyi rang dang spyi'i mtshan nyid ma nor ba gtan la phab pas chos rnams kyi mtshan nyid yang dag shes pa'i shes rab skye ba'i phyir ro/ /

The Abhidharma Collection is the antidote to arrogant, self-centered views. What we call arrogant view is being proud of having received just a little bit of teaching and being attached to lax discipline, as a result of which one does not seek much teaching from a spiritual master. Since the general and specific characteristics of phenomena are determined in the Abhidharma, by studying it one will get rid of the different kinds of arrogance resulting from distorted views and inverted discipline and eliminate all sorts of wrong views. Next, with regard to the training, there are the three trainings. The training in superior discipline comprises the perfect discipline of the prātimokṣa common to all vehicles and the Mahāyāna discipline of avoiding negative actions, gathering virtue, and benefiting beings. The training in superior concentration comprises the eight common concentrations of the dhyānas and formless absorptions[6] and the uncommon concentrations of the bodhisattvas, such as the concentration of Brave Progression. And the training in superior wisdom comprises the four noble truths common to all vehicles and the extraordinary nonconceptual gnosis of the Great Vehicle. All these three trainings are presented in the Sūtra Collection. The trainings in discipline and concentration are set forth in the Vinaya, for if one conducts oneself in accordance with what appears in the Vinaya, one is keeping discipline, and through having nothing to regret and so forth, one will gradually achieve concentration.[7] The Abhidharma determines without error the general and specific characteristics of phenomena, and it is from this that wisdom, the correct knowledge of the characteristics of phenomena, is born.

yang shes bya la ltos nas mdo sdes chos dang don bshad do zhes pa/ chos ni ming dang don brjod bya gnyis bstan pa'am/ yang phung khams skye mched sogs bstan pa ni chos/ dgongs ldem dgongs bzhi la don zhes dang / yang mtho ris thob byed dge ba bcu la chos/ myang 'das thob byed byang chub phyogs chos so bdun sogs la don zhes bya ste de dag mdo sdes bshad pas so/ / 'dul bas chos dang don sgrub pa zhes pa nyon mongs pa 'dul ba la brtson pas de gnyis mngon du byas pa'am nyams su blangs te bsgrub pa'o/ / mngon pas chos dang don phyin ci ma log par ston cing shin tu rnam par nges par byas te mkhas par byed do/ /

In terms of knowledge, we speak of two aspects to the explanations in the Sūtra Collection—the terms and the topics; or alternatively, the topics (the aggregates, sense spheres, senses-and-fields, and so forth) and their meanings (the four kinds of implied teachings and four kinds of indirect teachings); or again, the basic way (the ten positive actions by which one attains the higher realms) and the ultimate way (the thirty-seven elements leading to enlightenment and so on by which one attains nirvāṇa).[8] These are explained in the Sūtra Collection. The Vinaya is said to accomplish both these aspects, for by being diligent in subduing the defilements one actualizes them both or puts them into practice and thereby accomplishes them. And by means of the Abhidharma, which teaches these two without error and ascertains them definitively, one masters one’s knowledge of them.
The Purpose of Investigating the Teachings in the Three Scriptural Collections

sde snod gsum gyi chos de dag btsal ba'i dgos pa gang zhe na/ de shes rab gsum gyis yongs su tshol zhing nyams su bstar ba des ni/ thos pas rang rgyud la thar pa'i lam gyi bag chags 'jog pa dang / bsams pas de'i don la nges pa rnyed pa'i tshul gyis rtogs pa dang / bsgoms pas zhi gnas la brten nas rnam par g.yeng ba'i rnam rtog zhi ba dang / lhag mthong gis de kho na nyid rab tu rtogs pas rang rgyud rnam par grol bar byed do/ /

It is by thoroughly investigating the three collections and putting them into practice using the three kinds of wisdom that one’s mind stream is brought to perfect liberation. Listening plants in one’s mind stream a habitual inclination for the path to liberation. Reflection brings understanding through one’s gaining certainty with regard to the meaning of the collections. And meditation based on sustained calm pacifies distracting thoughts and, through profound insight, results in full realization of thatness.
Points by Which the Three Scriptural Collections Are Classified, and Their Etymological Definition
mdo dang chos mngon 'dul ba dag / mdor na don ni rnam bzhir 'dod/ / blo dang ldan pas de shes nas/ / rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa 'thob/ /
Sūtra, Abhidharma, and Vinaya Are considered to comprise, in brief, four points. The wise who know these Will obtain omniscience. (XII, 2)

sde snod gsum don du zhig gis rnam par bzhag pa dang de dag gi nges tshig ji lta bu yin zhe na/ mdo sde dang chos mngon pa dang 'dul ba dag ni/ mdor bsdu ba'i dbang du byas na re re la yang don ni rnam pa bzhir 'dod de/ byang chub sems dpa' blo dang ldan pas theg pa che chung gi sde snod gsum po de mtha' dag legs par shes nas lam sbyangs pas rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa nyid 'thob bo/ / nyan thos rnams ni thams cad mkhyen pa mi tshol bas sde snod gsum ma shes par gang zag gi bdag med tsam ston pa'i tshigs su bcad pa gcig gi don shes pas kyang rang gi lam gyi zad mi skye shes pa'i ye shes 'thob par 'gyur ro/ / sde snod gsum gyi mdor bsdus pa'i don bzhi po gang zhe na/

The Sūtras, Vinaya, and Abhidharma, if considered in brief, are each held to comprise four points. A wise bodhisattva, by gaining a thorough knowledge of all three collections of the Great and Lesser Vehicles and training on the path will attain omniscience.
