The listeners do not seek omniscience and therefore do not know the entirety of the three collections, but even by knowing the meaning of a single verse that teaches just the individual no-self, they will, with their own path, obtain the gnosis of exhaustion and nonarising.[9] What are the four points that summarize each of the three collections?
gnas rnams dang ni mtshan nyid dang / / chos don smos phyir mdo yin no/ / mngon du'i phyir dang yang yang dang / / zil gnon rtogs phyir mngon pa'i chos/ /

Because they relate the settings, nature, Subjects, and meanings, they are the “sūtras.” Because it makes increasingly manifest, does so repeatedly, Overpowers, and brings understanding, it is the Abhidharma. (XII, 3)

mnyan yod sogs yul gang du bshad pa dang / bcom ldan 'das gang gis bshad pa dang / zhu ba po sogs gang gi don du bshad pa gsum po la gnas zhes bya ste mdo sde 'byung ba'i gnas sam gleng gzhi yin pas na de 'dra'i gnas rnams dang ni/ bden pa gnyis kyi mtshan nyid dang / phung khams skye mched rten 'brel sogs kyi chos dang / de'i don dgongs dgongs min ldem dgongs sogs su rnam par 'byed de/ mdo tsam du smos phyir mdo sde zhes bya ba yin te/ sU tra'i sgra las drangs nas don de dag der dkri ba'am mdo tsam du tshang bas so/ / a b+hi'i sgra la mngon pa zhes pa ste de yang a b+hi mu kha zhes pa mngon du phyogs pa'i don te/ bden pa byang phyogs rten 'brel sogs kyi don ma nor bar gtan la dbab pas myang 'das la mngon du phyogs par byed pa'i phyir dang / de bzhin du chos re re la yang gzugs can yin min zag bcas zag med sogs rnam par dbye ba sna tshogs yang dang yang du rnam par 'byed cing mngon pa bstan pa dang / rigs pa dang ldan par 'bel gtam dang bcad pa yi sgo nas phyir rgol ba mngon par zil gyis gnon par byed pa dang / mdo sde'i don rigs pa dang rnam par nges pa'i tshul gyis gtan la dbab ste mngon par rtogs par byed pa'i phyir mngon pa'i chos zhes bya'o/ /

The Sūtra Collection is summarized by the following four points: (1) the “setting,” by which is meant the situation or historical background in which a sūtra originated, which comprises three points—the place where a teaching was given (Śrāvastī, for example), the buddha who expounded it, and the disciples who requested the teaching and for whom it was given; (2) the nature of the two truths; (3) subjects such as the aggregates, sense spheres, senses-and-fields, and dependent arising; and (4) their meanings, divided into implied and explicit, indirect, and so on. Because these are mentioned concisely, we speak of “sūtras,” the Sanskrit word sūtra signifying that they contain these points in a complete and condensed (or “packaged”) form. The Sanskrit word abhi means “manifest.”[10] (1) Abhimukha means “increasingly manifest.” By unmistakenly determining the meaning of the truths, the elements leading to enlightenment, dependent arising, and so forth, the Abhidharma makes nirvāṇa increasingly manifest. (2) Similarly, it clearly demonstrates phenomena, repeatedly dividing and subdividing each one into different categories—material and immaterial, tainted and untainted, and so on. (3) By means of logical discussion and debate, it manifestly outshines all opponents. And (4) by means of reasoning and ascertainment it determines the points in the sūtras, so that they are clearly understood. For these reasons, we speak of the “Abhidharma.”
ltung dang 'byung dang ldang ba dang / / nges par 'byung dang gang zag dang / / bcas pa dang ni rab dbye dang / / rnam par nges phyir 'dul ba nyid/ /

Because there are downfalls, and there is their source, Their recovery, and certain deliverance, And with regard to the individual, the edict, Detailed description, and definition, it is the Vinaya. (XII, 4)
bi na ya zhes pa 'dul ba yin la/
The Vinaya, meaning “that which tames,” is classified by means of the following four points:
de yang ltung ba ni sde lnga ste/ phas pham/ lhag ma/ nyes pa sbom po/ ltung byed/ sor bshags lnga'o zhes dang / yang na pham lhag ltung byed sor bshags nyes byas so/ /

(1) Five classes of downfalls: the radical defeats, residual faults, gross faults, downfalls,[10] and faults to be specifically confessed; or alternatively, radical defeats, residual faults, downfalls, faults to be specifically confessed, and wrong actions.
ltung ba de skye ba'am 'byung ba'i rgyu ni ltung ba de dag gis mtshan nyid mi shes pa dang / nyon mongs pa dang / bag med pa dang / bslab pa la ma gus pa bzhi yin pa dang /
(2) The cause for these downfalls arising or occurring, which is fourfold: ignorance of the characteristics of these downfalls; defilements; carelessness; and failure to respect the precepts.
ltung ba las ldang ba'am bslang ba ni/ bsam pa'i sgo nas 'gyod cing phyin chad mi bya bar bsdam pa'i sgo nas nyes pa las bslang ba'o/ /
(3) Recovery from downfalls—by feeling regret from reflecting on what one has done and by vowing never to commit them in the future.
ltung ba las dbyung ba'am nges par 'byung ba ni rnam pa bdun te/
(4) Deliverance from downfalls or certain deliverance, of which there are seven aspects, as follows.
dang por so sor bshags pa ni dge slong gcig gam bzhi la sogs pa'i mdun du mthol nas bshags pas so/ /
Confession. This is to openly acknowledge and confess in the presence of one or four or more fully ordained monks.

gnyis pa chad pa'i las khas len pa ni/ pham pa 'chab sems med par spyod cing phyis 'gyod pa ma skyes pa nas bshags pa la chad pa'i las ni thams cad kyi gral gyi mthar bzhag cing tha mar bza' ba sbyin pa sogs khas len du bcug ste slar bslab pa sbyin pa'o/ /

Accepting what one has to do as punishment. After committing a radical defeat, without the intention of concealing it, and subsequently feeling regret, a monk confesses it and is made to accept the punishment—being sent to the end of the row of all the monks and given his food last, and so on. He is thus given the precepts again.
gsum pa bskyur bas dbyung ba ni bcom ldan 'das kyis phyi dro'i kha zas bza' bar ma gnang ba la/ rnam grangs kyis lam du son pa la dus zhes gnang ba lta bu'o/ /
Deliverance by dispensation. An example of this is that although Lord Buddha did not allow eating after midday, in certain circumstances he gave monks permission to eat at other specified times.

bzhi pa dgrol ba zhes sngon bcom ldan 'das kyis kun dga' bo la nga yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa'i dus su dran par gyis dang bslab gzhi bcas pa rnams las bslab pa'i tshig phran tshogs rnams dgrol bar bya zhes gsungs kyang mya ngan las 'das pa'i tshe kun dga' bo mya ngan gyis non nas zhu bar ma byung bas/ phyis 'od srungs chen po sogs sdud byed rnams kyis de ci'i phyir ma zhus zhes nyes chad du bsgrags so/ / bslab tshig phran tshegs dgrol bar bya'o zhes gsungs pa de la brten nas thams cad yod smra'i gzhung gi sde las dge 'dun tshogs pas bslab tshig phra mo rnams dgrol bar bya ba yod ces grag pa tsam las/ bslab tshig las dge 'dun gyis dgrol ba sngar yang med da ltar yang med ces blo brtan 'grel chen du gsungs/

“Waiver.” It is said that Lord Buddha once said to Ānanda, “When I pass into nirvāṇa, remember that apart from the fundamental precepts that I have laid down, the minor precepts may be waived.” However, when the Buddha passed into nirvāṇa, Ānanda, overcome with grief, did not manage to inquire about this. Subsequently, Mahākāśyapa and the other compilers of the teachings said to him, “Why didn’t you ask?” and punished him. Based on the Buddha’s saying, “The minor precepts are to be waived,” according to the Sarvāstivādin tradition the assembled Saṅgha can apparently grant exemption from the minor precepts. But in fact there has never been any exemption by the Saṅgha from the precepts in the past, nor is there at present. This is as stated in Sthiramati’s Great Commentary.

lnga pa gnas sam rten 'gyur ba zhes pa dge slong phan tshun mtshan 'gyur na de dag gi ltung ba ni dge slong la phas pham bzhi/ dge slong ma la brgyad yod pas pham pa dang ltung ba mang nyung du gyur bas na dge slong dge slong mar mtshan 'gyur na dge slong gi tshe'i ltung ba byung yang / ltung ba de thun mong ma yin te/ dge slong nyid kyis bshags par bya ba yin pas/ bud med du gyur nas nyes pa bshags pa sogs cho ga ma byas kyang nyes pa las 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / dge slong ma mtshan gyur na'ang de bzhin no/ /

Transformation of the body.[12] This refers to downfalls of fully ordained monks or nuns who have changed sex. For monks there are four radical defeats and for nuns there are eight radical defeats; monks have fewer defeats and downfalls, while nuns have more.[13] Take the case of a monk who changes sex into a nun. He may have committed a downfall when he was a monk, but if it is not a downfall common to both monks and nuns and is one that can be confessed only by a monk, because of having changed into a woman he will be delivered from the fault even if he has not performed the ritual of confessing the fault. The same principle applies to a nun who changes sex.[14]
drug pa/ yang dag par rtogs pas 'byung ba ni/ chos kyi mdo bzhi'i don 'dus byas mi rtag pa sogs bzhi la brtag ste don shes rab kyis mthong bas nyes pa phran tshegs las 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ /

Deliverance through correct realization. By examining the four summaries of the Dharma—compounded phenomena are impermanent, and so on—and, with wisdom, seeing the truth in them, one will be delivered from minor wrongdoings.
bdun pa chos nyid thob pas nges par 'byung ba ni/ bden pa mthong na sngon nyes pa phran tshegs byas pa las kyang thar la phyis mi byed pa'i chos nyid thob pas ltung ba las 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ /

Certain deliverance by attaining ultimate reality. When one sees the truth,[15] one is liberated from the minor faults one committed in the past, and by attaining ultimate reality, in which state future misdeeds are impossible, one will be delivered from downfalls.

de ltar don rnam pa bzhi'i sgo nas 'dul ba bzhag pa dang / yang rnam grangs gzhan bzhi'i sgo nas kyang bzhag ste gang zag gang la brten nas bslab tshig bcas pa ni/ thog mar bzang byin la brten nas mi tshangs pa spyod par mi gnang ba'i bslab tshig bcas pa lta bu dang / bcas pa ni gang zag gis nyes pa de dang de lta bu byas pa dge slong rnams kyis bcom ldan 'das la gsol ba na sangs rgyas kyis dge 'dun rnams la 'di skad du dge slong dag deng phyin chad dge slong rnams chos 'di dang 'di lta bu byed du mi gnang ngo zhes bslab pa bcas pa dang ni/ bcas pa de yi rab dbye ni 'di nyid 'di lta bu'o zhes rnam par dbye zhing zhib tu bshad pa'o/ / ltung ba sde lnga'i re re la yang 'di tsam gyis ltung bar 'gyur la/ 'di tsam gyis ltung bar mi 'gyur zhes rnam par gtan la dbab pa'am rnam par nges par byas pa'i phyir 'dul ba nyid do/ /

As well as these four points, there are four other points that are used in classifying the Vinaya: (1) The person for whom a precept was prescribed. For example, it was for Sudinna that the precept prohibiting sexual intercourse was prescribed for the first time. (2) The edict. When the monks told Lord Buddha that someone had committed such and such a fault, he spoke to the Saṅgha members and prescribed a precept as follows: “O monks, from now on monks are not allowed to do such and such a thing.” (3) The detailed description of the edict. This comprises a precise and detailed explanation of the precept. And (4) an exact or conclusive definition, for each of the five groups of downfalls, of the point at which something will or will not constitute a downfall. All this defines the Vinaya.
de yan chad kyis gang la ba dmigs par bya ba ni lung sde snod kyi chos yin par bstan to/ /

We have so far seen that the subject to be investigated is the three scriptural collections, the Dharma of transmission. We now have to look into discovering the point, as shown in the next three verses.
gnyis pa dmigs pa rnyed pa yongs su tshol ba ni/
ii. THOROUGH INVESTIGATION IN DISCOVERING THE POINT, THE MEANING INDICATED BY THE THREE SCRIPTURAL COLLECTIONS

dmigs pa chos dang nang dang ni/ / phyi dang gnyis ni yin par 'dod/ / don gnyis kyis ni gnyis po rnyed/ / gnyis po dag ni mi dmigs pas/ / yid kyi brjod pas bshad bzhin don/ / rab dang don du snang ba dang / / brjod las yin par rab 'dzin phyir/ / sems ni ming la gnas pa'i phyir/ / thos la sogs pa'i shes gsum gyis/ / chos kyi dmigs pa rnyed par 'gyur/ / dmigs pa rnam pa gsum rnyed pa/ / sngar bshad de la yang dag rten/ /

The point is held to be The teachings, the inner, the outer, and both. Two are discovered through two processes, And both by nonconceptuality. (XII, 5) Because, by means of mental verbalization, one has faith in the meaning as it is taught, Because one understands that the things that appear as objects Do so on account of such verbalization, And because the mind dwells on the nominal— (XII, 6) With the three wisdoms of listening and so on, One will discover the point of the teachings. Discovering the other three points Fully depends on those teachings, which were mentioned earlier. (XII, 7)
zhes sogs tshigs bcad gsum ste/
dmigs pa rnyed pa zhes pa dmigs pa mngon sum du gyur pa ste/ ji ltar na dmigs pa'i chos btsal te rnyed nas de'i don la gtan la phab nas 'di dang 'di'o zhes don shes par gyur pa'o/ /
Here “discovering the point” means “realizing the point.” In what way? Having investigated and discovered our subject, the teachings, we determine their meaning and know them to mean this or that.

dmigs pa'i yul yang rnam pa bzhi ste/ theg pa chen po'i sde snod kyi chos rnam pa de dag thos bsam bsgom pa'i shes rab gsum gyis dmigs pa'i yul yin no/ / nang rang rgyud kyi phung po'am 'dzin pa nang gi skye mched drug dang ni/ phyi ni rang rgyud kyis ma bsdus pa gzung ba phyi'i skye mched drug dang / phyi nang gnyis kas bsdus pa kun nyon dang rnam byang gi chos rnams ni yin par 'dod do/ / de las gzung ba phyi dang 'dzin pa nang gi dngos po la tshul bzhin dmigs pa'i don gnyis kyis ni/ phyi dang nang gi dngos po mi dmigs pa'i don gnyis po rnyed de nam phyi'i de bzhin nyid rtogs na phyi'i dmigs pa rnyed pa dang / nam nang gi de bzhin nyid mngon sum shes na nang gi dmigs pa rnyed pa'o/ / de yang sems las ma gtogs pa'i gzung ba'i don med par rnyed par ni bzod pa dus dang / 'dzin pa med pa ni chos mchog gi dus na rnyed pa'o/ /

There are held to be four objects of investigation here: (1) The different teachings in the Mahāyāna scriptural collections are the object of the three wisdoms—those that come from listening, reflecting, and meditating. (2) The inner object comprises one’s own aggregates or the six apprehending inner sense powers. (3) The outer object comprises the six apprehended outer sense fields not included in one’s own mind stream. (4) “Both” refers to the phenomena of the defilement and purity aspects included in both outer and inner. Of these, two points (not conceptualizing outer and inner objects) are discovered by means of two processes: proper consideration of the outer apprehended object and of the inner apprehending subject. That is, when the suchness of the outer object is realized, one discovers the outer point, and when one directly recognizes the suchness of the inner object, one discovers the inner point. The discovery that there are no apprehended objects apart from the mind is the discovery that occurs at the stage of acceptance, and the discovery that there is no existent apprehending subject is the discovery that occurs at the stage of the supreme mundane level.

gnyis ka'i de bzhin nyid ji ltar rnyed na/ gzung 'dzin gnyis po dag ni mi dmigs pas de bzhin nyid mngon sum du gyur pa sa dang po thob pas chos gnyis ka'i dmigs pa rnyed de chos thams cad mi dmigs pa'i de bzhin nyid rnyed pa'o/ / drod dang spyi ba'am dus chos nyid mngon sum du rnyed pa min pas dmigs pa rnyed par ma bshad do zhes gsungs pa mngon sum du rnyed pa yang don spyi'i tshul gyis the tshom med par mngon sum gyur pa yin 'dra snyam mo/ / stong pa nyid la dbye ba med mod kyi chos can la ltos nas rtogs pa phyi dang nang dang gnyis ka'i dmigs pa rnyed pa'i tha snyad du mdzad do/ /

How is the suchness of “both” discovered? When one has no concepts of subject and object, one realizes suchness directly and attains the first level; one thus discovers the point of both and discovers the nonconceptual suchness of all phenomena. At the stages of warmth and crown or peak, the direct realization of ultimate reality is not acquired, so the teachings do not speak of “discovering the point” at these stages. I think this is because actually discovering the point implies direct realization free of the uncertainties associated with an indirect understanding of suchness.[16] Although in emptiness there are no distinctions at all, as far as phenomena are concerned,[17] we use the conventional terms of discovering the point of outer realization, of inner realization, and of both.

chos kyi dmigs pa'i tshul ni/ yid ni brjod pas zhes yid rtog bcas kyis/ sde snod kyi gzhung las ji skad bshad pa bzhin gyi don la sems rab tu dwang ba ste dad pa rnyed nas de'i don de bzhin du 'dzin pa ni thos pas shes rab kyis chos la dmigs pa rnyed pa zhes bya ste/ mkhan po dang slob dpon gang gis chos bstan pa de la rna ba blags te nyan nas don la sems pas dper na ming tshig yi ge'i rang bzhin 'di thams cad sems la snang bar zad do zhes tshig gis bstan pa na de ltar shes shing yid ches pa lta bu'o/ /

As for the manner in which one discovers the point of the teachings, by means of “mental verbalization”—that is, with the conceptual mind—one acquires great mental clarity or faith with regard to the points explained in the texts of the scriptural collections, and one then retains their meaning accordingly. This is what we call “discovering the point of the teachings with the wisdom that comes from listening.” By listening attentively to the teachings given by a preceptor or instructor and thinking about the meaning, one gains confidence, knowing, when the teacher says, for example, “All these names, phrases, and letters are only appearances in the mind,” that that is how it is.

bsam pa'i shes rab kyis ni/ yid kyi brjod pa'i bag chags las ka bum sogs chos 'di dag tu brtags pa tsam las don gyi ngo bo brjod du med pas rang gi rtog pa tsam las don gzhan med pa yin par rab tu 'dzin pa ni dmigs pa rnyed pa'o/ /

Phenomena such as pillars and vases are merely labeled as such as a result of the habits of mental expression, and apart from that, their ultimately true nature is inexpressible: they are nothing more than one’s own conceptual structures. To understand this with the wisdom that comes from reflection is to discover the point of the teachings with the wisdom that comes from reflection.

bsgom pa'i shes rab kyi sems ni ming la zhes pa ming dang gzugs kyi zlas phye ba'i ming gzhi sems sems byung ste mdor na chos thams cad ni sems la snang ba sems kyis btags pa sems kyi dbang gis bzhag pa tsam ma gtogs pa gzhan med pas sems tsam dang sems de yang gzung ba dang 'dzin pa gnyis su mi dmigs pa'i de bzhin nyid stong zhing 'od gsal ba la gnas pa'i phyir bsgom pa'i shes rab kyis chos kyi dmigs pa rnyed pa'o/ /

The mind related to the wisdom of meditation “dwells on the nominal”—that is, name as opposed to form[18]—whose basis is the mind and mental factors. In brief, all phenomena are appearances in the mind; they are imputed by the mind and established by the power of the mind. There is nothing else that exists apart from that, and they are therefore only mind. This mind dwells in suchness free of dualistic concepts of subject and object, empty and radiant. This, then, is to discover the point of the teachings with the wisdom that comes from meditating.

de ltar thos pa la sogs pa'i shes rab gsum gyis/ sde snod kyi chos kyi dmigs pa rnyed par 'gyur te/ dang por thos pa bzhin ming gi sgo nas brjod bya'i don de sems la brda 'phrod de nas don de la bsam pas nges pa rnyed/ de nas de bsgoms pas nyams su myang ba gsum gyis dam pa'i chos kyi don nam dmigs pa rnyed pa yin no/ /

Thus, with the three wisdoms that come from listening, reflecting, and meditating one will discover the point of the teachings of the scriptural collections. First, by means of the names one hears, the meanings they express are conveyed to the mind. Then, by reflecting on those meanings, one acquires certainty. Finally, by meditating on them, one directly experiences them. It is by means of these three that one discovers the point or true meaning of the sacred Dharma.

gang du phyi dang nang dang gnyis ka'i dmigs pa rnam pa gsum rnyed pa de dag sngar thog mar bshad pa chos kyis dmigs pa rnyed pa de la yang dag par rten pa yin no zhes chos thos shing don bsams nas ma bsgoms na phyi dang nang dang gnyis ka'i chos mi dmigs pa'i de bzhin nyid rtogs pa'i thabs med pa'i phyir ro/ /

The three aspects (outer, inner, and both) of discovering the point depend entirely on discovering the point of the teachings, which earlier were mentioned first, because if, having listened to the teachings and reflected on their meaning, one does not meditate on them, it is impossible to realize suchness, the nonconceptual nature of outer, inner, and both.
gsum pa yid la byed yongs su tshol ba ni/
iii. THOROUGH INVESTIGATION OF THE INVESTIGATOR, ATTENTIVENESS
This topic is covered by the next five verses.
rigs gsum pa dang bya ba byed/ / gnod bcas gnod med rten can te/ / mos pa 'jog par byed dang gzhan/ / 'dun pa drag por byed pa dang / /
The three families, the performance of deeds, Having an impaired or unimpaired support, Maintaining interest, and furthermore Acting with intense keenness; (XII, 8)
ces tshigs bcad lngas bstan te/

de ltar dmigs pa rnyed nas de yang yang yid la byed pa'i sgo nas ting nge 'dzin rnyed par bya dgos pas de bshad pa la/ rnal 'byor pa'i yid la byed pa rnam grangs bco brgyad yod de/ rigs gsum yid la byed pa dang / bya ba byed pa yid la byed pa sogs bco brgyad las/ dang po rigs gsum pa dang zhes pa 'di mdor bstan pa yin la/ lhag ma rnams kyis de'i khyad par rgyas par bshad pa yin no/ /

Once one has discovered the point, it is necessary to acquire concentration by repeatedly keeping it in mind,[19] so this will now be explained. There are eighteen categories of yogis’ attentiveness, beginning with attentiveness associated with the three families, attentiveness in performing deeds, and so forth. The first of these, “the three families,” is a brief introduction, and the remainder comprise a detailed explanation of particular kinds of attentiveness:

de la dang po rigs gsum pa dang zhes nyan rang theg chen gyi rigs gsum ste/ nyan thos kyi rigs su nges pas chos bden pa bzhi la dmigs pa dag rang sangs rgyas su rigs nges pas de'i lam gyi chos rten 'brel la dmigs pa dang / byang sems kyi rigs su nges pas bdag med gnyis la dmigs nas yid la byed pa'o/ /

(1) Attentiveness associated with the three families. The three families are those of the listeners, solitary realizers, and followers of the Great Vehicle. Those who have the fixed potential of the listeners consider and keep in mind the four noble truths. Those who have the fixed potential of the solitary realizers consider and keep in mind dependent arising, which is the teaching related to their path. Those who have the fixed potential of the bodhisattvas consider and keep in mind the two kinds of no-self.

gnyis pa bya ba byed pa'i yid byed ni/ bya ba byed ces pas bstan te/ tshogs bsags pa'i bya ba byed pa yin la sa dang po thob pa'i rgyu mos spyod kyi sar bskal pa grangs med gcig tu bsod nams dang ye shes tshogs bsags pa rnams kyi yid la byed pa'o/ /

(2) Attentiveness associated with performing activities. This is indicated by “the performance of deeds” and refers to performing deeds that accumulate merit. It is the attentiveness of those on the level of earnest aspiration who are accumulating merit and wisdom for a single measureless kalpa, which leads to attaining the first bodhisattva level.

gsum pa rten nam gnas rnam par dbye ba'i yid la byed pa ni gnod bcas gnod med rten can te zhes pas bstan te/ gnod pa dang bcas pa'i rten nam gnas ni khyim na gnas pa ste 'jig rten gyi bya ba mang bas yid la byed pa la gnod pa dang bcas pa'o/ / rab tu byung ba de ni de las ldog ste gnod pa med pa'i rten can no/ /

(3) Attentiveness associated with different kinds of supports or conditions. This is shown by “having an impaired or unimpaired support.” Impaired supports or situations are those of laypeople: the abundance of their worldly activities adversely affects their attentiveness. The opposite is true for those who have taken monastic ordination and who therefore have unimpaired supports.

bzhi pa mos pa la 'jog pa'i yid la byed pa ni/ mos pa 'jog par byed pa dang zhes pas bstan te/ sangs rgyas rjes su dran pa'i sgo nas mos par 'jog par byed pa ste/ sangs rgyas kyi yon tan rgya che ba rnams rjes su dran pa mdo las ji skad 'byung ba rnams sam/ mdor bsdu na theg bsdus las gsungs pa ltar rnam pa bdun gyi sgo nas sangs rgyas rjes su dran par bya ste/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du thogs pa med par 'jug pa'i mngon par shes pa dang ldan pas chos thams cad la dbang bsgyur ba yin no zhes rjes su dran pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams rtag pa'i sku ste rtag tu dri ma med par gyur pa dang ldan no zhes rjes su dran pa dang / de bzhin du nyon mongs pa dang shes bya'i sgrib pa mtha' dag spangs pa'i phyir de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kha na ma tho ba med pa yin no zhes rjes su dran pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa ni mdzad pa thams cad lhun gyis grub cing rgyun mi 'chad pa yin no zhes rjes su dran pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams sangs rgyas kyi zhing rnam par dag pa sogs zag pa med pa'i longs spyod chen po'i mnga' dbang dang ldan pa'o zhes rjes su dran pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams 'jig rten chos brgyad kyi skyon gyis ma gos pa'o zhes gos pa med par rjes su dran pa dang / mngon par byang chub pa dang mya ngan las 'das par bstan pa'i thabs kyis sems can rnams smin pa dang grol bar mdzad pas de bzhin gshegs pa rnams don chen po yin par rjes su dran par bya'o/ /

(4) Attentiveness associated with maintaining interest is indicated by “maintaining interest.” It is by remembering the Buddha that one maintains one’s interest. This involves recalling the Buddha’s extensive qualities as mentioned in the sūtras or remembering the Buddha in seven ways as summarized in the Compendium of the Great Vehicle as follows: (a) remembering that since the buddha bhagavāns possess the preternatural power of unimpededly entering all worlds, they have mastery over all phenomena; (b) remembering that the tathāgatas possess the eternal body, which is forever uncontaminated; (c) remembering that similarly, because they have eliminated all the defilement-related and cognitive obscurations, the tathāgatas are free of shameful deeds; (d) remembering that all the tathāgatas’ deeds are spontaneous and unceasing; (e) remembering that the tathāgatas have dominion over great untainted riches such as pure buddha fields; (f) remembering that the tathāgatas are unstained—that is, untainted by the defects of the eight ordinary preoccupations; and (g) remembering that, since they bring sentient beings to maturation and liberation by skillfully displaying perfect enlightenment and the parinirvāṇa, the tathāgatas are great benefactors.

lnga pa rab tu 'dod pa'i yid la byed pa ni snga ma las gzhan 'dun pa drag por byed pa dang zhes pas bstan te/ sangs rgyas rjes su dran nas de la yid ches pa'i 'dun pa drag po byed pa ste/ sangs rgyas ni skyabs kyi mthar thug skyon kun zad yon tan kun rdzogs don gnyis lhun gyis grub pa sku gsum dang ldan par yid ches pa dang / chos ni lam dang 'gog pa mngon du byed pa la yang dag pa'i chos yin par yid ches pa dang / dge 'dun rnams lam yang dag la zhugs pa 'khor ba'i 'dam las brgal zhing yon gyi gnas yang dag yin par yid ches pa'i 'dun pa drag por byed pa'o/ /

(5) Attentiveness associated with enthusiasm. This is indicated by “furthermore acting with intense keenness,” which is different from the previous one. Having recalled the Buddha, one has an intense, keen confidence in him—that is, confidence that the Buddha is the ultimate refuge, has exhausted all defects, has perfected all good qualities, spontaneously accomplishes the two goals, and possesses the three buddha bodies; confidence that the Dharma is the authentic teaching for realizing the path and the cessation; and confidence that the members of the Saṅgha who are following the authentic path will cross the swamp of saṃsāra and are true objects of offering.
dman dang rdzogs rten rnam pa gnyis/ / brjod dang bcas dang brjod med nyid/ / shes pa dang ni mtshungs ldan pa/ / rnal 'byor rgyu dang bdag bcas dang / /
Inferior and complete supports Which are verbal and nonverbal; Equivalent to knowledge, Having the cause and nature of yoga; (XII, 9)

drug pa ting nge 'dzin la gnas pa'i yid la byed pa ni/ dman dang rdzogs rten rnam pa gnyis/ /brjod dang bcas dang brjod med nyid ces pas bstan te/ bsam gtan dang po'i nyer bsdogs mi lcogs med la brten pa ni dman pa dang / bsam gtan dang po nas bzhi pa'i bar gyi dngos gzhi'i ting 'dzin las rten pa ni rdzogs pa'i rten nam gnas zhes bya ste rnam pa gnyis so/ / dngos gzhi'i ting 'dzin de la yang nyer bsdogs rnams dang bsam gtan dang po'i dngos gzhi tsam po ba ni rtog dpyod gnyis bcas yin pas brjod bcas zhes bya ste/ ngag kun nas slong ba'i rgyu rtog dpyod yin pas brjod bcas so/ bsam gtan dang po'i dngos gzhi khyad par can rtog med dpyod bcas kyang snga ma de'i khongs su gtogs so/ / bsam gtan gnyis pa yan chad kyi dngos gzhi'i ting nge 'dzin ni rtog dpyod gnyis dang bral bas/ brjod med nyid ces bya'o/ / blo brtan 'grel par nyer bsdogs dang bsam gtan dang po rtog dpyod dang bcas pa/ bsam gtan gnyis pa dang bar gyi bsam gtan rnams rtog med dpyod bcas/ gsum pa dang bzhi pa mi rtog mi dpyod pa'i ting nge 'dzin zhes gsungs/

(6) Attentiveness associated with remaining in concentration. This is indicated by “inferior and complete supports which are verbal and nonverbal.” There are two kinds of supports or conditions: one that relies on the “all-sufficing preparation” of the first dhyāna and is termed “inferior,” and one that relies on the actual concentration of dhyāna, from the first to the fourth, and is termed “complete.” For the actual concentration of dhyāna, the preparatory stages and the rudimentary stage of the first dhyāna have both gross and subtle discursiveness and are therefore termed “verbal”—verbal because the causal factor that activates speech is gross and subtle discursiveness. The extraordinary actual first dhyāna, which is free of gross discursiveness but still possesses subtle discursiveness, also belongs to the first category. The actual concentrations of the second dhyāna onward are free of both gross and subtle discursiveness and therefore termed “nonverbal.” Sthiramati’s commentary states that the preparatory stage and the first dhyāna possess both gross and subtle discursiveness; in the second and intermediate dhyānas there is no gross discursiveness but there is subtle discursiveness; and the third and fourth constitute concentration with neither gross nor subtle discursiveness.

bdun pa/ shes pa dang ldan pa'i yid la byed pa ni/ shes pa dang ni mtshungs ldan pa/ / rnal 'byor rgyu dang bdag bcas dang / /zhes pas bstan te/ blo brtan 'grel par/ ye shes dang ni yang dag ldan/ / rnal 'byor rgyu yi rang bzhin no/ /zhes 'dug / de yang sgom byung gi ye shes sam shes pa dang ni mtshungs par ldan pa'am yang dag par ldan pa ni shes pa yid byed ces bya'o/ / shes pa de nyid rnal 'byor ram zhi lhag gi rang bzhin yin la de'i rgyu ni thos pa dang bsam pa'i shes rab kyi rang bzhin nam bdag nyid dang bcas pa'o zhes/ mdor na thos bsam dri med kyi rgyu las byung ba'i bsgom pa zhi lhag gi rnal 'byor ni shes pa dang ldan pa'i yid byed do/ /

(7) Attentiveness associated with knowledge. This is indicated by “equivalent to knowledge, having the cause and nature of yoga,” which appears in Sthiramati’s commentary as “That which perfectly possesses gnosis, the nature of yoga and its cause.” The state of mind that is equivalent to, or perfectly endowed with, the gnosis or knowledge that arises through meditation is what we call the attentiveness associated with knowledge. That knowledge is the nature of yoga or of sustained calm and profound insight, whose cause is associated with the wisdom that comes from listening and reflecting. In short, the yoga of sustained calm and profound insight meditation that comes from the immaculate cause of listening and reflecting is the attentiveness associated with knowledge.
de ni 'dres la dmigs pa dang / / ma 'dres pa la dmigs pa ste/ / rnam pa lnga dang rnam bdun nyid/ / 'di yi yongs su shes pa lnga / /
Considering things in combination And considering them separately, In five ways and seven; Fivefold complete knowledge of this; (XII, 10)

brgyad pa 'dres par dmigs pa yid la byed pa ni/ de ni 'dres la dmigs pa dang / /'og tu rnam pa lnga dang zhes pas bstan te/ 'dres par dmigs pa la rnam lnga yod de/ mdo sde las 'dres par dmigs pa/ ched brjod dam sdom gyi tshigs bcad la 'dres par dmigs pa/ gleng gzhi la 'dres par dmigs pa/ 'dzin pa la 'dres par dmigs pa/ 'chad pa la 'dres par dmigs pa lnga las dang po/ mdo sde sa bcu pa lta bu la sogs rnams kyi bstan don mdor bsdus nas spyir yid la byed pa dang / le'u re re'i bstan don don du'i nang du 'dus par bsdoms nas de ltar yid la byed pa dang / gleng gzhi dang gzhung don mjug sdud lta bu'i spyi chings kyi tshul du khong don bsdus te dmigs pa dang / rang gis ji ltar bzung ba bsgom bya'i don mdor bsdus na 'di tsam zhig yin no zhes dang / gzhan la 'chad pa la yang de dang 'dra bar sdud pa ste/

(8) Attentiveness associated with considering the teachings in combination. This is indicated by “considering things in combination…in five ways.” Considering the teachings in combination takes five forms: considering them summarized from the sūtras; considering them together in a summary or synoptic verse; considering them together in introductory instructions; considering them together in points one has committed to memory; and considering them together in an explanation. Of these five, the first consists of (a) summarizing the topics taught in the sūtras—the Sūtra of the Ten Levels, for example—and keeping them in mind in a general manner; (b) summarizing the topics taught in each chapter into a few points and in that way keeping them in mind; (c) summarizing the main subject in the form of a general outline comprising, for example, the introduction, main body of the text, and concluding summary, and considering that; (d) condensing the points of meditation that one has memorized into a simple point; and (e) in teaching others, condensing the teachings in the same way.

mdor na mdo sde dag gi don dang / de'i bar du ched brjod dam don bsdus pa'i tshigs bcad dang / gleng gzhi bsdus te yid la byed pa dang / 'chad nyan gyi don rnams kyang de bzhin du don dril te yid la byed pa'o/ /

In short, this is to keep in mind the topics of the sūtras, the intermediate summaries or synoptic verses, and introductory summaries, and to keep in mind the points one has heard and that one teaches similarly condensed.

theg pa chen po'i mdo sde thams cad kyi bstan don bsdus na zab pa dang rgya che ba gnyis yin la/ zab pa'i don bsdus na gzung ba dang 'dzin pa bdag dang gzhan sogs gnyis chos kyi spros pa med pa'i de bzhin nyid du bsdus pa lta bu dang / rnam pa'i sgo nas rgya cher bshad kyang mtha' de la thug par shes pa dang / rgya che ba'i chos thams cad gzhi lam 'bras gsum du bsdu ba dang / gzhi bden gnyis/ lam tshogs gnyis/ 'bras bu sku gnyis su 'du ba lta bur bsdus te 'dres pa la dmigs pa'o/ /

The points taught in all the Mahāyāna sūtras can be condensed into two: profound and extensive. The profound teachings can be summarized as suchness devoid of dualistic conceptual constructs such as subject and object, and self and other. Even though they are extensively explained in terms of different aspects, ultimately that is what they boil down to. The extensive teachings can all be summarized as ground, path, and result. The ground includes the two truths; the path includes the two accumulations; and the result includes the two buddha bodies. Thus the teachings are considered in combination.

dgu pa tha dad pa'am ma 'dres pa la dmigs pa ni/ ma 'dres pa la dmigs pa ste/ /zhes dang / rjes su/ rnam bdun nyid/ /ces pas bstan te/ ma 'dres pa la dmigs pa la rnam bdun yod de/ ming la dmigs pa ni/ ka ba dang bum pa zhes pa lta bu'o/ tshig la dmigs pa ka ba ring po bum pa gsar pa lta bu'i ming dang de'i khyad par sbyar nas ston pa'o/ / yi ge la dmigs pa ni/ ming thams cad kyi rtsom gzhi a dang ka la sogs pa'i yig 'bru la dmigs pa ste/ 'di gsum rjod byed la rnam pa gsum du dbye nas mdo sde gang du tshig dang ming dang yi ge 'di tsam yod pa de'i don 'di ston to zhes dmigs pa ste/ 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i bstan bcos thams cad ming tshig yi ge'i rang bzhin las ma 'das la/ de dag gis don ston mod sems kyis brdar byas pa'i dbang gis yin pas ming tshig yi ge thams cad kyang sems las byung ba sems kyis btags pa tsam du shes nas brjod du med par 'jug go / brjod bya'i dbang du byas na yongs grub kyi dbang du byas te gang zag gi bdag med pa dang / chos kyi bdag med pa la dmigs pa gnyis dang / gzhan dbang gi dbang du byas te/ gzung char snang ba'i gzhan dbang gzugs can gyi chos rnams du ma dang mi rtag pa dang / lus mi gtsang ba dang / sdug bsngal gyi rten yin pa dmigs pa dang / 'dzin char snang ba'i gzhan dbang gzugs can min pa sems sems byung rnams sdug bsngal ba dang mi rtag par dmigs pa'o/ /

(9) Attentiveness associated with considering things separately. This is indicated by “considering them separately…in seven [ways].” There are seven different ways in which things are considered separately: (a) considering names—“pillar” and “pot,” for example; (b) considering phrases—indicating particularities by combining them with names (a tall pillar, a new pot, for example); and (c) considering letters—considering the consonants and vowels that are the basic components of all names. Here one is considering these three different categories of expresser, considering that in any sūtra there are so many phrases, names, and letters indicating this and that meaning. There are no treatises, mundane or supramundane, that comprise anything other than names, phrases, and letters. Although they indicate meanings, they do so by the power of the mind’s communicative activity: all names, phrases, and letters originate from the mind and are mere labels imputed by the mind. It is in the knowledge of this that they are applied to things that are inexpressible.[20] From the point of view of what these three express, with regard to the fully present reality, there are two categories: (d) considering the no-self of the individual and (e) considering the no-self of phenomena. And with regard to the dependent reality: (f) considering that material phenomena and the body, which constitute the dependent reality appearing as the object, are respectively multiple and impermanent, and impure and subject to suffering; and (g) considering that the immaterial mind and mental factors, which constitute the dependent reality appearing as the subject, are suffering and impermanence.

bcu pa yongs su shes pa'i nges pa yid la byed pa ni/ 'di yi yongs su shes pa lnga zhes pas bstan te/ ting nge 'dzin 'di yi dmigs pa yongs su shes pa ni lnga yod de/ lnga po gang zhe na/ yongs su shes par bya ba'i gzhi bden pa bzhi/ yongs su shes par bya ba'i don mi rtag sogs rnam pa bcu drug yongs su shes par byed pa la mthong sgom gyi lam gnyis/ yongs su shes pa'i 'bras bu ni rnam par grol ba/ rnam grol de nyid rab tu shes pa rnam grol mthong ba'i ye shes gzigs pa'o/ / de yang gzhi nyer len gyi phung lnga la dmigs nas/ de sdug bsngal ba dang mi rtag pa dang bdag med pa dang stong pa'i don du shes pa'o/ / de ltar rab tu shes par byed pa ni 'phags pa'i lam yan lag brgyad pa ste mthong lam sgom lam du 'byung ngo / / lam des 'bras bu nyon mongs spangs pas sems rnam par grol ba dang / rnam grol de mthong ba'i ye shes 'byung ste/ don la bden pa bzhi yongs su shes pa yin no/ /

(10) Attentiveness associated with the certainty of complete knowledge is indicated by “fivefold complete knowledge of this.” Complete knowledge of the object of concentration is fivefold: (a) the basis that is to be completely known, which is the four truths; (b) the points that are to be completely known, which are their sixteen subdivisions—impermanence and the others; (c) the means for gaining complete knowledge, which is the two paths of seeing and meditation; (d) the result of complete knowledge, which is perfect liberation; and (e) the perfect knowledge of that perfect liberation, which is to see the gnosis that sees perfect liberation. Stated otherwise, having considered the five perpetuating aggregates (the basis), one knows that they are in fact suffering, impermanence, no-self, and emptiness. What makes one know this perfectly is the eightfold noble path—in other words, perfect knowledge comes on the paths of seeing and meditation. The result attained by that path is the perfect liberation of the mind through the elimination of defilements. And there arises the gnosis that beholds that perfect liberation. In fact, this refers to complete knowledge of the four noble truths.
rnam pa bsgom dang ldan pa ni/ / bzhi dang sum cu rtsa bdun no/ / de ni lam gnyis rang bzhin te/ / phan yon gnyis dang nod pa dang / /

bcu gcig pa bsgom pa'i rnam pa yid la byed pa ni/ rnam pa bsgom dang ldan pa ni/ /bzhi dang sum cu rtsa bdun no/ /zhes pas bstan te/ rnam pa bsgom pa dang ldan pa'am sgom pa'i rnam pa bzhi ni/ gang zag la bdag med pa'i rnam pa bsgom pa dang / chos la bdag med pa'i rnam pa bsgom dang / mthong ba'i rnam pa la bsgom pa dang / shes pa'i rnam pa la bsgom pa bzhi las/ dang po phung lnga mi rtag sogs bzhir rtogs pa nyan thos rnams kyis kyang bsgom mo/ / gnyis pa chos thams cad rang bzhin med pa byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis bsgom mo/ / mthong ba ni ye shes skad cig ma bcu drug las bzod pa brgyad ni mthong ba dang / shes pa brgyad shes pa'i rnam pa'o/ / yang na zhi gnas la mthong ba dang / lhag mthong la shes pa zhes bya'o/ /

(11) Attentiveness associated with the object of meditation, which is indicated by “objects associated with meditation.” The four objects of meditation (or objects associated with meditation) are meditation on the individual no-self, meditation on the no-self of phenomena, meditation on the object of seeing, and meditation on the object of knowing. Of these, the first—realizing that the five aggregates are impermanent and so on[21]—is also what the listeners meditate on. The second—that all phenomena are devoid of intrinsic nature—is what bodhisattvas meditate on. Seeing refers to the eight instants of acceptance (of the sixteen instants of gnosis on the path of seeing), and knowing to the eight instants of knowing. Alternatively, seeing can refer to sustained calm and knowing to profound insight.

bsgom pa'i rnam pa sum cu rtsa bdun ni byang chub phyogs mthun gyi chos sum cu rtsa bdun te/ lus mi gtsang ba/ tshor ba sdug bsngal ba/ sems mi rtag pa/ chos thams cad bdag med pa'i rnam par shes pa'i dran pa nye bar bzhag pa bzhi/ lhag pa'i bslab pa gsum ma skyes pa bskyed pa rab tu thob pa'i rnam pa la bsgom pa yang dag spong ba dang po dang / brten pa'i rnam pa la bsgom pa bslab pa gsum gyi chos skyes pa rnams gong nas gong du 'phel zhing rgyas pa gnyis pa dang / gdon pa'i rnam pa la bsgom pa la bsgom pa zhes pa bslab pa gsum gyi mi mthun phyogs skyes pa rnams spong ba'i phyir 'bad pa gsum pa dang / gnyen po'i rnam pa la bsgom pa zhes sdig pa mi dge ba'i chos ma skyes pa mi skyed pa'i phyir mi sdug pa dang byams pa dang rten 'brel gyi don bsgom pa bzhi pa'o/ /

The thirty-seven objects of meditation are the thirty-seven elements leading to enlightenment, which are as follows. The four close mindfulnesses comprise mindfulness of the body and impurity; of feelings and suffering; of the mind and impermanence; and of consciousness and the fact that all phenomena are devoid of self. The four genuine restraints are (a) training in attainment, that is, in developing the three superior trainings where they have not yet been developed; (b) training in stability, that is, further developing and enriching the three trainings once they have been developed; (c) “training in expulsion,” that is, being diligent in eliminating any counteragents to the three trainings that may arise; and (d) “training in the antidote,” that is, meditation on ugliness, love, and dependent arising in order to prevent any negative factors from arising.[22]

de nas rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa bzhi/ 'dun pa ni chog par 'dzin pa'i gnyen po yid la byed pa dang / brtson 'grus ni/ g.yeng ba dang the tshom gyi gnyen po yid la byed pa dang / sems pa ni sems rab tu 'dzin pa'i sgo nas rgod pa'i gnyen po yid la byed pa'o/ / dpyod pa ni rmugs pa dang zhum pa'i gnyen po yid la byed pa'o/ /

Next, there are the four bases of miraculous powers: keenness, which is to keep in mind the antidote to complacency; diligence, keeping in mind the antidote to distraction and doubt; mindfulness, keeping in mind the antidote to mental excitation by concentrating the mind; and analysis, keeping in mind the antidote to dullness and low spirits.

dbang po lnga'i dad pa ni yid ches pa'i rnam pa yid byed do/ / de bzhin brtson pa 'bad pa'i rnam pa/ dran pa mi brjed pa'i rnam pa/ ting nge 'dzin sems gnas pa'i rnam pa/ shes rab rnam par 'byed pa'i rnam pa la bsgom pa'o/ /

Of the five powers that are the object of meditation, faith is to keep confidence in mind. Similarly, diligence is to make effort, mindfulness is to not forget, concentration is to stabilize the mind, and wisdom is to discern perfectly.
dbang po lnga de dag gi mi mthun phyogs choms pa ni stobs lnga yid la byed pa'o/ /
Keeping in mind the five irresistible forces is what overcomes counteragents to these five powers.

byang chub kyi lam yan lag bdun gang zhe na/ zad mi skye shes pa'i ye shes kyi bdag nyid ni byang chub yin la de'i yan lag tu gyur pa ni dran pa sogs bdun no/ / yang na mthong lam thob pa'i gnyis su med pa'i ye shes byang chub yin la de'i yan lag tu gyur pa dran pa sogs bdun pa'o/ / 'di rnams la yang dag byang chub rab tu snang ba la/ bsgom pa zhes gsungs te/ mi brjed pa'i dran pa yang dag byang chub kyi yan lag dang / phyin ci ma log par shes pa'i chos rab tu 'byed pa byang chub kyi yan lag dang / dge ba la spro ba'i brtson 'grus/ yid bde ba'i rang bzhin dga' ba/ las su rung ba shin tu sbyangs pa/ mnyam par gnas pa'i btang snyoms/ sems gnas pa ting nge 'dzin byang chub kyi yan lag bdun no/ /

As for the seven elements of the path of enlightenment, in the case where enlightenment means the gnosis of exhaustion and nonarising,[23] they are the seven elements, beginning with mindfulness, that lead to that. Alternatively, they are the seven elements (mindfulness and the others) that lead to enlightenment in the sense of the nondual gnosis attained on the path of seeing. These constitute what has been described as “the meditation in which authentic enlightenment dawns.”[24] These seven elements leading to enlightenment are (a) unforgetting mindfulness as an element leading to perfect enlightenment; (b) the perfect discernment of phenomena as an element leading to enlightenment, and which knows things without error; (c) diligence, that is, delight in virtue; (d) joy, a happy frame of mind; (e) serviceability and fitness in body and mind; (f) evenness, resting in a state of equilibrium; and (g) concentration, a settled state of mind.
'phags lam brgyad kyi
The eightfold noble path is comprised of the following elements:

yang dag pa'i lta ba ni gdon mi za ba'i rnam pa la bsgom pa zhes bya ste/ sa dang por gdon mi za ba'am rnam par nges pa nyid du chos kyi dbyings rtogs zin pa de nyid bsgom pa'i lam rnams su yang nas yang du khyad par sgom par byed pa'o/ /

(a) Right view is referred to[25] as training in freedom from doubt. It particularly involves meditating repeatedly, on the different levels of the path of meditation, on the expanse of reality that one realized definitively, without any doubt, on the first bodhisattva level.

yang dag pa'i rtog pa ni yongs su sbyangs pa'i sa rtogs pa'i rnam pa la bsgom pa zhes bya ste/ mos spyod nas thos bsam bsgom pa rim par 'phel ba'i sa dang por chos kyi dbyings mngon sum rtogs pa ni yongs su sbyangs pa'i sa zhes bya'o/ / de mnyam bzhag las 'das nas bdag gis yongs su sbyangs pas chos kyi dbyings ji lta ba rtogs so zhes shes pas so/ /

(b) Right thought is referred to as training in realizing the level of complete purification. From the level of earnest aspiration, listening, reflection, and meditation are gradually developed until, on the first bodhisattva level, the expanse of reality is realized directly. This is known as the level of complete purification, because, having risen out of formal meditation, one knows, “By completely purifying myself, I have realized what the expanse of reality is like.”

yang dag pa'i ngag ni pha rol po la yang dag par rig par byed pa'i rnam pa la bsgom pa zhes dang / yang dag pa'i las kyi mtha' ni 'phags pa 'dun par byed pa'i tshul khrims la zhugs pa'i rnam pa la bsgom pa zhes bya ste/ 'phags pa dgyes pa'i tshul khrims yin pas so/ /

(c) Right speech is referred to as training in making other people understand correctly. (d) Right conduct is referred to as training in observing the discipline that the noble beings yearn for, for it is the discipline that pleases the noble beings.[26]
yang dag pa'i 'tsho ba ni bsnyungs pa'i tshul kun tu spyod pa'i rnam pa la bsgom pa zhes yo byad bsnyung zhing log 'tsho spangs pas so/ /
(e) Right livelihood is referred to as training in cutting back on one’s lifestyle, that is, making do with few possessions and avoiding wrong means of livelihood.[27]

yang dag pa'i rtsol ba ni/ sngon yongs su bsgoms pas thob pa'i lam la goms pa'i rnam pa la bsgom pa zhes bya ste/ mos spyod nas sa dang po'i bar du bsgoms pas sa dang por brtson 'grus khyad 'phags thob nas/ sa bcu pa'i bar du brtson 'grus khyad zhugs pa la goms par byed pas so/ /

(f) Right effort is referred to as training in habituation to the path that one has attained by thorough training in previous lives. By practicing from the level of earnest aspiration up to the first bodhisattva level, one acquires, on the first level, superior diligence, and subsequently, up to the tenth level, one cultivates increasingly enhanced diligence.

yang dag pa'i dran pa ni chos gnas pa'i mtshan ma mi brjed pa'i rnam pa la bsgom pa zhes bya ste/ chos ni chos kyi dbyings la brjod cing de la rtse gcig gnas pa'i tshe zhum rgod byung na gnyen po mtshan ma gsum gyis bsal te mi brjed pa'i rnam pa bsgom pa yin la/ mtshan ma gsum ni zhi gnas kyi mtshan ma dang / rab tu 'dzin pa'am gzengs bstod pa'i mtshan ma dang / btang snyoms kyi mtshan ma ste/ rgod pa na zhi gnas kyi mtshan ma bsgom ste zhi bar bya/ zhum rmugs byung na gzengs bstod pa'i mtshan ma rab tu 'dzin pas zhi bar byed/ zhum rgod med par nam gyur na btang snyoms kyi mtshan ma yid la bya zhing sems mi bskyod par rnal du bzhag go /

(g) Right mindfulness is referred to as training in not forgetting the special points for abiding in Dharma. When one concentrates one-pointedly on the expanse of reality, which is what is meant here by “Dharma,” one trains in not forgetting the three special points or antidotes for dispelling low spirits and wildness, should these occur. The three special points are the special point of sustained calm, the special point of maintaining one’s concentration or encouraging oneself, and the special point of equanimity. If the meditation becomes wild, one should calm it by practicing the special point of sustained calm. If low spirits and dullness occur, they should be corrected by concentration on the special point of encouraging oneself. When one is neither low-spirited nor wild, one should keep in mind the special point of equanimity and rest with the mind in its natural state, without movement.

yang dag pa'i ting nge 'dzin ni mtshan ma med pa sgom pa nyid gnas 'gyur ba'i rnam pa la bsgom pa zhes bya ste/ zhum rgod dang bral te mtshan ma gsum brten mi dgos pas sgom pa rtsol med du gnas gyur pa'i snying rje thob pa'o/ /

(h) Right concentration is referred to as training in the transformed state of meditation without special points. Once one is free of low spirits and wildness, there is no need to rely on the three special points, and one thus acquires the compassion of transformed, effortless meditation.

bcu gnyis pa lam gnyis kyi rang bzhin yid la byed pa ni/ de ni lam gnyis rang bzhin te/ /zhes pas bstan te/ bsgom pa de ni zhi gnas dang lhag mthong gi lam gnyis kyi rang bzhin te/ mi g.yeng ba zhi gnas la brten nas chos rab tu rnam par 'byed pa'i lhag mthong gi don rnams kyi rang bzhin ji lta ba bzhin du rtogs par byed pa'o/ /

(12) Attentiveness associated with the nature of the two paths. This is indicated by “the nature of the two paths.” The above meditation comprises the two paths of sustained calm and profound insight. Relying on undistracted sustained calm, one then, by means of the profound insight that perfectly discerns phenomena, realizes the nature of phenomena, as it is.

bcu gsum pa legs pa'am phan yon yid la byed pa ni/ phan yon gnyis dang zhes pas bstan te/ yid la byed pa gang gis gnas ngan len sel ba dang / lta ba sel ba'i sgo nas legs pa'i phan yon rnam pa gnyis su bzhag go / gnas ngan len la'ang gnyis te lus kyi gnas ngan len ni srog gcod pa dang / ma byin len dang / mi tshangs par spyod pa dang rdzun la sogs pa mi dge ba byed pa'o/ / sems kyi gnas ngan len ni mi dge ba spyod pa'i rgyu chags sdang rmongs gsum la sems g.yo bar byed pa'o/ / yid la byed pa gang gis gnas ngan len de sel zhe na chos la bdag med par yid la byed cing khong du chud pas sel lo/ / gang zag la bdag med par khong du chud pas 'jig lta mthar lta log lta mchog 'dzin gnyis bcas lta ba lnga po sel bar byed do/ /

(13) Attentiveness associated with excellence or benefits. This is indicated by “two benefits.” Attentiveness has two kinds of benefit: dispelling negative tendencies and dispelling defiled views. Negative tendencies are also of two kinds: physical negative tendencies that lead to negative actions such as killing, taking what is not given, unchaste conduct, lying, and so forth; and mental negative tendencies that move the mind toward attachment, aversion, and bewilderment, which are themselves the causal factors that lead to indulging in negative actions. These negative tendencies are dispelled by keeping in mind and assimilating the no-self of phenomena. Defiled views, of which there are five—the view of the transitory composite, the view of extremes, wrong views, and the two views of superiority[28]—are dispelled by assimilation of the individual no-self.

bcu bzhi pa gdams ngag rjes bstan yang dag par nod pa yid la byed pa ni/ nod pa dang zhes pas bstan te/ theg pa chen po'i rigs la gnas pa byang chub tu sems bskyed pa des mos pas spyod pa'i sar chos kyi rgyun gyi ting nge 'dzin thob par gyur nas/ sa dang po thob par 'gyur ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi gdams ngag sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams las len zhing 'dzin pa la yang dag par nod pa yid la byed pa zhes bya'o/ /

(14) Attentiveness associated with correctly receiving instructions and follow-up teachings.[29] This is indicated by “receiving.” Someone who has the Mahāyāna potential, has aroused the bodhicitta, and has attained the concentration of the stream of Dharma[30] on the level of earnest aspiration, then receives (and holds) from the buddhas and bodhisattvas the instructions on the concentration that leads to attaining the first level. This is known as attentiveness associated with correctly receiving.
sbyor ba pa dang dbang sgyur dang / / chung dang rgya che'i bdag nyid de/ / rnal 'byor rnams kyi yid byed 'di/ / thams cad bdag nyid yin par 'dod/ /
Application, mastery, The lesser, and the extensive— These aspects of yogis’ attentiveness Are held to include everything. (XII, 12)
bco lnga pa sbyor ba yid la byed pa ni/ sbyor ba dang zhes pas bstan te/ gdams ngag nod pa'i 'bras bu lam la sbyor ba'i sbyor ba la lnga yod de/
(15) Attentiveness associated with application. This is indicated by “application.” The result of receiving the instructions is their application on the path, and such application is of five kinds.

dang po grangs la nyer bar rtogs pa'i sbyor ba ni/ ting nge 'dzin gyi spyod yul mdo sde la sogs pa gsung rab yan lag bcu gnyis kyi gzhung dag gi gdams ngag rang gis nod pa de'i ming dang tshig dang yi ge'i grangs dang sh+lo ka sogs kyi grangs ji tsam yod pa la rtog pa'o/ /

First is application in investigating numbers. This is to consider how many names, phrases, and letters and how many verses and so forth there are in the instructions one has received—that is, in the texts of the Twelve Branches of Excellent Speech (the sūtras and so forth) that constitute the object of concentration.

gnyis pa gnas pa'am 'jug pa rnam pa gnyis la nyer bar rtogs pa'i sbyor ba ni rjod byed de dag gi gnas tshul ni/ yi ge ni ming tshig thams cad kyi rtsa ba'am phyi mo yin la de ni A li kA li lnga bcu tsam yin pas yi ge la tshad yod par rtog pa dang / ming dang tshig ni tshad med de sher phyin 'bum pa la sogs pa'i gzhung na ming tshig ches mang po yod pa bzhin mdo sde 'bum phrag du ma yin pas de tshad med par gnas pa'am 'jug pa la rtog pa'o/ /

Second is application in investigating the two aspects of their occurrence or usage. With regard to the occurrence of the above expressers, letters are the bases or precursors of all names and phrases, and since they comprise just fifty vowels and consonants, letters are considered to be finite in number. Names and phrases are considered to be infinite: there is no limit to their occurrence or usage, for in a scripture such as the Perfection of Wisdom in One Hundred Thousand Lines there are a very great many names and phrases, and there are many hundreds of thousands of sūtras like it.

gsum pa kun tu rtog pa nye bar rtogs pa'i sbyor ba ni/ gang zag gam yid byed gang gis bum pa zhes pa lta bu'i ming dang / de'i don lto ldir ba chu blugs pa'i snod lta bur/ ming de dang don de 'brel nas 'di'i ming ni 'di zhes bya la/ don ni 'di yin no zhes gdams ngag sogs nod pa'i ming dang don phyin ci ma log par rtogs pa ste/ ming gi sgra spyi la brten nas don rang mtshan gyi rnam pa blo yul du shar ba la don rang mtshan du zhen nas ming las don go ba don la kun tu rtogs pa dang / don rang mtshan mthong ba'i tshe don spyi la ming gis btags te 'di'i ming ni 'di yin no zhes rtogs pa ming kun tu rtogs pa'o/ /

Third is application in investigating conception. This is to understand unmistakenly the names and phrases of the instructions and so on that one has received (“The name for that is so-and-so, and its meaning is such and such”), associating names and their meanings. For example, when one says or thinks the name “vase,” one associates it with its meaning, “a bulbous container for pouring water.” On the basis of the general sound-image of the name, its specific characteristics appear as the object of the mind, and from fixating on its specific characteristics, one understands the meaning from the name and conceives the meaning. And when one sees the specific characteristics, one affixes the name to the object-image, thinking, “This is the name for that,” and conceives the name.

bzhi pa rim pa nye bar rtogs pa'i sbyor ba can ni/ 'jig rten na bum pa snam bu mi dang rta la sogs pa'i ming sna tshogs btags pa la 'dris nas/ ming gi rim bzhin du phyin ci ma log par brjod pa'i tshe don gang dang gang la de dang der zhen pa skye ba'i snga rol du de'i ming blo la 'char zhing de las don rtogs pa'o/ / grangs la sogs pa rtogs pa'i sbyor ba bzhi po de ni tshogs lam du chos nyan nas chos kyi dmigs pa rnyed pa'i thabs so/ /

Fourth is application in investigating order. In the conventional world, once one is accustomed to labeling things with different names—vase, woolen cloth, person, horse, and so forth—when they are mentioned correctly by their respective names, and before fixation on their respective meanings occurs, the thing’s name arises in the mind, and from that one conceives the meaning. These four kinds of application (of investigating numbers and so on) constitute the method, once one has listened to the teachings on the path of accumulation, for discovering the point of the teachings.

lnga pa rab tu rtogs pa'i sbyor ba ni sbyor lam sogs su ste/ 'di la rnam grangs bcu gcig yod cing / de dag rtogs pa la rab tu rtogs pa'i sbyor ba zhes bya'o/ / bcu gcig po gang zhe na/ sbyor lam du bzhi/ mthong lam du gcig rtogs bya'i sgo nas gnyis/ mchog dman gyi gnyis/ rjes thob kyi dbye bas gnyis te drug go /

Fifth, application in perfect realization refers to the path of joining and subsequent paths, and for this there are eleven categories, whose realization is termed “application in perfect realization.” With regard to these eleven categories, there are four on the path of joining, one on the path of seeing, and six comprising two in terms of what is to be realized, two that are superior and inferior, and two as categories of postmeditation.

sbyor lam gyi bzhi ni/ drod kyi dus su ming dang don gyi ngo bos 'brel ba med par ming la don du btags pa dang don la ming du btags pa 'di dag blos sgro btags nas ming dang don zhes bkod pa tsam du rtogs pa ni ming dang don glo bur byung bar rab tu rtogs pa zhes bya'o/ / rtse mo'i dus na gzung ba dang 'dzin pa gnyis su snang ba'i chos 'di dag gzung ba dang 'dzin pa'i ngo bor yod pa ma yin yang sems dang sems las byung ba gzhan gyi dbang gis de ltar yod yod grub grub ltar mngon du snang ba'am yang dag par snang ba'i mtshan ma tsam du shes pa ni mig btsir ba'i dbang gis zla ba gnyis snang ba la sogs pa bzhin no zhes rtogs pa ni/ yang dag par snang ba'i mtshan ma rab tu rtogs pa zhes bya ste/ mtshan ma zhes pa snang ba'i rgyu la bya ste/ de ltar snang ba'i rgyu sems yin par khong du chud pa'i phyir de skad brjod do/ / bzod pa'i dus na gzugs nas chos kyi bar gyi yul drug gam don drug po de dag la mi rtog cing gzung ba mi dmigs par rab tu rtogs pa ni don mi dmigs par rab tu rtogs pa zhes bya'o/ / chos mchog gi dus su yul drug la dmigs shing 'dzin par byed pa'i rnam shes tshogs drug po rang bzhin med par khong du chud pa ni/ dmigs pa mi dmigs par rab tu rtogs pa zhes bya'o/ / de ltar gzung 'dzin gnyis ka mi dmigs par rtogs pa'i rjes thogs su mthong ba'i lam sa dang po'i thob pa'i dus su gzung 'dzin gnyis dang bral ba'i chos nyid chos kyi dbyings kun tu 'gro ba rtogs pa ni/ chos kyi dbyings rab tu rtogs pa zhes bya'o/ /

The four on the path of joining are as follows. At the stage of warmth, one realizes that the imputation of meaning to name and of name to meaning (despite the fact that there is no essential connection between name and meaning) is merely the mind establishing “name” and “meaning” by superimposition. This is known as “the perfect realization that name and meaning arise adventitiously.” At the peak stage, one recognizes that the dualistic phenomena of subject and object, although not existing intrinsically as subject and object, appear perceptibly (or actually appear) on account of the mind and mental factors, as if they did exist as such, and that they are merely conceptual structures. They are like the two moons that we perceive when we look at the moon and press one eye. Realizing this is known as “perfect realization of conceptual structures that actually appear.” “Conceptual structure” here refers to the cause of appearances and is so termed because it is understood that the cause of such appearances is the mind. At the stage of acceptance, one ceases to conceptualize the six sense objects (or six objects) from forms through to phenomena and does not conceive an apprehended object. This perfect realization is what we call “perfect realization in not conceiving an object.” On the supreme mundane level, one fully understands that the six consciousnesses that subjectively apprehend and conceive the six sense objects have no intrinsic existence, and this is known as “perfect realization in not conceiving a conceiver.” Following on immediately from this realization beyond the concepts of both subject and object, one attains the path of seeing and the first bodhisattva level. The realization one has at that time of the all-embracing expanse of reality, the ultimate reality devoid of the duality of subject and object, is termed “perfect realization of the expanse of reality.”

nyan thos kyi mthong lam du gang zag la bdag med par rtogs pa zhes bya ste phung po lnga la gang zag gi bdag med pa tsam mngon sum rtogs te rgyun du zhugs pa'i 'bras bu thob bo/ / byang chub sems dpa'i mthong lam du gang zag gi bdag med par ma zad phung po lnga yang sgyu ma lta bu snang yang rang bzhin med pas chos la bdag med par rab tu rtogs pa zhes bya'o/ / bsam pa chung ngus rab tu rtogs pa ni nyan thos kyi rgyun zhugs sogs 'bras bu bzhi dang rang rgyal rnams te 'di dag bdag gi don bya ba tsam dang chos bdag med ma rtogs pa'i phyir ro/ / rgya che ba bdag nyid chen po'i bsam pa rab tu rtogs pa ni sa bcu pa'i byang sems rnams dang de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi ste/ bdag dang gzhan gyi don bya ba dang bdag med gnyis rdzogs par rtogs pas so/ /

On the listeners’ path of seeing, there is what we call “perfect realization of the individual no-self.” This is the direct realization only of the lack of individual self in the five aggregates and corresponds to the attainment of the result of stream enterer. On the bodhisattvas’ path of seeing, there is not only the realization of the individual no-self but also what we call the “perfect realization of the no-self of phenomena,” for both the five aggregates and illusion-like appearances are devoid of intrinsic existence. The “perfect realization of those with limited intentions” refers to listeners who have attained the four results (stream enterer and the others)[31] and to solitary realizers—“limited” because they have achieved only their own goal and have not realized the no-self of phenomena. The “perfect realization of great beings with vast intentions” is that of bodhisattvas on the tenth level and of the tathāgatas, because they have completely realized their own and others’ goals and the two kinds of no-self.

ji ltar khong du chud pa'i chos rnam par bzhag pa rab tu rtogs pa ni/ mthong lam sa dang po'i dus na chos kyi dbyings khong du chud pa'i phyir/ skad cig gcig la sangs rgyas brgya'i zhal blta ba sogs yon tan brgya phrag bcu gnyis rnams rtogs pa ni chos rnam par bzhag pa rtogs pa'o/ / de yang yang dag pa'i lta bas rtogs pa'o/ / rnam par bzhag pa'i chos rab tu rtogs pa ni/ sa gnyis pa nas bcu pa'i bar du bsgom par bya ba'i chos rnams kyang rtogs pas rang rang gi ngos skal gyi yon tan brgya phrag bcu gnyis stong la sogs par gong nas gong du 'phel ba'i rnam bzhag rang nyid kyis khong du chud cing rtogs pa'o/ / 'di ni bsgom lam pa'i yang dag pa'i rtogs pas so/ / phyi ma drug po 'di bsgom lam 'ba' zhig la sbyar ba bod 'grel rnams su snang yang dbyig gnyen dang blo brtan gyi dgongs pa dang bsgrig rgyu med par mthong ngo / /

“Perfect realization of the arrangement of the qualities of assimilation” refers to assimilating the expanse of reality on the path of seeing, on the first bodhisattva level, as a result of which one realizes the twelve sets of one hundred special qualities—having a vision of one hundred buddhas in a single instant, and so forth. This is the perfect realization of the arrangement of qualities, which is realized by those with the correct view. “Perfect realization of the qualities so arranged” refers to realizing the elements to be trained in from the second level up to the tenth, through which one assimilates and realizes the arrangement in which the corresponding twelve hundred sets of special qualities increase a thousandfold and more.[32] This is realized by the perfect realization of those on the path of meditation. In Tibetan commentaries, these last six are associated only with the path of meditation, but we can see that this does not at all fit the thinking of Vasubandhu and Sthiramati.

bcu drug pa dbang byed pa'i yid la byed pa ni/ dbang sgyur dang / /zhes pas bstan te/ dbang byed pa'i yid byed la gsum yod de/ nyon sgrib dag pa la dbang byed pa dang / nyon shes kyi sgrib pa gnyis ka dag pa la dbang byed pa dang / yon tan khyad par can sgrub par dbang byed pa gsum las/ dang po chags sogs nyon mongs de dag gi thar bar mya ngan las 'das pa la gegs byed pas de rnams gang zag gi bdag med rtogs pa mthong bsgom lam gyis spangs te phyis mi skye bar byas pa'o/ / 'di tsam nyan rang dgra bcom la yang yod do/ /

(16) Attentiveness associated with mastery. This is indicated by “mastery.” Keeping mastery in mind has three aspects: mastery in the purification of obscurations deriving from the defilements, mastery in the purification of both defilement-related and cognitive obscurations, and mastery in the accomplishment of extraordinary qualities. First, defilements such as attachment prevent one from attaining liberation in nirvāṇa. One therefore eliminates them by realizing the individual no-self on the paths of seeing and meditation so that they do not arise in the future. This much the listener and solitary-realizer arhats also have.

gnyis pa gzung 'dzin gyi chos la rang bzhin yod par zhen pa'i shes sgrib kyis thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes thob pa la gegs byed pa yin la nyon shes kyi sgrib pa gnyis spangs nas phyis nam yang mi skye bar byas pa ni theg pa chen po'i lam gyis so/ / gsum pa yon tan khyad par can mngon shes drug dang stobs dang mi 'jigs pa la sogs pa'i yon tan de dag thob pa'i gegs su gyur pa rnams spangs nas yon tan de dag mngon du byas pa la yon tan mngon par sgrub pa shin tu rnam par dag pa la dbang byed pa'o/ /

Second, the cognitive obscurations that conceive of the phenomena of subject and object as intrinsically existing prevent one from obtaining omniscient gnosis, and one therefore eliminates both defilement-related and cognitive obscurations so that they never occur again. This is achieved by means of the Mahāyāna path. Third, one eliminates the factors that prevent one from obtaining the extraordinary qualities—the six kinds of preternatural knowledge, the ten strengths, four fearlessnesses, and the other qualities—and realizes these qualities, attaining mastery in the perfect purification that is the full accomplishment of good qualities.
bcu bdun pa theg pa chung ngu nyan rang gi lam yid la byed pa dang /
(17) Attentiveness associated with the lesser vehicles, the paths of the listeners and solitary realizers.

bco brgyad pa rgya che ba'i bdag nyid byang chub sems dpa'i lam theg pa chen po yid la byed pa ste/ rnal 'byor rnams kyi yid byed bco brgyad 'di ni/ theg pa che chung kun gyi yid byed yin no cog thams cad bsdus pa yin par 'dod do/ /

(18) Attentiveness associated with the Great Vehicle, the extensive path of the bodhisattvas. These make up the eighteen categories of yogis’ attentiveness, which are held to include everything that they keep in mind, in all vehicles, greater and lesser.
gnyis pa/
b. INVESTIGATING THE DHARMA WHOSE MEANING IS TO BE REALIZED

rtogs bya don gyi chos btsal ba la/ de kho na nyid yongs su tshol ba dang sgyu ma lta bur yongs su tshol ba dang / de bzhin du shes bya yongs tshol dang / kun nyon dang rnam byang yongs tshol/ rnam par rig tsam yongs tshol/ mtshan nyid yongs tshol/ rnam par grol ba yongs tshol/ ngo bo nyid med pa yongs tshol/ mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa yongs tshol/ theg pa gcig tu bstan pa'i dgongs pa yongs su tshol ba/ rig pa'i gnas lnga yongs su tshol ba ste rnam grangs bcu gcig yod pa las/

Investigating the Dharma of realization is divided into eleven sections: (1) investigating the thatness of phenomena; (2) investigating the illusion-like nature of phenomena; (3) investigating knowable phenomena; (4) investigating defilement and purity; (5) investigating mere awareness; (6) investigating different realities; (7) investigating perfect liberation; (8) investigating absence of intrinsic existence; (9) investigating the acceptance that phenomena are unborn; (10) investigating the intention in teaching a single vehicle; and (11) investigating the five sciences.
dang po chos kyi de kho na nyid yongs su tshol ba ni/
i. INVESTIGATING THE THATNESS OF PHENOMENA

rtag tu gnyis bral 'khrul pa'i rten gang yin dang gang zhig rnam kun tu/ / brjod par nus ma yin zhing spros pa med pa'i bdag nyid de kho na/ / shes bya spang bya rang bzhin dri med 'dod gang rnam par sbyang bya ste/ / de ni nam mkha' gser dang chu ltar nyon mongs pa las rnam dag 'dod/ /

Delusion as to what is forever free of duality, its basis, and thatness (Utterly inexpressible and beyond elaboration) Should be recognized, eliminated, and, while accepted as intrinsically uncontaminated, completely purified. Thatness is held to be pure, free of defilements, like the sky, gold, and water. (XII, 13)
zhes tshigs bcad gnyis kyis bstan te/

kun nas nyon mongs pa dang rnam byang gi chos rnams kyi de kho na nyid tshol ba ni/ kun brtags dang gzhan dbang dang yongs grub ste ngo bo nyid gsum gyi sgo nas shes par bya ba la/ dus rtag tu gzung ba dang 'dzin pa gnyis dang bral ba yin yang gzung 'dzin gnyis su snang ba 'di ni kun du brtags pa'i mtshan nyid do/ / de ltar gzung 'dzin gnyis med bzhin de gnyis su snang ba 'khrul pa'i gzhi'am rten gang yin pa gzhan dbang dang / gang zhig rnam pa kun tu ngag gis brjod par nus pa ma yin zhing / rnam par rtog pa'i spros pa med pa'i bdag nyid ni yongs grub ste chos thams cad kyi gnas lugs de kho na nyid yin no/ / de ni gzung 'dzin gyi chos dang bral bas spros pa med pa'i rang bzhin so so rang gis rig par bya ba'o/ / de ltar kun brtags kyi mtshan nyid ni thag pa la sbrul bzhin du yod pa ma yin par shes par bya zhing / ma dag pa gzhan dbang gi mtshan nyid ni spang bar bya ba ste/ gzhan dbang la yod pa'i gzung 'dzin du snang ba sbyang bar bya ba yin pas so/ / rang bzhin gyis dri ma med par 'dod pa gang yin pa yongs grub la glo bur gyi dri ma rnams rnam par sbyang bar bya ste/ rang bzhin gyi dri ma med pa de ni rang gi ngo bo'i dbang du byas na nam mkha' rang bzhin gyis dag pa dang / gser rang bzhin gyis dag pa dang / chu rang bzhin gyis dwangs pa ltar rang gi ngo bo la ma dag pa ye nas med kyang / nam mkha' la sprin dang / gser la 'dam dang / chu la rnyogs pa bzhin/ glo bur gyi nyon mongs pas bsgribs te mngon du ma gyur pa yin pas nyon mongs de dang bral na rnam par dag pa nyid mngon du gyur par 'dod do/ /

The investigation of the thatness of the phenomena that lead to defilement or to purity has to be understood in terms of the three realities—imputed, dependent, and fully present. Although thatness is forever devoid of the duality of subject and object, we perceive things dualistically as subject and object. This is the imputed reality. The ground or support of deluded dualistic perception—even though there is no such subject-object duality—is the dependent reality. The nature that cannot be expressed by speech in any way and that is beyond the elaborations of discursive thought is the fully present reality. This is the actual condition of all phenomena—thatness. This, being devoid of the phenomena of subject and object and therefore beyond conceptual elaboration, can only be known personally. Thus, the imputed reality should be recognized as not existing, like the snake one might imagine on seeing a rope.[33] The impure dependent reality has to be eliminated, for the appearances of subject and object present in the dependent reality are what has to be purified. The fully present reality, which is accepted as being intrinsically uncontaminated, has to be purified of adventitious contaminants. “Intrinsically uncontaminated” means that it is in its very nature, from the beginning, devoid of any impurity, in the same way that, in terms of their very nature, the sky is unclouded, gold is naturally pure, and water is naturally limpid. Nevertheless, it is accepted that when the fully present reality is obscured by adventitious defilements, like clouds in the sky, mud on a piece of gold, or impurities in water, we do not realize that. Once it is free of the defilements, its perfect purity is realized.

'gro ba dag na de las gzhan yang cung zad yod min la/ / 'gro ba ma lus pa yang de la kun tu rmongs pa'i blo/ / yod pa kun nas spangs te med la mngon zhen gang yin pa/ / 'jig rten rmongs pa'i rnam pa tshabs chen 'di ko ji lta bu/ /

Apart from that, there’s not the slightest thing in beings that exists, Yet beings are all completely ignorant of this—their minds Reject what does exist and cling to what does not. Such is the enormity of the world’s confusion. (XII, 14)

don dam pa'i gnas tshul gyis gzhal na/ chos can 'gro ba yi khams dag na chos nyid yongs grub de las gzhan du gyur pa gzung ba dang 'dzin pa'i chos rdul tsam yang yod pa min la/ de ltar thams cad chos ni de yi ngang tshul du gnas mod kyi khams gsum gyi 'gro ba ma lus pa yang chos nyid de ma rtogs par gnas lugs de la kun tu rmongs pa'i blo gzung ba dang 'dzin pa'i chos su zhen pa gyur pas na/ dngos po la rang gi gshis lugs su yod pa yongs grub 'dzin pa kun nas spangs te/ med pa kun brtags la mngon par zhen pa gang yin pa 'jig rten rmongs pa'i rnam pa shin tu phyin ci log tshabs chen po can 'di ko ji lta bu zhig go zhes so/ /

Now, in terms of the way things are on the ultimate level, there is nothing existent in the elements that constitute beings other than the ultimate reality,[34] the fully present reality—not even an atom’s worth of subject and object. Everything dwells in the state of that true nature. However, none of the beings in the three worlds have realized that ultimate reality. Their minds are completely ignorant of that actual condition of things, and they cling to the phenomena of subject and object. Thus it is that, completely rejecting the apprehension of something that does exist—the fully present reality, the fundamental nature intrinsic to phenomena—they take to be real something that does not exist, the imputed reality. Such is the enormity of the error that ordinary, ignorant beings make.
gnyis pa sgyu ma lta bur yongs su tshol ba ni/
ii. INVESTIGATING THE ILLUSION-LIKE NATURE OF PHENOMENA
ji ltar sgyu ma de bzhin du/ / yang dag ma yin kun rtog brjod/ / sgyu ma'i rnam pa ji lta bar/ / de bzhin gnyis su 'khrul par brjod/ /
Of false imagination, We say it is like a magical illusion; And of dualistic delusion, We say it is like the forms in a magical illusion. (XII, 15)
ces tshigs bcad bcu drug gis bstan te/

de kho na nyid du med kyang snang ba tsam nyams su myong ba yod pas gzung 'dzin du snang ba'i chos thams cad snang yang rang bzhin med pa sgyu ma'i snang ba la sogs pa lta bu yin te/ ji ltar sgyu ma mkhan gyis rde'u sogs la sngags kyis btab pa'i mthu las rta dang glang po sogs kyi rnam pa dngos su snang ba sgyu ma yi snang ba de bzhin du gzung 'dzin gnyis su snang ba'i rgyu ni yang dag ma yin pa'i kun tu rtog pa gzung ba dang 'dzin par snang ba'i sems sems byung gzhan dbang gi rang bzhin de yin par brjod do/ / rta glang sogs sgyu ma yi snang ba de yi rnam pa lus dang yan lag kha dog sogs rta glang dngos lta bur snang ba ji lta bar de bzhin gzung 'dzin gnyis su 'khrul pa kun brtags pa ngo bo nyid do/ / med bzhin du gzung bar 'khrul pa dang 'dzin par 'khrul pa gnyis kyi bdag nyid du kun brtags pa thag pa la sbrul du 'khrul pa bzhin no/ /

Even though things do not exist in thatness, the experience of them does exist simply in their appearing. Phenomena perceived as subject and object all appear, but they have no intrinsic existence; they are like the things that appear in a magical illusion. Through the power of the spells that a magician intones over pebbles and other props, the images in a magical illusion actually appear in the form of horses, elephants, and the like.
