Moreover, even though they have eliminated the seed of defilements, they have not eliminated the subtle habitual tendencies. For this reason, even when they have attained the arhat level, because of their previous habitual tendencies from being born as monkeys, they may run and jump like monkeys; because of their previous tendencies as courtesans, they may look at their faces by looking in mirrors, or on the side of their alms bowls, and so on. So, although they do not have the defilements of such rebirths, they do have their habitual tendencies. The buddhas, on the other hand, do not have even the most subtle of the two kinds of obscurations and are therefore superior in terms of purity.

sangs rgyas kyi zhing sbyang bas rin po che'i sa gzhi dang / dpag bsam gyi shing dang / bdud rtsi'i chu bo sogs zhing yongs su dag pa'i bkod pa ston nus la nyan thos kyis mi nus pas zhing yongs su dag pa'i khyad par dang / sangs rgyas rnams bdag med gnyis rtogs pas de bzhin nyid mnyam pa chen po'i chos kyi sku thob la/ /nyan rang rnams la gang zag gi bdag med pa rtogs pa'i rnam par grol ba'i lus tsam las med do/ /

The buddhas, having trained in purifying their fields of perception, can display the array of completely pure buddha fields, with their ground of jewels, wish-fulfilling trees, rivers of nectar, and so forth. The listeners are unable to do this, so the buddhas are superior on account of their completely pure fields. By realizing the two kinds of no-self, the buddhas attain the body of truth—the great sameness, suchness. The listeners and solitary realizers, with their realization of the individual no-self, have no more than just the “body” of liberation.[49]

sangs rgyas rnams sa bcu byang sems kyi 'khor dang lhan cig srid pa ji srid du rgyun mi 'chad par theg pa chen po'i chos kyi longs spyod rdzogs par mdzad pa'i sku brnyes pa de lta bu nyan rang la med pa dang / sangs rgyas rnams mchog gi sprul sku la sogs pa sku gsung thugs kyi sprul pa'i rnam par rol pas sems can thams cad la phyi ma'i mtha'i bar du phan bde mdzad pa'i phrin las rgyun mi 'chad pa de lta bu nyan rang la med do/ / mtshon pa rnal 'byor gyi sa lnga po de'i snga ma bzhi rgyu yi rnal 'byor yin la/ phyi ma gcig ni 'bras bu'i rnal 'byor gyi sa yin no/ / rnal 'byor zhes pa zhi lhag zung du 'brel ba'i don yin la/ rnal 'byor gyi sa lnga po des mtshan nyid gsum mtshan gzhi lnga'i steng du mtshon par byed do/ / phung po lnga dang 'dus ma byas de bzhin nyid dang bcas pa'i chos rnams la'ang / byis pa rnams kyis gzung 'dzin gnyis su btags pa dang / gnyis su snang ba dang / gnyis su med pa'i don gsum po shes par byed pas so/ /

The buddhas have attained the body of perfect enjoyment, as a result of which they, together with their retinues of tenth-level bodhisattvas, have perfect enjoyment of the Mahāyāna teachings, unceasingly, for as long as saṃsāra lasts. This is something the listeners and solitary realizers do not have. Displaying supreme nirmāṇakāya manifestations and other manifestations of their body, speech, and mind, the buddhas, until the end of time, never cease their activities in bringing benefit and happiness to all sentient beings. This is not the case for the listeners and solitary realizers. Of these five indicative stages of yoga, the first four are stages of the causal yoga, while the fifth is the stage of the resultant yoga. “Yoga” means the union of sustained calm and profound insight. These five stages of yoga reveal how the three realities apply to the five bases, for they help us to understand all phenomena—the five aggregates and uncompounded phenomena, along with suchness—in three ways: the dualistic subject-object imputations of immature beings, dualistic appearance, and nonduality.

kha cig gzugs dang ldan min kun btags/ sems sems byung gzhan dbang / 'dus ma byas yongs grub ces gzhi lnga la so sor sbyar ba yod kyang cung mi legs la/ lnga po re re la yang gsum ga yod de/ kun btags kyi gzugs dang / gzhan dbang gi gzugs dang / chos nyid kyis khyad par du byas pa'i gzugs sam gzugs kyi chos nyid gsum phye ba ltar kun la shes par bya'o/ /

Some authorities associate the five bases with the three realities as follows. They associate form and nonassociated conditioning factors with the imputed reality, mind and mental factors with the dependent reality, and noncompounded phenomena with the fully present reality. But this is slightly incorrect. It should be understood that for each of the five bases there are all three realities—for example, form can be distinguished as imputed form, dependent form, and form qualified by its true nature (ultimate reality) or the true nature of form. The same applies to all five bases.
bdun pa rnam par grol ba yongs su tshol ba ni/
vii. INVESTIGATING PERFECT LIBERATION
Investigating perfect liberation is covered by six verses.

'phags pa'i lam gyis nyon mongs pa dang sdug bsngal spangs te mya ngan las 'das pa mngon sum byas pa ni rnam par grol ba yin la thabs gang gis mya ngan las 'das pa thob par 'gyur zhes brtags pa ni rnam par grol ba yongs su tshol ba zhes bya'o/ /

The elimination of defilements and suffering and the realization of nirvāṇa by means of the noble path is perfect liberation; and to examine the means by which one will attain nirvāṇa is what we call “investigating perfect liberation.”
sa bon gzhan du gyur pa'i phyir/ / gnas don lus su snang ba dag / gzhan du gyur pas zag med dbyings/ / de ni rten kun 'gro ba can/ /
When the seeds are transformed, The perceptions of place, sense objects, and body Are transformed. That untainted expanse Is the support pervading all. (XII, 44)
ces tshigs bcad drug gis bstan te/

de la nyon shes kyi sgrib pa'i bag chags sam/ gzung ba dang 'dzin pa'i bag chags sna tshogs pa kun gzhi'i rnam shes la yod pas de ni sa bon thams cad pa zhes bya ste/ de lta bu'i sa bon du gyur pa'i kun gzhi de gzung 'dzin gyi dri ma dang bral te gnas gzhan du gyur pa'i phyir na de las snang ba'i chos rnam pa gsum yang gnas 'gyur te/ gnas snod du snang ba dang / don yul drug tu snang ba dang / lus su snang ba dbang po drug dag gnas gzhan du gyur pa na snod ma dag pa ngam grog g.yang sa tsher ma can sogs ma yin par rin po che'i rang bzhin gyi snod kyi 'jig rten du snang ba dang / yul rnams dpag bsam gyi shing dang bdud rtsi'i rdzing bu sogs yid du 'ong ba'i longs spyod zag med kyi 'dod yon drug dang / lus sangs rgyas kyi sku lta bu dang*/ dbang po re res kyang dbang po thams cad kyi don byed nus pa dang / yon tan brgya rtsa bcu gnyis dang ldan pa'i yongs su dag pa'i lus phun sum tshogs pa rdo rje lta bu stobs dpag tu med par 'gyur ro/ / kun gzhi gnas 'gyur pa zag pa med pa'i dbyings de ni rnam par grol ba'i gnas sam rten yin pas gnas gyur gyi yon tan kun la khyab byed du 'gro ba yin no/ / yang na rnam par grol ba'i dbyings der nyan rang byang sems thams cad 'jug pas rten kun tu 'gro ba yang bshad do/ /

Because the various habitual tendencies associated with defilement-related and cognitive obscurations or dualistic habitual tendencies are present in the consciousness of the ground of all, the latter is referred to as “the one with all the seeds.” As a result of the ground of all that comprises such seeds being transformed and freed of the contaminants of subject and object, the three kinds of appearances that arise from those seeds are also transformed—namely, the appearance of the place or environment, the appearances of the six sense objects, and the appearances of the six sense organs as the body. When these are transformed, the environment is no longer impure, with thorny ravines, precipices, and the like, but is perceived as a jeweled universe. The sense objects become the six untainted pleasures of the senses to be enjoyed—beautiful wish-fulfilling trees, pools of nectar, and the like. The body becomes like the Buddha’s body, with each of the sense organs able to perform the functions of all the senses, the perfect, infinitely powerful, vajra-like body, utterly pure and endowed with the twelve sets of one hundred qualities. That untainted expanse of reality of the transformed ground of all is the location or support of perfect liberation, and it therefore pervades all the extraordinary qualities of transformation. An alternative explanation is that since the listeners, solitary realizers, and bodhisattvas all enter that expanse of perfect liberation, it is the universal support.
yid dang 'dzin dang rnam par rtog / gyur phyir rnam par mi rtog dang / / zhing dang ye shes las dag la/ / dbang ni rnam pa bzhi yin no/ /
When the mind, apprehenders, and conceptualization Are transformed, there are four kinds of mastery— In nonconceptuality, fields, Gnosis, and activities. (XII, 45)

nyon mongs pa'i yid dang 'dzin pa sgo lnga'i rnam shes dang/ rnam par rtog pa yid kyi rnam par shes pa gsum gnas gzhan du gyur phyir rim pa ltar nyon yid gnas gyur pas rnam par mi rtog pa la dbang bar 'gyur te/ gnas ma gyur pa'i dus na kun gzhi la bdag tu dmigs kyang gnas gyur pa'i tshe kun gzhi gnas gyur pa rnam par mi rtog pa la des dmigs pa'i phyir mi rtog la dbang ba thob pa dang / 'dzin pa sgo lnga'i rnam shes gnas gyur na tha mal ma dag pa'i spyod yul mi snang bar zhing yongs su dag pa la dbang ba dang / rnam par rtog pa yid kyi rnam shes gnas gyur na ye shes dang las gnyis po dag la dbang bar 'gyur te/ so sor yang dag par rig pa bzhi thob pas/ ye shes la dbang ba dang / mngon par shes pa'i mthus 'phrin las la dbang thob bo/ / gong du gnas gyur gyi skabs su'ang 'di dang mtshungs par gsungs so/ /

The results of transforming the defiled mind consciousness, the consciousnesses of the five apprehending sense doors, and the conceptual mind consciousness are now dealt with in order. By transforming the defiled mind consciousness, one will master nonconceptuality. When it is not transformed, it conceives of the ground of all as a self, but when it is transformed, it takes the transformed, nonconceptual ground of all as its object and one thus acquires mastery of nonconceptuality. When the consciousnesses of the five apprehending sense doors are transformed, instead of perceiving ordinary impure objects of experience, one has mastery over completely pure fields. And when the conceptual mind consciousness is transformed, one will master both gnosis and activities. By thus acquiring the four kinds of perfect knowledge, one achieves mastery in gnosis, and through the power of one’s preternatural knowledge, one achieves mastery in enlightened activities. This has been taught as being the same as in the section on transformation above.[50] Thus it is that the four kinds of mastery are acquired.
dbang de mi g.yo la sogs pa'i/ / sa gsum la ni rnam bzhi ste/ / gcig la rnam gnyis de las gzhan/ / dbang re rer ni 'dod pa yin/ /
These four kinds of mastery are gained On three levels—Immovable and the others. On one of these levels, two are gained, And on each of the others, one is gained. (XII, 46)

de ltar dbang ni rnam pa bzhi 'thob pa yin no/ / dbang bzhi po de sa brgyad pa mi g.yo ba la sogs pa'i sa gsum la ni dbang rnam pa bzhi thob ste/ gcig ste sa brgyad pa la dbang dang po mi rtog pa dang zhing la dbang ba gnyis thob la de las gzhan sa dgu par ye shes la dbang ba dang/ bcu par las la dbang ba thob pas/ sa de gnyis dbang re rer 'dod pa yin no/ /

These four kinds of mastery are gained on the three levels beginning with the eighth level, Immovable. On one, the eighth level, one acquires the first two masteries, mastery of nonconceptuality and mastery of fields. And on the others, one obtains mastery of gnosis (on the ninth level) and mastery of activities (on the tenth), these two levels therefore being described as having one mastery each.

blo dang ldan pas srid rtogs bdag med rnam pa gnyis ka'ang rig 'gyur la/ / de yang mnyam par shes nas de ni 'dzin pa'i sgo nas de nyid 'jug / de nas de la yid gnas phyir na de la de yang mi snang ngo*/ / de ni snang ba grol ba yin te mchog tu dmigs dang bral ba'o/ /

The wise will understand that all existence is devoid of both kinds of self, And knowing the sameness of that state, they approach suchness in terms of mental apprehension. Then, as they keep the mind on mind-only, that perception too will disappear. This nonappearance is liberation, sublimely free of references. (XII, 47)

rnam par grol ba'i rnam grangs gzhan yang / byang chub sems dpa' blo dang ldan pas khams gsum srid par gtogs pa'am yod pa'i chos thams cad la gang zag dang chos kyi bdag med pa rnam pa gnyi ga yang ro gcig khong du chud par gyur la zhes pas kun brtags pa'i bdag gnyis med par shes pas sgro 'dogs kyi mtha' bsal ba'o/ / bdag med rtogs pa de yang rnam pa thams cad du med pa tsam gyi stong rkyang ma yin par/ sgyu ma lta bu'i gzhan dbang bdag gnyis kyis stong pa'i yongs grub de bzhin nyid dang tha dad med par mnyam par shes pa ni skur 'debs chad pa'i mtha' bsal ba'o/ / de ltar dbu ma'i lam shes nas byang sems de ni lam de la de ltar 'dzin pa'i sems tsam gyi sgo nas de kho na nyid la 'jug cing de ltar blos yang yang goms par byed pa yin no/ / 'di ni sems tsam gyi sgo nas de kho na nyid yid la byed pa 'di drod nas bzod pa'i bar du'o/ / de nas sems tsam du rig pa de la yid gnas pa'i phyir na ji ltar gzung bar snang yang gzung ba'i ngo bo med pa de bzhin sems tsam gyis 'dzin par snang yang 'dzin pa nyid kyang gzung ba bzhin du med par rtogs nas chos mchog gi ting nge 'dzin thob pa de la 'dzin pa de yang mi snang ngo / / gzung ba dang 'dzin pa gnyis ka mgo mnyam du de dang der yongs su grub pa med par mthong nas gzung 'dzin gyi spros pa de rnam pa kun tu mi snang ba ni rnam par rtog pa mtha' dag las grol te 'phags pa'i ye shes mchog tu dmigs pa kun dang bral ba phyin ci ma log pa'i yongs grub gang yin pa'o/ /

Perfect liberation can also be explained in other ways. Wise bodhisattvas have realized the one taste of the two kinds of no-self (individual and phenomenal) in everything that belongs to or exists in the three worlds. In other words, by recognizing that they are devoid of the two kinds of imputed self, they have dispelled the extreme of superimposition. And when they know that the realization of no-self is not a complete vacuum, with nothing there at all, but the same as and not different from the illusion-like dependent nature and the fully present reality, suchness, devoid of the two kinds of self, they have dispelled the extreme of nihilistic repudiation. Knowing this middle way, bodhisattvas approach thatness in terms of the merely mental apprehension of such a path, and train their minds in this again and again.[51] This attentiveness to thatness in terms of mere mind occurs from the stage of warmth until the stage of acceptance. Then, by keeping the mind on the knowledge that everything is just the mind, they realize that even though things appear as the object, there is no intrinsically existent object, and that similarly even though the mind-only appears as the subject, the subject (like the object) does not exist either, and they then attain the concentration of the supreme mundane level—though there is no perception here of a subject attaining it. Once they have seen that both subject and object are equivalent and have no existence whatsoever, the conceptual elaborations of subject and object never appear in any way. This is liberation from all conceptual thought, the gnosis of the noble beings, the unmistaken fully present reality utterly free of all references.
tshogs kyi gzhi dang bskyed yod na/ / ming tsam du ni mthong bar 'gyur/ / ming tsam mthong ste der mthong nas/ / de yang phyi nas mi mthong ngo/ /
When the foundation—accumulation—and the development are present, One will see that everything is just a name. And seeing that seeing of just a name, One then no longer sees even that. (XII, 48)

yang rnam par grol ba'i rnam grangs gzhan bstan pa/ sngon tshogs gnyis bskal pa grangs med gcig tu bsags pa dang ldan pa'i tshe 'dir theg chen gyi chos thos bsam bsgom gsum byas pa'i tshogs kyi gzhi dang / mos spyod du mi rtag pa dang sdug bsngal dang stong pa dang bdag med par tshul bzhin yid la byed pas skyed pa'i sa de gnyis yod na/ rgyu de las sbyor lam drod dang rtse mo thob pa'i dus su/ chos thams cad sems kyis ming gis btags pa tsam las don rang mtshan pa med par rnam par rtog pa tsam du ni mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / de ltar btags bya'i chos med par kun tu rtog pas ming btags pa tsam gyi ming gzugs kyi zlas phye ba'i ming gzhi'i phung po sems sems byung tsam las phyi rol tu gyur pa'i don med par shes pa ni sbyor lam bzod pa thob pa'i tshe na/ phyi rol don gyis dben pa bzod pa der mthong nas/ ming tsam mam sems tsam du 'dzin pa phyi nas te chos mchog gi dus su mi mthong ngo*/ / de ltar gzung 'dzin gnyis ma mthong bas me long lta bu dang snang ba 'byung zhing mthar sangs rgyas kyi sa mnyam pa nyid thob pas rnam par grol ba yin no/ /

Another way of explaining perfect liberation is as follows. When one possesses the merit and wisdom accumulated over one measureless kalpa in the past, at this time both the foundation stage of accumulation in having listened to the Mahāyāna teachings, reflected on them, and meditated on them, and the developmental stage of properly keeping in mind impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self on the path of earnest aspiration are present, and as a result, one attains the stages of warmth and the peak on the path of joining. At this point one will see that all phenomena have simply been labeled with names by the mind, and that apart from that they are merely conceptual constructions and have no existence as specifically characterized phenomena. The phenomena that are the object of such imputation do not exist but are merely labeled by the imagination: apart from just the mind and mental factors (the aggregates that are the basis of name, as opposed to form), there are no objects outside. When one realizes this, one attains the stage of acceptance on the path of joining, at which time one accepts that reality is devoid of external objects. Having seen this, one subsequently, at the stage of supreme mundane realization, no longer sees the subject that apprehends things as just names or mere mind. Thus, from one’s no longer seeing both subject and object, the mirrorlike and vision stages occur, and finally one attains the state of sameness on the level of buddhahood, which is perfect liberation.
sems ni gnas ngan len dang bcas/ / bdag lta'i zhags pas zin par ni/ / rab tu 'jug par 'gyur te de/ / nang du gnas phyir ldog par 'dod/ /
The mind with its negative tendencies, Caught by the noose of belief in a self, Becomes totally immersed. By settling inward, we hold, it turns away. (XII, 49)

yang rnam par grol ba'i rnam grangs gzhan bstan pa/ sems ni zhes kun gzhi'i rnam shes la sogs pa sems dang sems las byung ba'i chos rnams so/ / sems de gnas ngan len dang bcas pa ste/ lus kyi gnas ngan len srog gcod pa sogs mi dge ba dang / sems kyi gnas ngan len chags sdang gti mug go / yang na nyon shes kyi sgrib pa'i bag chags kyi gnas ngan len gnyis so/ / gnas ngan len kyi rgyu ni gang zag la bdag tu lta ba dang / chos la bdag tu lta ba'i/ bdag lta'i zhags pas sems rab tu zin par gyur nas ni/ 'khor bar rab tu 'jug par 'gyur te zhes/

This verse shows yet another way of explaining perfect liberation. “Mind” in this case refers to the mind and mental factors, including the consciousness of the ground of all. That mind is accompanied by negative tendencies, of which there are two kinds: negative tendencies of the body (that is, nonvirtuous actions such as taking life) and those of the mind (attachment, aversion, and bewilderment); or alternatively, the negative habitual tendencies of obscurations deriving from the defilements and those of cognitive obscurations. The cause of negative tendencies is the belief in an individual self and the belief in a phenomenal self. Once caught in this noose of belief in a self, the mind enters fully into saṃsāra.

mdor na bdag 'dzin gnyis pos nyon shes kyi sgrib pa bsags pa'i gnas ngan len dang 'brel ba'i sems de ji srid bdag 'dzin gnyis po ma spangs pa de srid du sems la bag chags bsags shing 'khor bar 'jug ces so/ / sems de nang du gnas phyir ldog pa 'dod ces pa/ sems de ji ltar nang du gnas na/ gzung ba la zhen cing rnam par g.yeng ba'i sems nang du sems la bsdus te nang du yang dag par bzhag pa'i zhi gnas dang / gzung ba med par 'dzin pa'i sems tsam du rtogs pa dang sems kyang med par rtogs nas gzung 'dzin gnyis dang bral bas ni gnas ngan len gyi bag chags mi gsog cing sems 'khor bar 'jug pa las ldog te rnam par grol ba yin no zhes so/ /

In short, as long as the mind that is accompanied by the negative tendencies of defilement-related and cognitive obscurations accumulated by the two kinds of belief in a self has not abandoned these two beliefs, one accumulates habitual tendencies in the mind and is born in saṃsāra. By settling inward, it is held, that mind turns away. In what way does the mind settle inward? The distracted mind that attaches to the object is gathered in, into the mind itself, and rests peacefully, perfectly settled within. Once one has realized that it is just the mind that subjectively apprehends the nonexistent object and that the mind too is nonexistent, one is free of both subject and object. One therefore no longer accumulates habitual negative tendencies and one’s mind turns away from entering saṃsāra. This is what we call perfect liberation.

rnam par grol ba'i rnam grangs bzhi bshad pa 'di rnam grangs gzhan dang gzhan gyi sgo nas rnam par grol ba bstan pa tsam las blo brtan 'grel par don gzhan ma gsungs kyang / rnam grangs dang po ni gnas 'gyur ba'i sgo nas rnam grol gyi ngo bo bshad pa dang / gnyis pa rnam par grol ba'i lam gyi ngos nas bshad pa dang / gsum pa rnam pa grol ba 'byung ba'i go rims kyi sgo nas dang / bzhi pa rnam par grol ma grol sems la rag las te/ 'ching na sems 'ching / grol na sems grol ba yin gyi/ phyi rol pas 'dod pa ltar dbang phyug gi dbang bsgyur ba sogs kyis grol ba dang / gcer bu pas thar pa gzugs can du gyur pas grol ba sogs mi 'thad de/ sems kyi 'ching ba ma spangs par rnam par grol ba nam yang mi srid la/ bdag 'dzin gnyis kyi 'ching ba spangs na grol ba yin zhes rnam grangs bzhis rnam grol yongs su btsal ba yin no/ /

Although Sthiramati’s commentary does not give any other significance to these four different explanations of perfect liberation apart from their being different presentations, they represent the investigation of perfect liberation from four different points of view. The first gives a definition of liberation in terms of transformation. The second explains it from the point of view of the path to liberation. The third explains it in terms of the successive stages by which liberation takes place. The fourth shows that liberation or the absence of liberation depends on the mind: when there is bondage, it is the mind that is bound; when there is liberation, it is the mind that is liberated. On the other hand, the claims of non-Buddhists that one is liberated at God’s behest, for example, and those of the Nirgrantha Jains that liberation has a material form are illogical. Without getting rid of the mind’s bonds, it is impossible ever to be liberated. But if one eliminates the bonds of the two kinds of belief in a self, one will attain liberation.
brgyad pa ngo bo nyid med pa yongs su tshol ba ni/
viii. INVESTIGATING ABSENCE OF INTRINSIC EXISTENCE
rang dang rang gi bdag nyid du/ / med phyir rang gi ngo bo la/ / mi gnas phyir dang bzung bzhin de/ / med phyir ngo bo nyid med 'dod/ /

Because things do not exist of themselves and they do not exist as their own nature, And because they do not dwell in their own nature, And because they do not exist as they are apprehended, They are held to be devoid of intrinsic existence. (XII, 50)
ces tshigs bcad gnyis kyis bstan te/

mdo sde rnams las chos thams cad ngo bo nyid med pa rang bzhin gyis mya ngan 'das pa zhes gsungs na/ de'i don ngo bo nyid gsum dang sbyar na ji ltar yin tshul gsungs pa/ chos thams cad ces bya ba mdor bsdu na kun brtags dang / gzhan dbang yongs grub ste ngo bo nyid dam mtshan nyid gsum po 'dir 'du'o/ / de yang gzhan gyi dbang ni sems sems byung gzung 'dzin du snang ba skad cig ma'i rgyun can 'di yin la/ 'di la ni 'dus byas kyi mtshan nyid skye gnas 'gag pa gsum yod pas de la 'das pa 'gags zin pa ni da ltar chos de'i rang gi ngo bo med pa'i phyir dang / ma 'ongs pa ni da lta'i dus su rang gi bdag nyid du ma skyes pas med pa'i phyir dang / gnas bzhin pa'i da lta ba ni rang gi ngo bo grub zin pa la skad cig gnyis par mi gnas pa'i phyir dngos po med pa'am ngo bo med par 'dod do/ / skye 'gag gi sgo nas ngo bo med par brtags pa 'di ni nyan thos pa rnams kyis kyang stong pa dang ngo bo nyid med pa'i don 'chad tshe 'di lta bur 'chad do/ /

It is taught in the sūtras that all phenomena are devoid of intrinsic existence; they are by nature nirvāṇa. This section explains how this is related to the three realities. “All phenomena,” put briefly, are included in the three natures or realities—the imputed reality, the dependent reality, and the fully present reality. The dependent reality is the continuity of instants of the mind and mental factors appearing as subject and object. These have the three characteristics of compounded phenomena: they come into existence, continue to exist, and cease to exist. Now, the past, which has already ceased, is, by definition, not the present. The future, by definition, has not come into existence at the present time and therefore does not exist. And as for the present, which apparently continues to exist, it has, by definition, already been produced and it will not continue to exist for a second instant. For these three reasons, it is held that phenomena are devoid of substantial existence or intrinsic nature. This examination of the lack of intrinsic nature in terms of production and cessation is similar to the listeners’ own explanation of emptiness and the lack of intrinsic existence.

yang gzhan dbang skye ba ngo bo nyid med pa'i don du bshad na/ rang dang zhes pa gzhan dbang rten 'brel gyi snang ba 'di dag rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis ma skyes te rgyu rkyen tshogs pa'i gzhan dbang las skye bas na skye ba ngo bo nyid med pas na ngo bo nyid med par bshad de/ de ni grangs can pa dag gtso bo yod pa las gzhan rnams skye zhes sam/ 'bras bu rnams rgyu'i dus na yod pa nyid skyed kyi med na skye mi rigs so zhes 'dod pa 'gog pa'i don du'o/ / rang gi bdag nyid du med phyir zhes pa ni/ dngos po 'gags pa rnams slar yang sngon gyi rang bzhin du skye ba med ces pa'i don te 'dis zhig pa ni dngos po 'gag pa tsam las med ces bstan te/ grangs can pa rnams kyis dngos po zhig pa yang rnam pa thams cad du med par song ba ma yin gyi gtso bo'i klong du bag la nyal nas gnas sam zhes pa de lta bu ma yin zhes bstan pa'o/ / rang gi ngo bo la mi gnas phyir dang zhes pa da ltar gyi chos skyes pa thams cad kyang skad cig gnyis par mi gnas pa'i phyir 'dis ni gnas pa med par bstan te/ mu stegs rnams kyis skad cig gis 'jig pa ma yin te skyes nas ji srid gcig tu gnas te gzod 'jig go zhes smras pa lta bu ma yin no zhes bstan pa'o/ /

To explain further the dependent reality’s absence of intrinsic production, “because things do not exist of themselves” indicates that the dependent reality appears interdependently. Things do not come into being of themselves but arise in dependence on causes and conditions. Their arising has no intrinsic existence, and so they are said to be devoid of intrinsic existence. This refutes the Samkhyas’ assertion that there is a primal substance from which everything else is produced, or that results exist at the time of their cause and are produced of themselves, it being impossible for them to come into being if they were absent at the time of the cause. “They do not exist as their own nature” means that things that have ceased to exist do not arise again as their former nature, indicating that their disintegration is nothing more than things simply ceasing to exist—unlike what the Samkhyas say, that something that is destroyed does not become completely nonexistent but remains latent in the expanse of the primal substance. “And because they do not dwell in their own nature” shows that because all present phenomena that have arisen do not persist into the second instant, there is no continuing to exist. This is different from the tīrthikas’ assertion that things are not destroyed by momentariness: for them, once things have arisen, they remain the same as long as they last, until they are finally destroyed.

gzung 'dzin de med phyir zhes pa kun brtags gnyis su snang zhing de ltar gnyis su btags pa de la gzung 'dzin dang gtsang bde rtag bdag sogs phyin ci log tu brtags pa ni/ thag pa la sbrul du bzung ba ltar 'khrul pa'i blo'i zhen yul tsam las blo des bzung ba ltar cung zad kyang yod ma myong bas ngo bo nyid med pa zhes bya'o/ / de ltar gzhan dbang dang kun brtags la ngo bo nyid med par 'dod do/ /

“And because they do not exist as they are apprehended”[52] refers to the imputed reality, which appears as two things and is thus imputed as two things. These are incorrectly imputed as subject and object, as purity, happiness, permanence, a self, and so forth. Apart from being simply the conceived object of the deluded mind, like a rope mistaken for a snake, it has never, even slightly, existed in the way that it is apprehended by that mind and is therefore referred to as being devoid of essence. It is in this way that the dependent reality and the imputed reality are held to be devoid of intrinsic existence.
snga ma phyi ma'i rten yin pas/ / ngo bo nyid ni med pa yis/ / skye med 'gag med gzod nas zhi/ / rang bzhin mya ngan 'das pa 'grub/ /
Each proposition being the basis for subsequent ones, Absence of intrinsic existence Establishes absence of production, absence of cessation, Primordial peace, and natural nirvāṇa. (XII, 51)

ngo bo nyid med pa dang skye ba med pa sogs snga ma snga ma grub pa de phyi ma phyi ma 'grub pa'i rten yin pas/ 'di ltar ngo bo nyid med pa yis/ skye ba med pa 'grub ste gang ngo bo nyid med pa de skye ba yod pa mi rigs pas skye ba med par 'grub bo/ / skye ba med pa la 'gag pa med pa dang / gang skye 'gag med par de ni gsar du sus kyang ma byas par gzod nas zhi bar grub bo/ / gzod nas zhi ba la sdug bsngal kun 'byung yod mi srid pas rang bzhin gyis mya ngan las 'das par grub bo/ / de ltar na gzhan dbang ngo bo med pa'i tshul gsum dang / kun brtags ngo bo med tshul gcig gis bstan nas gzung 'dzin du snang ba'i chos thams cad ngo bo med pa de'i phyir chos thams cad skye med 'gag med gzod nas zhi ba rang bzhin gyis mya ngan las 'das par gsungs pa ni yongs grub bo/ / de'i phyir gzhan dbang skye 'gag tu snang yang rgyu rkyen tshogs pa'i rten 'brel las skye bar snang yang rang gi ngo bos skye ba med pa dang / kun brtags rang gi mtshan nyid kyis skye ba'am ngo bo nyid med pa dang / yongs grub don dam pa'i rang bzhin gdod nas gnas kyi skye 'gag gi ngo bo nyid med pa gsum la dgongs nas ngo bo nyid med pa dang / skye 'gag med pa sogs su gsungs pa shes par bya'o/ /

Each proposition, beginning with the absence of intrinsic existence, is the basis for establishing subsequent propositions, beginning with the absence of production. Thus, absence of intrinsic existence establishes absence of production: the fact that it is impossible for something devoid of intrinsic existence to come into being proves its absence of production. Absence of production proves absence of cessation. And anything that neither comes into existence nor ceases to exist must be peace from the beginning, uninvented by anyone. And the fact that it is impossible, in primordial peace, for there to be suffering or the cause of suffering, establishes natural nirvāṇa. Thus, having shown the three ways in which the dependent reality is devoid of intrinsic existence and the one way in which the imputed reality is devoid of intrinsic existence, the Buddha taught that all phenomena that appear as subject and object are devoid of intrinsic existence, and for this reason, all phenomena are devoid of production, are devoid of cessation, are peace from the very beginning, and are by their very nature nirvāṇa. He was referring here to the fully present reality. So, although the dependent reality appears as production and cessation, it appears to come into being interdependently through the gathering of causes and conditions, but it is by its very nature uncreated. The imputed reality is, by definition, uncreated or devoid of intrinsic existence. And the fully present reality is the ultimate nature, present since the beginning but devoid of intrinsic production and cessation. We should understand that it is with these three in mind that the Buddha spoke of the absence of intrinsic existence, absence of production and cessation, and so forth.
dgu pa mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa yongs su tshol ba ni/
ix. INVESTIGATING THE ACCEPTANCE THAT PHENOMENA ARE UNBORN
thog ma dang ni de nyid gzhan nyid dang / / rang gi mtshan nyid rang dang gzhan du 'gyur/ / kun nas nyon mongs pa dang khyad par la/ / skye ba med pa'i chos la bzod par bshad/ /

With regard to a beginning, a same thing, otherness, Its own definition, itself, transformation, Defilement, and extraordinary knowledge, Acceptance that phenomena are unborn has been explained. (XII, 52)
ces tshigs bcad gcig gis bstan te/

mdo sde rnams kyi nang nas mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa thob pa zhes gsungs na de'i rgyu mtshan ji lta bu yin zhe na/ skye ba med pa'i chos brgyad la blos bzod pa ni mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa zhes gsungs te/ gang zhe na

When, in the sūtras, the Buddha spoke of “acquiring the acceptance that phenomena are unborn,” what was he talking about? What he called “the acceptance that phenomena are unborn” is the mental tolerance to accept the eight ways in which phenomena are without production.[53] These will now be explained.

thog ma skye ba med pa la bzod pa ni/ 'khor ba'i thog ma 'di tsam na skyes zhes 'khor ba la thog ma yod par 'dzin pa mi rigs te/ dbang phyug dang tshangs pa sogs byed po gang gis kyang 'khor ba gsar du bskyed pa ma yin par/ thog ma med pa'i dus nas rten 'brel yan lag bcu gnyis gcig nas gcig tu brgyud de skyes pa'i phyir de'i thog ma mi rnyed pas 'khor ba la thog ma'i skye ba med do zhes bzod na don de la bzod pa thob pa dang ni/

The first category is acceptance that phenomena are unborn from the beginning. It is inappropriate to consider that there is a beginning to saṃsāra, that saṃsāra started at a specific moment. Saṃsāra was not invented by anyone, even by Īśvara, Brahmā, or any other so-called creator. From time without beginning it has been produced through the succession, one after another, of the twelve links of dependent arising, and one will therefore never find a beginning to saṃsāra. So when one accepts that saṃsāra has never had a beginning, a time when it came into being, one acquires the acceptance of that point.

'khor ba 'di na gang sngar skyes zin pa de nyid slar mi skye ste skyes zin pa 'gags pa gyur pa ni med pa yin pas med pa slar skye bar mi rigs pas/ skyes zin de nyid slar mi skye ba la bzod pa'i rnam grangs gnyis pa dang /

Here in saṃsāra, once something has already come into being, that same thing does not come into being again. Having come into being, it ceases, and since it is then no more, being nonexistent, it cannot come into existence again. So to accept that once arisen, the same thing does not arise again is the second category.

gzhan nyid ces pa/ 'khor ba 'di na sngar yongs su grags pa'i phung khams skye mched kyi chos de 'dra ba yang yang skye bar 'gyur gyi/ sngon med pa'i chos gsar du phung khams skye mched du ma gtogs pa zhig dang sngon med pa'i sems can gsar du skye ba med pa ni rnam grangs gsum pa dang/

Next is “otherness.” In this saṃsāra, similar aggregates, sense spheres, and senses-and-fields that were commonly known before will come into being again and again. But there are no new, unprecedented phenomena not included in the aggregates, sense spheres, and senses-and-fields, and no new, unprecedented kinds of sentient beings that can come into being. This is the third category.[54]
kun brtags ni rang gi mtshan nyid kyis skye ba med pa ste/ ri bong gi rwa skye ba med pa bzhin du de yang skye ba med par bzod pa ni rnam grangs bzhi pa'o/ /
The imputed reality, by definition, is unborn. Like the horn of a rabbit that has never come into existence, it too is unborn. Accepting this is the fourth category.

gzhan dbang gis rang nyid mi skye ste rgyu dang rkyen gzhan gyi dbang gis skye ba yin pa'i phyir de mi skye ba la bzod pa rnam grangs lnga pa dang / yongs grub ni gzhan du 'gyur ba'i skye ba med de ni nam mkha' bzhin du nam yang gzhan du 'gyur mi srid par bzod pa ni rnam grangs drug pa'o/ /

The dependent reality does not come into being of itself, for it arises in dependence on causes and conditions. Acceptance that it is unborn is the fifth category. The fully present reality has not been produced through transformation. Like space, it is impossible to turn it into something else. Acceptance of this is the sixth category.

'phags pa dgra bcom pa rnams kyis mthong sgom gyis spang bya'i nyon mongs pa mtha' dag spangs nas zad pa'i ye shes thob pa la/ slar kun nas nyon mongs pa nam yang mi skye bar shes nas don de la bzod pa rnam grangs bdun pa dang / zad mi skye shes pa khyad par ba'am bye brag pa sangs rgyas rnams kyi chos sku la sgrib gnyis slar skye ba med pa'am/ yang na sangs rgyas thams cad kyi chos kyi sku ni rang bzhin gcig yin gyi tha dad du med pa la/ sngon gyi sangs rgyas kha cig gi chos sku ci 'dra bar skyes/ de las gzhan pa phyis kyi sangs rgyas kha cig gi chos sku ci 'dra bar skye zhes chos kyi sku'i skye ba tha dad par mi mthun par skye ba med pa'i phyir/ de 'dra'i mi skye ba'i tshul la bzod pa ni rnam grangs brgyad pa ste/

Noble arhats,[55] having eliminated all the defilements that have to be eliminated through the paths of seeing and meditation, acquire the gnosis of exhaustion, and they know that the process of defilement will never occur again. Acceptance of this point is the seventh category. The extraordinary or specific knowledge that they are exhausted and will not arise is the truth body of the buddhas, in which the two obscurations do not arise again. Or, put another way, the truth body of all the buddhas is a single nature; there are not different truth bodies. There is no arising of the body of truth, inconsistently and distinctly, with some, former buddhas arising in one kind of truth body and other, future buddhas arising in another kind of truth body. Acceptance of this manner in which the body of truth is unborn constitutes the eighth category.

mi skye ba'i rnam grangs brgyad bshad pa de'i don la bzod pa ni skye ba med pa'i chos la bzod par bshad pa'i rnam grangs yin no/ / spyir skye ba med pa'i chos la bzod tshul gyis bzod pa thog pa'i rnam grangs chung 'bring chen po gsum bya ste/ sbyor lam bzod pa thob pa'i tshe skye med kyi don la don spyi'i tshul gyis bzod pa'i bzod pa chung ngu dang / mthong lam sa dang por skye med mngon sum rtogs pa'i bzod pa 'bring gi gnas skabs dang / sa brgyad par rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes yongs su smin pas chos thams cad gdod nas skye ba med pa'i don las mnyam rjes kun du mi g.yo bas mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa chen po thob pa'o/ /

This is how acceptance of the nonarising of phenomena is explained—as acceptance of the eight kinds of nonarising described here. There are three general categories in acquiring acceptance, according to the way in which one accepts the nonarising of phenomena—lesser, middling, and great. When one attains the stage of acceptance on the path of joining, one’s acceptance is through an indirect understanding of the meaning of nonarising. This is lesser acceptance. On the path of seeing, the first bodhisattva level, it is through direct realization that one accepts nonarising, which is the middling stage. On the eighth level, nonconceptual gnosis is fully matured so that in both meditation and postmeditation one never moves from the knowledge that all phenomena are primordially unborn, and one thus acquires the great acceptance of the nonarising of phenomena.

bzod pa thob pa'i phyir mi ldog pa'i byang sems rnams la sangs rgyas su lung ston cing / khyad par sa brgyad pa la lung bstan pa'i sa zhes kyang gsungs/ 'on kyang dgos pa'i dbang gis rigs la gnas pa dang / sems bskyed ma thag pa la yang sangs rgyas su lung ston pa yang yod do/ / mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa zhes pa chos kyi dbyings las gzhan du gyur pa'i chos med pas chos thams cad gdod nas skye ba med pa'i don la bzod pa la gtso bor bshad do/ /

It has been taught that nonreturning bodhisattvas[56] who have acquired acceptance are referred to as “predicted as buddhas,” and the eighth level in particular is called the “level of prediction.” However, when necessary,[57] those who possess the Mahāyāna potential and those who have just aroused the bodhicitta are also predicted as buddhas. What we call acceptance of the nonarising of phenomena is mainly explained as the acceptance that there are no phenomena other than the expanse of reality and that all phenomena are therefore unborn from the very beginning.
bcu pa theg pa gcig tu bstan pa'i dgongs pa yongs su tshol ba ni/
x. INVESTIGATING THE INTENTION IN TEACHING A SINGLE VEHICLE
This topic is covered by seven verses.
chos dang bdag med grol ba rnams/ / mtshungs phyir rigs ni tha dad phyir/ / bsam gnyis thob phyir sprul pa'i phyir/ / mthar thug phyir ni theg gcig nyid/ /

Because of similarity with regard to the path, no-self, And liberation, because of different potentials, Because of achieving both aspirations, because of manifestations, And because it is the ultimate, there is a single vehicle. (XII, 53)
zhes tshigs bcad bdun gyis bstan te/

mdo kha cig las theg pa gsum dang / kha cig las theg pa gcig yin par gsungs pa de dag gi dgongs pa gang zhe na/ mdo sde rnams la drang don dang nges don gnyis yod pas/ sems tsam pa'i lugs la theg gsum du bshad pa nges don dang / theg gcig bshad pa drang don dgongs pa can yin par 'dod pas de'i dbang du byas na/ mthar thug theg pa gcig las med par gsungs pa de ci la dgongs nas de skad bstan ce na/ don bdun la dgongs pa ste/

Why is it that some sūtras speak of three vehicles and others of one vehicle? In the sūtras, there are the ultimate teachings and the expedient teachings. The Cittamātra system maintains that the explanations in terms of three vehicles are ultimate teachings, while those that speak of a single vehicle are expedient teachings given with a particular intention. What, then, was the Buddha’s intention in saying that ultimately there is no more than one vehicle? In doing so, he had the following seven points in mind:

lam theg pa gsum dang 'bras bu byang chub gsum med pa ma yin yang / theg pa gsum la 'jug pa po dang / lam dang 'bras bu thams cad kyi chos nyid chos kyi dbyings gcig las med par chos mtshungs pa la dgongs pa dang / theg pa gsum la 'jug pa po'i gang zag thams cad kyang gang zag gi bdag med par mtshungs pa la dgongs pa dang / theg pa gsum ka'i 'bras bu las nyon sdug bsngal las rnam par grol ba rnams mtshungs pa la dgongs pa'i phyir dang / ma nges pa'i rigs can theg pa tha dad pa nyan rang lam la zhugs pa dag theg pa chen po la 'jug pa yod pa la dgongs pa'i phyir dang / sangs rgyas kyis bdag dang sems can thams cad mnyam par dgongs pa'i bsam pa dang / nyan rang rigs nges sngon byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa spyad pa btang bar 'dod pa la de bzhin gshegs pa'i dbugs dbyung bas bdag kyang sangs rgyas su 'gyur ro snyam bsam pa re zhig rnyed pa ste/

(1) He did not mean that there are not three paths or vehicles and three resultant enlightenments. In that the true nature of those who follow the three vehicles, of their respective paths, and of the results is none other than a single expanse of reality, he meant that the spiritual journey is equivalent. (2) He meant that all those who follow the three vehicles are the same in that they realize the same individual no-self. (3) He had in mind that the result of the three vehicles is equivalent in that it is perfect liberation from karma, defilements, and suffering. (4) He meant that there are individuals of unfixed potential in different vehicles following the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ paths who then enter the Great Vehicle. (5) He meant that there is no more than a single vehicle because both aspirations are achieved—the buddhas’ aspiration to realize the sameness of themselves and all sentient beings, and the aspiration that listeners and solitary realizers of fixed potential who have practiced the bodhisattvas’ activities in the past regain when they want to give them up and are encouraged by the Tathāgata, so that they think, “I too will become a buddha.”[58]

de ltar bsam pa gnyis thob pa'i phyir de la dgongs pa dang / sangs rgyas kyis sems can thabs des 'dul ba la nyan thos kyi theg pas mya ngan las 'das par bstan pa la dgongs nas nga ni lan brgya phrag du mar nyan thos kyi theg pas yongs su mya ngan las 'das so zhes gsungs pa lta bu sangs rgyas kyi sprul pa dang nyan thos rang rgyud pa gnyis nyan thos kyi theg pas mya ngan las 'das par snang ba theg pa gcig pa tsam la dgongs pa'i phyir dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams nyan thos kyi tshul du sprul pa rnams kyang nyan thos kyi mya ngan 'das pa mngon du mi byed kyi sangs rgyas su 'byung ba yang de bzhin no/ /

(6) Intending to show beings to be trained by such means how to attain nirvāṇa by the Listeners’ Vehicle, the Buddha said things like, “I have gone completely beyond suffering many hundreds of times through the Listeners’ Vehicle.” He was referring to buddha manifestations as listeners, and in that such manifestations and actual listeners both appear to attain nirvāṇa by the Listeners’ Vehicle, he spoke of just one vehicle. This is also true for bodhisattvas who manifest as listeners: they do not actually realize the listeners’ nirvāṇa but attain buddhahood.

mthar thug pa'i theg pa ni theg pa chen po nyid gcig pu yin gyi gzhan ma yin pa la dgongs nas theg pa gcig nyid yin gyi gsum ma yin no zhes gsungs so/ / 'di la 'grel chen du rgyas bshad mdzad kyang / rgyas che na go je dka' lta bur 'gyur dogs pas don gyi gnad mdor bsdus go bder brjod pa'o/ /

(7) He had in mind that the ultimate vehicle is the Great Vehicle alone, and there is no other. So it was with these points in mind that the Buddha spoke of a single vehicle and not of three. The Great Commentary explains these in considerable detail, but for fear of their being too complicated and difficult to grasp, I have summarized the key points to make them easier to understand.
kha cig dag ni drang phyir dang / / gzhan dag yang dag gzung ba'i phyir/ / rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyis ni/ / ma nges rnams la theg gcig bshad/ /
In order to draw some disciples on to it And to keep others properly on it, The perfect buddhas Teach uncertain disciples a single vehicle. (XII, 54)

theg pa gcig tu bstan pa'i dgos pa ni/ nyan thos kyi rigs ma nges pa dang / rang sangs rgyas kyi rigs ma nges pa kha cig dag ni theg pa chen po la drang ba'i phyir dang / byang chub sems dpa'i rigs ma nges pa gzhan dag theg chen la zhugs kyang 'khor ba 'dir phan btags kyang gnod pa byed pa/ gnod pa ma byas kyang gnod pa byed pa/ dgos pa med pa yang sems can la gnod par byed pa sogs sems can rnams kyi nyes pa mthong nas 'khor ba la skyo ste/ nyan thos kyi myang 'das la 'jug par 'dod pa dag theg chen las phyir mi ldog par yang dag par gzung ba'i phyir/ rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyis ni ma nges pa'i rigs can rnams la theg pa gcig yin par bshad do/ / de ltar bshad pas nyan thos kyi lam la zhugs kyang rang 'bras thob pa'i rjes su theg chen la cis kyang 'jug dgos pas dang po nas theg chen la zhugs pa btang bar mi bya'o snyam du byang chub sems dpa'i lam las mi ldog par byed/ nyan thos kyi rigs ma nges pa ni sngon nyan thos kyi spyod pa spyad pa'i dbang gis nyan thos kyi rigs zhes bya ste/ gzhan gnyis kyang de dang 'dra'o/ /

What is the reason for teaching that there is a single vehicle? It is in order to draw certain listeners of unfixed potential and solitary realizers of unfixed potential into the Great Vehicle. Then there are others, bodhisattvas of unfixed potential, who have entered the Great Vehicle. But when they see the evil ways of sentient beings—they see them doing harm even when they are helped, harming others even when they have not been harmed, harming beings for no reason, and so on—they despair of saṃsāra and want to enter the listeners’ nirvāṇa. So it is also in order to keep these bodhisattvas on the right path and prevent them from turning away from the Great Vehicle. For these reasons, the perfect buddhas explain to disciples of unfixed potential that there is a single vehicle. As a result of such explanations, the disciples realize that even if they follow the listeners’ path, once they have attained its result they will in any case have to enter the Great Vehicle, so it is better for them to follow the Great Vehicle from the start and not give it up. They are thus prevented from turning back from the bodhisattva path. Listeners of unfixed potential are referred to as being of “listener potential” on account of their having practiced the listeners’ activities in the past. The same applies, mutatis mutandis, to those with the other two kinds of potential.
nyan thos ma nges rnam gnyis te/ / theg don mthong dang ma mthong ba'o/ / don mthong 'dod chags bral ba dang / / 'dod chags bral min 'di dman pa'o/ /

Listeners of unfixed potential are of two kinds: Those who have seen the truth of their vehicle and those who have not. Those who have seen the truth, Whether or not rid of attachment, are inferior. (XII, 55)

nyan thos kyi rigs ma nges pa theg chen la zhugs nas 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur ba de las rnam pa gnyis yod pa yin te/ rang gi theg pa'i don bden pa mthong ba rgyun zhugs phyir 'ong phyir mi 'ong gsum dang / bden pa ma mthong ba so skye mos spyod pa'i gang zag gang yin pa'o/ / bden don mthong ba la yang 'dod pa'i 'dod chags dang bral ba'i phyir mi 'ong dang / /'dod khams la 'dod chags bral ba min par rgyun zhugs dang lan gcig phyir 'ong ba rnams so/ / de ltar bden mthong 'dod chags bral ma bral 'di gnyis ni theg chen la zhugs kyang dbang po rtul po dang dus ring po zhig gis 'bras bu sangs rgyas thob pas/ so skye theg chen la zhugs pa las dman pa'o/ /

Listeners of unfixed potential, having entered the Great Vehicle, will attain enlightenment, and for them there are two categories: (1) stream enterers, once-returners, and nonreturners who have seen the truth that is the point of their own vehicle[59] and (2) ordinary beings at the level of earnest aspiration who have not seen the truth. Those who have seen the truth are again divided into nonreturners who are rid of the attachment of the world of desire; and stream enterers and once-returners who are not. These two latter categories (of those who have seen the truth and are free or not free of attachment) may have entered the Great Vehicle, but they have dull faculties and take a long time to attain the result of buddhahood, so they are inferior compared to those who have entered the Great Vehicle as ordinary beings.
de gnyis 'phags pa'i lam thob pa/ / srid pa dag tu sgyur ba'i phyir/ / bsam gyis mi khyab sgyur ba yi/ / skye ba dang ni yang dag ldan/ /
Both have attained the noble path, And by transforming that attainment, They possess an inconceivable Birth of transformation in existence. (XII, 56)

nyan thos 'phags pa srid pa la rgyab kyis phyogs nas srid pa mi skye bar byed pa 'phags pa'i lam thob pa de theg chen la zhugs na 'khor ba skyes nas rdzogs smin sbyangs pa bskal pa grangs med gsum gyi bar du bsgrub dgos na srid pa zad byed kyi lam thob pa de dag 'khor bar ji ltar skye zhe na / bden pa mthong ba chags bral dang chags bral min pa de gnyis kyis khams gsum gyi srid pa'i gnyen po 'phags pa'i lam thob pa zag med kyi las de nyid kyis nyan thos kyi 'bras bu mngon du mi byed pas slar srid pa dag tu skye ba'i rgyur smon lam gyis sgyur ba'i phyir/ rtog ges bsam gyis mi khyab par sgyur ba yi skye ba dang ni yang dag par ldan te/ tshul des 'khor bar gcig nas gcig tu brgyud de skyes nas rdzogs smin sbyang gsum la 'jug 'phags pa'i lam ni 'khor ba la rgyab kyis phyogs pa srid pa zad byed kyi gnyen po yin pas de 'khor bar skye ba'i rgyu ji ltar rung snyam na

Noble listeners have turned their backs on existence and attained the noble path by which they will no longer take birth in existence. If they enter the Great Vehicle, they have to be reborn in saṃsāra and accomplish completion, maturation, and purification for three measureless kalpas. So how, having achieved the path that brings existence to an end, can they be reborn in saṃsāra? For both kinds of noble beings who have seen the truth, those that are free from attachment and those that are not, that untainted act—their attainment of the noble path, which is the antidote to existence in the three worlds—does not lead to their realizing the listener result but instead is transformed by their prayers of aspiration into the cause for their taking birth again in existence. So they have a transformation birth, inconceivable to the intellectual mind, and it is in this way that they take birth in saṃsāra in one life after another and undertake the practices of completion, maturation, and purification. How, one might ask, can the noble path act as the cause for taking birth in saṃsāra when it involves turning one’s back on saṃsāra and is the very antidote that brings existence to an end?

bden te 'phags lam 'ba' zhig gis 'khor bar skye ba min yang / phyir mi 'ong ba rnams la khams gong ma'i nyon mongs ldan pa dang / rgyun zhugs dang phyir 'ong la 'dod pa'i nyon mongs sgom spang ma zad pa dang / khams gong ma gnyis kyi nyon mongs yod pa de 'phags pa'i lam 'khor bar skye bar bsngos pa'i mthus bul nas nyon mongs pa'i rgyu byas te 'khor bar skye bar 'gyur te zhes 'grel par gsungs/ 'dir 'phags lam thob pa zag med kyi las ni zag bcas su nam yang bsgyur ba ma yin te zag med zag bcas dang / dge ba sdig par 'gyur mi srid mod/ sngar zag med kyi lam 'dis 'khor ba spangs nas rang nyid zhi ba myang 'das su gzhol ba'i bsam pa de btang nas/ da 'khor bar skye bar byed pa'i smon lam yongs su bzung ba'i mthus nyan thos kyi 'bras bu mngon du mi byed pa'i bsam gyis mi khyab par sgyur ba'i skye ba dang ldan pa ni de'i sems kyi smon pa'i dbang gis skye ba len la de yang zag med kyi las kyi dbang gis phal pa'i skye ba lta bu ma yin pas bsam gyis mi khyab par bsgyur ba'i skye ba thob pa yin par go bar bya'o/ /

In the commentary it is stated that although it is true that with the noble path alone one is not born in saṃsāra, nonreturners (who have the defilements of the two higher worlds) and stream enterers and once-returners (who have not exhausted the defilements of the world of desire to be eliminated by the path of meditation and have the defilements of the two higher worlds) dedicate the noble path to being born in saṃsāra and, because of this, they create the cause with defilements and will be born in saṃsāra. But in our view, the untainted action of attaining the noble path can never change into a tainted action: it is impossible for an untainted action to become tainted and for a positive action to become a negative one. Instead, having already abandoned saṃsāra by means of this untainted path, they give up the intention of striving for the peace of nirvāṇa for themselves and now, as a result of maintaining the aspirations that create birth in saṃsāra, possess an inconceivable transformation birth instead of achieving the listener result. You should understand that it is because of their aspirations that they take birth, and on account of their untainted action, the birth they obtain is not like birth as an ordinary person but an inconceivable transformation birth.

sangs rgyas kyis nyan thos rigs ma nges par 'dod pa'i 'dod chags dang ma bral ba rnams la lhag mthong gi lam 'khor ba sdug bsngal dang myang 'das zhi ba bsgom pa myang 'das thob pa dang rjes su mthun pa btang snyoms su byed du bcug nas 'khor ba la mngon du lta ba'i snying rje chen po bsgom pa'i lam la sbyor bar mdzad pa'i de dag snying rjes 'khor bar skye ba 'dzin pa ni srid par yongs su bsngos pa zhes bya la/ de dag bden don mthong ba'i 'phags pa yin pas phal pa ltar las nyon gyi dbang gis rang dbang med par 'khor ba yang yang skye ba ma yin par bsam gyis mi khyab par sgyur ba'i skye bar 'dzin zhes so/ /

The Buddha allows listeners of unfixed potential who are not free of the attachment of the world of desire to continue using the path of profound insight to meditate that saṃsāra is suffering and nirvāṇa is peace as if to attain nirvāṇa. He then joins them to the path of meditation on the great compassion, fixing their gaze on saṃsāra, and they take birth in saṃsāra through compassion, at which point they are referred to as “fully dedicated to existence.” These are noble beings who have seen the truth, so they are not repeatedly reborn in saṃsāra like ordinary beings, who are helplessly driven by their karmic actions and defilements, but take an inconceivable transformation birth.
gcig ni smon lam dbang gis na/ / skye ba rab tu sgrub par byed/ / cig shos phyir mi 'ong ba dang / / ldan phyir sprul pas rab tu sgrub/ /
One, by the power of prayers of aspiration, Attains accomplishment by being born; The other, because of being a nonreturner, Attains accomplishment through manifestation. (XII, 57)

ji ltar skye na 'dod pa'i 'dod chags ma bral ba dang / bral ba gnyis las/ gcig 'dod chags dang ma bral ba ni/ rgyun zhugs dang phyir 'ong gnyis yin la/ de dag sems can sdug bsngal la snying rje'i dbang gis gang dang gang du sems can gyi don bya ba 'dod pa de dag tu skye bar gyur cig ces smon lam gyi dbang gis ni/ de dang der skye ba mtshan nyid pa rab tu sgrub par byed de skyes nas sems can la phan pa dang bde ba byas nas tshogs gnyis bsags shing mthar 'tshang rgya bar byed do/ / cig shos 'dod pa'i 'dod chags dang bral ba 'dod khams su phyir mi 'ong ba dang ldan pa'i phyir rang nyid 'dod khams su mi skye yang ting nge 'dzin gyi sprul pas 'khor bar skye ba bstan nas tshogs bsags sgrub par byed cing mthar 'tshang rgya'o/ /

How do these noble beings take birth? Of those who are not free of the attachment of the world of desire and those who are free, the ones who are not free of attachment are stream enterers and once-returners. Out of their compassion for suffering beings, they pray, “Wherever I wish to benefit beings, may I be reborn there,” and by the power of that prayer they actually take birth in those places.[60] Having taken birth, they bring benefit and happiness to sentient beings, and by doing so accumulate merit and wisdom and ultimately attain buddhahood. The others, who are free of the attachment of the desire world, will not return to the world of desire, and because of this, although they do not themselves take birth in the world of desire, they display birth in saṃsāra through the manifestations of their concentration. They thus accumulate merit and wisdom and finally attain buddhahood.
de gnyis yang dang yang du ni/ / rang sems kun tu 'byung ldan pas/ / mya ngan 'das la mngon dga'i phyir/ / rtogs pa bul ba yin par 'dod/ /
Since these two, from repetition, Continue to think of themselves, They delight in nirvāṇa, So realization is slow. (XII, 58)

nyan thos pa'i lam gyis bden mthong 'dod pa'i 'dod chags dang bral ba dang ma bral ba de gnyis yang dang yang du ni sngar goms pa'i shugs kyis rang don la dga' ba'i sems kun du 'byung ba dang ldan pas/ mya ngan 'das pa la mngon par dga' ba'i phyir theg chen gyi 'bras bu la rtogs pa bul ba yin pa 'dod do/ /

For those who have seen the truth through the listeners’ path (both those who are free of the attachment of the desire world and those who are not), the force of repetition, that is, of their previous former habituation, is such that they constantly prefer their own welfare, and they therefore delight in nirvāṇa. For this reason, it is said, they are slow to realize the result of the Great Vehicle.
don byas ma yin de sangs rgyas/ / med par skyes nas sprul don gnyer/ / bsam gtan don brtson der brten nas/ / byang chub dam pa 'thob par 'gyur/ /
Those who have not attained the goal Take birth when there is no Buddha and, Yearning to manifest, strive for concentration, By which means they will attain supreme enlightenment. (XII, 59)

bden pa mthong ba'i don ma byas pa'i nyan thos kyi theg pa ba/ rigs ma nges pa so skye'am mos spyod kyi sa la gnas pa sangs rgyas kyi nyan thos su gyur pa de ni theg chen la zhugs pa dag 'dod khams mi'i ris las tshe 'phos nas lha tshe ring po'i nang du skye'o/ / de ltar lha tshe ring po'i nang du 'dug 'dug pa las/ nam zhig 'jig rten 'dir ston pa sangs rgyas mi bzhugs pa de'i bstan pa nub ste med par gyur pa dang / slar 'dod pa'i khams su skye bar byed do/ / 'dod khams su skye nas yul la sems mngon par mi dga' zhing sngon sangs rgyas kyi gsung la goms pa'i stobs kyis slob dpon med par 'phags pa'i lam mngon du byed de rang rgyal lta bu'o/ /

The Buddha’s disciples in the Listeners’ Vehicle who have not attained the goal of seeing the truth, who are of unfixed potential (ordinary beings or individuals on the level of earnest aspiration), and who have entered the Great Vehicle leave the human realm in the world of desire when they die and are reborn among the long-lived gods. There they remain for long periods of time. Then, when our teacher, the Buddha, is no longer in this world and his doctrine has disappeared, they will again take birth in the world of desire. Born in the world of desire, they will take no pleasure in the sense objects, and on the strength of their former habituation to the Buddha’s teachings, they will realize the noble path without having a spiritual master, like the solitary realizers.

de nas sprul pa byed par 'dod pa don du gnyer ba'i bsam pas gzugs khams kyi bsam gtan thob pa'i don la brtson par byed cing des bsam gtan thob pa de la brten nas sprul pa sprul te khams gsum du sems can gyi don byed cing bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs rdzogs par byas te mthar byang chub dam pa thob par 'gyur ro/ / de dag dpal phreng gi mdo las/ dang por me lci ba la mched do/ / de nas yul 'khor la mched do zhes gsungs pa'i dpes dang po nyan thos dang / de nas rang sangs rgyas dang / mthar rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas su 'gyur ba'i gnas gsum la dgongs nas de ltar gsungs so/ / de ltar mthar thug theg gsum 'dod pa'i lugs 'di ltar na rigs ma nges pa rnams theg chen la zhugs nas 'tshang rgya rung gi nyan rang du rigs nges pa ni nam yang 'tshang mi rgya zhing / rigs chad pa dag 'tshang rgya ba phar zhog nyan rang gi byang chub kyang thob pa'i skal ba gtan med la nyan rang dgra bcom rnams lhag med myang 'das kyi tshe phung po lnga gtan du rgyun 'chad pas theg chen la 'jug mi srid par bzhed do/ /

Subsequently, with a yearning to create manifestations, they will put their efforts into achieving the dhyānas of the world of form. Relying on such concentration, they will emanate manifestations and, benefiting sentient beings in the three worlds, they will complete the accumulations of merit and wisdom and finally attain supreme enlightenment. As we read in the Sūtra of the Lion’s Roar of Śrīmālādevī: First the fire sets alight the fuel, Then it spreads throughout the land. When he spoke this metaphor, the Buddha had in mind three states: first they become listeners, then solitary realizers, and finally perfect buddhas. Thus, it is possible, according to this tradition that holds that there are three final goals and vehicles, for beings of unfixed potential to enter the Great Vehicle and thence attain buddhahood. On the other hand, those who have the fixed potential to become listeners and solitary realizers will never attain buddhahood, while beings without potential will never have the chance to attain the enlightenment of the listeners and solitary realizers, let alone buddhahood. As for listener and solitary-realizer arhats, when they are in the state of nirvāṇa without residue their five aggregates are discontinued forever, so it is impossible for them to enter the Great Vehicle.

dbu ma pa dag gis sems can thams cad la bde bar gshegs pa'i snying po yod pas 'tshang rgya rung gi rigs can ma yin pa med de sems kyi rang bzhin 'od gsal ba yin pa dang / dri ma glo bur ba 'bral rung yin pas gnas skabs su theg pa gnyis kyi 'bras bu'i byang chub thob pa'i nyan rang lhag med myang 'das su zhugs pa dag kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i 'od zer gyis bskul bas 'gog pa'i dbyings las ldang ste bsam gyis mi khyab par bsgyur ba'i skye ba bzung nas rdzogs smin sbyangs pa mthar phyin par byas te 'tshang rgya bar bzhed pa ltar mthar thug gi don la de ltar 'grub pa yin zhing rgyud bla ma las kyang de ltar gsungs so/ / lugs de gnyis gang zag gi khams dbang bsam pa dang mthun par mdo rnams las kyang tshul de gnyis ka gsungs shing / gnas skabs kyi dbang du byas na theg pa gsum gyi lam dang 'bras bu so sor yod pa nam yang 'gog mi nus la/ rigs chad pa yang de dang 'dra bas skabs 'dir de ltar bshad par bya'o/ /

The Mādhyamikas maintain that all sentient beings have the essence of the sugatas[61] and can therefore attain buddhahood; there are no beings who do not have that potential. Since the nature of the mind is radiant light and it is possible to remove the adventitious contaminants, even listeners and solitary realizers who have temporarily reached the respective levels of enlightenment of their two vehicles and have entered nirvāṇa without residue will attain buddhahood. Aroused by the tathāgatas’ rays of light, they will emerge from the expanse of cessation and, having taken an inconceivable transformation birth, they will reach the culmination of completion, maturation, and purification. In the end, this is what really happens, as is also taught in the Sublime Continuum. As these two approaches accord with different individuals’ natures, faculties, and aspirations, they are both taught in the sūtras, and it is impossible to deny the existence, in terms of temporary situations, of the paths and results of the three vehicles, or equally of beings without potential. So in this context, this is how things are to be explained.
bcu gcig pa rig pa'i gnas lnga yongs su tshol ba ni/
xi. INVESTIGATING THE FIVE SCIENCES

rig pa'i gnas lnga dag la brtson par ma byas na/ / 'phags mchog gis kyang thams cad mkhyen nyid mi 'gyur te/ / de lta bas na gzhan dag tshar bcad rjes gzung dang / / bdag nyid kun shes bya phyir de la de brtson byed/ /

Without being diligent in the five sciences, Even the highest of noble beings will not attain omniscience. Therefore, in order to subjugate others, to care for them, And to know all things themselves, they are diligent in these. (XII, 60)
ces tshigs bcad gcig gis bstan to/ /

theg pa chen po'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni shes bya ji lta ba dang ji snyed pa kun la sgro 'dogs bcad nas mkhas par byas te thams cad mkhyen pa thob par byed pa yin pas shes bya thams cad legs par sbyang dgos shing / nyan thos zhi bde 'dod pa dag srid rtsa gcod byed kyi lam tshigs su bcad pa gcig gi don rtogs pas kyang rang 'bras thob nus pas shes bya rgya chen po la 'jug pa ma yin no/ / 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i shes bya mtha' dag gi don bsdus na rig pa'i gnas lnga po 'di tsam du 'du ste/

It is by removing misconceptions and becoming learned with regard to all knowable phenomena (both their nature and their multiplicity) that bodhisattvas, followers of the Great Vehicle, attain omniscience, so they need to train well in all the sciences. Listeners desirous of peace and happiness are able to attain the listeners’ enlightenment even by realizing the meaning of a single verse about the path for severing the root of existence, so they do not involve themselves in such extensive knowledge. All knowledge, mundane and supramundane, can be summarized in just five sciences, which comprise the following:

thog mar rig byed dang grub pa'i mtha' la sogs pa thams cad kyang rjod byed kyi tshig la brten nas don shes dgos pas/ ming tshig yi ge'i rang bzhin gyi ngag gang zhig ming dang tshig gi phrad sogs sbyar tshul phyin ci ma log pa'i rnam bzhag ston pa brda sprod pa'am sgra rig pa'i bstan bcos dang /

(1) The treatises on the science of grammar. To begin with, all the Vedas, tenet systems, and so on require a knowledge of the subjects that is based on the words used to describe them, so these treatises present the correct way in which speech, which is made up of names, phrases, and letters, is constructed using names, grammatical connectors, and so on.
bstan bya'i don yang dag pa dang phyin ci log ma nor bar 'byed par byed pa gtan tshigs kyi rig pa'am mngon sum dang rjes su dpag pa'i tshad ma'i tshul ma nor bar ston pa'i bstan bcos dang /

(2) The treatises on the science of logic that distinguish without error the true and mistaken meanings of what is being taught, or treatises that unmistakenly indicate the methods of valid cognition by direct perception and inference.

'jig rten pa'i bzo'i gnas lugs la brten pa lus kyi sgyu rtsal dang yi ge 'bri ba sogs lag bzo'i rigs rnams dang / ngag la brten pa dbyangs bdun dang chos dang srid kyi gtam byed pa/ yid kyi sgo nas 'jig rten pa'i lugs dang lugs min shes pa dang*/ brtags pa rnam pa brgyad la sogs pa lta bus mtshon nas 'jig rten pa'i bzo yi gnas rnams sna tshogs pa'i bstan bcos dang /

(3) The treatises on the various arts of ordinary beings. These follow mundane traditions of arts and crafts—physical arts and sports, and manual crafts such as calligraphy; vocal proficiency in the seven musical tones and in religious and secular speaking; and the theoretical knowledge of proper and improper worldly manners, of the eight kinds of examination,[62] and so on, to mention a few.

nad kyi rgyu dang / nad kyi ngo bo dang / nad zhi bar byed pa'i gnyen po dang / nad phyis mi 'byung bar byed pa'i yan lag bzhi la mkhas pa'i sgo nas skye dgu thams cad kyi lus la rlung mkhris bad kan gyi khams rang bzhin gyis gnas pa zas spyod sogs rkyen la brten te 'phel zad 'khrugs pa'i nyes pa rnam pa sna tshogs snyoms par byed pa lus gso ba zhes spyir bstan pa dang / bye brag tu rten byis pa dang bud med la khyad par gyi nad du gyur pa rnams gso ba dang / dug mtshon gdon sogs phyi rol gyi rkyen glo bur ba'i dbang gis na ba rnams bcos par byed pa dang/ khu ba cung 'phel zhing 'dod pa'i dga' ba nyams su myang bar byed pa ro tsa ba gso ba dang / lus nad med pa'i bde ba la reg pa'i sgo nas bcud len sogs thabs kyi cho gas rgyas pa gso zhing tshe yun ring por 'tsho bar byed pa ste gso ba'i rig pa'am tshe 'tsho ba'i rig pa yan lag brgyad pa dag gi bstan bcos dang /

(4) The treatises on the eight branches of the science of medicine or the maintenance of good health. These include general presentations on “restoring health,” that is, the correction of imbalances (due to diet and the like) of the wind, bile, and phlegm elements naturally present in all beings’ bodies through mastery in four branches—the causes of disease, the nature of disease, the remedies for treating illness, and the methods for preventing illness from occurring in the future. They also include specialized medicine—the treatment of diseases particular to women and children; the remedial treatment of unexpected illnesses caused by external causes such as poisoning, weapon injury, and possession by negative forces; sexual treatments that increase semen and maintain sexual health; and antiaging treatments and the promotion of long life by skillful techniques such as “taking the essence” on the basis of good health.
ji ltar ji snyed kyi shes bya'i rang bzhin phyin ci ma log par shes shing gtan bde thar pa dang thams cad mkhyen pa'i lam ston pa nang rig pa'am yang dag pa dam pa'i chos kyi bstan bcos te

(5) The treatises on the “inner science” or the perfect, sacred Dharma that teaches a correct understanding of the nature of knowable phenomena, as they are and as many as there are, and indicates the path to the everlasting happiness of liberation and omniscience.

'di lnga'i nang du rig gnas chung ba lnga la sogs pa'i gzhung mtha' dag 'dus pa yin pas/ 'di lta bu rig pa'i gnas lnga dag la brtson zhing mkhas par ma byas pa zhig na/ theg dman 'phags pa las mchog tu gyur pa theg chen pa'i gang zag 'phags pa mchog dag gis kyang thams cad mkhyen pa nyid du nam yang mi 'gyur te/ ci'i phyir na thams cad mkhyen pa ni shes bya thams cad mkhyen pa yin la/ shes bya thams cad ni rig pa'i gnas lngas bsdus pa'i phyir/ lnga po de ma shes pa'i thams cad mkhyen pa mi srid pa'i phyir ro/ /

All the texts of the five minor sciences and others are included in these five. Without being diligent in these five sciences and mastering them, even the highest noble beings of the Great Vehicle, who are far superior to the noble beings of the lesser vehicles, will never attain omniscience. Why? Because omniscience means knowing everything there is to know, and it is the five sciences that encompass everything there is to know. So it is impossible to be omniscient without knowing these five.

des na theg chen gyi rigs can rnams rang bzhin gyis dbang po rno ba dang / bsam pa dang shes rab rgya che bas mos spyod du yang rig pa'i gnas lngas bsdus pa'i shes bya thams cad la brtson zhing thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes thob pa'i rgyur bsngo ba yang byed la rgyu mthun pa'i dbang gis skye ba ches mang por goms par byed do/ / sa thob phan chad ting nge 'dzin dang ye shes kyi stobs kyis ji snyed pa'i shes bya rnams kyang tshegs med par mkhyen cing skye ba dpag tu med par rang gis goms pa'i phyir/ theg chen 'phags pa rnams rig pa'i gnas lnga la lhag par brtson par byas shing mkhas par byed pa yin gyi mi mkhas mi srid do zhes go dgos kyi 'phags pa mchog tu gyur nas da gdod rig gnas slob pa'i mgo gsar du 'dzin dgos pa lta bu'i go ba tha chad skyed par mi bya'o/ /

This is why even on the level of earnest aspiration, beings with the Mahāyāna potential, with their naturally sharp faculties and vast attitude and wisdom, are diligent in the five sciences, which encompass all branches of knowledge, and they dedicate them to attaining omniscient gnosis. As a result, and in similarity with the cause, they repeatedly train in this over many, many lives. Once they have attained the bodhisattva levels, the power of their concentration and gnosis is such that they have no difficulty in knowing all there is to know, and they habituate themselves to this over countless lives. Noble beings of the Great Vehicle are therefore especially diligent and learned in the five sciences. It is important to understand that it is impossible for them not to be learned. You must never have the sort of improper notion that once one has become a supreme noble being, one has to start learning the five sciences from scratch.

slob pa'i skabs su rig pa'i gnas lnga la ma rmongs pa'i shes rab phun sum tshogs pa la/ sman ci tsam tshogs dgos pa tshang ba la sman kun tshogs dang*/ de bzhin mi kun tshogs zhes brjod 'dod kyis dbang gis rig gnas thams cad mkhyen par gdags rung la rgyu de phul du phyin par gyur pa sangs rgyas kyi sa na rig pa'i gnas bsdus pa'i don mtha' dag mngon sum mkhyen pa la thams cad mkhyen pa'i mtshan yongs su rdzogs par thob bo/ /

At the stage of training, bodhisattvas’ abundant and unclouded knowledge of the five sciences may be called “omni-science,”[63] in much the same way as one might speak of having “all the medicines” when the necessary medicines are all there, or similarly of “everybody.” But it is on the buddha level, when that causal knowledge is consummated, that they truly know everything encompassed by the five sciences and that they fully acquire the epithet “omniscient.”

byang chub sems dpa'i gzhan don la brtson pas rig pa'i gnas lngar mkhas na gzhan don sgrub nus shing / thams cad mkhyen par 'gyur ba de lta bas na phyin ci log tu ston pa mu stegs can sogs gzhan dag tshig dang don gyi sgo nas tshar bcad pa'i phyir sgra dang tshad ma'i rig pa dang / sems can spyi dang bye brag rjes su gzung ba'i phyir bzo dang gso ba rig pa bslabs pa dang / bdag nyid kyis ji lta ji snyed kyi chos kun yang dag par shes par bya ba'i phyir nang rig pa'am dam pa'i chos bslab par bya ste/ de ltar bslab par bya ba rig pa'i gnas lnga de la byang chub sems dpa' de rab tu brtson par byed pa yin no/ /

By mastering the five sciences, anyone earnestly applying themselves to pursuing the bodhisattva’s work in benefiting others will be able to achieve others’ welfare and attain omniscience. For this reason, bodhisattvas are extremely diligent in learning these five sciences, studying the sciences of grammar and of logic so that they can use words and meanings to subjugate others—tīrthikas and the like—who teach perverse views, training in the sciences of the arts and medicine in order to care for beings generally and specifically, and learning the inner science or sacred Dharma in order to correctly know for themselves the nature and multiplicity of all phenomena.

de skad du yang drin lan bsab pa'i mdo las/ dam pa'i chos mdo sde bcu gnyis dang / rgyu'am gtan tshigs rig pa dang sgra rig pa dang / sman dpyad kyi rig pa dang / 'jig rten pa'i bzo'i rig pa bslab dgos tshul so sor gsungs nas/ gal te byang chub sems dpa'i rig pa'i dngos po lnga la ma bslab na nam du yang bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes thob par mi 'gyur ro/ / de bas na bla na med pa'i byang chub 'thob pa'i phyir rig pa'i dngos po lnga la bslab par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

This is also taught in the Sūtra in Repayment of Kindness, in which the Buddha spoke of the need to train in each of the sciences (the sūtras and the other eleven branches of the sacred Dharma, the science of reasons or proofs, the science of grammar, the science of medicine, and the science of mundane arts) and then declared, “If bodhisattvas do not train in the five sciences, they will never acquire the gnosis of unsurpassable, perfect, omniscient enlightenment. This is why, to attain unsurpassable enlightenment, one must train in the five sciences.”
gnyis pa
2. THE DIFFERENT FORMS OF ATTENTIVENESS USED IN INVESTIGATION
yid la byed pa ci lta bus tshol ba bshad pa pha rol tu phyin pa'i khams rgyas par 'gyur ba yid la byed pa ni/
There now follows an explanation of the different forms of attentiveness[64] with which bodhisattvas investigate the Dharma and which cause the potential for transcendent perfection to grow.

tshigs su bcad pa bcu gsum gyis bstan te/ dang po rgyu dmigs nas dga' ba yid la byed pa nas/ rten la de'i rjes su dran pa'i yid la byed pa dang 'bras bu thun mong 'dod pa yid byed dang ji ltar byang chub mos pa yid byed dang mthar thug gi dga' ba yid byed/ mi skyo ba yid byed/ mi mthun phyogs spangs dang gnyen po sgrub pa yid byed bdun dang rab tu dwang ba yid byed sogs nas bdag mchog tu 'dzin pa yid la byed pa'i bar gyi yid la byed pa 'di dag yid la byas nas rang rgyud kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i khams rgyas par 'gyur te/

These are indicated in the next thirteen verses, beginning with attentiveness to joy from considering the cause, attentiveness in mindfulness of the support, attentiveness in wishing for a shared result, attentiveness in yearning for the same enlightenment, attentiveness associated with joy on account of one’s powers, attentiveness associated with indefatigability, and attentiveness associated with abandoning incompatible traits and employing antidotes (making seven in all), and continuing from attentiveness associated with clear faith and so forth through to attentiveness associated with one’s own superiority. It is from having kept all these in mind that the potential for transcendent perfection in one’s mind stream will unfold.
rgyu dmigs nas ni dga' ba dang / / rten la de rjes dran pa dang / / 'bras bu thun mong 'dod pa dang / / ji ltar byang chub bzhin mos pa'o/ /
Joy from considering the cause, Mindfulness of the support, The wish for a shared result, And a yearning for a similar enlightenment; (XII, 61)
zhes
