dang po rgyu dmigs nas ni dga' ba dang zhes pa rigs la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpas thog mar bdag la sangs rgyas kyi rigs phar phyin drug sgrub nus pa'i rigs sam sa bon yod med brtags nas/ sangs rgyas thob 'dod dang phar phyin la 'jug par 'dod pa'i rgyu yod par dmigs nas bdag la 'tshang rgya ba'i skal pa yod do snyam du yang dang yang du dga' ba yid la byed pas phar phyin gyi sa bon kun gzhi la yod pa rgyas par 'gyur ba dang / de bzhin du rten la de rjes dran pa dang zhes pa rigs la gnas pa des de'i 'og tu bla med byang chub tu sems bskyed pa ni pha rol tu phyin pa rnams kyi gnas sam rten yin pas bdag gis sems bskyed pas phar phyin rnams rdzogs par 'gyur ro snyam du dga' zhing rten sems bskyed de la mi brjed pa'i dran pa dang shes rab kyis rjes su dran pa yid la byed pa des kyang phar phyin gyi khams rgyas par 'gyur ro/ /

First, there is “joy from considering the cause.” Bodhisattvas, who are individuals in whom the Mahāyāna potential is present, begin by examining to see whether or not they have the potential for buddhahood, the potential or seed for being able to accomplish the six transcendent perfections. From this they know that they have the cause for wanting to attain buddhahood and to practice the transcendent perfections. Because they repeatedly keep in mind their delight at this, thinking, “I have the good fortune for attaining buddhahood,” the seed of transcendent perfection present in the ground of all will develop. So it is with “mindfulness of the support.” Those people in whom the potential is present subsequently arouse the mind set on unsurpassable enlightenment. Since this is the foundation or support for the transcendent perfections, they rejoice, thinking, “By arousing the bodhicitta I will complete the transcendent perfections.” From their constantly remembering that support, their spiritual intent, with unforgetting mindfulness and wisdom, again, the potential for transcendent perfection will develop.

de'i 'og tu 'bras bu thun mong 'dod pa dang zhes pa pha rol du phyin pa drug la spyod cing phar phyin gyi 'bras bu rnam par smin pa rnams bdag 'ba' zhig gi ched du ma yin par gzhan dang thun mong du 'dod de/ de ltar bsngo bar byas pa'i yid la byed pas kyang phar phyin gyi khams rgyas par 'gyur ro/ / de'i rjes su ji ltar byang chub bzhin mos pa'o zhes pa ji ltar 'das pa dang da ltar dang ma 'ongs pa'i sangs rgyas thams cad kyis phar phyin drug spyad nas bla na med pa'i byang chub mngon du mdzad pa bzhin bdag gis kyang phar phyin drug spyod pas mngon par sangs rgyas par gyur cig ces mos pas kyang phar phyin gyi khams rgyas par 'gyur ba'o/ / de ltar rgyu dmigs pa'i dga' ba dang / sems bskyed rjes su dran pa dang phar phyin la spyod cing 'bras bu sems can rnams dang thun mong du 'dod pa dang / bla med 'thob pa'i yid byed bzhi po des rang gi kun gzhi rnam shes kyi khams la yod pa'i phar phyin drug gi sa bon gong nas gong du rgyas par byed pa bzhin yid byed 'og ma thams cad kyis kyang pha rol tu phyin pa drug gi khams rgyas par byed pa dang / gong 'og gi go rims kyang rim pa ltar 'byung ba shes par bya dgos shing / 'dir ni gzhung tshig mdor bsdus su 'chad do/ /

After that the bodhisattvas “wish for a shared result.” Practicing the six transcendent perfections, they desire the ripened effects of the transcendent perfections not for themselves alone but to be shared with others. Keeping this dedication in mind also makes the potential for transcendent perfection grow. After that comes “yearning for a similar enlightenment.” This is the yearning, “Just as the buddhas of the past, present, and future, having practiced the six transcendent perfections, realize unsurpassable enlightenment, may I too, by practicing the six transcendent perfections, actually attain buddhahood.” This too makes the potential for transcendent perfection unfold. Thus you should know that attentiveness to these four—joy from considering the cause, being mindful of one’s spiritual intent, wishing the result of practicing the transcendent perfections to be shared with all sentient beings, and the unsurpassable attainment—makes the seeds of the six transcendent perfections that are present in the element of one’s own ground consciousness grow more and more, and that in the same way all the different kinds of attentiveness that follow make the potential for transcendent perfection grow, and that this takes place in the given order. The root text here mentions these very succinctly.
mthu ni rnam pa bzhi dag gis/ / dka' dang nges par mi skyo dang / / mi mthun phyogs dang gnyen po la/ / sgrub pa rnam pa bzhi yin no/
Joy on account of the four powers, True indefatigability, And the four aspects of practice with regard to Incompatible traits and their antidotes; (XII, 62)

mthu ni rnam pa bzhi dag gis dga' dang zhes pa 'og nas 'chad 'gyur ltar rang la mthu ni rnam pa bzhi yod par mthong nas de dag gis dga' ba yid la byed pa dang / nges par mi skyo dang zhes pa mthu dang ldan na bdag gis sangs rgyas kyi chos yongs su rdzogs pa dang sems can smin par nges par mi skyo ba yid la byed pa dang / mi mthun phyogs dang gnyen po la/ mi skyo ba'i sgo nas bla med byang chub bsgrub pa'i ched du phar phyin rnams kyi mi mthun phyogs ser sna sogs spang ba dang / gnyen po sbyin sogs sgrub pa yid la byed pa rnam pa bzhi 'byung ba yin no/ /

“Joy on account of the four powers” refers to keeping in mind the joy that arises from the four powers once one has seen that one has them, as will be explained below. “True indefatigability” refers to keeping in mind the fact that if one possesses these powers, one will certainly never despair of completing the path to buddhahood oneself and maturing sentient beings. And with regard to incompatible traits and their antidotes, there are four aspects to keeping in mind the abandoning of stinginess and other factors incompatible with the transcendent perfections and the employment of their antidotes (generosity and the rest) in order to accomplish unsurpassable enlightenment without ever getting discouraged.

mthu rnam pa bzhi ni phar phyin gyi mi mthun pa'i phyogs spang ba'i mthu'am nus pa yod pa dang / gnyen po phar phyin gyi tshogs smin pa'i mthu dang / bdag dang pha rol la phan 'dogs pa'i mthu dang / ma 'ongs pa'i dus na rnam smin dang rgyu mthun gyi 'bras bu phar phyin sgrub pa la nus pa thob pa'o/ /

The four powers are the power or ability to abandon factors incompatible with the transcendent perfections; the power to ripen the accumulations with antidotes—that is, with the transcendent perfections; the power to benefit oneself and other beings; and the ability one gains, on account of the fully ripened effect and the effect similar to the cause, to accomplish the transcendent perfections in the future.

mi mthun phyogs spong ba'i mthu ji lta bu yin zhe na/ sbyin pas ser sna sel nus par mthong ba sogs phar phyin gzhan rang rang gi mi mthun phyogs 'chal tshul khong khro le lo rnam g.yeng shes 'chal spong nus pa'o/ / tshogs smin pa ni phar phyin drug gi bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs bsags shing smin par mthong ste/ sbyin tshul bzod gsum bsod nams kyi tshogs dang / sher ting gnyis ye shes kyi tshogs dang brtson 'grus ni gnyis ka'i char gtogs pa'o/ / bdag dang gzhan la phan ji ltar 'dogs na/ sbyin pa btang ba la dga' zhing mi 'gyod pas da lta dang phyi mar bdag la phan btags pa dang sbyin pa byin pas gzhan la phan 'dogs pa de bzhin/ tshul bzod kyis gzhan la gnod pa med pa dang / brtson 'grus kyis gzhan don bsgrub pa dang / bsam gtan gyi mthus gzhan gyi nad dang lo nyes sogs sel ba dang / shes rab kyis chos bstan pas gzhan la phan 'dogs shing rang la phan pa smos mi dgos so/ /

What is the power of abandoning incompatible traits? It is the ability to see that generosity can dispel stinginess, and similarly to abandon the factors incompatible with each of the other transcendent perfections—namely, lax discipline, anger, laziness, distraction, and aberrant understanding. Maturing the accumulations is seeing that with the six transcendent perfections the accumulations of merit and wisdom are gathered and ripened. Generosity, discipline, and patience are related to the accumulation of merit, wisdom and concentration to the accumulation of wisdom, and diligence to both of these. How does one benefit oneself and others? By taking pleasure in giving generously and not regretting it, one benefits oneself now and in the future, and the gifts one makes benefit others. Similarly, with discipline and patience one ceases to harm others; with diligence one accomplishes others’ good; by the power of concentration, one dispels others’ illnesses, disasters in bad years, and so forth; and by teaching the Dharma with wisdom, one benefits others—there is no need to mention the benefit to oneself.

ma 'ongs na rnam smin dang rgyu mthun pa'i 'bras bu ji ltar 'byung zhe na/ sbyin pas longs spyod chen po dang / tshul khrims kyis lha mi'i lus thob pa dang / bzod pas mdzes shing 'khor g.yog phun sum tshogs pa dang / brtson 'grus kyis las kyi mtha' thams cad 'grub pa 'gyur ba dang / bsam gtan gyis lus nad med pa dang / sems las su rung bar 'gyur ba dang / shes rab kyis rig pa'i gnas thams cad la mkhas par 'gyur ba ni rnam smin gyi 'bras bu'o/ / rgyu mthun pa'i 'bras bu ni tshe rabs gang dang gang du skyes kyang sbyin sogs de dang de 'grub pa la dga' zhing bsgrub pa dang / des rang don dang gzhan smin par byed par 'gyur ba'o/ / 'di ni mthu rnam pa bzhi'o/ /

What are the fully ripened effects and the effects similar to the cause that occur in the future? As a result of generosity, one will be wealthy. As a result of discipline, one will be reborn as a human or celestial being. As a result of patience, one will be beautiful and have a large retinue of excellent followers. Because of diligence, one will accomplish all one’s tasks completely. Concentration will result in good physical health and a workable mind. And as a result of wisdom, one will be learned in all the sciences. These are all fully ripened effects. The effects similar to the cause are such that wherever one is reborn in one’s future lives, one will take pleasure in practicing generosity and each of the other transcendent perfections and accomplish them, and by this means one will benefit oneself and bring others to maturity. These, then, are the four powers.

mi skyo ba yid la byed pa ni/ bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhis sems can yongs su smin par bya ba la mi skyo ba dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsten nas dam pa'i chos mnyan pa la sogs pa'i sgo nas rang gi sangs rgyas chos yongs su smin pa'am rdzogs par byed pa la mi skyo ba ste rang phar phyin la gnas nas gzhan de la 'god pa la de'i dus su sems can rnams kyi log sgrub dang / tsha grang bkres skom ngal dub sogs kyi sdug bsngal ci byung yang yid mi skyo bar chos spyod pas ngoms pa med pa'o / /

Attentiveness associated with indefatigability comprises never getting discouraged in bringing sentient beings to maturity through the four ways of attracting disciples, and never getting discouraged in bringing the Buddha’s teachings to maturity or perfection in oneself by following a spiritual master, listening to the sacred Dharma, and so forth. Despite beings’ ingratitude, despite the heat and cold, hunger and thirst, exhaustion, and the rest that one may suffer when one practices the transcendent perfections oneself and subsequently sets others to practicing them, rather than getting discouraged, one can never have enough of practicing the Dharma.

mi mthun phyogs spong ba dang gnyen po sgrub pa yid byed la rnam grangs bzhi ste/ phar phyin gyi mi mthun phyogs ser sna nas shes rab 'chal ba'i bar rnams sdig pa mi dge ba'i phyogs yin la de dag byung na so sor bshags pa bya ba dang / gnyen po sbyin pa sogs drug po rang dang gzhan gyis bsgrub pa la rjes su yi rang ba dang / phar phyin gyi chos zab cing rgya che ba'i chos kyi 'khor lo bskor bar de de bzhin gshegs pa rnams la gsol ba 'debs pa dang / bshags pa yi rang gsol gdab de gsum gyis mtshon pa'i rang gzhan gyi dge rtsa thams cad bla med byang chub kyi phyir yongs su bsngo ba bzhi'o/ /

Attentiveness associated with abandoning incompatible traits and employing antidotes involves four practices: (1) confessing traits, should they occur, that are incompatible with the transcendent perfections—traits from stinginess through to aberrant understanding that lead to negative actions; (2) rejoicing at one’s own and others’ application of the antidotes—generosity and the other five perfections; (3) praying to the tathāgatas to turn the wheel of the extensive and profound Dharma, the teachings on the transcendent perfections; and (4) fully dedicating all one’s own and others’ positive actions, beginning with the above three (confession, rejoicing, and prayer), to the attainment of unsurpassable enlightenment.

de ltar yang mdo las/ sdig pa thams cad ni so sor bshags so/ / dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad la rjes su yi rang bar bgyi'o/ / sangs rgyas thams cad la ni bskul zhing gsol ba 'debs so/ / bdag gzhan bla na med pa ye shes kyi mchog dam pa thob par gyur cig ces gsungs pa bzhin no/ /
As we read in the sūtras: I confess all my negative actions. I rejoice in all sources of good. All the buddhas I exhort and pray. May I and others obtain the sublime, unsurpassable gnosis.
rab dang yang dag nod pa dang / / gzhan la sbyin par 'dun pa dang / / go cha dang ni smon lam dang / / mngon par dga' dang bya ba'i yid/ /
Clear faith, correct reception, A longing to give to others, Armor, prayer, True joy, and a sense of duty; (XII, 63)

yang rab tu dwang ba yid byed/ yang dag par nod pa yid byed sogs yid byed kyi rnam grangs ji skad bstan pa 'di dag yid la byas pas phar phyin gyi khams rgyas par byed pa yin pas/ rab dwang zhes pas phar phyin drug gis chos dang don la yid rab tu dwang ba skyed par byed pa ni rab tu dwang ba yid byed de/ chos dang don zhes pa phar phyin rjod byed kyi chos dang don phar phyin nyid dam/ yang rgyu phar phyin chos dang / don de'i 'bras bu la bya ste/

Again, by one’s keeping in mind the different kinds of attentiveness that are indicated in this verse—attentiveness associated with clear faith, attentiveness associated with correct reception, and so on—the potential for transcendent perfection will develop. “Clear faith” refers to keeping in mind clear faith, which is to develop an untainted attitude with regard to the teachings on the six transcendent perfections and the transcendent perfections themselves (or alternatively, to the causal transcendent perfections and their result).

mdor na pha rol tu phyin pa drug ni rdzogs smin sbyang ba thams cad kyi gzhir gyur pa dang / 'bras bu'i yon tan tshad med par yid ches pa yid la byed pa'o/ / yang dag nod pa dang zhes/ de ltar dad nas phar phyin ston pa'i chos tshol zhing yang dag par nod pa ni yang dag nod pa yid byed dang / gzhan la sbyin par 'dod pa dang zhes pa chos de gzhan la sbyin par dga' ba'am 'dun pa yid la byed pa dang gsum ni bshad pa'i skabs so/ /

In short, one keeps in mind the confidence that the six transcendent perfections are the foundation of all completion, maturation, and purification, and that boundless good qualities are their result. “Correct reception” refers to attentiveness in correctly receiving instructions, that is, with that kind of faith, seeking the teachings on the transcendent perfections and receiving them correctly. “A longing to give to others” refers to keeping in mind the delight or longing to give others those teachings. These three are related to the study of the teachings.

go cha dang ni zhes pa phar phyin tshad dpag tu med par sgrub pa la go cha bgo ba go cha yid byed dang ni/ smon lam dang zhes pa tshe rabs thams cad du phar phyin drug rdzogs par byed pa'i rkyen dge ba'i bshes gnyen dang / nye du dang lus dang longs spyod la sogs tshang ba'i sgo nas pha rol tu phyin pa rgyun mi 'chad pa rlabs po che bsgrub par gyur cig ces smon lam yid la byed pa dang / mngon pa dga' dang zhes pa skye ba tshe rabs thams cad du bla med byang chub 'thob pa'i rgyu phar phyin rnams bsgrub pa la snying thag pa nas mngon par dga' ba yid la byed pa dang gsum ni phar phyin gyi gdams pa rjes bstan bzhin 'jug pa'i don to/ /

“Armor” refers to attentiveness to the donning of armor[65] in practicing the transcendent perfections on an infinite scale. “Prayer” refers to keeping in mind prayers of aspiration that in all one’s lives the conditions for completing the six transcendent perfections—the spiritual master, one’s relatives and friends, body, possessions, and so forth—may all be present so that one may practice the transcendent perfections continuously on a vast scale. “True joy” refers to keeping in mind a heartfelt delight in practicing the transcendent perfections, which are the cause for attaining unsurpassable enlightenment, throughout all one’s lives. These three refer to engaging in the transcendent perfections according to the instructions one has received.

de'i rjes su thabs dang ldan pa'i yid la byed pa ni/ bya ba'i yid ces pas bstan te phar phyin rnams rang gis dngos su sbyang ba 'ba' zhig tu ma zad/ gzhan gyis byas pa la/ rjes su yi rang ba dang mngon par dga' ba dang ro myang ba'i tshul gyis phar phyin rnams rdzogs par bya ba'i yid la byed pa'o/ /

After these comes attentiveness associated with the possession of skillful means, indicated by “a sense of duty.” In not only actually training in the transcendent perfections oneself but also rejoicing in others’ practice of the transcendent perfections, deriving pleasure from them and appreciating them, one keeps in mind one’s task of completing the transcendent perfections.
sbyin sogs rnam pa drug la ni/ / mthu thob pa dang yongs smin dang / / mchod pa dang ni sten pa la/ / yang dag spro ba mchog dang brtse/ /
The highest genuine enthusiasm For obtaining power in the six perfections, For full maturation, making offerings, And following a teacher; and affection; (XII, 64)

spro ba yid la byed pa rnam pa bzhi ni/ sbyin sogs rnam pa drug la ni/ /zhes pa nas/ yang dag spro ba mchog dang zhes pa'i bar gyis bstan te/ bzhi gang zhe na phar phyin drug gi mthu thob pa la spro ba yid byed/ sems can yongs su smin par byed pa la spro ba yid byed/ de bzhin gshegs pa mchod pa la spro ba yid byed/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsten pa la spro ba yid byed bzhi'o/ / de las dang po sbyin pa sogs re re la yang sbyin pa'i sbyin pa nas sbyin pa'i shes rab kyi bar drug re drug re yod pa sum cu rtsa drug tu gyur pa'i tshul gyis phar phyin de lta bu la 'jug nus pa'i mthu thob pa ni spro ba yid la byed pa dang po'o/ / sbyin sogs phyin drug re re yang drug tu 'gyur tshul rang rang dngos po sbyin pa'i sbyin pa sogs rang rang dang / de'i tshe gzhan la phan gdags pa'i cha nas sbyin pa nyes spyod sdom pa dge ba de byed pa dang sems can gyi don byed pa'i cha nas tshul khrims/ gnod pa bzod pa'i cha nas bzod pa/ de dang de la brtson pa'i cha brtson 'grus/ mi mthun phyogs kyis ma phrogs par sems rtse gcig tu byas pa'i cha nas bsam gtan/ phar phyin de dang de'i rgyu dang 'bras bu tha snyad du ma nor bar shes pa dang don dam par 'khor gsum mi dmigs pas zin pa'i cha nas shes rab bo/ /

Four kinds of enthusiasm to be kept in mind are indicated in this verse. They are enthusiasm for obtaining power in the six transcendent perfections, enthusiasm for bringing sentient beings to full maturity, enthusiasm for making offerings to the tathāgatas, and enthusiasm for following the spiritual master. With regard to the first, within each of the six transcendent perfections there are again six transcendent perfections: for generosity there is the generosity of generosity, the discipline of generosity, and so on through to the wisdom of generosity, making thirty-six in all. So the first factor to be kept in mind is enthusiasm for obtaining the power to be able to practice the transcendent perfections in that way. How does this subdivision of each perfection into six work? When one practices each transcendent perfection, one is practicing that particular transcendent perfection—the generosity of generosity, for example. At the same time, in practicing each transcendent perfection one is benefiting others, so in that respect one is practicing generosity. In that each perfection involves avoiding negative actions, undertaking positive actions, and bringing benefit to beings, one is practicing discipline. From the point of view of one’s patiently bearing harm at that time, one is practicing patience. Making an effort to practice this or that transcendent perfection is its diligence aspect. Keeping the mind focused one-pointedly without being carried away by counteragents is the concentration aspect. And in terms of one’s correctly knowing the cause and result of the respective transcendent perfection on the conventional level and remaining free from the three concepts of subject, object, and action on the ultimate level, one is practicing wisdom.
yongs smin dang zhes pa phar phyin drug nyid bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhi'i tshul du byas nas sems can rnams yongs su smin par byed pa ni spro ba yid la byed pa gnyis pa dang /

“Full maturation” refers to the second enthusiasm to be kept in mind—enthusiasm for practicing the six transcendent perfections in the form of the four ways of attracting disciples and thus bringing sentient beings to full maturation.

mchod pa dang ni zhes pas phar phyin drug gi nang nas sbyin pa'i phar phyin rnyed pa dang bkur stis de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pa dang / phar phyin lhag ma lngas sgrub pa'i sgo nas de bzhin gshegs pa mchod par byed pa ni spro ba yid la byed pa gsum pa'o/ / bsten pa la/ yang dag spro ba mchog dang zhes pas phar phyin gyi chos phyin ci ma log pa ston pa'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsten pa ni spro ba yid byed bzhi pa ste/ de ltar phar phyin dang bsdu dngos dang mchod pa dang bsten pa bzhi la yang dag spro ba mchog gi yid la byed pas phar phyin gyi khams rgyas par byed pa dang /

“Offering” refers to the third enthusiasm that is to be kept in mind—enthusiasm for making offerings to the tathāgatas, both in making material offerings and venerating them with transcendent generosity, and in offering one’s practice of the other five transcendent perfections. “Following” refers to the fourth enthusiasm to keep in mind—enthusiasm for following the spiritual master who teaches the unerring way of the transcendent perfections. Thus keeping in mind the “highest genuine enthusiasm” for the transcendent perfections, for attracting disciples, for making offerings, and for following a teacher makes the potential for transcendent perfection grow.

de'i rjes su snying brtse ba yid la byed pa ni brtse zhes pas bstan te/ de la yang byams pa dang snying rje dang dga' ba dang btang snyoms bzhi yod pa 'og tu tshad med kyi skabs su 'chad pa bzhin no/ / de yang snying rje'i phar phyin drug gi mi mthun phyogs la gnas pa'am de'i rgyus sdug bsngal can la snying rje skye ste snying rje ba tsam du ma zad de'i sdug bsngal ci nus su sel ba dang sdug bsngal mi myang ba'i rgyu ser sna sogs dor te phar phyin la 'jog par byed pa yin no/ /

After that, there is keeping in mind heartfelt affection, indicated by “affection.” This comprises love, compassion, sympathetic joy, and impartiality, as will be explained in the section below on the boundless attitudes.[66] Compassion refers to arousing compassion for those who have traits incompatible with the six transcendent perfections or who suffer as a result of that, and not only feeling compassion but also doing one’s best to dispel their suffering and introducing them to the transcendent perfections, through which traits like stinginess are abandoned, so that they no longer experience suffering.

byams pa ni sems can rnams bde bar 'dod pa yin la de yang byams pa tsam du ma zad bde ba'i rgyu phar phyin rnams la 'jog pa yin no/ / dga' ba ni sbyin sogs bde ba'i rgyu'am de'i 'bras bu bde ba ldan pa'i sems can de la bde ba dang ldan pa la snying thag pa nas dga' zhing de bde ba mi 'bral ba'i rgyu dge ba phar phyin la 'jog go /

Love involves wishing that sentient beings be happy, and there again, not simply feeling love but also introducing them to the transcendent perfections that are the cause of happiness. Sympathetic joy involves rejoicing from the bottom of one’s heart when sentient beings who possess generosity and other causes of happiness, or who are happy as the result of the latter, are happy, and introducing them to virtue and the transcendent perfections so that they will never be unhappy.

btang snyoms ni chags sdang med pa yin pas bde ba ldan pa rnams la 'dod chags skye bar ma gyur cig ces dang / longs spyod rnams gzhan gyis phrogs pa lta bu'i sdug bsngal can rnams la de dag zhe sdang skye bar ma gyur cig snyam du sems pa dang / chags sdang dang bral ba'i phyir phar phyin gyi chos ston pa'o/ /

Impartiality is to be without attachment and aversion, and therefore to think, “May those who are happy never feel attachment” and “May those who suffer (for example, from having their possessions appropriated by others) never feel aversion,” and to give them teachings on the transcendent perfections so as to free them from attachment and aversion.
ma byas ngan par byas pa la/ / ngo tsha 'gyod dang yul la dga'/ / skyo la dgra bo'i 'du shes dang / / 'gong dang brjod pa'i blo gros so/ /
Shame and regret for having practiced badly Or not at all, delighting in the object, The notion of despair as an enemy, Introducing, and expressive intelligence; (XII, 65)

ngo tsha ba yid la byed pa ni ma byas ngan par byas pa la/ /ngo tsha 'gyod dang zhes pas bstan te/ phar phyin rnams ye ma byas pa dang / rdzogs par ma byas pa dang ser sna dang dman lam yid byed kyis byas pa ni smad pa'am ngan par byas pa zhes bya ste de lta bu ngo tsha zhing 'gyod pa'o/ / yul la dga' zhes pa phar phyin rnams rgyun du spyod pa'i tshe rnam par g.yeng ba med par rtse gcig tu yul de la dga' ba ni/ dga' ba yid byed de 'di la brtan pa yid byed zhes kyang bya'o/ / skyo la dgra bo'i 'du shes dang zhes pa sbyin sogs phar phyin la 'jug pa'i tshe spyod par mi 'dod pa'i sems skyo ba skyes pa la 'di ni bla med byang chub thob pa'i bar du gcod pa yin pas dgra yin no snyam du dgra bo'i 'du shes 'jog pa ni mi skyo ba yid la byed pa'o/ / 'god dang zhes pa sems can rnams phar phyin drug dang 'brel ba'i chos bstan pas skyob par bya'o snyam du de dang 'brel ba'i gtsug lag gi gzhung ston pa'i bstan bcos la gdul bya rnams 'god pa ni 'god pa yid la byed pa zhes bya ste byang phyogs kyi le'u las bstan pa ltar shes par bya'o/ / brjod pa'i blo gros so zhes pa sems can so so'i snod kyi khyad par dang 'tsham par 'chad pa brjod pa'i blo gros te brjod pa yid la byed pa'o/ / 'di ni 'jig rten pa'i rgyud tshod shes pa la'o/ / 'og tu byang phyogs kyi le'ur 'jig rten 'byung ba dang 'gal ba'i bden pa shes pa la ni don dam shes pa yin no/ /

Keeping in mind a sense of shame is indicated by “shame and regret for having practiced badly or not at all.” This refers to shame and regret at, for example, never having practiced the transcendent perfections, and at what we call “having practiced badly or disgracefully,” that is, not having practiced them completely, and having practiced them with stinginess and with lower paths in mind. “Delighting in the object” refers to keeping delight in mind—one-pointed, undistracted delight as one continuously practices the transcendent perfections. This is also known as keeping stability in mind. “The notion of despair as an enemy.” When one is engaging in generosity and the other transcendent perfections, one may feel depressed and not wish to practice. To think of this as an enemy, since it is an obstacle to attaining unsurpassable enlightenment, is to keep in mind not getting discouraged. “Introducing” is explained as follows. Thinking that one will protect sentient beings by teaching them the path related to the six transcendent perfections, to introduce those to be trained to the treatises that teach the relevant scriptural tradition is what is known as “keeping introduction in mind.” This is as described in the chapter on elements leading to enlightenment. “Expressive intelligence” represents keeping expression in mind, that is, giving explanations in accord with beings’ individual particularities as receptacles for the teachings. This refers to mundane knowledge in assessing people’s minds. Below, the chapter on elements leading to enlightenment deals with knowledge of the truth rather than of what happens on the mundane level: this is ultimate knowledge.
sbyin sogs rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi/ / rten yin dbang phyug la sogs min/ / gnyis po dag la skyon dang ni/ / yon tan so so yang dag rig /
Generosity and so forth being the support Of perfect enlightenment (not Īśvara and the others), Distinguishing the faults in incompatible traits And the qualities in their antidotes; (XII, 66)

sbyin sogs rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi/ /rten yin dbang phyug la sogs min/ /zhes pas sbyin pa la sogs pa phar phyin drug ni rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi rten yin te dbang phyug tshangs pa la sogs ni byang chub thob pa'i rten min par shes pa ni/ rten pa yid la byed pa ste 'di ni rton pa bzhi dang ldan pa'i shes rab kyis 'byung ngo*/ / gnyis po dag la skyon dang ni/ /yon tan so so yang dag rig ces pas mi mthun phyogs ser sna sogs la dbul bar 'gyur ba sogs kyi skyon yod pa dang*/ sbyin sogs la de las ldog pa'i yon tan yod pa yi mi mthun phyogs dang gnyen po gnyis po dag la skyon dang ni yon tan yod pa don so sor yang dag pa rig pas shes nas yid la byed pa ni rtog pa yid la byed pa'o/ /

“Generosity and so forth being the support of perfect enlightenment (not Īśvara and the others)” refers to keeping in mind the support, knowing that the six transcendent perfections—generosity and the rest—are the foundation of perfect enlightenment and that Īśvara, Brahmā, and other gods are not supports for attaining enlightenment. This arises through the wisdom associated with the four reliances.[67] “Distinguishing the faults in incompatible traits and the qualities in their antidotes” refers to keeping discrimination in mind; that is, knowing and keeping in mind, with the perfect knowledge of meanings, the fact that there are faults and qualities in the two—incompatible traits and antidotes. In stinginess and other incompatible traits there are faults such as future poverty. And in generosity and the other transcendent perfections there are good qualities, which are the opposite of those faults.
bsags pa rjes su dran pa yis/ / dga' dang don chen mthong ba dang / / rnal 'byor rnam par mi rtog dang / / de 'dzin byed dang phrad 'dod pa/ /
Joy from the memory of accumulation, Seeing the great point, And the wish for yoga, for nonconceptuality, For retention, and for encountering; (XII, 67)

tshogs gnyis po bsags pa rjes su dran pas dga' ba ni/ bsags pa rjes su dran pa yis/ /dga' ba dang zhes pas bstan te/ sbyin tshul bzod gsum bsod nams kyi tshogs dang sher ting ye shes kyi tshogs dang / de dang de'i brtson pa de dang gtong ba ste de ltar tshogs bsags pa rjes su dran pa ni/ bsags pa dran nas dga' ba yid la byed pa zhes bya'o/ /

Joy from remembering that one has gathered the two accumulations is indicated by “Joy from the memory of accumulation.” This refers to keeping in mind one’s delight from having remembered that one has gathered the accumulations—the accumulation of merit through generosity, discipline, and patience; the accumulation of wisdom through concentration and wisdom; and the diligence in each of these by giving with generosity and so on.

don chen po mthong ba yid la byed pa ni don chen mthong ba dang zhes pas bstan te/ sbyin pa la sogs pa'i phar phyin rnams byang chub phyogs kyi dngos po'i don yin te rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes mthar phyin pa byang chub chen po yin la/ sbyin sogs phar phyin rnams byang chub chen po de'i rgyu yin pas de yongs su rdzogs pas byang chub chen po 'thob pa'i phyir de dag don chen po yin par mthong ba po/

Keeping in mind one’s seeing the great point is indicated by “seeing the great point.” Generosity and the other transcendent perfections constitute the point, for they are the elements that lead to enlightenment. The culmination of nonconceptual gnosis being great enlightenment, generosity and the other transcendent perfections are the cause of that great enlightenment, so it is by completing them that one attains great enlightenment. This is why they are seen as being the great point.
rnal 'byor zhes pas phar phyin drug yongs su rdzogs par bya ba'i phyir zhi gnas dang lhag mthong zung du 'brel bar bsgom pa ni/ rnal 'byor yid la byed pa zhes bya'o/ /
“Yoga” refers to keeping yoga in mind—that is, meditating on the union of sustained calm and profound insight in order to complete the six transcendent perfections.

rnam par mi rtog pa zhes pas rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes ni phar phyin rnams yongs su rdzogs par byed pa'i thabs yin pas rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes dang ldan par byed pa ni/ mi rtog par 'dod pa yid la byed pa zhes bya'o/ / yang na sbyor ba'i dus su rnam par mi rtog par pha rol tu phyin pa la 'jug par gyur cig ces smon lam 'debs pa la de ltar 'grub pa 'byung bas mi rtog par 'dod pa yid la byed pa zhes so/ / tshogs gnyis nas rnam par mi rtog pa'i bar byang phyogs le'u dang go rims bzhin sbyar du yod do/ /

“Nonconceptuality” refers to nonconceptual gnosis, which is the means for completing the transcendent perfections. What makes one have nonconceptual gnosis is what we call “keeping in mind the wish for nonconceptuality.” Put another way, when one actually practices, one’s prayers of aspiration that one may engage in the transcendent perfections nonconceptually will be fulfilled, so we speak of keeping in mind the wish for nonconceptuality. The above points, from the two accumulations up to nonconceptuality, are dealt with in the same order in the chapter on elements leading to enlightenment.
de 'dzin byed dang zhes pas pha rol tu phyin pa rjod byed kyi chos dang don de gnyis mi brjed par 'dzin par byed pa ni 'dzin pa yid la byed pa'o/ / 'di ni gzungs kyi stobs las 'byung ngo*/ /

“Retention” refers to keeping retention in mind, that is, retaining both the teachings that describe the transcendent perfections and their meaning, without forgetting them. This comes about through infallible memory.

phrad 'dod pa zhes pas gang du skyes kyang phar phyin rnams yongs su rdzogs pa'i rkyen bshes gnyen sogs dang phrad par 'dod cing smon lam 'debs pa ni rkyen thob pa yid la byed pa ste 'di ni smon lam mo/ /

“The wish for encountering” refers to keeping in mind the obtainment of conditions, and amounts to prayers of aspiration—wishing and praying that wherever one is born, one will encounter spiritual masters and other conditions for completing the transcendent perfections.
log par 'dzin pa rnam pa bdun/ / spong ba'i mthu ni thob pa dang / / ngo mtshar ngo mtshar med pa la/ / 'du shes rnam pa bzhi nyid do/ /
The obtainment of power for eliminating The seven kinds of wrong belief, And the four thoughts Of what is extraordinary and what is not; (XII, 68)

log par 'dzin pa rnam pa bdun/ /spong ba'i mthu ni thob pa dang zhes pas phar phyin bsgom pa la phyin ci log par 'dzin pa rnam pa bdun spong ba'i mthu ni thob par yid la byed pa ni/ ting nge 'dzin gsum dang chos kyi sdom bzhis phyin ci log gam log par 'dzin pa bdun ni/ kun brtags kyi chos med pa la yod par 'dzin pa dang / 'khor ba'i chos nyes pa can la rtag pa sogs yon tan du 'dzin pa dang / yon tan can mya ngan 'das pa la byis pa rnams kyis bdag chad du dogs pas yon tan can ma yin par g.yang sa lta bur lta ba'i phyin ci log par 'dzin pa gsum gyi gnyen po'i rim pa ltar stong pa nyid smon pa med pa dang mtshan ma med pa'i ting nge 'dzin gsum yin te des de dag spong bar byed do/ / 'dus byas la rtag par 'dzin pa dang / zag bcas la bde bar 'dzin pa dang / chos rnams la bdag tu 'dzin pa dang / mya ngan las 'das pa la ma zhi bar 'dzin pa'i log par 'dzin pa bzhi'i gnyen por rim pa ltar 'du byed thams cad mi rtag pa dang / zag bcas thams cad sdug bsngal ba dang / chos thams cad stong zhing bdag med pa dang / mya ngan las 'das pa zhi ba zhes bya ba'i chos kyi mdo bzhi bstan pa des spong bar byed do/ / de ltar yid byed de thams cad kyis phar phyin gyi khams rgyas par byed do/ /

“The obtainment of power for eliminating the seven kinds of wrong belief” refers to attentiveness in obtaining the power to get rid of the seven kinds of wrong belief in order to train in the transcendent perfections. These seven mistaken or wrong beliefs are eliminated by the three concentrations and the four summaries of the Dharma. The belief that the phenomena of imputed reality exist when they do not; the belief that the fault-ridden phenomena of saṃsāra have good qualities such as being permanent;[68] and the view held by immature beings that nirvāṇa, rather than being full of good qualities, is like an abyss devoid of good qualities (for they fear it entails the extinction of the self)—these are the three mistaken beliefs. The antidotes that eliminate them are the three concentrations on emptiness, absence of expectancy, and absence of attributes respectively. The belief that compounded phenomena are permanent, the belief that tainted phenomena are happiness, the belief that there is a self in phenomena, and the belief that nirvāṇa is not peace are the four wrong beliefs. The antidotes for eliminating these are the four summaries of the Dharma—respectively that all compounded phenomena are impermanent, that all tainted phenomena are suffering, that all phenomena are empty and devoid of self, and that nirvāṇa is peace. Keeping all these in mind makes the potential for transcendent perfection grow.

de ltar rab dang nas mngon dga'i bar drug gi rgyas bshad ni mos pa dang / chos tshol dang / chos bshad pa dang / sgrub pa'i le'u gsum dang / gdams ngag dang / rjes bstan drug dang sbyar ba yin la/ bya ba'i yid ces pa thabs ldan gyi le'u dang / sbyin sogs drug la mthu thob pa phar phyin gyi le'u'i phar phyin drug dang / sems can yongs smin bsdu dngos dang sbyar ro/ / mchod bsten brtse gsum mchod bsten tshad med kyi le'u las byung ba bzhin no/ / ngo tsha nas log par 'dzin pa bdun spong ba'i bar ni byang chub phyogs mthun gyi le'u las rim par 'byung ba bzhin no/ / yang ngo mtshar dang ngo mtshar med pa'i yid byed gnyis bshad pa/ ngo mtshar ngo mtshar med pa la/ / 'du shes rnam pa bzhi yin no/ zhes pas bstan te/ ngo mtshar gyi 'du shes yid la byed pa bzhi dang / ngo mtshar med pa la 'du shes yid la byed pa yang rnam pa bzhi nyid de/ 'di dag yid la byas kyang phar phyin drug gi khams rgyas par byed do/ / de bzhin yid byed thams cad kyis pha rol tu phyin pa bcu'i khams rgyas par byed pa ni mjug tu/ pha rol phyin bcu'i rgyus byung ba sogs tshigs bcad gcig gis bstan pa bzhin du shes par bya ste/ 'di re re nas de smos ma dgos so/ /

The detailed explanations of the six factors to be kept in mind from clear faith to true joy (verse 63) correspond to the six chapters on interest, investigating the Dharma, teaching the Dharma, practicing the Dharma, the instructions, and follow-up teachings. “A sense of duty” (verse 63) corresponds to the chapter on skillful activity (chapter 16). “Obtaining power in the six perfections” (verse 64) corresponds to the section on the six transcendent perfections in the chapter on transcendent perfections (chapter 17); and “full maturation” corresponds to the section on the four ways of attracting disciples in the same chapter. The next three, “offering,” “following,” and “affection,” are as they appear in the chapter on offerings, reliance, and boundless attitudes (chapter 18). The factors to be kept in mind from “shame” through to “eliminating the seven kinds of wrong belief” (verses 65–68) are as they appear in order in the chapter on elements leading to enlightenment (chapter 19). Then there is an explanation of two factors to be kept in mind with regard to what is extraordinary and what is not extraordinary, indicated by “four thoughts of what is extraordinary and what is not.” There are four thoughts to be kept in mind about what is extraordinary and four about what is not extraordinary. Keeping these in mind also makes the potential for transcendent perfection grow. It is to be understood that in the same way all the different kinds of attentiveness make the potential for the ten transcendent perfections grow, as is shown by the single verse (73) at the end of this section, “Keeping in mind the virtue that results from the ten transcendent perfections….” There is no need to repeat this in each individual case.

ngo mtshar ba'i 'du shes bzhi gang zhe na yon tan gyi le'u las rang gi lus dang sdom pa'i phyir/ /zhes sogs kyis bstan pa ltar pha rol tu phyin pa rnams la spang dka' ba spang ba'i 'du shes 'jug pa yang ngo mtshar yin te/ rang gi sbyin pa'i ched du lus gtong ba'am spang ba/ de bzhin tshul khrims kyi ched du lus dang nye du sogs phun sum tshogs pa gtong ba nas shes rab rnam par mi rtog pa'i bar ro/ / yun ring ba'i ngo mtshar ba ni phar phyin gyi spyod pa rgya chen po bskal pa grangs med gsum gyi bar du spyod pa'i 'du shes 'jug pa yang ngo mtshar ro/ / phar phyin drug la spyad kyang rang don du tshe 'dir lan la mi re ba'ang ngo mtshar/ de bzhin du phyi mar rnam par smin pa la mi re ba yang ngo mtshar ba bzhi'o/ / rnam grangs gzhan yang rigs su skye dang sogs bzhi gzhung ltar ro/ /

What are the four extraordinary thoughts? As indicated by “Their own bodies they give away…,”[69] in the Qualities chapter, they are as follows: (1) It is extraordinary to think that in practicing the transcendent perfections, bodhisattvas give up things that are very difficult to give up, giving away or renouncing their bodies for the sake of their own practice of generosity, abandoning all the wonderful things they have—their bodies, family, and the like—for the sake of their discipline, and so on through to having no concepts in their practice of wisdom. (2) We can also marvel at the length of time, for it is an extraordinary thought that they practice the extensive activities of the transcendent perfections for three measureless kalpas. (3) Even when they are practicing the six transcendent perfections, they do not hope for any personal reward in this life, which again is something quite amazing. (4) Similarly, it is quite extraordinary that they do not hope for any ripened karmic fruit in future lives. Other explanations for these four are also mentioned in the scriptures—being born in a good family, and so on.

ngo mtshar med pa bzhi ni/ 'bras btab pa las 'bras skye ba rgyu 'bras rten 'brel gyi chos nyid yin pas ngo mtshar mi che ba ltar/ rgyu phar phyin tshad med pa spyad pa'i 'bras bu byang chub yon tan tshad med pa thob pa'ang ngo mtshar mi che la/ bdag dang gzhan mi mnyam par 'dzin pas bdag bzhin du gzhan la phan 'dogs par byed na ngo mtshar gyi/ bdag gi 'du shes yun ring por gnyen po bsgom pas spangs te bdag dang gzhan mnyam pa nyid du mthong ba des bdag la ji ltar sems can la phan 'dogs pa ngo mtshar mi che ba dang / sems can phal pa rnams las mchog tshangs pa dang brgya sbyin sogs la byang chub sems dpas phan btags pa'i lan du tshangs pa sogs kyis mchod par bkur stir byas pa yang dang du mi len te 'dod chags dang bral ba des mchil ma'i rdog gu bzhin du sems la phan pas phan lan byed par re ba ga la yod de des sems can la snying brtse bas phan gdags pa yin pas lan la mi re ba tsam la ngo mtshar med do/ / rnam par smin pa la mi re ba'ang ngo mtshar mi che ste/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag 'jig rten pa'i rnam smin mi 'dod de 'jig rten las 'das pa sku gsum dang zag med kyi bde ba thob par nges pa'i phyir ro/ /

The four unextraordinary thoughts are as follows: (1) Just as there is nothing very extraordinary in a crop of rice growing from planting rice grain, for this is the very nature of the interdependence of cause and effect, there is no great wonder in obtaining the boundless qualities of enlightenment as the result of practicing the boundless transcendent perfections. (2) It would be quite surprising if, by considering oneself and others not equal, one were to benefit others as much as oneself. But since, through long habituation to the antidote, bodhisattvas have eliminated the notion of self and have seen that they are the same as others, there is nothing at all surprising in their benefiting sentient beings as much as themselves. (3) When the greatest of ordinary beings—Brahmā, Indra, and the like—are benefited by bodhisattvas and offer gifts and respect in return, those bodhisattvas do not accept them, for they are free of attachment and think as much of those offerings as of a gob of spit. So how could they hope that ordinary beings would do anything in return for their benefiting them? Bodhisattvas benefit sentient beings with tender affection, so there is nothing extraordinary in the fact that they do not have the slightest expectation of reward. (4) There is nothing extraordinary either in their not hoping for a ripened karmic result. Bodhisattvas have no desire for mundane karmic results because they are sure to attain the three buddha bodies and untainted bliss that transcend the mundane.
sems can rnams la snyoms pa dang / / bdag nyid chen po mthong ba dang / / gzhan gyi yon tan lan re dang / / gsum du smon dang rgyun du'o/ /
Impartiality toward sentient beings, Being seen as a great being, Hoping for the recompense of good qualities in others, A threefold aspiration, and continuity; (XII, 69)

sems can rnams la snyoms pa dang zhes pas sems can rnams la nye ring med par sems snyoms par byas te phar phyin la 'god pa ni sgom pa yid la byed pa ste 'di ni don gnyer ba la phyogs med dang sogs kyis bstan to/ / bdag nyid chen por mthong ba dang / /zhes pas phar phyin drug la spyad na bde ba dang phan pa 'ba' zhig las gnod pa'i dngos por cung zad mi 'gyur bas byang chub sems dpa' de ni rnam pa drug tu sems can thams cad la phan bde 'ba' zhig gis phan 'dogs par byed pa'i bdag nyid chen por mthong ba ni bdag nyid chen por dmigs pa yid la byed pa'o/ / 'di ni yon tan le'ur snod nyid du ni byed pa sogs phan 'dogs kyi tshigs bcad dang / phan 'dogs tshul gyi dpe ma dang pha dang rtsa lag sogs bdun bstan pa bzhin no/ /

“Impartiality toward beings” refers to keeping impartiality in mind—being even-minded with regard to sentient beings, without any notion of close or distant, and introducing them to the transcendent perfections. This is indicated by “In their impartiality to all in need…” and so on.[70] “Being seen as a great being” refers to keeping in mind being considered as a great being. When bodhisattvas practice the six transcendent perfections, their practice will lead exclusively to happiness and benefit and not to the slightest harm. They are therefore seen as great beings who benefit all sentient beings in six ways, bringing them nothing but benefit and happiness. This is indicated by the verse on bringing benefit (“Making beings fit vessels,…”) in the Qualities chapter,[71] and the seven similes for how bodhisattvas benefit—like mothers, fathers, kinsfolk, and so forth.[72]

gzhan gyi yon tan lan re dang zhes pas gzhan phar phyin la bkod nas gzhan phar phyin drug gi yon tan dang ldan par gyur na byang chub sems dpa' 'di dag rang gi 'dod pa grub pas sems can 'di dag gis bdag la phan btags so snyam du sems shing / gzhan gyi yon tan de tsam zhig phan pa'i lan du re ba yin te/ lan gzhan mi 'dod de sems can phar phyin gyi yon tan ldan par gyur na ci ma rung snyam pa'i de ltar smin par byed pa yin la sems can de smin par gyur na sems can de dag gis byang chub sems dpas re ba rdzogs par byas pas so/ / 'di ni lan 'dod pa yid la byed pa zhes bya ste sems can rnams phar phyin la bkod pa de phar phyin gyi yon tan dang ldan na byang chub sems dpa' la drin lan bla na med pa yin gyi lan gzhan gang gis kyang drin lan mi lon la/ lan du re ba gzhan byang chub sems dpa' la med pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di ni longs spyod rnams la ma chags dang sogs nas/ de bzhin lan du phan 'dogs yin zhes pas bstan to/ /

“Hoping for the recompense of good qualities in others.” When other beings, having been induced to practice the transcendent perfections, acquire the excellent qualities of the six transcendent perfections, the bodhisattvas’ wishes are fulfilled and they feel that those sentient beings have benefited them. All they hope for in return for their help is that others should gain the corresponding good qualities; they wish for no other reward. For it is by thinking, “If only sentient beings could have the excellent qualities of the transcendent perfections,” that they bring beings to maturity, and when those sentient beings become mature, they completely fulfill the bodhisattvas’ hopes. This is what we call “keeping in mind the desire for recompense.” There is nothing greater in repayment of the bodhisattvas’ kindness than that the sentient beings whom they have introduced to the transcendent perfections should acquire the qualities of the transcendent perfections. No other recompense can ever repay that kindness, because there is nothing else that bodhisattvas might wish for in return. This is described in verses 24 and 25 of chapter 20 from “Because they are not attached to wealth…” to “Similarly benefit bodhisattvas in return.”

gsum du smon dang zhes pa re ba yid byed dam 'dod pa yid la byed pa yin te/ ci zhig 'dod ce na 'di gsum du re zhing 'dod de/ sems can thams cad byang chub sems dpa'i sa'i mthar thug par re ba'am 'dod pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi sa'i mthar thug par re ba dang / sems can gyi don byed par re ba'o/ / de'i dang po sa dang por sbyin pa'i phar phyin rdzogs pa'i sbyin pa'i sa mthar thug pa nas/ sa bcu bar ye shes kyi phar phyin rdzogs nas byang chub sems dpa'i sa bcu mthar phyin par 'dod pa dang / gnyis pa sa bcu 'das nas sangs rgyas kyis mthar thug gi 'bras bu thob par 'dod pa dang / gsum pa byang chub sems dpa'i dus dang sangs rgyas nas sems can thams cad la phan bde byed par 'dod pa'o/ / 'di ni gzhung du/ rtag tu 'phel dang sogs tshigs bcad gcig gis bstan to/ /

“A threefold aspiration” refers to keeping hopes in mind or keeping wishes in mind. What do bodhisattvas wish for? They hope and wish for three things: that all sentient beings will complete the bodhisattva levels, that they will finally achieve the level of buddhahood, and that they will benefit beings. With regard to the first of these, bodhisattvas want beings to reach the culmination of the ten bodhisattva levels, from the ultimate reach of generosity which is the completion of transcendent generosity on the first level through to the completion of transcendent gnosis on the tenth level. Second, they want them to go beyond the ten levels and attain the ultimate result, buddhahood. Third, they want them to bring benefit and happiness to all sentient beings, both while they are bodhisattvas and once they have attained buddhahood. In the root text this is indicated by the verse, “For beings and themselves….”[73]

rgyun du'o/ /zhes pa phar phyin bar 'ga' spyod/ bar 'ga' mi spyod pa lta bu ma yin par chu bo'i rgyun bzhin rgyun mi chad par spyod pa ni rgyun du yid la byed pa zhes bya ste/ 'di ni gdams ngag dang rjes su bstan pa'i don chud mi za bar nyams su len pa yin te/ 'jigs spang yang dag bskyed sogs rgyal sras rtag tu chud mi za/ /zhes pa'i tshigs bcad gcig gis so/ /

“Continuity” refers to what we call “keeping continuity in mind”—that is, practicing the transcendent perfections uninterruptedly, like the flow of a river, rather than practicing sometimes and not at other times. This means actually putting the instructions and follow-up teachings into practice and not letting them go to waste. It is indicated by “In their absence of fear…the buddhas’ heirs are never wasteful.”[74]
sangs rgyas bstan pa bsgrub pa'i phyir/ / tshu rol mi gnas sems pa dang / / des sman dar ba'i sems can la/ / mi dga' ba dang rab dga' ba'o/ /
In order to accomplish the Buddha’s teaching, The intention to not fall short; Sadness with regard to beings who fail in that, And delight with regard to those who flourish; (XII, 70)

sangs rgyas bstan pa bsgrub pa'i phyir/ /tshu rol mi gnas sems dpa' dang / /zhes pa/ sangs rgyas kyis ji skad bstan pa bzhin du phar phyin rnam par dag pa nyid bsgrub pa ste/ dang por sems bskyed nas thos bsam byed pa nas mthar sangs rgyas ma thob kyi bar du phar phyin rnams bsgrub pa bar ma dor mi 'dor bar brtson 'grus brtsams pa ni yang dag sbyor ba yid la byed pa ste/ gzhung du re ba med pa'i sbyin pa dang sogs nas/ bstan pa rnams kyi yang dag sbyor zhes pa'i bar gyis bstan to/ / de'i phyir tshu rol mi gnas sems dpa' dang zhes sbyin sogs la spyad kyang de'i 'bras bu 'khor ba'i longs spyod 'dod pa sogs tshu rol 'jig rten pa'i spyod yul la mi gnas par sems pa'o/ / tshig rkang gcig po 'di ni bshad pa 'grel bar mi snang la gong la sbyar med pas gong du yar sbyar dgos so snyam ste dpyad par byos shig /

“In order to accomplish the Buddha’s teaching, the intention to not fall short.” To accomplish the transcendent perfections authentically as taught by the Buddha, from the moment one first arouses bodhicitta and then listens and reflects, and until one finally attains buddhahood, one must be diligent in unrelentingly practicing the transcendent perfections. This constitutes keeping in mind perfect application, which in the root text is indicated by “Generosity without expectation,…are applying them authentically.”[75] In order to do that, one must have “the intention to not fall short,” that is, the intention that in one’s practice of generosity and the rest, one will not fall short and remain mundane in one’s scope, with a desire for the samsaric riches and so on that will result from that practice. This line is not explained in the commentary, but I think it should be linked to the previous line, which is not linked to anything; this is a point that should be checked.

des dman dar ba'i sems can la/ /mi dga' ba dang rang dga' ba'o/ /zhes pa/ phar phyin des dman pa ni phar phyin gyi spyod pa nyams par gyur par mthong na de mi mos pa ni mi dga' ba yid la byed pa'o/ / sbyin sogs spyod pa 'phel zhing dar ba'i sems can mthong na de la mos pa ni dga' ba yid la byed pa ste/ gzhung du 'di gnyis longs spyod chags dang sogs tshigs bcad gnyis kyis so/ /

“Sadness with regard to beings who fail in that, and delight with regard to those who flourish.” When bodhisattvas see beings who are deficient in terms of the transcendent perfections—in other words, whose practice of the transcendent perfections has deteriorated—they lose interest in them. This constitutes keeping sadness in mind. When they see beings whose practice of generosity and the rest is increasing and progressing, they feel pleased with them. This constitutes keeping delight in mind. These two are described in the root text in the two verses beginning “Attachment to pleasure….”[76]
bsgom pa bcos dang yang dag la/ / ma dad pa dang dad pa dang / / dang du mi len yid byed dang / / lung bstan nges par dga' ba'o/ /
Not having faith in fake meditation And having faith in the authentic; Attentiveness to refusal, Pleasure from predictions and certainty; (XII, 71)

de bzhin du/ bsgom pa bcos dang yang dag la/ /ma dad pa dang dad pa dang / /zhes pa pha rol phyin pa drug ni gzugs brnyan nam bcos ma bsgom pa la ma dad pa ni mi mos pa yid la byed pa'o/ / bcos ma ni sbyin pa ma dag pa'am/ sbyin mdog byed pa sogs nas/ shes rab rnam par ma dag pa'i bar ro/ / yang dag pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa rnams bsgom pa la dad pa na mos pa yid la byed pa'o/ / 'di gnyis/ sprul pa dang ni sogs tshigs bcad gnyis kyis bstan pa bzhin no/ / dang du mi len yid byed dang zhes pa/ rang gzhan gyi rgyud la ser sna sogs phar phyin rnams kyi mi mthun phyogs byung na shes rab dang ldan pa'i gnyen pos 'dul bar byed cing dang du mi len pa ni/ dang du mi len pa yid la byed pa'o/ / 'di ni blo ldan de dag sa kun tu zhes sogs tshigs bcad gcig gis bstan pa bzhin no/ /

Similarly, there is “Not having faith in fake meditation and having faith in the authentic.” Not having faith in practicing a fake version or effigy of the six transcendent perfections constitutes keeping disinterest in mind. “Fake” here refers to impure generosity (or a semblance of generosity) and other impure perfections through to impure wisdom.[77] Having faith in the practice of genuine transcendent perfections constitutes keeping interest in mind. These two are indicated by the two verses beginning with “Making a show….”[78] “Attentiveness to refusal” refers to keeping in mind the refusal to accept stinginess and other traits running counter to the transcendent perfections, should they occur in one’s own or others’ mind streams, and correcting them with the antidotes, in association with wisdom. This is indicated by the verse “The wise, on all the levels,….”[79]

lung bstan zhes pa de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyis rigs kyi bu khyod ji srid cig na pha rol tu phyin pa rnams rdzogs nas bla na med pa'i byang chub tu 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur ro zhes lung bstan pa thob pa la dga' ba'am 'dod pa ni/ lung bstan par 'dod pa'o/ / yang na sa brgyad pa'i dus su lung bstan pas na sa brgyad pa thob par 'dod pa 'di ni/ lung bstan pa ji lta bu zhe na gang zag dus kyi bye brag gis sogs tshigs bcad gsum gyis bstan pa bzhin no/ / nges par dga' ba'o zhes pa nges pa'i sa la gnas pa thob par 'dod pa yid la byed pa ste/ de la longs spyod nges par 'dod pa dang / skye ba nges par 'dod pa gnyis kyi dang po/ sbyin pa'i phar phyin rdzogs pa sa dang po thob pa na skad cig la sangs rgyas brgya mthong ba dang / zhing brgya g.yo ba sogs yon tan brgya phrag bcu gnyis po sa nas sar gong du 'phel te ye shes kyi pha rol tu phyin pa rdzogs pa sa bcu pa'i dus su ngag yid kyi spyod yul ma yin pa'i zhing gi rdul snyed kyi grangs dang mnyam pa thob pa'i bar gyi mthu bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i 'byor pa dang rig pa'i gnas lnga la mkhas pa'i 'byor pa 'dod pa'o / /skye ba nges par 'dod pa ni sa bcu pa thob nas skye ba gcig gis thogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' thob par 'dod pa'o/ /skabs 'di/ blo ldan rnam pa thams cad du/ /phun tshogs skye dang sogs tshigs bcad gcig dang rkang pa gnyis kyis bstan to/ /

“Predictions” refers to the wish for predictions—the pleasure in receiving or desire to receive predictions from the tathāgatas: “Fortunate child, one day, when you have completed the transcendent perfections, you will attain buddhahood in unsurpassable enlightenment.” Alternatively, since bodhisattvas receive predictions at the time of the eighth level, it is the desire to attain the eighth level. The different kinds of predictions are indicated by the three verses beginning with “Specifying the individual and the time….”[80] “Pleasure from…certainty” refers to keeping in mind the desire to attain the level of certainty. This has two aspects: wishing for certainty with regard to wealth and wishing for certainty with regard to birth. Concerning the first of these, when one attains the first level, the level on which transcendent generosity is completed, in one instant one can see one hundred buddhas, shake one hundred worlds, and so on—in all, twelve sets of one hundred extraordinary qualities. From that level, one progresses from one level to the next until at the time of the tenth level, on which transcendent gnosis is completed, one obtains qualities equal in number to the atoms in the universe, beyond the scope of words or thought. To wish for the wealth of all these inconceivable powers and the wealth of expertise in the five sciences constitutes the wish for certainty with regard to wealth. Wishing for certainty with regard to birth is the desire to reach the level of a bodhisattva who has attained the tenth level and has only one more rebirth to go. This point is indicated by six lines beginning “For the wise, at all times, abundance, birth….”[81]

phyi ma'i tshe la mthong ba'i phyir/ / 'jug sems mnyam par blta ba'i phyir/ / mchog chos rnams la zhugs pa yis/ / bdag nyid mchog tu nges 'dzin phyir/ / pha rol phyin bcu'i rgyus byung ba/ / dge ba yid la byed 'di dag / rtag tu byang chub sems dpa' yi/ / khams ni brtas par byed pa yin/ /

The intention to practice with a view to future lives, Looking to equality, And, on account of engagement in the highest Dharma, The conviction of one’s own greatness— (XII, 72) Keeping in mind the virtue that results From the ten transcendent perfections Makes the potential within a bodhisattva Constantly unfold and grow. (XII, 73)

phyi ma'i tshe la mthong ba'i phyir/ /'jug sems zhes pa ma 'ongs pa phyi ma'i dus na mthong bas 'jug pa yid la byed pa ste/ byang chub tu sems bskyed nas bla med byang chub 'dod na de'i rgyu phar phyin rnams tshe rabs gang du skyes kyang spyad dgos par mthong nas/ tshe 'dir phar phyin drug la rgyun du 'jug pas sems sam yid byed kyis phar phyin drug gis spyod pa spyad na/ de'i rgyu mthun phyi ma'i tshe rabs rnams la yang phar phyin la 'jug pa mthong ba'i phyir de ltar bsams nas phar phyin la 'jug pa'o/ / mnyam par blta ba'i phyir zhes pa bdag gis kyang phar phyin rnams la rgyun du sbyangs pas na byang chub sems dpa' gzhan rnams dang lus ngag yid gsum mnyam mo snyam du rtog pa ni mnyam par rtog pa yid la byed pa'o/ /

“The intention to practice with a view to future lives” refers to keeping one’s practice in mind with a view to future lives. Once one has aroused the mind intent on enlightenment, if one wants to attain unsurpassable enlightenment, wherever one is reborn in one’s future lives one will have to practice the causal factors that lead to enlightenment—the transcendent perfections. Having seen this, one then sees that if one practices the six transcendent perfections with this intention or attentiveness while constantly practicing them in this life, the resulting effect similar to the cause will be that one will also practice the transcendent perfections in one’s future lives. This, then, is the attitude with which a bodhisattva practices the transcendent perfections. “Looking to equality” refers to keeping in mind the thought of equality—that is, the thought, “By training constantly in the transcendent perfections, I will be the same, physically, verbally, and mentally, as other bodhisattvas.”

mchog chos rnams la zhugs pa yis/ /bdag nyid mchog tu nges 'dzin phyir/ /zhes pa bdag mchog tu 'dzin pa yid la byed pa ste/ lam mchog tu gyur pa pha rol tu phyin pa drug la spyod pas 'bras bu byang chub sems dpa'i sa dang sangs rgyas kyi sa thob pas/ lam dang 'bras bu mchog gi chos rnams la zhugs pa yis bdag ni nyan rang dang bcas pa'i sems can rnams kyi mchog las mchog tu 'phags par nges par 'dzin pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar pha rol tu phyin pa bcu la dmigs pa'am de dag gis bsdus pa'i chos kyi rgyu las byung ba yi dge ba yid la byed pa 'di dag ni rtag tu byang chub sems dpa' yi rgyud la phar phyin bcu yi khams ni rgyas par byed pa yin no/ / phyi ma 'di gsum gdon mi za bar bya ba dang / rtag tu bya ba dang / phar phyin gyi mchog gam gtso bo bstan pa'i tshigs bcad lnga dang sbyor ro/ /

“On account of engagement in the highest Dharma, the conviction of one’s own greatness” refers to keeping one’s own greatness in mind. By practicing the six transcendent perfections, which constitute the highest path, one attains its result, the bodhisattva levels and buddha level. So because one is engaged in the highest Dharma, both as path and as result, one considers that one is definitely far superior to the highest of beings, including the listeners and solitary realizers. Thinking of the ten transcendent perfections like this, or keeping in mind the virtue that stems from the causal factors that they embody, makes the potential for the ten transcendent perfections in a bodhisattva’s mind constantly grow. These last three kinds of attentiveness correspond to the four verses that indicate definite duties, perpetual duties, and the paramount activities of the transcendent perfections.[82]

'di man chad la yid byed ma gsungs pa ni yon tan le'u'i chos dang bden pa rigs pa theg pa rnam par bzhag pa bzhi chos tshol sogs su 'dus zin pa dang / de man chad byang chub sems dpa'i bsngags pa yin pa dang / spyod pa'i le'u'i rtags nas sa'i bar lam gyi gnas skabs tsam yin la 'bras chos kyi tshigs bcad rnams byang chub kyi yon tan yin pas 'di rnams la yid byed sger du sbyar mi dgos te gong du 'dus pa'i phyir ro/ /

After that, there are a number of factors to be kept in mind that are not mentioned here because the four sections that present the teachings, the truth, rational application, and vehicles in the Qualities chapter have already been included in investigating the Dharma, and so on; and because the subsequent sections are a praise of the bodhisattva, and those in the Conduct chapter from the signs of a bodhisattva to the levels deal with just the temporary qualities of the path, while the verses on the resultant qualities deal with the qualities of enlightenment, for all of which it is not necessary to ascribe specific factors to be kept in mind as they are included in the above.

rgyu dmigs nas dga' ba yid byed nas bdag mchog tu 'dzin pa'i yid byed kyi bar nang gi bye brag 'ga' zhig so sor ma brtsis par spyir rnam grangs lnga bcu nga gcig tsam 'dug la/ yid byed 'di thams cad pha rol tu phyin pa'i khams rgyas byed du gsungs pa 'dir/ gzhung 'di'i le'u gong 'og gi mdo chings lta bur yang mthong ste/ rgyu dmigs sogs bdun po 'dis/ skyabs 'gro nas byang chub bar gyi le'u bcu'i don yang spyir bsdus te/ rgyu dmigs zhes pas rigs dang / rten la de rjes dran zhes pas lam gyi gzhi rten sems bskyed pa nang gi rten dang / sems bskyed len pa'i yul lam phyi'i rten mchog gsum yang bzung nas skyabs 'gro yang bsdus la/ ji ltar byang chub kyis de kho na nyid dang byang chub/ lhag ma bzhis mthu dang yongs smin sgrub pa rnams shugs kyis bzung bas le'u'i go rims ltar sbyar du med kyang don tshang bar snang la/ de man chad nas mos pa sogs dang go rims mtshungs par 'dug pa gong du bshad zin to/ /

In general, not counting any of the subdivisions, there are about fifty-one kinds of attentiveness, from keeping in mind joy from considering the cause (verse 61) to keeping one’s own greatness in mind (verse 72). All these kinds of attentiveness, it is taught, make the potential for transcendent perfection grow. I see that they also, as it were, summarize the earlier and later chapters in this text, for the seven lines beginning “Joy from considering the cause…”[83] are also a general summary of the meaning of the chapters from “Refuge” up to “Enlightenment.” “Joy from considering the cause” summarizes the chapter on the potential. “Mindfulness of the support,” summarizes the chapters on the spiritual intent, the inner support, which is the foundation of the path, and the refuge, in that the outer support or object from whom one receives the vow of bodhicitta is the Three Jewels. “A yearning for a similar enlightenment” refers to the chapters on thatness and enlightenment. The remaining four lines implicitly cover the chapters on powers, full maturation, and practice. Thus, although they do not follow the order of the chapters, their import appears to be complete. The different kinds of attentiveness that are mentioned after that correspond to the correct order of the chapters, beginning with the chapter on interest, as has already been explained above.
gsum pa yongs su tshol ba'i bye brag bshad pa/
3. SPECIFIC KINDS OF THOROUGH INVESTIGATION
bshad par bya ba lung gis chos dang khong du chud par bya ba rtogs pa'i chos ji ltar btsal ba de yang bye brag tu phyes nas rnam grangs bcu gsum gyis bstan pa ni/
The investigation of the Dharma of transmission that is to be explained and the Dharma of realization that is to be mastered can be divided into thirteen categories.
rgyas dang lhag pa'i bsam dang chen po ni/ / brtan pa'i yongs su tshol ba yin par 'dod/ / de dag gi ni spang dang bcas pa dang / / spang bya med dang de bzhin dbang 'byor pa'o/ /

Developing, possessed of superior mentality, and great— Such is held to be the thorough investigation of the steadfast. Their investigation is accompanied by factors to be eliminated, Is free of such factors, and is mastered. (XII, 74)
ces tshigs bcad gnyis kyis bstan te/

de yang so so'i skye bo'i dus na dam pa'i chos nyan pa dang sems pa nas brtsams te mos pa spyod pa'i sa 'jig rten chos mchog man chad du chos btsal ba ni/ thar pa'i sa bon rgyas par byed pas rgyas pa zhes bya ba dang / mos spyod pa 'jig rten chos mchog gi tshe chos kyi sgo'i rgyun gyi ting nge 'dzin rnyed pa brtsams te sa dang po nas bdun pa'i bar gyi tshe na ni lhag pa'i bsam pa dang ldan pa zhes bya ste/ bdag med gnyis rtogs pa dang bdag gzhan mnyam pa'i sems rnyed pa'i phyir ro/ / sa brgyad pa nas bcu pa'i bar gyi chos rtogs pa ni chen po zhes bya ste rnam par mi rtog pa lhun gyis grub pa'i ye shes thob pa'i phyir ro/ de ltar rtogs pa'i phye ba'i rnam grangs gsum ni/ brtan pa byang sems rnams kyi chos yongs su tshol ba yin par 'dod do/ / yang byang sems de dag gi ni 'jig rten chos mchog man chad mos spyod kyi sa na spang bya bar chad dang bcas pa ste/ bsam pa mi brtan pa dang / dge sdig gi grogs kyis 'gyur ba dang / sgrib gnyis ma spangs pa dang / sa dang po nas bdun pa'i bar spang bya bar chad kyi chos de dag med pas bar chad med pa dang / de bzhin du sa brgyad pa nas bcu pa'i bar gyi chos rtogs pa ni dbang 'byor ba zhes bya ste rnam par mi rtog pa dang / mngon shes dang / sangs rgyas kyi zhing yongs su sbyang bar lhun gyis grub par dbang 'byor ba'i phyir ro/ /

At the stage of an ordinary being on the level of earnest aspiration, beginning by listening to the sacred teachings and reflecting on them, and up to the supreme mundane level, investigating the Dharma is referred to as “developing,” since it makes the seed of liberation grow. From the moment someone on the path of earnest aspiration acquires the concentration of the stream of the door of Dharma at the time of the supreme mundane level, and then from the first bodhisattva level up to the seventh, investigation is referred to as “possessed of superior mentality” because one has acquired realization of the two kinds of no-self and of the sameness of oneself and others. From the eighth level up to the tenth, one’s realization of the Dharma is called “great,” because one acquires spontaneous nonconceptual gnosis. These three categories of realization are held to correspond to the thorough investigation of the Dharma by steadfast bodhisattvas. Again, on the level of earnest aspiration up to the supreme mundane level, those bodhisattvas’ investigation is accompanied by obstacles that have to be eliminated: their intention is unstable; they are influenced by the company they keep (virtuous or evil); and they have not eliminated the two kinds of obscurations. From the first level up to the seventh, their investigation does not have those obstructing factors to be eliminated and is therefore unhindered. Similarly, from the eighth up to the tenth, their realization of the Dharma is known as “mastered,” because they have spontaneously mastered nonconceptuality, preternatural knowledge, and complete purification of realms as buddha fields. These make three categories in terms of elimination.
byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi tshol ba ni/ / sku med pa dang sku bcas sku thob dang / / sku yongs rdzogs dang nga rgyal mang ba dang / / nga rgyal phra dang nga rgyal med par 'dod/ /
Bodhisattvas’ investigation is said to be Lacking the buddha body, body-associated, body-attained, And body-complete; and also with much pride, With subtle pride, and without pride. (XII, 75)

de ltar spang bya'i sgo nas dbye ba gsum dang / yang byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi chos tshol ba ni/ thob pa'i sgo nas phye na bzhi ste/ so so'i skye bo tshogs lam dang sbyor lam bzod pa'i bar du/ chos sku'i rigs 'dra'i rgyu rnam par mi rtog ma thob pas chos kyi sku med pa dang / 'jig rten chos mchog gi dus na gzung 'dzin spangs pas chos sku'i cha shas rnyed pas sku dang bcas pa zhes 'grel chen du gsungs / kha cig mos spyod tshogs lam 'bring gi bar sku med pa dang / tshogs lam chen po chos rgyun gyi ting nge 'dzin thob pa nas sbyor lam bzhir chos sku'i rgyu mi rtog ye shes rjes mthun rim gyis rnyed pa sku bcas zhes kyang gsungs / sa dang po nas bdun pa'i bar bden don mngon sum mthong ba'i mi rtog ye shes rtsol ba dang bcas pa thob pa'i sku rnyed pa'am thob pa dang / sa brgyad pa nas bcu pa'i bar gyis mi rtog ye shes rtsol med lhun gyis grub pas sku yongs su rdzogs pa dang bzhi'o/ / yang nga rgyal yod med kyi phye ba gsum ni/ chos mchog man chad so so'i skye bo'i dus na nga rgyal gyi shas mang ba dang / sa dang po nas bdun pa'i bar du nga rgyal phra ba dang zhes kun brtags spangs pa dang sa gnyis pa nas lhan skyes kyang ci rigs su spangs pas so/ / sa brgyad pa nas bcu pa'i bar du rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes yongs su smin pas nga rgyal med par 'dod do/ /

Furthermore, bodhisattvas’ investigation of the Dharma can be divided into four categories in terms of their attainment. Ordinary beings on the path of accumulation and up to the stage of acceptance on the path of joining have not acquired nonconceptuality, which is the cause of, and analogous to, the body of truth, so their investigation is said to be lacking the body of truth. At the stage of the supreme mundane level, by eliminating the concepts of subject and object, they acquire one aspect of the body of truth, and their investigation is therefore said to be associated with the buddha body, as is explained in the Great Commentary. (Some authorities use the term “lacking the buddha body” to refer to the path of earnest aspiration until the middle path of accumulation, and “body-associated” to cover the attainment of the concentration of the stream of Dharma on the greater path of accumulation and the subsequent gradual acquisition of the emulative nonconceptual gnosis that is the cause of dharmakāya on the four stages of the path of joining.) The investigation of bodhisattvas from the first level up to the seventh who have acquired the effortful nonconceptual gnosis that directly sees the truth is “body-attained.” And from the eighth level up to the tenth, since the effortless nonconceptual gnosis is spontaneously accomplished, it is “body-complete.” Finally, there are three categories distinguished by the presence or absence of pride. At the stage of ordinary beings up to the supreme mundane level, there is a predominance of pride. From the first level up to the seventh, there is subtle pride, because imputation has been eliminated, and from the second level onward the respective innate obscurations are also eliminated. From the eighth level up to the tenth, it is said, nonconceptual gnosis is fully matured and there is therefore no pride.
bzhi pa chos yongs su btsal ba'i 'bras bu
4. THE RESULTS OF INVESTIGATING THE DHARMA
['di] la yon tan 'grub pa dang / spang bya spang ba gnyis las
There are two categories of results: (1) the accomplishment of good qualities and (2) riddance of concepts that have to be eliminated.
dang po/
a. THE ACCOMPLISHMENT OF GOOD QUALITIES
brtan chos gzugs dang gzugs min la/ / mtshan dang de bzhin nad med dang / / mngon shes rnams kyi dbang phyug dang / / de zad mi shes nyid kyi rgyu/ /
The Dharma of the steadfast is the source Of qualities material and immaterial— The marks, and likewise freedom from disease— Of mastery in preternatural knowledge, and inexhaustibility. (XII, 76)
zhes tshigs bcad gcig gis bstan te/

brtan pa rnams kyi chos yongs su tshol ba'i 'bras bu gzugs can lus dang / gzugs can min pa sems la rim pa bzhin gzugs kyi yon tan mtshan bzang po sum cu rtsa gnyis dang de'i cha shas dpe byad brgyad cu 'grub par 'gyur te chos thos bsam bsgom pa'i sgo nas de dag 'grub pa'i phyir ro/ / de bzhin du gzugs min pa tshor 'du 'du byed rnam shes kyi phung po bzhi la 'dod chags dang zhe sdang sogs nyon mongs pa'i nad med par byed pa'i rgyu yang chos yin te chos shes nas nyams su blangs pas mthong sgom gyi spang bya'i nyon mongs pa thams cad gtan du zhi bar byed pa'i phyir ro/ / mngon par shes pa rnams kyi dbang phyug thob pa yang chos la brten nas 'byung ba dang / lhag med myang 'das na yang stobs sogs yon tan mi zad pa yang chos la brtson pa las 'byung bas na de ltar chos btsal zhing nyams su blangs pas gzugs can gyi yon tan dang gzugs min gyi yon tan nyon mongs pa'i nad zhi ba dang / dbang phyug dang / mi zad pa bzhi thob pa'i phyir/ tshangs pas zhus pa'i mdo las/ chos bzhi dang ldan na byang chub sems dpas chos tshol bar 'gyur ro/ / bzhi ni dkon pa'i phyir rin po cher 'du shes pa/ nad med pa'i rgyu'i phyir sman du 'du shes pa/ mngon par shes pas phyug pa'i phyir nor du 'du shes pa/ mi zad pa'i rgyu'i phyir mya ngan 'das par 'du shes pa'o/ /zhes gsungs pa'ang /

The results of steadfast bodhisattvas’ full investigation of the Dharma are physical or material, and mental or immaterial. Taken in order, the physical qualities that will be accomplished are the thirty-two major marks and, related to these, the eighty minor marks. These are accomplished by listening to, reflecting on, and meditating on the Dharma. Similarly, the causal factor that abolishes the disease of the defilements of attachment, aversion, and the rest in the four immaterial aggregates (feeling, perception, conditioning factors, and consciousness) is the Dharma, for by knowing the Dharma and putting it into practice, one removes forever all the defilements that have to be eliminated on the paths of seeing and meditation. Attainment of mastery in preternatural knowledge also depends on the Dharma. And even the inexhaustible qualities of the nirvāṇa without residue—the ten strengths and so on—arise through diligence in the Dharma. So it is by investigating the Dharma and putting it into practice that one obtains these four kinds of qualities—physical marks, immaterial virtues (the curing of the disease of defilements), mastery, and inexhaustibility. As we read in the Sūtra of the Questions of Brahmaviśeṣacintin: If they possess four notions, bodhisattvas will investigate the Dharma. These four are to consider that the Dharma is very rare and therefore precious; to consider it as medicine, for it results in freedom from disease; to consider it as riches on account of its wealth of preternatural knowledge; and to consider it as nirvāṇa, for it results in inexhaustibility.

chos ni dus res 'ga' las phrad dka' zhing / phrad na don che bas rin po che ltar 'dod pa 'jo ba yin la skabs 'dir rin po che mdzes shing dag pa lta bu'i mtshan dpe'ang 'jig rten na dkon pas chos la rin po che'i 'du shes su bya ba dang / sman gyis nad sel ba ltar chos kyi bdud rtsi sman gzhan gyis gso mi nus pa nyon mongs pa'i nad zhi ba'i sman chen por 'du shes pa dang / 'jig rten gyi nor ni nyung zhing rgya chung la 'dzad pas 'jig pa dang bcas shing dam pa'i chos kyis mngon par shes pa sogs kyi mthu phun sum tshogs pa 'dzad pa med pa'i dbang phyug chen po thob pas nor du 'du shes pa dang / dam pa'i chos ni skye ba dang rga ba sogs kyi sdug bsngal thams cad gtan du zad par byed pa'i gnyen po yin pas gtan du bde ba'am gang thob nas gtan du mi zad pa zhi ba bsil ba bde ba gya nom pa'i bdag nyid mya ngan las 'das pa lta bu'i 'du shes su bya ba'o/ /

Apart from occasionally, it is difficult to come across the Dharma, and to meet with it is of great significance, for it fulfills all one’s wishes like a precious gem. In this context, it is because of the rarity in this world of the major and minor marks—as rare as a beautiful, pure jewel—that the Dharma is to be considered so precious. Like medicine curing an illness, the nectar of the Dharma is to be considered as a great medicine that cures the disease of the defilements, which no other medicine can treat. With the sacred Dharma, one obtains the great mastery of abundant, inexhaustible powers such as preternatural knowledge, so it should be considered as riches, worldly riches being meager and volatile. The sacred Dharma is the remedy that brings to an end forever all the sufferings of birth, aging, and so on, so it should be considered as being like everlasting bliss or nirvāṇa—peace, coolth, happiness, the nature of perfection, which once obtained is never exhausted.
gnyis pa/
b. RIDDANCE OF CONCEPTS THAT HAVE TO BE ELIMINATED
