rgyal ba'i sras rnams kyis ni yod dang med pa dang / / sgro 'dogs skur ba'i rtog dang gcig dang du ma nyid/ / rang dang khyad par rtog dang ming don ji bzhin du/ / mngon par zhen pa'i rtog pa yang dag spang bar bya/ /

Children of the buddhas should completely abandon The concepts of existence and nonexistence, of superimposition and negation, The concepts of unity and multiplicity, of intrinsic nature and particularity, And the concepts of clinging to names and objects as real. (XII, 77)
zhes pas bstan te/

chos yongs su btsal bas spang bya bcu spong ste gang zhe na/ de kho na nyid rtogs pa'i mi mthun phyogs rnam g.yeng gi rnam par rtog pa bcu shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa las gsungs pa 'di lta ste/ rgyal ba'i sras po chos tshol ba rnams kyis ni yod pa dang / med pa dang / sgro 'dogs pa dang / skur ba 'debs pa'i rnam par rtog pa bzhi dang / de bzhin du gcig par rnam par rtog pa dang / du ma nyid dam tha dad du rnam par rtog pa dang / chos rnams kyi rang gi ngo bo nyid du rnam par rtog pa dang / de'i khyad par du rnam par rtog pa dang / ming ji lta ba bzhin du don la rnam par rtog pa dang / don ji lta ba bzhin du ming la mngon par zhen pa'i rnam par rtog pa bcu po chos kyi don shes pa'i sgo nas yang dag par spang bar bya'o/ /zhes gsungs te/

By thoroughly investigating the Dharma, bodhisattvas get rid of ten objects of elimination. These are the ten distracting concepts mentioned in the Perfection of Wisdom that conflict with the realization of thatness. By knowing the meaning of the teachings, children of the buddhas who investigate the Dharma should completely abandon these ten concepts: the four concepts of existence, nonexistence, superimposition, and negation and similarly, the concept of unity, the concept of multiplicity or of distinct entities, the concept of phenomena as intrinsic entities, the concept of their particularities, the concept of objects as names, and the conceptual clinging to names as objects.

shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa stong phrag brgya pa las/ byang chub sems dpa' yod bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' yang dag par rjes su mi mthong zhes gsungs pa/ stong pa nyid ces pa'i don chos rnams tha snyad du med par 'dzin pa ni chad pa'i stong pa yin pas bsal bya yin te/ gzhan dbang rten cing 'brel 'byung gi snang ba yod pa dang / don dam pa yongs grub chos nyid du yod pa ni yod pa la yod par yang dag par rtog pa yin pas mtha' min no/ / med pa'i mtha' bsal ba byang chub sems dpa' yod bzhin du zhes pas tha snyad rten 'brel gyi snang ba 'di gang zag yod par bstan to/ / de lta na yang byis pa so so'i skye bo rnams kyis kun brtags pa ltar gang zag gi bdag yod par bzung na yod pa'i mtha' yin pas de sel byed kyi gnyen por byang chub sems dpa' yang dag par rjes su mi mthong zhes gsungs te gang zag tu snang yang de la bdag ces bya ba'i dngos po med de bdag phung po dang gcig ma yin la tha dad du yang mi dmigs pa'i phyir ro/ /

It is said in the Perfection of Wisdom in One Hundred Thousand Lines: “[Seeing] a bodhisattva as existing is not seeing the bodhisattva correctly.” The belief that “emptiness” means that phenomena do not exist conventionally is a nihilistic emptiness, and it is therefore to be dispelled. The dependent reality exists as dependently arising appearances, and in ultimate truth the fully present reality exists as ultimate reality. It is correct to think this, that what exists does exist, and this is therefore not an extreme. To dispel the extreme of nonexistence, “a bodhisattva as existing” indicates that conventionally this interdependent appearance as a bodhisattva exists—there is an individual there. However, when immature, ordinary beings take it as existing as an individual self in the same way that it is imputed, this is the extreme of existence, and the antidote that dispels it is the statement, “not seeing the bodhisattva correctly.” There is an individual that appears, but there is nothing that is a “self,” for the self and the aggregates are not one and the same, nor are they observed to be different and distinct.

des gang zag la bdag med par bstan nas 'di man chad kyis chos la bdag med par ston te/ sgro 'dogs dang skur ba'i mtha' bsal ba'i gnyen por/ gzugs ni ngo bo nyid kyis stong ste/ stong pa nyid kyis kyang ma yin no zhes/ gzugs la sogs pa'i chos rnams snang yang de dang de'i ngo bor grub pa med pas ngo bo nyid kyis stong zhes pas gzugs kun brtags pa tsam du bstan pas don dam par yod pa'i sgro 'dogs pa bsal nas/ stong pa nyid kyis kyang ma yin zhes pa stong pa yongs grub med par skur ba 'debs pa bsal te yod med kyi shan legs par ma phyes par thams cad du med par 'dzin pa ni skur 'debs kyi lta ba'o/ / tshul de gnyis la dgongs nas yod pa'ang ma yin med pa yang ma yin zhes gnyis ka 'gog par mdzad kyi khas len gang yang med pa'i thams cad byung rgyal du dgag pa lugs 'dis ched du 'gog rgyu'i phyogs sngar 'dod pa yin no/ /

The above demonstrates that there is no self to the individual. We shall now proceed to show that there is no self in phenomena. The antidote that dispels the extremes of superimposition and nihilistic negation is to be found in “Form is devoid of intrinsic nature, but not of emptiness.” Although phenomena such as form appear, they do not exist as the nature of this or that, and for this reason they are said to be “devoid of intrinsic nature,” showing that form is a mere imputation and thus dispelling the superimposition of ultimate existence. Subsequently, with “but not [devoid] of emptiness,” we dispel the nihilistic negation to the effect that the empty fully present reality does not exist—the negationist view being the belief that everything is completely nonexistent, without making a clear distinction between existence and nonexistence. With these two approaches in mind, the Buddha refuted them both: “Neither do things exist, nor do they not exist.” But he did so without making any assertions, refuting all incompatible views as and when they were presented. This system is held to be specifically for refuting the above positions.

gcig pa nyid rnam par rtog pa'i gnyen po/ gzugs kyi stong pa nyid gang yin pa de gzugs ma yin/ gzugs gang yin pa de stong pa nyid ma yin zhes gsungs te/ chos can gzugs la sogs pa dang chos nyid stong pa nyid do/ / kun brtags pa dang yongs grub gnyis gcig ma yin te/ snga ma dpyad mi bzod pa 'khrul pa'i blo'i yul dang phyi ma dpyad bzod pa ma 'khrul pa'i blo'i yul yin pas so/ /

The antidote to the concept of unity is “The emptiness of form is not form; form is not emptiness”—referring to phenomena such as form that have attributes and to their true nature, which is emptiness. The imputed reality and fully present reality are not one and the same. The former does not stand up to analysis and is the object of the deluded mind; the latter withstands analysis and is the object of the undeluded mind.

tha dad par rnam par rtog pa'i gnyen por/ gzugs stong pa'o/ / stong pa nyid gzugs so/ / gzugs las kyang stong pa nyid gzhan ma yin no/ / stong pa nyid las gzugs gzhan ma yin no/ /zhes gsungs te/ chos can nam gzung 'dzin gnyis su snang ba de nyid stong par gnas kyi de las logs shig na stong pa nyid ces bya ba med de me'i tsha ba bzhin du chos de dag gi rang bzhin stong pa nyid yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

As the antidote to the concept that things are distinct and different, it is said, “Form is emptiness; emptiness is form. Emptiness is no other than form; form is no other than emptiness.” Phenomena with attributes, or dualistic appearances as subject and object, are themselves empty, and there is no so-called emptiness apart from that. Just as heat is the nature of fire, the nature of those phenomena is emptiness.

de skad du yang mdo sde dgongs pa nges par 'grel ba las/ 'du byed khams dang don dam mtshan nyid ni/ / gcig dang tha dad bral ba'i mtshan nyid de/ / gcig dang tha dad nyid du gang rtogs pa/ / de dag tshul bzhin ma yin zhugs pa yin/ / zhes gcig dang tha dad du 'dod pa re re la yang skyon bzhi re bzhi re gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

This is also stated in Unraveling the Intent: Compounded phenomena and the ultimate truth are not the same, nor are they different. Those who think of them as being identical or different are mistaken. And for each of these two beliefs, that they are the same or different, it points out four unwanted consequences.[84]

bum pa lta bu rang gi ngo bo nyid du rtog pa dang / bum pa mi rtag pa lta bu de'i khyad par gyi chos su rtog pa de gnyis kyi gnyen por gzugs gang yin pa de ni ming tsam mo zhes sogs gsungs pa ming dang brdas bzhag pa tsam ma gtogs don rang gi ngo bo gzugs su rung ba dang myong ba sogs dang sa sra ba chu gsher ba sogs kyi mtshan nyid dam ngo bo nyid dam rang bzhin gang yang med ces so/ / khyad par du rtog pa'i gnyen po gzugs skye ba yang med/ 'gag pa yang med/ kun nas nyon mongs pa ma yin/ rnam par byang ba yang ma yin sogs chos thams cad la de ltar sbyar te gsungs pa bzhin/ don dam par chos gang yang ngo bo med pa de la skye ba la sogs pa'i khyad par thams cad kyang yod pa ma yin no/ /

As the antidote to both the concept of intrinsic reality (that of a vase, for example), and the concept of particularities (for example, that a vase is impermanent), it is said, “Form is merely a name….” Apart from their merely being designated by names and their expressions,[85] there is in objects nothing intrinsic whatsoever that exists—no nature or essence or essential attribute such as functionality in form, experience in feeling, solidity in earth, or wetness in water. The antidote to the concept of particularity is that form has no production, it has no cessation, neither is it defilement, nor is it purity, and so on, and this applies to all phenomena, as has been taught in the Perfection of Wisdom. In ultimate truth, there are no phenomena that exist intrinsically, nor are there any particularities such as production that exist.

bum pa sogs kyi ming brjod pa na ming don 'dres nas ming ji lta ba bzhin don du rtog pa dang / don bum pa sogs kyi dngos po la ji lta ba bzhin ming du rtog pa'i gnyen por/ ming ni bcos ma rdzun pa zhes sogs gsungs te/ ming don gnyis ngo bos 'brel ba med kyang skyes bus don de go bar bya phyir glo bur brda byas pa tsam la byis pa rnams kyis ming bzhin du don der 'dzin pa dang / don mthong na don de ji lta ba bzhin 'di ni ming 'di zhes bya'o zhes 'dzin pa ni byis pa'i blos ming dang don du sgro btags pa ste yang dag par na brjod bya'i don gang yang ma grub pas rjod byed kyi ming yang mi 'grub ste/ chos thams cad ni ming gis brjod du med pa ming dang bral ba yin pas ming tsam yang dmigs su med do zhes so/ /

When one utters a name such as “vase,” one associates the name and the object and thinks of the object as if it were the name, and of the name as if it were the object—the vase, for example. The antidote to this is “Name is a counterfeit, a lie.” Although there is no intrinsic connection between the name and the object, human beings, in order to make themselves understood, have adventitiously created expressions and symbols. But immature beings apprehend the object as if it were the name, and when they see an object, they refer to it by its name as if the name were the object. This kind of apprehension is a superimposition on names and objects by the immature mind. In fact, since the object referred to does not exist in any way, neither does the name that refers to it. All phenomena are inexpressible by name; they are devoid of name, so even mere names cannot be observed.
lnga pa chos yongs su btsal ba'i che ba brjod pa'i sgo nas don bsdu ba ni/
5. CONCLUDING SUMMARY STATING THE IMPORTANCE OF THOROUGHLY INVESTIGATING THE DHARMA

de ltar blo gros dge ba brtson 'grus drag brten nas/ / de bzhin nyid bcas gnyis kyi chos nyid yongs btsal ba/ / de phyir rtag tu skye dgu rnams kyi ston par 'gyur/ / de ni rgya mtsho bzhin du yon tan rnams kyis gang / /

Those who are thus intelligent and virtuous, relying on intense diligence, Correctly investigate the nature of the two truths. Thereby, they will forever become the teachers of beings And like an ocean be filled with good qualities. (XII, 78)
zhes pas bstan te/

le'u 'dir ji skad bshad pa de ltar zab pa dang rgya che ba'i chos kun la dmigs pa'i blo gros dang / pha rol tu phyin pa dang ldan pa'i thabs kyi dge ba rgya chen po dang ldan la/ chos tshol ba la le lo dang zhum pa dang 'khrul ba med pa'i brtson 'grus drag po la brten nas/ phyin ci ma log pa de bzhin du nges pa'am yang dag par rtogs pa dang bcas pa'i sgo nas kun rdzob dang don dam pas bsdus pa bden pa'i gnyis kyi chos nyid yongs su btsal ba zhes so/ / 'di la blo brtan 'grel ba'i 'gyur ltar na/ bden pa gnyis ldan chos nyid dmigs pa na/ /zhes 'dug go / de ltar chos btsal ba de phyir dus rtag tu skye dgu rnams kyi ston par 'gyur te/ gzhan la legs par bshad pa'i chos phyin ci ma log par 'chad pa'i phyir ro/ / byang chub sems dpa' de ni rgya mtsho chen po chu dang rin po che'i tshogs kyis gang ba bzhin du lam dang 'bras bu'i chos kyi yon tan rnams kyis rgyud gang bar 'gyur ro/ /

As explained in this chapter, bodhisattvas possess the intelligence to consider all the profound and extensive teachings as well as the vast virtue of skillful means, their possession of the transcendent perfections. Relying on intense diligence in investigating the teachings, without becoming lazy, discouraged, or confused, they gain certainty as to what is not mistaken, or correct realization, and by this means thoroughly investigate the nature of the two truths comprising relative and ultimate truth. (The translation of this second line in Sthiramati’s commentary reads, “Possessed of the two truths, they see their true nature.”) As a result of investigating the Dharma in this way, they will always be the teachers of sentient beings, explaining the Excellent Dharma to others without error. Like the ocean full of water and precious things, those bodhisattvas will be filled with all the extraordinary qualities of the path and result.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ yongs su tshol ba'i le'u ste bcu gnyis pa'o// //
This completes the twelfth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on thorough investigation.
theg pa chen po mdo sde rgyan las/ chos yongs su tshol ba'i le'u ste bcu gnyis pa'i rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the twelfth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on thorough investigation.
! gzhan la chos bshad pa'i le'u
13. TEACHING THE DHARMA
'di la/ chos la ser sna med par gzhan la bstan 'os pa'i 'thad pa bstan pa/ chos bstan pa'i dgos pa/ ji ltar ston pa'i tshul/ bstan bya chos kyi rang bzhin/ de ltar bstan pa'i don bsdu ba lnga las/

This chapter is divided into five sections: (1) showing why it is worth teaching others the Dharma unstintingly; (2) the reason for teaching the Dharma; (3) how to teach the Dharma; (4) the nature of the Dharma that is taught; and (5) a summary in praise of the virtues of teaching the Dharma.
dang po/
1. SHOWING WHY IT IS WORTH TEACHING OTHERS THE DHARMA UNSTINTINGLY

byang chub sems dpa' chos yongs su 'tshol ba rnams kyis chos rnyed pa gyur te phyin ci ma log par rtogs par gyur pa na chos la ser sna med par sems can rnams la bshad par byas nas rang gi pha rol tu phyin pa rnams rdzogs pa dang sems can gzhan smin par byed pa la 'di bas lhag pa'i thabs gzhan med pas ci nas 'chad dgos te/

When bodhisattvas thoroughly investigating the Dharma have received the teachings and gained unmistaken realization of them, they explain them unstintingly to sentient beings and thereby complete their own transcendent perfections and bring other sentient beings to maturity. There is no better means for doing so than this, and one should therefore do whatever one can to teach.

brtan pa rnams ni srog dang longs spyod tshegs ches rnyed cing snying po med pa dag / rab dga'i yid kyis sems can sdug bsngal rnams la sbyin rnams rgya chen rtag gtong na/ / chos yangs skye dgu rnams la rnam pa kun tu phan byed tshegs ches rnyed min zhing / / shin tu btang yang zad med 'phel 'gyur ba lta lan cig ma yin smos ci dgos/ /

If steadfast bodhisattvas joyously and forever give away immense gifts to beings who suffer— The lives and riches they have won with such great difficulty and yet devoid of essence— Need one mention their unstintingly giving of the vast Dharma that benefits beings in every way, That is found with no great difficulty, and even when given away entirely grows inexhaustibly? (XIII, 1)
zhes tshigs bcad gcig gis bstan te/

brtan pa byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni lus sam srog sngon gyi dge ba bsags pa'i tshogs chen pos rnyed pa dang / longs spyod tshegs ches zhes rgya mtshor bgrod pa sogs dka' tshegs chen pos rnyed cing rang gir gyur pa'ang mthar 'dzad pa dang / yid brtan du rung ba'i snying po med pa dag tu shes nas sbyin pa la rab tu dga' ba'i yid kyis yul sems can sdug bsngal ba rnams la zang zing gi sbyin pa rnams/ tshul ji ltar na pha rol gyi bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par nus pa rgyal srid dam longs spyod rgya chen po dus rtag tu gtong bar byed na/ dam pa'i chos ni yangs shing rgya che ba nam yang zad par mi 'gyur ba gang zhig / de skye dgu rnams la 'di dang tshe rabs gzhan du yang rnam pa kun tu phan par byed pas zang zing gi sbyin pa dang mi 'dra bar gtan du yid brtan rung ba'i snying po yod pa/ sangs rgyas 'jig rten du byon pa dang / bstan pa gnas pa'i dus na chos 'tshol ba po rang gis kyang rgya mtshor 'jug pa sogs zang zing 'grub pa ltar tshegs ches rnyed pa min zhing bsgrub sla la/ chos kyi sbyin pa de shin tu btang yang rang rgyud kyi chos zad pa med par ma zad gong nas gong du 'phel bar 'gyur ba de dag gzhan las gzhan du yang 'phel bar 'gyur ba lta lan gcig ma yin par gtong ba ni smos ci dgos/ lta zhes pa tshigs bcad kha bskang ba'i ched de don gzhan med de/ de ltar byang chub sems dpas chos btsal nas gzhan la ston par nges pa yin no/ /

Steadfast bodhisattvas have realized that even though their bodies or lives, won with great difficulty by accumulating virtue in the past, and their wealth, acquired through great hardships such as journeying overseas,[1] belong to them, these finally come to an end and are meaningless and unreliable. So it is with sheer delight in practicing generosity that they are forever giving away material gifts to suffering beings—vast riches or dominions that can completely fulfill others’ wishes. If they can do this, then need one mention their giving away—and not just once—the vast and sacred Dharma, which will never be exhausted? Of course bodhisattvas will teach others, once they have investigated the teachings, for the Dharma benefits beings in every kind of way in both this and other lives and therefore, unlike material gifts, is utterly reliable and worthwhile. At a time when the Buddha has appeared in the world and his doctrine endures, anyone seeking the teachings can receive them quite easily without going through the enormous difficulties—setting out to sea, and so on—involved in the acquisition of material riches. And the gift of Dharma, even if given away completely, not only never runs out in the bodhisattva’s mind stream but will grow more and more, spreading from one person to the next.[2] (The Tibetan syllable lta in the last line has no significance other than completing the meter.)
gnyis pa chos bstan pa'i dgos pa ni/
2 THE REASON FOR TEACHING THE DHARMA

gang phyir so so rang rig bya phyir bcom ldan 'das kyis chos ma bstan/ / thugs rje'i bdag nyid sprul chen lta bus rigs bshad dbugs 'dra'i chos rnams kyis/ / skye bo nyid kyi chos la kun nas drangs te nyer zhi zhal gyi sgo/ / rnam par dag pa rgya chen thun mong zad mi shes la yang dag bkod/ / de ltas rnal 'byor can gyi sgom pa gang yin de ni don med min/ / de ltar bde bar gshegs kyi bstan pa gang yin de yang don med min/ / gal te thos pa tsam gyis don mthong 'gyur na sgom pa don med 'gyur/ / gal te ma thos par yang bsgom 'jug 'gyur na bstan pa don med 'gyur/ /

Because it is to be known by oneself, Lord Buddha did not teach the Dharma; Yet with the breath of his teachings, rationally explained, the embodiment of compassion, like a python, Draws beings onto the path, setting them perfectly in the mouth of total peace, Utterly pure, vast, common, and inexhaustible. (XIII, 2) Consequently, no practitioner’s meditation is pointless, And thus neither are the teachings of the sugatas pointless. If one could see the meaning simply by listening, there would be no point in meditating, And if one could practice meditation without having listened, there would be no point in teaching. (XIII, 3)
zhes pas bstan te/

rtogs pa'i mthar thug pa 'phags pa rnams kyis so so rang gis rig par bya ba ni tshig dang yi ge'i yul las 'das pa yin kyang / de lta bu thob par byed pa la tshig dang yi ges bstan pa'i lung gi chos la thos bsam ma byas par nam yang thob mi nus pas lung gi chos thos bsam gyi yul du gyur pa 'di ni bcom ldan 'das kyis so so rang rig rtogs pa'i thabs su bstan pa yin te/ gang gi phyir na 'phags pa rnams kyi thugs rgyud kyi rtogs pa'i chos so so rang gis rig par bya ba ni so so rang rig med pa la thad kar bstan par mi nus pas/ de 'dra'i rtogs pa'i chos ni mngon sum du so so rang rig par bya ba'i phyir sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyis tshig dang yi ge'i rnam pa can gyi chos ma bstan pa'am bstan pa de med de/ so so rang gis rig par bya ba'i don 'di yin no zhes tshig dang yi ges ji bzhin mtshon mi nus te/ 'jig rten pa'i brjod pa dang rtog pa dang dpe dang gtan tshigs las 'das pa yin pas so so rang rig pa zhes bya ste/ 'jig rten na ka bum sogs 'dus byas kyi chos dang / nam mkha' sogs 'dus ma byas kyi chos shes pa lta bu ma yin pas de bzhin nyid ni 'phags pa'i ye shes dang ldan pas so so rang gis rig par bya ba yin te/ 'jig rten pa'i bsam gtan thob pa rnams kyi spyod yul bsam gtan ma thob pa rnams kyis bsam par mi nus na 'jig rten las 'das pa'i ye shes kyi spyod yul 'jig rten pa'i thos pa sogs kyis bsam pa'i yul ma yin pa smos ci dgos so/ /

Although the ultimate realization that the noble beings are to know by their own individual experience is beyond the realm of words and letters, it is impossible to ever attain it without listening to and reflecting on the Dharma of transmission that is indicated by words and letters. This is why Lord Buddha taught the Dharma of transmission, which can be heard and reflected upon, as the means for realizing that personally experienced wisdom. It is impossible to show the Dharma of realization, the individually experienced wisdom present in the minds of noble beings, directly to beings who have not realized it personally. So because that Dharma of realization can only be known by actual personal experience, the buddha bhagavāns have not taught such a Dharma in the form of words and letters. They cannot demonstrate how it is with words and letters, saying, “This is the point that has to be realized individually.” It is beyond the expressions, concepts, analogies, and reasoning of ordinary people, which is why we say that it can only be known personally. It is not like the mundane knowledge of compounded phenomena such as vases and uncompounded phenomena such as space: suchness is something that is realized personally by those who have the gnosis of the noble beings. If the object of experience of those who have attained mundane dhyāna cannot be imagined by beings who have not attained it, then it goes without saying that the object of experience of supramundane gnosis is not something that can be conceived of by an ordinary person listening and reflecting.
'o na zab mo'i mdo sde rnams kyis nges pa'i don sangs rgyas kyi thugs su chud pa so so rang rig par bya ba'i don bshad do zhes gsungs pa ji ltar yin zhe na/
How is it, then, that the profound sūtras are said to explain the certain meaning—the Buddha’s realization, the point that can only be realized personally?

sems can rnams la thugs rje'i bdag nyid sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das sbrul chen po lta bus/ zhes pa dpe bstan te/ sbrul chen po a rdza gar zhes pa/ rgyab tu zhing rmo zhing chu bo yang 'bab pa'i khyon yod pa de'i kha nas chu byung ba rgyang ring por chu klung chen po bzhin du bab pa de la ri dwags rnams kyis chu klung yin par bsams nas 'thung ba na kha chu gdug pas shi bar gyur pa rnams sbrul de'i kha'i dbugs rngub pas drangs nas khar 'dzud par byed do/ de'i phyir sangs rgyas sbrul chen lta bus/ rig pa bzhi dang ldan pas shin tu rigs shing 'thad pa ste don thams cad phyin ci ma log par bshad pa ni gsung rab gang zhig sbrul gyi dbugs dang 'dra bar pha rol 'dren nus pa chos gsung rab yan lag bcu gnyis rnams kyis/ ri dwags kyi tshogs lta bu'i gdul bya'i skye bo rnams/ sangs rgyas nyid kyi yang dag pa'i lam gyi chos la kun nas drangs te/ mthar thug kun nye bar zhi ba myang 'das chos kyi sku sangs rgyas nyid kyi zhal gyi sgo lta bu/ sgrib gnyis rnam par dag pa gtsang ba dam pa dang / stobs sogs kyi yon tan rgya chen po dang ldan pa bde ba dam pa/ sangs rgyas thams cad dang thun mong du gyur pas bdag nyid chen po yi bdag dam pa/ gtan du zad mi shes pas rtag pa dam pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa la yang dag pa bkod do zhes

This is explained by a metaphor comparing Lord Buddha, who is the embodiment of compassion for sentient beings, to a giant snake. There is a giant snake, a python, that leaves behind it a furrow the size of a river, filled with the saliva flowing from its mouth, so that from a distance it looks like a huge river. The deer, thinking that it is a river, go to drink from it, whereupon they are killed by the poisonous saliva and sucked into the python’s mouth as it breathes in. Thus it is that the Buddha (illustrated by the python) draws potential disciples (analogous to the herds of deer) onto the correct path to buddhahood by means of the Twelve Branches of Excellent Speech, which are capable of drawing in others (like the python’s breath)—the Excellent Words that he expounds perfectly logically and reasonably, that is, with no mistake in any points, for they possess the four kinds of rational application.[3] Drawing them in, he finally places them in buddhahood (the snake’s mouth)—the body of truth, nirvāṇa, in which suffering and the origin of suffering are completely pacified; the transcendent state[4] of sublime purity (in which the two obscurations have been purified), of sublime bliss (which is endowed with the vast qualities of the ten strengths and so forth), of the sublime “self” of a great being (for it is common to all the buddhas), and of the sublime eternity (for it will never know an end).

so so rang rig par bya ba'i mthar thug pas sangs rgyas chos kyi sku de dngos su tshig gis bstan nas de de bzhin du rtogs par gyur nas sangs rgyas pa'i sems can su yang med kyang / mthar thug gi chos sku de nyid thob byed kyi rgyu zab mo de kho na nyid dang / thabs kyi phyogs rnams ma nor ba bstan pa'i lung gi chos la thos bsam bsgom pa phyin ci ma log par byas pa'i lam des 'phags pa'i ye shes so so rang rig pa thob pa la bslu ba med cing / ye shes des bsam gyis mi khyab pa so so rang gis rig par bya ba'i yul de kho na nyid ma nor bar thugs su chud nas/ mthar sangs rgyas kyi ye shes chos sku mngon du byed pa yin pas de ltar so so rang rig par bya ba'i yul ni dngos su tshig gis bstan du med cing lung gi chos la brten te brgyud nas bstan par 'gyur ba

This is the truth-body buddha, the culmination of personal realization, and there are no sentient beings who have ever attained buddhahood through its being directly indicated by words and then realized accordingly. Nevertheless, the causal factor that leads one to attain that ultimate truth body is the Dharma of transmission that indicates, without any error, profound thatness and skillful means. By means of the path—that is, by correctly listening to, reflecting on, and meditating on the Dharma of transmission—one unfailingly acquires the personally experienced gnosis of the noble beings. With that gnosis, one unerringly realizes thatness, the inconceivable object of personally experienced wisdom, and finally one realizes the Buddha’s gnosis, the body of truth. Thus, the object of personally experienced wisdom, while not being indicated directly by words, is based on, and indirectly indicated by, the Dharma of transmission.
de lta bas na zhi lhag dang ldan pa'i rnal 'byor can gyi sgom pa gang yin pa de ni don med pa ma yin te/ bsgom pa de la brten nas so so rang rig pa'i ye shes 'byung bas so/ /

Consequently, the meditation of a practitioner who possesses sustained calm and profound insight is not pointless, for it is in dependence on such meditation that the personally realized gnosis will arise.

sgom pa don yod pa de ltar na sgom pa phyin ci ma log par byed pa'i ched du bde bar gshegs pa rnams kyi chos mdo sde la sogs pa bstan pa gang yin pa de yang don med pa min te/ de kho na nyid bsgom pa'i lam dang bral ba phyi rol pas bdag bsgom pa sogs ni thar lam min la bdag med bsgom pa sogs dngos po'i de kho na nyid phyin ci ma log par bstan pa'i chos de thos pa dang de'i don bsams nas nges pa rnyed pa bzhin bsgom pa las de kho na nyid mthong ba'i so so rang rig pa 'byung ba'i phyir ro/ /

Meditation is indeed worthwhile, and thus the sūtras and other teachings, which the sugatas have given in order to enable one to meditate correctly, are not pointless either. For in contrast to non-Buddhist practices such as meditation on the self that are not related to the path of meditation on thatness and which are no way to attain liberation, the Dharma unmistakenly teaches the thatness of things, meditation on no-self, and so forth; and through one’s hearing it, reflecting on its meaning, and meditating in accordance with the certainty one has thereby acquired, the personally experienced vision of thatness will occur.

de ltar ma yin par gal te bdag med la sogs pa thos pa tsam gyis don de nyid mngon sum mthong bar 'gyur na de nyid du grol bar rigs kyi de'i don bsgom pa don med par 'gyur la gal te bdag med la sogs par bstan pa'i chos ma thos par yang de'i don bsgom pa la skye bo rang nyid 'jug par 'gyur na gsung rab rnams bstan pa don med par 'gyur te bstan mi dgos na yang de lta bu mi srid pa'i phyir/ 'phags pa rnams kyi ye shes gang zhig chos nyid ji lta ba bzhin du rtogs pa'i so so rang rig thob pa la dang por dam pa'i chos mnyan pa dang / de nas de'i don la bsam pas nges pa rnyed pa dang / de nas don de rtse gcig par bsgom dgos pas kun gyi thog mar thos pa'i shes rab bskyed dgos pa'i phyir chos nyan pa dang bshad pa'i lung gi bstan pa ni de ltar don che zhing dgos pa che ba yin par bstan pa'o/ /

If it were otherwise and one could directly see that very meaning simply by hearing the teachings on no-self and so forth, one would be liberated there and then, and there would be no point in meditating on the meaning of those teachings. And if one could practice meditation on no-self without listening to the relevant teachings, there would be no point either in teaching the Buddha’s Excellent Words. But it is impossible that the Buddha would have taught without reason. To acquire the gnosis of the noble beings, the personally experienced wisdom that realizes ultimate reality as it is, one must first listen to the sacred Dharma, then reflect on its meaning so that one acquires certainty, and subsequently meditate one-pointedly on that meaning. First of all, therefore, it is necessary to give rise to the wisdom that comes from listening, and it is for this reason that the Dharma of transmission, which involves listening to the teachings and explaining them, is very worthwhile and very necessary.
gsum pa chos ji ltar ston pa'i tshul
3. HOW TO TEACH THE DHARMA
['di] la/ byang chub sems dpas chos ston pa'i tshul dang / sangs rgyas kyis chos ston pa'i tshul gnyis/
This topic is divided into (1) the manner in which bodhisattvas teach the Dharma and (2) the manner in which the buddhas teach the Dharma.
[dang po]
a. THE MANNER IN WHICH BODHISATTVAS TEACH THE DHARMA
dang po byang chub sems dpas chos 'chad pa la 'chad tshul gyi rnam grangs dang / don bzang po dang / tshig bzang po gsum las/
The first of these two is further divided into three sections: (1) different ways of teaching; (2) the excellence of the import; and (3) the excellence of the words.
dang po/
i. DIFFERENT WAYS OF TEACHING
sems dpa' mchog gi ston pa ni/ / lung dang rtogs dang dbang 'byor las/ / kha dang gzugs ni thams cad dang / / nam mkha' las kyang 'byung ba yin/ /
The teaching of sublime bodhisattvas Occurs through transmission, realization, and mastery: From the mouth, from form of every kind, And from space it issues forth. (XIII, 4)
zhes tshigs bcad gcig gis bstan te/

mos pa'i spyod pa'i sa na dge ba'i bshes gnyen sangs rgyas dang byang sems gzhan las ji ltar thos pa bzhin 'chad pa ni lung la brten nas 'chad pa dang / sa dang po nas bdun pa'i bar chos kyi dbyings rtogs pa nyid kyi mthus 'chad pa dang / dag pa'i sa gsum du mi rtog ye shes dang mngon par shes pa lhun gyis grub pa'i dbang 'byor bas chos 'chad pa zhes bya ste rnam grangs gsum mo/ / yang sa brgyad pa sogs dbang 'byor bdag gi byin rlabs las rang gi kha dang gzhan gyi kha yi glu dbyangs dang rol mo sogs kyi sgra las chos 'chad pa'i sgra 'byung ba dang / rtsig pa dang rol mo'i cha byad sogs gzugs ni thams cad gang yang rung ba las kyang chos kyi sgra 'byung ba dang / nam mkha' las kyang chos bstan pa'i sgra 'byung ba yin no/ /

On the level of earnest aspiration, bodhisattvas explain the Dharma as they have heard it from other spiritual masters—buddhas and bodhisattvas. In other words, they teach by relying on the transmission. From the first bodhisattva level up to the seventh, they teach through the power of their realization of the expanse of reality. On the three pure levels, they explain the Dharma through their spontaneous mastery of nonconceptual gnosis and preternatural knowledge. This makes three categories. Furthermore, on the eighth and higher levels, through the blessing of their mastery, the sound of Dharma teachings issues forth as melodious song from their own and other people’s mouths, from the sounds of musical instruments, and so forth. From all kinds of form—walls, musical instruments, and other forms—come the sounds of the Dharma. And from the sky, too, comes the sound of the Dharma being taught.
gnyis pa/
ii. THE EXCELLENCE OF THE IMPORT
rgya che the tshom spong ba dang / / gzung 'os de nyid gnyis ston pa/ / 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' yi/ / ston pa phun tshogs yin zhes bya/ /
Extensive, doubt-dispelling, Acceptable, and indicative of both natures— This, a bodhisattva’s teaching, Is said to be perfect. (XIII, 5)
zhes tshigs bcad gnyis kyis bstan te/

mang du thos pas chos dang don du 'brel ba rgya che ba ston pa'am gsal ba dang / bdag nyid chos la the tshom med pas gzhan gyi the tshom spong bar byed pa dang / bdag chos la gnas pas gzhan gyis de'i tshig gzung bar 'os pa gyur te ngag la nyan du btub pa ni 'jebs pa zhes kyang bya'o/ / kun nyon dang rnam byang gi de nyid gnyis ston pa 'di bzhi dang ldan pa ni byang chub sems dpa' yi/ chos ston pa phun sum tshogs pa yin zhes bya'o/ / 'di ni tshangs pas zhus pa'i mdo las gsungs pa ltar/ mang du thos nas 'jig rten du dam pa'i chos yun du gnas pa'i phyir chos rgya chen po bshad pa dang bdag gi shes rab chos bshad cing sbyar bas gong nas gong du rno bar byed cing gzhan gyi the tshom gcod pa dang / bdag nyid chos la gnas pas skyes bu dam pa'i las byed pas gzhan gyi de'i tshig rtsi ba dang / bden bzhi'i rang bzhin gyi kun byang ngam kun rdzob don dam gnyis bstan pas don che ba'o/ /

As a result of their having heard a lot of teachings, bodhisattvas’ own teaching reveals or elucidates the extensive topics of the Dharma and their meanings connectedly. Since they are themselves free of doubts with regard to the teachings, it dispels others’ doubts. Since they live the Dharma themselves, their words are acceptable to others—what they say is worth listening to and is also termed “pleasing.” And they explain both the nature of defilement and that of purity. It is in possessing these four qualities that the Dharma teaching of a bodhisattva is said to be perfect. This is as stated in the Sūtra of the Questions of Brahmaviśeṣacintin. Having received numerous teachings, bodhisattvas explain the extensive Dharma so that the sacred doctrine may endure in the world for a long time. Through their explaining the teachings and training in them, their own wisdom becomes increasingly sharper, and they can remove others’ doubts. Because they abide by the Dharma themselves and thus perform the activities of holy beings, others value their words. And since they teach both ultimate and relative truths, or the defilement aspect and the purity aspect, embodied in the four noble truths, their teaching is of great import.
sems dpa' mchog gi ston pa ni/ / 'jam zhing rgyags bral mi skyo dang / / gsal zhing sna tshogs rigs pa dang / / go zhing zang zing med kun 'gro/ /
The Dharma teaching of a sublime bodhisattva Is gentle, free of conceit, tireless, Clear, diversified, rational, Intelligible, disinterested, and universal. (XIII, 6)

yang chos ston pa phun sum tshogs pa'i rnam grangs dgu ni/ sems dpa' mchog gi chos ston pa ni gzhan gyis brgal kyang tshig rtsub po mi 'byin pas 'jam zhing / bstod pa bkur sti sogs 'byor kyang rgyags pa dang bral ba dang / chos ston pa la ngal dub kyis mi skyo ba dang dpe mkhyud med par 'chad pa dang don tshang bar 'chad pas gsal zhing / don sna tshogs pa yang yang zlos pa med par 'chad pa dang / tshad ma dang mi 'gal bar rigs pa dang ldan par 'chad pa dang / tshig dang yi ge 'jig rten na yongs su grags par brjod pas gzhan gyis legs par go zhing rnyed pa dang bkur sti 'dod pa spangs pas zang zing med pa dang / theg pa kun la mkhas pas theg pa gsum char gyi don ston pas kun tu 'gro ba ste de lta bu'i yon tan dang ldan pa ni don bzang po ston pas ston pa phun sum tshogs pa zhes bya'o/ /

Furthermore, there are nine features in their perfect Dharma teaching. In teaching the Dharma, sublime bodhisattvas are gentle, since they never utter harsh words even when others argue with them. Even if they receive praise and veneration, they are free of conceit. In teaching the Dharma, they are never discouraged by difficulties. Their teachings are clear, for they teach unstintingly and explain the topics in full. They teach a wide variety of subjects without repeating themselves. They teach rationally, never contradicting valid cognition. They express themselves with words and letters that are perfectly familiar to ordinary people, so that others understand them well. Since they have given up any desire for gain and honor, they are not motivated by material offerings. Learned in all spiritual means, they expound the subjects of all three vehicles, and in this respect their teaching is universal. It is on account of its having these qualities, and of the excellent import revealed thereby, that it is termed “perfect teaching.”
tshig bzang po ni/
iii. THE EXCELLENCE OF THE WORDS
rgyal sras tshig ni mi zhen pa/ / snyan cing legs bshad grags pa dang / / ci rigs pa dang zang zing med/ / ran cing de bzhin yangs pa yin/ /
The bodhisattvas’ words are not faint, They are pleasing, well expounded, and conventional; They are appropriate, free of material motives, Moderate, and likewise abundant. (XIII, 7)
zhes pa'i bar gyis bstan te/

rgyal ba'i sras po rnams kyis chos 'chad pa'i tshig ni mi dma' ba'am mi zhan pa ni skad gdangs chung bas kha cig gis thos kha cig gis mi thos pa lta bu min pa 'khor kun la khyab par thos pa dang / snyan po ni tshig 'jam zhing rna bar snyan pa dang yid la 'thad pa bzang po dang / legs par bshad pa'am mdzes par bshad pa ni don go nus pa'i tshig gsal ba yin no/ / 'jig rten du ma grags pa'i tshig brjod na gzhan gyis go bar mi 'gyur kyang 'jig rten na grags pa'i tshig dang skad kyis brjod pas don shes par byed pas grags pa zhes bya ba dang / gdul bya'i rgyud dang 'tshams par bstan pa ni ji lta rigs pa'am ci rigs pa zhes bya ste de ltar bstan na de'i rna bar 'ong ba la 'gyur ro/ / rnyed bkur la mi lta bas zang zing med pa'am zang zing la mi bstan pa'o/ / ha cang mang na skyo bas tshig mang nyung ran cing 'dzin bde ba ni mthun pa'o/ / de bzhin du yangs pa ni rgyas par bshad pa na zad pa med par 'chad nus pa yin no/ / mdo las tshig gi yon tan brgyad bshad pa khyab pa bzang ba gsal ba shes par byed pa rnar 'ong ba mi brten pa mthun pa mi zad pa zhes gsungs pa gong ltar 'di dang sbyar te shes par bya'o/ / rnyed bkur la mi brten pa sems kyi yon tan yin yang rnyed bkur byed pa la bshad cing bstod pa dang rnyed bkur med na mi 'chad cing smad pa lta bu min pas tshig 'di dag la rgyu des skyon ma zhugs pa'i cha nas bshad dgos sam snyam/

The words that bodhisattvas use to teach the Dharma are not soft or feeble. Their voices are not faint, so that some people hear them and others do not—they are audible to their entire following. Their words are pleasant; they are gentle and good—pleasing to both ear and intellect. They are excellently or beautifully expounded—clear sentences whose meaning can be understood. If bodhisattvas were to express themselves with unconventional words, nobody else would understand them, but by using words and language that are familiar to everyone, they make them aware of the meaning—hence, their words are “conventional.” Expounded in a way suited to their disciples’ minds, their words are “appropriate,” and their teaching in this way will be to their disciples’ liking.[5] As bodhisattvas are not seeking riches and reverence, their words are disinterested or independent of material gain. A surfeit of words makes people bored, so bodhisattvas adapt their words to just the right amount that is easily retained. Similarly, their words are abundant, meaning that when bodhisattvas give detailed explanations, they are able to do so without ever running out of things to say. It should be understood that the above are related to the eight qualities of bodhisattvas’ words described in the sūtras, which speak of them being pervasive, good, clear, intelligible, pleasing to the ear, disinterested, adapted, and inexhaustible. Being disinterested in people’s offerings and reverence is, of course, a mental quality, but here it is a question of not, for example, praising and teaching people who offer riches and reverence while reproaching and refusing to teach those who do not, so I feel that perhaps this quality should be explained in terms of its being a causal factor that prevents faults from being introduced into a bodhisattva’s words.

bstan dang de bzhin bshad pa dang / / theg dang mthun dang bde ba dang / / grags pa dang ni ci rigs dang / / nges par 'byung dang mthun pa'i phyir/ / de mdor sems dpa' mchog rnams kyi/ / yi ge phun tshogs yin zhes bya/ /

Because they indicate, and likewise explain, Correspond to the vehicle, are pleasurable, Conventional, and appropriate, Lead to certain deliverance, and are concordant— (XIII, 8) The syllables uttered by the sublime bodhisattvas Are described, in short, as perfect. (XIII, 9ab)

tshig 'chad tshul gyi yon tan kyang brgyad de/ don mdor bsdus te bstan pas khog don 'dzin bde ba dang / de bzhin du don de dag zhib tu rgyas par bshad pa byas pas don la nges pa rnyed pa dang / gdul bya rigs can gsum so so la de dang de'i theg pa bstan pa ni theg pa dang mthun par bshad pa dang / tshig dang yi ge dang don go rim ma 'khrugs par bstan pas nyan bde ba dang / tshig dang yi ge yongs su grags pa dag gis ston pa dang / gdul bya'i rgyud dang 'tshams par ji ltar rigs pa'am ci rigs pa ston pa dang / khams gsum las nges par 'byung ba 'phags pa'i lam gyi chos ston pa dang / 'phags lam brgyad dang rjes su mthun pa'i chos ston pa'i phyir/ de lta bu ni mdor na sems dpa' mchog rnams kyi/ /yi ge phun tshogs yin zhes bya zhes so/ /

There are also eight good qualities with regard to the manner in which bodhisattvas deliver their teachings: (1) Because they indicate topics in a condensed form, the essential meaning is easily grasped. (2) Similarly, as a result of their explaining those topics in great detail, certainty as to the meaning is acquired. (3) Whichever of the three kinds of potential their disciples have, in teaching each individual their respective vehicle, bodhisattvas give explanations that correspond to the vehicle. (4) Since they teach without mixing up the order of the words, syllables, and topics, their teachings are a pleasure to listen to. (5) They teach using familiar phrases and spellings. (6) They teach appropriately in a way suited to their disciples’ minds. (7) They teach the noble path that gives certain deliverance from the three worlds. And (8) they give teachings concordant with the eightfold noble path. On account of these qualities, the syllables of these sublime bodhisattvas, in short, are said to be “perfect.”

mdo las yi ge'i yon tan ni rigs pa'i tshig dang yi ge dang ldan pa dang / rjes su 'brang ba dang / rjes su mthun pa dang / khas len pa dang / mthun pa dang / rjes su mthun pa dang / mkhas par sbyor ba'i tshogs rdzogs pa zhes brgyad gsungs pa de dag snga ma dang sbyar bar bya ste/ tshad ma gsum gyi rigs pa ldan pa'i tshig dang yi ges mdor bstan pa dang / mdor bstan bzhin du rgyas bshad ldan pa dang / theg pa dang mthun par rjes su 'brang ba dang*/ bden pa ni tshig dang yi ge ston tshul 'khrugs pas rna bar mi 'ong ba med pas 'jam pa ni yid dang rjes su mthun pa'o/ / grags pa ni khas len pa ste de bzhin du go bas so/ / ci rigs pa ni de'i snod dang mthun pa'o/ / 'phags lam ston pas myang 'das kyi rjes su mthun pa'o/ / mthun pa'i phyir dang mkhas pa sbyor ba'i tshogs rdzogs la gnyis sbyar te/ mkhas pa ni rgyun zhugs nas dgra bcom la zhugs pa'i bar gyi gang zag bdun la bya ste/ de dag gi mthong sgom gyi lam la tshogs rdzogs pa zhes bya la/ de gang du mthun na 'phags lam brgyad dang mthun pa'i phyir ro zhes 'grel chen du bshad do/ /

The sūtras speak of eight qualities for syllables: logical validity in the words and syllables, incorporation, conformity, harmony, acceptability, suitability, concordance, and completion of the accumulations of the wise. The Great Commentary explains how these correspond to the above qualities as follows: (1) Bodhisattvas’ teachings supply brief explanations using words and syllables that comprise the reasoning of the three kinds of valid cognition. (2) They incorporate detailed explanations of the subjects that have been briefly introduced. (3) They conform or correspond to the vehicle. (4) They are gentle, in harmony with the mind, for they are truthful and they do not grate on the ear as a result of the words and syllables being taught in a disordered fashion. (5) The words being familiar to everyone, they are acceptable and accordingly intelligible. (6) They are appropriate, suited to the listener. (7) They indicate the noble path and are therefore concordant with nirvāṇa. And (8) corresponding to “concordant” (in the root verse), they complete the accumulations of the wise. “The wise” refers to the seven kinds of noble beings, from stream enterers to candidates for arhatship.[6] Their paths of seeing and meditation are referred to as “the completion of the accumulations,” which are concordant with the eightfold noble path.
gnyis pa sangs rgyas kyis chos 'chad tshul/
b. THE MANNER IN WHICH THE BUDDHAS TEACH THE DHARMA
bde gshegs gsungs ni mtha' yas te/ / yan lag drug cu bsam mi khyab/ /
The speech of the sugatas is infinite; With sixty qualities, it is inconceivable. (XIII, 9cd)
zhes pa'i bar gyis bstan te/

bde bar gshegs pas chos ston pa'i gsung ni dbyangs mtha' yas pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa yin te/ 'on kyang mdor bsdu na gsung gi dbyangs yan lag drug cu gsang ba bsam gyis mi khyab par bstan pa'i mdo las bstan pa bzhin du shes par bya la/ de'i yan lag re re la yang gsungs dbyangs mtha' yas pa 'byung bas bsam gyis mi khyab bo/ / drug cu gang zhe na/

The words with which the sugatas teach the Dharma comprise infinite, inconceivable expressive elements, but these can all be condensed into the sixty expressive qualities of buddha speech, as taught in the Sūtra of the Inconceivable Secrets. And since in each of these qualities there are again infinite expressive forms of speech, their speech is inconceivable. What are these sixty?
dper na chus rtsa shing sogs skye zhing 'phel bar byed pa bzhin du sangs rgyas kyi gsung gis sems can rnams dge ba'i rtsa ba skyed cing 'phel bar byed pas mnyen pa'am snum pa zhes bya'o/ /

(1) The Buddha’s speech is mollifying or softening, for just as water, for example, makes the grass, trees, and so forth sprout and grow, the Buddha’s speech enables sentient beings to give rise to sources of good and to develop them.
lha'i gos 'jam pas lus la reg na bde ba ltar sangs rgyas kyi gsung thos pa tsam nas tshe 'dir yid bde bar byed pas 'jam pa dang /
(2) It is gentle, for like the gods’ soft clothes, whose contact with the body is so blissful, the mere sound of the Buddha’s voice makes one happy in this life.
de bzhin du bden pa gnyis dang rten 'byung dang byang phyogs sogs kyi don ston pas yid du 'ong ba/
(3) It is likewise beautiful, for it indicates the meaning of the two truths, dependent arising, the elements that lead to enlightenment, and so on.
tha mal pa ba lang rdzi sogs kyi tshig dang yi ge lta bu mi gsung gi lha dang 'phags pa'i tshig dang yi ge gsungs pas yid du 'thad pa/
(4) What the Buddha says is appealing, for he does not speak with the language of common folk such as cowherds, but speaks in the language of the gods and noble beings.
'jig rten las 'das pa'i ye shes chen po sgrib gnyis spangs pa rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyi rjes las thob pas rnam par dag pa/
(5) It is perfectly pure, for it ensues from the great supramundane gnosis, the nonconceptual gnosis in which the two obscurations have been eliminated.
nyon mongs pa'i bag nyal dang bral bas dri ma med pa/
(6) It is immaculate, being free of latent defilements.
'jig rten na grags pa'i tshig dang yi ge gsal bas rab tu gsal ba/
(7) It is very clear, since he teaches with language that is known to everyone.
mu stegs sogs kyi lta ba ngan pa sel ba'i stobs dang ldan pas snyan la 'jebs pa'am stobs dang ldan pa/
(8) It is sonorous or powerful and has the power to dispel unwholesome views such as those of the tīrthikas.
gsungs bzhin bsgrubs na khams gsum las nges par 'byung bas mnyan par 'os pa/
(9) It is worth listening to, for by practicing in accordance with his teaching, one is certain to be delivered from the three worlds.
pha rol gyi rgol bas gsung de sun dbyung mi nus pas mi tshugs pa/
(10) It is unassailable, for what he says cannot be refuted by his opponents.
nyan pa po'i yid la dga' ba skyed pas snyan pa/
(11) It is well-sounding, in that it delights the listener.
chags sogs nyon mongs pa thams cad kun nas 'dul bar byed pas 'dul ba/
(12) It is calming, for it completely subdues all the defilements—attachment and the rest.
bslab pa dang bcas pa yang mu stegs pa'i me lnga bsten pa sogs bgyid dka' ba rtsub po lta bu ma yin par 'jug sla ba ni mi rtsub pa/
(13) It is without harshness, in that the precepts the Buddha ordained are easy to follow, unlike the mortification by five fires[7] and other rigorous austerities that the tīrthikas practice.
ltung ba las yang dag par 'byung ba'i thabs bshags pa dang bsdams pa sogs ston pas bgyir med pa ma yin pas mi brlang ba/
(14) It is kindly, in that since the Buddha teaches the methods for perfect deliverance from downfalls (by confessing them, vowing not to repeat them, and so on), such downfalls are not irremediable.
theg pa gsum ston pas rigs can rnams rab tu dul ba/
(15) In teaching the three vehicles, the Buddha’s speech fully trains those with the corresponding potentials.
gsung snyan cing 'jam pas btang mi bra bar rna blags te nyan 'dod pas g.yeng ba mi 'byung phyir rna bar snyan pa/
(16) It is sweet to the ear, for what he says is so melodious and gentle that one cannot bring oneself to leave; one feels like giving all one’s attention and does not get distracted.
gsung de la brten nas ting nge 'dzin bskyed pas shin sbyangs gis lus sim par byed pa dang /
(17) It brings about physical ease, for reliance on the Buddha’s teaching gives rise to concentration, resulting in suppleness.
de bzhin lhag mthong gis sems tshim par byed pa/
(18) It similarly brings about mental contentment, on account of the profound insight it inspires.
the tshom gyi zug rngu thams cad gcod par byed pas snying dga' ba/
(19) It gladdens the heart, for it clears away all the torment of doubt.
mi shes pa dang log par 'dzin pa spangs pas rim pa bzhin dga' ba dang bde ba skyed pa/
(20) It is joyous and blissful, for it gets rid of ignorance and misunderstanding respectively.
gsung bzhin du bsgrubs na 'bras bu mi bslu bar thob pas gsung de mnyan pa don med do snyam pa'i 'gyod pa mi 'byung bas/ gdung ba med pa/

(21) It is undisappointing, in that one will never have any regrets and think that there was no point in listening to his teaching, because if one practices what the Buddha says, one will inevitably attain the result.
thos pa'i shes rab phun sum tshogs pa'i gnas kyi phyir kun gyis shes pa/
(22) It is a source of comprehensive knowledge, the source of the perfect wisdom that comes from listening.
bsam pa'i shes rab phun sum tshogs pa 'byung bar byed pa'i gnas su gyur pa'i phyir rnam par rig par bya ba/
(23) It is a source of discerning knowledge, the source that gives rise to the perfect wisdom that comes from reflecting.
dpe mkhyud med par ston pas rnam par gsal ba
(24) It is fully illuminating, in that the Buddha teaches without holding back on his knowledge.

bdag gi don rjes su thob pa ni rgyun du zhugs pa sogs gang zag brgyad dang / sa bcu pa'i sems dpa' rnams dang de bzhin gshegs pa rnams yin la/ nyan thos dang byang sems 'phags pa de dag gis kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung gi sgo nas bdag gi don rjes su thob par mthong nas gsung la dga' ba skyed par byed pas na dga' ba/

(25) It is a source of delight, for when those who have attained their goals—that is, the eight kinds of noble beings (stream enterer and the others), the bodhisattvas on the tenth level, and the tathāgatas—see that they have done so by means of the Tathāgata’s teachings, and when the noble listeners and bodhisattvas realize that by means of the Tathāgata’s teachings they too will achieve their respective goals, they rejoice at the Buddha’s word.
bdag gi don ma thob pa so so'i skye bo rnams kyis bdag gi don rjes su thob par bya ba'i phyir de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung la 'jug par 'dod pas mngon par dga' ba/
(26) It is inspiring, on account of the wish it inspires in ordinary beings who have not achieved their goals to practice the Tathāgata’s teaching in order to achieve their goals.[8]

zab mo so so rang gis rig par bya ba chos kyi dbyings dang rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes dang byang chub kyi phyogs rnams bsam gyis mi khyab pa yin la/ chos de dag yang dag par ston par byed pas kun shes par byed pa/ yang na phyi'i dngos po sna tshogs 'grub pa'i las rnal 'byor pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi spyod yul/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i spyod yul/ sman dang sngags kyi mthu bzhi phal pas bsam gyis mi khyab pas de dag bsam par mi bya bar bstan pa la yang 'chad pa yod/

(27) It is the bestower of all knowledge, in that the Buddha’s word perfectly indicates such inconceivable topics as the profound expanse of reality that is to be known personally, the nonconceptual gnosis, and the elements that lead to enlightenment. Another explanation is that the karmic actions that produce the whole variety of the external material world, the objects of a yogi’s concentration, those that are the domain of the Tathāgata’s gnosis, and the magical powers of medicine and mantra are all inconceivable to the ordinary mind and are therefore taught as being not to be reflected upon.
phung khams skye mched sa dang phar phyin sogs bsam par bya ba rgya che ba'i chos ston pas rnam par rig par byed pa/

(28) It is the bestower of discerning knowledge, for it teaches a vast range of topics that are to be reflected upon—the aggregates, sense spheres, and senses-and-fields; the levels; the transcendent perfections; and so forth.
tshad ma gsum dang ldan par brjod pas rigs pa/
(29) It is rational, for it expresses things in association with the three kinds of valid cognition.
gdul bya'i snod dang 'tshams par ston pas de'i rgyu dang mthun par 'brel ba/
(30) It is appropriate, in that the Buddha teaches in a manner suited to the disciple; what he says is consistent with the disciple’s mind stream.
rnam grangs du mas don gcig bstan kyang ming so so'i cha nas go rgyu'i dgos pa yod pa mdo rnams las rnam grangs kyis bstan pa lta bu ma zlos pa/

(31) It is not redundant—referring, for example, to the different enumerations in the sūtras—because although the Buddha used many different terms to teach a single point, each term has a deliberate implication.
rgol ba dang mu stegs can skrag par byed pas seng+ge'i sgra'i shugs lta bu zhes seng+ge'i sgras ri dwags rnams skrag par byed pa bzhin bdag med sogs bstan pa'i shugs mi bzod pa'o/ /

(32) It is similar in force to the lion’s roar, for the Buddha’s word frightens opponents and those with tīrthika views. Like the lion’s roar, which terrifies all the deer and antelope, the force of the teachings on no-self and similar topics is overwhelming.

'khor la khyab pa glang po che'i sgra dbyangs ni/ mi yul gyi glang po che la mi bya ste/ lha'i glang po che e ra wa ta la sogs pa la bya ste/ de dag gi sgra sub sub po dang 'dzer 'dzer po ma yin pa bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung gi sgra la yang de gnyis spangs pa'o zhes bshad/

(33) It is like the elephant’s trumpeting, reaching the entire retinue. This refers not to the elephants of the human realm but to celestial elephants like Airāvata. Its trumpeting is not muffled or hoarse, and neither is the sound of the Tathāgata’s words.

zab pa 'brug gi sgra dbyangs ni gdangs ldir la/ drung nas nyan na lhag par mi che yang rgyang nas nyan na lhag par chung ba min par nye ring 'dra bar snyoms par sprin gyi dbyangs te 'brug gi dbyangs lta bu zhes 'grel par bshad/

(34) It is like the deep rumbling of thunder.[9] The commentary explains that the thunder of the Buddha’s word sounds no louder in his presence and no softer when heard from far away: it is the same irrespective of distance, “like the voice in the clouds, the roar of the dragon.”

klu'i gnas na klu'i dbang po'i tshig ni/ 'jebs shing tshig btsun la klu kun nyan du btub pa bzhin sangs rgyas kyi gsung ni lha dang lha min mi la sogs pa thams cad bka' nyan pas klu'i dbang po'i dbyangs lta bu'o/ /

(35) It is like the voice of the nāga king, for just as in the nāga realm all the nāgas cannot but listen to the beautiful, noble words of the nāga king, the Buddha’s word is obeyed by everyone—gods, demigods, human beings, and the like.
sems can gyi sgra skad kyi nang na dri za'i skad ni mchog tu mnyen pa yin pas mi'am ci'am dri za'i dbyangs lta bu snyan pa dang /
(36) It is as sweet as the song of the gandharvas or of the kiṃnaras,[10] whose voices, of all the voices of sentient beings, are the softest.

bya ka la ping ka'i sgra ni gdangs snyan pa snga ma dang mi 'dra ba'i snyan pa gzhan dang gzhan 'byung la rgyun 'chad pa med pa ltar sangs rgyas kyi gsung rgyun mi gcod la snyan pa gzhan dang gzhan 'byung ba'o/ / kha cig ka la ping ka'i sgra snyan pa'i sems can rnams kyi sems su zhugs nas rgyun ci tsam pa nyan te nam sgra de rgyun chad pa'i tshe na de snyan pas slar yang nyan 'dod pa dang 'dra bar sangs rgyas kyi gsung lan cig thos na slar yang nyan par 'dod pa'o zhes zer/

(37) Like the song of the kalaviṅka,[11] which sings uninterruptedly, forever changing the melody, the Buddha’s teaching is uninterrupted and ever-changing. Some authorities say that the kalaviṅka’s beautiful song so delights beings that no matter how long they listen to it, when it stops, they want to hear its sweet notes again; and that in the same way, once one has heard the Buddha’s voice, one longs to hear it again.
tshangs pa'i dbyangs ni mnyen pa'i ring du song ba ste dum dum po ma yin pa ltar sangs rgyas kyi gsung dbugs rngub pa'i thung skyon med pas ring ba'am/ rgyang ring du grags pa'o/ /
(38) Like the voice of Brahmā, which is long and regular, not fragmented, the Buddha’s voice is not marred by shortness of breath and is therefore drawn out, or far-sounding.

'dab chags dza ba dzi pa ka zhes pa shang shang ti'u'i skad ni bkra shis pa ste/ don gnyer du 'gro bas thos na don thams cad nges par 'grub pa'i ltas yin pa ltar/ sangs rgyas kyi gsung thos pas 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i don thams cad 'grub pa'i bkra shis pa'i snga ltas su gyur pa ste gsung thos pa las phyis don kun 'grub par 'gyur bas so/ /

(39) It is auspicious, like the call of the jīvajīvaka,[12] which, when someone undertaking an important task hears it, is a sign that all their goals will surely be accomplished. Similarly, the sound of the Buddha’s voice is an auspicious sign that all supramundane goals will be achieved, for it is through listening to the Buddha’s teachings that one will subsequently accomplish all one’s goals.
tshig btsun pas thams cad kyis de bzhin snyan cing mi 'da' bas lha'i dbang po'i dbyangs dang 'dra bas sangs rgyas kyis gsung ni bka' gzhan gyis mi gcog pa'o/ /
(40) It is like the voice of Indra, whose noble words everyone obeys and no one transgresses: no one can go against anything the Buddha has said.

lha'i rnga bo ches lha min pham zhing lha rgyal ba'i sgra byung ba nas lha min rang 'byer ba ltar sangs rgyas kyang bdud dang phyir rgol ba kun nas rgyal te dang por chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba dang gang thos pa rnams bdud sogs las rgyal bar byed pas so/ /

(41) It is like the beat of the great celestial drum that heralds the demigods’ defeat at the hands of the gods and at whose sound the demigods naturally scatter, for the Buddha similarly routs demons and opponents, turning the wheel of the Dharma for the first time and overcoming negative attitudes in those who hear it.
lha dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten gyis sangs rgyas la bstod kyang nga rgyal med pas mi 'gying pa'am ma khengs pa/
(42) It is without show or conceit, for even when the Buddha is praised by the gods and everyone else, he has no pride.[13]
bdud dang mu stegs sogs kyis chos bstan pa 'di ma legs pa yin zhes smad kyang zhums pa med pas sku mi dma' ba/
(43) It is not timid, in that if demons and tīrthikas criticize the Buddha’s teachings saying that they are no good, he is not discouraged.

byA ka ra Na zhes pa brda sprod pa'am lung ston pa ste skabs 'dir sangs rgyas kyis 'das ma 'ongs da lta'i don lung bstan pa thams cad de kho na ltar nges par 'gyur ba'am/ yang na shes bya rig pa'i gnas thams cad ji ltar brda sprod pa ltar nges pa'am yang na brda sprod pa'i sgra'i mtshan nyid la yang zhugs pa ste brda sprod pa'i lugs dang ldan pas sgra kun gyi rjes su zhugs pa'ang ngo*/ /

(44) It is fully imbued with all manner of expression, in that the Buddha’s words communicate or convey (the Sanskrit term is vyākaraṇa), meaning in this context that everything the Buddha declares[14] concerning the past, present, and future is certain to be exactly as he has said; or that his words definitively communicate all branches of knowledge; or that they follow the rules of grammar and communicate effectively.
dran pa nyams pa med pas brjod bya 'ga' zhig lus nas tshig gi rnam pa ma tshang ba'am/ bstan bya'i don thams cad la bsnyel ba med pa'i tshig gi zur chag pa med pa dang

(45) It is uncorrupted, because, the Buddha’s memory being unimpaired, he never omits any subjects or fails to complete the form of the words. Another explanation is that he never forgets any points that need teaching.
gdul bya'i don gyi bya ba dge rtsa bskyed pa dang 'phel ba dang mthar phyin pa'i bya ba thams cad ma lus par ston pas ma tshang ba med pa/
(46) It is never incomplete, in that he teaches all the actions without exception that benefit beings—actions that give rise to sources of good, make them grow, and perfect them.
rnyed bkur sogs kyis sred pa dang bral bas ma chags pa'o/ /dpe la lar 'di la ma zhum pa zhes su snang /
(47) It is without attachment, for the Buddha does not hanker after honors and riches. Some editions list this quality as “undaunted.”
'khor du chos 'chad pa la bdud sogs kyis rgol ba'i 'jigs pa med pas mi zhan pa'am/ dpe la lar 'di la ma zhum pa zer/
(48) It is not feeble (or, as certain editions say for this, undaunted), for in teaching the Dharma to his followers, the Buddha has no fear of opposition from demons and the like.
chos ston pa la thugs skyo ba dang sku la mi bde bas dub pa med pas rab tu dga' ba/
(49) It is extremely joyous, in that when he teaches the Dharma, the Buddha does not become mentally discouraged or physically worn out by illness.

rig pa'i gnas thams cad lhag ma med par thugs su chud pa'i sgo nas shes bya gang dang ci dris pa thogs med du 'chad pas don mtha' dag rgyas par ston pa'am/ khyab pa nyid du ston pa'i phyir rgyas pa'am khyab pa zhes bya'o/ /

(50) It is extensive or fully comprehensive, in that he teaches all subjects extensively, or teaches pervasively: through his complete mastery of all branches of knowledge, he explains without impediment everything he is asked.
sems can dge rtsa ma skyed pa tha ba bcas pa'i don mdzad cing tha ba med pa'i sems can thams cad kyis don khong du chud par mdzad pas tha ba med pa
(51) It is soothing, for it benefits angry sentient beings who have not given rise to sources of good, and it leads all gentle beings to realize the truth.
rtag tu chos rgyun mi 'chad par gsungs pas rjes su zhugs pa'am rgyun chags pa/
(52) It is continuous or uninterrupted, for the Buddha is always teaching the Dharma, without interruption.
ming dang tshig dang yi ge sna tshogs mang po'i sgo nas 'bel ba'am rol bar mdzad pas brjid pa'am rol pa'am 'bel ba zhes bya'o/ /
(53) It is described as magnificent, elaborate, or rich, in that he speaks richly or elaborately, using a wide variety of names, phrases, and letters.
gsung gcig la yang lha klu mi dang byol song yi dwags la sogs pa'i sems can so so'i sgra skad du thos pa'i sgra kun rdzogs par byed pa'o/ /
(54) It incorporates all languages, even in a single voice, for gods, nāgas, humans, animals, hungry spirits, and other sentient beings each hear it in their respective language.
gsung gcig gi so so rang rang gis don gang shes par 'dod pa de khong du chud par byed pas sems can de dag gis dbang po thams cad mgu bar byed pa'am tshim par byed pa'o/ /
(55) It delights or satisfies all the different intellectual capacities of beings, for the same voice leads to each being understanding whichever meaning he or she wishes to know.

dang por ji skad zhal gyis bzhes pa'i dam bca' de mthar phyin par mdzad kyi nam yang bar ma dor ba'am chud za ba med pas mi smad pa'am ma smad pa'o/ / yang lam 'di la zhugs par byas na 'bras bu 'di thob bo zhes gsungs pa ltar don de nges par thob pas sems can rnams kyi de ltar ma yin zhes smad du med pa yang go bar bya'o/ /

(56) It is beyond reproach, in that once he has made a promise, the Buddha always fulfills it; he never lets it drop or cannot be bothered. This can also be understood to mean that when the Buddha says, “If you practice this path, you will achieve this result,” it will definitely happen like that, so beings cannot criticize what he says as untrue.
gdul bya gang zhig nam 'dul ba'i dus la bab par 'doms pas de'i don du bsnyel ba med pa dang gzhan don 'byung ba las mi g.yo ba'am mi 'gyur ba'o/ /

(57) It never wavers or deviates from the Buddha’s unfailing mindfulness of beings’ welfare and from his actually benefiting others: the Buddha’s instructions are always perfectly timed for the particular beings that need training.
mi rigs pa'am mi legs par ha cang myur ches pa dang rtab rtab por mi gsungs pas brtan pa'am ma rtab pa'o/ /
(58) It is steady or unhurried: the Buddha never teaches irrationally or badly, speaking too fast or nervously.

ji ltar drung na gnas pa rnams kyis sgra ha cang mi che mi chung ba gsal zhing legs par thos pa bzhin du/ rgyang na gnas pa dang gdul byar gyur pa gzhan 'jig rten gyi khams shin tu mang po'i pha rol na gnas pas kyang / drung na gnas pa rnams kyis ji ltar thos pa dang mtshungs par thos pas 'khor thams cad la gsungs pa'am 'khor kun tu grags pa'o/ /

(59) What he says is spoken to all his disciples or resounds throughout his following, for while those in his presence hear his voice perfectly clearly, without it being too loud or too soft, those who are far away and even other beings to be trained who are many myriads of world systems distant hear it just as well as those who are near him.
chos 'chad pa la thogs pa med pas dngos po thams cad dper byas te don thams cad rdzogs par ston par byed pas rnam pa kun gyi mchog dang ldan pa ste de ltar drug cu tham pa'o/ /

(60) His speech is most excellent in every respect: there is nothing that impedes his teaching the Dharma, and he can take anything as an example, using it to teach every kind of subject perfectly. These, then, are the sixty expressive qualities of buddha speech.[15]
sangs rgyas kyi gsung gis chos ston pa'i tshul ni rnam pa brgyad de/
As for the manner in which the Buddha uses his speech to teach the Dharma, this has eight aspects.

ngag tshig shin tu rigs pa dang / / brten dang rnam 'byed the tshom gcod/ / lan mang byed dang ldan pa ni/ / mgo smos rnam spros go rnams la/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyi ston pa 'di/ / 'khor gsum gyis ni dag pa ste/ / 'di ni nyes pa brgyad dag dang / / bral ba nyid du shes par bya/ /

With words, solid reasoning, Brief introductions, detailed explanations, The clearing of doubts, and much repetition, For those who understand when merely told the title or else from detailed presentations, (XIII, 10) The buddhas teach, and their teaching Is pure, free of the three spheres; Know that it is devoid Of eight faults: (XIII, 11)

don gyi ngo bo ston pa ka ba lta bu'i ming ngam ngag dang don gyi khyad par ka ba mi rtag lta bu tshig gi sgo nas 'chad pa dang / tshad ma dang ldan par ston pas shin tu rigs pa ni/ don nam rtsa ba dang rab tu ldan par 'chad pa dang / mdor bstan pas 'chad pa dang / de'i don rgyas par bshad pa'am rnam par 'byed pas 'chad pa dang / rigs pa'i sgo nas the tshom gcod pa dang / sgrub byed kyi rnam par yang nas yang du lan mang por byed pa dang ldan pa dang ni/ mgo smos pas go ba la 'chad pa dang / rnam par spro bas go ba rnams la 'chad pa dang brgyad do/ / 'di dag gi don mdo las brjod do/ /'dogs so rab tu 'jog go /rnam par 'byed do/ /rnam par 'grel to/ /gsal bar byed do/ /ston to/ /yang dag par rab tu ston to zhes gsungs te/

(1) He explains things using names and expressions such as “pillar” to indicate the essence of an object, and phrases such as “Pillars are impermanent” to indicate its particular characteristics. (2) Using valid cognition to teach, he explains things logically, fully incorporating the meaning or main point. (3) He explains things with brief presentations and (4) with detailed explanations or analyses. (5) Using logic, he removes doubts. (6) He repeats the teachings many times, making use of proofs. (7) He gives explanations for those who can understand merely from being told the title. (8) He gives explanations for those who can understand only from being given detailed presentations. These eight are mentioned in the sūtras, which state that the Buddha expresses, designates, defines, analyzes, comments, clarifies, indicates, and gives complete instruction.

ming gi ngo bo brjod cing tshig gis de'i khyad par bstan pa'i sgo nas/ dad pa'i rjes su 'brang ba'i gang zag la 'dus byas thams cad mi rtag pa'o zhes tshig gis 'chad pa dang / rigs pa'i rjes 'brangs la mi rtag pa nyid du rigs pas sgrub par byed pa ni rtsa ba'am don dang bcas par byed pa'am tshad mas 'dogs so zhes dang / mdor bstan pa tsam gyis lus rnam par 'jog go / de'i don zhib cing rgyas par rnam par 'byed do/ / de nas the tshom bcad pa ni rnam pa 'grel bar byed do/ / don phyin ci ma log par rtogs par bya ba'i phyir 'chad pa'i rnam grangs du mar spros te lan mang du yang yang ston pa ni don shin tu gsal bar byed do zhes so/ / mgo smos pa tsam gyis go ba la don gyi gnad mdo tsam ston te/ rnam par spros pas go ba rnams la zhib tu spros te rgyas par bshad ni/ yang dag par rab tu ston pa'am/ rab tu bsgrags so/ /zhes gsungs so/ /

(1) By expressing the essence of a thing with its name and indicating its particular characteristics with phrases, the Buddha explains things to individuals who follow him on the basis of faith with the phrase “All that is compounded is impermanent.” (2) To those who follow him on the basis of reasoning, he establishes impermanence by means of reasoning—associating things with the main point or meaning, or “designating” things by means of valid cognition. (3) He defines the main body of the subject with just a brief presentation. (4) He gives a thorough, detailed analysis of its meaning. (5) He subsequently resolves uncertainties by giving a full commentary. (6) In order that the meaning be understood correctly, he expands upon the subject with numerous different explanations, repeating the teaching many times to make the meaning quite clear. (7) To those who understand simply from the title being mentioned he briefly indicates the key points. (8) To those who understand only from details he gives elaborate and detailed explanations, giving complete instructions or “fully proclaiming.”

de'i dang po gnyis gang gis bshad pa dang / de'i rjes kyi bstan sogs bzhi ji ltar bshad pa dang / phyi ma gnyis gang la bshad pa yin la de ltar sangs rgyas rnams kyi chos ston pa rnam pa brgyad po 'di ni gang gis ston pa dang / ji ltar ston pa dang / gang la ston pa zhes bya ba'i 'khor gsum gyis ni rnam par dag pa ste/ sangs rgyas rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes mthar phyin pas chos ston kyang de'i 'khor gsum du dmigs pa med pas shin tu rnam par dag pa yin la/

The first two of these refer to what the buddhas use to give an explanation; the next four (brief presentation and so on) refer to how they explain things; and the last two refer to the persons to whom they give explanations. The buddhas’ teaching of the Dharma, with these eight aspects, is perfectly pure in terms of the three spheres—namely, who is teaching, the manner in which they teach, and whom they teach. The buddhas have perfected nonconceptual gnosis, so in their teaching of the Dharma too they have no concepts of these three spheres, and their teaching is therefore utterly, perfectly pure.
der ma zad sangs rgyas kyis chos ston pa 'di ni gtam gyi nyes pa brgyad dang yang bral ba nyid du shes par bya'o/ /
Moreover, the buddhas’ teaching the Dharma should be understood as being free of eight faults in discourse.

le lo dang ni mi go ba/ / skabs mi 'byed dang ma nges dang / / the tshom dag ni mi gcod dang / / de dang bral bar brten mi byed/ / skyo ba dang ni ser sna nyid/ / 'di dag gtam gyis nyes par 'dod/ / de dag med phyir sangs rgyas kyi/ / bshad pa bla na med par 'gyur/ /

Laziness, incomprehensibility, Failure to set a time, lack of certainty, Failure to resolve doubts, Failure to stabilize freedom from doubt, (XIII, 12) Discouragement, and stinginess— These are held to be faults in discourse. Because it is free of these, The buddhas’ teaching is unexcelled. (XIII, 13)

brgyad gang zhe na/ nyal ba dang 'khres pa sogs la zhen nas chos 'chad par mi spro ba'i le lo dang ni/ chos bshad kyang rang gi ji bzhin ma rtogs pa'am tshig gam don gsal bar ma bstan pas rtogs bya'i chos mi go ba dang / chos bstan par mi 'dod pas chos bstan pa'i skabs mi 'byed pa dang ma nges pa'am nges don min pa ni nges don gyi chos mi 'chad par drang don 'chad pa'am/ yang na rgyas par ma bshad pas gzhan gyis de'i don ma nges pa dang / bstan kyang gdul bya rnams gang la som nyi za ba'i the tshom dag ni mi gcod pa dang / the tshom de dang bral bar yang yang rnam grangs sna tshogs kyis gtan la dbab ste bstan par mi byed pa dang / chos 'chad pa la dka' tshegs kyi 'du shes kyis skyo ba dang / chos la ser sna byas te 'chab pa nyid de 'di dag gtam gyi skabs su nyes par 'dod de rnam pa brgyad po de dag gtan nas med phyir sangs rgyas kyi chos bshad pa ni bla na med pa yin par brjod do/ / phyi ma 'di brgyad kyang snga ma brgyad po'i mi mthun phyogs spangs pa'i cha nas le lo med par ston/ rigs pa dang 'brel pas don go bar byed/ skabs 'byed de mdor bsdus te ston/ rgyas par bshad pas ma nges pa spangs/ the tshom gcod pa dngos/ bstan par byed pa lan mang ston/ rnam par spros pas go ba la skyo ba med par ston/ mgo smos pas go ba la ser sna med par ston zhes sbyar ba yod de don la 'byor par 'dug blo brtan 'grel chen du de ltar sbyor ba mi snang ngo /

What are these eight? (1) A disinclination to expound the Dharma on account of a penchant for sleeping, lounging, and so on, constitutes laziness. (2) Even if one does teach the Dharma, because one does not understand it oneself, or because one fails to set forth the words or meanings clearly, the subject to be understood is not comprehended. (3) Since one does not want to teach the Dharma, one does not set a time to do so. (4) One teaches “without certainty” or without the ultimate meaning, giving the expedient teachings rather than explaining the ultimate teachings; or, alternatively, not giving detailed explanations, so that others are uncertain as to their meaning.[16] (5) Even if one does teach, one fails to clear up disciples’ doubts. (6) While freeing them of their doubts, one fails to use a wide range of different explanations, repeatedly, to help them gain a definitive understanding and render it stable. (7) One is discouraged by the thought of how difficult it is to teach the Dharma. (8) One is miserly with the teachings and keeps them to oneself. These are held to be faults in the context of giving discourses. Because it is completely free of these eight faults, the buddhas’ exposition of the Dharma is described as unsurpassable. From the point of view of these eight incompatible traits having been abandoned, there is a correlation with the above eight aspects of the buddhas’ teaching the Dharma, as follows: teaching without laziness; making the meaning understood by associating it with reasoning; choosing the right moment and giving brief presentations; getting rid of uncertainty by giving detailed explanations; actually resolving doubts; bringing about stability by repeated teaching; not getting fed up with those who need elaborate explanations to understand the subject; and unstintingly teaching those for whom the mere mention of the title affords comprehension. This correlation is not mentioned in Sthiramati’s Great Commentary.
bzhi pa bshad bya dam pa'i chos
4. THE NATURE OF THE DHARMA THAT IS TAUGHT
['di] la chos spyi yi mtshan nyid dang / dgongs ldem dgongs bye brag tu bshad pa'o/ /
This section comprises (1) the general characteristics of the Dharma and (2) a specific explanation of the implied and indirect teachings.
dang po/
a. THE GENERAL CHARACTERISTICS OF THE DHARMA

dad dang dga' dang blo rnams kyi/ / rgyu phyir chos 'di dge ba yin/ / don rnam gnyis ldan gzung bla dang / / yon tan gzhi can tshangs spyod ston/ / gzhan dag thun mong ma yin ldan pa dang / / khams gsum nyon mongs rnams spong rdzogs byed dang / / ngo bo nyid dag dri mas dag pa ste/ / tshangs spyod yon tan bzhi ldan yin par 'dod/ /

Because it engenders faith, joy, and understanding, This Dharma is virtuous; Having twofold meaning and easy to retain, It teaches pure activity with four good qualities. (XIII, 14) Having nothing in common with others, Completing the elimination of the defilements of the three worlds, Naturally pure, and decontaminating— Such is held to be pure activity with four good qualities. (XIII, 15)
ces tshigs bcad gnyis kyis bstan te/
