dam pa'i chos zhes pa ji lta bu zhig la 'dod ce na/ dge ba gsum dang / bzang po gnyis dang / yon tan bzhi dang ldan pa ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung rab dam pa'i chos zhes bya ba yin no/ / de gang zhe na/ dam pa'i chos nyan pa'i dus su yid ches kyi dad pa skyed pa'i rgyu yin pa'i phyir chos ni thog mar dge ba'o/ / bsam pa'i dus na nges pa rnyed de yid dga' ba skye ba'i rgyu'i phyir bar du dge ba'o/ / bsgom pa'i dus na yang dag pa'i blo gros rnams kyi rgyu byed pa'i phyir tha mar dge ba ste/ de ltar dam pa'i chos 'di ni dus thog mtha' bar gsum du dge ba dang legs pa kho na yin no/ /

What constitutes the “sacred Dharma”? That which is triply virtuous, doubly excellent, and possessed of four good qualities is what we call the “sacred Dharma,” the Excellent Words of the Tathāgata. What do these refer to? Because the sacred Dharma makes us feel confident faith when we listen to it, it is virtuous in the beginning. Because it causes us to gain certainty and to feel joyful when we reflect on it, it is virtuous in the middle. And because it leads to correct understanding when we meditate, it is virtuous in the end. Thus the sacred Dharma is nothing but virtuous and wholesome, in the beginning, the middle, and the end.

bzang po gnyis ni shes par bya ba kun rdzob kyi bden pa dang / don dam pa'i bden pa yi don rnam pa gnyis phyin ci ma log par yang dag par ston pa dang ldan pa ni don bzang po dang / 'jig rten na yongs su grags pa'i skad kyi nges tshig dang mthun par tshig dang yi ge phun sum tshogs pas bstan pas go sla ba'am gzung sla ba ni tshig 'bru bzang po'o/ /

Its double excellence refers to (1) excellent meaning, in that the sacred Dharma correctly and unmistakenly teaches the twofold meaning that is to be known—that of relative truth and of ultimate truth, and (2) excellent words, in that it is taught using all the right words and letters in accordance with the etymological definitions of universally accepted language, and it is therefore easy to understand or retain.

yon tan bzhi can gyi tshangs par spyod pa 'phags pa'i lam nyid lung gi chos kyis ston pa yin no/ / tshangs pa zhes pa ni skabs 'dir mya ngan las 'das pa la bya ste/ mdo las tshangs par gyur/ bsil bar gyur/ mya ngan las 'das par gyur ces gsungs pa bzhin no/ / mya ngan las 'das pa thob par byed pa 'phags pa'i lam la tshangs par spyod pa zhes bya'o/ / 'phags lam de yon tan bzhi dang ldan pa ste/ 'phags pa'i de nyid chos 'di 'ba' zhig la yod kyi 'di las phyi rol du gyur ba mu stegs sogs gzhan dang thun mong ma yin pa ldan pa ma 'dres pa dang / 'phags pa'i lam ni khams gsum gyi nyon mongs pa mtha' dag rnam par spong ba yongs su rdzogs par byed pas yongs su rdzogs pa dang / 'jig rten pa'i lam de srid rtse bar du song yang slar ldog pas khams gsum gyi nyon mongs mtha' dag gtan du spong ba'i lam yongs su ma rdzogs pa'o/ / 'phags pa'i lam de nam mkha' dang shel ltar rang bzhin gyis rnam par dag pa zag pa med pa'i rang bzhin yin pa'i phyir yongs su dag pa dang / lam des glo bur gyi dri ma bsal nas slar mi skye bar sems zag pa med pa'i rang bzhin du byed pas yongs su byang ba ste/ tshangs par spyod pa'i yon tan bzhi dang ldan pa yin par 'dod do/ /

The four good qualities are properties of pure activity, the noble path, which is shown by the Dharma of transmission. “Pure,” in this context, refers to nirvāṇa—as we read in the sūtras, “It is pure, it is cool, it is beyond suffering.” The noble path that leads us to attain nirvāṇa is what we call “pure activity.” This noble path has the following four good qualities: (1) The noble path itself is only to be found in the Buddha’s teachings: it is quite distinct from other, non-Buddhist traditions such as those of the tīrthikas and has nothing in common with them. (2) The noble path brings to perfect completion the elimination of all the defilements related to the three worlds, so it is perfectly complete. Mundane paths may lead to the peak of existence, but since they subsequently involve returning, they are not complete paths that eliminate all the defilements related to the three worlds forever. (3) The noble path is completely pure, for it is untainted by nature, naturally pure like space or a crystal. (4) That path is completely purifying, for it renders the mind free of taint, removing adventitious contaminants so that they never occur again. The Dharma is thus said to have the four good qualities of pure activity.
b. A SPECIFIC EXPLANATION OF THE IMPLIED AND INDIRECT TEACHINGS

de bzhin gshegs pa rnams gdul bya'i khams dbang mos pa dang mthun par chos ston par mdzad pas dgongs pa dang ldem dgongs kyi tshul du dgongs pa'i dbang gis bstan pa yang du ma yod pas de dag gi dgongs pa tshul bzhin du ma shes nas/ sgra ji bzhin du gzung na yang dag pa nges pa'i don mi rtogs shing dgongs pa can drang ba'i don dang tshig gi don bzhin phyin ci log tu 'dzin par 'gyur bas de shan 'byed pa shin tu gal che bas ldem dgongs bzhi bshad pa dang / dgongs pa bzhi bshad pa dang / gnyen por dgongs pa brgyad gsungs pa'i phan yon bcas bstan pa gsum las/

The tathāgatas teach the Dharma in accord with the dispositions, faculties, and aspirations of the beings to be trained, and there are therefore numerous teachings that take the form of implied teachings and indirect teachings and depend on the tathāgatas’ intentions. If one takes the teachings literally without having properly understood their intention, one will not realize the correct, definitive meaning, and one will mistakenly take the intended meaning to be an expedient meaning or to be the literal meaning. Since it is extremely important to distinguish between these, there now follow explanations of (1) the four indirect teachings; (2) the four implied teachings; and (3) eight sayings intended as antidotes, together with their benefits.
dang po ni/
i. AN EXPLANATION OF THE FOUR INDIRECT TEACHINGS

gzhug pa ldem por dgongs pa dang / / mtshan nyid ldem por dgongs pa dang / / gnyen po ldem por dgongs pa dang / / bsgyur ba ldem por dgongs pa ste/ / nyan thos dang ni ngo bo nyid/ / de bzhin nyes pa 'dul ba dang / / brjod pa zab pa nyid la ni/ / ldem por dgongs pa 'di rnam bzhi/ /

Indirect teachings given for the purpose of introducing, Indirect teachings on reality, Indirect teachings connected with remedial methods, And indirect teachings expressed through metaphors— (XIII, 16) These are the four kinds of indirect teachings, Given when the buddhas have in mind the listeners, reality, And likewise the suppression of faults And the expression of the profound. (XIII, 17)
zhes pas bstan te/

gang zag gzhug pa la ldem por dgongs pa dang / chos kyi mtshan nyid la ldem por dgongs pa dang / gdul bya'i rgyud kyi nyes pa 'dul ba'i gnyen po la ldem por dgongs pa dang / tshig dang yi ges bstan don 'jig rten grags tshod las don gzhan du bsgyur ba la ldem por dgongs pa bzhi ste/ de dag gi don ni rim pa bzhin du brjod na/ chos bdag med la 'jug mi nus pa'i nyan thos rnams thar pa'i lam la gzhug pa la dgongs nas/ gang zag gi bdag med kyi phung sogs kyi chos yod par bstan pa ni kun brtags pa'i gang zag med pa dang gzhan dbang rten 'brel gyi chos tha snyad du yod pa tsam la dgongs te de ltar gsungs pa dang ni/ ngo bo nyid med pa dang skye ba med pa la sogs par gsungs pa ni tha snyad du yod pa'i chos rnams gtan med pa dang skye 'gag ltar snang ba med ces gsungs pa ma yin gyi don dam pa'i mtshan nyid dam ngo bo nyid la ldem por dgongs pa ste dper na ngo bo nyid gsum kun brtags dang / gzhan dbang / yongs grub gsum bstan pa'i nang nas/ kun brtags pa'i ngo bo'am mtshan nyid ni rten med pas mtshan nyid med pa dang / gzhan dbang sems sems byung las gnas don lus snang ba rnams la skye 'gag tu snang ba yod kyang rgyu rkyen rten 'brel dbang gis de ltar snang ba las rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis skye 'gag med pa'i skye ba ngo bo nyid med pa dang / yongs grub ni rang bzhin gyis mya ngan las 'das pa zhi ba stong pa don dam pa ngo bo nyid med pa'o/ /

The four indirect teachings are indirect teachings aimed at introducing people to the path; indirect teachings on the nature of reality; indirect teachings connected with remedial methods for overcoming faults in beings’ mind streams; and indirect teachings in which the accepted, conventional meanings shown by the words and letters are given a different, metaphoric sense. These will be discussed in turn. With the intention of introducing listeners, who are unable to approach the no-self of phenomena, to the path of liberation, the Buddha taught the existence of phenomena such as the aggregates of the nonexisting individual self. What he had in mind was that the imputed individual does not exist and that the interdependent phenomena of the dependent nature merely exist conventionally. When the Buddha declared that phenomena are devoid of essence, are unborn, and so on, he was not saying that phenomena that exist on the conventional level do not exist at all and that there is no apparent arising and ceasing. Rather, he was indirectly teaching the ultimate reality or essential nature. Take, for example, his teaching on the three natures—namely, the imputed reality, the dependent reality, and the fully present reality. Since the imputed nature or reality does not exist at all, he spoke of the absence of characteristics. For the dependent reality, although the environment, sense objects, and body do appear to arise and cease from the mind and mental factors, apart from their appearing like that as a result of the interdependence of causes and conditions, they have no intrinsic production and cessation, and he spoke of them being unborn, devoid of essence. And for the fully present reality, he taught that it is by nature beyond suffering, peaceful, empty, ultimate, and devoid of essence.

gnyen po la ldem por dgongs pa ni/ snga ma de bzhin du gang zag gi rgyud kyi nyes pa 'dul ba'i phyir/ sngon sangs rgyas rnam par gzigs su gyur ces sogs 'og tu 'chad 'gyur brgyad bzhin no/ / bsgyur ba ldem dgongs ni sgra ji bzhin du ma yin pa'i brjod pa zab pa nyid la dgongs pa can te/ ji skad du/ snying po med la snying por shes/ / phyin ci log la rab tu gnas/ / nyon mongs pas ni rab nyon mongs/ / byang chub dam pa thob par 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs pa la sogs pa lta bu ste/ tshig 'di sgra ji bzhin du gzung na byang chub mi thob pa'i rgyu bstan pa ltar gnas kyang / don sa ra zhes pa rnam g.yeng dang snying po gnyis ka la 'jug pas de'i sngon du dgag pa'i a thung sbyar bas a sa ra rnam g.yeng med pa lhag pa sems kyi bslab pa la snying por rtogs pa'am shes pa dang / gtsang bde rtag bdag tu rtog pa bzhi ni dngos po la phyin ci log tu 'dzin pa yin la/ de las phyin ci log tu gyur pa ni/ mi rtag sdug bsngal mi gtsang bdag med pa shes pa'i lhag pa shes rab kyi bslab pa la rab tu gnas pa dang / sems can gyi don du yun ring por dka' spyad kyi nyon mongs pas ni rab tu nyon mongs par byas na byang chub dam pa thob ces so/ / 'grel chen du tshigs rkang snga ma gsum mos spyod dang mthong lam dang sgom lam sbyar bar mdzad 'dug kyang rung la so sor ma sbyar kyang ting nge 'dzin dang shes rab brtson 'grus gsum la sbyar bas chog go / de ltar ldem por dgongs pa 'di ni rnam pa bzhi'o/ /
gnyis pa/
ii. AN EXPLANATION OF THE FOUR IMPLIED TEACHINGS
mnyam pa nyid dang don gzhan dang / / de bzhin du ni dus gzhan dang / / gang zag gi ni bsam pa la/ / dgongs pa rnam pa bzhir shes bya/ /
Know that implied teachings are of four kinds, Implying sameness, another sense, And similarly another time, And with people’s attitudes in mind. (XIII, 18)
zhes pas bstan te/

sangs rgyas thams cad kyi chos sku mnyam pa nyid la dgongs nas ston pa shAkya'i rgyal po nga nyid de tshe sangs rgyas rnam par gzigs su gyur to zhes gsungs pa lta bu dang / don dam pa'i don gzhan la dgongs nas chos thams cad ngo bo nyid med pa dang ma skyes ma 'gag gzod nas zhi ba rang bzhin gyis mya ngan las 'das par gsungs pa dang / de bzhin du ni dus gzhan la dgongs pa/ le lo can dge rtsa cung zad byed du mi btub pa de bzhin gshegs pa snang ba mtha' yas kyi zhing du smon lam btab pa tsam gyis skye bar gsungs pa tshe rabs gzhan nam zhig la skye ba la dgongs pa dang / gang zag gi bsam pa la dgongs pa sbyin sogs rgya cher byed nus pa la sbyin pa bsngags pa dang / kha cig sbyin sogs cung zad tsam gyis chog par 'dzin pa la sbyin sogs smad pa'am ches ngo mtshar med tshul bstan pa dang / sbyin pa lta bu gcig gis chog pa dang / de gcig pu mchog tu 'dzin pa la/ tshul khrims la ltos na sbyin pa dman shing tshul khrims 'phags par bsngags pa lta bu'o/ / de ltar dgongs pa rnam pa bzhir shes par bya'o/ / dgongs pa can gyi gsung 'di dag ni shin tu mang po 'byung ste ci rigs shig theg bsdus su bstan pa bzhin no/ /

Having in mind the fact that all the buddhas are identical in the body of truth, our teacher, the King of the Śākyas, said, “At that time, I was the Buddha Vipaśyin.” With another sense, that of ultimate truth, in mind, he declared that all phenomena are devoid of inherent identity, that they are unborn and unceasing, primordial peace, by nature nirvāṇa. Similarly, with another time in mind, he told lazy people unable to perform a few positive actions that simply by reciting the prayer to be reborn in the tathāgata Amitābha’s buddha field, they would be born there—implying that one day, in some future life, they would be reborn there. Having in mind different people’s attitudes, he spoke in praise of generosity to those who were able to practice generosity and the like on a vast scale. To some who were content with just a little generosity or another of the transcendent perfections, he scorned their practice or assumed a look of not being greatly impressed. To those who were satisfied with a single practice like generosity, and those who considered that there was no better practice than generosity, he compared it unfavorably to discipline and praised discipline as being better. These, then, are examples of the four kinds of implied teaching that one should know. There are an enormous number of these implied teachings, as described in the Compendium of the Great Vehicle.
gsum pa/
iii. EIGHT SAYINGS INTENDED AS ANTIDOTES, TOGETHER WITH THEIR BENEFITS
The Teachings of the Supreme Vehicle as Antidotes to Eight Obscurations

sangs rgyas chos la brnyas pa dang / / le lo cung zad chog 'dzin dang / / nga rgyal 'dod chags spyod pa dang / / 'gyod dang ma nges ldog pa ni/ / sems can rnams kyi sgrib pa ste/ / de yi gnyen por theg mchog gsungs/ / des de'i bar du gcod pa yi/ / nyes pa thams cad spong bar 'gyur/ /

Contempt for the Buddha and for the Dharma, Laziness, complacency, Indulgence in pride and in attachment, Remorse, and rejection by those of unfixed potential—(XIII, 19) As the remedy to these obscurations in beings, The Buddha taught the Supreme Vehicle. With it, all the faults obstructing them Will be removed. (XIII, 20)

zhes sgrib pa brgyad kyi gnyen por theg pa mchog gi chos bstan pa ni/ ji ltar tshe lo brgya pa'i dus su byon pa'i shAkya'i rgyal po ni sku tshad chung zhing sku tshe yang brgyad cu las ma bzhes pa dang / snod kyi zhing yang ma dag la gdul bya sems can rnams kyang snyigs ma lnga dang ldan pa'o/ / sangs rgyas rnam gzigs sogs dus bzang bskal pa rdzogs ldan gyi dus byon pas de dag ni mchog la/ bdag cag gi ston pa ni de las dman no snyam du sangs rgyas la brnyas pa'i gnyen por nga de'i tshe de'i dus na sangs rgyas rnam gzigs su gyur to zhes sangs rgyas thams cad chos kyi skur mnyam pas bzang ngan med par dgongs pa yin gyi gdul bya rnams kyis rnam gzigs kyang ston pa nyid yin no snyam du mchog dman med par 'dzin to/ /

There were some who thought that our teacher was inferior to sublime buddhas like the Buddha Vipaśyin, who came at an auspicious time, during the age of perfect endowment.[17] The King of the Śākyas, who appeared at a time when human life span was one hundred years, was small in stature, and his life span was no longer than eighty years. His world was impure, and the beings he came to benefit were subject to the five degenerations.[18] With such thoughts, they disparaged the Buddha. To correct such attitudes, the Buddha said, “At that time, I was the Buddha Vipaśyin.” What he had in mind was the fact that all the buddhas are identical in the body of truth and that consequently there are no such things as good buddhas and bad buddhas. But his disciples thought, “Vipaśyin is the Teacher himself,” and they abandoned their notions of superiority or inferiority.

chos la brnyas te bram ze rnams kyi cho rigs 'byed pa'i bram ze dang rgyal rigs la sogs rigs bzang pos gdol pa sogs kyi spyad bya min la sangs rgyas kyi chos ni rigs ngan gdol pa tshun chad kyi spyod du rung bas rnyed sla'o snyam du brnyas pa'i gnyen por/ gang+ga'i klung gi bye ma snyed kyi sangs rgyas bsnyen bkur byas na gzod theg pa chen po'i chos khong du chud par 'gyur zhes tshogs bsags pa de lta bu dang mi ldan na rtogs dka' bar bstan pas chos rnyed sla'o snyam du brnyas pa spong bar byed do/ /

“Contempt for the Dharma” concerned high castes such as the priestly and warrior castes who were segregated by their brahmanical traditions and culture—which were certainly not for the likes of untouchables and other low castes. Since the Buddha’s teachings could be practiced by anyone, even by low-caste untouchables, the higher castes held them in contempt, thinking, “Such teachings must be easily acquired.” To remedy such attitudes, the Buddha said, “It is from having worshipped buddhas as numerous as the grains of sand in the Ganges that one will subsequently master the teachings of the Great Vehicle,” indicating how difficult it is to realize the Mahāyāna teachings unless one has accumulated similar merit. In this way he made those who thought that the Dharma is easily accessible give up their disrespectful attitudes.

gang zag le lo can dge ba cung zad kyang skyed mi nus pa la bde ba can du smon lam btab na der skye bar 'gyur zhes dang / de bzhin gshegs pa dri ma med pa'i zla ba'i mtshan bzung ba tsam gyis bla med byang chub thob par 'gyur ro/ / zhes sogs dang gzungs gang zhig bklags pa tsam gyis mtshams med pa lnga'i las sogs dag par gsungs pa ltar le lo can dag kyang / smon lam de lta bu 'debs pa dang / mtshan 'dzin pa dang / gzungs bklags pa'i sgo nas dge rtsa bsags pa'i rgyu des nam zhig ji skad gsungs pa ltar bde ba can du skye ba dang 'tshang rgya ba sogs su nges par 'gyur ba dang / rgyu de tsam la brten nas gong nas gong du brtson par yang 'gyur bas le lo spong bar byed do/ /

For lazy people who are unable to give rise to even a little virtue, the Buddha said such things as, “If you say the prayer of aspiration to attain the Blissful Realm, you will be reborn there” and “Simply by reciting the name of the tathāgata Vimalacandra, you will attain unsurpassable enlightenment.” He also declared that the mere recitation of a dhāraṇī would purify negative actions like the five crimes with immediate retribution. Accordingly, by saying such prayers, reciting the buddhas’ names, and chanting dhāraṇīs, even lazy people will accumulate virtue. As a result, they will definitely, one day, be reborn in the Blissful Realm, attain buddhahood, and so on, as he declared. And simply by using those practices, they will also become more and more diligent and thus get rid of their laziness.

dge rtsa cung zad tsam gyis chog par 'dzin pa'i gnyen por dper na sbyin pa kho nas chog 'dzin can la/ tshul khrims bsngags shing sbyin pa de las dman pa'i don gyis smad pa'i rnam par bstan pa dang / 'jig rten pa'i dge ba zag bcas las zag med kyi dge ba khyad par du bsngags pa lta bu dang / sems can kha cig rang gi lus dang longs spyod kyis rgyags pa'i dbang gis nga rgyal la spyod pa'i gnyen por sangs rgyas dang byang sems kyi sku dang longs spyod rgya chen por bsngags pa brjod pa thos nas 'jig rten pa'i lus dang longs spyod ni ji ltar bzang yang chen po ci yang ma yin snyam du sems par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

To remedy being content with just a little virtue, the Buddha instructed those who were satisfied with practicing only generosity, for instance, by praising discipline and disparaging generosity (in the sense of it being inferior to discipline). And he praised untainted virtue as being superior to the tainted virtue of mundane paths. Some beings are infatuated with their bodies and possessions and thus indulge in pride. To remedy this, the Buddha spoke in praise of the buddhas’ and bodhisattvas’ immense bodies and wealth, so that when those beings heard this, they would think, “Worldly bodies and possessions, however good or great, are nothing much at all.”

'jig rten gyi longs spyod dman pa 'dod yon lnga la 'dod chags la spyod pa'i gnyen por sangs rgyas kyis zhing yongs su dag pa rnams kyi bde ba'i longs spyod tshad med pa 'di dang 'di lta bu yod ces bsngags pas zag bcas bsdug bsngal gyi rang bzhin 'khor ba'i 'dod yon la ngan skyugs ltar mthong nas yid nges par 'byung bar byed pa dang /

As a remedy against indulging in attachment to the five sense pleasures, the base enjoyments of the worldly, the Buddha gave glowing descriptions of the boundless riches and happiness to be had in the perfectly pure buddha fields. In this way he led beings full of attachment to regard samsaric sense pleasures, which are inherently tainted and associated with suffering, as if they were vomit, and to develop the determination to be free.

sems can la las mi shes pa'i dbang gis sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' la gnod pa byas nas/ phyis de dran pas bdag gis shin tu mi rigs pa zhig byas te bdag ngan song du 'gro bar 'gyur ro snyam du 'gyod pas sems dkrugs nas dge ba la tshul bzhin 'jug pa'i gegs su gyur pa la/ de'i gnyen por sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' la gnod pa byas na yang mtho ris su 'gro zhes gsungs pas 'gyod pa gtong bar byed de/ de dag la gnod pa byas na yang mtho ris su skye na phan pa byas na lta ci smos snyam du dad cing dge rtsa rim par 'phel ba byed de/ sangs rgyas byang sems la gnod pa byas pa'i 'bras bu sdug bsngal myong ba yod mod kyi/ sangs rgyas byang sems kyi smon lam gyi mthus nam zhig mtho ris sogs kyi bde bar 'brel ba la dgongs nas gnyen po'i phyir de skad gsungs pa'o/ /

Some beings, in ignorance, might injure a buddha or bodhisattva, and later, when they think about it and realize that what they have done is extremely wrong and that they will go to the lower realms, they feel such remorse that they become mentally disturbed. This can prevent them from properly engaging in positive activities. So to remedy this, the Buddha said that even if one has harmed a buddha or bodhisattva, one will go to the higher realms. As a result, those beings stop feeling so remorseful, and they gain faith and think, “If I’ll be reborn in the higher realms despite having hurt them, no need to mention what will come from helping them!” In the process, their virtuous activities will gradually increase. Of course, the result of inflicting injury on a buddha or bodhisattva is that one will experience suffering, but by the power of the buddhas’ and bodhisattvas’ aspirations, one will one day meet with happiness in the higher realms and so on, so it was with this in mind that the Buddha gave this remedial instruction.

byang sems ma nges pa'i rigs can rnams sngon byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa spyad pa las/ phyis nyan thos la sogs pa'i bshes gnyen gyis nyan thos kyi theg par spyod du bcug nas byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa btang na theg pa chen po las ldog pa nyid 'dod pa'i gnyen por nyan thos rnams kyang mthar sangs rgyas 'thob ces theg pa gcig tu bstan pas nyan thos kyi theg pas mya ngan las 'da' bar 'dod pa rnams kyang theg pa chen po la gzhol bar byed do/ / de ltar sangs rgyas dang chos la brnyas pa sogs brgyad po de gang yin yang sems can rnams kyi sgrib pa ste/ sgrib pa de yi gnyen por theg pa chen po mchog gsungs pa yin la/ theg pa mchog de las bshad ma thag pa gnyen po brgyad po des/ gang zag de'i sgrib pa'am theg chen la 'jug pa'i bar du gcod pa yi nyes pa de thams cad spong bar 'gyur ro/ /

Certain beings of unfixed bodhisattva potential begin by practicing the activities of a bodhisattva but are subsequently induced to practice the Listeners’ Vehicle by a teacher such as a listener, so that they give up the bodhisattva way. In doing so, they are rejecting the Great Vehicle, so to remedy this sort of inclination, the Buddha said, “Even the listeners will ultimately attain buddhahood.” By thus indicating a single vehicle, he induced those who wished to attain nirvāṇa by means of the Listeners’ Vehicle to dedicate themselves to the Great Vehicle. These eight cases, beginning with contempt for the Buddha and Dharma, all constitute obscurations for beings, and it was to remedy these obscurations that the Buddha taught the supreme Great Vehicle. The above-mentioned eight remedies from the Supreme Vehicle will remove all those people’s obscurations or faults that prevent them from following the Great Vehicle.
Ten Benefits
gang zhig tshig gam don sgo nas/ / tshigs bcad gnyis 'dzin rab sbyor ba/ / sems can blo ldan mchog de yis/ / yon tan rnam bcu thob 'gyur te/ /
The best of wise beings who apply themselves To holding the Two Stanzas, By means of the words or meaning, Will acquire ten kinds of good qualities: (XIII, 21)

gang zhig sgrib pa brgyad spong ba'i gnyen po brgyad ston pa'i tshig gam don gyi sgo nas tshigs su bcad pa gnyis pa'i gzungs las/ sangs rgyas dang ni chos la brnyas pa dang sogs tshigs bcad gnyis gsungs pa de lta bu yin la/ de nyid kyi tshig blo la 'dzin pa dang / don 'di dang 'di zhes rab tu dbye ba yid la byed pa la rab tu sbyor ba sems can blo ldan mchog de yis/ yon tan rnam pa bcu thob par 'gyur te/ gang zhe na

As to the words or points that indicate the eight remedies that eliminate the eight obscurations, they are enunciated in two verses in the Two Stanza Incantation: “Disparaging the Buddha, and the Dharma…,” and so on. The best of wise beings who apply themselves to retaining its words and keeping in mind their distinct meanings will acquire ten kinds of excellent qualities. What are these ten?

khams ni zad par brtas pa dang / / 'chi ba'i tshe na rab dga' mchog / ji ltar 'dod par skye ba dang / / kun tu tshe rabs dran pa dang / / sangs rgyas rnams dang 'phrad pa dang / / de las theg mchog thos pa dang / / mos pa blo dang bcas pa dang / / sgo gnyis byang chub myur thob pa'o/ /

The fullest increase of their potential, The greatest happiness at the moment of death, Rebirth wherever they wish, And in all their lives, recollection of their past lives, (XIII, 22) Meetings with the buddhas, Hearing the Supreme Vehicle from them, Endowment with interest and understanding, Acquisition of the two doors, and swift attainment of enlightenment. (XIII, 23)

theg pa chen po'i chos thams cad la mos shing dad pas theg chen gyi rigs sam khams ni zad par te mtha' dag brtas par 'gyur ba dang / 'chi ba'i tshe na yid rab tu dga' ba mchog thob par 'gyur ba dang gnyis mthong chos tshe 'dir 'byung ba'i yon tan no/ / phyi mar 'byung ba brgyad ni/ shi nas rang gis gang ji ltar 'dod par skye ba dang / skye ba thams cad kun tu tshe rabs dran pa dang / ston pa sangs rgyas rnams dang phrad pa dang / sangs rgyas de las theg pa mchog gi chos thos pa dang / theg pa chen po la mos pa dang / don nges pa'i blo gros dang bcas par 'gyur ba dang / dpa' bar 'gro ba sogs ting 'dzin gyi sgo dang / mi zad pa'i za ma tog sogs gzungs kyi sgo gnyis thob pa dang / mthar bla na med pa'i byang chub myur du thob pa'o/ /

As a result of interest and faith in all the Mahāyāna teachings, their Mahāyāna potential or buddha nature will grow to its fullest extent, and at the time of death, they will be utterly happy. These two are qualities that will occur in this present life. The next eight will occur in subsequent lives. After death, they will take birth wherever they wish. In all their lives, wherever they are reborn, they will remember their past lives; encounter their teachers, the buddhas; and hear the teachings of the Supreme Vehicle from those buddhas. They will have an interest in the Great Vehicle and gain a definitive understanding as to its meaning. They will acquire both the door of concentration (concentrations such as the Concentration of Brave Progression) and the door of retention (Inexhaustible Caskets and others). And finally, they will swiftly attain unsurpassable enlightenment.
lnga pa chos bshad pa'i yon tan bsngags pa'i sgo nas don bsdu ba ni/
5. A SUMMARY IN PRAISE OF THE VIRTUES OF TEACHING THE DHARMA

de ltar blo bzang skyo ba med ldan brtse ba can/ / snyan par rab grags cho ga bzang shes ldan pa yi/ / byang chub sems dpa' legs par smra ba yin pa ste/ / bshad pas skye bo'i nang na nyi ma bzhin du lham/ /

Thus, bodhisattvas with good intellects, who are tireless, Loving, renowned, and expert in the right procedures, Are excellent exponents. In teaching, They are brightly shining suns in the midst of humankind. (XIII, 24)
zhes pas bstan te/

de ltar chos rnams phyin ci ma log par 'chad nus pa'i blo gros bzang po/ rgyun du chos 'chad pa la skyo ba med pa dang ldan pa dang rnyed bkur gyi ched ma yin par sems can la snying brtse ba can/ phar phyin drug dang ldan zhing 'jig rten na dam pa dang mkhas pa'i snyan pa rab tu grags pa/ sems can gang la chos gang bstan par 'os pa de ston pa sogs chos 'chad tshul gyi thabs sam cho ga bzang po shes pa dang ldan pa yi/ byang chub sems dpa' de ni dam pa'i chos legs par smra ba yin pa ste/ des dam pa'i chos bshad pas skye bo'i tshogs kyi nang na dper na nyi ma bzhin du lham mer snang zhing nyi mas dro ba dang lo tog sogs smin pas phan par byed pa bzhin du sems can la phan par byed do/ /

Thus, bodhisattvas who have excellent intellects and are able to explain the teachings correctly; who never lose heart in constantly explaining the Dharma; who truly love sentient beings and have no interest in honors or riches; who practice the six transcendent perfections and are universally renowned for their goodness and learning; who know the best procedure or way for teaching the Dharma (knowing, for example, which teachings to give which kinds of beings)—such bodhisattvas are excellent exponents of the sacred Dharma. In explaining the sacred Dharma, they shine as brightly as the sun among the hosts of human beings, benefiting them like the sun warming the earth and ripening the crops.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ bshad pa'i le'u ste bcu gsum pa'o// //
This completes the thirteenth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on teaching.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ bshad pa'i le'u ste bcu gsum pa rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the thirteenth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on teaching.
[sgrub pa'i le'u]
14. PRACTICING THE DHARMA
! de ltar chos tshol bas sgyu mang du thos pa dang ldan pa des chos bsgrub par bya dgos pas sgrub pa'i le'u la spyir bstan/ bye brag tu bshad/ don bsdu ba gsum las/

Someone who has investigated the Dharma and thereby received a lot of teachings needs to practice those teachings, so there now follows the chapter on practice, which is divided into three sections: (1) a general presentation; (2) a detailed explanation; and (3) a summary.
dang po/
1. GENERAL PRESENTATION

mdo las sgrub pa rnam par dbye ba bstan pa la/ don kun shes dang / chos kun shes pa dang / chos la chos kyi rjes su sgrub par 'gyur ba dang / mthun par zhugs pa dang / mthun pa'i chos la spyod pa yin zhes tshig lngas bstan pa ltar/

In the sūtras, the practice is divided into five categories: (1) full knowledge of meanings; (2) knowledge of the way; (3) practicing the way consistent with realization; (4) entrance into conformity; and (5) cultivation of consistent realization.
dang po don kun shes pa ni/
a. FULL KNOWLEDGE OF MEANINGS
blo ldan gnyis la log nyid dang / / yang dag nyid rnam spangs gsum gyis/ / gang zag dang ni chos dag la/ / bdag med rnam gnyis kun shes nas/ /
The wise, neither wrong Nor right with regard to the two, Fully know, by means of the three, The two kinds of no-self, individual and phenomenal. (XIV, 1)
zhes tshigs bcad drug gis bstan te/

blo ldan mos spyod du byang chub sems dpa' des bden pa gnyis sam/ yang na kun brtags med pa dang gzhan dbang dang yongs grub yod pa gnyis la/ log pa nyid dang yang dag pa rnam spangs zhes pa/ mos spyod pas bdag med gnyis rtogs pa de de kho na nyid dang mthun pas 'jig rten pa'i blo gzhan la ltos na phyin ci ma log pa yin pas log pa nyid kyang ma yin pa dang / 'jig rten pa yin pas 'jig rten las 'das pa'i blo la ltos na yang dag pa nyid kyang ma yin pas de gnyis rnam par spangs pa'i rang bzhin yin la/ de ltar mos spyod pa'i stong nyid dang / smon pa med pa dang / mtshan ma med pa'i ting nge 'dzin gsum gyis/ gang zag dang ni chos dag la bdag med pa rnam pa gnyis kun shes nas zhes/ stong pa nyid kyi ting nge 'dzin gyis gang zag dang chos su ming dang mtshan ma dang brda dang tha snyad kyis btags pa tsam yin par khong du chud nas kun brtags pa'i ngo bo med par stong pa nyid shes nas/ gang zag gi bdag kyang gzung ba'i ngo bor med par 'dzin pa'i ngo bor med pa dang / gzugs sgra sogs chos rnams kyi bdag kyang gzung ba'i ngo bor med/ 'dzin pa'i ngo bor med pas bdag gnyis po de ri bong gi rwa ltar don la ye nas yod ma myong bar kun nas shes so/ /

Wise beings, bodhisattvas on the level of earnest aspiration, are “neither wrong nor right” with regard to the two truths or, alternatively, with regard to the imputed reality, which does not exist, and the dependent and fully present realities, which do exist. Their understanding, on the level of earnest aspiration, of the two kinds of no-self is consistent with thatness, and so, compared to other ordinary beings’ minds, they are not mistaken and they are therefore not wrong. But, compared to supramundane beings’ minds, they are not right either, for they are still ordinary beings. They are therefore, by nature, not either of these two. Thus, with the three concentrations of emptiness, absence of expectancy, and absence of attributes, bodhisattvas on the level of earnest aspiration are said to have a full knowledge of the two kinds of no-self: the individual no-self and the phenomenal no-self. With the concentration of emptiness, they understand that individuals and phenomena are merely labeled as such with names, attributes, words, and conventional designations, and know emptiness as the absence of any entity in the imputed reality. And since neither the individual self nor the phenomenal self (in form, sound, and so on) exists as an objective or subjective entity, they know fully that both kinds of self have in fact never existed since the very beginning, like the horns of a rabbit.

gzung 'dzin gnyis su snang ba'i gzhi gzhan dbang gi sems sems byung yang dag ma yin pa'i kun tu rtog pa ni tha snyad du yod de kun nas nyon mongs pa dang 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal sna tshogs pa bsnyon med bslu med du grub pa 'di la sus kyang med ces brjod mi rigs te 'di med na kun nyon dang rnam byang du rnam par bzhag pa'ang ye nas mi srid na yang 'khor 'das gnyis yod pa la su yang rtsod pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar gzhan dbang yod kyang yang dag min rtog sdug bsngal gyi gnas dang chags sogs nyon mongs pas skyon can du byas pas re smon gyi gnas ma yin par rtogs pa smon pa med pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyis de'i rang bzhin ji lta ba bzhin du shes so/ /

The incorrect mental processes of false imagination—in other words, the mind and mental factors that constitute the dependent nature, which is the basis of the dualistic appearances of subject and object—exist on the conventional level, for the process of defilement and the various sufferings of saṃsāra surely and undeniably exist, and no one can say that they do not. If they did not exist, it would be impossible, from the start, to present things in terms of defilement and purity. But there is saṃsāra and there is nirvāṇa, and no one can dispute that. Despite the dependent reality existing in this way, it is flawed by the false imagination that is the source of suffering and by defilements such as attachment, so it is not something to be hoped for or aspired to. Realizing this, bodhisattvas come to know the nature of the dependent reality through the concentration of absence of expectancy.

yongs su grub pa ni bdag gnyis dang gzung 'dzin gnyis kyis stong pa'i rang bzhin yin pas de ni chos kun la me'i tsha ba dang chu'i gsher ba ltar chos nyid du ye nas yod pa yin te/ de med na bdag gnyis dang gzung 'dzin yod par 'gyur ro/ / de ltar chos nyid yongs grub de ni yod kyang gzung 'dzin gyi spros pa gang gi yang mtshan ma med pas smra ba dang bsam pa'i rnam par rtog pa nye bar zhi ba de mtshan ma med pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyis shes par byed pas de ltar yod pa med pa'i don kun shes pa'am/ kun brtags dang gzhan dbang kun rdzob kyi bden pa dang / yongs grub don dam pa'i bden pa gnyis la de ltar med pa dang yod pa'i don kun shes nas zhes so/ /

The fully present reality is the nature of emptiness devoid of the two kinds of self and of duality. From the beginning, it is present in all phenomena as their true nature, like the heat in fire or the wetness in water. If there were no fully present reality, subject and object and the two kinds of self would exist. Although this true nature, the fully present reality, exists, it is entirely devoid of attributes, of the conceptual elaborations of subject and object, and it is therefore a state in which all concepts that can be expressed or conceived have completely subsided. This is known with the concentration of absence of attributes. It is thus that bodhisattvas have a full knowledge of the meanings[1] of existence and nonexistence or, put another way, that they have a full knowledge of the meanings of nonexistence and existence in relation to the two truths—relative truth (the imputed reality and dependent reality) and ultimate truth (the fully present reality).
gnyis pa
b. KNOWLEDGE OF THE WAY
don shes pa ni chos rnams kun/ / gzings dang 'dra ba nyid du rig / thos pas chog par 'dzin spong ba/ / des na chos shes pa zhes brjod/ /
Then, those who know the meaning Realize that all teachings are like a boat And give up being content with listening. Thus they are said to know the way. (XIV, 2)

chos shes pa gang zhe na/ de ltar mdo sde sogs kyi bstan don shes pa ni/ mdo la sogs pa'i ming tshig yi ge tshogs pa'i rnam pa can gyi rjod byed chos rnams kun/ dper na chu brgal ba la gzings med du mi rung yang chu brgal zin nas gzings kyi don byas zin pas gzings kho na la brten mi dgos pa ltar brjod bya go zhing shes pa'i ched du brda sbyar ba'i ming tshig yi ge'i rnam pa'i chos rnams kyang gzings de dang 'dra ba nyid du rig nas tshig tsam thos pas chog par 'dzin pa spang ba nyid du byas nas tshig don la bsam byung gi shes rab bskyed par gtso bor bya ba ni chos shes pa zhes bya'o/ /

What is knowledge of the way? Bodhisattvas who in this manner know the meanings of the points taught in the sūtras realize that all the teachings that express those points in the form of the names, phrases, and letters in texts such as the sūtras are dispensable. Just as a boat’s usefulness comes to an end once one has crossed a river (indispensable though it has been for doing so), and one then no longer needs to rely exclusively on the boat, so too the teachings, in the form of the names, phrases, and letters used to communicate the subject they express so that one can know and understand it, are, like the boat, dispensable. Having realized this, bodhisattvas give up being content with merely hearing the words, and they put the emphasis on developing the wisdom that comes from reflecting on the words and their meanings. This is what we call “knowing the way.”[2]
gsum pa chos la chos kyi rjes su mthun par sgrub pa ni/
c. PRACTICING THE WAY CONSISTENT WITH REALIZATION
so so skye bo'i shes pa yis/ / de bzhin du ni gnyis rtogs nas/ / shes pa de yongs rdzogs bya'i phyir/ / mthun pa'i chos ni rab tu sgrub/ /
With the knowledge of an ordinary person, They thus realize the two, And then, in order to perfect that knowledge, They practice the consistent way. (XIV, 3)

mos spyod so so'i skye bo'i dus kyi chos nyan pa dang bsam pa'i shes rab la brten nas don dang chos shes pa yis/ yang dag dang log pa gnyis gnyis spangs pa sngar bshad pa de bzhin du ni bdag med gnyis gzugs brnyan nam don spyi'i tshul du rtogs nas ni/ shes pa de nyid yongs su rdzogs shing dag pa dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i ye shes kyi mtshan nyid du 'gyur bar bya ba'i phyir/ drod nas chos mchog gi bar du gong nas gong du bsgom pa ni chos kyi rjes su mthun pa'i chos ni rab tu bsgrub pa'o/ /

As ordinary beings at the stage of earnest aspiration, on the basis of the wisdom that comes from listening and reflection, bodhisattvas have knowledge of meanings and of the way. In doing so, they are neither mistaken nor correct, as explained above, and in this way they realize a general notion or reflection of the two kinds of no-self. Subsequently, in order to perfect and purify that knowledge and transform it into supramundane gnosis, they meditate on it further and further, from the stage of warmth up to that of the supreme mundane level. This is practicing the way consistent with realization.[3]
bzhi pa mthun par zhugs pa ni/
d. ENTRANCE INTO CONFORMITY
de nas des ni sa dang por/ / byang chub sems dpa' de bdag nyid/ / kun dang mnyam par 'jig rten las/ / 'das pa'i ye shes bla med 'thob/ /
After that, on the first level, As the equals of all bodhisattvas in that state, They acquire the supramundane, Unsurpassable gnosis. (XIV, 4)

de nas byang sems des ni sa dang por te rab tu dga' ba la/ byang chub sems dpa' mthong lam de yi bdag nyid thob pa kun dang mnyam par gyur te 'jig rten las 'das pa'i ye shes rnam par mi rtog pa nyan rang las 'phags pa'i bla na med pa 'thob pa ni/ chos nyid kyi don mngon du rtogs pas byang chub sems dpa'i sa skyon med par rab tu zhugs pa kun dang mthun par zhugs pas sgrub pa zhes bya'o/ /

After that, on the first bodhisattva level, Perfect Joy, those bodhisattvas become identical to all the bodhisattvas who have attained the essence of the path of seeing—that is, they acquire the unsurpassable supramundane nonconceptual gnosis, superior to that of the listeners and solitary realizers. Since they have realized the ultimate reality directly, they are referred to as practicing by having entered into conformity[4] with all those who have penetrated the faultless level of the bodhisattva.
lnga pa mthun pa'i chos la spyod pa ni/
e. CULTIVATION OF CONSISTENT REALIZATION

mthong bas spang bya'i nyon mongs rnams/ / thams cad yang dag zad byas nas/ / shes bya'i sgrib pa spang ba'i phyir/ / bsgom pa la ni rab tu sbyor/ / rnam 'jog rnam par mi rtog pa'i/ / ye shes lhan cig spyod pa yis/ / de bzhin sa ni lhag ma la/ / mthun pa yi ni chos spyod do/ /

Having fully extinguished All the defilements that need to be eliminated by seeing, In order to eliminate cognitive obscurations, They apply themselves to meditation. (XIV, 5) By the combined practice of gnosis, Conceptual and nonconceptual, On the remaining levels they continue To cultivate consistent realization. (XIV, 6)

bsgom lam pa'i sgrub pa la bya ste/ sngar mthong lam thob pas mthong bas spang bya'i nyon mongs rnams thams cad yang dag par zad par byas nas/ shes bya'i sgrib pa spang ba'i phyir/ sa gnyis pa nas bcu pa'i bar du bsgom pa la ni rab tu sbyor ro/ / gang gis sgrib pa spong bar byed pa'i ye shes ji lta bu zhe na/ rjes thob shes bya rnam par 'jog pa dag pa 'jig rten pa'i ye shes kyis ji snyed pa shes par byed pa dang / mnyam bzhag rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyis chos nyid nam mkha' lta bu ji lta ba bzhin shes pa de gnyis gcig gi rjes thogs su gcig 'byung ba'i tshul gyis lhan cig spel mar spyod pa yis/ rim pa rgyun gyis 'byung ba de bzhin sa ni gnyis pa sogs lhag ma rnams la mthong zin dang rjes su mthun pa yi chos spyod par byed do/ / de ltar mdo las sgrub pa'i rnam grangs lnga gsungs pa dang mthun par mos spyod nas bsgom lam sa bcu pa'i bar gyis sgrub pa byed tshul spyir bstan nas/

Cultivating consistent realization[5] refers to practice on the path of meditation. Earlier, with the attainment of the path of seeing, all the defilements to be eliminated on the path of seeing have been completely extinguished. Subsequently, in order to eliminate cognitive obscurations, from the second to tenth levels bodhisattvas apply themselves to meditation. As to the kind of gnosis that eliminates the obscurations, with the pure mundane gnosis that determines knowable phenomena in the postmeditation, bodhisattvas know phenomena in their multiplicity; and with the nonconceptual gnosis of formal meditation, they know the space-like ultimate reality as it is. Practicing these two kinds of knowledge together, in alternation one after the other, they continue in the same order on the remaining levels (the second level and higher levels), cultivating the realization consistent with the insight they have already had. The above is a general account of how one practices according to the fivefold division of the practice described in the sūtras, from the stage of earnest aspiration up to the tenth level on the path of meditation. It is now followed by a detailed explanation.
bye brag tu bshad pa
2 DETAILED EXPLANATION
['di] la/ bsgrub pa'i rkyen/ bsgrub pa'i ngo bo/ /ji ltar sgrub tshul dpes bstan pa gsum/
The detailed explanation has three parts: (1) the conditions for practicing; (2) the essence of the practice; and (3) similes for how bodhisattvas practice.
dang po/
a. THE CONDITIONS FOR PRACTICING

bsgrub pa'i mthun rkyen ni 'khor lo chen po bzhi ste mthun pa'i yul na gnas pa/ skyes bu dam pa la brten pa/ bdag nyid legs par smon pa/ sngon bsod nams bgyis pa'i las 'phro yod pa bzhi dang ldan na bsgrub pa phun sum tshogs par 'gyur bas de bshad pa la/

The conditions favorable to practice are the four great wheels—namely, staying in a suitable location, relying on a holy being, spiritual ambition,[6] and having enduring merit from deeds performed in the past. If one has these four, one will be able to practice perfectly. Therefore, these will now be explained.
[gnas]
The Place
blo ldan gang du sgrub pa'i yul/ / legs par rnyed dang gnas bzang dang / / sa bzang ba dang grogs bzang dang / / rnal 'byor bde ba'i yon tan ldan/ /
The place in which the wise practice Is full of virtues—well supplied, A good place, a healthy place, With good company, and comfortable for yoga. (XIV, 7)
ces pas bstan te/

gnas ni blo ldan des gang du sgrub pa'i yul 'tsho ba'i yo byad tshegs chung ngus legs par rnyed pa dang / skye bo mi srun pa dang gcan gzan gdug pa sogs med pas gnas bzang ba dang / sa chu 'phrod cing nad mi skyed pa dang shu ba dang mdze sogs med pa'i sa bzang ba yid dang 'thad pa dang / tshul khrims dang lta ba mtshungs pa'i dge ba'i grogs bzang po yod pa dang / bsam gtan gyi rnal 'byor byed pa la gegs su gyur pa nyin par skye bo'i rgyu 'grul dang / mtshan mo sgra yi klag col che ba sogs bsam gtan gyi tsher ma med pas nyams bde ba'i yon tan dang ldan pa de lta bur gnas na rnal 'byor 'phel bar 'gyur gyi ldog phyogs rnams kyis sgrub pa la bar chad du 'gyur bas thog mar gnas la brtags te bag yod par bya dgos kyi gang byung du sgrub pa brtsam par mi bya'o/ /

The place in which wise bodhisattvas practice is one in which they can come by everything they need to live on, with little difficulty. It is a good place, without uncivilized people, dangerous wild animals, and so forth. There, the soil and water agree with one, and one will not fall ill; it is a pleasant and healthy place, where there is no risk of skin diseases, leprosy, and the like. It is a place in which there are good, virtuous companions who share the same discipline and view; a place that feels comfortable, in which there is nothing to prick one’s concentration—people going to and fro during the day, people making a lot of noise at night, and other things that act as obstacles for anyone practicing concentration. If one stays somewhere with qualities like these, one’s practice will flourish. On the other hand, the opposite characteristics will hinder practice. So you should be careful to check the place first and avoid beginning your practice in any old place that is available.
[grogs skyes bu dam pa la brten pa]
Relying on a Holy Spiritual Companion
grogs skyes bu dam pa la brten pa ni yon tan kun gyi rkyen mchog yin pas dam pa'i mtshan nyid ji lta bu zhe na/
Relying on a holy spiritual companion is the most important condition for acquiring any good qualities, so what are the characteristics of holy beings?
byang chub sems dpa' thos mang dang / / bden mthong smra mkhas brtse ba can/ / skyo med skyes bu dam pa ni/ / chen po yin par shes par bya/ /
Recognize that learned bodhisattvas Who have seen the truth, who are skilled in discourse, Full of love, and never tire Are great and holy beings. (XIV, 8)

theg chen la zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gang zhig lung gi chos thos pa shin tu mang ba dang / rtogs pa'i chos bden pa rnams khong du chud pas de yi don mthong ba dang / gzhan la chos smra ba'am 'chad pa la mkhas pa dang / gzhan don du brtse ba can gzhan don byed pa la skyo ba med pa'i skyes bu dam pa ni/ bsten par bya ba dge ba'i bshes gnyen chen po yin par shes par bya'o/ /

They are bodhisattvas who have entered the Great Vehicle and are extremely learned in the scriptures that constitute the Dharma of transmission. They have mastered the truths that constitute the Dharma of realization and have thus seen its meaning. They are expert at relating or explaining the Dharma to others. Full of love for others, they never tire of working for others’ benefit. You should know that such holy beings are to be relied upon: they are great spiritual masters.
[rang nyid legs par smon pa]
Spiritual Ambition
dmigs pa bzang dang ston pa bzang / / thabs bzang ba dang nges 'byung dang / / sbyor ba bzang po'i bdag nyid kyi/ / yang dag gtod pa yin par bshad/ /
Excellent aim, excellent reliance, Excellent method, determination to be free, And excellent application—with these, One is said to have the right orientation. (XIV, 9)

rang nyid legs par smon pa ji lta bu zhe na/ sgrub pa byed pa'i gang zag rang nyid theg chen gyi chos la don du gnyer zhing shes rab gsum gyis dmigs pas dmigs pa bzang ba dang / dge rtsa chung ngus chog par mi 'dzin par bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs ji ltar rigs par bsags pas rton pa bzang ba dang / nam sems rgod cing g.yengs par gyur na de la skyon du bsams te zhi gnas kyi mtshan ma yid la byed pas spong ba dang / nam sems zhum pa dang rmugs par gyur na sangs rgyas byang sems kyi yon tan dang ting nge 'dzin gyi phan yon dang chos rnams kyi rang dang spyi'i mtshan nyid bsams te sems gzengs bstod pa ni lhag mthong gi mtshan ma bsgom pas zhum pa spong bar byed pa dang / nam zhum rgod med par gyur na de'i ngang du btang snyoms kyi mtshan ma bsgoms te mi g.yo bar de ga'i ngang du gnas par bya ste/ de ltar zhi lhag btang snyoms kyi mtshan ma gsum rnal 'byor bsgom pa rnams kyi thabs bzang po yin pas de dang ldan pa dang / rang sa'i gnas skabs tsam gyis chog par mi 'dzin par sa dang lam gong nas gong du nges par 'byung ba'am rab tu 'jug par byed par bzang po dang / lam de zhi gnas dang lhag mthong gi sgo las rtag du 'jug pa ni sbyor ba bzang po'i rang bzhin no/ / de ltar bzang po lnga dang ldan pa'i bdag nyid kyi don la yang dag par blo rtse gcig tu gtod pa'am smon lam gyi go cha dang ldan pa ni rang nyid legs par smon pa'o/ /

Spiritual ambition concerns the practitioners themselves, who are pursuing the Mahāyāna path and considering it with the three kinds of wisdom, so their aim is excellent. Not content with a few sources of good, they have accumulated as much merit and wisdom as they can, and so their reliance is excellent.[7] When their minds become wild and distracted, they reflect on the fault in this and abandon distraction by keeping in mind the special point of sustained calm. When their minds are low-spirited and dull, they encourage themselves, reflecting on the excellent qualities of the buddhas and bodhisattvas, on the benefits of concentration, and on the general and specific characteristics of the teachings; by meditating on the special point of profound insight in this way, they abandon their low spirits. When they are neither low-spirited nor wildly distracted, in that state they apply the special point of equanimity and maintain that very state without moving. These special points of sustained calm, profound insight, and equanimity constitute the meditators’ excellent method. Not content with the level they are on, they are determined to gain freedom on (or are fully committed to) ever higher levels and paths, so their determination to be free is excellent. And their constant engagement on the path, using sustained calm and profound insight, constitutes excellent application. To genuinely and single-mindedly focus on having these five excellent principles—in other words, to have the armor of aspiration—constitutes spiritual ambition.
[sngon gyi bsod nams]
Having Merit from the Past
dga' dang dal bar skye ba dang / / nad med pa dang ting nge 'dzin/ / rnam par 'byed pa'i byed rgyu ni/ / sngon chad bsod nams byas pa nyid/ /
A happy mind, and birth in freedom, Absence of disease, a capacity for concentration, And thorough discernment— All these result from merit gathered in past lives. (XIV, 10)

sngon bsod nams bgyis pa'i dbang gis 'di ltar mthun pa'i yul na gnas shing bshes gnyen dang chos dang phrad pa sogs kyis sems dga' ba rnyed pa dang / mi khoms pa brgyad spangs pa'i dal bar skyes pa dang / lus la nad med pas chos la sbyor rung ba dang / sems las su rung ba'i ting nge 'dzin dang / bden pa gnyis kyi don la rnam par 'byed pa'i shes rab dang ldan pa 'di lnga'i byed pa'i rgyu ni/ sngon chad kyi tshe rabs dag tu bsod nams byas pa nyid yin te da ltar de'i 'bras bu snang bas na du bas me bzhin sngon gyi bsod nams nges par 'gyur ro/ /

Because of the meritorious deeds they have performed in the past, bodhisattvas live in correspondingly pleasant places, meet with spiritual masters and the teachings, and so on, as a result of which they acquire a happy mind. They are born in freedom, rid of the eight states lacking opportunity.[8] They are physically healthy and can therefore apply themselves to the practice. They have workable minds, fit for concentration. And they possess the wisdom that distinguishes the two truths. The causal factor that produces these five advantages is their having created merit in their former lives, the results of which are now visible, and as surely indicative of past merit as smoke is indicative of fire.
gnyis pa
b. THE ESSENCE OF THE PRACTICE

theg pa chen po'i sgrub pa'i ngo bo ni dmigs med kyi shes rab dang / sems can yongs su mi 'dor ba'i snying rje chen po gnyis yin pas de bshad pa la mdor bsdus tsam bstan pa dang / slar yang phye ste bshad pa gnyis las/

The essence of the practice in the Great Vehicle is nonconceptual wisdom and the great compassion that never, ever abandons sentient beings. This is indicated in a brief synopsis and then explained again in greater detail.
dang po ni/
i. BRIEF SYNOPSIS

tshigs bcad gsum gyis 'khor ba skyon du bltas nas nyon mongs ched du mi spong ba'i shes rab dmigs pa med pa bstan/ sems can ched du sogs tshigs bcad gnyis kyis sems can dor nas rang gcig pu zhi bar 'jug pa theg chen gyi sgrub pa dang 'gal bar bstan pa yin pas/ de dag dkyus gcig tu bshad na/

The first three verses indicate the nonconceptual wisdom in which there is no regarding saṃsāra as harmful and deliberately getting rid of defilements. The two verses that follow those (verses 14 and 15) show that abandoning sentient beings and entering the peaceful state of nirvāṇa alone is contrary to the practice of the Great Vehicle. I will now go straight through these.
[shes rab dmigs pa med pa]
(1) NONCONCEPTUAL WISDOM
chos kyi dbyings ni ma gtogs pa/ / gang phyir chos med de yi phyir/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis de dag las/ / nges 'byung chags sogs yin par dgongs/ /
Besides the expanse of reality, There is nothing that exists. For this reason, the buddhas have it in mind That certain deliverance is attachment and the like. (XIV, 11)
zhes

dman lam pa dag gis nyon mongs rang bzhin gyis yod pa nyid lam gyis spangs te zad nas myang 'das thob par bzung nas 'khor 'das la skyon yon zhen pa'i bsam pa drag pos 'khor ba spangs nas zhi bar 'jug la/ byang chub sems dpa' nyon mongs pa nyid la rang bzhin med pas nyon mongs nyid kyis grol ba ster ba'i thabs mkhas pa rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes dang ldan pa'i dbang gis 'khor ba yongs su mi 'dor kyang 'khor ba'i nyes pas mi gos par byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa spyad de/ mthar srid zhir mi gnas pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa thob pa yin pas dmigs pa med pa'i shes rab rnam parami rtog pas 'khor 'das mnyam pa nyid du rtogs tshul gsungs pa/

Those on lower paths consider that the defilements exist inherently and that once these are eliminated or brought to an end by means of the path, they will attain nirvāṇa. Obsessed with the defects of saṃsāra and the good qualities of nirvāṇa, they abandon saṃsāra and enter peace. For bodhisattvas, on the other hand, defilements have no intrinsic existence: because they possess nonconceptual gnosis, which is a skillful means that brings liberation by means of the defilements themselves, they do not completely reject saṃsāra but practice the bodhisattva activities without being affected by the defects of saṃsāra. Ultimately they attain nirvāṇa, dwelling in neither existence nor peace: with the nonconceptual wisdom free of references, they realize the sameness of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa.

ji ltar shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa 'bum pa las/ 'dod chags ma gtogs par 'dod chags las nges par 'byung ba gzhan nga mi smra'o zhes dang zhe sdang dang gti mug kyang de bzhin du gsungs pa ni/ 'dod chags nyid kyis 'dod chags las nges par 'byin gyi nges 'byung gzhan gyis ma yin par gsungs pa'i dgongs don can yin te chos kyi dbyings nyid ni ma gtogs pa/ gang phyir chos gzhan med pa ste/ chos thams cad kyi gnas lugs sam ngo bo nyid dam rang bzhin ni chos dbyings de bzhin nyid kho nar nges kyi de las gzhan du gyur pa'i chos rdul tsam yod pa ma yin pa de'i phyir sangs rgyas rnams kyis 'dod chags la sogs pa de dag las nges par 'byung ba 'dod chags la sogs pa de dag yin par dgongs pa thugs la bzhag nas de ltar gsungs te/ de ltar nyon mongs pa'i rang bzhin ye nas rnam par dag pa nyid du shes nas nyon mongs nyid kyis nyon mongs rang grol bar shes na gnyen po gzhan du 'tshol mi dgos lu la/ rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis ma grol ba'i nyon mongs zhig gal te yod pa lta na/ de sus kyang bkrol mi nus te spang du'ang med do/ /

How they do so is described in the Perfection of Wisdom in One Hundred Thousand Lines: “I do not speak of any deliverance from attachment other than by attachment.” And it is similar for aversion and bewilderment. What the Buddha had in mind was that it is attachment itself, and not some other deliverance, that gives certain deliverance from attachment. Apart from the expanse of reality, there is no other entity. The very essence or mode of being or nature of all phenomena is nothing but the expanse of reality, suchness, and there is not so much as an atom’s worth of phenomena that is other than that. For this reason, the buddhas had it in mind, and taught, that what gives deliverance from attachment and the other defilements is attachment and the others. If one recognizes that the nature of defilements is primordial purity and one realizes that defilements are naturally liberated by the defilements themselves, there is no need to look for other antidotes. On the other hand, if there were such a thing as a defilement that was not liberated by its very nature, no one would be able to liberate it and there would be no getting rid of it.

de'i phyir mtshan nyid theg pa'i nges don gyi mdo rnams su chos thams cad ye nas bcings grol med par bstan pa bzhin/ 'bras bu sngags kyi theg par yang / kai rdo rje'i rgyud brtag pa gnyis pa'i rnal 'byor dag pa'i le'u las/ nges par dngos po thams cad kyi/ / dag pa de bzhin nyid du brjod/ / ces sogs dang / rang rig bdag nyid dag pa nyid/ / dag pa gzhan gyis rnam grol min/ / zhes sogs gsungs pa 'di dag dgongs gnad gcig yin gyi tha dad med do/ /

For this reason, in the Vehicle of Characteristics, the sūtras of the ultimate teachings indicate that all phenomena are from the very beginning not bound and not liberated. And similarly, in the Resultant Vehicle of the Mantras, we read in the Purity chapter of the Two Segments:[9] Ultimately the purity of all things Is expressed as suchness…. and, The pure, self-cognizant nature Is not liberated with any other purity…. The intended essential point in these quotations is the same.
chos kyi dbyings ni ma gtogs par/ / gang phyir chos med de yi phyir/ / kun nas nyon mongs bstan pa la/ / blo ldan dgongs pa de yin 'dod/ /
Besides the expanse of reality, There is nothing that exists. So this, the wise accept, was the intended implication Of the teaching on defilement. (XIV, 12)

de bzhin du ma rig pa dang byang chub gcig par gsungs pa yang chos kyi dbyings ni ma gtogs par gang gi phyir na de las gzhan du gyur pa'i chos ni med pa de'i phyir kun nas nyon mongs rnams rang bzhin gyis byang chub kyi ngo bor bstan pa la/ blo ldan byang sems rnams kyis sangs rgyas kyi dgongs pa de lta bu yin par shes nas de ltar 'dod do/ /zhes mdo rnams las nyon mongs pa rnams ni byang chub rdo rje'i gzhi lags so zhes sogs gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

Similarly, when the Buddha said that ignorance and enlightenment are the same, he was indicating that apart from the expanse of reality, there are no phenomena that are other than it, and therefore that defilement is naturally the essence of enlightenment. Wise bodhisattvas know that this is what the Buddha had in mind and accept it to be thus, as we find in the sūtras, which declare that defilements are the ground of the vajra awakening, and so on.
gang phyir chags sogs de nyid la/ / tshul bzhin 'jug pa de yi phyir/ / de las rnam grol 'gyur des na/ / de yis de dag las nges 'byung / /
Because they properly approach Attachment and the like as suchness, They will be completely free from them: Thus they are delivered from them by means of them. (XIV, 13)

'o na nyon mongs pa nyid kyis nyon mongs las nges par 'byung na nyon mongs spyod pa'i sems can thams cad nges par 'byung bar cis ma gyur snyam na/ de ni dgongs don tshul bzhin ma shes pa yin te/ de dag gis chags sogs nyid kyi de kho na nyid mi shes par de dang de'i mtshan mar zhen pas 'ching ba yin la/ gang phyir byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis chags sogs kyi de kho na nyid chos kyi dbyings kyi rang bzhin la/ de ltar rtogs nas tshul bzhin du 'jug pa de yi phyir/ chags sogs tha mal rang mtshan pa de las rnam par grol bar 'gyur ba des na/ chags sogs de yis chags sogs de dag las nges par 'byung ba yin te/ 'dod chags la sogs pa'i dngos po dang / mtshan mar mi dmigs pas chags pa dang sdang ba gang yang mi 'byung ngo / /

Why, then, if certain deliverance from defilements is achieved by means of the defilements themselves, have all sentient beings who indulge in defilements not achieved certain deliverance? People who ask such a question have not properly understood the intended meaning of such teachings. Beings do not know the thatness of attachment and the other defilements, and they are bound by their clinging to their attributes. Bodhisattvas, on the other hand, have realized the thatness of attachment and so forth, which is the nature of the expanse of reality, and they approach them properly, so they will be completely freed from ordinary, independently existing defilements. This is why they achieve certain deliverance from defilements by means of the defilements. Since they have no concepts of defilements such as attachment and of their attributes, attachment and aversion simply do not occur.

de nas chags sogs kyi rang bzhin rtogs nas gdod nas zad pa dang gdod nas mi skye ba'i don mngon du gyur pa'i zad mi skye shes ba'i ye shes byang chub chen po 'thob par 'gyur ba'i chags sogs kyi ngo bo yod bzhin du nam zhig de zad nas slar rang rgyud la mi skye bar shes pa'i nyan thos kyi byang chub ni de kho na nyid la rmongs pa ste/ mngon rtogs rgyan las/ gzhan gyi chos rnams kyang yod la/ / shes bya la yang ston pa yi/ / sgrib pa zad par brjod pa gang / / de la kho bos mtshar du brtsis/ / zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

Subsequently, having realized the nature of attachment and the other defilements, they will attain the great enlightenment, the gnosis of exhaustion and nonarising that realizes the meaning of defilements being exhausted from the beginning and nonarisen from the beginning. But for the listeners, it is as if these defilements (which for bodhisattvas lead to great enlightenment) actually exist but will one day be exhausted and will never arise again in their streams of being. Their enlightenment is bewilderment with regard to thatness, as is stated in the Ornament of True Realization: When others say that things exist But that our teacher has brought to an end The obscurations related to the knowable, I am much surprised.[10]

de bzhin du 'phags pa thogs med kyis/ theg pa chen po bsdus par yang / chos sku zab pa'i tshigs bcad du/ / thabs chen rnams dang ldan pa la/ / nyon mongs byang chub yan lag 'gyur/ / 'khor ba'ang zhi ba'i chos nyid de/ / de phyir de bzhin gshegs bsam yas/ / zhes 'khor ba nyid myang 'das dang nyon mongs rnams byang chub kyi yan lag gang lam du 'gyur bar gsungs pa 'di lta bu mtshan nyid theg pa las kyang gsal bar bstan te shes rab kyis de ltar ma rtogs par srid zhi'i mtha' la mi gnas pa'i byang chub chen po 'thob mi nus pa'i phyir ro/ / 'bras bu'i theg pa las ni rtogs pa de dang mthun pa'i thabs khyad par can gyi lam rnams kyang ma sbas par mngon du bstan pas 'tshang rgya ba la myur lam du grub pa yin no/ /

Similarly, Ārya Asaṅga has written in the Compendium of the Great Vehicle in the verse on the profundity of the body of truth: For those who possess great means, Defilements will be branches of enlightenment, And saṃsāra is the nature of peace. For this reason, the Tathāgata is inconceivable. This sort of pronouncement—that saṃsāra is nirvāṇa and that defilements, as elements of enlightenment, become the path—is clearly made not only in the Vehicle of Characteristics (for without realizing this with wisdom, it is not possible to attain the great enlightenment that does not dwell in either extreme of existence or peace) but also in the Resultant Vehicle, which shows in an unconcealed manner the extraordinary methods that lead to such realization. This is therefore the swift path to enlightenment.
gnyis pa
(2) THE SKILLFUL MEANS OF NEVER ABANDONING SENTIENT BEINGS
sems can yongs su mi 'dor ba'i thabs ni byang chub chen po thob pa'i thabs yin par bstan pa ni/
The skillful means of never abandoning sentient beings is shown as being the method for attaining great enlightenment.

sems can ched du dmyal ba'i srid par gnas pa yi/ / sdug bsngal mi bzad cis kyang rgyal sras gnod byed min/ / zhi srid yon tan skyon gyis theg pa dman zhugs pa'i/ / rnam rtog dge ba sna tshogs blo ldan gnod byed yin/ / blo dang ldan pa dmyal bar gnas pa dus kun tu/ / byang chub dri med yangs pa'i bar du gcod byed min/ / theg pa gzhan la rab bsil rnam rtog bdag phan pa/ / rab tu bde bar gnas kyang bar du gcod par byed/ /

Even the most terrible sufferings of dwelling in the hell realms For beings’ sake do not harm the buddhas’ heirs at all. The various good thoughts of those who follow lower vehicles, Thinking of the defects and virtues of existence and peace, are harmful to the wise. (XIV, 14) For the wise, staying in the hells does not forever Prevent their vast and uncontaminated enlightenment. Thinking of the complete coolth of benefiting oneself in the other vehicles Brings great happiness, but it is an obstacle. (XIV, 15)
zhes pas bstan te/

sems can ched du dmyal ba'i srid par gnas pa yi btso bsreg la sogs pa'i sdug bsngal mi bzad pa ni cis kyang rgyal ba'i sras rnams la lus dang sems la gnod pa dang theg pa chen po'i lam la bar du gcod pa'i gnod par byed pa min te rgyu des sgyu ma lta bu'i blo dang sems can rnams la shin tu snying rje'i go cha bgo bar 'gyur ro/ / zhi ba myang 'das la yon tan dang srid pa 'khor ba la skyon du 'dzin pa nyid kyis theg pa dman pa'i lam la zhugs pa'i rnam par rtog pa dge ba ltar snang ba sna tshogs ni blo ldan byang chub sems dpa'i lam la bar du gcod pa'i gnod byed yin te/ ci'i phyir na blo ldan dmyal bar gnas pa de ni de nyid kyi tshe da ltar sdug bsngal bar gyur pa tsam las dus kun tu'am gtan du byang chub chen po sgrib gnyis kyi dri ma med par stobs sogs kyi yon tan rgya che zhing yangs pa'i bar du gcod byed min te mdza' bo'i bu mo dang gyod pa gi ta'i rnam thar bzhin no/ / theg pa gzhan nyan rang gi lam 'bras la rang don du nyon mongs dang sdug bsngal rab tu bsil bar rnam par rtog cing bdag la phan pa 'ba' zhig don du gnyer ba ni skabs der rab tu bde bar gnas kyang byang chub chen po la bar du gcod par byed de/ theg chen lam la zhugs pa dag kyang gzhan gyis log sgrub la brten nas bla med byang chub tu sems bskyed pa btang ste/ nyan rang gi myang 'das mngon du byed pa bzhin no/ /

Even the most terrible sufferings from being burned, boiled, and so forth when they stay in the hell realms for the sake of sentient beings do not in any way harm the bodies or minds of the Buddha’s children or obstruct them on the Mahāyāna path. Indeed, because of those sufferings, they understand that everything is illusory and don the armor of deep compassion for beings. What does harm the wise, acting as an obstacle on the bodhisattva path, is the various, apparently virtuous, thoughts of those who follow the lower vehicles and consider that there are good qualities in the peaceful state of nirvāṇa and defects in saṃsāra. Why is that? When wise bodhisattvas stay in the hells, they only suffer for the time they are there, but this is not a permanent or lasting obstacle to their gaining the ten strengths and the rest of the vast and abundant qualities of great enlightenment, uncontaminated by the two obscurations—as we know from the story of Daughter the son of Vallabha and that of the strong man Bakshita.[11] Those in other vehicles who aspire to the paths and results of the listeners and solitary realizers, who think of cooling the defilements and sufferings for their own good and who strive to benefit only themselves, may be extremely happy in that situation, but it is an obstacle to great enlightenment. The same is true for those who have entered the Great Vehicle but who, because of others’ ingratitude, give up their intention to attain unsurpassable enlightenment and instead realize the listeners’ or solitary realizers’ nirvāṇa.
slar yang dmigs med kyi shes rab dang / byams pa chen po gnyis bshad pa'i
ii. FURTHER DETAILED EXPLANATIONS OF NONCONCEPTUAL WISDOM AND GREAT LOVE
dang por/
(1) NONCONCEPTUAL WISDOM
chos med pa dang dmigs pa dang / / kun nas nyon mongs med rnam dag / sgyu ma la sogs 'dra ba dang / / de bzhin nam mkha' 'drar shes bya/ /

chos thams cad don dam par med pa dang snang tsam du dmigs pa 'gal bar bzung nas byis pa rnams don de khong du ma chud pas skrag pa dang / rang bzhin gyis kun nas nyon mongs med kyang glo bur gyi dri ma rnam par dag pa'ang 'gal lo snyam du skrag cing theg chen la mi mos pa yang dgongs don zab mo ma shes pa'i dbang gis yin gyi shes na don de dag 'gal ba med de/ ci'i phyir na snang ba tsam du chos 'di dag yod kyang snang ba ltar bden par ma grub pa sgyu ma dang rmi lam la sogs 'dra ba yin pas tha snyad du dmigs pa yod la/ de bzhin du don dam par mtshan mar dmigs su med pas nam mkha' dang 'dra bar shes par bya ba yin pas dmigs pa dang dmigs med mi 'gal lo/ /

In considering that there is a contradiction between the fact that in ultimate truth phenomena do not exist and the fact that they are perceived as mere appearances, immature beings fail to understand this point and find it frightening. Furthermore, they think that there is a contradiction between defilement being intrinsically nonexistent and adventitious contaminants being purified: they grow afraid and lose interest in the Great Vehicle. This is because they do not understand the profundity of its intended meaning. If one does understand it, however, these points do not contradict each other. Why? Although phenomena exist as mere appearances, they do not truly exist in the way they appear. They are like magical illusions, dreams, and so forth, so they do exist conventionally as perceptions. And similarly, in the ultimate truth, they do not exist as things conceptualized with attributes: they are to be understood as being like space. There is therefore no contradiction between perception and nonconceptuality.
ji ltar tshul bzhin bris pa'i ri mo la/ / mtho dman med kyang snang ba de bzhin du/ / yang dag ma yin rtog la rnam kun tu/ / gnyis po rtag tu med kyang snang bar 'gyur/ /
Just as on a well-drawn picture There are no different planes, yet there seem to be, To the false imagination, duality, Though never there, appears in different ways. (XIV, 17)

dpe ji ltar na ras la ri mo mkhan mkhas pas bzo sbyang gi thabs goms pa'am cho ga bzhin du tshon sna tshogs pas tshul bzhin legs par bris pa'i gzugs rnam pa sna tshogs pa dag la/ ri mo la dngos su mtho dman dang 'bar 'bur med kyang mig lam du rkang lag dang gdong la sogs pa mtho dman dang 'bar 'bur du snang ba de bzhin du/ dngos po'i don tshul bzhin ma rtogs pa yang dag ma yin pa'i rtog pa la gzung ba 'dzin pa gnyis po rnam pa tha dad du med kyang yod pa ltar snang bar 'gyur te/ gnas tshul dang snang tshul mi mthun par snang ba yod pas don la med bzhin de ltar yod par snang ba'ang mi 'gal lo/ /

Here is an analogy, that of a clever artist skillfully painting a variety of forms on a canvas, using different colors according to the traditions or procedures of their craft. Although the surface of the painting is actually perfectly flat, the hands and feet, faces, and so forth in the painting appear to the eye to be on different planes, behind or in front of the canvas. In the same way, to the false imagination that has not realized how things truly are, subject and object, while not existent as different aspects, will appear as if they were. The way things are and the way they appear being incompatible, there are appearances, so there is no contradiction in things appearing as they do without ultimately existing.
ji ltar chu rnyog pa las dang ba ni/ / dang ba nyid de de las skyes min gyi/ / de ni de la dri ma bral bar zad/ / de bzhin rang sems dag la tshul de nyid/ /
When muddy water becomes clear, Its clarity is not something produced from the muddy state, But rather the removal of the dirt contaminating it. So it is with the purity of one’s own mind. (XIV, 18)

rang bzhin gyis dag kyang phyis su dri ma dang bral tshe dag par snang ba yang mi 'gal ba ni/ ji ltar chu rang bzhin gyis sa rdul dang ma 'dres pa dwang ba yin yang / sa 'dam dang 'dres nas rnyogs pa na chu yi rang bzhin ni sa yi rdul dang 'dres nas dbye mi rung ba ma yin par chu nyid du gnas mod kyi rnyogs pa dang bcas par yang snang ba las/ phyis dwang ba nyid du gyur pa ni sngar gyi chu'i rang bzhin nyid mngon du gyur pa'i dwang ba nyid de sngon med par rnyog pa de las gsar du skyes min gyi/ dwang ba de ni chu de la glo bur ba 'dam gyis bslad pa'i dri ma dang bral bar zad do/ / de bzhin nam mkhar rang bzhin gyis rnam par dag pa sprin dang bcas pa dang sprin dang bral ba dang / gser 'dam las grol ba yang snga nas dri ma med kyang / dri ma dang bcas pa'i gnas skabs dang / dri ma dang bral ba'i gnas skabs gnyis su snang ba yod pa bzhin no/ / dpe de bzhin du rang sems dag la dag ma dag tu snang ba'ang tshul de nyid dang 'dra'o/ /

Neither is there any contradiction between things’ being naturally pure and their appearing to be pure when they are later freed of contaminants. In its natural state, water is not mixed with bits of earth: it is quite clear. But when it is mixed with mud, it becomes turbid. When this happens, it is not that the nature of the water blends with the particles of earth and is indistinguishable from them. Rather, the water remains itself but appears to be dirty. On the other hand, when it subsequently becomes clear and its former nature becomes manifest, it is not that its clarity has been newly produced from the dirty state and was not present before. Rather, that clarity has been rid of the adventitious contaminants of mud dirtying the water. It is the same for the sky, which is naturally pure but may be cloudy or cloudless. And in the case of gold cleared of mud, there was no dirt there in the beginning, yet there appear to be two conditions, one with contaminants and one free of contaminants. Analogous to these examples are our own minds, which are similarly pure while appearing to be impure.
sems ni rtag tu rang bzhin 'od gsal 'dod/ / de ni glo bur nyes pas ma rungs byas/ / chos nyid sems las gzhan pa'i sems gzhan ni/ / 'od gsal ma yin rang bzhin la brjod do/ /

The mind is held to be eternally natural clear light; It is coarsened by adventitious faults. The mind is ultimate reality, and there is no other mind but clear light. We speak of this as the nature of mind. (XIV, 19)

de yang sems kyi gshis sam gnas lugs ni dus rtag tu rang bzhin gyis dri ma med pa 'od gsal bar 'dod do/ / sems de ni rang gi gshis la 'bral mi rung du ma grub pa glo bur gyi nyes pa 'dod chags la sogs pa tshul min yid byed kyi nyon mongs pas ma rungs pa dri ma dang bcas par byas pa yin pas/ dri mas gos par byar med pa'i chos nyid 'od gsal ba'i sems las gzhan pa'i sems gzhan rnam rtog gam yang dag min pa'i rtog pa ni 'od gsal ma yin la/ dri ma med pa chos nyid kyi sems sam 'od gsal ba'i ye shes ni sems kyi rang bzhin nam gshis gsal stong zung 'jug la brjod do/ /

In this regard, the mind’s fundamental state or mode of being is held to be clear light, naturally always immaculate. That mind is contaminated and coarsened by adventitious blemishes on its own basic nature—attachment and other defilements due to improper thinking—that are not indelible. No other mind, comprising concepts or incorrect mental processes and different from the clear-light mind, the ultimate reality for which there is no contamination, is clear light. The mind that is the uncontaminated ultimate reality, or the gnosis of clear light, is termed the nature or fundamental state of the mind, the union of clarity and emptiness.
gnyis pa sems can yongs su mi gtong ba'i byams snying rje ni/
(2) THE LOVE AND COMPASSION THAT NEVER FORSAKES SENTIENT BEINGS
byang chub sems dpa' sems can la/ / bu gcig pa la bya ba bzhin/ / rkang gi khong nas byams pa che/ / de ltas rtag phan byed par 'dod/ /
Bodhisattvas feel for sentient beings A heartfelt love as great as that Felt for an only child— Their constant wish is to bring them help. (XIV, 20)
zhes pas bstan te/

byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni sems can rnams la/ ma yis rang bu gcig pu yid du sdug pa la bya ba bzhin du/ bcos ma ma yin par rkang gi khong nas byams pa che ba yin pas bsam pa de lta bus rtag tu sems can la phan par byed par 'dod pas sems can nam yang mi 'dor ro/ /

Bodhisattvas have the same affection for sentient beings as a mother has for her only beloved child—an immense, unfeigned love, from the depth of the heart. Such an attitude leads to their always wanting to benefit beings and never abandoning them.
sems can rnams la phan byed phyir/ / de la chags skyes ltung mi 'gyur/ / 'di yi zhe sdang rnam kun tu/ / sems can kun dang 'gal bar 'gyur/ /
Because it brings benefit to sentient beings, The fondness bodhisattvas feel does not become a downfall. But hatred in them will always violate And act against all beings. (XIV, 21)
