sems can rnams la phan par byed phyir byang sems de la yul sems can la chags pa skyes pa de lta bus ltung ba'am nyes par mi 'gyur te chags pa des sems can bdag gir 'dzin pa las 'dor ba min na yang / de lta bu'i byams pa la gnas shing byang chub tu sems bskyed pa 'di yi sems can la zhe sdang ba ni rnam pa kun tu bdag gir gzung bar bya ba'i sems can kun dang 'gal bar 'gyur te/ zhe sdang skyes na de dag 'dor zhing gnod par byed pa la 'jug pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir mdo las byang chub sems dpa' la 'dod chags kyi nyes pa bskal pa du mar byung ba las/ zhe sdang gi sems skad cig gcig tu skyes pa nyes pa che bar gsungs te byams pas sems can rjes su 'dzin pa la sems can la rjes su chags par bshad pa ni nyon mongs can ma yin la/ byang chub sems dpa' khyim pa lta bu rang gi bu dang chung ma sogs la chags pa yang byams pa dang mi 'gal bas chags pa des byang sems kyi ltung ba ci yang mi skyed do/ /

Because it benefits sentient beings, the fondness bodhisattvas feel for them does not become a fault or downfall, for with that “attachment,” they never give up feeling responsible for beings. On the other hand, hatred for sentient beings in bodhisattvas—who are individuals who live by such love and who are intent on enlightenment—is totally incompatible with their responsibility for all beings, for if they start to feel hateful, it will induce them to abandon beings and to do them harm. This is why it is said in the sūtras that it is a much greater fault for a bodhisattva to give rise to a single instant’s hateful thought than to feel attachment over numerous kalpas. “Attachment to beings” here is used to mean lovingly caring for them: it does not mean having the defilement of attachment. Lay bodhisattvas’ fondness for their spouses and children, for example, does not conflict with their lovingkindness, so this kind of “attachment” does not give rise to any transgression of the bodhisattva precepts.[12]

ji ltar phug ron rang gi bu mchog byams/ / rang gi bu de nye bar 'khyud nas 'dug / de 'dra ba la khong khro 'gal ba ltar/ / brtser bcas lus can bu la'ang de dang 'dra/ / gang phyir byams pa de phyir khong khro 'gal/ / gang phyir zhi ba de phyir gnod sems 'gal/ / gang phyir don byed de phyir sgyu sems 'gal/ / gang phyir sim byed de phyir 'jigs byed 'gal/ /

Like doves who love their young the most, Staying with them and holding them close, With not the slightest place for anger, Are those whose hearts are full of love for beings, their children. (XIV, 22) Because they love, there’s never room for rage. Because they pacify, malice is out of place. Because they benefit, they never think deceitfully. Because they comfort, they’ll never terrify. (XIV, 23)

ji ltar 'dab chags phug ron ni bya gzhan las 'dod chags che bas rang gi bu la mchog tu byams shing chags pas na/ nam sgo nga byung ba'i dus nas brtsams te sgro gshog ma rdzogs kyi bar chad med rang gis bu la nye bar 'khyud nas lus dang gshog pas 'gebs shing 'khyud nas 'dug pa'i byams pa/ de 'dra ba la rang gi bu la khong khro skye ba rnam par kun tu 'gal ba yin pas khong khro mi skye ba ltar/ brtser bcas byang sems de lus can nam sems can gzhan bu dang 'dra ba la'ang de dang 'dra ste/ gang phyir bde bar 'dod pas byams pa can yin pa de phyir gnod sems kyi rgyu khong khro skye ba 'gal la/ gang gi phyir sems can gyis nyon mongs dang sdug bsngal zhi ba nyid du 'dod pa de yi phyir sdug bsngal bar byed pa'i gnod sems byed pa 'gal lo/ / gang phyir rang gi lus longs spyod kyis sems can gyi don byed par 'dod pa de phyir sems can bslu ba 'dod pa'i g.yo sgyu'i sems byed pa 'gal lo/ / gang phyir byang sems rnams ni sems can rnams dga' bdes sim par byed pa dang byang chub sems dpa' mthong ba dang ming thos pas kyang 'jigs pa las skyob pa yin pa de phyir brdung brdeg sogs kyis 'jigs shing skrag par byed pa 'gal lo/ / de'i phyir snying thag pa nas g.yo dang sgyu'i sems bcos ma ma yin pa'i byams pa dang snying rje chen po'i sems kyis sems can yongs su mi 'dor ba dang rnam par mi rtog pa'i shes rab kyis srid zhi tha dad du mngon zhen spang ba'i byang chub sems dpa'i sgrub pa mchog yin no/ /

Of all birds, doves have the greatest attachment and are thus the most affectionate and loving with their young. From the moment they lay their eggs until the young are fully fledged, they hold them close, covering and snuggling them with their wings and body. They never get angry with the little birds, for to do so would be totally out of place with that kind of love. Kindhearted bodhisattvas feel just the same toward other living creatures or sentient beings, who are like their children. They are full of love and want beings to be happy, so it is out of the question for them to feel angry, which would lead to their wanting to harm others. They want beings’ defilements and sufferings to be eased, so it is out of the question for them to give rise to malice, which would create suffering. They want to use their bodies and possessions to benefit beings, so it is counterproductive for them to have deceitful thoughts and to want to cheat them. A bodhisattva is someone who comforts beings, bringing them happiness and joy, and even seeing a bodhisattva or hearing their name protects beings from fear, so it is out of the question for bodhisattvas to frighten beings by beating them up and so on. Thus, on account of their attitude of love and great compassion, which is completely sincere and unfeigned, with no dishonesty or pretension, bodhisattvas never abandon beings. And on account of their nonconceptual wisdom, they have eliminated the notion of existence and peace as being different. It is for all these reasons that their practice is sublime.
gsum pa ji ltar sgrub tshul dpes bstan pa ni/
c. SIMILES FOR HOW BODHISATTVAS PRACTICE
sman bzang po la nad pa bzhin/ / 'khor ba la ni 'jug par byed/ / nad pa la ni sman pa bzhin/ / sems can rnams la sgrub par byed/ /
Like the sick taking efficacious medicine, They enter saṃsāra. Like doctors for those who are ill, Bodhisattvas practice for sentient beings. (XIV, 24)
ces pas bstan te/

byang chub sems dpa' ni bla med byang chub kyi phyir bsam bzhin 'khor bar skye ba yongs su 'dzin cing 'khor bar ma chags par sems can rnams kyi sdug bsngal sel zhing phan bde bsgrub pa yin pas/ ji ltar nad sel ba'i sman bzang po la nad pa dag nan tan gyis 'jug pa bzhin du/ 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal shes kyang dang du len pa ni sman dku ba dang kha ba shes kyang nad sel ba'i phyir nan tan gyis brten pa bzhin 'khor ba dang du blang bas sgrib gnyis kyi nad mtha' dag zhi ba'i don gnyis lhun grub byang chub chen po thob pa'i phyir/ 'khor ba la ni 'jug par byed kyi 'khor ba gtong bar mi byed do/ / nad pa nyam thag pa sdug bsngal can la ni/ sman pa snying brtse ba sems dge ba can dag gis/ nad gzhi dang sbyar ba'i sman gtong ba bzhin du/ sems can rnams la nyon mongs pa'i nad zhi bar byed pa'i phyir dam pa'i chos kyi sman gtong zhing phan 'dogs pa sna tshogs sgrub par byed do/ /

Bodhisattvas, in order to attain unsurpassable enlightenment, deliberately take birth in saṃsāra and, without being attached to saṃsāra, dispel the sufferings of sentient beings and bring them benefit and happiness. So, like sick people conscientiously taking the right medicine that will get rid of their disease, bodhisattvas, despite their knowing the misery that is saṃsāra, willingly accept it. Patients conscientiously rely on the medicine, even though they know it is pungent and bitter, because it will cure their disease. Similarly, because, by deliberately accepting saṃsāra, they will cure the diseases of the two obscurations, spontaneously accomplish the two goals, and attain the great enlightenment, bodhisattvas enter saṃsāra and never abandon it. Like good, kindhearted doctors giving sick people, weakened and in pain, the medicine that matches the underlying cause of their illness, bodhisattvas give sentient beings the medicine of the sacred Dharma to cure the disease of the defilements and bring them all kinds of benefit.
bran ma grub pa ji bzhin du/ / bdag nyid la ni sgrub par byed/ / zong la tshong ba ji bzhin du/ / 'dod pa dag la sgrub par byed/ /
As with servants who will not work, Likewise do they treat themselves. As with merchants and their wares, Likewise do they use their pleasures. (XIV, 25)

bran mi srun pa las ma bkol ba sogs ji 'dod du ma grub pa la brdeg pa sogs kyi sgo nas bkol du btub par sgrub pa ji bzhin bdag nyid la ni sems nyon mongs pa'i dbang du gyur nas dmu rgod pa dang / sems can gyi don la skyo ba sogs skyes nas tshul bzhin yid la byed pa'i sgo nas nan tur gyis bdag gis sems ngan pa rnams tshar gcod sgrub par byed de/ dkon mchog brtsegs pa las rta 'dul sbyong gi dpes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ / bu tsha dang 'khor gso ba'i phyir zong gi dngos po la chung ngu zhig kyang chen por bsgyur ba'i khe spogs byed pa'i tshong pa rnams ji bzhin du/ rang la bdog pa'i 'dod pa'i longs spyod pa dag la brten nas sbyin pa'i zong gis 'dod pa lnga'i yon tan dang longs spyod phun sum tshogs pa bsgrubs nas sems can thams cad la yongs su gtong zhing phan bde sgrub par byed pa sbyin pa bsgrub pa'o/ /

When unruly servants do not do their job or anything else one wants them to do, they can be made to work by beating them, and so on. Similarly, when their minds are influenced by defilements and become unruly, or when they feel fed up with benefiting beings, bodhisattvas punish and subdue their wicked minds by being properly attentive. This is similar to the simile of breaking a horse given in the Heap of Jewels. Like merchants who, in order to provide for their children and household, transform a few items of merchandise into a large profit, bodhisattvas make use of the desirable possessions they own and, with these wares of generosity, produce abundant riches and things to delight the five senses, which they then give away to all sentient beings, accomplishing their benefit and happiness. This refers to the practice of generosity.
gos la btso blag mkhan bzhin du/ / las la rab tu sgrub par byed/ / bu gzhon pa la pha bzhin du/ / sems can mi 'tsho sgrub par byed/ /
As with dyers and their cloth, Likewise do they work on karmic acts. As with fathers and their infant sons, Likewise do they never injure beings. (XIV, 26)

gos la btso blag mkhan rnams kyis 'bad pas bkru zhing yang yang tshon gyis gzhan par bgo ba bzhin du rang gis lus ngag yid kyi las mi dge bcu byang zhing dag pa dang dge ba bcu'i las rnams la rab tu sgrub par byed pa ni tshul khrims la'o/ / bu gzhon pa shed ma phye ba dag gis ma bsdam pa'i spyod lam sna tshogs kyi nyes pa phra mo byed kyang pha mas zhe sdang mi byed kyi snying brtse ba skyed pa bzhin du bzod dang ldan pa'i sgo nas sems can rnams rmongs pa'i dbang du gyur nas nyes pa sna tshogs byas kyang de la lan du mi 'tshe zhing / zhe sdang med par ma zad snying rje 'phel ba sgrub par byed do/ /

Just as dyers energetically wash the cloth and repeatedly apply the dye to make it fast, bodhisattvas purify their ten physical, verbal, and mental negative actions and intensively practice the ten positive actions. This refers to discipline. Even though very young children, who are not old enough to know better, may be unrestrained in their behavior and get up to all sorts of mischief, their parents never get angry but feel all the more loving. Similarly, even when beings in the grip of ignorance commit all kinds of negative actions, bodhisattvas, on account of their patience, not only never retaliate or get angry but also manage to develop their compassion.
me don gnyer la gtsub shing ltar/ / rtag par rab tu sgrub par byed/ / yid brtan bzhin du lhag pa'i sems/ / ma rdzogs pa la sgrub par byed/ /
As when one rubs two sticks to make a fire, Likewise do they practice hard and all the time. Like a trustworthy person, They practice their incomplete superior concentration. (XIV, 27)

me don du gnyer bas gtsub shing brdar ba na/ me ma byung bar nan tan rgyun ma chad par brtson pa ltar/ dge ba mthar ma phyin bar du bar ma dor mi 'dor bar brtson pa chen pos rtag par rab tu sgrub par byed do/ / yid brtan pa'i gang zag la bang mdzod dang yo byad thams cad bcol bar byas nas/ des rang dbang du blang chog kyang cung zad kyang rang don du sred pas mi len pa bzhin du/ byang chub sems dpas lhag pa'i sems kyi bslab pa ting nge 'dzin rnams ma rdzogs pa la yongs su rdzogs par sgrub par byed kyang bsam gtan gyi ro myong bar mi byed do/ /

Just as someone trying to light a fire by rubbing pieces of wood together perseveres energetically without stopping until the fire is lit, bodhisattvas never lose interest or give up but practice constantly, with great diligence, until they have perfected all virtue. When one entrusts all one’s store of valuables and belongings to trustworthy people, they will not take the smallest thing for themselves even though they could if they wanted. It is the same with regard to bodhisattvas’ incomplete concentrations in the training in superior concentration: even while they are in the process of completing them, bodhisattvas do not relish the taste of concentration.
sgyu ma mkhan ltar shes bya la/ / shes rab kyis ni sgrub par byed/ / de ni byang chub sems dpa' yi/ / ji ltar gong du sgrub par 'dod/ /
In the same way as magicians, They practice with wisdom regarding phenomena. All these are held to show the how and the what Of the practice of the bodhisattvas. (XIV, 28)

sgyu ma mkhan rnams kyis sgyu ma'i sngags dang rdzas kyi tshogs rta glang sogs dngos por snang ba sna tshogs mngon du snang bar sprul kyang 'di ni sgyu ma'i snang ba tsam ste yang dag par grub pa med do zhes shes pa ltar/ byang chub sems dpas kyang pha rol tu phyin pa rnams sgrub kyang shes bya thams cad la/ de yi rang bzhin yongs su shes pa'i shes rab kyis ni bden gnyis zung 'jug tu sgrub par byed do/ / de ltar dpe dang sbyar te bshad pa de rnams ni/ byang chub sems dpa' yi/ dpe ji ltar don gang du sgrub par 'dod pa yin no/ /

In a show of magic, magicians use a combination of spells and props to make things like horses and elephants actually appear, yet they know that these are just illusory appearances and that they do not really exist. In the same way, even while they are practicing the transcendent perfections, bodhisattvas practice them as the union of the two truths, with the wisdom that comprises complete knowledge of the nature of all phenomena. These explanations, associated with similes, are held to refer to the manner in which bodhisattvas practice and the points on which they practice.
gsum pa don bsdu ba/
3. SUMMARY
de ltar rtag tu brtson 'grus rgya chen ldan/ / gnyis yongs smin par bya la rab brtson de/ / rim gyis dri med mi rtog blo mchog gis/ / sgrub pa bla na med par rab tu 'gro/ /

Thus, armed with constant diligence on a vast scale, They make the greatest efforts to bring about a twofold maturation. Gradually, with supreme, nonconceptual intelligence devoid of contaminants, They proceed to the unsurpassable accomplishment. (XIV, 29)
zhes pas bstan te/

gong du ji skad bshad pa de ltar dus rtag tu phar phyin rnams tshad med pa spyod pa la brtson 'grus rgya chen po dang ldan pa/ sbyor ba tshogs gnyis sam rang dang gzhan gnyis smin par bya ba la rab tu brtson pa de ni tshogs kyi lam nas rim gyis nyon shes kyi dri ma med pa 'khor gsum du rnam par mi rtog pa'i blo gros mchog gis sa bcu'i mthar thug par sgrub pa de ni bla na med pa'i byang chub 'thob par rab tu 'gro ba yin no/ /

Thus, as explained above, armed with immense diligence in constantly practicing the transcendent perfections on an infinite scale, bodhisattvas apply themselves with great effort to achieving double maturation—maturation of the two accumulations, or of themselves and others. With the highest intelligence that is uncontaminated by defilement-related and cognitive obscurations and free of the concepts of the three spheres, they gradually, starting from the path of accumulation, accomplish the ten levels to the end. This is the process by which they attain unsurpassable enlightenment.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ sgrub pa'i le'u ste bcu bzhi pa'o// //
This completes the fourteenth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on practice.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ sgrub pa'i le'u ste bcu bzhi pa rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the fourteenth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on practice.
[gdams ngag rjes su bstan pa'i le'u]
15. INSTRUCTIONS AND FOLLOW-UP TEACHINGS[1]

! de'i rjes su sgrub pa khyad par du 'gro ba'i rgyu gdams ngag dang rjes bstan yin pas de 'chad pa la/ gdams ngag ji ltar rnyed pa'i tshul/ gdams ngag de tshul bzhin yid la byed pa/ de la sa lam bgrod tshul/ gdams ngag gi che ba'i phan yon brjod pa bzhi las/

The means by which the practice is enhanced are the instructions and follow-up teachings, so these will be explained next. There are four parts: (1) how the instructions are acquired; (2) keeping the meanings of the instructions properly in mind; (3) how bodhisattvas progress further along the path; and (4) a description of the great benefits of the instructions and follow-up teachings.
dang po/
1. HOW THE INSTRUCTIONS ARE ACQUIRED
bskal pa grangs med nges 'byung zhing / / mos pa rnam par 'phel byed pa/ / ji ltar chu yis rgya mtsho bzhin/ / dge chos rnams kyis yang dag rdzogs/ /
After a measureless kalpa, there is certain deliverance, And faith grows ever greater. Like rivers flowing into the ocean, Virtuous activities lead to true completion. (XV, 1)
zhes pas bstan te/

mos pa'i spyod pa'i sa la bskal pa grangs med gcig tu tshogs bsags pas 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sa dang por nges par 'byung bar byed cing / theg pa chen po'i lam la mos pa gong nas gong du rnam par 'phel bar byed pa de ni ji ltar phyogs bzhi'i chu rnams 'bab pa yis rgya mtsho chen po bzhin du bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs kyis bsdus pa'i dge ba'i chos rnams kyis rang rgyud kyi yon tan yang dag par rdzogs nas chos mchog gi mthar 'phags pa'i sa skyon med pa la 'jug par 'gyur ro/ /

The accumulation of merit on the level of earnest aspiration over one measureless kalpa leads to certain deliverance on the first supramundane level and makes one’s faith in the Mahāyāna path grow greater and greater. Like the rivers that flow into the ocean from the four directions, all the positive practices comprised in the accumulation of merit and wisdom bring the excellent qualities in one’s mind stream to true completion, and at the end of the supreme mundane level one will reach the flawless level of the noble ones.
de bzhin du ni tshogs bsags pa'i/ / rgyal sras gzod nas dag pa po/ / legs par shes shing sems dge ba/ / bsgom pa la ni rab tu sbyor/ /
The conquerors’ heirs who have thus gathered the accumulations Are pure from the outset. They have perfect understanding and a virtuous mind; They apply themselves to meditation. (XV, 2)

bshad ma thag pa de bzhin du ni tshogs bsags pa'i rgyal sras gzod nas te bskal pa du ma'i sngon nas rgyud yongs su dag cing tshul khrims rnam par dag pa'o/ / theg pa chen po'i chos zab cing rgya che ba mang du thos shing don ji lta ba bzhin legs par shes shing sems sgrib pa lnga dang mi 'grogs pa'i las su rung ba'i dge ba des/ sbyor ba'i lam bsgom pa la ni rab tu sbyor ro/ /

Bodhisattvas who have accumulated merit and wisdom as just mentioned have, from the beginning (that is, for many previous kalpas), purified their streams of being and observed perfect discipline. They have listened repeatedly to the extensive and profound teachings of the Great Vehicle and have perfectly understood their meaning. And they have virtuous minds, workable and free of the five hindrances.[2] Such bodhisattvas apply themselves to meditation on the path of joining.
de tshe chos kyi rgyun la ni/ / sangs rgyas rnams las zhi gnas dang / / ye shes yangs pa thob bya'i phyir/ / gdams ngag rgya chen rnyed par 'gyur/ /
At that time, bodhisattvas in the stream of Dharma Will receive from the buddhas Extensive oral instructions For achieving a vast degree of sustained calm and gnosis. (XV, 3)

des de ltar sngar tshogs rdzogs pas sa dang po'i ye shes khong du chud pa'i skal pa dang ldan pa'i phyir/ de yi tshe na chos kyi sgo'i rgyun gyi ting nge 'dzin thob par 'gyur ro/ / chos kyi rgyun gyi ting 'dzin zhes pa ci lta bur zhig yin zhe na/ gang la mnyam par bzhag pas sangs rgyas grangs med pa las dam pa'i chos kyi gdams ngag tshad med pa nod cing de'i tshig don rgyun bar ma chad du 'dzin nus pa'o/ / de ltar dbang po rnon pos tshogs lam chen po na ting 'dzin de thob pa yod la/ 'ga' zhig gis chos mchog gi dus su thob par bshad/ de ltar thob nas ting 'dzin de yang yon tan gyi khyad par gong nas gong du 'phel bar 'gyur/ de ltar chos kyi rgyun gyi ting nge 'dzin la gnas pa de las ni/ bshes gnyen gyi mchog sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams las/ 'phags pa'i ye shes sa dang po thob par byed pa'i zhi gnas shin tu rgyas pa'am yangs pa dang lhag mthong gi ye shes shin tu yangs pa thob par bya ba'i phyir de dang de'i gdams ngag tshad med pa mdo sde 'bum phrag du ma'i don dang ldan pa'i rgya chen po rnyed par 'gyur ro/ /

From having completed the accumulation of merit and wisdom in the past, they possess the good fortune to master the gnosis of the first bodhisattva level, so at that time they will acquire the concentration of the door-like stream of Dharma. Why is it called the “concentration of the stream of Dharma”? Because by remaining in equanimity in that concentration, bodhisattvas receive countless instructions on the sacred Dharma from innumerable buddhas and are able to continuously retain the words and meanings. While there are bodhisattvas with sharp faculties who acquire such concentration on the greater path of accumulation, some authorities say that it is acquired at the stage of the supreme mundane level. Once they have acquired it, the distinctive qualities of that concentration will grow more and more. Thus, from remaining in the concentration of the stream of Dharma, they will receive from the buddha bhagavāns, the greatest of spiritual teachers, countless oral instructions on achieving the utterly vast sustained calm and utterly vast gnosis of profound insight that will enable them to acquire the gnosis of the noble beings on the first bodhisattva level—extensive instructions that contain the teachings of many hundreds of thousands of sūtras.
gnyis pa gdams ngag gi don tshul bzhin yid la byed pa
2 KEEPING THE MEANINGS OF THE INSTRUCTIONS PROPERLY IN MIND
['di] la/ bsam pas yid la byed pa dang / bsgom pas yid la byed pa gnyis/
This section is divided into (1) keeping the instructions in mind by reflecting and (2) keeping the instructions in mind by meditating.
dang po/
a. KEEPING THE INSTRUCTIONS IN MIND BY REFLECTING
de nas dang por sdom brtson de/ / mdo yi sde la sogs pa'i chos/ / mi gnyis don ni rnam 'byed pa/ / mdo sogs ming la sems 'jog go /
Next, those who are diligent in the precepts begin by Contemplating just the names of the sūtras And other scriptures That clearly explain nonduality. (XV, 4)
zhes pas bstan te/

gdams ngag rnyed pa de nas dang por ram thog mar sdom brtson byang chub sems dpa' de yi ni/ mdo yi sde la sogs pa gsung rab yan lag bcu gnyis kyi chos/ mi gnyis pa ni gzung 'dzin gnyis med pa'am/ yod med gnyis dang bral ba gnyis su med pa'i de kho na nyid kyi don gyi rnam par 'byed cing gsal bar bstan pa yi/ mdo sde sa bcu pa dang lang kar gshegs pa dang / zla ba sgron me la sogs pa lta bu'i ming tsam la sems bzhag ste/ mdo 'di'i ming ni 'di zhes pa'o/ / zhes de tsam la sems 'jog go / 'di ni rtsa ba'i sems so/ /

Having received the instructions, bodhisattvas diligent in the precepts[3] begin by contemplating just the names of the sūtras and other scriptures of the Twelve Branches of Excellent Speech that provide clear and detailed explanations of nondual thatness (nondual in being devoid of subject and object, or in being free of the two extremes of existence and nonexistence). They simply consider their respective titles—names like the Sūtra of the Ten Levels, Sūtra on the Descent into Laṅka, and Moon Lamp Sūtra. This is the basic reflection.
de nas de ni rim bzhin du/ / tshig rab dbye la dpyod byed cing / / so so'i nang la tshul bzhin du/ / de yi don yang rnam par dpyod/ /
After that, step by step, They classify and analyze the contents. In each, they properly Examine their meaning. (XV, 5)

de nas sdom brtson de ni rim pa bzhin du/ mdo de dang de'i tshig rab tu dbye ba dpyod par byed cing / zhes pa 'di skad bdag gis thos pa zhes sogs nas/ mjug yongs su rdzogs pa'i bar du tshig ma lus pa rab tu dbye ste mdo 'di la le'u 'di tsam zhig yod/ sh+lo ka 'di tsam dang / yi ge'i grangs 'di tsam yod ces dpyad pa'o/ / 'di la rjes su dpyad pa'am rjes su 'gro ba'i sems zhes bya'o/ / so so'i nang la tshul bzhin du/ / de yi don yang rnam par dpyod/ / ces pa/ mdo so so'i nang la zhes 'bru mnan pa'ang mi 'grig pa med la/ blo brtan 'grel pa ltar na so so'i nang rang rigs pas tshul bzhin du zhes 'bru mnan dgos 'dug / don du mdo sde de'i dpyad pa'i 'og tu/ tshig 'di'i don ni 'di yin no zhes shes par byed pa dang / brjod bya'i don la rtog pa dang rjod byed yi ge la rtog pa ste/ don de rnams bgrang ba dang / 'jal ba dang / rtog pa dang / so sor rtog pa bzhi las/

After that, those bodhisattvas diligent in the precepts step by step “classify and analyze the contents” of each of those sūtras. Starting with “Thus I have heard…”[4] and continuing through to the end, they examine every single phrase, classifying the sūtra by the number of chapters, verses, and letters. This is what we call the “reflection of subsequent analysis or subsequent reflection.” For the lines “In each, they properly examine their meaning,” it is acceptable to add the word “sūtra” (to read: “In each sūtra,…”), while according to Sthiramati’s commentary, it is necessary to add “their own understanding” (to read: “In each, with their own understanding, they properly…”). What this means is that after analyzing the elements in a sūtra, bodhisattvas learn the meaning of each phrase and consider both the point that is being expressed and the letters that express it. There are four processes involved here: enumerating those points, evaluating them, examining them, and discerning them.

dang po phung po lnga khams bco brgyad/ skye mched bcu gnyis kyi grangs lta bu dang / gzugs phung la skye mched bcu dang*/ chos khams kyi phyogs gcig rig byed min pa'i gzugs bcas bcu gcig dang / tshor ba la mig gi 'dus te reg pa las byung ba nas yid kyi bar tshogs drug go zhes pa la sogs pa mdor na don rnams grangs su bgrangs te brtags pa'o/ / 'jal ba ni grangs de las lhag par sgro mi 'dogs/ nyung bar skur ba mi 'debs par grangs nges par bcad de de yi mtshan nyid la so sor gzhal zhing bsam pa'o/ / rtog pa ni/ grangs su bcad pa de lta bu yi chos der gzugs sogs de dang der bzhag pa'i rgyu mtshan la tshad ma'i rigs pa dang ldan par rtog cing dpyod pa'o/ / so sor rtog pa ni/ snga ma gsum gyi don de dag gi rang spyi'i mtshan nyid la so sor rtog pa'o/ /

First, they consider and enumerate, for example, the five aggregates, eighteen sense spheres, and twelve senses-and-fields; the ten senses-and-fields relating to the aggregate of form, together with imperceptible form (which constitutes one part of the sense sphere of mental objects), making eleven; the six aspects of feeling, from feeling resulting from contact with the eye to that resulting from contact with the mind, and so on. Evaluation involves ascertaining that their numbers are not overestimated or underestimated and considering and reflecting on their characteristics individually. Examination involves considering and analyzing with valid logic the reasons for classifying the phenomena that have thus been enumerated as form and so on. Discernment refers to distinguishing the general and specific characteristics of the subjects of the above three.

mdor na don rnams rnam grangs du yod kyi grangs la bsams nas grangs ma nor bar brtsis/ mang nyung du slar gyur par de ltar nges pa'i rgyu mtshan rigs pas dpyad nas grangs de dag gi don re re bzhin rang spyi'i mtshan nyid rnam par 'byed par byed do/ / rjod byed yi ge a la sogs pa 'bru re re sil bu bas don ston pa med la/ yi ge du ma 'dus nas ming dang ming 'dus nas tshig dang tshig mang po 'dus pa ngag gi gzhung du grub pas don ston pa yod pas/ yi ge la don med pa dang don yod pa gnyis su brtag par bya ste 'di la rnam par rtog pa'i sems zhes bya'o/ /

In short, bodhisattvas reflect on how many categories of subjects there are, check that the numbers are exact, rationally analyze the reasons for their definitive enumeration, and distinguish the general and specific characteristics of each of those subjects enumerated. Although the individual syllables—the letter a, for example—of an expression may not signify anything, combining several letters to form a word, and words to form a phrase, and many phrases to form a text does indicate a meaning. So bodhisattvas have to examine whether the letters mean anything or not. All this is what we call “analytic reflection.”
don de dag ni nges bzung nas/ / chos la kun nas sdom par byed/ / de yi don ni thob bya'i phyir/ / de nas de ni smon par byed/ /
Having become certain of the meaning, They summarize all the teachings. In order to achieve the point of those teachings, They then proceed to form an aspiration. (XV, 6)

don de dag ni nges bzung nas/ zhes pa tshig gi don rnams kyi mtshan ma dang / don gyi grangs la sogs pa dang de'i rnam dbye dang mtshan nyid kyi mtshan ma rnams shes rab kyis ma nor bar nges par bzung ba ni/ nges par 'dzin pa'i sems so/ / sems bzhi po des mdo sogs chos kyi tshig dang don rags pa tsam min par shin tu zhib cing nges par gtan la phab nas de'i 'og tu/ chos la kun nas sdom par byed ces pa/ mdo sde 'di yi dbu nas zhabs kyi bar gyi bstan don gcig tu dril te bsdus na 'di tsam zhig go zhes shes pa dang / mdo sde thams cad kyi don bsdus nas yang bstan bya'i don gyi snying po 'di tsam zhig ces gnad bsdu ba ste/ dper na mdo sde sa bcu pa las sa bcu'i rnam bzhag rgya cher bstan pa thams cad sa bcu bshad pa'i khongs su 'du bas sa bcu pa'i ming gi don de tsam la 'dus so snyam du rtsa ba'i sems la bsdu ba ni/ chos gcig gi don la kun nas sdom par byed pa ni bsdu ba'i sems te/

“Having become certain of the meaning” refers to what we call the “reflection of certainty,” which is to be unmistakenly certain, with wisdom, of the attributes of the subjects expressed by the words, the numbers of subjects and so forth, their categories, and the attributes that define them. With these four kinds of reflection, bodhisattvas establish definitively, in great detail and not just approximately, the words and meanings in the sūtras and other scriptures. After that, they “summarize all the teachings.” When they have condensed the points taught in a particular sūtra from the beginning to the end into a single point, they understand, “It is just this.” And by condensing the points in all the sūtras, they arrive at the essential point: “The essential point that is being indicated is just this.” For example, in the Sūtra of the Ten Levels, the classification of the ten levels is taught in great detail, and everything is included in the explanations of the ten levels. So while to think, “It is all included in the meaning of the name ‘The Ten Levels’ ” is part of the basic reflection, to condense everything into a single point is the “reflection of condensation.”

mdor na mdo sde rnams la rgya cher bshad kyang / la la lam gyi yon tan/ la la go rim/ la la 'bras bu/ la la spang bya sogs kyi sgo nas yin pas de thams cad shes par bya dgos kyang don gyi snying po da ltar rang gis nyams su len par bya ba ni 'di tsam zhig go rnal 'byor gyi gnad la mdo 'gags sdom pa'o/ / de ltar mdo yi bstan don la the tshom med par gyur pa na/ mdo sde las ji skad gsungs pa de yi don/ sa bcu po lta bu de ni rang gis mngon du thob par bya ba'i phyir/ de nas rnal 'byor pa de ni bdag gis don 'di thob par bya'o zhes re ba drag por smon par byed pa ni smon pa'i sems so/ / de ltar sems drug gi sgo nas mdo sogs gsung rab dam pa'i chos kyi don tshul bzhin yid la byed tshul la yid byed bcu gcig ste/ yid kyi brjod pas sogs tshigs bcad bzhis bstan don/

In short, the sūtras contain extensive and detailed explanations, some in terms of the qualities of the path, some in terms of the order, some in terms of the result, some in terms of the obscurations that have to be eliminated, and so on. And although it is important to know all these, they should be condensed into the essential point of practice: “The heart of the subject, which I now have to practice, is just this.” When they have thus become free of doubts with regard to the points taught in the sūtras, in order to actually achieve themselves those elements taught in the sūtras—the ten levels, for example—practitioners then give rise to the intense, hopeful aspiration “I will achieve this goal.” This is the “reflection of aspiration.” By means of these six reflections, bodhisattvas properly keep in mind the meaning of the sacred Dharma—that is, of the sūtras and other branches of the Excellent Speech. There are eleven ways of doing so, and these are indicated in the next four verses.
yid kyi brjod pas rgyun chags su/ / btsal bya so sor brtag par bya/ / yid la byed pa brjod med par/ / ro gcig pas kyang dpyad par bya/ /
Continuously, with mental expressions, They should research and examine the teachings And analyze them with the attentiveness of the single taste In which expression is absent. (XV, 7)

yid kyi brjod pas zhes pa yid kyi rtog pa ste/ yid shes kyis ming don bsres te don 'di dang 'di lta bu'o zhes shes pa de ni yid rtog bcas yin la des gsung rab kyi tshig dang don rgyun chags su btsal bar bya zhing brtag cing dpyad par byed pa ni rtog dpyod dang bcas pa bsam gtan dang po'i nyer bsdogs mi lcogs pa med pa dang / bsam gtan dang po'i dngos gzhi tsam po pa thob pa'i sems kyis so/ / rtog pa med la dpyod pa dang bcas pa ni bar gyi bsam gtan zhes sa dang po'i dngos gzhi khyad par can dang bsam gtan gnyis pa thob pa'i sems kyis so sor brtag par bya'o zhes gsungs/ bsam gtan gsum pa dang bzhi pa'i dngos gzhi thob pa na rtog dpyod gnyis ka med pa'i phyir yid la byed pa rtog dpyod kyis brjod du med pa ting nge 'dzin du ro gcig pas kyang dpyad par bya ste rtog dpyod bcas pa'i yid byed la sogs pa 'di gsum ni blo'i ngo bo'i dbye ba gsum mo/ / sems drug gi nang nas chos kyi ming tsam la sems 'dzin pa dang ni tshig la 'dzin pa'ang sdud do/ /

“Mental expressions” refers to the thoughts in the mind. The use of the mind consciousness to associate names and objects and the knowledge that a given name indicates such and such a thing involves the conceptual mind, and it is this that continuously seeks out and examines the words and meanings of the Excellent Words. The latter are analyzed with gross and subtle discursiveness, that is, by the minds of those who have attained the all-sufficing preparation of the first dhyāna and the rudimentary stage of the first dhyāna, and with the subtle discursiveness (gross discursiveness being absent) in the minds of those who have attained the extraordinary stage of the actual first dhyāna, the so-called intermediate dhyāna, and the second dhyāna. When the actual concentrations of the third and fourth dhyānas are attained, both gross and subtle discursiveness are absent, so things are analyzed with the attentiveness of the single taste in concentration, where there is no expression involving gross or subtle discursiveness. These three kinds of attentiveness (that with gross and subtle discursiveness, and so on) correspond to three categories of mental state. Of the six reflections, these three kinds of attentiveness incorporate concentrating on just the names of the teachings and concentrating on the words.
chos kyi ming ni bsdoms pa'ang 'di/ / zhi gnas lam du shes par bya/ / lhag mthong lam ni de'i don rnams/ / rnam par dpyod par shes par bya/ /

The summarization of the scriptures in their titles Should be understood as being the path of sustained calm. The path of profound insight Should be understood as the analysis of their meaning. (XV, 8)

ming tsam du mdo sde de yi bstan don mtha' dag sdoms dang zhes pa/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa bstan pa'i don dang tshig mang po stong phrag brgya pa la sogs pa'i don shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa zhes pa'i ming gi don du 'dus pa 'di lta bu la sems 'dzin pa ni zhi gnas kyi lam du shes par bya'o/ / lhag mthong gi lam ni mdo sde de'i don rnams bgrang 'jal sogs bzhi la rnam par dpyod par shes par bya'o/ /

Where the root verse says that in just the title all the points taught in a sūtra are summarized, the meanings of the many subjects and words (the One Hundred Thousand Lines, for example) that teach transcendent wisdom are included in the meaning of the title “Perfection of Wisdom.” Concentration on this is to be understood as being the path of sustained calm. The path of profound insight is to be understood as analyzing the points in that sūtra with enumeration, evaluation, examination, and discernment.
zung du 'brel ba'i lam ni de/ / bsdoms pa yin par shes par bya/ / zhum pa'i sems ni rab gzung ste/ / rgod pa yang ni zhi bar bya/ /
Know that the path of their union Is a combination of these. A dull mind has to be kept focused, And wildness must be subdued. (XV, 9)

zhi lhag zung du 'brel ba'i lam ni ming don de gnyis ka bsdoms pa yin par shes par bya ste/ zhi lhag zung du ma 'brel ba'i dus na/ zhi gnas kyis ming dang tshig la dmigs/ lhag mthong gis don la dmigs par byed pa yin la/ nam zhi lhag zung du 'brel ba'i tshe na ming dang don so sor mi dmigs kyi/ de gnyis gcig tu bsdus nas zhi gnas dang lhag mthong mgo mnyam du 'brel te dmigs par byed do/ / zhi gnas yid byed dang / lhag mthong yid byed dang / zung 'brel yid byed 'di gsum ni lam gyi ngos nas dbye ba gsum mo/ / yang dmigs pas phye ba gsum ni mtshan ma gsum ste/ zhi gnas kyi mtshan ma dang / rab tu 'dzin pa'i mtshan ma dang / btang snyoms kyi mtshan ma zhes gsungs pa/ sems 'phro zhing rgod par gyur na g.yeng ba dang 'khor ba'i skyon bsams nas phyir mi 'phro bar sems nang du mnyam par 'jog pa zhi gnas kyi mtshan ma yid la byed pa dang / sems rmugs pa dang zhum par gyur na lhag mthong gi mtshan ma yid la byed pa/ sangs rgyas dang ting nge 'dzin gyi yon tan nam chos rnams kyi rang spyi'i mtshan ma yid la byed pas zhum pa las sems rab tu 'dzin te gzengs bstod par byed dgos pa yin te/ rgod pa na lhag mthong dang rjes su mthun pas lhag mthong gis sel mi nus pas zhi gnas yid la byed do/ / rmugs pa dang zhum pa dang gnyid ni zhi gnas dang rjes su mthun pas lhag mthong gis bsal dgos pas/ zhum pa'i sems ni lhag mthong gi mtshan ma yid la byed pas rab tu gzung ste/ rgod pa yang ni zhi gnas kyi mtshan ma yid la byed pas zhi bar bya zhing /

The path of the union of sustained calm and profound insight is to be understood as combining both names and meanings. When sustained calm and profound insight are not combined, one focuses on the names and words with sustained calm and considers their meanings with profound insight. When sustained calm and profound insight are united, names and meanings are not considered separately but are combined, and one focuses on them with sustained calm and profound insight equally. These three—attentiveness related to sustained calm, attentiveness related to profound insight, and attentiveness related to their union—make three categories in terms of the path. These are also classified into three in terms of their object, as three special points—the special points of sustained calm, maintaining one’s concentration, and equanimity. If thoughts proliferate and the mind becomes wild, then by reflecting on the defects of distraction and saṃsāra, one settles the mind inward in meditation, without letting it proceed outward again. This is to keep in mind the special point of sustained calm. If the mind becomes dull and low-spirited, one keeps in mind the special point of profound insight: it is necessary to rouse the mind out of its low spirits and to encourage oneself by thinking of the general and particular qualities or attributes of buddhahood and of concentration. Wildness is analogous to profound insight and cannot, therefore, be dispelled by profound insight, so it is sustained calm that needs to be kept in mind. Dullness and low spirits and somnolence are analogous to sustained calm, so they have to be cleared with profound insight.[5] Thus the low-spirited mind is kept roused by keeping in mind the special point of profound insight. And wildness is to be subdued by keeping in mind the special point of sustained calm.
de nas dmigs pa de la ni/ / mnyam par gyur na btang snyoms gzhag / de la rtag tu bya ba dang / / gus par bya ste sbyar bar bya/ /
Then, when there is evenness with regard to the object, Bodhisattvas settle in equanimity. In all this, constancy And devotion are to be applied. (XV, 10)

zhum rgod med par mnyam par gyur na de ga'i ngang du mi g.yo bar btang snyoms kyi mtshan ma yid la byed pas btang snyoms su bzhag par bya'o/ / de ltar bsgoms pa de thams cad kyang gus sbyor gyi yid byed dang rtag sbyor kyi yid byed gnyis kyis rgyun ma chad par nyams su len dgos pas yid byed snga ma de rnams la/ dus res 'ga' tsam 'jug pa ma yin par rtag tu bya ba yid la byed pa dang / yid byed rnams la spro zhing gus par bya ste lam de la sbyar bar bya'o/ /

When the mind is even, with neither low spirits nor wildness, one should settle evenly in that very state, without moving, keeping in mind the special point of equanimity. All these meditational processes have to be practiced without interruption, with two kinds of attentiveness related to devoted application and constant application. Thus, on the path one should apply to the above-mentioned kinds of attentiveness the attentiveness related to constancy (not merely keeping them in mind from time to time) and enthusiasm and respect for those different kinds of attentiveness.
gnyis pa gdams ngag gi don bsgom pa'i sgo nas yid la byed tshul/
b. KEEPING THE INSTRUCTIONS IN MIND BY MEDITATING

bsam pa'i shes rab tsam gyis lam gyi yon tan mngon du mi 'gyur ba'i rtse gcig tu bsgom dgos la/ de yang thog mar 'dod khams pa'i sems nang du mnyam par ma bzhag pas skad cig mi sdod par glog dang rlung dang sprin ltar g.yo ba rgya mtsho'i rlabs ltar dgag par dka' ba'i rnam rtog rnams sems gnas pa'i thabs dgus rim par brtul te nang du yang dag 'jog pa'i ting nge 'dzin bsgrub pa'i tshul ni/

The qualities of the path will not be actualized just with the wisdom that comes from reflecting; it is necessary to meditate one-pointedly. In the beginning, the mind of someone in the world of desire, not being inwardly settled in meditation, never stays still for a second. It moves like lightning, like the wind, like clouds. And like the waves in the ocean, it is difficult to stop. Yet if one uses the nine methods for settling the mind,[6] thoughts are gradually brought under control and the mind is correctly brought inward to meditation. How to accomplish such concentration is the subject of the following verses.
dmigs pa la ni sems gtad nas/ / de'i rgyun rnam par g.yeng mi bya/ / rnam g.yeng myur du rtogs byas nas/ / de la slar ni blan par bya/ /

Once they direct the mind at the object, They should not be distracted from the continuity of that. They should quickly realize when they are distracted And draw the mind back onto the object. (XV, 11)
ces pas bstan te/

dmigs pa gang yang rung ba la ni rang gi sems rtse gcig tu gtad nas bzhag pa dang / de ltar bzhag kyang skad cig mi sdod par rnam pa gzhan du g.yo na/ snga ma'i dmigs pa de'i rgyun las rnam par g.yeng bar mi bya bar dran pa'i sgo nas rgyun bskyang ci nus su bzhag go / gal te de ltar gzhag kyang rgyun ring du gnas mi nus par gzhan du g.yeng par gyur na/ bdag ni yul gzhan la rnam par g.yeng ngo snyam du myur du rtogs par byas nas/ sngar gyi dmigs pa la slar ni sems blan te bzhag par bya'o/ /

(1) Directing the mind one-pointedly at a suitable object of concentration, one should let it rest on it. (2) Even though it settles in this way, it may move toward other mental images without staying still for a second. If this happens, one should not be distracted from the continuity of the original object of concentration: one should use mindfulness to preserve the continuity and settle as long as possible. (3) It may be that, despite doing so, one is unable to stay like that for any length of time and becomes distracted by other things. In that case, one should quickly realize that one is distracted by other objects and summon the mind back, settling it on the original object.
blo ldan gong nas gong du yang / / sems ni nang du bsdu bar bya/ / de nas yon tan mthong ba'i phyir/ / ting nge 'dzin la sems gdul lo/ /
The wise should gather The mind inward more and more. Then, because they see the virtues of this, They tame the mind in concentration. (XV, 12)

de ltar yang yang goms pas rgyun bskyangs pas cung zad re rgyun gnas su btub na/ blo ldan des shin tu bsgrim te gong nas gong du yang / sems ni nang du yid kyi dmigs pa snga ma la bsdu bar bya ba ni nye bar 'jog pa zhes bya'o/ / de nas sems sngar bas cung zad gnas su btub pa ni sems nang du gnas pa de yi yon tan rang gis mthong ba'i phyir/ bdag gis sems gnas pa'i ting nge 'dzin thob na ci ma rung snyam du ting nge 'dzin la dga' zhing don du gnyer bas rang gi sems gdul lo/ /zhes pa/ rnam g.yeng gi rtog pas sems ma dul ba de ting nge 'dzin la dga' bas dul bar byed pa'o/ /

(4) By getting used to that again and again, one is able to maintain the continuity and thence to remain in meditation continuously for a short while. At this point, the wise should be extremely attentive and gather the mind in onto the original mental object more and more. This is known as “firmly settling.” (5) Then, when one is able to settle the mind a bit better than before, one sees for oneself the virtues of settling the mind in concentration and consequently thinks, “Wouldn’t it be good if I could achieve the concentration of mental stillness.” One feels pleased and enthusiastic about concentration, and this leads to one’s bringing the mind under control. It is the pleasure the distracted, untamed mind derives from concentration that acts to subdue it.
rnam g.yeng nyes pa mthong ba'i phyir/ / de la mi dga' zhi bar bya/ / brnab sems yid mi bde la sogs/ / langs pa de bzhin zhi bar bya/ /
Because they see the fault in distraction, They should pacify the disinclination to concentrate. Similarly, they should pacify covetousness And unhappiness, if these arise. (XV, 13)

de ltar ting nge 'dzin la dga' zhing don du gnyer bas sems dmigs pa la ci rigs su bzhag kyang / sngon rnam g.yeng goms pa'i shugs kyis rnam par g.yeng bar gyur na/ rnam g.yeng 'di ni ting nge 'dzin 'phrog pa'i chom rkun lta bu shin tu gnod pa byed pa'o/ /zhes rnam g.yeng gi nyes pa mthong ba'i phyir 'di'i dbang du mi 'gro bar yon tan kun gyi rtsa ba ting nge 'dzin la 'bad par bya'o snyam du rnam g.yeng gi rgyus ting nge 'dzin de la mi dga' ba de nyid zhi bar bya ba ni sems gnas drug pa zhi bar byed pa zhes bya'o/ / de ltar 'bad pas sems sngar bas ches bzang tsam du gnas na yang / skabs 'gar brnab sems dang yid mi bde ba la sogs pa dang bying rgod sogs nye ba'i nyon mongs pa gang dag langs pa'ang snga ma de bzhin du 'di dag gi dbang du song na ting nge 'dzin mi 'grub pas skyon che la/ ma song na mngon par shes pa sogs yon tan khyad par rnams kyi gzhir gyur pa'i ting nge 'dzin 'grub pas ci nas rnam rtog ngan pa 'di rnams yid la mi bya'o snyam du brnab sems la sogs pa de dag la so sor brtag pa'am gnyen po bsten pa'am yang na ci mi snyam pas zhi bar bya ba ni nye bar zhi bar byed pa'o/ /

(6) Even though one’s pleasure and keenness in concentration may result in the mind settling on the object to a certain extent, the force of one’s previous habituation to distraction may result in one’s becoming distracted. When this happens, one should see the defect of such distraction—that it is extremely deleterious to concentration, running off with it like a robber. So thinking, “Rather than being carried away by distraction, I must make an effort to concentrate, for concentration is the root of all good qualities,” one should counteract one’s disinclination to concentrate (which is caused by distraction). This is the sixth method for settling the mind, “pacifying.” (7) With this sort of effort, the mind will settle much better than before. Nevertheless, from time to time covetousness, unhappiness, and so forth, and lesser defilements like agitation and sinking may come up. As in the previous case, if one is influenced by these, one will not manage to concentrate, and they are therefore very damaging. On the other hand, if one does not fall prey to these, one will achieve meditative concentration, which is the basis of extraordinary qualities such as preternatural knowledge. So, thinking, “I must on no account keep these bad thoughts in mind!”[7] one should counteract covetousness and the like by means of analysis, or by applying an antidote, or alternatively by thinking nothing of them. This is “firmly pacifying.”
de nas sdom brtson can gyis ni/ / sems la mngon par 'du byed bcas/ / rang gi ngang gis 'byung ba 'thob/ / de goms pa las 'du mi byed/ /
Then, those who are diligent in the precepts, By deliberately acting on their states of mind, Achieve natural concentration. From getting used to that, they no longer make deliberate effort. (XV, 14)

de nas sdom brtson can gyi ni sems la rtsol ba'i sgo nas mngon par 'du byed pa dang bcas pa'i sems gnas pa brgyad pa goms pa'i shugs kyis ngang gis 'byung ba 'thob ste/ rtsol ba brten bzhin du bsgrims na rnam rtog gzhan gyis bar chad mi nus par dmigs pa la gnas pa ni 'du byed dang bcas pa zhes bya'o/ / 'du byed dang bcas pa'i sems gnas de yi ngang du goms pa rgyun bsring bar byas pa las 'bad rtsol gyis bsgrim mi dgos par sems ngang gis dmigs pa la gnas shing lhun gyis grub par gyur nas 'du mi byed pa thob pa ni sems gnas pa dgu'i tha ma yin te ting nge 'dzin mthun par 'dod pa'i sems rtse gcig pa zhes bya ba yin no/ / sems gnas pa'i thabs dgu po ni/ mdo las/ 'jog par byed/ yang dag par 'jog par byed/ bsdus te 'jog par byed/ nye bar 'jog par byed/ dul bar byed/ zhi bar byed/ nye bar zhi bar byed/ rgyud gcig tu byed/ ting nge 'dzin du byed pa'am mnyam par 'jog par byed ces gsungs so/ /

(8) Subsequently, bodhisattvas diligent in the precepts settle the mind deliberately, with effort. This is the eighth method, and from habituation to this, they arrive at a point where it happens naturally. If one makes an effort to be attentive, the mind settles on the object of concentration without other thoughts being able to interrupt it. This is what we call “deliberate concentration.” (9) By getting used over a long period to deliberately settling the mind, one no longer needs to make an effort to concentrate, and the mind settles automatically on the object of concentration. Concentration becomes spontaneous, and one reaches the stage of settling the mind without deliberate application. This is the last of the nine methods of settling the mind and is what we call “mental one-pointedness that is accepted as being consistent with concentration.”[8] These nine methods of settling the mind are described in the sūtras as settling, correctly settling, withdrawing and settling, firmly settling, taming, pacifying, firmly pacifying, maintaining continuous one-pointedness, and concentrating or settling in evenness.
de nas de yis lus dang sems/ / shin tu sbyangs pa che thob nas/ / yid la byed dang bcas shes bya/ / de yis de ni 'phel byas nas/ / 'phel ba ring du 'gro ba yis/ / dngos gzhi'i gnas pa des 'thob bo/ /

Then, they gain great fitness Of the body and mind, And are known to have attentiveness. Having fostered it, (XV, 15) By progressing further, They attain the states of the actual concentrations. (XV, 16ab)

'du mi byed par rang gis gnas pa'i sems thob pa de nas de'i ngang du goms na rnal 'byor pa de yi lus shin tu sbyang bas las su rung ba dang sems shin tu sbyangs pa thob ste/ lus yang zhing shin tu bde ba'i rnam pas dge ba bsgom pa la las su rung ba dang / sems gsal dwangs rnyog med dga' bas khyab pa'i nyams dang bcas te dge ba'i dmigs pa la las su rung ba shin sbyangs chung ngu dang 'bring thob nas/ grib ma ltar shin tu srab cing dwangs pa'i shin tu sbyangs pa rgya che ba thob nas/ bsam gtan dang po thob byed zhi rags rnam can gyi yid la byed pa dang bcas pa yin par shes par bya'o/ / yid byed de yis 'dod pa'i nyon mongs che 'bring chung gsum rim par spangs pa'i sgo nas ting nge 'dzin de ni 'phel bar byas nas/ 'phel ba de nyid sa 'og ma las ring du 'gro ba yis/ bsam gtan dang po'i dngos gzhi'i gnas pa rnal 'byor pa des thob bo/ /de bzhin du gong nas gong du zhi rags rnam can gyi yid byed kyis bsam gtan bzhi pa'i dngos gzhi'i bar du sgrub par shes par bya'o/ / 'di yan chad kyi ting 'dzin sgrub tshul bshad nas 'di nas mar la ting nge 'dzin thob pa'i yon tan ston te/

When practitioners have reached the stage where the mind settles by itself, without deliberate effort, and get used to that state, they acquire trained, fit bodies and fully trained minds. Their bodies become light and perfectly healthy, and thus fit for practicing virtue. And their minds feel lucid and clear and filled with joy, fit for conceiving virtue. After achieving this trained, workable state to a lesser and medium extent, they attain a vast degree of fitness, their bodies and minds being as subtle and limpid as shadows. It should be understood that they then keep in mind peaceful and gross states, enabling them to attain the first dhyāna.[9] That attentiveness successively eliminates the lesser, middling, and greater defilements of the world of desire, and by that means meditative concentration grows, progressing from the lower level so that practitioners attain the actual concentration of the first dhyāna. You should understood that by similarly keeping in mind peaceful and gross states progressively, they accomplish the concentrations up to the actual concentration of the fourth dhyāna. Up to this point we have explained how concentration is accomplished. There now follows a description of the virtues of achieving meditative concentration.

mngon shes don du gnyer bas de/ / sbyangs nas las su rung ba'i mchog / bsam gtan las 'thob mngon par shes/ / mngon par bsgrubs pa'i sgo nas de/ / sangs rgyas dpag tu med pa la/ / mchod pa'i phyir dang mnyan pa'i phyir/ / 'jig rten khams ni rnams su 'gro/ / 'dis ni sangs rgyas dpag med la/ / bskal dpag med par bsnyen bkur byas/ / de la bsnyen bkur byas pa'i phyir/ / sems ni las rung mchog tu 'gyur/ /

From striving for preternatural knowledge, They are purified and become supremely fit. (XV, 16cd) By using the preternatural powers Gained through concentration, In order to venerate and listen to Countless buddhas They travel to different worlds. (XV, 17) Thus they venerate infinite buddhas For infinite kalpas. And because they have venerated them, Their minds become supremely fit. (XV, 18)

bsam gtan bzhi'i dngos gzhi thob pa na/ mngon par shes pa don du gnyer bas bsam gtan gyi dngos gzhi thob pa de rang sa'i nyon mongs pa sred pa dang lta ba dang the tshom gyi shas che bas ma dag pa sbyangs nas las su rung ba'i mchog tu gyur na/ las su rung ba dag pa'i bsam gtan de las thos pa'i rdzu 'phrul la sogs pa'i mngon par shes pa lnga po nyid mngon par bsgrubs pa'i sgo nas rnal 'byor pa de sangs rgyas dpag tu med pa la mchod pa byed pa'i phyir dang dam pa'i chos mnyan pa'i phyir/ phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams rnams su 'gro bar byed do/ / tshul 'di lta bu'i ni sangs rgyas dpag tu med pa la bskal pa dpag tu med par mchod cing bsnyen bkur byas pa yin no/ / 'di'i skabs su bskal pa dpag tu med pa zhes pa/ grangs med gsum zhes pa lta bu'i don ma yin par bgrang ba las 'das pa'i bskal pa dpag tu med pa zhes bya ste/ sems kyi dbang ting nge 'dzin thob pa'i dbang gis so/ / zhing dam pa phyogs bcu'i sangs rgyas de la bsnyen bkur tshad med pa byas pa'i phyir/ bsam pa rnam par dag pa'i rnal 'byor pa de'i sems ni las su rung ba'i mchog tu 'gyur te ji ltar 'dod par 'jug nus so/ /

When bodhisattvas attain the actual concentrations of the four dhyānas, as a result of their keenness to acquire preternatural knowledge such practitioners attaining the actual concentration are purified of the impurities caused by the predominant defilements on their respective levels—craving, view, and doubt—and they become supremely fit. Through the concentration of that pure, fit state, they acquire the five kinds of preternatural knowledge (the knowledge and ability to perform miracles, for instance), and by making full use of these, they travel to different world systems in the ten directions in order to make offerings to infinite buddhas and to listen to the sacred Dharma. It is in this way that they serve and venerate infinite buddhas for infinite kalpas. “Infinite kalpas” in this context does not refer to the “three measureless kalpas”[10] but rather to infinite kalpas beyond counting—infinite on account of the mental power of the concentration these bodhisattvas have attained. Because they have made boundless offerings to those sublime objects of reverence, the buddhas of the ten directions, the minds of these purely motivated practitioners become sublimely fit, and they are able to use them just as they wish.

des na de dag sngon rol du/ / phan yon lnga ni 'thob 'gyur te/ / des ni rnam par dag pa'i snod/ / bla na med pa nyid 'gyur 'di'i/ / lus la gnas ngan len pa kun/ / skad cig re re la zad 'gyur/ / lus dang sems ni kun tu yang / / shin tu sbyangs pas gang bar 'gyur/ /

And so they will obtain Five prelusive benefits. For those who are to become unsurpassable, Perfectly pure vessels, (XV, 19) All the negative tendencies of the body Will be exhausted in each instant. And all the time, the mind and body Will throughout be perfectly fit. (XV, 20)

des na byang sems de dag sa dang po thob pa'i sngon rol du sa thob pa'i mtshan mar gyur pa'i phan yon lnga ni 'thob par 'gyur te/ gang zhe na/ sems las su rung ba de ni/ sa dang po'i ye shes nyan rang las khyad par du 'phags pa'i bla na med pa skye rung gi snod bla na med pa nyid du 'gyur bas de'i phyir byang chub sems dpa' 'di yi lus la gnas ngan len du gyur pa ma bsdams pa'i sems kyis spre'u ltar mchongs pa sogs dang lus lci zhing mi bde ba'i rnam pas dge ba la bkol du mi btub pa thams cad skad cig re re la zad par 'gyur te lus sems las su mi rung ba'i gnas ngan len gyi bag chags kun gzhi la yod pa byang bar byed pa'i yon tan dang po'o/ / lus dang sems ni dus kun tu yang shin tu sbyangs pas gang bar 'gyur ba ni gnyis pa'o/ /de gnyis ni khrus mkhan gyis ras sogs khrus rtsi'i tshul chus 'dag sbyong byed pa bzhin zhi gnas kyi chus lus las su mi rung ba sbyang ba dang / lus sems shin sbyangs kyi bde bas khyab par byas pa yin no/ /

Thus, prior to attaining the first bodhisattva level, those bodhisattvas will obtain five benefits, which are signs that they are going to attain the bodhisattva levels. What are these benefits? Because their fit minds are to be the unsurpassable vessels in which the unsurpassable gnosis of the first level (far superior to that of the listeners and solitary realizers) can take birth, in order for that to happen, all the negative tendencies in those bodhisattvas’ bodies—that is, of their unrestrained minds leaping about like monkeys and their heavy, unhealthy bodies, which they are unable to put to virtuous use—will, in each instant, be exhausted. This is the first good quality, that of the habitual negative tendencies of unfit body and mind present in the ground of all being purified. All the time, their bodies and minds will be impregnated with fitness.[11] This is the second good quality. Like a launderer using water to rinse soap out of cotton or other fabrics, these two qualities purify the unfit body with the water of sustained calm and fill the mind and body with the bliss of fitness.
chos rnams snang ba thams cad du/ / yongs su chad pa med rtogs 'gyur/ / yang dag pa yi rgyu mtshan ni/ / ma brtags pa dag rab tu mthong / /
They will realize uninterruptedly The whole light of the Dharma. The signs of perfect purity Will be clearly seen without checking. (XV, 21)

dam pa'i mdo sde la sogs pa kha cig shes kha cig mi shes pa lta bu ma yin par dam pa'i chos rnams kyi don shes pa'i snang ba dus thams cad du yongs su chad pa med pa rtogs par 'gyur ba ni gsum pa'o/ / yang dag pa 'phags pa'i sa thob pa'i mtshan ma dngos su lus la srin 'bu mi 'byung ba sogs dang / rmi lam du lus la khrus byed pa dang / sangs rgyas kyis lung ston pa sogs dang sa bcu pa las sa bcu thob par rmi lam gyi mtshan ma gsungs pa de lta bu la sogs pa sa thob pa'i rgyu mtshan nam mtshan ma rnams ni ched du ma brtags pa dag kyang rab tu mthong ba ni bzhi pa'o/ / de gnyis ni lhag mthong las byung ba'i rtags so/ /

The third special quality is that at all times, uninterruptedly, the light of knowledge of the whole of the sacred Dharma will be realized. It is not as if these bodhisattvas will know some of the sacred sūtras and not others. The signs of attaining the perfectly pure levels of the noble beings include, in real life, the absence of parasites in one’s body, and, in dreams, washing one’s body, receiving predictions from the buddhas, and the other signs of attaining the ten levels that one gets in dreams as described in the Sūtra of the Ten Levels. To clearly see these and other such signs of attaining the bodhisattva levels, even without specially checking for them, is the fourth quality. These last two qualities are indications that come through practicing profound insight.
de bzhin chos sku rab rdzogs dang / / rnam par dag par bya ba'i phyir/ / blo dang ldan pa rnam kun tu/ / rtag tu rgyu yongs 'dzin par byed/ /
Similarly, in order to perfect the body of truth And attain perfect purity, The wise take hold of their causes, Constantly and in all situations. (XV, 22)

de bzhin du mthar thug gi rtogs pa chos kyi sku rab tu rdzogs pa dang / spang bya sgrib pa gnyis rnam par dag par bya ba'i phyir/ blo dang ldan pa de mnyam rjes kyi rnam pa kun tu/ dus rtag tu yang spangs rtogs mthar thug gi de 'dra'i rgyu yongs su 'dzin par byed pa ni lnga pa'o/ / 'di ni zhi lhag gnyis ka'i cha'o/ / blo brtan 'grel par lus sems kyi gnas ngan len zad pa dang / lus shin sbyangs kyi bde bas khyab pa dang / sems shin sbyangs kyi bde bas khyab pa gnyis tha dad du bgrangs nas/ chos kyi snang ba yongs su ma chad pa dang / yang dag pa'i rgyu mtshan mthong ba lnga la phan yon lngar bshad/ chos sku rdzogs pa dang rnam dag thob pa'i rgyu yongs su 'dzin pa ni rnam pa yongs su 'dzin par byed pa zhes gsungs/ 'dir ni theg bsdus las gsungs pa ltar phan yon lnga gong ltar bshad do/ / gdams ngag gi le'u'i mgo nas brtsams te yon tan lnga bstan pa 'di yan chad kyi bar ni byang chub sems dpa' so so'i skye bo mos pa'i spyod pa'i sa la gnas pa'i chos dang yon tan ji ltar thob pa bstan pa yin no/ /

In this way, in order to perfect ultimate realization—the body of truth—and to purify the two obscurations that have to be eliminated, wise bodhisattvas grasp those same causes[12] of ultimate elimination and realization all the time, in both meditation and postmeditation. This is the fifth quality, which involves both sustained calm and profound insight. Sthiramati’s commentary explains the five benefits as the exhaustion of physical and mental negative tendencies, the body being filled with the bliss of fitness, the mind being filled with the bliss of fitness (in other words, he counts these two separately), the uninterrupted light of the Dharma, and seeing the signs of purity. And he refers to grasping the causes of perfecting the body of truth and attaining perfect purity as “fully grasping” them. The above explanation of the five benefits follows the description in the Compendium of the Great Vehicle. All the above, from the beginning of this Instructions chapter down to the description of the five good qualities, is an exposition of how a bodhisattva who is an ordinary being on the level of earnest aspiration obtains the teachings and good qualities.
gsum pa de las lam bgrod tshul ni/
3. HOW BODHISATTVAS PROGRESS FURTHER ALONG THE PATH
de nas de 'drar gyur pa yi/ / byang chub sems dpa' mnyam bzhag pas/ / yid kyi brjod pa ma gtogs par/ / don kun rab tu mi mthong ngo*/ /
Next, bodhisattvas like these Remain in evenness, and by doing so, No longer see any objects As anything other than mental expressions. (XV, 23)
ces pa'i bar gyis bstan te/

de nas tshogs lam du zhi lhag khyad par can thob pa de 'drar gyur pa yi/ byang chub sems dpa'i ting nge 'dzin la rtse gcig tu mnyam par bzhag pas/ yid kyi brjod pa'am rnam par rtog pa tsam ma gtogs par/ phyi rol gyi don kun sems las logs shig tu yod par rab tu mi mthong ba ni drod snang ba thob pa'i dus su'o/ /

After that, bodhisattvas who have become like that and acquired extraordinary sustained calm and profound insight on the path of accumulation rest in evenness in one-pointed concentration. As a result, they no longer see external objects as existing outside the mind—as anything more than mind-talk or thoughts. It is at this time that they gain the vision of the stage of warmth.[13]
chos kyi snang ba 'phel bya'i phyir/ / brtson 'grus brtan pa kun tu brtsam/ / chos kyi snang ba 'phel nas ni/ / sems tsam la ni gnas par 'gyur/ /
In order to enhance the light of Dharma, The steadfast apply themselves fully with diligence. The light of Dharma grows greater And they will remain in the state of mind-only. (XV, 24)

chos kyi snang ba thob pa de nyid je cher rab tu 'phel bar bya ba'i phyir brtson 'grus ni brtan pa byang chub sems dpa' des kun du rtsom pa ni snang ba mched pa'am rgyas pa rtse mo'i dus su'o/ / de ltar brtson 'grus brtsams pas chos kyi snang ba shas cher 'phel bar gyur nas ni/ phyi'i yul sogs rang mtshan pa'i snang ba dang bral bar gyur te sems tsam la ni gnas par gyur ro/ /

In order to greatly enhance the light of Dharma[14] that they have gained, steadfast bodhisattvas apply themselves fully, with diligence. This corresponds to the peak stage, where their vision unfolds or increases. As a result of their practicing diligently in this way, the light of Dharma grows ever greater, and they will remain in the state of mind-only, free from the perception of specifically characterized external objects and suchlike.
de nas don du snang ba kun/ / sems su rab tu snang bar 'gyur/ / de tshe de yi gzung ba yi/ / rnam par g.yeng ba de spangs 'gyur/ /
Then, everything that appears as a sense object Will clearly appear as the mind. At that time, the distracting apprehension Of those things will be eliminated. (XV, 25)

ji ltar sems tsam la gnas par gyur zhe na/ 'di ni don du snang ba gzugs la sogs pa thams cad kun rmi lam ngo shes pa'i dus kyi snang ba ltar 'di thams cad rang gi sems kyi snang ba tsam las phyi don rang mtshan pa med par rab tu snang bar 'gyur ro/ / de'i tshe na gzugs la sogs pa phyi don de yi gzung ba yi rnam par g.yeng ba de spangs nas mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ /

In what way will they remain in the state of mind-only? All forms and suchlike that appear as objects of the senses will then be clearly perceived as not existing as specifically characterized external objects—as nothing other than just the appearances of one’s own mind, like the appearances in a dream when one recognizes them as such. At that time, the distracting objective apprehension of those forms and other external objects will be eliminated and will no longer appear.
de nas de la 'dzin pa yi/ / rnam par g.yeng ba 'ba' zhig lus/ / de tshe bar chad med pa yi/ / ting nge 'dzin la myur du reg /
After that, only the distractions In the form of an apprehending subject are left. At that time, they quickly reach The concentration “with no obstruction.” (XV, 26)

de nas rnal 'byor pa de la sems yod do snyam pa'i 'dzin pa yi rnam par rtog pa'am g.yeng ba 'ba' zhig lhag mar lus te ma spangs pa ni/ bzod pa de kho na nyid kyi phyogs gcig la zhugs pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi dus su'o/ / de'i tshe gzung ba med na de la 'dzin pa'i sems kyang ga la yod snyam du de gnyis tshul 'dra bar myur du rtogs nas mthong lam dang bar chad med pa yi/ de ma thag pa'i ting nge 'dzin la ring por mi thogs par myur du reg pas chos mchog de ma thag pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi dus su'o/ /

Subsequently, for such practitioners, there is left, uneliminated, only the subjective thought or distraction “There is a mind.” This corresponds to the stage of acceptance, with the concentration that partly penetrates thatness. At this time they ask themselves, “If there is no apprehended object, how can there be a mind apprehending it?” And having rapidly come to the realization that the mode of existence of both subject and object is the same, they have no difficulty in swiftly reaching the “immediately preceding concentration”[15] for which there is nothing barring the way to the path of seeing. So this is the stage of the immediately preceding concentration of the supreme mundane level.
'di ltar de yi mjug thogs su/ / 'dzin pa'i rnam par g.yeng ba spong / / 'di dag go rims bzhin du ni/ / dro bar 'gyur sogs yin shes bya/ /
Immediately after that, Distractions in the form of a subject are eliminated. The above are to be understood as being The successive stages of warmth and so forth. (XV, 27)

de ma thag pa zhes pa ci zhe na/ 'di ltar gzung ba med par rtog pa'i bzod pa de yi mjug thogs su/ 'dzin pa'i rnam par g.yeng ba yang spong bar byed la de'i de ma thag tu sa dang po la 'jug par byed pa'i phyir chos mchog la de ma thag pa zhes bya'o/ / bshad ma thag pa 'di dag go rims bzhin du ni/ dro bar 'gyur sogs sbyor lam bzhi po yin par shes par bya'o/ /

What is meant by “immediately preceding” here? Immediately after the acceptance of this realization that there is no apprehended object, the distraction of an apprehending subject is also eliminated, and immediately after that bodhisattvas enter the first level, which is why the supreme mundane level is referred to as “immediately preceding.” These stages that have just been explained are to be understood as being the four successive stages—warmth, and so on—of the path of joining.[16]
de nas des ni 'jig rten las/ / 'das pa'i ye shes bla med pa/ / rnam par mi rtog dri ma med/ / 'dzin pa gnyis dang bral ba 'thob/ /
Subsequently they acquire Unsurpassable supramundane gnosis, Nonconceptual, uncontaminated, And free of the two kinds of grasping. (XV, 28)

chos mchog de'i rjes thog de ma thag par mthong lam thob tshul gsungs pa/ de nas byang chub sems dpa' chos mchog thob pa des ni/ 'jig rten las 'das pa'i ye shes nyan rang rnams las 'phags pa'i bla na med pa/ 'khor gsum du rnam par mi rtog pa mthong bas spang bya'i nyon mongs pa dang bral bas dri ma med pa/ gzung ba dang 'dzin pa gnyis spangs pas na 'dzin pa gnyis dang bral ba thob pa la mdo las chos la chos kyi mig rdul med cing dri ma dang bral ba thob ces gsungs te/ gzung 'dzin spangs pas rdul med pa dang / mthong spangs dang bral dri ma dang bral ba'am/ yang na bzod pa ni rdul med pa ste nyon shes kyi sgrib pa'i gnyen po bar chad med lam dang*/ ye shes ni rnam par grol ba'i lam yin pas dri ma med pa zhes so/ / chos la zhes pa chos rnams kyi chos nyid de bzhin nyid ji lta ba bzhin du mthong ba'i spyan nam ye shes kyi mig yin pas so/ /

There now follows a description of how the path of seeing is attained in the instant after the supreme mundane level. Bodhisattvas who have attained the supreme mundane level then acquire the supramundane gnosis that is unsurpassable (for it is superior to that of the listeners and solitary realizers), devoid of the concepts of the three spheres, uncontaminated (being free of the defilements to be eliminated by the path of seeing), and free of the two kinds of grasping (for they have eliminated the duality of grasping to subject and object). As we read in the sūtras, “They acquire the eye of Dharma with regard to the nature of phenomena, free of dust, devoid of contaminants.” Because they have eliminated subject and object, it is free of dust. And because they are free of the factors that have to be eliminated by the path of seeing, it is devoid of contaminants. Or, alternatively, it is “free of dust” in terms of acceptance,[17] this being the unobstructed path, the antidote to defilement-related and cognitive obscurations; and it is “devoid of contaminants” in terms of gnosis, this being the path of perfect liberation. “With regard to the nature of phenomena” refers to the fact that it is the eye of gnosis or eye that sees suchness as it is, the true nature of phenomena.
de 'di'i gnas yongs gyur pa ste/ / sa ni dang po yin par 'dod/ / de 'di bskal pa dpag med kyis/ / shin tu rnam par dag par 'gyur/ /
This, their transformation, Is held to be the first level. Over a measureless kalpa They have become utterly pure. (XV, 29)

de ltar rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes skyes pa de byang sems 'di'i kun gzhi gnas yongs su gyur pa ste 'phags pa'i sa ni dang po yin par 'dod do/ / sa dang po de dus ci tsam zhig gis thob ce na/ de ltar gnas yongs su gyur pa sa dang po la gnas pa 'di ni mos spyod kyi sar bskal pa grangs med pa gcig tu byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa dpag tu med pa spyod pa nyid kyis 'phags pa'i sa thob nas phyin chad 'khor ba'i nyes pa gtan nas mi 'byung bas shin tu rnam par dag par 'gyur pa yin no/ /

This birth of nonconceptual gnosis, the transformation in these bodhisattvas of the ground of all, is held to be the first of the noble levels. How long does it take to attain this first level? Those who dwell in this state of transformation on the first level have practiced the boundless activities of the bodhisattvas on the level of earnest aspiration for one measureless kalpa and by doing so have attained the noble levels. From then on, they never have any of the faults of saṃsāra, and they have therefore become utterly pure.
sa thob pa de'i yon tan gyi khyad par ni/
Specific Qualities of Attaining the Bodhisattva Levels

chos kyi dbyings ni mnyam pa nyid/ / rab tu rtogs nas de yi tshe/ / rtag tu sems can thams cad la/ / bdag dang mtshungs pa'i sems 'thob ste/ / sems can rnams la bdag med dang / / sdug bsngal dang ni don bya dang / / lan la mi re 'di sems snyoms/ / rgyal sras gzhan dang 'dra ba yin/ /

Having gained perfect realization Of the expanse of reality, sameness, At that time they acquire the awareness That all beings are the same as themselves, all the time. (XV, 30) With regard to sentient beings, they are even-minded Concerning their lack of self, their suffering, their goal, And in not hoping for reward; With regard to other bodhisattvas, they are alike. (XV, 31)

chos kyi dbyings ni so so'i skye bo'i chos dang 'phags pa'i chos sogs chos thams cad la khyad med par mnyam pa nyid du gyur pa mngon sum du rab tu rtogs nas sa thob pa de'i tshe/ dus rtag tu sems can thams cad la bdag rang nyid dang khyad par cung zad med par mnyam pa'am mtshungs pa'i sems 'thob ste/ de'i phyir mnyam pa nyid rnam pa lnga rtogs pa ni/ sems can rnams la bdag med pa mnyam par rtogs pa dang / rmongs pa'i dbang gis sdug bsngal myang ba'i sems can thams cad kyi sdug bsngal spang byar mnyam pa dang ni/ sems can de dag gi las nyon gyi kun 'byung spang ba'i don bya bar mnyam pa dang / rang nyid lam la zhugs te 'gog bden thob pas rang la phan btags kyang lan la re ba med pa ltar sems can gzhan 'gog lam la bkod pas phan btags pa'ang rang don dang 'dra bar sems can des lan la mi re bar mnyam par rgyal ba'i sras 'di de ltar sems snyoms pa dang / 'phags pa'i sa thob pa'i rgyal sras gzhan dang spangs rtogs mnyam pa'am 'dra ba yin no/

The expanse of reality is the nature of ordinary beings and the nature of noble beings: it is the same in everything, and there is no difference between them. When one gains full, direct realization of this and attains the levels, one will acquire the awareness that one is oneself the same as or equal to all sentient beings, and not the slightest bit different from them, all the time. As a result, one realizes five aspects of sameness: (1) One realizes that one is the same as beings in being devoid of self. (2) One is the same in that the sufferings of all sentient beings, who are experiencing suffering on account of ignorance, have to be eliminated. (3) One is the same in the goal to be achieved, that is, the elimination of the origin of beings’ suffering, our karmic actions and defilements. (4) As a child of the buddhas, one is even-minded in the sense that just as one would not expect to be rewarded for benefiting oneself by following the path and attaining the truth of cessation, one has the same absence of expectation that other beings will reward one for benefiting them by bringing them to the path and cessation—that being, after all, one’s own goal. And (5) in one’s elimination and realization, one is similar or equal to other children of the buddhas who have attained the noble levels.
des ni khams gsum 'dus byas rnams/ / yang dag ma yin kun rtog par/ / ye shes shin tu rnam dag pa/ / gnyis su med pa'i don gyis mthong / /
All things compounded in the three worlds Are false imagination. This they see by dint of gnosis, Utterly pure and free of duality. (XV, 32)

de ltar gzhan don du 'jug pa'i tshul bshad nas shes rab kyis rtogs pa'i khyad par ni/ sa dang po thob pa'i byang chub sems dpa' des ni 'dod gzugs kyi phung po lnga dang gzugs med pa'i phung po bzhi la sogs pa khams gsum gyis chos 'dus byas rnams thams cad sems can rnams kyi rgyud kyi yang dag pa ma yin pa'i kun tu rtog pa sems dang sems las byung ba tsam du mthong ste/ sems sems byung las ma gtogs pa'i chos gang yod pa ma yin par sems tsam du/ rjes thob dag pa 'jig rten pa'i ye shes kyis mthong ste/ mdo sde sa bcu pa las/ kye rgyal ba'i sras po dag khams gsum po 'di dag ni sems tsam mo zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ / ye shes gang gis mthong zhe na/ rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes sgrib pa shin tu rnam par dag pa/ gzung 'dzin gnyis su med pa'i don gyis mthong ste/ mnyam bzhag rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyis bdag gzhan dang sems tsam du'ang mi dmigs te de ni nam mkha'i ngos ltar dag pa gzung 'dzin med pa yin kyang / de ltar rtogs pa'i don gyis zhes pa de'i rjes thob ye shes kyis/ sems tsam las chos gzhan med kyang sems de nyid chos rnam pa sna tshogs su snang ba rmi lam dang sgyu ma'i snang ba ltar mthong ba'o/ /

The above describes the manner in which bodhisattvas engage in benefiting others. As for their specific realization with wisdom, bodhisattvas who have attained the first level see that all the compounded phenomena of the three worlds—the five aggregates of the worlds of desire and form, the four aggregates of the formless world, and so on—are the false imagination in beings’ mind streams; they are simply the mind and mental factors. With the pure mundane gnosis of postmeditation they see that there are no phenomena apart from the mind and mental factors—they are merely the mind. As we read in the Sūtra of the Ten Levels: O bodhisattvas, these three worlds are merely the mind. With what kind of gnosis do they see this? They see it by dint of nonconceptual gnosis, perfectly pure and free of obscuration, and devoid of the duality of subject and object. The nonconceptual gnosis of meditation does not perceive self and others or even “mind-only”: it is as pure as space, with no subject or object. However, “by dint of” such realization, the gnosis of postmeditation, despite there being no phenomena other than just the mind, sees that same mind appearing as all kinds of different phenomena, like the appearances in a dream or in a magical illusion.
de dag med pa'i ngo bo nyid/ / mthong bas spang bya rnams las grol/ / des na de tshe mthong ba'i lam/ / thob pa zhes ni nges par brjod/ /
By seeing the nature of nonexistence, Bodhisattvas are freed from the obscurations to be eliminated. Consequently, at that time they are said To have attained the path of seeing. (XV, 33)
