yang phyi ma las snga ma dag dman dang snga ma las phyi ma dag mchog tu gnas pa'i phyir dman pa sngar brjod la mchog phyis brjod pa ni/ 'jig rten na sbyin pa gtong ba dag yod kyang sgo gsum gyi nyes spyod sdom pa de bas dkon phyir sbyin pa dman la tshul khrims mchog go / de bzhin du nyes spyod bsdoms kyang gzhan gyi gnod pa de bas bzod dka' ba dang / bzod du zin kyang dge chos rgyun du brtson pa de bas dka' ba dang / brtson pa ci rigs dang ldan kyang sems ting 'dzin gyis dul ba de bas dkon pa dang / sems bsam gzugs kyi ting 'dzin grub kyang bden don mthong ba'i shes rab de bas dka' zhing dkon la/ gang sla ba de nyon mongs che zhing / dka' ba de de la ltos nas nyon mongs chung zhing yon tan che ba'i phyir sbyin pa nas shes rab kyi bar du go rim de ltar rnam par bzhag pa yin no/ /

Next, because the earlier transcendent perfections are inferior compared to the ones that follow, and the later ones superior to those that precede them, the inferior ones are mentioned first and the superior ones last. There may be people in the world who generously give things away, but much more rare are those who avoid negative actions physically, verbally, and mentally. So in this respect, generosity is inferior, and discipline superior. Similarly, compared to avoiding negative actions, it is much harder to patiently put up with harm from others. And compared to being patient, it is more difficult to be constantly diligent in performing positive actions. However much diligence one may have, taming the mind with concentration is much more rare. And even if one accomplishes the mental concentrations of the world of form and of the formless world, it is much harder and rarer to have the wisdom that sees the truth. So because the earlier transcendent perfections are easier and are for those who have more defilements, and the later ones are comparatively more difficult and are for those who have fewer defilements and more good qualities, they are presented in that order, from generosity to wisdom.

yang rags pa dang ni phra ba'i phyir/ gang rags pa rnams dang por bstan cing phra ba rnams rjes su bstan pa ni/ rags pa rnams 'jug sla zhing spyad sla la phra ba rnams rags pa la ltos nas snga ma las bzlog pa ste/ sbyin pa la ni rgyal po dang blon po sogs nas bran dang gdol pa'i bar gyis kyang ci rigs 'jug nus pas shes sla zhing rags pa bya sla ba'o/ / de bas tshul khrims dang / de bas bzod pa nas shes rab kyi bar du je phra je phrar gyur pa'i phyir snga ma snga ma las phyi ma ngo bo nyid kyis phra ba'i sgo nas sbyin pa nas shes rab kyi bar du spyad sla zhing 'jug sla ba'i rags pa dang / de las ldog pa phra ba'i rnam bzhag gi sgo nas go rim de ltar bstan pa yin no/ /

Again, because they are respectively more gross and more subtle, the gross transcendent perfections are taught first and the more subtle ones afterward. The gross ones are easy to engage in and continue practicing, while the subtler ones are comparatively difficult. Generosity is something that anyone, from kings and ministers down to servants and outcastes, can engage in: it is easy to understand and is an obvious action that is easy to do. Compared to that, discipline, patience, and the rest through to wisdom are increasingly subtle, the later ones being by their very nature more subtle than the earlier ones. It is in these terms that they are presented in order from generosity, which is the most gross and the easiest to begin and continue practicing, to wisdom, which is the most subtle and the hardest to practice.
bzhi pa phar phyin drug gi so so'i nges tshig ni/
iv. THE ETYMOLOGICAL DEFINITIONS OF EACH OF THE SIX TRANSCENDENT PERFECTIONS
dbul ba 'dor bar byed pa dang / / bsil ba 'thob dang khro bzod dang / / mchog sbyor ba dang yid 'dzin dang / / don dam shes pa'i phyir bshad do/ /

One perfection banishes poverty, One obtains coolth, one puts an end to anger, One connects one to what is supreme, one keeps the mind focused, And one knows the ultimate—thus are they explained. (XVII, 15)
zhes pas bstan te/

ci'i phyir sbyin pa zhes bya ba ni/ dA na'i sgra las sbyin pa zhes bya ste/ dA dbul ba dang na 'dor ba'i don gyis/ dbul ba 'dor bar byed pa la sbyin pa zhes bya ste/ longs spyod sbyin pas len pa po tshe 'di'i dbul ba 'dor ba dang / gtong ba po tshe rabs gzhan du cis kyang mi phongs pa'i longs spyod thob pas dbul ba 'dor ba'i phyir ro/ /

Why is generosity so called? The Sanskrit term for generosity is dāna, dā meaning “poverty” and na meaning “to throw out,” so what we call generosity is that which banishes poverty. For the recipients, the gift of one’s possessions removes their poverty in this life. And for the givers, it removes poverty in their other lives, for they will lack for nothing and always be wealthy.

de bzhin du tshul khrims kyi skad dod shI la zhes pa'i shI bsil ba dang / la thob pa'am len pa'i don yin pas/ bsil ba thob ces pa/ tshul khrims dang ldan na tshe 'dir yul la chags pa'i rgyu las byung ba'i rgyal po'i chad pa sogs nyes pa sna tshogs kyi tsha gdung med pa dang / phyi ma ngan song du mi skye zhing lha mi'i bde ba dang / mthar myang 'das kyi bde ba'i bsil ba thob pa'i phyir ro/ /

Similarly, the Sanskrit equivalent of discipline is śīla, where śī signifies “coolth” and la means “to obtain” or “to receive”—hence, to obtain coolth. If one observes discipline, in this life one will not suffer the heat of the various misfortunes that result from attachment to sense objects—criminal punishment, for example—and in future lives one will avoid rebirth in the lower realms and obtain the coolth of happy rebirth as a god or human and ultimately of the bliss of nirvāṇa.
bzod pa la k+ShAn+ti zhes bya ste/ k+ShAna ni zad pa dang ti byed pa la 'jug pas/ rang rgyud kyi khro ba zad par byed pa la bzod pa zhes btags pa'o/ /
Patience is kṣānti in Sanskrit. Kṣān signifies “finished,” while ti has the sense of “making,” so what we call patience is that which puts an end to anger in one’s own mind stream.
dang gi tshig rnams sdud sgra yin pa go sla bas 'dir 'bru ma mnan te skabs gzhan du'ang de ltar shes par bya'o/ /
(The use of the conjunction “and” (dang) in this verse is self-evident, so here and in other sections I have not followed the root text to the letter.)[2]
brtson 'grus bIr+ya zhes pa bI ni mchog gam dam pa'i don dang / r+ya ni sbyor ba ste/ 'jig rten las 'das pa'i dge ba dam pa la sbyor bas na mchog sbyor zhes kyang bya'o/ /

Diligence is vīrya. Vi means “supreme” or “sublime,” and rya means “to connect”—it is what connects one to sublime, supramundane virtue, and thus diligence is also called “connector to what is supreme.”[3]
bsam gtan ni d+h+yAna zhes pa ya btags ra dang mtshungs par d+ha ra na zhes pa 'dzin pa'i don te ci zhig 'dzin na yid dmigs pa la nang du 'dzin cing phyir mi g.yeng bar byed pa bsam gtan no/ /

Concentration is dhyāna in Sanskrit, or dhārana, the subjoined ya being equivalent to a ra, and it means “to hold.” What it holds is the mind, holding it in on the object of meditation and not letting it be distracted outwardly.

shes rab ni pradz+nyA zhes pa'i sgra la pra ni nyer bsgyur gyi sgra ste rab kyi don la 'jug cing pa ram ar+tha zhes pa don dam pa zhes pa'i ming thog dra yig tu bsdus pa'i dbang du byas na/ pra ni don dam pa dz+nyA shes pa yin pas don dam shes pa'i phyir bshad do/ /

Wisdom is prajñā. Pra is a prefix meaning “superior” and is a contraction of the word paramārtha meaning “ultimate,” so in these terms prajña is explained as “that which knows (jñā) the ultimate (pra).”

'chad tshul 'di dag sgra'i khams kyi yi ge bsdu ba dang bsnan pa'i 'chad tshul thun mong min pa'i don gyi dbang du byas pa yin la/ legs sbyar gyi sgra de dag bod skad du thad sor ji ltar bsgyur ba sbyin pa la sogs pa yongs su grags pa de dag la'ang nges tshig 'chad tshul de lta bu thob pa shes par bya'o/ /

It should be noted that these explanations constitute a particular way of explaining the meanings of the Sanskrit terms by contracting or adding to the syllables in their linguistic elements. The translation of these Sanskrit terms into Tibetan was made directly into currently used Tibetan words such as sbyin pa (generosity), for which such a way of explaining the etymological definitions was also applied.[4]
lnga pa phar phyin rnams ji ltar bsgom par bya ba ni/
v. HOW THE TRANSCENDENT PERFECTIONS ARE PRACTICED
thams cad bsgom pa dngos po dang / / de bzhin yid la byed pa dang / / bsam pa dang ni thabs dag dang / / dbang 'byor nyid la brten par brjod/ /
For all of them the training is described As relying on the substance, And similarly on attentiveness, On one’s attitude, pure method, and mastery. (XVII, 16)
ces tshigs bcad gcig gis bstan te/
sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa ji ltar bsgom pa nas shes rab kyi bar du ji ltar bsgom par bya zhe na/ phar phyin drug po thams cad re re nas kyang bsgom pa'am goms par bya tshul ni/

How does one train in the transcendent perfections, from generosity through to wisdom? This verse describes five aspects of how to train in or accustom oneself to each and every one of the six transcendent perfections:

dngos po la gnas pa'am brten te bsgom pa dang / de bzhin du yid la byed pa brten te bsgom pa dang / bsam pa la brten te bsgom pa dang ni/ thabs dag pa brten te sgom pa dang / dbang 'byor ba nyid la brten te sgom par byed pa'i rnam grangs lngar brjod do/ / de gang zhe na/

(1) to train by relying on or abiding in the substance; similarly, (2) to train by relying on attentiveness; (3) to train by relying on one’s attitude; (4) to train by relying on pure skillful means; and (5) to train by relying on mastery. What are all these?

dngos po zhes bya ba don nam rdzas lta bu la yang ste/ sbyin pa la sogs pa'i phar phyin gyi dngos po la gnas te bsgom pa la rnam pa bzhi ste/ rgyu la gnas pa dang / rnam par smin pa la gnas pa dang / smon lam la gnas pa dang / so sor brtags pa'i stobs la gnas pa'o/ /

(1) “Substance” refers to the object or thing. Abiding in or training in the substance of a transcendent perfection such as generosity has four aspects: abiding in the cause, abiding in the fully ripened effect, abiding in aspiration, and abiding in the power of analysis.

dang po rgyu byang chub sems dpa'i rigs kyi stobs kyis gang du skyes kyang gzhan gyis byed du bcug pa min yang gtong ba sogs phar phyin drug sgrub cing sgom pa la dga' ste de la brten nas phar phyin gang yang rung ba bsgrub pa'o/ /

First, by the power of one’s bodhisattva potential, acting as a cause, wherever one is reborn, even if others do not induce one to do so, one takes pleasure in practicing and training in generosity and the other five transcendent perfections, and on that basis one will accomplish the relevant transcendent perfections.
gnyis pa sngon phar phyin bsgrub pa la goms pas tshe gzhan du de la ngang gis 'jug pa'i lus rten thob pa'o/ /
Second, as a result of habituation to practicing the transcendent perfections in previous lives, in subsequent lives one obtains a physical support that naturally engages in practicing them.
gsum pa gang du skyes kyang lus longs spyod la ma chags pa'i sbyin pa gtong bar gyur cig ces sogs phar phyin drug spyod par smon lam btab pa'i mthus phar phyin rnams sgrub par byed pa'o/ /

Third, the power of the prayers of aspiration one has made to continue practicing the six transcendent perfections—of the kind, “Wherever I am reborn, may I give generously without being attached to my body and possessions”—enables one to practice the transcendent perfections.
bzhi pa blo shes rab kyis so sor brtags te longs spyod ni mi brtan pa snying po med par shes nas sbyin pa la 'jug pa sogs phar phyin rnams kyi yon tan shes nas tshul bzhin bsgrub pa'o/ /

Fourth, after analyzing things with wisdom and recognizing that possessions are transitory and devoid of essence, one engages in generosity and so on. Thus, by recognizing the excellent qualities of this and the other transcendent perfections, one can practice them properly.
gnyis pa yid la byed pa la brten te bsgom pa la yid byed bzhi ste/
(2) For relying on and training in attentiveness, there are four kinds of attentiveness.
mos pa yid la byed pa phar phyin drug ston pa'i theg chen gyi mdo sde rnams las ji skad bstan pa ltar yid ches shing mos pas phar phyin gyi khams brtas par 'gyur ro/ /

Attentiveness related to interest: through confidence and interest in the six transcendent perfections as they are taught in the relevant Mahāyāna sūtras, the potential for transcendent perfection grows.
ro myong ba yid la byed pa ni bdag gis sngon sbyin pa sogs bsgrubs pa la de ltar byas pa legs so zhes yon tan du lta zhing sngon byas pa dran nas mngon par dga' ba'o/ /

Attentiveness related to savoring, which is to see the good qualities in one’s past practice of generosity and the other transcendent perfections, thinking of it as very good, and to feel very happy at the memory of one’s past deeds.
rjes su yi rang ba yid la byed pa ni/ phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams na sbyin sogs phar phyin bsgrubs pa rnams la rang gis bsgrubs pa dang 'dra bar dga' zhing rjes su yi rang ba'o/ /

Attentiveness related to rejoicing, which is to rejoice at all those in the universes of the ten directions who have practiced generosity and the other transcendent perfections, feeling as delighted as if one had done so oneself.
mngon par dga' ba yid la byed pa ni/ rang dang gzhan dag ma 'ongs pa na gang du skyes kyang phar phyin bsgrub par shog cig snyam du phar phyin bsgrub par dga' ba'o/ /

Attentiveness related to delight, which is to take pleasure in practicing the transcendent perfections, thinking, “In the future, wherever we are reborn, may I and others practice the transcendent perfections.”

gsum pa bsam pa la brten te bsgrub pa la rnam pa drug ste/ chog mi shes pa'am ngoms mi shes pa'i bsam pa/ rgya chen po'i bsam pa/ dga' ba'i bsam pa/ phan pa'i bsam pa/ ma gos pa'i bsam pa/ dge ba'i bsam pa'o/ /

(3) Relying on or accomplishing one’s attitude has six aspects: a never-satisfied or insatiable attitude, vast attitude, joyful attitude, attitude regarding help, untainted attitude, and virtuous attitude.
dang po ngoms mi shes pa la yang rnam pa bzhi yod pa sbyin pa la mtshon na/
The first, the insatiable attitude, again has four aspects, which we shall illustrate with the example of generosity:

dngos po gtong ba la chog mi shes pa ni sems can gcig la phan btags shing yongs su smin par bya ba'i phyir/ gang+gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed kyi 'jig rten gyi khams rin po che sna bdun gyis bkang nas sems can gcig pu de la gtong bar byas kyang bdag gis 'di la 'di snyed cig byin pas da ni chog go snyam pa'i bsam pa mi skyed pa'o/ /

Never having enough of material generosity. In order to benefit a single sentient being and bring them to full maturation, even if a bodhisattva were to give that single being as many worlds as there are grains of sand in the River Ganges, all filled with the seven kinds of jewels,[5] it would never occur to that bodhisattva to think, “I have given them so much, now that’s enough.”

lus gtong ba la chog mi shes pa ni/ dus skad cig ma re re la sems can gcig gi ched du rang gi lus gang+gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed cig btang yang lus 'di snyed cig byin pas da ni chog go snyam pa'i sems mi bskyed pa chog mi shes la blo sbyong bar byed pa'o/ /

Never having enough of giving away one’s body. Even though bodhisattvas might every instant, for the sake of a single being, give away as many of their own bodies as there are grains of sand in the River Ganges, they train their minds in never being satisfied—in never thinking, “Now I have given away this many bodies, that will do.”

dus chog mi shes pa ni/ lus dang longs spyod gtong ba de lta bu sems can gcig gi ched du bskal pa gang+gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed du skad cig yud tsam gcig tu yang rgyun mi 'chad par btang bar byas kyang / bdag gis phyi dang nang gi dngos po 'di snyed cig bskal pa 'di snyed cig tu btang bas da ni chog go snyam du mi sems par chog mi shes pa'i bsam pa bskyed pa'o/ /

Never being satisfied with the time. Even though bodhisattvas give away their bodies and possessions in this way for the sake of a single being for as many kalpas as there are grains of sand in the River Ganges without stopping for a single moment, they develop an insatiable attitude, never thinking, “I’ve given all these outer and inner gifts for so many kalpas, now that’s long enough.”

bzhi pa sems can chog mi shes pa ni/ de ltar sems can gcig gang+gA'i klung gi bye snyed kyi 'jig rten gyi khams rin po che sna bdun gyis bkang ba dang de snyed kyi lus/ bskal pa de snyed du btang ste sems can gcig po de bla med byang chub tu bkod de smin par byas pa de bzhin du/ sems can gnyis dang gsum nas sems can thams cad kyi mtha' la thug gi bar du de ltar bla med byang chub la bkod de brtags pa mthar bzung gi dbang du byas na thams cad sangs rgyas par byas kyang da ni chog go snyam du mi sems pa lta bu'i ngoms pa med pa'i bsam pa skye ba de tsam du blo sbyangs nas chog mi shes pa'i bsam pa bskyed pa'o/ /

Never having enough of beings. Giving one being, in this way, as many worlds as there are grains of sand in the River Ganges, all filled with the seven kinds of jewels, and as many bodies, for as many kalpas, and bringing that one being to maturity by establishing them in unsurpassable enlightenment; and similarly establishing a second being, and a third, and finally the very entirety of sentient beings in unsurpassable enlightenment, bodhisattvas train their minds up to the point of developing the insatiable attitude that even if, hypothetically, they were to bring all those beings to buddhahood, they would never think, “Now I’m satisfied,” and they thus develop an attitude of never being satisfied.
gnyis pa rgya chen po'i bsam pa ni de lta bu'i sbyin pa sogs skad cig gcig tsam du mi byed pa'i dus med par byang chub snying po la 'dug gi bar du rgyun mi 'chad par byed par 'dod pa'i bsam pa'o/ /

Second, the vast attitude is the attitude of wishing to practice generosity and so forth in that way continuously until one dwells in the heart of enlightenment, without a single moment when one is not doing so.

gsum pa dga' ba'i bsam pa ni de ltar sbyin sogs kyis bsdus pa'i sems can smin par byas pa de dag la 'di rnams bdag gis bla med byang chub thob pa'i grogs yin no zhes dga' ba'i bsam pa skye ba de lta bu'i phan btags yul gyi sems can de dag dga' ba skye ba min pa'i tshul gyis zhing sems can de dag la shin tu drin du brtsi zhing dga' ba'o/ /

Third, the joyful attitude consists in giving rise to the happy thought that the beings whom one has attracted with generosity and the other transcendent perfections and brought to maturity are helping one to attain unsurpassable enlightenment, and to rejoice and be extremely grateful to those beings whom one has thus benefited, without their necessarily delighting in it themselves.

bzhi pa phan pa'i bsam pa ni/ byang chub sems dpas phan btags pa de lta bu'i sems can la bdag gis phan btags so snyam du mi sems kyi/ phan btags yul sems can de rnams kyis bdag la phan btags so snyam du sems par byed de/ phan btags yul gyi sems can med na bdag gis bla med byang chub kyi tshogs rdzogs par mi 'gyur la/ de dag la phan btags pas bdag bla na med pa'i byang chub thob pa'i phyir des bdag la phan chen po btags so zhes sems pa'i phyir ro/ /

Fourth, the attitude regarding help. Bodhisattvas do not think, with regard to these beings they have benefited, “I have helped them.” Instead, they have the attitude, “These beings who are the object of benefit have helped me.” For they think, “If there were no beings to benefit, I would not complete the accumulations necessary for unsurpassable enlightenment. But by benefiting them, I will attain unsurpassable enlightenment, so they are helping me enormously.”

lnga pa ma gos pa'i bsam pa ni/ byang chub sems dpa' sbyin sogs kyis gzhan la de ltar phan btags kyang / de'i lan du re ba dang mtho ris kyi 'bras bu'i rnam smin la re ba med par sems can gyi don du de ltar spyod cing rang don la ma chags pa'o/ /

Fifth, the untainted attitude. Even if bodhisattvas benefit others with their generosity and so forth, they do not hope for anything in return or for rebirth in the higher realms as the fully ripened result. Rather, they perform such deeds for the sake of sentient beings, without being attached to their own welfare.

drug pa dge ba'i bsam pa ni/ byang chub sems dpas de ltar sbyin sogs rgya chen po byas pa de'i 'bras bu rang gcig pus myong bar mi 'dod kyi/ dge ba'i rtsa ba des sems can thams cad bla na med pa'i byang chub kyi 'bras bu thob par yongs su bsngo ba'o/ /

Sixth, the virtuous attitude. Bodhisattvas do not wish to taste the fruit of their extensive practice of generosity and the other transcendent perfections on their own. Rather, they dedicate their sources of good so that all sentient beings may attain the result, unsurpassable enlightenment.

sbyin pa'i bsam pa drug po de bzhin du tshul khrims nas shes rab kyi bar la sbyar ba ni/ gang stong gsum stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams mes rab tu gang ba/ me'i gnyen po chu la sogs pa bde bar byed pa'i yo byad thams cad kyis rtag tu phongs pa de lta bu'i gnas su/ bdag gi lus gcig gi sdug bsngal myong ba tsam min par lus gang+gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed dang mnyam pas/ dus bskal pa tshad yod brgya dang stong sogs bgrang rung min par bskal pa gang+gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed dang mnyam pa'i tshe'i tshad du/ spyod lam sna gcig gis ma yin gyi/ 'gro 'dug nyal 'chag gi spyod lam bzhi spyod pas skad cig ma gcig gi tshul khrims bsgrubs pa nas mthar bla med byang chub tu 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur pa'i tshul khrims kyi phung po yongs su rdzogs kyang / de tshul khrims kyi phung po rdzogs pas chog go snyam du mi bsam pa dang / shes rab la yang de dang tshul 'dra bar sbyar te chog mi shes pa dang / rgya che ba sogs gong dang thun mong du bshad pa bzhin no/ /

These six attitudes to generosity apply equally to the other transcendent perfections, from discipline through to wisdom. One might remain in the cosmos of a billion worlds completely filled with fire, forever deprived of anything that could bring relief (such as water to quench the fire), enduring not just the suffering of one of one’s bodies, but of bodies equal in number to the grains of sand in the River Ganges, and not for a period of a limited number of kalpas such as a hundred or a thousand but for lifetimes lasting as many kalpas as there are grains of sand in the River Ganges. And even though, throughout all this time, one were to practice discipline in one’s performance of not just a single kind of conduct but in every instant of the four kinds of conduct (moving around, lying down, sitting, and walking), and one were finally to complete the aggregate of discipline, achieving buddhahood in unsurpassable enlightenment, one would never think, “Now the aggregate of discipline is complete, that will do.” The same applies to wisdom: the above attitudes—the insatiable attitude, vast attitude, and so forth—are explained as being common to all the transcendent perfections.

bzhi pa thabs la brten te bsgom pa ni/ phar phyin rnams gang dang gang spyod kyang de dang de'i 'khor gsum du dmigs pa med pa'i cha nas thabs rnam pa gsum du bshad kyang don la rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyis yongs su zin pa ste 'dis yid la byed pa thams cad dang sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad 'grub cing dag par byed pa'i phyir thabs zhes bya'o/ /

(4) Relying on and training in skillful means. Although this is explained as three skillful methods in terms of freedom from the concepts of the three spheres in whichever of the transcendent perfections one is practicing, in fact it refers to their being imbued with nonconceptual gnosis. It is because this enables one to accomplish all the different factors that are kept in mind[6] and all the Buddha’s teachings, rendering them pure, that it is referred to as “skillful means.”

lnga pa dbang 'byor pa nyid la brten pa ni/ dag pa'i sa gsum du dbang thob pa'i dus na phar phyin rnams la rtsol med lhun gyis grub par spyod pa ste/ de la brten nas mthar thug sangs rgyas kyi sar sku gsung thugs phun sum tshogs pa brnyes nas sems can gyi don du phar phyin drug la lhun gyis grub par 'jug pa'o/ / de la sku dang / spyod pa dang / ston pa la dbang 'byor bar gsum gyi dang po chos sku dang longs sku gnyis/ gnyis pa sprul pa'i sku dang / gsum pa gsung gis chos ston pa la dbang 'byor pa'o/ /

(5) Relying on mastery. When bodhisattvas attain mastery on the three pure levels, the transcendent perfections are practiced spontaneously, without effort. By relying on such mastery, they ultimately obtain the perfect buddha body, buddha speech, and buddha mind on the level of buddhahood and spontaneously engage in the six transcendent perfections for the benefit of sentient beings. In this regard, there are three masteries, of body, activity, and teaching. The first refers to mastery of the body of truth and body of perfect enjoyment, the second to mastery of the manifestation body, and the third to mastery in verbally teaching the Dharma.
drug pa pha rol tu phyin pa drug gi dbye ba bstan pa ni/
vi. DETAILED CLASSIFICATIONS

phar phyin rnams la nang gi dbye ba dpag tu med pa yod mod kyi/ mdor bsdus te dbye ba byas na phar phyin re re la yang / rang bzhin la sogs pa rnam pa drug re drug re yod pas phar phyin re re yang tshigs bcad gnyis res bstan pa ni/

Although there are infinite classifications within the transcendent perfections, in brief, each of the transcendent perfections can be divided into six headings, beginning with their nature. These are indicated in the next twelve verses, with two verses for each transcendent perfection.

don rnams gtong bar byed pa dang / / rtsa ba sems pa la brten dang / / lus dang longs spyod phun tshogs dang / / gnyis rjes 'dzin dang rdzogs byed dang / / de yang ser sna med ldan par/ / chos dang zang zing mi 'jigs gtong / / sbyin pa de 'drar yongs shes nas/ / mkhas pa yang dag sgrub par byed/ /

It is the giving-away of gifts, Springs from reliance on a rooted attitude, Results in a perfect body and riches, Cares for both oneself and others, leads to completion, (XVII, 17) Is endowed with freedom from stinginess, And comprises the gifts of Dharma, of material gifts, and of freedom from fear: Knowing that such is generosity, The wise accomplish it perfectly. (XVII, 18)
ces pas bstan te/
dang po/ sbyin pa'i phar phyin gyi rab dbye la/ /
The subdivisions of transcendent generosity are as follows.

sbyin pa'i rang bzhin nam ngo bo ni yon tan gyi zhing dang / phan 'dogs pa'i zhing dang sdug bsngal can gyi zhing la phyi dang nang gi don nam dngos po rnams gtong bar byed pa'o/ / rgyu'am gnas ni ma chags pa sogs dge ba'i rtsa ba gsum sems la brten pa dang 'bras bu lus dang longs spyod phun sum tshogs pa thob pa dang / byed las gzhan la phan btags pa dang rang skye ba gzhan du longs spyod chen po thob pas rang gzhan gnyis ka rjes su 'dzin pa dang / zang zing dang chos kyi sbyin pas bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs rdzogs par byed pa dang / ldan pa ni sbyin pa de yang ser sna med pa dang tha mi dad du ldan par ni/ dbye ba gsung rab kyi tshig don ma nor bar 'chad pa chos kyi sbyin pa dang / phyi nang gi dngos po gtong ba zang zing gi sbyin pa dang / rgyal po dang rkun po me chu'i 'jigs pa sogs las bskyab pa mi 'jigs pa gtong ba'am sbyin pa ste rnam pa gsum mo/ / sbyin pa yi ngo bo dang rgyu la sogs pa de 'dra bar yongs su shes nas mkhas pa byang sems rnams kyis yang dag par sgrub par byed do/ /

The nature or essence of generosity is to give away outer and inner objects[7] or possessions to different fields—those with excellent qualities, those who help one, and those who are suffering.[8] Its cause or source is reliance on a mind that has the three roots of virtue—freedom from attachment, and so on.[9] The result is the attainment of a perfect body and possessions. Its function is to take care of both oneself and others, since through generosity one helps others and one obtains great riches for oneself in other lives, and material giving and giving Dharma enable one to complete the accumulations of merit and wisdom. The property of generosity is that it is endowed with and indistinguishable from the absence of stinginess. There are three categories of generosity: giving the Dharma by expounding the words and meanings of the Buddha’s teaching without mistake; material generosity in giving away outer and inner objects; and giving or bestowing freedom from fear by protecting beings from the fear of rulers, robbers, fire, water, and so forth. Having fully understood that such are the nature, cause, and other subdivisions of generosity, wise bodhisattvas practice it correctly.

yan lag drug zhi bsam pas zin/ / bde 'gro gnas pa sbyin byed dang / / rten dang zhi dang 'jigs pa med/ / bsod nams tshogs dang ldan pa dang / / brdar btags chos nyid thob pa ste/ / sdom la gnas pa rnams la yod/ / tshul khrims de 'drar yongs shes nas/ / mkhas pa yang dag sgrub par byed/ /

It has six branches, springs from one’s being imbued with the wish for ultimate peace, Bestows happy states and a stable mind, Supports, stills, and frees from fear, Brings about the accumulation of merit, (XVII, 19) Is symbolically designated or naturally acquired, And is present in those who keep vows: Knowing that such is discipline, The wise accomplish it perfectly. (XVII, 20)
ces pas bstan te/

gnyis pa/ tshul khrims kyi ngo bo ni yan lag drug dang ldan pa ste/ tshul khrims dang ldan par gnas pa/ chos phun sum tshogs pa/ spyod yul phun sum tshogs pa/ so sor thar pa'i sdom pas bsdams pa/ kha na ma tho ba phra rab tsam la yang 'jigs par lta ba/ bslab pa'i gzhi rnams yang dag par blangs te slob pa'o/ / de yang dang po tshul khrims yang dag par srung ba'o/ / gnyis pa chos gos sogs lung bzhin spyod pa dang ldan pas dam pas ma smad pa'o/ / gsum pa smad 'tshong dang shan pa chang 'tshong sogs spyod yul ma yin pa'i gnas lngar 'jug pa spangs pa'o/ / bzhi pa nges par 'byung ba'i tshul khrims kyi dbang du byas pa'o/ / lnga pa nyes pa phra mos kyang ma gos par byed pa'o/ / drug pa bslab bzhi mtha' dag la rdzogs par slob pa'o/ / rgyu ni zhi ba nges 'byung gi bsam pas zin pa'o/ / 'bras bu bde 'gro 'thob par byed pa dang / sems 'gyod pa med par mthong chos bde bar reg pa'i sgo nas sems gnas pa'i ting nge 'dzin 'grub pa sbyin par byed pa dang / byed las sa chen po lo tog thams cad kyi rten yin pa ltar dge ba'i chos kun gyi gzhi rten du gyur pa dang / nyon mongs pa'i gdung ba zhi bar byed pa dang / tshe 'dir kha na ma tho ba dang sha 'khon gnyer ba sogs kyi 'jigs pa dang / tshe rabs gzhan du ngan song gsum gyi 'jigs pa med pa dang gsum mo/ / ldan pa ni sgo gsum dge ba la gnas pa'i bsod nams kyi tshogs dang ldan pa dang / 'jug pa'am dbye ba ni gsol zhing zhu ba'i las kyis mkhan slob las so sor thar pa'i sdom pa nod pa ni brdar btags pa'i tshul khrims dang / bsam gtan dang zag med kyi sdom pa gnyis ni chos nyid kyis thob pa'i tshul khrims dag ste/ de lta bu rten gyi gang zag sdom pa la gnas pa rnams la yod kyi gzhan la ma yin no/ / tshul khrims de 'drar yongs shes nas/ / mkhas pa yang dag sgrub par byed/ /

The essence of discipline is to possess its six branches—namely, abiding by discipline, perfect observance, perfect environment, being bound by the prātimokṣa vows, regarding fearfully even the most subtle shameful deed, and correctly receiving and training in the precepts. The first of these is to observe discipline correctly. The second is to use the Dharma robes and so forth[10] according to the Vinaya texts and thus be beyond reproach by holy beings. The third is to avoid entering the five improper places—brothels, slaughterhouses, bars, and the like. The fourth is related to the discipline of certain deliverance.[11] The fifth is to not be tainted by even the slightest fault. The sixth is to train completely in all the precepts. The cause of discipline is to be imbued with the intention of certain release, that is, of nirvāṇa. The result is that one will attain the higher realms and, with a mind free of regret, one will be happy in this life, on account of which one will be granted a stable mind and accomplish concentration. Its functions are to act as the basis for all virtuous practices (in the same way that the earth supports all kinds of crops); to still the torments of the defilements; and to free one from the fear in this life of shameful deeds, of blood feuds, and so forth, and from the fear in other lives of the lower realms. The property of discipline is the possession of the accumulation of merit from practicing positive actions with the body, speech, and mind. As for its manifestations or categories, there is the symbolically designated discipline, which refers to receiving the prātimokṣa vows from a preceptor by requesting and receiving them, and the discipline that is acquired naturally, referring to the dhyāna vow and the untainted vow.[12] All these aspects of discipline are present in those individuals who observe the vows and not in others. Having fully understood that discipline is like this, the wise practice it correctly.

mi mjed ji mi snyam shes dang / / snying rjes chos la brten pa'i phyir/ / phan yon lngar ni yang dag bshad/ / de ni gnyis kyi don byed de/ / dka' thub gtso dang kun tu ldan/ / de la de ni rnam gsum 'dod/ / bzod pa de 'drar yongs shes nas/ / mkhas pa yang dag sgrub par byed/ /

It endures, ignores, and understands, Springs from compassion and dependence on the Dharma, Is described as having five benefits, Brings benefit to both oneself and others, (XVII, 21) Is fully endowed as the greatest of austerities, And is held to be of the above three kinds: Knowing that such is patience, The wise accomplish it perfectly. (XVII, 22)
ces pas bstan te/

gsum pa/ bzod pa'i ngo bo ni sems can gyi gnod pas mi mjed pa'i bzod pa dang / sdug bsngal la ji mi snyam pa'i bzod pa dang / chos zab mo'i don la mi skrag pa'i bzod pa gsum gyi rang bzhin du gyur pa'o/ / rgyu ni sems can la snying rje bas gnod pas mi mjed pa'am mi 'khrugs pa dang / tshul khrims la gnas pa dang thos pa'i chos la brten pa'i phyir bzod pa gzhan gnyis 'byung ngo / / 'bras bu phan yon lngar ni yang dag par bshad de/ 'thab rtsod med pas 'khon mi mang ba dang*/ mdza' bo mang bas dbyen mi mang ba dang / mthong chos la lus sems bde ba dang / dga' bzhin du 'chi ba'i dus byed pa dang / shi 'phos nas bde 'gror 'gro ba'i phan yon lnga'o/ / bzod pa de ni rang bde bar gnas pa dang gzhan la zug rngu mi 'byin pas rang dang gzhan gnyis kyi don byed de zhes pa byed las so/ / dka' thub kun gyi nang na gtso bor gyur pa'i yon tan dang kun du ldan pa ni don no/ / bzod pa de la sngar ngo bo'i skabs su bshad pa de ni dbye ba rnam pa gsum du 'dod do/ / bzod pa de 'drar yongs shes nas/ / mkhas pa yang dag sgrub par byed/ /

The essence of patience is threefold: forbearance in the face of harm done to one by sentient beings; the patience of thinking nothing of suffering; and the patience of not being scared by the meaning of the profound teachings. Its causes are compassion for sentient beings, so that one is tolerant of injury or unaffected by it; and the observance of discipline and listening to the teachings, in dependence on which the other two kinds of patience come about. Its result has been perfectly explained in terms of five benefits. Since one will have no disputes, one will not have many grudges. Because of having many friends, one will have few differences with people. In this life one will be physically well and mentally happy. One will die joyfully. And after death, one will go to the higher realms. These are its five benefits. Since patience keeps one happy and does not cause others any pain, it benefits both oneself and others—this is its function. It is fully endowed with the qualities of being the greatest of all austerities. Patience is held to be of three kinds, as already explained in the above description of its essence. Having fully understood that patience is like this, the wise practice it correctly.

dge la yang dag spro ba dang / / dad dang 'dun la brten pa dang / / dran sogs yon tan 'phel byed dang / / kun nas nyon mongs gnyen po dang / / ma chags la sogs yon tan ldan/ / de dag la ni de rnam bdun/ / brtson 'grus de 'drar yongs shes nas/ / mkhas pa yang dag sgrub par byed/ /

It is the true delight in virtue, Springs from interest and determination, Increases qualities such as mindfulness, Is the antidote to defilement, (XVII, 23) Is possessed of qualities such as the absence of attachment, And is of seven kinds: Knowing that such is diligence, The wise accomplish it perfectly. (XVII, 24)
ces pas bstan te/

bzhi pa/ brtson 'grus kyi ngo bo ni dge ba'i chos la yang dag par spro ba dang / rgyu dge chos la mos shing dad pa dang / de bsgrub par 'dun pa la brten pa dang / 'bras bu dran pa sogs yon tan thams cad gong nas gong du 'phel bar byed pa dang / byed las kun nas nyon mongs pa'i gnyen po byed pa dang / lnga pa ma chags pa la sogs pa dag pa'i yon tan kun dang ldan pa dang / brtson 'grus de dag la ni dbye ba de ni rnam pa bdun te/ yul gyis phye na bslab pa gsum la brtson pa'i sgo nas gsum/ ngo bos phye na lus dang sems kyi brtson 'grus gnyis/ sbyor bas phye na gus sbyor dang rtag sbyor gnyis te bdun nam/ yang rnam grangs kyi dbye sgo gzhan lhag pa'i tshul khrims kyi bslab pa lus kyi brtson 'grus la sgo lnga'i 'khor du skyes pa'i sems byung brtson 'grus lnga dang / lhag pa'i sems dang / lhag pa'i shes rab kyi bslab pa yid shes kyi 'khor du byung ba gnyis ni sems kyi brtson 'grus te rnam pa bdun du yang gsungs so/ / brtson 'grus de 'drar yongs shes nas/ / mkhas pa yang dag sgrub par byed/ /

The essence of diligence is a true enthusiasm for virtuous activities. Its cause is interest and confidence in virtuous ways, and it is based on a determination to accomplish the latter. Its result is to make all good qualities such as mindfulness grow greater and greater. Its function is to act as the antidote to defilement. Its property is that it has all the pure qualities such as absence of attachment and so forth. Such diligence has seven categories: three for its object—namely, the three trainings; two for its essence—diligence of body and mind; and two for its application—devoted application and constant application. Another classification also lists seven categories: five kinds of physical diligence in the training in superior discipline, these being mental factors arising in association with the five sense consciousnesses, and two kinds of mental diligence in the training in superior concentration and superior wisdom, which occur in association with the mind consciousness. Having fully understood that diligence is like this, the wise practice it correctly.

sems ni nang du gnas pa dang / / dran dang brtson 'grus la brten pa/ / bde ba skyed par byed pa dang / / mngon shes gnas la dbang bsgyur ba/ / chos rnams kyi ni gtso bo ste/ / de dag la yod de rnam gsum/ / bsam gtan de 'drar yongs shes nas/ / mkhas pa yang dag sgrub par byed/ /

It is the settling of the mind within, Springs from mindfulness and diligence, Gives rise to bliss, Brings mastery of preternatural powers and the ways of abiding, (XVII, 25) Is the foremost of all practices, And is threefold for those who have it: Knowing that such is concentration, The wise accomplish it perfectly. (XVII, 26)
ces pas bstan te/

lnga pa/ bsam gtan gyi ngo bo sems ni phyi rol gyi yul la mi g.yeng bar nang du rtse gcig gnas pa dang / rgyu ni dmigs pa ma brjed par dran pa dang / rgyun du sgom par byed pa'i brtson 'grus la brten pa dang*/ 'bras bu lus sems la shin tu sbyangs pa'i bde ba dang / 'dod pa'i khams kyi sdug bsngal bral ba'i khams gong ma gzugs khams su skye bas bde ba skyed par byed pa dang / byed las rdzu 'phrul sogs mngon par shes pa la dbang bsgyur ba dang / lha dang tshangs pa 'phags pa'i gnas pa la dbang bsgyur ba nyid byed do/ / lha'i gnas pa ni bsam gtan bzhi dang gzugs med pa'i snyoms 'jug bzhi'o/ / tshangs pa'i gnas pa ni tshad med pa bzhi'o/ /

The essence of concentration is that the mind rests inwardly focused and one-pointed, rather than being distracted toward objects outside. Its cause is unforgetting mindfulness of the object of meditation, and it depends on constant diligence in meditating. Its result is that it gives rise to the happiness of a trained, fit body and mind and to the bliss of rebirth in the world of form, a higher world free of the suffering of the world of desire. Its function is to lead to mastery of preternatural powers such as performing miracles, and to mastery over the ways of abiding of the beings in the celestial realms, the ways of abiding of those in the Brahmā realms, and the ways of abiding of the noble beings. The ways of abiding of the gods refer to the four dhyānas and to the four absorptions of the formless world. The ways of abiding of those in the Brahmā realms refer to the four boundless states.[13]

rnam thar sgo gsum la sogs pa 'phags pa'i gnas pa'o/ / ldan pa ni dkar po'i chos rnams kyi gtso bo yi yon tan dang ldan pa ste sems kyi dbang thob pa la brten nas yon tan khyad par can 'grub pa dang / rnam par grol ba dang rnam par grol ba'i ye shes kyi rten du gyur pa'i phyir ro/ / gzhi'i 'jug pa ni bsam gtan bsgom pa'i gang zag de dag la yod kyi gzhan la med cing de ni dbye ba rnam pa gsum ste/ gnyen po'i yan lag gis dbye na/ rtog dpyod gnyis bcas/ rtog med dpyod bcas/ rtog dpyod gnyis ka med pa gsum ste don gong du bshad pa bzhin no/ / yon tan gyi yan lag gis phye na/ bsam gtan gnyis pa man chad dga' ba dang ldan pa dang / gsum pa bde ba dang ldan pa/ bzhi pa yan chad btang snyoms dang ldan pa ste rnam pa gsum mo/ / bsam gtan de 'drar yongs shes nas/ / mkhas pa yang dag sgrub par byed/ /

The ways of abiding of the noble beings are the three doors of perfect liberation and so forth. The property of concentration is that it possesses the quality of being the foremost of all virtuous practices,[14] because it is in dependence on one’s mastering the mind that one accomplishes extraordinary qualities and becomes a suitable support for perfect liberation and the gnosis of perfect liberation. There are three categories, which are present in individuals who train in concentration and not present in other individuals. When classified in terms of the antidote branch, the three categories are concentration with both gross and subtle discursiveness, concentration without gross discursiveness and with subtle discursiveness, and concentration without either gross or subtle discursiveness, as has been explained above. If classified in terms of the qualities branch, the three categories are as follows: up to the second dhyāna, concentration endowed with joy; on the third, concentration endowed with bliss; and from the fourth onward, concentration endowed with evenness. Having fully understood that concentration is like this, the wise practice it correctly.

shes bya yang dag rab rnam 'byed/ / ting nge 'dzin la brten pa dang / / kun nas nyon mongs shin tu grol/ / shes rab 'tsho ba legs bshad dang / / chos rnams kyi ni mchog yin te/ / de dag la yod de rnam gsum/ / shes rab de 'drar yongs shes nas/ / mkhas pa yang dag sgrub par byed/ /

It correctly discerns knowable phenomena, Depends on concentration, Gives complete freedom from defilement, Provides sustenance through superior knowledge and perfect explanations, (XVII, 27) Is highest of all the teachings, And is threefold for those who have it: Knowing that such is wisdom, The wise accomplish it perfectly. (XVII, 28)
ces pas bstan te/

drug pa/ shes rab kyi ngo bo ji lta ji snyed kyi shes bya thams cad phyin ci ma log pas yang dag par rab tu rnam par 'byed pa'o/ / bden don mthong ba'i shes rab de lta bu'i rgyu ni ting nge 'dzin la brten pa dang / 'bras bu kun nas nyon mongs pa rnams las grol bar byed de 'jig rten pa'i shes rab kyis nyon mongs pa re zhig gzhil bar byed/ 'jig rten las 'das pa nyan rang gi shes rab kyis nyon mongs pa'i sgrib pa bag la nyal spong bar byed/ bdag med gnyis rtogs pa theg pa chen po'i shes rab kyis sgrib pa gnyis kyi bag la nyal spong bar byed do/ / byed las ni 'jig rten pa'i tshong dang zhing rmo sogs 'tsho tshis shes pa'i shes rab kyis srog gnas skabs su 'tsho ba tsam byed mod kyang / de las khyad par du 'phags pa/ zab cing rgya che ba'i chos kyi 'tsho bas / dge ba'i rtsa ba'i srog mi 'chad par mthar thug byang chub chen po rtag pa'i go 'phang 'grub pas shes rab kyi 'tsho ba dam pa dang gzhan la legs par bshad pas dge ba'i 'tsho ba sgrub par byed pa'i phyir ro/ / ldan pa ni chos rnams thams cad kyi snod mchog tu gyur pa shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i yon tan dang ldan pa yin te/ yum rnams las/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa ni pha rol tu phyin pa rnams kyi dam pa'o/ / gtso bo'o/ / khyad par can no/ / zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ / gzhi'i 'jug pa ni rten gyi gang zag shes rab can rnams la yod kyi gzhan la med pa'i khyad par dang / shes rab de la 'jug pa'i dbye ba ni/ skabs 'dir shes rab kyi gtso bo'i dbang du byas te 'jig rten pa'i shes rab chos mchog man chad dang 'jig rten 'das pa chung ngu nyan rang gi shes rab dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa chen po/ byang sems 'phags pa rnams kyi shes rab dang rnam pa gsum mo/ shes rab de 'drar yongs shes nas/ /mkhas pa yang dag sgrub par byed/ / ces so/ /

The essence of wisdom is to perfectly and unmistakenly discern all knowable phenomena, as they are and as many as there are. The cause of such wisdom that sees the truth is meditative concentration, on which it depends. Its result is that it leads to liberation from all defilement: mundane wisdom temporarily quenches defilements; the supramundane wisdom of the listeners and solitary realizers eliminates the latent obscurations related to the defilements; and the wisdom of the Great Vehicle, the realization of both kinds of no-self, eliminates the latent tendencies of both obscurations. As for its function, the mundane wisdom that knows how to make a living by commerce, agriculture, and so forth merely sustains life temporarily, but transcendent wisdom is far superior, for with the sustenance of the profound and extensive teachings, the very life of virtuous activities continues uninterrupted, and ultimately the eternal level of great enlightenment is accomplished. Thus it is with the sublime nourishment of wisdom and with excellent discourses to others that virtue is sustained. The property of wisdom is that it possesses the qualities of transcendent wisdom, the supreme vessel of all the teachings, as is stated in the Perfection of Wisdom: Transcendent wisdom is the sublime transcendent perfection, the foremost, the most outstanding. The categories of wisdom, which are specific to individuals who have wisdom but are not present in others, are three in number, classified in this context in terms of wisdom itself: the wisdom of mundane beings up to those on the supreme mundane level; the wisdom of lesser supramundane beings, that is, listeners and solitary realizers; and the wisdom of greater supramundane beings, that is, noble bodhisattvas. Having fully understood that wisdom is like this, the wise practice it correctly.
bdun pa dkar po'i chos thams cad pha rol tu phyin pa drug gi nang du bsdu ba ni/
vii. ALL POSITIVE PRACTICES ARE INCLUDED IN THE SIX TRANSCENDENT PERFECTIONS
dkar po'i chos kun rnam par g.yengs pa dang / / mnyam par bzhag dang gnyis kar shes par bya/ / pha rol phyin pa gnyis dang ni/ / gnyis dang gnyis kyis yongs su bsdus/ /
All virtuous practices are to be understood As distracted, meditational, or both. These three each include Two transcendent perfections. (XVII, 29)
zhes tshigs bcad gcig gis bstan te/

sa dang phar phyin byang phyogs dge bcu la sogs pa'i chos thams cad pha rol tu phyin pa drug gi nang du 'du ste/ ji ltar na dkar po'i chos kun ni mdor bsdu na mnyam par ma bzhag pa rnam par g.yeng ba yi gnas skabs kyis bsdus pa'i dge ba ji snyed pa dang / mnyam par bzhag pa'i sems kyis bsdus pa'i dge ba ji snyed pa dang / mnyam par bzhag pa yang yin la ma bzhag pa yang yin pas gnyis kar shes par bya ba bzod brtson lta bu ste cha gsum du 'du ba las/ mnyam par ma bzhag pa'i dge ba'am dkar po'i chos kun pha rol tu phyin pa sbyin pa dang tshul khrims te dang po gnyis kyis yongs su bsdus pa yin te/ sbyin pa yang lus kyi sgo nas yongs su gtong bas mnyam par ma bzhag pa'i ngo bo yin zhing / tshul khrims kyang / so thar dang / bsam gtan/ zag med kyi sdom pa gsum las/ so thar gyi lus ngag gi spong ba bdun ni mnyam par ma bzhag pa ste/ sems kyis bsdus pa min pas so/ / bsam gtan shes rab gnyis kyis mnyam par bzhag pa'i dkar chos rnams bsdus te/ bsam gtan ni dngos su mnyam par bzhag pa'i rang bzhin yin la/ de'i nang du bsam gtan dang zag med kyi sdom pa yang 'du'o/ shes rab la thos bsam gyi shes rab ni mnyam par ma bzhag pa'i nang du 'du la/ sgom pa'i shes rab ni mnyam bzhag tu 'du ste/ lhag mthong yin pas so/ / bzod pa brtson 'grus gnyis ni/ mnyam par ma bzhag pa'i sbyin pa dang tshul khrims la 'jug pa'i dus na yod pa mnyam par ma bzhag par gtogs la/ zhi lhag sgom pa'i dus na yang bzod brtson yod pa ni mnyam par bzhag par gtogs pa yin pas/ de gnyis kyis de dag yongs su bsdus pa'o/ /

The whole of the Dharma—the levels, transcendent perfections, elements leading to enlightenment, ten positive actions, and the rest—is included in the six transcendent perfections. In what way? All positive activities can be grouped into three aspects—namely, positive actions associated with circumstances in which one is distracted and not meditating; positive actions associated with the meditative mind; and those such as patience and diligence that are to be understood as being both, since they are both meditational and nonmeditational. Of these, nonmeditational positive actions or virtuous practices are included in the first two transcendent perfections, generosity and discipline. Generosity is essentially nonmeditational since it involves physically giving things away. As for discipline, it is nonmeditational in that, of the three kinds of vow—prātimokṣa, dhyāna, and untainted—it involves the prātimokṣa avoidance of the seven physical and verbal negative actions and is not mental. Concentration and wisdom are associated with meditational positive activities. Concentration is explicitly meditational. It includes the dhyāna vow and untainted vow. Wisdom is nonmeditational as regards the wisdom of listening and that of reflecting, and meditational as regards the wisdom of meditation, for it constitutes profound insight. Patience and diligence are classified as nonmeditational when one is practicing generosity and discipline, which are nonmeditational, and classified as meditational when one is practicing sustained calm and profound insight, so these are included in both.
brgyad pa phar phyin rnams kyi mi mthun phyogs spong ba ni/
viii. AVOIDING FACTORS THAT ARE INCOMPATIBLE WITH THE TRANSCENDENT PERFECTIONS
phyin drug re rer tshigs bcad re res bstan te/
This topic is covered by one verse for each of the six transcendent perfections.
byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa ni/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ / chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ /
In their generosity, bodhisattvas are Unattached, unattached, unattached, Quite without attachment, Unattached, unattached, and unattached.[15] (XVII, 30)
ces pas bstan te/

byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa ni/ mi mthun phyogs bdun dang bral ba ste/ gang zhe na longs spyod kyi dngos po la chags nas gtong mi phod pa ni mi mthun phyogs yin la/ de spangs pas longs spyod la ma chags pa'o/ / slong ba 'ong na de ma thag tu mi sbyin par dus brgyangs te phyi bshol byed pa spangs pas/ phyi bshol la mi chags pa dang / sbyin pa 'di tsam btang bas chog ce'am/ gang zag 'di tsam la sbyin zhes sam/ phyogs 'dir sbyin dus 'di tsam zhig sbyin zhes phyogs lhung ris chad lta bus chog 'dzin med par/ dngos po dang yul dus gang zag phyogs lhung med par byed pas chog par 'dzin pa la chags pa med pa dang / sbyin pa byin pa'i lan la re bas chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ sbyin pa byin pas ma 'ongs pa na longs spyod chen po'i rnam smin 'dod pa la ma chags pa dang / mi mthun phyogs ser sna dang chags pa'i bag nyal la mi chags pa ste/ ser snas bslad pa cung zad kyang med par gtong ba'o/ / yid byed dang rnam rtog gi rnam par g.yeng ba la chags pa med pa ni sbyin pa la sogs pa nyan rang gi byang chub tu bsngo ba'i yid byed dang / 'khor gsum du dmigs pa'i rnam par rtog pa spangs pa'o/ /

A bodhisattva’s generosity is free from seven opposing factors, as follows. Inability to give away one’s possessions on account of one’s attachment to them is an opposing factor, so bodhisattvas have given up such hesitation and are not attached to possessions. They have given up procrastination, that is, putting the time off and not giving immediately when a beggar arrives, and so they are not attached to postponement. They are never complacent, with biased, partial thoughts like “Giving just this much of a gift will do” or “I’ll give only to this many people” or “I will give in this area; I will give for just so long.” Rather, they act impartially with regard to the gift, the place, the duration, and the individual, and so they are free of attachment to any sense of satisfaction. They are also free of attachment in the form of hoping to receive something in return for their generosity. They are not attached to any wish that their acts of generosity will ripen as great wealth in the future. They are not attached to any latent tendency to the opposing factors of stinginess and attachment, and they give without being in the slightest way tainted by miserliness. They have no attachment to distracting forms of attentiveness and concepts, for they have eliminated attentiveness related to dedicating their generosity and other deeds to the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ enlightenment, and they are rid of the concepts of the three spheres.
de bzhin du/
Similarly,
byang chub sems dpa'i tshul khrims ni/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ / chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ /
In their discipline, bodhisattvas are Unattached, unattached, unattached, Quite without attachment, Unattached, unattached, and unattached. (XVII, 31)

ces 'chal tshul la ma chags/ phyi bshol la mi chags/ phyogs re'i chog 'dzin la chags pa med/ tshul khrims kyis gzhan gnod ma byas pa sogs kyi lan du re ba la chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ zag bcas kyi rnam smin la ma chags/ nyon mongs pa'i bag nyal la mi chags/ dman lam yid byed dang 'khor gsum dngos zhen gyi rnam rtog la chags pa med pa'o/ /

bodhisattvas, in their discipline, are not attached to lax ways, are not attached to postponement, and are free of attachment to a biased sense of satisfaction. Neither are they attached to hoping for a reward in return for their discipline of not harming others and so on. They are not attached to any tainted ripened effect, are not attached to latent defilements, and are free of attachment to keeping lower paths in mind and to concepts of the three spheres as having any substantial reality.
byang chub sems dpa'i bzod pa ni/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ / chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ /
In their patience, bodhisattvas are Unattached, unattached, unattached, Quite without attachment, Unattached, unattached, and unattached. (XVII, 32)
ces pas bstan te/

zhe sdang gis rgyud 'khrug nas gzhan la gnod pa byed pa la ma chags pa dang / de ma thag tu bzod par mi byed par phyi bshol la mi chags pa dang / bzod pa nyi tshe ba cung zad tsam gyis chog par 'dzin pa la chags pa med pa dang / 'di la bzod par byas na tshur rang la lan du phan 'dogs pa la chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ bzod pa bsgoms na ma 'ongs par gzugs byad bzang zhing 'khor mang por 'gyur ro snyam du rnam smin la ma chags pa dang / mi mthun phyogs zhe sdang gi bag nyal la mi chags pa dang / yid byed dang rnam rtog gi g.yeng ba la chags pa med pa'o/ /

Bodhisattvas, in their patience, have no attachment to states of mind disturbed by hatred and thus to harming others. They are not attached to postponement, that is, to not acting patiently right away. And they are free of attachment to being content with just a little, limited patience. Neither are they attached to receiving help themselves in return for their patience with someone. They do not think, “If I train in patience, in future lives I will have a beautiful face and physique and numerous attendants” but are unattached to the fully ripened effect of their patience. They are not attached to any latent tendency to hatred, which is the opposite of patience. And they are without attachment to distracting forms of attentiveness and concepts.
byang chub sems dpa'i brtson 'grus ni/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ / chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ /
In their diligence, bodhisattvas are Unattached, unattached, unattached, Quite without attachment, Unattached, unattached, and unattached. (XVII, 33)
ces pas bstan te/

mi mthun phyogs le lo mngon gyur la ma chags pa dang / dge phyogs la myur du mi 'jug par phyi bshol la mi chags pa dang / brtson 'grus nyi tshe bas chog par 'dzin pa la chags pa med pa dang / gzhan don la brtson pas des bdag la phan 'dogs pa'i lan la chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ ma 'ongs par las kyi mtha' rnams 'grub pa sogs rnam smin la ma chags pa dang / mi mthun phyogs le lo'i bag nyal la mi chags pa dang / dman lam yid byed dang 'khor gsum rnam par rtog pa la chags pa med pa'o/ /

Bodhisattvas, in their diligence, are not attached to the opposing factor of manifest laziness. They are not attached to postponement, on account of which they would not engage rapidly in virtuous activities. They are not attached to being content with making limited efforts. Neither are they attached to being benefited in return for their efforts in helping others. They are not attached to the ripened effect—the fact that in the future they will be able to complete everything they undertake, and so on. They are not attached to a latent tendency to laziness, the opposite of diligence. And they are free from attachment to keeping lower paths in mind and to the concepts of the three spheres.
byang chub sems dpa'i bsam gtan ni/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ / chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ /
In their concentration, bodhisattvas are Unattached, unattached, unattached, Quite without attachment, Unattached, unattached, and unattached. (XVII, 34)
ces pas bstan te/

mi mthun phyogs rnam g.yeng mngon gyur la ma chags pa dang / nam zhig bsgom snyam du phyi bshol la mi chags pa dang / bsam gtan nyi tshe ba tsam gyis chog 'dzin la chags pa med pa dang / bsam gtan gyis gzhan la phan btags pa'i lan la chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ lus la nad med pa dang khams gong mar skye ba'i rnam smin la ma chags pa dang / mi mthun phyogs rnam g.yeng gi bag nyal la mi chags pa dang / dman lam yid byed dang 'khor gsum du rtog pa'i g.yeng ba la chags pa med pa'o/ /

In their concentration, bodhisattvas are not attached to the opposing factor of manifest distraction. They are not attached to postponement, thinking, “One day I’ll meditate.” They are not attached to being content with just a limited concentration. Neither are they attached to receiving anything in return for helping others through their powers of concentration. They are not attached to the ripened effect—freedom from physical ailments and rebirth in the higher worlds.[16] They have no attachment to any latent tendency to distraction, which opposes concentration. And they are free from attachment to keeping lower paths in mind and to the concepts of the three spheres.
byang chub sems dpa'i shes rab ni/ / ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ / chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ ma chags mi chags chags pa med/ /
In their wisdom, bodhisattvas are Unattached, unattached, unattached, Quite without attachment, Unattached, unattached, and unattached. (XVII, 35)
ces pas bstan te/

rtag chad kyi lta ba sogs shes rab 'chal pa mngon gyur la ma chags pa dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen bkur stis bsten pa dang thos bsam sogs la phyi bshol byed pa la mi chags pa dang / shes rab cung zad tsam gyis chog par 'dzin pa la chags pa med pa dang / bdag gis chos bshad pa na gzhan gyis bdag la phan 'dogs su re bas lan la chags pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ de ltar shes rab sbyangs na ma 'ongs pa na mkhas par 'gyur snyam du rnam smin la ma chags pa dang / 'chal ba'i shes rab kyi bag la nyal la mi chags pa dang / dman pa'i myang 'das su bsngo ba dang 'khor gsum dngos zhen gyi rnam rtog gi g.yeng ba la chags pa med pa'o/ /

In their wisdom, bodhisattvas are not attached to manifestly aberrant understanding such as eternalistic or nihilistic views. They are not attached to postponing such activities as serving a spiritual teacher and listening and reflecting. They are not attached to being content with just limited understanding. Neither are they attached to any reward, with the expectation that when they explain the teachings, others will help them. They have no attachment to the ripened effect, thinking, “If I train in wisdom, in the future I will become very learned.” They have no attachment to any latent tendency to aberrant understanding. And they are free from attachment to the distractions of dedication to the nirvāṇa of lower paths and of concepts of the three spheres as having substantial reality.
dgu pa
ix. THE EXCELLENT QUALITIES OF THE SIX TRANSCENDENT PERFECTIONS

pha rol tu phyin pa rnams kyi yon tan bstan pa sangs rgyas sras rnams slong dang 'phrad na sogs tshigs bcad nyer gsum gyis bstan pa las/ dang po phar phyin drug po re re yang rgya che ba dang zang zing med pa dang don che ba dang / mi zad pa'i yon tan bzhi dang ldan par bstan pa ni/

Of the twenty-three verses that describe the qualities of the six transcendent perfections, the first ones show how each of the six transcendent perfections is endowed with four qualities: vastness, disinterestedness, immense benefit, and inexhaustibility.

sangs rgyas sras rnams slong dang 'phrad na rang gi srog kyang rtag tu gtong / / snying rjes gzhan las lan kyang mi re 'dod pa'i 'bras bu don mi gnyer/ / sbyin pa de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod/ / sbyin pa ye shes kyis yongs zin pas 'jig rten dag na mi zad bzhag /

The buddhas’ children, when meeting those in need, will always give them something, even their own lives. They do so out of compassion, with no hope of reward from others, and no interest in any desired result. With that same generosity, they bring all beings to the three levels of enlightenment. Since their generosity is imbued with gnosis, it remains unspent throughout all worlds. (XVII, 36)
zhes pas bstan te/

sangs rgyas kyi sras byang chub sems dpa' rnams slong ba po dang 'phrad na rang gi srog kyang gtong na dngos po gzhan lta ci smos so/ / gtong ba de yang dus res 'ga' ba ma yin par 'khor ba'i mtha'i bar du rtag tu gtong ba ni sbyin pa che ba'i yon tan no/ / snying rjes kun nas bslang ste gzhan la phan 'dod kho nas sbyin pa yin pas/ gzhan las phan btags pa de'i lan kyang mi re la phyi mar sbyin pa de'i rnam smin yid 'ong 'dod pa'i 'bras bu'ang don du mi gnyer ba ni zang zing med pa'o/ / sbyin pa de nyid kyis bsdus nas kyang skye bo thams cad rang rang mos pa'i byang chub gsum la bkod pa ni don che ba'o/ / sbyin pa de nyid 'khor gsum mi dmigs pa'i ye shes kyis yongs su zin pas 'jig rten pa ltar 'khor ba'i 'bras bu smin nas zad pa dang / nyan rang ltar myang 'das thob nas zad pa min par/ 'khor 'das kyi mtha' la mi gnas pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa chen po thob ste/ 'jig rten dag na phyi ma'i mtha'i bar du mi zad par bzhag pa ni mi zad pa'i yon tan no/ /

When they meet someone in need, bodhisattvas, the buddhas’ children, will even give their own lives, not to mention other things. And they do so not just once in a while but all the time, until the very end of saṃsāra. This is the vastness of their generosity. Motivated by compassion, they give only out of a desire to help others: they do not expect to receive anything in return for benefiting others and are not after a desired result in their future lives, the pleasant ripened effect of their generosity—they are quite disinterested. Having attracted beings with such generosity, they bring them all to whichever of the three kinds of enlightenment they aspire to—this is the immense benefit of their generosity. That very generosity is imbued with the gnosis free from the concepts of the three spheres, and so, unlike the generosity of mundane beings, which is spent once its result has ripened in saṃsāra, and unlike that of listeners and solitary realizers, which comes to an end once they have attained nirvāṇa, it leads to the attainment of the great nirvāṇa that does not dwell in the extremes of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa, and remains unspent in all worlds until the end of time. This is the quality of its inexhaustibility.

sangs rgyas sras rnams sdom dang brtson pa'i rang bzhin tshul khrims gsum rtag blangs/ / mtho ris mngon par mi 'dod yang dag thob kyang de la chags mi skyed/ / tshul khrims de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod/ / tshul khrims ye shes kyis yongs zin pas 'jig rten dag na mi zad bzhag /

The buddhas’ children constantly undertake the three kinds of discipline whose nature is restraint and diligence. They do not crave the higher realms and, even if they actually attain them, are not attached to such states. With that discipline, they bring all beings to the three levels of enlightenment. Since their discipline is imbued with gnosis, it remains unspent throughout all worlds. (XVII, 37)

sangs rgyas sras rnams nyes spyod sdom pa dang / dge chos sdud pa dang / gzhan don la brtson pa'i rang bzhin can gyi tshul khrims gsum po ma tshang ba med pa dus rtag pa ste byang chub chen po thob pa'i bar du yang dag par blangs pa ni nyan thos sogs la med pa'i rgya che ba'i yon tan no/ / tshul khrims de'i 'bras bu mtho ris mngon par mi 'dod la mtho ris yang dag par thob kyang de'i bde ba la chags pa mi skyed pa zang zing med pa'i yon tan no/ / tshul khrims de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod pa ni don che ba'i yon tan no/ / tshul khrims de rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyis yongs su zin pas 'jig rten dag na nam yang mi zad pa'i gter du bzhag pa mi zad pa'i yon tan no/ /

Bodhisattvas constantly, until they attain the great enlightenment, undertake all three forms of discipline correctly—that is, they refrain from negative actions and are diligent in undertaking positive actions and benefiting others. This is the vast quality of their discipline, which is lacking in listeners and the like. They do not crave higher rebirth, which is the result of that discipline, and even if they gain a perfect rebirth in the higher realms, they do not develop attachment to the happiness there. This is the quality of disinterestedness. By means of that discipline, they bring all beings to the three kinds of enlightenment, which is the quality of its immense benefit. And since their discipline is imbued with nonconceptual gnosis, it remains in all worlds as a never-depleted treasure, which is the quality of its inexhaustibility.

sangs rgyas sras rnams shin tu bya dka' de bzhin mi yi gnod kun bzod/ / mtho ris gnyer dang mi nus pas min 'jigs pas ma yin phan ltas min/ / bzod pa bla na med pas skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod/ / bzod pa ye shes kyis yongs zin pas 'jig rten dag na mi zad bzhag /

The buddhas’ children endure the most arduous tasks and all the harm that people do to them. This is not because they seek the higher realms or are powerless, nor out of fear, nor with an eye for their own benefit. With their unexcelled patience, they bring all beings to the three levels of enlightenment. Since their patience is imbued with gnosis, it remains unspent throughout all worlds. (XVII, 38)

rgyal ba'i sras rnams shin tu bya dka' ba sems can thams cad smin par bya ba dang bdag nyid kyis sangs rgyas kyi chos rdzogs par bya ba'i phyir yun ring por 'khor bar skye ba bsam bzhin 'dzin cing tsha grang bkres skom la sogs pa'i sdug bsngal la ci mi snyam pa dang / de bzhin mi yi gnod pa kun bzod pas rgya che ba'o/ / bzod pa bsgom pa de yang rang gis mtho ris kyi bde ba don du gnyer ba min la/ mngon par shes pa'i mthu dang ldan pas pha rol la gnod lan byed ma nus pas min zhing sems can de la 'jigs pas bzod pa ma yin te 'jigs pa lnga dang bral bas so/ / tshur rang la phan par lta bas ma yin pas zang zing med pa'o/ / bzod pa bla na med pas skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod pa ni don che ba'o/ / bzod pa ye shes kyis yongs su zin pas 'jig rten dag na mi zad par bzhag pa mi zad pa'i yon tan no/ /

Bodhisattvas, in order to carry out the extremely arduous tasks of bringing sentient beings to maturity and completing the Buddha’s path themselves, intentionally take birth in saṃsāra for long periods of time, thinking nothing of the sufferings they undergo—heat and cold, hunger and thirst, and so on—and similarly putting up with all the harm that people do to them. Hence the vastness of their patience. Their practice of patience is not aimed at their achieving happiness for themselves in the higher realms. Nor is it that they are incapable of retaliating when others wrong them, for they possess preternatural powers. Nor do they act patiently because they are afraid of those beings, for they are free of the five kinds of fear.[17] Nor are they patient because they are seeking to benefit themselves. So in all these respects their patience is disinterested. On account of their unexcelled patience, they bring all beings to the three kinds of enlightenment, so it is immensely beneficial. And since their patience is imbued with nonconceptual gnosis, it remains in all worlds unspent, which is the quality of its inexhaustibility.

rgyal ba'i sras rnams go cha sbyor ba'i bdag nyid brtson 'grus dpe med byas/ / rang dang gzhan gyi nyon mongs tshogs bcom byang chub dam pa 'thob par byed/ / brtson 'grus de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod/ / brtson 'grus ye shes kyis yongs zin pas 'jig rten dag na mi zad bzhag /

The buddhas’ children do things with incomparable diligence, armor-like and applied, Destroying their own and others’ defilements and causing them to attain supreme enlightenment. Through that very diligence, they bring all beings to the three levels of enlightenment. Since their diligence is imbued with gnosis, it remains unspent throughout all worlds. (XVII, 39)

rgyal ba'i sras rnams bsam pa go cha dang rjes su bsgrub pa'i sbyor ba'i bdag nyid kyi brtson 'grus ni nyon mongs pa dang ma 'dres pas 'jig rten pa'i brtson 'grus las 'phags shing / bdag med gnyis rtogs pa dang rang gzhan don gnyis sgrub pas nyan rang gi brtson 'grus las 'phags shing / phyogs dang dus kyi tshad dpag par dka' ba'i brtson 'grus yin pas dpe med pa brtsams par byas pa ni rgya che ba'o/ / des rang dang gzhan gyi nyon mongs pa'i tshogs bcom par byas nas byang chub dam pa 'thob par byed pa zang zing med pa'o/ / brtson 'grus de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod pa ni don che ba'i yon tan no/ / brtson 'grus ye shes kyis yongs zin pas 'jig rten dag na mi zad par bzhag pa mi zad pa'i yon tan no/ /

Bodhisattvas set about things with unparalleled diligence—diligence both in its armor-like intention and in the application of its subsequent accomplishment.[18] Unadulterated by defilements, it is superior to ordinary people’s diligence. On account of bodhisattvas’ having realized the two kinds of no-self and accomplished both their own and others’ goals, it is superior to the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ diligence. And it is hard to gauge in terms of space and time—hence its vastness. It is disinterested in its destroying all one’s own and others’ defilements and enabling everyone to attain supreme enlightenment. Such diligence also brings all beings to the three kinds of enlightenment, this being the quality of its immense benefit. And because bodhisattvas’ diligence is imbued with nonconceptual gnosis, it remains in all worlds unspent, which is the quality of its inexhaustibility.

rgyal ba'i sras rnams ting 'dzin mang ldan bsam gtan rnam pa thams cad sgrub/ / bsam gtan bde ba phul gyis gnas shing snying rjes skye ba dman la brten/ / bsam gtan de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod/ / bsam gtan ye shes kyis yongs zin pas 'jig rten dag na mi zad bzhag /

The buddhas’ children, endowed with concentration, have accomplished all kinds of concentrative states. They who have attained the highest bliss of concentration compassionately take lower births. Through that very concentration, they bring all beings to the three levels of enlightenment. Since their concentration is imbued with gnosis, it remains unspent throughout all worlds. (XVII, 40)

rgyal ba'i sras rnams dpa' bar 'gro ba la sogs pa'i ting nge 'dzin rnam pa shin tu mang po dang ldan zhing bsam gtan bzhi sogs dang rnam thar zad par zil gnon sogs kyi rnam pa thams cad sgrub pa ni rgya che ba'o/ / bsam gtan gyi bde ba phul du byung ba can gyis gnas shing de yi ro mi myong bar snying rjes skye ba dman pa 'dod pa'i khams su skye ba la brten pa ni zang zing med pa'o/ / bsam gtan de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod pa don che ba'o/ / bsam gtan ye shes kyis yongs su zin pas 'jig rten dag na mi zad par bzhag pa mi zad pa'i yon tan no/ /

Bodhisattvas have a great many different kinds of concentration, such as the concentration of Brave Progression, and are omnifariously accomplished—in the four dhyānas and so on, in perfect freedom, in the powers of perceptual limitlessness, the different kinds of perceptual domination, and so forth—hence the vastness of their concentration. They who possess the highest degree of bliss in concentration sustain it and, rather than savoring that bliss, compassionately take lower births, being reborn in the world of desire[19]—hence their disinterestedness. By means of such concentration, they bring all beings to the three kinds of enlightenment, so it is immensely beneficial. And since their concentration is imbued with nonconceptual gnosis, it remains in all worlds unspent, which is the quality of its inexhaustibility.

rgyal ba'i sras rnams de nyid shes bya gang yin mtha' dag rnam kun shes/ / mya ngan 'das la'ang blo yis chags rab mi skyed 'khor bar smos ci dgos/ / ye shes de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod/ / ye shes sems can yongs su bzung bas 'jig rten dag na mi zad bzhag /

The buddhas’ children have complete knowledge of everything there is to know and of its nature. They feel no attachment to nirvāṇa, not to mention to saṃsāra. With that very gnosis they bring all beings to the three levels of enlightenment. Since their gnosis envelops all beings, it remains unspent throughout all worlds. (XVII, 41)

rgyal ba'i sras rnams de kho na nyid ji lta ba dang / shes bya gang yin pa ji snyed pa mtha' dag rnam pa kun tu shes pa rgya che ba'i yon tan no/ / mya ngan las 'das pa la'ang blo yi chags pa rab tu mi skyed na 'khor bar smos ci dgos te 'khor 'das kyi snang ba thams cad kun rdzob sgyu ma lta bu dang / don dam mnyam pa nyid du rtogs pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di ni zang zing med pa'i yon tan no/ / ye shes de nyid kyis kyang skye bo thams cad byang chub gsum la bkod par byed pa ni don che ba'i yon tan no/ / ye shes de srid zhi'i mtha' la mi gnas pa yin pas ngo bo nyid kyis snying rje chen po dang 'du 'bral med par gyur pa'i phyir sems can yongs su bzung bas 'jig rten dag na nam yang mi zad pa nyid du bzhag pa ni nam yang rgyun mi 'chad cing khyab pas mi zad pa'i yon tan no/ /

Bodhisattvas have complete knowledge of everything—in its nature (thatness) and in its multiplicity (everything there is to know). This is the vast quality of their wisdom. In their minds, they feel no attachment at all to nirvāṇa, let alone to saṃsāra, for they have realized that all the appearances of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa, in relative truth, are like magical illusions and, in ultimate truth, are evenness. This is its disinterested quality. By means of such gnosis they bring all beings to the three kinds of enlightenment, this being the quality of its immense benefit. Because that gnosis does not dwell in the extremes of existence and peace, it is naturally inseparable from compassion, and therefore, since it envelops all beings, it remains in all worlds without ever being spent. This is the quality of its inexhaustibility, for it is unchanging and all-pervading.
rgya che ba dang zang zing med/ / don che ba dang mi zad pa/ / sbyin la sogs pa thams cad kyi/ / yon tan bzhir ni shes par bya/ /
Vast, disinterested, Immensely beneficial, and inexhaustible— Such are the four qualities that should be known Of all the perfections such as generosity. (XVII, 42)

de ltar rgya che ba dang zang zing med pa dang / don che ba dang / mi zad pa ste/ sbyin pa la sogs pa thams cad kyi yon tan bzhir ni shes par bya'o/ / slar yang phar phyin drug gi yon tan rnam par dag pas khyad par du 'phags tshul dang / mchog tu gyur pa'i tshul bstan pa dang / sbyin pa'i bsngags pas mtshon nas bstan pa dang / brtson 'grus kyi yon tan bye brag tu bshad pa bzhi las/

Thus, vastness, disinterestedness, immense benefit, and inexhaustibility are to be understood as the four excellent qualities of all the transcendent perfections, beginning with generosity. Furthermore, the excellent qualities of the six transcendent perfections are described from four points of view: their superiority on account of their purity; their supremacy; their qualities exemplified by a praise of generosity; and a specific explanation of the qualities of diligence.
dang po [khyad par du 'phags tshul]/
First, the Superiority of the Six Transcendent Perfections on Account of Their Purity
Of these four, the first is indicated in the next nine verses.
dang po sbyin pa'i bsngags pa ni/
Perfectly Pure Generosity
slong ba mthong rdzogs dga' ba dang / / mi dga' ba dang smon pa dang / / sbyin pa po ni brtser ldan pas/ / lhag par ldan pas rtag zil gnon/ /
In seeing and being fulfilled, beggars Are delighted, sad, and full of hope. But even more so are the loving ones who give, So they will always outshine those who beg. (XVII, 43)
ces pa'i bar gyis bstan te/

slong ba po des gtong ba po mthong na dga' ba dang / mthong nas rang gis 'dod pa bzhin sbyin pa rdzogs par byas pa'i gnas skabs na dga' ba dang / gtong ba po ma mthong ba dang sbyin pa ma rdzogs pa'i gnas skabs su mi dga' ba dang / gtong ldan mthong ba dang des rang la sbyin pa bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par byed pa la rtag tu yid kyis smon pa de lta bu yang / sbyin pa po byang chub sems dpa' sems can rnams la brtse bar ldan pas ni/ slong ba po mthong zhing sbyin pa rdzogs na dga' ba dang de gnyis bral ba la mi dga' ba dang slong ba mthong ba dang de la sbyin pa rdzogs par byed pa la smon pa de gsum slong ba po'i dga' ba sogs las lhag par ldan pas/ slong ba po'i de gsum rtag tu zil gyis gnon te/ slong ba pos sbyin pa byed pa de mthong bas dga' ba de bas ches lhag par byang chub sems dpas slong ba po mthong bas dga' ba dang / slong ba pos sbyin pa thob nas bsam pa yongs su rdzogs pa'i dga' ba de las byang chub sems dpas de la gtong ba yongs su rdzogs pa'i dga' ba lhag par che ba sogs yin pa'i phyir byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa rnam par dag pa khyad par du 'phags pa yin no/ /

This verse is a praise of perfectly pure generosity. When beggars see a charitable person, they feel happy and subsequently, in the event that their desires are fulfilled by a gift, are delighted. Should they not see someone charitable and not receive a gift, they get depressed. They are always hoping that they will see a charitable person and that the latter’s generosity will fulfill their wishes. In the same way, when charitable bodhisattvas, full of love for sentient beings, see some beggars and satisfy them with their generosity, they feel joyful. And when neither of these happens, they feel sad, and they hope and pray that they will see some beggars and be able to give them what they want.
