Their joy, sadness, and hopes are greater than those of the beggars, and they therefore always outshine the beggars in this respect. Compared to the beggars’ delight at seeing a donor, the bodhisattvas’ joy on seeing the beggars is much greater. And compared to the beggars’ happiness at receiving a gift and having their hopes fulfilled, the bodhisattvas’ joy at being able to give them what they want is much greater, and so on. For these reasons, bodhisattvas’ pure generosity is particularly sublime.
[tshul khrims rnam par dag pa]
Perfectly Pure Discipline
brtse bas sems can rnams la ni/ / srog dang longs spyod chung ma dag / rtag gtong shin tu dga' byed pa/ / de spong ji ltar srung mi 'gyur/ /
Out of love, they constantly give to sentient beings Their lives, possessions, and spouses, And are overjoyed to do so. How would they not maintain abstinence with regard to these? (XVII, 44)

tshul khrims rnam par dag pa'i yon tan ni/ snying brtse bas sems can rnams la ni/ rang gi srog dang longs spyod dang chung ma dag rtag tu gtong ba la mi dga' ba cung zad med par shin tu dga' bar byed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' des/ rang gi don du gzhan gyis srog gcod pa dang / ma byin par len pa dang / 'dod pas log par g.yem pa de spong ba ji ltar srung bar mi 'gyur/ de'i phyir lus kyi mi dge ba gsum spong ba'i tshul khrims rnam par dag pa dang ldan pa yin no/ /

The qualities of perfectly pure discipline are explained next. Bodhisattvas, out of love, are not in the slightest bit unhappy about constantly giving sentient beings their own lives, possessions, and spouses. They are, rather, overjoyed to do so. So how would they not maintain the discipline of avoiding selfishly taking others’ lives, appropriating their possessions, and committing adultery with their partners? It is because of this that they possess the perfectly pure discipline of avoiding the three physical negative actions.
'phags pa mi lta sems snyoms shing / / mi 'jigs brtse phyir kun ster ba/ / gzhan la gnod par byed pa yis/ / log pa'i tshig ni ji ltar smra/ /
Noble beings have no regard for themselves, are impartial, Fearless, and full of love, So how could they, who give everything away, Do others harm and tell them lies? (XVII, 45)

byang sems 'phags pa rang gi lus dang srog la'ang mi lta ba dang / sems can la sems snyoms shing / 'jigs pa lnga dang bral bas rgyal po'i chad pa sogs kyis mi 'jigs pa dang / lus can thams cad la snying brtse ba'i phyir rang la bdog pa kun ster ba de yis gzhan la bslu zhing gnod par byed pa yis/ mi bden pa log pa'i tshig rdzun ni ji ltar smra ste/ rdzun smra ba ni rang gi lus dang srog gi phyir smra ba'am/ yang na nye du sogs 'ga' zhig byams pas de'i ched du'am/ dgra sogs gcig la gnod pa'i phyir sems mi snyoms pa'i dbang gis rdzun smra la/ yang na rgyal po dang rkun po sogs kyi 'jigs pas rdzun smra ba dang / yang na rang gi chung ma dang nor sogs bral bar dogs nas mi bden par smra na'ang / rgyu de dag byang chub sems dpa' la med pa'i phyir/ rdzun smra ba mi srid do/ /

Noble bodhisattvas have no regard for their own bodies and lives. They are impartial with regard to sentient beings. They are free from the five fears and therefore not afraid of such things as punishment by the authorities. And they are full of love for all living beings. So how could they, who give away everything they own, deceive and harm others, telling them lies? People tell lies in order to save themselves from death or injury; or they lie out of partiality, for the sake of a friend or relative they love or in order to harm someone like an enemy; or out of fear of the authorities, robbers, and so forth; or because they are afraid of losing their spouse, riches, and so on. But bodhisattvas have none of these reasons for lying, so it is impossible for them to tell lies.
snyoms par phan par 'dod pas brtse ba can/ / gzhan gyi sdug bsngal skye bas shin tu 'jigs/ / sems can 'dul ba la ni sems brtson pa/ / ngag gi nyes rnam gsum las shin tu ring / /
Those with love who wish to help impartially, Who greatly fear that others might have pain, Who apply their minds to taming sentient beings, Have cast afar the three misdeeds of speech. (XVII, 46)

de bzhin du gzhan sems can kun la snyoms par phan 'dogs par 'dod pa'i brtse ba can yin pa dang / gang zag gzhan gyi sdug bsngal skye bas rang nyid shin tu 'jigs shing de la de mi 'byung bar 'dod pa dang / sems can rnams kyi nyon mongs 'dul ba la sems rtse gcig tu brtson pa yin pas/ gong gi rim pa bzhin ngag gi nyes pa mdza' ba dang mi mdza' ba'i sems mi snyoms pa'i dbang gis phra ma smra ba dang / gzhan sdug bsngal bar 'dod pas tshig rtsub mo dang / nyon mongs pa 'phel ba'i ngag 'khyal ba yi rnam pa gsum las shin tu ring du gyur pa yin no/ /

Similarly, since they are full of love and want to help all other sentient beings equally, they do not sow discord, driven by a lack of impartiality with regard to who are friends and who are not. Since they are extremely afraid of suffering happening to other people and want them not to suffer, they refrain from harsh speech, which comes from wanting others to suffer. And since they strive with one-pointed minds to subdue beings’ defilements, they avoid worthless chatter, which makes defilements grow. They are thus a very long way from committing these three kinds of verbal negative actions.
thams cad gtong ba snying rje can/ / rten 'byung chos la rab mkhas pa/ / de ni yid kyi nyon mongs kun/ / ji lta bur na dang du len/ /
Those who’ve given everything away, who are compassionate And know full well that things arise dependently— How could they indulge In all the mind’s defilements? (XVII, 47)

bdog pa thams cad gtong ba dang gzhan la snying rje chen po can/ rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba'i chos la rab tu mkhas pa de ni yid kyi nyon mongs pa/ brnab sems dang gnod sems dang log par lta ba la sogs pa chags sdang rmongs gsum las skyes pa kun ji lta bur na dang du len rigs te rang gi bdog pa kun gzhan la gtong bas gzhan gyi bdog pa la brnab sems mi rigs pa sogs su rim par sbyar nas shes par bya'o/ /

Bodhisattvas give away all their possessions, they have great compassion for others, and they are extremely knowledgeable about the doctrine of dependent arising. So how is it possible that they would indulge in all the mental negative actions, such as covetousness, evil intent, and wrong views, which arise through attachment, aversion, and bewilderment? It makes no sense that those who give others all their possessions would covet others’ possessions. This same principle should be understood as applying to the other mental negative actions.[20]
bzod pa rnam par dag pa ni
Perfectly Pure Patience
brtse ldan gang tshe gnod pa byed pa dang / / gzhan la phan pa'i sdug bsngal la rtag tu/ / phan pa'i 'du shes dga' ba rnyed gyur pa/ / de yis gang la ci zhig bzod par bya/ /
When those with love are harmed Or suffer helping others, They always find delight, thinking of the benefit. What, then, is there for them to bear? (XVII, 48)

brtse ldan byang chub sems dpa' la gang gi tshe/ gzhan gyis gnod pa byed pa dang / gzhan la phan pa'i phyir rang sdug bsngal ba la 'di ni byang chub mchog gi rgyu bzod pa rdzogs pa'i thabs yin no snyam du gnod byed dang sdug bsngal gyi 'du shes mi skye bar phan par byed pa'i mchog dang bde ba'i 'du shes kyi dga' ba rnyed par gyur pa byang chub sems dpa' de yis mi bzod pa'i yul gang la bzod par bya dka' ba ci zhig bzod par mi bya ste/ de la mi bzod pa'i 'du shes med pas na dper na nya chu la 'jug pa dang ri dwags me'i gtsang sbra can me la 'jug pa la mi bzod pa ci yang med pa lta bu'o/ /

When loving bodhisattvas are harmed by others or suffer in order to help others, they think, “This is the way for me to complete the practice of patience, which is a factor that leads to supreme enlightenment.” The idea that someone is harming them or that they are suffering does not occur to them. Rather, they are delighted, recognizing the situation as supremely beneficial and fortunate. For such bodhisattvas, what is there to bear that is so terrible and difficult to endure? They simply do not have the notion of these things being unbearable. They are like fish swimming in water or fire salamanders entering fire[21]—for them such things are not in any way unendurable.
brtson 'grus rnam par dag pa ni/
Perfectly Pure Diligence
gzhan la gzhan gyi 'du shes bral ba dang / / bdag pas ches lhag gzhan la rtag byams dang / / dka' ba spyod phyir brtse ba dang bcas la/ / brtson 'grus dka' ba min la shin tu dka'/ /

They have no notion of other beings as others, And constant love for others more than for themselves; For beings, they undertake austerities, and so for those with loving tenderness Diligence is not hard, even if extremely difficult. (XVII, 49)

byang chub sems dpa' rnams gzhan la gzhan gyi 'du shes dang bral te bdag gzhan mnyam pa nyid du rtogs pa dang / bdag gis bdag gzhan mnyam pa nyid kyi don rtogs kyang de ltar ma rtogs pa'i sems can gzhan la dmigs nas/ bdag pas ches lhag par sems can gzhan la rtag tu byams pa dang / sems can rnams kyi don du dka' ba dpag tu med pa spyod phyir brtse ba chen po dang bcas pa de la gzhan don du brtson 'grus rlabs po che spyod pa de lta bu dka' ba cung zad min la/ bdag bas gzhan gces kyi blos gzhan don du dka' ba spyod pa 'di ni gzhan 'jig rten dang nyan rang rnams kyis bgyi bar shin tu dka' ba yin no/ /

Bodhisattvas do not think of others as others. That is to say, they have realized the sameness of themselves and others. And although they have realized for themselves the meaning of the sameness of oneself and others, when they see other sentient beings who have not realized that, they always feel more love for the other beings than for themselves, and they undertake countless difficulties for beings’ sake. So for them, whose love is so great, the immense efforts they make for others’ sake are not in the least difficult. On the other hand, these hardships they undergo for others’ benefit, thinking of others as more important than themselves, are extremely difficult for anyone else to do—that is, for ordinary beings and listeners and solitary realizers.
bsam gtan rnam par dag pa ni/
Perfectly Pure Concentration
gsum gyi bsam gtan bde ba chung / / bdag bde gzhan pa yongs nyams 'gyur/ / zad 'gyur rmongs dang bcas par 'dod/ / byang chub sems dpa'i ldog pa'o/ /

The concentration of three kinds of beings is held to have but little bliss: It is selfish bliss, with clinging, that loses its strength, Or is exhausted, and is associated with ignorance. A bodhisattva’s concentration is just the opposite. (XVII, 50)

'jig rten pa dang nyan thos dang rang rgyal gsum gyi bsam gtan ni byang chub sems dpa'i bsam gtan la ltos na bde ba chung ba ste 'jig rten pa'i zag bcas kyi bde ba dang / nyan rang gi bsam gtan zag pa med pas rang rgyud 'ba' zhig tshim par byed kyi gzhan la sim par mi byed pa'i phyir ro/ / 'jig rten pa rnams bdag tu 'dzin pa'i dbang gis 'khor ba'i bde ba 'dod pa dang / nyan rang rnams bdag gcig pu myang 'das kyi bde ba 'dod pa dang / 'jig rten pa rnams 'khor ba la zhen pa dang / nyan rang rnams zhi ba la zhen pa dang / 'jig rten pa'i bsam gtan gyi bde ba yongs su nyams par 'gyur ba dang / nyan rang gi bsam gtan phung po lhag med du zad par 'gyur ba dang / 'jig rten pas sgrib pa gnyis ka ma spangs pa dang / nyan rang gis shes sgrib ma spangs pas rmongs pa dang bcas par 'dod la/ byang chub sems dpa'i bsam gtan ni de las ldog pa ste/ theg pa chen po'i bsam gtan dpag tu med pa'i bde ba rgya che zhing mang ba dang / gzhan don du zhugs pa dang / rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyis srid zhir zhen pa med pa dang / tshe rabs thams cad du 'byung bas nyams pa med pa dang / phung po lhag med kyi dbyings su yang mi zad pa dang / sgrib pa gnyis ka spangs pas ma rmongs pa'i khyad par drug dang ldan pa'o/

The concentration of mundane meditators, listeners, and solitary realizers, compared to that of bodhisattvas, leads to minor bliss, because the tainted bliss of mundane beings and the untainted concentration of the listeners and solitary realizers bring contentment only to their own minds and do not satisfy others. Mundane meditators, on account of their belief in a self, want samsaric happiness; the listeners and solitary realizers desire the bliss of nirvāṇa for themselves alone. Mundane beings cling to saṃsāra; listeners and solitary realizers cling to peaceful nirvāṇa. The bliss of mundane beings’ concentration loses its strength completely. The listeners’ and solitary realizers’ concentration will come to an end in the state of nirvāṇa with no residual aggregates. Mundane meditators have not eliminated either of the two kinds of obscurations, while listeners and solitary realizers have not eliminated the cognitive obscurations; their concentration is therefore held to be associated with ignorance. The bodhisattva’s concentration, on the other hand, is the opposite of these, differing from them in six respects, as follows. The boundless concentrations of the Great Vehicle lead to vast happiness. Bodhisattvas enter into concentration for others’ benefit. On account of their nonconceptual gnosis, it is free of clinging to existence and peace. It occurs throughout the bodhisattva’s series of lives and so does not lose its strength. It is never exhausted even in the expanse of nirvāṇa without residual aggregates. And since bodhisattvas have eliminated both kinds of obscurations, it is free of ignorance.
[shes rab rnam par dag pa]
Perfectly Pure Wisdom
ji ltar mtshan mo lag nom dang / / khebs sgron de bzhin shes pa gsum/ / snying rje can gyi shes pa ni/ / nyi ma'i zer bzhin mtshungs pa med/ /

There is wisdom like one who fumbles in the dark, And wisdom like a light that has been concealed. These bear no comparison with the knowledge of the compassionate ones, The third wisdom, which is like the rays of the sun. (XVII, 51)

shes rab rnam par dag pa'i yon tan ni/ dpe ji ltar na 'jig rten pa'i thos bsam sgom pa'i shes rab ni mtshan mo snang ba med par dngos po la lag pas nom zhing nyug ste btsal ba dang 'dra bar mi rtag pa dang sdug bsngal ba sogs dngos po'i de kho na nyid mngon sum du ma shes par rjes su dpag pa'i sgo nas 'jal ba tsam mo/ / nyan rang gi shes rab ni/ khebs kyi nang gi sgron me 'dra ste/ sgrom mam khang bu'am phug tu mar me bzhag na de'i nang tsam zhig gsal ba bzhin du rang rgyud kyi phung po lnga la gang zag gi bdag med pa tsam rtogs nas nyon mongs pa bsal ba'i shes rab tsam mo/ / de bzhin du shes pa gsum pa snying rje can byang chub sems dpa'i shes pa ni nyi ma'i zer bzhin du phyogs thams cad snang bar byed pas mtshungs pa med pa yin te/ ji lta ba bdag med gnyis yongs su rdzogs par rtogs pa dang / ji snyed pa kun nyon rnam byang gi chos thams cad ma 'dres par shes pas/ sgrib pa gnyis spong ba dang bden pa gnyis rtogs pa'i phyir ro/ /

To explain the qualities of perfectly pure wisdom, this verse uses an analogy. The wisdom that mundane beings acquire through listening, reflecting, and meditating is analogous to looking for something at night, in the dark, feeling for things with one’s hands. They can only judge the nature of things—impermanence, suffering, and so forth—by inference, without knowing it directly. The listeners’ and solitary realizers’ wisdom is like a concealed lamp. If a candle is placed inside a box or recess, it lights only the inside. Similarly, having realized merely the absence of an individual self in their own five aggregates, they have only the wisdom that comes from the removal of the defilements. By the same analogy, the third wisdom, the knowledge of the compassionate bodhisattvas, is like the rays of the sun, shining in all directions. It is without compare, for it has perfectly realized the nature of phenomena, the absence of the two kinds of self, and it knows clearly and distinctly all the phenomena of defilement and purity in their multiplicity. It has thereby eliminated the two kinds of obscurations and realized the two truths.
gnyis pa sbyin pa sogs mchog tu gyur pa'i yon tan ni/
Second, the Supremacy of Generosity and the Other Transcendent Perfections

tshigs bcad drug gis bstan te/ sbyin sogs phar phyin drug po re re yang mchog rnam pa brgyad dang ldan pas na mchog tu gyur pa yin no/ / mchog rnam pa brgyad ni/ rten mchog dang / gzhi'am dngos po mchog dang / rgyu mtshan mchog dang / yongs bsngo mchog dang / rgyu mchog dang / ye shes mchog dang / zhing mchog dang / gnas pa mchog go / de brgyad dang ldan pas na pha rol tu phyin pa dang / dam pa dang / mchog gi yon tan ldan pa'o/ /

As shown in the following six verses, the supremacy of generosity and the other five transcendent perfections is comprised in their each having eight supreme aspects. These eight supreme aspects are supreme individual,[22] supreme substance or object, supreme reason, supreme dedication, supreme cause, supreme gnosis, supreme field, and supreme reliance. Because they have these eight, they possess the qualities of being transcendent, sublime, and supreme.
sbyin pa rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /
In terms of the individual, substance, Reason, dedication, Cause, gnosis, fields, And reliance, their generosity is supreme. (XVII, 52)
ces
de yang sbyin pa ni/ sbyin pa gtong ba po so skye dang nyan rang lta bu ma yin gyi byang chub sems dpa' yin pas rten mchog tu gyur pa'o/ /
(1) As far as generosity is concerned, the giver is not like an ordinary person or a listener or solitary realizer, but is a bodhisattva—a supreme individual.

sbyin pa bya rgyu'i gzhi'am dngos po ni nyan thos pas zas gos sogs zang zing gi dngos po cung zad sbyin pa dang / chos nyan thos kyi sde snod sbyin pa/ tshe 'di'i gnod pa la skyabs kyi sbyin pa lta bu las mchog tu gyur pa shin tu gtong bar dka' ba'i longs spyod rgya chen po dang / mgo dang yan lag sogs gtong ba dang / chos theg pa chen po skyabs srid zhi'i mtha' las 'das pa'i byang chub chen po la 'god pa gtso bor gyur pa'i sbyin pa tshad med pa byed pa'o/ /

(2) As for the substance or object, the thing that is given, it is far superior to what listeners give, for example. The latter give a few material gifts such as food and clothing; their gift of Dharma is the listeners’ scriptural collection; and they give protection from harm in this life. But bodhisattvas make boundless gifts of things that are extremely difficult to give away (possessions on a vast scale, their heads and limbs, and so forth), of the Mahāyāna teachings, and of the refuge that, above all, brings one to the great enlightenment beyond the extremes of existence and peace.
rgyu mtshan ni kun slong ste nyan thos ltar 'dod pa'i dad pas ma yin te gtso cher sems can sdug bsngal ba mthong nas snying rjes gtong ba dang ni
(3) The reason is their motivation: bodhisattvas give not out of yearning faith, as do the listeners, but chiefly out of compassion from seeing sentient beings suffering.

yongs su bsngo ba mchog ni sbyin pa'i 'bras bu lha mi'i bde 'bras kyi ched dang / nyan rang gi byang chub kyi phyir yongs su mi bsngo zhing / sems can thams cad kyi don du bla med rdzogs pa'i byang chub 'thob pa'i phyir bsngo ba dang /

(4) With regard to the supreme dedication, bodhisattvas dedicate the result of their acts of generosity not to any happiness in the celestial and human realms that might result, nor to the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ enlightenment, but to the attainment of perfect, unsurpassable enlightenment for the benefit of all sentient beings.

rgyu ni tshe rabs snga mar ma chags pa sogs dge rtsa gsum gyis zin pa'i sbyin pa la yang dag par goms pa'i bag chags kun gzhi la yod pa'i dbang gis gang du skyes kyang sbyin pa'i phar phyin la brgyud mar 'jug pa'o/ / 'di ni nyer len gyi rgyu sa bon lta bu dang / rgyu mtshan nam kun slong snying rje ni lhan cig byed rkyen chu dang sa la sogs pa lta bu grogs yin no/ /

(5) The cause is the habitual tendency present in the ground of all that comes from their having thoroughly accustomed themselves in previous lives to the practice of generosity imbued with the three roots of virtue (freedom from attachment, and so on), as a result of which, wherever they are reborn, they continue to engage in the practice of transcendent generosity. This is the original cause, which is like a seed, while the reason or motivation—compassion—is the cooperative condition, helping the seed to grow, like earth and water.
ye shes mchog sbyin pa'i 'khor gsum mi dmigs pa rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyis zin pa'o/ /
(6) Supreme gnosis refers to generosity being imbued with nonconceptual gnosis, free of the three concepts of giver, recipient, and gift.

zhing ni lnga ste/ bram ze dang tshong pa sogs rang la nor cung zad yod kyang slong bar byed pa ni slong ba'i zhing dang / nad pa sogs sdug bsngal ba'i zhing / bza' ba dang bgo ba sogs dang bral ba mgon med pa'i zhing / zang zing bsgrub pa'i phyir sdig pa spyod pa log par spyod pa'i zhing / tshul khrims dang shes rab sogs kyi yon tan dang ldan pa yon tan gyi zhing zhes bshad la/ nyan thos dang 'jig rten pa'i tshul lugs kyis yon tan gyi zhing gtso bor byed kyang / byang chub sems dpa' rnams snying rje'i dbang gis sdug bsngal gyi zhing gtso bor byed cing / sdug bsngal bsal ba dang / lhag par sdug bsngal gyi rgyu las bzlog pa'i ched du sbyin zhing / yon tan gyi zhing sogs la'ang ji ltar rigs par sbyin no/ / sdug bsngal gyi zhing ni/ ji tsam du dman zhing sdug bsngal che ba de tsam du sbyin yul mchog yin te/ mi phyug po mang po la sbyin pa bas dbul po dang / dbul po las kyang shin tu nyam thag pa dang / de las yi dwags la sbyin pa dang / de las 'jur gegs kyi yi dwags la sbyin pa phan yon ches che ba lta bu'o/ / yon tan gyi zhing ni ci tsam mtho ba de tsam du phan yon che ste/ gang zag phal pa tshad med pa las/ tshul khrims dang ldan pa dang / nyan rang byang sems sangs rgyas kyi bar du zhing khyad par 'phags pa lta bu'o/ /

(7) There are five kinds of fields: Those who beg—anyone who asks, even if they are brahmins, shopkeepers, and so on, who have a little money. Those who are suffering, such as sick people. Those who have no protector, who have no food or clothes. Those who lead immoral lives, indulging in negative actions for material gain. And those with excellent qualities, who possess qualities such as discipline and wisdom. For listeners and those who follow mundane ways, fields with excellent qualities are the most important, but bodhisattvas, on account of their compassion, esteem fields of suffering the most. They give in order to dispel their suffering and especially to turn them away from the cause of suffering, while also giving to fields of excellent qualities and the other fields when appropriate. The more lowly the fields of suffering, and the greater their suffering, the better they are as objects of generosity. It is better to give to a poor person than to any number of wealthy people, even better to give to the most destitute, and even better to give to hungry spirits, while the benefits of giving to hungry spirits with constricted throats are greatest of all. As for fields with excellent qualities, the more exalted they are, the greater the benefits of giving to them. Far better to give to one who keeps pure discipline than to countless ordinary people, and the most exalted fields are listeners, solitary realizers, bodhisattvas, and, most of all, buddhas.
de ltar rang don las gzhan don gtso bor byed pa'i byang sems rnams kyis sbyin pa'i zhing sdug bsngal rgyu 'bras can la lhag par ster ba ni zhing gi sgo nas mchog tu gyur pa'i khyad par dag dang /

Thus, bodhisattvas, who consider others’ welfare far above their own, give especially to those fields of generosity who manifest suffering and its cause; in terms of the fields, their generosity is particularly supreme.

gnas kyi sgo nas zhes pa'i gnas ni gang la gnas nas gtong ba'i gnas te/ 'di la mos pa la gnas pa dang / yid la byed pa la gnas pa dang / ting nge 'dzin la gnas pa gsum ni/ gong du chos tshol gyi skabs kyi de gsum dang 'dra ste/ mos pa yid byed ni phar phyin ston pa'i theg chen gyi chos la de bzhin du yid ches pa'o/ / yid la byed pa ni sbyin pa sogs de dang de ni sngar gyi sbyin pa legs so snyam du ro myang ba/ gzhan gyi sbyin pa la rjes su yi rang ba/ rang gzhan gyi ma 'ongs pa'i sbyin pa la mngon par dga' ba'o/ / ting nge 'dzin ni nam mkha' mdzod la sogs pa la dbang 'byor ba'i sgo nas sbyin pa dang sangs rgyas kyi sar sku gsum brnyes nas gzhan don du dbang 'byor ba'o/ /

(8) The “reliance” of giving (that is, what bodhisattvas rely on when they give) refers to relying on interest in generosity, relying on attentiveness, and relying on concentration, which are similar to these three as mentioned in the chapter on investigating the Dharma above. Keeping interest in mind is a corresponding confidence in the Mahāyāna teachings on the transcendent perfections. Attentiveness refers to savoring one’s past generosity (or other transcendent perfection), thinking, “That was very good”; to rejoicing in others’ generosity; and to delighting in one’s own and others’ future generosity. Concentration refers to practicing generosity by mastering concentrations such as the Sky Treasury, and, having attained the three buddha bodies on the level of buddhahood, mastering generosity for the benefit of others.

de ltar rten la sogs pa rnam pa brgyad kyi sgo nas byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa ni 'jig rten pa dang nyan rang gi sbyin pa las mchog tu 'dod do/ / de bzhin du tshul khrims nas shes rab kyi bar du dngos po so so'i dbye ba dang / zhing theg chen gyi chos la dmigs nas gzhan der 'god pa mchog yin gyi nyan rang la bkod pa ni de lta ma yin pa gnyis ma gtogs pa gzhan drug la khyad med par shes par bya ste/

Thus, by means of these eight aspects, the individual and the rest, a bodhisattva’s generosity is held to be supreme compared to that of mundane beings and listeners and solitary realizers. The same should be understood for the other transcendent perfections, from discipline through to wisdom. Apart from the substance (which is distinguished in each case) and the field (which is the Great Vehicle and which, unlike the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ vehicles, is the supreme field to focus on and to set beings in), the other six aspects are no different, as we shall now see.
tshul khrims rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /
In terms of the individual, substance, Reason, dedication, Cause, gnosis, field, And reliance, their discipline is supreme. (XVII, 53)

tshul khrims ni rten byang chub sems dpas bsrung ba dang / gzhi ni dngos po byang chub sems dpa'i nyes spyod sdom pa dge ba chos sdud sems can don byed gsum dang ni/ rgyu mtshan sems can la snying rje dang ni bla med byang chub tu yongs su bsngo ba dang / rgyu tshe rabs snga mar tshul khrims goms pa dang / ye shes rnam par mi rtog pas zin pa dang / zhing ni theg pa chen po'i chos la dmigs nas sems can rnams de la 'god pa dag dang / gnas gsum po mos pa dang yid byed dang ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo nas tshul khrims srung ba'o/ /

The individual who maintains discipline is a bodhisattva. The substance or object comprises the three aspects of a bodhisattva’s discipline—refraining from negative actions, gathering positive actions, and working for the benefit of sentient beings. The reason is compassion for sentient beings. The dedication is made to unsurpassable enlightenment. The cause is habituation to discipline in previous lives. It is imbued with nonconceptual gnosis. The field, on which bodhisattvas focus and in which they set sentient beings, is the Great Vehicle. And the reliance is the three kinds of reliance on interest, attentiveness, and concentration. It is by means of these that discipline is preserved.
bzod pa rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /
In terms of the individual, substance, Reason, dedication, Cause, gnosis, field, And reliance, their patience is supreme. (XVII, 54)

bzod pa'i gzhi ni gnod pa nyams su len pa'i bzod pa/ sdug bsngal la ci mi snyam pa'i bzod pa chos la nges par sems pa'i bzod pa'o/ / gzhan snga ma bzhin du shes par byas nas/ bzod pa rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /

The substance of patience comprises patience in taking harm as the practice, patience in thinking nothing of suffering, and patience in aspiring to a true knowledge of reality. The other aspects of patience are to be understood as being the same as those of the previous transcendent perfection. Hence, in terms of the individual, substance, reason, dedication, cause, gnosis, field, and reliance, patience is held to be supreme.
brtson 'grus rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /
In terms of the individual, substance, Reason, dedication, Cause, gnosis, field, And reliance, their diligence is supreme. (XVII, 55)

brtson 'grus kyi gzhi ni/ go cha'i brtson 'grus dang sbyor ba'i brtson 'grus dang / sems can don byed kyi brtson 'grus so/ / brtson 'grus rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /

The substance of diligence comprises armor-like diligence, diligence in application, and diligence in benefiting sentient beings. In terms of the individual, substance, reason, dedication, cause, gnosis, field, and reliance, diligence is held to be supreme.
bsam gtan rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /
In terms of the individual, substance, Reason, dedication, Cause, gnosis, field, And reliance, their concentration is supreme. (XVII, 56)

bsam gtan kyi gzhi ni/ mthong chos bder gnas kyi bsam gtan/ mngon par shes pa bsgrub pa'i bsam gtan/ sems can don byed kyi bsam gtan gsum yin la/ bsam gtan rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /

The substance of concentration comprises the concentration that procures a feeling of well-being in this life, the concentration that accomplishes preternatural knowledge, and the concentration that brings about the benefit of sentient beings. In terms of the individual, substance, reason, dedication, cause, gnosis, field, and reliance, concentration is held to be supreme.
shes rab rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ /
In terms of the individual, substance, Reason, dedication, Cause, gnosis, field, And reliance, their wisdom is supreme. (XVII, 57)

shes rab kyi gzhi ni/ kun rdzob bden pa shes pa'i shes rab/ don dam bden pa shes pa'i shes rab/ sems can gyi don sgrub par shes pa'i shes rab gsum mo/ / shes rab rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas mchog tu 'dod/ / ces so/ / gzhi'am dngos po'i nang nas kyang mchog tu gyur pa ni/ dman 'bring chen po'i tshul gyis mchog tu gyur pa shes par bya'o/ /

The substance of wisdom comprises the wisdom of knowing the relative truth, the wisdom of knowing the ultimate truth, and the wisdom of knowing how to accomplish the welfare of sentient beings. In terms of the individual, substance, reason, dedication, cause, gnosis, field, and reliance, their wisdom is held to be supreme. It should also be understood that the substance or object in each case is divided into modest, middling, and greatest, and that the “supreme substance” is the best of these.
gsum pa sbyin pa'i yon tan ni/
Third, the Qualities of Generosity
byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa ni/ / sems can gcig bde bskal mang du/ / gnod pa byed kyang dga' 'gyur na/ / de las bzlog pa smos ci dgos/ /

Bodhisattvas feel the greatest joy When their generosity makes a single being happy, Even if it has brought them many kalpas of difficulty. No need is there to mention what they feel when this is not the case. (XVII, 58)

zhes tshigs bcad bdun gyis bstan te/ byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa gtong ba ni gal te sems can gcig gi bde ba'i slad du bdag gi bdog pa thams cad btang bas/ bdag nyid la bskal pa mang po'i bar du brel ba dang phongs pa'i sdug bsngal gyis gnod pa byed kyang sems mi dga' ba med par shin tu dga' bar 'gyur na/ de las bzlog ste chos dang zang zing btang bas sems can mang po la phan pa dang bde bar gyur cing / bdag nyid kyang yun du phan pa dang bde bar 'gyur ba la thugs dgyes pa smos ci dgos te/ 'di lta bu ni sems can la snying brtse ba'i dbang gis yin no/ /

In giving generously, bodhisattvas never get depressed, even if by giving away everything they own in order to make a single sentient being happy they inflict upon themselves many kalpas of constant toil and deprivation. Rather, it brings them the greatest joy. So one need hardly mention their delight in the opposite situation, where, by bestowing the gift of Dharma and material gifts, they bring benefit and happiness not only to numerous beings but also, in the long term, to themselves. That this should be so can be put down to their heartfelt love for sentient beings.
lus can rnams ni gang phyir nor 'dod pa/ / brtan rnams de nyid lus can rnams la gtong / / skye bo rnams ni lus phyir nor 'dod de/ / de nyid brtan rnams brgya phrag rnams su gtong / /

Because living beings desire wealth, The steadfast give them the very things they want. While humans seek riches for the sake of their bodies, Those very bodies the steadfast give away a hundred times. (XVII, 59)

lus can rnams ni gang phangs pa dang gang gces pa gang gi phyir nor 'dod pas btsal zhing gces spras kyis 'chang bar byed kyang / brtan pa byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni gang gces pa dang phangs pa'i dngos po de nyid lus can rnams la phar gtong bar byed kyi rang gis 'chang bar mi mdzad pa ni ma chags pa'i yon tan yin no/ / skye bo rnams ni lus dang srog gi phyir nor 'dod nas tshol zhing gsog par byed de/ lus de nyid brtan pa byang sems rnams kyis ni lan brgya phrag rnams su gzhan la gtong bar mdzad do/ /

Because living beings desire riches—the things they treasure and cannot bear to part with, which they seek and carefully look after—steadfast bodhisattvas give beings those very things that are prized and cherished and do not keep anything for themselves. This is the quality of their lack of attachment. People desire wealth for the sake of their bodies and lives, and so they seek and hoard it. Steadfast bodhisattvas give away their bodies hundreds of times to others.

gang tshe lus nyid gtong yang yid sdug mi bsngal ba/ / de tshe rdzas ngan lta la smos kyang ci zhig dgos/ / de 'di'i 'jig rten 'das pa de des dga' 'gyur ba/ / gang yin de ni de yi yang ni bla ma yin/ /

When even giving their bodies brings them no mental pain, What need is there to mention lesser gifts? In this they are beyond the world, and from it they derive the greatest joy— The highest of all the joys experienced by those beyond the world. (XVII, 60)

gang tshe rang gi lus dang srog nyid gtong yang yid sdug mi bsngal ba de yi tshe lus la ltos na gtong sla ba rdzas ngan phyi rol gyi dngos po lta bu la gtong zhing mi skyo ba smos kyang ci zhig dgos te 'di ni mi skyo ba'i yon tan no/ / de ltar lus srog gtong ba la mi skyo zhing shin tu dga' ba de ni byang sems 'di'i 'jig rten pa kun gyi spyod yul las 'das pa yi yon tan yin la/ byang chub sems dpa' de ni lus btang ba des mchog tu dga' ba nyid du 'gyur ba gang yin pa de ni/ 'jig rten 'das pa nyan thos dang rang rgyal 'phags pa de yi yang ni bla ma yin te byang sems kyi dga' ba de lta bu nyan rang 'phags pa rnams la med pa'i phyir ro/ / byang sems 'di ni gtong ba de lta bu la dga' bas sbyin pa rgyun mi 'chad par byed kyi nam yang skyo ba med par ma zad de la mchog tu dga' ba yin no/ /

Even though they give away their own bodies and lives, bodhisattvas do not suffer mentally. At such times, there is no need to mention their never getting discouraged in giving away outer things that, compared to their bodies, are inferior things that are easy to give away. This is the indefatigable quality of their generosity. This ability to give their bodies and lives without getting discouraged and to derive great pleasure from doing so is these bodhisattvas’ quality of being beyond the domain of any mundane beings. And the supreme joy that bodhisattvas derive from giving away their bodies is the highest of the joys of supramundane beings, greater even than those of the noble listeners and solitary realizers, for the listeners and solitary realizers have nothing like the joy that the bodhisattvas have. Not only do those bodhisattvas delight in such sacrifice and thus never tire of continuously practicing generosity, but they also derive the greatest joy from doing so.
ji ltar blo ldan 'di ni kun gtong bas/ / don gnyer skye bo dga' bas dga' ba ltar/ / de ltar slong mo ba dag blang bya ba/ / 'dod rgu thob pa dag gis dgar mi 'gyur/ /
The wise, by giving all, derive delight From the pleasure of those who were longing for those gifts. The beggars feel no similar delight When they receive the alms they begged. (XVII, 61)

ji ltar blo ldan 'di ni lus dang longs spyod kun gtong bas/ de dag don du gnyer ba'i skye bo rnams sbyin pa de lta bu thob pas dga' bar gyur pa dang de la phan thogs pa mthong nas byang sems rang nyid de la dga' ba ltar/ de ltar slong mo ba dag gis byang sems de las bslang bar bya ba 'dod rgu thob pa dag gis dga' bar mi 'gyur te/ byang sems rnams zhing de la de ltar byams pa yin no/ /

Wise bodhisattvas give away everything—their bodies and possessions—and when they see that the people who long for those things are delighted to receive such gifts and that they have helped them, the bodhisattvas feel delighted themselves. The beggars do not derive anything like such great joy when they receive the things they have begged from those bodhisattvas—such is the bodhisattvas’ love for those fields.
blo can bdog dgu btang bas nor med pa/ / bdag nyid nor ldan sems pa ji lta bar/ / slong ba longs spyod kun rdzogs bdag nyid ni/ / de ltar nor dang ldan par mi sems so/ /
The wise, impoverished by giving all they own, Think themselves enriched. The beggars, now the owners of all that wealth, Have no such feeling that they’re rich. (XVII, 62)

blo gros chen po can byang chub sems dpa' 'dis rang la bdog rgu thams cad btang bas gnas skabs de na rang la nor med pa nyid du gyur kyang / bdag ni nor rnams sbyin pa'i gter du byas so snyam du bdag nyid nor dang ldan par sems pa ji lta bar/ slong ba po byang chub sems dpa' de las thob pa'i longs spyod rgya chen po kun tu rdzogs pa'i bdag nyid du gyur pa de'i byang sems de'i bsam pa de ltar bdag nor dang ldan par mi sems te da dung nor la ser sna dang bcas te 'jug pa'i ngang tshul la mi gnas so/ / 'di ni sbyin pa'i 'bras bu ches cher 'dzin pa'i yon tan no/ /

By giving away everything they own, these immensely wise bodhisattvas become momentarily penniless. Yet despite this, they consider themselves wealthy, thinking, “I have turned my wealth into the treasure of generosity.” On the other hand, the beggars, who now possess all the abundant wealth that they have obtained from the bodhisattvas, do not think of themselves as wealthy in quite the same way as the bodhisattvas do, and they still maintain a miserly, avaricious disposition with regard to possessions. This is the bodhisattvas’ quality of considering their result of generosity as much greater.

ji ltar blo ldan 'di ni sbyin pa bzang pos tshul bzhin du/ / don gnyer tshims byas de la phan chen 'dogs par sems pa ltar/ / de bzhin slong mo ba dag shin tu nor mang thob nas ni/ / sbyin pa po la rnyed pa'i rgyu yis drin du mi brtsi'o/ /

The wise, when properly satisfying the needy with excellent gifts, Think of them as great benefactors. The beggars, once they have received great quantities of wealth, Have no such gratitude to the giver for what they’ve gained. (XVII, 63)

ji ltar blo ldan 'di ni gus shing bsam pa rdzogs par byed cing rlom pa med pa'i sbyin pa bzang pos tshul bzhin du lus dang longs spyod gang 'dod pa don du gnyer ba rnams rang rang gi 'dod pa bzhin tshims par byas pa yi yul sems can de la byang chub sems dpa' 'di ni bdag gi phar phyin rdzogs pa dang bla med byang chub 'thob pa'i grogs su gyur to snyam du rang la des phan chen 'dogs par sems par ltar/ de bzhin nam de dang 'dra bar slong mo ba dag gis ni shin tu nor mang po rlabs che ba thob nas ni/ sbyin pa po la 'dis 'di lta bu zhig byin no snyam du rnyed pa'i rgyu yis drin du mi brtsi'o/ /

The wise satisfy those who hanker after their bodies and possessions according to their desires, properly, with excellent gifts that combine respect, the fulfillment of wishes, and a lack of arrogance. In doing so, those bodhisattvas think of the beings they have satisfied as greatly benefiting them: “These people are friends helping me to complete the transcendent perfections and attain unsurpassable enlightenment.” Unlike them, the beggars, having received immense quantities of riches, feel nothing like the same sort of gratitude to their benefactor for what they have acquired—they do not think, “They have given me all this.”

lam ka'i 'bras mchog ldan pa'i shing las longs spyod ji lta bar/ / lus can rnams kyis gang gi nor rdzas rgya cher blangs nas ni/ / bdag nyid dogs dang bral bar rang nyams spyod par byed pa la/ / btang dga' longs spyod can de byang chub sems dpa' las gzhan min/ /

Just as they enjoy delicious fruit from a tree along the road, Beings partake greatly of a bodhisattva’s riches, Using them unhesitatingly as they please. Yet no one but a bodhisattva has such wealth—the joy of generosity. (XVII, 64)

skye bo mang po 'gro ba'i lam ka'i 'bras bu mchog dang ldan pa'i shing chen po las mi rnams kyis dogs pa dang 'jigs pa med par rang gis ci 'dod du shing de'i 'bras bu la longs spyod pa ji ltar bar/ lus can rnams kyis byang chub sems dpa' gang gi nor rdzas rgya cher dwogs pa med par rang gis blangs nas ni/ 'di la mi sbyin su yang med do snyam du bdag nyid dwogs pa dang bral bar rang nyams ji dga' bar spyod par byed pa la dgyes shing nor rdzas 'chang na mi dgyes par btang bas dga' ba dang ldan la longs spyod mi zad pa can de ni byang chub sems dpa' las gzhan du de lta bu su yang yod pa min no/ / tshigs bcad phyi ma 'di gnyis nges pa'i yon tan no/ / ji ltar snying rjes gzhan don du sbyin pa byed tshul gyi khyad par 'dis mtshon nas/ tshul khrims la sogs pa'i phar phyin gzhan bsgrub pa'ang 'di dang tshul mtshungs par snying rje chen pos gzhan don du gtso bor rtsom pa don gyis shes par 'gyur ro/ /

From a great tree laden with the most sublime fruit along a well-traveled road, people partake of the fruit as they wish, without hesitation or fear. In the same way, living beings liberally and unhesitatingly take for themselves a bodhisattva’s possessions, and, thinking of such bodhisattvas, “There is no one they will not give to,” they use those very things as they please, without hesitation. Yet in taking pleasure from giving everything away, pleasing beings and never displeasing them by holding back any possessions, no one but a bodhisattva has such inexhaustible wealth. These last two verses refer to the quality of certainty. From these particular ways in which bodhisattvas practice generosity with compassion, for the benefit of others, we can understand implicitly how they also accomplish discipline and the other transcendent perfections, undertaking them in the same way, with great compassion, principally for others’ benefit.
bzhi pa brtson 'grus kyi phar phyin gyi yon tan bye brag tu bshad pa
Fourth, a Specific Explanation of the Qualities of Transcendent Diligence
['di] la mdor bstan rgyas bshad gnyis/
dang po/
Brief Introduction
gtso dang de'i rgyu las kyi dbye ba dang / / rnam pa'i dbye ba rten gyi dbye ba dang / / bar chad rnam bzhi'i gnyen po'i dbye ba yis/ / brtson 'grus yongs shes bya zhes rab tu bstan/ /

Diligence, it has been well taught, should be known For its importance, the reason for its importance, its different functions, Different aspects, categories in terms of individuals, And categories as the antidote to the four kinds of obstacles. (XVII, 65)
ces pas bstan te/

brtson 'grus ni phar phyin rnams las gtso bo'i mchog yin pa dang / de'i rgyu mtshan dang / brtson 'grus la las kyi dbye ba dang / rnam pa'i dbye ba dang / rten gyi dbye ba dang / bar chad rnam pa bzhi'i gnyen po'i dbye ba yis/ brtson 'grus yongs su shes par bya zhes de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyis rab tu bstan to/ /

The tathāgatas have fully explained that diligence is to be understood in terms of its paramount importance among the transcendent perfections, the reasons for this, its different functions, different aspects, classification in terms of individuals, and classification as the antidote to the four kinds of obstacles.
gnyis pa rgyas bshad ni/
Detailed Explanation
dang po/
First: Its Paramount Importance
dge ba'i tshogs kyi nang na brtson 'grus mchog /
Of all the host of virtues, diligence is the best. (XVII, 66a)
ces pas bstan te/
bsod nams dge ba'i chos thams cad kyi nang na brtson 'grus ni mchog yin no/ /
Of all virtuous, meritorious qualities, diligence is the greatest.
gnyis pa de'i rgyu mtshan bkod pa ni/
Second: Establishing the Reasons for That
'di ltar de la brten nas de rjes 'thob/ /
When one relies on it, virtue is subsequently achieved. (XVII, 66b)

mchog yin pa ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di ltar brtson 'grus de la brten nas dge ba'i chos kyi tshogs de dag rjes su 'thob pa'i phyir brtson 'grus med na dkar po'i chos sam dge ba'i tshogs gang yang mi 'thob la/ tshogs che chung ji yod kyang de brtson 'grus che chung la rag las te des thob pa'i phyir ro/ / bsam gtan dang shes rab kyis nyon mongs pa 'joms pas de dag mchog ma yin nam zhe na/ yin mod kyi de dag kyang brtson 'grus ma rtsom par mi 'byung ba'i phyir dge chos kun gyi rgyu ni brtson 'grus yin pa'i cha nas mchog yin no/ /

Why is diligence the most important? Because by relying on diligence, one will subsequently achieve those virtuous activities. Unless one makes the effort, one can never achieve any good qualities or virtuous practices. The extent of one’s positive activities depends on the extent of one’s diligence, because they are achieved through the latter. One might wonder whether concentration and wisdom are not the most important, since they destroy defilements. Indeed they are, but they do not happen without the application of diligence. So in terms of being the cause of all virtuous activities, it is diligence that is the most important.
gsum pa byed las kyi dbye ba ni/
Third: Its Different Functions

brtson 'grus kyis ni mod la bde gnas mchog / 'jig rten 'das dang 'jig rten gtogs pa 'grub/ / brtson 'grus kyis ni srid spyod 'dod pa thob/ / brtson 'grus kyis ni dag pa rab 'gyur ldan/ / brtson 'grus kyis ni 'jig tshogs 'das nas grol/ / brtson 'grus kyis ni byang chub mchog sangs rgyas/ /

Through diligence, one instantly achieves the greatest happiness And all the qualities of this world and beyond. (XVII, 66cd) Through diligence, one obtains the enjoyments one desires in saṃsāra. Through diligence, one gains changeable pure states. Through diligence, one transcends the transitory composite and is freed. Through diligence, one attains supreme enlightenment and buddhahood. (XVII, 67)
zhes pas bstan te/

brtson 'grus brtsams pa nyid kyis ni de'i mod mthong ba'i chos la bde bar gnas pa mchog 'grub ste/ 'jig rten tha mal pa rnams kyis kyang nad zhi ba dang dbul ba sel ba sogs kyi thabs la brtson pas tshe 'di la de'i 'bras bu mthong ba dang / zhi lhag la brtson pas tshe 'dir mthong chos su bsam gtan dang lhag mthong gi yon tan thob pa bzhin no/ / brtson 'grus kyis tshe 'di dang phyi ma la 'jig rten 'das pa dang / 'jig rten du gtogs pa'i yon tan thams cad 'grub bo/ / 'jig rten pa'i dge ba bcu la spyod pa'i brtson 'grus kyis ni srid pa na spyod pa'i 'dod pa yid 'ong lha mi'i bde 'bras thob bo/ / bsam gzugs kyi ting nge 'dzin la brtson 'grus brtsams pa nyid kyis ni/ khams 'og ma 'dod khams pa'i nyon mongs pa dag pa gtan du ba min pas rab tu 'gyur ba dang ldan pa bsam gtan bzhi dang / gzugs med pa bzhi'i ris su skye ba thob bo/ / bden pa bzhi dang rten 'brel gyi don bsgom pa'i brtson 'grus kyis ni 'jig tshogs lta ba las 'das nas nyan rang gi myang 'das kyi rnam par grol ba thob bo/ / theg pa chen po'i chos la brtson 'grus brtsams pa nyid kyis ni byang chub mchog tu sangs rgyas par 'gyur ro/ /

By applying diligence, one will immediately accomplish the highest state of happiness in this life. Even ordinary, mundane people who work hard at treating sickness, overcoming poverty, and so on, see the results of their efforts in this life. And by practicing sustained calm and profound insight assiduously, they visibly acquire the good qualities of concentration and profound insight in this life. By means of diligence, one will accomplish all supramundane and mundane qualities in one’s present and future lives. By being diligent in practicing the ten mundane positive actions, one will obtain, as the result, the pleasurable states that one wishes to enjoy in saṃsāra—the happiness of gods and humans. By applying diligence in the concentrations of form and formlessness, one will obtain rebirth in the realms of the four concentrations and the four formless realms, endowed with the changeable (since it does not last forever) purity of freedom from the defilements of the lower, desire realm. Through diligence in meditating on the four truths and dependent arising, one will transcend the view of the transitory composite and attain perfect liberation in nirvāṇa as a listener or solitary realizer. Through diligence in practicing the teachings of the Great Vehicle, one will attain the supreme enlightenment of buddhahood.
bzhi pa rnam pa'i dbye ba ni/
Fourth: Different Aspects of Diligence

gzhan yang nyams dang 'phel ba'i brtson 'grus dang / / thar pa'i dbang dang mi mthun phyogs spangs gzhan/ / de nyid rab zhugs yongs su sgyur byed dang / / brtson 'grus don chen nges tshig gzhan du 'dod/ /

Furthermore, there is one diligence that leads to decrease and increase, One that has power over liberation, another that eliminates counteragents, One that realizes thatness, one that completely transforms, And diligence of great significance, which is variously defined. (XVII, 68)
zhes pas bstan te/

gzhan yang yang dag par spong ba bzhi dang ldan pa'i brtson 'grus ni mi dge ba skyes pa zhi ba dang ma skyes pa mi skye bar byed pas nyes pa nyams par byed pa dang / dge ba ma skyes pa skyed pa dang skyes pa 'phel bar byed pa'i brtson 'grus ni tshogs kyi bar ro/ / dbang po lnga dang ldan pa'i brtson 'grus ni thar pa'i dbang ste thar pa la dbang byed pa'i brtson 'grus dang / stobs lnga'i brtson 'grus ni mi mthun phyogs spangs par brtson 'grus gzhan dang / yang dag byang chub kyi skabs na de kho na nyid la rab tu zhugs pa'i brtson 'grus dang / 'phags lam brgyad kyi skabs su rtsol ba yang dag pa 'phags pa'i lam ni gnas yongs su bsgyur ba'i rgyu byed pa dang / spyod pa phar phyin la brtson pa'i brtson 'grus ni/ sangs rgyas thob pa'i don chen po'i brtson 'grus zhes nyan rang gi brtson 'grus las khyad par 'phags pa'i phyir nges tshig gzhan don chen po zhes pa'i khyad par du byas par 'dod do/ /

Furthermore, there is diligence associated with the four genuine restraints, which refers to diligence that weakens one’s faults by quelling negative actions that have arisen and preventing those that have not arisen from arising; and diligence that gives rise to positive states that are not yet present and augments positive states that have already arisen. Diligence associated with the five powers is “power over liberation”—the diligence that masters liberation. Diligence in the five irresistible forces is another kind of diligence, which gets rid of countering factors. At the stage of the elements leading to perfect enlightenment, there is the diligence of full engagement with thatness. At the stage of the eightfold noble path, on the noble path of right effort, there is the diligence that creates the cause of complete transformation. And there is the diligence of effort in transcendent activity, which is held to be variously defined as the “diligence of the great goal,” the attainment of buddhahood, and as the “great import,” since it is far superior to the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ diligence.
thog mar dge ba'i brtson 'grus de nas ni/ / tshul bzhin rab zhugs sbyor ba'i brtson 'grus te/ / ma zhum mi 'gong chog mi shes brtson 'grus/ / rnam pa thams cad sangs rgyas rnams rab gsungs/ /

First comes the diligence of virtue, Then the diligence of proper application, And the diligence of not being disheartened, overpowered, or content. All these aspects the buddhas have explained. (XVII, 69)

gzhan yang thog mar bsam pa dge ba'i brtson 'grus ni gus sbyor gyi brtson 'grus dang / de nas dam bcas pa ltar dge ba la tshul bzhin rab tu sbyor ba'i brtson 'grus ni rtag sbyor gyi brtson 'grus te ngo bo'i sgo nas dbye ba gnyis dang / lam 'bras rgya chen po bsgrub pa ma zhum pa'i brtson 'grus dang / mi mthun phyogs kyis mi 'gong ba'i brtson 'grus dang / gnyen po la chog mi shes pa'i brtson 'grus te/ brtson 'grus kyi dbye ba'i rnam pa sna tshogs pa thams cad sangs rgyas rnams kyis rab tu gsungs so/ /

Moreover, to begin with there is the diligence of a positive attitude, which is the diligence of devoted application. This is followed by the diligence of properly applying oneself to virtue, as one had pledged, which is the diligence of constant application. These two are distinguished in terms of their essence. There are also the diligence of not losing heart in accomplishing the extensive path and result, the diligence of not being overpowered by countering factors, and the diligence of not being satisfied with the antidotes. All these various categories of diligence have been fully described by the buddhas.
lnga pa rten gyi sgo nas dbye na/
Fifth: Categories in terms of Different Individuals
theg pa gsum brtson skye bo la brten nas/ / bsam blo zhan dang rgya rab che ldan phyir/ / brtson 'grus tha ma 'bring dang mchog gzhan te/ / de ni don chung ba dang don chen 'dod/ /

As for those people diligent in the three vehicles, Their attitudes and wisdom vary from limited through to vast, So there are further forms of diligence—lesser, middling, and best— These are applied to the lesser goal and the greater goal. (XVII, 70)
ces pas bstan te/

theg pa gsum gyi lam la brtson pa nyan rang byang sems kyi skye bo la brten nas/ rim pa ltar bsam pa dang blo shes rab zhan pa dang 'bring dang / rgya rab tu che ba dang ldan pa'i phyir/ brtson 'grus tha ma dang 'bring dang mchog gi dbye ba gsum yang gzhan rten gyi sgo nas so/ / de gsum gyi dang po gnyis ni rang don tsam la zhugs pas don chung ba dang / phyi ma rang gzhan don gnyis sgrub par zhugs pas don chen po'i brtson 'grus su 'dod do/ /

With regard to the persons exerting themselves on the paths of the three vehicles—namely, listeners, solitary realizers, and bodhisattvas—their attitudes and wisdom are respectively limited, middling, and vast. Diligence, therefore, has three further categories in terms of these individuals: least, middling, and greatest. Since the first two of these three are applied only to one’s own goal, they are referred to as diligence for the lesser goal, while the last, being applied to accomplishing both one’s own and others’ goals, is held to be diligence for the greater goal.
drug pa bar chad bzhi'i gnyen po'i sgo nas dbye na/
Sixth: Categories in terms of Antidotes to the Four Kinds of Obstacles
brtson 'grus ldan pa longs spyod kyis pham med/ / brtson 'grus ldan pa nyon mongs kyis pham med/ / brtson 'grus ldan pa skyo bas pham pa med/ / brtson 'grus ldan pa thob pas pham pa med/ /

Those with diligence are never short of possessions. Those with diligence are not overwhelmed by defilements. Those with diligence are not overcome by loss of heart. Those with diligence are never short of attainments. (XVII, 71)
ces pas bstan te/

longs spyod nyams pa'i bar chad dang / nyon mongs pas bar du gcod pa dang / skyo bas bar chad byed pa dang yon tan thob pa las nyams pa'i bar chad bzhi brtson 'grus kyis spong bar bstan pa ni/ brtson 'grus ldan pa ni longs spyod kyis pham pa med de/ de'i rgyu bsgrubs pas so/ / brtson 'grus ldan pa nyon mongs pas pham pa med de de'i gnyen po bskyed pas so/ / brtson 'grus ldan pa sbyin sogs kyi sbyor ba la skyo bas pham pa med de/ chog mi shes pa'i brtson pa dang ldan pas so/ / brtson 'grus ldan pa yon tan gyi chos gang yang thob pas pham pa med de/ sangs rgyas kyi sa'i bar du brtson 'grus kyi stobs kyis 'grub pa'i phyir ro/ /

Four kinds of obstacles are shown to be avoided through diligence: obstacles from lack of wealth, obstacles due to defilements, obstacles from getting discouraged, and obstacles that prevent one from acquiring good qualities. For people who have diligence, wealth will never be a problem, because they are accomplishing the cause of wealth.[23] Those who are diligent are not overwhelmed by defilements, because they can give rise to their antidotes. Those who have diligence are not overcome by discouragement in actively practicing generosity and so forth, because they possess the diligence of never being satisfied. And those who are diligent have no obstacles to acquiring any good qualities,[24] because by the force of their diligence they will continue to accomplish such qualities until they reach buddhahood.
bcu pa
x. DETERMINING THE INTERRELATIONSHIPS OF THE SIX TRANSCENDENT PERFECTIONS
pha rol tu phyin pa rnams gcig gi nang du'ang gzhan rnams 'dus pas phan tshun rnam par nges pa ni/
Since within a single one of the transcendent perfections all the others are also included, they are determined as being interrelated, as shown in the following verse.
phan tshun bsdus phyir rab dbye'i phyir/ / chos nyid phyir dang rgyu mtshan phyir/ / pha rol phyin drug rnam kun tu/ / rnam par nges par shes par bya/ /

Because they are mutually inclusive, because of their subdivisions, Because of their very nature, and because they are causal, You should know that the six transcendent perfections Are determined as being in every way interrelated. (XVII, 72)
pas bstan te/

zhes sbyin pa sogs rang rang gi ldog pa nas tha dad kyang ngo bo gcig gi nang du gzhan kun kyang don gyis tshang bas phan tshun bsdus pa'i phyir dang / gcig la'ang drug tu rab tu dbye ba'i phyir dang / chos nyid kyis gang na sbyin sogs phar phyin re re yod na de na gzhan kun kyang ci rigs su yod pa'i phyir dang / sbyin sogs kyis phar phyin gzhan gyi rgyu mtshan nam rgyu byed pa'i phyir/ rgyu mtshan rnam pa de bzhi'i sgo nas pha rol tu phyin pa drug ni rnam pa kun tu phan tshun rnam par nges par shes par bya'o/ / de la phan tshun gcig gis gcig bsdus pa ji ltar yin zhe na/ sbyin pa la yang ser sna spong ba dang / sbyin pa nyid dang du len pa dang / sems can gyi don byed pa'i tshul khrims tshang la/ sbyin pa'i tshe log sgrub bzod pa dang / longs spyod gtong bar bzod pa bzod pa'i cha yin zhing / gtong ba la mos shing rtag tu brtson pa'i brtson 'grus dang / sems rtse gcig tu 'jug cing mi mthun phyogs kyi g.yeng ba'i dbang du ma gyur pa'i cha nas bsam gtan/ sbyin pa dag pa dang ma dag pa sogs sbyin pa'i chos kyi mtshan nyid khong du chud pa ni shes rab yin la/ nam mkha' mdzod kyi ting nge 'dzin thob nas sbyin pa ni bsam gtan dang / des bsdus nas chos sbyin pa shes rab bo/ / gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa'i phar phyin ni mi rtog ye shes kyis zin pas de kho na nyid rtogs pa'i shes rab dang ldan te phar phyin lhag ma kun la'ang de ltar shes par bya'o/ /

Although each transcendent perfection is distinct as an isolate, in fact the others are all complete within the same entity, and they are therefore mutually inclusive. Each one is divided into six aspects. By their very nature, if one of the transcendent perfections such as generosity is present, all the others, whichever they may be, are present in it too. And generosity and so forth is the causal factor of, or creates the cause for, the other transcendent perfections. So for these four reasons it should be understood that the six transcendent perfections are determined as being in every way interrelated. In what way are they mutually inclusive? In generosity, discipline is also complete—discipline in giving up stinginess, in the wholehearted act of generosity itself, and in benefiting others. When one is generous, one puts up with ingratitude and accepts the loss of one’s possessions—these constitute the patience aspect. In one’s aspiring to give and constantly striving to do so, diligence is present. From the point of view of engaging in generosity with one-pointed mind and not falling prey to distractions that counter generosity, one is practicing concentration. And understanding the defining characteristics of the practice of generosity—pure generosity, impure generosity, and so forth—is wisdom. Also, when one has acquired the Sky Treasury concentration, one’s generosity is concentration; when, by that means, one has gathered disciples, one’s giving the gift of Dharma is wisdom. Furthermore, since a bodhisattva’s generosity is permeated by nonconceptual gnosis, it is endowed with the wisdom that is the realization of thatness. It should be understood that this also holds for all the remaining transcendent perfections.

tshul khrims kyang dge ba chos sdud kyi nang du phar phyin thams cad 'du ste/ de thams cad sgrub par byed pa yin la/ tshul khrims gzhan don du srung bar don gyis sbyin pa yang yin/ tshul khrims dang ldan phyir ngang gis gzhan gnod la bzod pa'ang yin/ tshul khrims dang ldan pa nyid la de brtson pa'i brtson 'grus ngang gis tshang / tshul khrims nyid la sems rtse gcig tu dmigs pa bsam gtan gyi cha dang / ltung dang ltung min sogs tshul khrims kyi rnam par bzhag pa khong du chud pa ji snyed pa'i shes rab dang / tshul khrims kyi 'khor gsum mi dmigs pa ji lta ba rtogs pa'i shes rab bo/ /

Discipline includes all the transcendent perfections within the discipline of undertaking positive actions; it is what accomplishes them all. Keeping one’s vows for the sake of other beings is also, in fact, generosity. If one has discipline, one is also naturally patient with others who harm one. And in that one makes an effort to keep one’s vows, diligence is naturally fully present. Focusing one’s mind one-pointedly on discipline is the concentration aspect. A thorough understanding of the different categories of discipline—of what constitutes a downfall, what does not, and so forth—corresponds to the wisdom concerning the multiplicity of phenomena, and freedom from the concepts of the three spheres with regard to discipline constitutes the wisdom that realizes the nature of phenomena.

bzod pa nyid gzhan don du byed pa dang / bzod pa'i sgo nas gzhan la phan btags pa dang / gtong ba la bzod pa'i sbyin pa'ang tshang la/ bzod pa nyid khong khro ba'i nyes spyod sdom pa dang / dka' thub kyi gtso bo'i dge ba sdud pa'ang yin/ bzod pa la brtson pa nyid brtson 'grus/ phar phyin rnams spyod tshe sdug bsngal dang du len par yang gzhan kun 'du la/ sems mi 'khrugs par rtse gcig gnas pa'i cha nas bsam gtan chos la nges sems dang bzod pa sgom tshul shes pa dang rang bzhin med rtogs kyi cha nas shes rab kyang yin no/ /

In patience, generosity is also fully present, for patience itself benefits others, one resorts to patience in the process of helping others, and one accepts giving one’s things away. Patience is itself the avoidance of the negative act of anger and the undertaking of the positive action, in particular, of enduring hardship. The effort one puts into patience is diligence. All the other transcendent perfections are included in the willing acceptance of difficulties when one is practicing the transcendent perfections: from the point of view of keeping the mind one-pointed and imperturbable, there is concentration, and from the point of view of having certainty in the teachings, knowing how to train in patience, and realizing that phenomena are devoid of intrinsic nature, there is wisdom.

brtson 'grus ni gzhan thams cad dang mtshungs ldan du 'jug pas kun gyi cha yod do/ bsam gtan gyi bya ba bsgrub pa'i bsam gtan du gzhan kun 'du la/ bsam gtan gyis gzhan la phan 'dogs pa'i cha nas sbyin pa/ bsam gtan gyi sdom pa thob pa'i tshul khrims/ rnam g.yeng gis mi 'phrog pa'i bzod pa/ bsam gtan la gus rtag tu sbyor bas brtson 'grus/ rdzu 'phrul rkang bzhi'i dpyod pa shes rab dang / gzhan yang ji lta ji snyed kyi shes rab yod pa gong bzhin no/ /

Diligence is applied concurrently with all the others, and so aspects of all of them are present. The act of concentrating includes all the other transcendent perfections in its accomplishment. Benefiting others with concentration is the generosity aspect. Then there is discipline in the obtainment of the dhyāna vow, patience in not being ravished away by distractions, and diligence in the devoted and constant application to concentration. Analysis (one of the four bases of miraculous powers) corresponds to wisdom, and concentration moreover includes the wisdom that knows the nature and the multiplicity of phenomena, as above.
shes rab ni thabs la mkhas pa'i shes rab kyi nang du phar phyin gzhan thams cad 'du ste/ shes rab kyi sgo nas sbyin tshul bzod brtson bsam gtan bsgrub pa yin gyi de med na mi 'grub bo/ /

Wisdom includes all the other transcendent perfections within the wisdom of skill in means. It is through wisdom that generosity, discipline, patience, diligence, and concentration are accomplished. Without it, nothing will be accomplished.

rab dbye ni sbyin pa'i sbyin pa sogs re re la'ang drug tu phye bas so drug tu 'gyur tshul gong du chos tshol skabs su'ang bshad pa bzhin/ rang phyin drug la gnas nas gzhan de la 'god pa drug sbyin pa/ ser sna sogs mi mthun phyogs drug bral ba tshul khrims/ sbyor ba dka' ba bzod pa drug bzod pa/ spro ba drug brtson 'grus/ dmigs pa las gzhan du mi g.yeng ba drug bsam gtan/ 'khor gsum du mi rtog pa drug shes rab bo/ /

With regard to their subdivisions, the way in which each of the transcendent perfections is divided into six (the generosity of generosity, and so forth), making thirty-six subdivisions in all, has been described above in the chapter on investigating the Dharma.[25] To practice the six transcendent perfections oneself and then establish others in them gives six subdivisions that constitute generosity. Being free of the six countering factors (stinginess and the others) constitutes discipline. Putting up with difficulties in applying the six perfections constitutes patience. Enthusiasm in each of the six constitutes diligence. Not being distracted from whichever of the six perfections one is practicing constitutes concentration. And being free of the concepts of the three spheres with regard to each of the six constitutes wisdom.

yang na sbyin pa'i gtong sems sna gcig la yang / mi mthun phyogs spang ba/ gnyen po la sbyor ba/ spro ba/ mi g.yeng ba/ rab tu 'byed pa'i cha yod pas drug po 'bral med du tshang / tshul khrims sogs gzhan la'ang gzhan don du gtong ba'i sems pa sogs kun tshang ba'o/ /

Put differently, in a single thought of giving generously there are also the aspects of avoiding countering factors, applying the antidote, enthusiasm, lack of distraction, and discernment, so all six perfections are complete and inseparable from it. And in discipline and the others too, all the other aspects, beginning with the thought of giving for others’ benefit, are complete.

chos nyid kyi phyir zhes pa phar phyin ston pa'i rjod byed gsung rab kyi chos kyis phar phyin kun brjod byar bsdus pa dang / brjod bya phar phyin gyis rjod byed theg chen gyi gsung rab kun bsdus tshul du 'chad pa'ang snang la/ kun rdzob kyi chos nyid kyis bsdu tshul/ 'byung 'gyur gzugs kyi gong bu gcig la rgyu 'byung ba bzhi tshang ba ltar/ phar phyin drug gi nang nas gang rung gcig yod na gzhan kun gyi cha shas kyang tshang ba chos nyid yin pa dang / don dam pa rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyis zin tshe/ phar phyin gzhan thams cad rnam kun mchog ldan gyi stong nyid du ro gcig pas chos nyid kyis bsdus te/ yon tan rin po che sdud pa las/ dper na 'dzam bu'i gling gi shing rnams bye ba stong sogs/ grib ma'i dpes shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin par ro mnyam du 'byung tshul gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

For “Because of their very nature,” there is an explanation that the teachings of the Excellent Words that teach the transcendent perfections include all the transcendent perfections as their subjects, and those subjects, the transcendent perfections, include all the Excellent Words of the Great Vehicle that express them.[26] But here we shall explain how they are mutually inclusive by their very nature in relative truth: just as in a single lump of composite matter the four individual elements are all present, if any one of the six transcendent perfections is present, then by its very nature aspects of all the others are also present. And, in ultimate truth, when a transcendent perfection is imbued with nonconceptual gnosis, all the other transcendent perfections are naturally included, since they form a single taste as the emptiness supreme in all respects, as we find in the Verses Summarizing the Precious Qualities, which makes an analogy with the shade of a hundred billion trees in Jambudvīpa to show how everything appears to transcendent wisdom as the same taste.[27]

rgyu mtshan phyir zhes pa longs spyod la ma chags na tshul khrims srung nus shing / tshul khrims dang ldan na gzhan gyis gnod pa bzod nus pa dang / bzod pa dang ldan na brtson 'grus rtsom zhing des sems mnyam par 'jog la/ mnyam par bzhag na yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mthong bar gsungs pa lta bu dang / der ma zad sbyin pa lta bu phar phyin gang rung gcig la zhugs na yang / des gzhan kun 'grub pa la phan 'dogs par nges kyi mi phan pa sna gcig med do/ /

“Because they are causal” refers to the Buddha’s teaching that when one is not attached to possessions, one is able to maintain discipline. When one has discipline, one is able to patiently accept the harm others do one. If one is patient, one undertakes things with diligence. Because of that, one settles the mind in evenness, and once settled in evenness, one sees things correctly, as they are. Furthermore, even though one may be engaged in a single transcendent perfection—generosity, for example—it will definitely help in accomplishing all the others, and there is not a single one that will not help.
gnyis pa bsdu dngos bzhi bshad pa
2. AN EXPLANATION OF THE FOUR WAYS OF ATTRACTING DISCIPLES THAT BRING OTHER SENTIENT BEINGS TO MATURATION
['di] la/ rnam grangs lnga las/
This section is divided into five parts.
dang po ngo bo ni/
a. DEFINITIONS
sbyin mtshungs de ston len 'jug dang / / bdag nyid rjes su 'jug rnams kyis/ / snyan par smra dang don spyod dang / / don mthun nyid du 'dod pa yin/ /

Generosity is considered to be the same. Teaching them, encouraging others to practice them, And practicing them oneself are termed Agreeable speech, helpful activity, and consistent behavior. (XVII, 73)
zhes pas bstan te/

phyi pa yi bsdu ba ni sngar sbyin pa'i phar phyin bshad pa dang mtshungs te gzhan du med do/ / phar phyin drug po de yi rang dang spyi'i mtshan nyid ji lta ba bzhin du gzhan la 'chad cing ston pa ni snyan par smra ba dang / de ltar sems can rnams la phar phyin drug nyams su len tu 'jug cing sgrub par byed pa la bkod pa ni don spyod pa dang / sems can gzhan la sgrub tu bcug pa'i phar phyin de ni de nyid la bdag nyid rjes su 'jug cing sgrub par byed pa ni don mthun pa nyid du 'dod pa yin no/ / de ltar de ston len 'jug dang / / bdag nyid rjes su 'jug pa dang gsum po de rnams kyis snyan smra la sogs pa bsdu dngos phyi ma gsum bstan pa'o/ /

The definitions of the four ways of attracting disciples are held to be as follows. Generosity as a way of attracting disciples is the same as and nothing other than transcendent generosity, described earlier. To explain to others and teach the general and particular characteristics of the six transcendent perfections is “agreeable speech.” To thus encourage other beings to practice the six transcendent perfections and establish them as practitioners is “helpful activity.” And to oneself fully engage in and practice those same transcendent perfections that one has encouraged other sentient beings to practice is “consistent behavior.” Thus, teaching them, encouraging others to practice them, and practicing them oneself indicate the last three ways of attracting disciples—agreeable speech, and so on.[28]
gnyis pa grangs nges pa ni/
b. THE DEFINITIVE NUMBER OF THE WAYS OF ATTRACTING DISCIPLES
phan par byed pa'i thabs dang ni/ / 'dzin par byed dang 'jug byed dang / / de bzhin rjes su 'jug byed pas/ / bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhir shes bya/ /

Since they are the methods for bringing beings benefit, For making them comprehend, for making them engage, And similarly for making them continue the practice, Know that there are four ways of attracting disciples. (XVII, 74)
zhes pas bstan te/

bsdu ba'i dngos po dang po sbyin pa ni gzhan la tsha grang bkres skom sogs sel bas lus la phan par byed pa'i thabs dang ni/ snyan par smra bas phar phyin gyi mtshan nyid ma shes pa'am log shes sam the tshom du gyur pa bsal nas phar phyin rnams ma nor bar yid la 'dzin par byed pa'i thabs dang / don spyod pa ni phar phyin rnams nyams su len pa la 'jug par byed pa'i thabs dang*/ de bzhin du don mthun par spyod pa ni phar phyin rnams la yang yang rjes su 'jug par byed pa'i thabs yin te/ chos smra ba po rang nyid kyis chos de la spyod na gzhan de la bkod pa rnams kyang nan tan gyis chos de rjes su sgrub par byed pas na/ gdul bya sems can rnams 'khor du bsdus nas smin par byed pa'i thabs ni bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhir shes par bya ste de las mang mi dgos la nyung na mi 'du bas so/ /

The first way of attracting disciples, generosity, is the skillful way to benefit others physically by ridding them of such things as heat and cold, and hunger and thirst. Agreeable speech is the skillful way to clear away their ignorance, incorrect understanding, or doubts with regard to the characteristics of the transcendent perfections and to make them understand the transcendent perfections without error. Helpful activity is the skillful way to induce them to practice the transcendent perfections. And similarly, consistent behavior is the skillful way to make them pursue their practice of the transcendent perfections: if the persons teaching the Dharma practice those teachings themselves, it makes the other people too, whom they have established as practitioners, practice those teachings earnestly. So it should be understood that the method for attracting beings into one’s following and bringing them to maturity comprises four ways of attracting disciples—there is no need for more than four, but fewer would not include everything.
gsum pa bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhi'i byed las ni/
c. THE FUNCTIONS OF THE FOUR WAYS OF ATTRACTING DISCIPLES
dang pos snod 'gyur dngos po ste/ / gnyis pa yis ni mos pa yin/ / gsum pa yis ni sgrub pa ste/ / bzhi pas rnam par sbyong ba'o/ /
The first turns beings into proper receptacles, The second makes them interested, The third makes them practice, And the fourth helps them train and purify themselves. (XVII, 75)
zhes pas bstan te/

bsdu ba'i dngos po dang pos sems can rnams chos kyi snod du 'gyur bar byed de/ zang zing gi sbyin pas phan btags par byas pa'i sems can de rnams byang chub sems dpa' de la yid dga' nas de'i ngag nyan pa'i snod du 'gyur ba'i bsdu ba'i dngos po yin pa ste/ gnyis pa snyan par smra ba yis ni phar phyin dang yang dag par ldan pa'i chos la mos pa nyid du byed pa yin no/ / gsum pa don spyod pa yis ni pha rol tu phyin pa'i don sgrub tu bcug pa ste/ bzhi pa don mthun pas yang nas yang du pha rol tu phyin pa rnams spyod cing dri ma rnam par dag pa nyid du sbyong ba nyid du byed pa'o/ /

The first way of attracting disciples makes beings proper receptacles for the teachings. Sentient beings whom bodhisattvas have helped with material gifts feel happy with them and become suitable receptacles for listening to what they say. The second, agreeable speech, makes beings interested in the teachings that possess the riches of the transcendent perfections. The third, helpful activity, induces them to practice the transcendent perfections. And the fourth, consistent behavior, makes them practice the transcendent perfections repeatedly and train in purifying contaminants.
bzhi pa bsdu bzhi'i dbye ba
d. CATEGORIES OF THE FOUR WAYS OF ATTRACTING DISCIPLES
['di] la/ gnyis su bsdus pa'i dbye ba dang / gsum du dbye ba gnyis las
The four ways of attracting disciples can be classified into (1) two groups or (2) three categories.
dang po/
i. CLASSIFICATION INTO TWO GROUPS
zang zing dang ni chos kyi ste/ / dmigs pa'i chos la sogs pa yis/ / bsdu ba gnyis kyi sgo nas ni/ / bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhir 'dod do/ /
The four ways of attracting disciples Comprise two groups— Material and Dharma, Of which the latter includes the reference Dharma. (XVII, 76)
zhes pas bstan te/

zang zing gi bsdu ba dang ni/ chos kyi bsdu ba ste/ chos kyi bsdu ba la dmigs pa'i chos la sogs pa rnam pa gsum yod pa yis/ sbyin pa ni zang zing gi bsdu ba yin la/ gzhan gsum chos kyi bsdu ba yin pas/ de ltar bsdu ba gnyis kyi sgo nas ni/ chos kyi bsdu ba la gsum tu phyes nas bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhir 'dod do/ / chos kyi bsdu ba la dmigs pa'i chos dang / sgrub pa'i chos dang / rnam par dag pa'i chos gsum du yod pa'i dang po ni phar phyin drug dang ldan pa'i mdo sogs kyi chos yin pas de ni snyan par smra bas 'chad par byed do/ / sgrub pa'i chos ni don spyod pas nyams su len par byed do/ / rnam par dag pa'i chos ni don mthun pa'i sgo nas ser sna sogs phar phyin rnams mi mthun phyogs kyi dri ma dang bral bar spyod par byed pa'i phyir ro/ /

There are two groups: attracting with material gifts and attracting with the Dharma, of which the latter has three aspects—the reference Dharma and so on. Generosity is the material way of attracting disciples. The other three are the Dharma way. From these two ways of attracting disciples, with the Dharma way subdivided into three, there are held to be a total of four ways of attracting disciples. With regard to the Dharma way, there are the reference Dharma, the practice Dharma, and the purification Dharma. The first of these comprises the sūtras and other teachings that contain the six transcendent perfections, and these are explained by means agreeable speech. The practice Dharma, by means of helpful activity, makes disciples practice. As for the purification Dharma, consistent behavior induces disciples to train in freeing themselves of contamination by stinginess and other factors that counter the transcendent perfections.
gnyis pa gsum du dbye ba ni/
ii. CLASSIFICATION INTO THREE CATEGORIES
rnam pa'i dbye ba'i sgo nas ni/ / bsdu ba dman dang 'bring dang mchog / phal cher don med don yod dang / / rnam kun don yod shes par bya/ /
Know that they are categorized Into lesser, middling, and best ways of attracting, And the mostly unsuccessful, mostly successful, And entirely successful. (XVII, 77)
zhes pas bstan te/
