nyan thos kyi bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhi ni bsdu ba dman pa ste gzhan don mi byed pa'i phyir dang / rang rgyal gyi bsdu ba ni nyan thos las dbang po mchog dang byang chub sems dpa' las dman pa'i phyir 'bring dang / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi bsdu dngos bzhi ni/ mchog gi bsdu ba zhes bya ste/ bdag dang gzhan gyi don du zhugs pa'i phyir ro/ / byang chub sems dpas kyang nyan rang byang sems kyi theg pa la bkod pa de gsum dman 'bring mchog gi bsdu bar 'gyur ro/ / yang sdud pa po'i sgo nas dbye na/ mos spyod kyi sa la gnas pa'i byang sems rnams kyang bsdu dngos bzhis sems can bsdus shing smin par byed pa ni/ nyung shas shig smin par 'gyur ba las phal cher don med par 'gyur te chos kyi de kho na nyid ma mthong ba dang sems can gyi bsam pa sogs mi shes pa'i phyir ro/ / sa dang po nas bdun pa'i bar gyi byang chub sems dpas bsdu dngos bzhis sems can yongs su smin par byed pa ni phal cher smin par 'gyur bas don yod pa yin yang / nyung shas tsam smin par mi 'gyur ba yang yod pa dang / sa brgyad pa dang dgu pa bcu pa la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhis sems can rnams bsdus shing smin par byas pa de dag thams cad smin par 'gyur te gcig kyang chud mi za bas rnam pa kun tu don yod pa shes par bya'o/ /

When they are classified into different categories, there are the listeners’ four ways of attracting disciples, which are inferior ways because they do not benefit others; the solitary realizers’ ways, which are middling, in that their faculties are superior to the listeners’ but inferior to the bodhisattvas’; and the bodhisattvas’ four ways of attracting disciples, which are referred to as the best because they are applied for their own and others’ welfare. Bodhisattvas may also establish beings in the vehicles of the listeners, solitary realizers, or bodhisattvas, and in these three cases their attracting disciples will be inferior, middling, or best. Furthermore, the ways of attracting disciples can be categorized in terms of the individual who is attracting them. Bodhisattvas on the level of earnest aspiration may attract sentient beings and bring them to maturation with the four ways of attracting disciples, but, apart from bringing a few beings to maturity, for the most part they will not be successful because they have not seen the thatness of phenomena and do not know beings’ intentions and so forth. Bodhisattvas on the first level up to the seventh who use the four ways of attracting disciples to mature sentient beings are mostly successful in this, though there are still a few whom they will not bring to maturity. Bodhisattvas on the eighth, ninth, and tenth levels who use the four ways of attracting disciples to attract sentient beings and bring them to maturity will bring them all to maturity, without a single one being lost, and they are therefore entirely successful.
lnga pa bsdu dngos bzhi'i phan yon ni/
e. THE BENEFITS OF THE FOUR WAYS OF ATTRACTING DISCIPLES
'khor sdud pa dang ldan pa rnams/ / tshul 'di la ni yang dag rten/ / kun gyi don kun sgrub byed cing / / thabs bzang yin par rab tu bsngags/ /
Those who are attracting a following Properly depend on these methods. This accomplishes all the goals of everyone And is highly praised as the best of means. (XVII, 78)

zhes pas bstan te/ 'khor sdud pa dang ldan pa'i byang sems rnams/ tshul 'di lta bu la ni yang dag par rten pa de ni/ sems can kun gyi don mtha' dag kun sgrub par byed cing / de'i thabs bzang po 'di las gzhan du med pa yin par sangs rgyas rnams kyis rab tu bsngags so/ /

Bodhisattvas who are gathering around them an entourage of disciples place proper reliance on methods such as these. This accomplishes all the goals of all sentient beings. There is no better means for doing so than this, and it is praised as such by all the buddhas.
bsdus dang sdud par 'gyur ba dang / / gang dag da ltar sdud byed pa/ / de kun de 'drar de lta bas/ / 'di ni sems can smin byed lam/ /
Attracting disciples in the past, In the future, and in the present Are all by these same means, which therefore constitute The path for ripening sentient beings. (XVII, 79)

de phyir 'das pa'i sangs rgyas dang byang sems rnams kyis sngar sems can rnams bsdus pa dang / de bzhin ma 'ongs pa na sdud par 'gyur ba dang / gang dag da ltar sdud par byed pa de kun bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhi po yis sdud pa de 'dra bar gyur pa de bas na/ bsdu dngos bzhi po 'di ni sems can thams cad smin par byed pa'i lam gcig tu nges pa yin no/ /

For that reason, the past buddhas and bodhisattvas have attracted sentient beings in the past, and will similarly attract them in the future, and are attracting them at present, all by means of these same four ways of attracting disciples. It is certain, therefore, that these four ways of attracting disciples constitute the one route to bringing all sentient beings to maturity.
gsum pa le'u'i mjug bsdu ba ni/
3. CONCLUDING SUMMARY OF THE SIX TRANSCENDENT PERFECTIONS AND THE FOUR WAYS OF ATTRACTING DISCIPLES
de ltar rtag tu longs spyod ma chags blo/ / zhi sdom brtson pa'i pha rol phyin gnas bdag / srid yul mtshan ma rnam par mi rtog pa/ / de ni sems can tshogs sdud byed pa yin/ /

Thus those whose minds are ever unattached to wealth, Who are peaceful, restrained, perfectly diligent, settled, And are free of concepts with regard to existence and objects Are they who gather a host of sentient beings. (XVII, 80)

zhes pas bstan te/ de ltar rtag tu longs spyod la ma chags pa'i blo yis sbyin pa la 'jug pa dang / chags sogs kyi rgyu las byung ba'i mi dge ba'i las lam rnams zhi ba'i tshul khrims dang / bzod pa'i sgo nas zhe sdang gis rgyud mi 'khrug pa sdom pa dang / brtson 'grus kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang ldan pa dang / sems phyi rol du mi g.yeng bar nang du ting nge 'dzin la gnas pa'i bdag nyid/ shes rab kyis srid pa nang phung po lnga dang / yul gzugs sogs phyi'i chos dang de gnyis ka'i mtshan mar rnam par mi rtog pa yi byang chub sems dpa' bdag smin par gyur pa des ni bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhis sems can kyi tshogs sdud cing smin par byed pa yin no/ /

Thus, bodhisattvas engage in generosity with minds perpetually free of attachment to possessions. They are disciplined, their vows counteracting the definite negative actions[29] that result from attachment and so forth. Their mind streams are restrained by patience and so undisturbed by aversion. They possess transcendent diligence. Their minds rest in inner concentration, undistracted outwardly. And on account of their wisdom, they have no concepts of the attributes of existence (the five internal aggregates) or of objects (external phenomena such as forms) or of both. It is these bodhisattvas who, having thus ripened themselves, use the four ways of attracting disciples to gather hosts of sentient beings and bring them to maturity.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ pha rol tu phyin pa dang bsdu ba'i le'u ste bcu bdun pa'o// //
This completes the seventeenth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on the transcendent perfections and attracting disciples.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ pha rol tu phyin pa dang bsdu ba'i le'u ste bcu bdun pa rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the seventeenth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on the transcendent perfections and attracting disciples.
! gsum pa mchod bsten tshad med kyi
18. OFFERING, RELIANCE, AND BOUNDLESS ATTITUDES
le'u 'di la/ sangs rgyas mchod pa dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsten pa/ tshad med bzhi bsgom pa/ de dag gi mjug bsdu ba bzhi las
This chapter has four parts: (1) making offerings to the buddhas; (2) relying on a spiritual master; (3) meditating on the four boundless attitudes; and (4) a concluding summary.
dang po la mchod pa'i rang bzhin bstan pa ni/
1. MAKING OFFERINGS TO THE BUDDHAS
rab dang sems dang ldan pa yis/ / tshogs gnyis rdzogs par bya ba'i phyir/ / sangs rgyas rnams la gos sogs kyis/ / mngon sum mngon sum min par mchod/ /
In order to complete the two accumulations, Those whose minds are full of faith Offer to the buddhas robes and so forth, In both real and imagined ways. (XVIII, 1)
zhes tshigs bcad bdun gyis bstan te/

kun slong rab tu dang ba'i sems dang ldan pa yis/ dgos pa tshogs gnyis rdzogs par bya ba'i phyir/ zhing sangs rgyas rnams la mchod pa'i rdzas chos gos dang lhung bzed dang gdugs dang rgyal mtshan me tog la sogs pas zhes bkur sti dang chos nyan pa sogs kyang bsdu ste/ mdor na mchod pa'i dngos po sna tshogs kyis so/ / tshul ji ltar na sangs rgyas mchog gi sprul pa'i sku 'jig rten du byon pa'i dus yin na sangs rgyas nyid mngon sum du byas te mchod pa dang / sangs rgyas 'jig rten du mi bzhugs pa'i dus na de bzhin gshegs pa rnams la yid kyis dmigs te sku gzugs ri mo mchod rten la sogs pa mdun du byas te mchod pa byed pa ni mngon sum min par mchod pa rnam pa gnyis so/ /

The attitude with which offerings are made is one of very clear faith. The purpose is to complete the two accumulations. The field to which offerings are made is the buddhas. The offerings are Dharma robes, alms bowls, parasols, victory banners, flowers, and so forth (“and so forth” also includes such things as serving the buddhas and listening to the teachings)—in short, all kinds of things that can be offered. As to how these are offered, there are two ways. If it is at a time when a buddha’s supreme nirmāṇakāya manifestation has appeared in the world, one makes the offering to the Buddha in person. At times when the Buddha is not present in the world, one imagines the tathāgatas before one, and in front of a statue, painting, or stūpa one makes the offerings to them in one’s imagination.
sangs rgyas 'byung ba don yod par/ / smon lam dang ni ldan pa yi/ / gsum po dmigs par mi byed pa/ / sangs rgyas mchod pa rdzogs pa yin/ /
The offering of one who has made the prayer That the coming of the Buddha be beneficial, Offered without conceptualizing the three spheres, Is a complete offering to the Buddha. (XVIII, 2)

sangs rgyas 'jig rten du 'byung ba dang phrad nas mchod pa byed cing mnyes par byed pa'i sgo nas bdag dang sems can rnams la don yod par gyur cig ces smon lam dang ni ldan pa yi/ zhing sangs rgyas dang mchod pa po bdag dang / mchod pa'i rdzas gsum po de dang de'i mtshan mar dmigs par mi byed pa de ni sangs rgyas mchod pa yongs su rdzogs pa yin te/ phyogs bcu'i sangs rgyas rnams mngon sum byas nas mchod pa tshad med pas dus rtag tu bdag dang sems can thams cad kyi tshogs gnyis rdzogs pa'i phyir mchod par gyur cig ces smon pa dang / don dam par mchod pa'i 'khor gsum mi dmigs pa'i ngang nas mchod na mchod pa nyid tshul bzhin yongs su rdzogs pa zhes bya'o/ /

The offering of someone who has made the prayer that the Buddha will appear in the world; that one will meet him, make offerings to him, and please him; and that doing so will be meaningful for oneself and sentient beings, and all this without conceptualizing the field (the Buddha), the offerer (oneself), or the things being offered as having attributes, is a perfect and complete offering to the Buddha. If one makes an offering having prayed that one may always make boundless offerings directly to the buddhas of the ten directions in order to complete the two accumulations for oneself and all sentient beings, and in the state of mind that in ultimate truth is free of the concepts of the three spheres of offering, that offering is properly termed “complete.”

sems can dag ni tshad med pa/ / yongs su smin par byed pa gzhan/ / rdzas dang sems kyi sgo nas gzhan/ / mos pa dang ni smon pa dang / / brtse dang bzod pa dag dang ni/ / yang dag spyod pa'i sgo dang ni/ / gzhi la gtod dang rtogs pa dang / / grol dang de bzhin nyid kyis gzhan/ /

The different kinds of offerings include Bringing to maturity limitless sentient beings, Offering material things, and making offerings with the mind: Devotion, aspiration, (XVIII, 3) Compassion, patient forbearance, Correct practice, Focusing on the basics, realization, Liberation, and also suchness. (XVIII, 4)

mchod pa'i dbye ba la sems can dag ni tshad med pa yongs su smin par byed pa ni sangs rgyas mchod pa'i rnam grangs gcig ste sems can la phan btags pa ni de bzhin gshegs pa dgyes pa'i mchod pa mchog yin no/ / de yang sems can rnams kyi rgyud la sangs rgyas mchod pa'i bsam pa bskyed cing mchod pa'i las byed du 'jug pa sogs gtso bor gyur pa'i chos bshad de smin par byed cing de nyid de bzhin gshegs pa dgyes pa'i mchod par dmigs te phul ba'o/ /

With regard to the different categories of offering, one kind of offering to the buddhas is to bring infinite sentient beings to full maturation. To benefit sentient beings in this way is the best kind of offering that pleases the tathāgatas. In this case, one imagines that giving beings teachings particularly to arouse in their minds the wish to make offerings to the buddhas and induce them to do so, thus bringing them to maturity, is an offering that pleases the tathāgatas, and one offers it as such.

yang rdzas kyi sgo nas mchod pa chos gos dang me tog sogs kyi dngos po'i rdzas sna tshogs kyis mchod pa dang / rdzas la mi ltos par sems kyi sgo nas mchod pa yang gzhan de rnam grangs gnyis so/ / sems kyi mchod pa de la dbye na mos pa nas de bzhin nyid kyi bar dgu ste/ dang po mos pa ni sems kyis sangs rgyas la dmigs nas dang ba bskyed de bdag pos ma bzung ba dang bzung ba'i 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i mchod pa thams cad phul bar mos pa sems kyi sgo nas mchod pa yin mod kyang / skabs 'dir/ mos pa dang / bsam pa dang / dbang 'byor ba gsum du gsungs pa'i/ dang po de bzhin gshegs pa mchod pa'i chos ston pa'i theg pa chen po'i mdo yi don la mos pa de yang sems kyi mchod pa yin la/

Another two categories, in terms of what is offered, comprise on the one hand offerings of a variety of material offerings such as Dharma robes and flowers, and on the other hand immaterial, mental offerings. Mental offerings are of nine kinds, from devotion to suchness, as follows: (1) Devotion.[1] Although devotion—that is, thinking of the buddhas, developing clear faith, and imagining that one is offering every kind of offering (those that are owned, those with no owner, mundane, and supramundane)—is a mental offering, it is taught in this context as being three things: interest, mental state, and mastery. Interest refers to interest in the Mahāyāna sūtras that show how to make offerings to the tathāgatas. This is also a mental offering.

bsam pa ni/ ro myong ba dang / rjes su yi rangs ba dang / mngon par dga' ba dang / chog mi shes pa dang / rgya che ba dang / dga' ba dang / phan 'dogs pa dang / nyon mongs pa med pa dang / dge ba'i bsam pa dgu ste/ 'di dag kyang sems kyi mchod pa'o/ / de yang rang gi sngon mchod pa byas pa dran pa dang da ltar gyi mchod pa legs snyam du ro myang bya dang / gzhan gyi mchod pa la rjes su yi rang ba dang / rang gzhan gnyis kas ma 'ongs par mchod pa byed pa la mngon par dga' ba dang / mchod pa'i dngos po dang / mchod yul dang dus nyi tshe ba min pa tshad med pas chog mi shes pa dang / mchod pa rgyun mi 'chad par byang chub snying po la thug gi bar du byed 'dod pa dus chad pa med pa rgya che ba'i bsam pa dang / mchod pas smin par bya ba'i zhing sems can thams cad la byams shing dga' ba dang / mchod pa des sems can thams cad la phan btags par 'dod pa dang / chags pa nga rgyal sogs med cing zag bcas kyi 'bras bu mi 'dod pas nyon mongs pa med pa/ mchod pa des sems can thams cad bla med byang chub kyi 'bras bu thob par bsngo ba dge ba'i bsam pa'o/ /

Mental state has nine aspects: appreciation, rejoicing, delight, absence of complacency, vastness, joy, beneficence, freedom from defilements, and virtuous attitude. All these are also mental offerings. They are to savor the offerings one remembers having made in the past and those one is making at present, thinking how good they are; to rejoice in the offerings others make; to feel delighted at the offerings that both oneself and others will make in the future; to never be satisfied, even with unlimited offerings made to infinite objects over infinite periods of time; the vast, ceaseless attitude of the desire to make offerings uninterruptedly until one reaches the heart of enlightenment; love and joy with regard to all sentient beings, who are the field to be brought to maturity by making offerings; a desire to benefit all beings with one’s offerings; freedom from defilements in being without attachment, pride, and so on, and not wishing for a tainted result;[2] and a virtuous attitude, which is to dedicate the offering so that all sentient beings attain the result, unsurpassable enlightenment.
gsum pa dbang 'byor ba ni/ nam 'kha' mdzod kyi ting nge 'dzin sogs la brten nas de bzhin gshegs pa rnams mchod pa ste 'di yang sems kyi sgo nas mchod pa'o/ /
Third, mastery is to make offerings to the tathāgatas making use of such means as the Sky Treasury concentration. This too is an offering made with the mind.

smon pa ni bla med byang chub tu sems bskyed nas tshe rabs gar skyes kyang rang dang gzhan la phan pa bsgrub pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams mchod pa tshad med pas mchod par gyur cig ces smon lam btab pa 'di yang sems kyi sgo nas mchod pa'o/ / 'di la brten pa zhes kyang zer ro/ /

(2) Aspiration refers to arousing the mind intent on unsurpassable enlightenment and praying that in all one’s lives, wherever one is reborn, one will benefit oneself and others and make infinite offerings to the tathāgatas. This too is a mental offering. It is also referred to as “dependence.”[3]
sems can rnams kyi sdug bsngal bsal bar 'dod pa'i snying brtse bar byas pa des kyang de bzhin gshegs pa mchod par 'gyur ba dang /
(3) Compassion for sentient beings, that is, wanting to remove their sufferings, also becomes an offering to the tathāgatas.
bdag dang sems can yongs su smin pa'i phyir tsha grang bkres skom ngal dub sogs sdug bsngal dang du len pa'i bzod pa yang de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pa yin pa dag dang /
(4) Forbearance in willingly accepting difficulties such as heat and cold, hunger and thirst, and fatigue in order to bring oneself and beings to maturity is also an offering to the tathāgatas.
pha rol tu phyin pa drug la yang dag par spyod pa'i sgo ni sangs rgyas mchod pa yin pa dang ni/
(5) Correctly practicing the six transcendent perfections is a means for making offerings to the buddhas.
tshul bzhin yid la byed pa'i gzhi mi rtag sdug bsngal stong pa bdag med kyi don la yid gtod de dngos po rnams rnam par dpyod pa yang sangs rgyas mchod pa yin pa dang /
(6) Focusing on impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self, which are the basic points to be properly kept in mind, and analyzing things is also an offering to the buddhas.
sa dang po thob nas dngos po'i chos nyid khong du chud pa bdag med gnyis mngon sum rtogs pa'i yang dag pa'i lta ba skyes pa yang sangs rgyas mchod pa yin pa dang /

(7) Once one has attained the first bodhisattva level, understanding the true nature of phenomena and giving rise to the correct view, which is the direct realization of the two kinds of no-self, is also an offering to the buddhas.
nyan thos rnams nyon sgrib las rnam par grol ba de yang nyan thos rnams kyis sangs rgyas la mchod pa yin pa dang /
(8) Listeners are completely freed of the obscurations of defilements, and that liberation is the listeners’ offering to the buddhas.

byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis sa dang phar phyin rnams rim gyis grub pas sangs rgyas la mchod pa byas pa'i mthar sgrib gnyis spangs pa'i de bzhin nyid kyis bla na med pa'i byang chub thob pa yang sangs rgyas la mchod pa ste

(9) After making offerings to the buddhas by gradually accomplishing the levels and transcendent perfections, bodhisattvas finally attain suchness, the elimination of both kinds of obscurations, and thereby attain unsurpassable enlightenment. This too is an offering to the buddhas.
de ltar sems kyi mchod pa'i rnam grangs gzhan dgu'o/ /yang mchod pa'i don gyi rnam par dbye ba rnam pa brgyad ni/
These, then, are nine different kinds of mental offerings. Next, there are eight different points that apply to making offerings:
rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rten dang dngos dang rgyu dang ni/ / ye shes dang ni zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi mchod pa rab bstan pa/ /
Offering has been explained In terms of the reason, dedication, Support, substance, cause, Gnosis, fields, and location. (XVIII, 5)

rgyu mtshan ni yon tan thams cad kyi mthar thug pa sangs rgyas ni mchod pa'i zhing gi dam par dmigs pa'i rab tu dang ba'i dad pa dang / mchod pa'i rnam smin tshogs gnyis yongs su rdzogs te bla med byang chub 'thob pa'i phyir yongs su bsngo ba dang / rten nam gzhi ni mchod pa'i yul sangs rgyas rnams dang / mchod pa'i dngos po rdzas dang sems kyi mchod pa sna tshogs pa'o/ /

(1) The reason one makes offerings is perfectly clear faith—that one considers that the Buddha, who is the consummation of all excellent qualities, is the supreme field of offering. (2) The fully ripened effect of making offerings is the completion of the two accumulations, that is, the attainment of unsurpassable enlightenment, to which one’s offerings are entirely dedicated. (3) The support or basis is the buddhas, who are the object of offering. (4) The things offered are the various kinds of material and mental offerings.

rgyu ni sangs rgyas 'byung ba dang phrad nas mchod pa byed par smon lam btab pa dang / ye shes ni mchod pa'i 'khor gsum mi dmigs pa dang ni/ gang gi ched du bya ba sems can tshad med pa yongs su smin par bya ba'i phyir mchod pa byed pa yin pas zhing ni sems can dag dang / gnas kyi mchod pa ni rdzas kyi dngos po la gnas nas mchod pa/ sems la gnas nas mchod pa ste de gnyis ka gnas su bshad/ 'o na dngos po dang gnas gnyis la khyad ci yod snyam na/ sems la gnas pa'i mos pa la sogs pa de lta bu dang ldan pa'i gang zag kyang shugs kyis bstan pas khyad par yod dam snyam/

(5) The cause that leads one to make offerings is that one has prayed that one will coincide with the coming of a buddha and be able to make offerings to him. (6) Gnosis refers to the absence of concepts of the three spheres of offering. (7) The fields are sentient beings, for one makes the offering in order to bring countless sentient beings to maturity. (8) The location refers to both the material location and the location in the mind. If you were to ask what is the difference between the thing and its location, I think the difference is that it implicitly also indicates the individual who possesses devotion and so forth, which is located in the mind.[4]
de ltar rnam grangs brgyad po 'dis gong gi tshigs bcad bzhi po'i don bsdus nas rnam pa brgyad po der rab tu bstan pa yin no/ /
These eight points encompass the subjects of the four previous verses, in which the eight aspects have been explained.

rgyu dang 'bras bu nyid dang ni/ / bdag nyid dang ni gzhan dag dang / / rnyed dang bkur sti nyid dang ni/ / sgrub pa'i sgo nas de rnam gnyis/ / mchod pa chung dang chen po de/ / nga rgyal bcas dang nga rgyal med/ / sbyor dang 'gro ba nyid dang ni/ / smon pa'i sgo nas der 'dod do/ /

gzhan yang mchod pa'i dbye ba la/ sngon mchod pa byas pa rgyu dang / da ltar mchod pa byed pa 'bras bu dang / da lta mchod pa rgyu/ ma 'ongs par mchod pa byed pa 'bras bu ste/ rgyu mthun pa'i dbang gis de ltar rgyu 'bras su gyur pa dus gsum gyi mchod pa nyid du rnam par bzhag pa dang ni bdag nyid kyi lus dang yan lag 'bul ba dang / chos nyan pa dang sems pa sogs bdag nyid kyi mchod pa'am nang gi mchod pa dang / gzhan dag la mchod pa byed du bcug pa dang / rang gi rdzas chos gos sogs mchod pa ni gzhan gyi mchod pa'am phyi'i mchod pa dag dang / rnyed pa chos gos dang bsod snyoms mal cha sogs kyis mchod pa dang / phyag bya ba dang thal mo sbyar ba dang / bsu zhing ldang ba dang bstod pa byed pa sogs bkur sti'i mchod pa de gnyis ni mchod pa chung ngu'am rags pa nyid dang ni/ dam pa'i chos nyan bsam sgom pa'i tshul gyis sgrub pa'i sgo nas mchod pa ni mchod pa chen po'am phra ba zhes bya ste de ltar rnam pa gnyis so/ / sgrub pa de la'ang theg pa chung ngu'i sgrub pa ni mchod pa chung ba'am dman pa dang / theg chen sgrub pa ni mchod pa chen po'am gya noms pa de gnyis so/ / tshig rkang 'di tshig rkang snga ma'i don dang sbyar ba las sger du bshad pa med pa'ang snang / mchod pa'i 'khor gsum mi dmigs pa'i ye shes kyis ma zin pa'i mchod pa nga rgyal dang bcas pa dang / mi rtog ye shes kyis zin pa nga rgyal med pa'i mchod pa'o/ / de gnyis la mchod pa tha ma dang mchog gi tha snyad kyang byed do/ /

There are a number of other ways of classifying offerings. In terms of the effect similar to the cause (the offerings one has made in the past being the cause that has resulted in one’s making offerings now, and the offerings one is making at present being the cause that will result in one’s making offerings in the future), such causal and resultant offerings are classified as past, present, and future offerings. Offering one’s own body and limbs, and listening to the teachings, reflecting on them, and so on, constitute the offering of oneself, or internal offerings. Inducing others to make offerings and offering one’s own material belongings such as Dharma robes constitute the offering of others, or external offerings. Offerings of things one has acquired (Dharma robes, alms, bedding, and so forth) and offerings of veneration (prostrations, folding one’s hands in prayer, welcoming one’s teacher, standing up in the teacher’s presence, singing praises, and so on) are both lesser or gross offerings, while the offerings of practicing the sacred Dharma by listening, reflecting, and meditating are termed greater or subtle offerings, thus making two categories. Practice is again twofold: practice in the Lesser Vehicle, which is a lesser or inferior offering, and practice of the Great Vehicle, which is a greater or superior offering. Apart from the fact that this line is associated with the previous line, there does not appear to be a specific explanation for it. Offerings that are not imbued with the gnosis free from the concepts of the three spheres of offering are offerings with pride. Those that are imbued with nonconceptual gnosis are free of pride. These two are also termed least and best offerings.

sbyor dang zhes sbyor bas mchod pa la'ang rnam pa gnyis te/ dus gzhan phyis zhig na mchod par sbyor ba ni thag ring ba'i mchod pa dang / dus de nyid kyi tshe'am dran pa na mchod par sbyor ba ni/ nye ba'i mchod pa'o/ / de bzhin du 'gro bas mchod pa'ang rnam pa gnyis te/ 'gro ba chad nas mchod pa tshe rabs gnyis sam mang pos bar du mchod pa/ chad nas phyis mchod pa dang / de ma thag tu mchod pa ni gang du skyes kyang de ma thag nas mchod pa ste nye ring gnyis dang / smon pa'i sgo nas tshe 'di la mchod par smon pa dang / tshe rabs kun tu mchod par smon pa'i sgo nas kyang nye ring gnyis po der 'dod do/ /

“Application” refers to the actual deed of offering, for which there are two kinds: offerings that are actually made at some other, later time, which are distant offerings, and offerings that are carried out at that very moment or when one thinks of doing so, which are proximate offerings. Similarly, offerings made in terms of transmigration are also of two kinds, distant and proximate—that is, offerings that are made at a later time, having been interrupted by two or many more lives after one has died, and offerings that are made immediately wherever one is reborn. Offerings are also held to be of two kinds, proximate and distant, in terms of aspiration: one can aspire to make offerings in this life or aspire to do so throughout one’s series of lives.
rang gi sems kyis sangs rgyas rnams mchod pa/ / chos la mos dang bsam dang dbang 'byor dang / / rnam par mi rtog thabs yongs bzung ba dang / / kun dang don gcig nyid la 'jug pas mchog /

Offerings made to the buddhas mentally are best, That is, with interest in the Dharma, the right mental state, and mastery, Supported by nonconceptual means, And in a single identity with all. (XVIII, 8)
zhes pas bstan te/

mchod pa mchog tu gyur pa'i khyad par ni/ dmigs pa theg pa chen po'i chos la mos pa dang / bsam pa ro myang ba dang / rjes su yi rangs nas/ dge ba'i bar dgu la gnas pa dang / nam mkha' mdzod la sogs pa'i ting nge 'dzin thob pas mchod pa la dbang 'byor pa dang / 'khor gsum du rnam par mi rtog pa'i thabs yongs su bzung ba dang / sa brgyad pa nas mi rtog ye shes rtsol med lhan gyis grub pas de'i tshe byang sems gcig gis mchod pa byas pa der sa der zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyis kyang don gcig tu 'dres pa'i tshul gyis mchod pa de byas pa yin pas/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag kun dang don gcig la 'jug pas 'jig rten nyan rang dang bcas pa'i mchod pa las mchog tu gyur pa yin no/ /

The best kinds of offering are distinguished by the following features: devoted interest, whose object is the teachings of the Great Vehicle; the nine aspects of the mental state that is maintained, from savoring and rejoicing through to the virtuous attitude; mastery in making offerings through having attained concentrations such as the Sky Treasury concentration; the fully embraced skillful means of remaining free of the concepts of the three spheres; and the fact that from the eighth level onward, because of their spontaneous, effortless nonconceptual gnosis, the offerings made at that time by a single bodhisattva are offered in the same manner, indistinguishable from those of all the bodhisattvas on that level, and are equivalent to those of all bodhisattvas. It is on account of these features that bodhisattvas’ offerings are the best compared to the offerings of mundane beings and listeners and solitary realizers.
gnyis pa
2. RELIANCE ON A SPIRITUAL MASTER
dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsten pa la/ bshes gnyen bsten pa'i tshul/ de yi dbye ba/ mchog gi khyad par bstan pa gsum las
Reliance on a spiritual master comprises three parts: (1) how to follow a spiritual master; (2) categories of doing so; and (3) the best way to follow a spiritual master.
dang po
a. HOW TO FOLLOW A SPIRITUAL MASTER[5]
['di] la/ mdor bstan/ rgyas bshad gnyis/
The first of these is divided into a brief introduction and a detailed explanation.
dang po mdor bstan ni/
i. BRIEF INTRODUCTION
bsten pa rten dang gzhi dang ni/ / rgyu mtshan dang ni yongs bsngo dang / / rgyu dang ye shes zhing dag dang / / gnas kyi sgo nas rab tu bstan/ /
Reliance has been taught in terms of The support, basics, specific points, Dedication, cause, gnosis, Fields, and state. (XVIII, 9)

ces pas bstan te/ bshes gnyen bsten pa la/ rten dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi mtshan nyid dang / gzhi'am dngos po ci lta bus sten pa dang / bsten pa'i rgyu mtshan dang / gang gi ched du yongs su bsngo ba dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsgrub pa'i rgyu dang / de las ye shes la mkhas pa dang / zhing snod bcud dag par bya ba dag dang / ci la gnas nas bsten pa'i gnas kyi sgo nas rab tu bstan pa brgyad do/ /

Following a spiritual master has been described in terms of eight aspects: the characteristics of the support, a spiritual master; the basic principles for following spiritual masters; specific points in relying on them; to what goal this is dedicated; the cause, which is to practice the spiritual master’s instructions; the gnosis and learning one gains from a spiritual master; the fields, the container and contents that are to be purified; and the state from which one follows a spiritual master.
dang po rten dge ba'i bshes gnyen ni/
ii. DETAILED EXPLANATION
bshes gnyen dul ba zhi zhing nyer zhi ba/ / yon tan lhag pa brtson bcas lung gis phyug / de nyid rab tu rtogs pa smra mkhas ldan/ / brtse ba'i bdag nyid skyo ba spangs la bsten/ /

Take as a teacher someone disciplined, peaceful, totally at peace, Possessed of superior qualities, diligence, and knowledge of the texts; Who has full realization, is skilled in explanation, Full of love, and indefatigable. (XVIII, 10)
zhes pas bstan te/

lhag pa tshul khrims kyi bslab pas rgyud bsdams pas dbang po dul ba/ lhag pa ting nge 'dzin gyi bslab pas nyon mongs dang rnam g.yeng zhi zhing / lhag pa shes rab kyi bslab pas nyon mongs dang rnam rtog nye bar zhi ba gang zhig bsten pa po rang las tshul khrims dang mang thos sogs kyi yon tan lhag pa bsten na dge ba'i skyed 'don gyi rang dang mnyam pa dang / dman pa bsten kyang dgos pa chung ngo / / bshes gnyen de yang gzhan la chos ston pa sogs kyi brtson pa dang bcas pa dang dam pa'i chos mang du thos pas lung gis phyug pa/ rtogs pa'i chos bden bzhi dang rten 'brel stong pa nyid sogs kyi de kho na nyid rab tu gtan la phab nas rtogs pa dang / ming tshig yi ge 'brel zhing gsal por gyur pa'i sgo nas chos smra ba la mkhas pa dang ldan pa/ gdul bya slob ma rnams la thugs brtse ba'i bdag nyid du gyur pa/ chos ston pa la mi mos pa dang / legs par mi ston pa dang / cung zad ston pa las rgyun du nan tan gyis mi ston pa lta bu'i skyo ngal spangs pa de lta bu la bsten par bya'o/ /

(1) Because spiritual masters, the supports on which one relies, have bound their mind streams with the training in superior discipline, their senses are controlled. They have pacified defilements and distractions with the training in superior concentration. They have completely pacified defilements and concepts with the training in superior wisdom. Their qualities such as discipline and learning are greater than one’s own (that is, the disciple’s), and if one relies on them, one will progress in virtue. (If, on the other hand, their qualities were the same as one’s own or even less, there would be little point in following them.) These spiritual masters are also diligent in such things as teaching others the Dharma, and, since they have heard many teachings on the sacred Dharma, they are richly endowed with the transmissions. As for their qualities of realization, they have conclusively ascertained and realized thatness in relation to the four truths, dependent arising, emptiness, and so on. They are skilled in teaching the Dharma, clearly and relevantly. They are loving toward their disciples and never tire of teaching—they avoid such faults as being disinclined to teach the Dharma, not teaching properly, and teaching a little but not always carefully. These are the kinds of spiritual masters one should rely on.
bkur sti rnyed pa dag dang rim gro dang / / sgrub pa'i sgo nas bshes gnyen bsten par bya/ / bsten gzhi de bzhin blo ldan chos la ni/ / shes bsam dus su 'dud pas bshes gnyen bgrod/ /

Follow the spiritual master with respect, With belongings, service, and practice. In accordance with those principles, the wise approach the spiritual master With a wish to know the Dharma, from time to time, respectfully. (XVIII, 11)
zhes pas bstan te/

gnyis pa ni/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen rnyed nas bstan pa'i gzhi ci lta bus bsten par bya na phyag 'tshal ba dang / bsu bskyal dang stan las ldang ba dang / 'dzum pa'i bzhin gyis dga' ba'i mig gis blta ba sogs lus kyi bkur sti dang / bstod pa byed pa dang / ci gsungs dang mthun par smra ba dang / byams shing gus pa'i tshig brjod pa sogs ngag gi bkur sti dang / sems kyis kun nas dang zhing dad pa byed pa ste/ sgo gsum gyi bkur sti'i sgo nas legs par bsten pa'o/ / rnyed pa ni chos gos dang mal cha la sogs pa rdzas gang mkho ba phul te bsten pa dag dang / rim gro byed pa ni/ lus bkru ba dang mnye ba sogs g.yog byed pa dang ji ltar 'os pa'i las su bya ba thams cad sgrub pa'i sgo nas bsten pa ni phyi'i dngos pos bsten tshul lo/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen des chos bstan pa bzhin mnyan pa dang bsam pa sgom pa'i tshul gyis chos la chos kyi rjes su sgrub pa'i sgo nas bshes gnyen bsten par bya ste sgrub pa'i sgo nas bsten pa 'di nang gi dngos pos bsten pa zhes bya'o/ / de ltar phyi dang nang gi dngos pos bshes gnyen bsten par bya ba ste/ bsten gzhi zhes bya ba yin no/ / gsum pa rgyu mtshan nam mtshan ma ni/ dge ba'i bshes la dad pas bsten pa de bzhin du blo ldan slob ma des mnyan par bya ba'i chos la ni/ brnyas pa dang chos rku ba'i bsam pa dang klan ka btsal ba lta bu'i bsam pa ngan pa spangs te/ chos de nyid kun nas shes par 'dod pa'i bsam pa bzhag pa dang / dus dus su dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi drung du 'gro zhing chos mnyan par bya ba ni bshes gnyen des bsam gtan byed pa dang / zas za ba sogs skabs su ma bab pa'i tshe na 'gro bar mi bya la skabs su bab pa'i dus dus su 'gro zhing chos mnyan par bya'o/ / de'i tshe lus sems dul ba'i spyod lam gyis gus shing 'dud pas bshes gnyen gyi drung du 'gro ba'am bgrod par bya'o/ / ma gus pa dang nga rgyal gyi spyod lam gyis nam yang ma yin no/ /

(2) Having found such spiritual masters, what are the basic principles for following them? Physical respect—prostrating to them, going to meet them or seeing them off, rising from one’s seat, looking at them smilingly, with joyful eyes, and so on. Verbal respect, which includes praising them, speaking in accordance with whatever they say, and expressing oneself lovingly and respectfully. And mentally, having completely clear devotion toward them. By respecting them with one’s body, speech, and mind in this way, one will follow them properly. “Belongings” refers to following them by offering them whatever things they need, like Dharma robes and bedding. “Service” refers to serving them by attending to them (washing them, massaging them, and so forth) and carrying out any tasks that are appropriate. These ways of following them[6] constitute the outer way of doing so. The inner way of following them is to do so through practice: practicing the Dharma correctly by listening, reflecting, and meditating in accordance with the teachings the spiritual masters have given. These outer and inner ways in which one should follow the spiritual master are what we call the “basic principles of reliance.” (3) Specific points. Knowing the specific points[7] and relying on a spiritual master with devotion, wise disciples should accordingly give up negative attitudes with regard to the teachings they are to receive—contempt, wanting to misappropriate the Dharma,[8] or seeking to criticize them—and they should adopt the attitude of wanting to really learn the Dharma. From time to time, they should go before the spiritual master and listen to the teachings, but not at inappropriate times such as when the spiritual master is meditating or taking a meal. When the moment is right, however, they should go into the master’s presence, conducting themselves in a subdued manner, physically and mentally, and bowing down respectfully. They should never behave disrespectfully or arrogantly.
de ni bsnyen bkur rnyed la 'dod pa med/ / bsgrub par bya phyir de yongs sngo bar byed/ / brtan pa ji skad bstan pa sgrub pa des/ / de yi sems ni yang dag mgu bar byed/ /

With no desire for veneration and wealth, They dedicate their reliance for the sake of accomplishment. The steadfast practice all that they’ve been taught, And that is what makes the master truly pleased. (XVIII, 12)
ces pas bstan te/

bzhi pa yongs bsngo ni/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsten pa de don gang / gi phyir bsngo ba'am/ gang gi ched du bsams nas 'jug pa yin zhe na/ de ltar dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsten pa ni/ mkhas pa'am grags par gyur pa'i gang zag 'di la bsten na rang yang mkhas pa dang grags par gyur nas gzhan gyis bsnyen bkur dang rnyed pa 'byung ngo snyam du bsam pas yongs su bcings pa'am de'i don du bsngo ba la 'dod pa med par/ bslab pa gsum gyi chos dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis ji skad bstan pa ltar snying thag pa nas bsgrub par bya ba'i phyir dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsten pa de/ bdag gis 'di bsten nas chos nyan sems sgom pas 'phags pa'i lam bsgrub cing chos nyid kyi don rtogs par gyur cig ces blo'i 'phen pa des don de'i ched du yongs su bsngo bar byed do/ / lnga pa rgyu ni/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi thugs mgu ba ni chos ston par byed cing bsten pa don yod pa'i rgyu yin pas/ blo'i ngang tshul brtan pa slob ma bzang po/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis ji skad bstan pa bzhin du nyams su len zhing sgrub pa des/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen de yi sems ni yang dag par mgu bar byed do/ /

(4) Dedication. To what goal is following a spiritual master dedicated, or for what purpose does one think of following a master and actually do so? One’s following a spiritual master as described above should be free from desire—from being fixed on the idea that if one follows this person who is learned or famous, one will also become learned and famous oneself and be venerated by others and grow rich, or from the desire to dedicate one’s following the spiritual master to that goal. Rather, one should follow one’s spiritual masters in order to sincerely practice the three trainings in accordance with their instructions. With the determined wish, “May I follow them and, by listening to their teachings, reflecting on them, and meditating, may I accomplish the path of the noble beings and realize the meaning of ultimate reality,” one dedicates one’s reliance to that goal. (5) Cause. The fact of the spiritual masters’ being pleased is the causal factor that leads them to teach the Dharma and makes relying on them worthwhile. For this reason, a good disciple of stable character puts all the spiritual master’s instructions into practice and accomplishes them. This is what truly delights the spiritual masters.
theg pa gsum la mkhas pa blos rtogs nas/ / rang gi theg pa bsgrub par bya phyir 'bad/ / sems can tshad med yongs smin bya phyir dang / / zhing dag pa yang sbyang bar bya ba'i phyir/ /

Having become learned in the three vehicles and having realized them, They strive hard to accomplish their own vehicle. The purpose is to ripen countless beings, And as well to train in pure fields. (XVIII, 13)
zhes pas bstan te/

drug pa ye shes ni/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen las chos thos pas nyan rang byang sems kyi theg pa gsum la mkhas pa nyid du gyur nas rang blos theg pa gsum gyi don rtogs pa ni dge ba'i bshes gnyen la brten nas ye shes rnyed pa'o/ / de ltar theg pa gsum la mkhas par gyur nas/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams nyan rang gi theg pa mi sgrub kyi/ rang gi theg pa ni theg pa chen po ste/ rang gzhan gnyis kyi don sgrub cing 'bras bu byang chub chen po 'thob pa nyid bsgrub par bya ba'i phyir 'bad par byed do/ / bdun pa zhing dag pa ni/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsten nas nang bcud kyi sems can yongs su dag par bya ba'i phyir chos nyan pa sogs kyis sems can tshad med pa yongs su smin par bya ba'i phyir dang / phyi snod kyi 'jig rten yongs su dag par bya ba'i phyir/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing rin po che'i sa gzhi dang dpag bsam gyi shing dang bdud rtsi'i chu klung la sogs pa'i rgyan phun sum tshogs pa dang ldan pa'i zhing rnam par dag pa yongs su sbyang bar bya ba'i phyir bshes gnyen bsten te chos nyan pa yin no/ /

(6) Gnosis. By hearing the Dharma from a spiritual master, one becomes learned in the three vehicles of the listeners, solitary realizers, and bodhisattvas and gains realization of the three vehicles oneself. This is the gnosis one acquires in dependence on the spiritual master. Having thus become learned in the three vehicles, bodhisattvas practice not the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ vehicles but their own vehicle, the Great Vehicle, exerting themselves in order to achieve their own and others’ goals and to accomplish the result, the attainment of great enlightenment. (7) Pure fields. It is from relying on a spiritual master that, in order to purify the beings or inner contents, one brings to full maturity limitless numbers of sentient beings by such means as listening to the Dharma; and that, in order to purify the universe or outer container, one trains in pure fields—buddha fields endowed with the ground of jewels, wish-fulfilling trees, rivers of nectar, and similar features of eternal perfection. It is for these purposes that one follows spiritual masters and listens to their teachings.
de chos bgo skal la spyod yon tan ldan/ / bshes gnyen rab tu bsten bya zang zing min/ /
They should rely fully on a spiritual master in order to possess the qualities For enjoying their share of the Dharma and not material gain. (XVIII, 14ab)
ces pas bstan te/

brgyad pa gnas ni/ yid la byed pa gang la gnas pa ste/ 'di ltar pha ma'am phu nu sogs kyi spyi nor de so sor bgos pa'i tshe so so rang gi skal ba nga la 'di mkho zhes ched du len pa ltar/ byang chub sems dpa' de dam pa'i chos kyi bgo skal la spyod pa'i yon tan dang ldan pa'i phyir bshes gnyen rab tu bsten par bya yi/ zang zing gi bgo skal la longs spyod pa'i phyir min te/ byang chub sems dpa' zang zing gis bsdus pa na yang kha cig chos gtso bor mi byed kyi zang zing gi ngor chos nyan pa de lta bu ma yin pa ni gnas kyi sgo nas so/ /

(8) “State” refers to the bodhisattvas’ state of mind—what they keep in mind. Like people who each take what they most need as their share when their parent’s or other relative’s wealth is distributed, bodhisattvas have the qualities for enjoying their share of the sacred Dharma, and in order to do so they have to rely completely on a spiritual master. This is not so that they can enjoy their material share: they may have been attracted to the teacher by material gifts, but they are not like some people who, instead of giving preeminence to the Dharma, listen to the teachings with material motives. This is on account of their state.
gnyis pa bsten pa de'i dbye ba ni/
b. CATEGORIES

blo dang ldan pa rgyu dang 'bras bu dang / / chos sgo rjes 'gro phyi dang thos mnyan dang / / sems kyi rnal 'byor nga rgyal bcas pa dang / / nga rgyal med yid ldan pas bshes gnyen bsten/ / blo ldan 'gro dang sbyor ba dang / / smon pa'i sgo nas bshes gnyen bsten/ /

The wise follow a spiritual master by cause and effect, In progressing from the door of Dharma and outwardly, (XVIII, 14cd) By listening and with the yoga of mind, And with pride and without. The wise follow a spiritual master in terms of transmigration, Application, and aspiration. (XVIII, 15)
zhes pas bstan te/

blo dang ldan pa des bshes gnyen bsten pa la ni rgyu dang 'bras bu dag gi dbye ba ni/ tshe rabs snga ma dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsten pa ni rgyu yin la/ da ltar bsten pa 'bras bu dang / da ltar bsten pa rgyu ma 'ongs pa'i tshe rabs rnams su bsten pa 'bras bu ste/ de ltar 'das pa dang da lta dang ma 'ongs par bshes gnyen bsten pa gsum dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsten nas de'i gdams ngag dang rjes su bstan pa bzhin bsgrubs pas chos kyi sgo'i ting nge 'dzin thob nas de'i rjes su 'gro ba'am/ de rtogs pa dang rjes su mthun par dge ba'i bshes gnyen sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' bsten pa ni nang gi bsten pa'o/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen rnyed pa sogs kyis bsten pa ni phyi yi bsten pa dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen las chos thos pa'i sgra la mnyan pa tsam gyis sgo nas bsten pa ni rags pa'am rtsing ba ste/ gzhan gyi sgra tsam la sems phyi rol du rgyu ba'i phyir ro/ / bsam pa dang sgom byung gi sems kyi rnal 'byor dang bcas pa ni phra ba'am zhib pa ste/ don la nang du sems pa'i phyir ro/ /

Reliance on a spiritual master by the wise is classified in terms of cause and effect as follows. Following a spiritual master in previous lives is the cause, of which doing so at present is the result. Following a teacher at present is the cause, of which doing so in future lives will be the result. These, then, are three categories of following a spiritual master: past, present, and future. By following spiritual masters and practicing their instructions and follow-up teachings, one acquires the concentration of the door of Dharma. Subsequently, one relies on a buddha or bodhisattva as a spiritual master to progress in that or to emulate those who have realized that. This is the inner aspect of reliance. Following a spiritual master with “belongings”[9] and so forth is the outer aspect of reliance. Following spiritual masters simply by listening to the teachings—that is, hearing the sound of the Dharma from them—is gross or coarse reliance, because the mind is being distracted by just another sound. Doing the mental practice of reflection and meditation is fine or subtle reliance, because the mind is inwardly focused on the meaning.

yang 'di la bdag gis bkur sti sogs kyis bsten te dngos zhen dang bcas pa ni nga rgyal dang bcas pa dman pa'o/ / bdag dang bshes gnyen bsten pa'i bya ba gsum gyi mtshan mar mi 'dzin pa ni nga rgyal med pa'i yid dang ldan pas bshes gnyen bsten pa zhes bya ste mchog go /

Again, to cling to the concept that one is a real person following a real spiritual master by offering real service and so forth involves reliance with pride, which is the inferior kind of reliance. To be free of the concepts of attributes in oneself, a spiritual master, and the act of reliance is what we call “relying on a spiritual master with a mind free of pride,” which is the best kind of reliance.

blo ldan des bshes gnyen bsten pa la 'gro ba'i sgo nas thag nye ring gnyis dang sbyor ba'i sgo nas de gnyis dang / smon pa'i sgo nas de gnyis te bshes gnyen bsten pa'i dbye ba drug yod do/ / de gang zhe na/ tshe 'di'i 'gro bas bsten pa ni thag nye ba'o/ / tshe rabs du mas 'gro bas bar chod nas gzod bsten pa ring ba'o/ / sbyor bas ni tshe 'di la'ang dus gzhan phyis zhig na bsten pa'am tshe rabs gzhan du'ang de ma thag par bsten pa min par tshe rabs du mas bar chod nas bsten par sbyor ba thag ring la tshe 'di la da lta nyid du bsten par sbyor ba dang tshe rabs phyi ma nyid du bsten par sbyor ba ni thag nye ba'o/ / smon pa yang de bzhin du/ tshe 'di nyid la bsten par smon lam 'debs shing bsten pa thag nye la/ tshe rabs phyi mar bsten par smon pa ni thag ring ba'o/ / 'di gsum rten dang sbyor ba lag len dang bsam pas smon pa shugs drag zhan gyi dbye ba tsam mo/ /

When the wise follow spiritual masters, there are two categories related to distance in terms of transmigration, two in terms of application, and two in terms of aspiration, making six categories of reliance on spiritual masters. What are these? Following spiritual masters in this life is proximate reliance. Following them after an interruption of many successive lives is distant reliance. In terms of application, when one follows a spiritual master in this life but at another, later time, or when one does so in other lives but not immediately, after an interruption of several successive lives, one’s application in following the spiritual master is distant. On the other hand, application in following the master now, in this life, and in the very next life, is proximate. The same holds true for one’s aspiration: reliance with the prayer that one will follow a master in this very life is proximate, while the prayer that one will follow a master in future lives is distant. These three pairs of categories are simply classifications of the strength or weakness of one’s rebirth,[10] of one’s application or practice, and of one’s aspiration or intention.
gsum pa bsten pa mchog ni/
c. THE BEST WAY TO FOLLOW A SPIRITUAL MASTER
rang gi sems kyis bshes gnyen mchog bsten pa/ / chos la mos dang bsam dang dbang 'byor dang / / rnam par mi rtog thabs yongs bzung ba dang / / kun dang don gcig nyid la 'jug pas mchog /

Following the sublime spiritual master mentally is best— That is, with interest in the Dharma, the right mental state, and mastery, Supported by nonconceptual means, And in a single identity with all. (XVIII, 16)
ces pas bstan te/

rang gi sems kyis bshes gnyen mchog bsten pa la ni/ theg pa chen po'i chos la mos pa'i sgo nas bsten pa dang / bsam pa dgu gong du bshad pa bzhin bsten pa la sbyar te shes par bya ba dang / dbang 'byor ni ting nge 'dzin la dbang thob pa'i sgo nas bsten pa ste/ nam mkha' mdzod kyi ting nge 'dzin gyis longs spyod tshad med pa phul te bsten pa dang / gzungs kyis tshig dang don mi brjed par 'dzin pa sogs kyi sgo nas so/ / rnam par mi rtog pa'i thabs yongs su bzung ba dang / sa brgyad pa yan chad byang chub sems dpa' de kun mdzad pa gcig tu 'dres nas kun dang don gcig nyid la 'jug pa ste rnam grangs lnga po 'di'i gang yang rung ba dang ldan pa na yang bsten pa gzhan las mchog tu gyur pa'o/ /

The best way to rely on one’s spiritual masters is mentally, and for this there are five aspects: following them with interest in the teachings of the Great Vehicle; following them with the nine kinds of mental state explained above, which you should know and adapt accordingly;[11] following them with mastery, that is, by having attained mastery in concentration and offering limitless riches with the Sky Treasury concentration, and by unforgettingly retaining the words and their meanings through the power of memory; being completely imbued with nonconceptual methods; and, from the eighth level onward, engaging in following one’s masters in a manner indistinguishable from and equivalent to that of all the bodhisattvas. Whichever of these five aspects one possesses, it will be superior to other ways of following a spiritual master.
gsum pa
3. MEDITATING ON THE FOUR BOUNDLESS ATTITUDES
tshad med bzhi la/ tshad med bzhi bshad pa dang / snying rje bye brag tu bshad pa gnyis/
Meditating on the four boundless attitudes is divided into two parts: (1) an explanation of the four boundless attitudes and (2) a specific explanation of compassion.
dang po
a. EXPLANATION OF THE FOUR BOUNDLESS ATTITUDES
['di] la ngo bo dang / dmigs pa dang / dbye ba dang / 'bras bu dang / mi mthun phyogs dang / yon tan bstan pa ste rnam grangs drug gis bstan pa las/
The first of these is divided into six: (1) essence; (2) objects; (3) categories; (4) result; (5) countering factors; and (6) good qualities.
dang po ni/
i. ESSENCE
brtan pa'i tshangs pa mi mthun spangs/ / rnam par mi rtog ye shes ldan/ / dmigs pa rnam pa gsum la 'jug / sems can rnams ni yongs smin byed/ /
The pure states of the steadfast have abandoned countering agents, Are endowed with nonconceptual gnosis, Are applied to three kinds of objects, And bring sentient beings to maturity. (XVIII, 17)
ces pas bstan te/

byang chub sems dpa'i tshad med pa bzhi ni mtshan nyid bzhi dang ldan pa ste byang chub sems dpa' brtan pa'i rgyud kyi tshangs pa yi gnas pa byams snying rje dga' ba btang snyoms bzhi ni rim pa ltar byams sogs rang gi mi mthun phyogs gnod sems dang / rnam par 'tshe ba dang / mi dga' ba mang ba dang / chags sdang gis sems mi snyoms pa bzhi spangs pa dang / grogs rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes dang ldan pa dang / dmigs pa sems can dang chos dang dmigs pa med pa gsum la 'jug pa dang / byed las sems can rnams yongs su mi gtong zhing yongs su smin par byed pa ste mtshan nyid bzhi dang ldan no/ /

A bodhisattva’s four boundless attitudes have four defining characteristics. The four pure states in the mind stream of a steadfast bodhisattva—love, compassion, joy, and impartiality—comprise the elimination of their four counteragents: respectively, malice, cruelty, displeasure, and a biased mind swayed by attachment and aversion. They are imbued with and accompanied by nonconceptual gnosis. They are practiced in three ways: with reference to sentient beings, with reference to phenomena, and with no reference. And their function is to bring sentient beings to full maturity without ever abandoning them. These are the four defining characteristics.

de yang byams pa'i sems kyis gnod sems spangs nas bde ba dang phrad 'dod dang po/ byams pa sgom pa po dang / yul sems can/ bsgom bya byams pa lta bu de dag gi 'khor gsum mi dmigs pa gnyis pa/ dmigs pa gsum la 'jug pa khyad par gsum pa ste/ so skye dang mu stegs rnams kyi byams pa ni bdag dang sems can yod par dmigs pa'i sems can la dmigs pa dang / nyan rang gi byams pa ni/ bdag dang sems can zhes bya ba gang yang med kyang phung po lnga du ma dang mi rtag pa dang sdug bsngal ba'i rang bzhin can gyi du ma'i chos tsam la dmigs nas byams par 'byung ba'o/ / byang sems sa la zhugs pa dang sangs rgyas kyi byams pa ni don dam par sems can dang chos su yang mi dmigs pa ste/ rang bzhin gyis stong pa nyid yin yang rang snang 'khrul pa'i sdug bsngal sgyu ma lta bu myong ba'i sems can rnams ngo bo stong par rtogs nas dmigs pa med bzhin sems can la phan 'dogs dpag tu med pa mdzad pa'o/ / de la sems can tsam la dmigs pa'i tshad med bzhi ni/ so skye dang mu stegs nyan rang byang sems sangs rgyas lnga'i thun mong ngo/ / chos la dmigs pa'i byams sogs ni/ nyan rang byang sems sangs rgyas bzhi'i thun mong ngo / / mi dmigs pa'i byams pa ni sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi thun mong ma yin pa zhes rnal 'byor spyod pa'i sa las bshad do/ /

In this regard, to rid oneself of malice with a loving attitude and to wish that beings meet with happiness is the first distinguishing quality. To be free of the concepts of the three spheres—concepts, for instance, of someone who is meditating on love, of beings as the object, and of the love one is meditating on—is the second distinguishing quality. Applying love to three objects as follows is the third distinguishing quality. Love in ordinary beings and tīrthikas focuses on sentient beings, considering that oneself and sentient beings exist. As for listeners’ and solitary realizers’ love, for them there is no such thing as a so-called self and sentient beings, but they focus on these as merely multiple phenomena, that is, on the five aggregates, whose nature is multiplicity, impermanence, and suffering, and they thence give rise to love. The love of bodhisattvas who have reached the bodhisattva levels and of the buddhas has no concept of beings and phenomena existing in ultimate truth. It is from the state of their realization that sentient beings are devoid of essence (and that despite everything being, by nature, emptiness, they are experiencing the illusion-like sufferings that are their own deluded perceptions) that they perform infinite benefit for beings nonconceptually. Of these different approaches, the four boundless attitudes[12] focused on just sentient beings are common to all five—ordinary people and tīrthikas, listeners, solitary realizers, bodhisattvas, and buddhas. Love and so forth focused on phenomena are common to four: listeners, solitary realizers, bodhisattvas, and buddhas. Nonconceptual love is the uncommon love of the buddhas and bodhisattvas. This is explained in Stages of Yogic Practice.

'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las/ thog mar sems bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi byams pa sems can la dmigs pa ste/ bdag med gnyis mngon sum ma rtogs pa'i phyir dang / sa dang po nas bdun pa'i bar gyi spyod pa la zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi chos la dmigs pa'i byams pa ste/ chos kyi dbyings rnam par dag pa la mngon sum dmigs pa'i phyir dang / sa brgyad pa yan chad mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa thob pa rnams kyi byams pa dmigs pa med pa ste/ mi rtog bzhin du 'bad rtsol med par byams pa 'byung ba'i phyir de ltar gsungs so/ /

In the Sūtra of the Teaching of Akṣayamati we read: The love of bodhisattvas who have first aroused bodhicitta focuses on sentient beings, because these bodhisattvas have not directly realized either of the two kinds of no-self. The love of bodhisattvas who are engaged in the activities of the first to seventh levels focuses on phenomena, because they have directly realized the perfectly pure expanse of reality. The love of those on the eighth level up, who have attained the acceptance that phenomena are unborn, is nonconceptual, because love arises effortlessly, without thought.
gnyis pa byams sogs bzhi'i dmigs pa ni/
ii. THE OBJECTS OF THE FOUR BOUNDLESS ATTITUDES
brtan pa rnams kyi de dag bde 'dod dang / / sdug bsngal gyis nyam thag dang bde ba dang / / nyon mongs can dang de dag bstan bcos dang / / de yi de bzhin nyid la rab tu 'jug /

These attitudes of the steadfast are applied to Those who wish for happiness, those tormented by suffering, Those who are happy, and those with defilements, And to the treatises on these, and to their suchness. (XVIII, 18)
zhes pas bstan te/

brtan pa byang sems rnams kyi byams sogs bzhi po de dag gi dmigs pa ni bde ba 'dod pa'i sems can la dmigs te/ byams pa ni sems can bde ba dang 'phrad par 'dod pa'i rnam pa dang / snying rje ni sdug bsngal gyis nyam thag pa la dmigs nas sdug bsngal dang bral bar 'dod pa'i rnam pa can no/ / dga' ba ni bde ba dang ldan pa'i sems can la dmigs te de dag bde ba dang mi 'bral ba'i rnam pa can dang / btang snyoms ni tshor ba bde ba dang phrad pa dang / mdza' ba sogs dang phrad nas 'dod chags skye ba dang / tshor ba sdug bsngal dang dgra sogs gang phrad nas zhe sdang ldang bar gyur pa'i nyon mongs pa can gyi sems can la dmigs te de dag la chags sdang skye bar ma gyur cig ces chags sdang med par btang snyoms su 'gyur bar 'dod pa'i rnam par can no/ / de rnams kyis sems can gyi ris gang dang gang la dmigs pa bstan to/ / chos la dmigs pa'i byams pas ni/ tshad med pa bzhi po de dag ston pa'i bstan bcos yang dag pa theg pa chen po'i mdo sde la dmigs nas dmigs yul de dag 'du byed pa'i chos tsam gyi mtshan nyid du dmigs so/ / dmigs med kyi byams pas ni/ dmigs yul sems can bzhi dang theg chen chos de yi de bzhin nyid gzung 'dzin gnyis kyis stong pa la dmigs nas rab tu 'jug go /

The objects on which steadfast bodhisattvas focus with the four boundless attitudes are as follows. Focusing on sentient beings who want to be happy, their love takes the form of wishing that beings will meet with happiness. Their compassion focuses on beings tormented by suffering and takes the form of wishing that they will be free from suffering. Their joy focuses on sentient beings who are happy, and it takes the form of wishing that they will never separate from their happiness. And their impartiality focuses on sentient beings with defilements who, when they encounter pleasant feelings or friends, give rise to attachment, and when they encounter painful feelings or enemies, give rise to aversion; it takes the form of wishing that they may become even-minded, without attachment or aversion: “May attachment and aversion not arise in them.” These lines indicate the different kinds of beings on which bodhisattvas focus. Love focused on phenomena focuses on the sūtras of the Great Vehicle, which are the authentic scriptures that teach the four boundless attitudes, and thinks of those objects as simply productive entities.[13] Nonconceptual love focuses on and is applied to the suchness (that is, the emptiness devoid of the duality of subject and object) of its object—the above four kinds of beings and the Mahāyāna teachings.
de don de bzhin nyid phyir dang / / zhi ba thob pas dag phyir dang / / las gnyis nyon mongs zad pa'i phyir/ / byams pa dmigs pa med pa yin/ /
It is because of suchness that love is nonconceptual, And because of its purity through attaining peace, Because of the two kinds of action, And because defilements have been exhausted. (XVIII, 19)

dmigs pa med pa'i byams sogs de la don gyi dbye ba bzhi ste sems can dang chos rnams kyi de bzhin nyid la dmigs pa'i phyir mi dmigs pa'i byams pa zhes bya ste/ des bdag dang chos su dmigs pa'am phyi dang nang du dmigs pa med pa'i phyir dang / sa brgyad par mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa thob pa'i dus na rnam rtog dang 'bad rtsol nye bar zhi ba thob pas tshad med bzhi yi sa bon brtas pa mthar phyin nas 'bad rtsol dang rtog dpyod med par lhun gyis grub pas shin tu rnam par dag pa nyid du gyur pa'i phyir mi dmigs pa'i byams pa sogs su bzhag pa dang / byams pa'i lus kyi las dang ngag gi las gnyis ni byams pa'i rgyu mthun las byung ba yin yang gzugs kyi phung por gtogs phyir de dag la rtog pa med pas mi dmigs pa'i byams par bzhag pa dang / 'dod chags dang zhe sdang sogs nyon mongs pa rnams zad pa'i phyir 'phags pa rnams kyi byams pa ni dmigs pa med pa zhes bya ste/ nyon mongs pa rnams la sems kyi dmigs pa zhes bya ba ni/ yul la lhag par dmigs nas dam du 'dzin pa'i phyir mdo las kyang / sems kyi mdud pa spangs pa'i phyir dmigs pa chad do zhes gsungs pa ltar de lta bu'i dmigs pa med pa'i phyir yang byams sogs dmigs pa med pa'o/ / de ltar rgyu mtshan bzhi po de'i sgo nas byams pa dmigs pa med pa yin no/ /

Nonconceptual love and so on can mean four different things. Because it focuses on the suchness of sentient beings and the teachings, it is referred to as “nonconceptual love,” for it does not conceptualize them as self and phenomena or as outer and inner. On the eighth level, at the stage of attaining the acceptance that phenomena are unborn, bodhisattvas have obtained the complete pacification of conceptual thoughts and deliberate effort so that the seed of the four boundless attitudes has grown to its fullest extent and they happen spontaneously without effort or gross or subtle analysis. Because they have thus become perfectly pure, they are classified as nonconceptual boundless attitudes. Loving physical and verbal actions both originate from love, with which they are causally consistent, but because they are included in the aggregate of form,[14] they are devoid of thought, so they are classified as nonconceptual love. Because their attachment, aversion, and other defilements have been exhausted, the noble beings’ love is referred to as nonconceptual. Defilements are termed mental concepts because they focus excessively on their object and fixate on it. As it is said in the sūtras, “Because the knots in their minds have been eliminated, concepts have been annihilated.” So because they are devoid of such concepts, their love and other attitudes are nonconceptual. It is for these four reasons that love is nonconceptual.
gsum pa dbye ba ni/
iii. CATEGORIES
de dag g.yo dang mi g.yo dang / / chags pas ro myang min zhes bya/ / byang chub sems dpa' mi g.yo ba/ / chags dang bral bar rab tu gnas/ /
These attitudes are termed wavering, unwavering, Savored with attachment, and not savored. The attitudes of bodhisattvas remain Unwavering and free of attachment. (XVIII, 20)
ces pas bstan te/

byams sogs bzhi po de dag la phyis nyams pa'am 'bri bar 'gyur ba'i cha can ni g.yo ba zhes bya ba dang / gnas pa dang khyad par du 'gyur ba'i cha can ni mi g.yo ba ste nyams par mi 'gyur ba dang / tshad med bzhi'i ting 'dzin thob kyang ting 'dzin de la chags pas ro myangs shing des chog par 'dzin pas gong ma'i yon tan mi tshol ba ni nyon mongs pa dang bcas pa dang / ro myang ba dang chog 'dzin byed pa min pa ni nyon mongs pa med pa'i tshad med zhes bya ste de ltar dbye ba bzhi las/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi tshad med pa bzhi po ni mi g.yo ba dang / ro myang ba dang chog 'dzin gyi chags pa dang bral bar rab tu gnas kyi g.yo ba dang nyon mongs can gnyis ni ma yin no/ /

The four boundless attitudes are of four kinds: Those whose aspects subsequently decline or deteriorate, which are termed “wavering.” Those whose aspects are maintained and enhanced, which are “unwavering” and will not decline. Those that are said to be with defilements, where the concentration of the four boundless attitudes is attained but, because of attachment to it, is savored and considered sufficient, so that one does not seek more advanced qualities. And those that are said to be without defilements, which are not savored and do not give rise to a sense of satisfaction. Of these four categories, the four boundless attitudes of bodhisattvas remain unwavering and free of the attachment associated with relish and satisfaction: they are neither wavering nor defiled by defilements.
mnyam bzhag ngo bo nyid min chung / / 'bring dang dman pa'i sa pa dang / / bsam pa dman dang nga rgyal bcas/ / gang yin de dman gzhan nyid lhag /

In those who are, by nature, not concentrated, Who are lesser, middling, or on inferior levels, Whose motivation is inferior, or who have pride, Their love and so forth is inferior; in others it is superior. (XVIII, 21)
gzhan yang tshad med pa de'i dbye ba la/ mnyam par bzhag pa'i ngo bo nyid min pa 'dod pa'i khams kyi sems la brten pa'i tshad med bzhi ni chung ngu'o/ /

Further categories of the four boundless attitudes are as follows. The four boundless attitudes based on the minds of beings in the world of desire, which are not concentrated by nature,[15] are lesser.

gzugs dang gzugs med pa'i khams ni mnyam par bzhag pa zhes bya la/ de yang bsam gtan dang po la gnas ris gsum ste/ tshangs ris dang / tshangs lha nye ba'am tshangs pa mdun na 'don dang / tshangs chen gsum yod la/ bsam gtan gnyis par 'od chung sogs gsum/ bsam gtan gsum par dge chung sogs gsum/ bsam gtan bzhi par sprin med 'od sogs gsum dang / mi che ba sogs gnas gtsang lnga ste brgyad yod pa las/ tshangs ris kyi tshad med bzhi ni chung ngu / tshangs lha nye ldan gyi de bzhi 'bring dang / tshangs chen gyi tshad med bzhi ni chen po yin la/ de ltar mnyam par bzhag pa'i sa la tshad med chung 'bring che gsum du bzhag pa las chung ngu dang 'bring gnyis ka chung ngur bsdu zhing / chen po dang de gnyis su phye'o/ /

As to the worlds of form and formlessness, which are termed “concentrated,” there are three realms related to the first dhyāna (the Pure, Gods Close to Brahmā or Priests of Brahmā, and Great Pure Ones), three realms related to the second dhyāna (Dim Light, and so on), and three related to the third dhyāna (Lesser Virtue, and so on); and there are three realms (Cloudless Light and the others) related to the fourth dhyāna, and the five pure abodes (Not Greater, and so on), making another eight realms in all. Of these, the four boundless attitudes of those in the realm of the Pure are lesser, the four of those in Gods Close to Brahmā are middling, and the four boundless attitudes of those in Great Pure Ones are greater. Of these three classifications of the boundless attitudes as lesser, middling, and greater on the “concentrated” levels, the lesser and middling are included in the lesser,[16] making, with the greater, two categories.

yang dman pa'i sa pa zhes pa sa 'og ma 'og ma dman pa dang / gong ma'i rgyud kyi tshad med lhag pa ste/ mos spyod kyi sa pa'i tshad med bzhi bsgom pa dman zhing chung la/ sa dang po pa'i lhag cing che ba dang / sa dang po pa'i de dag dman la sa gnyis pa'i de bzhi lhag pa'i tshul gyis sa dang sa la ltos nas che chung du bzhag pa'o/ /

Again, “on inferior levels” refers to the fact that the boundless attitudes of those on respectively lower levels are inferior, and those in the minds of beings on higher levels are superior. The meditation on the four boundless attitudes of someone on the level of earnest aspiration is inferior and lesser compared to that of someone on the first bodhisattva level, which is superior and greater; and the meditation of someone on the first level is inferior to that of someone on the second level, which is superior—in this way they are classified as greater and lesser depending on the respective levels.
bsam pa dman dang zhes pa gzhan don mi byed pas nyan rang gi tshad med bzhi ni chung ngu dang /
“Inferior motivation” refers to the four boundless attitudes of the listeners and solitary realizers, which, since they are not applied to the benefit of others, are lesser.
sa dang po nas bdun pa'i bar du rnam par rtog pa'i 'bad rtsol dang bcas pa'i nga rgyal dang bcas pa yin pas chung ba ste/
From the first level up to the seventh, they are accompanied by pride—that is, they are associated with conceptual thoughts and effort, and so are lesser.

de ltar mnyam bzhag min pa dang / mnyam bzhag gi yang chung dang 'bring gnyis dang / de las gzhan mnyam bzhag gi skabs kyi chen po dang / dman pa'i sa 'og ma 'og ma dang / bsam pa dman pa ba'i dang / nga rgyal dang bcas pa gang yin pa de dman pas chung la/ de las gzhan mnyam bzhag gi skabs kyi chen po dang / dman pa'i sa min pa gong ma gong ma dang / bsam pa dman pa min pa byang chub sems dpa' de bzhin gshegs pa'i dang / sa brgyad pa sogs dag pa'i sa gsum na rnam rtog gi 'bad rtsol mi mnga' bas nga rgyal med pa de dag gi tshad med bzhi nyid lhag pa'am chen por shes par bya'o/ /

Thus the four boundless attitudes of beings in nonconcentrated states, of those in the lesser and middling concentrated levels, those on respectively inferior levels, those with inferior motivation, and those with pride are all inferior and therefore lesser. Besides these, the four boundless attitudes of others are to be understood as superior or great—that is, the boundless attitudes of those who are great in the context of meditative concentration; those who are on respectively higher levels and not on the inferior levels; bodhisattvas and tathāgatas, whose motivation is not inferior; and those on the three pure levels, beginning with the eighth, who do not have conceptual thoughts and effort and are therefore free of pride.
bzhi pa 'bras bu ni/
iv. RESULT

tshangs pa'i gnas pas gnas pa yi/ / blo ldan rtag tu 'dod par skye/ / des ni tshogs rnams rdzogs byed cing / / sems can dag kyang rnam smin byed/ / kun tu tshangs dang mi 'bral ba/ / de yi mi mthun phyogs dang bral/ / bag med gyur kyang de yi rkyen/ / mi bzad pas kyang mi 'gyur ro/ /

The wise who abide forever in these pure states Are born in the world of desire. By means of them, they complete the accumulations And bring beings to maturity. (XVIII, 22) In all their lives, they will never part from pure states And will be free from their counteragents. Even when they are not paying heed, They will never be overwhelmed by circumstances. (XVIII, 23)
zhes pas bstan te/

spyir tshad med bzhi bsgoms pa'i 'bras bu gzugs khams su skye ba yin na yang / byams sogs tshangs pa'i gnas pas rtag tu gnas pa'i blo ldan byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni sems shin tu las su rung zhing bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i ting nge 'dzin dang ldan pas/ rtag tu sems can gyi don du 'dod pa'i khams gang yin par skye ba ni rnam smin gyi 'bras bu'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams tshad med pa'i bsgom pa des ni bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs rdzogs par byed pa dbang byed pa'am bdag po'i 'bras bu'o/ / tshad med bzhi dang ldan pa'i byang sems rnams sems can bstan pa 'di la ma zhugs pa rnams bstan pa la gzhug pa dang / zhugs pa dag kyang gong nas gong du rim par rnam par smin par byed pa ni brtson 'grus kyi sgo nas skyes bu'i rtsal gyi 'bras bu'am skyes bu'i byed pa'i 'bras bu'o/ / tshe 'dir goms pas phyi ma'i skye ba kun tu tshangs gnas dang mi 'bral ba nyid du 'gyur ba rgyu mthun gyi 'bras bu'o/ / tshangs gnas bzhi po de yi mi mthun phyogs gnod sems sogs bzhi dang bral ba ni bral ba'i 'bras bu'o/ /

In general, the result of training in the four boundless attitudes is rebirth in the world of form. However, wise bodhisattvas who constantly abide in these pure states—love and the others—have perfectly fit minds and inconceivable powers of concentration, and they therefore take rebirth in the world of desire in order to constantly benefit beings. This is the fully ripened effect. By training in the four boundless attitudes, bodhisattvas complete the accumulations of merit and wisdom, this being the conditioning or environmental effect. Bodhisattvas who possess the four boundless attitudes introduce beings who have not yet entered the doctrine to the teachings, and bring those who have already done so to ever-increasing stages of maturity. This comes about on account of their diligence as the proliferating effect. As a result of training in this life, in all their future lives they will never separate from the pure states, which is the effect similar to the cause. And the fact that they are free from malice and the other three factors that counter the four pure states is the separational effect.
[tshangs gnas goms pa tshad du gyur pa'i rtags]
The Sign of the Extent to Which One Has Trained in the Pure States

tshangs gnas goms pa tshad du gyur pa'i rtags ni/ gnod sems sogs kyi gnyen po byams sogs ched du ma bsgoms pa rang dgar gnas pa'am bag zon byas pa med par gyur kyang / gnod sems sogs skyed par byed pa de yi rkyen mi bzad pa mngon du gyur pas kyang byams sogs nyams par mi 'gyur ba ni tshangs gnas goms shing mi mthun phyogs bral bar gyur pa'i rtags dang mtshan ma yin no/ / 'di 'bras bu'i zhar la bstan pa ltar byas na de'i sa bcad kyi khongs dang / logs su phye na tshad med goms pa'i rtags lnga par byas te sa bcad bdun du bya'o/ /

The sign or mark that bodhisattvas have trained in the pure states and are free of their countering factors is that although they may not be meditating specifically on love and the other boundless attitudes as the antidote to malice and so forth, but are rather conducting themselves casually or not particularly attentively, even in the face of overwhelming circumstances that would give rise to malice, their love and so forth will never degenerate. These two lines may be considered either as a digression within, and forming part of, this subsection on the result or as a separate, fifth subsection, in which case there would be a total of seven subsections in this section on the four boundless attitudes.
lnga pa mi mthun phyogs bshad pa ni/
v. COUNTERING FACTORS
byang chub sems dpa' gnod sems dang / / rnam 'tshe mi dga' gnod sems dang / / 'dod pa'i 'dod chags dang ldan pa/ / nyes dmigs rnam pa mang la reg /
Bodhisattvas who have the wish to harm, Who are cruel, unappreciative, And full of malice, attachment, and desire, Are affected by many kinds of negative consequences. (XVIII, 24)
ces pas bstan te/

byang chub sems dpa' tshad med bzhi dang mi ldan pa'i nyes pa ni/ sems can bde ba dang ma 'phrad na snyam pas sdug bsngal la sbyor phyir bsad pa dang brdeg pa sogs gnod pa bya bar sems pa ni byams pa'i mi mthun phyogs dang / lus kyis brdung brdeg sogs rnam par 'tshe bar byed pa ni/ sdug bsngal dang bral bar 'dod pa snying rje'i mi mthun phyogs dang / sems can bde ba dang ldan par mthong ba la phrag dog gi sems kyis de la mi mos mi dga' ba ni dga' ba'i mi mthun phyogs dang / tshor ba sdug bsngal ba dang dgra la sogs pa'i sems can mthong na gnod sems skye ba dang / tshor ba bde ba dang mdza' ba la sogs pa mthong na 'dod pa'i 'dod chags skye ba dang ldan pa ni btang snyoms kyi mi mthun phyogs so/ / de ltar tshad med bzhi'i mi mthun phyogs dang ldan na/ lus dang sems la gnod pa'i sdug bsngal sna tshogs pa'i nyes dmigs rnam pa mang po la reg par 'gyur ro/ / ji ltar nyes dmigs mang po 'byung zhe na

The defects of bodhisattvas who fail to keep the four boundless attitudes are as follows. Their thoughts are on preventing sentient beings from being happy by killing, beating, or otherwise harming them so as to make them suffer, which runs counter to love. They act cruelly, physically beating them up and so on, which runs counter to compassion, the wish that they be free from suffering. As a result of jealousy, they feel unappreciative and displeased when they see beings who are happy, which runs counter to joy. They give rise to malice when they have painful feelings or see enemies and other such beings, and they give rise to attachment and desire when they have pleasant feelings or see friends and the like, and that runs counter to impartiality. Those who possess these counteragents to the four boundless attitudes will be affected by a great many negative consequences in the form of all kinds of physical and mental suffering. What are these negative consequences?

nyon mongs kyis ni bdag 'joms sems can 'joms shing tshul khrims 'joms/ / nyams bcas rnyed pas dman zhing srung dang de bzhin ston pas smad/ / rtsod bcas mi snyan de ni gzhan du mi khom rnams su skye/ / thob dang ma thob nyams pas yid la sdug bsngal chen po 'thob/ /

Because of defilements, they destroy themselves, Destroy sentient beings, and destroy their discipline. These degenerate beings have few resources And are disparaged by protectors and the Teacher alike. (XVIII, 25) Subject to arguments and unpleasant gossip, In other lives they will be born deprived of freedom; Since they will lose what they have acquired and what they have not, They will suffer greatly in their minds. (XVIII, 26)

gnod sems rnam 'tsho sogs nyon mongs kyis ni srog gcod pa sogs sdig pa byas pas bdag nyid tshe 'di la bsad pa bcings pa sogs dang / tshe rabs gzhan du dmyal ba sogs su skye bas sdug bsngal gyis 'joms par byed do/ / nyon mongs de dag gis gzhan gyi srog dang longs spyod chung ma sogs la gnod pa'i sgo nas sems can 'joms shing / de ltar zhugs pa de tshul khrims yang dag par blangs pa las nyams par 'gyur bas tshul khrims kyang 'joms so/ /

On account of defilements like malice and cruelty, they will commit negative actions like taking life, as a result of which they will be crushed by suffering—in this life, they will be killed, imprisoned, and so forth; and in other lives, they will be reborn in the hells and other such realms.
