On account of the same defilements, they will destroy sentient beings by doing violence to others’ lives, property, spouses, and so forth. And since acting in that way will violate the vows they have properly taken, they will also destroy their discipline.

de ltar tshul khrims nyams pa dang bcas pa de 'di snyam du bdag ni 'phags pa rnams kyis bstan pa'i lam mtho ris su skye ba ni bor te/ so so'i skye bo sdig can gyis bstan pa'i lam ngan song gi lam du zhugs pas bdag ni brlag pa yin no zhes sems la gdung ba dang bcas pa'am 'gyod pa dang bcas shing sems nyams shing zhums pa dang bcas par 'gyur ba dang / tshul khrims nyams pa de la sngon sbyin bdag tu gyur pa rnams kyis kyang gang zag 'di ni sdig pa byed pa yin pas sbyin pa'i gnas ma yin no snyam du ci yang 'bul bar mi byed cing / de bzhin gzhan dag gis kyang brnyas shing mchod pa'i gnas su mi 'jog pas chos gos dang bza' btung yo byad kyi rnyed pas dman zhing / sngar tshul khrims dang ldan pa'i dus na lha la sogs pas srung bar byed pa yang de la smod cing phyin chad srung bar mi byed pa dang /

Those who have deteriorated their discipline like this will think, “I have abandoned the path praised by the noble beings that leads to rebirth in the higher realms, and I have set out on the path followed by wicked, ordinary beings, the path to the lower realms. I am ruined!” Their minds thus tormented or full of remorse, they will feel daunted and downcast. Moreover, those who formerly were their benefactors will think of these monks who have deteriorated their discipline, “These people are evildoers—they are not worth supporting” and will cease to offer them anything. Likewise, others will treat them with contempt and not consider them to be worthy of offerings, so they will receive less of robes, food and drink, and anything else they need. Even the gods and similar beings who protected them in the past, when they observed proper discipline, will now disparage them and will henceforth cease to protect them.

de bzhin du ston pas kyang dge slong 'di ni dge slong du mi rung ba/ dge sbyong gi chos las nyams pa/ bong bu ltar spyod pa/ shi ba'i ro dang 'dra ba zhes 'dul ba sogs las rnam pa du mar smad pa mdzad pa de yang de la thob pa dang / tshul khrims nyams pa de chos nyid kyis tshangs par mtshungs par spyod pa rnams kyis/ 'di dang lhan cig gnas su mi rung zhes tshig gis sma 'bebs shing rtsod par byed de/ chad pas gcod pa dang / skrod pa la sogs pa'i las byed pa dang bcas pa'i phyir ro/ / gang zag che ge mo zhig gis tshul khrims nyams shing sdig pa'i las 'di dang 'di lta bu byas zhes phyogs dang phyogs su mi snyan pa bsgrag par 'gyur ba dang / gang tshul khrims zhig pa de ni tshe 'dir sdug bsngal mang po thob pa de tsam du ma zad skye ba gzhan du dmyal ba la sogs pa mi khoms pa'i gnas rnams su skye ba dang / sngar rang rgyud la thob zin pa'i thos pa dang tshul khrims dang tshad med bzhi sogs las kyang nyams par 'gyur ba dang / slar yon tan gyi chos ma thob pa yang 'thob mi nus pas ma thob pa las kyang nyams pas yid la 'gyod pa dang gdung ba mi bzod pa'i sdug bsngal chen po 'thob par 'gyur te/

Similarly, they will also receive reproaches such as our teacher, the Buddha, made on numerous occasions, according to the Vinaya and other texts, when he said, “This monk is not fit to be a monk. He has fallen back from the principles of a śramaṇa. He is behaving like an ass. He’s no better than a corpse.” Furthermore, those degenerate monks’ colleagues will naturally censure them and object to them, saying, “It is not right for us to stay with him,” for it is their duty to punish such monks, expel them, and so on. People will say unpleasant things about them everywhere: “He has broken his vows and committed such and such evil deeds.” These individuals who have destroyed their discipline will gain much suffering not only in this life but also in other lives, being reborn in the hells and other states where there is no opportunity to practice the Dharma. The learning, discipline, four boundless attitudes, and so forth that they had previously acquired in their mind streams will fade away, and since they will subsequently be unable to acquire any as yet unacquired enlightened attributes, the qualities they have not yet acquired will be lost too. As a result, they will suffer unbearably, their minds filled with anguish and regret.
'di dag ni gnyen po byams sogs dang mi ldan pa'i dbang gis mi mthun phyogs nyon mongs rnams 'phel ba nyid kyi nyes dmigs so/ /
These, then, are the grave consequences of letting the countering factors, defilements, proliferate through not having their antidotes, love and the others.
drug pa yon tan ni/
vi. GOOD QUALITIES
nyes pa 'di kun byams sogs la/ / legs par gnas la mi 'byung ste/ / nyon mongs can min sems can gyi/ / don du 'khor ba yongs mi gtong / /
All these faults never occur In those who abide properly in love and the other attitudes. Free of defilements, for the sake of sentient beings, They never abandon saṃsāra. (XVIII, 27)
zhes pas bstan te/

ji skad bshad ma thag pa'i nyes pa 'di kun byams pa sogs tshad med bzhi la tshul bzhin legs par gnas pa rnams la nam yang mi 'byung ste/ tshad med bzhi dang ldan pa de ni shes rab kyi stobs kyis/ chags sogs nyon mongs pas mi gos pa'i phyir nyon mongs can min yang / snying rjes sems can gzhan gyi don du 'khor ba yongs su mi gtong ste 'khor bar skye ba bzung nas sems can smin par byed pa yin te/

All these defects just described never occur in those who abide properly in love and the other three boundless attitudes, because, on account of their wisdom, their having the four boundless attitudes is not tainted by defilements like attachment. And although they are without defilements, through compassion, for the sake of other sentient beings, they do not abandon saṃsāra but take birth in saṃsāra and bring beings to maturity.
ji ltar rgyal ba'i sras rnams sems can la/ / byams pa la sogs sems pa 'di 'byung ba/ / sems can thams cad yon tan ldan pa yi/ / bu gcig pa la'ang de lta ma yin no/ /
The thoughts of love and so forth That the Buddha’s children have for sentient beings No being can feel, even for Their one and only perfect child. (XVIII, 28)

ji ltar rgyal ba'i sras rnams sems can thams cad la/ byams pa sogs tshad med bzhi'i sems pa yis phan bde byed pa 'di lta bu 'byung ba ni sems can phal pa thams cad la yang med la pha ma gnyis kyis/ yon tan dang ldan pa yi/ bu gcig pu sdug cing phangs pa la yang byang chub sems dpa'i byams pa de lta bu bskyed nus pa ma yin no/ /

Even in the entirety of ordinary beings there is nothing like the bodhisattvas’ thoughts of love and the other three boundless attitudes with which they bring benefit and happiness to all sentient beings. No father or mother can give rise to anything like the love bodhisattvas have, even for an only, beloved, adorable child full of virtues.
gnyis pa snying rje bye brag tu bshad pa
b. A SPECIFIC EXPLANATION OF COMPASSION
['di] la rnam grangs dgu las
The specific explanation covers nine topics.
dang po snying rje'i dmigs yul ni/
i. THE OBJECTS OF BODHISATTVAS’ COMPASSION

rab 'bar dgra yi dbang du song / / sdug bsngal gyis non mun pas bsgribs/ / bgrod dka'i lam la kun tu zhugs/ / 'ching ba che dang yang dag ldan/ / zas chen dug dang 'dres la zhen/ / lam ni rab tu stor gyur pa/ / lam gol rab zhugs stobs chung ba'i/ / sems can rnams la snying rje'o/ /

Their compassion touches sentient beings Who are ablaze, who are overpowered by enemies, Who are oppressed by suffering or obscured by darkness, Who tread the hardest path, (XVIII, 29) Who are weighed down by great chains, Who are addicted to poisoned food, Who have completely lost the way, Who are following mistaken paths, and who are weak. (XVIII, 30)
zhes rnam pa bcu ste/

'dod khams pa 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga la 'dod chags rab tu 'bar ba rnams la dmigs nas byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis kye ma sems can 'di rnams tshim pa med par 'dod chags kyi me rab tu 'bar bas rang dbang med par byas so zhes snying rje rab tu skye'o/ /

There are ten objects of a bodhisattva’s compassion. As they consider the beings in the world of desire, who are blazing with attachment to the five sense pleasures, bodhisattvas give rise to intense compassion, thinking, “Alas! Without ever satisfying their desires, these beings are rendered helpless by the fiercely blazing fire of attachment.”
de bzhin du dge ba byed pa la zhugs kyang de yi dgra bdud kyis bar chad byas pa yi dbang du song nas dge ba byed pa btang ba rnams la yang snying rje ba skye'o/ /

In the same way, they give rise to compassion for those who, even if they have begun performing positive actions, have fallen under the influence of obstacles created by enemies and demons and have given up their practice of virtue.
ngan song gsum du skyes nas tshor ba mi bzod pa myong ba dang / mtho ris na yang skye rga na 'chi sogs sdug bsngal gyis non par gyur pa'i sems can rnams la dmigs nas snying rje rab tu skye'o/ /

They give rise to intense compassion when they think of sentient beings who, born in the three lower realms, are going through the most terrible experiences or who, even in the higher realms, are oppressed by the sufferings of birth, aging, sickness, death, and so on.

sdug bsngal gyi rgyu lus ngag yid kyi nyes par spyod pa srog gcod pa sogs la zhugs nas de'i 'bras bu dmyal sogs kyi sdug bsngal 'byung ba mi shes pa'i mun pas bsgribs pa shan pa dang rngon pa dang rkun po sogs sems can sdig pa byed pa rnams la snying rje ba dang / gang dag thar pa'i phyogs la yid gtan nas mi 'jug pa rigs chad pa'i gang zag rnams/ skye ba mtha' med par 'khor bar 'khyams pas bgrod dka'i lam la kun tu zhugs pa yin pas de rnams la snying rje skye'o/ /

They feel compassion for beings who commit negative actions—butchers, hunters, robbers, and the like—who, obscured by the gloom of ignorance, do not know that, from engaging in killing and other negative physical, verbal, and mental activities that are the cause of suffering, they will consequently suffer in the hells and other realms. They give rise to compassion for beings without potential[17] who never give a thought to liberation. They have wandered for endless lifetimes in saṃsāra and are thus fully engaged on the hardest path of all.

bstan pa 'di las phyi rol du gyur pa'i mu stegs can bdag dang bdag gir lta ba sogs lta ba ngan pa sna tshogs kyi 'ching ba che dang yang dag ldan pa rnams la snying rje skye'o/ / bsam gtan gzugs med kyi snyoms 'jug tsam la thar pa dang bde bar 'du shes pas ro myangs shing chags pa ni dper na zas chen po yid 'ong dug dang 'dres pa la zhen nas za ba dang 'dra bar gnas skabs der bde yang mthar nyams pa'i chos can yin pas 'khor ba las ma 'das pas de 'dra'i sems can rnams la dmigs nas snying rje skye'o/ /

They give rise to compassion for non-Buddhist tīrthikas, who are completely fettered by the view of “I” and “mine” and all kinds of other wrong views. They give rise to compassion for beings in the world of form and the formless world. Such beings consider that just their meditative absorption amounts to liberation and bliss, and so they savor it and are attached to it, just as one might be attached to good, delicious food mixed with poison. But even though that absorption, like the food, is blissful at the time, its very nature in the end is to fade away, and it does not, therefore, go beyond saṃsāra.

mu stegs pa dag thar pa'i ched du me lngas gdung ba dang brag kha nas lceb pa sogs tshul khrims dang brtul zhugs phyin ci log par lam du mthong nas thar pa tshol ba ni/ yang dag pa'i lam ni rab tu stor bar gyur pa yin pas de rnams la dmigs nas snying rje rab tu skye'o/ / nyan thos dang byang sems kyi rigs ma nges pa dag nyan rang gi lam du zhugs pa ni thar pa'i lam la zhugs kyang rang gzhan don gnyis sgrub pa'i theg pa chen po'i lam las gol ba dman lam la rab tu zhugs pa rnams la snying rje skye'o/ /

They feel intense compassion when they consider tīrthikas who mistakenly perceive their discipline and ascetic practices—being scorched by five fires,[18] throwing themselves to their death off cliffs, and so forth—as the path and who use this to seek liberation. They have strayed completely from the true path. They give rise to compassion for listeners and for bodhisattvas of unfixed potential who have set out on the path of the listeners or solitary realizers, for even though they have begun the path to liberation, they have strayed from the path of the Great Vehicle that accomplishes both one’s own and others’ goals, and they are completely involved in inferior paths.
theg pa chen po'i lam la zhugs kyang mthun rkyen tshogs ma rdzogs pa dang / 'gal rkyen gyis zin pas lam tshul bzhin sgrub mi nus par stobs chung ba'i sems can rnams la snying rje skye'o/ /

And they feel compassion for enfeebled beings who, even though they have set out on the Mahāyāna path, have not completed the accumulations that act as favorable conditions and have been seized by adverse circumstances, so that they are unable to practice the path properly.
de ltar dmigs yul bcu la brten nas skyes pa'i snying rje de yang / dbye ba rnam pa bcur 'gyur ro/ /
On the basis of these ten objects, we can therefore distinguish ten categories of compassion that bodhisattvas give rise to.
gnyis pa snying rjes sems can rnams la dmigs pa'i 'bras bu ci zhig 'thob na/
ii. THE RESULTS OF CONSIDERING SENTIENT BEINGS WITH COMPASSION
'tshe spangs byang chub mchog gi sa bon dang / / bde ba bskyed dang gdung byed 'dod pa'i rgyu/ / ngo bo nyid sbyin chos la brten pa yi/ / rgyal ba'i sras la byang chub thag mi ring / /

The rejection of harm, the seeds of supreme enlightenment, The creation of happiness and acceptance of pain, The cause for everything they desire, and the yielding of compassion itself— For the Buddha’s children who rely on these qualities, enlightenment is not far off. (XVIII, 31)
zhes pas bstan te/

snying rje dang ldan pa rnams ni sems can rnams la brdeg btsog sogs kyi 'tshe ba rnam par spangs pa ni bral ba'i 'bras bu'o/ / byang chub mchog gi sa bon du gyur pa'i tshogs gnyis gsog pa ni bdag po'i 'bras bu dang / sems can gzhan la sdug bsngal dang bral ba'i bde ba bskyed pa dang / de'i ched du rang gis tsha grang ngal dub sogs gdung ba sna tshogs dang du len par byed pa ni skyes bu byed pa'i 'bras bu'o/ / snying rje dang ldan pa rnams gang dang gang du skye bar 'dod pa der skye bar 'gyur ba ji ltar 'dod pa'i rgyu byed pa rnam smin gyi 'bras bu'o/ / tshe rabs snga ma rnams su snying rje goms pas tshe rabs phyi ma rnams su yang snying rje gong du 'phel zhing rgyun chags su 'byung ba ni snying rje'i rang bzhin nam ngo bo nyid sbyin pa ni rgyu mthun pa'i 'bras bu'o/ / de lta bu'i snying rje'i chos lnga po de la brten pa yi rgyal ba'i sras rnams bla na med pa'i byang chub ni thag mi ring ste myur du 'thob par 'gyur ro/ /

What are the results that one obtains from considering sentient beings with compassion? Those who are endowed with compassion have completely given up anything that harms sentient beings, such as beating them up. This is the separational effect of compassion. The conditioning effect is that they gather the two accumulations that are seeds of supreme enlightenment. The proliferating effect is that they make other beings happy and remove their sufferings, and that they willingly accept all sorts of discomforts such as heat, cold, and fatigue in order to achieve that. The fully ripened effect is that those with compassion will be reborn wherever they wish to be reborn; their compassion creates the cause for anything they wish. As for the effect similar to the cause, by training in compassion in their previous lives, in their future lives too their compassion will grow continuously more and more; in other words, it will yield compassion itself. For bodhisattvas who rely on these five qualities of compassion, unsurpassable enlightenment is not far away and will be swiftly attained.
gsum pa shes rab dang ldan pa'i snying rje'i byed las ni/
iii. THE FUNCTION OF COMPASSION ASSOCIATED WITH WISDOM
snying rje blo mchog 'khor bar gtogs pa yi/ / sdug bsngal bdag nyid kun dang bdag med par/ / rnam par shes nas skyo bar mi 'gyur zhing / / nyes pas rab gnod par yang mi 'gyur ro/ /

Those with compassion and the highest intelligence, Knowing that everything in saṃsāra is suffering And devoid of self, will never be discouraged, Nor will they be much troubled by its faults. (XVIII, 32)
zhes pas bstan te/

byang chub sems dpa' snying rje chen po dang ldan pa'i blo gros mchog shes rab kyi stobs kyis khams gsum 'khor bar gtogs pa yi phyi dang nang gi chos thams cad mi rtag pa dang sdug bsngal ba gsum dang nang gses su phye bas rnam grangs shin tu mang po'i sdug bsngal ba'i bdag nyid kun shes pa dang / chos de dag stong pa dang bdag med par rnam par shes nas 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal gyis skyo bar mi 'gyur zhing snying rjes gzhan don byed la/ shes rab kyis 'khor ba rang bzhin med par shes pa'i phyir 'khor ba'i nyes pa skye rga na 'chi sogs sdug bsngal ba dang / 'dod chags dang zhe sdang sogs nyon mongs pas rab tu gnod par yang mi 'gyur ro/ /

Because of their supreme intelligence, that is, wisdom, bodhisattvas who possess great compassion know that all the external and internal phenomena included in the three worlds of saṃsāra are by nature impermanent and unsatisfactory, with the three kinds of suffering that can be subdivided further into many, many different kinds of suffering, and they know that these phenomena are empty and devoid of self. So they never get discouraged by the sufferings of saṃsāra, and they work compassionately for others’ benefit. With their wisdom, they know that saṃsāra is without intrinsic existence, so they will never be greatly troubled by the ills of saṃsāra—sufferings such as birth, aging, sickness, and death—and by defilements such as attachment and aversion.
'jig rten sdug bsngal bdag nyid lta ba yi/ / brtse dang ldan pas sdug bsngal de dang ni/ / de yongs spong ba'i thabs kyang ji bzhin rig / nyam nga bar byed skyo bar yang mi 'gyur/ /
Those with tenderness, seeing the world’s pain as their own, Know just what suffering is And the means for eliminating it. Though pained by it, they will never be discouraged. (XVIII, 33)

'jig rten mtha' dag gi sdug bsngal gsum la bdag rang nyid kyi sdug bsngal dang 'dra bar lta ba yi/ gzhan la brtse ba dang ldan pa'i tshul de dang ni/ sdug bsngal de spong ba'i thabs sdug bsngal gyi rgyu kun 'byung yin par mkhyen nas de'i gnyen po lam dang 'gog pa dang bcas pa dag kyang ji lta ba bzhin du rig cing khong du chud pa'i phyir/ gzhan gyi sdug bsngal la btang snyoms su mi byed par snying rje zhing nyam nga bar byed kyang / de bsal ba'i thabs shes pas sdug bsngal des sems skyo bar yang mi 'gyur ro/ /

Those with tenderness for others, regarding the three sufferings of all worlds as if it were their own suffering, fully realize just what that suffering is and the way to eliminate it—namely, to know the origin or cause of suffering as well as its antidote, the path, and the cessation. As a result, even though they cannot remain indifferent to others’ suffering but are pained[19] by it, since they know the method for dispelling it, they never become discouraged by such suffering.
bzhi pa snying rje'i dbye ba ni/
iv. CATEGORIES OF COMPASSION
snying rje'i bdag nyid can gyi brtse ba 'di/ / rang bzhin dang ni so sor brtags pa dang / / de sngon goms par byas dang ldan pa dang / / mi mthun phyogs nyams rnam dag thob pa bzhi/ /
This tenderness of those whose nature is compassion Is fourfold: natural, analytic, Related to former training, And acquired with the purity that weakens its counteragents. (XVIII, 34)
zhes pas bstan te/

snying rje'i bdag nyid can byang chub sems dpa'i brtse ba 'di la rang bzhin te rigs kyi dbang gis snying rje'i rang bzhin can du gyur pa dang ni/ snying rje'i yon tan dang snying rje med pa'i skyon dang / sems can rnams rang dbang med par sdug bsngal gsum la 'phyan pa'i tshul dang de rnams rang gi gnyen dang bshes su gyur pa grangs med pa dang / bde ba 'dod cing sdug bsngal mi 'dod pa la thams cad 'dra yang / zhe 'dod dang lag len phyin ci log tu song ba sogs snying rje'i blo sbyang ba'i tshul rnams so sor brtags par byas pa dang / snying rje de sngon goms par byas pa dang ldan pa dang / mi mthun phyogs gnod sems rnam 'tshe sogs nyams par gyur pa'i snying rje rnam dag thob pa bzhi'o/ / phyi ma 'di ni gang la yang chags pa dang zhe sdang mi skye ba'i 'dod chags dang bral ba'i snying rje thob pa'o/ / de ltar rang bzhin dang / so sor brtags pa dang / bsgom pa dang / 'dod chags dang bral ba thob pa bzhi'o/ /

This tenderness[20] of bodhisattvas who are the embodiment of compassion is of four kinds: (1) Natural, meaning that bodhisattvas are naturally compassionate on account of their potential. (2) Analytic, in that as methods for training the mind in compassion, bodhisattvas examine such things as the good qualities of compassion, the disadvantages of not having compassion, the way in which sentient beings helplessly wander amid the three kinds of suffering, how they have been one’s relatives and friends countless times, and how, despite their all being the same in wanting to be happy and not wanting to suffer, their behavior runs counter to what they most wish for. (3) The tenderness of one who has trained in compassion in the past. And (4) the tenderness of one who has acquired the perfectly pure compassion that weakens countering factors such as malice and cruelty. This last refers to acquiring compassion free of attachment, whereby one does not give rise to attachment or aversion to anything or anyone at all. There are thus four categories: natural, analytical, trained, and attained with freedom from attachment.
lnga pa snying rje chen po'i khyad par bshad pa
v. THE PARTICULAR QUALITIES OF GREAT COMPASSION
['di] la dngos dang / de'i che ba dpes bstan pa gnyis/
This topic is divided into (1) the main explanation and (2) the greatness of great compassion indicated by the use of analogies.
dang po ni/
(1) MAIN EXPLANATION
mnyam dang rtag min lhag pa'i bsam pas min/ / sgrub pa'i sgo dang 'dod chags bral ba dang / / mi dmigs pas min gang de brtse min te/ / de bzhin brtse med gang de byang chub min/ /

That which is not uniform or constant, which is without superior intention, Which lacks the means for accomplishment, and is neither free from attachment Nor nonconceptual is not tenderness. Those who thus have no tender love are not bodhisattvas. (XVIII, 35)
zhes pas bstan te/

mnyam pa'i snying rje med na snying rje chen po ma yin zhing / so skye dang nyan thos/ rang sangs rgyas kyi snying rje lta bur 'gyur te ji ltar na/ sems can sdug bsngal gyi sdug bsngal mngon du gyur pa'i sems can rnams la snying rje skye yang / bde tshor dang ldan pa dang btang snyoms kyi tshor ba dang ldan pa la snying rje mi skye ba ni mi mnyam pa'i phyir snying rje chen po ma yin la/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis ni zag bcas kyi tshor ba bde sdug btang snyoms ci myong yang sdug bsngal gsum las ma 'das par gzigs nas/ ji ltar mnar med pa'i sems can rnams la snying rje ba ltar/ srid pa'i rtse mo'i bar gyi sems can rnams la yang de dang 'dra bar mnyam par snying rje skye bas na mnyam pa nyid kyi snying rje chen po zhes bya ba dang / bar 'ga' snying rje 'byung res 'ga' mi 'byung ba lta bu so skye'i snying rje dang / nyan rang rnams la yang sems can la snying rje ba tsam yod kyang phung po lhag med kyi dus na zad cing rgyun chad pas rtag pa min pas snying rje chen po zhes mi bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje ni slob pa lam gyi gnas skabs kun tu rgyun chags par 'byung ba dang / phung po lhag med kyi mya ngan las 'das pa'i dbyings su zhugs kyang nam yang mi zad pa'i rtag pa'i snying rje yin pa'i phyir snying rje chen po'o/ /

Unless one’s compassion is uniform, it is not great compassion. It is no different from ordinary beings’ compassion or that of listeners and solitary realizers. In what way? Even though they may feel compassion for beings who are experiencing the suffering upon suffering, they do not give rise to compassion for those who feel happy or those with neutral feelings. Theirs is unequal compassion, and therefore not great compassion. Bodhisattvas, on the other hand, see that none of the tainted feelings that beings experience, whether happy, painful, or neutral, are anything other than the three kinds of suffering, and they therefore feel the same compassion, equally—as much for the beings in the Hell of Torment Unsurpassed as for those at the Peak of Existence. This is why it is referred to as “the great compassion of sameness.” Ordinary beings’ compassion, which they feel intermittently, and that of listeners and solitary realizers, whose compassion for beings, however deep, is spent once they become arhats with no residual aggregates,[21] are interrupted and inconstant, and they cannot therefore be called “great compassion.” The compassion of bodhisattvas arises continuously, at all stages of the path of learning, and is never spent even when they enter the expanse of nirvāṇa without residual aggregates. It is constant compassion, and therefore great compassion.

gzhan don khur du 'khyer ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pas min pa'i snying rje ni/ 'jig rten pas rang don dang 'dres nas mdza' bshes sogs bdag gir 'dzin pa la snying rje ba dang / rang la phan 'dogs pa la snying rje ba tsam dang / nyan rang rnams la bdag gzhan mnyam pa nyid rtogs pas gzhan don khur du 'khyer ba'i bsam pa med pas de dag gi snying rje la snying rje chen po zhes mi bya la/ byang chub sems dpa' sa dang po thob nas bdag gzhan mnyam pa nyid kyi chos nyid mngon sum rtogs pas bsam pa'i sgo nas rang don dang gzhan don khyad med par gzhan don khur du 'khyer ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pa dang ldan pa'i snying rje ni snying rje chen po'o/ / gang la sems can sdug bsngal bar mthong nas snying brtse ba tsam yod kyang / sdug bsngal las bskyab pa'i bya ba dngos su sgrub pa'i sgo dang bral ba ni snying rje chen po ma yin te/ nyan rang rnams la yang sems can thams cad sdug bsngal ba la snying rje ba tsam yod kyang / sdug bsngal bskyab pa nyid sgrub par mi byed pa bzhin no/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni 'khor ba'i mtha'i bar du sems can la phan bde sgrub par mdzad pa'i phyir de dag ni snying rje chen po can yin no/ /

Compassion that lacks the superior intention of shouldering responsibility for others’ welfare refers to ordinary beings’ compassion, which is mixed with their own self-interest, and is merely felt for friends and relatives and other beings whom they consider as “mine” and for those who help them. It also refers to the compassion of listeners and solitary realizers, who have not realized the sameness of themselves and others and therefore do not have the motivation of taking responsibility for others’ welfare. These beings’ compassion cannot be called “great compassion.” Bodhisattvas, on the other hand, once they have attained the first level, have directly realized the ultimate reality, the sameness of themselves and others, and because of their motivation they make no distinction between their own and others’ goals. Their compassion, which is coupled with the superior intention of taking responsibility for others’ welfare, is great compassion. Certain people may feel some compassion when they see sentient beings suffering, but they do not have the means to actually accomplish protecting them from suffering. That tenderheartedness is not great compassion. The listeners and solitary realizers similarly have a certain compassion for all suffering beings, but it does not enable them to protect them from suffering. Bodhisattvas work to accomplish the benefit and happiness of sentient beings until the end of saṃsāra, so theirs is great compassion.

sems can rnams mdza' ba la snying rje yod kyang rnam pa kun tu ma yin par bar 'ga' zhe sdang 'byung ba dang / dgra la zhe sdang yod pas nyon mongs dang ma bral ba dang / nyan rang 'phags pa rnams la zhe sdang dngos su med kyang de'i bag chags phra mo ma spangs pas de dag gi snying rje la snying rje chen po zhes mi bya ste/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi snying rje'i mi mthun phyogs zhe sdang dang 'tshe ba'i bag la nyal la 'dod chags dang bral bas snying rje chen po yin pa dang / snying rje yod kyang snying rje'i 'khor gsum gyi mtshan mar mi dmigs pas min pa de ni snying rje chen po min la/ rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes dang ldan pa de ni snying rje chen po'o/ / 'di ni sa brgyad pa yan chad rnam par mi rtog pa yongs su smin pa'i gnas skabs la bzhed pa yod kyang / byang sems 'phags pa spyi la sbyar kyang mi 'grig pa med do/ /

Ordinary beings may have compassion for those dear to them, but not all the time, and sometimes they get angry with them, and they feel hatred for their enemies, so they are not free of defilements. The noble listeners and solitary realizers do not actually have aversion, but they have not eliminated the subtle habitual tendencies to aversion. So in neither of these two cases can their compassion be called “great compassion.” Bodhisattvas are free of attachment, that is, of the latent tendencies to aversion and violence, which are the counteragents of compassion, so theirs is great compassion. Even if one has compassion, if it is not free of the conceptual attributes of the three spheres of compassion, it is not great compassion. But compassion endowed with nonconceptual gnosis is great compassion. Although this is held to be the case for bodhisattvas from the eighth level onward—when nonconceptuality is fully ripened—it is not inappropriate to apply it also to noble bodhisattvas in general.

de ltar byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje chen po bshad pa de lta bu mthar phyin pa dmigs med kyi thugs rje chen po lhun gyis grub pa sangs rgyas kyi sa na sangs rgyas kyi thugs rje chen po zhes bya ste/ snying rje dang thugs rje ni skad dod gcig la zhe sa sbyar tsam las don 'dra yang chen po'i khyad par du byas pa ni skabs 'dir bshad ma thag pa ltar go dgos so/ / de ltar mnyam pa min pa dang / rtag pa min pa sogs rnam pa drug bshad pa gang de brtse ba snying rje chen po min te/ de las bzlog pa drug po'i khyad chos dang ldan pa ni snying rje chen po'o/ / bshad ma thag pa de bzhin du brtse ba chen po med pa gang de byang chub sems dpa' snying rje chen po can zhes bya ba min no/ /

The culmination of the bodhisattvas’ compassion as described here is the spontaneous nonconceptual compassion that on the buddha level is called “Great Compassion.”[22] Whether or not one associates great compassion and Great Compassion with the same original Sanskrit term, they mean the same, and the important thing to understand in this context is why they are distinguished as “great,” which is what has just been explained. Any tender love that is described with these six aspects—unequal, inconstant, devoid of superior intention, lacking the means for accomplishment, not free from attachment, and not nonconceptual—is not the tenderness that is great compassion. But if it has the six opposite qualities, it is great compassion. Without this great tender love, as has just been explained, one cannot be referred to as a “bodhisattva with great compassion.”
gnyis pa snying rje chen po'i che ba dpes bstan pa ni/
(2) THE GREATNESS OF GREAT COMPASSION INDICATED BY THE USE OF ANALOGIES
snying rje dang ni bzod dang sems pa dang / / smon lam skye ba sems can yongs smin byed/ / dang po rtsa ba tha ma 'bras mchog ldan/ / 'di ni snying rje'i ljon shing chen po yin/ /

That which possesses compassion, forbearance, intention, Aspiration, taking birth, and the maturation of sentient beings— The first being the root; the last, the sublime fruit— Is the great tree of compassion. (XVIII, 36)
zhes pas bstan te/

dpe ljon shing bzang po la rtsa ba dang / sdong po dang / yal ga dang / 'dab ma dang / me tog dang / 'bras bu drug yod pa bzhin du/ dpe can snying rje chen po la yang / sems can thams cad sdug bsngal las skyob par 'dod pa'i snying rje chen po dang ni/ de las gzhan don du dka' ba sna tshogs spyad pa la bzod pa dang / sems can gyi don bya ba'i thabs sna tshogs mngon du byed pa la sems pa dang / skye ba tshe rabs thams cad du sems can gyi don byed pa'i lus dang longs spyod 'khor dang gnas phun sum tshogs par skye bar gyur cig ces smon lam 'debs pa dang / smon lam gyi shugs kyis tshe rabs gar skyes kyang bdag dang gzhan la phan par byed pa'i skye ba mang po len pa dang / de'i sgo nas sems can yongs su smin par byed pa yin la/ dang po snying rje chen po ni phyi ma lnga po'i rtsa ba lta bu yin te/ byang chub sems dpa'i yon tan thams cad kyi rtsa ba lta bur sngon du 'gro ba ste/ blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las/ btsun pa sha ra dwa ti'i bu 'di lta ste dper na dbugs phyir 'bud pa dang rngub pa ni skyes bu'i srog gi dbang po'i sngon du 'gro ba'o/ / de bzhin du theg pa chen po yang dag par bsgrub pa'i phyir/ byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje chen po sngon du 'gro ba'o zhes dang / 'phags pa ga yA go ri'i mdo las/ byang chub sems dpa'i byang chub sems kyi rtsa ba ni snying rje chen po'o/ / sems can ni dmigs pa'o zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

Just as a fine fruit tree, for example, has six aspects—a root, trunk, branches, leaves, flowers, and fruit—in great compassion too (the subject of this analogy) there are the following aspects: (1) the great compassion that is the wish to protect all sentient beings from suffering; (2) arising from that, the patience to go through all kinds of difficulties for others’ sake; (3) the intention to realize the various means for benefiting beings; (4) the aspiration that in all one’s future lives, one may be reborn in a perfect situation, with a perfect body and abundant riches and entourage, by means of which one may benefit beings; (5) the taking of numerous births in which, by the power of one’s prayers, wherever one is reborn in one’s series of lives, one benefits oneself and others; and (6) the bringing, by the above means, of all sentient beings to full maturation. The first of these, great compassion, is, as it were, the root of the other five; it is the rootlike prerequisite for all the bodhisattva qualities, as is stated in the Sūtra of the Teaching of Akṣayamati: Venerable Śāriputra, it is thus. Let us use an analogy. Exhaling and inhaling in order to breathe is prerequisite to a person’s ability to live. Similarly, in order to accomplish the Great Vehicle properly, a bodhisattva’s great compassion must come first. And in the Sūtra on the Mountain Gayāśīrṣa we read: The root of a bodhisattva’s bodhicitta is great compassion. Sentient beings are its object.

tha ma sems can smin par byed pa ni shing las 'bras bu mchog yongs su smin pa dang ldan pa 'di ni snying rje'i ljon shing chen po yin no zhes gsungs pas/ rtsa ba snying rje chen po la brten nas sems can gyi don du sdug bsngal sna tshogs bzod pa'i sdong po 'byung la/ bzod pa'i sdong po la brten nas sems can sdug bsngal las bsgral ba'i thabs la sems pa yal ga lta bu 'byung ngo*/ / thabs sems pa'i yal ga las skye ba gcig tsam gyis sems can mtha' yas pa'i don byed mi nus pas skye ba thams cad du rim gyis sems can tshad med pa'i skye ba 'dzin par smon lam 'debs pa lo ma lta bu 'byung ngo / / smon lam gyi lo ma las sems can gyi don du ji ltar 'dod par skye ba'i me tog lta bu 'byung ngo / / skye ba'i me tog las sems can rnams yongs su smin par byed pa'i 'bras bu 'byung ste/ de ltar ljon shing bzang po dang 'dra bar bsngags pa yin no/ /

The last of the above aspects, bringing sentient beings to maturity, is the sublime, fully ripened fruit from the tree. That which possesses all these “is the great tree of compassion.” In other words, on the basis of the root, great compassion, the trunk appears—that is, the patience to put up with all kinds of suffering for the sake of sentient beings. Then from the trunk, forbearance, there grow the bough-like intentions regarding the means for liberating beings from suffering. From the boughs of these intentions, aspirations sprout like leaves—aspirations that, since it is impossible to benefit the infinity of sentient beings in just one lifetime, one will gradually, in all one’s rebirths, take birth as limitless sentient beings. From the leaves of those aspirations, the flowers of taking birth wherever one wishes for the sake of sentient beings blossom. And from the flowers of rebirth there comes the fruit—the bringing of sentient beings to maturity. In this way, great compassion is praised as if it were an excellent fruit tree.
de nyid rgyas par bshad pa la dang po rtsa ba med na gzhan rnams ldog pa'i tshul gyis bstan pa ni/
There now follows a detailed explanation of this. First, it is shown that without the root, the rest are prevented from occurring.

rtsa ba snying rje med gyur na/ / dka' spyad bzod pa nyid mi 'gyur/ / blo ldan sdug bsngal mi bzod na/ / sems can don sems nyid mi 'gyur/ / sems pa dang ni bral ba'i blo/ / skye ba dkar po rnam dag tu/ / smon lam 'debs par mi 'gyur ro/ / skye ba bzang po ma thob na/ / sems can yongs smin byed mi 'gyur/ /

If the root, compassion, is absent, There will not be the forbearance to put up with hardship. If the wise cannot endure suffering, They will not have the intention to help beings. (XVIII, 37) Their minds devoid of that intention, They will not pray for positive and pure rebirths. And if they do not achieve a good rebirth, They will never bring sentient beings to maturity. (XVIII, 38)
zhes pas bstan te/

ji ltar shing gi rtsa ba med na sdong po nas 'bras bu'i bar du mi 'byung ba bzhin du rtsa ba lta bu'i snying rje chen po med par gyur na/ sems can gyi don du dka' ba spyad pa dang du len pa la blos bzod pa nyid du mi 'gyur te/ 'jig rten pa dag kyang nye du sogs gang la brtse ba yod pa de'i ched du dka' yang 'bad kyi gzhan gyi don du mi 'bad pa dang / nyan rang rnams kyis kyang sems can gyi don la dka' spyad mi byed pa bzhin no/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis snying rje chen po'i dbang gis sems can gyi don du dka' ba spyad pa nam yang mi 'dor ba yin no/ /

Just as without a tree’s roots nothing, from the trunk to the fruit, will grow, if the rootlike great compassion is absent, one will have not the mental forbearance to willingly accept going through difficult practices for the sake of beings. One will be like ordinary beings, who feel tender love toward their relatives and exert themselves for their sake even if it is difficult but make no effort for anyone else’s welfare. Or they will be like listeners and solitary realizers, who do not undergo hardships for the sake of sentient beings. Bodhisattvas, on account of their great compassion, never turn away from undergoing hardships for beings’ sake.

blo ldan des gzhan gyi ched du rang sdug bsngal ba mi bzod pa na/ sems can gyi don la thabs 'di dang 'di lta bu bya'o zhes sems pa nyid du mi 'gyur te/ thabs yod kyang rang gis sgrub par mi nus pas de la bsam par yang mi byed do/ /

If the wise cannot put up with suffering themselves for the sake of others, they will not have the intention “I must use this or that means to help sentient beings,” for even if there exists such a means, they will be unable to accomplish it by themselves and so neither will they think of doing so.

sems can gyi don du bya bar sems pa dang ni bral ba'i blo can des sems can rnams la phan 'dogs pa'i skye ba sdig pa dang ma 'dres pa'i dkar po/ rang don yid byed kyis ma sbags pa'i rnam dag tu/ smon lam 'debs par mi 'gyur te/ byang chub sems dpa'i smon lam de ni sems can gyi don bya bar 'dod pas de ltar 'khor bar skye ba 'dzin pa yin gyi/ 'jig rten pa dag mtho ris kyi bde ba thob 'dod kyi bsam pas dge ba byed pa lta bu ma yin la/ nyan rang rnams 'khor bar skye ba spangs pa lta bu ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Those whose minds lack the intention to work for the welfare of sentient beings will never make prayers of aspiration to be reborn in such a way as to benefit sentient beings—rebirths that are positive in not being adulterated by negative actions, and perfectly pure in not being sullied by self-interest. Bodhisattvas’ aspirations amount to a wish to work for the welfare of sentient beings, and thus to taking rebirth in saṃsāra—not like mundane beings, who perform positive actions with the intention or wish to gain happiness in the higher realms, nor like listeners and solitary realizers, who have abandoned rebirth in saṃsāra.

smon lam gyi dbang gis srid pa 'di na sems can rnams la phan 'dogs pa'i skye ba bzang po ma thob na/ tshul des sems can rnams yongs su smin par byed par mi 'gyur te/ yang na 'jig rten pa rnams las kyi rnam par smin pas skye ba thob pa lta bu sems can smin par byed mi nus pa dang / yang na nyan rang ltar skye ba rgyun chad pas sems can gyi don mi byed pa bzhin no/ /

If they do not, by the power of their aspirations, obtain a good rebirth that will bring benefit to sentient beings here in existence, they will not thereby bring beings to full maturation. Either, like ordinary beings, they will obtain a birth that is the fully ripened effect of their karmic actions, in which they are unable to mature beings, or, like listeners and solitary realizers, they will have cut the stream of rebirths and will therefore not work for the good of beings.

de ltar rtsa ba snying rje chen po med na/ sdong po lta bu'i bzod pa nas/ 'bras bu lta bu sems can smin par byed pa'i bar lnga po de 'byung mi srid do/ / rtsa ba yod na gzhan rnams kyang rjes su 'gro ba'i tshul gyis bshad pa ni/

Thus, without the root, great compassion, it is impossible for the other five to appear, from the trunk of forbearance through to the fruit, the maturation of sentient beings. If the root is present, all the rest will follow, and how this happens is explained next.

snying rje'i 'chu ba byams pa ste/ / de sdug bsngal na bde ba yis/ / sangs rgyas tshul bzhin yid byed pas/ / yal ga rgya chen 'phel ba dang / / smon lam rgyun ni ma bcad pas/ / lo ma 'dor len rkyen rnam gnyis/ / grub pa de phyir me tog dang / / 'bras bu don yod shes par bya/ /

Know that with love watering their compassion, From their happiness when they suffer, It expands and grows; and from proper attentiveness, The great boughs grow and spread. (XVIII, 39) The unbroken stream of their aspirations, Like leaves that are cast off and renewed, Is fulfilled by two causes, as a result of which The flowers and fruit bring benefit. (XVIII, 40)

ji ltar ljon shing gi rtsa ba chus brlan na rtsa ba brtan pa dang rgyas par gyur nas/ de las sdong po nas 'bras bu'i bar rgya cher rgyas par 'byung ba ltar/ rtsa ba snying rje'i 'chu ba'am chus 'chu ba ste chus brlan pa la blo brtan 'grel du gsungs te 'chu ba ni byams pa'o/ / 'grel pa la las 'chu ba zhes pa shing gi rtsa ba'i skad phra mo dag gis sa'i chu 'thung ba'i shing rgyas pas rkang pas 'thung ba zhes grags pa ltar rtsa ba'i yang rtsa ba lta bur bshad pa'ang snang yang / de lta bu yang yin mod kyi de ni rtsa ba nyid kyi khongs su gtogs pa rtsa ba snying rje rang la bshad pa ni skabs 'di'i don yin la/ byams pa dang snying rje ni chos nyid kyis gcig yod na gcig shugs kyis tshang ba yin pas/ snying rje nyid rtsa ba ma yin par da dung rtsa ba gzhan byams pa la ngos 'dzin pa ltar ma byas par/ rtsa ba de nyid 'phel ba'i grogs su byams pa ni chus 'chu ba'am chus brlan pa lta bur 'grel pas bshad pa ltar go ba blangs na legs 'dra ste/ snying rje'i 'chu ba byams pa ste/ zhes rtsa bar yod pa dang 'grel pas kyang de bzhin du bshad pas/ 'chu ba zhes pa rtsa ba'i skad rnams kyis chu 'thung ba'am 'chu ba'am rtsa ba la chus 'gyed pa'am blugs pa la chus 'chu ba'am brlan pa'i don gyis byed tshig zhugs pa nyid yin pa 'dra'o/ /

When one waters the root of a tree, it becomes robust and grows, and then from it everything from the trunk to the fruit appears and develops on a magnificent scale. So it is with the watering or irrigation or moistening of compassion, the root, with love—as explained in Sthiramati’s commentary.[23] Some commentaries appear to explain the Tibetan word ’chu ba[24] as if it were the root of the root, referring to the tiny rootlets of a tree by which it draws up the water from the earth, as in the popular expression that a fully grown tree is “that which drinks with its feet.” However, such rootlets are part of the root itself, which would mean in this context explaining ’chu ba as the root itself, compassion—for love and compassion would naturally go together, and instead of just compassion being the root, one would have to distinguish love as still another root. Rather, it would seem better to understand love as being the watering or moistening of the root itself, helping it to grow, as explained in the commentary. “With love watering their compassion” occurs in the root text and is explained like that in the commentary, so ’chu ba must be used in the sense of the verb with the meaning of watering or wetting, the rootlets drinking or drawing up water or the root being sprinkled or drenched with water.

de'i phyir na snying rje'i rtsa ba 'phel bar byed pa'i phyir chus 'chu ba lta bu ni byams pa ste/ byams pa'i sems chu dang 'dra bas snying rje'i rtsa ba brlan par byas na snying rje 'phel bar 'gyur te/ sems can sdug bsngal ba rnams la dmigs nas sdug bsngal dang bral 'dod kyi snying rje yod pa de las yul de dag bde ba ldan 'dod kyi byams pas de'i phan bde sgrub par byed 'dod pas sems can rnams shin tu gces pa'i bu sdug gu bzhin du mthong bar 'gyur zhing / ji ltar bu na ba la pha ma sdug bsngal zhing de nad dang bral ba'i bde ba 'thob pa'i thabs la brtson pa'i dka' tshegs kyi sdug bsngal gyi 'du shes mi skyed par/ sman sogs thabs 'di ni 'di la phan par byed pa yin no snyam du de la brtson pa la dga' ba'i 'du shes skye ba ltar/ byang chub sems dpa' sems can la byams pa can de ni gzhan don du lus dang sems kyi sdug bsngal nyams su myong ba la yang / gzhan la phan 'dod kyi byams pas 'di'i ched du 'gyur bas 'di ni sdug bsngal ma yin gyi dang du blang bar bya ba'i mchog yin no snyam du bde ba yi 'du shes rnyed pa yis/ des ci la yang mi bzod pa med pa'i bzod pa'i sdong po yangs shing rgyas par 'gyur ro/ /

So, in order to make the root, compassion, grow, it is irrigated with love, so to speak. If compassion, the root, is moistened by the water of loving thoughts, compassion will increase. When bodhisattvas consider beings who are suffering, they have compassion (the wish to free them of suffering), and through that, with love (the wish that they be happy) and the consequent desire to accomplish their benefit and happiness, they see all beings as their beautiful and greatly beloved child. When a child falls sick, it does not occur to the parents that the difficulties they go through as they strive to rid the child of disease and restore him or her to good health are making them suffer. Thinking, “This medicine, this treatment, is what will help my child,” they feel nothing but joy in making every effort with that treatment. In the same way, bodhisattvas full of love for sentient beings go through the experience of physical and mental suffering for the sake of others, but because of their loving wish to help beings, they perceive it as blissful, thinking, “Since it is for their sake, this is not painful but the most sublime thing, to be willingly accepted.” Thus, the trunk of forbearance, for which there is nothing that cannot be borne, will expand and grow.

de ltar bzod pa'i sdong po yangs shing rgya che ba rgyas pa'i rgyu las/ gzhan don bya ba'i thabs kyi sgo bdag med gnyis dang mngon shes dang gzugs sogs bden pa gnyis kyis bsdus pa'i chos dang thabs rnam pa sna tshogs dpag tu med pa tshul bzhin du yid la byed pas gzhan don sems pa'i yal ga rgya chen po rnam pa du ma 'phel ba dang / rgyu de las sems can gyi don du phan bde rgyun mi 'chad par byed pa'i smon lam chen po'i rgyun ni ma bcad par tshe rabs grangs med par btab pas/ smon pa'i lo ma snga ma snga ma rgya chung ngu rnying pa rnams 'dor ba dang snga ma las rgya je cher 'phel ba'i smon lam gyi lo ma gsar pa rnams gong nas gong du len pa ste skye ba dang gzhan smin par byed pa'i me tog 'bras bu 'grub pa'i rkyen rnam pa de gnyis kyis smon lam grub pa de yi phyir skye ba'i me tog mngon du 'grub pa dang / skye ba blang ba'i rten de rnams kyis sems can tshad med pa yongs su smin par byed pa'i 'bras bu ste me 'bras de gnyis don yod pa'am 'byung bar shes pa bya ste/ ljon shing la yang rang gi nyer len gyi rgyu dang / sa chu sogs lhan cig byed rkyen gnyis kyis me tog dang 'bras bu 'byung ba ltar byang chub sems dpa'i skye ba dang gzhan smin par byed pa ni byang chub sems dpa' rang gi smon lam gyi dbang gis dang / yul sems can gnyis ka'i dbang gis 'grub bo/ /

As a result of their forbearance increasing extensively, bodhisattvas are properly attentive to the means for benefiting others—the two kinds of no-self, preternatural knowledge, form and the other phenomena included in the two truths, and the infinite different kinds of skillful means—and thus the great manifold boughs of their altruistic intention grow and spread. As a result of that, bodhisattvas unceasingly, throughout countless lives, make great prayers of aspiration to continuously bring about benefit and happiness for the sake of sentient beings. Thus they shed the small, old leaves of their previous aspirations and increasingly assume the new leaves of ever-greater aspirations. These aspirations are fulfilled by the two causes for producing the flowers of their taking birth and the fruit of their bringing others to maturity, as a result of which the flowers of rebirth materialize and produce the fruit, the maturation of countless sentient beings by the individuals in which the bodhisattvas have taken birth. It is thus that both flowers and fruit are to be understood as taking substance,[25] or appearing. Just as the direct cause of the fruit tree itself and the cooperative conditions of the soil, water, and so forth bring about the appearance of the flowers and fruit, bodhisattvas’ taking birth and bringing others to maturity are brought about on account of both their own aspirations and their object, sentient beings.[26]
drug pa snying rje'i yon tan bsngags pa
vi. IN PRAISE OF THE QUALITIES OF COMPASSION
['di] la rnam grangs gsum spyir bstan pa dang / rtogs dka' ba bye brag tu bshad pa gnyis las/
This topic comprises two parts: (1) a general exposition in three parts and (2) a specific explanation of points that are difficult to understand.
(1) A GENERAL EXPOSITION IN THREE PARTS
dang po yon tan chen po 'byung ba ni/
(a) THE EMERGENCE OF GREAT QUALITIES
snying rje chen po yon tan 'byung gnas kyi/ / sems can rnams la snying rje su mi byed/ / 'di ltar 'di dag la ni sdug bsngal yang / / brtses bskyed bde ba gzhal du med par 'byung / /

Since great compassion is the source of qualities, Who would not have compassion for sentient beings? Even though they thus feel pain for them, Aroused through tenderness, it produces immeasurable bliss. (XVIII, 41)
zhes pas bstan te/

snying rje chen po ni mthar thug gi 'bras bu sangs rgyas kyi sa'i yon tan stobs bcu dang mi 'jigs pa bzhi la sogs pa tshad dpag tu med pa'i 'byung gnas kyi rang bzhin yin pas/ sems can rnams la snying rje bar blo dang ldan pa su zhig mi byed de byed rigs so/ / sems can rnams la snying rje byas rgyun de dag gi don du rang yang sdug bsngal bas bzod dka'o snyam na de ltar ma yin te/ 'di ltar sems can 'di dag gi don la ni sdug bsngal yang / zhes so/ / 'di ltar byang sems 'di dag sems can gyi don la snying rje'i dbang gis sdug bsngal yang de ni sdug bsngal gzhan lta bu ma yin te/ brtse ba'i dbang gis bskyed pa'am sdug bsngal de las sdug bsngal thams cad rim gyis 'dzad cing / nyan rang dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten kun las 'phags pa'i bde ba gzhal du med pa 'byung ba'i phyir ro/ /

Since great compassion is the source of the ten strengths, the four fearlessnesses, and the other infinite qualities of buddhahood, which is the final result, what intelligent persons would not consider sentient beings compassionately? It is entirely appropriate to do so. One might think, “If I have compassion for beings, for their sake I myself will suffer, and that will be difficult to bear.” But it is not like that. “Even though they thus feel pain for those beings”—even though in this way those bodhisattvas are pained on account of their compassion for beings, their pain is not like other suffering, because through that suffering or product of their tenderness, all suffering gradually comes to end, and there arises an immeasurable happiness greater than any mundane bliss or indeed that of the listeners and solitary realizers.
gnyis pa ma chags pa'i yon tan ni/
(b) THE QUALITY OF NONATTACHMENT
snying rjes zin pa'i brtser ldan rnams/ / zhi la'ang yid ni mi gnas na/ / 'jig rten bde dang rang srog la/ / chags par 'gyur ba smos ci dgos/ /
Those with tenderness, who are imbued with compassion, Do not even set their minds on peace, Let alone become attached To mundane bliss or their own lives. (XVIII, 42)
zhes pas bstan te/

snying rje bskyed na sems can la chags nas yongs su 'dzin pa'i 'ching bar 'gyur ro snyam na ma yin te/ snying rjes rgyud yongs su zin pa'i brtser ldan byang sems rnams ni nyan rang ltar sdug bsngal nye bar zhi ba'i myang 'das la'ang yid ni mi chags shing mi gnas na 'jig rten pa ltar 'jig rten zag bcas kyi bde ba dang rang gi lus dang srog la chags par 'gyur ba smos ci dgos te de'i phyir 'khor 'das kyi chos gang la'ang ma chags pa yin no/ /

“If I give rise to compassion,” one might wonder, “will it not become a fetter, holding me down through attachment to sentient beings?” No. Unlike the listeners and solitary realizers, tender bodhisattvas, whose mind streams are completely imbued with compassion, do not even have attachment to and set their minds on the nirvāṇa in which suffering has been completely pacified, so what need is there to mention their becoming attached, like ordinary beings, to tainted, mundane happiness and to their own bodies and lives? They are not attached to anything in saṃsāra or nirvāṇa.
gsum pa khyad par 'phags pa'i yon tan ni/
(c) THE QUALITY OF SUBLIMITY
byams pa gang de kha na ma tho ba/ / med dang 'jig rten 'das pa yod ma yin/ / blo ldan rnams kyi brtse bas byams pa ni/ / kha na ma tho med cing 'jig rten 'das/ /
Ordinary love is not beyond reproach, Nor is it supramundane. The love the wise feel in their tenderness Is irreproachable and has gone beyond the world. (XVIII, 43)
zhes pas bstan te/

'jig rten na mas bu la byams pa la sogs pa de lta bu'i byams pa gang de ni kha na ma tho ba med pa dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa yod pa ma yin te/ bu sogs la chags nas de'i don du sdig pa byed pa dang / de dang mi mthun pa rnams la zhe sdang ba sogs nyon mongs pa dang 'dres pa'i phyir kha na ma tho ba gtan med pa ma yin la/ chos dang gang zag gi bdag tu 'dzin pa'i rmongs pa dang bcas pa'i phyir 'jig rten las 'das pa med do/ / blo ldan byang sems rnams kyi sems can la brtse ba'i dbang gis byung ba'i byams pa ni kha na ma tho ba med cing 'jig rten las 'das pa yin no/ / ji ltar kha na ma tho ba med pa yin zhe na/

Among ordinary people, the love such as a mother has for her children is not beyond reproach,[27] nor is it supramundane. Through attachment to children and the like, one performs negative actions for their sake, and one feels aversion to those who do not get on with them, so because such love is mixed with defilements it is not in any way free of shameful deeds. And because it is associated with bewilderment, the belief in the phenomenal and individual kinds of self, it is not supramundane. The love that arises because of the tenderness that wise bodhisattvas feel for sentient beings is free of shameful deeds and is supramundane. In what way is it free of shameful deeds?
sdug bsngal rba rgal che dang mi shes pa'i/ / mun pa che la brten par gyur pa yi/ / 'jig rten 'dren pa'i thabs gang yin pa de/ / ji ltar kha na ma tho med mi 'gyur/ /
It is the means for leading ordinary beings Dwelling in the gloom of ignorance And on the flooding waves of suffering. How could it not be free of fault? (XVIII, 44)

'bras bu sdug bsngal gsum gyi rba klong drag tu rdol ba'am bskyod pa'i 'khor ba'i chu bo che la 'phyan pa dang / de'i rgyu 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi mi shes pa'i mun pa che la brten par gyur pa yi/ 'jig rten pa rnams thar par 'dren pa'i thabs chen po shom par byed pa'i rgyu byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje dang byams pa gang yin pa de dag ji ltar kha na ma tho ba med par mi 'gyur te/ kha na ma tho ba med pa'i mchog tu yid ches pa nyid do/ /

As a result of their relying on the great darkness that is ignorance of the four noble truths, ordinary beings drift on the great river of saṃsāra, violently buffeted about on the flooding waves of the three kinds of suffering. If the cause that sets up the great means for leading them to liberation is the bodhisattva’s compassion and love, how could it not be irreproachable? One can be absolutely confident that it is free of shameful deeds.
'jig rten byang chub rang sangs rgyas pa yi/ / dgra bcom rnams la byams pa de med na/ / de las gzhan la smos kyang ci dgos pa/ / ji ltar 'jig rten 'das pa ma yin 'gyur/ /
If in this world, enlightened by themselves, The arhats do not have such love, What need to speak of anybody else? How could it not be supramundane? (XVIII, 45)

ji ltar 'jig rten las 'das pa yin zhe na/ 'jig rten 'di na dbang po rnon po zad mi skye shes pa'i ye shes byang chub pa nyid du rang sangs rgyas pa'am rang gis rtogs pa'i rang rgyal dgra bcom pa la yang byams pa de lta bu med na/ de las gzhan nyan thos dang 'jig rten pa la smos kyang ci dgos pa de lta bu'i brtse ba dang byams pa de ji ltar na 'jig rten las 'das pa ma yin par 'gyur te 'jig rten 'das pa nyan rang las kyang 'das na 'jig rten pa las 'das pa yin pa smos ma dgos so/ /

In what way is their love supramundane? In this world, even the solitary-realizer arhats, who have the sharpest faculties and have awakened themselves to, or realized by themselves, the enlightened gnosis of exhaustion and nonarising, do not have this kind of love, let alone others like listeners and mundane beings. So how could the bodhisattva’s love and tenderness not be supramundane? If it transcends even that of the listeners and solitary realizers, who are supramundane beings, one need hardly mention its being beyond the world.
gnyis pa
(2) A SPECIFIC EXPLANATION OF POINTS THAT ARE DIFFICULT TO UNDERSTAND
gong du gzhan don du sdug bsngal yang bde ba 'byung zhes gsungs pa'i rgyas bshad ni/
Earlier we mentioned that although bodhisattvas suffer for others’ sake, that produces happiness. This will now be explained in detail.

byang chub sems dpa'i sdug bsngal med/ / brtse bas sdug bsngal gyur pa gang / / de la dang por kun tu skrag / reg nas shin tu mngon par dga'/ / brtse bas bskyed pa'i sdug bsngal 'jig rten gyi/ / bde ba thams cad zil gyis gnon 'gyur zhing / / don byas rnams kyang de dang mi ldan gang / / de las ngo mtshar che ba ci zhig yod/ /

Bodhisattvas do not suffer, Yet any pain they feel through tender love At first makes them afraid, But once they have arrived, it gives them the greatest joy. (XVIII, 46) The pain that comes through tenderness Will outshine every mundane happiness, And even those who’ve reached their goal don’t have it. What could be more wonderful that? (XVIII, 47)
zhes pas bstan te/

byang chub sems dpa' rnams gnas skabs der rang la sdug bsngal med kyang zhes sam yang na 'grel pa ltar/ gzhan gyi sdug bsngal med par bya ba'i slad du/ brtse bas gzhan gyi don du rang gi sems sdug bsngal bar gyur pa gang yin de tsam skrag pa'i gnas ma yin par bstan pa ni/ blo chung ba rnams sems can gyi sdug bsngal la zhib tu bsams na shin tu skrag cing bzod dka' la sems can tshad med pa bzhin sdug bsngal yang tshad med pa yod pas de su zhig gis bsal nus snyam pa dang / mgo dang yan lag gtong ba dang sems can byas pa log par gzo ba rnams kyi log sgrub kyang bzod dka' ba dang / 'khor bar skye ba bzung na skye rga na 'chi dang gnas skabs der yang sdug bsngal sna tshogs myong dgos pa dang / sems can sdug bsngal can mang bas de'i sdug bsngal rang gi khur du blangs na rang sdug bsngal las nam yang ga la thar snyam du bsams nas sems zhum par mi bya ste/ ci'i phyir na sems can la brtse bas sdug bsngal bar gyur pa gang yin pa bshad ma thag pa de lta bu la dang por mos spyod kyi sa na kun tu skrag pa skye ba tsam yod de/ bdag gzhan mnyam pa nyid kyi sems ma thob pa dang / 'khor ba dang de'i sdug bsngal thams cad stong nyid du khong du ma chud pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir byang chub sems dpa'i rigs can rnams la thog mar 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal dang skyo ba shas che ba'i gtam 'ba' shig gtso bor mi ston par snying rje dang sgyu ma lta bu'i chos dang / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa'i yon tan bsngags pa ston dgos par mdo las gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

Although bodhisattvas in that situation do not suffer themselves (or alternatively, according to the commentary, in order that others do not suffer), because of their tenderness they experience mental suffering on behalf of others. This verse shows that however great that suffering is, it is not something to be afraid of. Less courageous people, when they reflect on the sufferings of sentient beings in detail, might consider them extremely intense and difficult to bear. They are as infinite as sentient beings. “Who,” they might wonder, “would be able to dispel those sufferings? Giving away our head and limbs and putting up with the ingratitude of beings who wrongly acknowledge what we have done for them must be difficult to bear. If we take birth in saṃsāra, we will have to go through the experiences of birth, aging, sickness, and death, as well as all kinds of sufferings in that situation. Sentient beings who suffer are so numerous, and if we take the burden of their suffering on ourselves, how will we ourselves ever be free from suffering?” But we should not think like this and feel disheartened. Why? On the level of earnest aspiration, any pain we feel on account of our tender love for sentient beings, as has just been mentioned, does make us thoroughly afraid, because we have not acquired the attitude of the sameness of ourselves and others and have not realized that saṃsāra and all its suffering are emptiness. For that reason, as is mentioned in the sūtras, one should not at first put the emphasis on giving those who have the bodhisattva potential only the teachings that deal predominantly with the sufferings of saṃsāra and disenchantment, but rather give teachings on compassion and illusion-like phenomena, and ones that praise the qualities of the buddhas and bodhisattvas.

reg nas zhes pa 'phags pa'i sa dang po la reg nas chos kyi dbyings kun tu 'gro ba'i mtshan nyid rtogs pa na bdag gzhan mnyam pa nyid kyi sems thob pas brtse ba'i dbang gis gzhan sems can gyi sdug bsngal bskyab pa'i phyir dmyal ba'i sdug bsngal dngos su dang du blangs pa ltar na yang de nyid gzhan bskyab pa'i don du song ba de'i phyir byang chub sems dpa' la rgyu de nyid bde ba chen po 'ba' zhig tu gyur te/ bde ba de lta bu ni 'jig rten lha dang mi dang nyan rang rnams la med pas bde ba thams cad kyi mchog dang phul du 'gyur bas na/ de ltar brtse bas bskyed pa'i sdug bsngal des lha dang mi la sogs pa 'jig rten gyi bde ba thams cad zil gyis gnon par 'gyur zhing*/ rang don byas pa nyan rang dgra bcom pa rnams kyang bde ba de lta bu dang mi ldan pa gang yin pa de las ngo mtshar che ba ci zhig yod ces so/ /

“Once they have arrived,” meaning once bodhisattvas have reached the first of the noble levels, they have realized the nature of the universal expanse of reality and therefore acquired the attitude of the sameness of oneself and others. Consequently, on account of their tender love, even if, in order to protect other sentient beings from suffering, they appear to willingly and actually accept the sufferings of the hells, it is in order to protect others, and that is what gives bodhisattvas nothing but the greatest happiness. Neither mundane celestial beings and humans nor listeners and solitary realizers have such happiness, and it is thus the greatest and most perfect of all happiness. So the suffering produced by tenderness in this way will outshine all the happiness of mundane beings such as gods and humans. Even the listener and solitary-realizer arhats, who have achieved their own goal, do not have such bliss. What could be more marvelous than that?

de ltar sa thob phan chad 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal gyis mi 'jigs pa yin yang / mos spyod kyi sa nas 'khor ba'i rang bzhin 'ba' zhig la bsams na sdug bsngal che ba shes kyang rigs kyi stobs dang / smon lam sogs kyi stobs las byang chub sems dpa' so skye'i gnas skabs su yang / 'khor ba'i thog mtha' sogs bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i gnas bsams nas sems khong du chud par mi 'gyur te/ sngon thog ma med pa'i dus nas da lta'i bar rang gzhan kun srid pa 'dir sdug bsngal yang ci rigs pa myong / res bde ba'ang ci rigs myong yang da lta de'i phan gnod ci yang med la/ ma 'ongs pa'i mtha' thug pa med kyang de snyed du sems can gyi khams kyang mi 'dzad mod/ sangs rgyas dang byang sems gsar du 'byung ba'ang de snyed du mi 'dzad pas/ dus kyi mtha' dang nam mkha'i mtha' dang / sems can gyi mtha' dang sdug bsngal gyi mtha' rnams kyang bsam gyis mi khyab pa yin yang / rang bzhin med pa sgyu ma lta bu yin pas/ sems can gyi khams phyogs dus kyi mtha' med pa de snyed du bdag gis kyang dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi rjes su bslab ste byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa rlabs po che spyod par bgyi'o snyam du go cha'i sems bskyed par byas nas sangs rgyas byang sems rnams la de ltar 'grub pa'i gsol ba btab cing dge ba'i rtsa ba rnams de lta bu'i ched du yongs su bsngo ba byas na/ theg pa chen po'i lam las phyir mi ldog par 'gyur zhing myur du 'jigs pa med par dbugs dbyung bar 'gyur ro/ /

Thus, from the moment one attains the bodhisattva levels onward, there is no fear of the sufferings of saṃsāra. At the same time, although bodhisattvas on the level of earnest aspiration, reflecting only on the nature of saṃsāra, recognize it as enormous suffering, even when they are at the stage of ordinary beings, on account of their potential, aspirations, and so forth they do not become discouraged by reflecting on the inconceivable state of saṃsāra—its beginning, its end, and so forth. In the past, since time without beginning until now, we and others have all experienced every kind of suffering in this existence, and each one has also experienced every kind of happiness. And yet none of all those sufferings and happiness is harming or benefiting us now. Neither is there any end to the future, and equally no time when the realms of sentient beings will ever be exhausted. On the other hand, neither will there be a time when the ever-renewed appearance of buddhas and bodhisattvas comes to an end. The end of time, the end of space, the end of sentient beings, the end of suffering—all these are inconceivable. Yet there is nothing that exists intrinsically; it is all like a magical illusion. It is in this light that we should arouse the armor-like spiritual intent: “As endless as are the realms of sentient beings, in time and space, to that extent I too will train, following the examples of the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the three times, and practice the infinite bodhisattva activities.” If we pray to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas that we may accomplish this and dedicate all our sources of good for that purpose, we will never turn back from the path of the Great Vehicle and will speedily find relief in fearlessness.
brtan pa'i brtse dang ldan pa'i sbyin pa yis/ / sbyin pa'i bde ba byed pa gang yin pa/ / de la khams gsum nye bar spyad rnams kyi/ / bde ba de yis char yang mi phod do/ /
The steadfast, with their tender gifts, Create the bliss of generosity; The happiness of those who find enjoyment in the three worlds Cannot compare to even a fraction of that. (XVIII, 48)

brtan pa byang chub sems dpas gzhan la brtse ba dang ldan pa'i sbyin pa lan dang rnam smin la re ba med par gzhan la phan 'dogs pa kho na'i ched du byin pa yis/ dngos po rang gis mi 'chang bar/ phar gtong ba'am byin pa na de ltar gzhan la phan 'dogs pa'i sbyin pa'i bya ba rdzogs pa las byung ba'i bde ba byed pa gang yin pa de la khams gsum gyi bde ba nye bar longs spyod pa las byung ba rnams kyi bde ba de yis byang chub sems dpa'i thugs rgyud la sbyin pa byin pa'i bde ba skyes pa de'i brgya dang stong la sogs pa'i cha la mi phod do/ / de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' rnams gzhan gyi don du sdug bsngal ba ltar snang yang nyid kyi thugs rgyud la sdug bsngal med par ma zad lus dang longs spyod sogs btang ba'i dga' ba 'jig rten pa'i bde ba gang gis kyang mtshon du mi nus pa skye ba'i phyir byang chub sems dpa' rnams la 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal dang du blang ba'i sdug bsngal ji ltar yod de rnam pa kun tu sdug bsngal med par shes par bya'o/ /

When steadfast bodhisattvas, with loving tenderness, give to others, they have no expectation of getting something in return or of karmic recompense: they practice generosity solely in order to help others. By doing so, when they give things away instead of keeping them for themselves, they complete their acts of generosity that benefit others. As for the happiness they derive from doing so, beings in the three worlds might enjoy some happiness, but their pleasure does not compare to a hundredth, a thousandth, or even the tiniest fraction of the bliss that develops in bodhisattvas’ minds from giving generously. Therefore, even though bodhisattvas appear to suffer for the sake of others, in their own minds there is no suffering. Moreover, because of the joy they feel at giving away their bodies and possessions, which no mundane happiness can ever illustrate, any discomfort bodhisattvas have in willingly accepting the sufferings of saṃsāra must be understood as not being in any way suffering.
sems can don phyir brtse bas sdug bsngal gyi/ / rang bzhin 'khor ba gang yin mi gtong na/ / snying rje can rnams gzhan la phan pa'i phyir/ / sdug bsngal ci ste khas len byed mi 'gyur/ /
If, out of tenderness, for beings’ sake They do not leave saṃsāra, suffering itself, What suffering will the compassionate ones Not accept in order to benefit others? (XVIII, 49)

sems can gyi don gyi phyir thugs brtse bas sdug bsngal gyi rang bzhin can 'khor ba nyid gang yin pa yongs su mi gtong ba yin na snying rje can de rnams sems can gzhan la phan pa'i phyir/ de dag gi sdug bsngal ci ste dang du len pa'am khas len byed par mi 'gyur ro/ / gzhan gyi sdug bsngal mtha' dag dang du len pa nyid do/ /

If, out of tender love, for the benefit of sentient beings, they do not completely abandon all that is saṃsāra, whose very nature is suffering, then which sufferings of other beings will the compassionate ones not willingly take on or accept in order to help them? They happily take on all others’ sufferings.
brtse dang ldan pa'i snying rje'i sbyin pa gang / / longs spyod dang ni de las byams pa dang / / rjes su gzung bas bskyed dang de yi mthus/ / byas pa'i bde ba rtag tu 'phel bar 'gyur/ /
From the compassion, generosity, And wealth of those with tender hearts, The happiness that grows from love, from caring, And from their power to help will constantly increase. (XVIII, 50)

brtse ba dang ldan pa byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje'i sbyin pa gang yin pa dang longs spyod dang ni zhes pa 'og gi 'phel bar 'gyur zhes pa'i tshig 'di mtha'i gsal byed yin pas 'di gsum re re bzhin du yar sbyar te brtse ba'i sbyin pa byas pa las snying rje 'phel ba dang / sbyin pa 'phel ba dang / longs spyod 'phel ba ste/ rgyu 'phel ba gsum ni/ snying rje'i stobs las sbyin pa byin pas tshe rabs thams cad snying rje gong nas gong du 'phel ba dang / snying rje'i dbang gis tshe rabs kun tu sbyin pa rgyun mi 'chad par gong nas gong du 'phel ba dang / sbyin pa'i stobs kyis tshe rabs kun tu longs spyod gong nas gong du 'phel ba'o/ /

The compassion, generosity, and possessions of a tenderhearted bodhisattva constitute three causes that grow. Here the Tibetan word ni clarifies the end of the clause “will constantly increase,” which therefore applies to each of the three preceding words in turn: from making gifts with tender love, compassion increases, generosity increases, and wealth increases. Out of compassion, bodhisattvas give generously, so that in all their lives their compassion grows more and more. Because of their compassion, in all their lives their generosity will grow greater and greater, uninterruptedly. And because of their generosity, in all their lives their wealth will increase more and more.

de las 'bras bu bde ba gsum 'phel ba ni/ bsam pa sems can gyi sdug bsngal bsal lo snyam pa'i snying rje las sems can rnams bde ba la bzhag par bya'o snyam du byams pa'i sems skye bas sbyin pa byed pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpa' de la bsam pa byams pa las byung ba'i bde ba 'phel te/ dper na mas bu la zas nor sbyin pa'i tshe byams pa'i dbang gis ma de la sems dga' ba skye ba bzhin no/ / de nas sbyin pa des sems can rjes su bzung bas bskyed pa'i bde ba 'phel ba ni/ sbyin pa des sems can la phan thogs par mthong nas byang chub sems dpa'i thugs rgyud la bde ba khyad par can 'phel ba dang sbyin pa de yi mthus byas pa'i bde ba ni sbyin pa'i dbang gis byang chub sems dpa' rnams longs spyod phongs pa med pa dang ldan par gyur nas sems can la phan 'dogs pa'i mthu yod par gyur pa'i phyir/ de'i mthus byas pa'i bde ba byang chub sems dpa' rnams la 'phel bar 'gyur te/ longs spyod med na sbyin par 'dod kyang pha rol gyi re ba rdzogs par bya mi nus kyang longs spyod yod pas de'i re ba bskang nus par mthong nas dga' ba khyad par can 'phel bar bya'o/ /

The result of these is that three kinds of happiness will increase. From the compassionate intention “I will dispel the suffering of sentient beings,” there arises the loving thought “I will establish sentient beings in happiness,” which leads to an act of generosity. At that time, the happiness that comes from the loving intention in that bodhisattva’s mind grows, like the delight a mother feels because of her love when she gives her children food and money. Then, that generosity increases the happiness that is produced by caring for sentient beings: when bodhisattvas see that their generosity is helping beings, an extraordinary happiness grows in their hearts. And the happiness that is produced by the power of that generosity grows: because of their generosity, bodhisattvas never lack wealth and consequently have the power to help sentient beings, so that the happiness produced by that power will grow in the bodhisattvas. If they had no possessions, even if they wanted to give, they would be unable to fulfill others’ hopes. But because they are wealthy, they can fulfill beings’ expectations, and when they see this, the most extraordinary joy grows in them.

de ltar byang chub sems dpa' rnams gzhan la phan 'dogs pa ji tsam pa de nyid de'i dga' bder 'gyur ba'i phyir gzhan gyi sdug bsngal bsal ba dang du blangs pas rang nyid bde bar 'gyur ba'i phyir lus dang longs spyod btang yang sdug bsngal ma yin te bde bar 'char ba'i phyir ro/ /

Thus, the more bodhisattvas help others, the more joy and happiness it will give them. Because of that, they willingly undertake to dispel others’ suffering and therefore become happy themselves, and for this reason, even though they give away their bodies and possessions, it is happiness, not pain, that they experience.
snying rjes rgyas par bya zhing 'phel bar bya/ / sbyin pas yongs smin bya zhing bde bar bya/ / kun tu drang bar bya zhing bkri bya zhes/ / zhen pa rnams la rab tu smra dang 'dra/ /

de'i phyir byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi sbyin pa gtong ba'i tshul 'di ni/ dper na mi le lo can zhig la mdza' bshes chen po zhig gis khyod 'di ltar le lo ma byed par 'di ltar gyis zhes bya ba slob pa dang 'dra ste/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis snying rjes sbyin pa byed pa'i tshe na/ 'di ltar snying rjes sbyin pa rnam pa sna tshogs rlabs chen po rgyas par bya zhing / de'i rnam smin longs spyod kyang 'di ltar 'phel bar bya'o/ / sbyin pas sems can rnams yongs su smin par bya zhing len pa po yang sems rab tu tshim pa'i bde ba dang / gtong ba po yang sbyin pa rdzogs pas bde ba'i phyir rang gzhan gnyis ka bde bar bya ba dang / gzhan sems can rnams bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs byed pa la kun tu drang bar bya zhing / bla na med pa'i byang chub kyi go 'phang la rim par bkri ba'am 'khrid par bya zhes/ sems can gtong ba la goms pa'i shugs zhan pa rnams la bskul zhing rab tu smra ba dang 'dra'o/ /

So the way in which bodhisattvas give generously is like a good friend advising someone who is lazy, saying, “Don’t be so lazy! Do it like this.” When bodhisattvas practice generosity with compassion, it is as if compassion is urging and encouraging those who are but feebly accustomed to giving to beings: “With compassion, you must swell the great waves of different forms of generosity and thus make wealth, its fully ripened effect, grow too. With generosity, you must bring sentient beings to full maturity and thus make both yourself and others happy, for the recipients will be happy, their minds content, and you who give will also be happy because of the completion of generosity. You must perfectly lead other sentient beings to accumulate merit and wisdom, and you must gradually guide them to the level of unsurpassable enlightenment.”
snying rjes sdug bsngal dag gis sdug bsngal ba/ / bde ma bskyed par gang gis bde bar 'gyur/ / de phyir brtse dang ldan pas gzhan bde ba/ / bskyed nas bdag nyid bde bar byed pa yin/ /

Because of their compassion, suffering makes them suffer. Without creating happiness, how could they be happy? It is because of this that those with tender love, By making others happy, bring happiness upon themselves. (XVIII, 52)

sems can phrag dog can rnams pha rol bde bar mthong na mi dga' zhing sdug bsngal bar mthong na dga' bar 'gyur yang / byang chub sems dpa' rnams de las bzlog pa ste/ snying rjes gzhan sdug bsngal ba dag gis rang nyid sdug bsngal ba yin pas/ sdug bsngal can de'i sdug bsngal bsal nas bde ba ma bskyed par rang nyid gang gis bde bar 'gyur te dper na bu gces pa shin tu nad kyis gzir ba'i ma bzhin no/ / de phyir brtse ba dang ldan pas gzhan sems can la rang gis bde ba bskyed nas de nyid bde bar byas pa'i bde ba des bdag rang nyid bde bar byed pa yin te/ mas bu la sman btsal te byin nas bu nad las grol te bde ba na ma de nyid sems bde ba bzhin no/ / de ltar yang dri med grags pa'i byang chub sems dpas kyang / sems can thams cad kyi nad ji srid kyi bar du bdag gi nad kyang de srid du mi 'tsho'o/ / zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

When jealous beings see others who are happy, they feel displeased, and when they see others suffering, they are delighted. Bodhisattvas are quite the opposite of them. Because of their compassion, others’ suffering makes them suffer. So unless they dispel the suffering of those who suffer and make them happy, how will they be happy themselves? They are like the mother of a beloved child who is seriously ill. For this reason, once those with tender love have themselves made other sentient beings happy, that very happiness that they have created is what makes them happy—just as when the mother has found some medicine and given it to the child. Once the child is cured of the illness and is happy and well, the mother herself feels happy. Indeed, the bodhisattva Vimalakīrti said, “As long as all sentient beings are ill, my own illness too will not be cured.”
gong du ma chags pa gsungs pa'i rgyas bshad ni/
There now follows a more detailed explanation of the quality of nonattachment mentioned above.
snying rje can ni rtag tu rang sbyin la/ / ston dang 'dra ste rang bde mi 'dod pa/ / longs spyod rnams kyis gzhan dag bde bar gyis/ / yang na tha dad min bde bdag la'ang min/ /

The compassionate always, as it were, instruct their generosity: “Do not desire happiness for yourself; Make others happy with gifts of your possessions. Otherwise, since I make no distinctions, happiness is also not for me.” (XVIII, 53)
zhes pas bstan te/
