snying rje can byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni/ snying rje slob dpon lta bu des/ dus rtag tu rang gi sbyin pa gang dang gang bya ba la/ 'di dang 'di ltar gyis zhes bslab bya ston pa dang 'dra ste ji ltar ston na dngos po 'di dang 'di dag rang gis 'chang ba'i bde ba mi 'dod pa dang / rang gi longs spyod rnams kyis gzhan dag bde bar gyis zhes 'doms shing rjes su bstan to/ / skabs 'dir snying rje slob dpon lta bus sbyin pa slob ma lta bu la 'doms pa dang 'dra ba'i tshul du 'grel pa las gsungs kyang / don 'dra la go bde bas 'di ltar bshad kyang chog par mthong ngo*/ gal te longs spyod rnams kyis gzhan bde bar byas kyang / de'i 'bras bu rang 'ba' zhig la 'thob par re bas sbyin pa ni byang chub sems dpa'i cha ma yin te/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams rang don dang gzhan don tha dad du mi 'dod par gzhan sdug bsngal la rang sdug bsngal ba dang gzhan bde bas rang bde ba skye ba yin pas longs spyod byin pa de'i 'bras bu yong sems can rnams la smin nas bde bar gyur cig ces gzhan la gtong ba yin no/ /

Compassionate bodhisattvas constantly take on the role of compassion as a master instructing their own generosity, telling it what to give and how: “Do not wish for happiness by keeping things for yourself. Make others happy with your possessions.” (In this context, the commentary says that it is as if compassion, the master, were instructing generosity, its pupil, but since it is easy to understand it as meaning the same thing, I consider it is also satisfactory to explain it like this.) Even when they make others happy with gifts of their possessions, it is not in character for bodhisattvas to give with the hope of obtaining the resulting happiness for themselves alone. Bodhisattvas do not consider their own welfare and others’ welfare as any different. They suffer in response to others’ suffering and feel happy when others are happy. So they give to others, thinking, “May even the result of my giving away my possessions ripen on sentient beings and bring them happiness.” On the other hand, if it were not to ripen on others, since their own and beings’ welfare are no different, they would never want that resulting happiness to come even to themselves.
de bdes bde ba bdag gis sbyin pa ni/ / 'bras dang bcas te sems can rnams la byin/ / gal te khyod kyis bdag la bya ba yod/ / de dag nyid la shin tu 'bras bur byos/ /
“Their happiness makes me happy, So give beings gifts along with the result. If there is something you should do for me, Make the result wholly theirs.” (XVIII, 54)

gal te yang na gzhan la mi smin pa zhig na/ bdag dang sems can gyi don tha dad min pas 'bras bu'i bde ba de bdag rang nyid la 'byung ba'ang 'dod pa min no/ / sems can de dag bde bas bdag kyang bde ba nyid du 'gyur ba de'i phyir bdag ni/ rang gces 'dzin dug dang 'dra bar spangs nas gzhan gces par 'dzin pa ches cher byed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi rjes su zhugs pa yin pas/ bdag gis sbyin pa byas pa ni/ sbyin pa'i 'bras bu dang bcas te sems can rnams la byin cig ces 'doms so/ / de'i phyir gal te sbyin pa khyod kyis bdag la longs spyod 'byung ba sogs kyi bya ba byed pa yod na/ gzhan sems can de dag nyid la shin tu 'bras bur 'gyur bar byos shig dang des bdag la phan btags pa yin no zhes snying rjes sbyin pa la 'doms pa'i tshul du sbyin pa dang 'bras bu bcas pa gzhan la gtong bar byed do/ /

“It is because sentient beings’ happiness makes me happy that I have followed the example of bodhisattvas who have abandoned their self-cherishing like poison and cherish others even more. Therefore, give sentient beings gifts along with the results of generosity.” Thus does compassion instruct generosity. “If there is something you should do for me, Generosity, like bringing me riches, you must arrange that it fully becomes the result for other beings themselves, and that will benefit me.” It is in this manner that bodhisattvas proceed to give others gifts along with the results.
sbyin pa po ni longs spyod mi 'dod kyang / / longs spyod shin tu mang la bzang dang phrad/ / bdag ni bde ba de 'dod ma yin te/ / 'di ltar bdag ni sbyin la brgyud dang ldan/ /
“Even though those who give have no desire for wealth, They gain abundant riches and good things. It’s not that I want such happiness, But like that I can continue to give.” (XVIII, 55)

de ltar sbyin pa'i 'bras bu yang sems can gzhan la snying thag pa nas btang bar byas te sbyin pa po byang chub sems dpa' rang don la ma chags pa rnams longs spyod mi 'dod kyang rung ste/ longs spyod shin tu mang la dngos po bzang po dang phrad pa rgyu 'bras rten 'brel gyi chos nyid yin no/ / de ltar gyur pa'i tshe na yang bdag ni zag bcas kyi longs spyod pa'i bde ba 'dod pa ma yin te/ longs spyod 'byor pa de'i sgo nas 'di ltar bdag gis ni sems can rnams la phan 'dogs pa'i sbyin pa byed pa la tshe rabs brgyud mar 'jug pa dang ldan pa tsam 'dod pa yin no/ /

In sincerely giving the result of generosity as well to sentient beings, the givers, bodhisattvas, who are not attached to their own welfare, have no desire for riches. But it is in the nature of the interdependence of cause and effect that they happen upon a great deal of wealth and things of good quality. “Even when this happens, it is not that I have any desire for the happiness of tainted wealth. I want merely to continue like that, from one life to the next, making gifts that will benefit sentient beings by using the wealth I have acquired.”[28]
bdag ni rtag tu brtse bas bdog pa kun/ / yongs su gtong ba gang yin de ltos la/ / des na khyod kyis bdag ni de'i 'bras la/ / don gnyer med pa nyid du shes par bya/ /
“Constantly observe me Fully giving all I own with tender love. Thus you should know that the result Does not interest me at all.” (XVIII, 56)

bdag ni rtag tu brtse bas rang gi bdog pa kun rang nyid nyams dga' ba'i ched du mi spyod par/ gzhan la yongs su gtong ba gang yin pa de ltos la des na sbyin pa khyod kyis bdag ni sbyin pa de'i 'bras bu la don du gnyer ba med pa nyid du shes par bya'o/ /

“Constantly examine me: instead of using everything I have for my own pleasure, I am giving it all away, with tender love, to others. That way you should understand, Generosity, that I am not interested in the result of those gifts.”
gal te khyod 'bras thob pa mi gtong na/ / sbyin la mngon dga' yin par mi 'gyur te/ / 'di ltar skad cig tsam yang sbyin med na/ / sbyin la mngon par dga' ba nyid ma yin/ /

“If you do not let go of the resulting benefits you will obtain, There’ll never be any delight in giving gifts. If, for a single instant, you fail to give like that, Then there will be no true joy in generosity.” (XVIII, 57)

gal te khyod longs spyod kyi dngos po tsam gzhan la gtong gi sbyin pa khyod kyi 'bras bu longs spyod thob pa mi gtong ba zhig na/ tshe phyi ma'i longs spyod dngos po thams cad la ma chags par gtong ba'i sbyin pa la mngon par dga' ba'i byang chub sems dpa' yin par mi 'gyur te/ 'di ltar tshe 'dir yang skad cig tsam du yang sbyin pa la mos pa med cing sbyin par mi 'dod pa'i blo yod na snying rjes gzhan don du sbyin pa la mngon par dga' ba nyid ma yin par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

“If you give others only your actual wealth but do not give the riches that you, Generosity, will gain as a result, you will not be a bodhisattva who delights in the unattached generosity of giving away all the riches of future lives; because if you are not interested in that sort of generosity in this life, even for an instant, and have no wish to give, there will not be the joy of giving compassionately for others’ benefit.”
ma byas pa la 'bras bu mi 'byin te/ / 'di ltar lan bltas bdag gi cha ma yin/ / khyod kyi lan la lta dang bral bas na/ / 'bras bu shin tu gzhan la gtong ba yin/ /

“You do not reward those who are not generous, But it is not like me to look for recompense like that. I do not have your hopes for something in return, And so I give the resulting benefits entirely to others.” (XVIII, 58)

sbyin pa khyod ni sbyin pa ma byas pa la 'bras bu mi 'byin pas lan la lta ba dang bcas pa min pa 'dra la/ 'di ltar sbyin pa byin pa'i 'bras bu'i lan la bltas pa ni/ gzhan la snying rjes bdag gi cha'am 'os ma yin pas/ sbyin pa khyod kyi lan la lta dang bral bas na/ khyod 'bras bu rnam par smin pa'ang bdag gir mi byed par shin tu gzhan la gtong ba yin no zhes snying rjes sbyin pa la smras pa'i tshul gyis lus longs spyod dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad la rang don du ma chags par gzhan la yongs su gtong ba'i tshul la blo sbyang tshul bstan pa yin no/ /

“Generosity, since you do not reward those who are not generous, are you not, it seems, looking for a reward? But this interest in a reward—a result from giving generously—is not a part of me or worthy of me,” declares compassion for others. “Since I am free of your looking for recompense, Generosity, I completely give away even your fully ripened effect, without considering it as mine.” This way in which compassion speaks to generosity indicates how to train the mind in giving all of one’s body, possessions, and sources of good completely to others without being attached to one’s own welfare.
snying rjes sbyin pa'i yon tan gyi don bsdus te bsngags pa/
There now follows a praise summarizing the qualities of giving with compassion.
rgyal sras rnams kyi brtse bas sbyin pa ni/ / kha na ma tho med cing dag pa'i gzhi/ / bde ba 'dren par byed pa nyid dang ni/ / rjes su srung bcas tshol med gos pa med/ /
The tender generosity of bodhisattvas Is free of shameful deeds, is based on purity, Leads to happiness, and is protective, Unquestioning, and without stain. (XVIII, 59)
zhes tshigs bcad gsum gyis bstan te/

rgyal ba'i sras po rnams kyi thugs brtse bas sbyin pa ni rnam pa drug ste/ kha na ma tho ba med pa ni/ gzhan la mi gnod par sbyin pa ste/ gzhan la phrogs nas gzhan la sbyin pa dang / sems can bsad nas de'i sha sbyin pa dang / slong ba po la brnyas shing bkres pa ltogs pa sogs tshig gis smad nas yid la sdug bsngal bskyed de sbyin pa sogs sems can gzhan la gnod pa med cing tshul bzhin legs par sbyin pa'o/ / dag pa'i gnas sam gzhi sbyin pa ni ma brtags pa'i dngos po dug dang mtshon la sogs pa ma dag pa'i dngos po sbyin pa mi byed par brtags nas dngos po dag cing gtsang ma sbyin par byed pa'o/ / phan par byed pa'i sbyin pa ni/ sbyin pas bsdus nas dge ba la sbyor bar byas pas sbyin yul sems can de dag skye ba phyi ma la mtho ris dang thar pa'i 'bras bu'i bde ba 'dren par byed pa nyid dang ni/ sbyin pa des rang gi 'khor gyi 'gro ba bu smad dang bran g.yog sogs la gnod pa ni thams cad btang nas de dag gi skal ba mi bzhag pa'am/ chung ma dang bu sogs gzhan la gtong na yang de dag gi sems dang mi 'gal ba'am mthar de dag sdug bsngal chen por mi 'gyur bar shes nas gtong gi de dag shin tu sdug bsngal ba dang / gnod sbyin srin po sogs ma rungs pa la 'khor sbyin pa sogs mdor na rang la dbang ba'i 'khor rnams la gnod pa med pa ni/ rjes su srung ba dang bcas par sbyin pa'o/ /

The generosity of the buddhas’ children, made with loving tenderness, has six aspects. It is free of shameful deeds, meaning that they give without harming others. They do not give things that they have stolen from someone else, or give the meat of beings that have been killed, or give to beggars while making them unhappy by belittling and humiliating them by calling them poor, starving beggars, and so on. Instead of this sort of generosity that involves harming others, bodhisattvas give properly and correctly. They give things whose state or basis is pure. Rather than giving things that they have not examined, impure things like poisonous substances or weapons, they give pure, clean things that they have checked first. Their gifts are beneficial, for having attracted beings with their generosity, bodhisattvas introduce them to virtue and thus lead these beings, the objects of their generosity, to its happy results in their future rebirths, that is, to the higher realms and liberation. Bodhisattvas give protectively, that is, their generosity does not involve harming members of their entourage for whom they are responsible. They do not, for instance, treat their family, attendants, and so on wrongfully by giving everything away and leaving them with nothing. And even if they give away their spouse and children to others, they do so knowing that it is not against their will or that they will not greatly suffer in the end, but never if it would cause them intense suffering. Nor would they ever give them away to ferocious beings like yakṣa spirits and rākṣasa ogres.

tshol ba med par sbyin pa ni/ sems can phongs par shes nas de dag gi ched du ma bslang yang de la phan pa'i ched du rang gi lag nas sbyin gyi sbyin gnas gzhan yongs su mi tshol ba'am/ 'di la sbyin 'di la mi sbyin zhes bsod nams kyi zhing bdam nas tshol zhing mi sbyin par/ phyogs lhang med par snyoms par sbyin pa'o/ / gos pa med pa'am chags pa med pa'i sbyin pa ni lan dang rnam smin la re ba med par gtong ba'o/ / 'di ni skyon dag pa'i cha nas bstan pa'o/ / yang yon tan gyi cha nas thams cad gtong ba'am mtha' dag gtong ba sogs dgu ste/

They give unquestioningly, that is, equally and impartially. Once they have realized that beings are in need, even if the latter are not begging expressly, they give them things from their own hands in order to help them. They never go looking for other worthy causes or give selectively, choosing the field of merit and thinking, “I’ll give this one something, but I won’t give that one anything.” Their generosity is untainted or unattached, for they give without hoping for anything in return or for karmic recompense. These six aspects are described from the point of view of purifying possible faults in practicing generosity. From the point of view of good qualities, there are nine aspects, beginning with giving away everything.
rgyal sras rnams kyi brtse bas sbyin pa ni/ / mtha' dag rgya che gtso dang rtag par dang / / dga' dang zang zing med dang dag pa dang / / byang chub la gzhol dge la gzhol ba yin/ /

With tender love, bodhisattvas give everything On a vast scale and of the best quality, constantly, With joy, an absence of materialism, and purity, Dedicating their generosity to enlightenment and to virtue. (XVIII, 60)

mtha' dag gtong ba ni phyi dang nang gi dngos po gang yang mi gtong ba cung zad med pa'o/ / rgyas par ram rgya che bar gtong ba ni/ dngos po chung ngu dang nyung ngu tsam min par mang la rgya che ba gtong ba'o/ / gtso bo gtong ba ni/ dngos po nyams pa dang rul ba dang spyad du mi rung ba mi gtong gi kha dog dang dbyibs dang dri phun sum tshogs pa dang dngos po bzang po gya nom pa gtong ba dang / rtag par gtong ba ni/ dus res 'ga' gtong res 'ga' mi gtong ba ma yin par/ dus rtag pa rgyun du gtong ba dang / dga' bar gtong ba ni/ ser sna'i sems med par slong ba po su la yang gtong mi gtong med par dga' ba dang bcas te gtong ba dang / zang zing med par gtong ba ni lan dang rnam smin la re ba med pas gtong ba dang / dag pa gtong ba ni gong du dag pa'i gzhi sbyin pa dang don gcig ste dngos po dag pa gtong ba dang / byang chub tu bsngo ba gtong ba ni/ sbyin pa byas pa ste mtho ris kyi bde ba dang nyan rang gi myang 'das kyi phyir mi bsngo bar sems can thams cad kyi don du bla na med pa'i byang chub 'thob pa'i phyir bsngo bas bla med byang chub la gzhol ba dang / dge ba bsngo ba'i gtong ba ni/ gong du phan par byed pa'i sbyin pa bshad pa dang don gcig ste sems can rnams sbyin pas bsdus nas dge ba la gzhol ba'am 'god pa yin no/ / de ltar sbyin pa byas pa las bde ba 'byung tshul ni/

Bodhisattvas give away everything: there is nothing, external or internal, that they do not give. They give extensively or on a vast scale—that is, they give many vast gifts, not just a few small things. They give the best, meaning that rather than giving things that are deteriorated or rotten or unfit for use, they give the very best things that are abundant and perfect in their color, shape, and fragrance. Their generosity is constant, for rather than giving sometimes and not at other times, they give all the time, continuously. They give joyfully, taking pleasure in giving, without stingy thoughts or wondering which beggars they will give to and which not. They give without materialistic attitudes—that is, without hoping for anything in return or for karmic recompense. Their generosity is pure, in that they make pure gifts, which means the same as giving things whose basis is pure as mentioned above. It is dedicated to enlightenment: rather than dedicate their acts of generosity to happiness in the higher realms or to the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ nirvāṇa, they dedicate them in order to attain unsurpassable enlightenment for the sake of all sentient beings, thus devoting those acts of generosity to unsurpassable enlightenment. And their generosity is dedicated to virtue, which means the same as their gifts being beneficial as explained above: having attracted sentient beings with their gifts, they apply those beings to, or establish them in, the practice of virtue. The manner in which practicing generosity in this way brings about happiness is as follows.
ji ltar bde ba gsum gyis tshims pa'i yid/ / brtse ldan yongs su gtong bas dga' 'gyur ba/ / longs spyod can dag nye bar spyad pa yis/ / de ltar dga' bar 'gyur ba ma yin no/ /

While those with tender love, their minds sated with joy on three accounts, Find great delight in giving everything away, No similar delight will those who revel in those gifts Derive from using all those things. (XVIII, 61)

ji ltar sbyin pa nyid la dga' ba'i bde ba dang / pha rol la phan btags pa'i dga' ba'i bde ba dang / byang chub kyi tshogs rdzogs pas dga' ba'i bde ba gsum gyis tshims pa'i yid can brtse ba dang ldan pa byang chub sems dpa' de/ rang gi bdog pa thams cad yongs su gtong bas dga' bar 'gyur ba lta bu ni/ longs spyod 'dod dgu thob pa can dag longs spyod de la nye bar spyad pa yis de ltar dga' bar 'gyur ba ma yin no/ / skabs 'di'i longs spyod can ni byang chub sems dpas sbyin pa gtong yul 'dod dgu thob pa de dag gtong ba po dga' ba ltar dga' mi nus zhes 'grel par bshad/ spyir mtho ris kyi longs spyod phun sum tshogs pa la longs spyad pa rnams kyang byang chub sems dpa'i gtong ba'i dga' ba lta bu nam yang myong ba med par bshad kyang rung ste/ yon tan rin po che sdud pa las/ gling bzhi legs par brgyan pa mchil ma'i thal ba 'dra/ / byin nas dga' bar 'gyur gyi gling thob de ltar min/ / zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

Tender bodhisattvas, whose minds are satiated with three kinds of happiness (those of the joy of giving, the joy of helping others, and the joy of completing the accumulations related to enlightenment) are delighted to give away everything they own. For those who receive all those pleasurable gifts, using them will never procure the same sort of delight. “Those who revel” in this context are the objects of the bodhisattvas’ generosity, who obtain all they could wish for. As the commentary explains, they are incapable of deriving the same delight as the givers. They can also be explained as being those in general who enjoy the abundant pleasures of the higher realms and who never experience anything like the pleasure a bodhisattva has in being generous, as the Verses Summarizing the Precious Qualities states: “To give away the four continents, so beautifully adorned, as if they were drops of spit brings great delight. But there is no such delight for those who receive those continents.”
bdun pa snying rje skye ba'i rgyu bshad pa ni/
vii. AN EXPLANATION OF THE CAUSAL FACTORS THAT GIVE RISE TO COMPASSION
bkren la brtse dang ma rungs pa la brtse/ / kun 'khrugs la brtse bag med rnams la brtse/ / yul gyi gzhan dbang can la snying rje dang / / log par mngon par zhen la snying rje'o/ /

Tender love for the stingy, tender love for the unruly, Tender love for those in turmoil, tender love for the careless, Compassion for those beguiled by objects, And compassion for those who mistakenly cling— (XVIII, 62)
zhes pas bstan te/

phar phyin drug sgrub pa dang bral ba'i sems can rnams la snying rje skye ste ser sna'i dbang gis sems rgyud bkren cing 'jungs par gyur nas cung zad gtong mi nus pa rnams la snying brtse bas ser sna'i skyon dang sbyin pa'i yon tan brjod nas sbyin pa'i chos la 'jog par mdzad pa dang / rgyud ngan pa'i ngang tshul can ma rungs pa srog gcod pa sogs sdig pa'i las spyod pa la brtse bas tshul khrims dang ldan pa'i chos bstan nas tshul khrims la 'jog par mdzad pa dang / rgyud khong khros kun nas 'khrugs pa rnams la brtse bas zhe sdang gi skyon dang bzod pa'i yon tan gyi chos bstan nas bzod pa la 'jog pa dang / tha mal gyi las la dga' ba'i le lo'i dbang gis dge ba'i las mi byed pa'i bag med pa rnams la brtse bas le lo spong bar byed pa'i brtson 'grus dang ldan pa'i chos bstan nas brtson 'grus la 'jog pa dang / 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga'i yul gyi gzhan dbang du song bas rtag tu sems rnam par g.yeng ba can rnams la snying rje bas bsam gtan gyi chos bstan nas bsam gtan la 'jog par mdzad pa dang / zag bcas kyi phung po rnams la rtag pa dang bdag dang gtsang ba dang bde bar 'dzin pa phyin ci log par mngon par zhen pa rnams la snying rje bas log pa'i shes rab kyi skyon bstan nas yang dag pa'i shes rab la 'jog par byed pa'o/ /

Compassion arises for sentient beings who lack the practice of the six transcendent perfections. With tenderness[29] in their hearts for those who, on account of stinginess, have become miserly and avaricious and are unable to give away the smallest thing, bodhisattvas tell them about the defects of stinginess and the qualities of generosity, and thus set them to practicing generosity. With tender love for those unruly beings of evil character who habitually commit negative actions such as taking life, they teach the qualities of keeping discipline and establish them in the practice of discipline. With tender love for those who minds are in a complete turmoil because of anger, they teach the defects of hatred and the good qualities of patience, and establish them in the practice of patience. With tender love for those who, on account of their laziness, delight in ordinary tasks but are careless about performing positive actions, they teach the qualities of having diligence and giving up laziness, and thus establish them in the practice of diligence. With compassion for those whose minds are constantly distracted by their being spellbound by the pleasures of the five senses, they teach the qualities of concentration and establish them in the practice of concentration. And with compassion for those who believe that there is permanence, a self, purity, and happiness in the tainted aggregates, and who are mistakenly attached to them, they teach the defects of incorrect understanding and establish them in true wisdom.
bde dang sdug bsngal bde rgyu las/ / byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje ste/ / rgyu dang bshes gnyen rang bzhin las/ / byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje'o/ /
A bodhisattva’s compassion Comes from happiness and suffering and their cause; A bodhisattva’s compassion Comes from its cause, the teacher, and its nature. (XVIII, 63)
zhes pas bstan te/

yang byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje skye ba'i rkyen ni bzhi ste/ dmigs rkyen ni/ khams gsum zag bcas kyi tshor ba bde ba thams cad la 'gyur ba'i sdug bsngal gyis khyab pa dang sdug bsngal ba'i tshor ba thams cad sdug bsngal gyi sdug bsngal gyis khyab pa dang / tshor ba btang snyoms la 'du byed gyi sdug bsngal gyis khyab pas gang ci tshor ba thams cad sdug bsngal ba las ma 'das pas de la dmigs nas snying rje skye ba dang / de rgyu zhes pa bde sdug btang snyoms kyi tshor ba gsum gyi bag la nyal bar 'grel pas bshad cing de ni bag chags kyi rang bzhin yin pas tshor ba btang snyoms pa yin zhing / bag nyal de ma spangs kyi bar du bde sdug gnyis yang yang 'byung bas 'du byed kyi sdug bsngal gyi sdug bsngal phra ba'ang de'o/ / yang na bde sdug gi tshor ba dang bcas pa'i zag bcas kyi phung po de yi rgyu la 'du byed kyi sdug bsngal zhes bshad kyang rung ste/ don du sdug bsngal gsum dang ldan pa'i sems can la dmigs nas byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje skye ba ste zhes so/ / tshe rabs gzhan du snying rje goms par byas pas kun gzhi la snying brtse ba'i bag chags bsags pa ni snying rje'i rgyu yi rkyen dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen las dam pa'i chos thos pas snying rje skye ba ni bdag po'i rkyen to/ / snying rje'i sems snga ma snga ma'i rang bzhin las phyi ma phyi ma skye ba ni snga ma rnams de ma thag pa'i rkyen te/ de ltar rgyu yi rkyen la sogs pa gsum las byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje skye ba'o/ /

Moreover, there are four contributory conditions that give rise to a bodhisattva’s compassion. The objective condition through which compassion arises consists in considering the fact that there are no feelings whatsoever that transcend suffering. For the three worlds are pervaded by the suffering of change, comprising all tainted pleasant feelings; they are pervaded by the suffering of suffering, comprising all painful feelings; and they are pervaded by the suffering of everything composite, comprising neutral feelings. “Their cause” is explained in the commentary as referring to the latent tendencies for pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings, and since these are by nature habitual tendencies, they are neutral feelings. Until these latent tendencies have been eliminated, happiness and suffering occur again and again, so they also constitute the subtle suffering of the suffering of everything composite. “Their cause” may also be explained as the cause of the tainted aggregates, along with pleasant and painful feelings, which refers to the suffering of everything composite. Whichever the case, the point being made here is that it is from considering sentient beings who have the three kinds of suffering that a bodhisattva’s compassion arises. The storing in the ground of all of the habitual tendency to tenderhearted compassion from training in compassion in other lives is the causal condition for compassion. Giving rise to compassion through hearing the sacred Dharma from a spiritual master is the dominant condition. And the arising of each instant of compassionate mind from the nature of the previous one is the immediately preceding condition. It is from these three conditions (causal, dominant, and immediately preceding) that a bodhisattva’s compassion arises.
brgyad pa byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje mnyam pa nyid kyi khyad par du 'phags pa ni/
viii. THE SUPERIORITY OF A BODHISATTVA’S COMPASSION IN TERMS OF ITS BEING EQUAL
byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje ni/ / mnyam par shes bya de bsam phyir/ / sgrub phyir 'dod chags bral phyir dang / / mi dmigs phyir dang dag phyir ro/ /
A bodhisattva’s compassion Is to be understood as equal on account of its attitude, Its accomplishment, its absence of attachment, Its nonconceptuality, and its purity. (XVIII, 64)
zhes pas bstan te/

byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje ni mnyam par shes par bya ste/ ji ltar na 'jig rten pa rnams gnyen bshes kyi tshogs la snying rje yang dgra la snying rje mi skye bar zhe sdang bar byed cing bar ma rnams la'ang snying rje mi skye ba dang / nyan rang rnams kyis sdug bsngal ba rnams la snying rje skye yi thams cad du mnyam par snying rje mi skye bas de dag gi snying rje mnyam pa ma yin la/ byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje ni gong du bshad pa ltar sdug bsngal gsum dang ldan pa'i sems can srid rtse nas mnar med pa'i bar la khyad med par snying rje chen po mnyam pa nyid du skye ba'o/ / de'i phyir de ltar sems can thams cad la bsam pa de lta bu bsam pa'i phyir bsam pa mnyam pas snying rje mnyam pa dang / sems can sdug bsngal can dmyal ba la sogs pa bskyab par mdzad pa de bzhin srid pa'i rtse mo'i bar gyi sems can thams cad la bskyab par mdzad pas sgrub pa mnyam pa'i phyir snying rje mnyam pa dang / sems can gyi ris su gyur pa gang la'ang chags pa dang sdang ba med pas 'dod chags dang bral ba'i phyir snying rje mnyam pa dang / bdag dang sems can dang snying rje gsum char gyi mtshan mar mi dmigs par thams cad stong pa nyid du ro gcig par khong du chud pa'i phyir snying rje mnyam pa dang / 'khor gsum mi dmigs pa'i shes rab de nyid 'bad rtsol dang mtshan ma'i g.yo ba dag pa sa brgyad pa nas thob pas de yan chad rnam par dag pa thob pa'i phyir snying rje mnyam pa dag tu 'gyur ro/ /

Bodhisattvas’ compassion should be understood as being equal. In what way? Although ordinary beings have compassion for their friends and relations, they do not feel compassion for their enemies, nor for those who are neither friend nor enemy. Listeners and solitary realizers have compassion for those who suffer, but they do not develop the same compassion for everybody, and their compassion is therefore unequal. Bodhisattvas’ compassion, on the other hand, as explained earlier, arises in the state of sameness, the great compassion that makes no distinction between beings who have the three kinds of suffering, from the peak of existence right down to the Hell of Torment Unsurpassed. It is because of this attitude toward all sentient beings that their compassion is equal—because that attitude is equal. Since bodhisattvas protect all beings—protecting those suffering in the hells and so forth as much as those at the peak of existence—their accomplishment is equal, so it is on account of this that their compassion is equal. They have no attachment or aversion to any class of beings, and therefore their compassion is equal on account of its absence of attachment. Their compassion is equal because they have realized that everything is one taste in emptiness, without any concepts of themselves, sentient beings, and compassion as having specific attributes. And it is equal because from the moment they attain the eighth level, in which the wisdom free of the concepts of the three spheres is purified of the movements of effort and of attributes, they have attained perfect purity.
dgu pa snying rje mchog tu gyur pa ni/
ix. THE BEST COMPASSION
rang gi sems kyis byams la sogs/ / sgom pa chos la mos pa dang / / bsam dang dbang 'byor nyid dang ni/ / rnam par mi rtog gcig phyir mchog /

The bodhisattvas’ mental training in the four boundless attitudes Is the best by virtue of their interest in the Dharma, Their specific mental states, mastery, Nonconceptuality, and oneness. (XVIII, 65)
ces pas bstan te/

spyir byams sogs tshad med pa bzhi po bsgom pa tsam gzugs khams kyi lha rnams dang nyan rang la yang yod mod kyi/ byang chub sems dpa'i tshad med pa'i bsgom pa ni mchog tu gyur pa'i tshul ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams rang gi sems kyis byams pa la sogs pa sgom pa ni/ tshe rabs snga ma rnams su byams sogs bsgoms pa'i bag chags kyis tshe rabs 'di dang phyi ma rnams su gong nas gong du khyad par 'phel ba'i phyir de 'dra'i bsgom pa de gzhan las mchog tu gyur pa dang / tshad med bzhi dang ldan pa'i chos mdo sde rnams la cher mos shing dad par byas pa dang / bsam pa'i khyad par dgu gong du bshad pa de lta bu dang ldan pa'i khyad par dang / ting nge 'dzin la dbang 'byor ba'am/ khyad par du'ang sa brgyad pa sogs su 'bad rtsol med par byams sogs lhun gyis grub par 'byung bas dbang 'byor ba nyid dang ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i byams sogs bzhi bsgom pa ni sgom pa po bdag dang / yul sems can bsgom par bya ba tshad med bzhi yi mtshan mar rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyis zin pa dang / sa brgyad pa thob nas brtsams te sa der zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' mdzad pa gcig tu 'dres shing nye bar 'dres par gyur pa'i phyir mchog tu gyur pa yin no/ /

From a general point of view, simple meditation on love and the other three boundless attitudes is something the gods of the world of form and the listeners and solitary realizers also have. But the bodhisattvas’ practice of the four boundless attitudes is the greatest. How? The bodhisattvas’ mental training in love and the other boundless attitudes grows especially greater in their present and future lives on account of their habitual tendencies from having trained in the four boundless attitudes in their previous lives. As a result, this kind of practice is superior to that of others. Bodhisattvas have great interest and faith in the sūtras related to the four boundless attitudes. Their boundless attitudes are distinctly superior in that they are associated with the nine specific mental states described above.[30] They have mastery in concentration, or especially mastery on account of the fact that their love and other boundless attitudes arise effortlessly and spontaneously on the eighth and higher levels. Bodhisattvas’ practice of the four boundless attitudes is imbued with the gnosis that has no concept of attributes in a meditator (themselves), of an object (sentient beings), and of four boundless attitudes to be practiced. And, beginning from their attainment of the eighth level, the deeds of the bodhisattvas on those levels are completely mingled and equivalent. It is on account of all this that bodhisattvas’ practice of the four boundless attitudes is the best.
bzhi pa mchod bsten tshad med kyi le'u'i mjug bsdu ba ni/
4. CONCLUSION TO THE CHAPTER ON OFFERING, RELIANCE, AND BOUNDLESS ATTITUDES

de ltar bcom ldan 'das la dang ba rab skyes shing / / rdzas dang bkur sti chen pos shin tu rgyun mchod ldan/ / yon tan mang ldan phan byed bshes la rtag bsten pa/ / 'gro la rjes su brtse ba grub pa kun 'thob 'gyur/ /

Thus, by developing deep faith in the bhagavāns And making constant, extraordinary offerings—material things as well as great veneration— By always following the beneficial friend who is possessed of many qualities, And through tender love for beings, they will gain every accomplishment. (XVIII, 66)
zhes pas bstan te/

ji skad bstan pa de ltar sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams la yon tan bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i bdag nyid du yid ches pa'i sems rab tu dang ba skyes shing / chos gos dang na bza' me tog dang bdug pa la sogs pa'i rdzas kyi mchod pa dang / phyag 'tshal ba dang bstod pa bsgrags pa dang bskor ba byed pa sogs dang / bka' bzhin gus pa'i bsgrub pa dang bcas pa'i bkur sti chen pos shin tu mchod pa dang / mchod pa de yang dus res 'ga' tsam ma yin par nam mam rgyun du mchod par byed pa dang ldan pas bdag dang gzhan gyi don du gyur pa'i 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i grub pa kun 'thob par 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi yon tan gong du bshad pa dang / de las gzhan yang mdo sde dang gtsug lag gi nang nas dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi yon tan bstan pa de lta bu'i yon tan dang ldan pa'i dge ba'i bshes la bsten na de yi yon tan tshad med pa mang po 'byung bar gsungs pa de lta bu dang ldan pa yi sgo nas/ tshe 'di dang tshe rabs gzhan thams cad du phan par byed pa'i bshes gnyen rtag tu bsten pa yis kyang grub pa kun 'thob par 'gyur ro/ / 'gro ba thams cad la rjes su brtse ba'i rang bzhin byams snying rje dga' ba btang snyoms tshad med pa bzhi'i sgo nas sems can la phan btags pas kyang grub pa kun 'thob par 'gyur ro/ / mchod bsten gnyis kyis gtso bor bdag gi don dang / tshad med bzhis gzhan don gtso bor grub bo zhes 'grel bar gsungs/ spyir gang rung gis kyang gnyis ka 'grub pa 'byung ngo / /

Thus, as described above, by developing extremely clear faith and confidence in the buddha bhagavāns as the embodiment of inconceivable qualities; by making material offerings of Dharma robes, garments, flowers, incense, and suchlike; by performing prostrations, reciting praises, circumambulating, and so on; by making the extraordinary offering of great veneration together with respectfully practicing the teachings; and by making those offerings not merely occasionally but constantly, one will obtain all mundane and supramundane accomplishments, benefiting both oneself and others. Similarly, it has been taught that if one relies on a teacher who possesses qualities such as the qualities of a spiritual master explained above and also the other relevant qualities described in the sūtras and sacred texts, one will gain many of those boundless good qualities. By possessing such qualities one will, in this life and in all one’s other lives, always follow a spiritual master who will benefit one, and one will thereby also obtain all the accomplishments. And by means of the four boundless attitudes—love, compassion, joy, and impartiality—whose nature is a tender affection for all beings, one will benefit beings and again, on account of this, obtain all the accomplishments. According to the commentary, by making offerings and following a spiritual master one mainly accomplishes one’s own goal, while with the four boundless attitudes one mainly accomplishes others’ goals. In general, any of these will lead to one’s accomplishing both.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ mchod pa dang bsten pa dang tshad med pa'i le'u ste bco brgyad pa'o// //
This completes the eighteenth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on offerings, reliance, and boundless attitudes.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ mchod pa dang bsten pa dang tshad med pa'i le'u ste bco brgyad pa rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the eighteenth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on offerings, reliance, and boundless attitudes.
! bzhi pa byang chub phyogs mthun gyi
19. ELEMENTS LEADING TO ENLIGHTENMENT
le'u 'di ni bsgom pa gtso bor ston pa yin pas 'di la/ rgyu dang / ngo bo dang / khyad par du byed pa'i yan lag gsum las/
This chapter deals mainly with meditation, and for this there are three parts: (1) prerequisites; (2) the essence of the path or training; and (3) branches that enhance the practice.
dang po
1. PREREQUISITES

['di] la ji ltar dam bcas pa'i tshul khrims la gnas pa dang / thos pa dang bsam pa dang ldan pas tshogs bsags pa'i bar gyis bstan te/ ngo tsha shes pa dang brtan pa dang mi skyo ba gsum gyi sgo nas bslab las mi 'da' bar byas te/ bstan bcos shes pa dang / 'jig rten shes pa'i tshul gyis thos pa dang / rton pa dang yang dag rig pa bzhi'i tshul gyis bsam byung gi shes rab rnam par dag pa dang ldan pas tshogs gnyis bsags pa la 'bad par bya ba yin pas/ de dag go rims bzhin bshad pa la/

This section explains different prerequisites, from the observance of the discipline to which one is pledged, through listening and reflection, up to the gathering of the accumulations. Bodhisattvas have to make efforts in not transgressing the precepts by relying on (1) a sense of shame, (2) steadfastness, and (3) indefatigability; in having the perfectly pure wisdom that comes from listening through (4) knowledge of the treatises and (5) knowledge of the world, and from reflecting by way of (6) the four reliances and (7) the four kinds of perfect knowledge; and thence (8) in gathering the two accumulations. These will now be explained in order.
dang po
a. A SENSE OF SHAME

ngo tsha shes pa ni/ ngo tsha mi mthun phyogs spangs dang / /zhes pa nas/ gcig pa nyid kyis gtso bo yin zhes pa'i bar gyis tshigs bcad bcu drug gis bstan pa 'di la'ang nang gses su/ ngo tsha shes pa'i mtshan nyid dang / gnas gang la ngo tsha ba dang / ngo tsha ba'i dbye ba dang / ngo tsha med pa'i nyes dmigs dang / ngo tsha ba'i phan yon dang / ngo tsha ba ldan pa la bsngags pa dang ngo tsha khrel yod dang ldan pa'i rtags dang / khrel yod mchog tu gyur pa bstan pa bcas rnam grangs brgyad las/

A sense of shame is covered by the first sixteen verses and is divided into eight topics: (1) the specific characteristics of a sense of shame; (2) shameful ways; (3) categories of a sense of shame, superior and inferior; (4) the disadvantages of not having a sense of shame and decency; (5) the benefits of having a sense of shame and decency; (6) in praise of those who have a sense of shame and decency; (7) the signs of having a sense of shame and decency; and (8) the best sense of shame and decency.
dang po ngo tsha shes pa dang khrel yod pa ni/
i. THE SPECIFIC CHARACTERISTICS OF A SENSE OF SHAME
ngo tsha mi mthun phyogs spangs dang / / rnam par mi rtog ye shes ldan/ / kha na ma tho med dman yul/ / sems can smin byed brtan pa'i yin/ /

A sense of shame has eliminated its opposite, Is coupled with nonconceptual gnosis, Has as its object lower paths that are merely free of wrongdoing, Matures sentient beings, and belongs to the steadfast. (XIX, 1)
zhes pas bstan te/

de'i mi mthun phyogs ngo tsha mi shes pa dang khrel med pa de gnyis spangs nas ngo tsha shes pa dang khrel yod pa'i rang bzhin du gyur pa'o/ / de yang bdag la ltos nas ngo tsha shes pa dang / gzhan la ltos nas khrel yod pa zhes bya ste byang chub sems dpa' rang gi bslab bya'i chos theg pa chen po'i lam btang nas nyan rang gi spyod pa la bslabs na 'di ni bdag byang chub sems dpa'i cha ma yin zhes ngo tsha ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' gzhan dag gis kyang smod par 'gyur ro zhes khrel yod pa ni de gnyis kyi rang bzhin dang grogs rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyis zin pa dang ldan pa ni bdag dang sems can gzhan dang / ngo tsha khrel yod kyi chos gsum gyi mtshan ma mi dmigs pa'o/ /

A sense of shame and a sense of decency consist in the elimination of their counteragents—shamelessness and a lack of consideration. One speaks of a sense of shame with regard to oneself, and of a sense of decency with regard to others. If bodhisattvas were to give up their own training, that is, the path of the Great Vehicle, and train in the practices of the listeners and solitary realizers, they would feel ashamed, thinking, “This is not for me, a bodhisattva.” And their sense of decency would tell them, “Other bodhisattvas will criticize you.” This, then, is the nature of a sense of shame and decency. Its ally, supporting it, is nonconceptual gnosis, which does not conceptualize any attributes in oneself, in other sentient beings, or in the sense of shame and decency.

dmigs pa ni theg pa dman pa'i lam ste de la zhugs na ngo tsha ba'o/ / de yang nyan rang gi theg pa de la zhugs pa dag la nyon mongs pa'i kha na ma tho ba med kyang bdag gi don 'ba' zhig la zhugs pas bsam pa dang shes rab dang sgrub pa dang 'bras bu dang thams cad theg pa chen po las ches dman pa'i yul yin pas yul de la dmigs nas byang chub sems dpa' rnams de la 'jug pa la ngo tsha bar byed do/ / byed las ni byang chub sems dpa'i ngo tsha dang khrel yod kyis sems can rnams smin par byed de/ de lta bu'i ngo tsha dang khrel yod ni brtan pa'i ste byang chub sems dpa'i yin gyi/ nyan rang rnams ni rang gi gnyen du gyur pa'i sems can rnams la ltos pa med par bor nas rang gcig pu zhi bde don du gnyer bas byang chub sems dpa' la ltos na rgyud las/ rang gi bu la'ang ma chags pa'i/ / nyan thos rnams ni skal ba ngan/ / sems can thams cad bde mdzad pa'i/ / skal bzang phyag na rdo rje dpal/ / zhes gsungs pa ltar de rnams ngo tsha dang khrel chung ba yin no/ /

Its objects are the paths of the lower vehicles, for bodhisattvas would feel ashamed of engaging in them. Although those who have entered the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ vehicles are free of any wrongdoing associated with defilements, they are engaged only in their own welfare, so their motivation, wisdom, accomplishment, and result all constitute objects that are far inferior to those of the Great Vehicle. So when they consider those objects, bodhisattvas are ashamed to engage in them. The function of a sense of shame and decency is to enable bodhisattvas to bring sentient beings to maturity. This kind of sense of shame and decency is that of a steadfast bodhisattva. But listeners and solitary realizers, with no regard for sentient beings, who are their own kin, reject them and strive for their own peace and happiness alone, so compared to bodhisattvas, they have little sense of shame and decency, as we read in a tantra: Unfortunate are the listeners, Who have no affection even for their own children. Fortunate is Vajrapāṇi, Who makes all sentient beings happy.
gnyis pa ni/
ii. SHAMEFUL WAYS

pha rol phyin pa drug po yi/ / mi mthun phyogs ni 'phel ba dang / / gnyen po 'grib pas byang chub sems/ / mi zad ngo tsha skye bar 'gyur/ / brtan rnams pha rol phyin pa drug / brtan pa la ni le lo dang / / nyon mongs rjes su mthun chos la/ / sbyor ba las kyang ngo tshar 'gyur/ /

When the counteragents Of the six perfections increase in them And the antidotes decrease, Bodhisattvas feel unbearably ashamed. (XIX, 2) The steadfast are ashamed of being lazy About training in the six perfections, And also of indulging in activities Related to the defilements. (XIX, 3)
ces pas bstan te/

gnas gang la ngo tsha ba yin zhe na/ /sbyin pa sogs pha rol tu phyin pa drug po yi/ mi mthun phyogs ser sna sogs rang gi rgyud la 'phel ba dang / gnyen po sbyin sogs 'grib pas byang chub sems dpa' rnams la/ mi bzad pa'i ngo tsha skye ba nyid du 'gyur te/ 'jig rten na rigs che zhing mtho ba dag rigs ngan gyi spyod pa byed pa la ngo tsha ba las kyang byang chub sems dpa' la ser sna sogs 'phel ba ngo tsha zhing sbyin pa sogs 'grib pa'ang shin tu ngo tsha ba yin no/ / 'di la 'phel ba dang 'grib pa la ngo tsha ba zhes bya'o/ / de bzhin du sbyor ba dang mi sbyor ba la ngo tsha ba ni brtan pa byang chub sems dpa' rnams pha rol phyin pa drug po rang rgyud la goms shing brten pa la ni le lo byed cing mi sbyor ba dang / 'dod chags zhe sdang sogs nyon mongs pa rnams skye ba dang rjes su mthun pa'i chos dbang po drug gi sgo mi sdom zhing 'dod yon lnga yi yul la 'jug pa la sbyor ba las kyang ngo tsha bar 'gyur ro/ /

One might wonder what sorts of ways bodhisattvas would be ashamed of. When stinginess and the other counteragents of generosity and the other five transcendent perfections increase in their mind streams, and their antidotes, generosity and the others, diminish, bodhisattvas are overcome with shame. They are ashamed of stinginess increasing and utterly ashamed of their generosity diminishing—even more ashamed than are worldly aristocrats of behaving like plebeians. This is known as a sense of shame with regard to increase and diminution. Similarly, there is shame with regard to application and nonapplication. Steadfast bodhisattvas are ashamed of lazing about and not applying themselves to training their mind streams in the six transcendent perfections. They are also ashamed of not restraining the doors of their six sense organs that correspond to and give rise to attachment, aversion, and other defilements, and of indulging in their objects, the five pleasures of the senses.
gsum pa mchog dman gyi dbye ba ni/
iii. CATEGORIES OF A SENSE OF SHAME, SUPERIOR AND INFERIOR
mnyam bzhag ngo bo nyid min chung / / 'bring dang dman pa'i sa pa dang / / bsam pa dman dang ngar bcas pa'i/ / ngo tsha dman de las gzhan lhag /

In those who are, by nature, not concentrated, Who are lesser, middling, or on inferior levels, Whose motivation is inferior, or who have a sense of “I,” Their sense of shame is inferior; in others it is superior. (XIX, 4)
ces pas bstan te/

mnyam bzhag gi ngo bo nyid min pa 'dod pa'i khams kyi sa pa'i ngo tsha dang khrel yod ni chung ngu'am dman la de bzhin du mnyam par bzhag pa gzugs dang gzugs med pa la yang ngo tsha khrel yod chung ngu dang / 'bring dang / chen po gsum du phye ba'i chung ngu dang 'bring chung ngur bsdu la/ mos spyod dang sa dang po sogs 'og ma 'og ma rnams rang rang gi gong ma gong ma la ltos nas chung ngu dang / gong ma rnams 'og ma la ltos nas chen por bzhag go / bsam pa dman pa nyan rang rnams kyi ngo tsha dang khrel yod pas bdag gi don 'ba' zhig bsgrub pas chung ngu dang / sa dang po nas bdun pa'i bar gyi ngar bcas zhes pa 'bad rtsol gyi mtshan ma'i nga rgyal dang bcas pa'i phyir/ de dag gi ngo tsha ni dman pa'am chung ngu zhes bya ste ltos 'jog gi sgo nas so/ / de las gzhan lhag pa'am chen po ste/ mnyam par bzhag pa'i sa pa'i ngo tsha dang / de'i yang chen po dang / sa 'og ma la ltos nas gong ma dag chen po dang / theg chen pa'i ngo tsha khrel yod dang / sa brgyad pa sogs gsum gyi ngar 'dzin med pa mi rtog ye shes lhun gyis grub pa'i ngo tsha dang khrel yod ni 'bad med lhun gyis grub pas chen po'am lhag par bzhag pa yin no/ /

The sense of shame and decency of those on the level of the world of desire, who are not concentrated by nature,[1] is lesser or inferior. Similarly, the sense of shame and decency of those in the worlds of form and formlessness, who are concentrated, is divided into lesser, middling, and greater, of which the lesser and middling can be classified as lesser. On the various levels—the level of earnest aspiration, the first bodhisattva level, and so forth—the sense of shame and decency on each level is categorized as lesser compared to that on the levels above it, and as greater compared to the levels below it. The sense of shame and decency of the listeners and solitary realizers, whose motivation is inferior, is lesser, since they accomplish only their own welfare. The sense of shame of bodhisattvas on the first to seventh levels is referred to as “self-interested” because it is accompanied by pride related to its being characterized by effort. The sense of shame of all these beings is referred to as inferior or lesser from a relative point of view. Compared to them, other degrees of sense of shame are classified as superior or greater—that is, the sense of shame of those on the level of meditative concentration; that of those in the greater category of beings on the level of meditative concentration; that of bodhisattvas on the higher levels, which is greater compared to the lower levels; the shame and decency of beings in the Great Vehicle; and the shame and decency of those on the three levels starting with the eighth who are free of any concept of self and whose nonconceptual gnosis is spontaneous, which is greater or superior because it is effortless and spontaneous.
bzhi pa ngo tsha dang khrel med pa'i nyes dmigs ni/
iv. THE DISADVANTAGES OF NOT HAVING A SENSE OF SHAME AND DECENCY
blo ldan khrel med tshul min las/ / nyon mongs dang len khro ba dang / / yal bar 'dor dang nga rgyal gyis/ / sems can rnams dang tshul khrims 'joms/ /

From a lack of decency and improper ways, the wise Indulge in defilements, get angry, Forsake what is good, and become proud, as a result of which They oppress sentient beings and destroy their discipline. (XIX, 5)
ces pas bstan te/

blo ldan gang ngo tsha dang khrel med pa de tshul bzhin min par zhugs pa las chags sogs nyon mongs pa skyes pa dang du len pa dang / khro ba yi dbang gis srog gcod pa sogs mi dge ba la zhugs pas bdag nyid tshul khrims nyams pas rang la 'di phyir gnod pa dang / sems can gzhan la gnod pa dang / de bzhin du dge ba'i las dang sems can gyi don bya ba yal bar 'dor ba'i le lo dang bag med pa sogs dang / nga rgyal gyi skyon chags pa rnams kyi sgo nas/ sems can rnams dang rang gi rgyud kyi tshul khrims 'joms pa dang /

Bodhisattvas who have no sense of shame and decency and who engage in improper ways consequently indulge in developing defilements such as attachment. On account of their getting angry, they engage in negative actions like killing, thereby degenerating their discipline. In this way, they harm themselves in this and future lives, and they harm other beings. Similarly, they become lazy and careless, disregarding positive actions and anything that benefits sentient beings. Because of these faults, and that of pride, they oppress sentient beings and destroy their own discipline.
'gyod pas nyams dang bcas 'gyur zhing / / bkur sti dman pa thob 'gyur des/ / dad ldan mi min tshogs dang ni/ / ston pas kyang ni btang snyoms mdzad/ /
They will be stricken with remorse, And will receive almost no respect. The hosts of faithful nonhumans And even the Teacher will ignore them. (XIX, 6)

de'i dbang gis rang nyid 'gyod cing gdung ba skyes pas bde ba las nyams pa dang bcas par 'gyur zhing / gzhan gyis kyang yon tan dang mi ldan par mthong nas bkur sti dang rnyed pas dman pa thob par 'gyur la/ ngo tsha dang khrel med pa'i rgyu des bstan pa la dad pa dang ldan pa'i mi min dkar phyogs skyong ba'i tshogs dang ni/ ston pa'i kyang lhag par dgongs pa'i yul du ma gyur pas btang snyoms su 'jog par mdzad do/ /

Because of this, they will be stricken with remorse and grow sad. Others too, seeing that they have no good qualities, will afford them scant respect and give them fewer offerings. And as a result of their lack of shame and decency, the assemblies of nonhuman protectors of virtue who have faith in the teachings, and even our teacher, the Buddha, will ignore those bodhisattvas, who will no longer be objects of their special consideration.
rgyal sras chos dang mthun rnams kyis/ / rnam par smod cing 'jig rten las/ / mthong ba'i chos la mi snyan 'thob/ / gzhan du phyir zhing mi khom skye/ /
Their fellow bodhisattvas will condemn them, And in this life the world will speak unpleasantly of them, While in other lives to come. They’ll be reborn in realms devoid of leisure. (XIX, 7)

rgyal ba'i sras po chos dang mthun pa rnams kyis che ge mos 'di ltar mi rigs pa byed pa yin no zhes rnam par smod cing / 'jig rten pa rnams las kyang mthong ba'i chos tshe 'di la mi snyan pa brjod pa thob bo/ / skye ba gzhan du phyir zhing ngan song sogs mi khoms pa'i gnas su skye ba

Their fellow bodhisattvas will speak disparagingly of them, saying, “So-and-so is acting unworthily like this.” Even from ordinary people, in this present life, they will receive insults. And later, in other lives, they will be reborn in the lower realms and other states devoid of leisure.[2]
des na chos dkar thob pa dang / / ma thob pa las rnam nyams 'gyur/ / de phyir sdug bsngal gnas pa dang / / yid kyang rnal du mi gnas 'gyur/ /
So all the good they have acquired And all that they have not yet gained Will fade away. Because of this they’ll suffer, And their minds will never find true rest. (XIX, 8)

des na rang rgyud la chos dkar po thob zin las nyams pa dang / sngar ma thob pa gsar du thob pa las kyang rnam par nyams par 'gyur ro/ / de phyir de'i lus sdug bsngal bar gnas pa dang / yid kyang mi bde bas zin nas rnal du gnas par mi 'gyur ro/ /

Thus, the good qualities they have already acquired in their mind streams will diminish, and they will fail to obtain those that they have hitherto not acquired. As a result, their bodies lodged in suffering and their minds pervaded by unhappiness, they will never abide in natural ease.
lnga pa ngo tsha dang khrel yod pa'i phan yon ni/
v. THE BENEFITS OF HAVING A SENSE OF SHAME AND DECENCY

rgyal sras ngo tsha ldan rnams la/ / nyes pa 'di dag kun mi 'byung / / mkhas pa rtag tu lha dag dang / / mi rnams su ni yang dag skye/ / blo ldan ngo tshas myur du ni/ / rdzogs pa'i byang chub tshogs rdzogs byed/ / rgyal ba'i sras ni sems can rnams/ / smin byed skyo bar mi 'gyur nyid/ / de rtag mi mthun phyogs dang ni/ / gnyen po bral dang mi 'bral 'gyur/ / de ltar rgyal sras ngo tsha ldan/ / phan yon de dag 'thob par 'gyur/ /

None of these misfortunes can occur For the buddhas’ heirs who have a sense of shame. The skillful always take the best rebirth As human beings or as gods. (XIX, 9) Wise beings with a sense of shame swiftly complete The accumulations that lead to perfect enlightenment. The buddhas’ children will never grow weary Of bringing beings to maturity. (XIX, 10) They will be forever free of shamelessness And never separate from the antidote. Such are the benefits Bodhisattvas with a sense of shame will gain. (XIX, 11)
zhes pas bstan te/

rgyal sras ngo tsha dang khrel yod ldan pa rnams la bshad ma thag pa'i nyes pa 'di dag kun gtan du mi 'byung ste/ mkhas pa de ni rtag tu lha dag dang / mi rnams su ni yang dag par skye ba ni rnam smin gyi 'bras bu blo dang ldan pa de khrel yod dang ngo tshas myur du ni/ bla med rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi tshogs rdzogs par byed pa bdag po'i 'bras bu dang / rgyal ba'i sras ngo tsha khrel yod ldan pa de ni sems can rnams smin par byed pa la/ skyo bar mi 'gyur ba nyid skyes bu byed pa'i 'bras bu dang / de ni dus rtag tu mi mthun phyogs ngo tsha med pa dang khrel med pa bral ba bral 'bras dang / gnyen po ngo tsha dang khrel yod pa dang mi 'bral bar 'gyur ba rgyu mthun pa'i 'bras bu ste/ de ltar rgyal sras ngo tsha khrel yod dang ldan pa des ni phan yon de dag 'thob par 'gyur ro/ /

None of these misfortunes that have just been described can ever occur in bodhisattvas who have a sense of shame and decency. These skillful beings always take the most excellent births as celestial beings and humans. This is the fully ripened effect of having a sense of shame and decency. The conditioning effect is that wise beings with a sense of shame and decency swiftly complete the accumulations that bring unsurpassable perfect enlightenment. The proliferating effect is that bodhisattvas with a sense of shame and decency bring sentient beings to maturity and will never tire of doing so. The separational effect is that they are always free of the counteragents—shamelessness and a lack of consideration. And the effect similar to the cause is that they will never separate from the antidote, a sense of shame and decency. These, then, are the benefits that bodhisattvas with a sense of shame and decency will gain.
drug pa ngo tsha khrel yod dang ldan pa la bsngags pa ni/
vi. IN PRAISE OF THOSE WHO HAVE A SENSE OF SHAME AND DECENCY

byis pa shin tu gos bzang gyon yang ni/ / khrel dang bral phyir nyes pas dri ma can/ / rgyal sras ngo tsha shes pa'i gos can ni/ / dgab pa med kyang nyes pa'i dri ma bral/ / rgyal ba'i sras ni khrel dang ldan gyur pa/ / nam mkha' bzhin du chos kyis gos mi 'gyur/ / rgyal sras rnams kyi nang du 'dus gyur pa/ / ngo tsha shes pas brgyan pa mdzes pa yin/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni ngo tsha bas/ / gdul bya rnams la ma bzhin byams pa nyid/ / ngo tsha ba ni nyes pa thams cad las/ / 'khor ba kun tu srung bar byed pa'ang yin/ /

The immature, though adorned in gorgeous clothes, Have no consideration and so are stained by faults. The buddhas’ children clothed in a sense of shame, Though uncovered, are unstained by faults. (XIX, 12) The buddhas’ children, with their sense of decency, Are, like the sky, never tainted by ordinary concerns. Counted among the assembly of buddhas’ children, Those who are adorned with a sense of shame are the loveliest. (XIX, 13) With their sense of shame, bodhisattvas Love beings like a mother would her children. It is their sense of shame as well that constantly Protects them in saṃsāra from all kinds of faults. (XIX, 14)
zhes pas bstan te/

byis pa so so'i skye bo rnams lus bkrus te rgyu bzang zhing kha dog dbyibs legs pa'i gos bzang po gyon yang ni/ sems ngo tsha khrel yod dang bral ba'i phyir chags sogs nyes pa'i dri ma can gyi rang bzhin yin pa gos kyis dgab par mi nus la/ rgyal sras ngo tsha shes pa dang khrel yod pa'i gos can ni/ phyi nas gos sogs kyis dgab pa med kyang rang bzhin gyis nyes pa'i dri ma dang bral ba yin no/ / 'dis ni nang du mnyam par bzhag pa'i rnal 'byor la gnas pa'i dus na ngo tsha khrel yod kyis nyon mongs skye ba'i gnyen po byed pa bstan to/ / rgyal ba'i sras rnams ni ngo tsha shes pa dang khrel yod pa dang ldan par gyur pa de dag dper na nam mkha' ni sprin dang khug sna la sogs pas gos su med pa bzhin du grong du gshegs pa sogs kyi tshe ngo tsha ba dang khrel yod pa'i rang bzhin nyid kyis/ 'jig rten chos brgyad kyis gos par mi 'gyur ro/ / rang gi lta spyod dang mthun pa'i grogs su gyur pa'i rgyal sras rnams kyi nang du 'dus gyur pa na yang / gang ngo tsha shes pa dang khrel yod pa'i rgyan gyis brgyan pa de ni spyod pa mthun zhing shin tu mdzes pa yin te/ rin chen la sogs pa'i rgyan gang gi yang 'gran zla med pa nyid de/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni gzhan don yal bar 'dor ba la khrel yod dang ngo tsha bas/ gdul bya rnams la ma bzhin du byams pa nyid kyis sems can smin par byed pa yin te sems can thams cad la bu ltar byams shing phangs pa mdzad pa de dag gis/ sems can rnams bskyab par mi byed cing yal bar 'dor na ngo tsha ba'i gnas yin pa'i phyir ro/ / khrel yod dang ngo tsha ni dper na dpung gi tshogs rta dang glang po dang shing rta ba dang / rkang thang gi tshogs bzhis rgyal srid dang yul phyogs bsrung ba ltar/ 'dod chags la sogs pa'i nyes pa thams cad kyi dgra yi tshogs las/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams 'khor ba 'dir sems can gyi don byed pa'i tshe na rnam pa kun tu srung bar byed pa'ang yin te/ ngo tsha dang khrel yod kyis nyon mongs pa'i nyes pa rnams la mi 'jug par byed pas so/ /

Although immature, ordinary beings wash their bodies and wear beautiful, well-cut clothes in fine, colorful materials, their minds are devoid of a sense of shame and decency and are therefore, by nature, stained with faults such as attachment, which is something they cannot conceal under their clothes. The buddhas’ children, on the other hand, are clothed with a sense of shame and decency, and even if they have no clothes to cover them outwardly, they are naturally free of contamination by faults. This verse shows that when they are resting in the natural state of union, inwardly settled in evenness, their sense of shame and decency acts as the antidote to the arising of defilements. The buddhas’ children, who have a sense of shame and decency, are like the sky unobscured by clouds or mist. Their sense of shame and decency is such that when they go somewhere like a town, they are never tainted by the eight ordinary preoccupations. Even when they are gathered among their fellow bodhisattvas who share the same view and conduct, those who are adorned with the ornaments of a sense of shame and decency are the most strikingly beautiful and well behaved. No jeweled ornaments can compare to that. Bodhisattvas would be ashamed of themselves and of what others might think if they were to forsake the welfare of others. And so it is, with a motherly love for their disciples, that they bring sentient beings to maturity, for it would be shameful for those who love and cherish all sentient beings as if they were their only child to abandon beings and fail to protect them. Like a kingdom and its regions protected by an army of four divisions (cavalry, elephants, chariots, and infantry), when bodhisattvas work for the benefit of sentient beings here in saṃsāra, their sense of shame and decency always protects them from hostile forces—attachment and all other such faults. For when one has a sense of shame and decency, one does not indulge in the faults of defilements.
bdun pa ngo tsha khrel yod ldan pa'i rtags ni bzhi ste/
vii. THE SIGNS OF HAVING A SENSE OF SHAME AND DECENCY
kun la dang du len pa dang / / kun la dang du mi len cing / / kun la mi 'jug 'jug pa ni/ / khrel ldan khrel bas byas pa'i rtags/ /
Acceptance of everything, Refusal of everything, Nonengagement, and engagement Are the signs of decency in an upright individual. (XIX, 15)
ces pas bstan te/

bsam pa'i sgo nas sbyin pa tshul khrims sogs yon tan gyi phyogs gang ci yang rung ba kun la dang du len pa bzod pa dang / ngo tsha med pa dang khrel med pa dang chags sdang sogs nyon mongs kun dang gang ci yang rung ba'i nyes pa'i phyogs kun dang du mi len cing / sbyor ba'i sgo nas nyes pa kun la mi 'jug pa dang yon tan kun la 'jug pa yi mtshan ma bzhi po de ni/ gang snang yang / ngo tsha khrel yod dang ldan pa'i gang zag de'i rgyud kyi ngo tsha shes pa dang khrel yod pas byas pa'i rtags yin no/ /

There are four signs of having a sense of shame and decency. In terms of their attitude, bodhisattvas happily accept everything to do with good qualities—generosity, discipline, and the like—and they do not willingly accept anything to do with negative qualities of any kind: shamelessness, a lack of consideration, attachment, aversion, and all the other defilements. In terms of their application, they do not engage in negative actions of any kind, and they engage in every kind of good quality. The appearance of any of these four signs is the mark of a sense of shame and decency in a conscientious and considerate person.
brgyad pa de gnyis mchog tu gyur pa ni/
viii. THE BEST SENSE OF SHAME AND DECENCY
rang gi sems kyis khrel sgom pa/ / chos la mos dang bsam pa dang / / dbang 'byor pa dang mi rtog dang / / gcig pa nyid kyis gtso bo yin/ /
The bodhisattvas’ mental training in decency Is the best by virtue of their interest in the teachings, Their specific mental states, mastery, Nonconceptuality, and oneness. (XIX, 16)
zhes pas bstan te/

rang gi sems kyis ngo tsha shes pa dang khrel yod bsgom pa ni/ gal te skyon 'di gzhan gyis shes na ngo tsha'o snyam pa las/ gzhan gyis shes rung ma shes rung rang nyid kyis nyes pa byas pa rang la rang gis khrel ba bsgom pa ni mchog ces 'grel bar gsungs/ khrel yod bsgom pa de yang rnam pa lngas mchog tu rig par bya ba ni/ ngo tsha khrel yod ston pa'i theg chen gyi chos la mos pa dang / bsam pa dgu gong bshad ltar dang / ting nge 'dzin gyi sems kyi dbang 'byor ba'am/ sa brgyad pa nas 'bad rtsol med par lhun gyis grub pa dag / bdag dang gzhan dang ngo tsha ba'i chos kyi 'khor gsum du rnam par mi rtog pa dang / dag sa pa'i byang sems bya ba de la don gcig par gyur pa nyid kyis gtso bo'am mchog tu gyur pa yin no/ /

The best sense of shame and decency is shame and decency that one trains in with one’s own mind. As the commentary says, rather than thinking, “I would be ashamed if others were to know about this fault,” it is much better to train in being ashamed of oneself for committing a negative action, whether or not anybody else knows about it. Training in a sense of decency like this is to be understood as best on account of the following five factors: interest in the Mahāyāna teachings that teach a sense of shame and decency; the nine mental states described earlier;[3] mastery of the mind through concentration or, from the eighth level up, effortlessness and spontaneity; freedom from the concepts of the three spheres (of oneself, others, and a sense of shame); and the fact that the activities of bodhisattvas on the pure levels are equivalent. It is on account of these that a bodhisattva’s sense of shame and decency is the most important or the best.
gnyis pa
b. STEADFASTNESS
brtan pa la mdor bstan/ rgyas bshad gnyis/
Steadfastness is divided into (1) a brief introduction and (2) a detailed explanation.
dang po byang chub sems dpa'i snying stobs brtan pa ni/
i. BRIEF INTRODUCTION
byang chub sems dpa'i brtan pa ni/ / de las gzhan pa thams cad las/ / mtshan nyid dang ni rab dbye dang / / mi 'gyur bas ni khyad par 'phags/ /
A bodhisattva’s steadfastness is far superior To that of those who are not bodhisattvas By virtue of its specific characteristics, Its categories, and its immutability. (XIX, 17)
zhes pas bstan te/
byang sems de las gzhan pa 'jig rten pa dang nyan rang gi tshogs thams cad las/ mtshan nyid dang ni rab tu dbye ba dang / mi 'gyur bas ni khyad par du 'phags pa yin no/ /

A bodhisattva’s steadfastness and strength of mind is far superior to that of those who are not bodhisattvas, that is, all the hosts of mundane beings and listeners and solitary realizers. This is on account of its specific characteristics, its categories, and its immutability.
gnyis pa de'i khyad par gsum po de'i don rgyas par bshad pa la/
ii. DETAILED EXPLANATION OF THREE PARTICULAR FEATURES OF STEADFASTNESS
dang po brtan pa'i mtshan nyid ni/
(1) SPECIFIC CHARACTERISTICS OF STEADFASTNESS

brtson 'grus ting 'dzin shes rab ni/ / snying stobs sran thub brtan par 'dod/ / gang phyir gsum gyis byang chub sems/ / 'jigs pa med par rab tu 'jug / zhum dang g.yo dang rmongs pa yis/ / bya ba rnams la 'jigs pa skye/ / de phyir gnyug ma gsum la ni/ / brtan pa'i ming du shes par bya/ /

Their diligence, concentration, and wisdom Correspond to strength of mind, endurance, and stability. On account of these three, bodhisattvas Apply themselves without fear. (XIX, 18) Through a lack of courage, wavering, and ignorance There is fear of all there is to do. So know that the three innate states Are included in the word “steadfastness.” (XIX, 19)
zhes pas bstan te/

brtson 'grus dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / shes rab gsum ni rim pa ltar sems ma zhum pa'i snying stobs dang gzhan du mi g.yo bar sran thub pa dang / don der yang dag par shes nas de las gzhan du mi 'gyur bas brtan par 'dod de/ gang gi phyir na chos de gsum gyis byang chub sems dpa' rnams lam bsgrub pa la 'jigs pa med par rab tu 'jug pa yin no/ / 'jigs pa ji lta bu skye na brtson 'grus med pa rnams byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa rnams bdag gis bsgrub mi nus snyam du zhum pa'i 'jigs pa skye ba dang / ting nge 'dzin med pa rnams sems rtse gcig tu bzhag mi nus pas rnam rtog g.yo ba'i 'jigs pa skye ba dang / shes rab med pa dag byang chub kyi spyod pa rnams ji lta bu yin pa mi shes par rmongs pa yis bya ba rnams la ji ltar bya gtol med pas 'jigs pa skye'o/ / zhum pa sogs de gsum gas byang chub sems dpa'i bsgrub par bya ba rnams la rang dbang du ma 'dus pas bsgrub mi nus snyam du 'jigs pa skye'o/ / de phyir 'jigs pa gsum po de yi gnyen po brtson 'grus ting 'dzin shes rab gang zhig gshis sam ngang gis grub pa'i gnyug ma gsum la ni/ mi mthun phyogs kyis mi 'phrog pas brtan pa'i ming can du shes par bya'o zhes/ so sor rtag cing 'bad mi dgos par brtson 'grus lhun gyis grub pa dang ting 'dzin dang shes rab lhun gyis grub pa gnyug ma'am rtag pa yod pas zhum sogs gsum med par mchog tu brtan pa ni brtan pa'i mtshan nyid do/ / las dang po pa rnams la'ang sems kyi gshis la ma zhum pa yod pas bya ba la 'jug nus pa zhig byung na de tsam la ltos 'jog gi sgo nas gnyug ma'i brtson 'grus kyi ming thogs par sogs su shes par bya'o/ /

The specific characteristics of steadfastness are asserted to be diligence, concentration, and wisdom, which correspond respectively to the strength of mind not to get discouraged, the endurance not to waver elsewhere, and stability in their object from correctly knowing it and not moving from that knowledge.[4] It is on account of these three factors that bodhisattvas engage in practicing the path without fear. What kind of fear might they feel? Those who do not have diligence feel disheartened and afraid, thinking, “I will not be able to accomplish the activities of a bodhisattva.” Those who do not have concentration are unable to settle their minds one-pointedly, and they are therefore apprehensive of the movements of discursive thoughts. Those without wisdom are afraid because, being ignorant as to what the activities of a bodhisattva are, they are not certain how to carry them out. As a result of these three (being disheartened and so on), they are afraid of everything a bodhisattva has to accomplish and think, “That is not in my power. I cannot do it.” So the antidotes to these three fears are diligence, concentration, and wisdom, which are accomplished naturally or spontaneously. These three innate states are to be understood as bearing the name “steadfastness” because they cannot be ravished away by their counteragents. When these innate or permanent states—spontaneous diligence, spontaneous concentration, and spontaneous wisdom—are present, and there is no need for analysis or effort, steadfastness is at its greatest, and the three kinds of fear (feeling disheartened and so on) are absent. These are the specific characteristics of steadfastness. Even beginners may have a natural disposition to not being easily discouraged and therefore able to throw themselves into whatever they are doing. In such cases, it should be understood that strictly in those terms they may be referred to as having innate diligence and so forth.
gnyis pa brtan pa'i dbye ba
(2) CATEGORIES OF STEADFASTNESS

rang bzhin dang ni smon lam dang / / lta ba med pa nyid dang ni/ / sems can log par sgrub pa dang / / zab cing rgya che thos pa dang / / gdul bya gdul bar dka' ba dang / / rgyal sku bsam gyis mi khyab dang / / dka' ba dag ni sna tshogs dang / / 'khor ba gtong ba med nyid dang / / de nyid nyon mongs med pa la/ / brtan pa'i brtan pa skye ba ni/ / de las gzhan dang mi mtshungs te/ / brtan ldan rnams kyi mchog tu 'dod/ /

The steadfastness of the steady arises Naturally, through their aspirations, In their lack of concern, In the face of sentient beings’ ingratitude, (XIX, 20) In their hearing of the profound and of the extensive, With regard to beings who are hard to train, And with regard to the inconceivable buddha bodies. It arises in the face of their different austerities, (XIX, 21) In their not abandoning saṃsāra, And in their freedom from defilements there. It is unequaled by other beings, So bodhisattvas are considered the greatest of steadfast beings. (XIX, 22)
zhes pas bstan te/
dang po ni rnam pa brgyad de/ rang bzhin gyis brtan pa ni rigs kyi stobs las brtson ting sher gsum gyi khams kyis byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la zhum sogs kyi 'jigs pa med pa gang yin pa dang ni/

To begin with, there are eight categories: (1) Natural steadfastness. Because of bodhisattvas’ capacity for diligence, concentration, and wisdom, which depends on the strength of their potential, they have no fear from losing heart and so on with regard to the bodhisattva activities and the like.

smon lam gyis brtan pa ni/ bla med byang chub sems bskyed nas byang chub chen po thob pa dang sems can thams cad yongs su bsgral bar bya ba las mi ldog cing mi 'gyur bar shog cig ces smon lam btab pa las gang du skyes kyang mi 'gyur zhing brtan par 'gyur ba'o/ / de yang byang chub sems dpa'i smon lam tshad med pa sangs rgyas kyi sa'i bar du 'byung ba thams cad kyi rtsa ba ni thog mar byang chub sems bskyed pa 'di yin te/ byang chub tu smon lam 'debs pa'i dang po 'di la brten nas smon lam kun 'byung zhing de phan chad kyi smon lam rnams kyis je bas je brtan du 'gyur ro/ /

(2) Steadfastness through aspiration. As a result of their arousing the mind intent on unsurpassable enlightenment and making the prayer, “May I never turn back or waver from attaining the great enlightenment and bringing all sentient beings to full liberation,” wherever they are reborn, they will be unwavering and steadfast. The root of all the boundless prayers of aspiration that bodhisattvas make until they reach buddhahood is their first arousing bodhicitta. It is on the basis of this initial aspiration to attain enlightenment that all their subsequent aspirations are made, as a result of which they become more and more steadfast.

chags pa med pa nyid dang ni zhes pa bdag gi don la brtan pa ste/ bdag gi don bsgrub pa la lus dang srog la yang lta ba'am chags pa dang 'jigs pa med pa nyid dang ni/ gzhan gyi don la brtan pa ni sems can rnams kyis log par sgrub pa sna tshogs byas kyang des skyo ba med par brtan pa dang / zab cing zhes pa de kho na nyid kyi don la brtan pa ste/ gdod nas skye 'gag med pa zab mo stong pa nyid kyi don la mi skrag cing mos pa brtan pa'o/ /

(3) “Freedom from attachment” refers to steadfastness in one’s own goal. This is to be fearless and unattached, or to have no regard[5] for one’s body and life, in accomplishing one’s own goal. (4) Steadfastness with regard to others’ goals. This is to remain steadfast without ever getting discouraged by sentient beings’ ingratitude, in all its various forms. (5) “Profound” indicates steadfastness with regard to the meaning of thatness. It refers to a firm interest and lack of apprehension with regard to the profound meaning of emptiness, from the very beginning unborn and unceasing.

mthu la brtan pa ni/ mngon shes dang stobs dang mi 'jigs pa sogs yon tan rgya che ba rnams bsgrub pa la mi zhum par mos pa dang / gdul bya nyon mongs pa shin tu bdo bas sus kyang gdul bar dka' ba rnams yal bar mi 'dor bar thabs sna tshogs kyis yun ring por 'dul bar byed pa ni sems can yongs su smin par bya ba la brtan pa dang / rgyal ba'i chos sku dang longs sku sprul pa'i sku gsum po yon tan bsam gyis mi khyab pa nyid bdag gis bsgrub par bya'o snyam du yid phyir ldog pa med pa ni byang chub dam pa la brtan pa ste/ de ltar brtan pa'i rnam grangs brgyad bshad pa dang /

(6) Steadfastness with regard to powers. This denotes a determination to accomplish the extensive qualities (the preternatural powers, strengths, fearlessnesses, and so forth) without ever losing heart. (7) Steadfastness in bringing sentient beings to full maturity, that is, in training those beings who, because of their rampant defilements, are difficult for anyone to train—training them for great lengths of time, by all kinds of means, without ever abandoning them. (8) Steadfastness with regard to supreme enlightenment. Bodhisattvas never change their minds about their vow to accomplish by themselves the inconceivable qualities of the buddhas’ three bodies—the body of truth, body of perfect enjoyment, and manifestation body.
slar yang brtan pa'i dbye ba gsum ni/
In addition to these eight kinds of steadfastness, there are the following three categories:
ces pas bstan te/

bla med byang chub kyi phyir dka' ba spyod pa dag ni sna tshogs tshad med pa nyams su len pa ni/ dka' ba spyod pa la brtan pa dang / gzhan don snying rjes 'khor ba yongs su gtong ba med par srid pa sna tshogs su skye ba yongs su 'dzin pa nyid ni/ bsam bzhin srid par skye ba la brtan pa dang / 'khor bar skye ba de nyid kyi tshe na 'khor ba'i skyon nyon mongs pas gos pa med pa ni/ nyon mongs pa med pa la brtan pa ste/ de ltar byang chub sems dpa' brtan pa'i rgyud la brtan pa skye ba ni/ de las gzhan 'jig rten pa dang nyan rang gi brtan pa dang mi mtshungs te/ gzhan brtan pa dang ldan pa rnams kyi mchog tu 'dod do/ /

(1) Steadfastness in practicing austerities. Bodhisattvas practice boundless different kinds of austerities in order to attain unsurpassable enlightenment. (2) Steadfastness in taking birth in existence intentionally. Instead of completely abandoning saṃsāra, they fully take birth in the various kinds of existence, through compassion, for the benefit of others. (3) Steadfastness in being free of defilements. When they take those births in saṃsāra, they are never tainted by the faults of saṃsāra, defilements. This steadfastness that takes birth in the mind streams of steadfast bodhisattvas is unequaled by the steadfastness of nonbodhisattvas—mundane beings and listeners and solitary realizers. Thus bodhisattvas are held to be the greatest of all steadfast beings.
gsum pa mi 'gyur ba ni/
(3) IMMUTABILITY
phye ma leb dang 'dab chags dang / / rgya mtsho dag gis ri rab ltar/ / brtan pa grogs ngan sdug bsngal dang / / zab mo thos pas mi g.yos so/ /
Like the king of mountains assailed by butterflies, Garuḍas, and the ocean, The steadfast are not shaken by evil company, By suffering, or by hearing the profound. (XIX, 23)
zhes pas bstan te/

ji ltar phye ma leb dang / 'dab chags mkha' lding gi gshog pa'i shugs dang / rgya mtsho chen po'i rlabs dag gis ri rab g.yo mi nus pa ltar dpe de gsum dang rim pa ltar sbyar te/ brtan pa byang chub sems dpa' rnams mi dge ba'i grogs ngan pa dang / sdug bsngal sna tshogs dang / chos zab mo stong pa bdag med thos pas mi 'khrugs shing mi g.yos so/ /

Steadfast bodhisattvas are like Mount Meru, which cannot be shaken by butterflies, by the power of the garuḍa’s wings, or by the waves of the ocean. These three similes indicate respectively that they are not perturbed or shaken by evil, nonvirtuous companions, by the different kinds of suffering, or by hearing the profound teachings on emptiness and no-self.
gsum pa mi skyo ba ni
c. INDEFATIGABILITY

byang chub mi skyo mnyam med pa/ / gzhi gsum thos pas mi ngoms dang / / brtson 'grus che dang sdug bsngal la'o/ / ngo tsha brtan la brten pa ste/ / byang chub che la 'dun pa dag / blo ldan rnams kyi mi skyo ba/ / sa rnams la ni ma rdzogs dang / / rdzogs dang shin tu rdzogs par 'dod/ /

Bodhisattvas’ indefatigability is incomparable And based on three things: their insatiable thirst for listening, Their great diligence, and their suffering. Relying on their sense of shame and their steadfastness, (XIX, 24) The indefatigability of the wise— Those who yearn for the great enlightenment— Is held to be, on the different levels, Imperfect, perfect, and utterly perfect. (XIX, 25)
ces pas bstan te/
