yang dag spong ba de'i rab tu dbye ba ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams sems can gyi don 'khor ba 'dir tshangs pa dang brgya byin 'khor los sgyur ba sogs kyi lus bzung nas longs spyod phun sum tshogs pa la nye bar longs spyod pa yi dus na 'dod chags la sogs pa'i nyon mongs pa'i dbang du mi 'gyur zhing de dag gis mi gos par bya ba'i phyir yang dag spong ba bzhi sgom par byed pa dang / de bzhin du 'dod la 'dun pa dang / gnod sems dang / gnyid rmugs dang / rgod 'gyod dang / the tshom ste/ sgrib pa lnga po dag ni 'dor ba yi ched du bsgom pa dang / theg pa chen po'i don yid la mi byed par theg pa dman pa dang nyan rang gi 'bras bu yid la byed pa dor ba dang / mos spyod kyi sa nas 'phags pa'i sa dang po la sogs par 'jug pa la sgrib par 'gyur ba'i chos rnams spong ba'i phyir dang / sa gnyis pa nas drug pa man chad la gnas pa'i sa bdun pa mtshan ma med par gnas pa thob pa la bar du gcod par gyur pa'i nyes pa spong ba'i phyir bsgom pa dang/ sa brgyad par lung bstan pa ni thob pa la gegs su gyur pa'i nyes pa rnams spong ba'i phyir spong bzhi bsgom pa dang /

There now follows a detailed classification of these genuine restraints. Once bodhisattvas have taken birth as Brahmā, Indra, a universal emperor, and so on, here in saṃsāra for beings’ benefit, in order not to be influenced and obscured by defilements such as attachment at the time they are making use of their abundant riches, they practice the four genuine restraints. They practice them, similarly, in order to get rid of the five hindrances—namely, an inclination for pleasure, malice, dullness and somnolence, wildness and remorse, and indecision. They practice the four genuine restraints in order to get rid of attentiveness to the lower vehicles and the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ result instead of attentiveness to the goal of the Great Vehicle; in order to eliminate factors that will become hindrances to their entering the first noble level from the level of earnest aspiration, and so on; and in order to eliminate faults on the second to sixth levels that will act as obstacles to attaining the way of abiding without attributes on the seventh level. They practice the four restraints in order to eliminate faults that will prevent them from receiving predictions on the eighth level.

sa dgu par so so yang dag rig pa bzhi thob pas sems can rnams la chos bstan pas yongs su smin par bya ba thob pa la bar chod du gyur pa'i sgrib pa spong ba'i phyir dang / sa bcu par de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyis rgyal tshab tu dbang ni bskur bar bya ba thob pa la sgrib par gyur pa spong phyir spong bzhi bsgom pa dang / sa brgyad pa dang dgu pa bcu pa ste dag pa'i sa gsum du sangs rgyas kyi zhing rnams dag par bya ba thob pa la bar du gcod pa'i sgrib pa spong ba'i phyir spong bzhi bsgom pa dang / mthar thug pa sa bcu gcig pa sangs rgyas kyi sa thob pa nyid du bya ba'i phyir de thob pa'i mi mthun phyogs su gyur pa'i sgrib pa spong ba'i phyir yang dag spong ba bzhi bsgom pa ste/ byang chub sems dpa' blo ldan rnams ni mos spyod nas sa bcu'i rgyun mtha'i bar du yang dag spong ba bzhi po lam gyi mi mthun phyogs kyi gnyen por de ltar bsgom pa yin no/ /

They practice them in order to eliminate obscurations that will obstruct their acquiring the four kinds of perfect knowledge and thereby teaching sentient beings the Dharma and bringing them to maturity on the ninth level. And they practice them in order to remove hindrances to the tathāgatas’ empowering them as Dharma regent on the tenth level. They practice the four restraints in order to eliminate obscurations that interrupt their achieving the purification of their environment as a buddha field on the three pure levels—the eighth, ninth, and tenth. And they practice the four genuine restraints in order to attain the eleventh and ultimate level, the level of buddhahood—in other words, in order to eliminate obscurations that will counter that attainment. Thus, wise bodhisattvas practice the four genuine restraints from the level of earnest aspiration up to the final stage of the tenth level as the antidotes to factors that act counter to the path.
'dun pa la ni brten nas su/ / rnal 'byor rgyu mtshan bcas bsgom pa/ / yang dag spong ba thams cad la/ / gnyen po zhes ni nges par brjod/ /
On the basis of keenness, They practice the yoga with special points, Described as the antidote In all the practices of genuine restraint. (XIX, 50)
ji ltar bsgom pa'i tshul ni/ mdo las 'dun pa skyed do/ /'bad do/ /brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ /sems rab tu 'dzin to/ /yang dag par rab tu 'jog go zhes tshig lngas bstan pa ltar bsgom ste/

As for how the four genuine restraints are practiced, this is indicated by five expressions in the sūtras: giving rise to keenness, making effort, applying diligence, keeping the mind focused, and letting the mind rest correctly.

dang po 'dun pa ni brtson 'grus kyi gzhi'o/ lhag ma bzhi brtson 'grus kyi rang bzhin no/ /de yang mi dge ba'i chos ma skyes pa mi skyed pa dang skyes pa spangs pa dang / dge ba'i chos ma skyes pa bskyed pa dang / skyes pa spel bar 'dun pa'i mos pa la ni brten nas su zhi gnas dang lhag mthong gi rnal 'byor bsgom pa ni/ 'bad pa'am rtsol ba'o/ /

Keenness is the basis of diligence. The other four refer to diligence itself. On the basis of keen interest to avoid nonvirtuous factors that have not yet occurred, to eliminate those that have occurred, to give rise to virtuous factors that have not yet arisen, and to increase those that have, bodhisattvas make efforts or strive to train in the yoga of sustained calm and profound insight, which is what is referred to as “making effort” (or “striving”).

de ltar zhi lhag bsgom pa'i dus na res zhi gnas kyi phyogs mthun gyi gnas ngan len zhum pa dang rmugs pa'am/ res lhag mthong gi phyogs mthun gyi gnas ngan len rgod pa dang g.yeng ba byung ba'am/ res de gnyis med par rnal du gnas pa 'byung bas de dag gang dang gang byung ba dran pa dang shes bzhin gyis rig par byas nas/ zhi gnas kyi mtshan ma dang / gzengs bstod pa'i mtshan ma dang btang snyoms kyi mtshan ma gsum ji ltar rigs par yid la byed pa ni rgyu mtshan nam mtshan ma gsum dang bcas par bsgom pa zhes bya ste/ mtshan ma gsum 'du byed bzhin brtson 'grus rtsom mo zhes pa'i don to/ /

When one is practicing sustained calm and profound insight like this, it sometimes happens that one feels low-spirited and dull, which is a negative tendency related to sustained calm; sometimes the mind becomes wild and distracted, which is a negative tendency related to profound insight; sometimes neither tendency is present, and one rests naturally. One therefore has to use mindfulness and vigilance to be aware of whichever of these tendencies occurs and to be attentive to the three special points of sustained calm, self-encouragement, and equanimity, as appropriate. This is what is referred to as “practicing the yoga with the three special points.” The application of the three special points is what is meant by “applying diligence.”

mtshan ma gsum gyi sgo nas sems rab tu 'dzin cing / zhum rgod med par rnal du gnas na de'i ngang du mi bsgul bar yang dag par rab tu 'jog par bya'o/ / de yang sems nang du zhum pa'am gnyid dang rmugs par gyur na/ de bzhin gshegs pa dang byang chub sems dpa'i yon tan nam/ ting nge 'dzin gyi yon tan sogs yid la byed pa gzengs bstod pa'i mtshan ma yid la byas nas zhum pa las bslang bar bya'o/ / nam 'dod pa'i yon tan nam phyi rol gyi dngos po la sems 'phros nas rgod cing g.yengs par gyur na 'khor ba'i skyon dang rnam g.yeng gi nyes pa bsams nas rgod pa'i sems gzhil bar byas te nang du zhi gnas kyi mtshan ma yid la byed pas sems yul la 'phro ba zhi bar byed pa yin no/ /

By means of the three special points, one keeps the mind focused, and when one is resting naturally without low spirits or wildness, one lets the mind rest correctly in that state without moving. In this regard, if the mind becomes introverted and low-spirited, or sleepy and dull, one should concentrate on the special point of self-encouragement, thinking of the excellent qualities of the tathāgatas and bodhisattvas or the virtues of concentration, and lift one’s spirits. If the mind becomes occupied with the pleasures of the senses or with external objects and grows wild and distracted, one should calm the mind’s involvement with objects by reflecting on the defects of saṃsāra and the drawbacks of distraction and by banishing wild thoughts, concentrating inwardly on the special point of sustained calm.

de ltar sems zhum rgod dang bral ba na de nas btang snyoms kyi mtshan ma yid la byed pas de'i ngang du btang snyoms su gnas par bya'i gnyen po gzhan 'du byed par mi bya ste/ de ltar mtshan ma gsum gyis sems rab tu 'dzin te/ zhi gnas kyi mtshan mas rgod pa las 'dzin pa dang / gzengs bstod pa'am lhag mthong gi mtshan mas/ zhum zhing bying ba las 'dzin pa dang / btang snyoms kyi mtshan mas bying rgod bral ba de nyid du sems 'dzin pa yin la/ brtson 'grus ni mtshan ma gsum la brtson pa dang / mtshan ma gsum ni sems 'dzin pa'i thabs yin la/ thabs de 'dra bas yang yang sems bzung bas las su rung nas rtsol ba med par ngang gis gnas pa ni yang dag par rab tu 'jog pa ste 'bras bu lta bu'o/ /

Then, when the mind is freed in this manner from low spirits and wildness, rest in equanimity in that state by keeping in mind the special point of equanimity, and do not apply any other remedy. This is how one keeps the mind focused with the three special points, using the special point of sustained calm to keep it from wildness, the special point of self-encouragement or profound insight to keep it from low spirits and dullness, and the special point of equanimity to hold the mind in that very state free of dullness and wildness. Here, diligence refers to diligence in employing the three special points, and the three special points are the means for keeping the mind focused. With the use of these same means to keep the mind focused again and again, it becomes fit and rests naturally with effort, and this is “letting the mind rest correctly,” which is, as it were, the result.

mdo tshig lnga po 'di la 'chad tshul gzhan snang yang skabs 'di blo brtan 'grel pa ltar bshad do/ / de ltar rnam pa lnga po de'i skabs kyi yang dag spong ba thams cad la de dang de'i mi mthun phyogs spong bar byed pa'i gnyen po zhes ni nges par brjod pa yin no/ /

Although there appear to be other ways of explaining these five expressions in the sūtras, we have explained them in this context according to Sthiramati’s commentary. Thus these five aspects are described in this context as the antidotes that eliminate the respective counteragents for all the genuine restraints.
gsum pa rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa bzhi bshad pa ni/
iii. THE FOUR BASES OF MIRACULOUS POWERS
brtan pa rnams kyi rdzu 'phrul gyi/ / rkang pa mtshan nyid mchog ldan bzhi/ / bdag nyid dang ni gzhan dag gi / don kun 'grub pa'i phyir skye'o/ /
Steadfast bodhisattvas’ four bases of miraculous powers, Endowed with superior characteristics, Are brought into play in order to accomplish All their own and others’ aims. (XIX, 51)
zhes pas bstan zla te/

brtan pa byang sems rnams kyi rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa dag gi mtshan nyid ni nyan rang gi de las mchog tu gyur pa'i yon tan dang ldan pa yin la/ / rnam pa bzhi ste/ 'dun pa'i rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa dang / de bzhin du brtson 'grus dang / sems pa dang / dpyod pa'i rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa'o/ / 'di bzhi dang ldan na nam mkha' la 'gro ba sogs rdzu 'phrul la dbang 'byor bas de skad ces gsungs so/ / de bzhi ni bdag nyid dang ni gzhan sems can dag gi 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i don kun 'grub pa'i phyir skye bas nyan rang gi rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa bzhi las mchog tu gyur pa'o/ /

The specific characteristic of steadfast bodhisattvas’ four bases of miraculous powers is that they have greater qualities than those of the listeners and solitary realizers. These four are keenness as a basis for miraculous powers, and likewise diligence, attention, and analysis as bases of miraculous powers. They are so called because if one possesses these four, one gains mastery in such miraculous powers as traveling through space. Since they are brought into play in order to accomplish all the goals, mundane and supramundane, of oneself and other sentient beings, they are superior to the four bases of miraculous powers of the listeners and solitary realizers.

rten dang rab tu dbye ba dang / / thabs dang mngon par sgrub pa yis/ / blo ldan rdzu 'phrul rkang pa rnams/ / rnam pa kun tu rnam gzhag 'dod/ / bsam gtan pha rol phyin brten nas/ / rab tu dbye ba dag dang thabs/ / rnam bzhi mngon par sgrub pa ni/ / rnam pa drug tu brjod pa yin/ /

With the support, detailed classification, Means, and full accomplishment, The bases of miraculous powers of the steadfast Are fully presented. (XIX, 52) They are described as being Based on transcendent concentration, With four categories and means, And six kinds of full accomplishment. (XIX, 53)

rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa rnam par bzhag pa ni/ rten dang rab tu dbye ba dang thabs dang mngon par sgrub pa dang bzhi yis blo ldan byang chub sems dpa'i rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa rnam pa kun tu rnam par bzhag par 'dod de/ de yang rten ni bsam gtan gyi pha rol tu phyin pa la brten nas 'byung ba ste/ tshad med pa bzhi goms pas sems las su rung zhing bsam gtan dang po dang / gnyis pa dang / gsum pa dang / bzhi pa yongs su dag pa thob pa la brten nas mngon par shes pa 'thob par 'gyur ro/ /

With regard to the presentation of the bases of miraculous powers, wise bodhisattvas’ four bases of miraculous powers are presented in full with four points: support, classification, means, and full accomplishment. The four bases of miraculous powers arise on the basis of the support—namely, transcendent concentration. It is in dependence on their training in the four boundless attitudes and thereby gaining a fit, workable mind and attaining perfect purity in the first, second, third, and fourth dhyānas that bodhisattvas acquire preternatural knowledge.

rab tu dbye ba dag dang thabs ni rnam pa bzhi ste/ 'dun pa dang brtson pa dang sems pa dang dpyod pa bzhi ni ngo bos dbye ba'o/ / de yang chos thams cad stong pa dang bdag med pa yid ches pa la brten nas spro zhing gus par brtson 'grus brtsams pa las sems rtse gcig pa'i ting 'dzin thob pa ni 'dun pa'i ting nge 'dzin no/ / yang na yang dag spong ba bzhi la 'dun pa'i sgo nas gus sbyor gyi brtson 'grus kyis sems rtse gcig pa thob pa'o/ / yang na yang dag spong bzhi la rtag sbyor gyi brtson 'grus brtsams pas sems rtse gcig thob pa ni brtson pa'i rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa'o/ / mdor na ting nge 'dzin la 'dun pa ni rgyu dang / de las brtson 'grus brtsams pa ni 'grub par byed pa'i thabs dngos so/ / sems ni zhi gnas dngos te tshe rabs snga ma'i zhi gnas bsgoms pa'i bag chags la brten nas tshe 'dir 'bad pa chung ngus sems rtse gcig gnas pa thob pa ni sems kyi ting nge 'dzin no/ / dpyod pa ni lhag mthong ste ting nge 'dzin gyi gdams ngag thob pa bzhin shes rab kyi rnam par dbye bas the tshom bral nas sems rtse gcig thob pa'o/ / mdor na dmigs pa la rtse gcig pa'i ting nge 'dzin de la 'dun brtson sems dpyod bzhi mtshungs ldan du tshang ba yin no/ /

The classification and the means are both fourfold. Keenness, diligence, attention, and analysis make up the four categories, based on their nature. On the basis of their conviction that all phenomena are empty and devoid of self, bodhisattvas undertake the practice with diligence, enthusiastically and respectfully, and through this they acquire one-pointed concentration—concentration based on keenness. Alternatively, they acquire one-pointed concentration through the diligence of devoted application on account of their keenness in the four genuine restraints. Or again, they acquire one-pointed concentration through the diligence of constant application in the four genuine restraints. This is diligence as a basis of miraculous powers. In short, keenness is the causal factor that leads to concentration, and from it comes diligent undertaking, which is the actual means for accomplishing concentration. Attention is actually sustained calm. Relying on their habitual tendency to sustained calm from having trained in it in previous lives, in this life, with little effort, bodhisattvas gain a state of mental one-pointedness, that is, mental concentration. Analysis refers to profound insight. Following the instructions they have received on concentration, bodhisattvas use the thorough discernment of wisdom to clear away all doubts and acquire one-pointed concentration. To sum up, in one-pointed concentration on the object, all four—keenness, diligence, attention, and analysis—are equivalent and complete.
gcig ni 'bad par byed pa ste/ / gnyis pa phan 'dogs bdag nyid yin/ / gsum pa gtod par byed pa ste/ / bzhi pa gnyen po pa yin no/ /
One of these means is the application of effort, The second acts as an aid, The third directs the mind, And the fourth is an antidote. (XIX, 54)

thabs rnam pa bzhi ni/ ting nge 'dzin mi 'grub pa'i nyes pa lnga spong bar byed pa'i 'du byed brgyad yod pa de dag skabs 'dir ting nge 'dzin 'grub pa'i thabs rnam pa bzhir bsdus pa ste/ spong ba'i 'du byed brgyad ni/ dad pa 'dun pa rtsol ba shin sbyangs/ dran pa shes bzhin sems pa btang snyoms brgyad do/ / de yang dang por ting nge 'dzin thob pa la dad nas de bsgrub par 'dun pas rtsol ba bskyed pa yin pas rtsol ba yod na dad 'dun sngon du yod par nges pas/ 'di gsum ni rtsol bar bsdus te de gcig ni spro ba'i thabs sam 'bad par byed pa ste/ thabs gnyis pa ni shin sbyangs te lus dang sems las su rung bas ting nge 'dzin 'grub pa la phan 'dogs pa'i bdag nyid yin no/ / dran pa shes bzhin byed las gcig pas gcig bsdus pa ni thabs gsum pa dmigs pa la mi yengs par gtong bar byed pa ste/ sems pa dang btang snyoms gnyis ni thabs bzhi pa rnam rtog dang nyon mongs pa'i gnyen por gyur pa yin no/ /

This verse indicates the four kinds of means. There are eight types of mental application that eliminate the five faults that prevent one from accomplishing concentration, and in this context they are condensed into four means for accomplishing concentration. The eight eliminatory types of mental application are faith, keenness, effort, fitness, mindfulness, vigilance, mental exertion, and equanimity. First of all, through faith that one will achieve concentration, one is keen to accomplish it, so one gives rise to effort. If effort is present, therefore, it has obviously been preceded by faith and keenness, so these three are included in effort, which is the first means, enthusiasm or “the application of effort.” The second means is fitness, whose nature is to help accomplish concentration by means of a workable body and mind. Mindfulness and vigilance have the same function and are therefore condensed into one to constitute the third means, directing the mind undistractedly onto the object. Mental exertion and equanimity together constitute the fourth means, which is the antidote to discursive thoughts and defilements.
mthong ba dang ni gdams ngag dang / / gnas pas rnam par rtse ba dang / / smon lam dang ni dbang dag dang / / chos thob pa ni sgrub pa'i phyir/ /
These result in the accomplishment of powers of vision, And of instructions, different displays, Aspirations, powers, And the acquisition of qualities. (XIX, 55)

mngon par sgrub pa drug ni rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa la brten nas mthong ba mngon par bsgrub pa ni spyan lnga ste/ rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa bsgoms pa'i rnam smin las sha'i spyan gyis stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten khams na gzugs phra rags gang yod pa thams cad mthong ba'o/ / rdzu 'phrul gyi spyan nam lha'i spyan ni bsam gtan dang po sogs bzhi pa'i bar bsgoms pas sha'i spyan las khyad du 'phags par phyogs bcu dus gsum gyi gzugs che phra ci rigs par shes pa'o/ / 'phags pa shes rab kyi spyan ni rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyis chos nyid de bzhin nyid gzigs pa'o/ / chos kyi spyan ni mdo la sogs pas gsung rab thams cad kyi tshig don thogs pa med par shes pa'o/ / sangs rgyas kyi spyan gyis dus gsum gyi shes bya'i chos ji lta ji snyed kyis bsdus pa kun mngon sum gzigs pa'o/ /

The six kinds of full accomplishment are as follows. By relying on the bases of miraculous powers, bodhisattvas fully accomplish the power of vision, that is, the five kinds of eye. Through the full ripening of their training in the bases of miraculous powers, they see with the eye of flesh all the gross and subtle forms that exist in the various worlds of a great universal system of one thousand million worlds. The miraculous eye, or divine eye, results from practicing the four concentrations, from the first up to the fourth; it is superior to the flesh eye in that it knows every kind of form, large and small, in the ten directions and the three times. The wisdom eye of the noble beings sees ultimate reality, thatness, with nonconceptual gnosis. The eye of Dharma constitutes unobstructed knowledge of the words and meanings of all the sūtras and other scriptures. And the buddha eye directly sees all knowable phenomena of the past, present, and future, in their nature and in their multiplicity.

sha'i mig de la dpag tshad gcig mthong bas brgya dang 'dzam gling tsam dang stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams kun gyi gzugs phra rags shes pa'i bar dang / sangs rgyas kyi sha'i spyan gyis phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten ma lus pa'i da ltar gyi gzugs thams cad gzigs pa'o/ / lha'i spyan la yang las las skyes pa dang bsgom pa las skyes pa gnyis yod pa'i dang po lha rnams kyi rang gi las las skyes pa'i shin tu dwangs pa'i dbang po thob pas thag nye ring gi gzugs kun gsal bar mthong ba'o/ / bsgoms pa las byung ba ni rnal 'byor pa rnams kyis bsam gtan bsgom pa'i mthus bsam gtan sa pa'i 'byung ba las gyur pa'i dbang po shin tu dwangs pa thob pa des/ sems can de dag sngar gang nas shi 'phos pa dang / ma 'ongs pa na gang du skye bar 'gyur ba'i 'das ma 'ongs pa'i gzugs dang da ltar gyi gzugs gzigs so/ / chos kyi spyan gyis chos rnams kyi rang spyi'i mtshan nyid dang / gang zag dag gi rgyud tshod rang dang mnyam pa dang dma' ba rnams gzigs so/ / sangs rgyas kyi spyan gyis chos thams cad la chags thogs dang bral bar gzigs pa'o/ / spyan lnga la rnam grangs gzhan dang gzhan du bshad pa'ang 'grel bar gsungs so/ /

The flesh eye ranges in power from seeing for one yojana, through a hundred yojanas, to the length and breadth of Jambudvīpa, up to knowing the gross and subtle forms in all the realms of a great thousandfold universe. The Buddha’s flesh eye sees all present forms in all the universes of the ten directions. As for the divine eye, there are two kinds: the divine eye that is produced by karmic actions and the one that is the result of meditation. The first is that of celestial beings, who have gained extremely clear faculties resulting from their karmic actions and can therefore clearly see all forms, near and far. The divine eye that results from meditation is that of practitioners who, by the power of their concentration, gain exceptionally clear faculties made from the elements in their particular worlds of concentration, and with it they see from where sentient beings have previously died and transmigrated, where they will be born in the future, and all past, present, and future forms. Those with the Dharma eye behold the general and specific characteristics of phenomena and see whether individuals’ mental level is equal to or less than their own. The buddha eye sees all phenomena unobstructedly. Different explanations of the five eyes are also given in the commentary.

gdams ngag mngon par sgrub pa ni mngon shes drug ste/ rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa la brten nas rang gis de bzhin gshegs pa las gdams ngag gi lung nod pa dang / sems can gzhan la bdag gis gdams ngag gi lung ster ba'i rgyu ni bsam gtan la brten nas mngon shes drug 'grub pa ste/ rdzu 'phrul gyi mngon par shes pas sangs rgyas rnams kyi zhing dang sems can gyi gnas de dang de dag tu thogs pa med par 'gro ba dang / lha'i mig gis sangs rgyas kyi sku dang sems can gyi lus mthong ba dang / lha'i rna bas de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung dang sems can rnams kyi sgra thos pa dang / gzhan sems shes pas sems can rnams kyi yid la ci bsams pa shes pa dang / sngon gnas rjes su dran pas rang gzhan 'das pa'i dus na gang dang gang du skyes pa shes pa dang / 'chi 'pho ba shes pas ma 'ongs par gang dang gang du skye ba shes pa dang / zag zad kyi mngon par shes pas bdag gzhan gyi sems rgyud la yod pa'i nyon mongs pa rnams zad par bya ba'i phyir de bzhin gshegs pa las gdams ngag gi lung nod nas sems can gzhan la'ang lung ston par byed pa nyid dang /

Full accomplishment of instructions refers to the six kinds of preternatural knowledge. Relying on the bases of miraculous powers, bodhisattvas receive instructions from the tathāgatas and give instructions to other sentient beings. The cause for their being able to do so is their accomplishing the six kinds of preternatural knowledge, on the basis of concentration. With the preternatural knowledge and ability to perform miracles, they travel unhindered to the realms of the buddhas and to the abodes of sentient beings. With the divine eye they can see the bodies of the buddhas and those of beings. With the divine ear they can hear the teachings[15] of the tathāgatas and the voices of sentient beings. By knowing others’ minds, they know what beings are thinking. From their memory of former lives, they know where they and others took birth in the past. Through their knowledge of death and transmigration, they know where they will be reborn in the future. And through their knowledge of the exhaustion of taints, they bring to an end the defilements present in their own and others’ minds. It is because of all these that they can receive instructions from the tathāgatas and teach and transmit them to other beings.
gnas pas rnam par rtse ba ni/ rdzu 'phrul gyi mngon par shes pas de bzhin gshegs pa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor sogs su rdzu 'phrul dang sprul pa sna tshogs kyis rnam par rtse ba'am rol par byed pa dang

Displaying different ways of abiding means that through their preternatural knowledge of miracles, they display all sorts of miracles and manifestations in the maṇḍala of the Tathāgata’s retinue and so on.

smon lam dang ni zhes pa/ smon lam mngon par bsgrub pa ni/ gang smon lam gyi mthu las skyes pa'i ye shes de'i dbang gis ji ltar smon lam btab pa bzhin du lha dang mi la sogs pa'i skye gnas de dag tu ci dgar 'gyur zhing sems can gyi don sna tshogs mdzad pas rol pa'o/ / smon lam gyi dbang gis skye ba bzung ba byang sems de dag gi lus kyi yon tan dang sems kyi mthu'i yon tan dang / sgra dbyangs kyi yon tan la sogs pa brjod du sla ba ma yin no zhes sa bcu pa'i mdo las gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

“Aspirations” refers to the full accomplishment of their prayers of aspiration. Through the power of their gnosis, which is born through the force of their aspirations, they take birth in accordance with the prayers they have made in whichever states they wish (as gods, humans, and so on) and display the deeds of benefiting sentient beings in all kinds of ways. As it is said in the Sūtra of the Ten Levels, the physical qualities of these bodhisattvas who have taken birth through the power of their prayers, the qualities of their mental powers, the qualities of their melodious voices, and so forth, are not easy to describe.

dbang thob pa mngon par sgrub pa ni/ dbang bcu thob pa ste rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa bzhi bsgom pa'i mthus tshe'i 'du byed byin gyis brlabs nas ji srid 'dod pa de srid du gnas pa ni tshe la dbang ba'o/ / de bzhin du ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin du theg pa chen po ting nge 'dzin dpag tu med pa la snyoms par 'jug pa ni sems la dbang ba'o/ / nam mkha' las ci dang ci 'dod pa'i yo byad sna tshogs char phab ste sems can rnams la phan 'dogs pa yo byad la dbang ba'o/ / lus ngag gi las kyi sprul pa sna tshogs byed pa'am/ khams dang 'gro ba skye gnas gzhan du skyes pa'i las dag byin gyis brlabs nas khams dang 'gro ba gzhan du 'gro bar byed pa las la dbang ba'o/ / gzugs khams kyi bsam gtan la gnas shing de las mi nyams bzhin du sems can gyi don du 'dod pa'i khams su skye ba skye ba la dbang ba'o/ / sa gser dang chu bdud rtsi la sogs pa ji ltar mos pa der gyur pa mos pa la dbang ba'o/ / sa dang por smon lam chen po bcu gsungs pas mtshon nas bdag dang gzhan gyi don phun sum tshogs par byed pa'i smon lam chen po grangs med pa mngon par bsgrub pa ni smon lam la dbang ba'o/ / sems can rnams dad pa bskyed pa'i phyir 'bar ba dang 'phur ba dang 'od 'gyed pa sogs rdzu 'phrul dang cho 'phrul dpag tu med pa ston pa ni rdzu 'phrul la dbang ba'o/ / chos dang don dang nges pa'i tshig dang spobs pa bzhi rab kyi mthar phyin pa ye shes la dbang ba'o/ / mdo sde la sogs pa'i chos thams cad ming tshig yi ge sna tshogs kyis sems can rnams la bstan nas sems tshim par byed pa chos la dbang ba'o/ /

The full accomplishment of acquiring powers refers to acquiring the ten powers. Because of their training in the four bases of miraculous powers, the conditioning factor of their vital energy[16] is blessed and they can live for as long as they wish. This is (1) power over life. Similarly, they have (2) power over mind: they can enter the infinite meditative absorptions of the Great Vehicle just as they wish; (3) power over material things: they rain down from the sky whatever kinds of material things are desired and thus benefit sentient beings; (4) power over activities: they manifest all kinds of physical and verbal activities, or they bless[17] their activities for taking birth in other worlds and realms in which beings are born and thus travel to different worlds and realms; (5) power over birth: while remaining in the concentrations of the world of form, without their concentration declining, they take birth in the world of desire to benefit sentient beings; (6) power over aspirations: whatever beings might aspire to (that the ground be of gold, the water be nectar, and so forth), it comes true; (7) power over prayers: they fully accomplish countless great prayers to completely fulfill their own and others’ goals, beginning with the ten great prayers of aspiration that they make on the first level; (8) power of miracles: in order to inspire faith in sentient beings, they exhibit infinite miracles and magical displays such as blazing with fire, flying through the sky, radiating light, and so on; (9) power over gnosis: they have reached the summit of the four kinds of knowledge related to phenomena, meanings, language, and inner confidence and eloquence; and (10) power over the Dharma: they teach beings all the sūtras and other forms of the Dharma, using a wide variety of names, words, and letters, and thus make them content.

dbang bcu'i rgyu ni dang po gsum sbyin pa'i phar phyin rdzogs pa las thob ste/ mi 'jigs pa'i sbyin pas tshe/ chos kyi sbyin pas sems/ zang zing gi sbyin pas yo byad la dbang thob bo/ / las dang skye bar dbang ba gnyis tshul khrims phar phyin rdzogs pa las te/ lus kyi las dag pas lus kyi sprul pa dang / ngag gi las dag pas ngag gi sprul pa sna tshogs 'gyed pa dang / tshul khrims yongs su dag par gang 'dod par skye ba thob bo/ / bzod pa'i phar phyin rdzogs pas sems can rnams kyi sems ma dkrugs shing yid dang mthun par byas pas/ gang dang gang du mos pa bskyed pa de dang de bzhin 'grub pas mos pa la dbang ba thob bo/ / brtson 'grus kyi phar phyin rdzogs pa'i mthus smon lam la dbang ba thob ste sngon dang gzhan gyi don la brtson pas phyis bdag dang gzhan gyi don du smon lam ji ltar btab pa de bzhin du 'grub pa'i phyir ro/ / bsam gtan gyi phar phyin rdzogs nas sems kyi dbang thob pas rdzu 'phrul ci 'dod pa la dbang thob bo/ / ye shes dang chos la dbang ba gnyis ni shes rab kyi phar phyin yongs su rdzogs pa'i stobs kyis 'grub bo/ / chos thob pa ni sgrub pa'i phyir/ / zhes pa chos thob pa mngon par bsgrub pa ste/ mthar thug gi yon tan sangs rgyas kyi stobs bcu dang mi 'jigs pa bzhi dang ma 'dres pa bco brgyad sogs sgrub pa'o/ / de ltar rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa bzhi la brten nas mngon par sgrub pa rnam pa drug bsgrub pa'i phyir ro/ /

The causes that produce these ten powers are as follows. The first three are gained through perfecting transcendent generosity: by giving protection from fear, bodhisattvas acquire power over life; with the gift of Dharma, power over the mind; and with material generosity, power over material things. Power over activities and power over birth are gained from perfecting transcendent discipline: by purifying their physical activities, they can send forth all kinds of bodily manifestations; by purifying their verbal activities, they can send forth many different manifestations of speech; and by maintaining perfectly pure discipline, they can take birth wherever they wish. By perfecting transcendent patience, they cease to disturb beings’ minds and can act in accordance with those beings’ wishes, so that they can accomplish whatever aspirations they make, thus obtaining power over aspirations. By perfecting transcendent diligence, they gain power over prayers, because as a result of their former efforts for their own and others’ welfare, they subsequently accomplish the prayers they have made for their own and others’ good. By perfecting transcendent concentration and gaining power over the mind, they gain the power to perform any miracles they wish. Power over gnosis and power over the Dharma are achieved by means of perfecting transcendent wisdom. “The acquisition of qualities” refers to full accomplishment of the acquisition of qualities, that is, to achieving the ultimate excellent qualities such as the Buddha’s ten strengths, four fearlessnesses, and eighteen distinctive qualities. Thus, by relying on the four bases of miraculous powers, bodhisattvas accomplish the six kinds of full accomplishment.
bzhi pa dbang po lnga bshad pa ni/
iv. THE FIVE POWERS

dad pa'i dbang po dang / de bzhin du/ brtson 'grus dang / dran pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / shes rab kyi dbang po lnga las/ dad pa ni las dang las kyi 'bras bu 'byung ba bslu med du yod pa sogs yod pa'i don la de bzhin du yid ches pa'i dad pa dang / dkon mchog gsum gyi yon tan la sems rab tu dwang ba'i dad pa dang / mya ngan las 'das pa 'thob par bya ba dang / 'phags pa'i lam bsgrub par bya ba la de ltar sgrub nus par mthong nas mngon par 'dod pa'i dad pa gsum mam/ yang na chos bzhi la dad pa ste/ las rgyu 'bras yod pa yid ches nas srog gi phyir yang sdig pa mi byed pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la dad de theg pa gzhan mi 'dod pa dang / rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba'i chos bdag med pa rnam thar sgo gsum gyi rang bzhin zab mo stong pa nyid la dad pas lta bar gyur pa thams cad kyi bag la nyal 'joms pa dang / stobs dang mi 'jigs pa sogs sangs rgyas kyi chos rgya chen po thams cad la dad pas the tshom dang som nyi med par de dag bsgrub pa ste rnam pa bzhi la dad pa'i dbang po zhes blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las gsungs so/ /

The five powers comprise the powers of faith, diligence, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom. Of these, faith is of three kinds: confidence in existent realities—the fact, for example, that actions infallibly give rise to their effects; the vivid faith and clear state of mind that is experienced when thinking of the qualities of the Three Jewels; and the yearning faith experienced on seeing that it is possible to achieve nirvāṇa and to accomplish the noble path. Another explanation of the power of faith is given in the Sūtra of the Teaching of Akṣayamati, which speaks of having faith in four things, which are as follows. Through having confidence in the reality of karmic cause and effect, one avoids negative actions even if one’s life is at risk. From having faith in the bodhisattva activities, one has no interest in other vehicles. Faith in profound emptiness—the absence of self in phenomena (which arise interdependently), the nature of the three doors of perfect liberation—destroys the latent tendencies of all kinds of wrong views. And through faith in all the extensive qualities of the Buddha—the strengths, fearlessnesses, and so forth—one will, without any doubts or uncertainties, accomplish them.
gang la dad pa'i chos de brtson 'grus kyi dbang pos sgrub par byed pa yang dag spong ba bzhi'i rang bzhin can ni brtson 'grus kyi dbang po'o/ /
It is the power of diligence that enables one to accomplish the teachings in which one has faith. This implies the four genuine restraints.
brtson 'grus kyi bsgrub pa'i chos la dran pas mi brjed par bya ba ste/ dran pa nye bar bzhag pa bzhi thob pa ni dran pa'i dbang po'o/ /
The power of mindfulness consists of being perfectly mindful of the teachings that are to be accomplished with diligence; this involves achieving the four close mindfulnesses.
bsam gtan bzhi dang gzugs med pa bzhi'i snyoms 'jug thob pa dang / dran pa'i dbang pos chud mi gzon par byas pa'i chos de la rgyun du sems rtse gcig tu 'jog pa ni ting nge 'dzin gyi dbang po'o/ /

The power of concentration consists of achieving the absorptions of the four dhyānas and four formless states and using the power of mindfulness to settle the mind one-pointedly and continuously on the teachings without letting them go to waste.
ting nge 'dzin gyi dbang pos rtse gcig tu byas pa'i chos rnams kyi rang dang spyi'i mtshan nyid shes pa'am/ 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi shes pa ni shes rab kyi dbang po'o/ /

And the power of wisdom consists of knowing the general and specific characteristics of the objects on which one has focused one-pointedly with the power of concentration, or of knowing the four noble truths.
de ltar spyir bstan nas skabs 'dir dbang po lnga po'i gzhi'am gnas sam dmigs pa bshad pa ni/
The above is a general explanation, but the text at this point describes the bases or grounds or objects of the five powers.
byang chub spyod dang thos mchog dang / / zhi gnas lhag mthong dad sogs kyi/ / gzhi yin par ni shes bya ste/ / don sgrub byed pa'i skabs kyis so/ /

Enlightenment, activities, supreme learning, Sustained calm, and profound insight Should be known as being the objects of faith and the others In the sense of these bringing the accomplishment of those goals. (XIX, 56)
zhes pas bstan te/

dad pa'i dbang pos dmigs yul las gzhi ni byang chub ste/ theg pa chen po'i 'bras bu zad mi shes pa'i ye shes sam/ sa dang po'i gnyis su med pa'i ye shes byang chub la dmigs nas de la dad cing de nyid 'thob par bya'o zhes dmigs pa'o/ / brtson 'grus kyi dbang pos ni sa dang pha rol tu phyin pa'i mtshan nyid can lhag pa'i tshul khrims dang / lhag pa'i shes rab kyis bsdus pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la dmigs nas brtson 'grus kyis spyod pa de dag sgrub par byed pa dang / dran pa'i dbang pos thos pa mchog theg pa chen po'i chos ji ltar thos pa dang / ji ltar gzung ba dang / de ltar tshig gis rgyas par gtan la dbab pa bzhin mi brjed par 'dzin pa dang / mos pas spyod pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi dbang pos sa dang po'i zhi gnas khyad par can de ji ltar 'thob par bya zhes dmigs pa'o/ / shes rab kyi dbang pos ni sa dang po'i lhag mthong rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes de ji ltar 'thob par bya zhes dmigs pa'i phyir de ltar byang chub la sogs pa de dag dad sogs kyi gzhi'am dmigs yul yin par ni shes par bya ste/ 'di lnga la ci'i phyir dbang po zhes brjod na rnam byang gi don kun sgrub pa la dbang byed pa'i skabs kyis dbang po zhes su bzhag ste/ dad pas byang chub la dbang byed pa dang / brtson 'grus kyis byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la dbang byed pa dang dran pas theg chen gyi chos dang / ting nge 'dzin gyis zhi gnas dang / shes rab kyis lhag mthong gi don sgrub pa la dbang byed pa'i phyir ro/ / yang na dbang po lngas rang gzhan gyi don sgrub par byed pa la'ang ngo/ /

The object or basis of the power of faith is enlightenment. When bodhisattvas consider enlightenment, referring to the inexhaustible gnosis that is the result of the Great Vehicle or to the nondual gnosis of the first level, they have faith in it and think, “I will attain that!” With the power of diligence, they consider the bodhisattva activities contained in the trainings in superior discipline and wisdom and characterized by the levels and transcendent perfections, and they use diligence to accomplish those activities. With the power of mindfulness, they retain their supreme learning, without ever forgetting the teachings of the Great Vehicle that they have heard, remembered, and thus extensively ascertained with words. With the power of concentration—that of bodhisattvas on the level of earnest aspiration—they consider how to attain the extraordinary sustained calm of the first level. And with the power of wisdom, they consider how to attain the nonconceptual gnosis, the profound insight, of the first level. Enlightenment and so forth are therefore to be understood as being the bases or objects of faith and the other powers. Why are these five described as powers? They are termed “powers” in the sense that they control the accomplishment of everything related to the process of purification. Faith enables bodhisattvas to master enlightenment, diligence to master the bodhisattva activities. Mindfulness enables them to master the Mahāyāna teachings, concentration the attainment of sustained calm, and wisdom the attainment of profound insight. Alternatively, it can be said that the five powers enable them to accomplish their own and others’ goals.
lnga pa stobs lnga bshad pa ni/
v. THE FIVE IRRESISTIBLE FORCES
dad sogs sa la 'jug pa ste/ / kun nas nyon mongs can du 'dod/ / mi mthun phyogs nyam chung bas kyang / / de dag nyid la stobs zhes bya/ /
Faith and the others lead to the bodhisattva levels But are considered to be associated with defilement. Because they weaken their counteragents, They are termed irresistible forces. (XIX, 57)
zhes pas bstan te/

dad pa'i stobs/ brtson 'grus kyi stobs/ dran pa'i stob sa/ ting nge 'dzin gyi stobs/ shes rab kyi stobs lnga ni/ rang rang gi mi mthun phyogs kyis brdzi mi nus pa'i tshe na stobs kyi ming can du brjod do/ / mos spyod kyi gnas skabs kyi dad sogs stobs lnga po 'di dag gi mthus 'phags pa'i sa dang po la 'jug pa ste/ 'di dag gong nas gong du 'phel bas 'phags pa'i sa dngos su 'dren pa yin yang / mthong spang las ma grol bas kun nas nyon mongs can so so'i skye bo'i sas bsdus pa'o/ / dbang po dang stobs kyi khyad par ji ltar yin zhe na/ stobs lnga po 'jig rten pa yin yang / ji srid du ma dad pa dang / le lo dang / brjed ngas dang / rnam g.yeng dang / shes rab 'chal ba'i rmongs pa yis brdzi zhing bar du gcod par byed nus pa de srid du dbang po zhes bya la/ mi mthun phyogs de dag nyam chung bas gnyen po dad pa sogs lnga po de la tshur mi tshugs shing brdzi mi nus pa'i tshe na dad sogs de dag nyid la stobs zhes bya'o/ /

The five irresistible forces comprise the forces of faith, diligence, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom—described as irresistible forces when they can no longer be quashed by their respective counteragents. It is because of the irresistible force of faith and the other four at the stage of earnest aspiration that bodhisattvas enter the first of the noble levels. As these forces grow stronger and stronger, they lead directly to the noble levels, but since they do not free one from the obscurations to be eliminated on the path of seeing, they belong to the level of ordinary beings, associated with defilement. What, then, is the difference between powers and irresistible forces? The five irresistible forces belong to the mundane level, but as long as they can be suppressed and obstructed by lack of faith, laziness, forgetfulness, distraction, and the ignorance of aberrant understanding, they are termed “powers.” When these countering factors are weakened and cannot adversely affect or suppress faith and the other four antidotes, that faith and the others are termed “irresistible forces.”
drug pa byang chub kyi yan lag bdun bshad pa ni/
vi. THE SEVEN BRANCHES OF ENLIGHTENMENT

dran pa byang chub kyi yan lag dang / de bzhin du/ chos rnam par 'byed pa dang / brtson 'grus dang / dga' ba dang / shin tu sbyangs pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / btang snyoms byang chub kyi yan lag bdun te/ dran pa ni zhi gnas kyi phyogs yin pas byang chub phyogs mthun gyi chos sum cu rtsa bdun bsgoms shing myong bas mngon du byas pa rnams ma brjed par sems la gsal ba'o/ /

The seven branches of enlightenment are those of mindfulness, perfect discernment, diligence, joy, fitness, concentration, and evenness. Mindfulness, on account of its relationship to sustained calm, makes the thirty-seven elements leading to enlightenment that are realized through practice and experience appear clearly to the mind, without being forgotten.

chos rnam par 'byed pa shes rab yin pas lhag mthong gi phyogs te mthong lam gyi dus na spang bya'i chos kun nyon gyi phyogs dang / blang bya'i chos rnam byang phyogs rnams kyi mtshan nyid ma 'dres par shes pa'o/ /

Perfect discernment of phenomena refers to wisdom and is related to profound insight; on the path of seeing, it is that which knows clearly and distinctly the specific characteristics of factors related to defilement (to be rejected) and factors related to purity (to be adopted).
brtson 'grus ni gong ma'i yon tan khyad par can len par byed cing yon tan de lta bu thob pa la gegs byed pa'i nyes pa rnams spong bar byed pa'o/ /
Diligence serves to take up the extraordinary qualities of higher levels and to eliminate the faults that prevent one from gaining such qualities.

dga' ba ni sa dang po pas chos kyi dbyings kun tu 'gro ba'i don mngon sum rtogs pas mthong spang gi sgrib pa rnams dang bral nas lus sems la dga' ba'i mchog skyes pa'o/ / de'i phyir sa de la'ang rab tu dga' ba zhes pa'i ming btags pa'o/ /

Joy is the sublime physical ease and mental happiness that occur when bodhisattvas on the first level gain direct realization of the universal expanse of reality and are thereby rid of the obscurations to be eliminated on the path of seeing (and it is for this reason that this level is called Perfect Joy).
shin tu sbyangs pa ni lus dang sems las su mi rung ba'i gnas ngan len dang bral bas/ lus las su rung bas zo mdog bde zhing / sems las su rung bas dmigs pa la thogs pa med par 'jug pa'o/ /

Fitness refers to being free of the negative tendencies that render the body and mind unworkable, resulting in a workable body, resplendent and healthy, and a workable mind that is unimpeded in engaging its object.
ting nge 'dzin ni chos kyi dbyings de bzhin nyid la dmigs pa'i sems rtse gcig pa'o/ /
Concentration refers to the one-pointed mind that considers suchness, the expanse of reality.
btang snyoms ni zhum pa dang rgod pa'i nyes pa thams cad spangs nas rgya mtsho dwangs pa rlabs dang rnyog pa med pa ltar ngang gis g.yo ba med par gnas pa'o/ /
Evenness refers to remaining naturally without movement, like a clear lake without waves or muddiness, once all faults—that is, low spirits and wildness—have been eliminated.

de bdun las chos rnam par 'byed pa dang / brtson 'grus dang dga' ba gsum ni lhag mthong gi phyogs so/ / shin sbyangs ting 'dzin btang snyoms gsum ni zhi gnas kyi phyogs so/ / dran pa ni gnyis ka'i phyogs te kun tu 'gro bas so/ /

Of these seven, perfect discernment, diligence, and joy are related to profound insight. Fitness, concentration, and evenness are related to sustained calm. Mindfulness is related to both and is universal.

de lta bu'i byang chub kyi yan lag bdun po 'di/ gang gis dus su rnam par bzhag pa dang / gang shes pas rnam par bzhag pa dang / bdun po nyid ji ltar yin pa rnam par bzhag pa dang / de bdun yan lag lngar rnam par bzhag pa bzhi las/

The classification of these seven branches of enlightenment has four aspects: their classification in terms of time, their classification in terms of what bodhisattvas know, their classification as seven branches, and the classification of these seven as five branches.
sar zhugs rnams la byang chub kyi/ / yan lag rnam par gzhag par 'dod/ / chos rnams dang ni sems can kun/ / mnyam pa nyid du rtogs phyir ro/ /
The branches of enlightenment are classified as such For those who have entered the levels. This is because they have realized sameness With regard to phenomena and all beings. (XIX, 58)
zhes pas bstan te/
dang po
(1) CLASSIFICATION IN TERMS OF TIME

sngar mos spyod kyi sar dran pa dang shes rab sogs yod kyang byang chub yan lag gi ming ma thob la/ 'phags pa'i sa skyon med pa'i sar zhugs pa sa dang po thob pa rnams kyi rgyud la yod pa'i dran pa sogs la byang chub kyi yan lag ces su rnam par bzhag par 'dod do/ /

Although bodhisattvas already have mindfulness, wisdom, and so forth on the level of earnest aspiration, these do not bear the name “branches of enlightenment.” On the other hand, the mindfulness and so forth present in the mind streams of those who have entered the noble levels—the levels without fault—and attained the first level are held to be classified as “branches of enlightenment.”
gnyis pa 'di dag byang chub kyi yan lag yin par brjod pa'i don ni/
(2) CLASSIFICATION IN TERMS OF BODHISATTVAS’ KNOWLEDGE: THE MEANING OF THESE BEING DESCRIBED AS BRANCHES OF ENLIGHTENMENT
zhes pas bstan te/

yan lag can mnyam pa nyid byang chub kyi rang bzhin mngon sum shes pa thob pa de'i phyir dran pa sogs kyang de yi yan lag tu bzhag ste/ kun 'byung gi chos rnams dang ni sems can kun gdod nas rang bzhin gyis ma skyes pa'i chos nyid rnam par dag pa ye nas byang chub par mnyam pa nyid du rtogs pa'i phyir de'i tshe na 'jig rten las 'das pa'i don dam byang chub kyi sems mngon du skyes pa'i phyir ro/ / de yang chos rnams la bdag med par rtogs pas chos mnyam pa nyid dang / sems can nam gang zag la bdag med par rtogs pas sems can mnyam pa nyid mngon du rtogs pa'o/ / yang na mnyam bzhag tu chos dang gang zag la bdag med pa nam mkha'i dkyil lta bur khong du chud pas chos rnams kyi mnyam pa nyid dang*/ rjes thob tu bdag gang yin pa sems can thams cad kyang de nyid yin la/ sems can thams cad gang yin pa bdag kyang de nyid yin te/ ji ltar bdag gi sdug bsngal zhi bar byed pa bzhin/ sems can thams cad kyi sdug bsngal yang bdag gis zhi bar bya'o zhes bdag dang gzhan khyad med par khong du chud pas sems can thams cad mnyam pa nyid du shes pa'o/ /

Why are they described as branches of enlightenment? Bodhisattvas have acquired direct knowledge of the nature of the arborescent state of evenness that is enlightenment, so for that reason mindfulness and the others are classified as its branches. Bodhisattvas have realized that all the phenomena of the origin of suffering and all sentient beings are sameness, being enlightened from the beginning, the perfectly pure ultimate reality that is primordially and naturally unborn. At that time, therefore, the supramundane, ultimate bodhicitta actually takes birth. Moreover, by realizing that phenomena are devoid of self, bodhisattvas directly realize the sameness of phenomena, and by realizing that beings or individuals are devoid of self, they directly realize the sameness of sentient beings. Alternatively, by fully understanding in formal meditation that phenomena and individuals are devoid of self, like the midst of space, they know the sameness of phenomena; and by fully understanding in postmeditation the absence of any difference between themselves and others—that all sentient beings are the same as oneself, that one is the same as all sentient beings, and that as much as one removes one’s own suffering, one must remove all beings’ suffering too—they know the sameness of all sentient beings.
gsum pa bdun po nyid ji ltar yin pa rnam par bzhag pa ni/
(3) CLASSIFICATION AS SEVEN

dper na 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po la/ rgyal srid kyi yan lag tu rin po che bdun dang ldan pa dang 'dra bar/ gdod nas skye ba med pa'i byang chub pa mngon du rtogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' la yang byang chub kyi yan lag bdun rnam par bzhag ste/

In the same way that, for example, the universal emperor possesses the seven precious attributes of his royal state, for a bodhisattva who has directly realized the primordially unborn enlightened state there are seven branches of enlightenment.

'khor los sgyur ba 'jig rten du nam byung ba na de'i bsod nams kyi stobs las lha'i bzo bos byas pa'i lha rdzas las grub pa'i 'khor lo rin po che rtsibs stong dang ldan pa mu khyud legs par bkra ba nyid 'byung ste/ de nyid nyi ma gnyis pa bzhin du nam mkha' la 'phags te song ba'i rjes su 'khor los sgyur ba nyid dpung gi tshogs dang bcas pa yang nam 'kha' la 'gro zhing yul phyogs kyi rdzong dang mkhar la gnas pa'i rgyal phran rnams kyi phyogs su phyin par tsam nas bsu zhing 'bangs su mchi ste sngar 'bangs su ma pheb cing ma rgyal ba'i sa kun las rnam par rgyal ba nyid du byed pa nyid ni 'khor lo rin po che zhes bya'o/ /

When a universal emperor appears in the world, by the force of his merit there appears a precious wheel made of celestial materials and fashioned by divine artisans, with a thousand spokes and a multicolored rim. Like a second sun, it rises high in the sky, followed by the universal emperor and his troops traveling through the sky. As soon as it arrives in the regions of the minor kings living in the forts and castles in the lands around, the latter receive the emperor and become his subjects, and the wheel confers absolute victory over all those lands that have not already fallen under its dominion and been conquered. This is what we call the precious wheel.

de bzhin du glang po rin po che ni gangs can ri bo nam mkha' la 'gro ba lta bu gzugs dang stobs phun sum tshogs pa/ yan lag thams cad legs par gnas pa rgyal po chen po la 'os shing dul ba phun sum tshogs pa phas kyi rgol ba'i dpung thams cad 'joms par byed pa'o/ /

Similarly, the precious elephant is like a snow mountain traveling through the sky. With its perfect, powerful body, all its limbs perfectly set, it befits the greatest of monarchs. It is perfectly tame and overcomes all hostile forces.

rta rin po che sngo bsang rma bya'i mgrin pa'i spu ltar yid du 'ong ba'i kha dog dang / gzugs byad phun sum tshogs pa/ cang shes pa tho rengs khye'u sus za ba'i yun tshod tsam la rgya mtsho'i mthar thug pa'i sa rnams bde blag tu 'khor te slar ldog nus pa'i bzhon pa'i yon tan phun sum tshogs pa/

The precious horse is pure blue in color, as beautiful as the feathers on a peacock’s neck, and of perfect build. All-knowing, in just the time it takes to eat breakfast it can easily go around the lands at the farthest reaches of the ocean and come back again, and it has all the qualities of the perfect steed.

nor bu rin po che dgos 'dod thams cad 'byung zhing rgyu baiDUr+ya las grub pa kha dog mthon mthing dbyibs lta na sdug pa mtshan mor yang nyi ma bzhin du dpag tshad tsam du snang bar nus pa tsha ba'i dus su bsil ba dang grang ba'i dus su dro ba 'byin pa/ reg pa tsam gyis nad thams cad zhi bar byed pa/ skams pa dang mya ngan gyi thang du yang chu rgyun bzang po 'byin pa sogs don thams cad sgrub par byed pa'i mthu phun sum tshogs pa dang*/

The precious jewel is the source of everything one could need or desire, made of beryl, dark blue in color and beautifully shaped. Even at night, it can light up everything for a yojana around as brightly as the sun. In hot weather it provides coolth; in cold weather it gives warmth. Its mere contact cures all kinds of illness, and even in arid, bleak plains it is the source of clear streams. In this and other ways it has the abundant power to fulfill every purpose.

btsun mo rin po che gzugs bzang ba'i mchog tu gyur pa/ lta na sdug cing mthong ba tsam gyis dga' ba skyed pa/ skyes pa gzhan la mi g.yem pa sogs nyon mongs pa chung zhing bdag po la mchog tu gus pas yid 'dzin pa/ tshul bzang po'i spyod pas thams cad kyi yid 'phrog pa/ kha dang lus las lha'i spos kyi dri 'byung zhing / bsil ba dang dro ba sogs yid du gang 'ong ba'i reg bya'i khyad par mchog dang ldan pa sogs pa yon tan thams cad ldan pa'o/ /

The precious queen is the height of physical beauty; the mere sight of her brings delight. Never indulging in adultery, she has few defilements and has the deepest respect for her husband. Her beautiful manners enchant everyone. From her mouth and body comes the fragrance of divine perfumes. Her sublime touch, cool or warm,[18] delights, and she possesses all kinds of other extraordinary qualities.

khyim bdag rin po che ni lag pa brkyang ba tsam gyis nor rdzas ci 'dod pa 'byung ba nor mang rnam thos kyi bu dang mtshungs pa/ rgyal pos ji ltar bsgo ba thams cad legs par bsgrub pa/ nang gi gnyer byed pa thams cad kyi mchog gi yon tan phul du phyin pa mnga' ba'o/ /

The precious steward is as wealthy as Vaiśravaṇa,[19] for simply stretching out his hand produces all the precious things one could wish for. He carries out all the emperor’s commands perfectly and possesses all the finest qualities of the highest of all the emperor’s closest commissioners.

kun mgon nam blon po'am dmag dpon rin po che ni dpa' brtan dang stobs phun sum tshogs pas pha rol zil gyis gnon pa/ dpung gi bkod pa dus su 'gro ba dang ldog pa la mkhas pa legs par byed pa rjes su 'dzin pa dang / nyes par byed pa tshar bcad pa rgyal po la bzhed pa dang pha rol gnon pa thams cad thogs med du sgrub par nus shing bka' bzhin byed pa'o/ /

The precious lord chancellor or minister or general outshines all others with his unparalleled courage, steadfastness, and strength. In disposing his troops, he is skillful in advance and retreat alike, cares for those who act correctly, subjugates those who do wrong, fulfills the emperor’s wishes, and vanquishes his enemies. He is able to accomplish all this without delay and acts in accordance with the emperor’s orders.
dpe de rnams bzhin du
All these can be used as analogies for what follows.
shes byas rgyal rgyal bya yi phyir/ / dran pa dag ni kun tu spyod/ / 'di yi rnam 'byed rtog pa yi/ / mtshan ma thams cad 'joms par byed/ /
In order to conquer unconquered knowledge, They specifically practice mindfulness. Their perfect discernment destroys Every conceptualized attribute. (XIX, 59)
zhes pas bstan te/

byang chub sems dpa' sa dang po thob pa'i tshe/ sngar mos spyod kyi sa la/ shes bya gang zhig mngon sum du ma shes pa'am/ mngon sum du shes pa'i sgrib pa las ma rgyal ba de las sa dang po de'i dus su mngon sum shes shing de'i sgrib pa mthong spang las rgyal bar bya ba'i phyir/ sngar mos spyod du bsgoms pa'i chos rnams ma brjed pa'i dran pa dag ni kun tu spyod pa 'khor los sgyur ba sa kun las rgyal bar byed pa'i 'khor lo rin chen lta bu'o/ /

When bodhisattvas attain the first level, there are knowable phenomena that they did not directly know previously on the level of earnest aspiration, or obscurations to direct knowledge that they have not previously overcome. So in order to have direct knowledge at the time of the first level and to overcome the obscurations to that direct knowledge that are to be eliminated on the path of seeing, they specifically practice unforgetting mindfulness of the elements in which they have previously trained on the path of earnest aspiration. Such mindfulness is like the precious wheel that enables the universal emperor to be victorious over the whole earth.

sa dang po pa 'di yi chos rab tu rnam par 'byed pa'i shes rab ni chos dang / gang zag gi bdag gnyis su rtogs pa yi mtshan ma thams cad 'joms par byed pas glang po rin po che phas rgol gyi dpung thams cad 'joms par byed pa bzhin no/ /
The wisdom of perfect discernment of these first-level bodhisattvas destroys all dualistic concepts of the phenomenal and individual self, like the precious elephant routing all the enemy’s troops.
'di yi brtson 'grus ma lus pa/ / myur du rtogs par bya phyir 'jug / chos kyi snang ba rnam 'phel ba'i/ / dga' bas rtag tu rgyas par 'gyur/ /
They apply their diligence In order to realize everything swiftly. As the light of Dharma grows, They are forever filled with joy. (XIX, 60)

sa dang po pa 'di yi brtson 'grus ni/ mngon par shes pa sogs yon tan khyad par can rnams ma lus pa myur du rtogs shing 'grub par bya ba'i phyir 'jug pa ni rta rin po ches gang 'dod pa'i gnas su myur du phyin par byed pa bzhin no/ / sa dang po thob pa de yi tshe na de kho na nyid mngon sum rtogs pas 'jig rten las 'das pa'i chos kyi snang ba chen po rnam par 'phel ba'i dga' bas lus dang sems rtag tu rgyas par 'gyur ba'i phyir dga' ba ni nor bu rin po che'i 'od kyis mun pa sel ba bzhin no/ /

The diligence of bodhisattvas on the first level is applied in order to swiftly realize and accomplish every one of the extraordinary qualities such as the different kinds of preternatural knowledge, like the precious horse, which swiftly reaches its desired destination. When they attain the first level, they realize thatness directly, so that the great supramundane light of the Dharma[20] shines brighter and brighter and their bodies and minds are constantly filled with joy. Joy, therefore, is likened to the light of the precious jewel dispelling the darkness.
sgrib pa kun las thar pa'i phyir/ / shin tu sbyangs pas bde ba 'thob/ / ting nge 'dzin las bsams pa'i don/ / 'byor pa nye bar skye bar 'gyur/ /
Because they are free of all obscurations, They are fully fit and thus accomplish bliss. Their concentration gives rise To all the wealth they could desire. (XIX, 61)

sa dang po'i rnam grol lam du mthong spang gi sgrib pa kun las rnam par grol ba'am thar pa'i phyir lus sems las su mi rung ba gtan med par shin tu sbyangs pas bde ba thob pa ni btsun mo rin po che'i reg byas 'khor los bsgyur ba'i rgyal po la dga' ba skyed pa bzhin no/ / ting nge 'dzin yang dag byang chub kyi yan lag las/ mngon par shes pa sogs yon tan dang bsam pa'i don thams cad yid bzhin du 'byor ba nye bar skye bar 'gyur bas na/ khyim bdag rin po ches rgyal pos ci bzhed pa'i nor thams cad phun sum tshogs pa sgrub par byed pa bzhin no/ /

On the path of perfect liberation at the first level, they are freed or liberated from all the obscurations to be eliminated by the path of seeing, and the resulting fitness and absolute workability of body and mind leads to their attaining bliss, like the precious queen’s touch that so delights the universal emperor. Through the branch of enlightenment that is genuine concentration, they come to acquire all the qualities such as preternatural knowledge and to reach all their intended goals according to their wishes, so concentration is likened to the precious steward, who produces all the precious things that the emperor wishes for in abundance.
btang snyoms kyis ni thams cad du/ / 'di ni ji ltar 'dod bzhin gnas/ / rjes la thob dang mi rtog pa'i/ / gnas pas mchog ni rtag tu gnas/ /
With evenness, they abide At all times as they wish; In their postmeditation and nonconceptual states, They remain constantly sublime. (XIX, 62)

btang snyoms yang dag byang chub kyi yan lag nyid kyis ni/ dus thams cad du byang chub sems dpa' sa dang po pa 'di ni sems la zhum rgod dang chags sdang sogs nyon mongs pa dang nye ba'i nyon mongs pa med pa'i ngo bos rang ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin rnal du gnas te de yang rjes la thob pa dag pa 'jig rten pa'i ye shes kyis sems can gyi don bya ba dang / rang gis sa gong ma'i yon tan ma thob pa rnams thob par byed pa dang / nyes pa ma spangs pa rnams spong bar byed cing sa 'og ma yang 'dor bar byed pa dang / mnyam bzhag tu rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyis ci la'ang mi gnas par gnas pas byang chub sems dpa' mchog ni rtag tu gnas par byed do/ / yang na 'phags pa mchog gi gnas pa la ni rtag tu gnas so zhes/ blo brtan 'grel par/ gnas pas rtag tu mchog yin no zhes snang / de ltar btang snyoms ni dmag dpon rin po ches dpung gi tshogs bzhi po bsdus te/ gzhom zhing bskrad par bya ba rnams skrod par byed pa dang / bsdu zhing skyong bar byed pa rnams sdud par byed la/ gang du 'tshe zhing gnod pa med pa'i phyogs su gnas par byed pa dang 'dra ste/ pha rol gyi sde bsdu ba dang skrod par byed pa lta bu ni dag pa 'jig rten pa'i ye shes te des blang bya len pa dang 'dor bya spong bar byed pas so/ / gang du 'tshe ba med par bag phab ste gnas pa lta bu ni rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes te de ni dmigs pa thams cad rab tu zhi ba la gnas pa'i phyir ro/ /

With the branch of enlightenment that is genuine evenness, the minds of bodhisattvas on the first level are at all times free of defilements and lesser defilements, such as attachment and aversion, and low spirits and wildness, as a result of which they rest naturally, just as they wish. In the postmeditation, the pure mundane gnosis enables them to act for beings’ benefit, to acquire the qualities of the higher levels that they have not yet obtained, and to eliminate the faults that they have not yet eliminated and leave the lower levels behind. And in formal meditation, with nonconceptual gnosis, the supreme bodhisattvas constantly remain in the state of dwelling without dwelling anywhere. Alternatively, it can be said that they remain constantly in the way of abiding of the greatest noble beings, Sthiramati’s commentary quoting this line of the verse as “In dwelling, they are forever sublime.” Evenness is thus like the precious general marshaling his four divisions, using them to put to flight those who have to be defeated and driven out, and withdrawing troops that need to be assembled and protected, placing them in a position where they will not be endangered or harmed. Similarly, as if assembling troops and banishing enemy forces, the pure mundane gnosis takes up those factors that have to be adopted and eliminates factors that must be abandoned. And as if letting the troops rest where they will not be in danger, the nonconceptual gnosis settles in the state where all concepts are completely stilled.
yon tan de lta'i sems dpa' ni/ / 'khor los sgyur ba 'dra bar 'jog / rtag tu rin chen bdun lta bu'i/ / byang chub yan lag rnams kyis bskor/ /
Courageous beings with such qualities Are compared to the universal emperor; They are constantly surrounded by the branches of enlightenment As if by his seven precious attributes. (XIX, 63)

yon tan de lta bu mnga' ba'i byang chub sems dpa' ni 'khor los sgyur ba dang 'dra bar yon tan de dag la 'jug pa'am dbang sgyur ba po yin la/ dus rtag tu rgyal srid rin po che bdun lta bu'i byang chub yan lag bdun po rnams kyis bskor zhing ldan pa yin no/ /

Like the universal emperor and his seven precious attributes of royalty, bodhisattvas who possess the above qualities are the masters or employers of those qualities, and as such are always surrounded by and endowed with the seven branches of enlightenment.
bzhi pa
(4) CLASSIFICATION OF THE SEVEN BRANCHES AS FIVE
rang bzhin yan lag gnas yan lag / gsum pa nges 'byung yan lag ste/ / bzhi pa phan yon yan lag yin/ / rnam gsum nyon mongs med yan lag /
These are the nature branch and the source branch, Third, the branch of certain deliverance, Fourth, the branch of benefit, And the threefold branch of absence of defilements. (XIX, 64)
zhes pas bstan te/

yan lag bdun yan lag lngar bsdu ba 'dis yan lag ces pa'i don kyang bshad pa yin te/ chos rab rnam 'byed ni rang bzhin gyi yan lag ste byang chub kyi ngo bo rtogs pa'i rang bzhin yin pa'i phyir ro/ / dran pa ni gnas kyi yan lag ste/ sngar mos spyod du chos rnams ma brjed par yang yang dran zhing goms pa'i mthar thug pa chos mchog chen po'i dus kyi dran pa de las chos rab rnam 'byed sogs yan lag kun byung ba'i phyir ro/ /

This condensation of the seven branches into five also explains the meaning of the term “branches.” Perfect discernment of phenomena is the nature branch, because it is, by nature, the realization of the essence of enlightenment. Mindfulness is the branch that is the source, because it is through the mindfulness at the time of the great supreme mundane level, which is the culmination of repeated training and unforgetting mindfulness of the elements of the practice at the stage of earnest aspiration, that perfect discernment and the other branches arise.

gsum pa brtson 'grus ni nges par 'byung ba'i yan lag ste/ brtson 'grus kyi mthus mos spyod kyi sa las 'das nas sa dang po la nges par 'byung ba'i phyir ro/ / sa dang po rang dus kyi dran pa dang brtson 'grus de ni mos spyod kyi dran pa dang brtson 'grus mthar thug pa'i 'bras bu'i dran brtson yin no/ / bzhi pa dga' ba ni sa dang po thob pa'i tshe chos kyi dbyings rtogs pa'i phan yon gyi yan lag ste de'i dbang gis yid la dga' ba khyad par can skyes pa'i phyir ro/ / shin sbyangs ting 'dzin btang snyoms rnam pa gsum ni nyon mongs med pa'i yan lag ste/ lus sems shin tu sbyangs pas nyon shes kyi sgrib pa'i gnas ngan len dang bral ba ni gang gis nyon mongs pa med par byed pa'am nyon mongs med pa'i gnas so/ / ting nge 'dzin ni gzhi gang la gnas nas nyon mongs pa med par byed pa ste ting 'dzin la gnas pa'i dus ni bying rgod sogs nye ba'i nyon mongs pa sel ba'i phyir ro/ / btang snyoms ni nyon mongs pa med pa'i ngo bo ste btang snyoms par rnal du gnas pa la nyon mongs gang yang med pas so/ /

Third, diligence is the branch of certain deliverance, because it is by the force of diligence that bodhisattvas pass beyond the level of earnest aspiration and attain certain deliverance on the first level. The specific mindfulness and diligence at the time of the first level are the resultant mindfulness and diligence, the culmination of the mindfulness and diligence employed on the path of earnest aspiration. Fourth, joy is the benefit branch—the benefit of realizing the expanse of reality when the first level is attained, for because of that realization, extraordinary joy arises in the mind. Fitness, concentration, and evenness together constitute the branch of absence of defilements. Physical and mental fitness frees bodhisattvas from the negative tendencies of the defilement-related and cognitive obscurations—it is what leads to absence of defilements or is the source of absence of defilements. Concentration is the ground on which they dwell, thus leading to absence of defilements, because when one rests in concentration, the lesser defilements such as drowsiness and excitement are dispelled. And evenness is the very essence of absence of defilements, for there can be no defilements when one is resting evenly in the natural state.
bdun pa
vii. THE EIGHTFOLD NOBLE PATH

'phags pa'i lam yan lag brgyad ni/ yang dag pa'i lta ba 'phags pa'i lam dang / de bzhin du yang dag pa'i rtog pa dang / yang dag pa'i ngag dang / yang dag pa'i las kyi mtha' dang / yang dag pa'i 'tsho ba dang / yang dag pa'i rtsol ba dang / yang dag pa'i dran pa dang / yang dag pa'i ting nge 'dzin 'phags pa'i lam mo/ / de la yang dag pa'i lta ba ni mthong lam du chos rab tu rnam par 'byed pa'i shes rab kyis gang zag dang chos la bdag med pa'i chos dbyings mnyam pa nyid mngon sum rtogs pa de nyid la dmigs shing bsgom pa'o/ / yang dag pa'i lta ba des rgyu byas nas/ khams gsum las nges par 'byin pa'i rgyu/ lhag pa'i tshul khrims dang sems dang shes rab la rtog cing de 'dod pa dang / 'dod 'dun dang gnod sems sogs nyon mongs med pa'i rtog pa ni/ yang dag pa'i rtog pa'o/ / yang dag pa'i lta ba dang rtog pa rang gis ji ltar khong du chud pa ltar sems can gzhan la phan pa'i phyir ston cing ngag gi nyes pa rdzun dang tshig rtsub po dang / phra ma dang ngag 'khyal rnam par spangs pa ni yang dag pa'i ngag go / lus kyi sgo nas srog gcod pa sogs nyes pa gsum spangs nas/ rnam par grol ba'i lam la 'jug pa ni yang dag pa'i las kyi mtha'o/ / kha gsag dang tshul 'chos pa la sogs pa log pa'i 'tsho ba thams cad spang ba ni yang dag pa'i 'tsho ba'o/ / yang dag pa'i lta rtog las mtha' 'tsho ba bzhi la brten nas bsgom pas spang bar bya ba'i sgrib pa gnyis po spang bar bya ba'i phyir 'phags pa'i lam la rgyun du sgom par byed pa ni yang dag pa'i rtsol ba'o/ / ji ltar khong du chud pa'i chos rnams kyi don ma brjed cing sems la gsal bar snang ba ni yang dag pa'i dran pa'o/ / chos kyi dbyings de bzhin nyid la sems rtse gcig tu mnyam par 'jog pa ni yang dag pa'i ting nge 'dzin no/ /

The eightfold noble path comprises the noble paths of right view, right thought, right speech, right conduct, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration. Right view involves contemplating and training in the direct realization—gained on the path of seeing with the wisdom of perfect discernment—of evenness, the expanse of reality, devoid of individual and phenomenal self. Right view leads to right thought—that is, the thought of or desire for superior discipline, superior concentration, and superior wisdom, which together constitute the cause for certain deliverance from the three worlds; and thoughts free of defilements such as hedonism and malice. Right speech involves teaching right view and right thought as one has understood them oneself to other beings in order to benefit them, and completely avoiding the negative verbal actions of lying, harsh words, sowing discord, and worthless chatter. Right conduct involves avoiding the three negative physical acts (taking life and so on) and engaging in the path to perfect liberation. Right livelihood implies the avoidance of all forms of wrong livelihood involving flattery, hypocrisy, and so forth. Right effort applies to training continuously on the noble path, relying on right view, thought, conduct, and livelihood, in order to eliminate the two obscurations to be eliminated on the path through meditation. With right mindfulness, the points of the teachings that one has understood are not forgotten and appear clearly to the mind. And with right concentration, the mind is settled evenly and one-pointedly on suchness, the expanse of reality.

de brgyad kyang spyod lam gyi tshe na/ yang dag pa'i ngag dang las mtha' dang 'tsho ba gsum la gnas par bya ba yin la/ nang du ting nge 'dzin la gnas pa'i tshe na zhi gnas dang lhag mthong bsgom par bya ba yin no/ / de yang yang dag pa'i lta ba dang rtog pa rtsol ba gsum lhag mthong gi phyogs te/ yang dag pa'i lta ba lhag mthong nyid yin la/ rtog pa dang rtsol ba gnyis ni lhag mthong gi 'khor ro/ / yang dag pa'i ting nge 'dzin dang dran pa ni zhi gnas kyi phyogs te ting nge 'dzin zhi gnas dngos dang dran pa zhi gnas de'i 'khor ro/ /

Of these eight, right speech, right conduct, and right livelihood are to be observed during one’s daily activities, whereas when one is practicing inner concentration one should train in sustained calm and profound insight. In the latter case, right view, right thought, and right effort are related to profound insight: right view is profound insight itself, while right thought and effort are accessories of profound insight. And right concentration and mindfulness are related to sustained calm: right concentration is sustained calm, and mindfulness is accessory to it.
lam yan lag brgyad po de bshad pa ni/
These eight branches of the path are indicated in the next two verses.

de yi 'og tu ji lta ba/ / rtogs pa'i rjes su 'jug pa ste/ / rnam gzhag ji bzhin rtogs pa dang / / rnam par gzhag la 'jug pa dang / / las gsum rnam par dag pa dang / / shes bya dag dang lam dang ni/ / yon tan khyad par can gyi ni/ / sgrib pa'i gnyen por sgom pa'o/ /

After that, bodhisattvas follow up Their realization of the nature as it is, They realize its presentation And apply that presentation, (XIX, 65) They purify the three acts, And they cultivate the antidotes To factors that obscure knowledge, The path, and extraordinary qualities. (XIX, 66)
zhes tshigs bcad gnyis kyis bstan te/

sa dang po thob pa de yi 'og tu sa gnyis pa yan chad du 'phags pa'i lam yan lag brgyad sgom par byed pa ni chos rab rnam 'byed kyi byang chub yan lag gis bdag med gnyis ji lta ba bzhin du rtogs pa'i rjes su 'jug pa'i sgo nas chos kyi dbyings de nyid rtogs shing bsgom pa ni yang dag pa'i lta ba ste yang dag pa'i lta bas de kho na nyid ji ltar khong du chud pa de nyid/ 'di dang 'di lta bu'o zhes rnam par bzhag par byed pa ni yang dag pa'i rtog pa'o/ / des ji ltar rnam par 'jog par byed na de kho na nyid kyi don 'di dang 'di lta bu zhes ming tshig yi ges bstan pa'i gtsug lag tu byas pa mdo sde la sogs pa ni rnam par bzhag pa'i chos zhes bya ste de kho na nyid kyi don ston pa rnam par bzhag pa'i phyir ro/ / des na rnam par bzhag pa de yi don ji lta ba bzhin du rang gis rtogs pa dang gzhan la de ltar 'chad pa dang / rnam par bzhag pa yi lung de nyid la dgongs don ma nor bar 'byed pa'i sgo nas 'jug pa ni yang dag pa'i rtog pa'o/ / ngag dang las mtha' 'tsho ba gsum gyis las gsum rnam par dag pa dang / bskal pa grangs med pa gnyis su yang dag pa'i rtsol ba brten pa ni/ shes bya'i sgrib pa'i gnyen por sgom pa dag dang / de bzhin du yang dag pa'i dran pa ni lam gyi sgrib pa'i gnyen por bsgom ste/ zhi gnas dang lhag mthong gi lam bsgom pa'i dus na lam de'i sgrib pa bying ba dang rgod pa byung na zhi gnas kyi mtshan ma dang rab tu 'dzin pa'i mtshan ma dang btang snyoms kyi mtshan ma gsum gong du bshad pa ltar dran pa'i stobs kyis sgrib pa de dag bsal ba'i phyir dang ni/ yang dag pa'i ting nge 'dzin ni mngon par shes pa drug sogs mtha'i le'u las bshad pa ltar gyi yon tan khyad par can gyi ni sgrib pa'i gnyen por bsgom pa'o/ /

After attaining the first level, from the second level onward bodhisattvas train in the eight branches of the noble path. By following up the realization (through the perfect discernment branch of enlightenment) of the nature as it is, the absence of the two kinds of self, they realize and meditate on that expanse of reality. This is right view, with which bodhisattvas master their understanding of thatness. What establishes that understanding as being like this or like that is right thought. How does it establish that? The sūtras and other scriptures that indicate by means of names, phrases, and letters that thatness is like this or like that are referred to as “teachings of presentation” because they indicate and present the meaning of thatness. Consequently, to realize oneself the meaning of that presentation as it is, to explain it like that to others, and to apply it by unmistakenly discerning the intended meaning of that scriptural presentation is right thought. The three kinds of acts[21] are purified by means of right speech, conduct, and livelihood. Relying on right effort for two measureless kalpas, bodhisattvas cultivate the antidotes to cognitive obscurations. Similarly, with right mindfulness they cultivate the antidotes to the factors that obscure the path—that is to say, when they are practicing the paths of sustained calm and profound insight, if sinking or wildness occur, obscuring that path, these obscurations are cleared by mindfulness of the three special points (the special point of sustained calm, the special point of maintaining one’s concentration, and the special point of equanimity, as has already been explained).[22] With right concentration they cultivate the antidotes to the factors that obscure extraordinary qualities such as the six kinds of preternatural knowledge described in the Powers chapter.
gnyis pa zhi gnas lhag mthong rnam par dbye ba ni/
b. SUMMARY, AN ANALYSIS OF SUSTAINED CALM AND PROFOUND INSIGHT
yang dag gnas pa la brten nas/ / sems la sems ni 'jog phyir dang / / chos rab rnam par 'byed pa'i phyir/ / zhi gnas dang ni lhag mthong yin/ /
Because, on the basis of right abiding, The mind settles on the mind, And because phenomena are perfectly discerned, There is sustained calm and profound insight. (XIX, 67)
zhes tshigs su bcad pa gsum gyis bstan te/

yang dag par gnas pa ni gzugs khams kyi bsam gtan bzhi zag pa med pa la brten nas sems las gzhan pa'i chos med pas sems tsam sems ni rtse gcig tu 'jog pa'i phyir zhi gnas dang / zhi gnas de la brten nas chos thams cad kyi de kho na nyid kyi don phyin ci ma log par shes pa chos rab tu rnam par 'byed pa'i phyir rnam par mi rtog pa ni lhag mthong ste/ de ltar theg pa chen po'i zhi gnas dang ni lhag mthong gi mtshan nyid mdor bstan pa yin no/ /

By relying on right abiding,[23] that is, on the four concentrations of the world of form, untainted by defilements, the mind settles one-pointedly on the mind alone (there being no phenomena apart from the mind), resulting in sustained calm. And on the basis of that sustained calm, the unmistaken knowledge of the meaning of the thatness of all phenomena perfectly discerns phenomena, resulting in nonconceptuality, that is, profound insight.
