This is a brief presentation of the defining characteristics of sustained calm and profound insight according to the Great Vehicle. There now follows a detailed treatment of sustained calm and profound insight.

de ni kun 'gro cha gcig dang / / cha gcig ma yin rgyur 'dod do/ / rtogs dang nges par 'byung ba dang / / mtshan med 'du mi byed pa dang / / yongs dag rnam par dag pa la/ / brten pa'i zhi gnas lhag mthong gi / rnal 'byor de sa kun 'gro ste/ / thams cad sgrub par byed pa yin/ /

These are held to be universal, partial, Not partial, and causal. Related to realization and to certain deliverance, Devoid of attributes, not deliberate, (XIX, 68) Completely purifying, and perfectly pure— The yoga of sustained calm and profound insight of the steadfast Is universal for all levels; It is this that accomplishes everything. (XIX, 69)

zhi gnas dang lhag mthong gi rab tu dbye ba bstan pa ni/ zhi lhag gnyis po de ni yon tan sgrub pa dang bsgom pa thams cad la kun tu 'gro ba yin te byang chub kyi phyogs bsgom pa dang / bsam gtan dang ting nge 'dzin thob par 'dod pa dang / mngon shes la sogs pa thob par 'dod pa de dag kun la med du mi rung bas kun tu 'gro ba zhes bya ste bsgom pa thams cad kyi dngos gzhi ni 'di gnyis yin no/ / cha gcig dang zhes pa/ gzugs med pa'i snyoms 'jug bzhi sgom pa ni zhi gnas shas che ba lhag mthong shas chung bas cha gcig dang / gzugs khams kyi bsam gtan dang po dang / gnyis pa dang / gsum pa gsum ni lhag mthong shas che ba la zhi gnas shas chung bas de yang phyogs gcig gam cha gcig pa'o/ / cha gcig ma yin zhes pa zhi gnas dang lhag mthong zung du 'brel bas shas che chung med pas cha gcig pa'i phyogs ma yin pa ni gzugs khams kyi bsam gtan bzhi pa bsgom pa'i dus na'o/ /

Sustained calm and profound insight are both universal for the whole training and accomplishment of good qualities—“universal” because they are indispensable for all who are training toward enlightenment, who wish to acquire the dhyānas and concentration, and who want to gain preternatural knowledge and other qualities. The main body of all meditation is these two. “Partial” refers to the fact that the meditation of the four formless absorptions is predominantly sustained calm, with little profound insight, and therefore partial, and that the first, second, and third concentrations of the world of form consist predominantly of profound insight, with a little sustained calm, and they are therefore also one-sided or partial. “Not partial” refers to the fact that sustained calm and profound insight are combined, with neither being predominant, and they are therefore not partial or one-sided—this being the case during the meditation of the fourth concentration of the world of form.

mos pas spyod pa'i zhi gnas dang lhag mthong bsgom pa ni sa dang po thob pa'i rgyur 'dod do/ / sa dang po'i dus kyi zhi lhag ni rab tu rtogs pa'i zhi lhag zhes te de tshe chos kyi dbyings kun tu 'gro ba rtogs pa'i phyir dang / sa gnyis pa nas drug pa'i bar gyi zhi gnas dang lhag mthong ni nges par 'byung ba'i zhi lhag zhes bya ste/ mtshan ma thams cad rim gyis spong bar byed cing mtshan ma med pas bdun par nges par 'byung ba'i phyir dang / sa bdun pa'i dus kyi zhi lhag ni mtshan ma med pa'i zhi gnas dang lhag mthong zhes bya ste/ de'i dus na mdo sde la sogs pa'i chos rnam pa sna tshogs la mtshan ma tha dad par mi byed cing thams cad mtshan ma med par ro gcig par bsgom pa'i phyir ro/ / sa brgyad pa dang dgu pa dang bcu pa'i dus na zhi lhag bsgom pa ni 'du mi byed pa'i zhi gnas dang lhag mthong zhes bya ste/ 'bad rtsol med par lhun gyis grub pa'i zhi gnas dang lhag mthong la gnas pa'i phyir dang / dag pa'i sa de gsum gyi zhi lhag bsgom pas sangs rgyas kyi zhing yongs su dag pa zhes bya la/ sgrib gnyis bag chags dang bcas pa rnam par dag pa sangs rgyas kyi sa 'thob par byed pas rnam par dag pa zhes bya ste/ de ltar sa dang sa rnams la brten pa'i zhi gnas dang lhag mthong gi rnal 'byor de ni mos spyod nas sa bcu pa'i bar gyis kun tu 'gro ba ste/ de ni bdag dang gzhan gyi don thams cad sgrub par byed pa dang / 'og ma 'og mas sa gong ma'i yon tan thams cad sgrub par byed pa yin no/ /

The practice of sustained calm and profound insight on the level of earnest aspiration is held to be the cause for attaining the first bodhisattva level. The sustained calm and profound insight practiced at the time of the first level are termed “sustained calm and profound insight of perfect realization,” because at that time bodhisattvas realize the all-pervading expanse of reality. From the second level up to the sixth, sustained calm and profound insight are termed “sustained calm and profound insight of certain deliverance” because they successively eliminate all conceptual attributes and lead to certain deliverance on the seventh level, devoid of attributes. The sustained calm and profound insight on the seventh level are known as “sustained calm and profound insight without attributes” because at that stage bodhisattvas no longer distinguish different attributes in the various teachings such as the sūtras, and everything is meditated as a single taste without any attributes. On the eighth, ninth, and tenth levels, the practice of sustained calm and profound insight is termed “nondeliberate sustained calm and profound insight” because bodhisattvas remain in sustained calm and profound insight effortlessly and spontaneously. The practice of sustained calm and profound insight on these three pure levels leads to their “completely purifying” buddha fields. And because they enable the bodhisattva to attain buddhahood, in which the two obscurations together with habitual tendencies have been totally purified, they are referred to as “perfectly pure.” Thus the yoga of sustained calm and profound insight of the steadfast on these different levels is universal to all the levels, from that of earnest aspiration up to the tenth level. It is this that enables bodhisattvas to accomplish all their own and others’ goals and to accomplish all the excellent qualities from each level to the next.
gsum pa bsgom pa khyad par du byed pa'i yan lag
3. BRANCHES THAT ENHANCE THE PRACTICE

['di] la/ don chen po bsgrub pa la tshegs chung zhing bslu ba med par byed pa'i thabs mkhas dang / sngar gzung ba'i chos rnams mi brjed pa'i gzungs dang / ma 'ongs pa'i yon tan rnams thob par byed pa'i smon lam dang / lam yongs su dag par byed pa ting nge 'dzin dang sdom bzhi bstan pa bzhi las/

The branches are explained in four parts: (1) skill in the means that enable one to accomplish the great meaning unfailingly and with little difficulty; (2) the power of memory that never forgets teachings previously received; (3) prayers of aspiration that enable one to acquire good qualities in the future; and (4) an explanation of concentration and the four summaries of the Dharma that make the path completely pure.
dang po sangs rgyas kyi chos ni/
a. SKILL IN THE MEANS THAT ENABLE ONE TO ACCOMPLISH THE GREAT MEANING UNFAILINGLY AND WITH LITTLE DIFFICULTY

sangs rgyas chos rnams rdzogs bya dang / / sems can rnams yongs smin bya dang / / myur thob bya ba 'grub pa dang / / lam rgyun mi gcod la mkhas pa/ / byang chub sems dpa'i sa kun la/ / thabs ni mtshungs pa med pa ste/ / thabs mkhas de la brten nas ni/ / de dag don kun sgrub par byed/ /

Skill in completing the Buddha Dharma, In bringing sentient beings to full maturation, In swift attainment, in accomplishing activities, And in not interrupting the path—(XIX, 70) The means employed by bodhisattvas On all levels are without equal: By relying on such skill in means, They accomplish every kind of goal. (XIX, 71)
ces pas bstan te/

sa dang phar phyin dang byang chub phyogs mthun sogs lam gyi chos dang / 'bras bu stobs dang mi 'jigs pa dang rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa'i bar gyi chos rnams thams cad rdzogs par bya ba'i thabs ni rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes te/ lam dang 'bras bu'i chos gang la yang mtshan mar dmigs pa med pas yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur te/ sher phyin 'bum pa las/ gal te sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa yongs su rdzogs par 'dod na shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la bslab par bya'o/ /zhes bya ba nas/ rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes thob par 'dod pas shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la bslab par bya'o/ /zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ / sems can rnams yongs su smin par byed pa'am bya ba'i thabs ni bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhi ste/ des sems can mi dge ba'i gnas las bslang nas dge ba'i gnas su 'jog par byed pa'i phyir ro/ /

The means for completing the whole of the Buddha Dharma, from the qualities of the path such as the levels, transcendent perfections, and elements leading to enlightenment through to the resultant qualities of the strengths, fearlessnesses, omniscience, and so forth, is nonconceptual gnosis. It is through the absence of concepts with regard to attributes that every one of the qualities of the path and its result will be completed and perfected. For as we find in the Perfection of Wisdom in One Hundred Thousand Lines, “If one wishes to complete transcendent generosity, one must train in transcendent wisdom,” and so on, through to “Those who wish to acquire omniscient gnosis should train in transcendent wisdom.” The means for bringing sentient beings to full maturation are the four ways of attracting disciples, because these extract beings from nonvirtuous modes of conduct and set them in virtuous practices.

mngon par shes pa myur du thob cing myur du mngon par 'tshang rgya ba thob pa'i thabs ni mdo las sdig pa thams cad ni bshags par bya'o/ / bsod nams kun la rjes su yi rang bar bya'o/ / sangs rgyas thams cad la gsol ba gdab par bya'o/ / bdag bla na med pa ye shes kyi mchog dam pa 'tshang rgya bar gyur cig / ces gsungs pa de bzhin du bshags pa dang / yi rang gsol ba dang bsngo ba bstan pa 'di lta bu'o/ / bya ba 'grub pa'i thabs ni gzungs dang ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo gnyis te/ gzungs kyis chos kyi tshig dang don mi brjed par 'dzin pas bdag gi don du bya ba 'grub la/ ting nge 'dzin gyis rdzu 'phrul rnam pa sna tshogs bstan pa'i sgo nas gzhan gyi don bya ba 'grub bo/ /

The means for rapidly acquiring preternatural powers and swiftly attaining buddhahood is to confess, rejoice, pray, and dedicate, as is shown in the sūtras: I shall confess all negative actions. I shall rejoice in all merit. I shall pray to all the buddhas. May I attain supreme enlightenment, unsurpassable gnosis. The means for accomplishing activities are the two doors of the power of memory and concentration. By using the power of memory to retain the words and meanings, bodhisattvas accomplish their own good; by using concentration to display all kinds of miraculous activities, they accomplish others’ good.

lam rgyun mi gcod pa la mkhas pa ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i gdung ngam rigs rgyun mi gcod pa ste/ mi gnas pa'i myang 'das sgrub pa'i lam shes rab dang snying rje gnyis so/ / de yang shes rab kyis 'khor ba'i mtha' la mi gnas/ snying rjes zhi mthar mi gnas pa'o/ / de yang kun rdzob dang don dam pa'i sems rnam pa gnyis zung 'brel du bskyed pa la ni thabs de gnyis ka tshang zhing gzhan rnams kyang don gyis der 'dus pas thabs mkhas kyi mchog gcig chog yin no/ /

Skill in not interrupting the path refers to not interrupting the lineage or family line of the tathāgatas, the path that accomplishes the nondwelling nirvāṇa, combining wisdom and compassion—for with wisdom one does not dwell in the extreme of saṃsāra, and with compassion one does not dwell in the extreme of peace. Here, in developing the two aspects of bodhicitta (relative and ultimate) together, these two means being complete, the others are also implicitly included in it, so this is the supreme skillful means, sufficient on its own.

de ltar na thabs la mkhas pa rnam pa lnga po de ni byang chub sems dpa'i mos spyod dang 'phags pa'i sa bcu po kun la 'gro zhing / theg pa dman par mi 'jug cing theg chen gyi lam dang 'bras bu 'grub pa'i thabs de lta bu ni 'jig rten pa dang / nyan rang gi thabs dang mtshungs pa med pa ste thabs la mkhas pa de lta bu la brten nas byang chub sems dpa' de dag gis rang dang gzhan gyi don kun bde blag tu sgrub par byed pa yin no/ /

These five aspects of skill in means apply to bodhisattvas on all levels, from the level of earnest aspiration to the ten noble levels. Such skillful means, which are used not for following the lower vehicles but for accomplishing the path and result of the Great Vehicle, are without equal compared to the methods of mundane beings and listeners and solitary realizers, and it is by relying on such skill in means that bodhisattvas easily accomplish all their own and others’ goals.
gnyis pa gzungs ni/
b. THE POWER OF MEMORY THAT NEVER FORGETS TEACHINGS PREVIOUSLY RECEIVED

rnam smin thos la goms pa dang / / ting nge 'dzin gyi gzungs dag ni/ / chung ngu dang ni chen po ste/ / chen po de yang rnam pa gsum/ / blo ldan ma zhugs zhugs pa yang / / ma dag sa pa rnams kyi ni/ / chung ngu dang ni 'bring po ste/ / dag pa'i sa pa'i gzungs chen yin/ /

The powers of memory that come through maturation, Habitual listening, and concentration Are respectively lesser and greater, The greater itself being threefold. (XIX, 72) That of the wise who have not yet entered And that of those who have entered, albeit on impure levels, Are lesser and middling. The power of memory of those on pure levels is greater. (XIX, 73)
ces pas bstan te/

dran pa dang shes rab khyad par can gyi sgo nas gsung rab kyi tshig don ma lus pa chud mi za bar 'dzin pa dang / sngon ma thos pa'i chos dang don rnams kyang sems la snang ba dang / byang chub phyogs kyi chos rnams thob par 'gyur ba yin la/ gzungs thob pa de yang tshe rabs gzhan du dam pa'i chos dris pa dang / mchod pa dang / bcangs pa dang / bklag pa la sogs pa gzungs 'thob par 'gyur ba'i dge ba bsags pas chos gang lan gcig bshad pas tshig don rnams kun nas 'dzin par nus pa ni rnam par smin pa las byung ba'i gzungs dang / tshe 'dir dge ba'i bshes gnyen du ma las chos mang po thos pa la goms par byas pas/ sangs rgyas dang byang sems dang mkhan slob la sogs pas bshad pa'i chos kyi tshig don mi brjed par 'dzin pa ni thos pa la goms pa'i gzungs dang / gang gis stong nyid mtshan med smon med la sogs pa'i ting nge 'dzin gang rung goms pa'i dbang gis chos lan cig thos pas 'dzin nus pa ni/ ting nge 'dzin gyi gzungs zhes bya'o/ /

The power of memory consists of extraordinary memory and wisdom. By this means, bodhisattvas perfectly retain every single one of the words and meanings of the Buddha’s teachings. Even teachings and topics they have not previously heard manifest in their minds. And they gain all the qualities that lead to enlightenment. As to how the power of memory is gained, by asking questions on the sacred Dharma, making offerings, memorizing the teachings, reading them, and so on in other lives and thereby accumulating the merit for acquiring the power of memory, bodhisattvas are able to perfectly retain the words and meanings of any subject from a single explanation. This is the power of memory that comes through maturation. Through habituation to hearing a lot of teachings from numerous spiritual masters in the present life, they retain, without forgetting them, the words and meanings of the subjects explained by the buddhas, bodhisattvas, preceptors, and instructors; this is the power of memory through habituation to listening. And as a result of training in the appropriate concentration—that of emptiness, absence of attributes, or absence of expectancy, for example—they are able to retain any teaching they have heard once, which is the power of memory through concentration.

rnam smin dang thos pa las byung ba'i gzungs chung ngu dang ni ting nge 'dzin las byung ba'i gzungs ni chen po ste/ chen po de la yang rnam pa gsum yod pa ni blo ldan 'phags pa'i sa la ma zhugs mos spyod pa rnams kyis ting nge 'dzin bsgom pa las byung ba ni chung ngu dang / 'phags pa'i sa la zhugs pa yang ma dag sa bdun po la gnas pa rnams kyi ni 'bring po ste/ dag pa'i sa gsum la gnas pa'i gzungs ni chen po yin no/ / 'di dag ni gzungs kyi dbye ba'o/ /

The powers of memory that come through maturation and listening are termed lesser, while the power of memory that comes through concentration is greater. The greater power of memory itself is of three kinds: lesser, in the case of the power of memory that arises through the practice of concentration by bodhisattvas on the level of earnest aspiration, who have not entered the noble levels; middling, for those who have reached the noble levels but are still on the seven impure levels; and greater in the case of those dwelling on the three pure levels. All these are categories of the power of memory.
byang chub sems dpa' yang dang yang / / de la yang dag brten nas ni/ / rtag tu dam pa'i chos dag kyang / / rab tu ston cing 'dzin par byed/ /
Bodhisattvas who repeatedly Rely correctly on these Constantly teach others the sacred Dharma And retain it themselves. (XIX, 74)

gzungs kyi byed las ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis yang dang yang du rgyun mi 'chad par rnam smin la sogs pa'i gzungs gsum po de la yang dag par brten nas ni/ dus rtag tu dam pa'i chos dag kyang gzhan la rab tu ston cing rang gis de'i tshig dang don 'dzin par byed do/ /

As for the function of the power of memory, it is by relying correctly on the three powers of memory that come through maturation and so on, continuously, again and again, that bodhisattvas constantly teach others the sacred Dharma and retain its words and meanings themselves.
gsum pa smon lam ni brtan pa byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi smon lam ni/
c. PRAYERS OF ASPIRATION THAT ENABLE ONE TO ACQUIRE GOOD QUALITIES IN THE FUTURE
brtan pa rnams kyi smon lam ni/ / sems pa 'dun dang bcas pa ste/ / de ni ye shes kyis bskul ba/ / sa rnams kun la mnyam pa med/ /
The prayers of the steadfast Are accompanied by a yearning intention, Aroused by gnosis, And on all levels they have no equal. (XIX, 75)
zhes pa bstan te/

byang chub chen po sogs gang 'dod pa'i 'bras bu la sems shing de don du gnyer ba'i 'dun pa dang bcas pa ste/ de yang smon par bya ba'i yul legs par shes pa'i ye shes kyis bskul ba ste/ rang don du zag bcas kyi dngos po la smon pa lta bu ma yin pas ye shes khyad par can gyis sems pa bskul nas de yid du 'dod cing tshig tu'ang smon lam 'debs pa smon lam gyi rgyu'am ngo bo'o/ / skabs 'dir ye shes ni rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyi rgyu las byung ba'am/ yang na ye shes de 'thob pa'i phyir bsngos pa ni ye shes kyis bskul ba'o zhes 'grel chen du gsungs/ sa rnams kun la mnyam pa med ces pas smon lam gyi sa bstan te/ mos spyod dang sa bcu po kun gyi gnas skabs de dang de la byang chub sems dpa'i smon lam 'debs pa ni/ 'jig rten pa'i smon lam dang / nyan rang gi smon lam dang mnyam pa med pa yin no/ /

The prayers[24] of steadfast bodhisattvas are accompanied by the intention and earnest aspiration to achieve the great enlightenment and any other result they may wish for. The prayers are initiated by the gnosis that knows that the object that is aspired to is a proper one: it is not as if bodhisattvas pray for tainted things for their own benefit. So having aroused their intention with extraordinary gnosis, they make their prayers by mentally wishing them and also putting them into words. This is the cause or essence of their prayers of aspiration. The Great Commentary explains that the fact that they arise from gnosis as their cause (gnosis in this context being nonconceptual gnosis), or alternatively that they are dedicated to gaining that gnosis, is what is termed “aroused by gnosis.” “On all levels they have no equal” indicates the level of the aspirations. The prayers that bodhisattvas make at different times on all the levels—the level of earnest aspiration and the ten noble levels—are never equaled by the prayers of mundane beings, nor by the prayers of the listeners and solitary realizers.
de ni rgyu gyur shes bya ste/ / sems tsam las ni 'grub pa'i phyir/ / sems las mod la 'bras bu can/ / de ni ma 'ongs don 'grub byed/ /
They are to be known as the cause, Bringing accomplishment through their mere intent; They thus bear fruit the moment they are conceived And in the future are fulfilled. (XIX, 76)

smon lam gyi yon tan ni/ smon lam de ni rang dang gzhan gyi don gnyis 'grub pa'i rgyur gyur pa shes par bya ste/ tshe 'dir bdag dang gzhan gyi don gnyis 'grub pa dang / tshe rabs gzhan du bdag dang gzhan gyi don gnyis 'grub par byed do/ / de yang lus dang ngag gi sgo nas don de yi ched du las gzhan byas pa med kyang / smon pa'i sems tsam las ni ji ltar smon pa de bzhin 'grub pa'i phyir/ sems kyis ji ltar 'dun zhing smon pa las de'i mod mthong ba'i chos la 'bras bu 'byin pa can dang / smon lam de ni ma 'ongs pa'i don thams cad 'grub par byed pa yin no/ /

The virtues of bodhisattvas’ aspirations are as follows. Bodhisattvas’ aspirations are to be understood as being the causal factors that enable them to accomplish their own and others’ goals, both in this life and in other lives. Even if they do not do anything else for that purpose physically or verbally, the mere intent of whatever aspirations they make ensures their being accomplished accordingly. For that reason, the very instant they wish and pray for something in their minds, it starts to yield results in this present life, and in the future that prayer will accomplish all goals.
sna tshogs che dang byang chub par/ / sa rnams gong nas gong du ni/ / rnam dag byang chub sems dpa' yi/ / rang bzhin don rab sgrub byed yin/ /
They are diverse, great, and, on ever higher levels Until enlightenment, pure; Thus it is that bodhisattvas’ goals, Their own as well as others’, are fully accomplished. (XIX, 77)

smon lam gyi dbye ba ni/ mos pas spyod pa'i dus kyi byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi smon lam ni sna tshogs te/ de'i dus na chos kyi dbyings kun tu 'gro ba'i mtshan nyid ma rtogs shing / 'khor ba'i nyer 'tshe mthong nas de dang de zhi ba'i sgo dang / yon tan la dmigs nas de dang de lta bu bsgrub par 'dod pas bdag ma 'ongs pa na sems can gyi don du 'di dang 'di ltar gyur cig ces sogs smon lam 'debs pa dang tha dad pa mi mthun sna tshogs yod do/ / sa dang po la zhugs nas smon lam chen po bcu mngon par sgrub pa'i phyir smon lam rgya che ba dang / de nas brtsams te mthar thug gi byang chub chen po thob kyi bar du/ sa gnyis pa sogs sa lhag ma rnams la gong nas gong du ni smon lam rgya che zhing khyad par du 'phags pa dang rnam par dag par 'gyur ro/ / smon lam gyi byed las ni/ smon lam la brten nas byang chub sems dpa' yis rang dang gzhan gyi don gnyis sgrub par byed de/ bsod nams kyi stobs dang ldan pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i smon lam gyi mthus/ lus dpag tu med pa dang / 'od zer dpag tu med pa dang / rdzu 'phrul dpag tu med pas bdag dang gzhan gyi don sgrub pa ni tshig gis brjod par sla ba ma yin no zhes mdo las gsungs pas mtshon nas shes par bya'o/ /

The different categories of aspirations are described next. The prayers of bodhisattvas who are at the stage of earnest aspiration are of all different kinds. At that time they have not yet realized the nature of the universal expanse of reality: they see the dangers of saṃsāra and want a means for finding peace from them, and they consider good qualities and want to accomplish them. So the prayers they make—“In the future, may I become like this or that to benefit sentient beings,” and so on—are of all different kinds. Once they have reached the first level, because they are fully accomplishing the ten great aspirations,[25] their prayers are made on a vast scale. From then on until they attain ultimate great enlightenment, as they progress further through the second and other remaining levels, their aspirations become more and more vast and exalted and more and more pure. As for the function of their aspirations, it should be understood that it is on the basis of their prayers of aspiration that bodhisattvas’ goals, both their own and those of others, are achieved, as is indicated in the sūtras, which state that it is not easy to describe in words how the power of bodhisattvas’ aspirations, charged with the force of their merit, brings about their own and others’ benefit by means of infinite bodily manifestations, infinite rays of light, and infinite miraculous activities.
bzhi pa
d. AN EXPLANATION OF CONCENTRATION AND THE FOUR SUMMARIES OF THE DHARMA THAT MAKE THE PATH COMPLETELY PURE
['di] la yul can ting nge 'dzin gsum bshad pa dang / de'i shes par bya ba'i yul chos kyi sdom bzhi bshad pa gnyis las/

This section consists of (1) an explanation of the three kinds of concentration (the subject)[26] and (2) an explanation of the four summaries of the Dharma (the object to be understood through concentration).
dang po ni/
i. AN EXPLANATION OF THE THREE KINDS OF CONCENTRATION
ting 'dzin gsum gyi spyod yul ni/ / bdag med rnam pa gnyis po dang / / bdag tu 'dzin pa'i rten dang ni/ / de rtag nyer zhi yin zhes bya/ /
The domains of the three kinds of concentration are The two kinds of no-self, The support of belief in a self, And the permanent elimination of the latter. (XIX, 78)
zhes pas bstan te/

stong pa nyid kyi ting nge 'dzin dang / smon pa med pa'i ting nge 'dzin dang / mtshan ma med pa'i ting nge 'dzin gsum ni lam gyi gtso bo yin pas de bshad pa/ ting nge 'dzin gsum gyi spyod yul lam dmigs pa'i yul ni/ kun tu brtags pa'i gang zag dang chos la bdag med pa rnam pa gnyis po ni/ stong pa nyid kyi ting nge 'dzin gyi spyod yul yin pa dang / smon pa med pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi spyod yul ni/ gzhan dbang rten 'brel gyi snang ba bdag gnyis su 'dzin pa'i rten zag bcas nyer len gyi phung po lnga yin pa dang / mtshan ma med pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi spyod yul ni/ bdag gnyis su sgro 'dogs pa'i gzhi'am rten de nyid dus rtag tu rang gi ngo bos bdag gnyis dang bral ba mtshan ma thams cad nye bar zhi ba'i yongs su grub pa yin no/ /zhes shes par bya'o/ /

The three kinds of concentration—concentration related to emptiness, to absence of expectancy, and to absence of attributes—constitute the most important aspect of the path, so they will now be explained. The domains or objects of these three kinds of concentration are as follows. The two aspects of absence of an imputed self—in the individual and in phenomena—constitute the domain of the concentration related to emptiness. The domain of the concentration related to absence of expectancy comprises the five perpetuating aggregates, which are the tainted support for the interdependent appearances of the dependent reality that constitute the belief in the two kinds of self. The domain of the concentration related to absence of attributes is the fully present reality in which all attributes have been completely eliminated, the very basis or support for the exaggerated misconceptions of the two kinds of self having always been, by its very nature, devoid of the two kinds of self.
de ni gzung 'dzin ngo bo'i phyir/ / rnam pa gsum du shes par bya/ / rnam par mi rtog rgyab kyis phyogs/ / rab tu dga' dang ldan pa'o/ /
From the very nature of subjects and objects, You should know these concentrations are of three kinds. They take the form of nonconceptuality, Rejection, and perfect joy. (XIX, 79)
zhes pas bstan te/

de ltar ting 'dzin gsum po de ni gzung ba de gsum la dmigs nas de ltar 'dzin pa'i ting nge 'dzin gsum gyi ngo bo'i phyir na/ dmigs pa mi 'dra ba'i cha nas 'dzin pa ting nge 'dzin de yang de ltar rnam pa gsum du shes par bya'o/ / gnyis pa/ ting nge 'dzin gsum gyi rnam pa bstan pa ni/ stong pa nyid kyi ting nge 'dzin ni bdag gnyis su rnam par mi rtog pa'i rnam pa can no/ / smon pa med pa'i ting nge 'dzin ni nye bar len pa'i phung po lnga mi rtag cing sdug bsngal sna tshogs kyi gnas yin pas de la ma chags shing rgyab kyis phyogs nas mi smon pa'i rnam pa can no/ / mtshan ma med pa'i ting nge 'dzin ni mtshan ma dang sdug bsngal thams cad rab tu zhi ba'i dbyings don dam pa bden pa la yid ches shing rab tu dga' ba'i rnam pa dang ldan pa'o/ /

Because these three concentrations focus on the above three objects and are thus, by their very nature, their subjects, inasmuch as the objects are different, their subjects the concentrations are also to be understood as being of three kinds. Now to explain the aspects of the three kinds of concentrations, the concentration of emptiness takes the form of nonconceptuality—the absence of concepts of the two kinds of self. The concentration of absence of expectancy takes the form of nonattachment, rejection,[27] and absence of expectancy with regard to the five causal aggregates, for they are impermanent and are the seat of all kinds of suffering. The concentration of absence of attributes takes the form of intense joy and confidence in the ultimate truth, the expanse in which all attributes and sufferings have been completely extinguished.
yongs su shes dang spang ba dang / / mngon sum du ni bya ba'i phyir/ / stong nyid la sogs ting 'dzin rnams/ / don rnam gsum du yongs su bsgrags/ /
In order to completely know, To eliminate, and to realize, The concentrations such as emptiness Are declared to be three. (XIX, 80)

gsum du grangs nges pa ni/ zhes pas bstan te/ kun brtags pa'i bdag gnyis ye nas med par yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir stong nyid kyi ting 'dzin dang / bdag gnyis su 'dzin pa'i rten ma dag gzhan dbang spang bar bya ba'i phyir smon med kyi ting 'dzin dang / yongs grub 'gog bden mngon sum du ni bya ba'i phyir mtshan med kyi ting 'dzin te/ de ltar stong pa nyid la sogs pa'i ting nge 'dzin gsum po rnams ni/ don rnam pa gsum bshad ma thag pa de nyid kyi phyir du yongs su bsgrags pa yin no/ /

The reasons for there being three concentrations are as follows. In order to know completely that from the very beginning the two kinds of imputed self do not exist, there is the concentration of emptiness. In order to eliminate the dependent, impure support for the belief in the two kinds of self, there is the concentration of absence of expectancy. And in order to realize the fully present truth of cessation, there is the concentration of absence of attributes. Thus three kinds of concentration, beginning with the concentration of emptiness, are proclaimed for the three purposes just mentioned.
gnyis pa ni/
ii. AN EXPLANATION OF THE FOUR SUMMARIES OF THE DHARMA
sems can rnams la phan bzhed pas/ / ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyu nyid du/ / chos kyi sdom ni rnam pa bzhi/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams la bshad/ /
With the wish to benefit beings, The four summaries of the Dharma Were taught to bodhisattvas As the causal basis for concentration. (XIX, 81)
zhes pas bstan te/

ston pa mtshungs pa med pa sangs rgyas rnams kyis sems can rnams la mchog tu phan par bzhed pas stong pa nyid la sogs pa'i ting nge 'dzin gsum gyi rgyu nyid du chos kyi don ma lus pa'i mdo'am gnad 'dus pa'i sdom ni rnam pa bzhi 'di ltar/ 'dus byas thams cad mi rtag pa'o/ / zag pa dang bcas pa'i 'dus byas thams cad sdug bsngal ba'o/ / chos thams cad ni bdag med pa'o/ / mya ngan las 'das pa ni zhi ba'o/ / zhes su byang chub sems dpa' rnams la bshad pa yin no/ / de bzhi ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyu ji ltar yin na/ 'dus byas thams cad mi rtag pa dang / 'dus byas thams cad sdug bsngal ba'i sdom gnyis ni smon pa med pa'i ting nge 'dzin mngon du bya ba'i rgyu nyid du bshad de/ 'dus byas mi rtag pa dang sdug bsngal ba'i rang bzhin shes nas/ sog le'i so dang dug gi bza' ba 'dra ba'i 'dus byas rnams la chags shing smon par mi byed pas/ smon pa med pa'i ting nge 'dzin mngon du 'gyur ro/ / chos thams cad bdag med par bstan pa'i sdom ni stong pa nyid kyi ting nge 'dzin mngon du 'gyur ba'i rgyu ste/ chos thams cad la gang zag dang chos kyi bdag gnyis ni kun brtags pa tsam las don la ma grub par shes na stong nyid kyi ting 'dzin mngon du byed pa'i phyir ro/ / mya ngan 'das pa zhi ba'o/ / zhes pa'i mdo ni mtshan ma med pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyu ste/ gdod nas zhi ba'i yongs grub so so rang gis rig par bya ba nyid la mnyam par bzhag pas spros pa'i mtshan ma thams cad zhi ba'i mya ngan las 'das pa 'gog bden mngon du byed pa'i phyir ro/ /

Our incomparable teachers, the buddhas, wishing to bring the greatest possible benefit to sentient beings, taught the bodhisattvas four summaries or epitomes that include the whole meaning of the Dharma, these being the causal bases of the three concentrations on emptiness, and so on. They are as follows: “All that is compounded is impermanent. All that is tainted is suffering. All phenomena are devoid of self. Nirvāṇa is peace.” In what way are these four the causal bases of concentration? Two summaries—“All that is compounded is impermanent” and “All that is tainted is suffering”—are explained as the causal basis for realizing the concentration of absence of expectancy. Once one realizes that compounded phenomena are by nature impermanence and suffering, one has no attachment or expectancy with regard to compounded phenomena, which are like the teeth of a saw, or like poisoned food, and one thus realizes the concentration of absence of expectancy. The summary that teaches “All phenomena are devoid of self” is the causal basis for realizing the concentration of emptiness, for if one knows that the individual self and phenomenal self are merely imputed to all phenomena and do not in fact exist, one realizes the concentration of emptiness. The summary that says “Nirvāṇa is peace” is the causal basis of the concentration of absence of attributes, because by settling in evenness in the fully present reality, which is peace from the very beginning and can only be known personally, one realizes the truth of cessation, nirvāṇa in which all conceptual constructions have been extinguished.
brtan pa rnams kyi bzhi po de/ / med pa'i don dang rnam rtog don/ / kun tu rtog don kho na dang / / rnam rtog nye bar zhi ba'i don/ /
For the steadfast, these four signify Nonexistence, conceptualization, Simple imputation, And the complete extinction of concepts. (XIX, 82)

mi rtag pa dang sdug bsngal ba dang bdag med pa dang zhi ba zhes pa'i don bzhi po ci yin zhe na/ brtan pa byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi sdom bzhi po de yi don ni 'du byed rnams byung nas skad cig gnyis par mi gnas te rtag par med pa'i don ni mi rtag pa'i don te/ mi rtag pa'i skad dod a nit+ya zhes pa'i nit+ya ni rtag pa dang a dgag tshig yin pas rtag pa med pa'am mi rtag pa zhes bya'o/ / 'grel chen las skye zhing 'jig pa tsam byang chub sems dpas rtogs bya'i mi rtag pa ma yin te/ bdag gnyis su kun brtags pa ltar rtag tu med pa'o zhes gsungs/ byung nas 'jig pa lta bur snang yang / dam pa'i don du byung ba'ang med na 'jig pa ga la yod de med do/ / de ltar med pa la rtag par 'dzin pa'i gzhi yang med pas smon par bya ba med pa'ang yin te/ 'di ni don dam pa'i dbang du byas par mngon no/ / rnam par rtog pa tsam gyi don ni sdug bsngal ba ste/ med bzhin du gzung ba dang 'dzin par phyin ci log tu brtags pa de tsam du 'khor ba na sdug bsngal ba yin par shes pa ni sdug bsngal gyi don to/ /

What do these four terms—impermanence, suffering, no-self, and peace—mean? For steadfast bodhisattvas, these four summaries have the following significance. Once compounded phenomena have come into being, they do not remain for a second instant: they do not exist permanently, and this is what is meant by impermanence. The Sanskrit word for “impermanence” is anityatā: nityatā means “eternal,” and a is a negative particle, giving “not eternal” or “impermanent.” The Great Commentary states that it is not merely the coming into being and disintegration of phenomena that bodhisattvas should understand as impermanence but rather that things do not last forever in the way that the two kinds of self are imagined as doing. Although they appear to arise and then disintegrate, in ultimate truth, they do not even arise, so how can they disintegrate? They do not. Thus there is no basis at all for considering that what is not permanent is permanent, so neither is there anything to be expected. This is evident from the point of view of ultimate truth. Mere conceptualization refers to suffering. Bodhisattvas know that as long as one mistakenly imputes a subject and object that do not exist, one will suffer in saṃsāra, and this is the meaning of suffering.

bdag med pa'i don ni/ gzung 'dzin du snang ba'i gzhan dbang la/ gzung ba dang 'dzin pa gang zag dang chos su kun tu rtog pa tsam gyi don kho na las/ de ltar grub pa med pa'o/ / zhi ba'i don ni/ yongs grub kyi rang bzhin shes nas goms pa mthar thug pa'i dus na mtshan ma'i rnam par rtog pa thams cad nye bar zhi ba'i don yin no/ /

The meaning of absence of self is that within the dependent reality that appears as subject and object, apart from subject and object merely being imputed as individual and phenomenon, there is nothing that exists in that way. The meaning of peace is that once the nature of the fully present reality has been recognized, when one reaches the ultimate point of training in this, all concepts of attributes are completely extinguished.
da ni mi rtag pa dang bdag med pa'i don rigs pas bsgrub pa la/
We shall now establish, using reasoning, the meanings of (1) impermanence and (2) absence of self.
dang po
(1) ESTABLISHING IMPERMANENCE
'dus byas thams cad mi rtag par bsgrub pa la/ 'dus byas thams cad mi rtag par spyir bstan pa dang bye brag tu bshad pa gnyis kyi
The first of these, establishing that everything that is compounded is impermanent, is indicated in the next ten verses. It is divided into a general exposition and a detailed explanation.
dang po/
(a) GENERAL EXPOSITION

phyi dang nang gi 'dus byas rnams skad cig re re bzhin du mi rtag pa yin par dam bcas nas/ mi rung ba'i phyir dang / rgyu las skyes phyir sogs/ phyir sgras bcad pa ltar dang / dag pa'i phyir dang sems can gyi rjes su 'jug pa'i phyir zhes pa'i bar gyi gtan tshigs bcu bzhi bkod pa yin no/ /
From the basic premise that all outer and inner compounded phenomena are impermanent from one moment to the next, there are fourteen arguments in the next two verses that establish it.
mi rung rgyu las skye phyir dang / / 'gal phyir rang nyid mi gnas phyir/ / med phyir mtshan nyid nges phyir dang / / rjes su 'jug phyir 'gag pa'i phyir/ /

Impermanence is established because of an impossibility, because things arise from causes, Because of a contradiction, because things do not last by themselves, Because of an absence, because the nature of things has been determined, Because of their succession, and because of cessation; (XIX, 83)
zhes pas bstan te/

de yang mi rung zhes par mi rung ba'i phyir zhes pa'i don te ci zhig ma rung zhe na 'dus byas rnams ni rgyu rkyen las skyes nas ji srid rgyun 'gag par ma gyur pa de srid du chu bo'i rgyun 'jug pa bzhin skad cig snga ma 'gags shing phyi ma skye ba bar ma chad par rgyun gyis 'byung ba yin gyi skad cig ma min na dngos po de skyes nas yun ring thung sna tshogs su 'byung ba'i rgyun mi rigs pa'am mi rung ba'i phyir ro/ /

(1) In saying, “because of an impossibility,” what is it that is impossible? All compounded things arise from causes and conditions, and their ceasing in the previous instant and arising in the next instant occurs continuously and uninterruptedly, just as a river continues to flow for as long as the flow is not obstructed. But if they were not momentary, it would be illogical or impossible for those things, once having arisen, to continue to occur for variously greater or shorter lengths of time.

gzhan dag na re mi rung ba ma yin te dngos po rnams rgyu rkyen tshogs pa'i dbang gis skad cig ma dang por skyes nas de ma thag tu mi 'gag par/ zhag dang zla ba lo la sogs pa ji srid 'jig pa'i rkyen dang ma 'phrad pa de'i bar du de ltar gnas so zer na/ de ltar na skad cig dang po snang du chug kyang gnyis pa phan chad la rgyu med pa'i phyir skad cig dang po byung ba'i de ma thag tu rgyun 'byung ba med par 'gag par 'gyur te/ skad cig gnyis pa sogs su gnas pa'i rgyu dang / mthar 'gag pa'i rgyu yang brjod dgos kyi skad cig dang po bskyed pa'i rgyu des skad cig ma ma yin pa'i dngos po lo dang zhag dang zla ba sogs su gnas pa de 'dra ba skyed mi nus te/ rgyu 'bras gnyis ka skad cig ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Our opponents might say,[28] “It is not impossible. Because of the coming together of causes and conditions, things are produced in the first instant and then do not cease immediately but continue for as long as they do not encounter the condition for their disintegration, which may be for days or months or years.” If that were the case, although we can see the thing in the first instant, there is no causal factor to give rise to a second and subsequent instants, and therefore the thing would not continue but would cease to exist immediately after the first instant had occurred. You would have to tell us what are the causes that make it persist for a second instant and so on, and what is the cause for it finally ceasing. In fact the cause that has produced the first instant cannot give rise to a nonmomentary entity that continues to exist for days and months like that, because both cause and result are momentary.

dpe ji ltar na chu bo'i rgyun 'bab pa ni chu gsar pa gsar pa 'bab pa rgyun ma chad pa yin gyi/ gsar pa rgyun chad na rgyun 'chad par 'gyur ba dang / mar me'i me lce'i rgyun yang ras dang snum gyi rgyu las snyam ma zad kyi bar du snum me lcer gyur te gsar pa gsar pa rgyun ma chad par 'byung ba yin gyi rgyu snum zad pas 'bras bu me lce yang rgyun 'chad kyi me lce skad cig dang po de nyid rgyu gzhan snum med par yun cig tu gnas pa ma yin pa bzhin no/ /

Let us take the example of a flowing river. Its flow is constantly renewed without being interrupted. But if one were to block the water upstream, the flow would be cut. The flame of a lamp too burns continuously: from the causal factors of the cotton wick and the oil, the oil is transformed into a flame until the lamp runs out of oil. The flame is continuously renewed, but when the causal oil is exhausted, the resultant flame too ceases to continue. However, the flame that was there in that first instant does not last for a moment without there being more oil as the causal factor.

kha cig gis skad cig gi 'jig pa ma yin na rgyun mthar yang 'jig pa mi rung ba'i phyir zhes 'bru mnan pa ni dang po mi 'jig mthar mi 'gyur zhes pa dang 'dra bas don la mi 'gal yang / 'grel pas gong ltar bshad pa bzhin gzung dgos so/ / yang gzhan dag na re skyes nas ji srid cig tu gnas pa la rgyu gzhan mi dgos te skad cig dang po bskyed pa'i rgyu des de ltar gnas par 'phangs so snyam na ma yin te/ skad cig dang po bskyed pa'i rgyu des de bskyed nas 'gags zin pa'i phyir skad cig du mar gnas pa 'phen mi srid de skad cig ma ma yin pa'i dngos po mi srid pa'i phyir mo gsham gyi bu 'phangs zer ba dang 'dra'o/ / skad cig min pa'i dngos po rgyus bskyed na rtag pa'i dngos po yang skye rigs na de ni shin tu mi rigs shing mi rung ba'i phyir ro/ /

Some authorities pad this out by saying that if a thing were not destroyed by momentariness, it would be impossible for it to ever disintegrate (at the end of its continuity), which comes to the same thing as saying that something that does not disintegrate in the beginning will not do so at the end. Although this is not incorrect, it is better to understand this point according to the above explanation from the commentary. Again, our opponents might think that for a thing to continue as long as it does, no other cause is necessary; the cause that produced its first instant propels it into persisting like that. But this is not the case. Once the cause that produces the first instant has produced it, that cause has ceased, and for that reason it is impossible for it to drive the thing’s persisting for a greater number of instants. A thing that is not momentary is impossible: one might as well speak of the son of a barren woman being born. If a nonmomentary thing could be produced by a cause, it would also follow that a permanent thing could arise, which is utterly illogical and impossible.

skad cig dang po rgyus bskyed nas ji srid cig tu gnas nas de nas rang nyid 'jig pa la yang rgyu gzhan med de dang po rgyu de kho nas de ltar byas so snyam pa yang de dang 'dra ste/ ji srid cig tu gnas pa dang mthar 'jig pa la rgyu gzhan med par 'dod pa de lta na/ skad cig dang po yang rgyu med du byung ngo zhes cis mi 'dod/ skad cig dang po rgyu med par 'byung ba mngon sum tshad ma dang 'gal bas khas mi len na/

The same holds for those who think that the first instant of a thing is created by a cause and that after lasting for as long as it does the thing then disintegrates by itself without any other cause—that it is all done by just the initial cause. If they claim that there are no other causes for the thing enduring as long as it does and finally disintegrating, in that case why do they not claim that there is no cause for the first instant either? That a first instant could occur without a cause contradicts direct valid cognition, so we cannot accept their assertions, and this brings us to the next argument.

rgyu las skye phyir dang zhes pa ni de ltar skyes nas de'i rgyun gnas pa 'di yang snga ma snga ma'i skad cig gi rgyu las skye ba nyid du grub pa'i phyir dang / de las gzhan pa'i rgyu ma dmigs pa'i phyir ro/ / gzhan dag na re dngos po rnams skye bar byed pa'i rgyu des bskyed nas skyes zin pa de nyid slar yang nas yang du skye mi dgos par skyes pa de'i ngang tshul du yun ji srid gcig tu gnas pa yin gyi de'i bar du skad cig gzhan dang gzhan skye ba dang 'jig pa med la rgyu gzhan yang mi dgos so zhe na/

(2) “Because things arise from causes.” We have established that having been produced in that way,[29] a thing’s continuity too is produced from the causes of the succeeding instants, and no other causes than those can be observed. Our opponents might say that once the cause that makes things arise has produced them, they have finished arising, and they do not need to arise again and again but remain in that situation of having arisen for as long as they last; and until then, there is no succession of other instants of creation and disintegration, and no need for other causes to bring them about.

de mi 'thad pa'i 'gal ba brjod pa ni/ dngos po rnams skyes nas de ma thag tu mi 'jig par phyis bshig nas 'jig pa yin na/ dngos po de nyid skad cig gis mi 'jig par gnas pa zhig phyis 'jig pa yin nam/ skad cig gis 'jig pa zhig phyis zhig nas 'gags pa gang yin/ dang po dngos po skad cig gis mi 'jig par gnas pa yin na/ gnas pa'i rang bzhin la 'jig pa'i rang bzhin med pas gnas pa'i dngos po de phyis kyang mi 'jig par 'gyur te rtag tu gnas par 'gyur ro/ / 'jig pa'i rang bzhin can yin na 'jig pa'i rang bzhin la rtag pa dang yun du gnas pa'i rang bzhin med pas skad cig dang po nas 'jig par 'gyur gyi yun gcig tu mi 'gags par gnas pa mi srid pas 'gal lo/ / gzhan yang dngos po skyes nas yun ji tsam par gnas nas gzod 'gag par 'gyur ba yin na/ 'gag pa'i rgyu gang yin brjod dgos so/ / skyed pa'i rgyu gang yin pa de nyid do zhe na 'gal te/ skye ba ni dngos po yod pa dang / 'gag pa dngos po med pa rgyu gcig gis skyed na rgyu des dngos po yod par byed pa dang med par byed pa'i 'gal ba gnyis byed par mi rigs te/ snang ba dang / mun pa dang / grang ba dro ba gnyis rgyu gcig gis byed mi srid pa bzhin no/ /

Let us look at the illogicality and contradiction in this. If things do not disintegrate immediately after arising but are destroyed at a later time, is it that the things are not destroyed by momentariness but persist and are then destroyed later? Or is it that they are destroyed by momentariness and then later cease? To answer the first question, if a thing persists without being destroyed by momentariness, it must be persistent by nature and it cannot be perishable by nature, so that thing will not disintegrate even later—it will last forever. While if it is something that is perishable by nature, then in its perishable nature there cannot be a permanent or long-lasting nature, so the thing will disintegrate from the very first instant and it will be impossible for it to last any length of time without ceasing—hence the contradiction. Furthermore, if a thing were to come into being, endure for a while, and then finally cease, you would have to tell us what the cause for its ceasing would be. If you say that it is the cause that created the thing, you are contradicting yourself: if creation, whereby a thing exists, and cessation, whereby it no longer exists, are brought about by one and the same cause, there is a contradiction between that cause making the thing exist and making it not exist—it cannot possibly do both, just as it is impossible for a single cause to produce both light and darkness, or cold and warmth.

'gal phyir zhes pa ni/ dngos po rnams rang skyes nas skad cig gnyis par mi sdod par 'jig pa'i ngang tshul can min par skyes nas ji srid cig tu rtag pa gnas na lung dang rigs pa gnyis dang 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ / ji ltar 'gal na bcom ldan 'das kyi bka' lung las/ 'du byed dag ni rgyu rkyen las skye ba'i sgyu ma lta bu dang / skye zhing 'gag pa'i chos can yin pa'i 'jig pa dang / skyes nas skad cig ma gcig las ring du mi gnas pas re zhig pa dang / skyes ma thag tu 'jig pas yun thung ngur gnas pa zhes gsungs pa dang 'gal lo/ / rigs pa yang rnal 'byor mngon sum dang 'gal ba ni/ rnal 'byor pa 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi sgom zhing yid la byed pa rnams kyis 'du byed thams cad skad cig gis skye ba dang 'gag pa'i mtshan nyid can du mthong ste skyo ba skye zhing chags pa dang bral nas grol zhing mya ngan las 'das pa 'thob par 'gyur gyi/ de ltar mthong na skyo zhing chags bral dang rnam grol nyid du mi 'gyur te/ dper na 'jig rten phal pa rnams kyis mi rnams 'chi ba'i dus su 'gag pa dang mi rtag pa shes nas skyo ba skye yang de'i bar du skyo ba mi skye bar gnas par 'du shes bskyed nas su yang 'du byed thams cad la skyo bas chags bral du ma gyur pa bzhin no/ /

(3) “Because of a contradiction.” If things were produced by themselves and, instead of being perishable by nature and not remaining for a second instant, they were to come into being and then last forever, they would contradict both scriptural authority and reason. Where is the contradiction? Such a thesis would contradict Lord Buddha’s own words, for he said, “Compounded phenomena are like magical illusions, which come into being through causes and conditions. Being born, it is their nature to cease, and therefore they disintegrate. Having arisen, they do not remain longer than a single instant, and they are therefore temporary. They disintegrate as soon as they are produced, and so they last a very short time.” And from the point of view of reason, it would contradict the direct experience of practitioners. Practitioners who meditate on or keep in mind the four noble truths see that all compounded phenomena are characterized by arising and ceasing through momentariness; disenchantment grows in them, and they become free from attachment and attain liberation and nirvāṇa. But if they were to see things as lasting forever, they would not become disenchanted, nor would they attain freedom from attachment or perfect liberation. They would be like ordinary people: even if they recognize cessation and impermanence when people are dying and they then feel sad, up until that point they never feel disenchanted but think they will go on living. That way, no one would ever become disenchanted with compounded phenomena and be free of attachment.

rang nyid mi gnas phyir zhes pa rjes su dpag pas 'gal ba brjod pa ni/ 'du byed rnams skyes ma thag tu mi 'jig pa ji srid cig tu gnas pa yin na/ 'du byed rnams rang nyid kyi mthus gnas sam/ rgyu rkyen gzhan zhig gi mthus gnas pa gang yin/ dang po ltar na rtag tu gnas pa rigs na yang / dus ji srid du mthar phyin par gnas nus pa'i 'du byed gcig kyang med de/ rang gi ngo bos skad cig gis 'jig pa'i ngang tshul can yin pa dang / rgyun yang rkyen dang phrad na 'jig pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ / rgyu rkyen gzhan gyis gnas par byed pa'i rgyu ni 'di yin no zhes rgyu gzhan tshad mas ma dmigs pa'i phyir/ rang nyid grub nas skad cig gnyis par mi gnas pa'i phyir ro/ /

(4) “Because things do not last by themselves” refers to a contradiction by inference. If compounded phenomena were not to disintegrate as soon as they came into being and were to last for as long as they do, would it be that they last because of something intrinsic to themselves, or that they endure because of other, extrinsic causes and conditions? If the first case were true, they would have to last forever, but there are no compounded phenomena that can last until the very end of time, because it is their very nature to be destroyed by momentariness; even their continuity is destroyed when they encounter the relevant conditions.[30] As for their enduring because of other causes and conditions, we cannot, with valid cognition, observe any other causes and say, “The cause is this.” Once a thing has been produced, it does not last for a second instant.

med phyir zhes pa ni/ gzhan dag na re dngos po rnams ji srid cig tu gnas pa la rgyu gzhan mi dgos kyi rang nyid skyes zin pa de nyid ji srid 'jig pa'i rgyu ma phrad pa de srid du gnas nas gzod 'jig rgyu phrad na 'jig ste/ dper na lcags sngon po dang tsha ba med par ji srid cig tu gnas nas gzod me dang nam phrad na sngon po dang bsil ba 'gags nas dmar po dang tsha ba skye ba dang / rdza yi bum pa tho ba dang ma phrad pa'i bar du gnas nas tho ba phrad pa'i tshe bum pa zhig nas gyo mor 'gyur ba zhig yin no zer na/ de mi rigs te dngos po rnams ngang gis 'jig pa yin gyi 'jig pa'i rgyu gzhan med pa'i phyir ro/ /

(5) “Because of an absence.”[31] Our opponents say, “Things do not need another cause for them to remain for as long as they do. Once they themselves have come into being, as long as they do not encounter the cause for their disintegrating, they persist; and subsequently, when they encounter a cause for their disintegrating, they disintegrate. Take the case of an iron, which stays blue and without heat for a while; then, when it is brought into contact with fire, it ceases to be blue and cool and becomes red and hot.[32] And an earthenware pot, for example, persists until it encounters a hammer; then, when it comes into contact with a hammer, the pot is smashed to pieces.” This is not correct, because things disintegrate by themselves, and there are no other causes for their disintegration.

ji ltar med na dper na rdo gnam du 'phang ba'i tshe gnam du 'phen pa'i rgyu lag pa sogs yod kyi/ sa la ltung bar byed pa'i rgyu gzhan mi dgos te rang nyid ngang gis lhung bar byed pa bzhin du/ dngos po rnams rang rang gi skyed rgyus bskyed ma thag tu ngang gis 'jig pa la rgyu gzhan mi dgos te/ lcags kyi sngon po dang bum pa'i dbyibs ni/ me dang tho ba dang ma phrad pa'i snga rol na yang skad cig re rer ngang gis 'jig pa yin pas/ de me dang tho bas bshig pa ma yin la/ lcags dang bum pa'i skad cig tha mas nyer len gyi rgyu byas me dang tho bas lhan cig byed rkyen byas nas dmar po dang gyo mo'i gnas skabs bskyed pa na da gzod lcags kyi dmar po dang bum pa bshig go zhes bzung nas de'i bar du rtag pa sems pa ni rigs 'dra bar ma chad pa'i rgyun la 'khrul pa yin gyi yang dag pa ma yin te/

How? For example, when a stone is thrown into the air, there is a cause (one’s hand, for example) that projects it into the air, but it does not need another cause to make it fall to the ground—it falls of its own accord. Similarly, as soon as things are brought into being by the respective causes that create them, they disintegrate of their own accord: they do not need another cause for that. The iron’s blueness and the pot’s shape disintegrate naturally from one instant to the next even before they come in contact with the fire and the hammer, so it is not that the fire and hammer destroy them. Rather, the final instants of the iron and the pot constitute the direct cause of their destruction, and the fire and hammer constitute the cooperating condition, and these produce the situation of their redness and fragments, at which point we consider that the iron is red and the pot has been smashed. Until then, our impression that the iron and pot are lasting is an illusion of homogeneity and continuity, but it is not correct.

lcags dang bum pa la ri mo bris na de 'jig rgyu ma yin par khyod 'dod mod/ ri mo ma bris pa'i lcags dang bum pa'i gnas skabs 'gags nas ri mo bris pa'i gnas skabs thob pa yang / lcags dang bum pa mi rtag pa mtshan nyid du mkhas pa rnams kyis shes so/ / des na rgyu mi 'dra ba'i khyad par las dngos po rnams rnam pa mi 'dra bar sna tshogs su 'gyur la/ rgyu 'dra ba'i khyad par las rigs 'dra bar ma chad du skye ba yin yang / de gnyis ka skad cig ma yin pa la ni khyad par cung zad med de/ skad cig ma min pa'i dngos po la gnas skabs mi 'dra ba'i khyad par nam yang dmigs pa mi srid do/ /

You might argue that a figure painted on the iron or pot is not a cause for its disintegration. But in fact one state (the unpainted iron or pot) has ceased and another state (the painted iron or pot) has been obtained. The iron and the pot are by nature impermanent, as the wise know. That being so, from the fact of their causes being different, things take on a variety of different aspects, while from the fact of the causes being the same, they arise as a homogeneous, unbroken continuum. However, both of these situations are momentary: there is not the slightest difference between them. In a nonmomentary thing it would be impossible to ever see different, dissimilar states.

de bzhin mes chu bskol nas zad pa dang / bum pa gyo mor byas nas gtun du 'thag pa sogs 'jig rgyur 'dod pa thams cad legs par brtags na dngos po skad cig ma dang / rkyen gzhan phrad pas gnas skabs mi 'dra ba de ltar gyur pa las dngos po skad cig ma ma yin pa rgyu gzhan gyis bshig pa cung zad med de/ rdza mkhan gyi lag pa dang dbyig gu sogs kyis 'jim pa las bum pa skyed par byed pa dang 'dra'o/ / bum pa skyes pa'i dus na 'jim pa'i gnas skabs rang kha ma zhig pa dang / lag pa sogs kyis 'du byed kyang zhig nas 'gag pa bzhin no/ /

Similarly, it might be asserted that boiling water over a fire and evaporating it, smashing a pot and reducing it to powder, and other such cases constitute the causes for their destruction. If we examine such assertions properly, we will see that things are changed into different states like that by momentariness and contact with other conditions, but otherwise, there is absolutely nothing that is destroyed by any cause other than momentariness. We can compare this to the creation of a pot from clay by means of the potter’s hands, tools, and so on.[33] When the pot is created, the clay’s own condition has not been destroyed, while the fashioning of the pot by the hand and so forth has “disintegrated” and ceases to be.

gzhan yang 'jig rgyus 'jig par bya ba'i dngos po de rang gi ngo bo mi 'jig pa zhig gam/ 'jig pa gang yin/ mi 'jig na ni 'jig rgyus 'jig mi nus la/ rang 'jig na 'jig rgyus 'jig mi dgos so/ / gzhan yang 'jig rgyus dngos po gang de 'jig pa'i dus na/ dngos po de nyid byas sam/ de las gzhan zhig byas/ dngos po de nyid byas na skyed par byas kyi 'jig par ma byas la/ dngos po de las gzhan zhig byas na/ dngos po de la ci yang ma byas pas/ snam bu byas pas ka ba 'jig pa ma yin pa bzhin no/ /

Furthermore, with regard to anything that is to be destroyed by a destructive cause, is it that thing’s own nature to disintegrate or not? If its nature is not to disintegrate, the destructive cause could never make it disintegrate. And if its nature is to disintegrate, then it would not need a destructive cause to make it disintegrate. Again, when the destructive cause is bringing about a thing’s disintegration, is it making the thing itself or something else? If it is making the thing itself, then it is creating and not destroying. And if it is making something other than the thing, it is not affecting the thing in any way, just as making woolen cloth does not destroy a pillar.

mtshan nyid nges pa'i phyir zhes pa ni/ 'dus byas thams cad kyi mtshan nyid ni mi rtag par gcig tu nges kyi 'dus byas kha cig rtag pa dang / kha cig mi rtag pa dang / kha cig rtag mi rtag gnyis ka dang / kha cig rtag mi rtag gnyis ka ma yin pa lta bu'i khyad par yod pa ma yin pas/ bcom ldan 'das kyis kyang 'dus byas thams cad ni mi rtag pa'o zhes mgo gcig tu lung bstan pa yin no/ / gal te dngos po rnams re zhig rtag la de nas mi rtag na rtag mi rtag gnyis kar 'gyur na mi srid pas 'dus byas thams cad skad cig gis 'jig pa'i ngang tshul can las mi 'da' ste me'i rang bzhin tsha ba bzhin no/ /

(6) “Because the nature of things has been determined.” The nature of all compounded phenomena has been unequivocally determined as impermanent. It is not as if there are different possibilities—that some compounded phenomena, for example, are permanent and some are impermanent, while some are both permanent and impermanent, and others are neither permanent nor impermanent. And Lord Buddha was unequivocal in affirming that all compounded phenomena are impermanent. If things were to be permanent for a while and then impermanent, they would be both permanent and impermanent, and that is impossible, so all compounded phenomena cannot be anything other than naturally subject to destruction by momentariness—just as it is the nature of fire to be hot.

rjes su 'jug phyir zhes pa ni/ gzhan dag na re dngos po thams cad skad cig gis mi rtag pas dngos po gsar pa gzhan dang gzhan yin na sngar mthong ba'i dngos po dag phyis mthong ba'i tshe 'di ni sngar gyis mthong ba de yin no snyam du ngo shes pa ltar rung ste des na sngar mthong ba'i dngos po ma zhig bar gnas pa yin zer ba la/ de ni khyod nyid snga phyi'i dngos po gcig ma yin yang / 'dra ba bar ma chad du rjes su 'jug pa'i phyir gcig tu 'khrul bar zad de/ mig 'phrul can gyi rde'u du ma myur bar nam mkha' la dor zhing slar yang lag par sdud pa rgyun ma chad par byas pa la rje'u gcig yang yang 'phangs shing sdud do snyam du sems pa dang / chu bo rnams skad cig re rer snga ma rnams gzhan du 'gro zhing gsar pa rnams shul du 'jug pa rgyun mi 'chad pa yin yang / 'dra ba'i sgo nas chu bo 'di la bdag gis sngar yang lan mang brgal lo/ / da yang brgal lo snyam du sems shing / gzod kyang brgal dgos so snyam du sems pa bzhin no/ /

(7) “Because of their succession.” Our opponents might argue, “If all things are impermanent and momentary and therefore a thing is a new, different thing from one moment to the next, how is it that later, when one sees the things one saw earlier, one recognizes them and says, ‘This is what I saw before’? Surely, the thing one saw earlier did not disintegrate but has persisted.” Your earlier and later things are not the same thing but similar things that succeed each other in an unbroken sequence. Their being one and the same thing is simply an illusion. It is like when an illusionist throws several balls rapidly into the air and catches them again continuously, and one thinks that he is repeatedly throwing and catching the same ball. A river too is an unceasing flow of preceding instances of water going by followed by new instances of water; yet, because of their similarity, we think, “I have already crossed this river many times, and now I am crossing it again” and “Later I will again have to cross it.”

'gag pa'i phyir zhes pa ni/ gal te sngar mthong ba dang phyis mthong ba dag mngon sum gyi spyod yul du mi 'dra ba ma dmigs bzhin du snga phyi gcig ma yin no zhes smra ba ji ltar rigs snyam na/ dngos po'i chos nyid kyis snga ma snga ma'i skad cig rnams 'gag pa'i phyir gcig ma yin te/ gal te skad cig dang po mi 'gag par de bzhin du gnas pa yin na/ phyis kyang 'gag par mi 'gyur te/ sngar mthong ba'i dngos po skad cig ma de da lta yang gnas pa de bzhin phyis kyang gnas par 'gyur te skad cig ma ma yin pa'i dngos po yin pa nam yang bye brag med pa'i phyir ro/ /

(8) “Because of cessation.” According to our direct experience, we do not think that the first thing we saw and the one we see later are different, and we might ask, “How can you say that the former and the latter are not the same?” It is the nature of things that every instant ceases before the next, so for that reason they are not the same. If the thing that was there in the first instant did not cease but remained as it was, it could never cease later. The thing one saw earlier would still be there in the present instant, and it would likewise still be there in the subsequent instants: the thing would be a nonmomentary thing, and it could never have different aspects.
yongs su 'gyur ba dmigs phyir dang / / de rgyu nyid dang 'bras bu'i phyir/ / zin pa'i phyir dang bdag po'i phyir/ / dge dang sems can rjes 'jug phyir/ /
Because of visible transformation, Because of cause and result, Because of being seized, because of ownership, And because of following purity and beings. (XIX, 84)

yongs su 'gyur ba dmigs phyir dang zhes pa/ gal te dngos po rnams skad cig gis ma yin par rang gi ngo bo dus re zhig bar du mi 'gyur na skad cig dang po'i dus dang mi 'dra ba'i yongs su 'gyur ba'i khyad par dmigs mi srid na yang / nang gi dngos po sems can gyi lus rnams ni/ byis pa dang gzhon nu dang lang tsho dang dar la bab dang rgas shing 'khogs pa skra dkar gnyer ma dang bcas pa'i bar gyi yongs su 'gyur bar dmigs pa dang / phyi'i dngos po gnas dang yo byad rnams kyang so ma dang rnying pa dang / snga phyi'i dus kyi khyad par mi 'dra bas yongs su 'gyur bar dmigs pa'i phyir/ dang po skyes pa'i skad cig dang po nas brtsams te rim pas 'gyur ba yin par nges te/ dang po'i skad cig las ma 'gyur na skad cig phyi ma'i gnas skabs su 'gyur ba mi srid na yang yongs su 'gyur ba dngos su dmigs pa'i phyir skad cig gis 'gyur bar nges te/ byis pa gzhon nu zhig gi lus la mig gtad nas ma yengs bar lta mkhan zhig yod pa lta na yang / de'i lus skad cig dang zhag gis je rgas su 'gyur ba cha mi phyed kyang / nam zhig skra dkar ba'i bar du 'gyur ba'i 'gyur ba rags pa mthong ba la dpags nas/ lo zla ba dang zla ba zhag dang*/ zhag dus tshod dang / dus tshod skad cig gis de ltar rim par 'gyur ba yin gyi/ res gcig mi 'gyur bar bsdad nas thang gcig na de ltar 'gyur ba ma yin pa ltar phyi'i dngos po rnams kyang de ltar skad cig gi cha phra ba'i sgo nas 'gyur ba yin no/ / de dper na 'o ma zhor 'gyur ba na skad cig re re bzhin du rim pas ji skad nga ro skyur bar 'gyur gyi/ skad cig ma ma yin pa'i 'gyur ba gzhan mi dmigs pa bzhin no/ / skad cig phra bas 'gyur ba ma dmigs nas rgyun 'dra ba tsam la dngos po gcig tu zhen nas gcig tu 'khrul pas sngar gyi de 'di yin no zhes 'jig rten rnams dngos po rtag par 'khrul ba yin no/ /

(9) “Because of visible transformation.” If things were not momentary and their nature did not change over time, one would never see any change from how they were in the beginning. And yet we do notice that, on the inner level, people’s bodies change from childhood to youth, through early adulthood and the prime of life to old age, when they become decrepit, white-haired, and wrinkled. And on the outer level too we notice places changing, articles changing from fresh to old, and the time changing from before to after. Beginning from the first instant when things first come into being, they definitely gradually change. If they did not change from the first instant onward, it would be impossible for them to change in subsequent instants. But because we actually see them transforming, we can be sure that they are changing from moment to moment. Even if people who look at the body of a young child and watch undistractedly cannot distinguish the aging of its body from moment to moment and day to day, they can infer it in seeing the gross changes that have taken place when the “child” becomes white-haired. As years and months go by, months and days, days and hours, hours and minutes, the child is gradually changing. But it is not that it remains without changing for a while and then becomes white-haired all of a sudden. The same is true for external things, which also change like that, subtly with every instant. For example, when milk turns into yogurt, with each instant it gradually becomes sourer—we never see any other way of changing that is not from moment to moment. Ordinary people, who fail to notice subtle, moment-to-moment change and take what is merely the same continuum to be a single thing, mistake it as one and the same thing. Thinking, “This is the thing I saw before,” they are deluded into thinking that things are permanent.

de rgyu nyid dang 'bras bu'i phyir zhes pa ni/ rtag smra ba dag na re bdag cag gis ji ltar brtags kyang phra ba'i 'gyur ba blos mngon sum du gcod par mi nus la dngos po de nyid ni 'di'o zhes gcod par nus pas skad cig ma'i 'gyur ba 'di la ji ltar yid ches par bya zhe na/ dngos po de dag rgyu las skyes pa'i 'bras bu yin pa'i phyir/ snga ma snga ma rgyu nyid dang phyi ma phyi ma 'bras bu yin pa'i phyir/ skad cig mar 'grub ste/ rgyu skad cig ma yin pas 'bras bu skad cig ma yin pa dang / 'bras bu skad cig ma yin pas de'i rgyu yang skad cig mar 'grub ste/ rgyu rtag pas 'bras bu mi skyed de nam mkha' las me tog dang bum pa sogs mi 'byung ba bzhin no/ / 'bras bu rtag pa ni gang gis kyang bskyed bya min te nam mkha' bzhin no/ / des na rgyu dang 'bras bur gyur pa ni skad cig ma'i rang bzhin yin gyi skad cig ma min pa la 'gyur ba med pas rgyu 'bras su mi rung ngo / /

(10) “Because of cause and result.” The eternalists say, “However much we examine things, we cannot directly distinguish subtle change, while we can decide, ‘That thing is this,’ so how can we believe in momentary change?” The fact that those things are results that have arisen from causes, and the fact that causes come before and results come after, prove that those things are momentary. Since the cause is momentary, the result is momentary, and since the result is momentary, its cause too must be momentary. Permanent causes cannot give rise to results, just as flowers and pots cannot appear from space. Permanent results cannot be the products of anything, as is the case with space. So causes and results are by nature momentary. If they were nonmomentary, nothing would change, so cause and result would be impossible.

de ltar spyir bstan nas bye brag tu dpyad na mig shes la sogs pa rnam par shes pa thams cad ni rkyen bzhi las skye ba'i phyir skad cig gis mgyogs par 'byung ba sangs rgyas pa dang mu stegs pa tshun chad la grags pa yin te blo rtag pa mi 'gyur ba yod par mi 'dod do/ / rnam par shes pa de'i rgyu ni dbang po dang yul gzugs sogs yin te/ mdo las mig dang gzugs la brten nas mig gi rnam par shes pa skye ba sogs su gsungs so/ / de bas na 'du byed rnams kyi 'bras bu sems skad cig mar grub pas na de skyed par byed pa'i rgyu 'du byed rnams kyang skad cig mar grub bo/ / gzhan dag 'du byed rnams ni rtag la/ des sems skad cig ma mi rtag pa bskyed do zhes 'dod na/ skad cig ma min pa las skad cig ma 'byung na ni rtag pa las mi rtag pa 'byung dgos na de mi rigs te nam mkha' las bum sogs bzhin no/ / des na sems kyi rgyu rnams kyang sems bzhin du skad cig mar grub bo/ / yang 'du byed thams cad ni sems kyi 'bras bu ste sems la bag chags bzhag pa'i dbang gis snang ba las gzhan du gyur pa'i phyi don med pa dang / sems kyi las bsags pa las byung ba ma yin pa'i phyi don rang rkya ba med do/ / de ltar na rgyu sems skad cig ma yin pa la 'bras bu 'du byed rnams skad cig mar grub bo/ / 'du byed rnams sems kyi 'bras bu yin par cis shes la/ sems skad cig ma yin pas 'du byed rnams skad cig ma yin pa yang ji ltar shes par bya zhe na/ de'i lan du zin pa dang / bdag po'am dbang ba'i phyir dang / dag pa dang / sems can gyi rjes su 'jug pa'i phyir ro zhes rigs pa phyi ma 'di bzhi bstan pa yin no/ /

This is a general overview. Now, to examine this point in detail, because all the different consciousnesses, starting with the eye consciousness, arise from four conditions, they occur momentarily in rapid succession—Buddhists and tīrthikas both acknowledge this, and neither claim that the mind exists permanently, without changing. The cause of that consciousness is the sense organ and its object (form, for example), as is explained in the sūtras: “In dependence on the eye and form, the eye consciousness arises…” and so on. Therefore, since the mind, which is the result of compounded phenomena, has been established as being momentary, the compounded phenomena that cause and produce it must be momentary too. Our opponents might claim that compounded phenomena are permanent and that they give rise to an impermanent, momentary mind. But it is a logical impossibility for something momentary to arise from something nonmomentary, for that would mean that something impermanent like a pot could arise from something permanent like space. So the causes of the mind too are established as being momentary, in the same way that the mind is. Again, all compounded phenomena are the result of the mind: there are no external objects that are other than those that appear on account of the habitual tendencies present in the mind, and there are no such things as independent external objects that do not originate from the karmic actions accumulated by the mind. Thus, the causal mind being momentary, the resultant compounded phenomena are shown to be momentary. One might wonder how we know that compounded phenomena are the result of the mind and how we know that since the mind is momentary, compounded phenomena are also momentary. The answer to this is indicated in the last four arguments—“because of being seized, because of ownership, and because of following purity and beings.”

de la zin pa'i phyir dang zhes pa/ dbang po lnga dang gnas te dbang rten lus khog pa dang bcas pa rnam par shes pas zin pa las byung ba'i phyir sems kyi 'bras bur grub bo/ / ji ltar zin na ma'i mngal du rnam par shes pa zhugs te brgyal bar gyur nas de zin pa na gdod pha ma'i khu khrag las nur nur po dang mer mer po la sogs pa nas dbang po dang bcas pa'i lus yongs su 'grub kyi/ rnam shes khu khrag la zhugs nas de dang lhan cig 'dres te brgyal bar ma gyur na nur nur po la sogs pa'i gnas skabs rnams rnam pa kun tu mi 'byung bas lus ni sems kyi rjes su 'brang zhing sems kyis yongs su zin pa ste/ mdo las dga' bo rnam par shes pa ma'i mngal du brgyal bar ma gyur na/ pha ma'i mi gtsang ba las nur nur po la sogs par mi 'gyur ro/ /zhes gsungs so/ / gzhan yang sems la gnod par gyur na lus la yang gnod par 'gyur la/ sems bde bar gyur na lus kyang legs par bde bar 'gyur bas sems kyi rjes su 'brang ba dang / sems dang bral na lus tshor ba med par gyur nas rul bar 'gyur ba'i phyir sems kyis zin pa'i phyir 'du byed rnams sems kyi 'bras bu yin no/ /

(11) “Because of being seized.” The fact that the five sense organs and their location, the body that supports the sense organs together with the innards, arise through being seized by the consciousness proves that they are the result of the mind. In what way are they seized? When the consciousness enters the mother’s womb and blacks out, it takes hold of it, then, beginning with the different stages of the embryo formed from the father’s semen and mother’s ovum,[34] the body together with the sense organs becomes fully formed. But if the consciousness, having infiltrated the semen and ovum, did not combine with them and black out, the various stages of embryonic development would never occur. So the body follows the mind and is seized by the mind, as is stated in a sūtra: “Nanda, if the consciousness does not black out in the womb, no embryo will develop from the parents’ fluids.” Furthermore, if the mind is hurt, the body too will be hurt; when the mind is happy, the body too will feel perfectly at ease. It follows the mind. Without the mind, the body becomes devoid of feeling and decomposes. So because they are seized by the mind, compounded phenomena are the results of the mind.

bdag po'i phyir/ zhes pa sems ni 'du byed rnams la dbang byed pa'am bdag por gyur pa yin pa'i phyir sems kyi 'bras bu yin no/ / ji ltar bdag por gyur na/ bcom ldan 'das kyis/ 'jig rten 'di ni sems kyis khrid do/ / sems kyis drangs so/ /zhes gsungs te/ sems kyi gang bsam par lus kyang de'i rjes su 'brang bas na des khrid pa dang drangs pa dang / sems la 'dod chags skyes pa na/ lus kyang de'i rjes su 'brangs nas spyod pa zed zed po'am gzed gzed po dang / bzhin 'dzum pa dang dgod pa la sogs pa'i mtshan nyid gzhan du 'gyur ro/ / gal te zhe sdang skyes na sdang mig dang bzhin khro gnyer dang khu tshur bcangs pa la sogs pa'i spyod pa gzhan du gyur pas 'du byed rnams la sems bdag por byed cing dbang byed do/ /

(12) “Because of ownership.” Because the mind has mastery over compounded phenomena or is their owner, they are the results of the mind. In what way is it the owner? Lord Buddha said, “This world is conducted by the mind; it is led by the mind.” Whatever the mind intends, the body follows—it is conducted and led by the mind. If attachment arises in the mind, the body too follows it and one behaves excitedly, laughing and smiling and so on. When aversion arises in the mind, one’s behavior is transformed accordingly—angry looks, a scowling face, clenched fists, and so forth. So the mind is the owner or master of compounded phenomena.

yang lung gi gtan tshigs gnyis pa ni/ de bzhin gshegs pas rnam par shes pa'i rkyen gyis ming dang gzugs zhes gsungs te/ rnam shes med na ming gzugs kyi gnas skabs mi 'byung la/ de med na skye mched drug sogs mi 'byung ba'i phyir ro/ /

There is a second scriptural argument, given by the Tathāgata when he said, “Because of consciousness, there is name-and-form.” Without consciousness, the stage of name-and-form will not occur, and without name-and-form, the six sense powers and the rest will not arise.

dag dang zhes pa/ sems dag pa'i rjes su 'jug pa ste rnal 'byor pa rnams kyi dag pa'i sems kyi dbang gis/ sa gser du mos na gser du snang ba sogs ji ltar mos pa bzhin du ting nge 'dzin gyi dbang gis rnam pa gzhan dang gzhan 'gyur ba'i phyir/ mdo las kyang / dge slong bsam gtan thob pa zhes sogs rgyas par gsungs so/ / de'i phyir 'du byed rnams sems kyi 'bras bu yin no/ /

(13) “Because of following purity” refers to things following the pure mind. By the power of their pure minds, yogis can transform things through concentration into whatever they like. For example, if they want the ground to be gold, it appears as gold. The sūtras too speak at length of the attainments of monks’ meditative concentration and so on. So for this reason, compounded phenomena are said to result from the mind.

sems can rjes 'jug phyir zhes pa/ sems can rnams kyi sems kyis las dge sdig bsags pas 'jig rten gyi khams sna tshogs mngon par grub pa yin la/ 'du byed rnams sems can rnams kyi sems kyi rjes su 'jug pa yang sdig pa byed pa'i sems can rnams kyi lo tog rnams kha dog dri ro sogs mthu chung zhing / gser la sogs pa'i dngos po yang sol ba la sogs par snang la/ bsod nams byed pa rnams kyi sems kyi dbang gis/ 'bru la sogs pa kha dog dri ro phun sum tshogs pa dang / dngos po ngan pa rnams kyang rin po che la sogs par snang bas na 'du byed rnams sems kyi 'bras bu yin par mngon no/ /

(14) “Because of following beings.” In that it is the positive and negative karmic actions accumulated by sentient beings’ minds that bring into existence the various worlds, compounded phenomena follow beings’ minds. The crops harvested by beings who have committed negative actions are of inferior color, smell, taste, and so forth, and even things made of gold appear to them as charcoal and the like. On the other hand, for those who have performed meritorious actions, because of their minds, the grains and so forth are fully and perfectly colored, fragrant, and flavorsome, and even unpleasant things appear to them as precious substances and the like. From this, it is evident that compounded phenomena are the result of the mind.

de'i phyir rgyu sems skad cig ma yin pas 'bras bu 'du byed rnams kyang rtag pa yin par mi rigs pas skad cig ma nyid du shes par bya'o/ / 'di yan chad kyis phyi dang nang gi dngos po so sor ma phye bar bsdoms te spyir 'du byed rnams skad cig ma'i mi rtag pa yin par tshigs bcad gnyis kyis bstan to/ /

For all these reasons, since the cause, mind, is momentary, its results, compounded phenomena, cannot possibly be permanent, and we should therefore understand that they too are momentary by nature.
