rnam pa brgyad yod de/ theg chen gyi chos bshad pas gang zag gzhan bla na med pa'i byang chub tu sems ni bskyed pa dang / mi skye ba'i don la bzod pa nyid thob pa ni theg chen gyi chos bstan pas gang zag la la mos spyod kyi dus na mi skye ba'i chos la don spyi'i tshul gyis bzod pa thob pa/ bzod pa de kho na nyid kyi phyogs gcig la zhugs pa ste 'di ni bzod pa chung ngu'o/ / sa dang po thob nas gzung 'dzin dang bral ba'i de kho na nyid mngon sum rtogs nas mi skye ba'i don la bzod pa dngos su thob pa ni/ sa brgyad pa la ltos nas bzod pa 'bring po'o/ / sa brgyad par mi rtog pa lhun gyis grub pas mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa chen po thob pa ste/ mdo rnams las kyang chos kyi rnam grangs 'di bshad pa'i tshe gang zag 'di tsam zhig gis bla med byang chub tu sems bskyed pa dang / chos rnams la chos kyi rjes su mthun pa'i bzod pa thob pa dang / 'phags lam thob pa dang / mi skye ba'i bzod pa thob par gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

There are eight aspects: As a result of bodhisattvas teaching the Great Vehicle, (1) some beings arouse the mind intent on unsurpassable enlightenment, and (2) others attain the acceptance that objects are unborn. Through the teaching of the Great Vehicle, some individuals, at the stage of earnest aspiration, acquire an indirect understanding of the acceptance that phenomena are unborn; their acceptance applies to a part of thatness—this is lesser acceptance. Having attained the first bodhisattva level, they directly realize thatness devoid of subject and object and actually attain the acceptance that objects are unborn. Compared to the eighth level, this is middling acceptance. On the eighth level, they spontaneously and nonconceptually attain the great acceptance that phenomena are unborn. This accords with the sūtras, where, in the exposition of these categories, it is said that such and such an individual has aroused the mind intent on unsurpassable enlightenment, acquired the acceptance of phenomena consistent with the Dharma, attained the noble path, and attained the acceptance that phenomena are unborn.

nyan thos kyi chos bstan pas/ chos rnams la chos kyi mig dri ma med pa theg pa chen po'i mthong lam las dman pa thob pa dang / mthar thug zag pa thams cad zad pa dgra bcom pa thob pa gnyis so/ / de la chos kyi mig thob pa ni nyan thos kyi mthong lam ste/ bden pa bzhi mthong ba'i chos kyi mig lta bu'i ye shes skyes pas so/ / de yang bzod pa brgyad gnyen po yin pas nyon mongs pa'i rdul med pa dang / shes pa brgyad mthong spang las grol ba'i dri ma med pa zhes bya ste/ de ltar chos kyi mig rdul med cing dri ma dang bral ba thob pa ni mthong spang las grol ba'i rgyun du zhugs pa'o/ / de ltar nyan thos kyi mthong lam thob pa des chos la brten nas bsgom pa'i spang bya'i nyon mongs khams gsum gyi sas bsdus pa rnams spangs nas zag pa thams cad zad nas zad mi skye shes pa'i ye shes thob pa dgra bcom pa 'thob par 'gyur ro/ / de ltar yang mdo las chos kyi rnam grangs 'di bshad pas gang zag kha cig rdul med cing dri ma dang bral ba'i chos la chos kyi mig skyes so zhes dang / gang zag kha cig len pa med par zag pa thams cad las sems rnam par grol bar gyur to zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

(3) As a result of bodhisattvas teaching the Dharma of the Listeners’ Vehicle, their disciples acquire the uncontaminated eye of Dharma with regard to phenomena (which is an inferior level to the Mahāyāna path of seeing); and (4) ultimately they attain the level of arhat where all taints have been exhausted. Acquiring the eye of Dharma represents the listeners’ path of seeing, on which there arises gnosis like the eye of Dharma, which sees the four truths. Since the eight instants of acceptance are antidotes, we speak of this eye being free of the dust of defilements, and for the eight instants of knowing we speak of it being uncontaminated, that is, freed of the obscurations that have to be eliminated on the path of seeing. Thus, someone who acquires the dustless, uncontaminated eye of Dharma is a stream enterer freed of the obscurations to be eliminated on the path of seeing. Such a person who has attained the listeners’ path of seeing relies on the teachings to eliminate the defilements included in all the levels of the three worlds that are to be eliminated on the path of meditation, and having exhausted all taints, acquires the gnosis of exhaustion and nonarising and attains the level of arhat. Again, the sūtras, explaining these categories, say, “Some individuals give rise to the dustless, uncontaminated eye of Dharma with regard to phenomena,” and, “Some individuals completely free their minds from all taints, without grasping.”

theg pa che chung gi chos gang bshad kyang / chos smra ba gcig las gzhan 'phel te 'jig rten 'dir dam pa'i chos yun ring du gnas pa dang / chos rnams kyi rang dang spyi'i mtshan nyid sngon ma shes pa shes shing / the tshom du gyur pa rnams gcod par byed pa dang / mi shes pa dang the tshom med par chos kyi don nges par gyur nas dam pa'i chos kyi dga' ba kha na ma tho ba med pa'i gnas la longs spyod pa nyid du gyur pa gang yin pa de ni/ chos ston pa de la zhugs pa blo ldan gyi chos bshad pa'i 'bras bu yin par shes par bya'o/ /

Whether it is the teachings of the Great Vehicle or lesser vehicles that are taught, (5) the teachings spread from one teacher to another, so that the sacred Dharma endures for a long time here in the world. (6) Those who have no previous knowledge of the general and particular characteristics of the teachings acquire that knowledge. (7) Those who are doubtful have their doubts resolved. And (8) having become certain of the meaning of the teachings, without any gaps of knowledge or doubts, they become the enjoyers of the sacred Dharma, delighting in it unashamedly.[21] Any of these are to be understood as being the result of the Dharma teachings of the wise, who are engaged in teaching the Dharma.
lnga pa theg pa chen po'i khyad chos dang bsdu ba rnam par bzhag pa ni/
(5) HOW THE FEATURES THAT DISTINGUISH THE GREAT VEHICLE ARE PRESENTED, ALONG WITH A SUMMARY

dmigs pa che ba nyid dang ni/ / de bzhin sgrub pa nyid dag dang / / ye shes brtson 'grus rtsom pa dang / / thabs la mkhas par gyur pa dang / / yang dag 'grub pa chen po dang / / sangs rgyas phrin las chen po ste/ / chen po 'di dang ldan pa'i phyir/ / theg chen zhes ni nges par brjod/ /

The greatness of its reference, And likewise of its twin accomplishment, Its gnosis, diligent application, Its skill in means, (XX, 59) Its great consummation, And great buddha activities— It is because it possesses these forms of greatness That the Great Vehicle is so described. (XX, 60)
ces pas bstan te/

theg pa chen po ni theg pa chung ngu las khyad par bdun gyis 'phags te/ dmigs pa che ba ni/ nyan thos rnams nyan thos kyi sde snod gsum la dmigs pa las/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams theg pa chen po zab cing rgya che ba'i sde snod dpag tu med pa nyid la dmigs pa dang ni/ de bzhin du sgrub pa chen po ni nyan thos rnams bdag gi don tsam sgrub pa la/ byang chub sems dpas bdag dang gzhan gyi don sgrub pa gnyis dang ldan pa dag dang / ye shes chen po ni nyan thos rnams gang zag gi bdag med tsam rtogs shing byang chub sems dpas chos dang gang zag la bdag med par rtogs pa dang / nyan thos rnams tshe gsum mam bdun tsam du brtson 'grus rtsom la/ byang chub sems dpas bskal pa grangs med gsum gyi bar du brtson 'grus rtsom pas brtson 'grus rtsom pa che ba dang / nyan thos rnams 'khor bar 'jigs nas de spangs pa'i zhi bde don du gnyer ba'i thabs mkhas pa dang mi ldan la byang chub sems dpa' rnams snying rjes 'khor ba yongs su mi gtong yang shes rab kyis nyon mongs pas mi gos pa pad+mo 'dam las skyes pa lta bu'i thabs la mkhas par gyur pa dang lnga ni 'dis 'degs pa rgyu'am lam gyi theg pa'i khyad par ro/ /

The Great Vehicle is superior to the Lesser Vehicle in seven respects: (1) Its great reference: compared to the listeners, who refer to the three listeners’ collections, bodhisattvas refer to the infinite scriptural collections of the extensive and profound Great Vehicle. (2) Likewise, its great accomplishment: whereas listeners accomplish only their own goal, bodhisattvas have a double accomplishment—that of their own goal and that of others’ goals. (3) Great gnosis: listeners realize only the no-self of the individual; bodhisattvas realize the no-self in the individual and in phenomena. (4) Listeners practice diligently for a mere three or seven lifetimes; bodhisattvas practice diligently for as long as three measureless kalpas, hence their greater application of diligence. (5) Listeners are not skilled in means, for out of fear they reject saṃsāra and strive for peace. Bodhisattvas, on the other hand, are skilled in means: they are like lotuses growing out of the mud, never abandoning saṃsāra (because of their compassion) and yet never tainted by defilements (because of their wisdom). These five distinguish the vehicles in terms of the carrier—that is, the cause or path.

nyan thos rnams dgra bcom pa'i 'bras bu dang zad par zil gnon mngon shes drug tsam thob nas phung po lhag med du zad pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i theg pas 'bras bu stobs dang mi 'jigs pa sogs dpag tu med pa dag nam yang mi zad pa yang dag par 'grub pa chen po dang / nyan thos rnams dgra bcom thob kyang mngon par byang chub pa dang chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba sogs mi byed kyi/ byang sems rnams mngon par sangs rgyas nas 'og min gyi pho brang na bzhugs pa dang / lhums su zhugs pa dang mngon par byang chub pa sogs kyi mdzad pa sems can gyi mtha'i bar du ston pa'i sangs rgyas kyi phrin las chen po ste 'di gnyis 'dir 'degs pa 'bras bu'i theg pa'i dbang du byas pa'o/ /

(6) Once listeners have attained the result of arhat and just the various powers of perceptual limitlessness, different kinds of perceptual domination, and the six kinds of preternatural knowledge, these come to an end in the state without residual aggregates. The result of the Bodhisattva Vehicle, comprising immeasurable qualities such as the strengths and fearlessnesses, never comes to an end, hence their great consummation. And (7) even though listeners attain the level of arhat, they do not achieve full enlightenment, turn the wheel of the Dharma, or anything else like that. Bodhisattvas, on the other hand, attain true buddhahood and subsequently display such deeds as residing in the palace of the highest heaven,[22] entering the womb, and manifesting full enlightenment, and this for as long as there are sentient beings—hence their great buddha activities. These two distinguish the vehicles in terms of where they carry one—that is, the result.
de ltar chen po bdun po 'di dang ldan pa'i phyir/ theg chen zhes ni nges par brjod do/
It is because it possesses these seven aspects of greatness that it is described as the “Great Vehicle.”
theg pa chen po bsdu ba rnam par bzhag pa ni/
Presentation of a Summary of the Great Vehicle

rigs dang chos la mos pa dang / / de bzhin sems ni bskyed pa dang / / sbyin la sogs pa sgrub pa dang / / skyon med pa la 'jug nyid dang / / sems can rnams yongs smin byed dang / / zhing ni rnam par sbyong ba dang / / mi gnas mya ngan 'das pa dang / / byang chub mchog dang ston pa'o/ /

This is summarized as the potential, interest in the teachings, And likewise arousing bodhicitta, Practicing the transcendent perfections, Entering the flawless levels, (XX, 61) Bringing beings to maturity, Purifying the universe, Realizing the nondwelling nirvāṇa, Attaining supreme enlightenment, and displaying enlightened activities. (XX, 62)
zhes pas bstan te/

theg pa chen po shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa stong phrag brgya pa dang sangs rgyas phal po che la sogs pa theg pa chen po'i mdo dpag tu med pa rnams kyi don brjod na mtha' las 'das kyang theg chen thams cad kyi don bsdus na rnam bzhag rnam pa brgyad dam bcu po 'dir 'dus pas na/ de dag la theg pa chen po zhes bya'o/ /

If we were to mention all the points in the countless Mahāyāna sūtras, such as the Perfection of Wisdom in One Hundred Thousand Lines and the Sūtra of the Ornament of the Buddhas, they would exceed all bounds. Nevertheless, if we summarize the meaning of the whole Great Vehicle, it can be condensed into the following eightfold or tenfold presentation, which we refer to as the Great Vehicle.

de gang zhe na theg pa chen po'i rigs sam khams yod pa dang / rigs la brten nas theg chen gyi chos la mos pa dang / de bzhin du mos pa'i dbang gis bla med byang chub tu sems ni bskyed pa gsum ni rigs la gnas pa'i skabs kyis so/ /

What are these points? (1) Possession of the Mahāyāna potential or element; based on that, (2) interest in the teachings of the Great Vehicle; and similarly, because of interest, (3) the arousal of the mind intent on unsurpassable enlightenment. These three result from the condition of abiding in the Mahāyāna family.

de ltar sems bskyed nas mos spyod kyi sar sbyin pa la sogs pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa drug bsgrub pa dang / de las sa dang por gzung 'dzin dang bral ba'i ye shes skyes nas 'jig rten las 'das pa 'phags pa'i sa skyon med la 'jug pa nyid dang / sa gnyis pa nas bdun pa'i bar du byang phyogs dang pha rol tu phyin pa'i chos kyis sems can ma dad pa rnams dad par byed cing dad pa rnams dge ba la yongs su smin par byed pa dang drug go /

After arousing the mind intent on enlightenment like this, (4) bodhisattvas on the level of earnest aspiration practice the six transcendent perfections—generosity and the others. As a result, (5) on the first level there arises the gnosis devoid of subject and object, and they enter the flawless, supramundane noble levels. (6) From the second level up to the seventh, they practice the elements leading to enlightenment and the transcendent perfections, and by doing so they lead beings who do not have faith to develop faith and bring those who have faith to full maturity in virtue. This makes six points.

dag pa'i sa gsum du snod dang bcud dag par bsgrub pa ste sangs rgyas kyi zhing ni rnam par sbyong ba dang shes rab kyis 'khor bar mi gnas la/ snying rjes zhi bar mi gnas pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa srid zhi mnyam pa nyid du rtogs pa'i sbyor ba gnyis gcig tu brtsis pa dang / de nas sa bcu 'das nas sangs rgyas kyi sar sku gsum thob pa ni byang chub mchog thob pa dang byang chub thob nas sems can ji srid du sangs rgyas kyi mdzad pa mngon par byang chub pa sogs kyi phrin las ston pa 'di gnyis gcig tu brtsis na de ltar brgyad yin la/ phyi ma bzhi so sor bgrangs na rnam grangs bcur rnam par bzhag pa'o/ / de yan chad kyis byang chub sems dpa'i sgrub pa'i yon tan ngo mtshar ba nas rnam par bzhag pa'i bar gyi rnam grangs bcu bdun bshad nas/

On the three pure levels, they accomplish the purification of the universe and beings.[23] For this they combine (7a) training in purifying them as buddha fields and (7b) realizing the nondwelling nirvāṇa as the sameness of existence and peace: because of wisdom there is no dwelling in saṃsāra, and because of compassion there is no dwelling in peace. These two are counted as one. Subsequently, (8a) they pass the tenth level and achieve supreme enlightenment, attaining the three buddha bodies on the level of buddhahood; and (8b) having attained enlightenment, for as long as there are sentient beings they display activities such as manifesting full enlightenment and the other deeds of a buddha. These two are also counted as one, making eight in all. Alternatively, if these last four are counted separately, they are presented as ten categories. Up to here we have explained the seventeen categories of the qualities that bodhisattvas accomplish, from wondrous qualities through to how they teach the Dharma. These are now followed by the qualities that are highly praised.
gnyis pa rab tu bsngags pa'i yon tan
2. QUALITIES THAT ARE HIGHLY PRAISED
['di] la/ bsngags yul byang chub sems dpa'i dbye ba dang / bsngags pa dngos gnyis las/
This section has two parts: (1) categories of bodhisattvas as objects of praise and (2) the actual praise.
dang po ni/
a. CATEGORIES OF BODHISATTVAS AS OBJECTS OF PRAISE

gcig ni mos pa dang ldan pa/ / lhag pa'i bsam pa dag pa gzhan/ / mtshan ma dang ni mtshan med dang / / mngon par 'du byed med spyod pa/ / lnga po 'di dag sa kun la/ / byang chub sems dpa' yin zhes bya/ /

Some bodhisattvas are interested, Others have pure superior intention, Conceive attributes, are without attributes, And practice without deliberate effort— These five should be understood As referring to the bodhisattvas on all the levels. (XX, 63)
zhes pas bstan te/

sa bcu dang mos pa'i spyod pa'i sa bcas sa bcu gcig la gnas pa de la byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya la/ de yang gnas skabs kyi rnam grangs lngas bsdus te/ gcig ste mos spyod kyi sa la gnas pa ni chos kyi dbyings kun tu 'gro ba'i mtshan nyid mngon du ma byas kyang / chos kyi dbyings la dad cing yid ches pa yin pa'i phyir mos pa dang ldan pa zhes bya'o/ /

What we call bodhisattvas are those dwelling on the eleven levels, that is, the ten levels and the level of earnest aspiration, and these are summarized under five categories according to their situation: (1) One of these refers to those on the level of earnest aspiration. They have not directly realized the nature of the universal expanse of reality but nevertheless have confidence and faith in the expanse of reality and are therefore termed “interested.”

sa dang po la zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ni lhag pa'i bsam pa rnam par dag pa zhes bya ste chos dbyings kun tu 'gro ba'i mtshan nyid rtogs nas bdag gzhan mnyam pa nyid kyi sems thob pas gzhan don khur 'khyer gyi lhag bsam mthong spang gi sgrib pa rnam par dag pa dang ldan pa'i phyir ro/ / de ni byang chub sems dpa'i rnam grangs snga ma las gzhan gnyis so/ /

(2) Bodhisattvas who have reached the first level are known as having “pure superior intention” because, having realized the nature of the universal expanse of reality and acquired the state of mind that realizes the sameness of oneself and others, they therefore possess the superior intention of taking responsibility for others’ welfare, purified of the obscurations that are to be eliminated on the path of seeing. This one is different[24] from the previous category of bodhisattva and is the second category.

sa gnyis pa nas drug pa'i bar la gnas pa ni mtshan ma dang bcas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya ste/ sa gnyis par nyan rang byang sems kyi theg pa sna tshogs su 'byed pa'i mtshan ma la spyod pa'i phyir dang ni/ sa gsum par lhan skyes kyi 'jig tshogs la lta ba'i mtshan ma dang / bzhi par sdug bsngal dang kun 'byung gi bden pa la gnod pa'i mtshan mar mthong ba dang / 'gog lam gyi bden par zhi ba'i mtshan mar mthong ba dang / sa lnga par bzo'i las kyi gnas sna tshogs la 'jug cing de'i mtshan ma'i rtog pa dang / sa drug par rten cing 'brel 'byung lugs 'byung ldog gi mtshan mar rtog pa'i phyir ro/ /

(3) Those on the second to sixth levels are called “bodhisattvas with attributes.” On the second level, they use the attributes that variously distinguish the vehicles of the listeners, solitary realizers, and bodhisattvas. On the third level, they eliminate[25] the attributes of the innate view of the transitory composite. On the fourth level, they see the truths of suffering and of the origin as harmful attributes and see the truths of cessation and of the path as pacifying attributes. On the fifth level, they engage in different kinds of arts, while conceptualizing their attributes. And on the sixth level, they still have concepts with regard to dependent arising in forward and reverse orders.

sa bdun pa la gnas pa la mtshan ma med pa'i byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya ste sa drug pa man chad du 'byung ba'i mtshan ma thams cad spangs pa'i phyir dang / phyir mi ldog pa'i sa brgyad pa dang dgu pa dang bcu pa gsum la gnas pa la mngon par 'du byed med pa la spyod pa'i byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya ste/ rnam par mi rtog pa'i ting nge 'dzin 'bad rtsol med par lhun gyis grub pas bdag gzhan gyi don byed pa'i phyir ro/ /

(4) Bodhisattvas on the seventh level are referred to as “bodhisattvas without attributes” because they have eliminated all the attributes that occur up to the sixth level. (5) Those on the nonreturner levels—that is, the eighth, ninth, and tenth levels—are known as “bodhisattvas who practice without deliberate effort” because they act for their own and others’ welfare by means of spontaneous and effortless nonconceptual concentration.
de ltar byang chub sems dpa'i gnas skabs lnga po 'di dag sa kun la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' yi khyad par yin pa shes par bya'o/ /
These five instances of bodhisattvas should be understood as being the specific qualities of the bodhisattvas abiding on all the levels.
gnyis pa byang chub sems dpa' lnga po de'i mtshan nyid la bsngags pa ni/
b. THE ACTUAL PRAISE: PRAISING THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THESE FIVE KINDS OF BODHISATTVAS

rgyu phar phyin rnams sgrub pa la snying stobs mi bzlog pa'i sgo nas byang chub sems dpa'i sgra don gyi bsngags pa dang / 'bras bu byang chub rtogs pa'i cha nas byang chub sems dpa'i sgra don gyi sgo nas bsngags pa gnyis las/

The actual praise is divided into two: (1) a praise based on the significance of the word “bodhisattva” from the point of view of their irreversible strength of mind in practicing the causal factors, the transcendent perfections, and (2) the qualities that are praised in accordance with the significance of the word “bodhisattva” from the point of view of their realization of the result, enlightenment.
dang po
i. A PRAISE BASED ON THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THE WORD “BODHISATTVA” FROM THE POINT OF VIEW OF THEIR IRREVERSIBLE STRENGTH OF MIND IN PRACTICING THE CAUSAL FACTORS, THE TRANSCENDENT PERFECTIONS
['di] la byang chub dga' ldan sogs rnam grangs dgus bsngags pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i mtshan gyi rnam grangs bstan pa gnyis las/
The first of these is divided into, first, a praise in terms of nine categories beginning with delight in enlightenment and, second, an indication of the different names of a bodhisattva.
dang po/
(1) A PRAISE IN TERMS OF NINE CATEGORIES BEGINNING WITH DELIGHT IN ENLIGHTENMENT
'dod la ma chags las gsum rnam par dag / khro ba zil gnon yon tan mchog lhur len/ / chos las mi g.yo de nyid zab mo mthong / / byang chub dga' ldan byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /

One who is unattached to pleasure, pure in the three deeds, Who overpowers anger, strives for sublime qualities, Never moves from the practice, and sees profound thatness Is a bodhisattva who delights in enlightenment. (XX, 64)
ces pas bstan te/

'dod pa'i yon tan lnga'i longs spyod la ma chags par phyi nang gi dngos po yongs su gtong ba'i sbyin pa'i phar phyin bsgrub pa dang / tshul khrims la lus ngag yid kyi las gsum mi dge ba med pas rnam par dag pa dang / bzod pa la gnas nas khro ba zil gyis gnon pa dang / brtson 'grus kyis 'jig rten las 'das pa'i dge ba'i yon tan mchog gyur len pa dang / bsam gtan gyis rtse gcig tu gnas pa'i chos las mi g.yo ba dang / shes rab kyis bdag med gnyis kyi de nyid zab mo mthong ba ste de ltar phar phyin drug sgrub pa yang 'bras bu byang chub chen po 'thob pa la dga' ba dang ldan zhing de'i ched du bsgrub cing der bsngo ba'i phyir byang chub la dga' ba dang ldan pa'i byang chub sems dpa' yin zhes tshigs bcad 'dis phar phyin drug rnam par dag pa'i yon tan la bsngags pa'o/ /

In completely giving away their outer and inner possessions without any attachment to the five sense pleasures, bodhisattvas practice transcendent generosity. Their discipline is devoid of negative actions—physical, verbal, or mental—and so it is perfectly pure. By exercising patience, they overpower anger. With their diligence, they devote themselves to sublime qualities—that is, supramundane virtue.[26] Because of their concentration, they never waver from the practice of resting one-pointedly. And with wisdom, they see profound thatness, the two kinds of no-self. Those who practice the six transcendent perfections in this way are delighted that they will attain the result, great enlightenment; they practice for that purpose and dedicate their practice to that. For this reason, it is said that they are bodhisattvas who delight in enlightenment. This verse praises the qualities of those who practice the six transcendent perfections purely.
phan 'dogs 'dod dang gnod pa med lta dang / / gzhan gyi gnod pa dang du len pa dang / / brtan pa bag yod mang du thos pa dang / / gzhan gyi don brtson byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /
One who wants to help, intends no harm, Willingly accepts others’ harm, Is steadfast, careful, and learned Is a bodhisattva who strives for others’ good. (XX, 65)

de bzhin du sbyin pas sems can rnams la phan 'dogs par 'dod pa dang / tshul khrims kyis gzhan gyi srog dang longs spyod chung ma la gnod pa dang / rdzun gyis bslu ba sogs kyi sgo gsum gyi gnod pa gang yang med par lta ba'am mi 'dod pa dang / bzod pas gzhan gyis gnod pa dang du len pa dang / brtson 'grus las mi ldog par brtan pa nyid du gyur pa'i brtson 'grus rtsom pa dang / dgon par gnas shing rnam g.yeng med pa dang bsam gtan gyi ro la ma chags pa'i bag yod pas bsam gtan dang / dam pa'i chos mang du thos pa ldan pa'i shes rab kyi sgo nas sems can gzhan gyi don la brtson pa'i byang chub sems dpa' yin te/ phar phyin bsgrub pa thams cad kyi gnas skabs su sems can gyi don byed pa dang mthar thug sems can thams cad kyi don du bla med byang chub tu bsngo ba'i phyir ro/ / 'dis gzhan don byed pa'i yon tan gyi cha nas byang sems yin par bsngags pa'o/ /

Similarly, they want to help beings by means of their generosity. With discipline they look to, or wish to, do no harm whatsoever with their three doors, such as adversely affecting others’ lives, possessions, and spouses, and cheating them with lies. With patience they willingly accept being harmed by others. They undertake everything with diligence, steadfast in never turning back from their efforts. Their concentration is characterized by carefulness—that is, they remain in solitary places, undistracted, and have no attachment to the taste of concentration. And they have the wisdom that comes from having listened many times to the teachings of the sacred Dharma. It is in these terms that they are bodhisattvas who exert themselves for others’ welfare, for their whole practice of the transcendent perfections helps sentient beings on a temporary level and is dedicated ultimately to unsurpassable enlightenment for the sake of all beings. This verse praises them as being bodhisattvas from the point of view of their qualities in benefiting others.
rang gis yongs su gzung ba'i nyes dmigs shes/ / longs spyod ma chags zhe la 'khon mi 'dzin/ / rnal 'byor rgyu mtshan la mkhas lta ngan med/ / nang du rab gnas byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /

One who knows the defects of keeping things for oneself, Who is without attachment, and never holds a grudge, Practices yoga, is expert in the special points, and is without wrong views Is a bodhisattva who is perfectly settled inwardly. (XX, 66)

longs spyod rnams rang gis yongs su bzung ba'i nyes dmigs ni snying po med pa dang / mi rtag pa dang / sdug bsngal dang / sgyu ma lta bu yin pa dang longs spyod la chags pa'i skyon gyis ngan song du skye ba dang 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i phun sum tshogs pa thob pa'i gegs su gyur pa sogs nyes pa shes nas sbyin pa gtong ba dang / 'dod pa'i longs spyod la ma chags par khyim spangs te rab tu byung nas tshul khrims bsrung ba dang / gzhan gyis gnod pa byas pa zhe la 'khon du mi 'dzin par bzod pa dang / theg pa chen po'i zhi lhag gi rnal 'byor la brtson pa dang / nam rtse gcig pa'i ting 'dzin bsgom pa na zhi gnas kyi mtshan ma dang / gzengs bstod pa'am rab tu 'dzin pa'i mtshan ma dang / btang snyoms kyi mtshan ma ste rgyu mtshan gsum la mkhas pa dang / bdag lta sogs lta ba ngan pa med pa'i shes rab dang ldan pa'i nang du rab gnas byang chub sems dpa' yin te/ tshul des nang du yang dag 'jog la rab tu gnas pa'i cha nas bsngags pa'o/ /

Bodhisattvas know the disadvantages of keeping their possessions for themselves—namely, that they are without essence, impermanent, associated with suffering, and illusory, and that the mistake of being attached to wealth leads to rebirth in the lower realms and is an obstacle to the attainment of mundane and supramundane perfection—and so they give them away as gifts. Free of attachment to sensual pleasure, they abandon lay life to take ordination and subsequently observe discipline. Rather than harboring resentment for the harm others have done them, they are patient. They are diligent in the Mahāyāna yoga of sustained calm and profound insight. When they are training in one-pointed concentration, they are expert in the three special points—the special point of sustained calm, that of encouraging or rousing oneself, and that of equanimity. And they possess the wisdom that is free of wrong views such as the view of a self. They are bodhisattvas who are perfectly settled inwardly. In this manner, they are praised from the point of view of their abiding perfectly in true inner composure.
brtse dang ldan pa ngo tsha yon tan gnas/ / sdug bsngal dang len rang gi bde ma chags/ / dran gtso shin tu mnyam par bzhag pa'i bdag / theg pa mi 'khrugs byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /

One who is full of love, maintains the virtues of a sense of shame, Who happily accepts suffering, is unattached to personal well-being, Gives priority to mindfulness, and is a master of perfect equipoise Is a bodhisattva who is never at odds with the vehicle. (XX, 67)

sems can sdug bsngal can la snying brtse ba dang ldan pa des sbyin pa byed pa dang / ngo tsha ba'i yon tan la gnas pas tshul khrims bsrung ba dang / gzhan gyis gnod pa sogs sdug bsngal dang du len par bzod pa dang / gnyid dang snyom las sogs rang gi bde ba la ma chags par gzhan don du brtson 'grus rtsom pa dang / rtag tu dran pa dang ldan pa gtso bor gyur pas rnam g.yeng gi dbang du mi 'gyur ba dang / chos thams cad yod med kyi mtha' dang bral bar mnyam pa nyid kyi shes rab dang rtag tu ldan pas shin tu mnyam par bzhag pa'i bdag nyid yin pas/ theg pa chen po las sems mi 'khrugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' yin no/ / 'dis theg pa chen po'i lam las mi 'khrugs pa'i yon tan gyi cha nas bsngags pa'o/ / blo brtan 'grel pas skabs 'di thams cad du rkang pa snga ma gsum gyis phar phyin drug bsgrub pa dang / rkang pa bzhi pas bla med byang chub tu bsngo ba bstan par gsungs so/ /

Those who are full of love for all suffering sentient beings give generously. Maintaining the qualities of a sense of shame, they observe discipline. They willingly accept the harm others do them and similar sufferings, and thus are patient. Without any attachment to their own well-being, in particular the pleasures of sleep and idleness, they work diligently for the good of others. Constant mindfulness is their chief preoccupation, so they never give in to distraction. And because they constantly possess the wisdom that knows the sameness of all phenomena, free from the extremes of existence and nonexistence, they are lords of perfect meditative equipoise. They are thus bodhisattvas whose minds are never at variance with the Great Vehicle. This verse praises them from the point of view of the quality of their never being in conflict with the Mahāyāna path. In his commentary, Sthiramati notes that in all these verses, the first three lines indicate bodhisattvas’ practice of the six transcendent perfections, and the fourth line indicates the fact of their being dedicated to unsurpassable enlightenment.
sdug bsngal sel ba sdug bsngal mi byed nyid/ / sdug bsngal bzod pa sdug bsngal 'jigs pa med/ / sdug bsngal rnam grol sdug bsngal mi rtog pa/ / sdug bsngal khas len byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /

One who dispels suffering, never causes pain, Who accepts suffering, is unafraid of difficulties, Is liberated from suffering, and has no concepts of misery Is a bodhisattva who willingly takes on suffering. (XX, 68)

sbyin pas gzhan gyi phongs pa'i sdug bsngal sel ba dang / tshul khrims kyis srog gcod pa dang rku ba sogs kyis sems can sdug bsngal bar mi byed pa dang / rang gi sdug bsngal thams cad bzod pa dang / gzhan don du 'khor bar 'jug cing sems can gyi don la brtson pa la sdug bsngal gyis 'jigs pa med pa dang / bsam gtan gyi ting 'dzin thob pas 'dod khams kyi sdug bsngal dang yid mi bde ba las rnam par grol ba dang / shes rab kyis sdug bsngal gyi mtshan mar mi rtog pa de lta bu sdug bsngal khas len pa'am dang du len pa'i byang chub sems dpa' yin no/ / 'dis sdug bsngal can gyi 'khor ba mi spong ba dang / sdug bsngal gyis skyo ba med pa'i cha nas bsngags pa'o/ /

Because of bodhisattvas’ generosity, other beings’ sufferings due to deprivation are dispelled. On account of their discipline, they never cause sentient beings to suffer, by killing or robbing them, for instance. They patiently accept their own suffering. They have no fear of suffering in entering saṃsāra for others’ sake and striving diligently for beings’ welfare. Since they have acquired the concentrations of the dhyānas, they have been completely released from the pain and anguish of the world of desire. And on account of their wisdom, they do not conceptualize suffering. Such beings are bodhisattvas who willingly accept or take on suffering. This verse praises them from the point of view of their not abandoning saṃsāra, with all its suffering, and not being discouraged by suffering.
chos la mi dga' rang bzhin chos la dga'/ / chos la smod cing chos la mngon par brtson/ / chos la dbang ba chos la mun pa med/ / chos gtsor byed pa byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /

One who gets no joy in certain ways, delights in natural ways, Despises other ways, and is diligent in virtue, Has mastered the teachings, and is not obscured with regard to phenomena Is a bodhisattva for whom the Dharma is the most important thing.[27] (XX, 69)

ser snas mi gtong ba'i chos la mi dga' ba dang / nyes pa med cing yon tan gyi rang bzhin du gyur pa'i tshul khrims kyi chos la dga' ba dang / khong khro'i chos la smod cing dge ba'i chos la mngon par brtson pa dang / chos la dbang ba ting nge 'dzin gyi mthus sems kyi dbang thob pa dang / chos kun la rmongs pa'i mun pa med pa'i shes rab dang ldan pa de'i phyir/ yang dag pa'i chos gtso bor byed pa yi byang chub sems dpa' yin no/ / 'dis zang zing gtso bo mi byed par dam pa'i chos gtso bor byed pa'i cha nas bsngags pa'o/ /

Bodhisattvas take no delight in stingy, ungenerous ways. They delight in disciplined ways, which are by nature free of faults and full of virtues. They condemn angry ways and are truly diligent in virtuous ways. By the power of the concentration of mastery of the teachings, they have acquired mastery of the mind. And they possess the wisdom that is free of the gloom of ignorance with regard to all phenomena. Thus, they are bodhisattvas who give priority to the true Dharma. This is a praise from the point of view of not giving priority to material considerations and instead making the sacred Dharma the most important thing.
longs spyod bag yod nges la bag yod dang / / bsrung la bag yod dge la bag yod dang / / bde la bag yod chos la bag yod dang / / theg pa bag yod byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /

One who is careful with possessions, careful in discipline, Careful to remain on guard, careful in virtue, Careful with bliss, and careful with regard to phenomena Is a bodhisattva who is careful with regard to the vehicle. (XX, 70)

longs spyod yod kyang gzhan la mi gtong bar bsags srung byed pa de dag bag med pa ste mthar longs spyod chud za ba'i phyir ro/ / des na longs spyod don yod par bya phyir gzhan la gtong ba ni longs spyod la bag yod pa dang / bcas pa dang rang bzhin gyi kha na ma tho ba mi bsrung ba ni bag med pa yin la/ gang dag tshul khrims dang ldan pas sgo gsum dul zhing bcas rang gi nyes pa ma gos pa ni dul ba la bag yod pa zhes bya ste des kha cig tu des la bag yod ces 'dug kyang blo brtan 'grel pa'i 'gyur ltar du bya na legs so/ / kha cig ngos la bag yod ces 'bru mnan pa ni yig nor byung ba zad do/ / gzhan gnod la mi bzod par gnod lan byed pa ni rang gzhan gnyis ka'i sems ma bsrung bas bag med pa yin la/ byang chub sems dpas gzhan gnod byas pa la rgyud mi 'khrugs shing gnod lan mi byed par slar phan 'dogs pa ni rang gzhan gnyis ka bsrung ba la bag yod pa bzod pa dang / le lo'i dbang gis dge chos mi 'grub pa'i bag med ma yin par/ 'jig rten dang 'jig rten 'das pa'i dge ba bsgrub pa la bag yod par brtson 'grus dang / bsam gtan gyi bde ba thob pa la ro myang ba'i sred pa med pa ni bde ba la bag yod pa dang / chos rnams la rtag pas bde ba dang bdag dang mi stong par 'dzin pa ni bag med pa yin la/ mi rtag pa la sogs par phyin ci ma log par rtogs pa ni chos la bag yod pa'i shes rab ste/ de ltar theg pa chen po'i chos tshul bzhin yid la byed pa'i bag yod dang ldan pa'i byang chub sems dpa' yin no/ /'dis bag yod dang ldan pa'i phar phyin drug bsgrub pa'i yon tan gyi cha nas bsngags pa'o/ /

Those who have wealth yet hoard and guard it instead of giving it away to others are careless, for in the end, possessions go to waste. So in order to make their possessions meaningful, bodhisattvas give them away to others. This is being careful with regard to possessions. To not guard oneself from naturally shameful deeds and those that violate edicts would be careless. But those who are disciplined control their body, speech, and mind and are untainted by faults, natural and proscribed. They are termed “careful in discipline.” (Some texts have “careful in certainty,”[28] but it is better to say “disciplined” as in the translation of Sthiramati’s commentary. In some texts one finds “careful on the surface,”[29] which is simply a misspelling.) Failure to guard one’s mind, and that of others, from retaliating instead of patiently accepting harm from others is careless. But bodhisattvas’ minds are never perturbed when others harm them, and instead of retaliating, they help them. This is patience—being careful in guarding both oneself and others. Failure, due to laziness, to practice positive actions, would be careless, but instead bodhisattvas are diligent, taking care to practice mundane and supramundane virtue. Though they have gained the bliss of concentration, they never crave the experience of bliss—this is being careful with regard to bliss. To consider that phenomena are permanent, and that they are therefore associated with happiness, constitute a self, and are not empty, would be careless, but bodhisattvas have unmistakenly realized that phenomena are impermanent and so on. This is wisdom—being careful with regard to phenomena. In these respects, they are bodhisattvas who are careful in properly keeping in mind the teachings of the Great Vehicle. This is a praise from the point of view of the qualities of practicing the six transcendent perfections in someone who is careful.
ma gus ngo tsha nyes chung ngo tsha dang / / mi bzod ngo tsha yongs nyams ngo tsha dang / / rnam 'phro ngo tsha lta chung ngo tsha dang / / theg gzhan ngo tsha byang chub sems dpa' yin/ /

One who is ashamed of showing disrespect, ashamed of the slightest fault, Ashamed of not being patient, ashamed of failing, Ashamed of distraction, and ashamed of lower views Is a bodhisattva who is ashamed of other vehicles. (XX, 71)

slong ba byung yang sbyin pa mi byed pa'am bzhin 'gyur zhing gshe ba dang bcas nas ma gus par sbyin pa la ngo tsha ba ste 'jig rten na yang phyug po dag la slong ba byung na cung zad mi sbyin cing gshe bar byed pa ni ngo tsha ba yin la byang chub sems dpa' ni snying rjes gzhan don du dngos po thams cad gtong bar khas len pa yin pas slong ba byung na mi dga' zhing rgud de 'dug pa ni byang chub sems dpa'i cha ma yin pas ngo tsha'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams bcas pa dang rang bzhin gyi kha na ma tho ba chung ngu la yang 'jigs par blta zhing 'dzem pa yin pas nyes pa chung du byung ba la yang ngo tsha ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' ni gnod pa dang sdug bsngal thams cad bzod par byed pa yin pas gzhan gyis gnod pa byas pa la mi bzod cing rgyud 'khrugs na ngo tsha ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' rnams brtson 'grus rlabs po che rgyun mi 'chad par rtsom pa yin na dge ba'i chos bsgrub pa las yongs su nyams nas le lo byed pa ni ngo tsha ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' rnams snyoms 'jug dang ting nge 'dzin tshad med pa'i sems kyis dbang 'thob par byed pa yin na lus 'du 'dzi'i khrod du gnas te sems phyi rol gyi yul la rnam par 'phro zhing g.yeng ba la gnas pa ni ngo tsha'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams rang bzhin gyis shes rab dang ldan zhing theg pa chen po'i chos las bstan pa'i bdag med gnyis rtogs pa'i shes rab can yin na/ lta ba chung ngu gang zag gi bdag med pa tsam dang / chos la mtshan mar lta ba dang ma bral na ngo tsha ba dang ldan pa yin pas/ theg pa gzhan nyan rang gi theg par mi 'jug cing bsgrub pa la ngo tsha ba'i byang chub sems dpa' yin no/ / 'dis theg pa gzhan mi 'dod pa'i cha nas bsngags pa'o/ /

Bodhisattvas would be ashamed to not give when beggars appear, or to give disrespectfully, scowling and abusing them. In ordinary life, when beggars ask rich people for alms, the latter abuse them and do not even give them anything. How shameful! But bodhisattvas, out of compassion, are committed to giving away everything for the sake of others, and so it would be shameful and out of character for them to be displeased and reproachful when they are asked for alms. Bodhisattvas view fearfully, and shy away from, the smallest shameful deeds (those that are naturally shameful and those that violate edicts), so they are ashamed of even the smallest faults occurring. They patiently put up with all harm and suffering, so they are ashamed if they fail to be patient and let their minds be perturbed when others harm them. If a bodhisattva is someone who is diligent, continuously undertaking great waves of activities, then it is shameful when they founder from their practice of virtue and succumb to laziness. Bodhisattvas are beings who gain mastery of the mind in boundless meditative absorptions and concentrations, so it is shameful for them to remain physically distracted in the midst of frivolous entertainments and to stay mentally distracted, their minds occupied with outer objects. Since bodhisattvas are beings who naturally possess wisdom and have the wisdom that has realized the two kinds of no-self taught in the teachings of the Great Vehicle, they are ashamed if they have realized only the lower view of the individual no-self and are not free of the view of attributes in phenomena. So they do not engage in other vehicles, the vehicles of the listeners and solitary realizers. They are bodhisattvas who are ashamed of practicing other vehicles. This is a praise from the point of view of their having no desire for other vehicles.
'di dang pha rol dang ni btang snyoms dang / / 'du byed ldan dang dbang 'byor nyid thob dang / / mtshungs par ston dang 'bras bu chen po yis/ / byang chub sems dpa' phan 'dogs byed la 'jug /
For now and the hereafter, through equanimity, Application, attainment of mastery, Appropriate teaching, and the great result, Bodhisattvas engage in benefiting beings. (XX, 72)

de ltar phar phyin bsgrub pa de thams cad gzhan don gtso bor byed pa'i sgo nas gzhan la phan 'dogs pa yin pa'i yon tan gyi sgo nas bsngags pa'o/ / sbyin pas brel phongs rnams la longs spyod byin pas tshe 'di la phan 'dogs pa dang sbyin pa sogs kyis bsdus te tshul khrims la bkod pas/ 'jig rten pha rol du phan 'dogs pa dang / bzod pas rgyud mi 'khrugs shing gnod lan mi byed par btang snyoms su 'jog pa'i sgo nas sems can la phan 'dogs pa dang / gzhan gyi bya ba la grogs byed pa'i brtson pa'am 'du byed dang ldan pas phan 'dogs pa dang / bsam gtan gyis mngon shes sogs kyi yon tan la dbang 'byor pa nyid thob pa'i sgo nas gzhan la phan 'dogs pa dang / shes rab kyis rig pa'i gnas lnga dang / khyad par nang rig pa theg pa gsum gyi chos thams cad gang la gang mos pa de bzhin mtshungs par ston pa'i sgo nas phan 'dogs pa dang / de ltar phar phyin bsgrub pa'i 'bras bu chen po sangs rgyas nyid thob pa yis/ sems can rnams la nam mkha' ji srid du phan 'dogs pa yin pas de ltar rgyu dang 'bras bu'i sgo nas byang chub sems dpa' rnams sems can thams cad la phan 'dogs par byed pa la 'jug pa yin no/ / blo brtan 'grel par tshigs bcad 'di gong ma rnams kyi don mdor bsdus te bstan par bzhed do/ /

There now follows a praise in terms of the qualities of those who benefit others by means of all these practices of the transcendent perfections, giving priority to others’ welfare. By generously giving their possessions to the poor, they benefit them in this life; attracting them with gifts and the like, they introduce them to discipline, thereby benefiting them in the next world. By patiently remaining even-minded, instead of letting their minds be perturbed and retaliating when hurt, they bring benefit to sentient beings. Because of their diligence or application in helping others with their tasks, they benefit them. By acquiring mastery, through concentration, in such qualities as preternatural knowledge, they benefit others. By using their wisdom to teach the five sciences, and especially all the teachings of the three vehicles that make up the inner science of Buddhist teachings, in accordance with beings’ inclinations, they benefit them. And by attaining buddhahood, which is the great result of practicing the transcendent perfections in this way, they benefit sentient beings for as long as space exists. So it is by means of these causal factors and their result that bodhisattvas engage in bringing benefit to all sentient beings. Sthiramati’s commentary explains that this verse summarizes the meaning of the previous verses.
gnyis pa byang chub sems dpa'i mtshan gyi rnam grangs bstan pa ni/
(2) AN INDICATION OF THE DIFFERENT NAMES OF A BODHISATTVA

'di dag kyang yon tan gyi sgo nas don dang mthun pa'i ming yin pas yon tan gyi rnam grangs su yang 'gro'o/ /de la byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi spyi yi ming du byang chub sems dpa' la sogs pa rnam grangs bcu drug po 'di ltar bsgrags so/ /

These are names whose meanings correspond to bodhisattvas’ qualities, so they also serve as enumerations of their qualities. This section thus proclaims sixteen different names—Hero of Enlightenment, and so on—as general names for all bodhisattvas.
byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' che/ / blo ldan nyid dang gsal ba'i mchog / rgyal sras rgyal ba'i gzhi dang ni/ / rgyal byed rgyal ba'i myu gu dang / /
Hero of Enlightenment, Great Hero, Wise One, Supremely Brilliant One, Child of the Buddhas, Foundation of the Victorious Ones, Victor, Sprout of the Victors; (XX, 73)
zhes pas bstan te/

bdag med gnyis kyi rang bzhin shes bya zab mo la sems gcig tu dad pas byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya la/ yang na bla na med pa'i byang chub bsgrub pa la bsam pa brtan pas byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ / sems dpa' chen po ni mthu chen po la mnga' dbang 'byor ba ste ba spu'i bu ga gcig tu'ang stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams 'byung ba dang 'jig pa'i bskal pa ston pa la sogs pa'o/ / yang na bdag bla med byang chub thob par 'dod pa'i byang chub sems dpa' dang / sems can thams cad 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal las bsgral nas mya ngan las 'das pa la bzhag par 'dod pas sems dpa' chen po zhes dang / yang na shes rab chen pos 'khor bar gnas kyang 'khor ba'i nyes pas ma gos pa'i cha nas byang chub sems dpa' dang / snying rje chen pos sems can gyi don du brtson 'grus mtha' thug pa med pa rtsom pas sems dpa' chen po zhes bya'o/ /

Because they have single-minded faith in the profound knowledge of the two kinds of no-self, they are known as Heroes of Enlightenment.[30] Alternatively, it is because of their steadfast intention to accomplish unsurpassable enlightenment that they are called Heroes of Enlightenment. “Great Heroes”[31] designates those who have mastered great magical powers, such as displaying in a single pore of their bodies a kalpa of formation and destruction of a third-order great universal system of one thousand million worlds. Alternatively, because they wish to attain unsurpassable enlightenment themselves, they are called Heroes of Enlightenment, and because they wish to liberate all sentient beings from the sufferings of saṃsāra and set them in nirvāṇa, they are called Great Heroes. Again, from the point of view of their being, on account of their great wisdom, untainted by the faults of saṃsāra even while staying in saṃsāra, they are Heroes of Enlightenment; and because, through their great compassion, they strive endlessly for the welfare of sentient beings, they are referred to as Great Heroes.

yang na bla med byang chub bsgrub par sems bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' dang / de yang chen po bdun dang ldan pa gong du bshad pa lta bu dang ldan pas sems dpa' chen po'o/ / tshul de dag ltar na ldog pas dbye ba tsam las byang chub sems dpa' dang / sems dpa' chen po gnyis ka byang chub sems dpa' spyi'i ming du 'gyur ba la khyad med do/ / yang sa dang sa la ltos nas snga ma snga ma byang chub sems dpa' dang / phyi ma phyi ma rnams sems dpa' chen po dang / mos spyod du sems bskyed pa byang chub sems dpa' dang / 'phags pa sa thob pa rnams byang chub sems dpa' chen po dang / ma dag sa bdun pa rnams byang chub sems dpa' dang / dag pa'i sa la gnas pa rnams sems dpa' chen po'o/ / gang ltar kyang bla med byang chub kyi rgyu bsgrub par dka' ba phar phyin rnams tshad med pa bsgrub pa dang / 'bras bu thob par dka' ba bla med byang chub thob par byed pa la snying stobs zhum pa med pas byang chub sems dpa' zhes btags pa yin no/ /

And again, those who have aroused the mind intent on accomplishing unsurpassable enlightenment are Heroes of Enlightenment, and those who possess that which has the seven forms of greatness as explained above are Great Heroes.[32] Apart from these comparative distinctions, there is no difference between a Hero of Enlightenment and a Great Hero, both being general names for a bodhisattva. From the point of view of different levels, those on the earlier levels are Heroes of Enlightenment and those on the later ones are Great Heroes. Those on the level of earnest aspiration, who have aroused the mind intent on enlightenment, are Heroes of Enlightenment, while those who have attained the noble levels are Great Heroes of Enlightenment. Those on the seven impure levels are Heroes of Enlightenment, while those dwelling on the pure levels are Great Heroes. Whichever the case, it is because they are courageous and undaunted in practicing boundless transcendent perfections, the causes of unsurpassable enlightenment that are so difficult to practice, and in attaining unsurpassable enlightenment, the result that is so difficult to attain, that they are called Heroes of Enlightenment.

zab cing rgya che ba'i shes rab kyi blo dang ldan pas blo ldan dang / zab mo'i don gyi dgongs pa 'grel zhing phyogs bcur chos kyi snang ba 'gyed pas gsal ba'i mchog gam gzi brjid mchog ces bya'o/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i gdung rgyun mi 'chad par 'dzin cing sangs rgyas kyi rigs su skyes pas rgyal ba'i sras zhes bya'o/ /

Because they possess the intelligence that is the wisdom of the profound and extensive, they are called The Wise. And because they elucidate the intended meaning of the profound teachings and spread the light of the teachings in the ten directions, they are called The Supremely Brilliant or The Supremely Resplendent. Since they hold the lineage of the tathāgatas uninterruptedly and have been born in the family of the buddhas, they are known as Children of the Buddhas.

sangs rgyas nyid du 'gyur ba'i rgyu yin pas rgyal ba'i gzhi zhes bya ba dang ni/ de bzhin du bdag dang gzhan gyi rgyud la yod pa'i nyon mongs pa thams cad las rgyal bar byed pa dang / rgyal ba sangs rgyas kyi chos sku gsum dang stobs dang mi 'jigs pa la sogs pa'i 'dab ma dang me tog dang 'bras bu lta bu rnams kyi rgyur gyur pas rgyal ba'i myu gu dang /

Because they are the causes for becoming buddhas, they are known as The Foundations of the Victorious Ones. Similarly, they are called Victors—victorious over all the defilements present in their own and others’ mind streams. And because they are the causes that grow into the qualities of the victorious buddhas—the three buddha bodies, the strengths, fearlessnesses, and so forth, which are like leaves, flowers, and fruits—they are the Sprouts of the Victorious Ones.
rtsal ldan dang ni 'phags mchog dang / / ded dpon dang ni grags mchog dang / / snying rje can dang bsod nams che/ / dbang phyug de bzhin chos dang ldan/ /
Powerful One, Most Exalted One, Pilot, Supremely Famed One, Compassionate One, One of Great Merit, Mighty Lord, and likewise, Truthful One. (XX, 74)

bdud 'dul zhing ma rig bag chags kyi sa las brgal nus pas dpa' bo gcig pu mthu dang rtsal ldan pa dang ni/ 'jig rten pa thams cad las ngo mtshar mchog tu gyur pas 'phags mchog dang / 'khor ba'i rgya mtshor chud pa rnams mya ngan las 'das pa'i grong khyer du phyin par byed pas ded dpon dang ni/ phyogs bcu'i zhing rab 'byams rnams su yon tan gyi sgra snyan par grags pa la grags pa chen po'am grags pa mchog dang / sems can thams cad yongs su mi gtong ba'i snying rje chen po dang ldan pas thugs rje'am snying rje can dang / sbyin sogs kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba tshad med pa dang ldan pas bsod nams che ba dang / 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i phun sum tshogs pa kun la dbang 'byor bas dbang phyug dang de bzhin du kha na ma tho ba med pa zag pa med pa'i chos dang ldan pa zhes bya'o/ / de ltar mtshan gyi gtso bo yongs su grags pa bcu drug gis mtshan nas 'jigs pa med pa dang / dpa' bo dang brtan pa dang / sems can gyi mchog la sogs pa'i rnam grangs sna tshogs kyis brjod pa yin no/ /

Bodhisattvas are able to subdue demons and cross beyond the land of ignorance and habitual tendencies, so they are singularly courageous Powerful Ones. They are the most marvelous of beings in the world, so they are the Most Exalted Ones. They enable those who have set sail on the ocean of saṃsāra to reach the city of nirvāṇa, so they are Pilots. Because the delightful sound of their qualities resounds throughout the infinite buddha fields in the ten directions, they are Greatly Famed or Supremely Famed Ones. Having the great compassion that never abandons any beings, they are Compassionate Ones. They possess boundless sources of good from their generosity and so forth, and so are Ones of Great Merit. Since they have mastery over everything that is perfect, both mundane and supramundane, they are Mighty Lords. And similarly, being free of shameful deeds and untainted, they are called Truthful Ones. Thus, beginning with these sixteen names, which are the main ones and the most widely known, bodhisattvas are described by all kinds of synonyms, including the fearless, heroes, the steadfast, chiefs among beings, and so on.
gnyis pa byang chub kyi rgyu dang 'bras bu rtogs pa'i cha nas byang chub sems dpa'i sgra don dang mthun par bsngags pa'i yon tan
ii. THE QUALITIES THAT ARE PRAISED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THE WORD “BODHISATTVA” FROM THE POINT OF VIEW OF THEIR REALIZATION OF THE RESULT, ENLIGHTENMENT
['di] la dngos dang / de'i dbye ba gnyis las
This topic has two parts: (1) the actual praise and (2) categories. The former is indicated by five verses.
dang po/
(1) THE ACTUAL PRAISE
de nyid bzang rtogs don chen legs rtogs dang / / don kun rtogs dang kun tu rtogs pa dang / / thabs rnams rtogs par 'gyur ba'i khyad par rgyu/ / des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ /

Because of five particularities—their excellent realization of thatness, Their perfect realization of the great goal, their realization of everything, Their constant realization, and their realization of means— They are called bodhisattvas. (XX, 75)
zhes pas bstan te/

chos dang gang zag la bdag med par rtogs pas de nyid bzang po rtogs pa dang / bdag dang gzhan gyi don chen po 'grub par bya ba rtogs pas don chen po legs par rtogs pa/ 'dus byas dang 'dus ma byas zag bcas dang zag med kyis bsdus pa'i shes bya'i don thams cad kun nas rtogs pa dang / bar 'ga' rtogs kyang nam zhig zad par 'gyur ba ma yin par phung po lhag med kyi dbyings su yang mkhyen pa mi mdzad pas/ rtag par dus kun tu rtogs pa dang / gdul bya 'dul ba la sprul pa ci lta bu dang chos ji lta bu bstan pa sogs gdul ba'i thabs mtha' yas pa'i thabs rnams mtha' dag rtogs par 'gyur ba'i yon tan lnga po de yis khyad par du gyur pa'i rgyu mtshan des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya ste/ / bo d+hi ni khong du chud pa'i don dang / sa twa ni sems dang ldan pa'i don gyis ci zhig sems shing khong du chud pa'i nges tshig dang mthun pa'i yon tan bsngags pa 'di ni spyir bstan pa'o/ /

Because they realize[33] that there is no self in phenomena and individuals, they have excellent realization of thatness. Since they realize what they have to accomplish—their own and others’ great goal—they have perfect realization of the great goal. They have complete realization of all knowable objects—compounded and uncompounded, tainted and untainted. Their knowledge, rather than being realized for a while and then one day being spent, does not come to an end in the expanse without residual aggregates, so their realization is constant and eternal. And they realize all the skillful means—the infinite methods for training beings, such as what manifestations to display and what teachings to give in order to train them. Because of their superiority on account of these five qualities, they are called bodhisattvas. Bodhi indicates complete understanding and mastery, and sattva means “possessing the mind,” so a bodhisattva is someone who considers and realizes something. This praise of the qualities based on the etymological definition of the word “bodhisattva” is a general explanation.
gzhan yang rtogs pa'i rnam grangs bzhi ste/
There are four further aspects of their realization, as follows.
bdag rjes rtogs dang lta ba phra rtogs dang / / rnam rig sna tshogs rnam par rtogs dang kun/ / yang dag min rtog yin par rtogs pa'i rgyu/ / des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ /

Because of their subsequent realization of the self, Realization of subtle views, realization of the various consciousnesses, And realization of all as being false imagination, They are called bodhisattvas. (XX, 76)

sems dang yid dang rnam shes gsum las sems ni sa bon thams cad pa kun gzhi'i rnam par shes pa las snod dang don yul dang / lus kyi snang ba thams cad 'byung bar shes pa'am rtogs pa de ni bdag rjes su rtogs zhes bya ste/ bdag ces bya ba'i dngos po gzhan med de rang rgyud kyi kun gzhi'i rnam shes skad cig rgyun chags pa la nyon yid kyis kha nang du bltas nas bdag tu dmigs pa tsam yin par shes pa dang / yid ces bya ba'i nyon yid de/ des kun gzhi la dmigs nas bdag go zhes 'dzin pa 'khor kun 'gro lnga dang bdag lta bdag chags bdag tu rmongs pa bdag tu nga rgyal ba bzhi dang ldan pa/ dge mi dge lung ma bstan gyi sems kyi gnas skabs kun tu 'gro ba ma bsgrib lung ma bstan de lta bu ji lta bar rtogs pa ni lta ba phra ba rtogs pa zhes bya ste/ 'jig tshogs la lta ba ni lta ba ngan pa dang nyon mongs pa kun gyi rgyu yin pas lta ba'i rtsa ba phra ba de ngos zin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Of the three—mind, mind faculty, and consciousness—mind refers to the consciousness of the ground of all, the one with all the seeds. To know or realize that it is from mind that the place or container, the sense objects, and the appearances of the body all arise is what we call “subsequent realization of the self.” It is to know that there is no other so-called self and that the continuous flow of instants of one’s own ground consciousness is merely imagined as a self by the defiled mind consciousness, looking inward. What we call “mind faculty” is the defiled mind consciousness. Taking the ground of all as its object, it possesses the subjective apprehension of “I,” accompanied by the five omnipresent factors[34] together with four factors—the view of a self, attachment to self, ignorance with regard to a self, and egoistic pride. To realize the nature of this omnipresent, unobscured indeterminate state of the mind, which is virtuous, nonvirtuous, or unspecified, is what we call “the realization of subtle views,” because bodhisattvas have identified the view of the transitory composite, which, since it is the cause of all wrong views and defilements, is the subtle fundamental view.

rnam rig sna tshogs rnam par rtogs dang zhes pa rnam par shes pa tshogs drug gi rang bzhin shes pa ste/ yul dbang yid byed gsum las skyes pa'i mig shes nas yid shes kyi bar drug pos gzugs sogs yul drug la dmigs shing / 'khor sems byung rnams dang bcas te dge mi dge lung ma bstan gsum dang / tshor ba dang ci rigs su ldan pa'i sna tshogs par gyur pa de yi rang bzhin shes pa ni/ rnam rig sna tshogs rnam par rtogs pa zhes bya ba dang / de ltar rnam shes tshogs brgyad po de dag thams cad kun/ gzung 'dzin gnyis su med kyang gzung 'dzin gnyis su rtog pa/ yang dag min pa'i rtog pa gzhan dbang gi rang bzhin tsam sgyu ma dang / rmi lam lta bu yin par rtogs pa'i rgyu mtshan bzhi po des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ /

“Realization of the various consciousnesses” refers to understanding the nature of the six consciousnesses. The six consciousnesses (from the eye consciousness to the mental consciousness), which arise from the object, sense organ, and attentiveness, take as their objects the six sense objects (form and the others) and are associated with the accompanying mental factors—virtuous, nonvirtuous, and unspecified—and whichever feelings may then arise. To recognize the nature of these various aspects of consciousness is what we call “realization of the various consciousnesses.” All these eight consciousnesses dualistically conceive subject and object, even though there is no dualistic existence of subject and object. Bodhisattvas realize that this false imagination is merely the nature of the dependent reality, like an illusion or dream. Because of these four kinds of realization, they are called bodhisattvas.
'di ni kun rdzob kyi snang tshul rtogs pa'i tshul lo/ /
This is the way in which they realize the way things appear in relative truth.
ma rtogs rtogs dang rjes su rtogs pa rtogs/ / dngos med rtogs dang rab tu skye ba rtogs/ / ma rtogs rtogs pa so sor rtogs pa'i rgyu/ / des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ /

Because of their realization of the unrealized, Realization of the subsequent realization, realization of nonsubstantiality, Realization of production, and realization of the unknown, They are called bodhisattvas. (XX, 77)

'jig rten pas sngar ma rtogs pa rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes dmigs pa med pa nam mkha' lta bu so sor rtogs pa ni/ ma rtogs pa rtogs pa dang / rjes las thob pa'i ye shes kyis chos thams cad sgyu ma la sogs pa dang mnyam par rtogs pa de so sor rtogs pa ni/ rjes su rtogs pa rtogs pa'o/ / yang na ma rtogs pa ma rig pa la sogs lugs 'byung gi tshul shes pa ma rtogs pa rtogs pa dang / ma rig pa 'gags na 'du byed 'gag pa sogs rten 'brel lugs ldog shes pa ni rjes su rtogs pa so sor rtogs pa zhes bya'o/ / rang mtshan gyi dngos po med pa kun brtags rtogs pa ni dngos po med pa so sor rtogs pa dang / gzung ba dang 'dzin par snang ba thams cad gzhan dbang skad cig ma'i tshul gyis rab tu 'byung bar shes pa ni/ rab tu skye ba so sor rtogs pa dang / byis pa so so'i skye bo rnams kyis sngar ma shes pa chos nyid gnyis stong yongs grub shes pa ni/ ma shes pa'am ma rtogs pa so sor rtogs pa zhes bya'o/ / de ltar don lnga po de so sor rtogs pa'i rgyu mtshan des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ / 'di yang bden pa gnyis rtogs tshul gyi sgo nas so/ / yang bden gnyis rtogs tshul gyi rnam grangs gzhan lnga ni/

The space-like, nonreferential realization, the nonconceptual gnosis that has not been previously realized by mundane beings, is “realization of the unrealized.” The realization that realizes, with the subsequently attained gnosis, that all phenomena are the same as illusions and so forth is “realization of the subsequent realization.” Alternatively, knowledge of dependent arising in the forward order, starting with nonrealization or ignorance, is realizing what has not been realized; and knowledge of dependent arising in the reverse order—that if ignorance is halted, conditioning factors are halted, and so on—is what we call the realization of the subsequent realization. Realization of the imputed reality, which is devoid of substantial specific characteristics, is “realization of nonsubstantiality.” The knowledge that everything that appears as subject and object arises momentarily from the dependent nature is “realization of production.” And to know the fully present reality, the ultimate reality devoid of duality that was previously unknown by them when they were ordinary, immature beings, is what we call “realization of the unknown (or unrealized).” Because they realize these five objects, they are called bodhisattvas. This is in terms of the way in which they realize the two truths. There are five other ways in which they realize the two truths, as now follows.
don med rtogs dang don dam rtogs pa dang / / don kun rtogs dang mtha' dag don rtogs dang / / rtogs bya rtogs gzhi rtogs pa rtogs pa'i rgyu/ / des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ /

Because of their realization that objects do not exist, Realization of ultimate truth, realization of all objects, Realization of the totality of objects, and realization of the realized, realizer, and realization, They are called bodhisattvas. (XX, 78)

gzhan dbang gi rnam shes las khams gsum gyi gzung 'dzin du snang ba thams cad byung zhing de la zhen pas sdug bsngal rgyun du myong yang / gzung ba dang 'dzin pa'i don du grub pa med par rtogs pa ni don med par rtogs pa dang / gnyis stong gi rang bzhin yongs grub rtogs pa ni don dam rtogs pa dang / gnyis su snang ba thams cad kun brtags pa tsam las med par rtogs pa ni gzung 'dzin du snang ba'i don kun rtogs pa dang / phung khams skye mched sogs ji snyed pas bsdus pa'i chos mtha' dag rtogs pa ni kun rdzob rtogs pa dang / rtogs par bya ba'i yul dang rtogs pa'i gzhi rtogs pa po dang / rtogs pa ste 'khor gsum mi dmigs par rtogs pa ni don dam rtogs pa'o/ / de ltar mtshan nyid gsum dang bden pa gnyis te chos lnga po de dag rtogs pa'i rgyu mtshan des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ /

From the dependent nature or consciousness all the subject-object appearances of the three worlds arise and, as a result of attachment to them, suffering is continuously experienced. However, bodhisattvas realize that they do not exist as subject-object objects.[35] This realization is known as “realization that objects do not exist.” Their realization of the fully present reality, the nature of emptiness that is the absence of duality,[36] is “realization of ultimate truth.” Their realization that all dualistic appearances are none other than mere imputations is the “realization of all objects” that appear as subject and object. Their “realization of the totality” of phenomena included in the multiplicity of aggregates, sense spheres, senses-and-fields, and the rest is realization of relative truth. And their realization without concepts of the three spheres—that is, of the object that is to be realized, of the realizer (the basis of realization), and of realization—is realization of the ultimate truth. Because they have realized these five points—the three realities and the two truths—they are called bodhisattvas.
grub par gyur pa rtogs dang gnas rtogs dang / / lhums rjes rtogs dang rim pa rtogs pa dang / / rab tu rtogs dang the tshom bsal rtogs rgyur/ / des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ /

Because of their realization of the accomplishment, Realization of the abode, realization of the womb, realization of the stages, And realization of bringing about realization and dispelling doubts, They are called bodhisattvas. (XX, 79)

yang rnam grangs lnga shes pas byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya ste/ bla na med pa'i byang chub chen po grub par gyur pa rtogs pa ni 'og min chen por sku gsum mngon du bya ba rtogs pa dang / gnas rtogs pa ni srid pa tha ma pa'i byang sems kyi tshul du dga' ldan gyi gnas su gnas shing lha rnams la phan gdags par bya ba shes pa'o/ / lhums rjes su rtogs pa ni 'dzam bu'i gling du yum gyi lhums su 'jug pa dang der sems can smin par bya ba shes pa dang / rim pa rtogs pa ni lhums nas 'byung ba dang / pho brang gi slas su 'dod yon lnga la longs spyod pa dang / khab nas phyung zhing rab tu 'byung ba dang / dka' ba spyad pa dang / rdo rje'i gdan la sprul pa'i skus mngon par byang chub pa bstan pa shes pa'o/ / sangs rgyas nas sems can thams cad kyi the tshom sel bar byed pa chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba rtogs pa yi rgyu des na byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya'o/ / 'di ni srid pa tha ma pa'i byang chub sems dpas 'og min du longs sku'i rten la byang chub chen po mngon du mdzad nas sprul pa'i skus 'dzam bu'i gling du byang chub chen po ston pa'i tshul mkhyen pa'i cha nas bstan pa'o/ /

There are five more kinds of knowledge for which they are called bodhisattvas. The “realization of the accomplishment” of the unsurpassable great enlightenment refers to realization of the three buddha bodies that must be actualized in the Great Unexcelled.[37] “Realization of the abode” refers to knowing that one must dwell in the Tuṣita realm as a bodhisattva in their final existence and benefit the gods. “Realization of the womb” refers to knowing that one must enter a mother’s womb in Jambudvīpa and bring beings to maturity there. “Realization of the stages” refers to knowing that one will appear from the womb, enjoy the five pleasures of the senses in the retinue of queens at the palace, leave the palace and renounce worldly life, practice austerities, and at Vajrāsana display the attainment of manifest enlightenment as a manifestation-body emanation. And there is the realization that having attained buddhahood, one will turn the wheel of the Dharma that dispels the doubts of all sentient beings. Because of these, one is called a bodhisattva. This verse indicates bodhisattvas’ realization from the point of view of knowing the manner in which a bodhisattva in their final existence, taking support of the body of perfect enjoyment in the Unexcelled, realizes the great enlightenment and then, as a body of manifestation, displays the great enlightenment in Jambudvīpa.
gnyis pa shes pa'i dbye ba bcu gcig gis sgo nas byang chub sems dpar bstan pa ni/
(2) SHOWING THEM TO BE BODHISATTVAS IN TERMS OF ELEVEN CATEGORIES OF KNOWLEDGE
blo dang ldan pa blo thob ma thob dang / / rab gnas rtogs dang rjes su rtogs pa dang / / so sor 'chad blo rjod med nga bcom dang / / nga can blo gros ma smin yang dag smin/ /
zhes pas bstan te/

shes pa'i rnam grangs bcu gcig shes shing rtogs pas kyang byang chub sems dpa' zhes brjod de/ rnam grangs bcu gcig ni/ 'das ma 'ongs da lta gsum dang / nang dang phyi/ rtsing ba dang zhib pa/ tha ma dang bzang po/ nye ba dang ring bar shes pa'o/ / de yang blo dang ldan pa byang chub sems dpa' des 'das pa'i chos shes pa'i/ blo la thob pa'am rnyed pa shes pa zhes bya ste/ 'das pa'i chos de dag sngar rang rang gi dngos po thob zin pa'i phyir ro/ / ma 'ongs pa na 'byung 'gyur gyi chos rtogs pa ni ma thob pa shes pa zhes bya ba chos de dag da lta rang gi dngos por ma grub pa'am ma thob pa'i phyir ro/ / da lta ba'i chos rtogs pa ni rab tu gnas pa zhes bya ste byung nas ma 'gags pa'i phyir ro/ /

It is also on account of their knowing and realizing eleven kinds of knowledge that they are described as bodhisattvas. The eleven categories are past, present, and future; inner and outer; gross and subtle; base and excellent; and proximate and distant. The intelligence of wise bodhisattvas in their knowing past phenomena is referred to as “knowledge that has been obtained (or acquired),” because those past phenomena have already been obtained as such in the past. Their realization of phenomena that will appear in the future is referred to as “knowledge that has not been acquired,” because at present those phenomena do not exist (or have not been obtained) as such. Their realization of present phenomena is referred to as “fully present” because they have arisen and have not yet ceased.

byang chub sems dpa' rang gi blos mi rtag sdug bsngal sogs rtogs pa ni nang shes pa ste nang rang gi blos rtogs pa'i phyir dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen gzhan gyis bstan pa'i rgyu las shes pa ni phyi'i rkyen de'i rjes su rtogs pa dang / chos rnams kyi rang dang spyi'i mtshan nyid so sor 'chad pa'i blo ni ming tshig yi ge la brten pa'i rags pa'o/ / nang du mnyam par bzhag pa'i blo ni ngag tu brjod pa med par rtog med la gnas pa'i zhi ba'o/ /

Bodhisattvas’ own mental realization of impermanence, suffering, and so forth is inner knowledge, because they have realized it within, with their own intelligence. The knowledge that comes from the causal factor of being taught by another person, a spiritual master, is realization consequent on that outer condition. The intelligence used to teach the general and specific characteristics of phenomena is gross, in that it is dependent on names, phrases, and letters. The intelligence related to resting in inner evenness is subtle, in that it remains in a state free of thoughts without verbal expression.

sa bdun pa man chad ngar 'dzin gyi rgyu ba phra mo dang bcas pa'i phyir nga can gyi blo gros te tha mal lam dman pa'o/ / sa brgyad pa yan chad mi rtog pa'i ye shes lhun gyis grub pas ngar 'dzin gyi rgyu ba phra mo yang med pas nga bcom pa'i blo ste bzang po'o/ / yang na nga can mos spyod kyi sa'i rtogs pa ste gzung 'dzin du rtog par ma spangs pa'i phyir ro/ / 'phags pa'i sar gzung 'dzin rtog pa spangs pas nga bcom pa zhes bya'o/ /

Up to the seventh level, bodhisattvas have subtle movements of the belief in a self, and therefore their intelligence with an “I” is ordinary or inferior. From the eighth level onward, on account of their spontaneous nonconceptual gnosis, they are free of even the subtle movements of the belief in a self, and therefore their intelligence, in which the “I” has been destroyed, is excellent. Alternatively, “with an ‘I’ ” can refer to the realization of those on the level of earnest aspiration, because they have not eliminated the concepts of subject and object. Those on the noble levels have eliminated the concepts of subject and object and are therefore referred to as having destroyed the “I.”

blo gros ma smin pa ni/ sa bdun pa man chad kyi blo gros te mi rtog pa'i ye shes 'bad rtsol med par lhun grub tu ma thob pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di ni ring ba'i blo'o/ / sa brgyad pa yan chad kyi blo gros ni yang dag par smin pa zhes bya ste/ rnam par mi rtog ye shes 'bad rtsol mi dgos par lhun gyis grub pa'i phyir 'di ni nye ba'i blo gros te sangs rgyas kyi sa la nye ba'i phyir ro/ / yang na mos spyod kyi sa dang / 'phags pa'i sa la ma smin pa dang smin pa zhes bya'o/ /

Immature intelligence refers to bodhisattvas’ intelligence up to the seventh level, because they have not acquired nonconceptual gnosis spontaneously, without effort. This is distant intelligence. From the eighth level onward, their intelligence is referred to as “truly mature,” because their nonconceptual gnosis is spontaneous and requires no effort. This is proximate intelligence, because they are close to the level of buddhahood. Alternatively, we can speak of “immature” and “mature” for the level of earnest aspiration and the noble levels respectively.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ yon tan gyi le'u ste nyi shu pa'o// //
This completes the twentieth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on qualities.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ yon tan gyi le'u ste nyi shu pa rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the twentieth chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on qualities.
! drug pa blo spyod pa dang mthar thug gi le'u
21. CONDUCT AND CONSUMMATION[1]
'di la/ byang chub sems dpa'i rtags dang / skye ba bzhes pa'i tshul dang / sa thob pa'i tshul dang / mthar thug gi yon tan bstod pa'i sgo nas bstan pa bzhi las/
This chapter is divided into four sections: (1) the signs of a bodhisattva; (2) how bodhisattvas take birth; (3) how they attain the levels; and (4) a praise of the ultimate qualities.
dang po/
1. THE SIGNS OF A BODHISATTVA

brtse dang snyan par smra ba dang / / brtan pa nyid dang lag brkyang nyid/ / dgongs pa zab mo nges 'grel pa/ / 'di dag blo ldan rnams kyi rtags/ / yongs gzung mos pa thob pa dang / / mi skyo gnyis kyis bsdu ba'i phyir/ / bsam pa dang ni sbyor ba las/ rtags lngar rnam par shes par bya/ /

Compassionate, soft-spoken, Steadfast, openhanded, And able to comment on the profound intention— These are the marks of the wise. (XXI, 1) For they are caring, inspire interest, Are not discouraged, and attract in two ways. It should thus be understood there are five signs, Which are related to their intention and application. (XXI, 2)
zhes pas bstan te/ /

du ba'i rtags sam mtshan ma las mer shes pa bzhin du gang byang chub sems dpa' yin pa de la phar phyin drug bsgrub pa dang rjes su mthun pa'i mtshan ma lnga snang bar 'gyur te/ mtshan ma de dag las 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' 'o snyam du shes par gyur nas byang chub sems dpa'i grangs su bgrang bar byed do/ / mtshan ma lnga ni snying brtse ba dang ldan pas sems can yongs su 'dzin pa dang / 'jig rten dang chos gtam legs par snyan par smra ba dang ldan pa dang / gzhan don du 'jigs pa dang sdug bsngal gang gis kyang mi zhum par brtan pa nyid dang / dngos po thams cad sbyin pa la rtag tu bag mi 'khum par lag brkyang ste gtong ba nyid dang / gsung rab kyi dgongs pa nges par 'grel pa dang rnam pa lnga po 'di dag blo ldan byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi rtags yin no/ /

Just as one knows from an indication or sign such as smoke that there is fire, there are five signs that appear in those who are bodhisattvas, consistent with their practicing the six transcendent perfections. From these signs one knows that they are bodhisattvas and can be counted as bodhisattvas. The five signs are that (1) they are full of compassion and thus care for sentient beings; (2) they speak pleasantly and well, both in ordinary conversation and when teaching the Dharma; (3) for others’ sake, they are steadfast and undaunted by danger and suffering; (4) they are always unreservedly openhanded and generous, giving away all they possess; and (5) they can comment definitively on the enlightened intention of the Buddha’s Excellent Speech. These five are the marks of wise bodhisattvas.

de yang snying rjes sems can yongs su gzung ba dang / snyan par smra bas mos pa thob pa dang / brtan pas sdug bsngal gyis mi skyo ba dang / lag brkyang ba dang dgongs zab 'grel pa gnyis kyi sgo nas zang zing dang chos kyis sems can rnams bsdu ba'i phyir na/ dang po bsam pa dang ni phyi ma bzhi sbyor ba yin pa las rtags lngar rnam par shes par bya'o/ /

With their compassion, they take care of beings. Their gentle speech has the effect of inspiring beings to take an interest. On account of their steadfastness, they are not discouraged by suffering. And by being openhanded and elucidating the profound intention, they attract sentient beings with material gifts and the gift of Dharma. The first of these signs relates to intention and the last four relate to application. From these we are to understand that there are five signs.

de la snying rje'i rang bzhin ni bsam pa dang ldan pa dang bsgrub pa dang ldan pa gnyis las/ bsam pa la mi dge ba las bslangs te dge ba la bzhag pa phan pa'i bsam pa/ ngan song gsum sogs kyi sdug bsngal bsal nas mtho ris kyi bde ba la bzhag pa bde ba'i bsam pa'o/ / sgrub pa dang ldan pa ni phan bde'i bsam pa de lta bu la brten nas sgo gsum gyi sgo nas sems can phan bde la 'god pa'o/ / de lta bu dang ldan pa la byang chub sems dpa' snying rje dang ldan pa zhes bya'o/ /

The nature of compassion is twofold, related to intention and to practice. The intention is the intention to bring benefit, raising beings out of nonvirtuous activities and introducing them to virtue, and the intention to bring happiness, dispelling the sufferings of the three lower realms and so on and setting beings in the happiness of the higher realms.
