When they so desire, they can bestow their blessing on a world, transforming it from something small and cramped into something vast and spacious, and from vast and spacious into small and cramped.” And, “They acquire countless hundreds of thousands of doors of perfect liberation such as these ten doors of perfect liberation, and likewise similar numbers of doors of concentration and powers of retention.”

chos kyi sprin 'di la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ni 'jig rten gyi khams gcig na/ dga' ldan gyi pho brang na bzhugs pa nas bzung ste/ 'pho ba dang gshegs pa dang / lhums su zhugs pa dang sogs nas mngon par byang chub pa dang / bskul ba dang chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba dang / yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa chen po'i sa zhes bya ba'i bar du de bzhin gshegs pa'i mdzad pa thams cad sems can rnams kyi bsam pa ji lta ba dang / 'dul ba ji lta ba bzhin du byin gyis brlabs so zhes dang / gzhan yang de mngon du gyur ma thag tu stong gsum brgya stong phrag bcu'i tha gru dang mnyam pa'i rin po che'i pad+mo chen po'i rgyal po las byung ba zhes sogs 'khor los bsgyur ba'i bu thu bo mtshan dang ldan pa gser gyi khri la bzhag nas/ rgyan sna tshogs bkram zhing glu dbyangs rol mo bcas gser gyi bum pas rgya mtsho'i chus spyi bo nas dbang skur na rgyal rigs spyi bo nas dbang bskur ba'i grangs su 'gro ba bzhin du/ byang chub sems dpa' de la'ang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyis 'od zer chen pos dbang skur ma thag tu ye shes kyi dbang mngon par bskur bas dbang bskur ba zhes bya'o/ / des stobs bcu yongs su rdzogs nas yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi grangs su 'gro'o/ /zhes sogs rgya cher gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

“Bodhisattvas dwelling on this Cloud of Dharma bestow their blessing in one world to display all the deeds of a tathāgata according to sentient beings’ aspirations and how they are to be trained—beginning with residence in the Tuṣita heaven, transfer and descent, entrance into the womb, and so on, through to the attainment of manifest enlightenment, exhortation, the turning of the wheel of the Dharma, and the great parinirvāṇa.” And, “As soon as they achieve that,[15] there appears a great jeweled king of lotuses, equal in size to a million trichiliocosms….”[16] “When the eldest son of a universal emperor, bearing the marks of his royal state, is placed on a golden throne, amid all kinds of ornamental arrays and to the accompaniment of music and song, and empowered on the crown of his head with water from a golden vase containing water from the oceans, he is counted as having been empowered, crowned as the princely future king. In the same way, as soon as those bodhisattvas are empowered by the buddha bhagavāns with the great rays of light, they are said to have been empowered with the full empowerment of gnosis. Having completely perfected the ten strengths, they are counted as truly perfect buddhas….”
gsum pa sa bcu po rnams su bslab pa gsum la bslab pa rdzogs par byed pa'i tshul ni/
iii. HOW BODHISATTVAS COMPLETE THE TRAINING IN THE THREE TRAININGS ON THE TEN LEVELS

chos nyid rab tu rtogs nas 'dir/ / lhag pa'i tshul khrims lhag sems dang / / lhag pa'i shes rab la rjes slob/ / shes rab spyod yul gnyis yin te/ / chos kyi de nyid dang de ni/ / mi shes shes sogs 'jug pa nyid/ / shes rab spyod yul de lta bas/ / de sa gnyis la rnam par gnas/ / bslab pa rnams dang bsgom pa yis/ / 'bras bu gzhan ni rnam pa bzhi/ / mtshan med 'du byed dang bcas par/ / gnas pa 'bras bu dang po yin/ / de nyid mngon 'du byed med dang / / zhing ni rnam par dag pa dag / 'bras bu gnyis par 'dod pa yin/ / sems can smin par 'grub nyid dang / / ting nge 'dzin dang gzungs rnams ni/ / 'grub pa 'bras bu dam pa yin/ / 'bras bu rnam pa 'di bzhi ni/ / sa bzhi po la yang dag brten/ /

After truly realizing ultimate reality, They train here in superior discipline, Superior mind, and superior wisdom. The object of wisdom is twofold: (XXI, 17) The suchness of phenomena, and the processes That operate from not knowing and knowing that suchness. These are the objects of wisdom On which they dwell on the two levels. (XXI, 18) Training and meditating Leads to four further results: Dwelling in the absence of attributes With deliberate effort is the first result. (XXI, 19) Doing the same without deliberate effort And purifying everything as a buddha field Is the second result. Then there is the accomplishment of maturing beings, (XXI, 20) And the accomplishment of concentrations and powers of retention, Which constitutes the supreme result. These four results Are directly related to the four levels. (XXI, 21)
ces pas bstan te/

sa dang po chos nyid kyi bden pa mngon sum rtogs pa ni bslab pa thams cad dag par byed pa'i gzhi rten no/ / de nas sa gzhan gyi skabs 'dir sa gnyis pa la lhag pa'i tshul khrims kyi bslab pa la slob par byed de/ rmi lam du yang 'chal ba'i tshul khrims kyi rnam pa mi rmis na dngos su lta ci smos so/ / de ltar tshul khrims shin tu rnam par dag pa yin no/ / sa gsum pa lhag pa sems kyi bslab pa la slob ste bsam gtan dang ting nge 'dzin nyams pa med pa thob pas so/ /

The direct realization on the first level of the truth of ultimate reality is the foundation for rendering all the trainings pure. After that, “here” (meaning at the time of the other levels), on the second level, bodhisattvas train in the training of superior discipline. Even in their dreams they never break their vows, so one need hardly mention their ever actually doing so. Thus their discipline is of the purest kind. Those on the third level train in the training in superior concentration, attaining the dhyānas and unfailing concentration.

sa bzhi pa dang lnga pa dang drug pa gsum la lhag pa'i shes rab la gtso bor slob ste/ bzhi par byang phyogs so bdun bsgoms pa'i shes rab khyad par can dang / byang phyogs bsgom pa'i shes rab kyi spyod yul de yang rnam pa gnyis yin te/ chos kyi de bzhin nyid dang 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi la sa lnga par slob pa dang / sa drug pa de ni rten 'brel gyi don mi shes pa ma rig sogs lugs 'byung dang / shes pa ye shes kyi stobs kyis ma rig pa 'gags par 'du byed 'gag pa sogs lugs las bzlog pa'i don la shes rab kyis tshul bzhin 'jug pa nyid de/ shes rab kyi spyod yul bden bzhi dang rten 'brel bcu gnyis yin pa de lta bas na/ de gnyis ni sa lnga pa dang drug pa gnyis la rnam par gnas pa yin no/ /

On the fourth, fifth, and sixth levels, they train mainly in the training of superior wisdom. On the fourth level there is the extraordinary wisdom that comes from practicing the thirty-seven elements leading to enlightenment. The object of that wisdom that comes from practicing the elements leading to enlightenment has two aspects. The object on which bodhisattvas train on the fifth level comprises the suchness of phenomena and the four noble truths. On the sixth level, their object is the manner or process by which not knowing suchness (referring to dependent arising) results in the forward order of dependent arising, starting from ignorance, while knowing it with wisdom results in the reverse order, in which the power of gnosis brings about the halting of ignorance and leads to the halting of conditioning factors and so on. The two objects of their wisdom, then, are the four truths and the twelve links of dependent arising, so it is on these two that bodhisattvas dwell on the fifth and sixth levels.

rjes thob tu bslab pa rnams la slob pa dang mnyam bzhag tu mi rtog ye shes bsgom pa yis/ 'bras bu gzhan ni rnam pa bzhi ste/ mtshan ma med pa la gnas kyang 'du byed dang bcas par gnas pa sa bdun pa ni 'bras bu dang po yin no/ / mtshan ma med pa de nyid mngon par 'du byed pa med par lhun gyis grub pa dang sangs rgyas kyi zhing rnam par dag par sbyong ba sa brgyad pa ni 'bras bu gnyis par 'dod pa yin no/ / sa dgu par so so yang dag rig pa bzhis chos bstan pas sems can smin par byed pa 'grub pa nyid ni 'bras bu gsum pa'o/ / ting nge 'dzin dang gzungs rnams kyi mchog ni 'grub pa sa bcu pa ni 'bras bu bzhi pa ste sa kun gyi rtse mor gyur pa'i 'bras bu dam pa yin no/ / de ltar 'bras bu rnam pa 'di bzhi ni/ sa bdun pa nas bcu pa'i bar gyis bzhi po la yang dag pa brten pa yin no/ /

In the postmeditation period, they train in these trainings, and during formal meditation they train in nonconceptual gnosis, and these lead to four further results. Their dwelling in the absence of attributes, albeit with deliberate effort, on the seventh level is the first result. Spontaneous absence of attributes without deliberate effort and purifying everything as a buddha field on the eighth level is held to be the second result. On the ninth level, bodhisattvas teach the Dharma by means of the four kinds of perfect knowledge and thereby accomplish bringing sentient beings to maturity, which constitutes the third result. Accomplishing the highest concentration and powers of retention corresponds to the tenth level, the fourth result. This is the supreme result, the summit of all the levels. These four results are thus directly related to four levels, from the seventh to the tenth.
bzhi pa zag pa med pa'i phung po lnga sa rnams su ji ltar sbyong ba'i tshul ni/
iv. HOW THE FIVE UNTAINTED AGGREGATES ARE PURIFIED ON THE LEVELS

chos nyid rab tu rtogs nas 'dir/ / tshul khrims kyi ni phung po sbyong / / de yi 'og tu ting 'dzin dang / / shes rab phung po rnam par sbyong / / de las gzhan pa dag la ni/ / sgrib rnam bzhi dang thogs pa yi/ / sgrib pa las kyang rnam grol dang / / grol ba'i ye shes rnam par sbyong / /

Having truly realized ultimate reality, Here, they purify the aggregate of discipline, After which they purify the aggregates Of concentration and wisdom. (XXI, 22) On the other levels They purify liberation from four obscurations And the gnosis of liberation From even the impeding obscurations. (XXI, 23)
zhes pas bstan te/

sa dang por chos nyid rab tu rtogs pa na zag med kyi phung po kun gyi rten yin pas de ltar rtogs par byas nas 'dir/ sa gnyis par tshul khrims kyi phung po rnam par dag par sbyong ngo / / sa gnyis pa de yi 'og tu sa gsum par ting nge 'dzin dang / bzhi pa lnga pa drug pa gsum la shes rab kyi phung po rnam par sbyong ba gong bzhin no/ /

The perfect realization of ultimate reality on the first level is the support for all the untainted aggregates, so having achieved such realization, here, on the second level, bodhisattvas train in purifying the aggregate of discipline. After the second level, on the third level they train in purifying the aggregate of concentration, and on the fourth, fifth, and sixth levels they train in purifying the aggregate of wisdom, as above.

sa de dag las gzhan pa sa bdun pa brgyad pa dgu pa bcu pa bzhi po dag la ni/ sgrib pa rnam pa bzhi las grol ba'i rnam par grol ba'i phung po sbyong ste/ sa bdun pa la sogs pa bzhi po la mtshan ma med pa dang / 'du byed med pa dang / sems can smin par byed pa dang / gzungs ting 'dzin thob pa 'bras bu rnam pa bzhi bshad ma thag pa de lta bu thob pa la gegs su gyur pa ni mtshan ma phra mo 'byung ba dang / 'bad rtsol dang / sems can smin par byed pa'i yang dag rig pa ma thob pa dang / gzungs dang ting nge 'dzin la dbang ma thob pa bzhi po/ rim pa ltar sa bdun pa sogs bzhi po thob pa na/ mi mthun phyogs sgrib pa de dag las rnam par grol nas mtshan ma phra mo yang mi 'byung ba sogs yin pas de bzhi rnam par grol ba'i phung po sbyong ba dang / sangs rgyas kyi sa rdor ting bar chad med lam gyis shes bya'i sgrib pa phra ba gnyis snang 'khrul pa'i bag chags bcom pas/ shes bya'i chos thams cad la thogs pa'i sgrib pa las kyang rnam par grol ba'i phyir/ rnam par grol ba'i ye shes kyi phung po rnam par sbyong ba yin no/ / de ltar sa bdun pa nas bcu pa'i bar du rnam grol gyi phung po dang / sangs rgyas kyi sa la rnam par grol ba'i ye shes kyi phung po rnam par sbyong bar bzhag go /

On the four further levels (namely, the seventh, eighth, ninth, and tenth levels), they purify the aggregate of perfect liberation—that is, liberation from four kinds of obscuration. On these four levels, beginning with the seventh, they obtain the four results as have just been explained—the absence of attributes, the absence of deliberate effort, the maturation of beings, and the acquisition of powers of retention and concentration. The four hindrances to their obtaining these are the arising of subtle attributes, efforts, failure to acquire the perfect knowledge for bringing sentient beings to maturity, and failure to acquire mastery in powers of retention and concentration. As they attain the four levels, beginning with the seventh, in order, they are liberated from these obscuring counteragents, so that even the most subtle attributes do not arise, and thus they purify the aggregate of perfect liberation of these four. And on the level of buddhahood, the vajra-like concentration, the path without obstacles, destroys the most subtle cognitive obscurations, the habitual tendencies of deluded dualistic perception, so that they are completely freed even from the impeding factors that obscure their knowing the totality of knowable phenomena, and they thereby purify the aggregate of the gnosis of perfect liberation. This verse thus presents the purification of the aggregate of perfect liberation on the seventh to tenth levels and the purification of the aggregate of the gnosis of perfect liberation on the level of buddhahood.

rnam par grol ba ni sgrib pa spangs pa'i brtags 'gog 'dus ma byas yin na de phung por ji ltar bzhag rigs zhes brgal ba la bi muk+ti zhes pa rnam par grol ba ste/ sgra 'di spangs pa dang / mos pa'i mtshan nyid gnyis la 'jug pas skabs 'dir mos pa la 'jug pas de nyid phung por bzhag pa yin no zhes 'grel par gsungs/ 'du byed 'jug pa thams cad las rnam par grol yang / ye shes bya rtsol med pa lhun gyis grub pa yod pas spang bya zad pa'i med dgag chad stong dang mi 'dra bas sgrib pa las grol ba'i ye shes nyid kyis spangs pa'i yon tan gyi cha nas phung por rung ngo / /

One might argue that if perfect liberation, the analytical cessation that corresponds to the elimination of obscurations, is uncompounded, how can it be classified as an aggregate? In reply to this objection, the commentary states that the Sanskrit term for perfect liberation, vimukti, can refer to both elimination and inclination, and that in this context it refers to inclination, so it is classified as an aggregate. Even though one is completely freed of all deliberate application, the spontaneous, effortless gnosis is present, so this is not like a nonaffirming nihilistic emptiness in which the factors to be eliminated have been exhausted. It is from the point of view of the presence of the qualities of elimination of that gnosis, freed of obscurations, that perfect liberation can be thought of as an aggregate.
lnga pa yon tan grub pa dang ma grub pa'i tshul rnam par bzhag pa ni/
v. HOW QUALITIES ARE ACCOMPLISHED AND NOT ACCOMPLISHED
sa rnams thams cad ma grub dang / / grub pa dag tu shes par bya/ / grub pa dag kyang ma grub dang / / grub pa dag tu yang 'dod do/ /
All the levels should be understood As levels of nonaccomplishment and accomplishment. And those of accomplishment are again held to be Levels of nonaccomplishment and accomplishment. (XXI, 24)
ces pas bstan te/

mos spyod kyi sa dang sa bcu ste bcu gcig yod pa'i sa rnams thams cad ni/ ma grub pa dang grub pa yis gnyis su 'du bar shes par bya ste/ gang zhe na mos spyod kyi sa la ni sa yi ming btags kyi 'phags pa'i sar ma chud pas sa ma grub pa'am/ ma grub pa'i sa zhes bya ste chos kyi dbyings kun tu 'gro ba'i mtshan nyid ma rtogs pas bden pa mthong bar ma grub pa'i phyir ro/ / sa dang po yan chad grub pa dag tu bshad par bya ste/ chos nyid kyi bden pa mthong bas 'jig rten las 'das pa'i 'phags pa nyid du grub cing sa so so'i rtogs bya yang mngon du byas nas grub pa'i phyir ro/ / grub pa sa bcu po de dag kyang yon tan che chung la ltos nas ma grub pa dang grub pa dag tu yang 'dod de/ ma dag sa bdun rnams 'bad rtsol dang bcas pas mtshan ma med pa'i rnal 'byor lhun gyis grub pa yin pa'i ma grub pa dang / dag pa'i sa gsum ni mtshan med kyi rnal 'byor rtsol med lhun gyis grub pa'i phyir grub pa yi sa zhes bya'o/ /

All the eleven levels—the level of earnest aspiration and the ten levels—are to be understood as including both nonaccomplishment and accomplishment. How is that? Even though the level of earnest aspiration is called a level, it is not included in the noble levels, and so it is referred to as a level of nonaccomplishment, because bodhisattvas on that level have not realized the nature of the all-pervasive expanse of reality and have not therefore accomplished seeing the truth. The levels from the first level onward are to be understood as being levels of accomplishment, because bodhisattvas have seen the truth of ultimate reality, and they have therefore accomplished the supramundane state of noble beings and have also realized and accomplished the qualities that have to be realized on each of the respective levels. These ten levels are also held to be levels of nonaccomplishment and of accomplishment from the point of view of their greater and lesser qualities. The seven impure levels, on which the yoga of absence of attributes involves effort and is therefore not spontaneous, are levels of nonaccomplishment. And the three pure levels, on which the yoga of absence of attributes is effortless and spontaneous, are referred to as levels of accomplishment.
grub pa ji ltar rnam bzhag bzhin/ / yid la byed pas de rtog par/ / shes pa'i phyir dang de nyid la/ / rnam mi rtog phyir rnam shes bya/ /
Their accomplishment is to be understood from Keeping the system in mind, From knowing that it is all thought, And from nonconceptuality with regard to that. (XXI, 25)

'phags pa'i sa dang sa de dag grub pa nyid du byed pa ni/ 'di ltar sa re re bzhin du/ sa de'i yon tan gang yin pa dang / sa'i spang bya skyon gang yin pa dang / sa der bsgom par bya ba'i chos gang yin pa ji ltar rnam par bzhag pa bzhin du de sems la gsal bar snang la/ sa gong ma'i yon tan ci lta bu yin pa dang / de thob par byed pa'i chos gang yin pa dag kyang yid la byed pa ni ji ltar rnam par bzhag pa bzhin yid la byed pa zhes bya ste/ dper na sa dang po 'grub par bya ba la/ sa dang po'i yon tan dang des bsgom par bya ba dag kyang yid la byed pa/ sa de la yod pa'i sa gnyis pa 'thob par bya ba'i rgyu'i chos rnams kyang yid la byed pa ni rnam bzhag yid la byed pa'o/ / sa dang po'i yon tan yid byed kyang mdo las kye rgyal ba'i sras dag de la sems can dge ba'i rtsa ba shin tu bsags pa spyad pa/ tshogs shin tu bsags pa la sogs pa zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ / sa dang po pa de sa gnyis pa 'thob par bya ba'i rgyu yid la byed pa ni/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag de ltar byang chub sems dpa' sa dang po la shin tu sbyangs par byas pa de sa gnyis pa la mngon par mos pa yin te de'i sems kyi bsam pa bcu 'byung ngo / / bcu gang zhe na 'di lta ste/ drang po'i bsam pa dang / 'jam pa'i bsam pa dang / las su rung ba'i bsam pa dang / zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs pa bzhin no/ / yang na sa re re'i don rtogs par bya ba'i phyir ming tshig yi ge'i tshogs rnams kyis ji ltar bshad pa sems shing yid la byed pa ni ji ltar rnam bzhag yid la byed pa'o/ /

What is it that enables bodhisattvas to accomplish those noble levels? It is what is known as “keeping the system in mind.” In other words, the system of each level—its qualities, the faults that have to be eliminated on it, and the factors in which the bodhisattva has to train on that level—appear clearly to the mind, and the bodhisattva keeps in mind the qualities of the next level and the factors that enable one to achieve it. For example, with regard to the first level that is to be accomplished, keeping the system in mind involves keeping in mind the qualities of the first level and the factors in which one must train on that level, and keeping in mind the causal factors on that level that will lead to attaining the second level. Keeping in mind the qualities of the first level is also mentioned in the sūtra: “O children of the buddhas, beings who have practiced the intensive accumulation of sources of good, who have intensively gathered the accumulations….” And with regard to how first-level bodhisattvas keep in mind the cause for attaining the second level, we read, “O children of the buddhas, a bodhisattva who has trained thoroughly on the first level and is now bent on attaining the second level has ten mental attitudes. What are these ten? They are the attitudes of straightforwardness, tenderness, workability….” Alternatively, keeping the system in mind involves reflecting on and keeping in mind the points of the respective levels as they have been described with names, phrases, and letters in order to realize them.

de ltar sa ji ltar rnam par bzhag pa yid la byed pas sa 'grub par byed pa de yi tshe na/ sa dang de'i rnam bzhag thams cad rang gi sems nyid de dang der snang ba tsam las gzhan pa'i don du grub pa med pa'i phyir/ sa de dag kyang rang gi rnam par brtag pa'i rtog par shes pa'i phyir gzung ba med pa dang / gzung ba med na 'dzin pa de nyid la yang de ltar grub pa med par shes nas 'dzin par rnam par mi rtog pa'i phyir/ gzung 'dzin med par rnam par shes par bya'o/ / de ltar sa so so'i yid dang de'ang rang sems tsam dang gzung 'dzin med par shes pas sa dang po 'grub pa sogs gzhan kun la yang de ltar bsgom pas so so'i sa grub pa shes par bya'o/ /

When bodhisattvas accomplish a level by keeping the system in mind like this, they recognize that apart from the levels and their arrangements appearing to their respective minds, there is nothing else that exists as an object, and therefore even the levels are their own conceptualized thoughts. Because of this, they understand that there is no apprehended object, and that if there is no object, the subject too must be nonexistent. Subsequently, as a result of their no longer conceptualizing an apprehending subject, they are to understand the absence of subject and object. Thus, by recognizing the mental state corresponding to each level, the fact that it is merely one’s own mind, and that there is no subject or object, bodhisattvas accomplish the first level, and so on—it should be understood that for all the other levels too, each respective level is accomplished by one’s training in this way.
so sor rang rig bya phyir dang / / sangs rgyas rnams kyi yul gyi phyir/ / sa rnams kun la bsgom pa dang / / grub pa yang ni bsam mi khyab/ /
Because they can only be known personally, And because they are the domain of the buddhas, The training and its accomplishment On all the levels are inconceivable. (XXI, 26)

de ltar sa bsgom pa dang grub pa phal pas bsam gyis mi khyab ste/ sa rnams ni 'phags pas de dang de thob pa rnams kyi so so rang gis rig par bya ba yin pa'i phyir dang / sa de dag gi rnam par bzhag pa yang sangs rgyas rnams kyi spyod yul gyi chos yin pa de'i phyir/ sa rnams kun la de dang de bsgom pa dang / bsgom pa mthar phyin te sa grub pa yang ni so skye dang nyan rang rnams kyis bsam gyis mi khyab pa nyid du shes par bya ste/ phal po che las/ ji ltar bar snang gnas kyi bya yi rjes/ / shin tu blta dka' smra ba mi nus pa/ / de bzhin bde gshegs sras kyi sa rnams kyang / / yid dang sems kyi yul gyis shes mi nus/ / zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

Training on the levels and accomplishing them in this manner are something that ordinary folk could never possibly imagine. Because the levels can only be known personally by the noble beings who attain them, and also because the arrangement of those levels is the domain of the buddhas, you should understand that on all the levels, the respective training and the accomplishment of those levels by completing the training are inconceivable to ordinary beings, listeners, and solitary realizers, as is stated in the Sūtra of the Ornament of the Buddhas: Just as the trace of a bird flying through the sky Is extremely hard to see, impossible to describe, So too, the levels of the children of the sugatas Cannot be known by the mind or be an object of the mind.
drug pa sa thob pa'i rtags
vi. THE SIGNS OF ATTAINING THE LEVELS
['di] la rtags dngos dang rtags can sa yi yon tan bshad pa gnyis las
The explanation of these signs is divided into (1) the actual signs and (2) the qualities of the levels that bear those signs.
dang po/
(1) THE ACTUAL SIGNS

snang dang bcas dang mos pa dang / / ma zhum pa dang mi dman nyid/ / gzhan dring mi 'jog bdag nyid dang / / thams cad rab tu rtogs pa dang / / kun la sems ni mnyam pa dang / / bkri dang rjes su chags med dang / / thabs shes 'khor du skye ba ni/ / kun la rtags su 'dod pa yin/ /

They have clear vision and interest, Are undaunted and never weak-minded, Are independent of others, Have understood everything perfectly, (XXI, 27) Are even-minded toward all, Are never influenced, have no attachment, Know the means, and take birth within the retinue— These are considered the signs on all the levels. (XXI, 28)
zhes pas bstan te/

chu skyar las chu dang du ba las mer shes pa ltar/ rtags sam mtshan ma gang gis sa thob par shes pa bshad pa ste/ gong du rtags lnga ni sa thob pa dang ma thob pa'i byang chub sems dpa' spyi'i rtags yin la 'dir ni sa thob pa rnams kyi rtags bcu bshad pa yin no/ /

Just as one recognizes the presence of water from seeing water birds, and fire from seeing smoke, one knows from the corresponding signs or marks that bodhisattvas have attained the levels, as will now be explained. The five signs described above[17] are the general signs of bodhisattvas who have or have not attained the levels, but here it is the ten signs of those who have attained the levels that are described.

sa gang dang gang thob pa de'i spang bya dang blang bya dang bsgom pa'i chos rnams sems la mngon sum du gsal bar snang ba dang bcas pa dang / sa gong ma dag 'thob par bya ba la mos shing 'dod pa ni mtshan ma'am rtags dang po dang /

(1) The first mark or sign is their clear vision of the factors to be eliminated, of those to be adopted, and of the elements to be cultivated on whichever level they have attained, together with an interest and desire to attain the levels above it.
bden pa mthong bas na zab cing rgya che ba'i chos rnams la mi skrag cing ma zhum pa ni gnyis pa dang /
(2) Bodhisattvas have seen the truth, so they are unafraid of and undaunted by the profound and extensive teachings.

tsha grang ngal dub sogs dang mgo dang yan lag gtong ba sogs kyis dka' spyad dang sdug bsngal gyi rnam pa gang la'ang sems mi dman pa nyid kyis skyo ba med pa yongs su ldog pa med pa ni gsum pa dang /

(3) They never turn back and are never discouraged, on account of their irrepressible attitude in the face of such things as heat and cold, exhaustion, and austerities and painful experiences such as giving away their heads and limbs.

tshogs gnyis kyi stobs las rang gi sa nyid rtogs zin kyang sa so so gang dang gang grub pa de la gzhan gyis bstan mi dgos pas de'i rnam bzhag 'chad pa dang don bsgom pa la gzhan gyis dring la mi 'jog pa'i bdag nyid ni bzhi pa dang /

(4) Through the strength of their two accumulations, they have realized their own particular level, and they do not have to rely on others for whatever they have accomplished on their respective level. They are not dependent on others to explain the arrangement of that level and to train in its meaning.

sa dang po thob pa'i dus na yang lhag ma thams cad 'grub pa'i rnam bzhag thams cad rab tu rtogs pa la mkhas pa thob ste/ mnyam bzhag tu rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes la gnas pa'i stobs kyis rjes thob tu dag pa 'jig rten pa'i ye shes kyis sa lhag ma rnams 'grub par 'gyur ba'i thabs shes pa yin pas na sa rang rang gi gong ma dag 'grub par byed pa'i thabs sa dang po pas gnyis par 'jug pa'i thabs drang ba dang 'jam pa sogs bcu dang / gnyis pa sa gsum par 'jug pa'i thabs/ dag pa'i bsam pa dang mi g.yo ba'i bsam pa sogs bcu gsungs pa sogs de bzhin sa kun la sa gong ma 'grub pa'i thabs rnam par bzhag pa la shin tu mkhas pa ni lnga pa dang /

(5) Even at the time they attain the first level, they acquire full proficiency in perfectly understanding all the systems for accomplishing all the remaining levels. On the strength of their dwelling in nonconceptual gnosis in formal meditation, in the postmeditation period they know, through their pure mundane gnosis, the methods for accomplishing the remaining levels. Thus, on all the levels, they are thoroughly proficient in the systems that constitute the means for accomplishing the higher levels, following the teachings on the methods by which each level is accomplished from the one before it—for example, the ten expedients by which first-level bodhisattvas enter the second level (straightforwardness, tenderness, and so on), and the ten expedients by which second-level bodhisattvas enter the third level (pure intention, immovable intention, and so on).
sems can mtha' yas kun la bdag dang tha dad du bya ba med pa'i sems ni mnyam pa thob pa ni drug pa dang /
(6) Bodhisattvas have acquired the attitude of sameness, for which there is no difference between oneself and the whole infinity of sentient beings.

bkri ba med pa ni sar zhugs pa rnams bsod nams kyi tshogs phun sum tshogs pa dang ldan pa dang / ye shes kyi tshogs chos thams cad stong pa nyid du rtogs pas gang la yang chags pa dang sdang ba med pas/ bsngags pa dang bde bas mi 'gying zhing / mi bsngags pa dang sdug bsngal gyis sems zhum pa'am sro shi ba med pas rkyen gang gi dbang du mi 'gyur ba ni drangs pa'am bkri bar byar med pa ni mtshan ma bdun pa dang /

(7) They are never led astray. Bodhisattvas who have entered the levels possess the most perfect and abundant accumulation of merit and, in their accumulation of wisdom, have realized the emptiness of all phenomena. They therefore have no attachment or aversion to anything. So they do not swagger when they are praised or happy, and they do not get depressed or disheartened when they are not praised or are suffering. Never influenced by circumstances, they cannot be drawn or led.

sa la zhugs pa rnams 'jig rten las 'das pa sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa'i 'byor pa phun tshogs dang ldan pas/ tshangs pa dang brgya byin 'khor los sgyur ba sogs kyi longs spyod la yang mi gtsang ba ltar mthong nas rjes su chags pa med pas de dag spangs nas gzhan la gtong ba dang rab tu byung bar byed pa ni brgyad pa dang /

(8) Those who have entered the levels possess the abundant supramundane wealth of the buddhas and bodhisattvas, so they regard even the riches of such beings as Brahmā, Indra, and the universal emperor as being like excrement and have no attachment to them. As a result, they abandon them and give them to others and renounce worldly life.
byang chub bla na med pa 'grub pa'i thabs 'khor gsum du rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes mngon du shes pa ni dgu pa dang /
(9) They know the means for accomplishing unsurpassable enlightenment—namely, the gnosis free of the concepts of the three spheres.

sems can gyi don du smon lam gyi dbang gis sangs rgyas mi bzhugs pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams su skye ba ma gtogs par/ tshe rabs kun tu sangs rgyas kyi 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor du skye ba ni mtshan ma bcu pa ste/

(10) On account of their prayers of aspiration for the sake of sentient beings, unless they take birth in worlds in which no buddha is present, in all their lives they are born in the circle of a buddha’s retinue.

de ltar rtags bcu po 'di ni sa bcu po kun la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' spyi yi rtags su 'dod pa yin no/ / rtags bcu po der ma zad sa re re la yang phar phyin bcu thob pa'i mtshan ma bcu drug 'byung ba ni/

These ten signs are held to be the signs common to bodhisattvas dwelling on all the ten levels. They are not the only signs. There also occur sixteen marks[18] related to achieving the ten transcendent perfections on the corresponding levels.

'dun pa med pa ma yin chags dang 'khu ba'i snying med khro med le lo med/ / byams dang snying rje min pa'i bsam med blo gros ngan rtog rnam rtog 'phrogs pa med/ / blo gros rnam par g.yengs min bde bas mi 'phrogs sdug bsngal dag gis gnod pa med/ / dge ba'i bshes la nye bar brten cing thos pa lhur len ston pa mchod la brtson/ / thabs mchog shes pa gang zhig bsod nams yang dag bsdus pa shin tu rgya chen kun/ / gzhan dang thun mong byas nas nyin gcig bzhin du rdzogs pa'i byang chub yongs bsngo zhing / / bzang po'i gnas su skyes pas rtag tu dge byed mngon shes yon tan rnams kyis rtsen/ / sangs rgyas sras de kun gyi bla na 'dug pa yon tan gter du shes par bya/ /

Never lacking determination, bodhisattvas have no attachment, no hostile feelings, no anger, no laziness, No intentions that are not loving and compassionate, and they are not carried away by wrong understanding and concepts. Their minds are not distracted; they are not carried away by happiness, nor affected by suffering. They follow spiritual masters, devote themselves to listening, and are diligent in making offerings to their teachers. (XXI, 29) They who know the supreme means share with others The vast entirety of the merit they have gathered and dedicate it daily to perfect enlightenment. Born in excellent places, they constantly practice virtue and revel in the qualities of preternatural knowledge. Know that they are treasuries of qualities surpassing all the buddhas’ children. (XXI, 30)

sa kun tu yang pha rol tu phyin pa bcu bsgrub pa la 'dun pa med pa ma yin te/ 'dun pa mchog tu yod pa ni spyir bstan pa'o/ / bye brag tu sa dang por sbyin pa'i phar phyin yongs su dag pa thob pas lus longs spyod la chags pa med pa dang / sa gnyis par tshul khrims rnam par dag pa'i mi dge bcu rmi lam du mi spyod pas gzhan la gnod pa 'khu ba'i snying ngam sems med pa dang / sa gsum par bzod pa'i phar phyin yongs su dag pas khro ba gtan nas med pa dang / sa bzhi par brtson 'grus kyi phar phyin yongs su dag pas le lo med pa dang / sa lnga par bsam gtan gyi phar phyin yongs su dag pa tshad med bzhi lhag par ldan pas byams dang snying rjes min pa'i bsam pa med pa dang / sa drug par shes rab kyi phar phyin yongs su dag pas blo gros ngan pa gtsang bde rtag bdag tu rtog pa lta bu'i ngan pa rtog pa'am phyin ci log gi rtog pa dang dngos zhen gyi rnam rtog gis yongs su 'phrogs pa med pa'o/ / de ltar sa drug dang phar phyin drug sbyar te mtshan ma drug go /

Bodhisattvas never lack the determination to practice the ten transcendent perfections on all the levels. This is a general statement showing that they very much have determination. Specifically, on the first level, bodhisattvas achieve the completely pure transcendent perfection of generosity, so they are free of attachment to their bodies and possessions. On the second level, related to their pure discipline, they do not indulge in the ten negative actions, even in their dreams, so they are free of hostile, injurious feelings or thoughts. On the third level, on account of their completely pure transcendent patience, they never get angry. On the fourth level, their completely pure transcendent diligence results in their never being lazy. On the fifth level, because of their completely pure transcendent concentration, they possess in particular the four boundless attitudes, so they are free of intentions that are not loving and compassionate. On the sixth level, related to their completely pure transcendent wisdom, they are never carried away by wrong or inverted thoughts such as the wrong understanding of purity, happiness, permanence, and a self, or by the concepts of clinging to substantiality. This makes six marks associated with the six levels and six transcendent perfections.

sa bcu po rnams su sbyin pa nas ye shes kyi phar phyin gyi bar de dag shas che bas lhag par brjod kyi sa thams cad du phar phyin bcu char bsgrub pa yod do/ / 'di man chad kyi drug ji ltar bgrang ba'i gsal kha 'grel chen du cher mi snang bas 'grel pa gzhan las brtsi tshul mi 'dra ba 'ga' snang yang /

On the ten levels there are certain transcendent perfections, from generosity to gnosis, that predominate, so these are mentioned in particular, but the ten transcendent perfections are practiced to some degree on all the levels. The numbering of the next six signs does not seem to be clearly explained in the Great Commentary, though several different ways of counting them appear in other commentaries.

sa bdun par thabs mkhas pa'i phar phyin yongs su dag pa thob pas/ nyan rang gi yid kyis rnam par g.yeng ba med pa dang / sa brgyad par stobs kyi phar phyin yongs su dag pa thob pas bde ba la chags pas mi 'phrogs pa dang sdug bsngal dag gis gnod pa med de mnyam pa nyid mi rtog pa'i ye shes lhun gyis grub pa las ma g.yos bzhin du tshangs pa dang brgya byin 'khor los sgyur ba sogs su ston pa dang / lus zhing gi rdul snyed skad cig la btang yang rnam rtog med pa'o/ / sa dgu par smon lam gyi phar phyin gyis/ sangs rgyas byang sems dge ba'i bshes gnyen nye bar bsten cing chos kyi sgo thams cad thos pa lhur len cing phyogs bcu'i zhing mtha' dag gi ston pa sangs rgyas rnams la me tog dang spos la sogs pa mchod pa'i rnam grangs tshad med pas mchod pa byed pa la brtson pa dang /

On the seventh level, bodhisattvas achieve completely pure transcendent skill in means and are therefore not distracted by the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ ways of thinking. On the eighth level, they achieve completely pure transcendent strength, so they are not carried away by attachment to happiness, nor are they affected by suffering. Without moving from the state of evenness, of spontaneous nonconceptual gnosis, they manifest as Brahmā, Indra, universal emperors, and so on, and even though they send out bodies as numerous as the atoms in the universe, they are free of concepts. On the ninth level, through their transcendent aspirations they closely follow the buddhas and bodhisattvas as spiritual masters and devote themselves to listening to all the teachings as entrances to the Dharma. And they are diligent in venerating their teachers, the buddhas in all the buddha fields in the ten directions, with infinite kinds of offerings such as flowers and incense.

sa bdun par 'tshang rgya bar byed pa'i thabs mchog shes pa gang zhig dus gsum du rang gzhan gyis bsags pa'i bsod nams thams cad gcig tu yang dag bsdus pa shin tu rgya chen po kun/ gzhan sems can thams cad dang thun mong du byas nas nyin gcig bzhin du yang bla med rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi phyir yongs su bsngo zhing / smon lam gyi dbang gis bzang po'i gnas su skyes pa dang / stobs kyi phar phyin gyis mi mthun phyogs zil gyis gnon nas rtag tu dge ba 'ba' zhig byed pa de gsum gtso bor sa bdun pa dang dgu pa brgyad pa'i phyogs la sbyar rgyu yin yang / bzang po'i gnas su skyes pa dang rtag tu dge ba byed pa rten gcig la bsdus te gcig tu brtsis pa dang /

On the seventh level, those who know the supreme method that enables one to attain buddhahood dedicate all the merit accumulated by themselves and others in the past, present, and future, all perfectly gathered into one utterly vast whole, and share it with all other sentient beings, also dedicating it daily to unsurpassable perfect enlightenment. By the power of their prayers of aspiration, they are reborn in excellent places.[19] Through their transcendent strength, they overwhelm unfavorable factors and constantly perform exclusively positive actions. Although these three signs are principally associated with the seventh, ninth, and eighth levels respectively, taking birth in excellent places and constantly performing positive actions are included in one support and counted as a single sign.

sa bcu par ye shes kyi pha rol tu phyin pa yongs su dag pas mngon par shes pa'i yon tan rnams kyis rtsen pa ste/ /rdul phra mo gcig gis kyang 'jig rten gyi khams rab 'byams khyab pas chen por ston pa dang / 'jig rten gyi khams rab 'byams dag kyang rdul phra mo gcig gi khongs su chud par bsdus pas chung ngu ston pa sogs rnam par rol pa sna tshogs pas rtsen pa sangs rgyas kyi sras sa bcu pa de ni gzungs dang ting nge 'dzin sogs kyi yon tan rgya che bas byang chub sems dpa' gzhan kun gyi bla na 'dug pa yon tan gyi gter du shes par bya'o/ / de ltar sa so sor phar phyin de dang de dag shas che bas phar phyin de dag gi yon tan gyi rtags kyang de ltar gtso cher sbyangs kyang / sa bcu po thams cad du yang phar phyin bcu bsgrub pa yod pas mtshan ma bcu drug po'i cha yod pa shes par bya'o/ /

On the tenth level, with their completely pure transcendent gnosis, bodhisattvas play with the qualities of preternatural knowledge. Reveling in all kinds of displays, such as demonstrating immensity by filling the vast universe with a single speck of dust and demonstrating minuteness by condensing and enclosing vast universes in a single speck of dust, the buddhas’ children on the tenth level, on account of their extensive qualities (powers of retention, concentrations, and the rest), are to be known as treasuries of qualities, surpassing all other bodhisattvas. Since each level is associated with a predominant transcendent perfection, the signs that constitute the qualities of those transcendent perfections are also mainly refined on the respective levels. But you should understand that bodhisattvas also practice the ten transcendent perfections on all ten levels, so they have parts of all sixteen marks as well.
gnyis pa rtags can sa'i yon tan ni/
(2) THE QUALITIES OF THE LEVELS THAT BEAR THOSE SIGNS
sa rnams kun la rnam kun tu/ / blo ldan rnams kyi phan yon ni/ / zhi gnas lhag mthong gnyis ka la/ / lnga po'i bdag nyid dag tu 'dod/ /
On all the levels, overall, There are five benefits for the wise, Related to sustained calm, To profound insight, and to both. (XXI, 31)
ces pas bstan te/

'phags pa'i sa bcu po kun la rnam pa kun tu blo ldan byang sems rnams kyi sa de dang de'i phan yon ni/ zhi gnas la brten pa'i phyogs gnyis dang lhag mthong la brten pa'i phyogs gnyis dang / zhi lhag gnyis ka la brten pa thun mong ba'i phyogs gcig ste/ lnga po'i bdag nyid dag tu 'dod do/ / zhi gnas la brten pa'i phyogs gnyis ni zhi gnas kyi sems las su rung ba'i mthus nyon shes kyi sgrib pa'i bag nyal du gyur pa gnas ngan len gyi rten thams cad skad cig re re la yang 'joms shing zad par byed pa ni phan yon dang po'o/ / mos spyod kyi zhi lhag gis kyang gnas ngan len gyi mtshan ma nyams par byed kyi rtsad nas 'joms mi nus la/ sa dang po phan chad du skad cig re re la rtsad nas 'joms pa yin no/ / de bzhin du gzugs can gzugs med 'dus byas 'dus ma byas sogs chos tha dad kyi 'du shes sna tshogs dang bral te sems rtse gcig par mtshan ma med pa la gnas pa'i chos kyi dga' ba rab tu myong ba ni phan yon gnyis pa'o/ / 'di gnyis zhi gnas kyi phyogs su gyur pa'i yon tan no/ /

On all ten noble levels, overall, the benefits of those levels for wise bodhisattvas are held to be essentially five: two related to sustained calm, two related to profound insight, and one common benefit related to both sustained calm and profound insight. The two benefits that depend on sustained calm are as follows. The power of the workable mind that results from practicing sustained calm is such that all the supports of negative tendencies that become latent defilement-related and cognitive obscurations are, in each instant, destroyed and brought to an end. This is the first benefit. Even the sustained calm and profound insight of the level of earnest aspiration weaken the attributes associated with negative tendencies, but they cannot completely destroy them, while from the first level onward, in each instant those attributes are completely destroyed. Similarly, bodhisattvas are free of the various notions of distinct phenomena—those with form, those without form, compounded, uncompounded, and so on—and they experience in one-pointed concentration the joy of the quality of abiding in the absence of attributes. This is the second benefit. These two are the qualities related to sustained calm.

lhag mthong gi phyogs su gyur pa'i yon tan gnyis ni/ chos thams cad mtshan ma med par ro gcig kyang phyogs bcu dus gsum gyi shes bya'i chos kyi snang ba lung gi chos rnams kyi rnam par bzhag pa tshad med ris su ma chad pa'i chos kyi snang ba thob pa dang / rnam pa ma brtag par yang rnam par dag pa'i skabs dang mthun pa'i rgyu mtshan rnams mngon du snang ba'o/ /

Of the two qualities related to profound insight, the first is the bodhisattvas’ attainment of the undifferentiated light of Dharma, of the boundless presentations of the Dharma of transmission, the vision of all the knowable phenomena in the ten directions and three times, all phenomena being a single taste in the absence of attributes. The second sign is the manifest appearance, without checking for them, of the signs corresponding to the stages of purity.

zhi lhag gnyis kar gtogs pa ni spang ba rnam par grol ba dang rtogs pa chos kyi sku'i rgyu gong nas gong du 'dzin pa dang lnga ste/ 'di lnga'i ngo bo sngar yang bshad zin to/ / phan yon lnga po 'di dag byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis nang rang gis nyams su myong bas rig par bya ba yin pas sa yi rtags su byas kyang rung ngo / / blo brtan 'grel par phan yon gsum pa bshad nas de man chad kyis mjug ma tshang ngo / /

The benefit that appertains to both sustained calm and profound insight is that the bodhisattva increasingly takes hold of elimination and realization, which are the causes of liberation and of the body of truth respectively. The nature of these five has already been explained.[20] Since these five benefits have to be seen with the bodhisattvas’ own inner experience, they may be treated as signs of the levels. Sthiramati’s commentary explains three of these benefits and then concludes, so it is incomplete.[21]
bdun pa sa'i nges tshig ni/
vii. THE ETYMOLOGICAL DEFINITIONS OF THE LEVELS
byang chub la ni nye ba dang / / sems can don sgrub mthong ba la/ / rab tu dga' ba skye 'gyur te/ / de phyir rab dga' zhes brjod do/ /
When they see they are approaching enlightenment And accomplishing beings’ goals, They will feel the greatest joy. Because of that, it is called Perfect Joy. (XXI, 32)
zhes pas bstan te/

rang don du bla med byang chub thob pa la ni nye ba ste 'thob nges par gyur pa dang / gzhan sems can gyi don sgrub nus par mthong ba la/ rab tu dga' ba skye ba 'gyur te de phyir sa dang po la rab tu dga' ba zhes brjod do/ /

When bodhisattvas see that they are approaching their own goal, the attainment of unsurpassable enlightenment (in other words, when they see that they are certain to attain it), and that they can accomplish the goals of other sentient beings, they feel extremely happy. For this reason, the first level is called Perfect Joy.
'chal tshul rtsol ba'i dri bral phyir/ / dri ma med pa'i sa zhes bya/ / chos kyi snang ba chen po ni/ / byed pa'i phyir na 'od byed pa'o/ /
Because they are free of the contamination of broken vows and misplaced efforts, This level is called Immaculate. Because they make the great light of Dharma shine, It is called Luminous. (XXI, 33)

sa gnyis pa la ni 'chal ba'i tshul khrims dang / theg pa dman pa yid byed kyi rtsol ba'i dri ma dang bral ba'i phyir/ dri ma med pa'i sa zhes bya'o/ / sa gsum pa la ni ting nge 'dzin gyi stobs kyis chos tshad med pa thob cing gzhan yang chos kyi snang ba chen po ni byed pa'i phyir na 'od byed pa zhes bya'o/ /

On the second level, bodhisattvas are free of contamination by breaches of discipline and by attentiveness and efforts related to the lower vehicles, so this level is called Immaculate. On the third level, by the power of their concentration, they receive infinite teachings and moreover make the great light of the Dharma shine for others, so this level is called Luminous.
'di ltar byang chub phyogs mthun chos/ / rab tu sreg byed 'od lta bu/ / de dang ldan phyir sa de ni/ / gnyis po sreg pas 'od 'phro can/ /
Because they have the hotly burning light, This Dharma leading to enlightenment, This level, burning up the two, Is known as Radiant. (XXI, 34)

sa bzhi pa la 'di ltar byang chub kyi phyogs dang mthun pa'i chos bsgom pa'i nyon mongs dang shes bya'i sgrib pa rab tu sreg par byed pa'i 'od lta bu de dang ldan pa'i phyir sa de ni sgrib pa gnyis po sreg pas 'od 'phro ba can zhes bya'o/ /

On the fourth level, they thus have the teachings that lead to enlightenment, whose practice is like a light completely burning up the defilement-related and cognitive obscurations. So this level, in burning up the two obscurations, is called Radiant.
sems can rnams yongs smin byed cing / / rang gi sems kyang bsrung ba'i phyir/ / blo ldan rnams kyis sbyang dka' ba/ / de phyir sbyong dka' zhes bya'o/ /
Because they bring sentient beings to maturity And also guard their own minds, It is difficult for the wise to train, So it is called Hard to Conquer. (XXI, 35)

sa lnga pa la bden pa bzhi rtogs pas sems can rnams yongs su smin par byed cing / sems can rnams kyis log sgrub bzod cing rang gi sems kyang bsrung ba'i phyir/ de gnyis bgyid dka' ba yin pas/ blo ldan rnams kyis sbyang dka' ba dang du len pa de phyir sbyong dka' ba zhes bya'o/ /

On the fifth level, through their realization of the four truths, they bring sentient beings to full maturation and, putting up with beings’ ingratitude, they protect their own minds. These two are difficult to do, so because the wise take on this difficult training, this level is called Hard to Conquer.[22]
shes rab pha rol phyin brten nas/ / 'khor ba dang ni mya ngan 'das/ / gnyis 'dir mngon du gyur pa'i phyir/ / mngon du gyur pa'i sa zhes bshad/ /
As bodhisattvas rely on transcendent wisdom, Both saṃsāra and nirvāṇa Become clearly manifest here, So this level is called Clearly Manifest. (XXI, 36)

sa drug pa la shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la brten nas/ rten 'brel lugs 'byung gis 'khor ba dang ni lugs las ldog pas mya ngan las 'das pa gnyis kyi rang bzhin sa 'dir mngon du gyur nas 'khor 'das la mi gnas pa'i phyir/ mngon du gyur pa'i sa zhes bshad do/ /

On the sixth level, bodhisattvas rely on transcendent wisdom, and on this level the nature of both saṃsāra (the result of dependent arising in the forward order) and nirvāṇa (the result of the reverse process) becomes clearly manifest, so they dwell in neither saṃsāra nor nirvāṇa. For this reason, it is called the Clearly Manifest level.
bgrod gcig lam dang 'brel ba'i phyir/ / ring du song ba'i sar 'dod do/ / 'du shes gnyis kyis mi g.yo'i phyir/ / mi g.yo ba zhes nges par brjod/ /
Because it is connected to the sole path to tread, This level is known as Far Progressed. Because it is unmoved by the two kinds of apprehension, It is called Immovable. (XXI, 37)

sa bdun pa ni bgrod pa gcig pa'i lam sa brgyad pa dang 'brel ba ste de dang nye ba snga logs de ma thag pa yin pa'i phyir 'bad rtsol gyis bsgrub pa'i mthar phyin pa'i phyir ring du song ba'i sar 'dod do/ / sa brgyad pa la sa drug pa yan chad kyis mtshan ma'i 'du shes dang / bdun pa'i mtshan med kyi 'bad rtsol dang bcas pa'i 'du shes gnyis kyis mi g.yo bar mi rtog ye shes lhun gyis grub pa'i phyir mi g.yo zhes par brjod do/ /

Because the seventh level is connected to the eighth level, the sole path to tread, coming immediately before the latter, and because it is the culmination of practice with effort, it is held to be the Far Progressed level. On the eighth level, nonconceptual gnosis is spontaneously accomplished, unmoved by either the apprehension of attributes up to the sixth level or the effortful apprehension of absence of attributes, so it is called Immovable.
so so yang dag rig blo bzang / / sa de legs pa'i blo gros yin/ / sprin bzhin gnyis kyis nam mkha'i chos/ / khyab pa'i phyir na chos kyi sprin/ /

Because of their excellent intelligence, with perfect knowledge, That level is Perfect Intellect. Because the immensity of their sky-like minds is filled With the two like clouds, it is Cloud of Dharma. (XXI, 38)

sa dgu pa la so so yang dag rig pa bzhi'i blo gros khyad par 'phags pa bzang po dang ldan pa'i phyir des ni legs pa'i blo gros zhes bya ba yin no/ / sa bcu pa la dper na sprin chen po nam mkha' la khyab pa bzhin/ gzungs dang ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo tshad med pa sprin chen po lta bus sems kyi rgyud kyi chos kyi dbyings nam mkha'i chos sam gtos kun la khyab pa'i phyir na chos kyi sprin zhes bya'o/ /

Bodhisattvas on the ninth level possess the excellent, especially sublime intelligence related to the four kinds of perfect knowledge, so for this reason that level is known as Perfect Intellect. On the tenth level, like great clouds filling the sky, the cloud-like, boundless doors of powers of retention and concentration fill the whole immensity of the sky-like expanse of reality of the bodhisattva’s mind stream, so this level is called Cloud of Dharma.
dge ba sgrub pa sna tshogs la/ / dga' bas rtag par thams cad du/ / gnas phyir byang chub sems dpa' yi/ / sa rnams gnas pa yin par 'dod/ /
Because they constantly and joyfully abide In the various practices of virtue, The levels of those bodhisattvas Are considered to be “states of abiding.” (XXI, 39)

sa bcu po de dag la byang chub sems dpa' rnams gnas pa yin pa'i gnas pa'i don ji ltar yin zhe na/ sa de dang de'i bsdus pa'i tshogs gnyis kyi dge ba tshad med pa sna tshogs bsgrub pa la sems rab tu dga' bas dus rtag par thams cad du gnas pa'i phyir na byang chub sems dpa' yi sa rnams ni gnas pa zhes bya ba yin par 'dod do/ /

What is meant by the “states of abiding” of the bodhisattvas dwelling on these ten levels? Because bodhisattvas constantly abide with joyful minds in the boundless, multifarious practices of virtue related to the two accumulations that are included in those different levels, the bodhisattva levels are held to be “states of abiding.”
'byung po dpag med 'jigs med phyir/ / dpag tu med pa de dag la/ / phyi phyir gong du 'gro ldan phyir/ / de dag nyid ni sar 'dod do/ /
On them, the fears of countless beings are removed; On them, there’s ever higher progress. For these reasons, those immeasurable states Are considered to be levels. (XXI, 40)

ci'i phyir sa zhes bya zhe na/ b+hU mi zhes pa'i sgra ni 'jig rten na 'byung po sems can dang rtsi shing nags tshal la sogs pa dpag tu med pa'i rten yin pas des brten nas ltung ba'i 'jigs pa med pa dang / yul dang spyod yul gzhan dang gzhan du bgrod pa'i gzhir gyur pa bzhin du/ byang chub sems dpa'i sa rnams kyang 'byung po gdul bya'i skye bo dpag tu med pa'i rten gnas su gyur te 'jigs pa med par byed pa'i gnas yin pa'i phyir dang / sa gong ma gong ma dag gi yon tan dpag tu med pa yi gnas skabs de dag la phyi phyir gong nas gong du 'gro ba'am bgrod par bya ba'i rten du gyur pa dang ldan pa'i phyir/ byang chub sems dpa'i gnas pa de dag nyid ni sar 'dod do/ /

Why do we speak of “levels”? In ordinary, mundane terms, the Sanskrit word bhūmi, meaning “the ground,” is the support for the infinite sentient beings, grasses and trees, forests, and so on. They are supported by it and thus have no fear of falling, and it is the medium on which they can travel from one place and sphere of activity to another. In the same way, the bodhisattva levels are the supports and dwelling places of infinite beings to be trained. They are the places where they are rendered fearless; they provide the medium on which they can go or progress further and further, higher and higher, on those stages associated with the infinite qualities of increasingly higher levels. It is for these two reasons that these bodhisattvas’ states of abiding are held to be levels.
brgyad pa sa 'thob pa rnam pa bzhi ni/
viii. FOUR WAYS OF ATTAINING THE LEVELS
sa 'thob pa ni mos pa dang / / spyod pa dag la 'jug pa dang / / rtogs pa'i phyir dang sa rnams ni/ / 'grub pa'i sgo nas rnam pa bzhi/ /
Attainment of the levels is fourfold: By means of interest, By engagement in activities, By realization, and by accomplishment. (XXI, 41)
zhes pas bstan te/

theg chen gyi don la mos pa thob pa mos spyod kyi sa dang / spyod pa thob pa mos spyod kyi sa de nyid du chos spyod pa bcu po dag la 'jug pa dang / rtogs pa thob pa sa dang po nas bdun pa'i bar chos kyi don rtogs pa'i phyir dang 'grub pa thob pa ni dag pa'i sa gsum ste rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes rtsol med du 'grub pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar mos pa dang spyod pa dang rtog pa dang grub pa'i sgo nas sa 'thob tshul gyi rnam grangs rnam pa bzhi yin no/ /

There are four ways in which bodhisattvas attain the levels: (1) by acquiring interest in the meaning of the Great Vehicle, corresponding to the level of earnest aspiration; (2) by acquiring the conduct on that same level of earnest aspiration[23]—namely, engaging in the ten Dharma activities;[24] (3) by attaining realization on the first to seventh levels, realizing the meaning of the Dharma; and (4) by acquiring accomplishment on the three pure levels, effortlessly accomplishing nonconceptual gnosis. These make four different ways of attaining the levels, by means of interest, activity, realization, and accomplishment.

lus can theg pa chen po dang / / theg pa dman la mos pa rnams/ / gnyis ka 'dun par bya ba dang / / gdul bya'i phyir ni brtan rnams kyi/ / spyod pa bzhi po mdo bzhin du/ / rjes su 'brangs nas bshad pa yin/ /

The four activities of the steadfast Were taught in accordance with a sūtra In order to inspire beings interested in the Great Vehicle, To inspire those interested in lower vehicles, To inspire those interested in both, And in order to subdue beings. (XXI, 42)

byang chub phyogs dang mthun pa'i spyod pa rgyas par phye na tshad med la/ mdor bsdus na lus can theg pa chen po la mos pa rnams la pha rol tu phyin pa drug gi spyod pa dang / theg pa dman pa la mos pa la gtso bor byang phyogs so bdun gyi spyod pa dang / de gnyis ka mthu'i sgo la 'dun par bya ba'i phyir mngon shes kyi spyod pa dang / gdul bya rnams gdul zhing smin par bya ba'i phyir ni bsdu dngos bzhi'i spyod pa ste/ de ltar byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa bzhi po de ni gtsug na rin chen gyis zhus pa'i mdo bzhin du/ bstan bcos 'dir yang mdo de'i rjes su 'brangs nas bshad pa yin no/ /

A detailed account of the activities that lead to enlightenment would be infinitely long, but in brief they can be summarized as follows. The activities of the six transcendent perfections were taught for those beings who are interested in the Great Vehicle. The activities of the thirty-seven elements leading to enlightenment were taught mainly for those who are interested in the lower vehicles. The activities of preternatural knowledge were taught in order to inspire both of these kinds of beings as a gateway to attaining powers. And the activities of the four ways of gathering disciples were taught in order to subdue beings and bring them to maturation. These four bodhisattva activities are explained in the Sūtra of the Questions of Ratnacūda and have been presented in this treatise too following that sūtra.

zhes sa lam gyi chos byang chub kyi phyogs dang mthun pa'i ngo bo nyid bstan pa'i skabs bsdus nas/ sngar bshad pa'i 'bras bu byang chub chen po'i yon tan rnams la bsngags pa'i tshigs su bcad pa rnams ni sa bcu bsgrod nas 'bras bu'i yon tan thob tshul yin te/ tshad med bzhi nas phar phyin drug gi yon tan gyi bar dang / sangs rgyas kyi sa'i mtshan nyid rnam par dbye ba'i tshigs bcad gnyis kyi bar gyis bstan te/

This concludes the section explaining the paths and levels that constitute the approach to enlightenment. There now follows a series of verses praising the qualities of the result, great enlightenment, which has already been explained above. These verses describe the qualities obtained as the result once the ten levels have been traversed, beginning with the qualities of the four boundless attitudes and ending with those of the six transcendent perfections. Finally, there are two verses that distinguish the characteristics of the buddha level.
[mthar thug gi yon tan bstod pa]
4. IN PRAISE OF THE ULTIMATE QUALITIES
sangs rgyas kyi tshad med pa bzhi'i yon tan la bsngags pa ni/
In Praise of the Buddha’s Four Boundless Attitudes
sems can rnams la brtse ba can/ / phrad dang bral ba'i dgongs pa can/ / mi 'bral ba yi dgongs pa can/ / phan bde dgongs khyod la phyag 'tshal/ /
To you possessed of love for sentient beings, Who wish them to encounter and be free, Who wish them to never be deprived, And who wish for their benefit and happiness, I pay homage. (XXI, 43)
zhes pas bstan te/

sems can rnams la rnam pa kun tu thugs brtse ba can zhes pas spyir bstan/ bye brag tu byams pa tshad med pa ni sems can bde ba dang phrad par 'dod pa'i dgongs pa dang / snying rje tshad med pa sdug bsngal dang bral ba'i dgongs pa can dang / dga' ba tshad med pa bde ba mi 'bral ba yi dgongs pa can yin la de gsum sems can rnams la bde ba'i dgongs pa dang / btang snyoms tshad med ni/ chags sdang gi nyon mongs med par btang snyoms la gnas par bzhed pa'i dgongs pa can yin pas/ de ltar sems can thams cad la phan pa dang bde bar dgongs pa can sangs rgyas khyod la sgo gsum gus pa chen pos phyag 'tshal lo/ / zhes so/ /

“Possessed of constant love for sentient beings”[25] is a general indication. Specifically, boundless love is the enlightened intention or wish that sentient beings encounter happiness; boundless compassion is the enlightened intention that they be free from suffering; and boundless joy is the enlightened intention that they be never deprived of happiness. These three constitute the enlightened intention that beings be happy. Boundless impartiality is the enlightened intention or wish that they remain impartial, without the defilements of attachment and aversion. So, with great respect physically, verbally, and mentally, the author pays homage to the Buddha, to him[26] who has this enlightened intention to bring benefit and happiness to all sentient beings.
The Eight Perfect Freedoms, Eight Kinds of Perceptual Domination, and Ten Powers of Perceptual Limitlessness[27]
thub pa sgrib kun nges par grol/ / 'jig rten thams cad zil gyis gnon/ / khyod kyi mkhyen pas shes bya khyab/ / thugs grol khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Capable One, definitively released from all obscuration, Dominant over all worlds, Your knowledge pervades all that can be known. To you whose mind is free, I pay homage. (XXI, 44)

gzugs can gzugs la lta ba'i rnam thar nas/ 'gog pa'i rnam pa thar pa'i bar rnam thar brgyad dang / nang gzugs su 'du shes pas phyi rol gyi gzugs chung du zil gnon sogs/ dbyibs dang kha dog zil gnon brgyad dang / sa chu me rlung nam mkha' rnam shes sngo ser dkar dmar bcas zad pa bcu po 'di dag ting nge 'dzin gyi sprul pa 'byong bar byed pa'i lam yin pas/ rnam thar gyi rtsom/ zil gnon gyis sbyor/ zad par gyis grub pa lta bu yin la sangs rgyas kyi de gsum ni rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyi ngo bor lhun gyis grub cing 'jig rten pa dang nyan rang gi de dag bsgom pa las chos khyad par du 'phags pa yin la/ thub pa sangs rgyas kyi thugs rgyud la mnga' ba'i rnam thar brgyad ni rang rang so so'i mi mthun phyogs las rnam par thar pa tsam du ma zad sgrib gnyis bag chags dang bcas pa kun las nges par grol ba dang / de bzhin du zil gnon brgyad ni dbyibs kha dog tsam zil gyis gnon par ma zad 'jig rten thams cad zil gyis gnon pa dang / zad par gyi sa sogs kyi snang bas yul nyi tshe bar khyab par byed pa tsam du ma zad/ rgyal ba khyod kyi mkhyen pas shes bya thams cad la khyab pas thugs snyoms 'jug dang nyon shes kyi sgrib pa las grol ba khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

The eight perfect freedoms (from the perfect freedom of form beholding form to the perfect freedom of cessation), the eight kinds of perceptual domination related to shapes and colors (for example, perceiving oneself as physically embodied, to have power over smaller external physical forms), and the ten powers of perceptual limitlessness (which are associated with earth, water, fire, wind, space, consciousness, blue, yellow, white, and red)—all these constitute the path of training in manifestation through concentration, which is begun with the perfect freedoms, applied with perceptual domination, and accomplished with perceptual limitlessness. These three qualities of the Buddha are spontaneously accomplished within the nature of nonconceptual gnosis and are superior to the equivalent qualities that mundane beings and listeners and solitary realizers cultivate. Not only are the eight perfect freedoms present in the Buddha’s (the Capable One’s) mind perfectly free from their respective counteragents, but they have also been definitively and entirely released from the influence of the two obscurations and habitual tendencies. Similarly, his eight kinds of perceptual domination constitute not only dominance over shape and color but also dominance over all world systems. And not only does his perceptual limitlessness fill restricted localities with the perceptions of earth and other elements, but the Victorious One’s knowledge pervades all knowable phenomena. Homage is therefore paid to him whose mind is free of all obscuring factors—those that obscure meditative absorption, obscurations related to the defilements, and cognitive obscurations.
nyon mongs med pa ni
The Nonarising of Defilement
sems can dag ni thams cad kyi/ / nyon mongs ma lus thams cad 'joms/ / nyon mongs 'joms mdzad nyon mongs la/ / brtse bcas khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
To you who destroy every defilement In all sentient beings, Who act to overcome defilements And are imbued with love for those with defilements, I pay homage. (XXI, 45)

nyan rang rnams kyis rang la dmigs nas sems can rnams kyi nyon mongs mi skye bar rjes su bsrung ba tsam yin la/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i nyon mongs med pas ni/ sems can dag ni thams cad kyi nyon mongs pa ma lus 'joms par nus pa dang / nyon mongs skyes pa'i sems can de'i ched du gshegs te nyon mongs pa 'joms par mdzad pa dang / nyon mongs pa can gyi sems can thams cad la brtse ba dang bcas pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

The listeners and solitary realizers, with reference to themselves, can only guard against causing defilements to arise in other sentient beings. The Tathāgata’s nonarising of defilement, on the other hand, can destroy all the defilements without exception in the minds of all beings. Proceeding deliberately for the sake of those beings in whom defilements have arisen, he acts to overcome their defilements. Homage is paid to him who is imbued with love for all sentient beings with defilements.
smon nas shes pa ni
Knowledge of Wishes and Aspirations
lhun gyis grub cing chags mi mnga'/ / thogs par mi mnga' rtag par ni/ / mnyam par bzhag cing 'dri kun gyi/ / lan ldon khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Spontaneous, free of attachment, Without impediment, constantly in meditation— To you who give answers to all questions, I pay homage. (XXI, 46)

nyan thos rnams la gzhan gyis dri ba sogs kyi tshe ched du bsams nas ting nge 'dzin la mnyam par bzhag pa'i sgo nas ci rigs shes kyi shes bya thams cad thogs med du shes pa yang ma yin zhing / rtag tu mnyam par bzhag pa yang ma yin la dri ba thams cad kyi lan ldon par nus pa'ang ma yin no/ / sangs rgyas kyi smon nas mkhyen pa ni de las ldog pa'i khyad par lnga dang ldan te/ rtsol ba med par lhun gyis grub cing nyon mongs pa'i bag chags mi mnga' ba'am/ snyoms 'jug la ltos mi dgos pas chags pa mi mnga' ba dang / shes sgrib spangs pas shes bya gang la yang thogs pa mi mnga' ba dang / rtag tu mnyam par bzhag pa las g.yo ba med cing / sems can rnams kyis gang dang gang dris pa'i 'dri ba kun gyi lan ldon pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo zhes so/ /

When other people ask listeners questions and so on, the listeners have to specially reflect and settle evenly in concentration in order to know the answer. But they do not know all knowable phenomena without impediment; neither are they constantly in equipoise, nor are they able to answer all questions. The Buddha’s knowledge of wishes and aspirations is quite different and has the following five special features. It is spontaneous and effortless. It does not have the habitual tendencies of defilements (or, alternatively, it does not require reliance on meditative absorption), and it is therefore free of attachment. Because he has eliminated cognitive obscurations, it is without impediment. He never moves from constant equipoise. And he answers all the questions sentient beings may ask. So it is to him, the Buddha, that homage is paid.
so so yang dag rig pa bzhi ni/
The Four Kinds of Perfect Knowledge
rten dang brten pa bshad bya dang / / gsung dang mkhyen pa 'chad byed la/ / blo gros rtag thogs mi mnga' ba/ / legs ston khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
With regard to what is explained—the support and supported— And what is used to explain—your words and knowledge— Your mind is always unimpeded. To you, excellent teacher, I pay homage. (XXI, 47)
zhes pas bstan te/

rten chos dang brten pa don gnyis ni gang bshad par bya ba dang / gsung sems can thams cad kyi skad du go ba'i nges pa'i tshig dang / shes bya mtha' dag mkhyen pa'i spobs pa mtha' gtugs pa med pa gnyis ni 'chad par byed pa la/ blo gros rtag tu thogs pa mi mnga' ba 'gyur ba yi sgo nas dam pa'i chos legs ! par ston pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

The Buddha’s intellect is always unimpeded with regard to what is taught (the subjects that are the support, and the meanings they support), and what it is that is used to teach (both the Buddha’s words, the expressions that are understood in the languages of all sentient beings, and the unbounded confidence and eloquence that comes from his knowledge of everything there is to be known). So homage is paid to him who, by these means, perfectly teaches the sacred Dharma.
mngon par shes pa drug ni/
The Six Kinds of Preternatural Knowledge
gshegs nas spyod pa mkhyen mdzad de/ / de dag skad kyis sems can gyi/ / 'ong dang 'gro dang nges 'byung la/ / legs 'doms khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Proceeding and knowing all activities, You give excellent instructions, In their languages, on the comings and goings of beings And their certain deliverance. To you, I pay homage. (XXI, 48)
zhes pas bstan te/

rdzu 'phrul gyi mngon shes kyis gdul bya gang na gnas pa der gshegs nas/ gzhan sems shes pas de'i sems kyi spyod pa brgyad khri bzhi stong mkhyen pa mdzad de/ lha'i rna ba'i mngon shes kyi stobs kyis sems can de dag so so'i skad kyis sngon gnas shes pas sems can rnams gang nas 'dir 'ong ba dang / lha'i mig gi mngon shes kyis ma 'ongs pa na skye ba'i gnas gang du 'gro ba dang / zag zad kyi mngon shes kyis 'khor ba las nges par 'byung ba'i tshul la legs par 'doms pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

With his preternatural power to perform miracles, the Buddha proceeds to wherever there are beings to be trained. Then, with his knowledge of others’ minds, he knows the eighty-four thousand activities in their minds. By means of the clairaudience of the divine ear, he gives excellent instruction, in the language of each of those sentient beings, on where beings in this life have come from (through the knowledge of their previous lives), on where they will be reborn in the future (through the clairvoyance of the divine eye), and on the manner of their certain deliverance from saṃsāra (through the preternatural knowledge of the exhaustion of taints). To him who has such preternatural knowledge, homage is paid.
mtshan bzang po sum cu rtsa gnyis dang dpe byad bzang po brgyad cu dang ldan pa ni/
The Thirty-Two Major Marks and Eighty Minor Marks of Excellence
lus can kun gyis khyod mthong na/ / skyes bu dam pa lags par 'tshal/ / mthong ba tsam gyis rab dang bar/ / mdzad pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
When beings see you, They all know you to be a holy being. To you, the mere sight of whom Creates faith, I pay homage. (XXI, 49)
zhes pas bstan te/

lus can kun gyis khyod kyi sku mthong ba dang / 'di ni skyes bu chen po zhig yin no zhes/ skyes bu dam pa yin pa legs par 'tshal ba'am shes par 'gyur zhing / mthong ba tsam gyis yid rab tu dang bar mdzad pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

When beings of all kinds see his body, they fully acknowledge or know that he is a holy being, saying, “This is a great being.” Just seeing him inspires clear faith in them, and they pay homage to him.
yongs su dag pa bzhi ni/
The Four Complete Purities
len dang gnas dang gtong ba dang / / sprul dang yongs su sgyur ba dang / / ting nge 'dzin dang ye shes la/ / mnga' brnyes khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
To you who have mastery In assuming, abiding, and relinquishing, In manifestation and transformation, In concentration, and in gnosis, I pay homage. (XXI, 50)
zhes pas bstan te/

rten nam gnas sam lus yongs su dag pas rten gsar du len pa dang / rten des ji srid du gnas pa dang / tshe'i 'du byed gtong ba la bzhed pa bzhin du dbang 'byor ba dang / dmigs pa dag pas sngon med gsar du sprul pa dang / sngar yod pa rnam pa gzhan du yongs su sgyur ba la mnga' brnyes pa dang / sems yongs su dag pas ting nge 'dzin la mnga' brnyes pa dang / shes rab yongs su dag pas ye shes bsam gyis mi khyab pa la mnga' brnyes pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

Because of the complete purity of the body, or support or place, the Buddha has mastery in assuming a new support, in abiding with that support for a while, and relinquishing the conditioning factor of life as he wishes. On account of the purity of objects, he has mastery in newly manifesting things that did not previously exist and in transforming things that already exist. Through the complete purity of his mind, he has mastery in concentration. And through the complete purity of his wisdom, he has mastery in inconceivable gnosis. To him, therefore, homage is paid.
stobs bcu ni/
The Ten Strengths
thabs dang skyabs dang dag pa dang / / theg chen nges par 'byung ba la/ / sems can rnams la rab slu ba'i/ / bdud 'joms khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
To you who vanquish the demons That utterly deceive sentient beings with regard to The means, refuge, purity, And certain deliverance by the Great Vehicle, I pay homage. (XXI, 51)
zhes pas bstan te/

gnas dang gnas ma yin pa mkhyen pa'i stobs kyis rgyu dang rgyu min shes pas bde 'gro dang ngan 'gror skye ba'i rgyu'am thabs la bslu ba'i bdud 'joms te/ bde 'gro'i rgyu min pa 'tshe ba can gyi mchod sbyin la sogs pa bde 'gro 'thob pa'i thabs la bslu ba de lta bu 'joms pa dang las kyi rnam smin mkhyen pa'i stobs kyis las kyi dbang ma gtogs par dbang phyug sogs kyis rang dbang du skyabs byed mi nus par bstan pas skyabs la bslu ba'i bdud 'joms pa dang / kun nyon dang rnam byang gi bsam gtan thams cad mkhyen pa'i stobs kyis bsam gzugs thob pa tsam gyis 'khor ba las thar zhing dag par lta ba'i dag pa bslu ba'i bdud 'joms pa dang /

With the strength of the knowledge of what is correct and what is incorrect, the Buddha knows what is and what is not a causal factor, and thus he vanquishes the demon that deceives beings as to the cause or means for rebirth in the higher and lower realms—overcoming, for example, the deceptive idea that things like harmful offerings and gifts, which are not the cause of higher rebirth, constitute the way to obtain happy rebirths. With the strength of knowing the fully ripened effects of actions, he shows that apart from the power of deeds, nothing, including Īśvara and similar beings, is able to afford protection on its own, and thus he destroys deceptive notions with regard to refuge. With the strength of knowing all the concentrations related to defilement and purity, he destroys deceptive notions with regard to purity—the view that one can be purified and liberated from saṃsāra simply by attaining the world of form and formless world.

stobs lhag ma bdun gyis/ theg pa chen po'i sgo nas nges par 'byung ba la sems can rnams la rab tu bslu ba'i bdud 'joms te/ khams thams cad mkhyen pa'i stobs kyis rigs/ mos pa sna tshogs mkhyen pa'i stobs kyis dad pa/ dbang po sna tshogs pa mkhyen pa'i stobs kyis gdul bya'i dad sogs kyi dbye ba las snod kyi khyad par mkhyen nas/ sngon gnas mkhyen pa'i stobs dang / 'chi 'pho ba mkhyen pa'i stobs gnyis kyis lam gyi rten dang / thams cad du 'gro ba'i lam mkhyen pa'i stobs kyis lam gyi ngo bo dang / zag zad mkhyen pa'i stobs kyis nges par 'byung ba'i 'bras bu mkhyen nas gdul bya rnams la de ltar bstan pas theg pa chen po'i lam gyis nges par 'byung ba las gzhan du bslu bar byed pa'i bdud 'joms pa ste/ de lta bu'i stobs bcu'i yon tan dang ldan pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / zhes so/ /

And with the remaining seven strengths, he vanquishes the demon that utterly deceives sentient beings with regard to certain deliverance by means of the Great Vehicle. With the strength of knowing all beings’ fundamental makeup, the strength of knowing their various interests, and the strength of knowing their various mental capacities, he knows, respectively, their potential, their faith, and the different categories of faith and so forth in the beings to be trained, and hence their particularities as potential disciples. Then, with the strength of knowing past lives and the strength of knowing deaths and transmigrations, he knows the supports for the path. With the strength of knowing all paths and where they lead, he knows the nature of the path. And with the strength of knowing the exhaustion of taints, he knows the result, certain deliverance. With such knowledge, he teaches disciples accordingly, and thus he vanquishes the demon that lures beings away from certain deliverance by the path of the Great Vehicle. Homage is therefore paid to him who possesses these qualities, the ten strengths.
mi 'jigs pa bzhi ni/
The Four Fearlessnesses
rang gzhan don du ye shes dang / / spangs dang nges 'byung bgegs mdzad par/ / ston mdzad mu stegs gzhan dag gis/ / mi brdzi khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
To you who, for your own and others’ sake, Show gnosis and elimination, Teach certain deliverance and what hinders it, And will never be crushed by tīrthikas and others, I pay homage. (XXI, 52)
zhes pas bstan te/

rang don du rtogs pa phun tshogs zhal gyis bzhes pa la mi 'jigs pa rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes mnga' ba dang / spangs pa phun tshogs zhal gyis bzhes pa la mi 'jigs pa sgrib gnyis bag chags dang bcas spangs pa dang / gzhan don du lam ston pa la mi 'jigs pa 'khor ba las nges par 'byung ba'i lam yang dag pa ston pa dang / lam gyi bgegs ston pa la mi 'jigs pa/ lam la bar du gcod pa'i bgegs sam gegs byed pa bdag lta dang chags sogs nyon mongs rnams kyis 'khor ba las thar pa'i gegs byed pa yin no zhes par bden pa'i gsung tshad ma dang ldan pa ston par mdzad pa la/ lha'am bdud dam tshangs pa'am dge sbyong dang bram ze'am mu stegs can gzhan dag gis/ de ltar ma yin zhes chos dang mthun pa'i rgol bas nam yang mi brdzi ba khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

For his own sake, the Buddha is not afraid of proclaiming his perfect realization, for he possesses omniscient gnosis, and he is not afraid of proclaiming his perfect elimination, for he is rid of the two obscurations together with their habitual tendencies. And for others’ sake, he is not afraid of teaching the path, for he shows the correct path that affords certain deliverance from saṃsāra, and he is not afraid of teaching the hindrances on the path, for he indicates the hindrances or obstacle makers that interrupt the path, with authentic words of truth, saying, “The belief in a self, and defilements such as attachment, create obstacles to being liberated from saṃsāra.” He will never be crushed by attacks from others who dispute that, whether they are celestial beings, demons, Brahmā, śrāmaṇeras and brahmins, or tīrthikas. It is to him that homage is paid.
bsrung ba med pa ni/
Absence of Secretiveness and the Threefold Limpidity
bsrung med bsnyel ba mi mnga' bar/ 'khor gyi nang na bag brkyang gsung / / kun nas nyon mongs gnyis spangs pa/ / 'khor sdud khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Never on your guard nor forgetful, You speak boldly in the midst of your disciples; To you who have eliminated the two defilements And gather a following, I pay homage. (XXI, 53)
zhes pas bstan te/
