sku gsung thugs la nyes pa'i dri ma gtan nas mi mnga' bas gzhan gyi shes su dogs nas bcab pa'am 'dzem dgos pa gang yang med pas sgo gsum gyi spyod pa sba ba'am bsrung ba med par gnas bzhin skyon byung na ched du btang snyoms su bya ba'i bsnyel ba lta bu mi mnga' bar 'khor gyi nang na bag mi tsha zhing seng+ge bzhin du bag brkyang ba'i gsung gis chos ston pa dang / chos nyan pa la chags pa/ mi nyan pa la sdang ba/ nyan mi nyan gnyis ka la chags sdang skye ba med pa dran pa nye bar bzhag pa gsum dang ldan pa'i phyir na/ chags pa dang sdang ba'i kun nas nyon mongs pa gnyis spangs pas 'khor gyi tshogs kun nas sdud pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

The Buddha is utterly uncontaminated by faults in body, speech, and mind, so there is nothing that he needs to keep secret or be shy about, out of fear that others might come to know of it. He therefore never hides or guards any aspect of his physical, verbal, or mental conduct. Accordingly, it is not as if he deliberately forgets and ignores any faults that might have occurred. Rather, he is fearless in the midst of his disciples and teaches the Dharma with a bold voice, like a lion. Moreover, he possesses threefold limpidity: he never feels attached to those who listen to the teachings, hostile toward those who do not listen, or attached and hostile to both those who listen and those who do not listen. So because he has eliminated both defilements—attachment and hostility—he gathers a group of followers around him. To him homage is paid.
bag chags yang dag par bcom pa ni/
The Complete Destruction of Habitual Tendencies
kun mkhyen khyod la rgyu ba dang / / gnas pa kun la rtag par ni/ / kun mkhyen min spyod mi mnga' ste/ / yang dag don ldan khyod phyag 'tshal/ /
Omniscient One, all the time, Whenever you move, whenever you stay, You have no activities in which you are not omniscient. To you who truly merit that name, I pay homage. (XXI, 54)
zhes pas bstan te/

kun mkhyen khyod la grong du bsod snyoms sogs kyi phyir rgyu ba dang / nang du yang dag 'jog pa la gnas pa kun la dus rtag par ni kun mkhyen min pa'i spyod pa mi mnga' ste gshegs pa dang bzhugs pa sogs kyi spyod lam thams cad du thams cad gzigs shing mkhyen la mnyam par bzhag bzhin pa las mi 'da' bas 'khrul pa'i spyod lam kun mkhyen min par skyon gdags su rung ba'i gzhi cung zad tsam yang mi mnga' bas kun mkhyen zhes pa'i mtshan yang dag pa'i don dang ldan pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / zhes nyan thos dgra bcom pa rnams la nyon mongs med kyang bag chags ma spangs pa'i dbang gis/ 'gro ba'i tshe na res 'ga' glang po myos pa dang shing rta sogs dang thug pa dang / sbrul nag po rkang pas brdzi ba dang / nag 'thibs por lam nor ba dang / spre'u ltar mchongs pa dang / gad mo rta gad ltar du cher rgod pa sogs ma brtag pa'i spyod lam ci rigs skabs su 'byung srid kyang sangs rgyas la de lta bu gtan mi mnga' ba'o/ /

All the time, in everything he does, whether he is moving about (for such purposes as seeking alms in the villages) or staying still, perfectly settled inwardly, the Omniscient One never does anything in which he is not omniscient. In all his activities—going, sitting, and so forth—he never falls out of the state of remaining evenly in all-seeing omniscience. So he does not have even the slightest deluded, nonomniscient behavior that could be called a defect, and thus he can truly be called omniscient. To him, then, we pay homage. Although the listener arhats have no defilements, they have not eliminated the habitual tendencies, so when they travel, they can sometimes behave in all kinds of unconsidered ways—sometimes they meet crazed elephants, chariots, and so forth; they tread on venomous snakes, lose their way in the dark, jump like monkeys, laugh loudly like horses, and so on. But this is never the case for the Buddha.
bsnyel ba mi mnga' ba ni/
Absence of Forgetfulness
sems can kun gyi bya ba la/ / khyod ni dus las mi 'da' bas/ / mdzad pa rtag tu don mnga' ba/ / mi bsnyel khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
In acting for the sake of all beings, You are never untimely, So your deeds are always meaningful. To you who are never forgetful, I pay homage. (XXI, 55)
zhes pas bstan te/
sems can kun gyi don bya ba la khyod ni nam yang dus las mi 'da' bas/ gang dang gang mdzad pa thams cad rtag tu don mnga' ba yi sgo nas/ sems can gyi don la mi bsnyel ba khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Since he never misses the right moment for benefiting all beings, all his actions are always meaningful. In this respect, he never forgets beings’ welfare. To him we pay homage.
thugs rje chen po ni/
Great Compassion
'jig rten kun la nyin mtshan du/ / lan drug tu ni so sor gzigs/ / thugs rje chen po dang ldan pa/ / phan dgongs khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
In all worlds, six times during the night and day, You look upon each and every being, Manifesting great compassion. To you whose intention is to help, I pay homage. (XXI, 56)
zhes pas bstan te/

phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams kun la nyin dang mtshan du lan drug gis brtson pas dus rtag tu ni/ so sor gzigs shing su zhig rgud su zhig dar/ su la thabs gang gis phan gdags par bya zhes thugs rje chen po dang ldan pa ni ngo bo'o/ / de'i byed las sems can thams cad la phan par byed pa yin pas/ de lta bu'i phan par dgongs pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

In all the worlds in the ten directions, the Buddha constantly, rousing himself six times by day and night, looks on each and every being and manifests great compassion, thinking, “Who is ailing, who is flourishing, whom should I help, and how?” This is the essence of his compassion. Its function is to bring benefit to all sentient beings. So homage is paid to him who has this intention to help.
ma 'dres pa bco brgyad ni/
The Eighteen Distinctive Qualities
spyod pa dang ni rtogs pa dang / / ye shes dang ni phrin las kyis/ / nyan thos rang sangs rgyas kun gyi/ / bla ma khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
To you who surpass All the listeners and solitary realizers In your conduct, realization, gnosis, And activities, I pay homage. (XXI, 57)
zhes pas bstan te/

sku la 'khrul pa mi mnga' ba dang / gsung la ca co mi mnga' ba dang / thugs la dran pa nyams pa mi mnga' ba dang / mnyam par ma bzhag pa'i thugs mi mnga' ba dang / 'du shes sna tshogs mi mnga' ba dang / ma brtags pa'i btang snyoms mi mnga' ste/ spyod pa yis bsdus pa drug dang / 'dun pa brtson 'grus dran pa ting 'dzin shes rab rnam par grol ba las nyams pa mi mnga' ba ni rtogs pa yis bsdus pa drug dang / gzhung la lar ting 'dzin mi bgrang bar rnam grol gzigs pa'i ye shes dang drug la bzhed pa yod de mdo tha dad kyi dgongs pa'o/ / 'das pa'i dus la ma chags ma thogs pa'i ye shes 'jug pa dang / de bzhin da lta dang ma 'ongs pa la sbyar ba gsum ni ye shes kyis bsdus pa gsum dang ni/ sku'i las thams cad ye shes sngon du 'gro zhing ye shes kyi rjes su 'brang ba dang / de bzhin gsung dang thugs kyi ste phrin las kyis bsdus pa gsum ste/ de ltar sangs rgyas nyid kyi thun mong min pa'i chos gzhan dang ma 'dres pa bco brgyad dang ldan pas nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas kun gyi bla med nyid du gyur pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

Six of the eighteen distinctive qualities are included in the Buddha’s conduct: physically, he is free of erroneous behavior; concerning his speech, he never speaks noisily and unrestrainedly; mentally, he never loses mindfulness; his mind is never not in meditative equipoise; he does not have different kinds of discriminatory perceptions; and his equanimity never lacks discernment. Another six are included in his realization and concern his unfailing enthusiasm, diligence, mindfulness, concentration, wisdom, and perfect freedom. (Some source texts list these six with “gnosis that sees perfect freedom” instead of “concentration.” These follow the intended meanings of different sūtras.) Three concern his gnosis, which penetrates the past, and likewise the present and future, unobstructedly. And three concern his activities: all the activities of his body, which are preceded and accompanied by gnosis, and likewise the activities of his speech and mind. To him who possesses these eighteen distinctive, uncommon qualities of buddhahood, and who therefore surpasses all the listeners and solitary realizers, we pay homage.
rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa nyid ni/
Omniscience
sku gsum dag gis byang chub che/ / rnam pa kun brnyes thams cad du/ / sems can kun gyi the tshom dag / gcod pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
With the three buddha bodies, you have attained Great enlightenment, in all aspects. To you who remove the doubts of all beings On every plane, I pay homage. (XXI, 58)
zhes pas bstan te/

sku gsum dag gis byang chub chen po rnam pa kun gyi mchog dang ldan pa'am rnam pa kun mkhyen pa nyid brnyes pa ste/ chos kyi sku brnyes pas dbyings dag pa gnyis ldan thabs zab mo mngon par byang chub pa dang / longs spyod rdzogs pa'i sku brnyes pas ye shes bzhi thob pa thun mong min par mngon par byang chub pa dang / sprul pa'i sku brnyes pas nam mkha' ji srid du sems can gyi don sna tshogs mdzad pa 'jig rten 'das par mngon par byang chub pa'o/ / gzugs sku gnyis bsdoms te rgya che ba mngon par byang chub pa zhes bya'o/ / de ltar byang chub chen po brnyes nas de'i byed las rnam pa thams cad du sems can kun gyi the tshom dag gcod pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

With the three buddha bodies, the Buddha has attained great enlightenment supreme in all aspects, or knowledge of all aspects.[28] By attaining the body of truth, he attains the expanse of reality endowed with the two purities; this is called profound manifest enlightenment. By attaining the body of perfect enjoyment, he acquires the four kinds of gnosis, which is called uncommon manifest enlightenment. And by attaining the manifestation body, he acts in multifarious ways for the benefit of sentient beings for as long as space endures, which is supramundane manifest enlightenment. The two aspects of the form body together constitute vast manifest enlightenment. Homage is paid to him who has thus attained great enlightenment, whose function is to remove all sentient beings’ doubts on every level.
pha rol tu phyin pa drug gi yon tan mthar phyin pa ni/
The Consummate Qualities of the Six Transcendent Perfections
'dzin pa mi mnga' nyes mi mnga'/ / rnyog pa mi mnga' mi gnas pa/ / mi g.yo chos rnams thams cad la/ / spros med khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
To you who have no grasping, commit no fault, Are undisturbed, never stay still, Never stir, and are free from elaborations With regard to all phenomena, I pay homage. (XXI, 59)
zhes pas bstan te/

yongs su 'dzin pa mi mnga' bas sbyin pa'i phar phyin rdzogs pa dang / de bzhin du nyes pa gtan mi mnga' bas tshul khrims dang / rgyud 'khrugs pa'i rnyog pa gtan mi mnga' bas bzod pa dang / sems can gyi don la btang snyoms su gnas pa mi mnga' ba brtson 'grus dang / rtag tu ting nge 'dzin las mi g.yo ba bsam gtan dang / chos rnams thams cad la rnam rtog gi spros pa med pa'i shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa rdzogs pa khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

Because he has no grasping, the Buddha has completed transcendent generosity. Similarly, he has completed the transcendent perfection of discipline, for he never commits any fault; transcendent patience, for his mind is never disturbed; transcendent diligence, for he is never indifferent to beings’ welfare; transcendent concentration, for he never moves from meditative absorption; and transcendent wisdom, the absence of all mental elaborations and concepts with regard to all phenomena. So to him we pay homage.
sangs rgyas kyi sa'i don bsdus te/ sangs rgyas kyi sa'i mtshan nyid rnam par dbye ba ni/
A Concise Description of the Buddha Level, Distinguishing Its Characteristics

dam pa'i don ni grub pa ste/ / sa kun las ni nges par 'byung / / sems can kun gyi mchog tu gyur/ / sems can thams cad rnam grol mdzad/ / yon tan mi zad mnyam med ldan/ / 'jig rten dag kyang dkyil 'khor na'ang / / snang la lha dang mi rnams kyis/ / rnam pa kun tu mi mthong ngo / /

He has accomplished ultimate truth, Having been definitively released from all the levels. He is the highest of all beings And acts to liberate all sentient beings. (XXI, 60) Possessing unequaled, inexhaustible qualities, He appears in worldly realms, and in maṇḍalas, But is completely invisible To gods and humans. (XXI, 61)
ces pas bstan te/

ngo bo ni dam pa'i don nam de bzhin nyid rang bzhin rnam dag glo bur ba'i dri ma dang bral ba'i dag pa gnyis ldan gyi byang chub chen po nyid du ni grub pa ste/ de'i rgyu ni sa kun las nges par gong nas gong du phyung ste mthar phyin pa'o/ / 'bras bu ni sems can kun gyi mchog tu gyur pa mnyam pa med pa'o/ / byed las sems can thams cad rnam par grol bar mdzad pa'o/ / ldan pa ni stobs la sogs pa'i yon tan nam yang mi zad pa/ nyan rang gi byang chub dang mnyam pa med pa ldan pa'o/ / 'jug pa'am dbye ba ni sangs rgyas de ni ma dag pa'i 'jig rten dag na snang ba sprul sku dang / dag pa'i gdul byar sangs rgyas kyi dkyil 'khor na'ang snang ba longs sku yin la/ chos kyi sku ni sangs rgyas nyid ma gtogs lha dang mi rnams kyis rnam pa kun tu mi mthong ngo / / 'dis gzhung rdzogs par yin yang 'gro don 'phel ba'i rten 'brel du mkhas pa dag gis tshigs bcad gcig mjug tu sbyar ba ni/

The essence of the buddha level is the accomplishment of the ultimate truth or suchness in great enlightenment, endowed with twofold purity—natural purity and the purity of freedom from adventitious contaminants. Its cause is to have been definitively released from all the levels, one after the other, and to have reached their culmination. The result is that one has become the very best of all sentient beings and is without peer. Its function is to bring all beings to perfect liberation. Its property is that it possesses inexhaustible excellent qualities such as the strengths, unequaled by the listeners’ and solitary realizers’ enlightenment. Its manifestations or categories are the body of manifestation, in which the buddhas appear in impure worlds; the body of enjoyment, which appears in a buddha’s maṇḍala to pure disciples; and the body of truth, which, however, is invisible in any form to anyone (celestial beings or humans) but the Buddha himself. Although this completes the original text, the following single verse was added by scholars to create auspicious conditions for increasing beings’ welfare.
de lta na'ang de yi mthus/ / gdul bya'i skal ba ji bzhin du/ / srid pa ji ltar gnas kyi bar/ / de yi mdzad pa rgyun mi 'chad/ /
Nevertheless, through his power, In accordance with the fortunes of beings And for as long as the world endures, The stream of his deeds will never cease. (XXI, 62)

de ltar na yang chos sku de yis mthus/ / gdul bya'i skal pa ji lta ba bzhin du/ / srid pa 'jig rten gyi khams ji srid gnas kyi bar du/ / sangs rgyas chos sku de yi mdzad pa rgyun mi 'chad par 'byung ngo / / 'dis ni phrin las rgyun mi 'chad pa bstan pa yin no/ /

Nevertheless, by the power of the body of truth, in accordance with the fortunes of beings to be trained, and for as long as existence—that is, the world—endures, the deeds of that truth-body buddha occur uninterruptedly. This verse indicates his uninterrupted activities.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las/ spyod pa dang mthar thug pa'i le'u ste nyi shu rtsa gcig pa'o/
This completes the twenty-first chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on conduct and consummation.
theg pa chen po mdo sde'i rgyan las spyod pa dang mthar thug pa'i le'u ste nyi shu rtsa gcig pa rnam par bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the twenty-first chapter of Ornament of the Mahāyāna Sūtras, the chapter on conduct and consummation.

LAMA MIPHAM’S COLOPHON

e ma/ bskal mang tshogs kyis rnyed dka'i theg chen chos tshul kun 'dus pa/ / rgyal tshab mchog gi bstan bcos 'di don bshad dang nyan byas na/ / theg chen chos kun 'chad nyan bgyis pa'i phan yon kyang thob pa/ / shing rta chen pos byang chub sems dpa'i sa las bshad dang mtshungs pa'i phyir/ /

Wonder! This treatise by the sublime regent Maitreya Includes the whole tradition of the Great Vehicle, Obtained but rarely through merit that takes many kalpas to gain. To teach and study it will bring the benefits Of explaining and receiving all the Mahāyāna teachings, The same as teaching from the Great Charioteer’s The Stage of a Bodhisattva.
theg mchog chos kyi bdud rtsi'i dga' ston ni/ / mtha' yas 'gro la rab tu bkye ba'i slad/ / bstan pa mchog la rab tu gus pa dang / / gzhan la phan par 'dod pas 'di byas so/ /
I composed this nectarous feast of teachings from the Supreme Vehicle In order to share it with infinite beings, With great respect for the sublime doctrine, And out of a desire to benefit others.
'dir 'bad dge tshogs rab dkar zla 'od kyis/ / 'gro blo'i kun+da gzhon nu kha phye zhing / / legs bshad bsung zhim phyogs su khyab pa yis/ / 'gro kun sems kyi rnyogs pa dwangs gyur cig /

With the brilliant moonlight of the virtue gathered by my efforts in this, May the fresh night-jasmine flowers of beings’ minds open, And may the sweet scent of the excellent teachings spread everywhere, Clearing away the cloudiness in every being’s mind.
bdag kyang skye ba tshe rabs thams cad du/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs dang rgyal tshab mi pham pa'i/ / dgyes spyan ut+pal bzhad pas gzigs bzhin du/ / rgyal sras spyod pa rgya mtshor 'jug gyur cig /
In my whole series of lives, With Mañjuśrī and the Invincible Regent[1] Watching me with the blossoming utpalas of their joyful eyes, May I engage in the infinite activities of the bodhisattvas.
nam mkha' mtha'i khyab gyur pa'i 'gro ba kun/ / theg pa mchog gi lam la rab zhugs nas/ / rdzogs smin spyad pa rgya mtsho'i mthar phyin te/ / thams cad gzigs pa'i go 'phang thob par shog /

May all the infinite beings filling the ends of space Set out on the path of the Supreme Vehicle And, reaching the end of the ocean of completion, maturation, and purification, May they attain the level of the All-Seeing One.

ces pa'ang lcags phag gi lor rje btsun mkhyen pa'i bdag po'i rig sngags bzla ba'i bcad rgya'i tshe dbyar phyogs zhag bzhi bcu tsam gyi thun gseng la/ slob dpon chen po blo brtan gyi 'grel pa gzhir bzhag byas nas don gsal bar bsdus te mi pham 'jam dbyangs rgya mtshos bkod pa dge legs su gyur cig / mang+ga laM/ /

During the summer months of the Iron Pig year (1911) while in strict retreat reciting the mantra of the Noble Lord of Knowledge,[2] I, Mipham Jamyang Gyatso, wrote this between sessions in about forty days, taking the commentary of Ācārya Sthiramati as a basis and clarifying and condensing the meaning. May it be auspicious. Maṅgalam.

dga' ldan lha brgya'i bdag po ma pham pa/ / thub pa'i cod paN nyid kyi gtsug na bkod/ / byams chen rgyal ba gnyis pa chos kyi rje/ / rgyal tshab sa bcu'i dbang phyug zhabs la 'dud/ 1/

Invincible lord of a hundred gods in Tuṣita, Set on the crown of the very crown of the Capable One, Great Love, Second Conqueror, Lord of Dharma, I bow at the feet of the Regent, lord of the tenth level.
gang gi legs gsung chos kyi rnga bo che/ / phyogs bcu'i zhing kun khyab par rjes 'gro ba'i/ / chos tshul nor bu'i sprin gyi bla bre bres/ / 'gro ba'i nyon mongs me dbal bcom par mdzad/ 2 /

His Excellent Speech, the great drum of the teachings, The Dharma tradition pervading the whole of the ten directions, Decorated with canopies of jeweled clouds, Extinguishes the flames of beings’ defilements.
thub pa'i mdo sde zab cing rgya che ba/ / rtogs par dka' ba 'bum phrag mang po yi/ / zab rgyas gnad dril rdo rje rin po che'i/ / rgyan phreng 'phags pa thogs med spyi bor bcings 3 /

This necklace, a diamond ornament That essentializes the extensive and profound teachings Of the many hundreds of thousands, hard to comprehend, Of the Buddha’s extensive and profound sūtras, The Noble Asaṅga tied to his crown.
sngon rabs 'grel pa ngo mtshar rnam mang yang / / blo gros thogs med mkhas mchog mi pham rje'i/ / rnam grol theg mchog bdud rtsi'i dga' ston 'di/ / sa gsum skal bzang skye bo'i mig gcig pu/ 4 /

Many wondrous commentaries are there by earlier masters, But this liberating feast of the nectar of the Supreme Vehicle By Lord Mipham, sublime scholar of unimpeded intellect, Stands alone in the eyes of fortunate beings of the three worlds.
'di ko lhar bcas 'jig rten kun gyi rgyan/ / sdeb legs don bzang pad+ma rgyas pa bzhin/ / de phyir thar 'dod rnams la smon pa'i blos/ / skyabs mchog 'jam dbyangs bla ma rgyal tshab rje'i/ 5 /

It is an ornament for the gods and all the world, An elegant volume of excellent meaning, like a blossoming lotus. Therefore, with the aspiration for those who desire liberation, In order to fulfill the wishes of the uncontaminated mind Of the supreme refuge, the Lord, Jamyang Lama Gyaltsab,
zag med thugs kyi dgongs pa rdzogs pa dang / / mkha' mnyam 'gro la byang chub sems 'phel ched/ / sku dpon bslab ldan dge legs rgya mtsho dang / / nye gnas zhing skyong bcas kyi gus sbyor gyi/ 6 /
And to increase the mind intent on enlightenment For beings as numerous as the sky is vast, My nephew, the monk Gelek Gyatso And the attendant Shingkyong, with devoted diligence,
rnam dkar slar gyi 'du 'god 'phrul par 'di/ / sde bzhi dge bcu'i chos mdzod mdzes pa'i rgyan/ / ji srid nam mkha' gnas par mi 'dzad pa'i/ / chos sbyin gtan pa med pa'i sgo 'phar dbye/ 7 /

Virtuously put together the magical woodblocks, An ornament embellishing the treasure of the Dharma Of the four classes and ten virtuous actions, Thus opening the door of the unstinting gift of Dharma, Which is never exhausted for as long as space endures.

I, Jamyang Lodrö Gyatso, prayed with these verses of aspiration as a publisher’s colophon. May excellence increase.
